headline: Where Paella Meets Plantains
abstract: The menu at La Parrilla combines Spanish classics with Latin American dishes.
lead_paragraph: La Parrilla has a Spanish accent that encompasses both the Old World and the New. This Port Jefferson newcomer, which opened in late March, took over the building that housed the Spanish restaurant Costa de España for many years. The owner of La Parrilla, Vin Grillo, a first-time restaurateur, said his menu was a combination of Spanish and Latin American food.

headline: The Kids Are Not Happy About Dad’s New Friend
abstract: Sandra Nettelbeck’s “Last Love” stars Michael Caine as a cantankerous widower whose two children are concerned about his relationship with a young Parisian.
lead_paragraph: Psychological verisimilitude: If that were all it took to make a powerful movie about family strife and impending mortality, the German filmmaker Sandra Nettelbeck’s “Last Love” would join Michael Haneke’s “Amour” on the short list of touching late-life dramas.

headline: Outdistancing Suicide, Papa’s Family Curse
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: In a Barbara Kopple documentary, Mariel Hemingway discusses the struggle against a genetic predisposition to mental illness.
lead_paragraph: The up-close-and-personal promise of cinéma vérité in the 1960s could be exploited in a number of ways. Some documentaries explored ordinary life as a subject (“Salesman,” “High School”), but just as often they orbited stars (Bob Dylan in “Don’t Look Back,” John F. Kennedy in “Primary”). The career of the award-winning filmmaker Barbara Kopple has intriguingly spanned this spectrum, as she has both risked her life to chronicle a miners strike in the 1976 stone-cold classic, “Harlan County, U.S.A.,” and watched Woody Allen quip about hotel laundry service in “Wild Man Blues” (1998).

headline: Federal Review Opened in Georgia Death
abstract: The death Kendrick L. Johnson, which was ruled accidental, has been the subject of persistent questions since his body was found in a blue mat at his high school.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The United States Department of Justice said Thursday that it had opened a formal review of the death of a 17-year-old boy found in a rolled-up wrestling mat at his Georgia high school in January.

headline: A War on the Poor
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'Welfare (US)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Medicaid']
abstract: What happened to the Republican Party? It’s almost as if the party is solely focused on its hostility to the less fortunate.
lead_paragraph: John Kasich, the Republican governor of Ohio, has done some surprising things lately. First, he did an end run around his state’s Legislature — controlled by his own party — to proceed with the federally funded expansion of Medicaid that is an important piece of Obamacare. Then, defending his action, he let loose on his political allies, declaring, “I’m concerned about the fact there seems to be a war on the poor. That, if you’re poor, somehow you’re shiftless and lazy.”

headline: Judge Invalidates Patent for a Down Syndrome Test
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Down Syndrome', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Susan Illston, a federal judge, ruled the patent for the noninvasive test invalid because it covered a natural phenomenon, the presence of DNA from the fetus in a mother’s blood.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has invalidated the central patent underlying a noninvasive method of detecting Down syndrome in fetuses without the risk of inducing a miscarriage.

headline: Rethinking the Main Course
abstract: In “Free Birds,” Woody Harrelson and Owen Wilson provide the voices for two turkeys who travel back in time to alter the first Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: Some animated films, like “My Neighbor Totoro,” seem nonsensical because they replicate the strange logic of a child’s imagination. Others make little sense because the concept is inane, and the execution is manic and unoriginal. “Free Birds,” the new cartoon about time-traveling turkeys, is the second kind.

headline: The Ode Heard Round the World
abstract: “Following the Ninth,” a documentary, explores the legacy of Beethoven’s final symphony.
lead_paragraph: With the release last spring of a phenomenally popular iPad app, an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum of the original manuscript, and now the documentary “Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethoven’s Final Symphony,” the Ninth seems to be having a cultural moment. Of course, that’s not quite right: Since its premiere in 1824, it has never truly left the spotlight.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Being ‘Partly Jewish’
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Families and Family Life', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Parenting']
abstract: Children who grow up in interfaith communities, learning and celebrating both family religions, are not lost to Judaism.
lead_paragraph: IN the course of a year, my family celebrates Yom Kippur, Rosh Hashana, Sukkot, Simhat Torah, Hanukkah, Passover and many Shabbats. We also celebrate All Saints’ Day and All Souls, Advent, Christmas, Lent and Easter. We are part of a growing movement to raise interfaith children with both family religions.

headline: Serious Danger of Blood Clots Halts Sale of Leukemia Drug
abstract: The drug, Iclusig, has been linked to severe heart attacks and strokes, blindness and loss of blood flow in the extremities that can require amputation.
lead_paragraph: Sales of a promising leukemia drug, Iclusig, are being suspended because of “the risk of life-threatening blood clots and severe narrowing of blood vessels,” the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: In Alabama Race, a Test of Business Efforts to Derail Tea Party
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Business groups like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are pouring money into a special House primary runoff that is seen as a test case for the fight over the Republican Party’s future.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — With only days to go before a special Republican primary runoff for Congress here in South Alabama, the national business lobby is going all in.

headline: No Lights or Cameras, but Draft Has Action
abstract: The N.B.A. Development League on Friday will stage its annual draft, an unglamorous exercise that is nonetheless essential for recruiting players whom teams see value in developing.
lead_paragraph: When the N.B.A.’s Development League stages its annual draft Friday night, the event might be most notable for everything that it is not.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Welcomed With Kisses, Stanford Freshmen Risk the ‘Kissing Disease’
abstract: Full Moon on the Quad, an orgy of interclass kissing reluctantly but officially sanctioned by Stanford University, is followed by another tradition: the spread of mono and the flu.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — It is minutes to midnight. A sultry full moon hangs over Stanford’s Memorial Church, bathing the campus’s red roofs and adobe-toned walls.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Singularity & Co.
abstract: The vintage science fiction bookstore Singularity & Co. operates from a small storefront in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The vintage science fiction bookstore Singularity & Co. operates from a small storefront in Brooklyn.

headline: Kenya: Somali Militants Attacked
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)']
abstract: The Kenyan military led an African Union operation against the Shabab in southern Somalia on Thursday in an effort to vanquish the group that claimed responsibility for an attack on a Kenyan mall.
lead_paragraph: The Kenyan military led an African Union operation against Islamist militants in southern Somalia on Thursday in an effort to vanquish the group that claimed responsibility for a terrorist attack last month in a Kenyan mall that killed more than 60 people. In a statement on Thursday, Kenya said it had “conducted a major aerial offensive” on a militant training camp run by the group, the Shabab, in the Dinsoor region of Somalia, possibly killing as many as 300 militants and destroying the site. The casualty estimate could not be independently confirmed. Kenya said that the training camp had been used by Shabab “operatives” who had “infiltrated” Kenya, and that it was where those who carried out the mall attack had “received their training.” A spokesman for the African Union peacekeeping mission said the attack was part of the force’s broader campaign against the Shabab. A Shabab spokesman denied that any of its camps had been attacked, Reuters reported.

headline: The Invisible Team: Barcelona’s Little Brother, Espanyol
abstract: Money, politics and success on the field divide two soccer teams (and their fans) in the Catalan capital.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Every day, Javier Aguirre sits in his office and reads four all-sports newspapers. And every day, he finds himself furious as he turns page after page (after page after page).

headline: Mexico: Junk Food Tax Is Approved
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Taxation', 'Soft Drinks', 'Food', 'Medicine and Health', 'Snack Foods']
abstract: Aiming to curb unhealthy consumption habits, Mexico’s Congress on Thursday approved new taxes on sugary drinks and junk food.
lead_paragraph: Aiming to curb unhealthy consumption habits, Mexico’s Congress on Thursday approved new taxes on sugary drinks and junk food. Lawmakers approved a tax of one peso per liter, or about 8 cents, on soft drinks and an 8 percent sales tax on high-calorie foods, including potato chips, sweets and cereal. President Enrique Peña Nieto is expected to sign the taxes into law in January. The soft drink and food industries lobbied heavily to defeat the plan, but lawmakers said it was necessary to reduce rising rates of obesity and diabetes, as well as to raise revenue. Almost 70 percent of Mexicans are overweight, and about a third are obese, according to the World Health Organization. The foundation of New York City’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, financed an ad campaign to support the so-called soda tax. The taxes were among several revenue-raising measures approved by lawmakers, including higher taxes on the wealthy and the elimination of some breaks for industrial plants on the border with the United States, known as maquiladoras.

headline: Preserving the Future From the Past
abstract: Singularity & Co., a subscription service for out-of-print science fiction books, also sells sci-fi, fantasy, pulp and horror.
lead_paragraph: Sometime during Singularity & Co.’s first year in business, a 10-year-old boy walked with his father into this science fiction, fantasy and vintage pulp bookstore. The boy stopped at the entrance, inhaled audibly and announced, “I love the smell of old books!”

headline: With Gritty Slugger Brian McCann, It’s Buyer Beware
abstract: Some projections have Atlanta catcher Brian McCann landing a $100 million contract, but a recent lack of durability and a potential decline in his 30s could be problems.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Brian McCann, the free-agent catcher who has spent his entire career with the Atlanta Braves, the phrase most often used is old school. A big, burly, bearded catcher with a picture-perfect left-handed swing, McCann is easy to imagine playing in baseball’s early days.

headline: South Sudan: One-Sided Vote in Disputed District
abstract: Residents of Abyei voted overwhelmingly in favor of joining South Sudan, according to results announced on Thursday, but the nonbinding referendum was not recognized by Sudan and South Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Residents of the disputed district of Abyei voted overwhelmingly in favor of joining South Sudan, according to results announced by the referendum’s organizers on Thursday. Zachariah Deng Majok of the Abyei Referendum High Committee said that 99.9 percent of those who had voted wanted to be part of South Sudan. But the nonbinding referendum was not recognized by the governments of Sudan and South Sudan or by the African Union. Both Sudan and South Sudan claim ownership of oil-rich Abyei, and the region is shared uneasily by two ethnic groups: the more-settled Ngok Dinka and the nomadic Misseriya. The Ngok Dinka, allied with South Sudan, took part in the referendum, but the Misseriya, who are close to Sudan’s government, did not. President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan has said he will work with his South Sudanese counterpart, Salva Kiir, to resolve the Abyei dispute.

headline: Tunnel for Smuggling Found Under U.S.-Mexico Border; Tons of Drugs Seized
abstract: The sophisticated underground passageway featured electricity, ventilation and an electronic rail system and took about a year to build, officials said.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — A deep tunnel snaking nearly 600 yards from Mexico under the border and into a San Diego warehouse is one of the most sophisticated underground drug smuggling passageways ever discovered, complete with electricity, ventilation and an electronic rail system, federal authorities said Thursday.

headline: International Court Postpones Kenyatta’s Trial
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)']
abstract: The International Criminal Court on Thursday postponed the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya on crimes against humanity charges until February.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court on Thursday postponed the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya on crimes against humanity charges until February.

headline: The Politics of Petulance
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: The latest casualty of the Senate Republican filibuster is Patricia Ann Millett, a highly qualified judicial nominee.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans on Thursday again refused to allow the nomination of a highly qualified judicial nominee to come up for a full vote. Their use of the filibuster is by now all too familiar, and the latest casualty is Patricia Ann Millett, whom President Obama nominated in June, along with two other people, to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

headline: In Reversal, Court Allows Texas Law on Abortion
abstract: Days after a federal judge blocked a Texas law that threatened to shut down many of the state’s abortion clinics, an appeals court said the rule should take effect while the case goes forward.
lead_paragraph: Only three days after a federal judge blocked a new Texas law that threatened to shut down many of the state’s abortion clinics, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, reversed the decision, saying the rule should take effect while the case is argued in the months to come.

headline: Virginia Tech Held Not Negligent in ’07 Killings
keywords: ['Supreme Courts (State)', 'School Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The university’s warnings to students as a mass shooting began in 2007 were not negligent, the state’s Supreme Court ruled Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Tech’s warnings to students as a mass shooting began in 2007 were not negligent, the state’s Supreme Court ruled Thursday, thwarting a wrongful-death lawsuit brought on behalf of two students who were killed.

headline: Fisher Price Commercial
abstract: A Spanish-language advertisement for Fisher Price toys.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish-language advertisement for Fisher Price toys.

headline: Manna Dey, 94, the Voice of Many a Bollywood Star, Dies
abstract: Mr. Dey was an acclaimed playback singer for Bengali as well as Bollywood films, but like most Bollywood singers, he was not seen onscreen.
lead_paragraph: Manna Dey, an acclaimed Indian singer whose voice was heard in scores of Bollywood movies, died on Oct. 24 in Bangalore. He was 94.

headline: Spanish Message With One Word That Needs No Translation
abstract: As the holidays approach, the toy maker Mattel is making a playful appeal to Latina mothers and their children.
lead_paragraph: TO get ready for the holiday season, Mattel is adding some informal Spanish language to a marketing campaign meant to reach Latina mothers. The campaign, called “ ’Toy Feliz,” or “Toy Happy” in English, is a play on the Spanish phrase “Estoy feliz,” or “I’m happy.”

headline: Chiefs Owner’s Plan Yields Quick Fix (but Not a Hasty One)
abstract: Taking a more active role in running the Chiefs, the owner Clark Hunt, whose father, Lamar, founded the team, has led a remarkable turnaround.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Clark Hunt is used to hearing from fans of the Kansas City Chiefs. After all, he grew up around the team, which his father, Lamar, founded as the Dallas Texans more than half a century ago, and he has been its chairman and chief executive since Lamar died in 2006.

headline: As Cuts to Food Stamps Take Effect, More Trims to Benefits Are Expected
abstract: Cuts to food stamps reflect the lapse of a temporary increase in benefits created by the Obama administration’s stimulus program, and are likely to deepen.
lead_paragraph: Starting Friday, millions of Americans receiving food stamps will be required to get by with less government assistance every month, a move that not only will cost them money they use to feed their families but is expected to slightly dampen economic growth as well.

headline: Secular Turkish Government Permits Religious Symbol
abstract: Four female lawmakers were welcomed into Parliament with Islamic head scarves, which for some was an unwelcome break with secular traditions and for others a sign of the nation’s maturing democracy.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Before Thursday, the last time a female lawmaker entered Turkey’s Parliament wearing an Islamic head scarf was in 1999. She was taunted, expelled from the building and later stripped of her Turkish citizenship after it was revealed that she also carried an American passport.

headline: Banksy-Altered Painting Brings $615,000 at Auction
abstract: A thrift-store painting is now worth well over half a million dollars, thanks to the imprimatur of Banksy.
lead_paragraph: A thrift-store painting is now worth well over half a million dollars, thanks to the imprimatur of Banksy. “The Banality of the Banality of Evil,” a landscape that he doctored by adding a Nazi military figure, his own signature and a certificate of authenticity, sold for $615,000 in a charity auction that ended on Thursday evening. The money was to benefit Housing Works, which anonymously received the painting in its Gramercy shop and put it up for sale online on Tuesday. The auction attracted 138 bids, from a minimum starting offer of $74,000, with the price jumping by several hundred thousand dollars in the final moments.

headline: Germany’s Blind Spot
abstract: An obsession with exports is coming at a high cost for other euro countries and its own economy.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department’s semiannual report on the international economy and exchange rates usually makes for boring reading. But the latest edition, released this week, broke from that tradition by offering some blunt and much-needed perspective about the German economy: Its heavy reliance on exports is hurting weaker European countries that share the euro.

headline: New York’s Constitutional Amendments
keywords: ['Constitutional Amendments', 'Land Use Policies', 'Gambling', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials']
abstract: An amendment that would allow state judges to stay on the bench to age 80 deserves a yes vote. Four others should be approved, too.
lead_paragraph: New York State voters will decide on Tuesday on six amendments to the highly detailed State Constitution. In earlier editorials, we argued that the amendment to expand casino gambling in the state should be rejected. An amendment that would allow state judges to stay on the bench to age 80 deserves a yes vote.

headline: A Bad Ruling on Stop-and-Frisk
abstract: A federal appeals court was unwise to block necessary changes ordered by Judge Shira Scheindlin.
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was unwise to put a stay on the necessary remedies Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan ordered in August in response to the civil rights violations of New York City’s stop-and-frisk policy. And it overreached in taking the extraordinary step of removing Judge Scheindlin from the long-running litigation.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 1, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, November 1, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “He’s free, but he’s not completely free.”

headline: Bill Limiting Pesticide Use on Hawaii Island Is Vetoed
abstract: The legislation, vetoed by the mayor on the ground that it was flawed, was aimed at seed companies developing genetically modified crops on the island of Kauai.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Kauai County, Hawaii, has vetoed a hotly contested bill that would have restricted the use of pesticides by companies developing genetically modified crops on the island.

headline: Palestinians in Peace Talks With Israel Offer Resignations
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'United States International Relations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The Palestinian negotiators on Thursday offered to resign in protest over the continuing construction of Israeli settlements, but the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, was not likely to accept them.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian negotiators engaged in peace talks with Israel offered their resignations on Thursday in protest over the continuing construction of Israeli settlements and what Palestinians say is a lack of strong American action on this issue, according to an official involved in the process.

headline: A Colorful Food Lover’s Feast for the Eyes, Starring Flavors of the Bronx
abstract: Justin Fornal, a.k.a. Baron Ambrosia, roves the Bronx’s ethnic enclaves in search of homegrown restaurants, and he has cast some of his favorites in a new movie.
lead_paragraph: The man in the purple suit knocked insistently until the metal door finally swung open on a recent afternoon. He bounded down the steps to a basement pool hall in the Bronx, where a worn lunch counter served some of the tastiest pork-and-okra stews and braised goat outside of the Dominican Republic.

headline: The Baron and the Bronx
abstract: Baron Ambrosia, the fictional food enthusiast created by the filmmaker Justin Fornal, explores hidden culinary treasures in the Bronx ahead of the premier of his new movie.
lead_paragraph: Baron Ambrosia, the fictional food enthusiast created by the filmmaker Justin Fornal, explores hidden culinary treasures in the Bronx ahead of the premier of his new movie.

headline: Chinatowns Renew Push for Traditional Gateways
abstract: Most large Chinese enclaves outside Asia have bright, elaborate gateways. New York’s do not, but efforts to get them are gaining momentum.
lead_paragraph: In those moments of imaginative flight, when he suspends reason and allows himself to dream, Wellington Z. Chen pictures glory on the streets of Lower Manhattan.

headline: Breeders’ Cup: Trainers Aren’t Helping as Drugs Damage Sport
abstract: As the Breeders’ Cup, a two-day showcase of horse racing, begins Saturday, the sport is still mired in credibility and image problems linked to drug violations.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — The Breeders’ Cup World Championships are milestone days for a sport that can’t get out of the way of itself for 363 days a year. There are two days of full fields of the finest American racehorses and a European or South American invader or two.

headline: De Blasio Attracts Silicon Valley Donors
abstract: A list of donors to Bill de Blasio’s campaign shows the growing clout of technology entrepreneurs and investors.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Blecharczyk, Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia live in California, but they have a lot riding on the policies of the next mayor of New York.

headline: Müller, an Architect of the Holocaust, Is Said to Be Buried in a Jewish Cemetery in Berlin
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Cemeteries', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The head of an association that watches over memorials to German resistance fighters says a document indicates that Heinrich Müller was killed and eventually buried in a mass grave in the heart of the German capital.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For all the efforts Germany has made in coming to terms with its Nazi past, the fate of one of the prime architects of the Holocaust has long eluded the authorities and historians.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 31, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Angry Over U.S. Surveillance, Tech Giants Bolster Defenses
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: What began as a public relations predicament for American technology companies has evolved into a moral crisis that threatens the foundation of their businesses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has spent months and millions of dollars encrypting email, search queries and other information flowing among its data centers worldwide. Facebook’s chief executive said at a conference this fall that the government “blew it.” And though it has not been announced publicly, Twitter plans to set up new types of encryption to protect messages from snoops.

headline: A New Account in a Murder Case Closed 21 Years Ago
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Fresh doubts have been raised about the convictions of two men in the 1992 death of Jennifer Negron.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Negron died on New Year’s Day, 1992, a week after she turned 16, her beaten, stabbed body found near dawn on a corner in East New York, Brooklyn.

headline: Corrections: November 1, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 1, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Tab Carrier in a Bar
abstract: In which I am roundly beWilbered.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., Brad Wilber. You finally got the best of me. This was a DNF (Did Not Finish, for those just joining us) for me. Laugh your maniacal laugh and enjoy your victory. I will vanquish you next time. I hope.

headline: Homeownership Has Crucial Role in Westchester Race
keywords: ['Elections, County Executives', 'Property Taxes', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Westchester’s property taxes are among the highest in the nation and are pushing aside other issues in the campaigns for county executive.
lead_paragraph: In Westchester, a county of both horse farms and homeless shelters, property taxes, not surprisingly, are at the heart of the race for county executive.

headline: Garnett Has a Precise System Before He’s a ‘Go’
abstract: Kevin Garnett’s pregame progression — a series of idiosyncratic acts and subtle gestures — has been calibrated and perfected over 1,455 total games.
lead_paragraph: It is moments before tipoff, and Kevin Garnett is a space shuttle, advancing methodically through a complex launch sequence, preparing himself for thunderous flight.

headline: When Insurers Drop Policies: Three Stories
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Insurance companies are canceling millions of health insurance plans that fail to meet minimum standards, and a look at the stories of three people with such plans tells a complex tale.
lead_paragraph: Charles Nance, Dean Wright and Julie Tyrrell are getting dropped — forced out of their existing health insurance plans — and landing smack in the middle of the uproar over President Obama’s health care law.

headline: On Fox, a Sterile End to a Series
abstract: Modern celebrations of World Series wins have a lack of spontaneity, with security preventing fans from going on the field and interviews conducted on a stage.
lead_paragraph: The days of ecstatic fans tearing up a field after home teams have won a World Series and announcers conducting clubhouse interviews with their eyes stinging from Champagne doused on them are in the past. Now, security prevents fans from exuberant marauding, and a gigantic stage is erected on the field to accommodate interviews with players, owners and commissioners.

headline: De Blasio as Manager: Delegating, Yet Keeping a Tight Leash
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate in the race to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, discussed his management style.
lead_paragraph: They have staked out positions on taxes and charter schools, pedestrian plazas and a ban on large sugary drinks. But the Democratic and Republican candidates to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have rarely expounded on the biggest day-to-day challenge that awaits them in City Hall: managing a bureaucracy of 300,000 workers.

headline: U.S. Plans to Sweeten Its Sales Pitch to Foreign Investors
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The Obama administration said it would expand efforts, including streamlining regulations, to make the nation more attractive to overseas companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Declaring “we are open for business,” President Obama on Thursday announced an expansion of federal efforts to lure foreign companies to invest in the United States, including making sales pitches a formal part of every American ambassador’s portfolio.

headline: Troubled Start for Health Law Has Democrats Feeling Anxious
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Democrats say that the law’s woes are cutting into the momentum they gained after the government shutdown, and that the troubles could cost them in the 2014 midterm races.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Already under fierce attack from Republicans over the new health care law, President Obama now faces broad and mounting Democratic concerns that the troubled start of the insurance program will cut into the political benefit the party received from the government shutdown and cost Democratic candidates in next year’s midterm elections.

headline: A Way of Life, and Its Slow Death
abstract: “Behind the Blue Veil” chronicles the Tuareg people of Mali and the threats to their culture.
lead_paragraph: The Tuareg are good people, Robyn Symon’s billowy but deadly serious documentary “Behind the Blue Veil” tells us early on. Theirs is a matriarchal society (unusual for Muslims), monogamous and family-oriented. They cherish the desert, because they feel fully alive there. It is their culture. And they are being forced into extinction.

headline: Stephen Drew Is Just Like His Brother, Right Down to the Ring
abstract: The Red Sox shortstop claims he does not follow in his brother J.D.’s footsteps, except that he wears a No.7 jersey and now has a Red Sox ring like him.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — During the mayhem in the Red Sox clubhouse after their third World Series championship in 10 seasons, Stephen Drew claimed that he does not follow in his older brother J. D.’s footsteps. But the evidence suggests otherwise; in the very next sentence he described how he wears the No. 7 jersey to honor J. D.

headline: America, That Very Tough Neighborhood
abstract: “Immigrant,” a tale of a Russian family’s move in the 1970s, shows the United States as anything but welcoming.
lead_paragraph: The immigrant couple in Barry Shurchin’s new film leave the Soviet Union in the late 1970s in hopes of finding religious freedom in the United States, so their son can “be a Jew.” What they experience is more like an American horror story, one filled with knives and guns, suicide, abuse and nefarious figures. It’s an unseemly pileup of misfortune resting on a rather weak foundation.

headline: German Politician Meets With Snowden
abstract: A member of the parliamentary committee that oversees German intelligence met Edward J. Snowden to explore whether he would testify in an inquiry of the N.S.A.’s monitoring of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s calls.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, met for almost three hours in Moscow on Thursday with Hans-Christian Ströbele, the longest serving member of the parliamentary committee that oversees German intelligence.

headline: The Hidden Meaning of Films, Take 2
abstract: “The Pervert’s Guide to Ideology” is the second critical analysis of what values the movies are really imparting, by the philosopher Slavoj Zizek.
lead_paragraph: “The Pervert’s Guide to Ideology,” Sophie Fiennes’s second collaboration with the public intellectual Slavoj Zizek, sets out a daunting task. Titling a film that way, even tongue in cheek, recalls the Monty Python sketch about summarizing Proust, only with an even broader remit.

headline: 50 Years Ago, That’s the Way It Was
abstract: “One PM Central Standard Time” recalls Nov. 22, 1963, as Walter Cronkite delivered the news.
lead_paragraph: The overstatement starts early and never lets up in “One PM Central Standard Time,” a documentary about coverage of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy that strives mightily to reinforce the perception that Walter Cronkite was the only journalist working that day.

headline: Saoirse Ronan, Hollywood’s Leading Lady in Waiting
abstract: Following an Oscar nod for “Atonement,” the Irish actress is coming into her own with new films with Wes Anderson and Ryan Gosling.
lead_paragraph: Poised on the edge of adulthood, the Irish actress Saoirse Ronan still lives at home with her parents, but is coming into her own with an Oscar nomination, films with Wes Anderson and Ryan Gosling, and a budding friendship with Patti Smith.

headline: In Tbilisi, Georgia, Bold New Buildings Rise From the Ruins of Dead Empires
abstract: The historic city’s shiny new skyline is a source of both aesthetic and political controversy.
lead_paragraph: In Tbilisi, Georgia, a shiny new architectural skyline has become a political issue as much as an aesthetic one — is it slapdash commercialism ruining the culture’s authentic history or a step toward a more progressive society?

headline: Word of the Day | evenhanded
abstract: This word has appeared in 38 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: evenhanded •\ˌe-vən-ˈhan-dəd\• adjective

headline: With Late Floater, Rose Sinks Knicks
abstract: The Bulls’ Derrick Rose hit a teardrop floater with 5.7 seconds remaining to spoil a late surge by the Knicks in a game that began with pyrotechnics and a thick haze.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It was an impossible shot, or at least it looked that way to Carmelo Anthony.

headline: White House Will Focus on Climate Shifts While Trying to Cut Greenhouse Gases
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)']
abstract: White House aides said President Obama would sign an executive order on Friday morning directing federal agencies to make it easier for states to build resilience against storms.
lead_paragraph: The White House is expected to take new steps on Friday to help society adapt to global warming, an acknowledgment that worldwide efforts to control emissions will be inadequate to head off big climatic shifts.

headline: A Rapid Revival for the Chiefs
abstract: Clark Hunt, the Chiefs’ chairman and chief executive, reshaped his team after a 2-14 finish, and the moves quickly paid dividends.
lead_paragraph: Clark Hunt, the Chiefs’ chairman and chief executive, reshaped his team after a 2-14 finish, and the moves quickly paid dividends.

headline: Gearing Up for an Ultramarathon in Southwest China
abstract: A 100-kilometer race that takes runners up a mountainous course exceeding heights of 4,000 meters, or 13,400 feet, is not for the weak of heart.
lead_paragraph: We were near the end of our morning run when Zhang Mei looked up at the imposing escarpment rising to the west of the ancient town of Dali. Ms. Zhang, the founder of WildChina, a boutique travel agency, was visiting her hometown, in a remote and mountainous corner of southwestern China. I knew her from Beijing and happened to be in Dali this week, too, so I somehow allowed myself to be talked into doing a run with her. She was training for her fifth marathon, which she planned to run in Guangdong Province in late November. Our morning run had taken us past farm fields and white-washed village homes and the blue expanse of Erhai Lake, one of China’s largest bodies of fresh water.

headline: From Today’s Paper: A Homecoming After Troops Rout Congo Rebels
abstract: People displaced by fighting between the Congolese Army and M23 rebels inthe eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo made their way home on Thursday, a day after troops seized the rebel stronghold of Bunagana on the Ugandan border.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) MOBY-DICK FROM SAN FRANCISCO OPERA Jay Hunter Morris, below, tackles the role of the obsessive Captain Ahab in Jake Heggie and Gene Scheer’s adaptation of the Melville classic, presented by the San Francisco Opera last fall. Stephen Costello (as Greenhorn), Jonathan Lemalu (Queequeg), Morgan Smith (Starbuck), Talise Trevigne (Pip), Matthew O’Neill (Flask) and Robert Orth (Stubb) round out the cast. Patrick Summers, the company’s principal guest conductor, led this production (above), directed by Leonard Foglia and presented here as part of the PBS Fall Arts Festival.

headline: News Quiz | November 1, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: China Says Terror Group Was Behind Tiananmen Attack
abstract: A Chinese official said the deadly attack that killed five people was instigated by the East Turkestan Islamic Movement.
lead_paragraph: China’s domestic security chief said a terrorist organization was behind this week’s attack at Beijing’s Tiananmen gate that left five people dead and 40 injured.

headline: Asian Economies Strengthen as Demand for Exports Grows
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Data released Friday shows that a recovery among Western economies has fed improving conditions around Asia, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The gradual recovery in the United States, Europe and China filtered through to much of the rest of Asia in October, data released Friday showed, lifting manufacturing activity and easing concerns about the region’s flagging growth.

headline: One Casualty of Eavesdropping on Merkel: A Warm Rapport
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: For President Obama, the collateral damage the National Security Agency surveillance has inflicted on his relationship with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is, perhaps, a more painful cost of the episode.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At one level, the National Security Agency’s surveillance of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is a highly technical story of digital-age espionage, in which the spying is done by entering codes into a distant mainframe instead of by hiding bugs in a politician’s boudoir.

headline: Chinese Doctors Becoming the Targets of Patients’ Anger
abstract: Doctors in China face violence at work from patients and their relatives who are dissatisfied over treatment. In growing numbers, physicians have been attacked, and sometimes killed.
lead_paragraph: China’s hospitals are a battleground — not just for the war on illness but also for the one between physicians and their patients.

abstract: The bank also said it would focus on retail and commercial banking in Britain and move up an initial public offering of Citizens Financial Group in the United States to next year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON –  Little over five years after the world’s biggest bank rescue, Britain’s Royal Bank of Scotland on Friday announced a new plan aimed at speeding up its overhaul, returning money to taxpayers and returning the company to profit.

headline: Hong Kong Finds Switch to Cleaner Fuels Has Flaws
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Automobiles', 'Buses', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: A switch to cleaner-burning vehicles has in one respect actually worsened smog in Hong Kong, forcing the city to modify its effort.
lead_paragraph: Municipal governments all over the world, particularly in developing countries with rapidly growing fleets of cars and choking air pollution, have been rushing over the last few years to force taxis and buses to switch to burning liquefied petroleum gas and compressed natural gas, frequently offering subsidies for them to do so.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Environmental Activists Arrested After Protesting Arctic Oil Exploration
abstract: How do you feel about Russia arresting these Greenpeace activists?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Activists Feel Powerful Wrath as Russia Guards Its Arctic Claims,” Steven Lee Myers reports on Greenpeace activists arrested by Russia.

headline: Should the U.S. Be Spying on Its Friends?
abstract: Would you spy on your friends if you had the capability? What limits would you set for yourself?
lead_paragraph: Germany is angry at the United States for spying on Chancellor Angela Merkel. Brazil and Mexico were upset to learn that the National Security Agency was eavesdropping on their leaders, too. The French and Spanish both summoned the American ambassador to address spying allegations in their countries as well.

headline: Broccoli’s Extreme Makeover
keywords: ['Broccoli', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Vegetables', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Broccoli is about to get a serious makeover — and maybe, just maybe, be a model of how to persuade Americans to eat better.
lead_paragraph: The ad agency Victors & Spoils has created campaigns for some of the biggest brands in the food industry — Coca-Cola, Quiznos and General Mills among them. Until now, what they’d never done was try to figure out how to sell broccoli. Or any vegetables or fruits of any kind. This of course is not unique to Victors & Spoils. Major American advertising agencies tend not to get hired by produce growers to help them market fresh fruits and vegetables. They are hired by large companies making huge profits from processed foods to reach into whatever crannies of the American (or global) public they have not yet connected with. Victors & Spoils is exceedingly good at doing just that. The agency’s “Smile Back” campaign for Coca-Cola, which was released this summer, has been hailed as an ingenious use of a kind of guerrilla advertising, albeit with very slick production, composed of footage of grinning, attractive ambassadors for Coca-Cola pedaling through cities and rural areas around the globe, handing out free Cokes to anyone who smiled back.

headline: Forever 15
abstract: Ilana Panich-Linsman shadowed a group of 15-year-old girls — having been 15 herself not too long ago — to document their making the small decisions that began to define them as women.
lead_paragraph: Ilana Panich-Linsman still recalls being an awkward 15-year-old in western Massachusetts, leading a fairly innocent life with a few brainy friends.

headline: Can You Make Cabbage Cool?
abstract: We invite you to come up with a slogan for some tough-sell vegetables: peas, cauliflower, beet, cabbage and turnip.
lead_paragraph: It should surprise no one that vegetables have an image problem. Even if you don’t have a kid who scrunches his nose at anything leafy, you may have done so yourself when you were small.

headline: The Life of an Undocumented South Asian Immigrant
keywords: ['Asian-Americans', 'Deportation', 'Foreign Workers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Restaurants', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Nirmal, a chef in New York, has been away from his family in Nepal for 14 years and has never seen his only child.
lead_paragraph: I met Nirmal several years ago in New York. I had become increasingly interested in the lives of undocumented laborers in the city, and therefore had started talking with taxi drivers, kebab sellers, and restaurant workers. I was looking for answers to two questions, the first of which was what might happen if illegal immigrants from South Asia should ever want to retire in the United States?

headline: New York Today: Marathon Revival
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: the marathon returns, tropical weather and a parrot safari in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:12 p.m. | Chances are you remember last year’s New York City Marathon.

headline: Indonesia Confronts Australian Ambassador on Reports of Spying
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: A furor is growing over reports that Australian Embassies carried out intelligence-gathering missions in several Asian nations as part of a United States-led effort.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs summoned Australia’s ambassador on Friday to respond to news media reports that Australia’s embassy in Jakarta was used as part of a United States-led spying effort, saying such actions were “not acceptable” and had harmed its diplomatic relations with both countries.

headline: At N.S.A. Headquarters
abstract: Inbox management at the National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: Inbox management at the National Security Agency.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Giants Bolster Defenses in Response to U.S. Surveillance
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: What began as a public relations predicament for the companies has evolved into a moral and business crisis that threatens their businesses.
lead_paragraph: Google has spent months and millions of dollars encrypting email, search queries and other information flowing among its data centers worldwide. Facebook’s chief executive said at a conference this fall that the government “blew it.” And though it has not been announced publicly, Twitter plans to set up new types of encryption to protect messages from snoops. It is all reaction to reports of how far the government has gone in spying on Internet users, sneaking around tech companies to tap into their systems without their knowledge or cooperation, Claire Cain Miller reports.

headline: Week 9 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: One would be hard pressed to find a luckier coach in the N.F.L. this season than Andy Reid, whose Kansas City Chiefs will play a fourth game in five weeks with a team starting a backup quarterback.
lead_paragraph: Chiefs (8-0) at Bills (3-5)

headline: ING to Unwind Mortgage Securities
abstract: In another sign of improving headwinds for European banks, the Dutch financial services firm said on Friday that it would unwind a portfolio of securities tied to mortgages in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In another sign of improving outlook for European banks, the Dutch financial services firm ING said on Friday that it would unwind a portfolio of securities tied to mortgages in the United States that was shifted off its books by the Dutch government during the financial crisis.

headline: Restoring Trans-Atlantic Trust
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: After the revelations of America’s spying on its European allies, the question is how to rebuild the relationship.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — IN the wake of revelations that the American government tapped the cellphone of Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, trans-Atlantic relations have reached a low point not seen since the Iraq war.

headline: Baseline Epics Spur a Debate About Court Speed
abstract: There is a push to encourage more variety in play and court speed with an eye on the net and, in a Darwinian entertainment landscape, an eye on the clock.
lead_paragraph: With another ATP Tour season set to finish Monday at the World Tour Finals in London, there would seem little cause for concern for men’s tennis.

headline: The Repurposed Ph.D.
keywords: ['Graduate Schools and Students', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The past few years have seen a surge in efforts to connect Ph.D.’s with gratifying employment outside the ivory tower, and even to rethink doctoral education itself.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, a monthly meeting convened around a long table in a Whole Foods cafeteria on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. As people settled in, the organizer plopped down a bag of potato chips and tackled housekeeping matters, like soliciting contributions. But she did not insist. “I know that some of you are in fragile situations,” she said.

headline: Federer and Nadal Have Equal Claims on Greatness, for Now
abstract: With the men’s season about to end with the ATP World Tour Finals, there is increasing discussion about who the greatest tennis player of this generation might be.
lead_paragraph: Let’s agree, for the moment, to swear off the greatest-of-all-time-debate even if Rod Laver’s two true Grand Slams still seem quite a pair of trump cards.

headline: Today in Small Business: Thank You for Sharing
abstract: Assessing the government shutdown’s impact. Stores plan to be open longer on Thanksgiving. How to ask people for stuff via email.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | October 2013
abstract: The latest monthly collection of stories about young people published in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson “Teaching With ‘Teenagers in The Times’”.

headline: Israeli Strikes in Gaza Kill 4 Hamas Militants
abstract: Israeli forces responded after five Israeli soldiers were injured in an explosion while they were destroying a tunnel from Gaza into Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli military strikes killed four Palestinian militants from the military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, late Thursday and early Friday after five Israeli soldiers were wounded in an explosion near the Israel-Gaza border.

keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']

headline: Optimism, and Caution, as Spain Attracts Investment

lead_paragraph: MADRID — Like other Spanish builders, Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, or F.C.C., had struggled to convince investors that it could extract itself from Spain’s housing market quagmire.

headline: An Early Split, but Their Commitment Grew Stronger
abstract: Lisa Holtby  and David Hlavsa were married about seven years when they went their separate ways. But then they figured out what they wanted and find marriage worth the work.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Q. & A. | Brian Eno on the Best Use of a Television, Why Art Students Make Good Pop Stars and the Meaning of ‘Visual Music’
abstract: With the publication of a new book surveying his visual practice, the pioneering composer reflects on the relationship between his art- and music-making.
lead_paragraph: Most know Brian Eno as the multifarious musician who was a founding member of the glam band Roxy Music; produced seminal albums by U2 and Talking Heads; and is widely considered to be one of the pioneers of ambient music. But Eno was an art student before he became a musician, and he never lost his yen for visual innovation. The recently released book “Brian Eno: Visual Music” (Chronicle, $50) chronicles more than four decades of his experiments with video, light and new media. Here, Eno looks back on the intersection between his visual art and his music making.

headline: Fright Night on the Subway
abstract: New Yorkers and tourists appeared on the subway in their best costumes for Halloween night.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers and tourists appeared on the subway in their best costumes for Halloween night.

headline: Pentagon News Service, Read at First Light and Debated All Day, Fades Away
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: There were many causes of death for the Early Bird, among them Internet services that made the effort seem like an anachronism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department’s Early Bird news service — which drove debates at the Pentagon, and its senior leaders to frustration, with its compilation of articles on military operations, budget politics and weapons programs — was declared dead on Friday.

headline: Babies Can Learn Music in the Womb
abstract: A new study suggests that babies can learn a melody they hear while still in the womb, and recognize it after they are born.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that babies can learn a melody they hear while still in the womb, and recognize it after they are born.

headline: India a Hub for Patients From Afghanistan
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Hospitals', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Visas']
abstract: In India, sophisticated treatment at far lower prices compared to developed countries, is attracting a large number of Afghans every year.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – Three years ago, the family of Rohullah Afzali, 23, a medical student at a university in Herat in western Afghanistan, noticed changes in his behavior. He was often brooding, anxious and sometimes angry. He would stay awake for three, even four nights on end.

headline: Amanda Peet on Her New Play
abstract: Amanda Peet, Sarah Jessica Parker and Blythe Danner talk about collaborating on Ms. Peet’s new play, “The Commons of Pensacola.”
lead_paragraph: Amanda Peet, Sarah Jessica Parker and Blythe Danner talk about collaborating on Ms. Peet’s new play, “The Commons of Pensacola.”

headline: New York Leads Country in Foreign-Born Voters, Analysis Says
abstract: Fully three in 10 New Yorkers who go to the polls on Tuesday are likely to have been born abroad, a modern high for the city.
lead_paragraph: Even without legislation to let noncitizens vote in local elections, fully three in 10 New Yorkers who go to the polls on Tuesday are likely to have been born abroad.

headline: Changing Her Game: Actress to Author
abstract: Amanda Peet turns playwright, with “The Commons of Pensacola,” starring Sarah Jessica Parker and Blythe Danner.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Peet turned 40 last year deeply disillusioned about her acting career. After early success with off-kilter film performances as a would-be assassin in “The Whole Nine Yards” and a drug-addled mistress in “Igby Goes Down,” she was mostly getting offers to play peripheral roles — girlfriends, wives, ex-wives. (Her furrowed brow was no match for the end of the world in “2012.”) And she couldn’t help resenting bigger stars who were nabbing plum cable series “that used to be for those of us who were waiting to do TV,” as Ms. Peet put it.

headline: The (Not So) Secret Life of Walter Mitty
abstract: The Times’s David Carr chats with Ben Stiller about his upcoming movie, “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.”
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Carr chats with Ben Stiller about his upcoming movie, “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.”

headline: Letting a Milquetoast Live Large
abstract: Ben Stiller directs and stars in the second movie version of James Thurber’s short story “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.”
lead_paragraph: “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty” is a piece so deeply knit into the culture that even many people who have not read the short story could tell you that it is about a very average Joe who flees his banal existence through a trapdoor of the imagination. James Thurber’s 1939 tale is a model of economy, a portrait of a hapless man who cycles through heroic fantasies as he goes about the quotidian business of his day.

headline: Lou Reed and the Neighbors
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A former resident of the same apartment building as Lou Reed recalled taking the elevator with him and not having a clue.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Roth Unbound’ and ‘Enemies Within’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of books about Philip Roth and the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: ‘Roth Unbound’

headline: Checking In on a Diner That Understands Social Media
abstract: The biggest change at Squeeze In, since my last post, has been in leadership.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I blogged here about a small business in Reno, Nev. that takes social media very seriously. The Squeeze In restaurants, open only seven hours a day, just for breakfast and lunch, have been serving guests since 1974. It has four locations, with plans to open a fifth in San Diego next year, and it also happens to be one of the savviest users of social media that I’ve come across.

headline: Ring of Power
abstract: In Dave Eggers’s dystopian novel, an eager young woman gives up her private life to work at a company called the Circle.
lead_paragraph: Mae Holland, a woman in her 20s, arrives for her first day of work at a company called the Circle. She marvels at the beautiful campus, the fountain, the tennis and volleyball courts, the squeals of children from the day care center “weaving like water.” The first line in the book is: “ ‘My God,’ Mae thought. ‘It’s heaven.’ ”

headline: Is Tech Lit an Oxymoron?
abstract: Signs of deep division between technology and literature remain.
lead_paragraph: Aldous Huxley once maintained that the “most profoundly important sociological factor of modern times” was “the growth of technology and what may be called the technicization of every aspect of human life.” And Huxley, of course, didn’t live long enough to book a hotel room with his iPhone.

headline: Comics, One Frame at a Time
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Books and Literature', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: New apps include ComiXology, which isolates each panel of a comic and expands it to the full size of a phone screen.
lead_paragraph: Reading a comic book or a graphic novel used to be a relatively straightforward affair. After you bought one, you’d follow the narrative fusion of words and art, turning the pages manually, admiring ads for sugar water and Sea-Monkeys along the way. But digital conversion has brought new possibilities. Now that comics creators can present stories on tablets and smartphones, they’re reinventing the reader experience.

headline: Subjective Lives
abstract: New novels take their inspiration from Edgar Allan Poe, Sigmund Freud, Dashiell Hammett, Lillian Hellman and other historical figures.
lead_paragraph: MRS. POEBy Lynn Cullen  Gallery Books, $26.

headline: Attention Must Be Paid
abstract: Daniel Goleman explores the link between mental focus and success.
lead_paragraph: “Ineluctable modality of the visible.” So begin the musings of Stephen Dedalus as he walks along Sandymount Strand in the third chapter of James Joyce’s “Ulys­ses.” “Signatures of all things I am here to read.” The chapter isn’t just a tour de force of prose writing. It’s an exquisitely sensitive depiction of a mind at play. Conscious of his own consciousness, Dedalus monitors his thoughts without reining them in. He’s at once focused and un­focused. Seemingly scattered ideas, sensations and memories coalesce into patterns, into art.

headline: Don’t Be a Jerk
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Randi Zuckerberg urges us to avoid the dark side of technology.
lead_paragraph: We expect startling ideas from those Silicon Valley technocrats whose brightness so often leaves the young dazzled and the old dazed.

headline: Engineered Performances
abstract: A study of Silicon Valley Web enthusiasts concludes that social media produce self-promoting, competitive corporate citizens.
lead_paragraph: The strange anthropological lesson of social media is that human beings, if given a choice, often prefer to socialize alone. Since the founding of Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other mainstays of what technology writers have come to call “the social Web” or “Web 2.0,” a sizable portion of humanity has learned to be together while apart, sacrificing intimacy for control and spontaneity for predictability. On the Web, we can be whoever we wish to be, editing the face we show to others in ways that aren’t possible in physical space. We can also fine-tune the complexity and depth of our interactions and relationships. The result is a sense of freedom whose appeal is evident in the exponential growth of the largest social media services, but it may be a misleading sense of freedom since the tools that make it possible are, for the most part, commercial enterprises, subtly shaping our behavior in ways designed to earn profits for their proprietors.

headline: Brain Gain
abstract: Has the Internet age made us lazy, or has it produced, as Clive Thompson says, a “radical new style of human intelligence”?
lead_paragraph: When the world chess champion Garry Kasparov was beaten in 1997 by Deep Blue, an I.B.M. supercomputer, it was considered to be a major milestone in the march toward artificial intelligence. It probably shouldn’t have been. As complex as chess is, it’s easy to see that its rules can be translated into algorithms so that computers, when they eventually got enough processing power, could crunch through billions of possible moves and past games. Deep Blue’s calculations were a fundamentally different process, most people would say, from the “real” thinking and intuition a human player would use.

headline: Spyware vs. Spyware
abstract: Hackers and cybercrooks aren’t the only ones lurking on the Internet. The police are there, too.
lead_paragraph: When we hear about people’s identities being stolen — e-mail appropriated, accounts infiltrated, lives invaded and subverted — a sense of helplessness envelops us. Sure, the victims of such crimes can rebuild their virtual lives, with new account numbers, passwords, Internet providers and computers. But none of this changes the fact that the culprits are unlikely to be caught. We feel something similar when we learn of a new governmental encroachment into our privacy, as we did with the revelations Edward Snowden furnished last spring about the National Security Agency’s ability to monitor our lives online. In both instances, it’s as if everything that was once promised by the computer age — certainty, precision, safety, power — has been little more than a lie.

headline: Pushing Their Buttons
abstract: A journalist goes behind the bitter rivalry between Apple and Google, and how it’s reshaping the way we think about technology.
lead_paragraph: Why do many people think that Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Apple are rivals? They hardly compete directly. Sure, Facebook and Google both sell targeted Web-based advertisements. But they offer such different services that they don’t share a core mission. Apple makes its money selling devices and mobile apps. Microsoft sells computer software and video game consoles. Google makes a free suite of applications that could challenge Microsoft Office. But it has not. Google also runs a social network that no one uses. And it gives away a mobile smartphone operating system. All four seem to be safely in control of distinct missions and markets. They intersect only slightly.

headline: One-Click Wonder
abstract: The story of Jeff Bezos and the $140 billion company he founded.
lead_paragraph: About a quarter of the way into “The Everything Store,” Brad Stone’s engrossing chronicle of the rise of Jeff Bezos and Amazon, he reveals that in the late 1990s, Bezos seriously contemplated trying to collect two copies of every book ever printed and store them in a warehouse in Lexington, Ky. Called the Alexandria Project, a k a Noah’s Ark, the initiative never got out of dry dock. And Lexington had no idea about its near miss with biblical importance.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Wally Lamb, a regular best seller since his debut novel was selected for Oprah Winfrey’s book club, is back on the hardcover fiction list at No. 4, with “We Are Water.”
lead_paragraph: Nothing Fancy: Wally Lamb’s fifth novel, “We Are Water” — about a dysfunctional family coming together for a same-sex wedding — enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. Lamb was one of the early winners of the Oprah Winfrey sweepstakes; he vaulted onto the list in 1997 when his debut, “She’s Come Undone,” was chosen for her book club, and all of his novels since have also been best sellers.

headline: Four Characters
abstract: Nick Bilton profiles the founders of Twitter and details their fight for control of the company.
lead_paragraph: A hundred and forty characters doesn’t sound like much, but as Twitter has shown over the course of its short, intense life, they’re enough to aid a revolution, ruin a reputation or direct help after a disaster. Critics tend to focus on the irresponsibility or narcissism of the form, or to say it breeds snark or false praise, or that it enables people to feel politically involved when they’re just ranting from their couches.

headline: Put That Down!
abstract: Teenage life in a wired age.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I found myself on the subway next to a young girl watching cartoons on an iDevice. She stroked its screen softly — lovingly, even — while her face relaxed in happiness. I was charmed. And terrified. We don’t yet know what, if any, the implications will be for a generation coming of age in a digital era, and the question fills even the most tech-savvy among us with a mixture of wonder and trepidation. But that is exactly what two youth-­minded researchers, Howard Gardner and Katie Davis, set out to answer in an ambitious and admirable project. Their efforts, spanning several years, have culminated in the meticulously researched and thoughtful book “The App Generation: How Today’s Youth Navigate Identity, Intimacy and Imagination in a Digital World,” which explores how young people view themselves and their relationships when smart devices are nearly ubiquitous, social rites happen via text message and the currency of popularity is traded in likes and comments on social-sharing apps.

headline: Linked In
abstract: A psychologist examines our basic need to connect with others.
lead_paragraph: Social psychologists love the Prisoner’s Dilemma. They use it to demonstrate the nature of calculated self-interest, with a setup like this: There’s a reward ($10, say) to be split between two players, and what one gets depends on whether the other decides to split things fairly. If both players choose to cooperate, each gets $5. If one cooperates but the other chooses to “defect,” the cooperative player gets nothing and the defector gets all $10. If both defect, they each get a dollar. The challenge is to decide without knowing what your partner has chosen. Defecting is the safer bet: you’ll get at least $1 and possibly $10. If you cooperate, you run the risk that your partner will defect, grabbing the whole pot and leaving you looking like a chump.

headline: Word Travels Fast
abstract: Twitter and Facebook are just the latest incarnations of a tradition that dates back 2,000 years, Tom Standage says.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 20 years, we’ve thought of “new media” as the brash young upstart and “old media” as the stalwart if increasingly embattled establishment. But what if new media aren’t as new as we assume — and old media not really old at all? So argues Tom Standage in “Writing on the Wall,” a provocative book that asks us to look at media less in terms of technology — digital or analog? — than in terms of the role they invite us to play. Are we passive receptors for whatever facts, opinions and ad messages come our way? Or are we participants, sharing what we like with others, amending or commenting in the process? The second is characteristic of the Internet in general and social media in particular. But there’s nothing revolutionary about this, Standage says. Instead, it’s the role of consumer, so typical of 20th-­century mass media, that’s unnatural — and to Standage, a historical blip.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE KEATS BROTHERS: The Life of John and George,  by Denise Gigante. (Belknap/Harvard University, $22.95.) “The Cockney Pioneer deserves a place next to the Cockney Poet in the visionary company of Romanticism,” Gigante writes in this savvy pairing of the lives of John Keats (1795-1821) and George Keats, whose emigration to America and fluctuating fortunes on the Western frontier inspired his brother’s most sublime poetry.

headline: Whole Wheat Almond Biscotti
abstract: A less sweet version of the classic biscotti de Prato.
lead_paragraph: These are based on the classic biscotti de Prato, but they are much less sweet and made with whole wheat flour and almond flour. Cut them in thin slices on the diagonal and dip them in tea, coffee or wine.

headline: 36 Hours in Düsseldorf, Germany
abstract: No, it’s not Berlin or Munich, but this city on the Rhine has more than enough attractions to fill a rewarding weekend.
lead_paragraph: Don’t pity Düsseldorf. Yes, it probably has a much lower profile than it should, far lower than bigger cities like Berlin and Munich — even arguably lower than that of its nearby archrival, Cologne. Yes, its soccer team, Fortuna Düsseldorf, was recently relegated from the top division to the second Bundesliga. And no, the capital of the North-Rhine Westphalia state is not regularly considered one of Europe’s top tourist destinations. But let this be your advantage. The artsy, cultivated hometown of both the great Romantic poet Heinrich Heine and the German punk-rock legend Die Toten Hosen, Düsseldorf has more than enough attractions for a rich cultural weekend — or even longer. Although the city is celebrating the 725th anniversary of its founding this year, Düsseldorf’s real draws are to be found in its dozens of new developments: stylish contemporary architecture, impressive modern art, cool new restaurants and even new takes on altbier, the local brew that ranks among Germany’s best beer styles.

headline: The Tell-Tale Green Heart
abstract: A very odd finding during routine surgery helps explain everything.
lead_paragraph: “Wow! Would you look at this!” Dr. Stephen Lahey, the chief of cardiac surgery at the University of Connecticut, broke the soothing rhythm of the Beatles song playing in the background of the operating room. He looked up at the anesthesiologist and his surgical assistant. “This guy’s heart — it’s green.”

headline: My Own Unprivate Little Italy
abstract: A photograph pulled me back into a world I thought I had imagined.
lead_paragraph: The smell of warm chicken blood in the stairwell of my friend Zoe’s apartment building on Mulberry Street is one thing I will never forget from the summer of 1980. Zoe and I held our breath against the thick air as we came and went. Was the family downstairs really slaughtering chickens in their apartment? Or were we just little girls with active imaginations?

headline: Fahrenheit 45-Fun
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Tape destroying; burglar fooling.
lead_paragraph: I help run a college TV network that recently held a promotional event where we destroyed a large number of VHS tapes to celebrate an upgrade. The tapes were all either ours (and already digitized) or donated explicitly for the purpose of destroying them. Some people were upset, even publicly comparing it to a book burning. Does it make sense to see a book burning as wrong but a tape smashing as acceptable? Is there a moral component to destroying one’s own property? ETHAN GOLDSTEIN, WORCESTER, MASS.

headline: Who Made That Referee Shirt?
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Football', 'Uniforms']
abstract: When the black-and-white-striped uniform made its first appearance on the field in 1921, the fans hated it.
lead_paragraph: “In the early days of football, the officials wore white dress shirts, often with a bow tie and usually a beret-type hat,” says Paul Lukas, editor of the Uni Watch blog, which chronicles sartorial trends in sports. “The notion was that a formally dressed gentleman has an air of authority, and that’s what you want in an official.”

headline: Randi Zuckerberg: ‘I Really Put Myself Out There’
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The first sister of Silicon Valley on online etiquette and why privacy is a Web 2.0 concern.
lead_paragraph: You were among the first 20 people hired at Facebook, and the sister of the C.E.O. Why did you leave?  I had been working seven days a week for six straight years. Having a son was the first time I got to pull my head up and see that there was a whole big world out there besides just working for Facebook.

headline: ‘As Long as You’re Watching People Have Sex, You Could Be Learning Something’
abstract: The quandary for “Masters of Sex”: How do you make a smart TV show about sex when every TV show is jampacked with sex?
lead_paragraph: Once, 15 years ago, I spent three strange days hanging around the Sheraton hotel in Universal City — which is not so much a city as a mostly unincorporated area in Los Angeles County that houses Universal Studios and its attendant theme park — reporting on an event that billed itself as an academic conference on the First Amendment and pornography. I was there on assignment for a magazine that was introducing a section on education, and the hook was that the conference was being sponsored by the Center for Sex Research at California State, Northridge, and something called the Free Speech Coalition, which I later learned was the lobbying arm of the adult-entertainment industry.

lead_paragraph: A very odd finding during routine surgery helps explain everything.

headline: Jumper Cables for the Mind
abstract: Would you give your brain a jolt if a Harvard scientist said it could make you smarter, more creative and less depressed?
lead_paragraph: This couldn’t possibly be a good idea. On Friday the 13th of September, in an old brick building on 13th Street in Boston’s Charlestown neighborhood, a pair of electrodes was attached to my forehead, one over my brain’s left prefrontal cortex, the other just above my right eye socket. I was about to undergo transcranial direct-current stimulation, or tDCS, an experimental technique for delivering extremely low dose electrical stimulation to the brain. Using less than 1 percent of the electrical energy necessary for electroconvulsive therapy, powered by an ordinary nine-volt battery, tDCS has been shown in hundreds of studies to enhance an astonishing, seemingly implausible variety of intellectual, emotional and movement-related brain functions. And its side effects appear limited to a mild tingling at the site of the electrode, sometimes a slight reddening of the skin, very rarely a headache and certainly no seizures or memory loss. Still, I felt more than a bit apprehensive as I prepared to find out if a little bit of juice could amp up my cognitive reserves and make me, in a word, smarter.

headline: Extra Care Curbs MRSA in Hospitals
abstract: MRSA infections dropped in some Veterans Affairs hospital after a quality improvement program was instituted.
lead_paragraph: The life-threatening bacterial infections known as MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, don’t respond well to antibiotics, but a new study in Veterans Affairs hospitals suggests they do respond to infection control techniques. Efforts like screening every patient for MRSA, using gowns and gloves when caring for infected patients, washing hands often, and creating a conviction among hospital staff that everyone is personally responsible for infection control were found to help reduce the rate of infections.

German officials say that the report’s conclusions are “incomprehensible” — which is just bizarre, because they’re absolutely straightforward.

headline: Why Would Reading Is Fundamental Partner With McDonald’s?
abstract: The nonprofit organization hopes families who aren’t in the habit of reading with children associate books with the relaxed atmosphere of McDonald’s.
lead_paragraph: Starting on Friday, McDonald’s plans to give away 20 million books in its Happy Meals over a two-week period, while giving another 100,000 books to children nationwide through a partnership with the nonprofit organization Reading Is Fundamental, commonly known as RIF. McDonald’s would prefer that we focus on the positives of its campaign: RIF’s website notes that two-thirds of children living in poverty have no books at home, and 80 percent of preschool and after-school programs serving low-income populations have no age-appropriate books for their children.
