headline: Tales of Danger for You to Survive
abstract: After summer’s postapocalyptic cinema, four new films confront the primal concern of staying alive.
lead_paragraph: Not always, but every now and then, the movies tell us what’s on our minds almost before we know ourselves. After a summer of postapocalyptic films in which the earth became a labor camp or else was overrun by zombies, we now have, just in time for the holiday season, four exceptionally good movies that are concerned just with surviving. They’re not about victory but about merely enduring, getting through some bad days and then some even worse ones, with a little help at the very end, perhaps, but mostly on your own.

headline: Tale of the Seed and the Song
abstract: The epic Douglas firs that rule the Oregon woods grow from something small and inconceivable. So does a song.
lead_paragraph: Up here, you know the Douglas fir rules the woods. It’s the tree among trees, reaching heights over 400 feet and these Oregon hills and mountains are full of their kind. As a kid I recall wandering up through the western coast range by truck, a rickety old Ford Bronco my buddy’s uncle let us use since it had a winch on account of nine times out of ten we’d get stuck up to the knee in some sloppy earth up there from the rains.

headline: Folk Art Collection From Imprisoned Former Museum Chairman Going to Auction
abstract: Sotheby’s will auction paintings, furniture and other works that belonged to Ralph O. Esmerian, the former chairman of the American Folk Art Museum, who is now imprisoned for financial fraud.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 watercolors, pieces of furniture, carvings, weather vanes and other valuable items that were once destined for the American Folk Art Museum are being auctioned at Sotheby’s on Jan. 25. The collection, estimated to be worth between $6.4 million and $9.5 million, belonged to the museum’s former chairman Ralph O. Esmerian, who once owned  the jewelry retailer Fred Leighton and who is currently serving a six-year sentence for a series of financial frauds totaling $210 million.

headline: Brentano Quartet Moves From Princeton to Yale
abstract: The group will become quartet-in-residence at the Yale School of Music, ending its association with Princeton.
lead_paragraph: When the Tokyo String Quartet retired earlier this year, Yale University’s music school found itself without a faculty string quartet for the first time in 37 years. But it has not taken the school long to remedy that. Yale announced on Friday that the Brentano Quartet – an ensemble known for its inventive programming, its passion for new music, and its polished but driven performances – would become the school’s quartet in residence starting in the fall of 2014.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in London; Washington; and Thailand
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: ‘Georgians Revealed: Life, Style and the Making of Modern Britain,’ London The Victorian and Elizabethan periods may be well known, but many quintessentially “polite” things thought of as British — taking tea, theatergoing and a fascination with gardening — originated in Georgian England. “Georgians Revealed,” from Nov. 8 to March 11 at the British Library, explores the roots of popular culture and “the revolution in everyday life” that took place between 1714 and 1830, through artwork, rare books and everyday objects, like the first fashion magazines. (Above, a circa 1714 portrait of George I.) Talks about culinary history, poetry and the emerging middle class; guided walking tours; and a night of “Vice and Virtue” with live music and performances, and food and drink, are highlights.

headline: Kerry Plans Brief Stop in Egypt, His First Since Military Takeover, State Media Report
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry will visit Egypt on Sunday, a day before Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president, is to make his first court appearance.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry will travel to Egypt on Sunday in his first visit since the military deposed President Mohamed Morsi four months ago, state news media reported. The trip, which is supposed to last a few hours, was an unpublicized addition to Mr. Kerry’s official itinerary as he begins a nine-day trip that includes a fence-mending visit to Saudi Arabia.

abstract: The police said several other agents were injured in a shooting at Los Angeles International Airport that led to the evacuation of thousands of passengers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A 23-year-old man wielding an assault rifle and carrying 100 rounds of ammunition shot and killed a Transportation Security Administration officer at Los Angeles International Airport on Friday morning, sending travelers fleeing in panic and paralyzing one of the world’s busiest airports for hours.

Now, at 21, after a series of false starts and a trail of gossip-column notoriety, she’s made a substantial debut album, literate in pop history, full of big melodies, frustration, distortion and a glamorous kind of antiglamour.

keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Workplace Environment', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: How to deal with a colleague who brings much of his home life to the office? A hospital doctor asks the Workologist for help.
lead_paragraph: I am a hospital physician. The consultant colleague with whom I share an office spends a large amount of paid work time doing Internet banking and arranging his family affairs. This includes phone calls to his wife and children. He’s supposed to spend his generously allocated nonclinical time preparing the resident education program, and the residents have complained about his apparent lack of interest in their training.

abstract: For a lot of fans, the real score in the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry, is not 27-8 but 5-3, the number of World Series titles each franchise has won in the last 20 years.

headline: Jets’ Defense Preparing for Another Tall Order
abstract: When the Jets face the 6-1 Saints on Sunday they will try to stop Jimmy Graham, who leads the N.F.L. in receiving yards at tight end with 630.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — If there is any consolation from last Sunday’s debacle against Cincinnati, Calvin Pace said, it is that the Jets get to play again before their bye week.

headline: Troubleshooter Reports Progress and Barriers in Bid to Repair Health Portal
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Officials expressed frustration Friday with hardware and software problems that continued to complicate the federal health insurance website.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials said Friday that they had spent $630 million on information technology for the federal health insurance website, and they expressed growing frustration with hardware and software problems that continued to thwart millions of people trying to buy insurance in the online market.

headline: Breakthrough Performances
abstract: Logan Hill looks at some of the noteworthy performances of the holiday movie season.
lead_paragraph: Logan Hill looks at some of the noteworthy performances of the holiday movie season.

headline: Irish Karaoke: Livin’ on a Prayer
abstract: Performing in order: Cam McDaniel, T.J. Jones, Zack Martin, Austin Collinsworth, Mathias Farley, Amir Carlisle, Corey Robinson, Sheldon Day and Louis Nix III.
lead_paragraph: Performing in order: Cam McDaniel, T.J. Jones, Zack Martin, Austin Collinsworth, Mathias Farley, Amir Carlisle, Corey Robinson, Sheldon Day and Louis Nix III.

headline: A Risk Communicator Says Industry Should Embrace Labeling of Genetically Modified Foods
keywords: ['Food', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A longtime risk communicator says industry should drop its fierce opposition to GMO labels.
lead_paragraph: David Ropeik, a consultant in risk communication who has worked for industry in the past (along with other clients), has posted a provocative call for big food and agriculture companies to end their aggressive fight against labeling requirements for foods containing genetically modified ingredients.

headline: Activists Accuse Walmart of Condoning Torture of Pigs by Pork Suppliers
abstract: Mercy for Animals, an animal rights organization, released video this week documenting what activists are calling the torture of pigs by workers at a Minnesota pork farm that supplies Walmart.
lead_paragraph: As part of a campaign to put pressure on Walmart, Mercy for Animals, an animal rights organization, released harrowing video this week documenting what activists call the torture of pigs by workers at a Minnesota pork farm that supplies the retail chain.

headline: At Notre Dame, a Parents’ Day Game Might Require a Red Carpet
abstract: The singer Jon Bon Jovi and athletes like Torii Hunter and David Robinson, among other celebrities, have sons on the Fighting Irish football team.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — At some point in the fourth quarter of home games, the Notre Dame marching band plays “Livin’ on a Prayer,” an ’80s rock anthem by Bon Jovi. The 10,000-plus green-shirted faithful in the student section sing along with the chorus: “Whoa, we’re halfway there. ...”

headline: Republican Campaign Committee Pushes Back Against Conservative Group
abstract: The National Republican Senatorial Committee told a Republican advertising firm that it would not receive any contracts with the committee because of its work with a group that targets incumbent Senate Republicans.
lead_paragraph: In a warning shot to outside conservative groups, the National Republican Senatorial Committee this week informed a prominent Republican advertising firm that it would not receive any contracts with the campaign committee because of its work with a group that targets incumbent Senate Republicans.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Brain Gain
abstract: Clive Thompson discusses his new book, “Smarter Than You Think.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review’s Tech Issue, Walter Isaacson reviews “Smarter Than You Think: How Technology Is Changing Our Minds for the Better,” by Clive Thompson. Mr. Isaacson writes:

headline: Star Turns Amid a Winter Flurry
abstract: Performances from four actors stand out among the season’s releases.
lead_paragraph: Jared Leto, ‘Dallas Buyers Club’

headline: In the East at Dawn, an Eclipse on Sunday
abstract: Early risers in the eastern United States will wake to a rare site on Sunday morning: a partial eclipse. A brief total eclipse will then sweep across the Atlantic and Central Africa.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday in the eastern United States, the sun will rise with a large bite taken out of it by the moon — a partial eclipse at dawn.

headline: Manage Fatigue in a Nonstop World With a Nap
abstract: No single behavior has more power to influence overall well-being and productivity than additional sleep, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t get enough sleep one night recently. I realize that’s scarcely a big confession, but it’s a rare event for me. Because I’m acutely aware of how critical sleep is to my mood, focus, creativity and even my motivation, I’m usually vigilant about getting the sleep I require to wake up fully rested.

headline: Call It Amphibious Cooking
abstract: When cooking tuna, treat it like beefsteak: showered with crushed black peppercorns and pan seared.
lead_paragraph: SELDOM DOES A RECIPE say it doesn’t matter whether you use meat or fish. But sometimes, it’s true. Grilled swordfish, for instance, tastes good with a savory wild mushroom sauce of the sort you might make for a pork roast.

headline: A Prankster and His Films Mature
abstract: Spike Jonze discusses the evolution of “Her,” the first feature that he has written and directed by himself.
lead_paragraph: “When I was 20 years old, I had no plans to ever be a filmmaker,” said the director Spike Jonze, cozy in a cotton button-down oxford shirt and a crew-neck sweatshirt, even on a stiff couch in a bland, beige Hell’s Kitchen video-editing suite. “Me and my friends had BMX magazines and skate magazines, and I was a photographer who made skate videos. There was just no way that would have ever even crossed my mind.”

headline: Both Parties Are Abusing the Filibuster
abstract: When Democrats place unreasonable holds, they make it easier for Republicans to engage in ideological crusades.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the same day that Republicans filibustered two of President Obama’s nominees, a Democratic senator announced that she too would block a vote on someone the president wants to hire. That means both parties are now abusing their power to “advise and consent.”

headline: F.C.C. Plans Sweeping Changes to Bolster AM Radio
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has proposed loosening or eliminating rules that govern nighttime transmissions by AM stations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission, seeking to revive the sagging fortunes of AM radio, has proposed removing or updating regulations that station owners believe have left many AM channels on the precipice of death.

headline: Yankees Re-Sign Jeter for One Year at $12 Million
abstract: The Yankees showed that they still have confidence in shortstop Derek Jeter by signing him to a deal worth more than his one-year, $9.5 million player option.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter endured the most agonizing season of his career in 2013, getting into only 17 games as a series of leg injuries and four trips to the disabled list prevented him from doing anything close to what he normally does on a baseball field.

headline: In-Flight Devices, Yes. But What About the Power?
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Text Messaging', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: After the F.A.A’s approval of the use of electronic devices on flights, airlines will need to provide the power for smartphones and tablets.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:44 p.m. | With the Federal Aviation Administration’s decision to allow passengers to use portable electronic devices throughout flights, the next question from fliers will most likely be, “So, where’s the power outlet?”

headline: Norman Rockwell’s New England
abstract: You can sleep and wander where the artist once did in a small Vermont town, but finding deeper clues about his life and work requires more exploration.
lead_paragraph: I had driven for three and a half hours from New York so that I could go for a walk. And here I was at last, strolling along River Road in Arlington, Vt. The quiet, unpaved street winds along the banks of the Batten Kill, which is said to be the best trout stream in Vermont. In the distance, the green hills were ablaze with red and orange and offered what seemed like a quintessential New England view.

headline: A Father Tries to End the Fat Talk
abstract: I was overweight until my 20s, and I still talk about myself as a fat person. Can I curb my tongue to help prevent my son from developing the same harsh self-judgment that’s been with me all of my life?
lead_paragraph: Recently, I was changing my 2-year-old son’s diaper and I happened to be shirtless.

headline: Knit One, Purl Two and Run 26.2
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'Knitting and Knit Goods', 'Running', 'Scarves', 'Marathon Running']
abstract: A college professor in Missouri recently ran a marathon while knitting a scarf over 12 feet long, weaving together pastimes first combined by an Englishwoman, Susie Hewer, in 2008.
lead_paragraph: The long-distance friendship between Susie Hewer and David Babcock is held together by colored yarn and a world record few people knew existed.

headline: Dickens’s Unknown Character: Himself
abstract: “Who was he, really?” asks Ralph Fiennes, who plays Charles Dickens in “The Invisible Woman,” about that writer’s longtime mistress, Nelly Ternan.
lead_paragraph: “He still preoccupies me, Dickens, as a person,” Ralph Fiennes said recently, between bites of grilled salmon in the back room of a quiet restaurant on a bright, breezy October day in New York. His film “The Invisible Woman,” which he directed and in which he stars as Charles Dickens, had just been screened for the news media at the Walter Reade Theater a few blocks away, and he’d spent half an hour afterward fielding questions about the strange, painful love story the movie tells. So you would think he might, at this point, be rather Dickensed out. He was not. “The psychology of him fascinates me, still,” he said, softly, sounding a little surprised himself. “Who was he, really?”

headline: Where Mental Asylums Live On
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Group Homes', 'Hospitals', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Disabilities']
abstract: In many poor and developing countries, thousands of mentally ill people are warehoused in dirty and dangerous institutions.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — DONALD RODAS, a baby-faced man in his late 20s with paranoid schizophrenia, arrived at Guatemala’s only public psychiatric hospital last year after being charged with murdering his parents. He says he often wanders freely through the sprawling facility of dilapidated one-story buildings and wooded courtyards, where detainees charged with crimes mingle with ordinary patients and the developmentally disabled.

headline: Changes in Labor Force Mask Gains in the Jobs Situation
abstract: When employment statistics are adjusted to account for demographic changes in the labor force, they indicate that the overall jobs situation has improved.
lead_paragraph: THE unemployment rate has fallen by nearly three percentage points since the Great Recession was at its worst four years ago. But another indicator of the labor market has shown no improvement at all.

headline: New York City Marathon, by the Numbers
abstract: The world’s largest marathon took place on Sunday. A look at the number of paper cups, the oldest runner and other unexpected facts about the race.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest marathon took place on Sunday. A look at the number of paper cups, the oldest runner and other unexpected facts about the race.

headline: Brooklyn Motor Works: From Underwater to on the Water
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Small Business']
abstract: A year after Hurricane Sandy flooded Brooklyn Motor Works, Carlos Dos Santos is still on his feet and keeping motorcycle enthusiasts on the road.
lead_paragraph: When you think of waterfront property, beach houses and restaurants probably supersede motorcycle shops among the things that come to mind. But Brooklyn Motor Works, the Harley-Davidson repair shop that occupies the garage perched on a small pad of concrete and gravel in Red Hook, on the banks of New York Harbor, wasn’t always a waterfront property. It took Hurricane Sandy for it to end up there.

headline: Off the Charts: Job Picture May Be Better Than It Appears
abstract: Much of the decline in the labor force participation rate is actually a result of an aging population.
lead_paragraph: Much of the decline in the labor force participation rate is actually a result of an aging population.

headline: Same New York Rivers, but All Else Was New
abstract: The exhibition “Industrial Sublime: Modernism and the Transformation of New York’s Rivers, 1900-1940” is at the Hudson River Museum.
lead_paragraph: They came to New York from near and far — Connecticut and Australia, Pennsylvania and Norway — to paint the wonders of the new century. But even though the 50-odd artists whose works are on view in the magnificent new show at the Hudson River Museum were all looking at the same railyards and bridges and waterways, they were seeing very different things.

headline: You’re Going to Need a Bigger Bowl
abstract: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers hearty vegetarian meals in a bowl (or on a plate) inspired by the Korean dish bibimbap.
lead_paragraph: These hearty vegetarian meals in a bowl (or on a plate) are inspired by the Korean dish bibimbap. I call them “Big Bowls” because they are also inspired by a popular food truck I’ve eaten at, in Portland, Ore., whose only offering is called Whole Bowl, and is a comforting bowl of brown rice, with black beans, salsa, avocado and queso blanco. The long line of people I observed at this truck confirmed for me the fact that a simple, satisfying meal with grain, protein and terrific vegetables can be worth standing in line for.

headline: Snowden’s Letter of Appeal to Washington
keywords: ['Letters', 'United States International Relations', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden appealed to Washington in a letter he gave to Hans-Christian Ströbele, a veteran member of the Green Party in the German Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden appealed to Washington in a letter he gave to Hans-Christian Ströbele, a veteran member of the Green Party in the German Parliament.

headline: Snowden Asks U.S. to Stop Treating Him Like a Traitor
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: In a letter handed to a German politician, the former intelligence contractor says that “my government continues to treat dissent as defection.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American security contractor granted temporary asylum by Russia, has appealed to Washington to stop treating him like a traitor for revealing that the United States has been eavesdropping on its allies, a German politician who met with Mr. Snowden said on Friday.

headline: Descriptions of Chaos and Fear at Los Angeles Airport Shooting
abstract: Witnesses described a scene of uncertainty during the shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, where a T.S.A. officer was killed, at least one terminal was evacuated, flights were grounded and several people were sent to the hospital with injuries.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:03 p.m. | As my colleagues Jennifer Medina and Timothy Williams reported, a Transportation Security Administration officer was killed, at least one terminal was evacuated, flights were grounded, and several other people were sent to the hospital with injuries after a shooting at Los Angeles International Airport on Friday, the authorities said.

headline: In Whitman’s Backyard, a Salute to Poetry
abstract: Nationally recognized poets will gather in South Huntington, where a literary giant was born in 1819.
lead_paragraph: Faith Lieberman is a poet and former teacher, among other things, who in the late 1990s discovered that she also had a talent for organization. Starting in 1997, she put together three poetry festivals in Huntington, the last of which was shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and resonated with the trauma of that event, she said. “I felt I needed a rest,” said Ms. Lieberman, who lives in Lloyd Harbor.

headline: For Vettel, No Pressure in Abu Dhabi Race
abstract: With Sebastian Vettel crowned this year’s Formula One champion, Ferrari and Mercedes-Benz will fight over season scraps in the last three races.
lead_paragraph: Sunday’s Grand Prix of Abu Dhabi —– 17th of the 19 races counting for the Formula One World Drivers and Constructors championships — finds itself in a peculiar situation. Aside from providing some entertainment for the local citizenry, the race won’t count for anything of note.

headline: Bloomers on the Loose Side. Then the Aftermath.
abstract: “The Underpants,” by Steve Martin, adapted from Carl Sternheim, explores gender politics in 1910 Düsseldorf.
lead_paragraph: The audience does not actually see the mortifying incident in “The Underpants.”

headline: Nas Gives a Benediction for a Harvard Hip-Hop Fellowship
abstract: An anonymous donor established a fellowship for the study of hip-hop, naming it after Nas.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Nas made his first appearance at Harvard University on Thursday, not to perform but to give his blessing to a new fellowship in his name – formally, the Nasir Jones Hip-Hop Fellowship.

headline: Lhota’s Strengths and Weaknesses, Exposed on 9/11
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota’s approach to the unfolding crisis of Sept. 11, 2001, revealed a Boy Scout’s obsession with preparedness and a bureaucrat’s faith in the problem-solving powers of government.
lead_paragraph: Nobody ever asked Joseph J. Lhota about the thick three-ring binder on his desk at City Hall, a dusty tome that bore a cryptic label: E.O.W.

headline: Aiming for Truly Sustainable Buildings
keywords: ['Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A growing list of eco-friendly construction technologies enables developers to go beyond LEED certification.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, the most widely recognized seal of approval for green buildings among New York City buyers has been LEED, a label that stands for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design.

headline: A Toast to Dearest Distant Friends
abstract: In “The High Water Mark,” a new play by Ben Clawson that Luna Stage is presenting in West Orange, childhood chums reconnect in the middle of the night to hash out their midlife crises.
lead_paragraph: It is a sorry fact of life that sometimes and somehow we lose touch with our oldest and closest friends. Such is the case of Janet and Lily, the middle-age characters of “The High Water Mark,” a new play by Ben Clawson that Luna Stage is presenting in West Orange.

headline: Market Failure and Government Failure
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The regulatory lapses that invited the financial crisis have been compounded by an inadequate and sometimes misguided government response in fostering economic revival, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Pricewaterhouse Takeover of Booz Risks Culture Clash
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Consultants', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Sarbanes-Oxley Act']
abstract: Restrictions enacted after the Enron scandal mean advisory services employees at Booz & Company could end up battling with PricewaterhouseCoopers accountants over clients.
lead_paragraph: PricewaterhouseCoopers’ proposed takeover of the strategy firm Booz & Company would be the most prominent example yet of a Big Four auditor bulking up on consulting. But restrictions enacted after the Enron scandal of 2001 mean advisory services employees could end up battling with accountants over clients. While the midsize Booz & Company may feel pressure to compete with rivals like Boston Consulting Group and McKinsey & Company, the proposed deal with PricewaterhouseCoopers risks a huge culture clash.

headline: Above Ground and Below
abstract: One new book takes readers on a 6,000-mile walk across New York City, and another explores an unbuilt subway system.
lead_paragraph: The delight is definitely in the details in William B. Helmreich’s “The New York Nobody Knows: Walking 6,000 Miles in the City” (Princeton University Press). Professor Helmreich, a sociologist at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, invites readers on a romp through largely unexplored neighborhoods that is as entertaining as it is enlightening.

headline: Q. & A. | Nick Waplington on the Last Days of Alexander McQueen
abstract: The photographer, who captured the creation of the designer’s final fall/winter collection in the book “Alexander McQueen: Working Process,” shares his memories of the experience.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: More Than Shadows: Stars of Strauss
abstract: “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” returns to the Metropolitan Opera with Anne Schwanewilms and Christine Goerke.
lead_paragraph: It’s late in the afternoon near the end of a long rehearsal day at the Metropolitan Opera House, and in a spacious room deep in the storied building’s recesses, two illustrious sopranos, Anne Schwanewilms and Christine Goerke, look as though they might start a Rockettes kick line. Arms around each other’s waists as they run through a triumphant final ensemble number in “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” (“The Woman Without a Shadow”), the Richard Strauss opera that returns to the Met stage this Thursday night, the vocalists briefly cavort in lock step, beaming as they sing.

headline: The Steps of City Hall
abstract: New York's City Hall has long been a theatrical setting where aspiring politicians make and break their careers, and where mayors have courted stage, screen, sporting and other celebrities.
lead_paragraph: New York's City Hall has long been a theatrical setting where aspiring politicians make and break their careers, and where mayors have courted stage, screen, sporting and other celebrities.

headline: A Romance With a Long Interruption
abstract: Anne Koch and Robert Sibson met in high school. Then almost two decades intervened.
lead_paragraph: The love story between Anne Koch and Robert Sibson began like a European version of a teenage romance dreamed up by the director John Hughes.

headline: Attraction Unmasked
abstract: Poems about Halloween’s erotic underpinnings were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: Children relish Halloween for the candy, but as patrons of a Ricky’s store know, adults prefer a salacious Sailor Moon costume to a Mars bar. These poems about the holiday’s erotic underpinnings were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: First Big Role, Right Out of School
abstract: The actor Ben Schnetzer talks about his first big role, in “The Book Thief,” which opens on Friday.
lead_paragraph: “It’s been the craziest year of my life,” Ben Schnetzer said, laughing.

headline: What Governor Cuomo’s Dad Said About Gambling
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants more casinos in New York State. His father, Mario Cuomo, once argued against such a step.
lead_paragraph: Gambling interests have tons of cash and are spending it freely to support Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s constitutional amendment to add seven new casinos in New York State. But opponents of the amendment have the words of one especially persuasive advocate: former Gov. Mario Cuomo, the present governor’s father.

headline: A Nod to Siberia and the Balkans
abstract: It’s rare to hear a new work that surprises with both its beauty and originality, as does Caroline Shaw’s a cappella Partita for Eight Voices.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to hear a new work that surprises with both its beauty and originality, as does Caroline Shaw’s a cappella Partita for Eight Voices, for which she was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in music earlier this year. Ms. Shaw, who is also a violinist, wrote the work for the ensemble Roomful of Teeth, of which she is a member. The Partita, released on New Amsterdam Records last year, incorporates nontraditional vocal techniques like Tuvan throat singing, yodeling, speech, murmurs and other vocal effects. On Monday at Le Poisson Rouge, Roomful offers the premiere performance of the Partita, as well as works by Caleb Burhans, Brad Wells and William Brittelle. (8 p.m., 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village, 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com; $25.)

headline: He Knew Men, He Knew Women
abstract: “Men like to look,” Bob Guccione said. “I think if you took that away from them, they wouldn’t enjoy participating as much.”
lead_paragraph: Bob Guccione liked to brag that he knew women. But he also knew men.

headline: Hoping for Morning Lows in the 30s
abstract: Irv Gikofsky, the meteorologist known as Mr. G, spends his Sundays running in Central Park, working with charities and rooting for the Giants.
lead_paragraph: Rain or shine, the meteorologist Irv Gikofsky, known as Mr. G, reserves Sundays for long runs, short naps and time with his family. On weekdays, Mr. G, 68, delivers the weather at 6 a.m. on WCBS-FM radio, and again at 5 and 10 p.m. on WPIX-TV newscasts; on Fridays, he also has a WPIX segment, “It’s a G Thing,” about noteworthy New Yorkers. With no broadcast on Sunday, he relaxes in the Upper West Side apartment he shares with his wife, Sang Mota Gikofsky, 45, a social worker, and stepdaughter, Jaida Kyi, 23, a fashion student. Lately he has been training for this year’s New York City Marathon, taking place Sunday; this will be his 30th year participating in the event. “The marathon reveals the human spirit at its best,” he said. This year, Jaida will join him for the first time.

headline: Creepy, Silent Ode to Death
abstract: Images redolent of World War I and German Expressionism converge in F. W. Murnau’s silent “Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror” (1922), coming to Film Forum on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Images redolent of World War I and German Expressionism converge in F. W. Murnau’s silent “Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror” (1922), coming to Film Forum on Monday. An unauthorized adaptation of “Dracula,” the film employs a range of visual flourishes (coffins overflowing with vermin, a carriage pulled by masked horses) and treatments (accelerated film speeds, reverse negative images) to convey its singular ambience of plague, dread and menace. The film’s principal special effect is its antagonist, Max Schreck’s Count Orlok, a hairless predator with large clawlike hands, pointy ears and a rodentlike countenance.

headline: Windows to Past, Wide and Tall
abstract: Over the years, Reinhard Mucha has been something of an elusive artist.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Reinhard Mucha has been something of an elusive artist. He avoided New York in the 1980s to escape a scene that catered to celebrity artists. But Mr. Mucha, who is German, has even so remained a New York presence, turning up in museum shows (he’s also in the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection) and as an influence on others’ work. Now Mr. Mucha himself has come to town with his first solo New York show in 13 years, which opened on Saturday at the Luhring Augustine Gallery.

headline: Movement Extremes
abstract: Too much strength can just about ruin a dance, but this week affords a rare opportunity to experience its power in both formidable and subtle ways.
lead_paragraph: Too much strength can just about ruin a dance, but this week affords a rare opportunity to experience its power in both formidable and subtle ways when two choreographers, Maria Hassabi and Elizabeth Streb, reveal its nerve and beauty. In “Premiere,” a work for five at the Kitchen, Ms. Hassabi displays her captivation with bodies that move at an unimaginably slow pace. The shakes, the tremors and the sweat — results of such pared-down motion — tell the real story. (Wednesday to Saturday, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, 212-255-5793, thekitchen.org.)

headline: A Not-Quite New Guy on ‘New Girl’
abstract: Damon Wayans Jr. had to drop out of the sitcom “New Girl” after appearing in the pilot. Now, in Season 3, he’s back.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Meriwether found herself in a pickle familiar to veteran renters: She had lined up the perfect apartment — a sun-filled loft — and rounded up four roommates who got along perfectly. Plans were made. Contracts were signed. Then, at the last minute, somebody backed out.

headline: Weekend Reading: Calm Before the Storm
abstract: [Editors’ note: Please do not read this if you are a junior banker at Goldman Sachs.]
lead_paragraph: [Editors’ note: Please do not read this if you are a junior banker at Goldman Sachs.]

headline: Irreverent, Sure, but Relevant, Too
abstract: Let the rice and laughter flow: at some weddings, comedians and other performers administer the “I dos.”
lead_paragraph: Kenny Kramer stood at a podium, his hair tied in a ponytail. He shuffled a stack of readings, adjusted his glasses and scanned the wedding guests, looking very much the officiant.

headline: 2013 Nissan Sentra
abstract: Nissan’s redesigned compact claims a place at the table, but it won’t be the life of the party.
lead_paragraph: Nissan’s redesigned compact claims a place at the table, but it won’t be the life of the party.

headline: Missing Hand in Met’s Commissions
abstract: The future for new opera at the Met may be getting a little brighter, but one significant name was mostly missing from a recent announcement: James Levine.
lead_paragraph: If the Metropolitan Opera is going to become a house that truly fosters new works, it has a lot of catching up to do, and the general manager, Peter Gelb, seems to know it. Since taking over the company in 2006, he has asked opera fans to have patience as the Met grapples with this essential responsibility.

headline: The Secret to Their Staying Power
abstract: Steve Humphrey, Norwood Pennewell, Natalie Rogers of Garth Fagan’s troupe, which will perform at the Joyce on Nov. 12, are anomalies in the dance world.
lead_paragraph: Dancing past the age of 40 is hard enough. But what about 50? Or 60? At Garth Fagan Dance, the burning question, from one season to the next, is simple: How do they do it?

headline: New Yorkers: Mentoria Hutchinson
abstract: For decades, Ms. Hutchinson, 61, has been energetically directing traffic with a shoulder shake and a hip shimmy.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Ms. Hutchinson, 61, has been energetically directing traffic with a shoulder shake and a hip shimmy.

headline: Women Edging Their Way Into the D.J. Booth
abstract: Female D.J.’s like Nicole Moudaber, Nina Kraviz, Cassy and the duo Nervo are making strides in the male-dominated world of electronic dance music.
lead_paragraph: When the D.J. duo Nervo, the Australian twins Olivia and Miriam Nervo, first began spinning three years ago, they used to shock people just by showing up.

headline: Just Like the Films We Used to Know
abstract: Richard Curtis, John Lee Hancock, Kasi Lemmons and Malcolm D. Lee describe the holiday movies that they cherish.
lead_paragraph: ‘White Christmas’ (1954), Directed by Michael Curtiz

headline: Indie Grace, African Funk, Whispery Muscle
abstract: New albums from Minor Alps, Juana Molina, Tal National and Omar Souleyman.
lead_paragraph: Minor Alps GET THERE

headline: Why Attractive Candidates Win
abstract: The preference for attractive politicians seems to ebb and flow with voters’ concerns about germs and avoiding disease.
lead_paragraph: JOHN F. KENNEDY, Sarah Palin, Mitt Romney, Kirsten Gillibrand: Americans have a long history of electing good-looking leaders. Of course, not every successful candidate could be a stand-in for George Clooney or Angelina Jolie. Indeed, sometimes a less attractive candidate triumphs over a better-looking rival. So when and why do voters prefer more attractive politicians?

headline: ’90s Comebacks: Of Toad and Live
abstract: The mid-1990s had room for all sorts of unlikely rock stars.
lead_paragraph: The mid-1990s had room for all sorts of unlikely rock stars. Indie rock and grunge had — how to put it politely? — wiped the glamour off the guys with guitars. Once those modes had been mainstreamed, the genre’s stars could be just, you know, dudes. Resilient dudes at that. Two of the most dudely are in the midst of whodathunkit comebacks.

headline: Tinsel Time! Peek-a-Boo, Twirling and Retreat, in a 10th-Anniversary Celebration
abstract: Keigwin & Company celebrates its 10th anniversary at the Joyce with some City Ballet dancers making guest appearances.
lead_paragraph: This week at the Joyce Theater, the choreographer Larry Keigwin celebrates his company’s 10th anniversary, an achievement that shouldn’t be taken lightly. In modern dance, that’s an eon.

headline: Dancing With the Cars
abstract: Mentoria Hutchinson dances to direct morning rush traffic leaving the Queensboro Bridge, eliciting honks and drawing spectators.
lead_paragraph: A busy Manhattan intersection during the morning rush might seem an unlikely place to make your dance floor, but that’s where Mentoria Hutchinson mixes it up with thousands of impatient drivers every day.

headline: Canada Tests Animal Detectors
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'ANIMALS', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Deer', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Two new motion-detection systems are being tested in Ontario to warn motorists when animals like moose and deer wander onto the road.
lead_paragraph: MONKLAND, ONTARIO — Signs warning motorists about deer and moose, some approaching mooselike dimensions themselves, are a fixture on many Ontario highways. But the signs’ ubiquity is also their shortcoming.

headline: Aware at the Wheel
abstract: Here are some recommendations to reduce the chance of a collision with an animal.
lead_paragraph: Here are recommendations from the Insurance Information Institute to reduce the chance of a collision with an animal:

headline: Heading Over to Queens
abstract: Queens neighborhoods are giving Manhattan and Brooklyn a run for the money.
lead_paragraph: Queens neighborhoods are giving Manhattan and Brooklyn a run for the money.

headline: The Tilt Toward Queens
abstract: The borough’s neighborhoods are giving Manhattan and Brooklyn a run for the money.
lead_paragraph: Queens, the city’s most sprawling borough, has long been a landing pad for new arrivals and those looking for a cheaper alternative to Manhattan. Over the decades, newcomers from practically every corner of the world have moved in, making it the most diverse borough in New York City.

headline: Scene City: Who Said Halloween Was for Kids?
abstract: Heidi Klum goes geriatric at Marquee, V Magazine dazzles at the Standard.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Klum goes geriatric at Marquee, V Magazine dazzles at the Standard.

headline: In Communion With Bach, Head, Heart and Fingers
abstract: The pianist Andras Schiff, a legendary Bach enthusiast, performed all six of the composer’s partitas on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, the 300th anniversary of Bach’s birth, the Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff, then 31, gave three concerts at the Metropolitan Museum, prompting many to declare him the Bach pianist of his generation. The first two programs offered the six keyboard partitas and another work or two, and the third consisted of the “Goldberg” Variations.

headline: Review: Nissan Sentra
abstract: Compact sedan buyers have never had so many excellent choices. Deciding on one means doing your homework. Tom Voelk checks out the Nissan Sentra to see if it makes the grade.
lead_paragraph: Compact sedan buyers have never had so many excellent choices. Deciding on one means doing your homework. Tom Voelk checks out the Nissan Sentra to see if it makes the grade.

headline: Even in Bright Hues, Color It Beige
abstract: Although the market for compact sedans is highly competitive, with such solid cars as the Honda Civic and Ford Focus, Nissan has made its new Sentra rather average.
lead_paragraph: If the redesigned 2013 Sentra has hit its target, what was Nissan aiming at?

headline: Rules for Sending Packages to Inmates in New York
abstract: A New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision list of who can send what, and how, and what is permitted and what is not.
lead_paragraph: A New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision list of who can send what, and how, and what is permitted and what is not.

headline: CHART
abstract: A tale of two royal princesses — and the besties who stepped into their heels to play Diana of Wales and Grace of Monaco.
lead_paragraph: A tale of two royal princesses — and the besties who stepped into their heels to play Diana of Wales and Grace of Monaco.

headline: Transforming Movements
abstract: Works by Room 100 and Eisa Jocson for the Queer New York International Arts Festival explore ideas of otherness.
lead_paragraph: What does “queer performance” mean? In the second edition of the Queer New York International Arts Festival, the notion of queer relates not only to gender and identity, but also falls under the bigger umbrella of otherness. Programmed by André von Ah (who died in September) and Zvonimir Dobrovic, the event offers a look at artists working in anomalous, eccentric and even otherworldly forms.

headline: Rye Spaetzle Gratin
abstract: Mixing up a batch of spaetzle is as easy making pancake batter. But you’ll need a hand to make the dumplings without a spaetzle maker.
lead_paragraph: Mixing up a batch of spaetzle is as easy making pancake batter. But you’ll need a hand to make the dumplings without a spaetzle maker.

headline: Innovation Imperative: Change Everything
abstract: Online education is beginning to show itself as a disruptive innovation, introducing more convenient and affordable services that can transform sectors.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the first commercially successful steamship traveled the Hudson River in 1807, it didn’t appear to be much of a competitive threat to transoceanic sailing ships. It was more expensive, less reliable and couldn’t travel very far. Sailors dismissed the idea that steam technology could ever measure up — the vast reach of the Atlantic Ocean surely demanded sails. And so steam power gained its foothold as a “disruptive innovation” in inland waterways, where the ability to move against the wind, or when there was no wind at all, was important.

headline: For Interfaith Gay Couples, Just One Obstacle Is Cleared
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Many couples learn that finding a religious leader to officiate at a same-sex wedding is far easier than finding one for a religiously mixed ceremony.
lead_paragraph: OSSINING, N.Y. — One morning last summer, Connie Knapp got a phone call from her minister. Several days earlier, the Supreme Court had handed down a ruling fortifying the movement for same-sex marriage. Her pastor, the Rev. Chip Low, had a feeling that Ms. Knapp and her partner, Anne Corey, might want to have a wedding.

headline: Machines for Building That Serve a Higher Purpose
abstract: A Belgian artist blends the shapes of industrial machinery with medieval architecture to create Gothic art. A model is on display at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The dump truck is bent and full of holes, but the daily abuse of a construction site is not to blame. This mass of perforated steel is a work of art.

headline: Construction, Elevated
abstract: A look at some of the pieces in Wim Delvoye’s Gothic works series.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the pieces in Wim Delvoye’s Gothic works series.

headline: DVDs Screening by an Open Fire
abstract: The holiday season’s new videos include masterpieces from the likes of Robert Altman, William Wyler, George Stevens and Philip Kaufman.
lead_paragraph: ‘Nashville’ (1975), Directed by Robert Altman

headline: Deer Mating Season: Drivers Beware
abstract: Nearly half of vehicle accidents involving white-tail deer occur from October to December, with November the worst month.
lead_paragraph: It’s the deadliest time of the year for deer, which also pose a particular danger to motorists in autumn with the arrival of the mating and hunting seasons.

headline: Hawks’ Mystical Marathon
abstract: About 14 species of hawks can be found with varying regularity in New York City and the vicinity during their annual fall migration.
lead_paragraph: For those in tune with the annual cadence of the seasons, migration is nothing less than mystical. What superficially seems random can shimmer with the kaleidoscopic diversity of evolution when more thoroughly examined.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Costumery
abstract: The fall foliage brings an abundance of lumberjack plaids and checks.
lead_paragraph: The fall foliage brings an abundance of lumberjack plaids and checks.

headline: Spaetzle at Home: Crank Up the Fluegelhorn and Fill the Steins
abstract: Add leeks and cabbage, cover with cheese, and bake until everything is bubbling and crunchy on top.
lead_paragraph: Unless you have an Eastern European heritage or a penchant for replicating the hearty cuisine of German beer halls, it may never have occurred to you to make spaetzle at home. I have both, and the small, squiggly egg dumplings are one of the first carb-heavy, comfort-food dishes I crave when the weather turns cold.

headline: The Cellblocks’ Amazon.com
abstract: Sending packages to loved ones doing time can be, as thousands of local families know, a Kafkaesque process.  Sendapackage.com helps get the goods behind bars.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, a street team from Sendapackage.com was standing on a sidewalk near Columbus Circle in Manhattan talking with a dozen women about to board a charter bus that would take them upstate to visit their relatives in prison. It was 10 p.m. and many of the women huddled in the darkness were toting sleepy children; most were also burdened with plastic bags of Pop Tarts, pretzels, cookies and potato chips — junk food unavailable to men behind bars.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 1
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy, a century-old land dispute and a Halloween parade.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy, a century-old land dispute and a Halloween parade.

headline: Big Gains for Auto Sales Despite a Government Pothole
abstract: Even with the partial federal shutdown, new-car sales in October were up 10.6 percent as the industry stayed on track for its best sales in six years.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The tempo for new-car sales in the United States accelerated after the 16-day partial government shutdown, as pent-up demand for refreshed vehicle models are keeping the industry on track for its best sales in six years.

headline: Catching Up on the Bennett Hypothesis
abstract: What’s to blame for the high cost of college? It’s financial aid, stupid.
lead_paragraph: ON HIS nationally syndicated radio show, “Bill Bennett’s Morning in America,” William J. Bennett often advises students about college. Stories from callers burdened by student loans inspired his latest book, “Is College Worth It?,” written with David Wilezol. Dr. Bennett, 70, is not surprised that the cost of a four-year college has increased so much. In a 1987 opinion piece in The New York Times, which he wrote when he was President Reagan’s education secretary, he predicted it.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Costumery
abstract: The fall foliage brings an abundance of lumberjack plaids and checks.
lead_paragraph: A tiptop autumn week of color in New York, what with the foliage, Halloween and the art of carving pumpkins, the arrival of marathon runners and the abundance of lumberjack plaids and checks. In Paris, the rage is patchwork jeans from Junya Watanabe, but people could just as well make their own patchwork. In Central Park, a headless horseman rides again.

headline: Big Ticket | Treetop Park Views for $16 Million
abstract: A four-bedroom condominium with a corner living room commands 40 feet of park frontage.
lead_paragraph: Another of the floor-through luxury residences at 18 Gramercy Park with direct treetop views, along with dibs on a special key permitting access to that private and historic park, sold for $16 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The 4,207-square-foot residence, No. 7, has four bedrooms, five and a half baths, and a corner living room that commands 40 feet of park frontage; the monthly carrying charges are $11,225.31.

headline: La Scala Musicians Endorse Successor to Barenboim
abstract: The orchestra of Teatro alla Scala in Milan approves the choice of Riccardo Chailly to succeed Daniel Barenbom as artistic director.
lead_paragraph: The musicians of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan have agreed to endorse Riccardo Chailly as artistic director to succeed Daniel Barenboim, who announced that he would step down two years ahead of schedule, in 2014, a spokesman for La Scala, Carlo Maria Cella, said.

headline: After Boston Bombings, New York Police Plan Tight Security at Marathon
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: Almost the entire New York City Marathon route will be covered, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Friday, and hundreds of cameras will be monitored in real time.
lead_paragraph: As part of an enhanced security plan developed after the Boston Marathon bombings in April, the New York Police Department plans to deploy helicopters, police boats, scuba divers, bomb-sniffing dogs and hundreds of cameras, as well as hundreds of officers, at Sunday’s New York City Marathon.

headline: More Notes On Germany
abstract: Adding to world excess savings.
lead_paragraph: A few more things to say about Germany’s trade surplus and the US report saying, correctly, that it’s harmful to the world economy.

headline: What the Well-Dressed Warrior Wears
abstract: The costume designer Trish Summerville used feathers, froth and haute couture in a chilly winter palette for “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.”
lead_paragraph: Katniss Everdeen as fashion’s It Girl? That’s how the costume designer Trish Summerville imagined the teenage warrior portrayed by Jennifer Lawrence in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire”: As a previous victor, she must be camera-ready as Panem prepares for the 75th games.

headline: Application Upload: Your Voice via Video
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Some students express themselves best via multimedia, so they are making videos to go with their applications. How are they viewed?
lead_paragraph: IN 2009, Tufts and George Mason University opened the multimedia floodgates by inviting applicants to submit videos. While few admissions offices have followed suit and added a video solicitation, a sweep through YouTube shows videos, from existential mulling to absurdist displays of multitasking, being made for a wide swath of institutions. The incentive is clear for students who express themselves best via multimedia, and who isn’t looking for an edge?

headline: The New Faces of College Admissions
abstract: Parents are being asked to promote their child’s college at fairs, to reach out to local parents and even to conduct admissions interviews.
lead_paragraph: MY DAUGHTER was in college. I had let go, just as the school had suggested. Then the email arrived, asking me to pitch in and join its “admission network.” I’d thought I was finished with school volunteer work!

headline: Words of Admissions Wisdom
abstract: Novels set amid application angst.
lead_paragraph: The misty bogs of Scotland may perennially top the Bowker list of favorite fictional settings, but what can beat the twisted, ivy-trimmed road to First Choice U for melodrama and suspense? The latest in the increasingly popular admissions genre is a novel called “Early Decision: Based on a True Frenzy.”

headline: The Sophomore Slump
abstract: College can really drag the second year. Programs try to make sophomores feel less like overlooked middle children.
lead_paragraph: Pity the sophomore. You are feted as a freshman, but no one seems to care that you’re back on campus. Quirky first-year seminars have been replaced by large foundation classes, making you doubt that major in econ or bio. You’re not high enough up the totem pole to do fun stuff like join a research team or lead student organizations. With the newness of college gone, malaise sets in.

headline: Tax on Textbooks? Yes and No
abstract: Don’t cross the state line if you can’t pay the fine.
lead_paragraph: ATTENTION out-of-state students: don’t take that rental copy of “The Art of Public Speaking” home with you. Textbooks rented through Amazon’s “Warehouse Deals” are not to be carried over state lines. Renters will be charged the purchase price of any textbook that goes interstate, according to Amazon’s Textbook Rental Terms and Conditions.

headline: Looking for Intimacy in the Age of Facebook
abstract: A college course aimed at jolting students into face-to-Facebook confrontations — and expressing their emotions.
lead_paragraph: IT WAS the only time I have ever allowed college students to have their cellphones out during class, in their hands no less.

headline: Bulletproof Whiteboards
abstract: To hide behind, and write on.
lead_paragraph: THE University of Maryland Eastern Shore will introduce a security upgrade later this year: 200 bulletproof whiteboards for professors to hang in their classrooms and, if need be, hide behind. “We just wanted to add one more tool to help us ensure the safety of the campus community,” said Ernest Leatherbury, chief of campus police. “The whiteboards are user-friendly and noninvasive.”

headline: For Profit and People
abstract: At UniversityNow, adaptive learning and low tuition replace lecture halls and federal financial aid.
lead_paragraph: Imagine we could actually build a system of schools that … set up every single student who enrolled in it for success, unlike the schools we have today in higher education, where most students who enter it get no credential at all, most students that enter it are left with a mountain of student debt.  GENE WADE at TEDx San Francisco

headline: The Value in a Free Degree
abstract: Four years in, students are beginning to graduate from the world’s first free online university. What is their credential worth?
lead_paragraph: WHEN it opened in 2009 to some media fuss, University of the People was a free-culture concept in a competitive, proprietary universe. It charged no tuition and was open to anyone who could do the work. Professors volunteered their time. Now, four years later, the first students are reaching graduation, raising a question no R.O.I. calculator has yet sought to answer: What is a free online degree worth?

headline: Rewards for Showing Up
abstract: How to get overscheduled students to attend events on campus? Give them something.
lead_paragraph: HOW to get overscheduled students to show up at events? Frequent-shopper rewards.

headline: Move Over G.E.D.
abstract: An all-digital test faces two new competitors in the high school equivalency industry.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S something that New York State wants to clarify for those facing the “diploma or G.E.D.” box on job applications: General Educational Development is a brand name (like Kleenex and Xerox). That’s important because come Jan. 2 adults in New York and Indiana cannot take the G.E.D. They’ll sit for the Test Assessing Secondary Completion (TASC), from CTB/McGraw, while adults in nine states can take HiSET, the new E.T.S. High School Equivalency Test. After the G.E.D.’s 72-year reign, the splintering comes as a result of an ambitious agenda: the G.E.D. being unveiled in January will align with Common Core State Standards and be offered only on computer (in sync with federal digital literacy standards for adults). Rankled that the adult demographic had not yet been exposed to these new standards — and that their costs will double, to $120 a test taker — states asked other test makers to develop something. As for the new G.E.D., it is being positioned as more than just a high school endpoint. It will now indicate test takers’ levels of performance, with an honors category for those deemed at college or career readiness. Are you ready? Here are sample questions from the new tests, all of which assess math, science, social studies and language arts abilities.

headline: LinkedIn for Students
abstract: A new platform about career paths.
lead_paragraph: LINKEDIN has been skewing younger. It lowered its minimum user age from 18 to 14, and introduced University Pages in August. So far, more than 1,000 pages are being curated by universities. The centerpiece of each page is a school-specific data crunch of LinkedIn users who are students and alumni, including where they live and work. The school itself nearly always tops the “where they work” lists, apparently because of teaching assistants and work-study. The largest employer of Ivy Leaguers on LinkedIn, after the school, is Google. And McKinsey & Company apparently likes graduates of highly ranked business schools. A look at the University Pages of Businessweek’s top 10 schools shows the following companies employing the most alumni, or at least those who list the school and company on their LinkedIn profiles. (Numbers on LinkedIn frequently fluctuate.)

headline: Harvard-Size Ambitions
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'For-Profit Schools', 'E-Learning', 'International Study and Teaching']
abstract: Building a new global model from scratch.
lead_paragraph: THE ambition of the Minerva Schools at K.G.I., which calls itself the first elite American university to open in 100 years, is certainly not modest. The founder, Ben Nelson, a businessman with a longstanding armchair interest in education, aims to mount a stripped-down, low-cost challenge to Harvard.

headline: How to Get an A- in Organic Chemistry
abstract: A pre-med student conquers orgo, that most dreaded of courses, and discovers why the subject matters. It’s more than knowing how to draw arrows.
lead_paragraph: THE molecule looked like a giant jellyfish. Or maybe a spider. Halfway through my organic chemistry final, the monster lay there on the page, mocking me. My task: explain how the ungainly molecule folds into a tidy package. The problem: I had no clue. Maybe if I looked at it sideways? No, that didn’t help. This was getting ugly.

headline: Disability Studies: A New Normal
abstract: A progressive and empowering approach, for those able-bodied or not, that says: a disability is not a deficit that needs fixing.
lead_paragraph: THE temporarily able-bodied, or TABs. That’s what disability activists call those who are not physically or mentally impaired. And they like to remind them that disability is a porous state; anyone can enter or leave at any time. Live long enough and you will almost certainly enter it.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 1
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy, a century-old land dispute and a Halloween parade.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy, a century-old land dispute and a Halloween parade.

headline: 2 Shot Dead at Greek Site Used by Party on Far Right
abstract: Golden Dawn, the Greek neo-fascist party that is one of Europe’s most violent far-right groups, said the attack was politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Gunmen on a motorcycle killed two people and wounded a third on Friday evening outside the offices of the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party in a northern suburb of Athens, the police said, and the party called it a politically motivated attack.

headline: Adieu, Manhattan; Bonjour, Bushwick
abstract: A pioneer of the meatpacking district, Florent Morellet has moved to Bushwick to reinvent himself.
lead_paragraph: Beams of light and fog bathed Florent Morellet in the middle of a crowded dance floor. He cut through the shadows, a compact figure waving his sweat-drenched arms and grinning in an epiphany.

headline: Pop Quiz Answers
abstract: Answers to the Pop Quiz.

headline: Squeezing the Big City Into One Ring
abstract: Big Apple Circus’s “Luminocity” engages toddlers and jaded circusgoers alike.
lead_paragraph: A circus that can keep a rambunctious toddler rapt for two hours deserves special praise. But an even greater test of quality is whether it can entertain a jaded grown-up for just as long.

headline: Celebrating Pop That’s Just a Click Away
keywords: ['Web-Original Programming', 'Music', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The YouTube Music Awards, an online celebration of pop music and performers, will debut on Sunday, joining a crowded field of congratulatory broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: “Does there really need to be another awards show?” Spike Jonze recently wondered aloud. “If there’s going to be one, why?”

headline: A Surprise Ally for the Rich
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the front-runner among mayoral candidates, is often cast as a threat to the real estate industry, but he has won over some skeptics.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Leonard Steinberg, a leading broker at Douglas Elliman who has been responsible for more than $2 billion in residential real estate transactions, largely in downtown Manhattan, publishes something called The Luxury Letter. The report combines various listings — for $9 million duplexes in Chelsea, for a $44.9 million “loft mansion” in TriBeCa — with Mr. Steinberg’s insights on the high-end property market and the city more generally. Titled “Mayoral Issues: A Tale of Two Cities?” the October editor’s note recommended that the city’s presumptive next leader, Bill de Blasio, devise a “worst tenants” list, and cautioned those who criticize Michael R. Bloomberg that a mayor’s role is to be “effective C.E.O. of the city, not ‘best friend.’ ”

headline: The Parallel Lives of Princess Di, Princess Grace and the B.F.F. Actresses Playing Them in the Movies
abstract: Naomi Watts and Nicole Kidman are portraying the Princess of Wales and the Princess of Monaco, respectively, in a pair of upcoming biopics. Here’s how the four ladies’ stories stack up.
lead_paragraph: Two new films are coming out about the not-so-fairy-tale lives of Diana, Princess of Wales (played by Naomi Watts), and Grace, Princess of Monaco (Nicole Kidman). Both were universally adored before dying in mysterious auto accidents. Their biopics appear to be star vehicles for the B.F.F. actresses — and the chattering class is abuzz, because both movies are so tiara-twistingly bad as to inspire outrage and bewilderment. Are they propaganda campaigns to bring down parasitic Western monarchies as we know them? You be the judge.

headline: Climate Change Seen Posing Risk to Food Supplies
abstract: A leaked draft of a report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change said that climate change could reduce output and send prices higher in a period when global food demand is expected to soar.
lead_paragraph: Climate change will pose sharp risks to the world’s food supply in coming decades, potentially undermining crop production and driving up prices at a time when the demand for food is expected to soar, scientists have found.

headline: Twinkling Stars Look Back
abstract: Actors in the season’s releases name their own film favorites.
lead_paragraph: “'Christmas Vacation.’ My father looks like Chevy Chase, and my uncle drives an RV called ‘the love shack,’ so the story seemed oddly familiar.”

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A New Jersey farmhouse built with beams from an 18th-century barn and an 1878 Victorian in Nassau County with a pool house/cottage.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey farmhouse built with beams from an 18th-century barn and an 1878 Victorian in Nassau County with a pool house/cottage.

headline: Gift Books on Bridge for Players on Your List
abstract: The first in a five-part look at the best bridge books published this year.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season is fast approaching, and perhaps you have been wondering what books to buy for your bridge-playing friends. Over the next five columns, let’s look at the best that were published this year.

headline: Salt Licks and Other Civilization Engines
abstract: “Big History,” a new series on H2, examines underrecognized trends, values and movements that helped to propel great events and cultures.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever spent an afternoon at a racetrack and munched some salty popcorn or French fries while watching the ponies stampede past, you have been a witness to, and an eater of, history.

headline: Dick Cavett and Alec Baldwin Start the Conversation
abstract: Mr. Cavett and Mr. Baldwin had lunch with Philip Galanes and discussed talk shows, Richard Nixon, being chased by the paparazzi and dealing with depression.
lead_paragraph: The “21” Club was packed when Dick Cavett, the longtime television talk-show host and a regular contributor to the Opinionator blog for The New York Times, and Alec Baldwin, star of TV (“30 Rock”), film (“Blue Jasmine”), theater (“Orphans” on Broadway) and, most recently, his own talk show on MSNBC, “Up Late With Alec Baldwin,” arrived.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Philippines, Gaza, Russia and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Philippines, Gaza, Russia and Afghanistan.

headline: The Real-Life Stories Told in ‘Walk on the Wild Side’
abstract: Lou Reed memorialized the denizens of the Warhol Factory.
lead_paragraph: Snagged from among the thousands of condolences, recollections, posthumous mash notes and encomiums launched into the Twitter slipstream last week was a message from the actress Virginia Madsen to her 74,656 followers. Lou Reed was a “cool cat,” the award-winning indie star observed. What is more, Ms. Madsen wrote, the singer’s biggest hit and most famous lyric, “Walk on the Wild Side,” once served as “encouraging words for a young Virginia.”

headline: Furnishing Buyer Information to Condominium Boards
abstract: This week’s questions address the rights of condo boards to screen buyers; how sponsor apartments differ from others in co-ops; and a monumental proprietary lease mix-up.
lead_paragraph: Furnishing Condo Buyer Information

headline: Coming Soon
abstract: Select movies releasing this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Select movies releasing this holiday season.

headline: Lisa Kron: Life Through Gray-Tinted Glasses
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Theater', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Design', 'Art']
abstract: The playwright, who wrote the book for a musical depicting a family tug of war, possesses her own reminder of how complicated our stories can be.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you learn in painting class is how to do a gray scale, the spectrum from white to black: dove, mouse, elephant, battleship, charcoal. Why don’t they teach that in writing class? Drama loves conflict, but that doesn’t mean either side of a struggle is ever black or white.

headline: Holiday Movie Release Schedule
abstract: A listing of movies opening during the season.
lead_paragraph: November

headline: Seven Days of Style | Ines de la Fressange’s Design Debut, Paris Hilton’s Many Halloween Costumes and Karl Lagerfeld’s Kerfuffle With the P.C. Police
abstract: Plus, Jay Z’s first fragrance, Jeremy Scott’s new job, Terry Richardson’s replacement and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREOct. 26 – Nov. 1

headline: In the Keys, in the Air
abstract: An open cockpit in an antique airplane is a new way to see the Florida Keys.
lead_paragraph: The newest way to see the Florida Keys is from the open cockpit of an antique airplane. Overseas Aero Tours began flight-seeing tours last spring in a World War II- vintage biplane.

headline: Your Holiday Movie Match
abstract: A step-by-step guide to help filmgoers choose the best movie for them this season.
lead_paragraph: A step-by-step guide to help filmgoers choose the best movie for them this season.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: An Upper East Side one-bedroom; a Midtown East two-bedroom; and another two-bedroom in Boerum Hill.
lead_paragraph: An Upper East Side one-bedroom; a Midtown East two-bedroom; and another two-bedroom in Boerum Hill.

headline: Song and Script Taking One Space After Another
abstract: “Private Country,” an experimental hybrid of song, dance and text by Tatyana Tenenbaum, uses multiple spaces in the Chocolate Factory in Queens.
lead_paragraph: “Private Country,” a hybrid work choreographed, composed, written and directed by Tatyana Tenenbaum, creates a theatrical world of its own. But many features of the landscape are familiar.

headline: T’s Luxury Issue
abstract: In our latest issue, we explore the many definitions of luxury.
lead_paragraph: In our latest issue, we explore the many definitions of luxury. Our cover story features Saoirse Ronan, the Irish actress on the brink of adulthood who has upcoming films with Wes Anderson and Ryan Gosling and an Oscar nomination already under her belt. Countess Marina Cicogna — the 79-year-old Italian who is also an award-winning movie producer, photographer of the jet set and hostess of truly legendary parties — shows us that glamour has no age limit. We head to Tbilisi, Georgia, where a shiny new skyline is rising from centuries of architectural history. In China we meet Melvin Chua, the man who is connecting the world’s luxury brands with the world’s fastest-growing consumer market. In Milan, we visit one of the last truly Old World interiors firms, Studio Peregalli, and in Belgium designer Michael Verheyden shares the objects he creates, which are imbued with remarkable beauty and spiritual power. Finally, we check in with one of the greatest icons of luxury, Giorgio Armani, cataloging the reach of his multibillion-dollar empire and the pleasures of his sweet, sweet life.See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Plutocrats vs. Populists
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Pop-up plutocracy and the new populism are in conflict over the direction of America’s future.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — HERE’S the puzzle of America today: the plutocrats have never been richer, and their economic power continues to grow, but the populists, the wilder the better, are taking over. The rise of the political extremes is most evident, of course, in the domination of the Republican Party by the Tea Party and in the astonishing ability of this small group to shut down the American government. But the centrists are losing out in more genteel political battles on the left, too — that is the story of Bill de Blasio’s dark-horse surge to the mayoralty in New York, and of the Democratic president’s inability to push through his choice to run the Federal Reserve, Lawrence H. Summers.

headline: Egyptian Network Abruptly Suspends TV Satirist

headline: A Bad Reversal on the Texas Abortion Law
abstract: A federal appeals court has dealt a grievous blow to the reproductive health and rights of Texas women.
lead_paragraph: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has dealt a grievous blow to the reproductive health and rights of Texas women. On Thursday, the court allowed Texas, pending the court’s final resolution of the case, to enforce a provision in the state’s new abortion law that requires doctors who perform the procedure to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital. As a result, a third of the state’s 36 licensed abortion clinics have stopped providing abortions.

This was quite a turnabout, since he had essentially forced American troops to leave in 2011. Since then, the pressures in Iraq have grown, and Mr. Maliki bears much responsibility for the current turmoil.
