Robert Rheault, and six of his officers with murder and conspiracy on July 21, 1969, in the secret execution of a Vietnamese spy suspect, it caused consternation on both sides of the growing American divide over the war in Vietnam.

headline: Red Bulls’ Cahill a Soccer Globetrotter
abstract: Tim Cahill, a midfielder for the Red Bulls and Australia’s national team, might have been the most well-traveled player in the world in the past 16 months.
lead_paragraph: If things go according to plan, the peripatetic Tim Cahill will have only a few more soccer sojourns on his itinerary this year.

headline: How Trains Saved the Union
abstract: How the North moved thousands of troops thousands of miles in less than two weeks.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 20, 1863, Union Gen. William S. Rosecrans was defeated at the crucial battle of Chickamauga that left 16,000 men killed, wounded and captured, after which he retreated into Chattanooga, situated on the south bank of the Tennessee River. Confederate Gen. Braxton Bragg pursued him, taking possession of the heights of Missionary Ridge and Lookout Mountain, east and south of town. Rosecrans was trapped – the only main road out of town, along the river toward a railhead that linked Chattanooga with Nashville, was in range of Confederate artillery in the mountains. Rosecrans’s only good supply route was lost.

headline: After Long Careers, Hill and Kidd Are on Different Paths This Season
abstract: Grant Hill and Jason Kidd, longtime N.B.A. stars, have moved on this year: one to coaching and one to broadcasting.
lead_paragraph: Grant Hill celebrated his 41st birthday last month, and on that day he was on the Duke campus, appearing at an event to mark the 50th anniversary of black students attending the university.

headline: Nets Prevail, Showing Heat That Rivalry Has Two Sides
abstract: The Nets gained their first win over the Miami Heat after a 13-game losing streak against the team, and it improved their record to 1-1.
lead_paragraph: It is too early, perhaps, to assess how the Nets will fare against the Miami Heat as this N.B.A. season progresses. But within a so-called rivalry that has been so one-sided, so punishing, in recent years, it is probably never too early to start the emotional buildup.

headline: One-Month Checkup
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Success signing up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has been elusive for some and a dream come true for others. It often depends on geography.
lead_paragraph: Success signing up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has been elusive for some and a dream come true for others. It often depends on geography.

headline: Health Exchange: A One-Month Checkup
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Success signing up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has been elusive for some and a dream come true for others. It often depends on geography.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act’s goal of providing health insurance for all Americans grew more complicated when governors of more than 30 statesopted not to create their own health care exchanges. That left the federal government responsible for enrolling a much larger portion of the population than it had expected, which is at least part of the reason for the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov.

headline: Revisiting Case Amid Doubts on Evidence
abstract: After 18 years in prison, Sundhe Moses was paroled. His case is part of a broad investigation into Louis Scarcella, a retired detective suspected of using questionable tactics and evidence.
lead_paragraph: After 18 years in prison, Sundhe Moses was paroled. His case is part of a broad investigation into Louis Scarcella, a retired detective suspected of using questionable tactics and evidence.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) PROMISED LAND (2012) Matt Damon, above, plays a corporate predator and staunch defender of his company’s cause — fracking, the contentious drilling technique for natural gas — who arrives in a small farming town with the belief that he is offering local landowners a lifeline. Some, hearing the amounts being offered for drilling rights, are eager to sign up. But troubles arise when an old-timer (Hal Holbrook) starts asking questions about what fracking will do to the water supply, the livestock and the land itself. Then an environmental activist (John Krasinski) appears on the scene. The movie “has a point to make, and it does so in a way that is both honorable and disappointing,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, directed by Gus Van Sant and written by Mr. Damon and Mr. Krasinski. “It admirably tries to represent both sides of the fracking debate, even though its allegiance is clearly to the antifracking position. There is nothing wrong with such advocacy, except that in this case it means that the movie veers away from its strengths, ending in a welter of convenient (and dubious) plot twists and puffed-up speeches.”

headline: How the Pakistani Taliban Became a Deadly Force
abstract: Formally founded in 2007, a group traces its roots to cross-border radicalization spread by the Afghan Taliban and fighters from Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: Q. Who are the Pakistani Taliban?

headline: Education Life: The Disrupters
abstract: Pioneering online upstarts are trying to transform higher education with things like programs intended to make college more affordable and those that dispense with the credit hour and classroom time with a professor in favor of self-paced online learning,
lead_paragraph: When President Obama visited campuses recently to push to make college more affordable, he called on educators to think creatively. And he gave a shout-out to new competency-based programs at public universities, private institutions and profit-making colleges alike. The programs dispense with the credit hour and classrooom time with a professor in favor of self-paced online learning and assessments that measure what people can actually do.

headline: Defending Germany
abstract: Complaining about the wrong things.
lead_paragraph: OK, I’ve just written a couple of posts talking about the harm German policy is doing. But this is dumb and destructive:

headline: A Closer Look at Climate Panel’s Findings on Global Warming Impacts
abstract: An early look at draft findings coming in a big report on the impacts of climate change on humans and ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:02 p.m. | Justin Gillis has provided a look at the forthcoming report on climate change impacts, vulnerability and adaptation options from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, based on a leaked final draft (dated Oct. 28) that was posted on the blog of Donna Laframboise, a longtime critic of the panel. (You can also download it here.)

headline: 344,000 Minivans Recalled by Honda for Brake Problem
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Brakes', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The recall, like an earlier one in March, is to fix a problem in the vehicle’s computer that could result in unexpected braking.
lead_paragraph: Honda is recalling 344,000 of its 2007-8 Odyssey minivans because a malfunctioning computer could cause “heavy and unexpected braking without the driver pressing on the brake pedal and without illumination of the brake lamps,” the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: In Baseball’s Time Machine, 21st Century Belongs to the Red Sox
abstract: That the Red Sox have won three times as many championships as the Yankees over a decade seems implausible, unless one examines history.
lead_paragraph: If it were not bad enough that the Yankees missed the playoffs for only the second time since 1993, and if there were not enough agony with all the injuries and the losses and the Alex Rodriguez story leaving a sour taste for everyone, surely the final indignity came the night before Halloween when their archrivals became champions — again.

headline: The N.S.A.’s Evolution
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The National Security Agency was founded in 1952, and its surveillance capabilities were limited by legislation in 1978. But with the attacks of September 2001 came a new sense of urgency.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency was founded in 1952, and its surveillance capabilities were limited by legislation in 1978. But with the attacks of September 2001 came a new sense of urgency.

headline: Documents Show N.S.A. Efforts to Spy on Both Enemies and Allies
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Classified documents showing how the N.S.A. routinely spies on friends as well as foes.
lead_paragraph: Classified documents showing how the N.S.A. routinely spies on friends as well as foes.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic to Set Your Clock By
abstract: An acrostic you can set your clock by.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — A very timely puzzle this is, because we get to set our clocks back this Sunday and enjoy either an extra hour’s sleep or additional mayhem, depending on your lifestyle.

headline: Pace’s Influence Grows as His Playing Time on Jets’ Defense Declines
abstract: Calvin Pace, in his 11th season, has adapted to diminished playing time at outside linebacker while remaining a stabilizing force, a player Coach Rex Ryan likened to glue.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The wall outside the Jets’ locker room at their headquarters here is lined with the team’s historical numerical roster, and that was where Calvin Pace was pointing, discussing his football mortality, on a recent afternoon.

headline: No Morsel Too Minuscule for All-Consuming N.S.A.
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The National Security Agency finds itself under intense pressure after disclosures of spying on allies and rivals alike, but it defends the wide net it casts.
lead_paragraph: When Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, sat down with President Obama at the White House in April to discuss Syrian chemical weapons, Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and climate change, it was a cordial, routine exchange.

headline: With Saints, Affable Ryan Is Locked in a Big Easy Bear Hug
abstract: Rob Ryan, the Saints’ defensive coordinator, endears himself to New Orleans’ residents by being an everyman.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — On a recent night at Ms. Mae’s, a smoky, always-open bar in the Uptown section here at the corner of Magazine and Napoleon Streets, a woman with rollers in her hair feverishly danced alone to Robin Thicke’s “Blurred Lines” under a flag that read, “You’re in Saints country.” In the back of the bar, the air hockey, Foosball and pool tables went unattended, and the video poker machines, sandwiched by an ATM on one side and a Ms. Pac-Man game on the other, managed to lure only one patron.

headline: How Anna Chakvetadze, Rising Star at 20, Became a Retiree at 26
abstract: At age 26, a rising Russian tennis star was forced to deal with an unthinkable prospect — retirement — after a violent robbery and a crippling back injury.
lead_paragraph: As Russia faces Italy in the Fed Cup final without its top 11 players, Anna Chakvetadze will be watching and reminiscing. She represented her country eight times at the Fed Cup and helped Russia defeat Italy in the final six years ago.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Gather to Select Successor to Leader Killed in U.S. Drone Strike
abstract: Four candidates are thought to be in the running to succeed Hakimullah Mehsud, in an opaque process rived with tribal rivalry and personality-driven tensions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pakistani Taliban commanders met Saturday to choose a successor to Hakimullah Mehsud, their leader who was killed Friday in an American drone strike, as mainstream political leaders stepped up their criticism of the United States and vowed to press ahead with peace talks.

headline: At Los Angeles International Airport, Two Lives Collide in a Fatal Instant
abstract: As officials sought a motive for Paul A. Ciancia, charged in the death of a T.S.A. agent, it became clear that he was a drifter with a grudge against the government.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One was a troubled 23-year-old, with an assault rifle and an apparent grudge against the government, who witnesses said seemed to be hunting for airport security officials. The other was a 39-year-old father of two who for three years had been a screener of the torrent of passengers who move through the security lines at Los Angeles International Airport.

headline: Women’s Flexibility Is a Liability (in Yoga)
abstract: Those extreme yoga poses that feel like they’re pulling your hips out of the sockets? They might.
lead_paragraph: FROM my own practice and research, I know that yoga is generally a good thing. The bending, stretching and deep breathing can renew, calm, heal, strengthen, lift moods, lower the risk of heart disease, increase flexibility and balance, counter aging and improve sex. In short, the benefits are many and commonplace while the serious dangers tend to be few and comparatively rare.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 3
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not going anywhere. There’s plenty of work left to do.”

headline: Robots or Aliens as Parents? Colleges Gauge Applicants’ Creativity
abstract: More universities are including offbeat essay topics on students’ admissions applications to separate the highly creative from the highly ordinary.
lead_paragraph: As legions of high school seniors polish their college applications, plowing through predictable essay topics about their lives and goals, they might also run across something like this: “Tell us your favorite joke and try to explain the joke without ruining it.”

headline: Seeking Laughs in a New Place
abstract: The journalist Sami Shah satirized Pakistani politics. Then, facing security threats, he and his family moved to Australia, where he now uses stand-up comedy to help adapt to his new life.
lead_paragraph: The journalist Sami Shah satirized Pakistani politics. Then, facing security threats, he and his family moved to Australia, where he now uses stand-up comedy to help adapt to his new life.

headline: Honeywell’s David Cote, on Decisiveness as a 2-Edged Sword
abstract: “Your job as a leader is to be right at the end of the meeting,” says the Honeywell chairman and C.E.O., “not at the beginning.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  David Cote, chairman and chief executive of Honeywell, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Hopefuls in New York and New Jersey Pack Their Final Weekend
abstract: As Election Day nears, even frontrunners like Gov. Chris Christie and Bill de Blasio were out rallying voters to show up at the polls.
lead_paragraph: On a bright autumn day, the candidates for governor of New Jersey and mayor of New York City embraced the final days of their campaigns with rallies, bus tours and visits to diners, butcher shops — and the site of a planned garbage transfer station.

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: Combined print and e-book sales.
lead_paragraph: 1. Lean In by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell (Knopf). The chief operating officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.

headline: When Backstage Was No Big Deal
abstract: I met Lou Reed in the old days of rock ’n’ roll, when artists were accessible to fans.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE Lou I knew liked speed and cheap Scotch. Had short hair and wore weird shoes. Just as he could write something as harrowing as “Rock Minuet” or as tender as “Perfect Day,” he could also be frightening, the surliest of misanthropes, or the most gentle person imaginable.

headline: At Sears, Those Big Losses Get in the Way
abstract: Eight years into a merger, a retailer’s transformation is still a work in progress. Could a spin-off of a prized asset, Lands’ End, help?
lead_paragraph: “I’d like to go faster. I’d like to go bigger. We’re just not making money, which makes it much, much harder to fund the transformation.”

headline: Red Bulls Prepare for a Seasoned Rival
abstract: The Houston Dynamo, hosts in the opening game of an Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series, have reached the M.L.S. title game four times in seven years.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.J. — On their last trip to Texas, only two weeks ago, the Red Bulls’ game against the Houston Dynamo was over moments after it started.

headline: In New York Casino Vote, a Dance With Temptation
abstract: New Yorkers will vote Tuesday on whether to expand the number of casinos in the state by up to seven, a proposal that a Cornell economist calls a bad idea.
lead_paragraph: In the 48 states that permit at least some form of commercial gambling, lively debate continues over the industry’s relentless efforts to expand. On Tuesday, New Yorkers will vote on a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit up to seven new full-scale gambling casinos in the state. (The state’s five existing casinos are confined to Indian reservations.)

headline: Oden Has a Fragile Body but a Strengthened Spirit
abstract: The first overall pick by Portland in the 2007 draft, Greg Oden signed as a free agent for what feels like a last-chance comeback with the Miami Heat.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Never a man of many words, Greg Oden still has a few quick moves. On the eve of another season he was not physically ready for, he posted up his slender 7-foot frame for an interview in a corner of the Heat’s practice gym, took a few questions and spun his way through the door leading into the locker room.

headline: Keep the Gates of Paradise Open
abstract: Just because a city is impoverished doesn’t mean its people are not worthy of great art.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY made what can best be described as a personal pilgrimage to Florence, Italy, where I wanted to gaze once again on Lorenzo Ghiberti’s recently restored golden Baptistery doors, known as the Gates of Paradise, and remember how they changed my life.

headline: Japanese Civil Servant Runs Marathon for Fun, Not Profit
abstract: Some Japanese marathoners have broken away from their corporate teams to compete against the best in Chicago, London, New York and other races.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Japan has produced some of the world’s best marathon runners, yet few of them have made their mark in New York, largely because many of them run for corporate teams that have restrictive schedules.

headline: Virginia Governor’s Race
abstract: I.O.U.’s Give the Democrat a Significant Edge
lead_paragraph: I.O.U.’s Give the Democrat a Significant Edge

headline: The Dangers of a Stock Market Melt-Up
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Though a steadfast market bull, a strategist worries about investors’ nonchalant attitude toward ever-rising stocks.
lead_paragraph: Investors aren’t worrying much about the stock market, and that worries Edward Yardeni.

headline: Earning Less, but at Home
abstract: A technical consultant traded in his old job — and long air-travel commutes — for a new one that has meant 20 percent less pay but lets him work from home.

headline: A Goalkeeper’s Revenge: Stoke City’s Begovic Scores Goal
abstract: Stoke City goalkeeper Asmir Begovic scored a goal 12 seconds into the match on Saturday when the wind grabbed a clearing pass.
lead_paragraph: It is one thing to score a goal only 14 seconds into a game. But it is quite another when that goal scorer turns out to be a goalkeeper.

headline: I Want to Be Friends With Republicans
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: My prejudices against conservatives were just as uncompromising as the prejudices I’d often projected onto them.
lead_paragraph: The trouble started the night Jeff, one of the guys I drink and talk about God with, announced that he’d been summoned to court for the Zimmerman trial jury pool. We’d kept politics out of our Wednesday night meetings, which are held on my back porch, the six of us seated at an old dining room table propped next to my broken hot tub (Florida short-sale homes come standard with broken hot tubs). Instead of Bible Study, we call it our Tavern Ministry, and while we were often drunk halfway through, a churchlike decorum had always held sway. Once the case came up, though, decorum collapsed.

headline: In Praise of Art Forgeries
abstract: While forgery is an economic crime, it may not always be an artistic or aesthetic one.
lead_paragraph: IN Queens, a guy working in his garage churned out “Pollocks” and “Rothkos” that fooled the experts, sold for millions of dollars and helped destroy the Knoedler & Company gallery, as we learned in recent months. In China, thousands of artisans have forged the country’s artistic treasures, both ancient and modern, according to a report in The New York Times.

headline: Calling America: Hello? Hello? Hello? Hello?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Gun Control', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Once the envy of others, the U.S. is more likely to be scrutinized these days.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — HAVING lived and worked abroad for many years, I’m sensitive to the changing ways that foreigners look at America. Over the years, I’ve seen an America that was respected, hated, feared and loved. But traveling around China and Singapore last week, I was confronted repeatedly with an attitude toward America that I’ve never heard before: “What’s up with you guys?”

headline: A Bad Day to Die
keywords: ['Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Something evil, or just plain weird, was in the air back in 1963.
lead_paragraph: You probably know the scene in Stanley Kubrick’s “Dr. Strangelove”: Slim Pickens, playing the pilot of the B-52 that has been ordered to attack Russia by his bonkers commander, General Ripper, is reviewing the contents of the crew’s survival kit. It contains among other essential items $100 in gold, nylon stockings and “one issue of prophylactics.” At the end of the list he remarks, “Shoot, a fella could have a pretty good weekend in Vegas with all that stuff.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Obama’s Use of His Power
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Readers discuss the president’s style and accomplishments.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the president’s style and accomplishments.

headline: Pot and Jackpots
keywords: ['Casinos', 'Marijuana', 'Gambling', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: There’s a cultural revolution in America, and it isn’t about sex.
lead_paragraph: BASED on what stirs passions and wins headlines, it would be easy to imagine that the only cultural debates that matter in America are the ones that have to do with sex.

headline: The Tumbling Boundaries of Gay Rights
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: Conservative donors funding a new gay-rights project run by a group usually associated with Democrats? We’re not in Kansas anymore.
lead_paragraph: ELLIOTT MANAGEMENT’S lofty offices in Midtown Manhattan look north, south, east and west across the borough’s thicket of skyscrapers. But the most intriguing view I got during a visit there last week was of something else: the changed gay-rights landscape and its implications for the Republican Party.

headline: This Is Why We Need Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Colon and Colorectal Cancer']
abstract: Lost in the debate over website glitches and broken promises made by President Obama are people’s lives. Consider this 47-year-old Oregon truck driver.
lead_paragraph: THE biggest health care crisis in America right now is not the inexcusably messy rollout of Obamacare.

headline: Mark Rampolla
abstract: A coconut water mogul on Southeast Asia, surfboards and the composting debate.
lead_paragraph: As a Peace Corps volunteer in Latin America, Mark Rampolla developed a taste for coconut water and turned it into a food trend by founding Zico, a leading brand of coconut water.

headline: From Love Nests to Desire Surveillance
keywords: ['ADULTERY', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Tabloid editors charged with breaking the law to expose others’ intimate secrets are now having their own intimate secrets exposed in court.
lead_paragraph: I ASKED Mike Nichols, the director of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal” on Broadway, why love triangles have such a mythic hold on the imagination.

headline: Poverty in America Is Mainstream
abstract: Contrary to popular belief, the percentage of the population that directly encounters poverty is exceedingly high.
lead_paragraph: Few topics in American society have more myths and stereotypes surrounding them than poverty, misconceptions that distort both our politics and our domestic policy making.

headline: In the N.B.A., ZIP Code Matters
abstract: On average, black players are born in nicer neighborhoods than other black men.
lead_paragraph: AS the N.B.A. season gets under way, there is no doubt that the league’s best player is 6-foot-8 LeBron James, of the Miami Heat. Mr. James was born poor to a 16-year-old single mother in Akron, Ohio. The conventional wisdom is that his background is typical for an N.B.A. player. A majority of Americans, Google consumer survey data show, think that the N.B.A. is composed mostly of men like Mr. James. But it isn’t.

headline: ‘The Frackers’ and the Birth of an Energy Boom
abstract: A new book focuses on the half-dozen Texas and Oklahoma energy companies behind the surging growth of hydraulic fracturing for oil and gas in the last two decades.
lead_paragraph: One could argue that, except for the Internet, the most important technological advance of the last two decades has been hydraulic fracturing, widely known as fracking. Practically overnight, it seems, this drilling technique has produced so much oil and gas beneath American soil that we are at the brink of something once thought unattainable: true energy independence. And its repercussions, for geopolitics, the environment and other areas, are only now being grasped.

headline: That Dreadful Day in December
abstract: In Newtown, Conn., the suffering is made raw again as the anniversary of the shooting nears.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — “Every day in this first year is a very difficult journey,” said Mark Barden, whose 7-year-old son Daniel was one of the 20 schoolchildren slain last December here in the Sandy Hook shooting massacre. “And with the anniversary of the tragedy coming up, it seems to be getting more difficult.”

headline: Insurance Policies Not Worth Keeping
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Some plans with inadequate coverage policies will be canceled, but consumers will not be left out in the cold.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans have stoked consumer fears and confusion with charges that the health care reform law is causing insurers to cancel existing policies and will force many people to pay substantially higher premiums next year for coverage they don’t want. That, they say, violates President Obama’s pledge that if you like the insurance you have, you can keep it.

headline: The Aloha Spirit, for Everyone
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'State Legislatures', 'Editorials']
abstract: Hawaii is on the verge of allowing same-sex marriage, yet its path to equality hasn’t always been strewn with leis.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — Hawaii is on the brink of becoming the 15th state to allow same-sex couples to marry. The victory, once it comes, will have a special resonance. This is the state whose Supreme Court in 1993 first opened the door to marriage equality by declaring marriage a basic civil right, setting off a reactionary scramble that led to the federal Defense of Marriage Act, a legal bulwark against gay couples that the United States Supreme Court has partly demolished.

headline: A Victory Against Dark Money
abstract: California has imposed $16 million in penalties and fines in a case demonstrating the importance of state laws requiring the disclosure of political donations.
lead_paragraph: A group of wealthy donors wanted to give millions to two right-wing California political campaigns last year, but didn’t want anyone to know their identities. They came up with a scheme that any money-launderer would be proud of, funneling the cash through a convoluted series of independent spending groups that were allowed to collect unlimited dollars. By the time the donations had been used to buy advertising, the original money trail had been erased.

headline: States Take on Privacy
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'States (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: With Congress deadlocked, state legislatures have begun placing restrictions on the collection of personal data.
lead_paragraph: Tired of waiting for Congress to pass comprehensive privacy legislation, state lawmakers are taking matters into their own hands, and not a moment too soon. Legislatures across the country have enacted laws to regulate the kinds of information that companies and law enforcement agencies can collect about individuals and how it can be done.

headline: A Teenager’s Course, Altered by Motherhood
abstract: Daniel Harris said that after her mother was killed at their home in Queens, she knew that she had to be strong for her son, who was born two months later.
lead_paragraph: In the third trimester of her pregnancy, Daniel Harris, then 16, struggled to comfortably sleep through the night. So she was awake just after 4 a.m., when the sound of screaming became audible. She thought a next-door neighbor was responsible for the commotion, until her frightened younger sister went to her bedroom and a sick realization hit.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: So You Want to Play Pro Basketball
abstract: A look at the traits of basketball players.
lead_paragraph: A look at the traits of basketball players.

headline: Week 9: Saints (6-1) at Jets (4-4)
abstract: After hitting Cincinnati quarterback Andy Dalton only once last week, the Jets realize that generating a consistent pass rush against Drew Brees is not only a priority but an imperative.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Eloquent Empty Spaces
abstract: A photographer captures glimpses of cityscapes in their rare moments of emptiness.
lead_paragraph: A photographer captures glimpses of cityscapes in their rare moments of emptiness.

headline: Eloquent Empty Spaces
abstract: Obscure city corners at the golden hour.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I began photographing cities at twilight, I was attracted to outlying regions, places that seemed unloved and overlooked. More recently, I have been lured back to the central areas of cities, where economic turmoil has produced its own gaps in the urban facade.

headline: The Human Face of Our Health Care Mess
abstract: Readers comment on my Sunday column that aims to show why, in human terms, health care reform like Obamacare is so needed.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have been focusing on the messiness of the Obamacare rollout, and that’s perfectly legitimate. It has been very messy. Some liberals think they shouldn’t acknowledge the problems, because that just gives the critics more talking points. I disagree: The rollout has been a disaster, and President Obama was misleading when he said everyone could keep their existing insurance. Let’s not disguise the truth.

headline: In Touch With Nature, and With Rock ’n’ Roll
abstract: Chuck Leavell, 61, of the Mother Nature Network, also plays piano for the Rolling Stones. His office reflects his work with both the environment and his music — and his love of family.
lead_paragraph: WOODEN WONDERS My business partner, Joel Babbit, picked out the furniture, including the desk in my office. I was really pleased with his choice. Wood gives us so much, including beautiful furniture. And let’s not forget that wood is a renewable resource. The instrument that has given me so much joy and a great career, the piano, is also made of wood, as are so many other musical instruments.

headline: Boy, 9, Is Killed by S.U.V. in Brooklyn
abstract: Three other people were injured when a Ford Expedition jumped a curb at an intersection and plowed into a group of pedestrians.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old boy was killed and three other people were hurt when a sport utility vehicle jumped the curb at an intersection in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Filly Sustains Fatal Injury at Breeders’ Cup
abstract: Secret Compass fell during the Juvenile Fillies race and was euthanized after sustaining a lateral condylar fracture with dislocation.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — The second day of the Breeders’ Cup off to a tragic start when Secret Compass fell during the Juvenile Fillies race, dismounting her rider, John Velazquez. The filly sustained a lateral condylar fracture with dislocation and was euthanized.

headline: Sin and Unsinn
abstract: Germany does a bad, bad thing.
lead_paragraph: Continuing on my German theme: Matt O’Brien catches something that I’d missed — and it’s really, really bad. I’ve mentioned before that the European Commission’s estimates of the structural rate of unemployment in troubled economies are disastrously misleading. Its model (pdf) just isn’t designed to cope with sustained slumps that put some countries into near- or actual deflation, where the downward stickiness of nominal wages becomes a crucial issue. What the model does in such cases is interpret the failure of these countries to experience accelerating deflation as a rise in the structural rate of unemployment.

headline: If a Young Child Wanders, Technology Can Follow
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Children and Childhood', 'Smartphones', 'Mobile Applications', 'Global Positioning System', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: New devices for keeping tabs on small children use GPS, Wi-Fi and other location-tracking technology and can be linked to apps on a parent’s phone.
lead_paragraph: Most parents have experienced that feeling of fear when a young child wanders off at the playground or disappears during a trip to the supermarket. New technology, in the form of voice watches and miniature sensing devices, is aimed at thwarting such distress by keeping track of children who are too young to carry a smartphone.

headline: Fantasy Football: 2013 Matchup Analysis, Wide Receiver
abstract: This chart looks ahead to the rest of the season and indicates what kind of fantasy matchup a player will have.
lead_paragraph: This chart looks ahead to the rest of the season and indicates what kind of fantasy matchup a player will have.

headline: Riding the Hashtag in Social Media Marketing
abstract: Gary Vaynerchuk, a social media marketer, pounces on any trend — tweeted or otherwise — in his quest to sell, sell, sell.
lead_paragraph: About once a week, Gary Vaynerchuk posts a Twitter message that reads, “Is there anything I can do for you?” He means it literally. He is inviting his roughly one million followers to send requests for any kind of help or favor. And if you respond, he will try to punch you in the face.

headline: Social Media Animal for Hire
abstract: A day in the life of Gary Vaynerchuk, an entrepreneur whose energy seems endless.
lead_paragraph: A day in the life of Gary Vaynerchuk, an entrepreneur whose energy seems endless.

headline: Oarfish Offer Chance to Study an Elusive Animal Long Thought a Monster
abstract: Within five days, two oarfish were found in California last month, giving marine biologists a rare opportunity to study a lengthy and elusive big fish.
lead_paragraph: It was a big day for marine biologists: On Oct. 13, the body of an 18-foot oarfish was dragged from the water onto Santa Catalina Island off the California coast, presenting a rare opportunity for local scientists to study one of the world’s most elusive and awe-inspiring big fish.

headline: Two French Journalists Are Kidnapped and Killed by Gunmen in Mali
abstract: Two reporters for Radio France Internationale had been interviewing a leader with a separatist group in Mali’s unstable desert north. Their bodies were found with their throats slit.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Two French journalists were kidnapped and killed in northern Mali on Saturday, the French Foreign Ministry said, underscoring the continuing instability of a region retaken from fighters linked to Al Qaeda only eight months ago.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 3
abstract: Topics on this week’s talk shows include the technical problems with President Obama’s health care law, the scope of surveillance by the National Security Agency, and new demands by some Republican lawmakers for more information about the attack on an American mission in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: Technical problems that continue to complicate President Obama’s signature health care law and reports of high-level espionage on both enemies and allies have made for a tumultuous week in the White House. Also, some Republicans are threatening to block the administration’s nominees for federal posts until the survivors of the 2012 attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, appear before Congress. Supporters on both sides of each issue will hash it out on the Sunday news shows.

headline: France 1930, Germany 2013
abstract: Surprising parallels, none of them good.
lead_paragraph: Did France cause the Great Depression? It sounds a bit like a joke (Billy Crystal in Moscow, 1989: “I was raised thinking you were the enemy; you were raised thinking I was the enemy. We were both wrong: it’s the French”) But it’s the actual title of a very good paper by Doug Irwin, who points out that France, with its undervalued currency, soaked up a huge proportion of the world’s gold reserves in 1930-31, and suggests that France was responsible for about half the global deflation that took place over that period.

headline: Stolen Produce
abstract: In which Andy Kravis and Victor Barocas knock over the fruit cart.
lead_paragraph: Greetings all! I’m filling in for Deb for the day, which is just long enough to rave about this Sunday puzzle from Andy Kravis and Victor Barocas. Fair warning first: there are spoilers below.

headline: Little-Noticed Czech Team Snares a European Title
abstract: G-Team Novy Bor won the open section at the European Club Cup’s tournament despite its lack of big-name talent.
lead_paragraph: A Czech team with few top-ranked players on its roster was the surprise winner of the European Club Cup open division title last week in Rhodes, Greece.

headline: In Detroit, Mayor’s Race Is One Piece of a Puzzle
abstract: The mayoral race in Detroit is riddled with complications, among them the presence of an emergency manager running the city.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — If people along the streets of this city seem less than consumed by the prospect of choosing a new mayor on Tuesday, perhaps it is the barrage of distractions: the governor who has been testifying in a courthouse here about Detroit’s descent into bankruptcy; the appointed emergency manager who has brought in his own team to run City Hall; the long list of questions about the fate of this city’s artwork, its streetlights, its tens of thousands of empty buildings.

headline: I.O.U.’s Give the Democrat an Edge in Virginia
abstract: Democrats nationwide are reaching out to Terry McAuliffe, a former fund-raiser, with endorsements, strategic advice and, of course, an avalanche of money for his run for governor.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Their cheeks brushed as they whispered into each other’s ears, Bill Clinton and Terry McAuliffe, together again.

headline: As Bush Settles Into Dallas, Golf Tees and Family Time Now Trump Politics
abstract: Nearly five years after leaving office, former President George W. Bush lives a life of self-imposed exile in Texas, with new interests and few regrets.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — When the executive director of former President George W. Bush’s public policy institute decided to move on recently, he stopped by for an exit interview. Mr. Bush asked if he had anything in particular he wanted to talk about.

headline: Japanese Pitcher’s Winning Streak Ends at 30
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, 25, who has caught the eye of Major League Baseball teams as he compiled a 30-0 record dating to August 2012, was defeated in Game 6 of the Japan Series.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka finally lost. In what may have been his last start in Japan, the ace of the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles, who had not lost in more than a calendar year, dropped a game with his team on the verge of a championship.

headline: G.O.P. Pursues Hispanic Votes With Abortion Stance
abstract: Democrats, however, argue that the reputation of most Hispanics as socially conservative is inaccurate.
lead_paragraph: Following this summer’s divisive abortion debate in the State Legislature, Texas Republicans see an opening for the 2014 election as they work to reach out to Hispanic voters who could be spurred to the polls by the party’s anti-abortion stance.

headline: Twerking? Oh, Please. That Was Back in ’10.
abstract: Fun Fun Fun Fest in Austin is nothing like the Austin City Limits festival and doesn’t want to be, thank you.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, on a small side stage of Austin’s Fun Fun Fun Fest, the rapper Big Freedia introduced Austin to New Orleans “bounce music,” the hip-hop subgenre that prominently features what — thanks to Miley Cyrus’s performance at this year’s Video Music Awards ceremony — has since become known far and wide as twerking.

headline: Names Invoked on the Stump May Shift Votes
abstract: The key candidates in the lieutenant governor and attorney general races in Texas are all Republicans, so they don’t need to worry about appealing to swing voters.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: With or Without $2 Billion, Water Woes Unlikely to Go Away
abstract: Texas has a long way to go before solving its water deficit, though the passage of Proposition 6 would mean $2 billion for water infrastructure projects.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of Tuesday’s election, hundreds of thousands of Texans have already cast ballots on Proposition 6, which would amend the State Constitution so that $2 billion could be taken from the state’s savings account to help finance water infrastructure projects.

headline: Allan Block, Whose Sandal Shop Was Folk Music Hub, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Block helped popularize open-toed footwear, and his store in Greenwich Village drew musicians like Doc Watson and Bob Dylan during the 1950s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: Allan Block, a leather craftsman and fiddler who made sandals and music in his Greenwich Village shop — which became a bubbling hub of folk music during the 1950s and ’60s; a showcase for talented pickers and singers like Ramblin’ Jack Elliott, Doc Watson and Maria Muldaur; and a destination for aspiring musicians like John Sebastian and Bob Dylan — died on Oct. 23 at his home in Francestown, N.H. He was 90.

headline: College Football Around the Country
abstract: Teams, players and games that stood out in the tenth week of college football.
lead_paragraph: ANTHONY LACOSTE The Air Force back, right, ran for 263 yards, the second most in program history, and scored three touchdowns for the host Falcons, who ended a seven-game skid with a 42-28 win over Army, which had three scores from Angel Santiago.

headline: Bernard Goetz, Man in ’84 Subway Shooting, Faces Marijuana Charges
abstract: Bernard H. Goetz, who became notorious as the subway rider who shot four teenagers, was charged with trying to sell marijuana to an undercover police officer.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three decades after becoming notorious as the subway rider who shot four teenagers on a Manhattan train, Bernard H. Goetz found himself back in the news on Saturday, after being charged with trying to sell marijuana to an undercover police officer.

headline: Brothers Share Stage, but Rangers’ Stepan Steals It
abstract: Derek Stepan had a hat trick for the Rangers, while Marc Staal shared the ice with his brothers Jordan and Eric of the Hurricanes for the first time in an N.H.L. game.
lead_paragraph: Neither Jordan nor Eric Staal could recall a time when they and their brother Marc played an organized game together.

headline: A Mansion Without an Occupant
abstract: After 12 years as a backdrop for V.I.P. receptions and high-powered meetings, Gracie Mansion, home of New York’s mayors, is expecting a full-time resident.
lead_paragraph: After 12 years as a backdrop for V.I.P. receptions and high-powered meetings, Gracie Mansion, home of New York’s mayors, is expecting a full-time resident.

headline: New York Mayor’s Mansion Seeks a Missing Item (the Mayor)
abstract: Gracie Mansion hasn’t had a full-time resident in 12 years, but one of the candidates vying to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to move in in January.
lead_paragraph: John Quincy Adams slept there before he was president, and Louis-Philippe of France slept there before he was king — as did, at one time or another, Charlie Chaplin and Menachem Begin; also, Fiorello H. La Guardia and eight other mayors.

headline: Filly’s Death Overshadows a Triumph at the Breeders’ Cup
abstract: New Year’s Day stamped himself as an early Kentucky Derby favorite by winning in the Juvenile less than three hours after Secret Compass fell and was euthanized.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — A span of less than three hours at the Breeders’ Cup World Championships at Santa Anita Park on Saturday starkly illustrated the excruciating swings of emotion intrinsic to thoroughbred racing.

headline: Srdja Popovic, 76, Serbian Champion of Rights, Dies
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Mr. Popovic was a Serbian lawyer and celebrated human rights advocate who pressed for reform and free speech for five decades.
lead_paragraph: Srdja Popovic, a Serbian lawyer and celebrated human rights advocate who pressed for reform and free speech for five decades, first under Communist rule in the former Yugoslavia and later under the strongman Slobodan Milosevic and his successors, died on Tuesday in Belgrade. He was 76.

headline: Gérard de Villiers, 83, French Spy Writer, Dies
abstract: Mr. de Villiers was a French popular novelist whose long-running spy-thriller series, S.A.S., sold more than 100 million copies.
lead_paragraph: Gérard de Villiers, a French popular novelist whose raffish, long-running spy-thriller series, S.A.S., sold more than 100 million copies and became a kind of drop box for real-world secrets from intelligence agencies around the world, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 83.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 2, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Schumer Endorses Clinton for President in Iowa Speech
abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer’s endorsement adds to the  support among Democrats for a campaign bid by Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has not said whether she will run in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, used a speech to Iowa Democrats on Saturday night to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton for president, another indication of how quickly the party is coalescing behind the former secretary of state.

headline: Corrections: November 3, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 3, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mutai and Jeptoo Storm to Victories in New York Marathon
abstract: Follow our updates on Sunday for a live report of the 2013 New York City Marathon, mile by mile and stride by stride.
lead_paragraph: It was a day for the Kenyans at the New York City Marathon on Sunday: Geoffrey Mutai and Priscah Jeptoo won the men’s and women’s races. This is their country’s third sweep of the individual titles in this race.

headline: Stick Figures and Stunted Growth as Warring Syria Goes Hungry
abstract: Across Syria, a country that long prided itself on providing affordable food to its people, efforts to ensure basic sustenance appear to be failing, and millions are going hungry.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rana Obaid began her life less than two years ago in a comfortable house draped with roses, the daughter of a grocer locally famous for his rich homemade yogurt. But war and siege brought hunger so quickly to their town near Damascus that when she died in September, at 19 months, her arms and legs were as thin as broomsticks.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 1, 2013
abstract: This week, Joe discusses executive apologies.
lead_paragraph: When Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius apologized about the rollout of the Obamacare website this week, she joined a growing number of leaders in business and government who have decided that saying sorry was the smart choice in the face of some crisis or gaffe.

headline: Hard-Luck Horse Wins Breeders’ Cup Classic by a Nostril
abstract: Mucho Macho Man, a horse who has too often found himself just short of the winner’s circle, won the Breeders’ Cup in a race that was down to the wire.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — This is how championship races should be run — with fury and beauty and with the horses carrying not only jockeys on their backs, but hopes and dreams and stories. As Mucho Macho Man, Declaration of War and Will Take Charge pounded down the stretch of North America’s richest race, the people who had taken them here gritted teeth, pounded their programs and willed their horses to the finish line.

headline: Reeling From War, Afghan Society Ill-Equipped to Face Addiction
abstract: Afghanistan’s western border towns with Iran have become veritable zombie villages in recent years — encampments where entire families are shambling addicts.
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan’s western border towns with Iran have become veritable zombie villages in recent years — encampments where entire families are shambling addicts.

headline: That Other Big Afghan Crisis, the Growing Army of Addicts
abstract: A new report underscores a growing crisis in the city of Herat: one in every five households contains at least one drug user.
lead_paragraph: ISLAM QALA, Afghanistan — The addicts stalk the streets of this border post like hollowed-out skeletons, hair matted by filth and eyes glassy. The villages that hug the roads are veritable zombie towns, where families of men, women and children hide their addiction within barren mud compounds.

abstract: No. 3 Florida State overcame some early trouble by Jameis Winston, its star quarterback, and shut down the running game of No. 7 Miami.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The Florida State crowd, a Doak Campbell Stadium record of 84,409, decided it was going to be impatient, brush off the final month of the season, ignore unbeatens Oregon and Ohio State, and just declare what was on its mind.
