lead_paragraph: The small town of Kakunodate is the only place in the world where cherry bark ware, or kabazaiku, is still made.

headline: Samsung Ready to Slowly Lift Veil to Investors
abstract: The technology giant, known for playing its cards close to the vest, is holding only its second meeting of management with analysts.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Secrecy has served Samsung Electronics well. Keeping its rivals guessing has helped Samsung, the South Korean technology giant, build a formidable lead in the smartphone industry, where it now sells more than one in three handsets worldwide.

headline: London’s National Theater Celebrates 50 Years on Stage
abstract: London’s National Theater threw itself a 50th birthday party on Saturday, paying tribute to the storied past of what is arguably the most important address in the English-speaking stage.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — London’s National Theater threw itself a 50th birthday party on Saturday, paying tribute to the storied past of what is arguably the most important address in the English-speaking stage.

headline: Egyptians Following Right Path, Kerry Says
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In Cairo, Secretary of State John Kerry indicated that additional steps needed to be taken to establish an inclusive, civilian-led government.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In the highest-level American visit here since the Egyptian military removed the country’s first democratically elected president from power, Secretary of State John Kerry pressed Egyptian leaders on Sunday to stick to their “road map” for restoring democracy.

headline: Bangladesh Sentences 2 Expatriates to Death for War Crimes
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Capital Punishment', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Bangladesh’s war crimes tribunal on Sunday sentenced to death two expatriates, one now living in the United States, for crimes against humanity during the country’s 1971 war of independence from Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A war crimes tribunal in Bangladesh on Sunday sentenced two expatriates — one now living in the United States and the other in Britain — to death by hanging for the murder of 18 people described as prominent intellectuals, during the country’s 1971 war of independence from Pakistan.

headline: German Surpluses: This Time Is Different
abstract: It wasn’t always thus.
lead_paragraph: There’s a tendency, in discussing Germany’s position in world trade, to assume that massive surpluses have always been the German norm — that the country’s high-quality products have always fueled an export engine that inevitably sold much more abroad than Germans bought. But it’s not true. Here’s Germany’s current account balance as a percentage of GDP since 1980:

headline: Behind Autism and a Tantrum, a Break in a Child’s Routine
abstract: It took me a few minutes to figure out why a few minutes of shopping had brought my 4-year-old son to the point of a tantrum. Then he reminded me of how I had let him down.
lead_paragraph: The game plan was simple. My mother Brenda and I were on a shopping trip to buy clothes for Michael, my 4-year-old autistic son, and his 5-year-old sister, B.J., at the PX in West Point, N.Y. I figured 15 minutes, tops, from front door to checkout. Anything longer was courting trouble. I never took both children out unless I had a one-to-one adult-to-child ratio. Yet my mother had limited mobility. She had recently moved in with us after a serious illness. Two months later, my son was given his diagnosis, and since then I had felt torn between taking care of the children and giving my mother the time she needed.

headline: In Our Pages: November 4
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: 1913 German Scientist Lauds America’s Aigrette LawBERLIN — ‘‘In prohibiting the importation and wearing of the plumage of live birds, the American Government has enacted an epoch-making legislative measure!’’

headline: ‘To Those Influencing Environmental Policy But Opposed to Nuclear Power’
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Wastes', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: Four climate scientists press environmental organizations to embrace efforts to develop and deploy a new generation of nuclear power plants.
lead_paragraph: Four climate scientists, three of whom have published in peer-reviewed literature on energy issues (a sampler from Wigley, Hansen and Caldeira), are pressing the case for environmental groups to embrace the need for a new generation of nuclear power plants in a letter they distributed overnight to a variety of organizations and journalists.

headline: Disruptions: Under a New Chief, Yahoo Still Seeks Its Voice
abstract: It is not at all clear that the interface decisions Marissa Mayer has made as chief of Yahoo are paying off.
lead_paragraph: In Google’s early days, when employees were preparing to release a new project, they had to make a pilgrimage to see Marissa Mayer, employee No. 20, and the head of design and user interface. This was not fun.

headline: Bringing Golf to East Harlem’s Girls
abstract: East Harlem Pride is a team made up of girls from several public high schools in East Harlem, who though having little experience with golf, has started this season with a record of four wins, four losses and a tie.
lead_paragraph: It was on the first tee at the Mosholu Golf Course in the Bronx that Teddy Griffith introduced a group of teenage girls to golf.

headline: Driver Charged With Negligent Homicide in Death of Boy, 9
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A red Ford Expedition mounted the sidewalk in Brooklyn on Saturday not once, but twice, crashing into two other vehicles before plowing into pedestrians on the opposite curb.
lead_paragraph: The red Ford Expedition mounted the sidewalk along DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Saturday afternoon not once, but twice.

headline: First Winner Named in Madonna’s ‘Art for Freedom’ Project
abstract: Madonna and Vice established the prize in September to encourage visual and video artists, photographers and poets to create new works that focus on social justice.
lead_paragraph: Madonna announced on Sunday the first winner in the Art for Freedom online competition that she and Vice, the multimedia company, have established to encourage visual and video artists, photographers and poets to create works that focus on social justice. Madonna has also expanded her partnerships in the project to include the social website Tumblr.

headline: Jeptoo Wins in a Sprint From Behind
abstract: Buzunesh Deba and Tigist Tufa built a huge lead before Priscah Jeptoo ran them down, taking the lead around Mile 24 to win by 49 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Priscah Jeptoo of Kenya sprinted on the last leg to win the New York City Marathon women’s race on Sunday and take the World Marathon Majors series title.

headline: Mutai Bides His Time for a Repeat Victory
abstract: The Kenyan Geoffrey Mutai became the first man to win back-to-back New York Marathon titles in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Before the New York City Marathon started Sunday, Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya was the man to watch. He set the course record of 2 hours 5 minutes 6 seconds in 2011 and owned the unofficial world record, set in Boston the same year.

headline: Clemency for Snowden? U.S. Officials Say No
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The White House and two key members of Congress rejected Edward J. Snowden’s argument that he deserves clemency for his disclosures of classified documents because they provoked an important debate about the reach of American spying.
lead_paragraph: If Edward J. Snowden believes he deserves clemency for his disclosures of classified government documents because they provoked an important public debate about the reach of American spying, he has failed to sway the White House and at least two key members of Congress.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (BET) BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Black Girls Rock!, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the emotional development of young black women, joins forces with BET to pay tribute to role models in professional and public service. Tracee Ellis Ross and Regina King host this special, taped at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, honoring women in business, politics, entertainment, sports and community service, including Queen Latifah, Patti LaBelle, Venus Williams, Misty Copeland, Marian Wright Edelman and Ameena Matthews. Performers include Ledisi, foreground above, and Jennifer Hudson, Kelly Rowland, Janelle Monáe, Sevyn Streeter and Amber Riley.

headline: When the Sky Is No Limit
abstract: Julie Taymor takes on Shakespeare’s “Midsummer Night’s Dream” and inaugurates the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, the first proper home for the Theater for a New Audience.
lead_paragraph: There was no way that Julie Taymor was ever going to dream a little “Dream.” The director who redefined spectacle on Broadway for better (“The Lion King”) and for worse (“Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”) has now given New York a “Midsummer Night’s Dream” that doesn’t so much reach for the heavens as roll around in them, with joyous but calculated abandon.

headline: ‘Ender’s Game’ Is No. 1, With a Caveat
abstract: The film took in $28 million at North American theaters over the weekend, which might not be enough to sustain a franchise.
lead_paragraph: Summit Entertainment marketed “Ender’s Game” as “the motion picture event of the year,” but moviegoers — fresh off “Gravity” and looking ahead to “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” — apparently saw through that: “Ender’s Game” took in a so-so $28 million at North American theaters over the weekend, winning the box-office race but probably ending studio hopes of introducing a new film franchise. A Summit spokesman called the total “solid” and “in line with the studio’s preweekend expectations.”

headline: Are We Too Dependent on Apps?
abstract: A new academic book tries to understand how technology influences and affects the way younger people relate to each other and how the public nature of interactions shapes their view of the world around them.
lead_paragraph: How many times a day do you play a game on your phone, send messages through WhatsApp or Snapchat, post updates on Twitter and Facebook or upload a selfie to Instagram? A dozen? Two dozen?

headline: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’
abstract: Photos from Julie Taymor’s production for Theater for a New Audience.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Julie Taymor’s production for Theater for a New Audience.

headline: Djokovic Rallies Twice Against Ferrer to Win Paris Masters
abstract: Novak Djokovic defeated David Ferrer, 7-5, 7-5, to extend his winning streak to 17 matches since losing the United States Open final to Rafael Nadal.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The resilient autumn of Novak Djokovic was showcased in microcosmic form Sunday as he twice rallied to defeat David Ferrer, 7-5, 7-5, in the final of the BNP Paribas Masters.

headline: 4 Wheelchair Titles in 4 Top Marathons
abstract: Tatyana McFadden won the New York City Marathon, after capturing Boston, London and Chicago this year. She is the first person to win all four major marathons in a year.
lead_paragraph: Nothing could stop Tatyana McFadden’s race toward a milestone — not the headwind, not the concern about another searing rib injury, not the threat of another crippling flat tire and certainly not the other female wheelchair competitors Sunday in the New York City Marathon. McFadden sped past them all.

headline: Rand Paul Muses About ‘Dueling’ With His Accusers
abstract: Senator Rand Paul defended himself from accusations that he lifted wording for a speech from a Wikipedia entry, saying that if dueling were legal in his home state of Kentucky, the accusing journalists would receive a “duel challenge.”
lead_paragraph: In the 1800s, so many Kentuckians were killing one another in duels that the Legislature saw fit to require that incoming state officeholders swear an oath that they had not fought in a duel, issued a challenge for a duel or assisted at a duel, “so help me God.”

headline: China Strips Army Official of Position After Attack
abstract: Gen. Peng Yong, an army chief in Xinjiang, lost his post on a Communist Party governing body after what was described as a terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A senior military commander in China’s restive far west has been stripped of his position on a powerful Communist Party governing body after an attack in the nation’s capital last week that claimed five lives and deeply unnerved the Chinese leadership.

headline: The Changing Geography of Beggar-thy-Neighbor
abstract: Not about China anymore.

headline: Power Plants Try Burning Wood With Coal to Cut Carbon Emissions
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Coal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Adding waste wood from paper mills, furniture factories and logging operations has been used with varying levels of success.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the Environmental Protection Agency considers requiring existing coal-fired power plants to cut their carbon dioxide output, some utilities have started to use a decidedly low-tech additive that accomplishes that goal: wood.

headline: Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Seem
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Research', 'Consumer Protection', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: A study using DNA testing offers perhaps the most credible evidence to date of adulteration, contamination and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.
lead_paragraph: Americans spend an estimated $5 billion a year on unproven herbal supplements that promise everything from fighting off colds to curbing hot flashes and boosting memory. But now there is a new reason for supplement buyers to beware: DNA tests show that many pills labeled as healing herbs are little more than powdered rice and weeds.

headline: When Socrates Met Phaedrus: Eros in Philosophy
abstract: We know eros as the force behind physical passion, but in dialogue with rhetoric, it can drive us toward another sort of love — philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Crazy Hot

headline: Senate Vote on Workplace Bias Against Gays Poses a Test for the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Accused of being out of touch on social issues, Republicans face a question of gay rights at the federal level with the vote Monday to outlaw workplace discrimination against gay men, lesbians and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A major test of how carefully Republicans can navigate the intraparty politics of sexuality will come on Monday, when the Senate holds a crucial vote on a bill to outlaw workplace discrimination against gay men, lesbians and transgender people.

headline: The Difference Four Days Can Make
abstract: Television networks would prefer ratings that include those who view a recorded show up to seven days after it airs as opposed to the current standard of three days. On these shows, the extra days would result in a measure that boosted the audience by a million viewers, on average.
lead_paragraph: Television networks would prefer ratings that include those who view a recorded show up to seven days after it airs as opposed to the current standard of three days. On these shows, the extra days would result in a measure that boosted the audience by a million viewers, on average.

headline: Colorado Is Asking Taxpayers for $1 Billion to Help Schools
abstract: On Tuesday, Colorado will ask voters to raise taxes to fund one of the most ambitious and sweeping education overhauls in the country.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — In one poor school district in Colorado’s San Luis Valley, students take classes in a bus garage, using plastic sheeting to keep the diesel fumes at bay. In another, there is no more money to tutor young immigrants struggling to read. And just south of Denver, a district where one in four kindergartners is homeless has cut 10 staff positions and is bracing for another cull.

headline: Error-Free Jets Outrun Saints
abstract: A week after a humbling loss to the Bengals, the Jets ran for 198 yards, committed no turnovers and headed into the bye week with a 5-4 record.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It has been like this for the Jets every week for the last two months, whether on the banks of the Ohio River or in a dome in Atlanta or in a Boston suburb, so on Sunday, it had to be that way again: They walked into a stadium and, for three hours, transformed it into one of the most interesting places in town.

headline: Sharing a Heritage, a Home and a Way With Words
abstract: Eamon Morrissey performs in “Maeve’s House,” a one-man show about the writer Maeve Brennan at the Irish Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: The Celtic oral tradition merges with snapshots of old Manhattan — and old Dublin — in Eamon Morrissey’s engrossing one-man show “Maeve’s House,” at the Irish Arts Center. The woman of the title is Maeve Brennan, the Irish writer whose short stories and Talk of the Town items, often written under the nom de plume “the Long-Winded Lady,” filled pages at The New Yorker for about 30 years, beginning in 1949. Mr. Morrissey’s play recites passages from some of her work and recalls his family’s links with Brennan as well.

headline: Epic TV Series Aims to Celebrate China-Myanmar Ties
abstract: Work has finished on “The Dancing Girl From the Pyu Kingdom,” whose 40 episodes will begin airing next year.
lead_paragraph: The first-ever television series jointly produced by China and Myanmar — a 40-episode epic depicting the adventures of a ninth-century Burmese prince who travels to the Tang dynasty imperial court with his famed dancing troupe — has wrapped up filming and is scheduled for broadcast next year.

headline: Elections Today
abstract: Voters in New York and Connecticut will elect local officials, and New Jersey will choose a governor and members of the State Legislature.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday is Election Day, and voters across the region will elect local and state officials and will decide the fate of proposed constitutional amendments.

headline: Short Peeks Backstage at New York City Ballet
abstract: The web series “city.ballet.,” produced and conceived by the actress and City Ballet board member Sarah Jessica Parker, explores different facets of the company.
lead_paragraph: What does it really take to be a dancer in New York City Ballet? In “city.ballet.,” a new web series to be released on Monday by AOL On Originals, key ingredients are strength, grit, talent and perseverance. Having a life outside ballet is not a bad idea. And when all else fails, reach for the wine. After a recent performance of “Swan Lake,” the principal dancer Teresa Reichlen confesses, she “kind of had two dinners, half a bottle of wine and” — she adds with a sheepish smile — “a margarita, and that’s it. That’s it!”

headline: Camp Classic
abstract: A tribute to an extremely optimistic song, in my opinion, by John Lieb.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — The Monday through Thursday puzzles this week appeared last Saturday at the Arlington Puzzle Festival in Arlington, Va. A report on the 2012 festival is posted here and the 2013 results should be posted soon.

headline: Recovery on the Roads
abstract: Since losing a leg while serving in Afghanistan, Alfredo De Los Santos has become a national champion in the handcycle marathon.
lead_paragraph: Since losing a leg while serving in Afghanistan, Alfredo De Los Santos has become a national champion in the handcycle marathon.

headline: A Night of Revivals With Fokine, Tharp and Morris
abstract: Michel Fokine’s “Les Sylphides,” Twyla Tharp’s “Bach Partita” and Mark Morris’s “Gong” returned to American Ballet Theater’s repertory after long absences.
lead_paragraph: All three works shown on Friday by American Ballet Theater at the David H. Koch Theater were making welcome returns to the company’s repertory after too-long absences. All three were pure dance; they made marvelously diverse fare. The opener was Michel Fokine’s “Les Sylphides” (1909), which used to be a signature work for Ballet Theater through most of its first five decades; when Fokine staged it for this company in 1940, it was his final version of what was already a classic. This revival was followed on Friday by two ballets created for this troupe: Twyla Tharp’s “Bach Partita” (1983) and Mark Morris’s “Gong” (2001).

headline: A Veteran’s Path to Recovery by Marathon Racing
abstract: After losing a leg while serving in the Army in Afghanistan, Alfredo De Los Santos took up competing in marathons with a handcycle and finished second in New York.
lead_paragraph: A light mist covered the hilly roads by Alfredo De Los Santos’s neighborhood in Hopewell Junction, N.Y., last week. The streets of his tidy development were quiet and deserted, except for Freddie, as he likes to be called, whizzing along the rain-slicked road, intensely pumping his handcycle.

headline: Solemn Panorama of Battle
abstract: Joe Sacco’s latest book, “The Great War,” is a 24-foot-long panoramic pen-and-ink imagining of the first day of World War I’s bloody Battle of the Somme.
lead_paragraph: Graphic novelists tend to be a little neurotic and obsessive, but in that fraternity, Joe Sacco has long been regarded as an exception. For one thing, Mr. Sacco, whose new book, “The Great War,” comes out on Monday, is completely well adjusted. “Of all of us, he’s far and away the most normal,” his colleague Art Spiegelman said recently. Mr. Sacco laughed when told of this and said, “I’m not sure that’s a good thing or not.”

headline: Voices Raised for Peace, With Noh and Manga
abstract: “War Sum Up” was just the kind of thing that could get adventuresome opera lovers thinking and talking.
lead_paragraph: Looking for new frontiers in opera has become a full-time preoccupation for some observers, critics and fans alike. It’s disappointing, then, that “War Sum Up,” presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House as part of the Next Wave Festival on Friday night, had just two engagements. A stimulating multidisciplinary, pan-cultural creation mounted by the Danish arts laboratory Hotel Pro Forma, the show was just the kind of thing that could get adventuresome opera lovers thinking and talking.

headline: Tug of War Stretches Architect’s Legacy
abstract: In a New York homage to the Mexican architect Luis Barragán, the artist Jill Magid plays cat and mouse with the Swiss group that owns rights to his work.
lead_paragraph: When Luis Barragán, considered by many to be Mexico’s greatest architect, died in 1988, he left a scattering of gemlike private houses and public works around Mexico City and Guadalajara, his hometown. But an important part of his legacy — his professional archive and the copyright to designs and images of much of his work — ended up thousands of miles from his native land.

headline: Rebelling With Global Beats and WikiLeaks
abstract: M.I.A., the British singer-rapper, included a live message from Julian Assange, as well as pan-cultural tunes from her new album, “Matangi,” to Terminal 5 on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Not every dance party starts — as did M.I.A.’s show on Friday night at Terminal 5 — with a live video transmission from Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, urging a sold-out crowd to fight the “military occupation of cyberspace.” Mr. Assange called M.I.A. “the most courageous woman working in Western music” and “prescient.” He cited lyrics from “The Message,” a song M.I.A. released in 2010 with the lines “iPhone connected to the Internet/Connected to the Google/Connected to the government,” and added, “It turns out she was right.”

headline: A Spider-Man Caper Full of Broadway Characters, All of Them Real
abstract: Glen Berger’s new book looks at the making of the Spider-Man musical that seemed to be doomed on several fronts.
lead_paragraph: It’s unseemly to take pleasure in any creative failure. Artists strive and struggle all the time, and those who refuse to court the possibility of humiliation probably aren’t trying hard enough. If the sound of somebody’s well-intentioned work going splat makes you happy, perhaps you should seek worthier targets for your schadenfreude.

headline: Ex-Bassist for the Grateful Dead Strikes a Deal
abstract: Phil Lesh, the former Grateful Dead bassist, has agreed to a business arrangement with the theater owner Peter Shapiro.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — Phil Lesh has logged countless miles on the road as the bassist of the Grateful Dead and, since the late 1990s, in various post-Dead ensembles. But at 73, he is looking for a change.

headline: New Details Emerge About Tainted Gallery
abstract: A newly amended complaint against Knoedler & Company challenges declarations by that gallery, now shuttered, that it did everything possible to authenticate artworks.
lead_paragraph: The art forger Ken Perenyi remembers Anthony Masaccio as a practiced partner in the sale of fake paintings, a man with movie-star looks and the nickname Tony Cha Cha who mingled with models and artists in the back room of Andy Warhol’s hangout Max’s Kansas City during the 1970s.

headline: Art Found in Germany Linked to Nazi Looting
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Works by Matisse, Picasso and Chagall are said to be among a collection of 1,500 pieces of art found in Munich, according to BBC News and the German magazine Focus.
lead_paragraph: Works by Matisse, Picasso and Chagall are said to be among a collection of 1,500 pieces of art found in Munich, according to BBC News and the German magazine Focus. The works were reportedly confiscated by the Nazis during the 1930s and ’40s and, if confirmed as genuine, would be among the largest recoveries of looted art with a possible value over $1.3 billion. The stockpile was discovered by chance in 2011, when tax investigators obtained a warrant to search the home of Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of the art dealer Hildebrand Gurlitt. There are international warrants out for at least 200 pieces in the collection, which is being stored in a secured warehouse in Munich. It is unclear why the discovery was not publicly reported until now. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum estimates that the Nazis seized about 16,000 works of art in all, according to BBC News.

headline: Distance Swimmer Has a Book Deal
abstract: Diana Nyad, the 64-year-old whose quest to swim from Cuba to Florida captivated the world, has struck a deal to write a memoir.
lead_paragraph: Diana Nyad, the 64-year-old whose quest to swim from Cuba to Florida captivated the world, has struck a deal to write a memoir. Knopf, the publisher of Sheryl Sandberg, Alice Munro and Nathan Englander, acquired the memoir, calling it a book “about her life in and out of the water.” Jordan Pavlin, executive editor at Knopf, will edit the book.

headline: ABC Extends the Lives of Some New Sitcoms
abstract: ABC has announced the short-term fates of its remaining freshman comedies, with “The Goldbergs” and “Trophy Wife” both receiving full-season orders.
lead_paragraph: ABC has announced the short-term fates of its remaining freshman comedies, with “The Goldbergs” and “Trophy Wife” both receiving full-season orders. “Super Fun Night,” which stars Rebel Wilson, received an additional order of only four episodes, setting the show up to be replaced at some point later in the season. Another new comedy, “Back in the Game” starring James Caan, did not receive an additional episode order, leaving its future in doubt after its initial 13-episode order is completed. The vote of confidence for “Trophy Wife” was something of a surprise, considering its ratings have been the lowest out of the four shows through the early part of the season. The other three have been on fairly equal ground in terms of viewership, but none could be qualified as hits. “The Goldbergs” has averaged 6.1 million total viewers; “Super Fun Night” 6.4 million; “Back in the Game” 6.7 million; “Trophy Wife” has averaged 4.7 million.

headline: The Tallest, Richest Additions to the Skyline
abstract: Three residential buildings under construction in Manhattan are so tall that they will be instant landmarks. And apartments inside are selling for record amounts.
lead_paragraph: Three residential buildings under construction in Manhattan are so tall that they will be instant landmarks. And apartments inside are selling for record amounts.

headline: Amnesty Bill That Would Clear Ousted Premier Stirs Thai Anger
abstract: The bill, which could allow former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to return home, has attracted opposition even among government supporters.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The Thai government is facing growing anger among its own supporters as well as protests by an emboldened opposition over a far-reaching amnesty bill that could allow former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to return home by wiping clean corruption cases against him.

headline: Gift Books for Your Favorite Bridge Player
abstract: As we continue our look at bridge gift books published this year, we come to those for intermediate players looking to improve.
lead_paragraph: As we continue our look at bridge gift books published this year, we come to those for intermediate players looking to better their game.

abstract: Readers respond to articles about books and apps for babies.

abstract: Grassroots Leadership urges that people arrested crossing the border not be tried in criminal courts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Seeking More Pay for Delayed Play
abstract: With the pace of delayed television viewing increasing, networks want advertisers to pay for seven days of commercial viewing to cover computer screens and tablets as well as TV sets.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, faced with the growing popularity of digital video recorders, advertisers agreed to pay television networks for commercials viewed within three days of a show’s first broadcast.

abstract: A psychologist asks, When will we address the sexist bottom line?

abstract: A Boston provider says those who fault the program are doing a disservice to early education for poor children.

headline: Talk to Iran, It Works
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Based on talks in 2001, the outlines of a deal on Iran’s nuclear program and Western sanctions are clear.
lead_paragraph: There were high expectations after President Obama and Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, talked on the phone in late September. Those hoping for a diplomatic resolution to the nuclear standoff were excited that a breakthrough was imminent; meanwhile, some American allies, like Israel and Saudi Arabia, expressed deep skepticism over a potential American rapprochement with Iran.

headline: Start-Up to Offer Didion E-Books
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Beginning Monday, ZolaBooks.com alone will sell the e-book  of “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” as well as other digital books by Joan Didion.
lead_paragraph: The start-up Zola Books is trying to persuade book buyers to flock to its website, a hybrid that is designed to be a bookseller, curator and social-networking site all in one.

headline: New Leaders for Bucks County Playhouse
abstract: The theater in New Hope, Pa., has announced that Robyn Goodman will be the theater’s new executive producer and that Alexander Fraser will be the new producing director.
lead_paragraph: Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., has announced that Robyn Goodman will be the theater’s new executive producer and that Alexander Fraser will be the new producing director. They will assume their roles in January, after the departure of Jed Bernstein, who is set to become the next president of Lincoln Center. Ms. Goodman is the lead producer of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” on Broadway. She was also the producer of the Broadway runs of “Avenue Q” and “In the Heights.” Mr. Fraser’s recent credits include serving as an associate producer on the Chicago staging of “Kinky Boots” and the Broadway production of “The Normal Heart.”

headline: Doctor, First Tell Me What It Costs
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Avastin (Drug)']
abstract: Discussing money in the doctor’s office is good medicine.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — IF an antibiotic would cure your infection, your doctor would probably still warn you about the chance of sun sensitivity before prescribing the pill.

headline: Frank Wess, 91, Saxophonist and Flutist With the Basie Band, Dies
abstract: Mr. Wess was not the first flutist in jazz, but his deft flute solos enjoyed a prominent platform: the front row of the Basie ensemble.
lead_paragraph: Frank Wess, who helped popularize the flute as a jazz instrument in the 1950s and ’60s with the Count Basie Orchestra, where he was also a standout saxophone soloist, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Mexico's Soda Pop Ploy
abstract: If you think a tax on soft drinks will help fight obesity, think what a tax on corruption could do for our economy.
lead_paragraph: My first job out of college, in 1983, was working for Coca-Cola. The training, which lasted a month, was the same for everyone: all day in a truck, making deliveries, mostly to rural areas. We would leave before dawn and return as the sun was setting. We delivered soft drinks to churches and whorehouses. We went to places that didn’t appear on any map, where there were no roads beyond the tracks left by trucks like ours. We went where the government didn’t go, where there were no hospitals, no schools and sometimes even no running water.

headline: A New Publisher for Playbill
abstract: Bruce Hallett, former president of Time and Sports Illustrated, has joined Playbill Inc. as its publisher.
lead_paragraph: It seems as if Bruce Hallett will work only for magazines with instantly identifiable covers.

headline: Brands Align With the Mustachioed Month of Movember
keywords: ['Beards and Mustaches', 'Men and Boys', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: The Movember charity, a mash-up of mustache and November, raises money for men’s health issues. Brands like Just for Men are eagerly teaming with the organization.
lead_paragraph: IN November 2011, executives at Just for Men, the hair color brand, noticed an inexplicable surge in Canada for sales of its facial-hair line, Mustache & Beard. The brand had done no special advertising or promotion, and yet Canadian sales were up 30 percent over the month before, and up slightly in the United States as well.

headline: Sub-Elite Runners Chase Improvement
abstract: Greg Cass is part of a mostly invisible and underappreciated group known as the sub-elites, who have respectable times but no chance to win the biggest marathons.
lead_paragraph: Greg Cass crossed the finish line in 2 hours 36 minutes 33 seconds, his lifetime earnings from distance running holding steady at $75.

headline: Reflecting on a Dream, and Preparing to Move On
abstract: Mallory Hagan, the Miss America 2013 pageant winner from Brooklyn, discusses child sexual abuse, E.B. White and why she’s giving up New York for Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Let’s first get a few things out of the way, like any “there she is” clichés you may be entertaining, or smirking asides about how “world peace” must be her idea of deep thought.

headline: Ads Scant When Twitter Crosses Borders
abstract: Though three-quarters of its users are outside the United States, only a modest portion of its ad revenue is generated there. But it’s growing fast.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter.

headline: Walt Bellamy, Hall of Famer Traded by the Knicks, Dies at 74
abstract: Bellamy was a Hall of Fame center who was among the leading N.B.A. scorers and rebounders of his time, but he was overshadowed in his 14-year N.B.A. career by Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Russell.
lead_paragraph: Walt Bellamy, the Hall of Fame center who was among the leading N.B.A. scorers and rebounders of his time but who was remembered as well for being traded away by the Knicks for Dave DeBusschere in a final step toward their first championship season, died on Saturday. He was 74.

headline: In Rodriguez Arbitration, Two Sides Play Hardball
abstract: In the months since several players were linked to a Florida anti-aging clinic, Major League Baseball and Alex Rodriguez have engaged in a cloak-and-dagger struggle surpassing anything the sport has seen.
lead_paragraph: A trainer for Alex Rodriguez was shopping in Times Square with his wife and three young children one recent Saturday when he was followed into Toys “R” Us. A man working on behalf of Major League Baseball approached and handed him some paperwork. It was a subpoena to testify against Mr. Rodriguez.

headline: An Event for the Elite and the Average Alike
abstract: The New York City marathon gives everyday runners a chance to take the field with the best in their sport, a rare opportunity in athletics.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back. The New York City Marathon had to be canceled in 2012 after the killer storm Sandy invaded the region, and Sunday’s marathon was shadowed by the memory of shrapnel murderously exploding across Boylston Street in Boston last April. But back they came, the elite whippets near the front, the more standard human body types massed in the back — two races in one.

headline: The Appearance of Impartiality
abstract: A New York judge is accused of improperly steering cases and commenting out of court. What restrictions should be placed on judges?

lead_paragraph: One day after he threw 160 pitches in a complete-game loss in Game 6 of the Japan Series on Saturday, Masahiro Tanaka went back to the mound and threw 15 more pitches to get the save in Game 7.

headline: Lonely Advocate for Restraint in Egypt Tiptoes Around Talk of Compromise
abstract: With the country on war footing and security officials rallying a fight against Islamists, Ziad Bahaa el-Din, a cabinet minister, is in a precarious place, trying to coax the government toward moderation.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The news agency headline last week seemed harmless enough, perhaps even flattering. It paraphrased an Egyptian cabinet minister saying that his government and its opponent, the Muslim Brotherhood, should pursue “reconciliation.”

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Building (Construction)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Hard as it may be to believe, the price per square foot for luxury apartments in New York City is considerably less than it is for luxury elsewhere in the world.
lead_paragraph: Walking slowly to the windows facing the meadow of green that is Central Park, Gary Barnett slips into salesman mode as he spreads his arms wide, embracing the sweeping bird’s-eye view he has from the 87th floor of his shimmering skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Diverse Neighborhood Has Mixed Enthusiasm About New York City Mayor’s Race
abstract: At a restaurant in Sheepshead Bay, a mosaic of Russians, Irish, Italians and Jews, pessimism shared equal billing with optimism over the candidates for mayor.
lead_paragraph: The last presidential candidate Steve Waldman voted for was Hubert H. Humphrey. The last mayor he cast a ballot for was Edward I. Koch. And he’ll be darned if he is going to break his nonvoting streak by partaking in the mayoral election on Tuesday.

headline: Security Noticeable at First and Then a Blur
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Many New York City marathoners said they felt safe with the increase in police officers, metal detectors, checkpoints and cameras.
lead_paragraph: As the elite runners came down the final 150 yards of the New York City Marathon, and the finish line came into focus, the crowd on either side of them erupted in cheers, blowing horns, ringing bells and clapping inflatable sticks. They passed several police officers and four bomb-sniffing dogs sitting in the middle of the street and an officer wearing an N.Y.P.D. hat and wielding a video camera. Just beyond the finish line, to the side, were more officers and more dogs.

headline: Disney and Dish Wrangle Not Over Broadcast Fees, but the Future of TV
abstract: The protracted distribution negotiations under way between Dish Network and the Walt Disney Company are said to focus on digital rights like ad-skipping and online streaming.
lead_paragraph: A sweeping distribution deal between television giants, the Walt Disney Company and Dish Network, expired more than a month ago, and there is still no new deal in sight.

headline: Obama Campaigns for Terry McAuliffe
abstract: Ahead of Tuesday's election, President Obama campaigned in Arlington alongside Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of Tuesday's election, President Obama campaigned in Arlington alongside Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia.

headline: Breakneck Pace a Certainty in Duel Between Sixers and Warriors

headline: In Pakistan, Drone Strike Turns a Villain Into a Victim
abstract: Pakistan’s political leaders have reacted with unusual vehemence since missiles fired by American drones killed the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, Hakimullah Mehsud, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In life, Hakimullah Mehsud, the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, was Public Enemy No. 1: a ruthless figure who devoted his career to bloodshed and mayhem, whom Pakistani pundits occasionally accused of being a pawn of Indian, or even American, intelligence.

headline: Moving Moments Send Shivers, Both Good and Bad
abstract: Mucho Macho Man won the Breeders’ Cup World Championships title by a nose, but the day was also marked by a filly who broke her leg and was euthanized.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — There were awe-inspiring moments aplenty, like Magician moving like a John Deere tractor as he mowed down rivals in the lane of the Breeders’ Cup Turf to give European horses their fifth victory of these world championships. Or Wise Dan, the reigning horse of the year, showing why he should retain that title with a last-to-first rush in the Turf Mile that was as breathtaking as it was powerful.

headline: Both Sides Invoke Obama in Climax of Virginia Governor’s Race
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Voting and Voters']

headline: It’s the Golden Age of News
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Newspapers']
abstract: But not if you’re a freelance reporter being held captive in Syria.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past 20 years, to loud laments from media veterans, American news organizations have retreated from the costly business of foreign coverage — closing bureaus, slashing space and airtime. Yet for the curious reader with a sense of direction, this is a time of unprecedented bounty.

headline: Romney Sees Christie as Potential G.O.P. Savior in ’16
abstract: He appeared to contradict reports that the Romney campaign, when considering Chris Christie for the vice presidency, was concerned about his health.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney said on Sunday that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey could be the Republican nominee for president in 2016 and could “save our party,” comments that appeared to contradict reports that Mr. Romney’s presidential campaign had been concerned about Mr. Christie’s health.

headline: Those Depressing Germans
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: They are beggaring their neighbors, and the world, by running big trade surpluses.
lead_paragraph: German officials are furious at America, and not just because of the business about Angela Merkel’s cellphone. What has them enraged now is one (long) paragraph in a U.S. Treasury report on foreign economic and currency policies. In that paragraph Treasury argues that Germany’s huge surplus on current account — a broad measure of the trade balance — is harmful, creating “a deflationary bias for the euro area, as well as for the world economy.”

headline: Under Health Care Act, Millions Eligible for Free Policies
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Federal subsidies will pay the entire monthly cost of some plans being offered in the online marketplaces, a surprising figure that has not gotten much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people could qualify for federal subsidies that will pay the entire monthly cost of some health care plans being offered in the online marketplaces set up under President Obama’s health care law, a surprising figure that has not garnered much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.

headline: A Prayer in the Town Hall
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: When the Supreme Court revisits the blurry boundary between church and state it should ensure government neutrality toward all religions.
lead_paragraph: The wall between church and state is one of the most powerful and enduring images in American law, but as a metaphor it fails to capture the complicated and porous relationship most Americans have to the expression of religion in public life.

headline: Arrest of the Avalanche’s Goalie Casts a Shadow on a Promising Season
abstract: The Colorado Avalanche, who are off to an N.H.L.-best start, were jolted out of their reverie Wednesday by the arrest of goaltender Semyon Varlamov in connection with an assault on his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — During their drive to Pepsi Center, there was much shimmering ground for two Colorado Avalanche fans to cover: the poise and production of the team’s 18-year-old rookie forward, Nathan MacKinnon; the inspired play of the defense; the mad genius of the first-year coach, Patrick Roy. And yet, as Keith Martin and his son-in-law drove to the Avalanche’s game here Saturday night against the Montreal Canadiens, they spoke mostly of the dark cloud shadowing the team’s resurgence.

headline: Congress Can Help on Iran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: With positive noise from Tehran, this is not the time to impose new economic sanctions.
lead_paragraph: It is crucial that Congress work constructively with President Obama as he tries to lead the way in negotiating a nuclear agreement with Iran. But some lawmakers are so suspicious of Iran and so blindly committed to more sanctions that they could sabotage the best opportunity in years for a peaceful resolution of an issue that has long blocked any fundamental improvement in relations between the two countries while complicating the prospects for stability in the Middle East.

headline: Marijuana and Alcohol
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Law and Legislation', 'Youth', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Editorials']
abstract: Researchers point to a possible side benefit to the legalization of marijuana for medical use: reductions in heavy drinking by young people.
lead_paragraph: Americans are growing more comfortable with marijuana, with 58 percent favoring legalization, according to the latest Gallup poll. At the same time, some researchers believe they have identified a side benefit to increasing availability of the drug: It could lead to decreased consumption of alcohol among young people.

headline: Add a Dollar an Hour in New Jersey
abstract: The state should adopt a constitutional amendment that would provide relief for low-wage workers.
lead_paragraph: Ideally, Congress would raise the federal minimum wage above the paltry $7.25 an hour. But since there is little chance of that happening soon, it is up to the states to provide relief for low-wage workers. Nineteen states and the District of Columbia have so far increased the minimum wage above the federal level. Tuesday will be New Jersey’s chance to do the same.

headline: Outside Money at Issue in Boston Mayor’s Race as Labor Unions Weigh In
abstract: The first competitive race for mayor of Boston in three decades is coming down to the wire, and outside cash has poured into the race.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With Boston’s first competitive mayor’s race in three decades going down to the wire, John R. Connolly has seized on the issue of outside labor support for his opponent, Martin J. Walsh.

headline: To Shape Young Palestinians, Hamas Creates Its Own Textbooks
abstract: The Hamas movement is deviating from the approved Palestinian Authority curriculum, using the new texts as part of a broader push to infuse the next generation with its militant ideology.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — When a class of Palestinian ninth graders in Gaza recently discussed the deadly 1929 riots over access to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, it was guided by a new textbook, introduced this fall by the Islamist Hamas movement.

headline: SAC Nears an Insider Trading Guilty Plea, but Legal Cases Aren’t Shut
abstract: A plea deal for SAC Capital Advisors would resolve a criminal case involving insider trading charges, but the firm’s owner, Steven A. Cohen, would still face a civil lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The criminal case against the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors has reached a conclusion, people briefed on the matter said, with the government expected to announce Monday that SAC will plead guilty to insider trading charges and pay a fine of roughly $1.2 billion.

headline: End of Casino Partnership Leaves Fate of East Boston Racetrack in Doubt
abstract: Suffolk Downs, a famed but fading East Boston racetrack, is looking for a new partner in a competition for the area’s sole casino license.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Suffolk Downs, a famed but fading thoroughbred racetrack in the neighborhood of East Boston, had dreams of a major revitalization, and when the state approved casinos in 2011, it partnered with the Caesars Entertainment Corporation to apply for the sole casino license that would be awarded in the greater Boston area.

headline: Iran’s Top Leader and U.S. Counter Criticism of Talks
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Iran’s supreme leader rebuked his country’s hard-liners, and the chief American negotiator offered assurances to Israel in a television interview.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — With talks over Iran’s nuclear program set to resume in Geneva this week, both sides engaged in a bit of public diplomacy Sunday: Iran’s supreme leader moved to quiet hard-liners in his country by expressing support for his negotiating team, while the chief American negotiator reiterated in an Israeli television interview that “no deal is better than a bad deal.”

headline: Time Travel and Time Steps: Tapping Into Harlem History

lead_paragraph: The band takes the last bow in “After Midnight,” the sparkling new jazz revue that opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Sunday night. This may be unusual for Broadway, where the players are normally in the pit — and the music often sounds as if it could have been piped in from Hong Kong — but it’s entirely as it should be.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 4
keywords: ['BlackBerry (Handheld Device)', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The government will release its economic growth and jobs reports this week, and beginning Thursday, investors can buy a piece of the microblogging network, Twitter.
lead_paragraph: BLACKBERRY Shareholders of BlackBerry will learn on Monday if Fairfax Financial Holdings, which owns about 10 percent of the beleaguered smartphone maker, will transform a tentative offer for the company into a formal bid. Fairfax is conditionally offering $9 a share, valuing BlackBerry at about $4.7 billion, but it is unclear if it has raised enough money to make a firm offer. A group made up of BlackBerry’s co-founders, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, as well as Qualcomm, which makes the chips inside BlackBerry phones, and the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management may also make a bid as soon as Monday.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — There was nothing extraordinary about the casually dressed businessman waiting on a Paris train platform except, it turned out, for the envelopes he carried — stuffed with 350,000 euros in cash, and seized by French customs agents as he prepared to depart for Belgium.

headline: Saints’ High-Octane Offense Sputters

When the offense is in rhythm, the team scores a plethora of points, and opponents are left helpless.

headline: Referendum on Casinos Stirs Hopes in Tiny Town

headline: Tapping Medical Marijuana’s Potential
abstract: Despite growing acceptance of the drug, researchers have been able to relatively little to test its most promising ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana has been used medically, recreationally and spiritually for about 5,000 years. Known botanically as cannabis, it has been called a “crude drug”: marijuana contains more than 400 chemicals from 18 chemical families. More than 2,000 compounds are released when it is smoked, and as with tobacco, there are dangers in smoking it.

headline: Jets Close-Up
abstract: A quick look at key moments from the Jets’ win over the Saints.
lead_paragraph: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Trailing by 26-17 midway through the fourth quarter, New Orleans went for it on a fourth-and-inches at the Jets’ 36. The Saints, with all their offensive talent, handed the ball off to tight end Josh Hill on a misdirection play. Jets linebacker Quinton Coples thundered in and stopped Hill for an 8-yard loss. Coples said that he had not seen the play on film but that “you can’t be surprised by anything.”

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) LOU REED: ROCK AND ROLL HEART (1998) The director Timothy Greenfield-Sanders tours Mr. Reed’s career, from his days with the Velvet Underground and denizen of Warhol’s Factory to his solo work and collaboration with Robert Wilson. The film also touches on dark side of Mr. Reed, above, but “is careful to note that he has gone past all that,” Caryn James wrote in The New York Times about this “American Masters” presentation. “And though the documentary takes too much at face value, Mr. Reed himself sounds more sophisticated about how public image and reality bleed together. ‘I’m not remotely really like the Lou Reed character that I managed to make on record, although after a while I thought he was so cool that I thought it might be fun to be him, so I did,’ he says. He later points out that in the ’80s he married and started going to A.A. Having cleaned up his act no doubt certifies him as PBS ready.” Mr. Reed died at 71 on Oct. 27.

abstract: This first YouTube Music Awards was a show of essentially no consequence, but one that valued a theoretically equal playing field, risk taking, resilience in the face of failure and evanescence.
lead_paragraph: If you believe in awards, you believe in importance, in hierarchies, in arcs of triumph that take you from the bottom to the top. An award says you matter. An awards show is not only a celebration of excellence, but also of people who believe in the system.

headline: Take Me to the River
abstract: Trudging across concrete landscapes, the laundry Sherpas of Brooklyn carry their heavy loads in search of a place to do their wash.
lead_paragraph: In Erica McDonald’s imagination, normal folks doing their laundry become hardy trekkers hauling their cumbersome loads across a concrete plain looking for somewhere to clean their clothes. She sees them as victims of industrial prosperity, where a built-over landscape obliterates rivers and forces the sherpas on a search for man-made oases for washing. To carry out her vision, Ms. McDonald, a New York-based art and documentary photographer and founder of Develop Photo, an online photo educational resource, followed real-life strangers to and from the Laundromat — some quite a ways away.

headline: HSBC Profit Rises; Bank Is Cooperating With Foreign Exchange Inquiry
abstract: The bank said pretax profit rose to $5.1 billion in the three months ended Sept. 30 from $4.6 billion in the period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – HSBC, Britain’s biggest bank, said on Monday that third-quarter earnings rose 10 percent from the period a year earlier, helped by its cost-reduction program.

His last article for the magazine, about the processed-food industry, was adapted from his book, “Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us.”

headline: Changing Style in Hollywood
abstract: A Los Angeles gala shows that the ubiquitous strapless dress suddenly seems like a vulgar distortion of dressing up.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sting had Hollywood’s finest up on their feet and dancing when he performed at the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles on Saturday. But there was no pushy paparazzi or frenetic public cheering and flourishing cellphone cameras, as music, film and art stars from Mary J. Blige, through Jane Fonda and Jake Gyllenhaal, to the art dealers Larry Gagosian and Dasha Zhukova gathered at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art for its third annual fund-raising gala.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ryanair, the European budget airline, slashed its annual profit forecast for the second time in two months on Monday, reflecting the intensifying scramble for passengers among airlines, particularly in Western Europe, at a time of high unemployment and stalled economic growth.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 4, 2013

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Looks to Increase Ad Revenue Beyond U.S.
abstract: Although three-quarters of the social media company’s 232 million users are outside the United States, foreign markets represented only 26 percent of its third-quarter ad revenue.
lead_paragraph: From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter. The problem is, Twitter is still figuring out how to make money from those users abroad. The company received 26 percent of its total revenue from markets outside the United States in the third quarter, compared with around 17 percent at the end of last year, according to regulatory filings, Mark Scott reports.

headline: The War on Cancer: From Nixon Until Now
abstract: When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act many expected quick results, comparing the effort to the one that put man on the moon. After 42 years, what progress have we made?
lead_paragraph: When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act many expected quick results, comparing the effort to the one that put man on the moon. After 42 years, what progress have we made?

headline: Hopeful Glimmers in Long War on Cancer
abstract: A Retro Report and a medical writer reflect on the grand hopes and stuttering progress of Richard Nixon’s “war on cancer.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s Retro Report video examines the “war on cancer” — a federal research initiative authorized by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971. Many anticipated quick results, in part because of the public relations campaign, complete with ads suggesting we could cure cancer by the bicentennial, that successfully pushed Mr. Nixon into making the commitment.

headline: Hedge Funds Plan Proxy Battle for ValueVision Media

lead_paragraph: Two activist hedge funds, the Clinton Group and Cannell Capital, have joined forces to mount a proxy battle for control of the Internet and television shopping network ValueVision Media.

headline: New Options for Small Businesses Looking to Go Paperless
abstract: Three new tools designed to make it easier to manage a small business.
lead_paragraph: Academics predicted the rise of a paperless society decades ago. We’re not there yet, but at least on the small-business front, we’re getting closer. In fact, a host of new tools have arrived recently, including Shake, an app platform that allows users to create, sign and send legally binding agreements from their smartphones; Zipmark, a digital checkbook; and SimpleScan, a mobile scanner and document management system that integrates with cloud apps used by small businesses.

headline: Home Builders to Merge in $2.7 Billion Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Tri Pointe Homes, the West Coast builder controlled by Barry S. Sternlicht’s Starwood Capital, is merging with the home-building subsidiary of Weyerhaeuser, a large owner of timberlands.
lead_paragraph: Tri Pointe Homes, the West Coast builder controlled by Barry S. Sternlicht’s Starwood Capital, is merging with the home-building subsidiary of Weyerhaeuser, a large owner of timberlands, in a deal valued at $2.7 billion.

headline: What Will a New Army Chief Mean for Pakistan and the Neighborhood?
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The choice for the new army chief in Pakistan will affect the civil-military relations in the country and its relationship with India.
lead_paragraph: Since it was announced last month that Pakistan’s army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, would be retiring, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has kept the country dangling on his choice, creating a new parlor game for the chattering classes in the process. General Kayani has been characteristically mum, except for an unusual press release that said he was leaving the office on Nov. 29, without closing out other options, even as he accepted the concurrent role of chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

headline: In Providence, a Hipster Hotel in a Former Brothel
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Though it has a bookish name, the new lodging caters to more than the R.I.S.D. and Brown crowd.
lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time before Providence, R.I., long a petri dish for eggheads, design wunderkinds and culinary aspirants, would get its very own vintage-y, self-consciously cool hotel. The Dean, 52 rooms housed in a historic building from 1911 that was once a brothel, reflects the state’s bookish and somewhat gritty impulses toward homegrown authenticity. The lodging’s original mosaic tile flooring is intact, as is the old-timey brick facade, and rooms are furnished mostly with flea market finds. While the hotel’s name is an ode to the area’s academic community — it’s close to R.I.S.D. and Brown University — its arrival signals Providence’s continued cultural renaissance outside campus gates.

headline: In Poll, Many Chinese ‘Angry’ at Perceived U.S. Media Bias
abstract: The multiple-choice responses provided did not offer readers the chance to express support for commentaries that questioned the official Chinese view of events.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers might call it a leading question, one that would possibly be ruled out of order in a court of law: “How do you feel about the American media repeatedly putting out malicious views of China?”

headline: Report of Nazi-Looted Trove Puts Art World in an Uproar
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art']
abstract: The discovery in Munich of what are said to be artworks confiscated or banned by the Nazis has prompted criticism of why Germany did not disclose the find more than two years ago.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — There was no hint that the older man who called a couple of years back about selling a picture could be sitting on an unimaginable trove of art confiscated or banned by the Nazis. When the proffered work, “Lion Tamer” by the German artist Max Beckmann, was collected, the seller seemed to be a proper gentleman in Munich dispensing with a lone, dusty art gem at the end of his life.

headline: Militant Attack Kills Seven in Assam

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least seven members of the Rabha tribe were gunned down during Diwali celebrations in the northeastern state of Assam, killed by militants from a rival tribe, the state police said Monday.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:06 p.m. | OTTAWA — A tentative takeover bid for BlackBerry from its largest shareholder collapsed on Monday, clouding the immediate future of the company.

headline: Issue of Prayer Returns to the Court
abstract: As the question of legislative prayer goes to the Supreme Court, the litigants in a 1983 case — a state senator and a Presbyterian minister — differ about the role of religion in public life.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thirty years ago, a state senator and a Presbyterian minister faced off in the Supreme Court over whether the Nebraska Legislature could open its sessions with a prayer. The court said yes, siding with the minister, and for three decades that settled matters. Such prayers are commonplace.

headline: Violence Mars Election in Kosovo
abstract: The elections were seen as a test of an accord brokered by the European Union that aimed to overcome ethnic enmities in Kosovo and the region.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The future of a landmark power-sharing agreement between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in Kosovo was called into doubt on Monday after local elections in Kosovo over the weekend were blighted by violence and intimidation by people suspected of being Serbian hard-liners.

headline: A Tale of Two Fed Presidents
abstract: On not learning from experience.
lead_paragraph: Props to Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Richmond Fed, for admitting that he has been wrong so far about inflation. Indeed he has: Lacker has been warning about inflationary dangers for more than five years. Still, given the behavior of so many interest rate and inflation hawks in this Lesser Depression — the norm seems to be never even acknowledging the wrong predictions, or trying to rewrite what they said in the past — Lacker’s frank confession of error is refreshing.

headline: Reaction on the Streets and Online as Morsi Appears in Court

lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:38 p.m. | As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Mayy el-Sheikh report, Egypt’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, appeared in court on Monday to face charges of inciting the murder of protesters, his first public appearance since his removal from office in July.

keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Taxation']
abstract: A number of New Yorkers make a substantial portion of their income by renting out apartments on a short-term basis through the Airbnb website.
lead_paragraph: Tama Robertson is an artist who sells paintings and makes jewelry, but this being New York City, she also works in real estate. She has worked as an associate broker and invested in some properties of her own, but in recent years, she has supplemented her income with something a bit more contentious: She rents out a room in her own apartment to travelers she finds on the website Airbnb.

headline: Reports of a Positive Test in 2006 Call Rodriguez’s Words Into Question
abstract: Two people with knowledge of the situation confirmed the Yankees’ slugger was found to have used a banned substance.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez tested positive for a banned stimulant in 2006, the first year Major League Baseball tested for the substance, according to two people with knowledge of the drug testing results. The positive test raises questions about public statements Rodriguez has made in connection with the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: ScienceTake: The Contagious Yawn
abstract: People are not the only animals who yawn, or who catch yawns from each other; dogs and chimps even catch human yawns. It may have to do with empathy, which seems to have deep roots in evolution.
lead_paragraph: People are not the only animals who yawn, or who catch yawns from each other; dogs and chimps even catch human yawns. It may have to do with empathy, which seems to have deep roots in evolution.

lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — In his first meeting with Saudi Arabia’s ruling monarch since becoming secretary of state, John Kerry sought to reassure the king on Monday that the Obama administration and the Saudis shared common objectives on Syria, Iran and Egypt.

headline: Where Is Nadya of Pussy Riot?
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The leader of Pussy Riot has gone missing in the Russian prison system.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Soon after she arrived in a penal colony in Mordovia in late 2012, Nadezhda (Nadya) Tolokonnikova, the leader of the protest punk group Pussy Riot, asked for a copy of Anatoly Marchenko’s “My Testimony,” an exhaustive accounting of the life of Soviet political prisoners. Marchenko spent 15 of his 48 years in Soviet prisons, including a number in Mordovlag (an acronym for Mordovian camps), the part of the gulag where Tolokonnikova was serving her two-year sentence.

headline: Feeling For | Boys in the Hood
abstract: The season brings a fresh batch of parkas for men that are great for both après-ski socializing and wearing around town.
lead_paragraph: The season’s best men’s parkas are vibrant, sleek and meant to be worn on the slopes and off.

keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The government said its top intelligence agency had spied on diplomatic targets from countries including the United States, putting officials on the defensive.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s government acknowledged on Monday that its top intelligence agency had spied on diplomatic targets from countries including the United States, Iran and Russia, putting the Brazilian authorities in the uncomfortable position of defending their own surveillance practices after repeatedly criticizing American spying operations.

headline: Justices Decline an Appeal on Abortion

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court decided on Monday not to hear an appeal from a decision striking down an Oklahoma abortion law after all, dismissing as “improvidently granted” a case it had agreed to consider in June.

headline: Sting and Paul Simon Will Tour Together
abstract: They will perform individually and as a duo on a North American tour, from Feb. 8 through March 16.
lead_paragraph: In the continuing sitcom that is popular music — and also in real life — Sting and Paul Simon once lived in the same building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, they recalled in a recent telephone conversation.

headline: Teenagers Postpone Learning to Drive, and That’s Not Good
keywords: ['Drivers Education', 'Drivers Licenses', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Many parents and experts encourage teenagers to postpone driving lessons until they’re older. I disagree. The way new drivers get to be good drivers is by driving.
lead_paragraph: More and more teenagers are putting the brakes on driving.

headline: Gluten-Free Chocolate Buckwheat Biscotti
abstract: Buckwheat flour provides a great backdrop for the chocolate in these cookies.
lead_paragraph: These biscotti have a crumbly texture when they emerge from the first baking, so allow the logs to cool and cut them carefully, about 1/2 inch thick (if you cut them too thin they can fall apart). Buckwheat flour is a great backdrop for the chocolate; it doesn’t dominate but seems rather to show off the chocolate.

headline: Gluten-Free Raisin Pistachio Biscotti
abstract: Using a bit of butter results in a delicate cookie that is irresistible.
lead_paragraph: I use a mix of almond flour and either millet flour or cornmeal for these. They are irresistible. If you soak the raisins in amaretto before you make the biscotti there will be a slightly bitter edge to the flavor. As in other whole grain biscotti I use some butter here, which makes for a more delicate cookie, requiring a slightly thicker slice than a wheat flour cookie.

headline: Hazelnut, Orange and Honey Biscotti
abstract: A wonderful combination of flavors results in a cookie that tastes great when dipped in tea.
lead_paragraph: Orange, hazelnut and honey make a wonderful combination in this whole wheat biscotti. The hard cookies should be sliced thin, which will yield a lot of cookies! They are wonderful dipped in tea.

headline: Cornmeal Coconut Biscotti
abstract: Coconut oil provides great flavor a sweet smell to these cookies.
lead_paragraph: When I use a grainy flour like cornmeal I always include some fat in the biscotti, and this time I went with coconut oil, which contributes great flavor and a sweet perfume. Use fine or medium-grind cornmeal and make sure to use fine coconut flakes. I used organic sugar (not brown) for these; the sugar is off-white rather than white, and coarser than regular granulated sugar.

headline: Image of the Day: November 4
abstract: Cricketer Sachin Tendulkar at the entrance of the Eden Gardens cricket ground in Kolkata, West Bengal.

lead_paragraph: Nikolai Tsiskaridze, the flamboyant former Bolshoi Ballet star who hit the headlines when his disputes with company management were linked to the January acid attack on the company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, is once again in the spotlight.

headline: J.&J. to Pay $2.2 Billion in Risperdal Settlement
abstract: Federal officials said Johnson & Johnson promoted the antipsychotic drug as a way to treat dementia patients for many ailments, when it was only approved for schizophrenia.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay more than $2.2 billion in criminal and civil fines to settle accusations that it improperly promoted the antipsychotic drug Risperdal to older adults, children and people with developmental disabilities, the Justice Department said on Monday.

headline: High-Level Executive Switches to Carlyle From Warburg Pincus
abstract: Kewsong Lee, who had been at Warburg for more than two decades, will hold the new position of deputy chief investment officer for corporate private equity at Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group has hired Kewsong Lee away from his post as managing director at Warburg Pincus, an unusually high-level transition within private equity’s executive ranks.

headline: Weigh In on Twitter’s I.P.O. Value
abstract: With its new price range, Twitter is worth as much as $14 billion. A calculator offers a way for investors to decide if that is too high or just right.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is increasing the price for its upcoming initial public offering by as much as a third. The social network is now looking to raise $23 to $25 a share, according to a filing on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Lithuanian Opera Rounds Out Prototype Festival Lineup
abstract: Lina Lapelyte’s “Have a Good Day!” will make its American premiere at the festival in January.
lead_paragraph: The “Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now” festival of avant-garde chamber opera and musical theater has added one stage production — the American premiere of “Have a Good Day!” by the Lithuanian composer Lina Lapelyte — as well as two concerts to the schedule it announced in July. It has also set the dates for the individual productions.

headline: Casinos, Pot and the Quest For Consistency
abstract: How an (unwise) aversion to arbitrariness can drive rapid social change.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column on “pot and jackpots” — that is, the march toward marijuana legalization and the spread of casino gambling — tried to widen the usual culture-war frame to encompass not just bedroom-and-altar hot buttons, but the way the broader logic of “consenting adults” is working itself out in other areas of American life. One point I didn’t get to, though, is the extent to which both of these issues, pot and gambling, illustrate what one might call the rationalizing impulse in modern American politics, which seeks perfect fairness and consistency at the expense of compromises rooted in the accidents of history, and which makes it hard for conservatives to defend older, inherently-arbitrary arrangements even when they make practical sense.

headline: Rosie Huntington-Whiteley’s Jet-Set Chic
abstract: The actress looked casual and cozy at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The actress was travel-ready in a star-print cardigan, oversize shades and fedora at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday.
