lead_paragraph: The Frick Collection has appointed Xavier F. Salomon to be its chief curator, filling a spot left vacant by Colin B. Bailey who left in June to become director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Lowe Campbell Ewald said it would open an office in New York, and Deloitte bought substantially all of the assets of the Seattle digital and social media agency Banyan Branch.
lead_paragraph: AARP promoted three members of the AARP Media Sales management team, based in New York, to new posts. Mark Bradbury, director of insights and integrated marketing, becomes senior director of insights and integrated marketing. Shelagh Daly Miller, vice president for advertising, becomes vice president and group publisher. And Peter Zeuschner, Northeast sales manager, was promoted to digital sales manager.

headline: Iranians Rally Against U.S., 34 Years After Embassy Takeover
abstract: The former American Embassy in Tehran was the backdrop for a protest that bolstered hard-liners opposed to the Iranian president’s diplomacy efforts.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Thousands of Iranian demonstrators surrounded the former United States Embassy building in Tehran on Monday, in the largest anti-American rally in years, bolstering hard-liners who oppose attempts by the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, to establish relations with the Islamic republic’s archenemy.

headline: So, Travis Bickle Walked Into a Bar
abstract: Golden Cadillac, a new bar opening this week in the East Village, is bringing back the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade or so, mixologists have seemed to resurrect almost every significant drinking era in American history. Pre-Prohibition cocktails have been meticulously recreated. The aesthetic of the Prohibition-era speakeasy has been thoroughly explored. And “Mad Men” has inspired bars to plumb the hard-drinking days that followed World War II.

headline: On Gay Rights, Congress Lags
abstract: West Point hosted a same-sex marriage over the weekend. But Congress still hasn’t gotten it together to protect gays and lesbians from employment discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a study in contrast:

headline: LACMA Red Carpet
abstract: Looks from the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles red carpet, including Kate Hudson’s dress, with its barely-there breast pieces.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles red carpet, including Kate Hudson’s dress, with its barely-there breast pieces.

headline: Ads Celebrate Mozart in the City
abstract: A WQXR campaign aims to present the composer in an accessible, even quirky, light, while reminding New Yorkers that the radio station offers great programming.
lead_paragraph: Each year, November becomes Movember as men raise money to fight cancer by growing mustaches. This year, November is Movember for another reason, as a radio station and website known for classical music celebrate what they are declaring to be a “month of Mozart.”

headline: An Operatic Monster Mash
abstract: Experiments in Opera, a composer-driven initiative, opened its season with a post-Halloween program of short choral operas bathed in a ghoulish light at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: A mild-mannered bachelor tried to kiss a zombie on Saturday evening on the Lower East Side. He succumbed to her bite soon after. A group of medical students made earnest attempts to reanimate a corpse. Religious objects were desecrated. There was blood.

headline: Marathon Style
abstract: Runners in the New York City Marathon showed their style during the race.
lead_paragraph: Runners in the New York City Marathon showed their style during the race.

headline: Excerpt: 'Domesticated'
abstract: Laurie Metcalf and Jeff Goldblum in a scene from Bruce Norris's new play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Metcalf and Jeff Goldblum in a scene from Bruce Norris's new play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Johnson Overwhelms Texas Nascar Field
abstract: Jimmie Johnson claims the Nascar Sprint Cup points lead, and Sebastian Vettel dominates the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: Jimmie Johnson proved to be unbeatable Sunday in the 500-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Texas Motor Speedway. In the process, he moved into the points lead in the chase for the season championship.

headline: A Memorial for Marcella Hazan
abstract: The cooking teacher and author was remembered Sunday at a memorial dinner in New York, where she lived and taught for four decades.
lead_paragraph: Marcella Hazan, the cooking teacher and author whose works redefined Italian food for a generation of American cooks, was remembered Sunday by her friends and colleagues at a memorial dinner in New York, where she lived and taught for four decades. Mrs. Hazan died at 89 in Florida on Sept. 29. Friends and colleagues said at the dinner, which was at SD26 in Chelsea, Mrs. Hazan was remembered as a rigorous teacher, a fond mother, a brilliant and straightforward cook and a curmudgeon on culinary matters.

headline: Dismiss Diversification at Your Own Risk
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Financial Planners', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: This way of buffering the ups and downs of the stock market might not be trendy, but it’s tried and true.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

headline: A Key to Quantum Computing, Close to Home
keywords: ['Quantum Computing', 'Dyes and Dyestuffs', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Copper phthalocyanine, a blue dye found in many household items, could fill a critical need in the quest for a quantum computer, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: A blue dye found in many household items, including the British five-pound note, could fill an important need in the quest to develop a quantum computer, researchers say.

headline: No Heroism in Playing After a Head Injury
abstract: Hugo Lloris’s ability to persuade trainers that he could play after a blow to the head showed the flaws of the Premier League’s treatment of head injuries.
lead_paragraph: Manchester City once had a goalkeeper named Bert Trautmann. Trautmann, a German, spent his professional career in England and was known for his uncanny ability to save penalty kicks. His most famous moment, though, came when he helped City win the F.A. Cup at Wembley Stadium despite playing the final part of the game with a broken neck.

headline: Ali, Tyson and Captain Kirk: Coil Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: Among the offerings of the Coil Festival in January will be an imagined match between Muhammad Ali and Mike Tyson, and a video remix of Captain Kirk’s observations from the original “Star Trek” television series.
lead_paragraph: An imagined boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Mike Tyson and a video remix built of Capt. James T. Kirk’s observations from the original “Star Trek” television series are among the offerings in the 2014 edition of Performance Space 122’s ninth Coil Festival.

headline: Central Connecticut State University Ends Lockdown After Suspect’s Arrest
abstract: The school, in New Britain, directed all students to stay indoors for several hours Monday after a report of a man in fatigues with a gun and a sword.
lead_paragraph: The report on Monday afternoon was alarming: A man in a ski mask carrying a gun and a samurai sword had been seen walking on campus at Central Connecticut State University. That 911 call led officials to declare a campus emergency, direct everyone on campus to stay indoors for several hours and cancel classes.

headline: The Impact of the Settlement on SAC Capital and Cohen
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Insider Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: While the hedge fund has put the government’s criminal case behind it, Steven A. Cohen remains the focus of a criminal investigation and an S.E.C. administrative complaint.
lead_paragraph: The plea agreement between the Justice Department and SAC Capital Advisors that calls for the firm to pay almost $1.2 billion to resolve insider trading charges is carefully drafted to permit the government to continue its pursuit of Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund firm’s founder and owner. SAC has finally put the government’s criminal case behind it, but Mr. Cohen remains the focus of a continuing criminal investigation and an administrative complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Editorial Is Under Fire for Saying President ‘Clearly Misspoke’ on Health Care
abstract: The Times’s editorial page editor addresses reader complaints about a phrase.
lead_paragraph: A Times editorial on Sunday on the new health care law let President Obama off the hook with its too-soft choice of words, according to some readers who complained to me on Monday.

headline: Hepatitis C, a Silent Killer, Meets Its Match
abstract: New drugs are close to market that promise complete cures in more people, with shorter courses and fewer side effects. But they will not be cheap.
lead_paragraph: Determined to get rid of the hepatitis C infection that was slowly destroying his liver, Arthur Rubens tried one experimental treatment after another. None worked, and most brought side effects, like fever, insomnia, depression, anemia and a rash that “felt like your skin was on fire.”

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert Finds Inspiration Behind the Garden Gate
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Science and Technology', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: After the success of “Eat, Pray, Love,” Elizabeth Gilbert set off on a different path with her new novel, about a 19th-century botanist.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After the runaway success of “Eat, Pray, Love,” her 2006 memoir of divorce, spirituality and self-improvement, the writer Elizabeth Gilbert set off on an entirely different path. “The Signature of All Things,” her acclaimed new novel, is about — of all things — a fictional 19th-century botanist.

headline: New Hope on Hepatitis, Herbal Supplements Under Scrutiny, Eat, Pray, Botany
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health', 'Hepatitis', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies']
abstract: New drugs could change the way Hepatitis C is treated; think that’s St. John’s Wort you’re buying?; Elizabeth Gilbert talks about her new novel, “The Signature of All Things.”
lead_paragraph: New drugs could change the way Hepatitis C is treated; think that’s St. John’s Wort you’re buying?; Elizabeth Gilbert talks about her new novel, “The Signature of All Things.”

headline: Extra Cash and New Chief Buy BlackBerry Just a Bit More Time
abstract: Calling off an auction without a buyer in hand can leave a company in a precarious position, the author notes.
lead_paragraph: BlackBerry’s liquid infusion won’t douse its cash burn. The troubled company is selling $1 billion of convertible debt after attempts to find a buyer flopped. Even its big supporter, Fairfax Financial, has backed away from taking full control. The extra money and a new boss buy BlackBerry a bit more time. But its prospects are bleak.

headline: Far-Off Planets Like the Earth Dot the Galaxy
abstract: With the help of the Kepler spacecraft, astronomers calculate the number of habitable Earth-like planets in the Goldilocks zone — not too hot, not too cold.
lead_paragraph: The known odds of something — or someone — living far, far away from Earth improved beyond astronomers’ boldest dreams on Monday.

headline: Pakistani Party Votes to Block NATO Supply Lines if Drones Persist
abstract: The vote by the ruling party in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province was in response to a C.I.A. missile strike that killed a Pakistani Taliban leader Friday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The ruling party in a northwestern province of Pakistan voted Monday to block NATO supply lines by Nov. 20 unless the United States stops its drone strikes in the nearby tribal belt.

headline: Vaccine Approved for Brain Fever
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Encephalitis', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The World Health Organization has approved a vaccine for brain fever, also known as Japanese encephalitis, which kills up to 15,000 children a year and disables many more.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization has approved a new vaccine for a strain of encephalitis that kills thousands of children and leaves many survivors with permanent brain damage.

headline: Poisonous to Pets
abstract: In addition to chocolate, canine food risks include the artificial sweetener xylitol, macadamia nuts, onions, garlic, leeks and chives.
lead_paragraph: Q. I know chocolate is harmful to dogs. What else hurts pets but not people?

headline: Why a Pension Case Will Not Change Private Equity Tax Law
abstract: The head of the Private Equity Growth Capital Council defends the tax treatment of carried interest.
lead_paragraph: Steve Judge is president and chief executive of the Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

headline: Wall Street’s Marathoners Go the Extra Mile
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Marathon Running', 'New York City Marathon']
abstract: Amateur runners who work on Wall Street have to balance a training regimen against the demands of a job that can dominate their waking hours.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:14 p.m. |

headline: S.E.C. Clarifies That Crowdfunding Portals Will Be Able to Take Commissions
abstract: By at least one lawyer’s reading, the S.E.C. seemed to be shutting the door to portals earning big money.
lead_paragraph: Last week, in our post about the Securities and Exchange Commission’s proposed regulation for crowdfunding, we reported that the rules might make it harder for specialized crowdfunding portals to earn much of a living facilitating such deals.

headline: Medical Ethics Have Been Violated at Detention Sites, a New Report Says
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Doctors', 'Interrogations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Torture']
abstract: A group of experts in medicine, law and ethics accused the United States government of directing doctors and others to ignore their professional codes of ethics by abusing detainees.
lead_paragraph: A group of experts in medicine, law and ethics has issued a blistering report that accuses the United States government of directing doctors, nurses and psychologists, among others, to ignore their professional codes of ethics and participate in the abuse of detainees in Afghanistan, Iraq and Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Walkabout: A Flight Safety Video Set to Song; a Museum Dedicated to Show Biz
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Jazz Hands Virgin America’s new foot-stomping, musical flight-safety video is attracting lots of attention on the Internet (our In Transit post is here), but some remain unconvinced that all of the pizzazz will actually get passengers’ attention. (The Economist)

headline: Concerns About Jerky Pet Treats
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The F.D.A. has been investigating cases of suspected poisonings — 3,600 cases and 580 deaths, nearly all of dogs — associated with chicken and other jerky since 2007, with scant success.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, Jordan Smith offered her two dogs a Christmas treat: pieces of chicken jerky. Within hours, Eugene, a 14-year-old wire-haired pointing griffon, and Choppy White, a poodle of uncertain age, had diarrhea and were vomiting. A week later, Choppy White died of liver failure.

headline: Humpback Dolphin Clan Branches Out
abstract: New research confirmed that there are four distinct species of humpback dolphins, not two.
lead_paragraph: A group of humpback dolphins off the northern coast of Australia has been designated a separate species, previously unknown, following a genetic investigation by scientists with the Wildlife Conservation Society. Looking to prove that there were more than two species of humpback dolphin, researchers collected physical and genetic evidence from the animals around the world, eventually proving there were four distinct species. The Australian group has not yet been given a name.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 29 – Nov. 4, 2013
abstract: Election Day, a drone strike, a mysterious fish and more: Can you answer all ten questions correctly?
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Rethinking Medical Programs (2 Letters)
abstract: A letter to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: How to Shorten Commutes (1 Letter)
abstract: A letter to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Survival of the Extraordinary – A Fly With Tricky* Wings
abstract: An extraordinary fly in the United Arab Emirates has images of ants on its wings.
lead_paragraph: [Update, Nov.8, 8:00 p.m. | The wings on this fly are tricky, indeed. Read this great post by Morgan D. Jackson, an entomology grad student and photographer, to get a very nuanced and appropriately skeptical examination of such wing patterns: “Ants, Spiders, or Wishful Thinking?“]

headline: Maine Governor Candidate Says He Is Gay
abstract: Michael H. Michaud, now the seventh openly gay member of Congress, made the announcement in a newspaper column, asking, “But why should it matter?”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Michael H. Michaud, a Democrat who represents conservative, northern Maine in Congress and is a leading candidate for governor next year, announced in a newspaper column Monday that he is gay.

headline: Not-So-Herbal Supplements
abstract: A study using DNA testing offers perhaps the most credible evidence to date of adulteration, contamination and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.
lead_paragraph: A study using DNA testing offers perhaps the most credible evidence to date of adulteration, contamination and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.

headline: Bangladesh Takes Step to Increase Lowest Pay
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Factory owners said a proposed increase, nearly doubling wages, was too high, while labor leaders said it was not enough.
lead_paragraph: Criticized over unsafe conditions and low pay in its garment industry, Bangladesh took a first step to raise wages on Monday with a special government-appointed board voting to nearly double the minimum wage. Factory owners complained that the increase was too high, labor leaders that it was too low.

headline: Science on His Own Terms
abstract: In his autobiography, Gene Shinn recounts his life and research, driven among other things by a boundless curiosity and a sure hand at underwater demolition.
lead_paragraph: There is Big Science, defined as science that gets the big bucks. There is tried and true science, which, from an adventurous dissident’s point of view, is boldly going where others have gone before but extending the prevailing knowledge by a couple of decimal places (a safe approach for dissertation writers and grant seekers).

headline: More Like Her
abstract: Letter to the editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Netflix Acquires Streaming Rights to a Highly Praised Documentary
abstract: The service’s deal for “The Square,” about protests in Egypt, follows its strategy of extending its reach beyond television series.
lead_paragraph: Netflix said on Monday that starting early next year it will be the exclusive streaming distributor for “The Square,” an Arabic documentary about the Egyptian protest centered in Tahrir Square, which is considered a leading contender for an Oscar nomination.

headline: The Read Around: Nicholas Sparks
abstract: Nicholas Sparks, author of “The Longest Ride,” says elements like betrayal, loss and honesty are all needed to make a novel work.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Sparks, author of “The Longest Ride,” says elements like betrayal, loss and honesty are all needed to make a novel work.

headline: Finding the Higgs Leads to More Puzzles
abstract: As scientists try to reconcile the discovery of the Higgs boson with what they thought they knew, one theory suggests that a glitch in the Higgs field could end the universe as we know it.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of “The Tempest,” in what has been taken as Shakespeare’s farewell speech, the sorcerer Prospero breaks his staff and declares, “Our revels now are ended.” And he goes on:

headline: When Fuzzy Slippers Aren’t Enough
abstract: A bowl of thick, puréed vegetable soup can warm the body when the wind blows cold.
lead_paragraph: I eat soup all year long. But when the wind blows cold enough for me to unearth my fuzzy slippers, that’s when I really crave a bowl of thick, puréed vegetable soup.

headline: Yankees Offer One-Year Deals to Three Players
abstract: Curtis Granderson, Robinson Cano and Hiroki Kuroda were extended qualifying contract offers of $14.1 million by the Yankees on Monday. Each has until Nov. 11 to accept or reject the offer.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees extended one-year qualifying contract offers of $14.1 million to Curtis Granderson, Robinson Cano and Hiroki Kuroda on Monday, setting the stage for intrigue in the days ahead.

headline: The Texas Abortion Emergency
abstract: The Supreme Court lets a restrictive law stay in place.
lead_paragraph: Outside the chambers of federal appellate judges Priscilla Owen, Jennifer Elrod, and Catharina Haynes, virtually everyone understands that H.B. 2, the new Texas law that places various restrictions on a woman’s ability to obtain an abortion, is not about protecting women’s health — it’s about stopping abortion.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 1-3, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, Paul Ciancia, 23, walked into Los Angeles International Airport with a legally purchased .223-caliber assault rifle and five 30-round magazines and opened fire on a T.S.A. security checkpoint, killing 39-year-old Gerardo Hernandez, a father of two who had screened passengers there for three years, and wounding four others—two additional T.S.A. agents and two passengers. The rampage was halted when he was shot in the mouth and the leg by authorities. The next day, federal prosecutors charged him with murder.

headline: A Talent Whose Light Was Bright but Brief
abstract: “American Masters: Jimi Hendrix — Hear My Train a Comin’” is a documentary about the guitarist whose death in 1970 at the age of 27 cemented his legendary status.
lead_paragraph: For some in the dismayingly large club of rock stars who died too young, it’s easy to imagine an alternate future in which fate or bad judgment does not intervene and they live to a ripe old age. John Lennon becomes a patron of the arts and fends off repeated requests that he run for office. Cass Elliot does a stint on “The View.”

headline: Testing Supplements
abstract: Genetic testing of 44 herbal supplements from a dozen companies found that only two companies used completely authentic ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Genetic testing of 44 herbal supplements from a dozen companies found that only two companies used completely authentic ingredients.

headline: Raft of New Works Scheduled for Ecstatic Music Festival
abstract: The festival, which has become the alt-classical world’s main showcase, will offer 11 concerts, with new works by several young composers.
lead_paragraph: The Ecstatic Music Festival, which has quickly become the alt-classical world’s main showcase, will offer 11 concerts during its fourth season, which opens Jan. 31 and runs through March 29. As in past years, the concerts, which are assembled by the composer Judd Greenstein, are double or triple bills in which ensembles (many led by composers) perform separate sets and also join forces, either on new collaborative works or improvisations.

headline: The Read Around: Nicholas Sparks
abstract: Mr. Sparks discusses his work, including how he builds stories that will work for both page and screen.
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a new weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Nicholas Sparks talks about his novel “The Longest Ride” and how he approaches building a story that will work for both page and screen.

headline: Being a Working Mother Means Always Having to Say You’re Sorry
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours']
abstract: How often did you apologize to your boss, your friends or your family last week?
lead_paragraph: Sorry!

headline: Editor Did Not Agree to Phone Hacking, Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Andy Coulson, on trial with seven others in a scandal involving the tabloid The News of the World, does regret some of his decisions, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Andy Coulson, former editor of the tabloid The News of the World, now defunct, never agreed to any illegal phone hacking at the newspaper, his lawyer told the jury on Monday at the Old Bailey in the trial of Mr. Coulson; his former boss and onetime lover, Rebekah Brooks; and six others.

headline: Book About Amazon Is Reviewed on Amazon, by Founder’s Wife
abstract: In her lengthy review, MacKenzie Bezos took issue with “The Everything Store,” about Amazon and Jeff Bezos.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has yet to make a public peep about “The Everything Store,” a major biography of Mr. Bezos and his company that was published last month.

headline: Disabled Chinese Struggle for a Good Education, and Acceptance
abstract: Providing education for people with disabilities and integrating them into mainstream society is difficult in China, but many advocates say they have seen steady, if slow, progress.
lead_paragraph: Ni Zhen didn’t want to become a masseur, even though neighbors, educators and seemingly everyone else in his native Shandong Province urged him in that direction — because he is blind.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: A smattering of food links from near and far.
lead_paragraph: With cuts to SNAP, 76 million meals will be off the table for the poorest families in New York City alone. Related: A sobering piece by Ian Frazier in the New Yorker about homelessness in New York, which is higher than it’s been in decades.

headline: Supreme Court Takes Up Steelworkers’ Bid for Time to Put on Work Gear
abstract: In Sandifer v. United States Steel Corp., No. 12-417, questions about whether protective glasses, gloves and boots are clothing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which ordinarily confronts complicated questions, heard arguments on Monday about what might seem like a simple one: What does it mean to change clothes?

headline: Brahms to Ives to Knotty Swedish Consonants, a Mezzo Goes the Full Range
abstract: Fresh from two performances at the Met, the mezzo-soprano Jamie Barton inaugurated the Voce at Pace recital series at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts.
lead_paragraph: The superb mezzo-soprano Jamie Barton, quickly becoming known for the flood of sound she can unleash, began her recital on Sunday afternoon singing against type.

headline: A Science Project With Legs
keywords: ['ANTIBIOTICS', 'Chickens', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Are kosher or organic chickens healthier? One teenager found out.
lead_paragraph: The average teenage boy is likely to have an interest in chicken only when it hits his dinner plate.

headline: A Traitor to His Class? Such Good Fun
abstract: In “This Land Was Made for You and Me (but Mostly Me),” David Letterman and Bruce McCall conduct a satirical survey of how the superrich spend their money.
lead_paragraph: David Letterman is not only an author of “This Land Was Made for You and Me (but Mostly Me),” a new humor book he created with Bruce McCall. He is also a target of its pointed populist satire, and he knows it.

headline: Taking a Toll
abstract: The number of new infections and acute cases of hepatitis C has fallen sharply, but because many of those currently infected are baby boomers now middle-aged and older, long-term medical problems caused by the virus are expected to rise.
lead_paragraph: The number of new infections and acute cases of hepatitis C has fallen sharply, but because many of those currently infected are baby boomers now middle-aged and older, long-term medical problems caused by the virus are expected to rise.

headline: Defectors Land on Their Feet
abstract: Seven defectors from the National Ballet of Cuba have found jobs with American ballet companies since their arrival in the spring.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Cuba takes special measures to hold on to one of its most precious cultural resources: ballet dancers. To discourage defections, authorities sometimes keep talented performers from touring or warn younger artists that finding a ballet job will be tough in an unappreciative capitalist world.

headline: Don’t Start Up Your Tablet on the Runway Just Yet
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Flight Attendants', 'Handheld Computers', 'Electronics', 'Mobile Applications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: New federal guidelines on in-flight use of electronic devices will be adopted slowly and piecemeal, at first.
lead_paragraph: THE confusion light is on.

headline: Holidays Holding Hands
abstract: The convergence of Thanksgiving and the first day of Hanukkah offers options for an epic feast.
lead_paragraph: The expectations for our family’s holiday meals are usually as rigid as the compartments of a plastic prison plate. Any deviation, any scrambling of tradition (“Who put raisins in the cranberry sauce?” “You call this a latke? It looks more like matzo brei!”), is treated as heresy. The offending cook can expect hours of protest, and maybe a loss of skillet privileges.

headline: In Performance: Patrick Page
abstract: Patrick Page plays Rufus Buckley, the district attorney in the stage adaptation of John Grisham’s novel “A Time to Kill.” The show is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Page plays Rufus Buckley, the district attorney in the stage adaptation of John Grisham’s novel “A Time to Kill.” The show is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Fergus Henderson’s ‘The Complete Nose to Tail’ Cookbook
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a cookbook full of witty, beautifully executed food-related imagery.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: The Sounds of a Torn Region United in Many Languages
abstract: The early-music explorer Jordi Savall brought a survey of traditional Jewish, Christian and Muslim music from the Balkans to Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: At the end of “The Cycles of Life: A Musical Exploration of the Balkans,” conceived and presented by the Catalan early-music explorer Jordi Savall at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, five soloists sang five different songs at once. In five different languages.

headline: Using a Familiar Device to Dance Out of the Past, Page by Page
abstract: Boris Charmatz’s “Flip Book” uses photographs of Merce Cunningham’s choreography as material for new dances.
lead_paragraph: The device of using old dance photographs as material for new choreography goes back decades. Nineteenth-century photographs of people in motion by Eadweard Muybridge — pointing the way to flip-book continuity — have inspired several choreographers. Images of Isadora Duncan and Vaslav Nijinsky have entered into many dances.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Russia and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Russia and Indonesia.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Graywolf Press
abstract: An interview with Jeffrey Shotts and Fiona McCrae of Graywolf, publisher of Tracy K. Smith, Tomas Transtromer and more.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Jeffrey Shotts, Graywolf’s executive editor, with Fiona McCrae, the press’s director and publisher.

headline: CDs From Celine Dion and Midlake
abstract: A pop superstar sings with more rhythm and a prog-folkish indie-rock band pursues a messier sound.
lead_paragraph: CELINE DION

headline: A Roman Sculpture, a Study on Lying and a Disturbing F.D.A. Report
keywords: ['Rhinoceroses', 'Global Warming', 'Spices', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: This week brought news of an auction for a permit to shoot an endangered black rhinoceros, and a Food and Drug Administration report on contamination in imported spices.
lead_paragraph: There are only about 4,000 black rhinoceroses left in the world — at least until next year, when a high bidder gets a chance to shoot one. This week brought news of a controversial auction, plus an account of what the Food and Drug Administration found in imported spices.

headline: Playing the Game Again, With an Insider’s Look at the Players
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Double Down,” the follow-up to “Game Change,” looks inside the primaries and the presidential campaigns of President Obama and Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama’s performance in Denver in Debate No. 1 against Mitt Romney was widely perceived as something between a flop and a disaster: even supporters complained that the president seemed listless, passive, peevish, disdainful and distracted. The president and his aides promised a comeback in Debate No. 2 — suddenly a must-win showdown, needed to stop the bleeding, reassure the base and stem a migration of independents to Mr. Romney.

headline: A Force for Face-to-Face Communication
abstract: Clifford I. Nass, a professor of communication at Stanford University who died over the weekend, did pioneering work on multitasking and its impact on behavior and the brain.
lead_paragraph: Clifford I. Nass, a professor of communication at Stanford who died on Saturday, regaled me several times over the years about his method for torturing students in the undergraduate dorm hall where he was an adviser. He would make them communicate face to face.

headline: CNN Ratings Fall as Health Care Coverage Rises
keywords: ['Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'News and News Media', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: CNN fell to fifth place during the week, below Fox News and MSNBC, as well as HLN and CNBC.
lead_paragraph: CNN provided heavy coverage last week of the troubled introduction of the website tied to the Affordable Care Act. The result was the lowest weekly ratings for CNN in more than a year.

headline: Bartok’s Quartets Mixed With a Dose of Indie Rock
abstract: The Calder Quartet was joined by David Longstreth of the rock band Dirty Projectors, illuminating the links between the quartets and vocal music.
lead_paragraph: Bartok primarily wrote instrumental music, with a large catalog that features relatively few vocal selections. But his instrumental pieces owe a substantial debt to the voice, with inflections of his native Hungarian woven throughout works like his fourth string quartet.

headline: The Continued Taming of the N.F.L.
abstract: The N.F.L. has made several rule changes to try to limit injuries. William C. Rhoden wonders if the often violent onside kick could be the next play to be outlawed.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has made several rule changes to try to limit injuries. William C. Rhoden wonders if the often violent onside kick could be the next play to be outlawed.

abstract: DNA Bar Coding  is a technique for quickly analyzing short sequences of genes to identify plant or animal species.
lead_paragraph: DNA Bar Coding  is a technique for quickly analyzing short sequences of genes to identify plant or animal species.

lead_paragraph: William Dean Singleton, the co-founder and chairman of MediaNews Group, who over the years earned a reputation for extensive cost-cutting, will retire in December, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Hillary in 2016? Not So Fast
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Democrats can cheer and pundits can lay their bets, but it’s an awkward moment for political royalty like Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton of all people knows how political fortunes turn on a dime. But she must be puzzled nonetheless, and spooked, that over a six-month period when she made no big news whatsoever, her popularity took a double-digit tumble.

headline: Glamour Travel With Four Boys
abstract: John Besh is a chef and author who says culinary training is hard work, and so is traveling with children.
lead_paragraph: MY father was a pilot, and when I was a child we never had family vacation road trips. We got to fly, and I thought that was so cool. My parents insisted that I had to wear a suit jacket. That rule stuck, and I still wear a jacket when I travel.

headline: The Animated Life of A. R. Wallace
abstract: This paper-puppet animation celebrates the life of Alfred Russel Wallace, who is co-credited with Charles Darwin for the theory of natural selection.
lead_paragraph: This paper-puppet animation celebrates the life of Alfred Russel Wallace, who is co-credited with Charles Darwin for the theory of natural selection.

headline: Secrets of a Game Show Writer
abstract: At “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,” one of the biggest challenges was to continually come up with new material.
lead_paragraph: The word “only,” an adverb that portends disappointment for the hopeful theatergoer (“standing room only”) and an adjective that mocks the sibling-deprived (“only child”), is a trivia writer’s best friend. Shortly before he died, Dr. Seuss confessed that “Green Eggs and Ham” was “the only book I ever wrote that still makes me laugh.” The actor Bruce Dern, after appearing alongside the Duke in the 1972 western “The Cowboys,” correctly boasted that he was “the only actor who ever killed John Wayne.”

headline: Crist, Former Florida Governor, Tosses Hat in Ring Again
abstract: Charlie Crist, a former Republican who was Florida’s governor from 2007 to 2011, formally announced that he would run for the job again, this time as a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG — Hopscotching from one Democratic touchstone to the next — education, voting rights, the environment and bipartisanship — former Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida announced Monday that he would run for the job once again, this time as a Democrat.

headline: ‘The Animated Life of A.R. Wallace’
abstract: A short film celebrates Alfred Russel Wallace, who is co-credited with discovering the theory of natural selection.
lead_paragraph: Although Alfred Russel Wallace made one of the most important scientific discoveries in history, he’s been all but forgotten. A contemporary of Charles Darwin, Wallace was the other guy to discover natural selection – the evolutionary process whereby better adapted organisms are more likely to survive and pass on their traits than less adapted ones. Although two people discovered this theory, evolution by natural selection is virtually synonymous with Darwin. This is partly due to the lasting fame of Darwin’s opus, “On the Origin of Species,” but some argue it is also due to Wallace’s extraordinary modesty – he lauded Darwin’s work and humbly downplayed his own contributions. In 1889 he even wrote a book in support of evolution titled “Darwinism.”

headline: No Riders Killed in First 5 Months of New York City Bike-Share Program
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration says the increase in bike ridership has heightened drivers’ awareness of cyclists and affected their behavior.
lead_paragraph: To many, the ingredients for New York City’s bike-share program suggested a sort of sadistic alchemy.

headline: With Cows in Mind, Swiss Farmers Wage Litter Battle
keywords: ['Livestock', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Rural Areas', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: A traditionally tidy nation is being alerted to the danger, sometimes fatal, that refuse poses to livestock.
lead_paragraph: SOLOTHURN, Switzerland — Before he mows the hay he feeds his dairy cows, Hansueli Wyss performs a new ritual: He scours the fields of his 65-acre farm amid the rolling hills of this farming region, dotted with steep-roofed homes like his 150-year-old farmhouse, for junk — empty bottles and soda or beer cans, hamburger cartons, and much else.

headline: Turning On iTunes Menus
abstract: Windows 8 makes the iTunes menu bar optional, but a user can easily call it up.
lead_paragraph: Turning On

headline: De Blasio Seeks Mandate as Lhota Hopes for Upset
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate for New York City mayor, says a big victory over Joseph J. Lhota could help him put his liberal agenda into effect.
lead_paragraph: Concerned that his overwhelming lead in the race to be New York mayor could depress voter turnout, Bill de Blasio on Monday warned supporters against complacency as he sought to win with a decisive mandate that could propel his liberal agenda.

headline: Ukraine: Workers Removing Parts of Chernobyl Plant
abstract: Workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine have begun dismantling a ventilation stack that has filtered radioactive gases from the reactor that was destroyed in an accident in 1986.
lead_paragraph: Workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine have begun dismantling a ventilation stack that has filtered radioactive gases from the reactor that was destroyed in an accident in 1986. The first section, weighing 33 tons, was lifted off the stack Thursday for storage in the plant’s turbine hall, according to a report on the plant’s website. The work is expected to take about five weeks. The distinctive red-and-white tower is being removed to allow a new arch-shaped enclosure to be placed over the concrete sarcophagus that was built after the disaster to entomb the wrecked reactor. The arch, scheduled to be completed in 2015, will allow workers to eventually dismantle the old sarcophagus and dispose of the radioactive fuel. As part of the preparation for the work, a new, smaller ventilation stack for removing radioactive aerosols that remain in Reactor 4 was built nearby.

headline: The Mets’ Delicate Dance With a Billionaire
abstract: The question of whether Steven A. Cohen, whose company, SAC Capital Advisors, pleaded guilty to insider trading charges, should sell his minority partnership of the Mets has surfaced.
lead_paragraph: When the Mets needed money after their owners were fleeced by Bernard L. Madoff, they turned to Steven A. Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire. Their first request to him to invest came in 2010. A year later, Cohen emerged again as a possible financial lifeline before the Mets agreed to sell 33 percent of the team for $200 million to David Einhorn, another hedge-fund wizard. But that deal eventually collapsed.

headline: For Athletes, a Home for Away Games
keywords: ['Business Travel', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: A niche market, professional sports teams are a reliable, lucrative and exacting group of business travelers.
lead_paragraph: When the Minnesota Vikings checked into the J. W. Marriott Chicago last season, the hotel’s staff scrambled to fix a mistake: They had stocked the wrong flavor of Pedialyte, a favorite rehydration drink for players.

headline: Election Day Choices
abstract: Here are recommendations for some races and state constitutional amendments in New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Here are our recommendations for some races and state constitutional amendments in New York and New Jersey. Poll hours are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. in New York and 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. in New Jersey.

headline: Arming the T.S.A. Is Not a Solution
abstract: If every shooting in a public place led to a new class of law enforcement officers, America would look like a war zone.
lead_paragraph: Police are still piecing together the details of Friday’s fatal shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, but it appears as if the gunman, Paul Ciancia, targeted Transportation Security Administration agents. In response to the attack, the union representing T.S.A. screeners said the agency should arm certain employees and assign them to checkpoints. The administrator of the T.S.A., John Pistole, said he would discuss changes to security protocols with Congress.

headline: F.C.C.’s Chief Hires a Critic of the Agency
abstract: Tom Wheeler was sworn in as chairman and promptly named to his senior staff Gigi B. Sohn, one of the agency’s most outspoken critics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tom Wheeler was sworn in on Monday as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and promptly named to his senior staff Gigi B. Sohn, one of the agency’s most outspoken critics but a supporter of the new leader.

headline: Mr. Kerry Fumbles in Egypt
abstract: An ill-advised visit to Cairo undercuts earlier efforts to rebuke generals and promote democracy.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry’s trip to Egypt, included in his Middle East itinerary at the last minute, served only to add to the confusion over the Obama administration’s policy toward this critically important Arab nation. Mr. Kerry was the highest-ranking American official to visit Cairo since Mohamed Morsi, the country’s first democratically elected president, was deposed in July. Mr. Kerry seemed to go further than necessary or prudent to make common cause with the authoritarian generals who led the coup and are now running the country.

headline: The Fate of the Humanities
abstract: Can the study of the humanities thrive at a time of changing needs, or will they be too much of an academic luxury?

headline: Brooklyn Diocese Sues One of Its High Schools in Queens
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Charter Schools', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: The Diocese of Brooklyn has accused Christ the King High School of flouting an agreement and wants it to turn over part of its revenues from leasing space to a new charter school.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and the nonprofit group running Christ the King High School in Queens have acted as one, managing the twin hurdles of declining enrollments and shrinking revenues with a joint aim of fostering parochial education.

headline: Toward Ending Workplace Discrimination
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: A Senate vote shows support for fair treatment of gay, bisexual and transgender workers.
lead_paragraph: An overdue measure to outlaw employment discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity cleared a procedural hurdle on Monday night in the Senate. The move is one step toward putting into federal law a basic principle most Americans support: Job applicants and employees should be judged on their professional credentials and the caliber of their work, and not be held back because of who they are.

headline: SAC: A Textbook Case of Corporate Prosecution
abstract: The decision to indict a company is one way to punish wrongdoing and influence deterrence.
lead_paragraph: SAC Capital’s guilty plea to insider trading and $1.2 billion fine may represent a sweeping victory for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney, and his team of prosecutors, and vindication for their multiyear investigation of one of the country’s most successful hedge funds. But the decision to indict a company, and to spare, at least for now, its founder and billionaire manager, Steven A. Cohen, has already ignited criticism.

headline: ‘Buy One, Give One’ Spirit Imbues an Online Store
abstract: The altruistic shoemaker Toms is blazing a trail for like-minded companies with a new online store that features retailers with a social bent.
lead_paragraph: TOMS started in 2006 with what was then a novel idea: for every pair of shoes it sold, it would donate a pair to a child living in poverty. Along with donating more than 10 million pairs to date, the company spurred a trend of “buy one, give one” companies, with the eyeglass maker Warby Parker among the best known.

headline: Few Eager to Talk Peace in Syria, but a Mediator Won’t Stop
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Lakhdar Brahimi’s latest mission — starting Syria peace talks — has proved to be among the most stubborn of the many conflicts he has mediated on behalf of the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Lakhdar Brahimi says he prefers to navigate by sight. By this, he means that to find ways out of war, he looks for a course while talking. It distinguishes his mediating style, those who have worked with him say, and it has worked in his favor in the many conflicts he has mediated on behalf of the United Nations: holding elections in Haiti, forming a government in Iraq, ending a civil war in Lebanon.

headline: Hockey History, as Documented by Prime Minister
abstract: Stephen J. Harper, the Canadian prime minister, took nine years to research, write and publish “A Great Game,” a new addition to the great volume of hockey books produced by Canada.
lead_paragraph: The historian Jacques Barzun once wrote, “Whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn baseball.” That notion probably goes double for Canada and hockey.

headline: Uighur Scholar in Ugly Confrontation With Security Agents
abstract: Ilham Tohti, arguably China’s most vocal advocate for the rights of its Uighur minority, said security agents in Beijing rammed his car, threatened to kill his wife and children and told him to stop speaking to foreign reporters.
lead_paragraph: Ilham Tohti, a well-known scholar who is arguably China’s most vocal advocate for the rights of its Uighur minority, said he got into an ugly confrontation with security agents in Beijing on Saturday after the men rammed his car and threatened to kill his wife and children.

headline: After a Decade, SAC Capital Blinks
abstract: The Justice Department’s deal with SAC Capital Advisors caps an investigation that turned a mighty hedge fund into a symbol of financial wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors first sought to fend off a federal indictment. Then the hedge fund, run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, offered to pay about $700 million to settle. Finally, SAC suggested it plead guilty to only some of the criminal charges in the five-count indictment.

headline: After Los Angeles Airport Shooting, No Easy Answers on Security Strategies
abstract: The Los Angeles International Airport shooting that left one Transportation Security Administration official dead has security experts re-examining strategy for making airports safe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Stephen L. Holl, the chief of police at the Washington Metropolitan Airports Authority, gathered his staff for the regular morning meeting on Monday, he opened with a sobering assessment.

headline: Americans Jailed for Months in Qatar After Daughter’s Death
abstract: Supporters described the case as a combination of flawed or nonexistent evidence, ethnic prejudice and extreme cultural misunderstandings.
lead_paragraph: Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple with three adopted children from Africa, lived as a family in the affluent Persian Gulf kingdom of Qatar starting in July 2012. For most of the time since then, the parents have been imprisoned there, accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death with the intent of selling her organs.

headline: For 36 Hours, N.Y.U. Student Was Trapped Between 2 Buildings
abstract: The Fire Department official who on Sunday oversaw the rescue of Asher Vongtau, 19, said he could not recall a situation quite like it in his 33-year career.
lead_paragraph: In a crowded city, Asher Vongtau was completely alone, trapped in a space barely wider than a shoe box after plummeting perhaps 100 feet into the tiny crevice between two buildings in TriBeCa.

headline: A Finding of Guilty in the Killing of Sean Taylor
abstract: After an 11-day trial, a 23-year-old man charged in the killing of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor in 2007 was found guilty of second-degree murder and armed burglary.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — After an 11-day trial, a 23-year-old man charged in the killing of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor in 2007 was found guilty Monday of second-degree murder and armed burglary.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']

lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has started talks with American Airlines and US Airways, seeking concessions on airport takeoff and landing slots in exchange for dropping an antitrust lawsuit aimed at blocking their merger, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said on Monday

headline: Shooting Suspect’s Steps Are Traced in Search for Clues to L.A. Airport Attack
abstract: According to the federal affidavit, Paul Ciancia asked a roommate for a ride to the Los Angeles Airport the morning that a security official was killed and two others wounded.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The morning that a gunman opened fire at the Los Angeles International Airport, killing a security official and wounding two others, Paul Ciancia walked unannounced into a roommate’s room and asked for a ride the airport, according to a federal search warrant released by federal prosecutors Monday.

headline: Fixing the System
keywords: ['Elections', 'Campaign Finance', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Term Limits (Political Office)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: It’s the first Tuesday of November, so it must be Election Day. Why do so many voters feel alienated?
lead_paragraph: It’s Election Day. Virginians are electing a new governor, New Yorkers are choosing a new mayor, and all over the country, dozens of local races are being decided. Because this is an off-year election, in which there are no federal races, voter turnout is going to be abysmal. We all know that.

headline: Strategic Move Exempts Health Law From Broader U.S. Statute
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: A surprise decision by the Obama administration exempts subsidized health insurance from a law that bans rebates, kickbacks and bribes in federal health programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Affordable Care Act is the biggest new health care program in decades, but the Obama administration has ruled that neither the federal insurance exchange nor the federal subsidies paid to insurance companies on behalf of low-income people are “federal health care programs.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 5, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 5, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “It seems that the universe produces plentiful real estate for life that somehow resembles life on Earth.”

headline: Big Money Flows in New Jersey Races to Thwart Christie Agenda

abstract: Democrats and unions, fearful of a landslide victory by Gov. Chris Christie, have spent tens of millions of dollars in a record-breaking outside spending campaign.
lead_paragraph: Democrats and unions, fearful that a landslide victory by Gov. Chris Christie will reshape New Jersey’s political landscape, have poured tens of millions of dollars into a record-breaking outside spending campaign that has transformed the state’s election season.

headline: In Bullying Case, Questions on N.F.L. Culture
abstract: The unfolding saga between the offensive linemen Jonathan Martin and Richie Incognito of the Miami Dolphins is forcing the league to start defining the gray areas between pranks and bullying.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Martin and Richie Incognito spent most of the season side by side, a pair of 300-pound men made rich from football, crouched inches apart on the offensive line of the Miami Dolphins. When the defense took the field, they sat on the bench in order of their position — Martin, the left tackle, next to Incognito, the left guard. They were as connected as teammates could be — though they could hardly be more different.

keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Voting and Voters', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Almost an assured presidential contender, Gov. Chris Christie is hoping to show his party that he can win big and attract black and Hispanic voters.
lead_paragraph: The question in the governor’s race in New Jersey on Tuesday is not who will win, but by how much, and where?

headline: A Plea for Catholic Schools to Ignore New Guidelines
abstract: A group of Roman Catholic scholars wrote to the nation’s bishops, saying that the new educational standards called Common Core would lower standards.
lead_paragraph: A group of Roman Catholic scholars has called on Catholic schools to ignore the new educational standards known as the Common Core, a set of guidelines on what students should know and be able to do from kindergarten through 12th grade, opening a front with parallels to the fight over using the guidelines in public schools.

headline: The Revolution Is Not an Apple

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The southeast was the last sector to fall in for me today, which may just be the way Paula Gamache wanted it. Whether or not that is true, it worked out well because it saved the reveal for last and, indeed, cracked me up.

headline: As U.S. Weighs Spying Changes, Officials Say Data Sweeps Must Continue
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Obama administration is considering reining in many N.S.A. practices overseas, but for now, officials have concluded that there is no workable alternative to the collection of huge quantities of “metadata.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has told allies and lawmakers it is considering reining in a variety of National Security Agency practices overseas, including holding White House reviews of the world leaders the agency is monitoring, forging a new accord with Germany for a closer intelligence relationship and minimizing collection on some foreigners.

headline: In Housing Court, Different View of New York City’s Mayoral Race
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: In sections of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, a majority of tenants pay more than 50 percent of their income for rent. Perhaps the new mayor will tackle this desperate mathematics.
lead_paragraph: A chill wind pinching his face, Compton Bremner takes his place among hundreds of men and women who clutch dispossess notices and rent receipts.

headline: Hearing Voices, and Listening to the Right One
abstract: RaeJanese Chambers, 41, who has schizophrenia, has gained counseling and financial support from the Brooklyn Community Services as part of a program that helps homeless women transition to permanent housing.
lead_paragraph: Two distinct voices have fought for authority over RaeJanese Chambers since the onset of her schizophrenia at age 29. While both speak with equal clarity, Ms. Chambers, 41, ascribes only one of them to her illness.

headline: A Yiddishe Momme of Music, Chana Mlotek, Dies at 91
abstract: Mrs. Mlotek was a sleuth and archivist of Yiddish music whose song collections allowed thousands to imbibe the mirthful and mournful melodies of the shtetl, ghetto and Yiddish theater.
lead_paragraph: Chana Mlotek, an impassioned sleuth and archivist of Yiddish music whose song collections allowed thousands to imbibe the mirthful and mournful melodies of the shtetl, ghetto and Yiddish theater, died on Monday at her home in the Bronx. She was 91.

headline: Knicks Dissect Ugly First Quarter With the Hope to ‘Clean It Up’

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It was not enough for Raymond Felton to live through one of the franchise’s worst first quarters in recent memory.

headline: Nalini Ambady, Psychologist of Intuition, Is Dead at 54
abstract: Professor Ambady was a social psychologist whose research on the surprising accuracy of first impressions was popularized by Malcolm Gladwell in his 2005 best seller, “Blink.”
lead_paragraph: Nalini Ambady, a social psychologist whose research on the surprising accuracy of first impressions was popularized by Malcolm Gladwell in “Blink,” his best-selling nonfiction book of 2005, died on Oct. 28 in Boston. She was 54.

headline: For Uninsured, Clearing a Way to Enrollment
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Series']
abstract: Kentucky and other states are using counselors to seek out and sign up uninsured residents, providing a clear view of how enrollment under the health care law should work.
lead_paragraph: LA GRANGE, Ky. — Kelli Cauley’s fingers raced over her keyboard as she asked the anxious woman at her side a series of questions. What was her income? How many people lived in her household? Did she smoke? (“That’s the only health question it asks,” Ms. Cauley said of the application they were completing.)

headline: North Korean Sailors Reported Killed in October Sinking; South Says There Was No Clash
abstract: The news appeared on Saturday, when North Korea’s official news agency reported that the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, had visited a newly built cemetery for an unspecified number of victims.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A North Korean naval vessel sank last month, killing an unspecified number of sailors, according to North and South Korean news media.

lead_paragraph: David Elson is among thousands of Kentuckians who are considering their options for health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Nets Full of Stars and Questions About Roles
abstract: After a blowout loss to the Orlando Magic, the Nets say they need to be more aggressive as each player finds his new role.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The most parroted word lately among Nets players and coaches has been “process.” It is a euphemism, really, that connotes the distinct growing pains the team is going through at the moment, trying to array its vast talent into winning combinations.
