lead_paragraph: The work of enrollment “navigators” in states like Kentucky shows how the federal exchange could work once its many technical problems are solved.

headline: Suspect Is Dead in New Jersey Mall Shooting
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: There were no injuries in the incident at Garden State Plaza mall, where the authorities said the suspect, Richard Shoop, 20, was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.
lead_paragraph: A man wearing black and carrying a rifle opened fire at a large northern New Jersey mall on Monday night, prompting hundreds of customers to seek cover and an extensive search for the suspect, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Pesticides Linked to Endometriosis Risk
abstract: Persistent environmental chemicals, even those used in the past, may affect the health of the current generation of reproductive-age women, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Why some women and not others get endometriosis — the growth of uterine tissue outside the uterus that can cause pain and infertility — is not known, but researchers have come up with one possible contributing factor: pesticide poisoning.

headline: Q. and A. With Ron Duguay
abstract: A former Ranger and now a hockey analyst for the MSG Network, Duguay provided his take on the evolution of the sport and the teams he has his eye on this season.
lead_paragraph: Ron Duguay was selected 13th in the 1977 N.H.L. amateur draft by the Rangers. He became a fan favorite, not just for his hockey skills but for his cascading brown hair, active night life and commercial appearances.

headline: Manning Set to Face Motivated Raiders
abstract: The Giants’ next opponent, the Oakland Raiders, lost on Sunday, giving Eli Manning reason to believe he will be facing a team seeking to prove itself.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning was on a plane home to New Jersey on Sunday evening when Philadelphia’s Nick Foles was heaving touchdown pass after touchdown pass against the Oakland Raiders.

headline: Seattle’s Mayor Faces Challenge, Despite Signs of Success
abstract: On the eve of Election Day, polls suggested that Mayor Mike McGinn was in trouble, even though the economy is doing pretty well and job numbers are growing.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Mayor Mike McGinn seems like the kind of candidate this city would love. A former Sierra Club chapter leader and an avid cyclist, he bikes to work from his home in north Seattle. He has focused his campaign for a second term on issues voters care about here: climate change, transportation and reducing police brutality. And the economy is doing pretty well, with construction cranes whirring on the horizon and job numbers growing.

headline: Idzik Pleased With Performance of Ryan and Jets
abstract: General Manager John Idzik had praise for the resilience of quarterback Geno Smith, the cohesiveness of the overhauled coaching staff and the leadership of Coach Rex Ryan.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — John Idzik committed a bit of a Freudian slip Monday while mentioning how many challenges Geno Smith has confronted during the last nine months — er, nine games.

headline: Senator Rand Paul Faces New Charges of Plagiarism
abstract: An op-ed article Mr. Paul wrote for The Washington Times on mandatory minimum prison sentences appears to have copied language from an essay in The Week.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who in recent weeks has had to explain how Wikipedia entries came to be incorporated into his speeches with no attribution, faced charges of direct plagiarism on Monday night.

headline: Mets Games Move to WOR-AM
abstract: The Mets formally announced that their radio games are moving to WOR-AM in a five-year deal with the news and talk station’s owner, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: The Mets formally announced that their radio games are moving to WOR-AM (710) in a five-year deal with the news and talk station’s owner, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment. The announcement did not say if Howie Rose, who has called Mets games since 1996, and Josh Lewin, who joined the Mets’ broadcast team in 2012, will be moving to WOR from WFAN, AM and FM, which had carried the games since 1987. In a statement, the Mets said: "Now that our agreement is official, WOR is in discussions regarding announcers.”

headline: Obama to Campaign to Ensure Health Law’s Success
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: President Obama told supporters on Monday that he was committed to fixing the problems of the health exchange website that have prevented enrollment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the fifth anniversary of his election, President Obama told a rally of grass-roots supporters on Monday evening that “I’ve got one more campaign in me” — to make sure his signature health care law works.

headline: The Bidding Is Sluggish at a Special Estate Sale
abstract: At a sale of paintings, drawings and sculptures from the estate of Jan Krugier, a Geneva-based dealer, many expensive works did not sell at all, or went far below expectations.
lead_paragraph: The highly anticipated fall auction season got off to a surprisingly gloomy start on Monday night at Christie’s, which held a special sale of paintings, drawings and sculptures from the estate of Jan Krugier, the Geneva-based dealer who died in 2008.

headline: The Decline of the Tea Party
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There are signs that the political pendulum may be swinging back toward the middle as wealthy elites and business interests push back against a hard-line Republican right wing, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Helpouts From Google Connects People With Experts Over Live Video
abstract: Acknowledging that its search engine cannot answer everybody’s questions, particularly in the age of social networking, Google introduced Helpouts, for live, one-on-one video chats with experts.
lead_paragraph: A new product from Google, Helpouts, connects people with experts over video chat to give free or paid advice for tasks as varied as how to apply lipstick, how to treat a burn or how to speak Mandarin.

headline: Word of the Day | congeal
abstract: This word has appeared in nine New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: congeal •\kən-ˈjel\• verb

headline: Ducks Defeat Rangers Behind a Rookie’s 32 Saves
abstract: The larger, speedier Anaheim Ducks defeated the Rangers with the help of rookie goaltender Frederik Andersen and two first-period goals from Corey Perry and Kyle Palmieri.
lead_paragraph: The Anaheim Ducks were concluding an eight-game trip, but the Rangers were the more lethargic squad Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) IN THE SPOTLIGHT WITH ROBIN ROBERTS: COUNTDOWN TO THE CMA AWARDS Ms. Roberts visits some of country music’s biggest stars at home in this lead-in to the Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday. The lineup features Jason Aldean (above with Ms. Roberts), who discusses fame, fortune and the tabloid headlines that he says contributed to the end of his marriage; Luke Bryan, who talks about two family tragedies that nearly broke him; Shania Twain, who ponders her battle with stage fright; and Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers, who reminisce about their hit “Islands in the Stream.”

headline: I Want to Be a Millennial When I Retire
abstract: For now my son Max writes songs, tours and does what he wants. He is not rich or secure, but why should he measure his life on the same scale as his parents’?
lead_paragraph: My son Max is a 25-year-old singer and songwriter who goes by the moniker Dolfish. When my friends ask how his career is going, I say, “There’s a girl in Indiana with Dolfish tattooed on her arm,” although that doesn’t exactly answer their question.

headline: China’s Dynasties, in Song
abstract: The order of China’s dynasties can be a complicated puzzle for students of Chinese history. The Harvard professors William Kirby and Peter Bol suggest singing them to the tune of “Frère Jacques.”
lead_paragraph: The order of China’s dynasties can be a complicated puzzle for students of Chinese history. The Harvard professors William Kirby and Peter Bol offer this trick: a song that names the major dynasties, the Republic of China and the People’s Republic of China (or as the lyrics have it, “Mao Zedong”) to the tune of “Frère Jacques.”

headline: News Quiz | November 5, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Tweets From Inside N.J. Mall During Gunfire
abstract: An online editor for The National Review posted live tweets from inside the Garden State. Christine Hauser contributed reporting.
lead_paragraph: Updated 9:05 a.m.Hundreds of police officers descended on the sprawling Garden State Plaza Mall in Paramus, N.J., Monday night after multiple shoppers reported a gunman with a long rifle fired shots inside the mall around 9:15 p.m. No one was reported injured, officials said.

headline: Home Buyers Feel Let Down by India’s Top Builders
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: India’s top builders fail to deliver apartments for home buyers years past delivery date.
lead_paragraph: Nitin Grover, a 33-year-old lawyer, has been dreaming of moving from his rented home to an apartment of his own. In 2008, Mr. Grover and his wife, who were paying monthly rent of 30,000 rupees, or nearly $500 at the current exchange rate, surveyed the real estate landscape around New Delhi, India’s capital. They decided to buy a place in Gurgaon, on the outskirts of the city.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 5, 2013
abstract: Answer this question about the 1968 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Claim to Be
abstract: Do you know anyone who takes herbal supplements? Have you ever seen these products in stores? Do you think the government should regulate herbal supplements more stringently?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Seem,” Fares Akram and Jodi Rudoren report on a recent study that found widespread adulteration and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.

headline: Renault and Nissan Seek a Tie-Up With Mitsubishi
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: The deal would include cooperation on electric vehicles, the companies said, adding that they are also looking to produce two new sedan models under the Mitsubishi brand.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Renault, the French automaker, and its Japanese alliance partner Nissan Motor, are exploring a possible tie-up with Mitsubishi Motors in a deal to include cooperation on electric vehicles, the companies said Tuesday.

headline: South Korean Government Seeks  Ban on Small Leftist Party
abstract: The United Progressive party is accused of plotting an armed rebellion against the Seoul government in event of war with North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The government of President Park Geun-hye asked the Constitutional Court of South Korea Tuesday to disband a small leftist party accused of supporting North Korea at the cost of the South’s national security.

headline: Outsource Your Way to Success
abstract: Want to get ahead in life? Pay others to do the boring stuff.
lead_paragraph: Jon Steinsson and Emi Nakamura do not have enough time to do everything they need to do. They’re recently tenured, highly productive rising stars at Columbia University, as well as parents to an infant. But they have a secret weapon helping them prioritize: Econ 101.

headline: At West Point: Duty, Honor, Gay Marriage
abstract: For months, the photographer Jill Knight had been following a couple of West Point graduates, who, on Saturday, sealed with a kiss the first male gay marriage at the military academy.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Lennox and Larry Choate III were wandering the aisles of a Walmart in Fort Benning, an Army post near Columbus, Ga.

headline: Does TV Capture the Diversity of America Yet?
abstract: What shows do you watch? Do you notice the ethnicity and race of the actors and characters on your favorite shows? Does it matter to you?
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” does not have a black woman as a cast member, a fact that has become a hotly discussed issue. The debate raises a larger issue that seems to come up again and again: Is television too white?

headline: E.U. Predicts Anemic Growth and High Unemployment in 2014
abstract: Economic growth in 2014 should hit 1.1 percent in the euro area and 1.4 percent across the European Union and continue to strengthen in 2015.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A fragile recovery across the European Union is not expected to bear fruit until next year. And unemployment is likely to remain high in countries like Greece and Spain, and even rise in France, the Union’s head of economic policy warned Tuesday.

headline: Diplomats Fail to Agree on Details for Syria Peace Talks
abstract: Senior American, Russian and United Nations diplomats could not agree on a date for peace talks, nor were they able to decide on which countries should participate.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Senior diplomats from the United States, Russia and the United Nations failed on Tuesday to agree on a date for convening a long-awaited peace conference aimed at settling the Syria conflict, acknowledging it would not take place this month and possibly not this year.

headline: German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: The first glimpse of the collection brought astonishment but also anger and the initial stirrings of what will likely be a long battle over who owns the works.
lead_paragraph: It is almost certainly the biggest trove of missing 20th-century European art discovered since the end of World War II, and the first glimpse of it on Tuesday brought astonishment but also anger and the early stirrings of what will likely be a prolonged battle over who owns the works.

headline: New York Today: To the Polls
abstract: What you need to know in New York for Tuesday: mayoral decision day, fall-appropriate weather and a 19th century election surprisingly free of “ruffianism.”
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:10 p.m. | It’s finally here — Election Day.

headline: It’s Election Day
abstract: Throughout the day, Times journalists will be filing dispatches from around the country, with a particular focus on New York City.
lead_paragraph: Today is Election Day across the nation, as voters in many states go to the polls to choose local and state officials.

headline: Broccoli Gone Wild
abstract: Three recipes for broccoli from chefs who know what they’re talking about (they have children).
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, while researching Michael Moss’s cover story about broccoli’s image problem, I learned about the Kitchen Community, a Colorado-based nonprofit that has put up, in low-income neighborhoods, billboards with simple recipes to encourage people to cook. Cool idea, except that the broccoli recipe struck me as wrong: “Olive oil & salt, 350° oven, 1 hour.” Broccoli is a favorite in my house. During the week, I boil the florets in two inches of water, drain and add butter and salt. Sometimes, if I’ve had enough sleep, I go wild and sauté it after parboiling — this adds char and brings out sweetness. My husband can steam it with scientific precision. None of these methods take an hour; maybe 15 minutes.

headline: Daily Report: In New York, Airbnb Offers Extra Income but Questionable Legality
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The often lucrative short-term rentals facilitated by Airbnb are often in violation of New York City zoning law or of tenants’ leases.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb is a service adored by some, despised by others, and most commonly known as a place to rent out your apartment while you are out of town for a few days, Elizabeth A. Harris reports. But doing so is often illegal in New York City, one reason the company has locked horns with the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: United Nations Group Warns on Emissions
abstract: A report by the United Nations Environment Program says that greenhouse gas emissions must start to fall immediately to avoid more drastic and expensive action later.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Major polluters must immediately begin to reduce greenhouse gas emissions if the rise in global temperatures is to be held in check, or else a higher price will have to be paid later, according to a report released Tuesday by the United Nations Environment Program.

headline: U.S.-Saudi Relations
abstract: A tense meeting between Secretary of State John Kerry and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: A tense meeting between Secretary of State John Kerry and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia.

headline: After Outside Pressure, Rebels in Congo Lay Down Their Arms
abstract: The surrender offered new hope for a region where conflict has gone on for so many years that it has often come to seem almost inevitable.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Col. Mamadou Moustafa stood at the front lines of the battle for eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, surveying his soldiers fighting to dislodge rebels from the surrounding hills.

headline: New Warnings for Old Problems
abstract: The stylebook revision gave us an opportunity to take aim at some perennial usage problems, nagging missteps that are staples of After Deadline. We’ve added a handful of new warnings in hopes of cutting down on these repeat offenses.
lead_paragraph: The latest revisions to The Times’s stylebook gave us an opportunity to take aim at some perennial usage problems, nagging missteps that are staples of After Deadline. We’ve added a handful of new warnings in hopes of cutting down on these repeat offenses.

headline: Where to Vote in the New York Region
abstract: Information on polling locations, hours and voting help in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: The polls are now open throughout the New York region.

headline: On the Chinese Internet, Big Interest in Smog’s Threat to Fertility
abstract: A passing reference to pollution’s effects on reproductive health in a government report on low-carbon development rivets public attention.
lead_paragraph: How do you get online readers to click on a story about a long, official report about climate change? One answer, grabbed by editors of Chinese news sites Tuesday, was to play up a single line about a link between air pollution and fertility rates.

headline: Intersection: Fall Style in Boston
abstract: In Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood, residents are inspired by the change of seasons, old relationships and the Beastie Boys.
lead_paragraph: In Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood, residents are inspired by the change of seasons, old relationships and the Beastie Boys.

headline: Chiara de Blasio Style
abstract: Looking at how the daughter of New York City’s Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio and others have made the floral headband a part of their fashion.
lead_paragraph: Looking at how the daughter of New York City’s Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio and others have made the floral headband a part of their fashion.

headline: Pink Floyd’s ‘Comfortably Numb’ and Other Takes
abstract: The universal message of  Pink Floyd’s hit song “Comfortably Numb” has inspired many to cover it.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: An 8-Year-Old Girl’s Lung Cancer Is Blamed on Air Pollution
abstract: According to her doctor, she has been living near heavily trafficked streets and breathing in the smog that often enshrouds cities in Jiangsu. A recent study found that polluted air had shortened life spans in northern China by five years.
lead_paragraph: An 8-year-old girl in Jiangsu Province is the youngest person in China to have received a diagnosis of lung cancer, which a doctor treating her has attributed to air pollution, according to an official news report.

headline: Endo Health to Buy Specialty Drug Maker for $1.6 Billion
abstract: Endo Health Solutions, a health care company known for its pain medication, has reached a deal to acquire a Canadian specialty drug company, Paladin Labs, for $1.6 billion in stock and cash.
lead_paragraph: Endo Health Solutions, a health care company known for its pain medication, has reached a deal to acquire a Canadian specialty drug company, Paladin Labs, for $1.6 billion in stock and cash.

headline: In Performance: Patrick Page of ‘A Time to Kill’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from the stage adaptation of John Grisham’s novel.
lead_paragraph: In the courtroom drama “A Time to Kill,” a stage adaptation of the John Grisham novel, Patrick Page plays a Mississippi district attorney, prosecuting the case against black man who kills his daughter’s two white attackers. In this scene, he addresses the jury. The show, adapted by Rupert Holmes and directed by Ethan McSweeny, is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.

headline: An Alternative to the Family Business: The Family Bank
abstract: A family bank can help business owners follow Warren Buffett’s advice of leaving children enough to do anything but not enough to do nothing.
lead_paragraph: Lately, I’ve noticed that children of business owners seem less interested than previous generations in joining a family business. Of course, just because they do not want to work in a business with their parents does not mean they are not interested in business at all. And that has led some families who have the means to try a concept known as the family bank.

headline: AOL Revenue Rises 6% as Profit Plunges
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Company Reports', 'News and News Media', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Sales of premium and programmatic advertising drove revenue, while costs related to Patch, the local news network, hurt profit.
lead_paragraph: AOL, the giant online portal turned media company, on Tuesday reported third-quarter revenue of $561 million, up 6 percent from a year earlier.

headline: The Changing Rules of Outing
abstract: Intention matters when a publication chooses to out a celebrity.
lead_paragraph: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: In Kentucky, a Glimpse of Health Insurance Help
abstract: To watch the health insurance sign-up process last month in Louisville, a city of 600,000, was to get a glimpse of how the rollout of the exchanges was supposed to work from coast to coast.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. – Jennifer Albrecht lost her job after being given a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis last year – a turn of events that her husband, Hugh, described as feeling like “a building fell on us.” She stretches out her medicine because she cannot afford the refills, suffering worse flare-ups as a result. But last month, after seeking the help of a “kynector” – one of Kentucky’s counselors certified to help people sign up for insurance under the federal health care law – Ms. Albrecht found she qualified for Medicaid. Her coverage will take effect at the beginning of 2014.

headline: Spies R Us
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Keep on eavesdropping, America, because as long as you do Israelis will know you’re still helping police the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A solid majority of Americans say it is “unacceptable for the United States to monitor the phones of allied leaders,” according to a recent poll by the Pew Research Center. But Israelis aren’t so fussed.

headline: Suicide Ends Long Night of Chaos Inside New Jersey Mall
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A man who fired a weapon Monday night in the Garden State Plaza mall, sending thousands running, shot and killed himself early Tuesday morning, authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A young man. A powerful weapon. And a crowded public space.

headline: European Telecom Giants in More Deals
abstract: Telefónica of Spain agreed to sell a 66 percent stake in its Czech subsidiary, while Vivendi of France said it was shedding its 53 percent stake in Maroc Telecom.
lead_paragraph: Consolidation continued on Tuesday in Europe’s telecommunications industry, as the big players dispose of assets to refocus their strategies.

headline: The Making Of | Waldorf Astoria’s Eccentric New Ad Campaign, Starring Olga Kurylenko
abstract: Besides striking an alluring pose for the primary campaign image, the Ukrainian actress had to become a character in a short story that is running online.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t laugh at her!” The French photographer Bruno Dayan was shushing two young crew members who were snickering while his subject, the actress Olga Kurylenko, flapped her arms in an effort to stay upright. It wasn’t her maroon stilettos that were giving her trouble, it was her pose. For the main image in a new campaign for Waldorf Astoria Hotels & Resorts, Dayan had positioned Kurylenko, a Ukrainian-born beauty, in midstride in the lobby of the luxury hotel chain’s Chicago location. A bellhop, who had been yanked into the shot by Dayan from the curb outside, stood 20 feet behind her holding a luggage cart. To Kurylenko’s left stood a male model in a velvet dinner jacket whom she was supposed to “notice” as she breezed by. Kurylenko took two deep breaths and made eye contact with the model as Dayan’s flash started again. “Beautiful,” he barked. “No, no, no, relax your mouth. Not too sultry.”

headline: A Child’s Take on the Mayoral Election
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: On the Upper West Side, a little girl explains why Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is leaving office.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Detroit: A Race Overshadowed by Bankruptcy
abstract: The contest has been largely overshadowed by the protracted legal battle (and pending public anxiety) over how Detroit will be restructured in federal Chapter 9 proceedings.
lead_paragraph: As a trial scrutinizing America’s largest municipal bankruptcy enters its seventh day here, the fight over Detroit’s top elected office will be decided Tuesday when voters select the next mayor of this battered city in desperate need of a comeback.

headline: My Suicide Attempt and My Struggles to Get Help
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Thomas James Brennan, a Marine, describes the difficulties he encountered when he sought help after trying to commit suicide.
lead_paragraph: “To the woman I love with my whole heart and soul: You are finally free of the terror I have caused in your life,” I wrote. “I am sorry for everything I have done to you. I deserve every bit of sorrow I feel.”

headline: During I.V.F., Keeping a Marriage Strong
abstract: A loving partnership can make fertility treatments far easier to bear — but we have to protect our partnerships from the toll that in vitro fertilization can take.
lead_paragraph: My friend Rachel is undergoing treatment at the same in vitro fertilization clinic, so I often check in with her: to commiserate, compare notes, even meet up – either at our clinic uptown or downtown at the acupuncturist, where we both got pricked a few times a week to “warm our wombs.” And yet for all our similarities in treatment, there’s one difference between us: she’s single.

headline: A Slum Spends Sleepless Nights in Fear of Eviction
abstract: A few thousand people in west Delhi live under constant threat of losing their homes to government authorities.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – On the morning of March 24, 2011, several hundred police officers, accompanied by giant bulldozers, surrounded the slum of Gayatri Colony in west Delhi as part of an eviction drive by the Delhi Development Authority, which claims ownership of the colony’s land.

headline: Militants Kill 5 Police Officers in India
abstract: A shootout, in Meghalaya State near Bangladesh, was the second in a week linked to an armed group known as the Garo National Liberation Army.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Militants killed five Indian police officers in a shootout in the forest near India’s border with Bangladesh on Tuesday, marking the second deadly episode in a week linked to the same armed group, known as the Garo National Liberation Army.

headline: New York: The Other Races on Your Ballot
abstract: The race for mayor of New York City has dominated headlines for months, but dozens of other contests will also take place during the general election on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The race for mayor of New York City has dominated headlines for months, but dozens of other contests will also take place during the general election on Tuesday. Click here to learn more about statewide ballot proposals and candidates for other New York City races, including borough president, district attorney and your local City Council seat.

headline: Greece Resumes Talks With Lenders Over Budget Gap
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Credit and Debt', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The two sides are disputing the size of a budget gap for next year and whether new austerity measures will be needed to cover it.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Government officials resumed talks with representatives of Greece’s foreign creditors on Tuesday amid a dispute over the size of a budget gap for next year and whether more austerity measures would be needed to cover it.

headline: The Gun Report: November 5, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Guns are now allowed in public libraries in Seattle, thanks to a state supreme court ruling holding that cities have no right to ban guns in public places such as parks and libraries. The board of the library system said it did not have a choice but to remove its longstanding ban on firearms.

headline: 1963: First Woman in Space
abstract: The New York Herald Tribune front page coverage of Cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova’s journey into space.
lead_paragraph: “Hello Hawk, hello Hawk, this is Seagull”

headline: National Races We’re Watching Today
abstract: Here is a sampling of some of the interesting races and ballot initiatives the National Desk will be following throughout the day.
lead_paragraph: In Virginia, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the Republican candidate, and Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, are running for governor of a state that had once been a Republican stronghold. Mr. McAuliffe, who has been slightly ahead in the polls, was joined by President Obama at a rally on Sunday. And Mr. Cuccinelli has been winding down his campaign with a whirlwind of events, campaigning alongside a roster of Republican governors and presidential hopefuls.

headline: Lady Gaga Said to Fire Her Manager
abstract: The dismissal of the manager, Troy Carter, occurred days before the scheduled release of the singer’s new album. Mr. Carter had managed Lady Gaga since 2007.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga has fired her manager, Troy Carter, just days before the release of her new album, according to three people with direct knowledge of the news who were not authorized to speak about it.

headline: New York: Lhota Has Little to Say as He Casts Ballot
abstract: With Election Day finally here, Mr. Lhota, who has trailed well behind his Democratic opponent, did not appear eager to engage in conversation.
lead_paragraph: If voting for himself for mayor felt climactic for Joseph J. Lhota, he did not revel in the moment on Tuesday morning.

headline: Acer’s Chief Resigns Amid Slump in PC Sales
abstract: The Taiwanese computer maker said Tuesday that its chief executive, J.T. Wang, had resigned, citing an inability to come to grips with a downturn in the PC business.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Acer, the Taiwanese computer maker, said Tuesday that its chief executive, J.T. Wang, had resigned, citing an inability to come to grips with a downturn in the PC business.

headline: Ford Pays a High Price for Plant Closing in Belgium
abstract: Ford’s plant in Genk, Belgium, is scheduled to close at the end of the year, but only after a long, bitter struggle that cost the company $750 million.
lead_paragraph: GENK, Belgium — Rumors of job cuts at the big Ford plant in this scruffy former coal mining town had been circulating for months. But on a clear morning a year ago, almost nobody in Genk expected what came next.

headline: Nominees Named for Clive Barnes Awards
abstract: The Clive Barnes Awards honor actors and dancers.
lead_paragraph: The nominees for the fourth annual Clive Barnes Awards for young actors and dancers were announced Tuesday by the Clive Barnes Foundation, which was established in 2009 to administer the prize.

headline: 152 Bangladeshi Border Guards Get Death Penalty Over Revolt
abstract: The sentence was imposed on members of the Bangladesh Rifles in connection with a 2009 mutiny in which scores were killed.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — In an apparently unprecedented ruling, 152 former members of the Bangladesh Rifles, a paramilitary border security force, were sentenced to death on Tuesday in connection with a bloody 2009 mutiny in which several thousand troops took control of their headquarters, demanding better working conditions, and killed scores of people.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Making of a Food Truck King
abstract: Wasting four billion hours a year. Gasoline prices fall. What small businesses in Virginia want from the next governor.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: New York: For Bloomberg, a Last Vote as Mr. Mayor
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg betrayed no feelings of nostalgia at seeing a ballot that for the first time in over a decade did not have his name on it.
lead_paragraph: When a man named Bloomberg, dressed in a crimson tie and a crisp winter coat, showed up to vote on Tuesday at Public School 6 on the Upper East Side, Jeris Coles, the poll worker assisting him, had a question. What was the mayor’s first name, again?

headline: Belgian Town Braces for Ford Exit
abstract: After battling unions and politicians, Ford has reached a settlement allowing it to close its factory in Genk, Belgium. The move comes at a high price for the company, its workers and the community.
lead_paragraph: After battling unions and politicians, Ford has reached a settlement allowing it to close its factory in Genk, Belgium. The move comes at a high price for the company, its workers and the community.

headline: Feeling For | Furry Accessories for Winter
abstract: To keep warm (and cool) during the colder months, consider layering with fur.
lead_paragraph: Take the chill off by layering on sumptuously shaggy gear that will keep you warm without sacrificing even a bit of cool.

headline: Paintings Discovered in Germany
abstract: Hundreds of forgotten art works were found hidden in a Munich apartment.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of forgotten art works were found hidden in a Munich apartment.

headline: In the N.F.L., Even the Strong Have Weaknesses
abstract: After nine weeks, 25 teams have lost at least three games. The other seven teams are the top contenders for the Super Bowl, but each has an Achilles’ heel to hide.
lead_paragraph: Who could have predicted that winless Tampa Bay would nearly upset Seattle? After nine weeks in the N.F.L., 25 teams have lost at least three games. The other seven teams, including the Seahawks, have significant strengths, but also weaknesses that they hope to hide.

headline: Free-Floating Inflation Hysteria
abstract: Who you gonna believe?
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong has some fun with Senator Pat Roberts, who has gone from praising Janet Yellen in August to denouncing her as a dangerous inflationist now. So the senator is willing to say whatever the Tea Party wants him to say; big surprise.

headline: What Would Aldous Huxley Make of the Way We Consume Media and Popular Culture?
abstract: Adam Kirsch and Jennifer Szalai on the prescience — or lack thereof — of the “Brave New World” author, who died 50 years ago this month.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Jennifer Szalai on the prescience — or lack thereof — of the “Brave New World” author, who died 50 years ago this month.

headline: Worst. Conspirators. Ever.
abstract: Couldn’t have happened to more deserving people.
lead_paragraph: From the FT, about the Murdoch phone-tapping affair:

headline: Image of the Day: November 5
abstract: India launched its first mission to Mars on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Democracy Gone Awry
abstract: A law professor says Supreme Court rulings have undermined our political system. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: In JetBlue Loyalty Program, Families Can Share Points
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Families can pool points in a shared account in the JetBlue Airways loyalty program.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue Airways recently announced the latest addition to its TrueBlue loyalty program – family pooling. Families can now elect to earn and share points as a group, free of charge.

headline: ‘Don’t Tell Coach': Playing Through Concussions
abstract: Despite progress in treating and preventing concussions, a new report identified one particularly stubborn challenge: the “culture of resistance” among athletes to reporting any problems.
lead_paragraph: Nausea, sensitivity to bright lights, headache: Chris Coyne knew right away that the helmet-to-helmet hit during football practice had given him a concussion. His fifth, in fact.

headline: For a Rich Fish, Red Wine Flatters
abstract: Try a red that’s not too heavy, oaky or tannic.
lead_paragraph: If you are going to treat a rich fish like tuna as if it were a steak, complete with a red-wine sauce, you’ll want to drink red wine, too. But not a red that’s heavy, oaky or tannic. I would look for a wine that will flatter the peppery spicing. This immediately suggests a Loire Valley red made with cabernet franc, like a Chinon, Bourgueil or Saumur-Champigny, either on the lighter, fresher side or well aged. Burgundy would be delicious, especially a lighter wine like a Marsannay or Santenay, or maybe an older Volnay.

headline: Bill De Blasio Votes With His Family
abstract: After voting in Park Slope, Bill De Blasio shared a story about how his daughter made a surprise visit on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: After voting in Park Slope, Bill De Blasio shared a story about how his daughter made a surprise visit on Election Day.

headline: New York: An Election Day Surprise for de Blasio
abstract: Bill de Blasio’s daughter, Chiara, who had told him that she couldn’t make it back from college in California for Election Day because of tests, surprised him by showing up at their house this morning, causing the delay.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio arrived almost an hour behind schedule at his polling place at a library in Park Slope, Brooklyn. But Mr. de Blasio, who recently admitted that he was not a morning person, said that he had not overslept. Instead, his daughter, Chiara, who had told him that she couldn’t make it back from college in California for Election Day because of tests, had surprised him by showing up at their house this morning, causing the delay.

headline: A New Design for Wireless Sound
abstract: The Danish audio company Libratone has embraced a new shape for wireless speakers: round. Its latest, the Loop, resembles a large plate.
lead_paragraph: Pity the poor audio speaker. So boxy and square.

headline: The Gin Goes Back Into the Barrel
abstract: Gin absorbs intriguing flavors when aged in barrels used for whiskey, rum or even wine, microdistilleries discover.
lead_paragraph: John Little, the founder and master distiller of Smooth Ambler, a West Virginia microdistillery, fell into the aged-gin business by accident. Early in 2012 he had just distilled a batch of his standard gin when he realized he was out of bottles to put it in.

headline: End of the Assembly Line
abstract: Automotive plants in Europe that closed or ceased production this year, or whose closure has been announced.
lead_paragraph: Automotive plants in Europe that closed or ceased production this year, or whose closure has been announced.

headline: Musical America Names Audra McDonald Musician of the Year
abstract: The classical music journal Musical America honors Audra McDonald among others in its annual awards.
lead_paragraph: The soprano and actress Audra McDonald, though better known for her theater and jazz performances than for her classical work these days, has been named musician of the year by Musical America, a classical music journal that was founded as a weekly newspaper in 1898 and now publishes an online magazine and an annual directory (in print and online) that lists performers, ensembles, music schools and management companies.

headline: New Jersey: Hometown Voting
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, left, cast his vote in his hometown of Mendham, N.J., on Tuesday morning. His Democratic opponent for governor, Barbara Buono, voted in Metuchen, N.J., where she currently lives.

headline: Though Defiant, Senator Accused of Plagiarism Admits Errors
abstract: In an interview, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky offered a mix of contrition and defiance, saying that he was being held to an unfair standard.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky acknowledged Tuesday that “mistakes” in his office had caused unattributed writing by others to appear in his own work and announced that he was instituting safeguards to prevent such breaches from happening again.

headline: Boston: A New Mayor for the First Time in 20 Years
abstract: Roger Croke waited outside of a polling location in the Dorchester neighborhood of Boston on Tuesday morning, as voters cast their ballots in the first open mayoral race in the city in a generation.
lead_paragraph: Election Day in Boston began briskly as voters went to the polls under sunny blue skies to elect a new mayor for the first time in two decades.

headline: New York: Crossover Votes Unlikely This Year
abstract: A pattern of New York City Democratic voters supporting Republican candidates for mayor is not likely to be repeated this year.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Michael R. Bloomberg both ran for mayor as Republicans (Mr. Bloomberg later became an independent) and were elected mayor in large part thanks to the support of Democratic voters. Scholars at the City University of New York’s Center for Urban Research have analyzed the crossover Democratic vote, and suggest that this year’s pattern is likely to be very different. Their analysis is available here.

headline: Brazil's North Zones
abstract: The Frugal Traveler heads to the north sides of São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, where urban explorers can find affordable adventures.
lead_paragraph: The Frugal Traveler heads to the north sides of São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, where urban explorers can find affordable adventures.

headline: In Rio and São Paulo, Go North
abstract: The generally ignored north sides of both Brazilian cities offer rewards that range from the cultural to the culinary.
lead_paragraph: It is a startlingly pleasant anomaly in the normally intimidating 11-million-person megacity of São Paulo. On a quaint square across from a tiny 112-year-old church, a bar called Frangó (frangobar.com.br) offers worn wooden tables in cozy nooks, an astonishing 500-label beer list and a celebrated version of the popular Brazilian chicken croquettes called coxinhas.

headline: Virginia: A Street Fight for Turnout
abstract: The race for governor in swing state Virginia has boiled down to a street fight for voter turnout Tuesday, with the rest of the country watching ahead of Congressional midterm elections next year.
lead_paragraph: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor, just shrugged when one commuter declined to shake his hand at a Metro station. “Can’t get ’em all,” he said, more amused than disappointed.

headline: Palestinian Inmate With Cancer Dies in Israeli Hospital
abstract: The death of the prisoner, a 22-year-old man who had leukemia, prompted accusations of medical malpractice by Palestinian leaders.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — A Palestinian prisoner with cancer died in an Israeli hospital on Tuesday, prompting accusations of medical malpractice by Palestinian leaders.

headline: Mighty, Muslim and Leaping Off the Page
abstract: Marvel Comics is expanding its superhero stable to include a teenage Muslim girl as a lead character.
lead_paragraph: With most superheroes, when you take away the colorful costume, mask and cape, what you find underneath is a white man. But not always. In February, as part of a continuing effort to diversify its offerings, Marvel Comics will begin a series whose lead character, Kamala Khan, is a teenage Muslim girl living in Jersey City.

headline: Should Our Daughters Come to Our (Gay) Wedding?
abstract: Our daughters (8 and 10) think we already are married. We had a commitment ceremony almost 20 years ago. When we head to City Hall to “make it legal,” wouldn’t it just confuse them if we ask them to come along?
lead_paragraph: One morning when I was making breakfast before school, my second-grade daughter, fresh off her school’s diversity unit on homosexuality, decided it was time I had a lesson in gay rights. First, she said, you should never use the word “gay” in a negative way, as in “That’s so gay!” Very interesting, I said, plotting to push a little deeper into this intriguing topic. So what is “gay,” I asked? Gay is when two boys like each other, and lesbian is when two girls like each other, she explained. Did she know anyone who was gay or lesbian, I asked? “I’m pretty sure I’m a lesbian because all my friends are girls,” she declared. Did she know anyone else? “Well, Larry only plays with boys, so he must be gay.” Anyone else? Nope.

headline: In Our Pages: November 6
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1938 Plot to Kill King of Siam Found

headline: Diane Paulus’s Cirque du Soleil Show Headed to New York
abstract: “Amaluna,” which opened in Montreal in April 2012, is inspired by “The Tempest,” and directed by Ms. Paulus, who won a Tony for directing this year’s “Pippin” revival.
lead_paragraph: Cirque du Soleil has discovered that one way to wow New Yorkers — that is, beyond the company’s usual blend of daring acrobatics and high-gloss artistry — is to come to town with productions staged by major directors. Last year, Cirque brought “Totem,” staged at Citi Field by Robert Lepage, the Canadian director whose production of Wagner’s “Ring” at the Metropolitan Opera has been the subject of debate among opera aficionados in recent years, and who also directed “Ka,” the Cirque spectacular in which an acrobat fell to her death in June.

headline: New Rule, and Vacancy, for a Wall St. Regulator
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commodities', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Bart Chilton said he would leave the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on the same day it voted for one of his favored proposals, a plan to limit speculation in commodities trading.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:10 p.m. | Bart Chilton, the outspoken regulator whose colorful commentary on financial risk taking positioned him as a fierce critic of the industry he helped oversee, announced on Tuesday that he was leaving his post at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The move is the latest sign that Wall Street’s scrappiest regulatory agency is poised for a makeover.

headline: It’s Election Day. Why Is No One Panicking?
abstract: New Yorkers will probably elect de Blasio, even though they have been warned not to do this by Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Election Day! A day for fresh starts and new directions, though probably not in New Jersey, which looks set to re-elect its Republican governor, Chris Christie, by an overwhelming margin over the Democrat, Barbara Buono. Just how overwhelming is the big question, and the answer may well affect how much Mr. Christie will intrude into the lives of non-Jersey Americans in the next presidential race.

headline: New York: Stop-and-Frisk Crosses into the Ballot Box
abstract: In Brownsville, Brooklyn, some voters said their views of the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk strategy influenced their opinions of the candidates.
lead_paragraph: Just after 7 a.m. on Tuesday, Darrian Smith, 48, a custodian at Public School 150 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, was sweeping the grounds outside the school, which also serves as a polling place.

headline: On the Verge | In Portland, a New Shopping Center That’s So Portland It Hurts
abstract: Sandwiched between the Ace Hotel and Powell’s City of Books, it features nine trendy food and retail outlets and has been endorsed by Carrie Brownstein, the city’s unofficial mayor.
lead_paragraph: An unexpected location in Portland, Ore., has evolved into a gleaming retail destination.

headline: ‘Listen to the Mockingbird’
abstract: A new recording of a Civil War classic gives us a picture into 19th century American culture.
lead_paragraph: The tune, so recognizable, was composed by an African-American street musician named Richard Milburn in 1855, about whom too little is known. The words were written by “Alice Hawthorne,” the nom de plume of a lyricist whose real name was Septimus Winner. (Why would anyone refuse to use such a name?)

headline: New York: As Expected, Not Very Many Voters at the Polls
abstract: City and campaign officials reported that turnout so far has been low, despite the opportunity to choose a new mayor for the first time in 12 years.
lead_paragraph: By early Tuesday afternoon, election officials and both mayoral campaigns said turnout at the city’s 1,200 polling places was low to moderate, at most.

headline: Allen Edmonds Changes Private Equity Hands
abstract: Brentwood Associates, based in Los Angeles, bought the men’s shoemaker from Goldner Hawn Johnson & Morrison, based in Minneapolis, for about $180 million.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Brentwood Associates has won the bidding war for the Allen Edmonds Corporation, the high-end men’s shoemaker, ending a sale process that included suitors like Men’s Wearhouse.

headline: Notes Reveal Chaotic White House Talks on Health Care Site
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: More than 100 pages of “war room notes” released by congressional investigators on Tuesday show how the White House reacted as it realized the extent of the problems with the health care website.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 100 pages of “war room notes” released by congressional investigators on Tuesday offer a window into the chaos that overwhelmed the Obama administration as the federal health insurance marketplace started up last month and officials realized that its problems could not be fixed quickly.

headline: Chris Chase, Actress Who Turned to Writing, Dies
abstract: Ms. Chase appeared on the New York stage, on television and in film under the name Irene Kane, before finding her voice in writing.
lead_paragraph: Chris Chase, an actress, journalist, memoirist and co-author of autobiographical books about Rosalind Russell, Josephine Baker and Betty Ford, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

headline: Behind Those Fast Growth Rates, Rising Inequality
abstract: There is a disquieting reality behind the “Africa Rising” narrative: The total number of people living in extreme poverty has increased.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — It was his first post-election news conference, at a luxurious villa high above the Congo River, and the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo was in a combative mood. How dare the reporters question his country’s progress, he argued: just look at our sizzling growth rate — double, even triple, the rates of those pitiful laggards in the West.

headline: DirecTV Reports Gain in U.S. Subscribers
abstract: The increase of 139,000 subscribers was certainly helped by CBS’s dispute with Time Warner Cable. In Latin America, growth slowed significantly.
lead_paragraph: DirecTV surprised Wall Street on Tuesday by reporting a gain of 139,000 television subscribers in the United States in the third quarter of the year, a sharply higher rise than analysts had expected.

headline: Proposed Rule Limits Size of Commodities Traders’ Positions
keywords: ['Commodities', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Silver']
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is seeking to expand the types of commodities future contracts subject to trading limits.
lead_paragraph: In 1979, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Hunt famously bought up as much silver as they could in the commodities market. By the time they were done, the brothers had acquired more than a third of the world’s supply of silver, sending the price of the precious metal soaring.

headline: Idaho Town Struggles After Pinning Hopes on a Failed Factory
abstract: Pocatello, a railroad town, welcomed a Chinese polysilicon factory with a land deal, banking on a high-tech future. But the company filed for bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: POCATELLO, Idaho — With great fanfare, a Chinese polysilicon factory broke ground on 67 acres here in 2007. Then, as the rest of the nation tumbled into recession, the plant rose up in shimmering promise, leaving this tough-edged railroad town — blue collar and union in a sea of southeast Idaho potato farms — feeling pretty good about the future.

headline: Detroit: Challenges Loom for Next Mayor
abstract: The mayoral contenders, Mike Duggan and Benny Napoleon, differ on how they would deal with an emergency manager, who has sweeping authority to restructure the city’s government.
lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge will have final say over this city’s financial overhaul. A state-appointed emergency manager has run this City Hall for months and may not leave anytime soon. The current mayor, Dave Bing, would not seek another term, criticizing a “supposed partnership” with state officials that has left him powerless and perturbed.

headline: Election Day in New York City
abstract: New Yorkers cast their vote for a new mayor.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers cast their vote for a new mayor.

headline: In Mideast, Kerry Tries to Nudge Peace Talks Along
abstract: An absence of progress on core issues and grousing by Israeli and Palestinian officials about each other’s motives suggest talks are sputtering.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With Middle East peace negotiations showing signs of lapsing into an all-too-familiar paralysis, Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here Tuesday night for a flurry of meetings aimed at jolting the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to reinvigorate the three-month-old round of talks.

headline: A Website Concludes Its Users Need More Hand-Holding
abstract: Bid4Spots is trying to figure out how to explain its reverse-auction process.
lead_paragraph: In my most recent post, we were challenged to simplify a fairly complex online value proposition. Bid4Spots allows advertising clients to “reverse bid” for radio airtime. When the site was introduced, the company believed that customers would fully commit to the auction online without human interaction. Over time, however, it realized that it was going to be necessary to have Bid4Spots representatives walk clients through the process.

headline: Buttercream Frosting
abstract: Melissa Clark gets help from her daughter Dahlia to make a delicious and fluffy cake topping.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark gets help from her daughter Dahlia to make a delicious and fluffy cake topping.

headline: New Italian Sculptures Will Have a Park View
abstract: Two works by the architect and designer Antonio Pio Saracino, gifts from Italy to the United States, will be installed next to Bryant Park.
lead_paragraph: A pair of 13-foot-high statues — one in marble and the other in polished stainless steel — by the architect and designer Antonio Pio Saracino are coming to a public plaza in Manhattan.

headline: Boston: Deciding on a New Mayor and a Casino
abstract: Besides deciding the city’s next mayor, voters are also deciding whether to approve a casino for one Boston neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: At lunch time on Election Day, there were more volunteers than voters clustered at a high school in East Boston, where voters had gone to pick the city’s first new mayor in 20 years and to decide whether to approve a referendum that could reshape this faded neighborhood by allowing a new casino there.

headline: A Party Is Icing on the Cake
abstract: A visual guide to making almond birthday cake with sherry-lemon buttercream.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a peek behind the scenes: we shot this video on my actual birthday. And this is the cake I have been making over the last several years to celebrate. It’s a rich almond birthday cake frosted with buttercream.

headline: Wheelies: The Pickup Slowdown Edition
abstract: Pickup truck sales slowed in October, and Carlos Ghosn gained more control of Renault-Nissan with the elimination of the chief operating officer position at Nissan.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

headline: Even Elected Officials Have Trouble Voting in Texas
abstract: Jim Wright, former House Speaker, and Greg Abbott, the Texas A.G., had trouble establishing their identities.
lead_paragraph: When Republican lawmakers began making it harder to vote by passing voter ID laws, their target was not white politicians.

headline: With TiVo, More Features for TV Lovers
abstract: With Roamio, TiVo has updated its DVR by adding more tuners and storage space and incorporating wireless streaming.
lead_paragraph: TiVo knows what television lovers want.

headline: Lael Brainard to Step Down From Treasury Post
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Brainard, who served as the under secretary for international affairs, might be in contention for a position on the Fed’s Board of Governors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lael Brainard, the country’s top financial diplomat, is leaving her post at the end of the week, a Treasury official said. Some have speculated that the White House might choose her for a position on the Federal Reserve’s board of governors.

headline: She Snoozes, but Wins
abstract: The Carlo Colla & Sons Marionette Company presents a slightly altered version of “Sleeping Beauty” that emphasizes the second word in the title.
lead_paragraph: What’s the most memorable moment in “Sleeping Beauty”? When Princess Aurora encounters the fateful spindle, or when the prince awakens her with a kiss?

headline: ‘I Have Smoked Crack Cocaine,’ Toronto’s Mayor Admits on Camera
abstract: Toronto Mayor Rob Ford stunned constituents and his own staff on Tuesday by telling a scrum of reporters, “Yes, I have smoked crack cocaine.”
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:34 p.m. | After dodging questions for months about video evidence said to show him using drugs, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto stunned constituents and his own staff on Tuesday by telling a scrum of reporters, “Yes, I have smoked crack cocaine.”

headline: A Congolese Rebellion Routed, a Photographer’s Work Continues
abstract: While the M23 rebels of Congo send signals of peace, the photographer Pete Muller, who has been documenting the conflict, will continue his work there exploring notions of masculinity.
lead_paragraph: The column of soldiers marched uphill single file, slowly but deliberately making its way to the town of Bunagana, on the border between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda. Pete Muller trekked alongside them to photograph the moment when Congolese soldiers liberated the town from the control of the M23 rebel group, part of a rapid advance by government forces that pushed the group out of areas it held in its year-and-a-half long insurrection.

headline: Taking a Better Selfie With an Audiovox App
abstract: An app from Audiovox works with a remote wireless shutter release to frame larger or more distant shots.
lead_paragraph: It appears that selfies — those self-portraits of you and your arm — are here to stay, even gaining mention in the Oxford Dictionaries.

headline: New York: In the Running
abstract: One of our major reporting efforts in covering the race for mayor was the long-form, biographical series called “In the Running,” which examined the lives and careers of the leading candidates for mayor.
lead_paragraph: A major element of The Times’s reporting on the mayoral race was the long-form, biographical series called “In the Running,” which examined the lives and careers of the leading candidates, with detail and perspective. The series was intended to offer a picture of the candidates behind the scenes, how they thought and how they acted in high-pressure situations. Here is a catalog of these articles. Check them out — they offer a unique look back at the campaign and some insight into the next administration.

headline: New York: Sunshine at the Polls
abstract: Mary Hennessey, left, and Joan Forhane, both election employees, shield their faces from the sun while waiting for voters at Public School 234 in Queens on Tuesday.

headline: Road to Morocco Stops in Yonkers
abstract: A Yonkers distillery keeps production of fig-based mahia in the family.
lead_paragraph: YONKERS — It is sometimes said that if you go to the makeshift Jewish museum in the medina of Fez, Morocco, and quietly ask the custodian there if he has any mahia, you might get lucky. Then again, you could simply turn to a married couple in downtown Yonkers.

headline: On Staten Island, Wilderness With Creature Comforts
abstract: A “hidden” Staten Island neighborhood of just over 100 houses retains anonymity, even by the standards of an island borough.
lead_paragraph: It’s not surprising that the 19th-century transcendentalists were attracted to Emerson Hill on Staten Island: The neighborhood still has a measure of the natural beauty of the wilderness that first attracted those poets and philosophers.

headline: Iranian Minister Says Nuclear Deal Is Possible This Week
abstract: Two days before talks over Iran’s disputed nuclear program resume in Geneva, the country’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, sounded an optimistic note.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two days before negotiations resume in Geneva between Iran and the United States and other Western powers aimed at ending a fight over the disputed Iranian nuclear program, the country’s foreign minister sounded an optimistic note on Tuesday, saying a deal was possible as soon as this week.

headline: Toronto Mayor Admits Crack Use, as Wild Ride in Office Continues
abstract: Rob Ford, who has been accused of many types of boorish behavior, reversed his denials about using crack cocaine after a video fell into the hands of the police.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — He has been thrown out of a Toronto Maple Leafs hockey game for being drunk and belligerent. He groped a female politician at a fund-raiser for a Jewish community group, and was asked to stop coaching a high school football team after having a violent confrontation with one of the players. He has admitted to drinking too much.

headline: New York Sees Light Turnout After Lopsided Mayoral Polls
abstract: Voters were presented with a stark choice between a politician who bills himself as having a progressive liberal vision for the city and one with a more conservative, bureaucratic approach to governance.
lead_paragraph: New York City voters headed to the polls on Tuesday to decide whether they would put a Democrat back in control of the nation’s largest city for the first time in two decades.

headline: Mayor of Toronto Admits to Drug Use
abstract: Mayor Rob Ford said he smoked crack cocaine when he was in a "drunken stupor" last year.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Rob Ford said he smoked crack cocaine when he was in a "drunken stupor" last year.

headline: Going
abstract: By Sam Phillips
lead_paragraph: By Sam Phillips

headline: Pretty Time Bomb
abstract: By Sam Phillips
lead_paragraph: By Sam Phillips

headline: Tavis Smiley to Write Book on Martin Luther King Jr.’s Final Days
abstract: The TV and radio host’s new book, “Death of a King,” was acquired by Little, Brown and Company and will show “the real Martin, a man hounded and set upon by all comers in the 12 months before he died.”
lead_paragraph: The television and radio host Tavis Smiley will write a book about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Smiley’s publisher said, exploring the attacks on Dr. King’s “character, ideology, and political tactics and how they shaped both the year leading up to his death in 1968 and his lasting legacy.”

headline: The Art of the Prosthesis
abstract: Sophie de Oliveira Barata makes bedazzled legs and reptilian arms — not your everyday prosthetic limbs. Here are some interesting tidbits about her work.
lead_paragraph: The people who ask Sophie de Oliveira Barata to make their prosthetic limbs — Nadav Kander photographed several of them for this past weekend’s health issue — want hands and legs that are not only functional but also personally expressive in some way. She produces her bespoke creations, like the snake-arm seen above, out of her London-based Alternative Limb Project. The pictures made us curious to know more about de Oliveira Barata’s enterprise, so she sent us some interesting facts about her work making prostheses:

headline: The Tax Motive in Endo Health’s Deal
abstract: Endo’s deal for Paladin Labs of Canada will involve creating a new holding company based in Ireland to house both firms. The move should significantly reduce Endo’s tax rate.
lead_paragraph: Greed is seeping into the art of mergers and acquisitions. Endo Health Solutions is the latest buyer to receive a warm welcome for a sensible acquisition with notable savings. Its market value jumped almost as much as the $1.6 billion price of its purchase, Paladin Labs. But the deal also involves a huge tax dodge, and investors aren’t factoring in enough risk.

headline: Look-Alikes Top the B.C.S. Standings
abstract: The similarities between the Nos. 1 and 2 teams in the B.C.S. standings are no accident: the teams’ head coaches worked together for five years at Louisiana State.
lead_paragraph: Alabama and Florida State, which both remain undefeated and are Nos. 1 and 2 in this week’s Bowl Championship Series standings, are look-alikes, right down to the shades of red in their jerseys, one crimson, the other garnet.

headline: At the Polls
abstract: Voters cast their ballots in races across the country.
lead_paragraph: Voters cast their ballots in races across the country.

headline: Colorado: Drive-Through Voting in Denver
abstract: Madeline Doak, a volunteer student election judge, collects ballots at a drive-up ballot drop-off station in Denver. Colorado voters will decide whether to increase taxes to raise $1 billion in exchange for more school funding and an educator’s wish-list of measures.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 10: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
abstract: The Eagles’ Nick Foles will follow up his monster performance against the Raiders with favorable matchups against the Packers and Redskins over the next two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Socrates said: “The more you learn, the more you realize how little you know.” That saying held true this past week more so than usual, leading to another abnormal scoring leader list that included the likes of Nick Foles, Jerricho Cotchery, Jason Campbell and the previously thought to be missing Tom Brady.

headline: Chevron and Ukraine Set Shale Gas Deal
abstract: The government hopes the project will reduce its dependence on Russian energy imports.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Western oil companies trying to find shale gas in Europe are discovering that Ukraine, eager to reduce its dependence on Russian energy imports, is one of their most willing partners.

lead_paragraph: Unlike many clothing designers, Rachel Roy, 39, lives in New York and Los Angeles, whose different climates pose skin-care challenges. But her beauty routine is fairly consistent. BEE SHAPIRO

headline: Rand Paul’s Plagiarism
abstract: The story so far, told (almost) entirely in other people’s words.
lead_paragraph: The story so far, told (almost) entirely in other people’s words. Brackets indicate original thinking. Click the links for attribution.

headline: Tasting Tokyo With a Chef’s Notes
abstract: David Kinch, the chef and owner of Manresa in California, names some of his favorite spots in what he calls “the greatest eating city in the world.”
lead_paragraph: As much as David Kinch, the chef and owner of the restaurant Manresa in Los Gatos, Calif., uses local ingredients like abalone and nasturtium petals in his kitchen and features them in his new cookbook, “Manresa: An Edible Reflection,” it would be misleading to say the Bay Area is his only muse.

headline: Restaurant Report: Cúrate in Asheville, N.C.
abstract: The chef of this traditional Spanish tapas spot opted out out of a neuroscience doctoral program to pursue a culinary career.
lead_paragraph: On paper, the recipe for Cúrate, a traditional Spanish tapas restaurant that opened in 2011 in downtown Asheville, seems to lack some requisite ingredients. First, the chef and co-owner Katie Button isn’t Spanish. Then there’s the fact that just six years ago she was a budding scientist, not a restaurateur. Finally, real Spanish food is an anomaly in this part of the country, where farm-to-table Americana is firmly rooted.

headline: New York: Awaiting a Democrat’s Return
abstract: Upper East Side voters were jubilant at the prospect of sending a Democrat to City Hall after two decades, even if they had mixed feelings about the candidate.
lead_paragraph: On the Upper East Side, some voters were jubilant at the prospect of sending a Democrat to City Hall after two decades — even if they had mixed feelings about the candidate.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royal households have historically been better at collecting tax than paying it. Prince Charles is about to find that out.
