lead_paragraph: HARDEEVILLE, S.C. — “I am sitting in the most amazing puddle of mire,” Matt Jennings, the chef at Farmstead in Providence, R.I., announced into the dark from his perch atop a 12-foot-high hunting blind.

headline: Federal Charges in Port Chester Police Dept. Feud
keywords: ['Police', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The dispute in Westchester County, N.Y., involves a chief on medical leave, his temporary replacement and questions about missing cash and other evidence.
lead_paragraph: A caustic feud in Westchester County between a village’s longtime police chief on medical leave and the acting chief reached a climax recently with some physical and verbal threats and resulted in a federal witness-tampering complaint against the longtime chief that carries the possibility of a 20-year sentence.

headline: J Mays, Noted Ford Designer, to Retire
abstract: Mr. Mays has directed the automaker’s designs for 16 years.  Succeeding him will be Moray Callum, who has been responsible for the design of Ford’s cars in the Americas since 2006.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor announced Tuesday that J Mays, who has directed the automaker’s designs for 16 years and is group vice president and chief creative officer, would retire in January. Succeeding Mr. Mays, 59, will be Moray Callum, 54, who has been responsible for the design of Ford’s cars in the Americas since 2006 and will assume the title of vice president of design.

headline: Virginia: Marking a Broken Voting Machine
abstract: A broken voting machine, left, was marked with tape at a polling station in Rosslyn, Va., on Tuesday.

headline: Syrian Children Draw What Used to be Home
abstract: A Syrian-American architect writes about how Syrian children draw the houses they left behind in the war.
lead_paragraph: After enduring two and a half years of the grueling brutality that defines Syria, the fall of Assad’s regime is no longer the most pressing concern of most Syrians. Rather, “When will we return home?” is the question that haunts the over seven million displaced Syrians. Of course, the fact that the first concern is the reason the second one exists adds to the country’s mass despair.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Brooks Brothers Cashmere Scarf
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a cozy winter accessory to warm up him or her.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Quality Italian
abstract: Inside the Midtown restaurant that seems to have figured out that some people would rather eat in a theater than a church.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Midtown restaurant that seems to have figured out that some people would rather eat in a theater than a church.

headline: Domestic Dispute Leads to Test of Federal Power
abstract: A domestic dispute was the backdrop for a Supreme Court case that asked whether a law implementing a treaty must be authorized by Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A lurid domestic dispute provided the unlikely backdrop for a major test of federal power on Tuesday at the Supreme Court, one a government lawyer said could affect the eradication of chemical weapons in Syria.

headline: The Hardy Folks Who Found Gold in Shale
abstract: In “The Frackers,” Gregory Zuckerman profiles several of the pioneering wildcatters who have helped revolutionize the oil industry.
lead_paragraph: The history of oil and natural gas extraction has largely been the story of men with long straws, as Daniel Day-Lewis memorably demonstrated in “There Will Be Blood,” trying to drink one another’s milkshakes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, Yemen and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, Yemen and the West Bank.

headline: New York: Hugs and Handshakes in Crown Heights
abstract: Outside a subway station in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, this afternoon, Bill de Blasio hugged and kissed women, shook men’s hands, and bent from his 6-foot-5-inch height to greet small children and ask their ages.
lead_paragraph: Outside a subway station in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, this afternoon, Bill de Blasio hugged and kissed women, shook men’s hands, and bent from his 6-foot-5-inch height to greet small children and ask their ages.

headline: Where the Trolleys Still Run in New York
abstract: Quality Italian in Midtown is a front in the battle against the creeping solemnity and earnestness of some parts of the New York restaurant scene.
lead_paragraph: The steak will be here in a minute. First, the show.

headline: The Pulitzer Prize Was Nice and All, but a Work Is Finally Fully Heard
abstract: Caroline Shaw’s Pulitzer Prize-winning work, “Partita for Eight Voices,” was performed in full for the first time on Monday at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: You might assume that any music piece that wins the Pulitzer Prize would already have had its premiere. Not necessarily, as indicated by the inspiring story of Caroline Shaw’s “Partita for Eight Voices,” an exhilarating, sensual and playful work.

headline: Parts of a Pretzel Empire Are for Sale in Amish Country
abstract: The founders of Auntie Anne’s Inc. are auctioning property in Pennsylvania that includes 94 acres and a center that offers services to families.
lead_paragraph: GAP, Pa. — Since 1988, philanthropy and a highly successful brand of soft pretzel have combined to provide marriage counseling and other family services to this community in Lancaster County, some 55 miles west of Philadelphia.

headline: Swan Song Too Hawkish for Some
abstract: “The Wind Rises,” the newest animated film from the Japanese director Hayao Miyazaki, has received complaints because of its focus on the creation of a fighter used during World War II.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Wind Rises” is the type of art film that typically speeds into the Oscar race. Critics at film festivals have swooned over its nuance. It delivers messages about turbulent modern times by examining traumatic events of the past. The film’s 72-year-old director and writer, Hayao Miyazaki, a cinematic giant, has said the ambitious animated picture will be his last, a final bow.

headline: Profits at 21st Century Fox Hampered by TV Investments
abstract: The media company’s revenues surpassed Wall Street expectations, but profits were down in part because of the cost of starting two new channels.
lead_paragraph: Investments in new cable channels were a drag on 21st Century Fox’s third-quarter profits, but total revenues still surpassed analysts’ expectations.

headline: Putting Up With Evil, Then Getting a Princely Hand
abstract: Ib Andersen’s presentation of “Cinderella” for Ballet Arizona proves touching, funny and musical.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Few careers in ballet have shown a more remarkable trajectory than that of Ib Andersen. I remember him in 1979 in Copenhagen as a young star of the Royal Danish Ballet (he had been the youngest principal in its history), shining in several of the mid-19th-century classics by the Danish master August Bournonville. A year later Mr. Andersen was a principal of New York City Ballet, where he created roles in new ballets by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins.

headline: Blooming, Languishing, Reviving
abstract: “The Stone Roses: Made of Stone” looks at a British band with a future that went unfulfilled.
lead_paragraph: Most of the guys are in their 50s now, and 50 isn’t old for rock stars anymore. But most rock stars have not messed things up as thoroughly as the Stone Roses did roughly 20 years ago. One minute their debut album was being acclaimed as among the greatest ever; the next they were embroiled in a legal battle that delayed their follow-up album for five years. It flopped, and the group broke up.

headline: Philip Smith, Philharmonic’s Principal Trumpet, to Retire
abstract: Mr. Smith will retire from the New York Philharmonic at the end of this season after 36 years with the orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Philip Smith, the New York Philharmonic’s principal trumpet, announced on Tuesday that he would retire from the orchestra at the end of the 2013-14 season. He will have been a member of the orchestra for 36 years: he joined as co-principal trumpet in 1978, when Zubin Mehta, then the orchestra’s music director, hired him away from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He became the orchestra’s principal trumpet in 1988.

headline: The Making of an Immortal Movie
abstract: George Romero’s “Night of the Living Dead,” which brought zombies to the screen, is the subject of the documentary “Birth of the Living Dead.”
lead_paragraph: In 1967, George Romero, a Bronx-born 27-year-old transplanted to Pittsburgh, shot a cheap independent movie in rural Pennsylvania. The film, “Night of the Living Dead,” became a horror classic, spawning sequels and helping to inspire the vogue for zombies raging on television and in multiplexes. Rob Kuhns’s informative documentary “Birth of the Living Dead” recounts the risks, improvisation and innovation that went into the movie’s production.

headline: Alabama: Small Race Reflects G.O.P. Divide
abstract: Tuesday’s runoff election, to decide the Republican Party’s nominee for a seat in the House of Representatives from the first congressional district, is an anomaly.
lead_paragraph: The city of Atmore in southwestern Alabama typically takes a turn in the national spotlight when an inmate is executed at the state prison there.

headline: N.J. Exit Poll: Economy Weighs Heavily on Voters
abstract: New Jersey voters remain pessimistic about the state’s economic situation.
lead_paragraph: According to early results from exit polls conducted by Edison Research, the issue that mattered most to voters in the New Jersey race for governor was the economy, with half of all voters selecting it as the key issue for them. The economy was followed by taxes, which was selected by one out of every four voters.

headline: Romantic Comedy: Imbibe in Moderation
abstract: In “A Case of You,” a struggling writer remakes himself into the perfect match for the woman he has his eye on.
lead_paragraph: In Kat Coiro’s new film, “A Case of You,” the mildly neurotic Sam (Justin Long) is a struggling writer in Brooklyn making a living from movie novelizations, but he has a Serious Book inside him. Shamed for his bachelor status by his happily married and pregnant former classmate (Sienna Miller), Sam woos the mildly daffy coffeehouse clerk Birdie (Evan Rachel Wood, in a departure from her darker portraits), who is also a caricature artist in Prospect Park. To impress her, he studies her Facebook page and awkwardly pretends to share her interests, including cooking, Joan Baez, the guitar, Carlos Castaneda and ballroom dancing.

headline: Va. Exit Poll: Mixed on Candidates, Sour on Economy
abstract: In the tight Virginia governor’s race, exit polls found voters giving the candidates equal marks on ethics.
lead_paragraph: In the tight Virginia governor’s race, exit polls found voters giving the candidates equal marks on ethics.

headline: Meadham Kirchhoff’s Rule-Breaking Topshop Collection
abstract: The London-based label brings its whimsical designs — including shiny red platforms, frilly dresses and mohair sweaters — to the retail chain.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off a triumphant ready-to-wear presentation this spring — a typically demented, dazzling mash-up of Charles Addams and Leigh Bowery — the London-based fashion label Meadham Kirchhoff has put together a witty new collection for Topshop, which includes everything from a pair of glittery ruby platforms with marshmallow heels to frilly baby-doll dresses and mohair jumpers. It’s another spirited line from a design team that is determined to break the rules. “The industry has become dictatorial,” Edward Meadham says. “All we ask is that we can show our clothes exactly how we want to, exactly how it comes out of us. What people make of it after that is up to them.” Available Nov. 21.

headline: Eminem Grows Older, but Not Up
abstract: Eminem’s technique remains finely tuned, but on his latest release, “The Marshall Mathers LP 2,” his worldview remains focused on the same territory.
lead_paragraph: We have watched Eminem age, all of us, difficult as it has been. We’ve seen him lash out at his mother, his then-wife, and his fans. We’ve seen him soften ever so slightly under the weight of fatherhood. We’ve seen him court protest, then express befuddlement over the hubbub. We’ve seen him retreat into drugs, and then climb out of the morass.

headline: A Fantastical Shootout, Moving Across Space and Time
abstract: Call of Duty: Ghosts begins just before an attack on the United States by a South American alliance.
lead_paragraph: With a story ripped not from the headlines but seemingly from a strategy guide for the Parker Brothers board game Risk — control of a unified South America is the best possible starting point for global military domination — Call of Duty: Ghosts is the silliest entry in an increasingly silly series, even as it remains quite possibly the most lucrative one in video games.

headline: N.Y. Exit Poll: Ready for Change
abstract: New York City residents went to the polls today with contrary views of the current administration.
lead_paragraph: New York City residents went to the polls today with contrary views of the current administration. While they approve of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s performance, they are also looking for a change from his policies.

lead_paragraph: The Illinois House of Representatives voted Tuesday to allow same-sex couples to wed, ending months of delay over the issue in the Capitol and clearing the way for Illinois to become the 15th state, along with the District of Columbia, to permit gay couples to marry.

lead_paragraph: Banksy! is still in police custody — that is, the balloons that spell the British street artist’s name, as well as an exclamation point, are. And they may never get out.

headline: In Public Education, Edge Still Goes to Rich
abstract: Funding for many school districts comes from local property taxes, which skews the playing field between wealthy and poor students early on.
lead_paragraph: “There aren’t many things that are more important to that idea of economic mobility — the idea that you can make it if you try — than a good education,” President Obama told students at the State University of New York in Buffalo in August.

headline: Deceased Wife’s Foresight Helps Man Make Progress
abstract: Before Eugenio German’s wife died of cancer, she petitioned to make him eligible for citizenship so that he could secure a future for himself and their three children.
lead_paragraph: The year: 1990. The place: Canóvanas, Puerto Rico. Anita Villalongo was a Puerto Rican, with dramatic cheekbones and skin the color of caramel. Eugenio German was a Dominican, the irises of his eyes chocolate brown rimmed by a deep ocean blue. Eugenio sold ice cream from a pushcart. Anita left her building each day to buy a cone.

keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Shopping and Retail', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: In part to increase its allure to shoppers seeking luxury goods, Macy’s is pouring $400 million into a makeover of its flagship Herald Square store.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all of the iconic wooden escalators still clack up and down at the flagship Macy’s store in Manhattan, but customers entering the store during its $400 million makeover will find little else familiar — especially in the street level’s grand hall, studded with gleaming luxury goods showcases, high ceilings and shiny white marble floors.

abstract: A federal safety board faulted city and police officials and the parade organizers in Midland, Tex., for allowing a procession to take place without a permit or a written safety plan and without notifying the railroad.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Lax oversight by city officials and parade organizers that allowed a parade route to pass over a railroad crossing without proper safety precautions was the probable cause of a train collision that killed four veterans on a parade float last year in Midland, Tex., federal investigators announced Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Open warfare is breaking out among rival Republican groups, with one, Main Street Advocacy, set to start an ad campaign on Wednesday that blames conservative groups like the Tea Party for the recent series of political losses in critical elections across the United States.

headline: New Student Loan Rules Add Protections for Borrowers
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: One new rule is meant to expand use of an income-based repayment plan for those in default. Another permits oral requests for loan “forbearance.”
lead_paragraph: If you are a former student having trouble paying back college debt, you may be relieved to hear that the Education Department has created new rules that will bolster borrower protections for federal education loans.

headline: Chris Christie Coasts to 2nd Term as Governor of New Jersey
abstract: Governor Christie won decisively, making impressive inroads among younger voters, blacks, Hispanics and women – all groups that Republicans nationally have struggled to attract.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey won re-election by a crushing margin on Tuesday, a victory that vaulted him to the front ranks of Republican presidential contenders and made him his party’s foremost proponent of pragmatism over ideology.

headline: Chris Christie Re-elected Governor of New Jersey
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, a Republican, easily defeated his Democratic opponent, State Senator Barbara Buono.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey won re-election by a crushing margin on Tuesday, a victory that vaulted him to the front of the pack of Republican presidential contenders and made him his party’s foremost proponent of pragmatism over ideology.

headline: N.J. Exit Polls: Complete Results
abstract: Complete exit poll results from the New Jersey race for governor.

headline: N.J. Exit Poll: Christie Gained Among Key Groups
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie is heading toward a re-election victory that could fall just short of landslide proportions (usually defined as over 60 percent of the vote).
lead_paragraph: Early results suggested that Gov. Chris Christie was heading toward a re-election victory that could fall just short of landslide proportions (usually defined as over 60 percent of the vote). News organizations declared him the winner shortly after the polls closed.

headline: Nicholas S. G. Stern
abstract: Mr. Stern is the founder and principal of Stern Projects, a boutique construction management company focused largely on high-end residential projects in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Stern, 45, is the founder and principal of Stern Projects, a boutique construction management company focused largely on high-end residential projects in Manhattan. Before starting the company in 2010, he served as an executive vice president of Taconic Builders.

headline: Bloomberg, Champion of the Poor
abstract: Usually depicted as a champion of the rich, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg also started a bold antipoverty program.
lead_paragraph: DURING New York City’s mayoral race, criticism of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for neglecting the poor ignored his bold and unprecedented antipoverty measures. He may not have eliminated inequality or reversed the impact of the Great Recession — over the last two years, the poverty rate has crept up to 21.2 percent from 20.1 percent — but failure to acknowledge what he did in fact accomplish is not only unfair but also shortsighted. Usually depicted as a champion of the rich, Mr. Bloomberg mounted an antipoverty program at a moment when poverty as an issue was off the national radar and even politically toxic.

headline: Toronto’s Hot Mess
abstract: Thanks to its crack-smoking mayor, a city becomes a spectacle.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — JUST the other day, a definitive Toronto image was making the rounds on Twitter. One of the turnstiles in the subway system had broken and no guards were around, so passengers had left their tickets and change in a small pile on the side. I live in an absurdly law-abiding, rule-following city. There’s one major exception: the mayor. He smokes crack. He said so on Tuesday. Twice.

headline: In a Message to Poachers, U.S. Will Destroy Its Ivory
abstract: Six tons of illegal elephant ivory that the government has been stockpiling for three decades will be crushed and used in antipoaching memorials, officials announced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Fish and Wildlife Service will destroy six tons of illegal African elephant ivory next week that it has been stockpiling since the ’80s, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Va. Exit Poll: Many Find Republican ‘Too Conservative’
abstract: In the Virginia gubernatorial race pitting Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, a Republican, against Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, voters on balance said that Mr. Cuccinelli’s positions on the issues were “too conservative,” while Mr. McAuliffe’s were “about right.”
lead_paragraph: In the Virginia governor’s pitting Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, a Republican, against Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, voters on balance said that Mr. Cuccinelli’s positions on the issues were “too conservative,” while Mr. McAuliffe’s were “about right.”

headline: On Becoming China’s Farm Team
keywords: ['Pork', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'United States Economy', 'Pigs', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Smithfield-Shuanghui deal guarantees China the pork while offloading the downsides of pork production onto the United States.
lead_paragraph: Look at the $4.7 billion purchase in September of the pork producer Smithfield Foods by Shuanghui International Holdings Ltd. -- the Chinese firm that counts Goldman Sachs among its backers -- from the standpoint of the Chinese. As this century’s economic titan, they had to “take a position” in United States pork. China’s population of nearly 1.4 billion is not only growing rapidly but growing wealthier rapidly, and flattering us by emulating our consumption patterns (for better or worse) while having trouble replicating some of our production systems.

headline: Too Big to Breathe?
abstract: What good are all the benefits achieved in rapid economic growth if China becomes too polluted a place to live?
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — I arrived here on Oct. 19th and was greeted with this news: A combination of cold weather, lack of wind, coal-powered heating and farmers burning off post-harvest debris had created a perfect storm of pollution in the northeastern industrial city of Harbin, home to 10 million people. It was so bad that bus drivers were getting lost because the smog-enveloped roads would only permit them to see a few yards ahead. Harbin’s official website reportedly warned that “cars with headlights turned on were moving no faster than pedestrians and honking frequently as drivers struggled to see traffic lights meters away.”

headline: Obama Presses Case for Immigration Changes
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']

The leaders included Joe Echevarria, chief executive of Deloitte LLP; Marillyn A. Hewson, chief executive of Lockheed Martin; Stephen A. Schwarzman, chairman of Blackstone, and several others who had not previously played such prominent roles in supporting an immigration overhaul.

headline: Approving, and Suspending, a Dangerous Drug
abstract: The F.D.A. was right to suspend a leukemia drug while researchers try to identify which patients might be helped without serious risk of harm.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration made the appropriate call last week when it suspended sales of a promising leukemia drug for desperately ill patients that turned out to be unexpectedly dangerous. About 2,000 people have taken the drug to treat a relatively uncommon form of leukemia that kills about 600 Americans each year.

headline: Remember the Second Responders
abstract: The next mayoral administration should work with federal, state and local agencies to make day laborers part of official disaster plans.
lead_paragraph: Nobody knows what kind of large-scale disaster will next hit the New York City region, but you can be sure that after the initial chaos will come the mess. And as Hurricane Sandy taught us, some of the hardest and most dangerous jobs fell not to first responders — cops, firefighters or utility crews — but to homeowners and small contractors left to improvise the cleanup and demolition and to the thousands of day laborers who joined them.

lead_paragraph: China said Tuesday that it had sent its top envoy to North Korea this week to push for the resumption of talks on denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the envoy, Wu Dawei, arrived in Pyongyang on Monday amid signs that tensions on the peninsula had begun to ease. China was one of the backers of the so-called six-party talks that began in 2003 to work toward a solution of the nuclear issue. The talks broke down in 2008.

lead_paragraph: Editta Sherman, a free-spirited photographer who made portraits of celebrities, raised four children and lived for 61 years in an artist’s paradise — a studio penthouse above Carnegie Hall — until forced out in 2010 in an epic landlord-tenant struggle, died on Friday at her Manhattan home on Central Park South, only blocks from the hall. lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s government has found a trove of secret documents from the military dictatorship, which held power from 1976 to 1983. The discovery provides rare insight into the persecution of intellectual figures and efforts then to deal with inquiries into human rights abuses during the Dirty War, when as many as 30,000 people are thought to have been killed or disappeared.

headline: Nets’ Pride Restored as Consistency Is Rediscovered

abstract: Forcing the healthy to buy health insurance may not be an efficient way to run a health insurance marketplace, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Keep Telling Yourself, ‘This Workout Feels Good’
abstract: Verbal mantras like “feeling good” and “doing well” can stave off fatigue and improve exercise performance, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Tell yourself during exercise that you’re not as tired as you think you are and you could make that statement true, a new study shows, reminding us that the body intertwines with the mind in ways that we are only starting to understand.

headline: Bill de Blasio’s Victory Speech
abstract: Bill de Blasio delivered his victory speech at the Park Slope Armory on Tuesday night after winning the mayoral election.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio delivered his victory speech at the Park Slope Armory on Tuesday night after winning the mayoral election.

headline: Christie's Victory Speech
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie looked back at lessons from Hurricane Sandy and ahead to his second term, in which he promised big things for New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie looked back at lessons from Hurricane Sandy and ahead to his second term, in which he promised big things for New Jersey.

headline: De Blasio’s Victory Speech
abstract: The prepared text of Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio’s victory speech.
lead_paragraph: Following is the prepared text of Bill de Blasio’s victory speech at the Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn.

headline: Plan to Raise Judges’ Retirement Age to 80 Is Rejected
abstract: Had the measure passed, it would have limited the ability of the governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, to shape the state’s highest court.
lead_paragraph: An amendment to the New York State Constitution raising the mandatory retirement age to 80 for judges on the Supreme Court and on the Court of Appeals went down in defeat in a referendum on Tuesday, handing Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman a stinging rebuke.

headline: Votes on Fracking Limits Show Mixed Results
abstract: Unofficial results showed three of four communities in Colorado voting to restrict fracking, while only one of three Ohio communities voted for the limits.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The national debate over hydraulic fracturing and oil and gas drilling found its way to ballots on Tuesday in several communities in Ohio and Colorado, where voters considered proposals to ban or restrict fracking.

headline: Cuccinelli Concedes Defeat in Virginia
abstract: Republican candidate Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II lost the race for governor of Virginia, but said his strong showing is a sign of dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Republican candidate Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II lost the race for governor of Virginia, but said his strong showing is a sign of dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Two New York Counties Re-elect G.O.P. Executives
abstract: The Republican incumbent in Westchester, Rob Astorino, defeated his Democratic challenger, and Edward P. Mangano won in Nassau.
lead_paragraph: Two of the wealthiest counties in the nation, both with voters worried about property tax increases, decided in Tuesday’s elections to stick with Republican county executives who held the line on taxes, keeping Rob Astorino in Westchester and Edward P. Mangano in Nassau.

headline: New Chinese Drone Unveiled in Video
abstract: The body of the new drone resembles that of the United States’ Global Hawk.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Internet lit up with an annotated video, above, of what appears to be China’s latest (or at least most recently unveiled) drone design.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 47TH ANNUAL CMA AWARDS Carrie Underwood and Brad Paisley (below) return as hosts of this ceremony, billed as “country music’s biggest night” and broadcast live from the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Kenny Rogers, a five-time Country Music Association Award winner and recent Country Music Hall of Fame inductee, will be honored with the Willie Nelson Lifetime Achievement Award and a tribute by Jennifer Nettles, Rascal Flatts and Darius Rucker. Taylor Swift will receive the Pinnacle Award, which recognizes an artist who has made a positive impact on the appreciation of country music. Ms. Swift will take the stage with Vince Gill and Alison Krauss, the Zac Brown Band will perform with Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, and Hunter Hayes will team up with Jason Mraz. And Jason Aldean, Luke Bryan, Blake Shelton, Ms. Swift and George Strait will compete for the evening’s top honor, entertainer of the year. “CMA Awards Red Carpet Live,” at 7 on Great American Country, features interviews with artists and nominees as they arrive.

headline: Decisions From Alabama to Boston, and Virginia to Detroit
abstract: Voters chose winners in races for mayor, governor and the Republican nomination for a vacant seat in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Voters chose winners in races for mayor, governor and the Republican nomination for a vacant seat in Congress.

headline: Terry McAullife’s Victory Speech
abstract: Mr. McAullife, a former fundraiser for the Democratic Party, narrowly defeated his socially conservative, Republican opponent.
lead_paragraph: Mr. McAullife, a former fundraiser for the Democratic Party, narrowly defeated his socially conservative, Republican opponent.

headline: News Quiz | November 6, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Milestones: Bill de Blasio
abstract: Bill de Blasio, who was elected to become the first Democratic mayor of New York City in 20 years, will have a far grander stage on which to test the liberal worldview that has been the hallmark of his career.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, who was elected to become the first Democratic mayor of New York City in 20 years, will have a far grander stage on which to test the liberal worldview that has been the hallmark of his career.

headline:
Profit Is Up 70% at Toyota,
Close to Its Old Milestone
abstract: The company expects to make $16.9 billion in a comeback from tough years that included huge recalls and a devastating earthquake and tsunami.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In 2008, Toyota Motor was at giddy heights. Profit soared to a record high. The Japanese company knocked General Motors off its perch as the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Animal Protection Remains Elusive in China
abstract: Amid reports of organized dog fighting in China and other, routine, animal abuses, grass-roots pressure is growing for an animal welfare law. But rights activists say officials fail to understand the need.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Guo breeds pit bulls and other potential fighting dogs. He’s guarded about what he does. Pit bulls are illegal in much of Beijing, as are 40 other breeds deemed “vicious and large” by the police, including the Dalmatian, collie and Weimaraner, and some valued in other countries as guide dogs.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 6, 2013
abstract: Can you calculate the estimated total value of Verizon Wireless, if given the amount paid for 45 percent of it?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Israeli Court Clears Former Foreign Minister of Fraud Charges
abstract: The acquittal opens the way for Avigdor Lieberman, a political powerhouse in Israel, to be reinstated as foreign minister by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Avigdor Lieberman, the former Israeli foreign minister who is among the nation’s most powerful and polarizing politicians, was acquitted Wednesday of corruption charges that have dogged him for more than a decade, a verdict with profound implications for Israel’s internal politics and its peace talks with the Palestinians.

headline: The Coach Who Exploded
abstract: Since Mike Rice’s promising career was derailed by the highlight reel from hell, there’s nothing he won’t do to prove he can get his competitive fire under control.
lead_paragraph: Mike Rice is coaching again. Or rather, he’s running after-school clinics for third-to-sixth graders at a vast, four-court indoor basketball facility in Neptune, N.J., where he also works out local high-school players on Friday afternoons and coaches his son’s high-school team in a fall recreational league.

headline: King of the New York Streets
abstract: Neal Boenzi, one of The Times’s storied staff photographers, surrendered a trove of photos to be organized for a new exhibit, showcasing the career he made with his index finger.
lead_paragraph: Neal Boenzi has an eye for quality, picking up deals on antique beer taps and neon signs at Southern California swap meets. His friends have no idea that the gravelly voiced East Coast retiree once used that eye to make some of the greatest New York City newspaper photographs for much of the latter half of the 20th century.

headline: Samsung’s Investment Plan Falls Short for Some
abstract: Samsung Electronics said it would double its dividend and increase spending on acquisitions, but some investors grumbled that the company was still being stingy with its cash.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Samsung Electronics, the world’s biggest smartphone maker, summoned investors to a luxury hotel here Wednesday to tell them why they should buy its stock. Despite a promise of more cash and other goodies, some investors left grumbling that it was not enough.

headline: Is It an Unaffordable Luxury to Major in the Humanities in College?
abstract: Do you think the main role of college is to make students ready for the job market? If so, why? If not, why not?
lead_paragraph: What do you plan to study in college? Why? How much do you think your choice will be based on preparing yourself for the job market, and how much will be about following an intellectual passion? Why?

headline: Notes From Egypt’s Show Trial
abstract: Whatever justice comes from Mohamed Morsi’s trial will be partial at best.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — DURING a court recess on Monday, I approached the floor-to-ceiling, webbed-metal cage confining Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president of Egypt, and seven other defendants.

headline: New York Today: Meet Your Mayor
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: Up close and personal with Bill de Blasio, slightly warmer weather and a play about Anthony Weiner’s fall.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:20 p.m. | The city woke today to a new mayor, Bill de Blasio, who won in a landslide.

headline: Wheelies: The High-Roller Thriftmaster Edition
abstract: Icon, the custom truck builder, releases its $250,000 classic Chevy pickup at SEMA; Nissan and Mitsubishi will build a car together.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

headline: Slow Dancing With Part D
abstract: Daunted by the plans’ complexity, very few Medicare beneficiaries bother to change their Part D enrollment — although perhaps they should.
lead_paragraph: With the open enrollment period for switching Medicare Part D drug plans upon us, the Kaiser Family Foundation has released two reports that both question the design of the plans and the inattention of 23 million of us who have them.

headline: When ‘Do No Harm’ Hurts
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The insistence that aid should “do no harm” too often obscures the fact that conflicts are also fueled by the lack of assistance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — IT’S increasingly clear that humanitarian assistance to rebel-held areas of Syria is being impeded by a fear — shared by the United States, the European Commission and many nongovernmental organizations — that food, medicine and other supplies might fall into the hands of terrorists.

headline: China Bids for 2022 Winter Olympic Games
abstract: One expected obstacle to China’s ambition to hold the Games in Beijing and Zhangjiakou, about 110 miles northwest of the capital, is air pollution.
lead_paragraph: Beijing and Zhangjiakou, a city about 110 miles, or 180 kilometers, northwest of the Chinese capital, are bidding to jointly host the 2022 Winter Olympic Games, the Chinese Olympic Committee has announced.

headline: Investors Cool to 2 Chinese Bank Offerings
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Investors were concerned about how China’s financial system would cope with a potential deluge of bad debt that could swamp the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Two Chinese banks that sold nearly $2 billion worth of shares in Hong Kong stock market listings received lukewarm receptions on Wednesday from investors concerned about how China’s financial system would cope with a potential deluge of bad debt that could swamp the country’s economy.

headline: A Small Business Starts to Navigate the Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: In my renewal package, I found two crucial pieces of information that I never would have had without the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I took a phone call from Maggie, my health insurance broker. “I’m calling my clients who are getting big increases this year,” she said. “I didn’t want to just send an email.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The New Mayor of New York City
abstract: What are the issues he ran on in this mayoral campaign?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Heading to City Hall, Bill de Blasio Is Used to Exceeding Expectations,” Javier C. Hernández writes about this man in the news.

headline: A Train Too Far
abstract: Istanbul’s grand new metro system is a ticket into the unknown.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Last Tuesday the city celebrated the 90th anniversary of Turkey’s founding with unusual pomp. Senior politicians cut the ribbon on a spectacular new metro system that runs some 200 feet below the Sea of Marmara and can carry 1.5 million people every day between the European and Asian sides of the city.

headline: Cisco Counters Its Young Competitors in Data Networking
abstract: The computer networking giant announced its long-awaited plan to combat upstarts, with an “application-centric infrastructure” that it says can be up to 93 percent cheaper than competitors.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems has announced its big play for the future of data networking, a multibillion-dollar business that holds the Internet together. It’s comprehensive, probably compelling for people who already own lots of Cisco equipment (which is most large companies that operate networks), and for Cisco at least, expensive.

headline: Blurring Art, Artifice and Pop Culture
abstract: In her new album, “Artpop,” Lady Gaga drops in references to the artists Jeff Koons, and more indirectly, Botticelli, a sign of her quest for validation from the visual arts world.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga the relentless is back in full force on “Artpop” (Streamline/Interscope), her third full-length studio album of new songs. It took hip surgery, for injuries that she had aggravated onstage, to knock her off her tour and sideline her from media exposure for a few months earlier this year. But in summer the next push began with a single, “Applause,” that simultaneously reaffirmed her need for the love of her audience and announced her new pivot to align herself with the (visual) art world, singing, “Pop culture was in art, now art’s in pop culture, in me.”

headline: Daily Report: Samsung Promises to Double Its Dividend
abstract: At a meeting with investors in Seoul on Wednesday, executives from Samsung Electronics laid out their vision for the company’s future, saying they would fine-tune a strategy that has helped the company become the world’s biggest smartphone maker.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting with investors in Seoul on Wednesday, executives from Samsung Electronics laid out their vision for the company’s future, saying they would fine-tune a strategy that has helped the company become the world’s biggest smartphone maker, Eric Pfanner reports. Samsung’s one-third share of the global smartphone business is more than double the volume of its nearest competitor, Apple.

headline: An Unofficial Barista at Starbucks
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A loud woman appointed herself the unofficial announcer to customers that their Starbucks orders were ready.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The European Central Bank’s Inflation Conundrum
abstract: Ahead of the bank’s meeting on Thursday, debate is heating up over whether a sharp drop in inflation is a sign of health — or impending stagnation.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank will meet on Thursday under renewed pressure to do more to stimulate the Continent’s sluggish economies, as evidence grows that the recovery is failing to pick up speed and that inflation has fallen so low as to become worrisome.

headline: Battle Over ValueVision Set to Heat Up
abstract: The move by the activist hedge fund Clinton Group to try to oust senior executives at the Internet and shopping network is poised to become a bitter battle.
lead_paragraph: The move by the activist hedge fund Clinton Group to try to oust senior executives at the Internet and shopping network ValueVision Media is poised to become a bitter battle.

headline: New York: De Blasio to Meet With Bloomberg
abstract: Fresh off his overwhelming victory in the mayoral election, Bill de Blasio planned to meet with Michael R. Bloomberg in the morning, and then will hold a new conference later in the day.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off his overwhelming victory in Tuesday’s mayoral election, Bill de Blasio planned to meet on Wednesday morning with the man who has run the city for the last 12 years, Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Helen Caldicott, Chernobyl and the New York Academy of Sciences
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Radiation', 'Thyroid Cancer']
abstract: A closer look at a claim of a million deaths from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster.
lead_paragraph: Helen Caldicott, a physician who for decades has fought nuclear power, wrote a letter to The Times criticizing David Ropeik‘s recent Op-Ed article on outsize fears of radiation. Caldicott’s letter contained a mischaracterization of a much-criticized Russian study that attributed a million deaths to the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, calling it a “New York Academy of Sciences report.” I contacted academy staff to get the organization’s view. Here’s the result:

headline: Carlyle Reports Lower Earnings for Third Quarter
abstract: For the private equity giant Carlyle Group, the quarter was a relatively slow one when it came to “exits,” industry parlance for realizing gains on investments.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:02 a.m. | The private equity giant Carlyle Group reported lower third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, amid a slow period in selling its investments.

headline: On Beauty | Bare Is Beautiful
abstract: Less can be more when it comes to makeup, but mastering the natural look does take some work.
lead_paragraph: A face without makeup looks wholesome and shows confidence — but doesn’t come without effort.

headline: Shrinking Numbers and Growing Persecution Threaten Sikhs and Hindus in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Children and Childhood', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Hinduism', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Most Hindus and Sikhs in Afghanistan are anxious about their prospects after American troops withdraw from the country at the end of 2014.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — J.K. Sharma, a large Sikh man in a black turban, works out of a small room lined with jars and herbs in the ruined and dusty Shor Bazaar in Kabul. In a war-ravaged country where miracles are in short supply, Mr. Sharma makes a living as a magician, providing advice and talismans to Muslim Afghans for a fee.

headline: If Only… Grazed Grasslands Could Sop Up All Industrial CO2
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Grass', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Livestock', 'Ranches']
abstract: A popular talk on how livestock grazing can stop global warming gets a tough scrub.
lead_paragraph: There’s a very helpful post on the RealClimate blog critiquing the appealing, virally shared, and largely wishful climate change strategy that Allan Savory laid out in a popular TED talk not long ago. Savory — a biologist, farmer and environmentalist and more — claimed that certain approaches to managing grazed grasslands could more than absorb all of the carbon dioxide we’re adding to the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels.

headline: Despite Fumbles, Obama Defends Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As Democrats get jittery over the troubled rollout of the health care law, President Obama traveled to Texas to defend it, in the largest state to refuse to participate.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — President Obama strongly defended his signature health care law on Wednesday in the largest state that has refused to participate, as rattled Senate Democrats called for changing or delaying key parts of the new health coverage.

headline: The Vespa 946: A Scooter for the Wealthy
abstract: With the introduction of its $9,946 Vespa 946, Piaggio has moved its famous scooters further than ever from their proletarian roots.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever come across a $10,000 scooter? Well, meet the 946, Vespa’s newest and most expensive model. With swooping lines and a big red leather-textured seat, it neatly epitomizes the Italian brand’s gradual transformation from maker of inexpensive transportation for the masses to purveyor of two-wheeled fashion accessories.

headline: A Meaningful Minute
abstract: “The Silver Button,” by the Australian artist and illustrator Bob Graham, shows the range of activity in a city over the course of a mere minute.
lead_paragraph: At 9:59 in the morning, in a seaside city somewhere, a little girl named Jodie is about to draw the final silver button on her picture of an elegantly dressed duck. She pauses for a minute to consider her work. That short span of time is all it takes for Jonathan, her baby brother, to take his first steps. And throughout the multiracial, multiethnic town, other important things happen in that same time frame. An ambulance speeds past, a soldier says goodbye to his mother, a grandfather plays a funny game of leaf houses with his granddaughter. A homeless woman pushes her belongings down the street in a grocery cart. A baby is born, and two friends, Belle and Vashti, pop seaweed on the beach.

headline: Lawyers Challenge Detention of Greenwald’s Partner in London
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Lawyers for David Michael Miranda, the partner of the journalist Glenn Greenwald, who has been writing about secret N.S.A. documents, said Mr. Miranda’s rights were violated.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In London’s High Court on Wednesday, lawyers challenged the legality of the temporary detention of David Michael Miranda, the partner of Glenn Greenwald, a journalist who has been writing about the secret documents taken by a former analyst for the National Security Agency, Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Sebelius Rejects Delays to Get Time to Repair Problems at Health Site
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The secretary of health and human services said there were hundreds of problems with the Affordable Care Act’s website, but she rejected calls to delay the law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Wednesday that the government needed to fix hundreds of problems with the website for the federal health insurance marketplace, but she categorically rejected bipartisan calls to delay parts of the new health care law.

headline: New York: Voter Turnout Appears to Be Record Low
abstract: A predicted landslide seemed to discourage many New Yorkers from voting in the mayor’s race.
lead_paragraph: Turnout in Tuesday’s election for New York City mayor appeared to have set a record low of 24 percent of registered voters.

headline: India Gives Foreign Banks New Door Into Local Market
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The regulations give access, but only through locally incorporated subsidiaries and only from countries that also allow in Indian banks.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — India’s central bank unveiled late Wednesday a far-reaching set of regulations to allow foreign banks into the country’s long-protected domestic market. But it demanded that they do so through subsidiaries incorporated in India and said that eligibility would be limited to banks from countries that reciprocate by letting in Indian banks.

headline: Neal Boenzi, Photographer
abstract: The art of the street photograph as told by Neal Boenzi, who has been recently celebrated as one of the most inventive masters of the form.
lead_paragraph: The art of the street photograph as told by Neal Boenzi, who has been recently celebrated as one of the most inventive masters of the form.

headline: Performing on the Paris Metro
abstract: Each year, thousands of musicians from around the world audition to earn a license to play on the Paris Metro.
lead_paragraph: Each year, thousands of musicians from around the world audition to earn a license to play on the Paris Metro.

headline: Pointless Political Punditry
abstract: Software is the issue — not entrails.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been a fan of the entrail reading that follows off-year elections, in which observers try to read great significance into details of the voting patterns. Partly that’s because nobody really knows how to do this; partly it’s because stuff happens, and the political environment a year or three years from now is going to be very different.

headline: In Our Pages: November 7
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1913 Olympia Auto Show

headline: North Atlantic Fiscal Policy
abstract: Bad here, worse there.
lead_paragraph: The economic crisis of 2008 was, as I like to say, a North Atlantic affair. There were monstrous housing bubbles in both America and Europe, rising household debt on both sides, and then more or less comparable busts in both places. Ours was more exotic, involving fancy instruments nobody understood, where theirs involved more plain-vanilla banking excess. But overall things weren’t that different.

headline: Reader Idea | Researching Political History to Understand How a Community Problem Was Solved
abstract: In this Reader Idea, students conduct research on the housing crisis in the South Bronx, its causes and proposed government solutions. Then they meet with and interview government leaders who tried to address the issues, along with residents who lived through the crisis. Next, students produce a video documenting their research.
lead_paragraph: With New York City electing Bill de Blasio as its new mayor, we thought it was a fitting time to publish this Reader Idea, from the coordinator for educational programs at the LaGuardia and Wagner Archives, part of LaGuardia Community College in Queens.

headline: Released From Prison, and Starting a Company
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Small Business']
abstract: Frederick Hutson served time for marijuana distribution. His company, Pigeonly, offers prison inmates and efficient way to receive photos from loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Like most entrepreneurs, Frederick Hutson cannot resist trying to solve a thorny problem. His company, Pigeonly, based in Las Vegas, taps an underserved and “captive” market by offering prison inmates an easy and efficient way to receive photos from loved ones and to make phone calls to them inexpensively. “Isolation is the worst thing for an inmate,” Mr. Hutson said. “It makes it hard for him to rebuild his life when he gets out.”

headline: Remembering Editta Sherman, Duchess of Carnegie Hall
abstract: Friends and relatives gathered on Tuesday to celebrate the life of Editta Sherman, the 101-year-old portrait photographer who died on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Someone had gotten a large black hat made of flowers and displayed it with a jaunty tilt – just the way Editta Sherman wore hers — next to the coffin, as if to set a “Let’s Party!” tone for the wake and funeral of Ms. Sherman, the 101-year-old portrait photographer who was known as the Duchess of Carnegie Hall.

headline: Backstage Nerves Through the Ages
abstract: Terrence McNally’s new play, “And Away We Go,” is a time-traveling backstage drama.
lead_paragraph: The theater is like an old Jewish mother in a Woody Allen film: always melodramatically, nonsensically on the verge of death. The cause of the affliction, however, varies. Some say ticket prices. Others blame those miserable critics. Television and the Internet are occasionally villains in this drama. But for a historically minded set, a crucial data point in this tragedy is the decline of the repertory, a resident company of actors of the sort that, say, Shakespeare used at the Globe.

headline: Qatari Court Orders Temporary Release of American Couple
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Eating Disorders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The couple, Matthew and Grace Huang, are accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death, but they say the girl had been struggling with an underlying eating disorder.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — A court in the wealthy Persian Gulf emirate of Qatar on Wednesday ordered the temporary release of Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death, a family member said after the hearing.

headline: SAC Capital Cuts a Deal
abstract: The hedge fund’s top guy gets off easy.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, was the target of a decade-long insider trading investigation. Six former SAC traders pleaded guilty and two others, who have denied the charges, have been indicted. Now the investigation has led to a deal that calls for SAC to plead guilty to criminal insider trading charges, and to pay a fine of $1.2 billion.

headline: Podesta Starting a Think Tank on Inequality
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Research', 'Think Tanks', 'United States Economy']
abstract: John Podesta, a former Clinton chief of staff and Obama adviser, will be joined by the economists J. Bradford DeLong and Heather Boushey at what he is calling the Washington Center for Equitable Growth.
lead_paragraph: John Podesta, a longtime adviser to Bill and Hillary Clinton and President Obama, is starting a research center in Washington to investigate the causes and effects of growing economic inequality.

headline: Knicks Trying to Find Themselves, or Anybody at All, on Defense
abstract: The Knicks made just about every defensive error a team could make in their loss Tuesday to Charlotte, and there appears to be no quick fix for their problems.
lead_paragraph: Missed assignments, blown rotations, wild closeouts and a general lack of communication and purpose — the Knicks made just about every defensive error a team could make in their 102-97 loss Tuesday to the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: After de Blasio’s Big Victory, Even Bigger Challenges
abstract: When Bill de Blasio succeeds Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, he will be tested immediately by some tough issues, including concerns about working with Albany, unions and crime.
lead_paragraph: He pledged to remake New York’s social fabric, stoked the hopes of discouraged liberals and vowed that a city defined by its luxuries would once again be a comfortable home for those with money struggles and the poor.

headline: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 1
keywords: ['Genealogy', 'Archives and Records', 'Baby Boomers', 'Families and Family Life', 'Slavery', 'States (US)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist, answers questions about how to use online sources, physical public records and the DNA of living relatives.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers’ questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members.

headline: Health Care Deal Is Latest to Seek Corporate Tax Shelter Abroad
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Endo Health’s proposed acquisition of Paladin Labs is the latest so-called inversion, and comes amid a flurry of mergers intended to extract American companies from federal taxes.
lead_paragraph: Corporate inversions keep coming as American companies seek ways to avoid paying high taxes.

headline: The Revenge of Donorism
abstract: Ken Cuccinelli’s defeat and the challenges facing Republican populists.
lead_paragraph: There were plenty of reasons for Ken Cuccinelli’s defeat last night in Virginia at the well-greased hands of Terry McAuliffe, but because the race turned out to be so surprisingly close we’re going to hear a lot about the money: McAuliffe (of course) had it, Cuccinelli did not, the national Republican Party did not exactly go all-in on his behalf, and so the campaign ended up being defined, and possibly won, by a Democratic advertising blitz that the G.O.P. barely countered.

headline: Today in Small Business: Working Weekends
abstract: Why start-ups run out of money. How a chocolate company built a community through social media. Business tactics you can learn from Disney villains.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Nikki Finke Leaves Deadline Hollywood
abstract: The influential blogger announced she was parting ways with Jay Penske, who bought the site Deadline.com from her in 2009.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of squabbling, the Hollywood blogger Nikki Finke has parted ways with Jay Penske, the media entrepreneur who in 2009 bought her high-octane industry website Deadline.com.

headline: Image of the Day: November 6
abstract: Prices of essential vegetables like onions have skyrocketed in recent months.

headline: Treating the Village to Cure the Disease
abstract: Can administering drugs to entire populations, whether they are sick or not, stop a parasitic disease that affects millions? Evidence is showing that the strategy works.
lead_paragraph: In communities across Africa, health workers are going house to house with medicine to combat lymphatic filariasis, or L.F., which is the world’s second-largest cause of chronic disability. They make sure the children are old enough, the women aren’t pregnant and no one is seriously ill. Then people take two pills while the health worker watches. She writes down their names in her ledger.

headline: It’s a ‘Captive’ Market. But Is It Big Enough?
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Photography', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Small Business']
abstract: At a San Francisco accelerator, Mr. Hutson, a former prison inmate, found skepticism about the market he wanted to reach. But his mentors came around.
lead_paragraph: Like most entrepreneurs, Frederick Hutson cannot resist trying to solve a thorny problem. As Donna Fenn explains in an article we have just published, his company, Pigeonly, which is based in Las Vegas, taps an under-served and “captive” market by offering prison inmates an easy way to receive photos from loved ones and to make phone calls to them inexpensively. “Isolation is the worst thing for an inmate,” Mr. Hutson said. “It makes it hard for him to rebuild his life when he gets out.”

headline: Classical Playlist: Jan Lisiecki, Mitsuko Uchida, Stile Antico and More
abstract: Times critics share what they are listening to this week.
lead_paragraph: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: An Argument for Federal Involvement in Housing
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: There’s an argument to be made that preserving the government’s role in the mortgage market will make it safer and more efficient than reforms will.
lead_paragraph: Obamacare’s early problems could recast the debate about a mortgage market overhaul.

headline: Marcella Cooks
abstract: Mark Bittman cooking with Marcella and Victor Hazan at their home in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman cooking with Marcella and Victor Hazan at their home in Florida.

headline: Remembering Marcella
abstract: The woman who taught us how to cook Italian food.
lead_paragraph: Marcella Hazan, who died Sept. 29 at the age of 89, never intended to bring real Italian cooking to America. But no matter how accidental her impact, it can hardly be overstated. What Alice Waters did for restaurants, Hazan did for home cooks, demonstrating that the simple treatment of decent ingredients leads to wonderful dishes.

headline: Amid Capitol Turmoil, Postal Crisis Drags On
abstract: The slowly paced overhaul of the Postal Service, which has lost about $41 billion since 2007, has frustrated unions, customers and lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early 2009, John E. Potter, then the postmaster general, delivered a dire warning to Congress: The United States Postal Service would run out of money unless lawmakers stepped in and passed legislation to help the agency stabilize its finances.

headline: Chandler’s Leg Fracture Leaves Knicks Thin in the Post
abstract: The Knicks, already struggling on defense, face another obstacle without center Tyson Chandler, who is expected to miss four to six weeks but is not expected to need surgery.
lead_paragraph: Even after 12 seasons in the N.B.A., Tyson Chandler wanted to improve his game over the summer. So he went to work on a short jump shot that he felt could stretch defenses and bolster the Knicks’ offense. The team considered it a bonus — a way for the 7-foot-1 Chandler to supplement his considerable responsibilities anchoring the post. But that was Chandler, searching for solutions where no problems existed.

headline: U.S. Investors Brush Aside Fears About Chinese Internet Companies
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: The interest in stateside I.P.O.’s of Chinese Internet companies is a striking contrast with the recent past, when accounting scams and poor governance prompted many to shun Chinese stocks.
lead_paragraph: For American investors, love of technology has conquered a fear of China.

headline: A Better Night’s Sleep for a Slimmer Christie
abstract: Fresh off his re-election, Gov. Chris Christie said his lap-band surgery had reduced his appetite and improved how he sleeps.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AMBOY, N.J. — While Gov. Chris Christie celebrated a big public victory in New Jersey on Tuesday, he has also been privately enjoying another success: better sleep, as a result of his weight loss.

headline: Homes for $750,000
abstract: Homes in Chicago, Georgia and Newport, R.I.
lead_paragraph: Homes in Chicago, Georgia and Newport, R.I.

headline: What You Get for $750,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a condo in Chicago, a 1910 house in suburban Atlanta and a Colonial in Newport, R.I.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO

headline: The Passion of Solomon Northup
abstract: What matters is not the veracity of every detail in “12 Years a Slave,” but its emotional truth.
lead_paragraph: Critics are already hailing the film adaption of Solomon Northup’s slave narrative, “12 Years a Slave,” as a shoo-in for the Academy Award nominations. But many viewers will likely wonder, given that this is a big-budget film with big-budget actors, how faithful it is to the book. The stakes may seem particularly high for a slave narrative, since many likely believe these books offer an unfiltered view of slavery.

headline: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Relive the ’70s
abstract: “Disaster!,” a musical at the St. Luke’s Theater, trawls through plotlines and characters from 1970s movies like “The Poseidon Adventure” as well as ’70s pop music.
lead_paragraph: Those gloriously cheesy 1970s movies in which fistfuls of C-list celebrities face wholesale slaughter at the hands of unnatural acts of nature are lampooned in the new musical “Disaster!” at the St. Luke’s Theater.

headline: Time Warner’s Profit Rises, Lifted by TV
abstract: Earnings were $1.2 billion in the third quarter, an increase of 44 percent compared with a year ago, reflecting growth in its television networks and production of TV shows.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner reported mostly upbeat earnings on Wednesday, and television was the biggest reason.

headline: A Larger Place in Park Slope, This Time Ours
abstract: Andrea Wolinetz and Alexis Placzek decided it was time to buy.
lead_paragraph: The small duplex on West 69th Street had been handed down to Andrea Wolinetz and Alexis Placzek by friends. During their three years there, the $2,050-a-month rent had risen to $2,300 — still a steal, but “not the same sort of steal,” Ms. Placzek said.

headline: Library Exhibition to Celebrate the Beatles’ Time in New York
abstract: The New York Public Library and the Grammy Museum will present a multimedia exhibition, “Ladies and Gentlemen … The Beatles!” in February.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first visit to New York, and the “Ed Sullivan Show” appearances that lit the fuse on Beatlemania in America, the New York Public Library and the Grammy Museum are collaborating on a multimedia exhibition, “Ladies and Gentlemen … The Beatles!”

headline: Justices Weigh Constitutionality of New York Town’s Prayers
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The Supreme Court questioned lawyers about whether the Town of Greece, N.Y., violated the Constitution in opening board meetings with mostly Christian prayers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which begins its sessions with an invocation to God, considered on Wednesday whether a town in upstate New York had crossed a constitutional line in opening its Town Board meetings with mostly Christian prayers. The justices seemed to find the issue unusually difficult, with several of them suggesting there was no satisfactory principled answer.

headline: Children Eat More After Sleeping Less
abstract: Children who get do not sleep enough may be increasing their risk for obesity, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Children who do not sleep enough may be increasing their risk for obesity, according to a new study.

headline: Beneath Martinique’s Beauty, Guided by a Poet
abstract: On the 100th anniversary of Aimé Césaire’s birth, the author explores the poet and politician’s homeland and its history.
lead_paragraph: As the stories poured out, eyes sparkled, smiles widened, hands danced. Everyone I met on Martinique harbored at least one intimate memory of Aimé Césaire — a quiet encounter or speech etched forever in their consciousness — but they all agreed: this poet, playwright and politician, who achieved an almost monumental status on the Caribbean island, was the most humble man they had ever known.

headline: Exploring Aimé Césaire’s Martinique
abstract: Scenes from the Caribbean island on the 100th anniversary of the poet and politician’s birth.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Caribbean island on the 100th anniversary of the poet and politician’s birth.

headline: Beyond Orlando’s Theme Parks, a Beer Culture Grows
abstract: Move over Disney and Universal: The number of breweries and craft beer bars in the Orlando area has more than doubled over the past five years.
lead_paragraph: Craft beer is usually not what comes to mind when thinking about Orlando. Walt Disney World, Universal Studios or another splashy theme park, yes, but not beer. Today, however, this landlocked central Florida city is getting a reputation for its growing craft beer scene. In the past few years, locals in the Orlando area have opened bars offering a wide selection of beers from small producers, and some are even opening spots that serve ales brewed in house.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Monaco in Philadelphia
abstract: The 11-story Monaco, which opened just over a year ago, is a  colorful and affordable addition to the city’s downtown.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Nietzsche and Wagner’s Greatest Hits, and Naughty Bits
abstract: In “Tragedy of a Friendship,” Jan Fabre creates a mash-up of Wagner operas, based on his friendship with Nietzsche.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — When Nietzsche and Wagner first met in 1868, the philosopher, more than 30 years Wagner’s junior, found a father figure. Wagner got an acolyte and mouthpiece.

headline: Russians Meet With an Uncle of Assad in an Effort to Jump-Start Peace Talks
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Rifaat al-Assad, an uncle of President Bashar al-Assad, was forced out of the country in 1984 after attempting to lead a coup.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As American diplomacy on the war in Syria flounders, unable to deliver the main exile opposition group to proposed peace talks, Russian officials on Wednesday stepped up their efforts to promote alternate opposition figures, meeting in Geneva with Rifaat al-Assad, an uncle of President Bashar al-Assad who was forced out of the country in 1984 after attempting to lead a coup.

headline: Why Twitter May Have to Pay Income Taxes One Day
abstract: Twitter has been losing money, allowing it to legally avoid paying corporate income taxes. But it may have to start paying taxes sooner rather than later, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Potential investors in Twitters’s planned initial public offering may be struggling to estimate how much the company will have to pay in taxes in the future. An article in Politico on Friday highlighted some of the techniques Twitter might use to legally avoid taxes.

headline: Baby’s Gaze May Signal Autism, a Study Finds
abstract: Researchers using eye-tracking technology found that 3-year-olds diagnosed with autism looked less at people’s eyes when they were babies than children who did not develop autism.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:11 a.m. | When and how long a baby looks at other people’s eyes offers the earliest behavioral sign to date of whether a child is likely to develop autism, scientists are reporting.

headline: Internet Kills the Video Store
abstract: The video-rental chain Blockbuster will close the 300 stores that it still has in the next two months, said the company’s owner, Dish Network.
lead_paragraph: Blockbuster, which had more than 9,000 retail stores across America just nine years ago, is closing the few hundred video-rental stores that it still has, the company’s owner, Dish Network, said on Wednesday in a bittersweet but long-expected announcement.

headline: House Hunting in Central Barcelona
abstract: Despite Spain’s punishing market, luxury properties like this one near Gaudí‘s Park Güell are showing some resilience.
lead_paragraph: Despite Spain’s punishing market, luxury properties like this one near Gaudí‘s Park Güell are showing some resilience.

headline: House Hunting in Barcelona, Spain
abstract: Barcelona benefits from being a cosmopolitan market, with lively interest among citizens of the Middle East, Russia and other parts of Europe.
lead_paragraph: A 19TH-CENTURY VILLA IN CENTRAL BARCELONA

headline: Do Moderates Have the Guts to Take Back the G.O.P.?
abstract: A new Republican group is about to begin running ads against the hard-liners who have done so much to embarrass the party.
lead_paragraph: Establishment Republicans feel pretty good about their wins yesterday in New Jersey and Alabama. (Many are also quietly saying “I told you so” about Ken Cuccinelli’s loss in the Virginia governor’s race.) For those in the traditional Chamber of Commerce wing of the party, the next year will be about regaining control from the Tea Partiers who have been driving the party’s policies since 2010.

headline: De Blasio, Preparing to Become Mayor, Signals Sea Change in New York
abstract: Bill de Blasio left little doubt that he would be overseeing an administration vastly different from the one he will succeed, describing his liberal social plans as a “sacred mission.”
lead_paragraph: In his first morning as New York City’s mayor-elect, Bill de Blasio spent a cordial, if somewhat awkward hour with the man he will soon replace, Michael R. Bloomberg, making small talk about the intricacies of garbage pickup.

headline: Bill de Blasio’s Path to Mayoral Success
abstract: With his mantra "A Tale of Two Cities," Bill de Blasio captured voters' concerns about inequality in New York City. But he had to overcome far more famous rivals to get to City Hall.
lead_paragraph: With his mantra "A Tale of Two Cities," Bill de Blasio captured voters' concerns about inequality in New York City. But he had to overcome far more famous rivals to get to City Hall.

headline: SAC’s $1.2 Billion Settlement Clears One Judicial Hurdle and Awaits Another
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Judge Richard J. Sullivan approved the civil portion of the settlement. Next stop: Judge Laura Taylor Swain will hold a hearing on the $900 million criminal fine.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors and SAC Capital Advisors cleared a legal hurdle on Wednesday after Judge Richard J. Sullivan said he would sign off on the civil portion of the hedge fund’s insider trading guilty plea and roughly $1.2 billion penalty.

headline: Fall Fashion That Is Anything but Stiff
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jeans (Apparel)', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: Collars with contrast or embellishments bring a little life to the party; Stella McCartney designs a new denim collection; “Love Me” graffiti becomes jewelry; and Esquivel’s designs for Tumi.
lead_paragraph: You’ll always feel put together in a collared shirt, so why not wear one that brings a little pizazz to the party? The shirts here, with contrast collars, embellishments and playful tweaks, do for the classic what vodka does for tonic. Wear as you normally would, with tailored pants or jeans and a blazer; just have more fun.

headline: The Gun Report: November 6, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Dick Metcalf, the technical editor of Guns & Ammo magazine, announced in his December editorial that he supports gun control regulations, a position that is earning him derision within the gun-rights crowd.

headline: Don’t Yell at Your Children. But If You Do, Don’t Yell at Yourself.
abstract: The author of new research on the effect of harsh verbal discipline on adolescents says that even the occasional lapse is “bad.”
lead_paragraph: Personally, I wouldn’t yell at my children if they would just do what I’ve asked the first time, or maybe do the thing I’ve asked them to do 463 times in the past. Or if they didn’t chase one another through the kitchen at dinnertime, brandishing light sabers. Or if they got up when the alarm clock went off in the morning, or put their shoes on so we could leave the house, or moved that glass of milk, the one that’s right by your elbow and … too late.

headline: First Draft Pick Finally Gets First Basket
abstract: Forward Anthony Bennett, a surprise No. 1 selection by the Cavaliers in June, was 0 for 15 in his first four N.B.A. games
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bennett, the N.B.A.’s No. 1 draft pick this year, has already had many firsts in these early weeks of the season: his first home game with the Cleveland Cavaliers, his first blocked shot, his first victory.

headline: Who Beats Christie?
abstract: The New Jersey governor has weaknesses, but so do his potential 2016 rivals.
lead_paragraph: And now for the requisite “Chris Christie and 2016″ post, occasioned by all the other “Chris Christie and 2016″ posts that his landslide re-election have spawned. Mine is inspired by the skeptics — from the right, Henry Olsen; from the left, Jonathan Chait; from the media version of the center, Ron Fournier — who all offer reasons to doubt Christie’s presidential mojo, and spin out entirely plausible scenarios in which his liabilities cost him the G.O.P. nomination.
