Well, entirely plausible except for one thing, which I think Chait’s conclusion underplays:

headline: Mayor-Elect Bill de Blasio
abstract: With his mantra “A Tale of Two Cities,” Bill de Blasio captured voters’ concerns about inequality in New York City. But he had to overcome far more famous rivals to get to City Hall.
lead_paragraph: When he began his mayoral campaign on a freezing cold January day outside his home in Brooklyn, Bill de Blasio was just one of several Democratic candidates all claiming to be the progressive voice of change for a post-Bloomberg New York. His Democratic and Republican opponents belittled his policy proposals, his record and his supposed lack of experience.

headline: De Blasio Enters to 'Royals'
abstract: Bill de Blasio entered his election night party to the song "Royals," by Lorde.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio entered his election night party to the song "Royals," by Lorde.

headline: Voters Reject* Labels for Genetically Engineered Food in Washington State
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Food', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Labeling and Labels']
abstract: A measure that would require labeling of genetically modified foods is rejected in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: Washington State voters, with only four* mainly-urban counties around Seattle bucking the tide, appeared to reject* a ballot initiative that would have required labeling for foods with genetically modified ingredients (with a variety of exceptions), according to the state’s election Web site. The map above is from the state Office of the Secretary of State. There’s more from CNN and USA Today. Industry heavily outspent backers of the labeling initiative, but the measure was also opposed by many newspapers, including the Seattle Times and Olympian.

headline: 'Ain't No Mountain High Enough'
abstract: Bill de Blasio exited his victory night speech to "Ain't No Mountain High Enough."
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio exited his victory night speech to "Ain't No Mountain High Enough."

headline: ‘Royals,’ a Dickensian Anthem, Becomes de Blasio’s Victory Song
abstract: The popular song, by a teenager, contrasting the rich and the not-so-rich, was played as Bill de Blasio took the stage on Tuesday evening as mayor-elect.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio strode onstage in Brooklyn on Tuesday night to give his victory speech as New York City’s mayor-elect to a song by a teenager from New Zealand, “Royals,” by Lorde. “Royals” is currently the No. 1 song in the United States on Billboard magazine’s Hot 100. It also gives catchy form to what had been a major theme of the de Blasio campaign: his “tale of two cities,” addressing the income inequality between the wealthy few and a struggling majority.

headline: Google Is Ordered to Block Images in Privacy Case
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Search Engines', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The Internet company said it would appeal a French court’s ruling that it strip from its search results nine images of the former European racing chief Max Mosley.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A French court ruled Wednesday that Google must remove from its Internet search results all images of a former Formula One car racing chief at an orgy. The ruling in the privacy case could have ramifications for the tech giant’s operations across Europe.

headline: Kerry’s Path Steepens in Israeli-Palestinian Talks
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian officials clashed over settlements, and a right-wing Israeli politician’s acquittal threatened to inject a volatile element into peace talks.
lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — Secretary of State John Kerry’s uphill path to a peace accord between Israel and the Palestinians seemed ever steeper on Wednesday, as the two sides clashed bitterly over Jewish settlements in the West Bank, while the exoneration of a right-wing Israeli politician threatened to inject a volatile element into the talks.

headline: Satellite Falls to Earth
abstract: The Gravity Field and Steady-State Ocean Circulation Explorer, which mapped Earth’s gravitational field in detail, met a fiery end when it crashed back to Earth.
lead_paragraph: A European satellite that mapped Earth’s gravitational field in exquisite detail will be pulled down by gravity to its fiery destruction sometime in the next few days.

headline: ‘Rocky’ on Broadway Finds Its Apollo Creed
abstract: Terence Archie, Dakin Matthews and Danny Mastrogiorgio join the cast of the Broadway musical adaptation of the Oscar-winning film.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway musical “Rocky” has its Master of Disaster.

headline: Sel Rrose on the Lower East Side
abstract: Sel Rrose, a newly opened bar, has a vaguely postwar Paris look, without feeling contrived.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, in a gray, nondescript box on Delancey Street, a bar opened. No one was hired to hype it. It didn’t bait the blogs with a top-secret tequila cave or bacon-infused cocktails. And the stratagem worked, insofar as Sel Rrose, as the bar is called, has been ignored by the right people.

headline: Fantagraphics Seeks Support With a Kickstarter Campaign
abstract: The graphic novel publisher Fantagraphics Books is seeking help from its readers after the death of Kim Thompson, a co-founder.
lead_paragraph: Fantagraphics Books, the graphic novel imprint that, since the mid-1970s, has published a large and varied line, with new works and classic reprints, and has fought to establish comic books as a form of high art, has fallen on hard times since its co-founder, Kim Thompson, was diagnosed with lung cancer in February.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Sesame Letterpress Bespoke Stationery
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a set of customized notecards, designed in Brooklyn and delivered in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Travel Diary
abstract: Sam Buffa, the entrepreneur behind the Fellow Barber shops and several Brooklyn restaurants, heads to the Italian island to ride for Team USA in the International Six Days of Enduro.
lead_paragraph: Sam Buffa, the entrepreneur behind the Fellow Barber shops and several Brooklyn restaurants, heads to the Italian island to ride for Team USA in the International Six Days of Enduro.

headline: Call Collins? Knicks Have Little to Lose
abstract: The 7-foot Jason Collins, 34, who has yet to be signed by a team since he announced in April that he is gay, could provide smart, positional defense to a club that just lost its center to injury.
lead_paragraph: One week into an already stressful season, the Knicks do not have a center, a defensive beacon in the N.B.A. storm. There is no short or complete answer to the loss of Tyson Chandler, who has a nondisplaced fracture of the right fibula. But there will be suggestions on how to cobble together a plan to survive for the next four to six weeks. And here is one:

headline: Gergiev Defends Himself Against Criticism Over Russia’s Anti-Gay Law
abstract: Valery Gergiev, the general director of the Mariinsky Theater, has been dogged by criticism for his support for President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: Valery Gergiev, the Russian conductor whose performances have drawn protests in New York and London this fall from gay-rights advocates opposing Russia’s new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality, issued a statement on his Facebook page Wednesday saying, “It is wrong to suggest that I have ever supported anti-gay legislation and in all my work I have upheld equal rights for all people.”

headline: Closing In: A Campaign’s Final Hours
abstract: Damon Winter went behind the scenes with Bill de Blasio in the days leading up to the mayoral election.
lead_paragraph: Damon Winter went behind the scenes with Bill de Blasio in the days leading up to the mayoral election.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Book Thief’
abstract: Brian Percival, the director of “The Book Thief,” narrates a scene from his film.
lead_paragraph: Brian Percival, the director of “The Book Thief,” narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Vote of Confidence in Mexico’s Version of Amazon.com
abstract: The Mexican venture capital firm Latin Idea Ventures said it had made its first investment in an e-commerce company, Linio, a start-up that sells a wide array of products in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican venture capital firm Latin Idea Ventures said this week that it had made its first investment in an e-commerce company, Linio, a Mexico City start-up that, like Amazon.com in the United States, sells a wide array of products.

headline: ‘A Time to Kill’ Sets Broadway Closing Date
abstract: The stage adaptation of John Grisham’s novel will have played 33 regular performances when it closes on Nov. 17
lead_paragraph: John Grisham may lure readers to his novels in droves, but not to Broadway: The stage adaptation of his best-selling book “A Time To Kill” will close there on Nov. 17, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Killing of French Journalists Reverberates in France and Mali
abstract: At a Paris service for two Radio France Internationale journalists abducted and killed in Mali over the weekend, Malian officials seemed to be asking for France’s continued support.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Diplomats, journalists and humanitarian workers gathered in Paris on Wednesday to mourn the brutal killing of two seasoned French journalists by insurgents in Mali, an episode that has raised questions about France’s plans to withdraw some of its troops from the country over the next two months.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Book Thief’
abstract: Brian Percival narrates a sequence from his film featuring Sophie Nélisse and Geoffrey Rush.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Brian Percival narrates a sequence from his film adaptation of the Markus Zusak novel featuring Sophie Nélisse as Liesel and Geoffrey Rush as her foster father Han. In this scene, Liesel has stolen a book from a Nazi book-burning rally. Mr. Percival discusses his ideas behind the scene and offers insight into how it was shot. The movie opens Nov. 8.

headline: Giving Old Loew’s Theater in Brooklyn a Second Chance
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Theaters (Buildings)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The Kings Theater, closed since the 1970s and seized for nonpayment of taxes, is being turned into a performing arts showcase and is scheduled to reopen in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The Kings Theater is big. It’s the borough that got small.

headline: In ‘The Counselor,’ Fashions and Furnishings Play a Pivotal Role
abstract: The director Ridley Scott’s new film derives much of its visual punch from a mash-up of refinement and vulgarity.
lead_paragraph: CLOTHING, CARS, STRETCHES OF ASPHALT, a plush leather chair: no object is too insignificant to escape the director Ridley Scott, who injects such totems in his films with spirited lives of their own.

headline: Hey, Players, Make Yourselves at Home
abstract: The violinist Hilary Hahn is the chief player and host of a music party at Greenwich House Music School.
lead_paragraph: You’d have to assume that the life of classical music’s star soloists and recitalists might be isolating and lonely, with long stretches of travel and short bursts of communal activity. But on Sunday, the violinist Hilary Hahn was at the center of a social whirl, which could be variously described as a marathon concert, a school day and a carnival.

headline: Nepal Tours Get Local
abstract: Village Ways is introducing trips to Nepal that have a focus on villages, where travelers stay in community guesthouses.
lead_paragraph: For those who want to meet local people as well as appreciate the grandeur of the landscape, the India-based tour operator Village Ways will introduce community-based trips to Nepal in 2014.

headline: Scene City: All Eyes on Tilda Swinton
abstract: Anna Wintour, David Bowie, Karl Lagerfeld and others at MoMA’s annual Film Benefit.
lead_paragraph: Anna Wintour, David Bowie, Karl Lagerfeld and others at MoMA’s annual Film Benefit.

headline: Beethoven and One of France’s Musical Mystics Strive for Glimpses of the Divine
abstract: As part of the Lincoln Center White Light Festival, the Cleveland Orchestra played “liturgies” by Messiaen and a Beethoven Mass.
lead_paragraph: Since white light results not from an absence of color but from the presence of all colors, it is altogether appropriate that Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival should find a place for that supreme musical colorist Olivier Messiaen. And on Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the Cleveland Orchestra, led by its music director, Franz Welser-Möst, performed Messiaen’s “Trois Petites Liturgies de la Présence Divine” of 1944, a piece for a chorus of sopranos, piano and an orchestra fitted out with exotic instruments, alongside works by Beethoven.

headline: Dancing to Bach, With Head Wobbling and Chest Thumping
abstract: American Ballet Theater presented mixed bills on Saturday at the David H. Koch Theater, and one stood out as the least distinguished offering of the fall season.
lead_paragraph: Along with new casts, the mixed bills by American Ballet Theater at the David H. Koch Theater on Saturday introduced the least distinguished offering of the company’s fall season. Made by Stanton Welch in 2001, it is a showpiece for seven men without shirts. The lead dancer slaps his chest, not like Tarzan but like a man applying a defibrillator to himself, an action that seems to call for a shouting of the work’s title: “Clear.”

headline: Enriching Your TV Picture, From the Couch
abstract: The default settings from the factory are often meant for the showroom, but making adjustments once the unit is in your home is easy.
lead_paragraph: IF you are close to spending thousands of dollars on a TV because you want a better picture, you may want to save your money. You can almost certainly make your TV’s picture look better than it did when the set was brand-new, and doing so is relatively easy.

headline: A Wall Street Island for Lhota
abstract: A precinct on the Upper West Side that cast just 39 votes — 33 of them for the Republican mayoral candidate.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota will not be moving into Gracie Mansion. New Yorkers made sure of that in the mayoral election on Tuesday.

headline: Missing Nash but Not the Net, the Rangers Win Their 4th in 5 Games
abstract: The Rangers and Henrik Lundqvist beat the Penguins, the Eastern Conference leaders, despite again playing without Rick Nash because of a concussion sustained Oct. 8.
lead_paragraph: Rick Nash followed through on a huge slap shot at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, but it was only in a photograph on the cover of the game program. The actual Nash was nowhere to be seen, still out with a concussion he sustained a month ago, leaving Rangers fans wondering when, if ever, he will be healthy enough to come back.

headline: Arcade Fire’s Album Is No. 1
abstract: The group’s previous album, “The Suburbs,” also topped the charts in its first week.
lead_paragraph: Arcade Fire’s new album, “Reflektor” (Merge/Universal), debuted at No. 1 on this week’s Billboard album chart, with sales of 140,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The band’s previous album, “The Suburbs” (Merge/Universal), from 2010, also topped Billboard’s chart in its first week.

headline: Sympathy for the Devil Worshipers
keywords: ['First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: The Supreme Court wonders if it’s possible to deliver a prayer that’s acceptable to everyone, including devil worshippers.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy enough to be in favor of a “nonsectarian” prayer before a legislative session — some invocation of a higher power that theoretically doesn’t exclude anyone (besides atheists, that is) — but what exactly does such a prayer sound like?

headline: Twitter, a Risky Investment
abstract: Twitter will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. Here are three reasons the company may be a risky investment.
lead_paragraph: Twitter will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. Here are three reasons the company may be a risky investment.

headline: BAE to Stop Building Ships at Historic British Site
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Defense Contracts', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Relocation of Business', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Britain’s biggest military contractor, BAE Systems, is closing down its shipbuilding yards in Portsmouth, and cutting nearly 1,800 jobs in England and Scotland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As an island nation that once built an empire by sea, Britain has a proud history and longstanding expertise in shipbuilding.

headline: Ombré: A Ubiquitous Word for That Faded Look
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Hair', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The term has spread from the hairstyles of the fashionable to clothing, home design, even wedding cakes.
lead_paragraph: Some clients point to the photos they are clutching of Khloé Kardashian and Alexa Chung as they enter the hair salon. Others describe the desired effect: hair that transitions from dark roots to light ends. Then, there are those who are fluent in the language of trend. They ask for ombré.

headline: Google Gives a Hint About Its Mystery Barges
abstract: In Google’s first public statement about its barges floating near California and Maine, it said they would be used as showrooms for people to learn about new technology.
lead_paragraph: Google has finally commented on its mysterious barges floating near San Francisco and Portland, Me. But its comments do not shed much light on the mystery.

headline: The CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, a Support Network Comes of Age
abstract: After 9/11, a fashion competition was born, with the first award of $200,000 going to the Proenza Schouler designers in 2004. Here’s what some designers are doing now.
lead_paragraph: After 9/11, a fashion competition was born, with the first award of $200,000 going to the Proenza Schouler designers in 2004. Here’s what some designers are doing now.

headline: Television Sales Look Grim Again This Year
abstract: The TV industry looks more bleak every year. After sales of TV sets fell last year, they are poised to shrink once again.
lead_paragraph: The TV industry looks more bleak every year. After sales of television sets fell last year, they are poised to shrink once again this year.

headline: W.H.O., Fighting Polio in Syria, Says More Children Need Vaccinations
abstract: Worried about containing an outbreak in Syria, the World Health Organization has doubled the number of young children it wants vaccinated to more than 20 million.
lead_paragraph: Escalating its emergency battle to stop the spread of a polio revival in Syria, the World Health Organization has doubled the number of children it says should be urgently vaccinated to more than 20 million throughout the Middle East, the organization’s top official in charge of eradicating the highly contagious and crippling disease said Wednesday.

headline: An African Past, Embodied and Onstage Today
abstract: In “Exit/Exist,” Gregory Maqoma dances as he channels an ancestor who died in prison in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: A man in a shiny suit faces away from those who watch him. His fingers tickle the air, as if feeling for something. The signals he senses must be intensifying, since his weather-vane body starts shunting into angles, bouncing like a car with loose suspension. As a beat fades in, his shoulders and knees pick it up, until he is stepping high in a dance you might identify as African.

headline: More Asteroid Strikes Are Likely, Scientists Say
abstract: In new research, a team of scientists is suggesting that the Earth is vulnerable to asteroid strikes as often as every decade or two.
lead_paragraph: When an asteroid exploded over the Russian city of Chelyabinsk in February, shattering windows for miles and injuring well over 1,000 people, experts said it was a rare event — of a magnitude that might occur only once every 100 to 200 years, on average.

headline: Tilda Swinton Saluted by MoMA and a Starry Guest List
abstract: The film actress is a muse to many fashion designers.
lead_paragraph: In her two-decade-plus film career, Tilda Swinton has been a muse to many fashion designers. No wonder a tribute to her on Tuesday night, at the Museum of Modern Art’s annual Film Benefit, had a starry guest list that rivaled the Met’s Costume Institute Gala.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, England, Greece and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, England, Greece and Syria.

headline: Why I Lost It on Election Night
abstract: How can we have an electoral process that is so hopelessly antiquated?
lead_paragraph: THE New York City mayoral election was hardly a nail-biter. But Bill de Blasio’s landslide win might have been nominally less historic had I not torn up my ballot and flung it at a bewildered election volunteer near my home on the Upper West Side.

headline: Thor’s Nemesis Makes Some Thunder
abstract: Tom Hiddleston, who plays Loki in “Thor: The Dark World,” has a Jim Jarmusch film and a Shakespeare play in London on his horizon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a scene close to the end of the 2011 superhero film “Thor,” the two central characters confront each other. They are brothers, although Loki, played by the British actor Tom Hiddleston, has just denied this. “Loki, this is madness,” says Thor (Chris Hemsworth). “Is it madness?” Mr. Hiddleston responds, his face quivering with intensity, his breath ragged, his eyes filming with tears. “Is it? Is it?”

headline: A Showman Whose Dazzle Hid Darkness
abstract: Sam Wasson’s “Fosse” is an intensively researched and sprawling biography of the director and choreographer.
lead_paragraph: After Bob Fosse won an Oscar (for directing “Cabaret”), two Tonys (for choreographing and directing “Pippin”) and an Emmy (for directing “Liza With a Z”) in 1973, a rare triple coup, he reacted the way any world-class show business depressive would: He decided he had nowhere to go but down.

headline: U.S. Will Ease Sanctions if Iran Halts Nuclear Program, Official Says
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: An Obama administration official said that an Iranian agreement to halt nuclear activity, for six months perhaps, would buy time for negotiators to work out a more sweeping deal.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — On the eve of a new round of talks between world powers and Iran, a senior Obama administration official said Wednesday that the United States was prepared to offer Iran limited relief from economic sanctions if Tehran agreed to halt its nuclear program temporarily and reversed part of it.

headline: Roiling the Waters at River House
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs']
abstract: The change facing a storied co-op: keep a beloved club or sell the space to the highest bidder?
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the River Club was far from bustling. The main dining room was closed, so a handful of elderly couples headed to the pool area, where a bar menu was being served. A man using a walker spoke with his lunch companions of a recent trip to an antiques show. An Elsie de Wolfe aesthetic prevailed in several nearby sitting rooms, where the tufted red leather furniture was unoccupied.

headline: Cooking the Turkey Dinner, With a Little Help From My Phone
abstract: Android and iOS apps to help in the kitchen and keep the children amused.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is a time to spend wholesome moments with family and enjoy great food and drink.

headline: App Smart: Help With Thanksgiving
abstract: Android and iOS apps to help in the kitchen and keep the kids amused during the holiday, as reviewed by The Times’s Kit Eaton.
lead_paragraph: Android and iOS apps to help in the kitchen and keep the kids amused during the holiday, as reviewed by The Times’s Kit Eaton.

headline: Conquering Android’s World of Themes
abstract: An app cuts out the technical gobbledygook and presents smartphone users with a clear path to their own identity.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I ditched my iPhone 4S for an HTC One, and now I think the difference between the world’s most popular smartphone operating systems — Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android — can be explained with a metaphor about home decorating.

headline: Hudson Valley Town Is a Playwright’s Home and Template
abstract: The playwright Richard Nelson’s cycle of plays, at the Public Theater this fall, features real places in Rhinebeck, N.Y., where he lives.
lead_paragraph: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — Whenever Richard Nelson hit a bump writing about the Apples, the fractious, fictitious family in his critically acclaimed cycle of four plays at the Public Theater this fall, inspiration lay just around the corner.

headline: Error Creates Deals Too Good to Be True on Walmart’s Site
abstract: There were deals like an $11 kayak and a $9 projector, and while Walmart blamed a technical error, it did not say whether it would honor the deals.
lead_paragraph: First, there was Black Friday. Then came Cyber Monday.

headline: With the Raven, Henry Stimler Expands His Nightlife Presence
abstract: Mr. Stimler is trying to draw a rock ’n’ roll clientele to the club with its distressed wallpaper and ceiling painting of heaven and hell.
lead_paragraph: In his own words, Henry Stimler was “always a wandering spirit and dreamer.” He grew up the second child of five in an ultra-Orthodox home in the predominantly Jewish area of Golders Green, North London.

headline: A Band Likes to Morph and Blend as It Reaches
abstract: Hiatus Kaiyote’s influences and flexibility were on display during a Tuesday concert in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: How far can R&B be pushed toward jazz? Hiatus Kaiyote, an Australian band that performed on Tuesday night at Le Poisson Rouge, seems determined to find out. It calls its music “future soul”; its album “Tawk Tomahawk” (Flying Buddha) was released in Australia last year and in the United States this year. On it, the band sails through one ambitious song after another.

headline: An Epic, Century-Old Motorcycle Race Comes to Sardinia
abstract: Sam Buffa, the entrepreneur behind the Fellow Barber shops and several Brooklyn restaurants, shares pictures from his trip to the Italian island to compete in the International Six Days of Enduro.
lead_paragraph: As the co-owner of the Brooklyn restaurants Vinegar Hill House and Hillside and the impresario behind the Fellow Barber mini-empire of elegant, old-timey men’s grooming salons, Sam Buffa is already the subject of major male lifestyle envy. The 35-year-old seems even more the embodiment of a certain type of guy’s fantasy life when you learn that he also races motorcycles, something he started doing with his dad as a kid growing up in Half Moon Bay, Calif.

headline: Vogue Fashion Fund: Where No Designer Is Left Behind
abstract: Many from the CFDA competition have landed high-profile positions or new backers. But has it all been a bed of roses?
lead_paragraph: Whoever said, “If you want to try a risky career, open a restaurant,” surely never considered becoming a clothing designer.

headline: Sweating the Details Is Part of the Test for Designers
abstract: A day of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund contest includes meeting with a model, having your design inspected by a panel and gaining some insight from a judge.
lead_paragraph: The challenge, as Steven Kolb, the chief executive of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, explained to the group in the backyard of Anna Wintour’s townhouse, was to create a ready-to-wear design incorporating elements from performance wear. In other words, something that could be worn “from the gym to the office,” he said.

headline: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 7
abstract: Openings, sales and new items in New York City this week.
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: Documents Reveal How Looted Nazi Art Was Restored to Dealer
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art']
abstract: New details are emerging about postwar decisions about artwork looted by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the waning years of World War II, a band of Allied soldiers, art historians, curators and scholars labored to safeguard Europe’s cultural heritage and recover the millions of artworks and other treasures plundered by the Nazis and their collaborators. Nicknamed the Monuments Men, this group set up a string of temporary collection points for the valuables.

headline: ‘Blue,’ Through Lesbian Eyes
abstract: The new film about a teenager and her female lover is getting mixed reviews from those it aims to depict.
lead_paragraph: Of the many things to note about the seven-minute lesbian sex scene in “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” a French drama about a teenage girl who becomes passionately involved with a slightly older woman, is how very long it seems to go on.

headline: Despite Blackout, CBS Profit and Revenue Rise
abstract: Stations in cities like New York, Los Angeles and Chicago were not carried by Time Warner Cable for a month in the summer during a contract dispute.
lead_paragraph: Despite its protracted dispute over the summer with Time Warner Cable, CBS posted another solid earnings report on Wednesday with steady increases in revenue and profit for the third quarter.

headline: Cuts Have Hagel Weighing Realigned Military Budget
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Reserves (Military)']
abstract: Under pressure from the threat of nearly $1 trillion in forced spending reductions, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel says the days of automatic, equitable allotment to the Army, Air Force and Navy may be over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has traditionally managed rivalries among services by giving each more or less equal shares of the base military budget.

headline: Late Night Ends Early for Some New York Clubbers
abstract: In the 1980s, a night out could end at noon the next day. But today’s partiers keep a stricter eye on the clock, the writer says.
lead_paragraph: At Greenhouse, the smallish two-level dance club on Varick Street in Manhattan, Sunday nights are filled with a frisky mix of gay guys, club kids, homeys and an occasional tourist with a guidebook.

headline: Going Beyond the Baseboard
abstract: What to keep in mind if you want a European radiator.
lead_paragraph: If you find yourself warming to a European-produced designer radiator, you’ll be happy to know that some models are distributed in the United States. Contact the company for the names of retailers. Or you can buy directly from overseas.

headline: Textiles with Roots in the Rain Forest
abstract: Cristina Grajales Gallery presents its second solo show of Hechizoo, an innovative weaving studio in Bogotá, Colombia.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Cristina Grajales Gallery in New York presented a solo exhibition of the work of Hechizoo, a textile studio founded in 2000 in Bogotá by Jorge Lizarazo, an architect-turned-weaver. Hechizoo combines native plant fibers like fique and cumare palm with nylon filament and metals to create iridescent carpets and screens.

headline: A Double Take Under Your Feet
abstract: Brightly colored wood-patterned carpets from the appropriately named Richard Woods.
lead_paragraph: The British artist Richard Woods creates stylized renderings of construction materials (such as brick and wood) and applies them to household décor. His colorful, comic book-like graphics have appeared on chairs, tables and wallpaper, as well as on the sides of buildings. The floor has certainly not escaped his attention. His latest project, a collection of 11 parquet- and floorboard-patterned wool rugs for Memphis-Milano, are produced in Nepal, where they are woven on traditional looms. “I like the idea of making a rug out of something that’s usually underneath the rug,” Mr. Woods said, adding that he isn’t conscious of any influence his surname may have had on his work. The rugs are produced in a signed limited edition of 36 and range in size from about 3 by 5 feet ($2,466) to about 8 by 11 feet ($14,466). Shown is RW Rug #5 ($6,692). Information: 011-39-02-655-4731 or store.memphis-milano.com.

headline: Dressing the Turkey? Dress the Menorah, Too.
abstract: A 9-year-old invents a table decoration to mark both Thanksgiving and Hanukkah.
lead_paragraph: When precocious children come up with ideas for salable inventions on long car rides, preoccupied parents typically just keep driving. But about 10 months ago, when Asher Weintraub, 9, suggested combining Thanksgiving table decorations and Hanukkah menorahs this year, since the holidays are making a rare simultaneous appearance, his parents, Anthony Weintraub and Caroline Baron, actually listened. The Manhattan family commissioned a prototype for Asher’s computer sketch of a menurkey, a menorah shaped like a turkey holding candles in its plumes. A Kickstarter campaign, also Asher’s idea, brought in $48,345 and Internet fame, and now plaster menurkeys are being sold for $50 at the Jewish Museum in New York. “When I saw it made,” Asher said, “it looked way better than I expected.” As for his next invention, he added, “Maybe an app.” Information: 212-423-3333 or shop.thejewishmuseum.org.

headline: Trust Me: You Should Be Impressed
abstract: The architect Zaha Hadid has designed a superyacht featuring one of her trademark exoskeletons.
lead_paragraph: A new superyacht by Zaha Hadid presents the billionaire playboy with a problem. There is undeniable prestige of trolling Mediterranean harbors in a yacht designed by a Pritzker-prize-winning architect. But the boat’s outer shell is made of an interwoven network of support bands, which gives it a futuristic webbed look and obscures the primary decks. Who on shore will see the bikinied frolicking?

headline: Turning Up the Heat
abstract: Europeans are endlessly inventive when it comes to radiator design. Why are Americans lagging behind?
lead_paragraph: Europeans are endlessly inventive when it comes to radiator design. Why are Americans lagging behind?

headline: A Radiance All Their Own
abstract: Europeans are endlessly inventive when it comes to radiator design. Why are Americans lagging behind?
lead_paragraph: Several winters ago, Guus van Leeuwen, who was then an industrial design student, was riding with his girlfriend in a horse-drawn sleigh in Sweden. Wrapped in reindeer pelts, the couple watched steam rise from the bodies of the sweating animals in front of them. That’s when “it all came together,” Mr. van Leeuwen said.

headline: A Fisherman in New York’s Sea of Faces
abstract: Brandon Stanton’s new book of 400 photographic portraits, “Humans of New York,” has become a best seller.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how Brandon Stanton spends several hours each day: He walks up to total strangers in New York City, requests permission to take their pictures and then asks questions so personal they might make Oprah Winfrey blush.

headline: 36 Hours in Aruba
abstract: You can settle in with a book and a beer on the beach, but if you prefer a more active itinerary, this sunny Dutch island offers everything from cultural exploration to beach tennis.
lead_paragraph: Averaging 82 sunny degrees year round, fringed with blond beaches and lapped by turquoise shallows, Aruba lets the climate do the talking when it comes to appealing to tourists. Beach lovers flock here, happy to claim a chaise with a paperback in one hand and a cold Balashi beer in the other. But the Dutch island’s manageable 20-by-6-mile dimensions and its desert landscape — calm and sandy on one coast, rough and rocky on the other — make it an explorer’s island, too. Notably multicultural, with Dutch, the Creole-like Papiamento, Spanish and English commonly spoken, the island is also increasingly sophisticated, with an aloe-focused spa, a new avant-garde restaurant and a Ritz-Carlton resort, the island’s most luxurious property, set to open Nov. 22.

headline: From Architecture to Art in Aruba
abstract: Take a spin around this sunny island off the coast of South America.
lead_paragraph: Take a spin around this sunny island off the coast of South America.

headline: A Garden of Creature Comforts
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Marta McDowell on her new book, “Beatrix Potter’s Gardening Life: The Plants and Places That Inspired the Classic Children’s Tales.”
lead_paragraph: Gardeners brought up on the mishaps of Peter Rabbit can now curl up with “Beatrix Potter’s Gardening Life: The Plants and Places That Inspired the Classic Children’s Tales,” by Marta McDowell, out this month from Timber Press ($24.95).

headline: Deals on Linens, Carpets and Chairs
abstract: Bargains at Mia & Finn’s, Niche Modern, Madeline Weinrib and Crate and Barrel.
lead_paragraph: During Mia & Finn’s basement sale, Friday and Saturday, bed and table linens are up to 70 percent off (an Izia quilt, usually $420, will be $135); 73 Saint James Place (Lafayette Avenue), Brooklyn, 646-943-0796.

headline: Should I Replace Worn Light Switches?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Lighting']
abstract: Advice on repairing or redecorating a home before selling.
lead_paragraph: Q. My home has old, worn light switches and outlets. Should I replace them before I put it on the market?

headline: Case of Insect Interruptus Yields a Rare Fossil Find
abstract: Researchers say the oldest fossil of two insects copulating — in this case, froghoppers killed in a volcanic eruption 165 million years ago — was identified in what is now Northeastern China.
lead_paragraph: About 165 million years ago, in what is now northeastern China, two insects were doing what comes naturally. Suddenly, in the middle of copulating, they were struck dead, felled by poisonous gas from a volcanic eruption.

headline: Judge Who Overturned Skakel Murder Conviction Declines Bail Request
abstract: Judge Thomas A. Bishop lifted his stay of his ruling but said a bail decision was now up to the court that would retry Michael C. Skakel.
lead_paragraph: ROCKVILLE, Conn. — Michael C. Skakel, a Kennedy relative who has been serving a 20-year-sentence for killing his Greenwich neighbor Martha Moxley when they were both 15, returned to prison on Wednesday after a hearing in which the judge who  set aside Mr. Skakel’s 2002 conviction declined to grant bail.

headline: Forgive Me, Virginia Woolf
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A dining room fantasy is finally realized (to the homeowner’s regret).
lead_paragraph: When I was 5, my parents decided I was old enough to decorate my own bedroom.

headline: Bolshoi Director Testifies at Acid-Attack Trial
abstract: Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet artistic director, took the stand on Wednesday to confront the dancer accused of being behind the assault that nearly blinded him.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It had all the intrigue and sensation of the Bolshoi Ballet’s most spectacular productions, but the drama that unfolded on Wednesday in the Meschchansky District Court here was one that storied dance company will forever dread.

headline: A Sprint or a Marathon? Bach and Beethoven Variations in a Single Evening
abstract: Andras Schiff tackled Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations and Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations in one night, on Tuesday, at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Andras Schiff’s latest traversal of Bach’s keyboard works, a two-year project, ended on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall with the “Goldberg” Variations.

headline: Teenager’s Lawyer Blames Pothole for Crash
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Potholes', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Franklin Reyes, 17, is facing manslaughter charges in the death of a 4-year-old girl he hit in June while fleeing police officers on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: There has been plenty of finger-pointing in the case of a teenage driver who struck a 4-year-old girl, killing her and injuring her grandmother in June while speeding away from the police on the Upper West Side. Now the boy’s lawyer is blaming a pothole for the accident.

headline: A Grand Slam From a Posthumous Victor Mollo Book
keywords: ['Cards and Card Games', 'Bridge (Card Game)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Two noteworthy bridge books offer instructive deals interlaced with amusing text.
lead_paragraph: For the past few columns, we have been looking at noteworthy bridge books published this year that might make good gifts.

headline: The Making Of
abstract: The Brooklyn design duo created to-scale installations of quintessentially British things for the windows of J. Crew’s new international flagship on Regent Street in London.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn design duo created to-scale installations of quintessentially British things for the windows of J. Crew’s new international flagship on Regent Street in London.

headline: Saving Buffalo, Wreck by Wreck
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: In Upstate New York, buyers with activist inclinations are preserving a city, one foreclosed house at a time.
lead_paragraph: In Upstate New York, buyers with activist inclinations are preserving a city, one foreclosed house at a time.

headline: Small-Scale Developers, Big Dreams
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: In upstate New York, buyers with activist inclinations are preserving a city, one foreclosed house at a time.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — It was the proverbial melting pot, festive, aromatic and polyphonic. There were young hipsters (identifiable by their wool caps and archaic facial hair) and local homesteaders, along with settlers from Myanmar, Bhutan, Pakistan and Africa, to name just a few of the cultures represented at this once-blighted city’s annual auction of foreclosed properties. Would-be homeowners and property moguls huddled over the listings for more than 4,300 parcels of vacant lots and houses, their hoped-for choices highlighted and starred.

headline: Tinkering With the Ghosts of Tailors
abstract: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns redo a Lower East Side loft, preserving the marks of former occupants (and their sewing machines).
lead_paragraph: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns redo a Lower East Side loft, preserving the marks of former occupants (and their sewing machines).

headline: Staying in Character
abstract: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns redo a Lower East Side loft, preserving the marks of former occupants and their sewing machines.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns had long fantasized about buying a place in New York, but it took an old clothing factory on Orchard Street to convince them.

abstract: Readers react to a Sunday Review essay, “In Praise of Art Forgeries,” by Blake Gopnik.

headline: Twitter Prices Its Initial Offering at $26 Per Share
abstract: Twitter’s initial public offering, which values the company at roughly $18 billion, is a sign of its maturity, even as it combats slowing growth.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter, long protected in its Silicon Valley nest, is about to venture into the more unforgiving world of Wall Street.

headline: For Detroit’s New Mayor, Power, With Conditions
abstract: Mike Duggan’s power is constrained by the presence of an emergency manager, with whom he must work effectively, while still winning the trust of city residents.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Congratulatory phone calls dominated Mike Duggan’s first 24 hours as the next mayor of this downtrodden city, but the coming days may be the most crucial to laying the groundwork for his administration, as conversations begin with state officials about his role at City Hall.

headline: Colombia and Rebels Reach Deal on Political Participation
abstract: The agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC, the country’s largest guerrilla group, is a crucial step forward in peace talks aimed at ending nearly 50 years of fighting.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Negotiators for the Colombian government and the country’s largest guerrilla group announced Wednesday that they had agreed on a framework for the rebels to take part in the political process, a crucial step forward in peace talks aimed at ending nearly 50 years of fighting between the government and the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: On Everpix, and ‘Silk Road 2.0’ Launches
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include how an examination of how an arguably great product like Everpix can hit the funding squeeze. Plus, with the demise of the online black market, Silk Road, the so-called dark Web dream, lives on.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: ‘First Date’ Announces Last Performance
abstract: The musical will finish its Broadway run on Jan. 5 after 174 regular performances.
lead_paragraph: No need to pick out invitations or hire a caterer: the musical comedy “First Date” will finish its Broadway run on Jan. 5 after 34 previews and 174 regular performances, the producers announced late Wednesday.

headline: Iowa Town’s Vote Delivers Rebuke to Kochs’ Group
abstract: All three incumbents who ran won their races in Coralville, Iowa, on Tuesday, despite being targeted by the conservative group Americans for Prosperity over the town’s debt.
lead_paragraph: The mayoral and City Council candidates in an Iowa town who were most closely aligned with the message promoted by Americans for Prosperity, the deep-pocketed conservative political group, were roundly defeated on Tuesday in a sharp rebuke of outside influence in local politics.

headline: Peacekeepers in Congo to Focus on Another Rebel Group
abstract: After routing the Congolese M23 rebels, United Nations peacekeepers are expected to turn their attention to subduing a Hutu militia.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Having helped rout one powerful rebel group in the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo, United Nations peacekeepers are expected to turn their attention to subduing another, diplomats said Wednesday, as the Security Council prepared to draft a statement on the next steps in that vast, mineral-rich country.

headline: History Channel Is Eying Remake of ‘Roots’
abstract: The History Channel may remake the ABC mini-series that made history when it was broadcast in 1977.
lead_paragraph: The History Channel may remake “Roots,” the ABC mini-series that made history when it was broadcast in 1977. The cable channel confirmed that it had bought the rights to the mini-series (and the Alex Haley book that it was based upon) and had started developing an eight-hour version of it. The original “Roots,” about a multigenerational African-American family’s experiences from the time of slavery onward, was 12 hours and a national phenomenon, as evidenced by the fact that more than half of all American households tuned in for the finale. The development was first reported by Deadline.com on Tuesday, which quoted a senior vice president at the channel, Dirk Hoogstra, as saying “We would like to revive that cultural icon for a new audience.”

headline: Taking Aim at the Wrong Deficit
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Reducing the trade deficit would lead to more growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ASK most people in this city what the most important step is to increasing economic growth and job creation, and they’ll reply, “Reduce the budget deficit!”

headline: On Holding Hands and Fake Marriage: Stories of Being Gay in Russia
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Parenting']
abstract: To better understand what it is like to identify as L.G.B.T. in a country that officially discourages openness, The Times asked readers to share their stories.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Yegor grew up in a Siberian town called Lyubov, which means “love” in Russian, but he has never told his parents that when he falls in love, it is with other men.

abstract: Oregon plays at Stanford and Oklahoma travels to Baylor in two matchups between top-ranked teams.

headline: Presidential! Season! Soonish!
abstract: It’s just two years until the Iowa caucuses, people! There is so much to discuss. Is Chris Christie the tough-talking truth-teller we’ve been waiting for?
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie! He won! Let’s talk about his presidential prospects incessantly for the rest of the month!

headline: Wall St. Bonuses Over All Are Predicted to Rise 5 to 10% (Bond Traders Excluded)
abstract: Bonuses for bond traders are expected to drop up to 10 percent, while financial advisers and asset managers can expect bonuses to increase by about 15 percent.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to compensation, it looks as if 2013 is going to be remembered as a pretty good year to have worked on Wall Street, unless you are a fixed-income trader.

headline: New Bow for CARE Packages
abstract: New ads bring back the Care package, but portray it as less of a symbol of short-term charity and more of a means of long-term empowerment.
lead_paragraph: THE CARE package, once a familiar symbol of providing relief overseas, is being taken down from the shelf, dusted off and reimagined for a new generation of potential donors.

headline: Slavery Isn’t a Thing of the Past
abstract: Finally, we can face the monstrosity of 19th-century slavery. But what about people enslaved today?
lead_paragraph: The movie “12 Years a Slave” is receiving rapturous reviews for depicting the antebellum South less as a gauzy land of elegant plantations than as the raw backdrop of monstrous brutality.

headline: N.F.L. Picks Lawyer to Lead Inquiry Into Dolphins
abstract: The N.F.L. appointed Ted Wells, one of the country’s top defense lawyers, to investigate the allegations of workplace misconduct swirling around the Miami Dolphins.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has appointed Ted Wells, one of the country’s top defense lawyers, to investigate the allegations of workplace misconduct swirling around the Miami Dolphins, a sign the league wants to reassure the public that it is taking the matter seriously.

headline: Swiss Report Supports Theory Arafat Was Poisoned
abstract: A forensics report said that taking into account analytical limitations, its findings “moderately support the proposition” that Yasir Arafat’s death was the consequence of polonium poisoning.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Nine years of mystery and intrigue surrounding the death of Yasir Arafat, the symbol of the Palestinian national struggle, took a contentious turn on Wednesday with the publication of a forensics report by Swiss scientists that lends support to the theory that Mr. Arafat died of poisoning with radioactive polonium-210.

headline: Defeat of School Tax Stings Colorado Democrats
abstract: The promise of higher teacher salaries and full-day kindergarten failed to resonate, even in areas where the money would have had the greatest benefit.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — They had $10 million in contributions, a barrage of advertising and support from the usually warring factions of the educational establishment. But Democratic leaders in this swing state were dealt a stinging defeat on Tuesday as voters resoundingly rejected an effort to raise taxes by $1 billion a year to pay for a sweeping school overhaul.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Redskins (3-5) at Vikings (1-7)
abstract: This prime-time matchup between Washington and Minnesota is clear evidence that the N.F.L. schedule makers do not possess a crystal ball.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m., NFL Network

headline: The Passion of Parenting
abstract: Children must grow up and go away, and that is as it should be.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been a single dad for 13 years. As with most single parents — and indeed with most parents — it hasn’t always been easy.

headline: Measures to Legalize Marijuana Are Passed
abstract: Lansing, Mich. and Portland, Me., are among cities that legalized possession of small amounts of the drug, while Colorado approved a tax on recreational marijuana.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Marijuana proponents scored significant victories on Tuesday as voters around the country passed ballot measures decriminalizing marijuana possession and approved regulatory taxes on the drug.

headline: Ruble Hopes to Join Ranks of the $ and €
keywords: ['Ruble (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Russian officials want to give the ruble a symbol that would become as easily recognizable as those for the dollar and the euro.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The ruble, once the legal tender of the bread line and little else, is now almost a normal currency for international commerce, but it lacks a graphic symbol like the dollar sign. On Wednesday, in an effort the leadership hopes will further raise the currency’s profile and make it as acceptable as the dollar or the euro, the Central Bank posted five possible symbols for Russians to vote on. The winner will be announced on Dec. 5.

headline: In Slide of Swedish Tennis, There Is No End in Sight
abstract: In the 1970s, ’80s and early ’90s, Swedish men won dozens of Grand Slam events, behind only the Americans. But there has been only one such victory in the last 21 years.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — When the second-highest-ranked Swedish player took the court for his first match at the recent Stockholm Open, the fans who were scattered around the warm, wooden benches at the Kungliga Tennishallen stomped approval that echoed off the arched ceiling.

headline: Twitter’s Market Valuation Suggests Wall St. Sees Huge Growth Potential
abstract: Investors are betting that Twitter will become wildly profitable as advertisers pay it increasing amounts of money to reach consumers who use the service.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is a young company generating large losses as it competes in a highly uncertain sector of the economy.

headline: Next Door to War, There’s Money to Be Made
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A half-dozen military supply stores are a source of military vests, camouflage pants, knives and gas masks for a clientele flooding in from all over the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Wars, as businessmen have recognized for centuries, can be very profitable. Evidence of that is on display here, where a half-dozen military supply stores in the center of this town near the Syrian border are busy catering to a clientele flooding in from all over the Middle East.

headline: Details Emerge of Potential Google Monitor in Europe
abstract: The outlines of the job offer a window into what Google faces if it agrees to the latest settlement offer from the European Commission in the long-running antitrust case against the company.

keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Piracy at Sea', 'Ships and Shipping']

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Years ago, aboard my first ship as a young cadet, I noticed a man pacing along the bridge deck. I asked the third mate who he was.

headline: Texas’ Stringent Voter ID Law Makes a Dent at Polls
abstract: Texas rolled out its tough new voter ID law this week, which requires voters for the first time to show a state-approved form of identification to vote.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — First, Judge Sandra Watts was stopped while trying to vote because the name on her photo ID, the same one she had used for voter registration and identification for 52 years, did not exactly match her name on the official voter rolls.

headline: Nepal’s Tentative Democracy Prepares to Vote
abstract: After decades of political upheaval and paralysis, Nepal is scheduled to hold national elections on Nov. 19.
lead_paragraph: After decades of political upheaval and paralysis, Nepal is scheduled to hold national elections on Nov. 19.

headline: Baylor’s Briles Is a Down-Home Innovator
abstract: The roots of Baylor’s offensive success under Coach Art Briles can be traced to the spread offense that he devised at a Texas high school.
lead_paragraph: STEPHENVILLE, Tex. — Jake and Dorothy’s Cafe opened in 1948, four decades before Art Briles came to town and helped change football with an offense that would, appropriately, spread from central Texas to the N.F.L.

headline: In Fractured Nepal, Plans for National Elections Provide a Series of Subplots
abstract: After decades of political upheaval, there is a growing consensus that the only way to arrest Nepal’s economic spiral is through elections, including one to finish the constitution.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Nepal’s former first lady insisted that she was not a crook.

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Moment
abstract: The hard work starts now for Bill de Blasio, the mayor-elect. He has promised a new approach in substance and style that voters clearly wanted.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio won the New York mayor’s race on Tuesday night, and, on Wednesday, he started accepting job applications and citizens’ ideas for his administration at a website for the transition. It is a nice gesture, striking the notes of diversity and openness that he hit throughout the campaign.

headline: In New York City’s Sharp Left Turn, Questions of Just How Far
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the mayor-elect, is a liberal Democrat, as are the newly elected public advocate and city comptroller.
lead_paragraph: New York City voters stepped decisively to the political left on Tuesday, turning their collective back on two decades of Republican-backed mayoral rule.

headline: Chinese Leader’s Economic Plan Tests Goal to Fortify Party Power
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Urban Areas', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: President Xi Jinping faces the daunting task of reconciling promises of market-driven economic reform with his goal to reinforce the Communist Party’s pillars of control.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s president, Xi Jinping, is about to plunge the country and himself into a risky experiment: an attempt to carry out market-driven economic overhauls while reinforcing the Communist Party’s pillars of political and ideological control. This mixed agenda has magnified doubts about whether he can deliver on his promises of transformation.

headline: China Wants Its Movies to Be Big in the U.S., Too
abstract: China’s ambitious new film entrepreneurs, dozens of whom gathered in California this week for industry events, want something that has largely eluded them: a homemade global hit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Investment capital? They’re loaded.

abstract: Agencies must adopt newer methods to avoid software failures, delays and cost increases.
lead_paragraph: The problems with the federal health insurance website have highlighted the need for broad reform in how the government uses technology to deliver public services.

headline: Second Thoughts on Neighborhood Watches
abstract: More than a year after Trayvon Martin was shot to death in Sanford, Fla., by a neighborhood watch volunteer, the town’s police department is wisely changing the program.
lead_paragraph: Far too late to save the life of Trayvon Martin, the community of Sanford, Fla., where Mr. Martin was shot to death last year by a roaming neighborhood watch volunteer, is wisely changing course and banning civilians from packing firearms on future citizen patrols.

headline: Subject to Further Review
abstract: The National Football League must be unflinching in its investigation into accusations of bullying and abuse in the Miami Dolphins’ locker room.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League once again finds itself searching beyond the X’s and O’s of the playing field to protect the game’s image as a rough-and-tumble entertainment rooted in innocent sport. The league has opened an investigation into accusations of locker room hazing on the Miami Dolphins that reportedly descended to racist and homophobic slurs and macho threats against a player and his mother.

headline: Lessons on Immigration in Two Governors’ Races
abstract: In New Jersey, Gov. Chris Christie won 50 percent of Latino voters, while in Virginia, Latinos voted heavily against Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, who lost his election.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in Congress studying the results from the governors’ elections in New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday see two starkly different test cases for how the party should move on immigration.

headline: Protest Over Kelly Is Focus of Inquiry, Brown University Says
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Search and Seizure', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The university’s president said the protest that forced the cancellation of a speech by the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, violated the institution’s code of conduct.
lead_paragraph: Brown University will investigate a protest last month that forced the cancellation of a speech by the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, and decide whether anyone should be disciplined, the university said on Wednesday.

headline: Mexico: Court Orders Full Sentence in Drug Agent’s Death, but Killer Is Free
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The Mexico Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a lower court ruling that allowed a drug kingpin accused of murdering an American drug enforcement agent in the 1980s to walk free.
lead_paragraph: The Mexico Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a lower court ruling that allowed a drug kingpin accused of murdering an American drug enforcement agent in the 1980s to walk free. The effect of the high court ruling is unclear; the drug lord, Rafael Caro Quintero, left prison Aug. 9 and may not be easy to find. The American government, which filed an extradition request for him after his release, this week offered a $5 million reward for information leading to his capture. According to the high court ruling, lower court judges made a mistake when they decided there had been a jurisdiction problem in trying Mr. Caro Quintero in federal court and ordered his release. The new ruling allows the Mexican authorities to order him back to prison to complete the remaining 12 years of his 40-year sentence for the killing of the agent, Enrique Camarena, although Mexico could choose to extradite Mr. Caro Quintero if he is found.

headline: The Netherlands Appeals Detentions of Greenpeace Activists in Russia
keywords: ['Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: Russia, which has charged Greenpeace crew members with hooliganism, refused to recognize the jurisdiction of an international tribunal in what it considers an internal legal matter.
lead_paragraph: The Netherlands appealed to an international tribunal to order Russia to release a ship and 30 crew members of Greenpeace International who were detained in September while protesting offshore oil exploration in the Arctic. Russia, which has since charged the crew members with hooliganism, refused to recognize the court’s jurisdiction in what it considers an internal legal matter. The tribunal of the Law of the Sea Treaty, based in Hamburg, scheduled a ruling for Nov. 22, which could increase diplomatic pressure on Russia’s government to resolve the case.

headline: Who Should Get Financial Aid?
abstract: What factors should determine eligibility for financial aid from the government and from colleges? Should parents' income be considered?

headline: Virginia G.O.P. Assesses Loss to Rival It Saw as Weak
abstract: Republicans who viewed Terry McAuliffe as a beatable candidate engaged in recriminations about how the party had gone wrong by nominating an outspoken social conservative.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Virginia awoke Wednesday with the knowledge that a bad streak had been extended: With the election of a Democratic governor, Terry McAuliffe, Republicans have lost seven of the past eight statewide, top-of-the-ballot races, including those for governor, senator and president — a run of misery dating to 2005.

headline: A College Degree Within Reach, Then Came the Medical Bills
abstract: One class shy of her bachelor’s degree, Manpriya Samra suddenly had thousands of dollars in medical bills after an emergency appendectomy.
lead_paragraph: The worst stomach ache of Manpriya Samra’s life sent her to Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn in March 2012, when doctors told her that her appendix was about to burst. An emergency surgery successfully removed the inflamed organ, but Ms. Samra soon learned that her ordeal was only just beginning.

headline: New Help for Poor Immigrants Who Are in Custody and Facing Deportation
abstract: The New York Immigrant Family Unity Project addresses concerns that the lack of competent legal representation results in unnecessary deportations and government costs.
lead_paragraph: At about 1:15 p.m. on Wednesday, Maximino Leyva Ortiz, wearing an orange jumpsuit, his wrists shackled, stood before a judge in an immigration courtroom in Lower Manhattan, a lawyer at his side. The federal government was seeking to deport him.

keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Amazon Kindle', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The giant retailer announced a program to pay independent bookstores to sell its e-books and popular reading devices.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon is going to the people who dislike and fear it the most — independent bookstore owners — and offering to work together to fulfill the needs and desires of their customers.

headline: Sharp Circle
abstract: An increasingly enjoyable debut by Alan Derkazarian.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I know what you’re thinking. You’re probably thinking, “It’s a rebus. Let’s see how badly Deb messed up on this one.” And, if history is any way to predict these things, you’d be right. But not today.

headline: Playing With a Full Deck, and Your Head
abstract: In “Nothing to Hide,” the magicians Helder Guimarães and Derek DelGaudio mesmerize the audience with nothing more (or less) than playing cards.
lead_paragraph: As I write these words, I sit staring at a playing card. The five of hearts, actually. There’s nothing special about it: It’s from a classic pack, with the familiar oil-defying coating and the ornate design on the back featuring two odd winged creatures on what appear to be bicycles. (Never noticed that before.)

headline: A Cop Will Get a Killer to Sing (That’s Not a Spoiler)
abstract: “Murder for Two,” a vaudevillian mystery musical with an energetic two-man cast, is now playing at New World Stages.
lead_paragraph: “Murder for Two,” which opened at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in July, reopened Wednesday at the New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton; 212-239-6200, telecharge.com. keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Leaders of the Republican establishment are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in less extreme contenders.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Republican establishment, alarmed by the emergence of far-right and often unpredictable Tea Party candidates, are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in the selection of less extreme contenders.

headline: An Exaggerated Vision of the Female Form in Venezuela
abstract: A national embrace of plastic surgery is reflected in increasing sales of mannequins with bulging bosoms and cantilevered buttocks, wasp waists and long legs.
lead_paragraph: A national embrace of plastic surgery is reflected in increasing sales of mannequins with bulging bosoms and cantilevered buttocks, wasp waists and long legs.

headline: Growing Endowments Change Colleges’ Investment Strategy
abstract: After years of increasing, alternative investments like private equity and venture capital funds fell from 54 percent of assets to 47 percent of college endowments.
lead_paragraph: In a year of strong gains, college endowments reversed a long-term trend toward alternative investments like private equity and venture capital funds, according to a study released Wednesday. Overall, endowments earned an 11.7 percent investment return in 2012-13, said the study, by the National Association of College and University Business Officers, and Commonfund. After years of increasing, alternative investments fell from 54 percent of assets to 47 percent. Endowment returns were sharply negative during the recession, then very strong for two years, and near zero in 2011-12.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 6, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Venezuela’s Inflated Vision of Beauty
abstract: In Venezuela, women are confronted with a culture of increasingly enhanced physiques fueled by beauty pageants and plastic surgery.
lead_paragraph: In Venezuela, women are confronted with a culture of increasingly enhanced physiques fueled by beauty pageants and plastic surgery.

headline: Mannequins Give Shape to a Venezuelan Fantasy
abstract: Mannequins with bulging bosoms have become standard in Venezuela, reflecting the country’s embrace of plastic surgery even among those who can least afford it.
lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Venezuela — Frustrated with the modest sales at his small mannequin factory, Eliezer Álvarez made a simple observation: Venezuelan women were increasingly using plastic surgery to transform their bodies, yet the mannequins in clothing stores did not reflect these new, often extreme proportions.

headline: Judge in Terrorism Case Orders Look at Secret Records
abstract: The judge, Col. James Pohl, has ordered the government to show him confidential correspondence about prison conditions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a defense lawyer said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A judge presiding over the military commission’s prosecution of five people accused in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has ordered the government to show him confidential correspondence with the International Committee of the Red Cross about prison conditions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a defense lawyer said Wednesday. The judge, Col. James Pohl, also issued an order taking control of the team that reviews correspondence between defense lawyers and the defendants, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. The order also relaxes some limits on what defense lawyers can discuss with their clients, said James G. Connell III, a defense lawyer for Ali Abd al Aziz Ali. The case has been bogged down in pretrial hearings, with no actual trial in sight. The judge decided that he would review the Red Cross records before deciding whether to allow the lawyers to see them.

headline: A Third Navy Official Is Arrested in Bribery Case
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Navy Cmdr. Jose Luis Sanchez, 41, was arrested in Tampa and was also charged with accepting $100,000 from an Asian ship-servicing company that overbilled the Navy.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors said Wednesday that a third Navy official had been arrested on charges of accepting prostitutes and luxury travel from an Asian ship-servicing company that overbilled the Navy by millions of dollars. Navy Cmdr. Jose Luis Sanchez, 41, was arrested in Tampa and was also charged with accepting $100,000 from Glenn Defense Marine Asia, whose chief executive, Leonard Glenn Francis, was arrested in September. Federal authorities in San Diego have also charged a Navy commander, Michael V.K. Misiewicz, 46, and John B. Beliveau II, a naval investigator, in the case.

keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Mike McGinn, who was elected mayor in 2009, was denied a second term on Tuesday as voters turned instead to Ed Murray, a longtime state senator.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Seattle voters performed what has become a fall ritual: dumping the mayor.

headline: Legal Brief Filed in Support of Judge in Stop-and-Frisk Case
abstract: The filing asked the full federal appeals court in Manhattan to review a decision by a court panel that stripped Judge Shira A. Scheindlin from the case.
lead_paragraph: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio has promised that on Day 1 of his administration, he would withdraw New York City’s appeal of sweeping reforms ordered by a federal judge in the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices.

headline: Arkansas: Man Charged in Power Grid Attacks
abstract: A 37-year-old man was charged with eight counts, including terrorism, in attacks sabotaging a power grid in Central Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: A 37-year-old man was indicted Wednesday in connection with a series of attacks on the power grid in Central Arkansas earlier this year. A federal grand jury charged Jason Woodring with eight counts, including a terrorist attack against a railroad carrier. Mr. Woodring was arrested last month after the authorities said he repeatedly sabotaged electrical equipment and caused at least $2.1 million in damage. In one instance, Mr. Woodring is alleged to have sought to use a moving train to down a support tower. No one was injured in the attacks, which began in August and led to brief power failures.

headline: Food Companies Claim Victory Against Labeling Initiative in Washington State
abstract: With roughly 990,000 votes counted, Washington residents appeared to reject mandatory labeling of genetically engineered products.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s major food companies declared victory on Wednesday over an initiative in Washington State that would have required labeling of some foods that contain biotech ingredients, although supporters of labeling held out hope that hundreds of thousands of uncounted votes might yet turn the tide.

headline: Ace Parker, Pro Football Hall of Famer From Leather-Helmet Days, Dies at 101
abstract: Parker, a star running back in the N.F.L. who also passed, caught passes, punted and place-kicked, was the oldest living member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Ace Parker, a star running back in the National Football League who could do just about everything on a football field in the days of leather helmets and 60-minute men, died on Wednesday in Portsmouth, Va. He was 101 and the oldest living member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

headline: Germany Considers Having Snowden Testify to Inquiry
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: As anger over United States surveillance continues, German officials said they would explore having Edward J. Snowden testify to a parliamentary inquiry.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German government will examine how the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden could testify to a parliamentary inquiry into American intelligence activities in Germany, the interior minister said Wednesday, amid rising demands not only to thank Mr. Snowden for his disclosures but also to grant him full political asylum.

headline: Clifford Nass, Who Warned of a Data Deluge, Dies at 55
abstract: Dr. Nass, a professor a Stanford, studied the effects of technology and in one pioneering study showed the deleterious effects of multitasking.
lead_paragraph: Clifford Nass, a Stanford professor whose pioneering research into how humans interact with technology found that the increasingly screen-saturated, multitasking modern world was not nurturing the ability to concentrate, analyze or feel empathy, died on Nov. 2 near Lake Tahoe. He was 55.

headline: Strong Mix of Art Propels a Fine Night at Sotheby’s
abstract: Bidders from 36 countries helped set record prices for several artists, but the highlight was a Giacometti bronze, which sold for $50 million.
lead_paragraph: “So the market is alive, right?” asked the relieved auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, as a buoyant, two-hour sale of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby’s concluded on Wednesday night. After two dreary evening sales at Christie’s this week, fears that the art market was diving into the doldrums were dashed, at least for one night.

abstract: A group of leading foundations, including the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, is erecting a center in Hudson Square to gather New Yorker’s views about the city’s future.

abstract: To realize the full intent of the Dodd-Frank financial reforms, big banks must be scaled back until a failure of one would not set off a global financial crisis, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Lee Harvey Oswald Was My Friend
abstract: Fifty years after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, an academic looks back at the summer that might have changed Oswald’s life.
lead_paragraph: It was 7 a.m. on Sunday when the single phone at the bottom of the stairs echoed through my parents’ red-brick house, right off Monticello Park in Fort Worth. “Mr. Gregory,” a woman said as my father picked up, “I need your help.” Who are you? he asked in his Texas-Russian accent, still half-asleep.

headline: Stars of the Silver Screen in Black Sweaters

lead_paragraph: In one of Victor Skrebneski’s earliest memories from the 1930s, he is 4 years old and sitting in the fifth row at Chicago’s Standard movie theater for a matinee double bill. His neck strains as he looks almost straight up at the towering image of Frankenstein.

headline: What Can Older People Learn From Your Generation?

headline: Why Zimbabwe Sanctions Boomerang

Shame, shame, shame to Britain and its allies,” he declared at the United Nations General Assembly in September. “Zimbabwe is for Zimbabweans, so are its resources. Please remove your illegal and filthy sanctions from my peaceful country.”

For most people in this nation of immigrants it is a Brazilian car with distant German roots.
