lead_paragraph: Twitter is ready for its Wall Street debut. The social media company set the price of its initial public offering at $26 a share on Wednesday evening, raising $1.8 billion and achieving a valuation of $18.1 billion, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times. Its stock is set to begin trading on Thursday under the ticker symbol TWTR on the New York Stock Exchange. The I.P.O. price, a subject of debate between the board and its underwriters until late on Wednesday afternoon, came in above an already heightened price range, reflecting strong demand for the stock, Mr. Goel reports.

headline: Fresno State Loves Its Bulldogs, but So Does a Gang

They call their children “little dogs” or “bull puppies.” Police raids find their targets asleep beneath red blankets emblazoned with the dog.

headline: Fast-Paced Evolution in the Andes
abstract: The remarkable ecosystems known as Páramos are home to the fastest evolution on Earth, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: In 1799 the great naturalist Alexander von Humboldt and his companions set out from Caracas, Venezuela, to climb the Andes. They struggled up a mountainside enveloped in mist so thick they had to clamber over rocks by hand. When the fog cleared, von Humboldt was left astonished by the view. Vast grasslands stretched all around him, home to an astonishing number of different trees, shrubs and flowers.

headline: Wendy Davis, Texas Legislator, to Write Memoir
abstract: Ms. Davis, whose 11-hour filibuster elevated her stature in the Democratic Party, is running for governor.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator whose 11-hour legislative filibuster of an abortion bill gave her instant fame in the Democratic Party, is about to take the next logical step in her political ascent: writing a memoir.

headline: Today in Small Business: Amazon’s Trojan Rabbit
abstract: Does Hubspot really work? Why small businesses have the most to gain from bitcoin. And Blockbuster gives up.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Carnegie Hall Benefit to Turn Nathan Lane Into Nathan Detroit Once Again
abstract: The actor will star alongside Megan Mullally, Patrick Wilson and Sierra Boggess in a one-night concert staging of “Guys and Dolls.”
lead_paragraph: For one night Nathan Lane will again roll the dice as the gambler Nathan Detroit in Carnegie Hall’s concert staging of “Guys and Dolls,” the music hall announced on Thursday.

headline: Colon Cancer Screening Lags
abstract: A third of older adults have not been appropriately screened for colon cancer.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all adults aged 50 to 75 be screened for colorectal cancer, but the agency announced this week that one third of them — 23 million people — have never been properly tested.

headline: The Long-Term Cost of Feckless Policy
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A study by three Federal Reserve economists indicates that an insufficient response to stagnation may not only hamper short-term output but also reduce the very potential for growth, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: In Fashion | Conquering the Urban Jungle
abstract: It’s a jungle out there. Keep bold patterns and prints refined by pairing them with monochromatic separates.
lead_paragraph: Tropical looks used to be best left at the beach, but this season printed bags, chunky sandals and Hawaiian shirts hit the street in a sophisticated mash-up.

headline: White House Tours Resume
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Sunny (Dog)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Public tours of the White House have resumed, although only three days a week.
lead_paragraph: The White House has resumed public tours of the executive residence and East Wing this week, after severe cuts to the government’s budget in March, known as sequestration, ended the visits, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Senate Approves Ban on Antigay Bias in Workplace
abstract: The Senate voted 64 to 32 in a bipartisan show of support that is rare for any social issue, though the bill’s prospects in the House are uncertain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved a ban on discrimination in the workplace based on sexual orientation and gender identity, voting 64 to 32 in a bipartisan show of support that is rare for any social issue. It was the first time in the institution’s history that it had voted to include gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people in the country’s nondiscrimination law.

headline: Ruling From the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
abstract: Jesse M. Furman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, found that the city, through “benign neglect,” was in violation of the of the Americans of Disabilities Act.
lead_paragraph: Jesse M. Furman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, found that the city, through “benign neglect,” was in violation of the of the Americans of Disabilities Act.

headline: What Our Patients Can Teach Us
abstract: A critical component to true health care reform is in changing our core expectations about the use of heroic measures at the end of life.
lead_paragraph: When the man who was about to become my patient couldn’t tolerate the fatigue any longer, he asked his son, one of 10 children, to take him in their buggy from his woodworking shop to the local doctor who tended to this Amish community, located 90 miles south of Cleveland. Labs showed a white blood cell count that was 12 times normal and profound anemia, and he was driven by ambulance to our hospital.

headline: Kerry Takes Personal Approach to Mideast Peace
abstract: Unlike Hillary Rodham Clinton, who mostly left managing the peace process to others, Secretary of State John Kerry seems to enjoy grinding it out.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Traveling around the Middle East with Secretary of State John Kerry, particularly for a reporter whose last State Department tour was with Hillary Rodham Clinton, is a seat-of-the-pants experience. Itineraries are notional. Improvisation is the rule.

headline: Goldman Discloses Foreign Exchange Inquiry
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Many of the largest banks in the currency trading market have acknowledged that they are facing inquiries from authorities in the United States, Europe and Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—Goldman Sachs on Thursday became the latest big bank to acknowledge that it was the subject of a series of wide-ranging investigations into the potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland to Pay $153.7 Million to Settle Mortgage Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission concluded that a bank subsidiary failed to investigate the quality of the underlying loans in a mortgage-backed security offering in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:14 p.m. |

headline: Michael Palmer, Doctor Who Became Top Author, Dies at 71
abstract: Dr. Palmer sold about five million books worldwide, including “Extreme Measures” and “Natural Causes,” after going through years of alcohol and drug addiction.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Michael Palmer, a physician who began writing tightly plotted thrillers at his kitchen table in 1978 to escape the inner chaos of alcohol and drug addiction, in the process finding a worldwide audience (and sobriety) as the author of top sellers like “Extreme Measures” and “Natural Causes,” died on Oct. 30 in Queens. He was 71.

headline: The Gun Report: November 7, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The father of Jose Reyes, the 12-year-old boy who killed a math teacher and wounded two classmates before committing suicide at a Sparks, Nev., middle school on Oct. 21, said the handgun his son used was procured from their home and wasn’t locked up. Jose Reyes and his wife, Liliana, said they never told him where the 9mm semi-automatic pistol was stored, but he somehow managed to find it.

headline: Katia Beauchamp of Birchbox, on the Strength of Optimism
abstract: The co-founder of a beauty products website wants employees who take control of their careers and don’t project negativism.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Katia Beauchamp, co-founder and co-chief executive of Birchbox, a beauty products website, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Court Says New York Neglected Disabled in Emergencies
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the city, which was sued after Tropical Storm Irene, has failed to accommodate for the needs of disabled residents during times of crisis.
lead_paragraph: New York City has violated the rights of about 900,000 of its residents with disabilities by failing to accommodate for their needs during emergencies, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: Scene City: At AREA Nightclubbing as an Art Form
abstract: AREA, the legendary nightclub from 30 years ago, reopens for one night only.
lead_paragraph: AREA, the legendary nightclub from 30 years ago, reopens for one night only.

headline: The CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund: Where No Designer Is Left Behind
abstract: Many have landed high-profile positions or new backers. But has it all been a bed of roses?
lead_paragraph: Many have landed high-profile positions or new backers. But has it all been a bed of roses?

headline: Card Act Cleared Up Credit Cards’ Hidden Costs
keywords: ['Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act (2009)', 'Credit Cards', 'Consumer Protection', 'Personal Finances', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Economists found that the Card Act, passed in 2009, saved consumers billions of dollars by cutting through a tangle of credit card fees.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Congress decided to force down the hidden fees that credit card companies collect from their customers. It passed a law called the 2009 Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act — a name chosen so the law would be known as the Card Act.

headline: Imported From Turkey, a Taste of Home
abstract: Good spirits and native Turkish cooking can be found at Lisa’s Mediterranean Cuisine in Ridgewood, a restaurant run by Lisa Mayisoglu and Selma Sozen, her sister.
lead_paragraph: For proof of how far hard work and a good attitude can take you in life, one could do worse than drop in at Lisa’s Mediterranean Cuisine in downtown Ridgewood.

headline: Reaction Is Cautiously Positive to India’s Bank Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The guidelines will make it easier for global banks to enter the Indian market, analysts said, a step toward opening up India’s long-protected banking sector.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — New regulations issued by India’s central bank would make it easier and more attractive for global banks to enter the Indian market, a senior banker and several analysts said on Thursday, though they cautioned that restrictions in the rules might slow the pace of expansion.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Player Tiers
abstract: Applying an algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data reveals natural tiers and clusters within the data.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: My Caribbean: 5 Vignettes
abstract: From a “mind-blowing” experience in the Dominican Republic to a “profound sense of awe” on Barbados, writers share personal stories about islands that matter to them.
lead_paragraph: How do you define the Caribbean? Writers intimately acquainted with the islands answer with postcards from their ancestral homes.

headline: Festivals Where the Beat Makes You Move
abstract: Want to mix music into a Caribbean vacation? Here’s a guide to festivals next year from Anguilla to St. Lucia.
lead_paragraph: Am I the only one who returns from the Caribbean acutely in need of rest? Blame the music. The region is drenched in genres I crave — reggae, calypso, zouk, and the list goes on — which means that night after night has me feeling like Odysseus battling the Sirens: cursed be that delicious din at the dancehall or the rum shop, destined to foil my fantasy of an early night’s sleep.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Looking to Norwegian, 22, to Revive Image of Chess
abstract: Magnus Carlsen, hip and telegenic, is taking on Viswanathan Anand for the world championship title on Saturday, but more is at stake than prize money.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, and Viswanathan Anand, a 43-year-old Indian, will stride to the center of a stage in a hotel in Chennai, India, shake hands and sit down at a chess board to begin a match for the world championship title.

headline: Rev. Eugene Callender, Who Saw Potential of School Dropouts, Dies at 87
abstract: Dr. Callender ministered in Harlem, served in the Lindsay and Mario Cuomo administrations and started a chain of “street academies” that became a model for programs nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Eugene S. Callender, a civil rights advocate best known for starting an innovative series of “street academies” for disadvantaged New York City youths that became a model for nontraditional educational programs nationwide, died on Nov. 2 in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: British Intelligence Chiefs Say Leaks by Snowden Hurt Security
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: In open testimony before Parliament, the three top intelligence officials in Britain said their ability to keep the country safe had been compromised.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s intelligence chiefs, in unprecedented public testimony before Parliament, said on Thursday that the published leaks of secret documents stolen by Edward J. Snowden, the former American intelligence analyst, had damaged their ability to keep Britain safe.

headline: Congo Rebels, After Giving Up Struggle, Are Disarmed
abstract: The Ugandan military has begun the process of taking weapons away from members of the rebel group known as M23.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Ugandan military has begun the process of disarming large numbers of rebels from the neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo, a military spokesman said Thursday.

headline: Living With Cancer: Tumbling Blocks
abstract: Three of my former graduate students have received a cancer diagnosis. Why are these people so young, and why are there so many? This cannot, should not, be happening to my students.
lead_paragraph: On a night several months ago, the digital clock blinked 11:53. My husband was asleep so I crept down the hall, only turning on a light when I got into my study. On a sheet on the floor were fabrics laid out for a new quilt in the tumbling block pattern. Pictures of my friends kept me company, but there was no photo of the woman over whom I was grieving.

headline: Hedge Fund Is Said to Push for Men’s Wearhouse Merger
abstract: Eminence Capital has acquired about a 9.8 percent stake in Men’s Wearhouse and is said to be planning to push for strategic options like a proposed merger with Jos. A. Bank.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two months, Men’s Wearhouse has steadfastly rebuffed a $2.3 billion takeover bid by a smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank.

headline: The Intrepid’s Re-enlisted Artifacts
abstract: Souvenirs of service aboard the Intrepid; Käthe Kollwitz’s disparate portfolio; African headrests.
lead_paragraph: Veterans of World War II and Vietnam War service on the Intrepid aircraft carrier, despite miserable living conditions aboard, developed sentimental attachments to souvenirs. Hundreds of artifacts have been donated in the last few months to the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in New York, in honor of the carrier’s 70th anniversary.

headline: So Far, So Good for Twitter
abstract: Twitter reached a valuation of $31.7 billion as it began trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, a figure the company will have to justify by showing a profit sooner rather than later.
lead_paragraph: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange called out orders for shares of Twitter for the first time Thursday morning as one of Wall Street’s traditional rituals thrust the young company into the public markets.

headline: Ethiopian Lunch Box
abstract: The pop-up vegan restaurant operates inside Mama Joy’s during daytime hours in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The pop-up vegan restaurant operates inside Mama Joy’s during daytime hours in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: The Ceremony Outshines the Stage
abstract: The dishes at Ethiopian Lunch Box, operating inside another restaurant in Bushwick, Brooklyn, reflect a long tradition of vegan cooking in the chef’s homeland.
lead_paragraph: “Is something burning?” someone at my table whispered.

headline: The Implications of Ownership
abstract: “Owners,” a 1972 play by Caryl Churchill at the Yale Repertory Theater, taps the ethos of “Do what you want. Get what you can.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s so ’70s” was the consensus of a group leaving a recent performance of the Yale Repertory Theater, where Caryl Churchill’s “Owners” is giving theatergoers much to discuss on the way home.

headline: Rape in the Ranks
abstract: A video explaining why Senator Gillibrand’s reform bill is so necessary.
lead_paragraph: At a press conference on Capitol Hill yesterday, two Marine veterans explained their support for Senator Kirsten Gillibrand’s bill to reform the way the military handles sexual assault cases. Instead of letting the accuser’s commander oversee the investigation and decide whether to bring charges, Ms. Gillibrand argues — sensibly — that such authority should rest outside the chain of command, with impartial military prosecutors.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Ashley Williams’s Raccoon Bag
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a colorful, furry friend for the slightly eccentric.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Twitter as the Yin to Facebook’s Yang
abstract: Twitter’s more muted approach more clearly benefits prospective investors, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s public debut is turning out to be the yin to Facebook’s yang.

headline: Marinated Snark Is a Dish Best Served Cold
abstract: Dana Goodyear’s “Anything That Moves” is a gastronomic adventure of exploring unusual foodstuff.
lead_paragraph: Dana Goodyear’s new book, about being a wallflower at the American food orgy, won me over on its second page. That’s where she admits that, as a kid in the back of the family station wagon, she used to nibble on Milk-Bone dog biscuits. I’m not sure why this image lit up my pleasure sensors. These Scooby snacks were, she writes, “tastier than you might expect.”

headline: More to Remember Than Just the Madeleine
abstract: The centennial of Marcel Proust’s “Swann’s Way” is being remembered through various events in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Most people spend the week before a marathon resting up and carbo loading.

headline: Your Advice for Seeing Chicago With Kids
abstract: What are the best ways to tackle the city with children? We’re looking for your tips.
lead_paragraph: After starting in New York, then heading to Paris, our series on traveling to big cities with children returns to the United States next week with a stop in Chicago.

headline: Trends from HTML5 Dev Conf
abstract: Andre Behrens shares trends he noticed at HTML5 Dev Conf.
lead_paragraph: I recently attended the HTML5 Developer Conference (their second event of 2013, I also went to the April conference) in San Francisco and enjoyed the sessions and feel. Here are a few trends I noticed this time:

headline: Touches of Tokyo, but California Rolls, Too
abstract: At the Norimaki restaurant, a co-owner was born in Japan and the menu offers items both challenging and satisfying to Western tastes.
lead_paragraph: Norimaki maintains a low profile between a furniture store and a dry cleaner in a small shopping plaza at the center of Washington Depot. Only two small signs hang outside; one is in Japanese characters, and the other says simply “sushi.” The restaurant’s spacious, 1,000-square-foot dining area contains just 22 seats (including six at the sushi bar), with the center of the room occupied by a tree sculpture that appears to be growing through the dropped ceiling.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Book Thief’ and ‘Auschwitz Shifts From Memorializing to Teaching’
abstract: A literary passage and a Times article, paired to raise questions for students about how the story of the Holocaust can and should be told to a new generation.
lead_paragraph: Over the years we have written extensively about the Holocaust, and linked in our lessons to just a tiny fraction of the thousands of articles on the topic that can be found in The Times’s archives.

headline: Bruce Dern in Pictures
abstract: Images from the actor’s career.
lead_paragraph: Images from the actor’s career.

headline: ‘Qualified’ Loans, Redefined
abstract: Lenders will be required to meet new underwriting standards for “qualified mortgages” — those eligible for sale on the secondary market.
lead_paragraph: The mortgage industry is bracing for the coming of “Q.M.,” the new federal rules defining a “qualified mortgage” — or one underwritten to standards deemed safe for consumers. The implementation of Q.M. poses a compliance headache for lenders, though the average borrower is unlikely to notice any difference when the rules take effect in January. The most immediate differences will be felt by borrowers at the higher and lower ends of the income scale.

headline: Gift Guide
abstract: Each day until Christmas, check in for a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, check in for a new holiday gift idea.

headline: For Vinyl Collectors, a $482,000 Bargain on eBay
abstract: The owner of On the Beat Records in London is offering his records – and store – on eBay.
lead_paragraph: Pssst. Wanna buy a record shop?

headline: Different Kinds of Health Care Disruption
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Comparing Obamacare’s disruption of existing insurance policies to the possible impact of conservative alternative.
lead_paragraph: After yesterday’s detour into electoral politics, let’s turn back to the health care debate. Last week, amid the ongoing coverage of rising premiums and cancelled plans, the health care law’s defenders took a new tack, arguing that the most plausible conservative alternatives to Obamacare would involve even more disruption of existing arrangements — with the implication being, then, that Republican outrage over “rate shock “is either straightforwardly cynical or else a sign that the G.O.P. would never, ever be willing to embrace a reform that disrupts the status quo at all.

headline: When Nest Emptied, Discontent Entered
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Women and Girls', 'Baby Boomers', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Parenting']
abstract: Arlene and Ed Petty first tried a trial separation, but looking back they would have chosen a different path.
lead_paragraph: When their last child left for college, Arlene Petty, now 64, felt resentment about her decades-long marriage to Ed Petty, also now 64. Facing an empty nest, she asked for a trial separation. In hindsight, both would have done things very differently.

headline: Photos From the Underground
abstract: The underground persists, but now it likes a little exposure.
lead_paragraph: The underground persists, but now it likes a little exposure.

headline: A Portrait of Eternally Beguiling Americana
abstract: The artful simplicity of “Our Town,” at the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey, is enhanced by staging both beautiful and thoughtful.
lead_paragraph: During the two intermissions of a recent performance of “Our Town” at the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey, I overheard a number of older patrons remark that they had never before seen it. That was a bit surprising, because this great, enduring play by Thornton Wilder has been staged countless times since its 1938 premiere in Princeton.

headline: What Obama Could Do for L.G.B.T. Workplace Protections
abstract: The Senate passed the Employment Non-Discrimination Act. But the House is unlikely to follow suit.
lead_paragraph: The United States Senate, which has had us all switching to the Paint Drying Network in search of relative excitement, did its job today and passed, 64-32, an important, far-too-delayed bill to ban discrimination in the workplace based on sexual orientation or identity.

headline: A Tax Subsidy for Richer Schools
abstract: The federal deduction for property taxes, the main source of public school funding, reduced federal income tax by $27 billion this year — more than the Education Department’s aid to K-12 education.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11/8/13 | to add chart and to include mention of 2004 study on deductibility.

headline: Letters: Searching for Kennedy
abstract: Readers respond to a recent essay about John F. Kennedy and recent reviews of books by Margaret MacMillan, Jonathan Franzen and John Boyne.
lead_paragraph: Searching for Kennedy

headline: Applying Plumbers’ Common Sense to Fix Europe’s Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Executive Compensation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Charlie Mullins, known as London’s richest plumber, has been on a vocal crusade to reduce bankers’ pay and force banks to become more cost-effective.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Mullins made his fortune fixing other people’s plumbing. More recently, Mr. Mullins, the outspoken founder and owner of Pimlico Plumbers in London, is seeking to fix the European banking sector.

headline: A Simple Way to Perk Up an Old-Fashioned
abstract: Two simple syrup recipes to go in an Old-Fashioned that are worth a little extra effort.
lead_paragraph: The recipe for Josey Packard’s Autumnal Old Fashioned — which appears in my Drink column this weekend — includes smallish quantities of two syrups: One with cinnamon, the other with Demerara sugar. These are easy to prepare, so don’t let the prospect of a little extra work deter you from making the cocktail.

headline: The Great Old-Fashioned Debate
abstract: Streamlined or with fruit? It has been more than a century, and people still can’t decide.
lead_paragraph: There’s a terrific mini-monologue in the 1942 film “You Were Never Lovelier” in which Fred Astaire’s fast-talking would-be roué tells Rita Hayworth’s ingénue: “As they’d say in Brooklyn, I can’t bat in your league. I’m a plain, ordinary guy from Omaha, Nebraska. Just an old-fashioned, everyday Middle Westerner.. . . But you’re streamlined. You’re today. Sister, I was raised amongst the grasshoppers, I am strictly from corn.” And then the duo breaks into song and dance, which is where Jerome Kern and Johnny Mercer’s sublime ballad, “I’m Old Fashioned,” debuted.

headline: War of Umbrage
abstract: In this follow-up to “Game Change,” the political reporters Mark Halperin and John Heilemann offer a detailed account of the 2012 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: “Chasmal.” Is that a word? Here, I’ll use it in a sentence for you: “Santorum had been turfed out of office in 2006, losing his re-election bid by a chasmal 18-point margin.” According to Merriam Webster, it is indeed a word, meaning ­“resembling a chasm.” In other words, Santorum got beaten badly. But why use other words, when “chasmal” is available?

headline: Da Vinci and the Biblioteca Reale
abstract: A look at works in an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at works in an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum.

headline: Where a Little Dose of Leonardo Is Still a Lot
abstract: An exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum features a group of works by Leonardo da Vinci from the Biblioteca Reale in Turin, Italy, including one of his celebrated notebooks.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, the Metropolitan Museum mounted an exhibition of just under 100 drawings by Leonardo da Vinci and pulled in close to half a million visitors in just over two months. This fall, the Morgan Library & Museum is presenting a miniature — very miniature — version of that show called “Leonardo da Vinci: Treasures From the Biblioteca Reale, Turin,” and it, too, should generate serious traffic, particularly as it includes two outstanding items — a book and a drawing — that the Met didn’t have.

headline: No Fairy Tale: Robert Hilburn Talks About ‘Johnny Cash: The Life’
abstract: Mr. Hilburn’s new biography covers the many highs and lows of the Man in Black’s career.
lead_paragraph: Robert Hilburn’s new biography of Johnny Cash starts with Cash as a young boy in rural Arkansas, walking along a gravel road at night and singing to himself. The more than 600 pages that follow cover everything — from the famed concert in Folsom Prison (Mr. Hilburn was there that day) to the unlikely, celebrated records Cash made with the hip-hop producer Rick Rubin starting in 1994. As Stephen Holden wrote in his obituary of Cash when the singer died at 71 in 2003, he “was one of the few performers who outlasted trends to become a mythical figure rediscovered by each new generation.” In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hilburn, a former longtime music critic for The Los Angeles Times, discussed the biopic “Walk the Line,” Cash’s tumultuous marriage to June Carter, Cash’s influence today and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: After a Break, Turkey’s Prime Minister Again Courts Controversy
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who had tempered his often divisive public comments after protests a few months ago, stirs anger by attacking a new target: coed dormitories.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In his time in power, more than a decade now, Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has alienated large portions of the population for his seeming intrusions into private lives. He has told women how many children they should have, has sought to outlaw abortion and adultery and to limit alcohol consumption and once, oddly, went on a public tirade against white bread.

headline: An Ibsen Who Rages Over Ritalin and Economic Austerity Plans
abstract: An adaptation of “An Enemy of the People,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater, updates the play into a critique of modern society.
lead_paragraph: “Get on with the play!”

headline: The Subjects Aren’t the Same
abstract: The Print Fair, of the International Fine Art Dealers Association, features many works exploring women’s identity,
lead_paragraph: Stepping into the Park Avenue Armory, you can time-travel backward through the history of prints, if you care to. Contemporary ones are clustered near the entrance to the International Fine Print Dealers Association’s annual Print Fair, now in its 23rd year, but a fine selection of modern and old master prints lies just beyond.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Monet Seaside Gardens, Blooming Side by Side
abstract: “Garden at Sainte-Adresse,” Monet’s 1867 painting of a sun-dappled seaside, has belonged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1967. For the next six months, anyway, it has a new companion.
lead_paragraph: “Garden at Sainte-Adresse,” Monet’s 1867 painting of a sun-dappled seaside that features the artist’s father, Adolphe, wearing a panama hat and watching boats, has belonged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1967. For the next six months, anyway, it has a new companion. Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive and co-founder of the Oracle Corporation, has lent the museum Monet’s “Adolphe Monet Reading in a Garden,” painted the same year, in which the artist’s father — wearing the same clothes — is relaxing with a newspaper in the shade.

headline: Steve Mumford: ‘The Snow Leopard’
abstract: Steve Mumford traveled to Guantánamo Bay Naval Station and brought back loosely realistic watercolors of things he saw.
lead_paragraph: Postmasters

headline: Konrad Lueg
abstract: Konrad Lueg had a short-lived career as an artist and a much longer one as a dealer.
lead_paragraph: Greene Naftali

headline: Martina Bacigalupo: ‘Gulu Real Art Studio’
abstract: In 2010, the Italian photojournalist Martina Bacigalupo spent time in the city of Gulu in northern Uganda, where she came across a curious form of portraiture.
lead_paragraph: The Walther Collection Project Space

headline: Arlene Shechet: ‘Slip’
abstract: In her latest, largely terrific exhibition, Arlene Shechet continues to expand upon the ceramic vessel as a one-stop art medium.

headline: Fixing the System: Your Turn
abstract: I asked, you answered. Here are your suggestions for fixing the political and electoral system.
lead_paragraph: In my last column I asked readers for their best ideas about how to fix the political and electoral system. Here’s a sampling of the responses. Thanks to everyone who participated.
