abstract: Photos from New York, Japan, Bangladesh and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Japan, Bangladesh and Spain.

headline: Housing Treasures and Trivia of Two World’s Fairs
abstract: A trove of artifacts at the newly renovated Queens Museum serves as a reminder that the building itself is a kind of artifact, built to house the New York City Pavilion at the 1939 fair.
lead_paragraph: ON April 22, 1963, John F. Kennedy, sitting in the Oval Office, pressed the numbers 1964 on an early touch-tone telephone. It was an exciting, if stage-managed, moment.

headline: The Corporate Chief of Sex as Big Business
abstract: “Filthy Gorgeous: The Bob Guccione Story” is an admiring portrait of the founder of the erotic magazine Penthouse.
lead_paragraph: Good Bob has “Filthy Gorgeous: The Bob Guccione Story” almost entirely to himself. Bad Bob never shows up, though Incompetent Bob does have a cameo.

headline: At Your Disposal
abstract: In this novel, Jonathan Miles explores varieties of waste and decay in a consumer world.
lead_paragraph: Well, I loved this book. I don’t know if it helps you or anyone to delay that assessment, so I won’t. Jonathan Miles can write, and here he’s written a wonderful book, and there’s no one I would not urge to read it.

headline: Another Dickens Orphan, Still Seeking More
abstract: Mike Newell’s new version of “Great Expectations” features supporting work by Ralph Fiennes and Helena Bonham Carter.
lead_paragraph: Mike Newell’s screen adaptation of Charles Dickens’s “Great Expectations” is never more alive than when it pauses from its breakneck storytelling to gawk at the chaos of 19th-century London. There is Pip, a former blacksmith’s assistant, now outfitted as a gentleman, being shoved this way and that while stumbling through the mud and the carnage of a London meat market. The bacchanals of the Finches of the Grove, the rich boys’ club he joins, are deafening animal-house melees of flying furniture and dishes.

headline: Safety Board Faults Truck and Bus Oversight
abstract: Federal safety officials missed warning signs before four crashes involving trucks or tour buses that left 25 people dead in the last year, the National Transportation Safety Board said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal safety officials missed or ignored warning signs before four deadly crashes involving heavy trucks or intercity buses in the last year, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday. The government shut down some of the companies, but only after a total of 25 people were killed and 83 injured in the four accidents.

headline: Art at Industry City, and Concerts for Brooklyn Conservatory
abstract: An exhibition in Sunset Park by artists hit by Hurricane Sandy; Dan Zanes gives three benefit concerts for the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year since Hurricane Sandy ransacked the city, certain communities are still recovering. Artists whose studios and galleries are clustered in hard-hit neighborhoods, like Chelsea in Manhattan and Red Hook in Brooklyn, were particularly affected, and to celebrate their perseverance, the artist and Brooklyn Rail publisher Phong Bui, whose own studio was ruined in the storm, has organized “Come Together: Surviving Sandy,” a new exhibition at the vast Industry City complex in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Next Cast of Yankees? To Be Continued
abstract: The Yankees won’t know if Derek Jeter can be the everyday shortstop until they see him in games, or whether Alex Rodriguez can play at all until an arbitrator decides.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter recently began working out in Tampa, Fla., in his effort to return to the Yankees as their everyday shortstop, and that is the team’s plan. But Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged Thursday that the Yankees could not be certain that Jeter, their 39-year-old captain, who is coming off the worst injury of his career, would be able to do so until they saw him in games. For now, it is merely a hope.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Love Is Its Own Reward
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Gifts', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Parenting', 'Parties (Social)', 'Dating and Courtship']
abstract: Addressing matters of families and gifts, an unwanted pass with a needed endorsement, a sour side note and sweet retribution, and a drink by any other name.
lead_paragraph: For the last nine years, I have been raising an ex’s son as my own. I am about to become his legal guardian. I never married or had biological children, so this is probably the only official family event I will have in my life. I have gone to countless weddings, showers, brises, christenings — you name it — and have given generously and happily to my friends. If my family hosts a celebration for the guardianship, would it be wrong to strongly hint that equivalent, big occasion gifts are welcome?

headline: Song and Dance, With Groove
abstract: Justin Timberlake, with signature songs and moves, kicked off his solo tour at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: What a trouper Justin Timberlake is. He started his solo tour — after sharing a summer tour with Jay Z — at Barclays Center on Wednesday night with a lavish marathon of a concert: two full-length sets separated by an intermission and ending just after midnight. He mustered large forces: dancers, a big band with horns, extensive videos and lasers, and an overhead catwalk-like stage that traversed the whole arena. (He brings his show to the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on Saturday.)

headline: This Guy’s No Puppy Hugger
abstract: Bill Burr, who performs Friday night at the New York Comedy Festival, exploits the anger of a domesticated white guy with caustic thoughts.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Bill Burr has a name that perfectly matches his delivery: informal, punchy, with a quick staccato snap.

headline: Disney Reports 13% Increase in Profit
abstract: Theme park and movie divisions were up, but television-related businesses reported declines.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company reported a 13 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, as strength in three major divisions — theme parks, consumer products and movies — offset television-related declines.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: medical marijuana, hepatitis C and contaminated chicken. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: medical marijuana, hepatitis C and contaminated chicken. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Tackling Obstacles, the Good Kind
abstract: Obstacle course races, a growing fitness activity, require a specialized skill set; fortunately, there’s a training center for that.
lead_paragraph: AT the Epic Hybrid Training Center in Manhattan, there are monkey bars, ropes, sandbags, resistance bands and some mysterious contraptions in place of the usual exercise machines and weights.

headline: A Refuge Found in Pages
abstract: “The Book Thief” reveals how a girl copes during the horrors of adolescence and World War II.
lead_paragraph: Speaking in the honeyed, insinuating tone of the Wolf cajoling Little Red Riding Hood to do his bidding, the narrator of “The Book Thief” is none other than Death himself (Roger Allam), although he coyly refuses to disclose his identity. This irritating know-it-all regularly interrupts the story of Liesel (Sophie Nélisse), a bright-eyed girl living with foster parents in a fictional German town during World War II, to comment obliquely on human nature and mortality.

headline: Originator of the Man-Skirt and Corset Revivals
abstract: The Brooklyn Museum displays the collections of Jean Paul Gaultier, corset and man-skirt designer, who witnessed the ascent of punk, New Wave and cultural and identity politics.
lead_paragraph: Jean Paul Gaultier’s contribution to late-20th-century fashion might be summed up in two garments: the corset and the men’s skirt. Stepping back a bit, however, Mr. Gaultier accomplished much more than that. He was one of the first openly gay designers, and in an era ruled by street fashion, he made being a high-fashion designer seem cool. The army of pop stars who followed in his wake, becoming designers themselves, is evidence of this, as well as the popularity of television shows like “Project Runway” and the smaller contingent of artists who have used fashion collections and runway shows as models for performance-based art works. (Just this week, Rainer Ganahl’s “Comme des Marxists,” an obvious play on Comme des Garçons, appeared at White Columns as part of Performa 13.)

headline: After a Parent’s Death, a Rush of Change
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Parenting', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: A writer goes from being lesbian and not wanting children, to dating men and trying to conceive.
lead_paragraph: When my father died six months shy of his 83rd birthday and my 42nd, I was shocked to find that in the midst of grief, one clear desire emerged, uncontestable: I wanted a child. This was not a decision, or even really a thought; it was more like a reflex.

headline: In Paris, a Ragtag, Resplendent District Prepares for Its Close-Up
abstract: The 25 million euro restoration of a classic Art Deco movie theater has shined a new light on the rough but storied neighborhood of Barbès.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Major University and How It Works
abstract: Frederick Wiseman’s documentary “At Berkeley” takes viewers into the classrooms and the broad campus life of a well-functioning university.
lead_paragraph: “At Berkeley,” the documentarian Frederick Wiseman’s magisterial examination of the University of California, Berkeley, is conspicuous for not identifying the scores of people shown teaching, studying and exchanging ideas in and out of the classroom. Some may recognize the university’s chipper, ever-smiling former chancellor Robert J. Birgeneau, who retired this year. An even more prominent figure is Robert Reich, the former secretary of labor, now a professor at Berkeley’s Goldman School of Public Policy, who delivers an insightful lecture on leadership and the need for self-evaluation.

headline: Guide Dog Schools
abstract: Training animals at guide dog schools takes two years and can cost $60,000.
lead_paragraph: Training animals at guide dog schools takes two years and can cost $60,000.

headline: Here, Home for a Baton
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s Contact! series finds a new location, at SubCulture, for its concert led by Esa-Pekka Salonen.
lead_paragraph: Good news: With the fifth season of Contact!, the contemporary-music series the New York Philharmonic inaugurated in 2009, comes a performance space that finally suits the informal tone the orchestra desired but never previously delivered.

headline: Precious Eyes
abstract: Guide dog training is a charity with a high cost, but one that has an incalculable payback.
lead_paragraph: JENNIFER MURRAY woke after a night out with friends and thought her husband was playing a trick on her. She could not see anything and did not believe him when he said it was daytime.

headline: How to Choose a Charity Wisely
abstract: Discriminating givers can turn to services and strategies to make sure their donations will mostly be spent on a charity’s stated mission.
lead_paragraph: DONATING to charities this time of year used to be relatively efficient and painless. After watching the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, you plunked some money into a Salvation Army bucket, wrote some checks, contributed some household items and were done.

headline: The Produce Isn’t Pretty, but It’s Edible
keywords: ['Food', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Nonprofit groups like Rotary First Harvest attack the hunger problem by gathering edible vegetables and fruit left behind in fields after harvest, some with cosmetic damage.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — BENJAMIN RASMUS cycled 850 miles over 10 days around Washington State last year to promote gleaning, or gathering edible produce left behind in fields after harvest.

headline: A Donation With Name Recognition
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Philanthropy', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: There are many chances to help an institution by giving a donation and having a name on a building or event.
lead_paragraph: AT the Children’s Center, a nonprofit organization that provides mental health services to families in Salt Lake City, some children might be drawing in the Dr. Paula Swaner and Dr. William McCreary art therapy room. Their parents could be meeting with staff members in the Katherine W. Dumke and Ezekiel R. Dumke Jr. speech and language therapy office.

headline: Her Name Is Famous, but She’s Not About Nothing
abstract: Jessica Seinfeld, in running her charity, Baby Buggy, which provides baby clothing, gear and services to families in need, has had to surmount the fact that her husband is Jerry.
lead_paragraph: YOU expect to see Jessica Seinfeld at fancy galas, turned out in designer gowns and stiletto pumps, smiling for the camera on the arm of her famous husband.

headline: Charities Get Into Fast Food
abstract: Nonprofit groups, struggling with declining contributions, are exploring food franchise opportunities.
lead_paragraph: FACED with declining donations, some nonprofit organizations are getting into the fast-food business.

headline: In Crowdfunding, New Source of Aid After Catastrophe
abstract: Two months after floods destroyed Wyl Collins’ home, an online charitable giving site helped him raise $8,000 in donations.
lead_paragraph: WYL COLLINS and his wife, Jessie, managed to salvage only a few belongings after Colorado’s devastating floods in September destroyed their home and their T-shirt printing equipment in Lyons, a small town about 15 miles north of Boulder.

headline: The Hammer Resurgent
abstract: “Thor: The Dark World” repackages the thunder god as an alien superhero played by Chris Hemsworth.
lead_paragraph: As if underscoring their film’s essential witlessness, the folks at Marvel Entertainment have inexplicably missed the opportunity to make a splash by opening “Thor: The Dark World” on a Thursday. But repackaging a Norse god as an alien superhero takes chutzpah, not humor (unless you count the Viking ship that serves as his spacecraft), and movie studios have yet to lose money by assuming that their audiences have the intellectual discernment of newborns. So if the multiple idiocies on view strike you as neither here nor there, it’s probably because your eyeballs are too busy recoiling from the onslaught of disorienting 3-D effects, or else too distracted by the title character’s Popeye arms and really big mallet.

headline: Gadfly Urges a Corporate Model for Charity
abstract: After shutting his fund-raising firm, Dan Pallotta has returned to preach his gospel that charities must act more like corporations to solve intractable problems.
lead_paragraph: TO illustrate the Charity Defense Council’s mission — “protect the protectors” — the nonprofit’s website displays a shield pierced by several arrows. Apparently, the organization’s founder and president, Dan Pallotta, got tired of taking barbs unarmed.

headline: Rethinking the Dinner Gala
abstract: A way to prevent fund-raising events from becoming predictable, experts say, is to arrange the food to encourage mingling. And keep the speeches short.
lead_paragraph: The three-course dinners. The auctions and raffles. The speeches from sponsors. The requests for donations. These are the ingredients of many a charity event, and they have stood the test of time.

headline: Charities Try Provocative Ads to Attract Attention
abstract: In a crowded field, turning to humor and parody, even the risqué.
lead_paragraph: TO introduce a wider audience to Water Is Life, an upstart aid organization that provides potable water to villages in developing countries, DDB New York startled even unflappable New Yorkers.

headline: Government Giving Nonprofits Angst
abstract: While the economy is recovering, government funding and private giving have not returned to where they were before the recession started.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FOR some nonprofits, the good times are back. Corporate profits and the stock market are up, and wealthy families have regained nearly all the income they lost during the recession. In turn, charitable giving has increased for each of the last three years, and many nonprofits have intensified fund-raising or seen huge donations roll in: a $100 million gift to the Central Park Conservancy, say, or Harvard’s new $6.5 billion capital campaign.

headline: A Few Good Causes, but Plenty of Time to Spend on Them
abstract: Sanford I. Weill and his wife, Joan, do not fund a lot of different causes, but they have spent about $1 billion on a few of them.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Sanford I. Weill wanted to test the sound of the new concert hall named for him and his wife, Joan, in Sonoma, Calif., he called his friend, the pianist Lang Lang, to stop by on his way to a concert with the San Francisco Symphony and approve the acoustics.

headline: After the Tuition Bill, the Fund-Raising Pitch
abstract: As donations wither and government aid decreases, colleges and universities are targeting parents for fund-raising efforts.
lead_paragraph: ON the University of Virginia’s website, next to a photo of parents of current students, there is a plea to join them in supporting school traditions by signing up for the Parents Committee; a separate link prompts parents to contribute $2,500 to $25,000 annually.

headline: Giving Circles: More Impact to Go Around
abstract: Members of “giving circles” pool their money to make grants to local nonprofit groups, realizing that one hefty contribution can have an immediate influence in a community.
lead_paragraph: INSIDE the red-brick St. Michael’s Lutheran Church in North Philadelphia, more than a century old, the walls, lined with stained glass windows, reverberate with the haunting strains of a chorus of middle schoolers singing Leonard Cohen’s “Hallelujah.”

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: North Korea Says It Arrested a South Korean Spy
abstract: According to the government, the arrested agent confessed to working in a “third country” under “the mask of religion” to plot against North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Thursday that it had arrested a spy sent by the intelligence agency of its rival, South Korea.

headline: $10 Minimum Wage Proposal Has Growing Support From White House
abstract: The White House is endorsing a bill sponsored in the Senate by Tom Harkin of Iowa and in the House by George Miller of California, both Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The White House has thrown its weight behind a proposal to raise the federal minimum wage to at least $10 an hour.

headline: Long Island Bakeries Prepare for Holiday Pie Demand
abstract: The demand for a Thanksgiving pie of choice follows traditional patterns: apple and pumpkin for traditionalists; mincemeat and pecan for outliers.
lead_paragraph: When George Zulkofske stepped into the kitchen at the Jericho Cider Mill on a recent afternoon, a cook was folding several pounds of peeled, sliced apples into a big bowl that contained a drift of cinnamon and light brown sugar. Twenty apple pies were browning in a large oven.

headline: He Lost His Titles, but Never His Cool
abstract: A movie shot while Lance Armstrong lied about doping and after he admitted it feels like two movies — a before and after — roughly stitched together.
lead_paragraph: In “The Armstrong Lie,” Alex Gibney’s absorbing but overlong documentary portrait of Lance Armstrong, begun after he won the Tour de France seven consecutive times (1999-2005), Mr. Armstrong exhibits an unwavering poise and an almost robotic self-possession and air of superiority, with barely discernible blips of defiance and irritation. In the face he presents to the camera, he is still a winner, despite having been stripped of his titles for doping.

headline: Clare Rojas Gets in Touch With Her Abstract Side
abstract: The multidisciplinary artist, who also performs music under the moniker Peggy Honeywell, unveils her new painting style in an exhibition in New York.
lead_paragraph: Clare Rojas, the Bay Area-based multidisciplinary artist, refuses to confine her expansive practice to a single medium. Instead, she glides from paintbrush to pen, from camera to guitar (or banjo — she produces bluegrass-infused music under the moniker Peggy Honeywell), and in recent years has become known for creating powerful folk-art-inspired tableaus that tackle traditional gender roles.

headline: West 57th’s Hodgepodge Block
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: West 57th Street between Broadway and Seventh has long been a jumbled block. Now Extell will add a 1,400-foot tower to the mix.
lead_paragraph: The developer Extell now has the go-ahead from the Landmarks Preservation Commission to cantilever a 1,400-foot tower over the Art Students League at 215 West 57th Street, which will create, certainly, a beanstalk presence on what was already a thoroughly jumbled block.

headline: Old Friends Make a Deal and Try to Avoid the Devil
abstract: John Sayles’s noirish thriller “Go for Sisters” travels deep into the worlds of various sorts of gangsters.
lead_paragraph: Bernice (LisaGay Hamilton) and Fontayne (Yolonda Ross), the title characters of John Sayles’s noirish thriller “Go for Sisters,” are not biological siblings but former high school friends who once looked so much alike that people said they could “go for sisters.” In their tense reunion 20 years later, in a seedy Los Angeles outlier, they are on opposite sides of the law.

headline: Across Generations, Gathering Insights
abstract: In “4000 Miles” at Pace University, the drama is built around a grandson’s visit.
lead_paragraph: Vera Joseph’s life could be a lot worse, but it could also be a lot more purposeful.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: As Twitter Trades, Honoring the ‘Hashtag Godfather’
abstract: Thursday highlights from around the Web include reactions to Twitter’s initial public offering, and the role its users — namely the man behind the hashtag — have played in the company’s success.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: In Soulful Devotion, Glimmers of Doom
abstract: The animated film “The Wind Rises,” which Hayao Miyazaki says will be his last, is a poetic yet somber depiction of Jiro Horikoshi as a young warplane designer.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki has long had an aerial fixation, setting one movie after another in the realms of fanciful flight, from “Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind” to “Kiki’s Delivery Service” to the underrated “Porco Rosso” (about a World War I flying ace who turns into a pig man). Mr. Miyazaki remains enchanted with the idea of being airborne, which animation freely lends itself to, having sent little girls, castles and even swine into flight. “ The Wind Rises ,” his newest film, tells the fictionalized story of Jiro Horikoshi, a gifted aeronautic engineer who is historically notable — or infamous — for designing deadly warplanes used by Japan in World War II. Mr. Miyazaki’s lyrical chronicle of the inventor’s creative process and his poignant romance reminds us that staying aloft is a fraught endeavor. Yet even in this film about an absorbed artist of the floating world, premonitions of the calamitous events to come cannot be entirely absent.

headline: A Sort Of Vacation (Personal)
abstract: Having a good time, but reality beckons.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a really nice, civilized day: talking about economic research and policy issues with smart, knowledgeable people, plus sharing some good memories of graduate school.

headline: The Jackpot’s Smaller, and the Winners More Relatable
abstract: A new campaign from the New York Lottery that promotes its scratch-off games, with prizes that are significant but not in the millions, is showing winners who are not that rich.
lead_paragraph: COMMERCIALS from the New York Lottery tend to take a humorous approach to how much life changes after winning millions. In a recent spot for the Powerball drawing, for example, a man makes everyone he talks to laugh heartily, with the commercial revealing that he is wearing an undetectable earpiece and repeating jokes from a room of seven comedy writers he is employing, led by the comedian Andy Richter.

headline: For the Beer, for the Food, for the Feeling
abstract: The Tapp in Tarrytown qualifies as a gastropub, with a wide selection of craft beers and a farm-to-table approach in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: The couple had just taken a big step: getting engaged. And of all the places they could have gone to celebrate on a recent fall evening, they chose the Tapp, a one-year-old bar in Tarrytown. Cuddling in a corner and showing her ring to the waitress and other patrons as they gathered around, the two had a grand time.

headline: The New Queens Museum
abstract: A look at renovations at the museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at renovations at the museum.

headline: A Local Place for a Global Neighborhood
abstract: On Saturday, the much-changed Queens Museum reopens, focusing on the wide world of art found in the cosmopolitan breadth of its borough’s population.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations of voices we encounter on Manhattan’s streets is global but transient: Visitors from abroad come to town and they look, they shop, they leave.

headline: In Iowa, but Dreaming of D.C.
keywords: ['Movies', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “Caucus,” an A. J. Schnack documentary, chronicles the Republican nominating contest in Iowa in 2012.
lead_paragraph: “A little sneeze, don’t worry,” Mitt Romney says to an Iowan while shaking hands during his 2012 campaign for president. “A little hay fever. I’m in hay country.” With off-the-cuff moments like that, A. J. Schnack’s new documentary, “Caucus,” which follows the candidates vying for the Republican nomination in Iowa, sometimes feels more like a Christopher Guest film than like a political documentary.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows and festivals in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: White House Names Senior Bank of America Executive to Commerce Post
abstract: If confirmed by the Senate, Stefan M. Selig would be joining an administration that has had a challenging relationship with Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:10 p.m. |

headline: Peter Max Art That Wasn’t on the Dorm Wall
abstract: Along with the well-known, colorful psychedelic paintings, the exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art includes pen-and-ink drawings never before shown publicly.
lead_paragraph: Some visitors to “Peter Max,” an exhibition that opened at the Nassau County Museum of Art last month, may find themselves saying, “I had that poster in my dorm room!”

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to electronic music, classic rock, folk-pop, bluesy funk, metal and more in the New York.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Eider Ducks Carry a Chilly Warning
abstract: The director Joel Heath examines the link between hydroelectric power and an endangered Arctic ecosystem in “People of a Feather.”
lead_paragraph: “The ice is harder to understand now,” the Inuit hunter and sculptor Simeonie Kavik tells us midway through “People of a Feather,” Joel Heath’s lyrical examination of the link between hydroelectric power and an endangered Arctic ecosystem.

headline: Twitter’s I.P.O. Draws Protesters to Company’s San Francisco Offices
abstract: As the social media company took to Wall Street, people worried about the impact of the booming tech industry took to the streets of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Some 150 protesters (more characters than a tweet!) gathered outside Twitter’s headquarters on Thursday, the first day of the company’s stock trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Most in the crowd wore stickers that read “Don’t Twit on Me. ”

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to a range of works involving the art of movement.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Device Rules May Vary by Flight
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Flight Attendants', 'Text Messaging', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Although the F.A.A. approved the use of electronic devices during flights, rules may be different between carriers and types of planes.
lead_paragraph: Don’t turn on those smartphones during takeoff just yet.

headline: Everything’s Broken? Then Let the Show Begin
abstract: An exhibition at the Long Island Children’s Museum teaches children how to repair watches, toys and lots of other things.
lead_paragraph: By the time Alaina Herman was finished with the “Broken? Fix It!” exhibition at the Long Island Children’s Museum, she had learned how to rebuild a brick wall, change the oil in a car and glue a cracked china plate back together. But what really caught her attention was a demonstration on repairing window screens.

headline: Seeking a Gateway to a Passport in Seattle
abstract: In “Finding Mr. Right,” the pregnant mistress of a rich man leaves China for Seattle, where she finds a new, unexpected love.
lead_paragraph: The very legitimate rom-com formula has been abused by budgets big and small; sugar is sweet, but sweet alone overwhelms all other tastes. The modest Hong Kong entry “Finding Mr. Right” has the standard odd-couple pairing you’ve seen on the menu before, but there are moments of substance in this macaroon of a movie.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Red Grooms’ New York City’

headline: Obamacare: Consider the Alternative
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Medicare']
abstract: Continuing the discussion about health care, readers respond to a news article, and to a column by Nicholas D. Kristof.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: BlackBerry’s Latest Investors Include Canadian and Qatari Groups
abstract: A combination of Canadian, American and Qatari investors are helping to finance Fairfax Financial Holding’s planned $1 billion investment in struggling smartphone maker BlackBerry, a filing shows.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A combination of Canadian, American and Qatari investors are helping to finance Fairfax Financial Holding’s planned $1 billion investment in the struggling smartphone maker BlackBerry.

headline: A Camera Aimed at the Conscience
keywords: ['Movies', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A crusading photographer, Jo-Anne McArthur, documents the treatment of animals used for meat, clothes and lab testing in Liz Marshall’s “The Ghosts in Our Machine.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a logic at work in the motivated, morality-jarring animal-rights documentary “The Ghosts in Our Machine”: If animals have emotions, and if we see that human actions cause them sadness, anger and fear, then we will become moved to help.

headline: 21st-Century Slavery
abstract: A reader urges that money be used to fight today’s bondage rather than as reparations for slavery of the past.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 8-14
abstract: A listing of walking tours, speaking engagements, cultural activities and Veterans Day events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Veterans Day Weekend (Friday through Monday) In keeping with a tradition largely in place since 1919, Veterans Day honors peace and those in the armed forces on the 11th day of the 11th month at the 11th hour. On Monday there will be a procession along Fifth Avenue, from 26th to 52nd Streets, starting at 11:10 a.m., with Ann E. Dunwoody, the first woman to become a four-star general and who is now retired, as the grand marshal. Sponsored by the United War Veterans Council, the parade also commemorates the 60th anniversary of the end of the Korean War. A ceremony at 10 a.m. in Madison Square Park, at Broadway and 23rd Street, will start things off. More details: vetsday.org.

headline: Battle Scars
abstract: Leonard Gold, 94, spent a year in Europe during World War Two as a photo reconnaissance pilot taking photos of bomb damage over Germany.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Gold, 94, spent a year in Europe during World War Two as a photo reconnaissance pilot taking photos of bomb damage over Germany.

headline: Plagiarism and Rand Paul
abstract: Susan J. Behrens, a communications professor at Marymount Manhattan, discusses the case of the Kentucky senator.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Even One Win Can Mean Everything
abstract: “Medora,” directed by Andrew Cohn and Davy Rothbart, views the decline of small-town America through the eyes of a high school basketball team in Indiana.
lead_paragraph: A mournful Midwestern ballad devoid of grace notes, “Medora” views the crumbling of small-town America through the eyes of the Hornets, a high school basketball team that can barely remember what it’s like to win a game.

headline: Time to License Bicyclists
abstract: A reader asks, “How can we make it safer for us pedestrians?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Family Grocery, With a Long Pedigree
abstract: At Zingone Brothers, operating as a grocery on Manhattan’s Upper West Side for 78 years, the regulars are treated like they are part of the family.
lead_paragraph: At Zingone Brothers, operating as a grocery on Manhattan’s Upper West Side for 78 years, the regulars are treated like they are part of the family.

headline: Youth and Sports
abstract: Joshua K. Dubrow and Jimi Adams, the authors of a study, write that young people should not be discouraged from pursuing sports as a means of upward mobility.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Q. and A. With Bayern Munich’s Arjen Robben
abstract: The wing discusses his winning goal in May’s Champions League final and his thoughts on playing in some of the biggest rivalries in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Arjen Robben has won nearly every title while playing for club teams in the Netherlands, England, Spain and Germany. One year after missing a crucial penalty kick for Bayern Munich in the Champions League final against Chelsea in Munich’s home stadium, the Allianz Arena, Robben silenced (some) doubters by scoring the winning goal as Munich defeated its Bundesliga rival, Borussia Dortmund, to win the Champions League title at Wembley Stadium last May. Robben, 29, who plays wing for Munich, spoke with Jack Bell of The Times before sustaining an injury against Hertha Berlin in late October.

headline: Army Suspends R.O.T.C. Closings at 13 Universities
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The military stepped back from its plan after colleges pushed to keep a door open to rural students and will instead place the programs on “probationary status.”
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Army told 13 universities this week that it would step back from a plan to shutter their Reserve Officers’ Training Corps programs, disrupting a strategy that had been promoted as an effort to refocus the military’s recruiting amid demographic shifts.

headline: A Report on Chernobyl
abstract: The New York Academy of Sciences responds to a letter by the antinuclear advocate Helen Caldicott.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Filling the Gaps of a Checkered Childhood
abstract: Jung Henin and Laurent Boileau’s “Approved for Adoption” is a documentary memoir of Mr. Henin, who was adopted by a Belgian family from South Korea.
lead_paragraph: It’s common for animated movies to tell stories about feeling like a fish (or a mermaid) out of water, but the hand-drawn hybrid “Approved for Adoption” is an actual memoir steeped in that sensation.

headline: Still Chasing That Elusive Tiara
abstract: The comedy “Ass Backwards” centers on best friends who take a road trip to their hometown to claim a beauty pageant crown that eluded them in childhood.
lead_paragraph: Having a modest amount of name recognition through television appears to have made Casey Wilson (“Happy Endings”) and June Diane Raphael (“NTSF:SD:SUV”) think they could write themselves a movie to star in. But they’re not big enough celebrities to make you want to sit through the tepid result just for the pleasure of their company.

headline: Apologizing, Obama Yields to Criticism of Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Apologies']
abstract: President Obama offered his apologies to people who were forced off their health insurance plans by the Affordable Care Act despite “assurances from me.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama bowed Thursday night to mounting criticism that he had misled the American people about the health care law, apologizing to people who were forced off their health insurance plans by the Affordable Care Act despite “assurances from me.”

headline: A Zingone in Every Aisle
abstract: Zingone Brothers is on Columbus Avenue on the Upper West Side, a street where a family member has been selling produce since 1927.
lead_paragraph: “Me? I’m from Columbus Avenue,” said Dominick Zingone, 53, a tall and suave member of the clan behind Zingone Brothers, an old-fashioned grocery store on the Upper West Side. And that’s exactly how the rest of the Zingones feel. No one has forgotten that Grandpa Domenico left the lemon groves of Praiano on the Amalfi Coast at 15, crossed to the New World on the Giuseppe Verdi and landed at Ellis Island on Sept. 3, 1920, but since 1927 a Zingone has been selling produce on the avenue.

headline: Like an Outlaw-Country Song
abstract: “The Motel Life,” based on a novel by Willy Vlautin, follows two brothers around seedy locales in the West.
lead_paragraph: All their lives, Frank (Emile Hirsch) and his brother, Jerry Lee (Stephen Dorff), have been dealt only bad hands. Abandoned by their father, their mother lost to illness, they jumped trains as teenagers, costing Jerry Lee part of his leg. Now the hard-drinking Frank works at a factory in Reno, Nev., when he isn’t tending to the fragile, disheveled Jerry Lee, whose sole gift is for drawing: pictures of Willie Nelson and, mostly, voluptuous women. Frank tells him fantastical stories, flights of fancy (beautifully animated by Mike Smith) in which Jerry Lee is often the hero.

headline: For Prisoners and Families, Burials With Dignity
abstract: Captain Joe Byrd Cemetery in Huntsville serves as the final resting place for state prisoners whose families do not claim their bodies or cannot afford burial services.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE — During a recent vigil at the Captain Joe Byrd Cemetery in this East Texas city, about 40 members and friends of the Texas Interfaith Center for Public Policy laid flowers at tombstones and remembered the more than 3,000 prisoners buried there.

headline: Balancing Act for India’s Top Banker
abstract: Raghuram Rajan is cutting interest rates to stimulate growth, while talking tough against India’s high inflation rate.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Raghuram Rajan, the head of India’s central bank, began his career as an economic theoretician. But a willingness to delve into the mechanics of an economic system may prove to be a bigger asset as he tries to straighten out India’s economy.

headline: Facing Limits on Financing Road Repairs
abstract: Next year, state lawmakers will try to sell voters on $1 billion in financing for highways, but voters tend to consider the costs of fixing even pressing problems.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Young Love, Interrupted by a Nuclear Bomb
abstract: In “How I Live Now,” based on the novel by Meg Rosoff, a surly American teenager finds herself caught in World War III in Britain.
lead_paragraph: You know what it’s like when you fall in love for the first time, and then World War III breaks out? Well, Daisy (Saoirse Ronan), the spiky 16-year-old American heroine of “How I Live Now,” is about to find out. Shipped off for the summer to relatives in the English countryside, Daisy hides her vulnerability behind bleached-out bangs and coal-black eyeliner, compulsively washing her hands after contact with her free-spirited cousins and their chaotic farmhouse.

headline: Accounts Differ to F.B.I. and CBS on Benghazi
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Television', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: Conflicting statements given by a security officer to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to CBS call into question a “60 Minutes” report.
lead_paragraph: Dylan Davies, a security officer hired to help protect the United States Special Mission in Benghazi, Libya, gave the F.B.I. an account of the night that terrorists attacked the mission on Sept. 11, 2012 that contradicts a version of events he provided in a recently published book and in an interview with the CBS News program “60 Minutes.”

headline: Guns, Chases and Disreputable Pleasures in the City of Light
abstract: In “Paris Countdown,” a freed psychopath goes after the two associates who testified against him.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Marie’s “Paris Countdown” is a buddy movie with a downbeat heart. Its two not quite heroes, Milan (Olivier Marchal) and Victor (Jacques Gamblin), have bad history with each other and worse history with the Terminator-like villain Serki (Carlo Brandt), whom they betrayed in an ochre-tinted Mexico. Six years later, Serki is out of jail and wants revenge in a purple-tinted nighttime Paris.

headline: Debating New Charter Schools, Their Policies and Their Effects
abstract: A new kind of charter school is on its way, with lofty academic goals, a load of fees every semester and a troubling record in terms of ethnic diversity and low-income students.
lead_paragraph: On an evening in late October, several hundred parents crowded into a Temple Beth-El auditorium near downtown San Antonio to learn about a new school opening next fall.

headline: What She’ll Do for a Passport
abstract: An immigrant model/actress gets bad career advice and an F.B.I. interrogation in “L.A. Superheroes: Illegal in Hollywood.”
lead_paragraph: In the low-budget satire “L.A. Superheroes: Illegal in Hollywood,” the government, the modeling industry and Hollywood all receive a bit of a flogging. The film centers on Helena, a down-on-her-luck, aging model trying to make the leap to acting. As if the odds weren’t already stacked against her, she is also an illegal immigrant. When a modeling opportunity arises in Paris, she reluctantly buys a fake birth certificate (at the urging of a dubious agent) so she can apply for a United States passport. Big mistake.

headline: TV Talk: Reality Check
abstract: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss which comedies have been renewed and the declining viewership of a legacy reality show.
lead_paragraph: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss which comedies have been renewed and the declining viewership of a legacy reality show.

headline: Friday Night Slights
abstract: What about this idea that you can’t bully a football player?
lead_paragraph: You didn’t have to be Michelin-man big to play football on my team in high school, though it helped in moving slabs of engorged sophomore on third down. You didn’t have to be gazelle-quick, though speed was how you dodged the less fleet-footed going for a cheap shot. What you needed, most, was an ability to absorb pain.

headline: West and Iran Seen as Nearing a Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Even as the two sides tried to finalize the agreement on Thursday, fissures have widened between the United States and some of its principal allies over the potential pact.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — After years of fruitless negotiations, Western and Iranian diplomats are on the verge of an agreement that would freeze Tehran’s nuclear program in exchange for an easing of some economic sanctions.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: The Mutilated Economy
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Credit and Debt', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The long-term costs of short-run failure are piling up and up and up and up.
lead_paragraph: Five years and eleven months have now passed since the U.S. economy entered recession. Officially, that recession ended in the middle of 2009, but nobody would argue that we’ve had anything like a full recovery. Official unemployment remains high, and it would be much higher if so many people hadn’t dropped out of the labor force. Long-term unemployment — the number of people who have been out of work for six months or more — is four times what it was before the recession.

headline: It Couldn’t Be Dad, Could It?
abstract: In “Blood and Ties,” a young woman wonders if her father is about to get away with murder.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean film “Blood and Ties” probably resonates strongly in its home country, where the central conceit has had well-known real-life parallels like the Hwaseong serial killings. But by the standards of American thrillers, after a promising start, it degenerates into unconvincing ticking-clock melodrama.

headline: A New Dog With Old Tricks
abstract: “Billy & Buddy,” based on a comic strip by Jean Roba, features a cocker spaniel and French comedic noises.
lead_paragraph: The title “Billy & Buddy” uses Anglicized versions of the names Bill and Boule, a dog and a boy who have been beloved comic-strip characters in Francophone countries for over 50 years. This live-action version about an English cocker spaniel who speaks French is, in a sense, a foreign film version of “Marmaduke.”

headline: Senate Bill on Bias Against Gays Finds Support in Mormons
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Homosexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Mormons, reflecting shifting attitudes inside their church, have stepped in to provide the political muscle, the additional momentum or the decisive vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At nearly every critical juncture, the Senate bill that passed Thursday banning workplace discrimination because of gender identity and sexual orientation has had an unconventional and powerful ally.

headline: A Poet’s Tempestuous Romance in Brazil
abstract: “Reaching for the Moon,” directed by Bruno Barretto, dramatizes the 1950s affair of Elizabeth Bishop and Lota de Macedo Soares.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the 1995 Brazilian best seller “Rare and Commonplace Flowers,” Bruno Barreto’s “Reaching for the Moon” likewise imagines Elizabeth Bishop’s extraordinary relationship with the Brazilian architect Lota de Macedo Soares. It’s an abridgment of a composite, which leads to the biographical equivalent of plot-point summary. But Mr. Barreto and his lead actresses do stage a battle of creative and romantic egos, as Bishop (Miranda Otto) and Lota (Glória Pires) push up against the bounds of what the heart can take.

headline: He Can’t Always Live With Himself
abstract: In “It’s Me, It’s Me,” a young salesman meets several duplicates of himself, and doesn’t much like some of them.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Me, It’s Me,” the new movie from the Japanese writer-director Satoshi Miki, is a small-scale sci-fi film that is weird, goofy and unprepossessing. But it’s also a brilliant depiction of living in a vortex of curated selves in a gadget-and password-filled culture.

headline: Metal Exchange Changes Rules to Trim Wait Times
keywords: ['Aluminum', 'Storage', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Commodities']
abstract: The London Metals Exchange released new regulations meant to reduce the waiting times at storage facilities owned by commodities traders and banks like Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to reduce the warehouse delays that have added billions of dollars to the prices that consumers pay for beverage cans and other aluminum products, the London Metal Exchange has released new regulations meant to reduce the waiting times at storage facilities owned by commodities traders and banks like Goldman Sachs.

headline: Keep the Iraqi Jews’ Legacy Safe — in America
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A trove of historic materials discovered after the fall of Saddam Hussein belongs in the United States.
lead_paragraph: SEVENTY-FIVE years ago, about 120,000 Jews lived in Iraq. In Baghdad, they were prominent in business and the professions — doctors, lawyers, bankers, professors, musicians, writers, artists, engineers. Last summer, a visitor just back from Iraq told me he could account for only five Iraqi Jews alive in the country. Not 5,000. Not 500. Five. They are too old to leave. When they die, there will be none.

headline: Under Strain, France Examines Its Safety Net
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: The pervasive presence of government in French life, from workplace rules to health and education benefits, is now the subject of a great debate.
lead_paragraph: ST.-ÉTIENNE, France — Patrick Jouve, the owner of a game store on the Rue Louis Braille here, assails the government regulations that limit the size of the bright chess set and bouncing balls he has painted on his storefront. If the painting covers more than 36 feet, it constitutes advertising and he has to pay a fee of $1,350.

headline: A Bend in the River
abstract: The Horcón Tract was a chunk of territory that Americans forgot. Let’s make sure we don’t do that again in the name of border security.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — IN 1970, the United States gave away 413 acres of American territory on the southern bank of the Rio Grande called the Horcón Tract. The handover was something of a formality, since for more than half a century everyone had thought that this remote patch of bottomland was actually part of Mexico. It wasn’t — it had just been forgotten after a Texas company illegally diverted the Rio Grande in 1906.

headline: Exhausted Workers Recall Minimal Efforts to Enforce a Minimum Wage Law
abstract: Complaints with the state Department of Labor about wage and hour violations were stacked 14,000 high at the end of July.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Pin Zhu Zheng, who says she worked 69 hours a week behind a steam table at a Chinatown restaurant on Centre Street, presented herself at a New York State office to report what seemed to be flagrant lawbreaking by her former bosses.

headline: Moments in the Toronto Mayor’s Scandal
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Earlier this year, Mayor Rob Ford denied smoking crack cocaine but now admits to drug use and remains adamant that he will remain in office.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Mayor Rob Ford denied smoking crack cocaine but now admits to drug use and remains adamant that he will remain in office.

headline: Hollywood Donors Set to Cast Hillary Clinton in Top Role
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many powerful donors in the entertainment industry chose Barack Obama over Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2008, but their calculations are different this time.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the prelude to the 2008 Democratic presidential primary season, the split between the Hollywood mogul David Geffen and Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton represented an early and embarrassing sign of trouble for Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Rand Paul May Have Had His Own Writings Plagiarized
abstract: The campaign website of a Republican candidate for the United States Senate in North Carolina, Greg Brannon, who Mr. Paul supports, includes descriptions of various policy positions that match those of Mr. Paul’s 2010 campaign website word for word.
lead_paragraph: For more than a week Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been fending off criticism for using the writings of others, unattributed, in his own speeches, in an opinion article and in one of his books.

headline: An American Boy Wonder in Barcelona
abstract: Ben Lederman, 13, is the first United States-born player invited to train at La Masia, the famed youth soccer academy run by the global soccer juggernaut Barcelona.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — More than six million Americans live abroad, according to recent estimates, so it was not altogether unusual when the Ledermans, a family of four from California, moved here in 2011. After all, one of them got a dream job.

headline: Lessons From European Prisons
abstract: American corrections officials look overseas for a better approach to creating a system geared toward social reintegration rather than punishment alone.
lead_paragraph: In February, a group of American corrections officials, judges, prosecutors and public defenders spent a week visiting prisons in Germany and the Netherlands. Those countries incarcerate people at about one-tenth the rate of the United States, for far less time, and under conditions geared toward social reintegration rather than punishment alone.

headline: Italy: Nazi War Criminal Buried at Jail
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The body of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain, has been buried in an anonymous grave in an abandoned cemetery in an Italian prison, the newspaper La Repubblica said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The body of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who had been serving a life sentence for his role in the execution of over 300 people in 1944 near Rome, has been buried in an anonymous grave in an abandoned cemetery in an Italian prison, the newspaper La Repubblica said Thursday. The newspaper said Mr. Priebke, who died last month under house arrest in Rome at the age of 100, was buried in late October. Officials at the Justice Ministry, which oversees Italy’s prison system, were unable to confirm the report. After Mr. Priebke’s death, Italian and church officials in Rome refused to allow a public funeral, and a private commemoration in a town outside the capital turned violent. Fearful that his grave would become a beacon for neo-Nazi sympathizers, officials in Italy, Germany and Argentina, where Mr. Priebke lived until he was extradited to Italy in 1995, refused to accept his body. The newspaper said that the body would eventually be released to Mr. Priebke’s two sons.

headline: Rejected Seat on U.N. Panel Is Considered by Jordan
abstract: Arab states are said to be conducting talks about which country might replace Saudi Arabia in a nonpermanent Security Council role.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Jordan is considering seeking the nonpermanent United Nations Security Council seat that Saudi Arabia rejected last month in a pique of anger at the United States, diplomats said Thursday.

headline: Iraq: Blasts Kill at Least 30 People
abstract: In the largest attack, two suicide bombers targeted an Iraqi military base north of Baghdad late Thursday, killing 22 soldiers and wounding at least 45 others, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Three separate attacks killed at least 30 people in Iraq on Thursday, the authorities said. Two suicide bombers attacked an Iraqi military base north of Baghdad late Thursday, killing 22 soldiers and wounding at least 45 others, officials said. That attack, in Tarmiya, about 30 miles north of Baghdad, was a coordinated strike, with the first bomber setting off his explosives at the base’s front gate and the second bomber following three minutes later as soldiers responded to the first blast. In another attack, an explosion at a tent serving food to people on their way to the holy city of Karbala killed five Shiite pilgrims and wounded 12 others in the neighborhood of Baghdad Jadida, the police said. Earlier, a suicide bomber denoted his explosives near a military base in Anbar Province, killing three soldiers and wounding 10, a security official said.

headline: The Philippines: Strong Typhoon Lands
abstract: The United States Navy’s Joint Typhoon Warning Center in Hawaii said the typhoon, Haiyan, had maximum sustained winds of 195 miles per hour, with gusts up to 235 m.p.h.
lead_paragraph: One of the strongest typhoons in recent history ripped through the Philippines early Friday, killing at least one person, cutting communications, snapping off roofs and putting millions of people at risk, officials said. Super Typhoon Haiyan, called Yolanda in the Philippines, slammed into the island of Samar, on the eastern edge of the country. It is expected to grind westward throughout the day and leave by Friday evening. The storm lashed fragile, impoverished communities with sustained winds of 195 miles per hour, gusting up to 235 m.p.h. A woman on the island of Cebu was hit by a falling tree and killed, the Philippine Information Agency reported. Local news media reported downed power lines, impassable roads and flooding. Tens of thousands of people were moved into evacuation centers before the storm hit.

headline: Religion, Contraception and Bosses’ Rights
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: An appellate court ruling goes the wrong way on whether employer health plans must cover birth control.
lead_paragraph: The federal health care law’s mandate that employer health plans cover birth control has sparked dozens of lawsuits by secular, for-profit companies and their owners seeking to be exempted on religious grounds from having to comply. At this point, a handful of federal appeals courts have ruled on the question, with a few correctly rejecting the specious religious liberty claims. The latest ruling, issued last week, goes the wrong way.

headline: Another Fire Raises Questions for Tesla
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Batteries']
abstract: Federal safety investigators said they would review an accident in Tennessee in which a Tesla Model S caught fire, the third such fire in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in six weeks, a Tesla Model S was destroyed by a fire after its battery was damaged, prompting new questions over the design of its advanced lithium-ion batteries.

headline: In Queens, Balking at Change, Even if It’s Called Improvement
abstract: A group wants to bring a business improvement district to Corona and Jackson Heights in Queens. Some residents fear it would be costly and rob the area of its character.
lead_paragraph: Like a king surveying his empire, Hector Burgos, 74, stood on Roosevelt Avenue at 102nd Street in Queens and spread his arms wide. “This is my corner,” he said.

headline: Judge Scheindlin’s Case
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Racial Profiling', 'Search and Seizure', 'Minorities', 'Editorials']
abstract: The beleaguered judge in New York City’s stop-and-frisk litigation rightly challenged an appellate court’s decision to remove her from overseeing the case.
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit erred badly last week when it stayed the remedies ordered by Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court to correct the civil rights violations associated with New York City’s stop-and-frisk policy, including an independent monitor to review police practices. It also unjustly damaged Judge Scheindlin’s reputation when it removed her from the case.

headline: Labels for Controversial Ingredients
abstract: Food companies would be better off voluntarily labeling genetically modified foods than fighting the passage of state laws.
lead_paragraph: A ballot initiative in Washington State would require many foods to carry conspicuous warning labels if they use genetically engineered ingredients. The votes will not be completely tallied for several days, but a partial count shows the initiative losing by 54 percent to 46 percent.

headline: Outsider’s Victory in Portugal Reflects Continent’s Discontent
abstract: Rui Moreira, 57, achieved a rare political victory in Western Europe by being elected the mayor of Porto, Portugal, without having been affiliated with an established political party.
lead_paragraph: PORTO, Portugal — Rui Moreira seems an unlikely answer to the populist discontent stalking Europe’s mainstream political parties. Scion of one of this city’s richest families, he studied abroad, ran the family shipping business for a while, and then invested in everything from a popular nightclub here to wine distribution in Brazil and real estate in Chile. Until recently, politics was of little interest, he said.

headline: Negotiating With a Different Iran
abstract: Iran is in a much different position now to negotiate on its nuclear program than it was four years ago when President Obama first broached the subject.
lead_paragraph: Iran is in a much different position now to negotiate on its nuclear program than it was four years ago when President Obama first broached the subject.

headline: Records Cite Lavish Gifts in Navy Bribery Case
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The charges against three Navy officials and a ship-servicing contractor have embarrassed military leaders and raised questions about lax oversight.
lead_paragraph: After a ship-servicing contractor promised to arrange prostitutes for a Navy commander and his buddies in Malaysia and Singapore in 2009, according to court records, the officer, Jose Luis Sanchez, shot back a Facebook message saying, “Yummy ... daddy like.”

headline: Hit Twice by Hard Times, a Town Works to Rebound
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Family Business', 'Restaurants', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: First a wildfire, and then the federal government shutdown, caused havoc for businesses in a small town that depends on tourists drawn to Yosemite National Park.
lead_paragraph: GROVELAND, Calif. — The fortunes of this gold rush town rise and fall on tourists funneling through on their way to Yosemite National Park. Dori Jones and her husband, Greg, owners of Dori’s Tea Cottage and Cafe, depend on travelers filing into their sun-drenched rooms full of lace, floral teacups and the scent of apple-cinnamon scones.

headline: Twice-Broken Leg Hasn’t Deterred a Giant
abstract: After fracturing the same leg in back-to-back seasons, the Giants’ Andre Brown is coming off injured reserve to bolster the team’s backfield.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the Giants’ final preseason game, Coach Tom Coughlin assessed risk versus reward before playing running back Andre Brown. He decided the risk was minimal and the reward could be substantial.

headline: Businesses Near Yosemite Try to Survive
abstract: In Groveland, a town located near Yosemite National Park, local businesses have not recovered from a wildfire and the government shut down.
lead_paragraph: In Groveland, a town located near Yosemite National Park, local businesses have not recovered from a wildfire and the government shut down.

headline: Lawyer for Dolphin Says Toughness Isn’t the Issue
abstract: A lawyer said Thursday that Miami lineman Jonathan Martin endured harassment that went far beyond the traditional locker room hazing.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Jonathan Martin, the Miami offensive tackle who accused Dolphins guard Richie Incognito of bullying, said Thursday that the problem was not a lack of toughness on Martin’s part, but his treatment by his teammates.

headline: The Cost of Being an Artist
abstract: With soaring housing and health care costs, has it become too expensive to pursue the arts in the U.S.?

headline: Charges in Hudson River Boat Crash That Killed Bride and Best Man
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Tappan Zee Bridge', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The driver, Jojo K. John, was intoxicated when the boat slammed into a barge near the Tappan Zee Bridge, an indictment says.
lead_paragraph: A 35-year-old man faces charges of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide stemming from a Hudson River boating accident in which a bride-to-be and the groom’s best man were killed in July, according to an indictment unsealed on Thursday.

headline: Put One’s Two Cents In
abstract: Does Alan Arbesfeld’s 66 word puzzle achieve the right balance?
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve said it before, and I’ll say it again: It’s all about balance. As a constructor, where should your focus lie? Do you focus primarily on good fill? Do you open up the grid so you have lots of long entries, possibly sacrificing some of the short ones along the way? How about the cluing? Or is it possible to pull as many of these and more constraints off and still come up with an enjoyable puzzle?

headline: Where Even the Juggling Is Naughty
abstract: “La Soirée,” a hybrid of circus and burlesque show at the Union Square Theater, offers quirky twists on classic routines.
lead_paragraph: People have various and peculiar tastes in the arts, I know. (“Duck Dynasty”: please explain.) But is there anyone out there who has been hankering to watch a man clad head-to-toe in black leather, with a painted-on Groucho mustache, lip-syncing to a Queen song while juggling?

headline: The Sweet Smell of Decay Pervades a Whodunit
abstract: “The Jacksonian,” a lurid new play on Theater Row, revolves around the night of a murder at a seedy Mississippi motel.
lead_paragraph: Mourning becomes Beth Henley. The humor in “The Jacksonian,” her delectably lurid new play on Theater Row, is as black as widow’s weeds. But with the aid of a crackerjack cast, directed by Robert Falls, this twisty study in murder, Mississippi-style, finds bright fireworks within shades of noir.

headline: Shanahan, Used to Handing Out Punishment, Is Receiving a Reward
abstract: Brendan Shanahan, the head of the N.H.L. department of player safety, will be inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame on Monday for a career that includes three Stanley Cups and an Olympic gold medal.
lead_paragraph: So much attention and controversy surround Brendan Shanahan the disciplinarian that people may have forgotten Brendan Shanahan the player, who in 21 seasons scored 656 goals, the 13th most in league history.

headline: Young Commuters Offer Little Sympathy for de Blasio’s Son
abstract: Dante de Blasio’s peers suggested that there were worse fates than a long ride to school, which he will face if his family moves to Gracie Mansion.
lead_paragraph: Nowshen Pranthi, 16, a high school junior from Parkchester, in the Bronx, takes the Bx4 bus each morning to the No. 6 train, transfers to the No. 4 at 125th Street, then either stays on the No. 4 until Nevins Street, or switches to the Q at Union Square, if she is in a hurry.

headline: Police Arrest Suspect in Northern China Blasts
abstract: The bombing Wednesday raised concerns about security in China, particularly in the wake of the deadly attack at the entrance to the Forbidden City the week before.

headline: No Wrongdoing Found Yet in Inquiry Into Scarcella, Brooklyn Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'District Attorneys', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Despite the recent parole of an inmate whose case was handled by Detective Louis Scarcella, the prosecution’s review of the detective’s work found no misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn prosecutors have provided the first glimpse of a monthslong review of the work of Louis Scarcella, a retired homicide detective whom defense lawyers have blamed for scores of flawed convictions, saying in a court filing that they have uncovered no proven wrongdoing.

headline: Winning With Panache at North Dakota State
abstract: Craig Bohl, a coach with a strong fashion sense, has led the Bison to consecutive national Football Championship Subdivision championships with a blue-collar philosophy.
lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — A rack of green-and-gold North Dakota State attire looks out of place inside Straus Clothing, the fine men’s store that has served North Dakotans for more than 100 years. A photograph on the display provides context. It shows Craig Bohl, N.D.S.U.’s football coach, disembarking from the team bus in a stylish dark suit and print tie sold in the display.

headline: At Twitter, Working Behind the Scenes Toward a Billion-Dollar Payday

headline: The Addictive Allure of the Steelhead’s Tug
abstract: The summer steelhead run faithfully draws aficionados, who say of the elusive fish that “the tug is the drug,” to the Deschutes River in Oregon.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Come September, many of this city’s fly-fishing enthusiasts head about 100 miles east on Interstate 84 to the Deschutes River.

headline: Swastikas, Slurs and Torment in Town’s Schools
abstract: In a school district 90 minutes north of New York City, Jewish families have filed a lawsuit seeking damages and policies to end what it calls pervasive anti-Semitism in the schools.
lead_paragraph: The swastikas, the students recalled, seemed to be everywhere: on walls, desks, lockers, textbooks, computer screens, a playground slide — even on a student’s face.

headline: Ed Pincus, Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Pincus’s intent, his son said, was to “make this statement that the documentarian’s job was to be subjective.”
lead_paragraph: Ed Pincus, a documentary filmmaker who was among the first to embrace deeply personal works, most notably in “Diaries,” an emotionally intense film that turned the camera on his own marriage and family life for more than five years, died on Tuesday at his home in Roxbury, Vt. He was 75.

headline: 2 Founders of Dia Sue to Stop Art Auction
abstract: Heiner Friedrich and Fariha de Menil Friedrich are seeking an injunction in the planned Sotheby’s auction of Dia Art Foundation pieces next week.
lead_paragraph: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation have taken the unusual step of going to court to try to stop the art organization from auctioning off as much as $20 million in works from its world-class holdings next week at Sotheby’s.

headline: Staring Down Homelessness, Yet Again
abstract: After living in group homes and a shelter, Venus Rivera was finally able to get an apartment she could call home. But it is a precarious stability.
lead_paragraph: On a March day three years ago, when Venus Rivera, 29, moved out of a homeless shelter and into a one-bedroom Bronx apartment, she hoped that she had finally found what she always wanted: a stable home.

headline: Dern Has a Story for You
abstract: Bruce Dern, reveling in what he sees as his big break in “Nebraska,” plays a taciturn, confused man who in most ways is his opposite.
lead_paragraph: In late May, in a gaudy hotel suite brimming with tuxedoed film executives at the Cannes Film Festival, a publicist was pacing anxiously. “Bruce, we’ve got to go,” she said. Then, “Bruce, it’s time.” Next she tried, “Bruce, we’re going to be late,” before finally resorting to, “Bruce, please, they can’t start without you.”

headline: Runners Who Love Beer
abstract: Some runners just love beer. For those who must have it after a race, scientists offer some advice, like choosing a light variety and having it with a salty snack.
lead_paragraph: In a dark corner of the 2nd Street Brew House in South Philadelphia, where the food menus are laminated and the chalkboard draft list lit by white Christmas lights, David April stood on a bar stool and called for attention. After thanking the 70 or so runners for joining him that night, he lifted a full pint above his head and gave a hearty yell: “To the Professor!”
