abstract: Members of the legendary choir Leipzig that is being reshaped by the ever-earlier onset of puberty.
lead_paragraph: Members of the legendary choir Leipzig that is being reshaped by the ever-earlier onset of puberty.

headline: This Week's Movies: Nov. 8, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on "The Book Thief," "The Wind Rises" and "Thor: The Dark World."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on "The Book Thief," "The Wind Rises" and "Thor: The Dark World."

headline: Price Cost Twitter Cash but Gave It Credibility
abstract: Had the company sold its 70 million shares at $45.10 instead of $26, it might have raised $3.16 billion instead $1.82 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:54 p.m. | Twitter’s stock gained 73 percent in its first day of trading, adding more than $10 billion to the company’s market capitalization.

headline: Adding Up the Risks in Floating Rate Debt
abstract: The biggest risk in investing in the Treasury Department’s new type of debt is one that, in theory, should not even exist: payment risk.
lead_paragraph: It’s basic corporate finance that bonds involve two basic risks: interest rate risk and payment risk.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about the bridle path along Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn, and feeding the squirrels in New York’s parks.
lead_paragraph: Q. We were driving on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn with my grandson. We told him there used to be a bridle path next to the roadway. He asked when the bridle path was eliminated and the reason for its removal.

headline: Where Have All the Sopranos Gone?
abstract: The ever-earlier onset of puberty is reshaping the legendary Leipzig boys choir.
lead_paragraph: The ever-earlier onset of puberty is reshaping the legendary Leipzig boys choir.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Book Thief, ‘The Wind Rises’ and ‘Thor: The Dark World’
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “The Book Thief,” “The Wind Rises” and “Thor: The Dark World.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the Holocaust drama “The Book Thief,” the animated film “The Wind Rises” and the superhero action movie “Thor: The Dark World.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: The Gun Report: November 8, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: * Last week we reported that the police chief in Sanford, Fla.—where a neighborhood watch volunteer, George Zimmerman, shot 17-year-old Trayvon Martin to death in 2012—was set to unveil rules banning such volunteers from carrying guns. This week, however, he reversed course. Sanford Police Chief Cecil Smith, who had disbanded the city’s neighborhood watch program upon taking over the department in April, refused repeated requests to explain the reversal.

headline: Up-to-Date Homes in Antique Packaging
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Two developers, and two rows of old buildings to be reinvented as multimillion-dollar condos.
lead_paragraph: Renovating or converting a historic building can be difficult and costly, but the city’s supercharged condominium market is enabling some developers to go far beyond merely sprucing up interiors.

headline: Seattle’s Addition to the Folk-Rock Boom
abstract: The Head and the Heart, a folk-rock band from the Northwest, played Webster Hall on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: There’s a trustworthy arc behind almost any song by the Head and the Heart. Often, it begins quiet and small, with the delicate plainness of a hand-thrown ceramic mug. Then comes a well-considered pileup of textures (strummed), layers (sung) and rhythms (drummed) that pushes everything upward and outward, straining toward catharsis.

headline: Big Ticket | A Gramercy Park Key for $15.47 Million
abstract: A floor-through unit with four bedrooms, five and a half baths and Gramercy Park frontage was the most expensive residential sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: The same cachet that worked for the elite team behind 15 Central Park West continues to bring buyers with big wallets to 18 Gramercy Park South, where yet another of the 4,207-square-foot floor-through units with 40 feet of park frontage was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: For Petra Cortright, the Web Is the Ultimate Canvas
abstract: A new show by the 26-year-old Angeleno includes “paintings” made from Internet scavenger hunts and webcam performance videos.
lead_paragraph: Digital art has become an accepted part of every biennial and international art fair. Last month, Philips de Pury even devoted an auction to it, October’s successful Paddles On!, presented in partnership with Tumblr. But the form is still the punk rock of the art world. For the 26-year-old L.A.-based artist Petra Cortright, it’s the ideal form, because it’s both more convenient and less precious than more traditional forms like painting. “There’s so many resources,” she says, “and it doesn’t feel like there’s so much riding on it.”

headline: Exclusive | 130 East 64th Street
abstract: A historic townhouse with a once-controversial facade is on the market for $9.95 million.
lead_paragraph: A historic townhouse with a once-controversial facade is on the market for $9.95 million.

headline: Upper East Side: To Live in an Artwork
abstract: A townhouse once served as home and muse to the modernist architect Edward Durell Stone.
lead_paragraph: The unique Upper East Side townhouse that served as home and muse to the modernist architect Edward Durell Stone, who in 1956 replaced its classic brownstone facade with a wall of windows camouflaged by a then-controversial white concrete grid of interlaced circles and squares, is poised to enter the market at $9.95 million. The home, at 130 East 64th Street, stands out like a snowflake on its tree-lined block between Park and Lexington Avenues; the annual taxes are $52,211.20.

headline: Love Is Giants Blue
abstract: Laurie M. Tisch, whose father, Preston Robert Tisch, bought a half-interest in the New York Giants in 1991, spends Sundays in the owners’ box at the team’s stadium.
lead_paragraph: Ever since her father, Preston Robert Tisch, bought half of the New York Giants in 1991, Laurie M. Tisch, 62, has spent fall Sundays in the owners’ box at the team’s stadium. There she can be seen jumping out of her front-row seat to cheer a touchdown in her Giants-blue blazer, custom Giants-blue cowboy boots and chunky 2011 Super Bowl ring. Indeed, Ms. Tisch — who lives on the Upper East Side with her Tibetan terrier, Lucy — has raised a true-blue Giants family. She is often joined at the game by her two grown daughters, Carolyn Tisch Blodgett and Emily Tisch Sussman, and her son-in-law, William Wilson Blodgett, as well as by her mother, Joan H. Tisch. The rest of Ms. Tisch’s week is devoted to supporting the causes she cares about through her Illumination Fund, founded in 2007, which aims to increase access and opportunity for New Yorkers in areas like the arts and nutrition.

headline: Late Loss After Hot Start Is Too Familiar to Oregon
abstract: With its victory on Thursday, Stanford dealt a severe blow to Oregon’s national title hopes for the second year in a row.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — Oregon players trudged through the tunnel at Stanford Stadium, toward the visitors’ locker room, after Thursday night’s 26-20 loss to the Cardinal. Their once pristine white uniforms were muddied, their once shiny green numbers muted by shadow. They were silent, mostly, and wore tight-lipped expressions, never looking back at the sea of giddy humanity that had rushed the field, awash in Cardinal Red. The clip-clop of the Ducks’ cleats on concrete was barely audible above the din.

headline: At the Cecil, Nourished and Inspired
abstract: A group of friends and artists convened at the Cecil in Harlem to enjoy fusion cuisine and the company of their mentor, Charles Gaines.
lead_paragraph: The neon green “Cecil” sign glows at the intersection of old and new Harlem — 118th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The historic hotel hosts more than fusion cuisine. Alexander Smalls, the executive chef and owner with Richard Parsons, the former chief executive of Time Warner, also reopened the landmark jazz club Minton’s next door. The Cecil’s menu is playfully didactic: “An edible conversation about the food of the African diaspora,” Mr. Smalls said on Wednesday. Since the Cecil opened two months ago, patrons have been buzzing about the Afro-Asian-American food and scene. There was the actress Tamara Tunie, who plays a medical examiner on “Law & Order: SVU.” In Mr. Smalls’s home kitchen she was the guinea pig for the cinnamon-scented fried guinea hen. There were parents enjoying a rare night without their wailing baby, downtown designers, Korean-American friends, and artists starving no more.

headline: Lafayette’s Ship, and Journey, Will Be Recreated
abstract: A replica of the ship that the French general Lafayette sailed in 1780 will recreate his journey from France to the United States.
lead_paragraph: A reconstruction of the ship that Lafayette sailed will recreate the journey the French general made in 1780 when he brought news of French support and troops for the American Revolutionary War.

headline: Ubiquitous Across Globe, Cellphones Have Become Tool for Doing Good
abstract: With 96 percent of the world connected, organizations are using mobile phones to deliver, via texts, water, energy, financial services, health care, even education.
lead_paragraph: The cellphone has become more of a tool and less of a toy, especially among the poor, and those trying to help them, in emerging markets. It helps deliver, via text message, water, energy, financial services, health care and even education.

headline: The Standouts of Private Equity
abstract: There now appear to be noticeable differences among the publicly traded private equity companies. It should be a welcome change, even if it reflects some short-term thinking about a long-term business, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The Great Separation has arrived in private equity.

headline: Standing Up for the Rights of New Fathers
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Paid Time Off', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Parenting', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: More workers are filing legal actions against their employers to gain paid parental leave for the birth of a child, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Josh Levs, father of a new baby girl, emerged from his sleep-deprived stupor last month to take a stand: He is challenging his employer’s parental leave policy on the grounds that it discriminates against biological dads.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Book Thief'
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "The Book Thief."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "The Book Thief."

headline: Movie Review: 'Thor: The Dark World'
abstract: The Times critic Jeannette Catsoulis reviews the movie “Thor: The Dark World.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Jeannette Catsoulis reviews the movie “Thor: The Dark World.”

headline: 2-Way Chemistry, Crackle to Fizzle
abstract: An usual number of new TV series rely on pairings of two characters to drive their plots this season. Neil Genzlinger looks at what’s working, and what’s not.
lead_paragraph: Do they click? Do their characters mesh, and can viewers stand to spend time with them? A lot can go into whether a television show succeeds — time slot, subject matter, budget — but sometimes a series rises or falls on the strength of two pivotal actors. And this season’s new shows offer illuminating examples.

headline: Familiar Drama Shines Among Guts and Gore
abstract: The legacy of Sept. 11 is heard loud and clear in a fall television season rife with the casual depiction of torture and mass murder.
lead_paragraph: Watching the latest fall television season unfold since September, I’ve been struck by two things, neither of them happy.

headline: Animal House (Republican Style)
abstract: The cartoonist Garry Trudeau conceived the comedy “Alpha House,” with John Goodman, while on the road with Jonathan Alter.
lead_paragraph: “Alpha House,” the first original series from Amazon, may be about four fictional scandal-clad senators living in a group house in Washington, but verisimilitude is a foundational element. The Russell Senate Office Building has been painstakingly recreated at Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens, right down to the hideaways and mail slots. And while there are quite a few other shows set in the milieu of Beltway politics, there is none other in which Barack Obama is president and Mitch McConnell is the Senate minority leader, as they are here. But there is one dead giveaway that we are not in the version of Washington that we read about every day: The Republicans and Democrats on “Alpha House” actually speak to one another.

headline: Equal Parts Teeny and Terrifying
abstract: The comedian Jenny Slate, who has been an “SNL” regular, TV actress and the animating force behind the stop-motion hit “Marcel the Shell,” talks about her career on the eve of a stand-up gig in New York.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Jenny Slate specializes in terrifying, from the lunatic girlfriend of Aziz Ansari’s Tom Haverford on “Parks and Recreation” to the catty, hypercompetitive frenemy on the new HBO comedy “Hello Ladies.” But her ideal role is even scarier. “The lady that Ruth Gordon plays in ‘Rosemary’s Baby’ is kind of my dream job,” she said, giggling. “She’s strangely maternal, and very New York, and completely satanic.”

headline: What the October Jobs Report Is Saying
abstract: The overall picture is the same: A sluggish economy made even more sluggish by bad economic policies.
lead_paragraph: The data in the October employment report is mixed, but the overall picture is the same: A sluggish economy made even more sluggish by bad economic policies.

headline: Sounds of Senegal, San Francisco and Beyond
abstract: New recordings by Mar Seck, Wooden Shjips, Simona Premazzi and Cian Nugent.
lead_paragraph: Mar Seck

headline: A Risotto With Substance
abstract: Form risotto studded with butternut squash into cakes and fry them lightly.
lead_paragraph: Risotto moves gracefully with the seasons. Nothing says spring like a risotto made with fava beans, tiny green peas and herbs, perhaps with a handful of asparagus tips for good measure. Summer risotto? Ripe tomatoes, zucchini and basil. Sweet corn, though never used in Italy, makes a fine summery version, too.

headline: A Beer by the Sensor
abstract: An Indiana start-up showcased technology this week meant to help bars and restaurants — and maybe even patrons — keep track of the beer remaining in a keg.
lead_paragraph: The much-hyped Internet of Things may someday arrive as promised. While we wait, maybe we should grab a pint of good beer?

headline: Grasping at Life, Petals, Pain and All
abstract: While ailing from a terminal illness, Ed Pincus, who died this week, teamed up with Lucia Small, a past collaborator, for one last joint documentary.
lead_paragraph: ROXBURY, Vt. — “Look up at those leaves and then frame them with your fingers,” Ed Pincus said, facing an enormous maple tree covered in orange and red. He arranged his unsteady hands — he had Parkinson’s since 2009 — so that he could view the leaves’ Technicolor contrast against blue sky. “Now, when you remove the frame, don’t they look different from before?”

headline: A White House in Crisis Mode, but Some Allies Prod for More Action
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The problems with HealthCare.gov have lit a fire under the West Wing staff, but some Democrats close to the White House think that the Obama administration is not sufficiently panicked.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama was seething. Two weeks after the disastrous launch of HealthCare.gov, Mr. Obama gathered his senior staff members in the Oval Office for what one aide recalled as an “unsparing” dressing-down.

headline: With Alabama and L.S.U., a More Earthbound Game
abstract: Both teams focus on their running backs, at odds with the airborne assaults of the flashier N.C.A.A. offenses.
lead_paragraph: In college football, the field has become the party deck for the quarterback. Many games are a loose, festive three hours of lickety-split football, a full buffet.

headline: Holiday
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Child-Proofing ‘Harry Potter’
abstract: I thought my 5-year-old was ready for the “Harry Potter” books. I was wrong, and I find myself verbally editing every page.
lead_paragraph: The second Professor McGonagall pulls Oliver Wood from his charms class, I realize I’m in “Pinkalicious” territory again. In a flash, the entire sequence from “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone” comes back to me: Madam Hooch orders the class not to fly; Harry hops on his broomstick; McGonagall catches him and introduces him to Wood, the captain of the Gryffindor quidditch team, as its new seeker.

headline: On Nicolas Ghesquière, and Sweatpants
abstract: Some of Cathy Horyn’s thoughts on Mr. Ghesquière’s appointment at Louis Vuitton.
lead_paragraph: MY OBSESSION THESE DAYS is to find a decent pair of sweatpants. And by decent, I mean particular: not too skinny, perhaps something in a fine knit (ribbing is O.K.), and definitely not anything pooling at my ankles. I’m willing to pay a lot of money for my dream sweats, not a fortune but certainly I can do better than Modell’s.

headline: Wholesome Biscotti (Some Even Gluten-Free)
abstract: Biscotti, the dry Italian cookies that are twice baked (which is what the name means), lend themselves to interpretation and adaptation to healthful whole grain variations.
lead_paragraph: Some pastries lend themselves to interpretation and adaptation to whole grain variations; others are best left alone in their white flour and sugar splendor. Biscotti, the dry Italian cookies that are twice baked (which is what the name means), are a kind of pastry that does. They are supposed to be hard, and don’t have to be too sweet, though most of the biscotti you find in coffee shops are – too sweet, that is.

headline: Late to the Race, but Early to the Finish Line
abstract: Sim Jae-duk, a South Korean shipyard worker, has run 210 amateur marathons since 1995, and finished all but three of them in under three hours.
lead_paragraph: GEOJE, South Korea — SIM JAE-DUK, a South Korean shipyard worker, checked into his motel in Front Royal, Va., on a May evening in 2006, sleepy after his first-ever trip to the United States — on a budget flight that first stopped in Tokyo and San Francisco. Two days later, he set off on the Massanutten Mountain Trails 100-Mile Run and won it, setting a record of 17 hours, 40 minutes, 45 seconds, which has yet to be broken.

headline: Tailgating Gets Online Playbooks
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Football', 'Colleges and Universities', 'iPhone', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Google Phone', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Parties (Social)']
abstract: The practice has become so popular it has generated all manner of websites and apps.
lead_paragraph: The coleslaw was the culprit. After receiving several dozen emails discussing who would bring the coleslaw to a football tailgate party at Washington & Lee University in Lexington, Va., Caroline Hundley was losing her patience.

headline: Against Disclosure
abstract: Corporate disclosure, though frequently valuable, also has serious drawbacks, often leading to adverse unintended consequences that can outweigh its benefits.
lead_paragraph: IN the policy world, corporate disclosure is widely seen as an unalloyed good. Publicly traded corporations are under growing pressure to reveal more information about C.E.O. compensation, political spending and even the dangers that climate change poses for the company.

headline: Chrysler Recalls 1.2 Million Ram Trucks
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The company also recalled 2014-model Jeep Grand Cherokees, and Toyota recalled some of its 2013-14 Tacoma pickup trucks.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler is recalling about 1.2 million Ram trucks to correct problems that could result in a loss of steering, as well as almost 94,000 of its 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of electronic problems that could disable two safety systems, the automaker said on Friday.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Wind Rises'
abstract: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews the movie "The Wind Rises."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews the movie "The Wind Rises."

headline: Market Report | Take a Hike
abstract: These designer boots, with their color and texture, are steps above the competition.
lead_paragraph: Rugged designer boots that are the height of style and can scale any mountain.

headline: Satire Show Raises Questions in Egypt
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Censorship']
abstract: Bassem Youssef, a popular satirist, was taken off the air after making jokes about Egypt’s military leadership. The shutdown set off a debate, calling into question the army’s commitment to democracy.
lead_paragraph: Bassem Youssef, a popular satirist, was taken off the air after making jokes about Egypt’s military leadership. The shutdown set off a debate, calling into question the army’s commitment to democracy.

headline: Bonus Work Space, Right in the Lobby
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Developers enlarge lobby spaces in rental buildings to create cozy work zones for self-employed tenants.
lead_paragraph: Pity the poor cubicle: modern-day workers seem to prefer any other place to these narrow, partitioned-off desks.

headline: A Horse of a Different Color
abstract: A woman who once hated all things equine marries a polo player.
lead_paragraph: Those who know Alexandra Solimine cannot quite get over the fact that a woman who has said she so “hated horses and everything about them” while growing up in the equestrian-minded community Far Hills, N.J., ended up marrying Kris Kampsen, a dedicated polo player from Florida.

headline: That Rangers Rush
abstract: “My whole life revolves around the Rangers schedule,” says Buddy Kurzweil, 64, a sports memorabilia shop owner who has seen more than 2,500 games.
lead_paragraph: Hours before the puck drops at 7:30 in Madison Square Garden, waves of energy begin to reach Buddy’s Sports Corner, a memorabilia store in the Paramus Park Mall in New Jersey.

headline: Protesting Twitter
abstract: San Franciscans picketed the company’s headquarters because its presence in their neighborhood has made it unaffordable.
lead_paragraph: This week, while executives from Twitter were celebrating a successful initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange, San Franciscans wearing “Don’t Twit on Me” stickers were picketing the company’s headquarters because its presence in their neighborhood has made it unaffordable.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
abstract: Rugged designer boots that are the height of style and can scale any mountain.
lead_paragraph: Rugged designer boots that are the height of style and can scale any mountain.

headline: Background: Iran’s Nuclear Program and Possible Steps to a Broad Agreement
abstract: While Iran enters the nuclear talks with hopes that the West will ease the economic sanctions, its nuclear program cannot be easily turned back.
lead_paragraph: While Iran enters the nuclear talks with hopes that the West will ease the economic sanctions, its nuclear program cannot be easily turned back.

headline: Lara Logan’s On-Air Apology for Flawed Benghazi Report
abstract: Video of the CBS News correspondent Lara Logan apologizing for her flawed “60 Minutes” report on the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, last year.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Bill Carter and Michael Schmidt report, the CBS News correspondent Lara Logan apologized on Friday for her flawed “60 Minutes” report on the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, last year.

headline: Gluten-Free Dessert Pastry
abstract: After much trial and error, a pie dough that’s delicious and gluten-free.
lead_paragraph: I worked with many different combinations of flours before settling on this one. I love the flavor of the oat flour, but it is so fine that when I tried using all oat flour the pastry crumbled much too easily. So I combined it with corn flour, which is finely ground cornmeal; Bob’s Red Mill produces the version I used. Millet flour will also work, but it has a chalkier flavor. The almond flour absorbs moisture and helps hold the dough together. The dough will crack if you roll it out cold, so I roll it between pieces of plastic before I chill it. Then I remove it from the refrigerator and let it soften just enough so that I can line the tart pans without it cracking.

headline: Boeing Warns Washington State Could Lose 777X if Labor Deal Is Rejected
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The company said it would start pursuing other options if a union did not vote to ratify a proposed contract extension by Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Boeing threatened on Friday to consider locations besides Washington State to assemble its new 777X jets after a union leader sharply criticized the terms of a tentative labor deal to keep the work in Washington.

headline: Bring Out the Good Stuff for the Guests
abstract: Gifts that will come in handy for entertaining.
lead_paragraph: Gifts that will come in handy for entertaining.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s listings include a duplex on the Upper West Side; a pet-friendly apartment in Murray Hill; and a Cobble Hill unit in a 2011 building.
lead_paragraph: This week’s listings include a duplex on the Upper West Side; a pet-friendly apartment in Murray Hill; and a Cobble Hill unit in a 2011 building.

headline: An App for Job Seekers
abstract: Apploi is meant to streamline the job search with a standardized process akin to the Common Application used by colleges.
lead_paragraph: Applying for jobs is unpleasant.It combines the tedium of filling out endless paperwork with the existential question of what you really want to do or, in more dire situations, whether there’s anything out there for you. And even in a recovering economy, employers still seem unwilling to take chances, leaving many applicants feeling doomed to repeat the process ad infinitum.

headline: Waking Area Nightclub From the Dead
abstract: The nightclub was where the downtown art and club scenes converged.
lead_paragraph: The sidewalk was crammed with kooky artists and well-dressed celebutantes, craning their necks to get a glimpse of “Invisible Sculpture,” a piece by Andy Warhol that consists of a pedestal and a wall label.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A townhouse in Dobbs Ferry with three bedrooms and a four-bedroom ranch in Sands Point.
lead_paragraph: A townhouse in Dobbs Ferry with three bedrooms and a four-bedroom ranch in Sands Point.

headline: A New Type of Cat, Ready to Rumble
abstract: The 2014 F-Type is Jaguar’s first pure two-seat sports car in 40 years. Although it’s relatively heavy and expensive, when a car nails the sex, sound and speed equation, it’s easy to forgive the little things.
lead_paragraph: Firesand Orange is what Jaguar calls the paint that flashed from the F-Type sports car that I recently drove. The crowd-pleasing shade recalled such things as a pumpkin, a traffic cone and a hunter’s vest.

headline: Bill de Blasio’s Circle of Power
abstract: Key advisors in the orbit of New York City’s mayor-elect: the people he met as a city official, a political operative and a Brooklyn parent.
lead_paragraph: Key advisors in the orbit of New York City’s mayor-elect: the people he met as a city official, a political operative and a Brooklyn parent.

headline: An Early Import Fighter That Only Embarrassed
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: Built to meet growing demand for more efficient cars and federal regulations mandating higher fuel economy, the X-cars represented a daring break from Detroit engineering conventions of the time.
lead_paragraph: General Motors’ first front-wheel-drive compact models — the Buick Skylark, Chevrolet Citation, Oldsmobile Omega and Pontiac Phoenix — arrived for 1980 with great promise. Known by G.M.’s internal code as the X-body models, or X-cars, the four models replaced larger rear-drive sedans that included the popular Chevy Nova.

headline: An Artifact From a Grim Era in Detroit’s Showrooms
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: The X-cars that General Motors produced in the 1980s helped lead to the company’s troubles, but to a Scarsdale man, that history just adds to the patina of his 1981 Chevrolet Citation.
lead_paragraph: “This was the car that started the decline,” Alan Spiegel said, turning his beige Chevrolet Citation into the parking lot of the Bridge View Tavern, a restaurant that, he promised, served the best burgers in Westchester County.

headline: Shady Paths on Which a Butterfly Flutters
abstract: “Dark Lark,” by the choreographer Kate Weare, at the Fishman Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, explores the relationship between sexual fantasy and creativity.
lead_paragraph: Space and time are precious commodities in the dance world. As the inaugural artist in residence at BAM Fisher, the newest and most versatile theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the choreographer Kate Weare had the relative luxury of two weeks to rehearse in the Fisher’s Fishman Space. Her new piece, “Dark Lark,” had its New York premiere there on Wednesday.

headline: More Muscle, Same Magic
abstract: The CX-5 is an outstanding little crossover, and its appeal lies in Mazda’s mastery of the nuances — the feel of the steering wheel in your hands, the smoothness of the motor and the tightly dampened body motions as you drive twisty roads.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2014 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD

headline: Cuomo Orders Investigations Into Claims of Anti-Semitic Acts in a School District
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo asked the State Police and the Human Rights Division to investigate charges that Jewish children in a district serving parts of Orange, Sullivan and Ulster Counties had been harassed.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that he had directed the New York State Police and the State Division of Human Rights to investigate allegations of anti-Semitic harassment of children in the Pine Bush Central School District.

headline: Roar, Britannia
abstract: Jaguar’s F-Type roadster is a snarling, clawing animal. It may have its flaws, but the supercharged 495-horsepower V8 engine isn’t one of them.
lead_paragraph: Jaguar’s F-Type roadster is a snarling, clawing animal. It may have its flaws, but the supercharged 495-horsepower V8 engine isn’t one of them.

headline: Review: 2014 Jaguar F-Type S
abstract: A high-end audio system that's fun to drive? Jaguar's 2014 F-Type snarls like the Rolling Stones and tracks as precisely as a needle in a groove. Tom Voelk recommends a good set of headphones.
lead_paragraph: A high-end audio system that's fun to drive? Jaguar's 2014 F-Type snarls like the Rolling Stones and tracks as precisely as a needle in a groove. Tom Voelk recommends a good set of headphones.

headline: Chamber Music of a Very Different Kind
abstract: With the help of computer modeling and mechanical gadgetry, automakers are tailoring exhaust notes to more precisely define the character of new models.
lead_paragraph: The tones emanating from a car’s exhaust pipes — a V8’s deep bellow, say, or the piercing wail of a high-revving V12 — have long been inspirations to an enthusiast’s ear. What others may deem mere noise can, appropriately tuned, become a symphony of internal combustion.

headline: Movie Trailer: 'Higher'
abstract: "Higher Unplugged" looks at the making of "Higher," which follows snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the Teton Gravity Research crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: "Higher Unplugged" looks at the making of "Higher," which follows snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the Teton Gravity Research crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal.

headline: Mapping a Life, and Finishing a Long Trip
abstract: When Artemis Cooper set out to write a biography of the travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor, she learned that great storytellers can be less than great when telling their own stories.
lead_paragraph: Great storytellers can be terrible interview subjects. Patrick Leigh Fermor, the British travel writer, was one of them. Artemis Cooper, the author of “Patrick Leigh Fermor: An Adventure,” recently published by New York Review Books, found out the hard way.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Louisiana and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Louisiana, Syria, India and Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Louisiana, Syria, India and Thailand.

headline: Coming: New Snowboarding and Skiing Video Series
abstract: Teton Gravity Research will produce a series of skiing and snowboarding web videos that will be shown at nytimes.com/sports starting Nov. 13.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Jones has long flirted with danger in executing daring feats atop his snowboard in far-flung locations. Teton Gravity Research has documented Jones’s efforts through a trilogy of films, “Deeper,” “Further” and, now, “Higher,” the trailer for which can be viewed here. This trailer sets the tone for TGR’s new web series, “Higher Unplugged,” which The Times will feature, starting on Nov. 20. Another series from TGR, “Behind the Line,” can be viewed at nytimes.com/sports, starting on Nov. 13.

headline: Through Group Dating, Getting to Know You (and You and You)
abstract: Companies interview applicants, then arrange small-group dates for a low fee.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy Tuesday evening, half a dozen young people gathered for drinks, as young people will, at the HiFi Bar in the East Village.

headline: Neighbors, Yet Worlds Apart
abstract: A block in East Harlem, where a new luxury high-rise stands near a food pantry and its patrons’ apartments, illustrates the class divide Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio wants to address.
lead_paragraph: If you lived in Apartment 17A at 1280 Fifth Avenue, a Robert A. M. Stern-designed building, which goes by the baptismal name One Museum Mile, you would have acquired 1,863 square feet for $2.8 million. After a while, perhaps following the birth of a second child or during a bout of the kind of enervating status anxiety that afflicts so many in Manhattan, you would find yourself coveting the combined unit upstairs — the five-bedroom place priced at $8.7 million. You don’t have the money, but maybe if you changed careers, or husbands, or gained a windfall from a dubious lawsuit, you would. You indulge these fantasies, even as you look out your window toward the gloomy, austere towers of Schomburg Plaza, a former Mitchell-Lama complex, or walk four blocks east and south to the sprawl of projects on Madison Avenue.

headline: 40 Years On, No Foul Play Found in Chilean Poet’s Death
abstract: A driver for Pablo Neruda, the Nobel-winning poet who died weeks after a coup ousting Salvador Allende, had alleged he was given a mysterious injection.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Chilean and international forensics experts have ruled out poisoning or other foul play in the death of the Nobel Prize-winning poet Pablo Neruda in 1973, according to a report released Friday.

headline: Adam Driver, Unconventional Looks and a Brooding Manner
abstract: Mr. Driver offers a respite from cookie-cutter beauty.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Driver offers a respite from cookie-cutter beauty.

headline: Your Vegetable Ad Here
abstract: Readers suggested nearly 400 slogans for untrendy vegetables. The magazine’s art department envisioned three of them as ad campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we challenged readers to follow the lead set by the ad agency Victors & Spoils in rebranding broccoli and write their own slogans for untrendy vegetables. We received nearly 400 submissions, demonstrating a full range of our readers’ imaginations (“Cauliflower is the Charlemagne of crucifers,” suggested Chuck Spohr, from Skokie, Ill.) and observations (“Beets turn your pee a beautiful shade of pink,” wrote Sally Macrae from Toronto.) “Ukrainian girls know. You?” was a suggestion for a slogan for cabbage, referring to, as Ksenia from New York put it, “the belief in Eastern Europe that consuming lots of cabbage makes breasts more appealing.” And Mike Williams from Melbourne, Australia, suggested this: “They say if you wrap your feet in cabbage it will cure your arthritis. Why not just eat it?” Why not, indeed.

headline: For Gore Vidal, a Final Plot Twist
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: The author and master contrarian left his entire estate to Harvard, forsaking loved ones and setting off a legal battle.
lead_paragraph: Gore Vidal always kept a fire burning in the grate, his nephew Burr Steers said as we stood in the author’s living room in Los Angeles, “even when it was 110 degrees outside.” Mr. Vidal had suffered hypothermia while serving in the Army during World War II, Mr. Steers added, and his left knee was made of titanium.

headline: The Syllable Everyone Recognizes
abstract: Researchers suggest in the journal PLOS One that the interrogative word “huh” could be a universal word.
lead_paragraph: Are there words that are universally understood, across all countries and cultures? A team of linguists has proposed one: “huh.”

headline: At New York Hotel, Marilyn and Joe Get a Room
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Centerfield suite at the renovated Lexington Hotel New York City pays tribute to Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe, who lived there after their marriage in 1954.
lead_paragraph: The Lexington New York City recently completed a $46 million renovation of its public spaces, guest rooms and suites, part of which pays homage to two of the property’s famous former residents, Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe.

headline: Different Side of a Continent
abstract: “Beautiful Africa” is the new record by Rokia Traoré, the middle-class daughter of a Malian diplomat.
lead_paragraph: Through her excellent new record, “Beautiful Africa” (Nonesuch), Rokia Traoré, the middle-class daughter of a Malian diplomat, remains honest, curious, feminist, defiant toward anyone who considers her work beneath her station — “Afro-progressive,” as she puts it in the title track.

headline: People as Puzzles of Infinite Variety
abstract: What was that about eight million stories in the naked city?
lead_paragraph: What was that about eight million stories in the naked city?

headline: Italian Light on Monteverdi
abstract: Though she is beloved of connoisseurs and critics, the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci remains little known among a broader New York public.
lead_paragraph: Though she is beloved of connoisseurs and critics, the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci remains little known among a broader New York public. It’s not for lack of talent, since she is an artist of singular gifts and refined temperament. But her local performances have been limited to just two concerts: one in February 1999, the other in April 2012. Unconventional and intense, Ms. Antonacci has become a specialist in the intimate affair, comfortable and potent in the early-music repertory.

headline: The Future Is African
abstract: Afrofuturism, a genre that mixes science fiction with the culture, history and politics of the African diaspora, is driving a lot of contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: Afrofuturism, a genre that mixes science fiction with the culture, history and politics of the African diaspora, is as old as Sun Ra’s 1974 film “Space Is the Place” and as new as Janelle Monáe’s latest album. If you’ve been following artists like Wangechi Mutu, Sanford Biggers or Robert Pruitt, you probably already know that it’s driving a lot of contemporary art. “The Shadows Took Shape,” opening Thursday at the Studio Museum in Harlem, cements the trend with work by 29 artists, including the three mentioned above.

headline: Exploding in Unison
abstract: “Sun,” by the Hofesh Shechter Company, will let bright light pour down upon chaos.
lead_paragraph: “Sun,” by the Hofesh Shechter Company, will let bright light pour down upon chaos. Yet the chaos may still smoke. Mr. Shechter — born in Israel, based in Britain — is known for explosive movements, and they abound in “Sun,” much of which is performed in unison. The choreography is also influenced by cinematic techniques of montage.

headline: ‘How Dare You Take Your Own Life?’
abstract: The rising incidence of suicide among service members and veterans has received considerable attention.
lead_paragraph: The rising incidence of suicide among service members and veterans has received considerable attention. A crisis call center for veterans based in Canandaigua, N.Y., is at the forefront of trying to address the problem, and the harrowing work done by operators there is chronicled in “Crisis Hotline: Veterans Press 1,” a documentary on HBO at 9 p.m. on Monday, Veterans Day.

headline: What to Eat With Hard Cider
abstract: Onion soup with a cheese-toast topping has an elegance of its own.
lead_paragraph: When the air turns brisk, cider is a stunning choice to accompany a weekend lunch. Here, in place of the classic soup and sandwich, you have what amounts to a sandwich floating atop a soup laced with cider. All you need is a salad and dessert.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Marathon Colors
abstract: An overview of the 2013 New York City Marathon, where the idea of a white T-shirt turned into the colors that children would wear.
lead_paragraph: An overview of the 2013 New York City Marathon, where the idea of a white T-shirt turned into the colors that children would wear.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 8
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Images include New York’s next mayor, an all-girls golf team and a racetrack upstate.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Images include New York’s next mayor, an all-girls golf team and a racetrack upstate.

headline: Adam Driver, an Unlikely Face on TV or in Fashion
abstract: The star of HBO’s “Girls” has become a presence in the fashion world, appearing in Gap ads, as well as in Vogue.
lead_paragraph: “I’m like a sight gag,” said Adam Driver, who plays the ugly-handsome, so-awful-to-Hannah-he’s-catnip bad boyfriend from HBO’s “Girls.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | On the Run
abstract: A candy shop of color was seen at last weekend’s New York City Marathon.
lead_paragraph: On the Run A candy shop of color was seen at last weekend’s New York City Marathon, and at Saturday’s international run, top left. Some of Sunday’s 50,000 runners are seen in 50 photographs in vibrant fall colors.

headline: How Hipsters Ruined Paris
abstract: Kale juice and organic brunch are replacing a legendary neighborhood of cabarets and seedy bars.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — THE northern edge of Paris’s Ninth Arrondissement, near the Place Pigalle, was once known as “la Nouvelle-Athènes,” both for the neo-Classical flourishes of its most graceful blocks and for the creative geniuses who swept in to inhabit them.

headline: So, This Is How a Book Moves: Page by Page
abstract: In “Henri Michaux: Mouvements,” Marie Chouinard tries to choreograph 64 pages of ink drawings and a 15-page poem.
lead_paragraph: For her company’s return to the Joyce Theater, the Montreal choreographer Marie Chouinard takes inspiration from a book, not bodies. In “Henri Michaux: Mouvements,” based on a volume by that Belgian poet and artist, Ms. Chouinard sets up a challenging task: to choreograph 64 pages of ink drawings, as well as a 15-page poem and an afterword.

headline: All Beethoven, All the Time, in a String Quartet Survey
abstract: The Hagen Quartet, known mostly in this country for its recordings, is performing a Beethoven quartet cycle at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: New York has not lacked for complete surveys of Beethoven’s string quartets in recent years. The Metropolitan Museum of Art alone presented one in each of the last two seasons, by the Pacifica Quartet in 2011-12 and the Endellion String Quartet in 2012-13.

headline: President Speaks in New Orleans
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: President Obama talked about the economy and his desire for more spending on major infrastructure projects.
lead_paragraph: President Obama talked about the economy and his desire for more spending on major infrastructure projects.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Nicolas Ghesquière’s New Role, Dueling YSL Biopics and the Return of the Pixie Cut
abstract: Plus, the latest vanity rage in Venezuela, Paris couture week’s new lineup, Isabel Marant’s forthcoming H&M collection and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 2 – 8

headline: The Pop-Up Activist of the Lower East Side
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)']
abstract: For seven weeks, tenants in a storefront on Delancey Street will range from a syringe-exchange program for homeless transients to an online community of knitters.
lead_paragraph: Eric Ho watches the boom on the Lower East Side, the torrent of new restaurants and boutiques opening, and sees something different. He sees Detroit. Specifically, walking the neighborhood last spring, he saw vacant storefronts — more than 200 of them in the area east of the Bowery and south of 14th Street.

headline: Dry Cider, an American Favorite, Rebounds
abstract: Producers both small and large are reintroducing dry cider to a country where it was once a farmhouse favorite.
lead_paragraph: In Paris earlier this year, I stopped for lunch at Breizh Café in the Marais, a Breton spot that is just about my favorite place to eat crepes. Not only is the food great, but Breizh offers an extraordinary list of dry artisanal ciders, most unavailable in the United States. It’s a joy for any cider lover.

headline: In Precision Pointwork, Rage and Sadness
abstract: “A Month in the Country,” with Julie Kent, was a highlight of an American Ballet Theater triple bill on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: When its artistic machinery clicks into gear, American Ballet Theater exemplifies three ideals in dance: classicism, dramatic brio and anything by Alexei Ratmansky. The company’s program on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was a stellar tripleheader.

headline: How the Internet Has Changed the R.S.V.P.
keywords: ['Parties (Social)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The web, Evite, Facebook and other social media have eroded the social contract at the heart of the R.S.V.P.
lead_paragraph: With ease come presumption and murk. Take, for instance, the modern R.S.V.P. The Internet has allowed a host or event producer to painlessly publicize his or her event to sultans and skateboarders in minutes, the digital invitation beaming on their computer screens and cellphones like an onion puff dangling from a stick.

headline: CBS Apologizes for Benghazi Report
abstract: Accounts differ from a man interviewed by “60 Minutes” who said he was at the U.S. mission the night of the attack that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.
lead_paragraph: Accounts differ from a man interviewed by “60 Minutes” who said he was at the U.S. mission the night of the attack that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

headline: Deadly Blast Hits Hotel in Somalia
abstract: Witnesses and officials said at least four people were killed and scores wounded in a bombing outside an expensive hotel in Mogadishu.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A car loaded with explosives blew up outside one of Mogadishu’s most expensive hotels Friday evening, leaving what witnesses and officials described as a scene of devastation, burning vehicles and mangled victims. News services said that four to 11 people were killed and scores wounded in the blast, which appeared to be carried out by the Shabab, the militant Islamist insurgent group battling Somalia’s government.

headline: Feels Like Old Brooklyn
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Newburgh, N.Y., with its grand but neglected architecture, is reminiscent of 1980s Brooklyn, before gentrification. The community is working to revitalize the troubled city.
lead_paragraph: Newburgh, N.Y., with its grand but neglected architecture, is reminiscent of 1980s Brooklyn, before gentrification. The community is working to revitalize the troubled city.

headline: Striking a Rich Vein, of Sorts
abstract: Syfy’s “Beast of the Bering Sea” brings back one of the stars of “Sharknado,” Cassie Scerbo.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve been rescued from inside a giant shark by a guy with a chain saw, anything is likely to seem anticlimactic. But for the actress who had that honor in “Sharknado,” Cassie Scerbo, the latest Syfy creature feature, “Beast of the Bering Sea,” must have seemed especially disappointing.

headline: ‘L’Allegro’ at 25
abstract: Mark Morris’s masterwork, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this month, returns to New York as part of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Mark Morris’s masterwork, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this month, returns to New York as part of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.

headline: Still Tingling Spines, After 25 Years
abstract: Mark Morris’s 25-year-old masterwork “Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” to be performed Nov. 21 to 23 at Lincoln Center, still fascinates audiences.
lead_paragraph: Some artistic creations cause immediate sensations, and some create a sense of wonder. With only a very few, however, does that sense of wonder address the entire culture that has produced the work of art. One such piece is Mark Morris’s “Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” a full-evening dance work that has almost invariably had a sensational effect on audiences and celebrates its 25th anniversary this month. When it was young, its virtues of innocence, exuberance and abundance amazed many viewers. (“Our era can produce this?”) In the last two years, I have met other people who have felt the same way after seeing it for the first time.

headline: Robert Rhinehart: Dreaming of the Skies and Traveling Light
abstract: The inventor of a food-replacement drink, Soylent, has a longstanding love for airplanes and flight.
lead_paragraph: Progress can be slippery to define. After all, one person’s progress is another one’s transgress. Case in point: Soylent, the food-replacement drink that Robert Rhinehart concocted and has been living on for more than 10 months. The project has sparked enough controversy and raised enough money on Crowdhoster for him to start manufacturing it. (The first shipments are expected to go out next month.)

headline: A Soft Spot for G.M.’s Bad Old Days
abstract: Alan Spiegel of Scarsdale, N.Y., knows the reputation of G.M.’s woeful front-wheel-drive compacts of the early 1980s. But he can’t help but love his Chevy Citation X-11.
lead_paragraph: Alan Spiegel of Scarsdale, N.Y., knows the reputation of G.M.’s woeful front-wheel-drive compacts of the early 1980s. But he can’t help but love his Chevy Citation X-11.

headline: Revivals Victorian, Gothic and Civic
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Drawn to the affordable, historic houses in Newburgh, N.Y., former New York City residents are attempting an architectural and civic restoration of the troubled upstate city.
lead_paragraph: NEWBURGH, N.Y. — As Hannah Brooks drove down Liberty Street, she felt the magnetic pull of this city 60 miles north of Manhattan, with its Hudson River views, its architectural masterpieces and its shocking decay. “You drive through these damaged areas and you find pockets of these amazing buildings,” said Ms. Brooks, who was at the time a resident of Fort Greene, Brooklyn. “You can see that they’re crying out to be saved.”

headline: Chilling Out: Life in a Slow, Cute Lane
abstract: “Meet the Sloths” is the first of three television shows this month giving exposure to animals that don’t get a tremendous amount of attention.
lead_paragraph: It’s a Saturday morning in autumn, and while other people are outside enjoying the last of the fall foliage or cheering on their kids’ sports teams, you’re sunk down on your couch, watching an Animal Planet program about sloths. Could this picture get any sadder?

headline: Merging and Splitting iPhoto Events
abstract: You can change photo groups that iPhoto automatically makes for you. Also, guarding your privacy on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Merging and Splitting iPhoto Events

headline: Poetic Tribute to a Composer
abstract: Ned Rorem turned 90 last month, and that gave the New York Festival of Song something to sing about.
lead_paragraph: Ned Rorem, the composer of poetic art songs and author of sharp-witted essays and diaries, turned 90 last month. He didn’t look a day over 70 on Tuesday as he acknowledged, with a wry smile, a standing ovation from the audience at Merkin Concert Hall after an evening-long birthday tribute by the New York Festival of Song. It contained all the key ingredients of his work: a deep poetic sensibility laced with sardonic wit and a romantic’s receptivity to the sublime in nature parceled into forms that have all the economy of New York apartment living.

headline: A Drummer, a Pianist and a Bassist, by Any Name, Find Their Niche
abstract: Three young jazz musicians forging an identity as the Colin Stranahan Trio, also known as Stranahan, Zaleski, Rosato, played at Smalls on Wednesday and Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The acoustic piano trio continues to be a stable currency in jazz, holding firm against so many other fluctuations. There’s always some attention-grabbing innovation in the field, but it’s also worth noting when a new trio simply seems to arrive at its own style, having sifted through a preponderance of options. The Colin Stranahan Trio is quietly becoming one of these, as it indicated on Thursday, in the second of two nights at Smalls.

headline: Eyewitness Reports After Typhoon in Philippines
abstract: Video and photos show the extent of the damage after powerful Typhoon Haiyan tore through the center of the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Updated 3:30 p.m., Nov. 9 Dramatic images and video from local journalists and eyewitnesses show the extent of the damage in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, which  tore through the center of the Philippines on Friday.

headline: Art Matters | A Different Kind of Light Show at the Guggenheim
abstract: For the 2013 Guggenheim International Gala honoring the James Turrell and Christopher Wool, the techno DJ Richie Hawtin built an installation that illuminated the rotunda, recalling Turrell’s show last summer.
lead_paragraph: James Turrell isn’t the only artist who can make the Guggenheim glow. Last Wednesday, for the first night of the 2013 Guggenheim International Gala made possible by Dior, the techno wizard Richie Hawtin brought back his Plastikman persona for one night with a light show that emanated from a cubic tower that rose from the floor of the museum’s famous rotunda. The event, which this year honored Turrell (whose “Aten Reign” illuminated the museum all summer) and Christopher Wool (whose career-spanning exhibition is on view now), centered around Hawtin’s pulsing installation, which gave a nod both to the history of rave culture and to the kinds of cross-genre artworks the museum supports (including the Performa piece by Florian Hecker coming to the museum this very weekend).As Hawtin slid up and down the scales, with pops, zips and plastic sounds, the tower produced synchronized light projections. Luminaries such as Zachary Quinto, Elizabeth Olsen and Zosia Mamet, all dressed in Dior for the event, looked on, transfixed.

headline: Bridge Books for Declarers and Duplicate Players
keywords: ['Cards and Card Games', 'Bridge (Card Game)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Among the popular bridge books reprinted this year are two updated classics: “The Secrets of Winning Bridge,” by Jeff Rubens, and “Treasury of Bidding Tips,” by Eddie Kantar.
lead_paragraph: Among the popular bridge books reprinted this year are two updated classics: “The Secrets of Winning Bridge,” by Jeff Rubens (Bridge World Books), and “Treasury of Bidding Tips,” by Eddie Kantar (Master Point Press).

headline: Trotter’s Legacy: A Legion of Chefs
abstract: Charlie Trotter’s influence on a generation of American chefs and sommeliers continues to be felt.
lead_paragraph: There are two eras in Chicago dining: B.C. and A.C.

headline: The Olympics of the Future
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2020)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Japan, finally emerging from a long economic downturn, hopes to re-establish itself as a technological powerhouse when Tokyo hosts the 2020 Games.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — From the moment in September when Tokyo won the tight race to host the 2020 Summer Olympics, locals have been unleashing ideas — some far-fetched, others tantalizingly imaginable — of what the city will offer the more than 10 million spectators expected to attend the Games.

headline: In a Shadow, a Well of Human Pain and Joy
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera presents Herbert Wernicke’s production of Strauss’s fairy tale opera “Die Frau Ohne Schatten,” about a woman making the journey from spirit to humanity.
lead_paragraph: There are some seemingly batty elements in Strauss’s fairy tale opera “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” (“The Woman Without a Shadow”), first performed in Vienna in 1919. Even Strauss was somewhat baffled by Hugo von Hofmannsthal’s libretto. The work has confused many opera lovers as well. There was a noticeable number of empty seats at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night when Herbert Wernicke’s 2001 production returned for the first time in 10 years.

headline: Swooning at Pop’s Altar
abstract: The multinational quartet Il Divo opened a six-night run on Thursday evening at the Marquis Theater.
lead_paragraph: The grandiloquent, soupy musical world of the multinational quartet Il Divo conjures a chaste romance-novel fantasy of dashing suitors tearing their hearts off their sleeves to make the ladies at court faint with ecstasy. Pass the smelling salts, please.

headline: Where a Camel Can Squeeze Through a Needle’s Eye
abstract: Parents who are also preachers maintain a high-priced lifestyle in “Thicker Than Water” on Bravo.
lead_paragraph: When Cyrene, the youngest daughter of Ben and Jewel Tankard, returns from prom on the premiere of “Thicker Than Water,” she nods at the promise ring on her finger and assures her parents, “I’m still a virgin.”

headline: Syrians on Both Sides of the War Increasingly See Assad as Likely to Stay
abstract: The insistence from the U.S.-backed opposition that President Bashar al-Assad must go before peace talks can begin is said to be outdated, failing to reflect the situation on the ground.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A growing number of Syrians on both sides of their country’s conflict, along with regional analysts and would-be mediators, are demanding new strategies to end the civil war, based on what they see as an inescapable new reality: President Bashar al-Assad is staying in office, at least for now.

headline: Speaking of the Devil, With Song
abstract: The Collegiate Chorale presented the opera “Mefistofele” on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: There was no memorial service for New York City Opera when it recently dissolved after a 70-year run.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: It’s a Wrap
abstract: After finishing No. 1 over all during the M.L.S. regular season, the Red Bulls were ousted in the first round of the playoffs. What went wrong?
lead_paragraph: Among his many haiku-like observations, the skillful genius and soccer philosopher Johan Cruyff once said, “They can’t beat you, but you can lose to them.”

headline: Label Updates May Be Allowed for Generics
keywords: ['Generic Brands and Products', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Liability for Products']
abstract: The move, if approved, would make generic firms equal to brand-name drug makers and open both to lawsuits by patients.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration proposed a rule on Friday that would permit generic drug makers to update their labels if they received information about potential safety problems. The move puts the companies on equal footing with brand-name manufacturers, but it also opens the door to lawsuits against them for the first time since the Supreme Court barred such cases two years ago.

headline: Three Questions on the Jobs Picture
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: October’s job growth is encouraging, particularly in the face of government turmoil, but the downward trend in labor-force participation is cause for concern, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Home Depot Apologizes for a Tweet That Offends
abstract: The home improvement chain said it had fired the people who sent a Twitter message that was criticized as being racially insensitive.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot spent much of Thursday and Friday scrambling to apologize after a message sent from the company’s primary Twitter account, @HomeDepot, was criticized as racially insensitive.

headline: Now, Batista’s Shipbuilding Firm to File for Bankruptcy
abstract: The move comes as Mr. Batista’s firms, once symbols of Brazil’s might, have suffered under the weight of huge debt.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The empire of the Brazilian businessman Eike Batista took another hit on Friday, as his shipbuilding firm OSX said it would file for bankruptcy.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 8
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New York’s next mayor, an all-girls golf team and a racetrack upstate.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New York’s next mayor, an all-girls golf team and a racetrack upstate.

headline: In a New Role, Ewing Falls to His Old Team
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored 28 points to help make Patrick Ewing’s first game as a temporary head coach a losing effort as the Knicks beat the Bobcats.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — From the suspension of J. R. Smith, to the loss of Tyson Chandler with a broken right leg, to a disappointing 1-3 start, the Knicks’ dramas have started early this season. So it was fitting that an otherwise nondescript November game would offer yet another odd twist to the year.

headline: Netanyahu Pre-Deplores ‘Bad Deal’ on Iran’s Nuclear Program
abstract: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, made his disapproval of a potential agreement over Iran’s nuclear program clear both before and after meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Michael Gordon and Mark Landler report, before Secretary of State John Kerry flew to Geneva from Tel Aviv on Friday to try to close an interim nuclear deal with Iran, he met with Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, who made his disapproval of the potential agreement clear to reporters at the airport.

headline: Video: The Fate of Egypt’s Jon Stewart
abstract: A popular satirist, Bassem Youssef, was taken off the air after he made jokes about Egypt’s military leaders, triggering a debate on the military’s commitment to democracy.
lead_paragraph: When Egyptians tuned in last week to watch the satire show “Al Bernameg,” often called Egypt’s answer to “The Daily Show,” they found instead an anchor announcing that the program had been suspended. A statement issued by the channel’s board said the program had violated its editorial policy.

headline: Rhino Horns: a) Increase Potency; b) Cure Cancer; or c) Bring a Prison Term
abstract: Michael Slattery, an Irishman said to have obtained black rhinos’ horns in Texas and to have sold four horns to a Chinese collector in Queens for $50,000, wept in federal court.
lead_paragraph: The sport utility vehicle pulled up outside an RV park in Alvarado, Tex., where a homeless man was hanging around, waiting for work doing odd jobs.

headline: Spotting Autism in an Infant’s Gaze
keywords: ['Autism', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A new study suggests that tracking a baby’s eye movement may lead to earlier autism detection.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that tracking a baby’s eye movement may lead to earlier autism detection.

headline: Why Surveillance Doesn’t Faze Britain
abstract: Many Brits accept the old securocrat formulation: If you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Think of it as the “Skyfall” session. In a committee room of the House of Commons, the heads of the British secret services appeared on Thursday before a panel of M.P.’s in what might have been a re-enactment of that scene from the latest Bond movie — minus the shootout.

headline: John Hawk, Hero of Normandy Battle, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Hawk, who received the Medal of Honor for action as an Army sergeant in World War II that led to the capture of more than 500 German troops in northern France, later became a school principal.
lead_paragraph: John Hawk, an Army sergeant in World War II who was awarded the Medal of Honor for a single-handed exploit that led to the capture of more than 500 German troops in northern France in 1944, died on Monday in Bremerton, Wash. He was 89.

headline: Central African Republic: Violence Increases Hunger Risk, U.N. Warns
abstract: The World Food Program of the United Nations said in a statement that 1.1 million people are at risk of hunger and that their plight could worsen.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials on Friday reported new deprivations in the Central African Republic, one of Africa’s most unstable countries. The World Food Program of the United Nations, which has been feeding 250,000 people in the Central African Republic since January, said in a statement that 1.1 million were at risk of hunger and that their plight could worsen because of poor harvests and economic collapse from political violence. Navi Pillay, the top United Nations human rights official, said fighting between members of the Seleka insurgent organization and self-defense groups had worsened sectarian and communal splits in the country. “This escalation of violence and hatred must be halted before it spins completely out of control,” she said. The warnings came as Jeffrey D. Feltman, the United Nations under secretary general for political affairs, attended an African Union emergency committee meeting in Bangui, the capital, and urged more cooperation to halt what he called the country’s “downward spiral.”

headline: Venezuela: U.S. Reporter Detained
abstract: The Miami Herald’s Jim Wyss was picked up Thursday near the country’s western border with Colombia, according to an article on the newspaper’s website.
lead_paragraph: Venezuelan authorities have detained an American journalist working for The Miami Herald, the newspaper said Friday. The journalist, Jim Wyss, was picked up Thursday near the country’s western border with Colombia while reporting on Venezuela’s economic problems and coming municipal elections, according to an article on the newspaper’s website. The article, posted Friday, said Mr. Wyss was being held by military intelligence authorities. Dave Wilson, a senior editor at the newspaper, said it was not clear why Mr. Wyss had been detained. Mr. Wyss is the newspaper’s Andes region bureau chief and lives in Colombia. An official with the Information Ministry in Caracas said he could not confirm Mr. Wyss’s detention.

headline: California: Co-Founder of Pinkberry Convicted
abstract: Young Lee, a co-founder of Pinkberry, the frozen yogurt chain, was found guilty of assault with a deadly weapon in the beating of a homeless man.
lead_paragraph: Young Lee, a co-founder of Pinkberry, the frozen yogurt chain, was found guilty Friday of assault with a deadly weapon in the beating of a homeless man. Mr. Lee accused the man, who was panhandling near a freeway ramp in Hollywood in 2011, of disrespecting him by flashing a sexually explicit tattoo, prosecutors said. Mr. Lee beat him with a tire iron, breaking his arm, they said. Mr. Lee, 49, is no longer connected to the chain. He faces up to seven years in prison.

headline: With Survey, Vatican Seeks Laity Comment on Family Issues
abstract: In a questionnaire being distributed to bishops in advance of their synod next fall, Pope Francis is asking Catholics for their thoughts and opinions on contentious social issues.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Often, when the Vatican speaks, it can be a fairly one-sided conversation, issuing encyclicals and other formal documents stating the Roman Catholic Church’s official position on doctrine or other matters.

headline: Chrysler and Toyota Announce Recalls
abstract: Chrysler is recalling 94,000 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of electronic problems that could disable two safety systems.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler said it was recalling about 1.2 million Ram trucks in North America to correct problems that could result in a loss of steering, after saying earlier Friday that it will recall 94,000 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of electronic problems that could disable two safety systems. Chrysler said it was aware of seven accidents involving the Rams, resulting in two injuries. The automaker estimated that 453,000 of the trucks would need repairs because the steering systems’ tie rods were not aligned properly, though it said it would need to recall all 1.2 million trucks to find the flawed vehicles. Meanwhile, Toyota also said it was recalling about 3,800 of its Tacoma pickups from the 2013-14 model years because their 4-cylinder engines could be damaged and possibly stop running.

headline: As City Hall Changes Hands, Construction Will Go On
abstract: The next mayor of New York City will have to deal with the latest renovations of City Hall, including a new roof.
lead_paragraph: A new tenant will move into the mayor’s office in January for the first time in 12 years and will have plenty of headaches to deal with — a looming budget deficit, being one. He may also want to pack a hard hat.

headline: Friday Night Music: San Fermin
abstract: And my life improves further.
lead_paragraph: Many thanks to the commenter who pointed me to this band — also featured on an NPR Tiny Desk Concert.

headline: The Russians Are Coming!
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The story behind the strange fleet of warships that showed up in New York Harbor in November 1863.
lead_paragraph: The eponymous heroine of Gaetano Donizetti’s opera “Lucrezia Borgia” had just died, and the final notes of music had barely faded into the November night when hundreds of workers began to transform New York City’s Academy of Music. Less than 24 hours later, the 4,000-seat entertainment emporium — an opera house, theater, and meeting and exposition hall, all under one roof — was to host the social event of the 1863 season. The city’s elite had quickly snapped up 2,000 tickets for the “Soirée Russe”: a grand ball for the officers of the Russian fleet at anchor in New York.

headline: Walter H. Stern, Who Coined the Term ‘Fiscal Cliff,’ Dies at 88
abstract: Decades before the term was used for a potentially catastrophic federal budget situation, Mr. Stern connected the two words in an article about property taxes.
lead_paragraph: Fiscal Cliff, n.

headline: Right Wing’s Surge in Europe Has the Establishment Rattled
abstract: All over Europe, established political forces are losing ground to grass-roots insurgents fired by resentment against a governing class many see as out of touch.
lead_paragraph: HVIDOVRE, Denmark — As right-wing populists surge across Europe, rattling established political parties with their hostility toward immigration, austerity and the European Union, Mikkel Dencker of the Danish People’s Party has found yet another cause to stir public anger: pork meatballs missing from kindergartens.

headline: SAC Pleads Guilty, Then Judge Calls a Timeout
abstract: Judge Laura Taylor Swain declined to give the hedge fund’s guilty plea preliminary approval, saying she would study the insider trading case and rule in March.
lead_paragraph: After spending the better part of a decade fighting a federal insider trading investigation, SAC Capital Advisors must wait a few extra months for closure.

headline: In a Helping Profession, She Needed Help, Too
abstract: Bernice Porterfield has had a long career as a psychotherapist, but after enduring years of her own health problems and deaths in her family, she found herself requiring assistance.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia heat that Bernice Porterfield had endured for more than 30 years did not compare to the furnace-like temperatures of a New York City apartment without air-conditioning in the summer.

headline: As Tensions Fall in Iran, So Do Costs of Gasoline
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Energy experts say prices may fall further if talks between the United States and Iran bear fruit.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices are tumbling just in time for the holiday shopping season to begin.

headline: Mormons Offer Cautionary Lesson on Sunny Outlook vs. Literary Greatness
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Books and Literature', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Some say the number of Mormons in sci-fi, fantasy and children’s fiction reflect teachings about optimism and a lack of comfort taking up topics like sex.
lead_paragraph: In 1888, speaking about the possibility of Mormon literature, the church leader Orson F. Whitney made an audacious promise to his fellow Mormons: “We will yet have Miltons and Shakespeares of our own.” Yet 125 years later, there is no Mormon Milton. There is no Mormon Milosz, no Mormon Munro.

headline: Politically Adrift, Algeria Clings to Its Old Ways
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A range of problems, from a prostrate economy to declining levels of education, have been left to fester and now threaten to undermine the country’s future and even eventual stability.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Algeria seems stuck in a state of limbo.

headline: Bidders Cry Foul Over Auction of Banksy Painting
abstract: A seeming good deed by the elusive street artist to donate a work to charity has left some art collectors complaining about how the sale of the piece was conducted.
lead_paragraph: The elusive street artist known as Banksy grabbed headlines on Halloween when a painting he donated to a New York charity sold online for $615,000.

headline: Prayers in Little Manila as a Typhoon Hits Home
abstract: Although the typhoon in the Philippines had flattened houses and flooded homes more than 8,500 miles away from a Filipino pocket of Queens, its effects were far-reaching.
lead_paragraph: At Krystal’s Cafe and Pastry Shop, a Filipino restaurant in Woodside, Queens, customers tucked into heaping platters of fish called sinigang na bangus, or pulled strips of pork off a Flintstones-size bone known as crispy pata. The very ordinariness of the Friday afternoon in the area known as Little Manila, where many of New York City’s more than 13,000 Filipinos live, underscored for some just how far they were from their homeland.

headline: Dan Lurie, 90, Star and Promoter of Bodybuilding, Dies
abstract: Mr. Lurie’s chiseled physique and feats of strength made him a cover model for fitness magazines and a walking promoter for both the sport and the business of bodybuilding.
lead_paragraph: Dan Lurie, whose chiseled physique and feats of strength earned him the title of America’s most muscular man and made him a cover model for fitness magazines and a walking promoter for both the sport and the business of bodybuilding, died on Wednesday in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Nov. 8 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
