abstract: No. 10 Louisiana State plays No. 1 Alabama in the top matchup of Saturday’s college football games.
lead_paragraph: 10 L.S.U. at 1 ALABAMA

headline: Era Fades for Helping Hand at the Washroom Sink
abstract: Younger customers have less of a liking for restroom attendants, but some restaurants and bars are sticking with them.
lead_paragraph: However you look at it, it’s a rather static life. All night long cooped up in the bathroom. Turn on the tap, squirt some soap, pass over a hand towel, offer a mint or a stick of gum, maybe suggest a dash of cologne — or would you like some dental floss? Then tidy up the sink, scoop up any trash or worse from the floor.

headline: Immigration Vote Unlikely This Year, Lawmaker Says
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The House will not have time to vote on a bill until early next year, Representative Kevin McCarthy, the majority whip, told protesters in his California district.
lead_paragraph: A top Republican lawmaker told protesters he met with in his home district in California this week that the House of Representatives would not have time this year to vote on any immigration measure.

headline: Candid Criticism for Fed That Wasn’t on the Agenda
abstract: At a meeting on financial crises, Lawrence H. Summers and Ben S. Bernanke engaged in a lively debate on the Fed’s monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It started off as yet another staid International Monetary Fund conference on financial crises, filled with ample praise for one of its high-wattage speakers, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, and carefully calibrated comments on optimal monetary policy.

headline: On Iran, Netanyahu Can Only Fume
abstract: The prime minister’s hard-line stance against a deal with Tehran reflects a widening gulf between Israel and the United States on issues in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Incensed by the prospect of an interim deal that would ease some sanctions against Iran during negotiations over its nuclear program, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is doing what he is best known for, and perhaps best at: He is speaking out, in strident tones, despite the inevitable discomfort for a high-profile guest from Washington.

headline: Detective Admits Spying on Colleagues
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A 20-year veteran of the Police Department pleaded guilty to arranging to hack into dozens of email accounts.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police detective pleaded guilty on Friday to arranging to hack into dozens of email accounts and gaining access to a federal law enforcement database to gather information on his colleagues, said Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.

headline: A Prosecutor Is Punished
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Legal Profession', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Editorials', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: A former prosecutor in Texas will spend 10 days in jail for withholding evidence in a murder trial — insultingly short, but a milestone.
lead_paragraph: For what may be the first time on record, a former prosecutor in Texas is going to jail for failing to turn over exculpatory evidence in a murder trial. The 10-day jail sentence for the prosecutor, Ken Anderson, is insultingly short — the victim of his misconduct, Michael Morton, spent nearly 25 years in prison. But because prosecutors are so rarely held accountable for their misconduct, the sentence is remarkable nonetheless.

headline: What Greece Cannot Afford
abstract: The warning by Prime Minister Antonis Samaras against additional austerity measures goes unheeded.
lead_paragraph: “Greek society and the economy cannot afford any more measures,” Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said on Monday. There is no room or need for any more across-the-board wage and pension cuts, he declared.

headline: The Wrong Way to Save a Forest
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'Wildfires', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: The “salvage” logging bill is based on an antiquated notion of the role of wildfires in nature.
lead_paragraph: In July 1995, President Bill Clinton, in a moment of weakness he later regretted, signed a budget bill containing a rider allowing timber companies to conduct so-called salvage logging in areas burned by forest fires. The measure, advertised as necessary to forest health, would in fact have allowed indiscriminate logging and caused widespread environmental damage. It took a year of protests, court battles and legislative wrangling to undo it.

headline: Equal Coverage for the Mentally Ill
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Editorials']
abstract: Important new rules, plus health care reform, will provide parity in mental health treatment.
lead_paragraph: A struggle over decades to force insurers to cover mental health and addiction services on the same basis as medical and surgical costs is headed for success under new rules issued on Friday by the Obama administration. The rules will cover most Americans with health insurance, including those in many employer-sponsored plans, in other group plans, in some but not all Medicaid plans, and in policies bought on the individual markets.

headline: Prized for His Aggression, Incognito Struggled to Stay in Bounds
abstract: Whatever trouble Richie Incognito encountered — and there were numerous scrapes with the law, with coaches and with teammates — there was always a football team that wanted him.
lead_paragraph: He was a timid Little Leaguer teased by opponents and belittled by teammates. He was mocked for being pudgy and gentler than the other boys, even though he was bigger than most of them.

headline: When a Gun Advocate Dissents
abstract: A writer who dared to call for sensible regulation is shouted down.
lead_paragraph: It’s not as if Dick Metcalf was some kind of gun control fanatic.

headline: Detroit Bankruptcy Case Turns on Issue of Good Faith
abstract: Nine days of emotional and often heated testimony focused in part on whether talks with city employee unions and retirees were held in good faith.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Detroit bankruptcy trial ended on Friday, after nine days of emotional and often heated testimony that raised questions about whether the city is insolvent and whether city and state officials gave creditors a fair chance to negotiate their debts before Detroit filed for Chapter 9 protection in July.

headline: Before Global Games, Rio Is Fighting to Dim Red Light
abstract: A racy metropolis is razing slums and shuttering red-light emporiums, but the campaign isn’t easy.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the frenzy to prepare this city for its big moment as host of next year’s World Cup and the 2016 Summer Olympics, the authorities are razing slums, upgrading stadiums and shuttering some of the city’s red-light emporiums, hoping to present a cleaned-up image of Brazil’s sexiest metropolis.

headline: Consumer Watchdog Takes Up Debt Collection
abstract: Complaints about debt collection outnumber those about credit cards and student loans, said Richard Cordray, chief of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
lead_paragraph: IF you have had a bad experience with a debt collector, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to hear from you. The bureau said this week it was getting ready to update rules governing how debt collectors may communicate with borrowers.

headline: Missing the Bad Old Days
abstract: Have you heard the latest big issue being debated in Congress? You are so wrong if you’re thinking the subject is Obamacare.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a tough week. Let’s take a break and discuss the catfish inspection program.

headline: For Rent: Fixer-Uppers in a National Park
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The National Park Service is now actively looking for tenants to invest in and help save historic buildings on Fort Hancock,  a one-time military base at the northern end of Sandy Hook, N.J.
lead_paragraph: SANDY HOOK, N.J. — The National Park Service put out an unusual for-rent sign last month: 35 historic buildings, including the genteel quarters of lieutenants and captains, at a wind-swept former Army base overlooking Sandy Hook Bay. The only catch: the structures are serious fixer-uppers.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 9, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, November 9, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “They really are a throwback to another era. Like a hatcheck girl. Who wears a hat anymore? What are you going to do — check your Yankees baseball cap?”

headline: Editors’ Note: November 9, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 9, 2013.
lead_paragraph: ARTS & LEISURE

headline: One Way to Stand
abstract: A tight and formidable Saturday puzzle by Michael Ashley.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a nice, tight puzzle that solved in a very businesslike way for me. Until 1 Across fell, of course. Then I laughed out loud. BUTT-DIALED is a new one for the New York Times puzzle archives, as you might have guessed. And that was quite a punny clue. We’ll find out more about how that came about in Michael Ashley’s notes.

headline: Bloomberg News Is Said to Curb Articles That Might Anger China
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Employees said Bloomberg News chose not to publish investigative articles about China’s leadership because of worries that it would be evicted from the country.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The decision came in an early evening call to four journalists huddled in a Hong Kong conference room. On the line 12 time zones away in New York was their boss, Matthew Winkler, the longtime editor in chief of Bloomberg News. And they were frustrated by what he was telling them.

headline: Gay Marriage Battle Nears End in Hawaii, the First Front Line
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The expected approval of same-sex marriage in Hawaii has special resonance because the contemporary fight over the issue was born there two decades ago with a pioneering legal case.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — When, as most everyone expects, Gov. Neil Abercrombie signs into law same-sex marriage here in the coming days, it may almost seem like a routine event. Hawaii is poised to be among 16 states to approve gay marriage, along with Illinois and shortly after Minnesota, New Jersey and Rhode Island.

headline: Animated Take on Bloomberg’s Coverage of China
abstract: A debate within Bloomberg News over how to handle coverage of China provokes an animated depiction of the situation.
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, Next Media Animation posted to the Internet its unique take on the emerging conflict at Bloomberg News over two ill-fated investigative stories about China. Both examine Chinese leaders and businesspeople and were written by veteran reporters in Hong Kong. Some Bloomberg employees say that senior editors in New York, led by Matthew Winkler, the longtime editor-in-chief, have barred the stories from publication to ensure that Bloomberg has access in China. Bloomberg has come under fire from Communist Party officials since it published a prize-winning investigative series last year on the family wealth of Chinese leaders, including that of Xi Jinping, the new party chief.

headline: Executions Stall as States Seek Different Drugs
abstract: Facing increasing pressure and scrutiny from death penalty opponents, the makers of several drugs used in lethal injections have ceased production or required that they not be used in executions.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Florida ran out of its primary lethal-injection drug last month and relied on a new drug that no state had ever used for an execution. At Ohio’s next scheduled execution, the state is planning to use a two-drug combination for the first time. Last month in Texas, Michael Yowell became that state’s first inmate executed using a drug made by a lightly regulated pharmacy that usually produces customized medications for individual patients.

headline: 11 Motorcyclists Are Indicted in Assault on an S.U.V. Driver
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The motorcyclists have been indicted in connection with the assault on a man who was driving a Range Rover with his wife and infant son on the Henry Hudson Parkway in September.
lead_paragraph: Eleven motorcyclists, including an undercover New York police detective, have been indicted in connection with the assault on a man who was driving a Range Rover with his wife and infant son on the Henry Hudson Parkway, the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced on Friday.

headline: Contracting Case Implicates 2 Admirals
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The two high-ranking Navy intelligence officers were accused of personal misconduct in connection with government contracts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two United States admirals, including the Navy’s chief intelligence officer, were stripped of their access to classified information on Friday after being implicated in a contracting scandal that federal prosecutors are investigating in San Diego.

headline: In Puerto Rico, but Unable to Leave New York Behind
abstract: Bill de Blasio is on vacation, and the city’s political class is trying to choose a City Council speaker.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — It would have been easy to be fooled by the sun and sand, the tropical drinks and the men in bathing suits playing cards on the beach, and think that New York’s politicos were simply unwinding after a marathon election season.

headline: Nets, Sloppy Again, Fall to the Wizards
abstract: Paul Pierce was sick and the Nets’ play was shoddy, but the visiting Wizards still needed overtime to pull out a victory on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Nets’ victory over the Utah Jazz on Tuesday night was cast as a learning experience, a redemptive triumph that would erase the bad taste left from a blowout loss on Sunday against the Orlando Magic. It would represent a turning point, they said, a move away from avoidable mistakes.

headline: In Sandy Hook Bay, an Unusual Opportunity
abstract: The National Park Service is looking for tenants for 35 historic buildings at Fort Hancock that can invest in the structures in order to save them.
lead_paragraph: The National Park Service is looking for tenants for 35 historic buildings at Fort Hancock that can invest in the structures in order to save them.

headline: Cuts in Hospital Subsidies Threaten Safety-Net Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Hospitals', 'States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A government subsidy critical to the survival of hospitals treating large numbers of poor patients is being sharply reduced under the new health law.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — The uninsured pour into Memorial Health hospital here: the waitress with cancer in her voice box who for two years assumed she just had a sore throat. The unemployed diabetic with a wound stretching the length of her shin. The construction worker who could no longer breathe on his own after weeks of untreated asthma attacks and had to be put on a respirator.

headline: UConn Survives Maryland and Renews Title Pursuit
abstract: Connecticut, eligible again for postseason play, held off a second-half surge by Maryland behind Shabazz Napier’s 18 points at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Shabazz Napier was one of the last Connecticut players to leave the floor at Barclays Center on Friday night, and a fan wearing a fuzzy-eared Huskies hat stopped him before he did.

headline: Yankees Bring Back Coaches
abstract: Joe Girardi’s entire coaching staff will come back for the 2014 season.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees failed to make the playoffs this year for the first time since 2008, the finger of blame did not fall on the front office, because ownership felt the staggering list of injuries was the problem, not the decision makers.

headline: Down but Not Out, a Polarizing Mayor Concedes Nothing
abstract: Loved by half the city of Lawrence, Mass., loathed by the other half, Mayor William Lantigua lost a close vote, but the race is not over yet.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — To some in this worn former mill town, Mayor William Lantigua is an ebullient man of the people, an old-style ward politician who can fix your streets and clear them of trash. To others, he is the incubator of political scandal, shaming a city already struggling with crises over schools and finances. Half the city loves him, half the city can’t stand him.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Olympic Games', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Macy’s renovates its flagship store in Manhattan, a shipbuilder cuts 1,800 shipbuilding jobs in Britain and Twitter’s stock starts trading in New York.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s renovates its flagship store in Manhattan, a shipbuilder cuts 1,800 shipbuilding jobs in Britain and Twitter’s stock starts trading in New York.

headline: Bobby Thomason, Pro Bowl Quarterback, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Thomason, a three-time Pro Bowler, set a record for the Eagles in 1953 by surpassing 400 passing yards.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Thomason, a three-time Pro Bowler who in 1953 became the first Philadelphia Eagles quarterback to pass for more than 400 yards in a game, died on Tuesday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 85.

headline: Philippine Typhoon Death Toll Feared in Thousands
abstract: One of the strongest storms ever to make landfall cut a path of destruction through several islands, leading to early, unconfirmed estimates of as many as 10,000 dead.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The powerful typhoon that swept across the Philippines on Friday, one of the strongest storms ever to make landfall, cut a path of destruction through several central islands, leaving the seaside city of Tacloban in ruins and leading to early, unconfirmed estimates of as many as 10,000 dead.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CUNY) THE SCENT OF GREEN PAPAYA (1993) In this first installment of “Contemporary French Film,” a five-movie series, the director Tran Anh Hung follows Mui (played by Lu Man San as a child; by Tran Nu Yen-Khe, left, as a woman), a 10-year-old servant for an affluent family in 1950s Vietnam, across a decade as she falls in love with a handsome pianist she has admired since childhood. “ ‘The Scent of the Green Papaya’ marks a luxuriant, visually seductive debut for Mr. Hung, whose film is often so wordlessly evocative that it barely needs dialogue,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Reaching into the past for its precisely drawn memories, it casts a rich, delicate spell.” Afterward, Jerry Carlson, the host of City Cinematheque, interviews La Frances Hui, the film curator for Asia Society New York.

headline: Portrait of Deng as Reformer in 1978 Plenum Ignores History
abstract: The conventional account of how the 1978 Third Plenum transformed Chinais a compound of selective memories, and a deceptive guide to how the country’s steps to economic transformation really happened.
lead_paragraph: China’s Communist Party leader, Xi Jinping, wants the late Deng Xiaoping’s magic. Mr. Xi will lay out proposals for economic rejuvenation at a leadership conference that started Saturday, and state-run media have likened the event to a historic meeting in 1978 when, they say, Mr. Deng began an era of market “reform and opening up.”

headline: The Sex Toys in the Attic
abstract: For the sake of your executors, throw them out. Now.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been thinking about an extremely beautiful sex toy an old boyfriend got me — I think it is on my mind because he is having heart surgery this week. This is how it is at a certain age; when you hear about an old boyfriend it’s not because he got married or got a great job, it is because they’re threading tubes into his chest and doing an ablation on his heart.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Gents Cashmere Cap
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a logo-free baseball cap in a luxe material.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Talks With Iran Fail to Produce a Nuclear Agreement
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Puncturing days of feverish anticipation, marathon talks were stymied not only by divisions between Iran and major powers, but also by fissures within the group negotiating with Iran.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Marathon talks between major powers and Iran failed on Sunday to produce a deal to freeze its nuclear program, puncturing days of feverish anticipation and underscoring how hard it will be to forge a lasting solution to Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: Non-Crisis France
abstract: France is really, really not Spain.
lead_paragraph: A few people have asked a pretty good question, albeit in fairly belligerent tones: How can I say that France isn’t doing too badly, when I also say that the euro has been such a problem?

headline: My Head Talks Actual Economics
abstract: From behind a podium.
lead_paragraph: Aha. The IMF has now posted video of the entire Jacques Polak research conference. If you scroll down on the right to the Mundell-Fleming lecture, you can see me in action. But I’d recommend some of the other material too, especially the tribute to Stan Fischer.

headline: A Founder of Twitter Goes Long
abstract: Evan Williams, who helped create companies like Blogger and Twitter, is setting his sights on longer-form writing with a new blogging platform, Medium.
lead_paragraph: Between downtown San Francisco and the new Twitter offices six city blocks to the west, things get sketchy. There is a strip club, a budget motel with weekly rates and, on the gentrified edge of this no-man’s land, the offices of Medium, the new venture of Evan Williams, one of Twitter’s co-founders.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Mario and the Austerians
abstract: About that success story.
lead_paragraph: Just an obvious point that I’m not sure enough people have been making: Mario Draghi’s surprise rate cut is, in effect, a repudiation of the nascent triumphalism of Europe’s austerians.

headline: Reporter for Reuters Won’t Receive China Visa
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The rejection comes amid rising tensions between foreign news organizations and the Chinese government, which has been using various means to express displeasure with coverage it deems unflattering.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government has rejected the visa application of a veteran American journalist who had been waiting eight months to begin a new reporting job in China for Thomson Reuters, the company said.

headline: Giants’ Defensive Revival Coincides With Their Opponents’ Woes
abstract: The Giants have not allowed an offensive touchdown in 10 quarters. On Sunday, they will face another uncertain young quarterback, the Raiders’ Terrelle Pryor.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A defense stung by lapses and backbreaking plays when the Giants dropped their first six games has not allowed a touchdown in the last 10 quarters, a turnaround that defies easy explanation entering Sunday’s home game against the Oakland Raiders.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Pair up your words with Fred Piscop’s Split Decisions.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — One of the things I love about Split Decisions is that they are both easy and maddeningly hard at the same time.

headline: Mets’ Alderson Can Finally Spend, Assuming He Wants To
abstract: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson has holes to fill, spare parts to trade and could have about $35 million to spend on free agents in baseball’s off-season.
lead_paragraph: For three years, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson has tried building a roster on a limited budget. At a clear disadvantage, he faced small expectations, as if batting with one hand tied behind his back and staring at Matt Harvey on the mound. He had to take a few weak swings and hope for the best, until more money came off the books.

headline: Transition Begins in Boston, for First Time in a Generation
abstract: With the election of Martin J. Walsh as mayor, Boston is poised to break out of the mold cast by Mayor Thomas M. Menino, who is widely credited with transforming the city during his 20-year tenure.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With the election last week of Martin J. Walsh as mayor, Boston is poised to break out of the mold cast by Mayor Thomas M. Menino, who has thoroughly dominated the city and its government during his 20-year tenure, the longest in the city’s history.

headline: Bernard Tyson of Kaiser Permanente, on Speaking Your Mind
abstract: The chief executive of the health care system says the freedom of speech applies to anyone who comes into his office.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Bernard J. Tyson, chief executive of Kaiser Permanente, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Maldives Court Orders Another Delay After Presidential Vote Sets Up Runoff
abstract: Former President Mohamed Nasheed won the most votes but did not break the 50 percent threshold needed to avoid a second round.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A third attempt to hold a presidential election in the tiny Indian Ocean nation of Maldives was thrown off course early Sunday, after an order from the Supreme Court delayed a runoff scheduled for that day.

headline: More Notes On France-Bashing
abstract: It’s a free-falling time bomb, I tell you.
lead_paragraph: First things first: France has problems. Unemployment is high, especially among young people, many small businesses are struggling, the population is aging (although not nearly as much as in many other countries, Germany very much included.)

headline: N.F.L. Coaches: In Charge and at Risk
abstract: John Fox of the Denver Broncos and Gary Kubiak of the Houston Texans are the latest to learn firsthand the hard truth about the demands of their jobs.
lead_paragraph: The day before he had emergency quadruple-bypass surgery in 1998, Dan Reeves relayed his symptoms — accelerated, burning sensations in his chest and throat — and asked his doctor if a checkup could wait until after the N.F.L. season.

headline: They Loved Your G.P.A. Then They Saw Your Tweets.
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: More colleges are finding the social media posts of their applicants — and sometimes denying admission as a result.
lead_paragraph: At Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., admissions officers are still talking about the high school senior who attended a campus information session last year for prospective students. Throughout the presentation, she apparently posted disparaging comments on Twitter about her fellow attendees, repeatedly using a common expletive.

headline: What Sets Spurs Apart Is Lost on Knicks
abstract: Over the last decade and a half, the Spurs have built one of the most stable and enduring foundations in the history of professional basketball.
lead_paragraph: Once every season, the San Antonio Spurs visit Madison Square Garden — as they are scheduled to do Sunday afternoon — to remind the Knicks, in a larger contextual sense, of everything they are not. And that is not good.

headline: Good Deals on Pills? It’s Anyone’s Guess
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: It’s hard to be a smart shopper for prescriptions, or any kind of health care.
lead_paragraph: THIS month, a dysfunctional website stymied hundreds of thousands of Americans trying to check out new health insurance options under the Affordable Care Act. But that embarrassing technical glitch may have masked a more fundamental question: Can Americans shop effectively for health care?

headline: Powerful Typhoon Causes Devastation in Philippines
abstract: A deadly storm left the seaside city of Tacloban in ruins.
lead_paragraph: A deadly storm left the seaside city of Tacloban in ruins.

headline: For Grieving Mother, Many More Challenges
abstract: Ena Griffin, who has been out of work since her son was killed in a brawl in 2012, hopes to start a nonprofit to reach out to youths.
lead_paragraph: Please don’t tell Ena Griffin that heaven needed another angel.

headline: Earnings, but Without the Bad Stuff
abstract: Managers of companies that have generated only losses, like Twitter, are happy to suggest metrics that they think are better suited for assessing their operations.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s red-hot stock offering last week makes clear that, as in the first Internet bubble, investors will pay up for a company even if it hasn’t turned a profit.

headline: The Co-Villains Behind Obesity’s Rise
abstract: A behavioral economist reminds himself that biology is also a part of the nation’s weight problem.
lead_paragraph: Why is obesity soaring? The answer seems pretty clear. In 1955, a standard soda at McDonald’s was only seven ounces. Today, a medium is three times as large, and even a child’s-size version is 12 ounces. It’s a widely held view that obesity is a consequence of our behaviors, and that behavioral economics thus plays a central role in understanding it — with markets, preferences and choices taking center stage. As a behavioral economist, I subscribed to that view — until recently, when I began to question my thinking.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 10
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Education', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Bankruptcies', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “We take responsibility for the handful of men who pleaded guilty and whose conduct gave rise to SAC’s liability.”

headline: Casinos and the Economy
abstract: Readers respond to “Dancing With Temptation in a Casino Vote” (Economic View, Nov. 3).

headline: Dolphins, a Franchise Under Fire, Now Under a Microscope
abstract: Allegations of bullying are only the latest issue to confront the Miami Dolphins and their owner, Stephen Ross.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Some days, the Miami Dolphins’ owner, Stephen Ross, must wonder why he bought the team.

headline: Work Up a Sweat, and Bargain Better
abstract: A new study from M.I.T. links a raised heart rate to success in negotiations.
lead_paragraph: If better health isn’t enough incentive to take a brisk walk, perhaps there is another one: it may get you a better deal.

headline: Mug-Shot Websites, Retreating or Adapting
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Privacy', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mug Shots']
abstract: After an October article, at least one big site has stopped charging fees for removing arrest photographs. But another has resumed the practice.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, a pair of updates.

headline: Embracing the Millennials’ Mind-Set at Work
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours']
abstract: With its emphasis on free-flowing information, the millennial generation is highly innovative — and thus has much to offer to corporate culture.
lead_paragraph: Are millennials — those born from roughly 1980 to 2000 — about to fundamentally change companies for the better? Yes, if companies dare to listen.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How the Justices Shape Our Democracy
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Constitution (US)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Minorities', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss recent Supreme Court rulings that have changed our political system.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss how court rulings have changed U.S. politics.

headline: My Kingdom for an English Course!
abstract: Selling Shakespeare on the delights of social networking.
lead_paragraph: His university had 394 English majors last year, down from 501 when he arrived in 1984, but Professor Edmundson said he does not fret about the future. “In the end, we can’t lose,” he said. “We have William Shakespeare.”

headline: Flyers’ ‘Riverton Rifle’ Content to Give His Coach the Glory
abstract: Reggie Leach, the high-scoring nonbully of the 1974 and ’75 Stanley Cup teams, is celebrated in song but has yet to be nominated to the Hall of Fame, as Coach Fred Shero has been.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Leach was setting out from his home on an island in Lake Huron to meet his teammates from the Stanley Cup-winning 1974 and ’75 Philadelphia Flyers this weekend in Toronto, where their coach, Fred Shero, will be inducted posthumously into the Hockey Hall of Fame.

headline: Week 10 Matchup: Raiders (3-5) at Giants (2-6)
abstract: Eli Manning’s eyes had to light up when he watched Philadelphia’s 49-20 victory at Oakland last Sunday.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Goodbyes With Respect
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: A retired police lieutenant from New Jersey founded a company that conducts burials at sea.

headline: Spurs and Knicks: Proud Era vs. Loud Errors
abstract: Since Tim Duncan joined San Antonio as a rookie for the 1997-98 season, the team has been a model of success and stability.
lead_paragraph: Since Tim Duncan joined San Antonio as a rookie for the 1997-98 season, the team has been a model of success and stability. During that period, the Knicks have often been a dysfunctional mess. The teams did meet in the 1999 N.B.A. finals, with the Spurs winning in five games, but for the most part the two clubs have gone distinctly separate ways.

headline: The Death of Letter-Writing
abstract: How does the constant influx of email affect the process of creative writing?
lead_paragraph: In recent years, a number of journalists and critics have lamented the death of the literary letter. The publication of Saul Bellow’s letters in 2010 and William Styron’s last year were accompanied by waves of speculation about how many more such collections we can expect. There was also no small amount of hand-wringing about how “The Collected Emails of Dave Eggers” (or whomever) will never cast quite the same spell.

headline: The 21st Century Silver Spoon
abstract: Silver spoons are out. Education is now the status symbol for the very wealthy.
lead_paragraph: In 1899, the sociologist Thorstein Veblen scathingly critiqued what he called the “conspicuous consumption” of America’s upper class. The rich were so obsessed with their social status, he wrote, that they would go to gratuitous lengths to signal it. His famous example was silver flatware: handcrafted silver spoons, though no more “serviceable” than and hardly distinguishable from aluminum ones, conferred high social rank and signaled membership in what he called the “leisure class.”

headline: The Mets’ Frank Francisco Fiasco
abstract: The biggest free-agent contract Sandy Alderson has approved to date with the Mets was the two-year, $12 million deal he gave to Frank Francisco
lead_paragraph: Until now, Sandy Alderson has spent little money on free agents as general manager of the Mets, for the most part because he did not have the money to spend. The biggest free-agent contract he has approved to date with the Mets was the two-year, $12 million deal he gave to Frank Francisco in December 2011. Francisco did not pitch particularly well — he had his highest earned run average in the majors in his first year as a Met — and then he got hurt.

headline: Alfre Woodard
abstract: The actress has only eight friends on Facebook — “otherwise, it becomes a job.”
lead_paragraph: Alfre Woodard has been a familiar face on stage, film and television since the 1980s. She plays Mistress Harriet Shaw in “12 Years a Slave,” which opened in theaters nationwide this weekend.

headline: Why I (Still) Support Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting']
abstract: In a world where middle-class work is in transition, we need a strong health care safety net.
lead_paragraph: AT the recent New York Times forum in Singapore, Eleonora Sharef, a co-founder of HireArt, was explaining what new skills employers were seeking from job applicants, but she really got the audience’s attention when she mentioned that her search firm was recently told by one employer that it wouldn’t look at any applicant for a marketing job who didn’t have at least 2,000 Twitter followers — and the more the better. She didn’t disclose the name of the firm, but she told me that it wasn’t Twitter.

headline: Lessons in a Surveillance Drama Redux
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Questions about the press acquiescing to government officials continue to resonate with Times readers.
lead_paragraph: IT was almost eight years ago that The Times published a blockbuster story by James Risen and Eric Lichtblau about a secret Bush administration program to eavesdrop on Americans without warrants. But for many Times readers, it still resonates deeply.

headline: Funny Girl
abstract: As Hillary takes Hollywood, Sarah Silverman offers a piece of advice. (And it’s not even funny.)
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — AS Hollywood bowed down to Hillary Clinton, who swept through on a state visit with Chelsea on Friday, there seemed to be only one person here with any reservations.

headline: A Cure for the Allergy Epidemic?
abstract: When we left farming life, we lost the microbes that kept our immune systems in check.
lead_paragraph: WILL the cure for allergies come from the cowshed?

headline: After Mental Illness, an Up and Down Life
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: We need to work harder to understand childhood mental illness and to reform our dysfunctional system of treatment.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — IN 2005, a distraught mother rushed her 13-year-old son to the emergency room for a psychiatric evaluation. The boy was overwrought, consumed by anxiety. The physicians asked the standard questions: Did he want to kill or hurt himself or others? No, was his answer.

headline: Is It O.K. to Kill Cyclists?
abstract: Based on how drivers who run over and kill cyclists are punished, you’d have to say yes.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — EVERYBODY who knows me knows that I love cycling and that I’m also completely freaked out by it. I got into the sport for middle-aged reasons: fat; creaky knees; the delusional vanity of tight shorts. Registering for a triathlon, I took my first ride in decades. Wind in my hair, smile on my face, I decided instantly that I would bike everywhere like all those beautiful hipster kids on fixies. Within minutes, however, I watched an S.U.V. hit another cyclist, and then I got my own front wheel stuck in a streetcar track, sending me to the pavement.

headline: Violence, Greed and the Gridiron
abstract: With its savage culture and wrecked bodies and minds, America’s most popular sport may also be its least conscionable.
lead_paragraph: WHILE Tony Dorsett described the collision, CNN played the footage, from 1984.

headline: Oklahoma! Where the Kids Learn Early
abstract: If America wants a national model for early education, it should look to what is being achieved in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — LIBERALS don’t expect Oklahoma to serve as a model of social policy. But, astonishingly, we can see in this reddest of red states a terrific example of what the United States can achieve in early education.

headline: Fear of the Dark
keywords: ['Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Energy is something people like to worry about, and grid failure is the latest target of that anxiety.
lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, the first time the government and the utility industry held an emergency drill to simulate a cyberattack on the nation’s power grid, 75 agencies and utilities showed up. For a second drill next week, organizers are expecting more than 200.

headline: Treasure Hunters of the Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In 2008, a year when the global financial system was falling apart and markets panicked, these investors didn’t. How three big risks, taken by three firms, turned to gold.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the global financial system was falling apart. Lehman Brothers had imploded. Banks had stopped lending. Foreclosure signs were as common as weeds on the front lawns of suburban homes.

headline: Kenya and the International Criminal Court
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Editorials']
abstract: Two Kenyan leaders charged with crimes against humanity for the violence in 2007-8 that killed more than 1,100 people are doing everything they can to discredit the court.
lead_paragraph: Two Kenyan leaders charged with crimes against humanity have retaliated with an all-out attack on the International Criminal Court. Although Kenya is a court member, and President Uhuru Kenyatta and Deputy President William Ruto have agreed to cooperate, they are doing everything they can to discredit the institution by accusing it of racial bias and of being a Western tool.

headline: Reality Sets In
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: As the American military’s presence abroad shrinks, so too must the Pentagon’s budget. The question is whether we can be smart about it.
lead_paragraph: For about a decade, American military commanders leading the fight against Al Qaeda, the Taliban and Saddam Hussein had a blank check from Congress to buy whatever weapons and other supplies they needed. Now, the Pentagon is being forced to live with less in a new era of fiscal austerity.

headline: Still Dangerous
keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: New rules for complex derivatives that continue to threaten the economy need to be aggressively enforced.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, when the economy imploded, the world learned that the global financial system was, in part, a casino built on derivatives, complex instruments that are supposed to reduce risk but are instead widely used by banks and other big investors for speculation. Since then, new rules have been created to rein in derivatives through transparency, oversight and competition. Issued by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the agency empowered by the Dodd-Frank reform law to regulate most derivatives, the rules could indeed make the system safer, if they are aggressively enforced.

headline: The Other Paris, Beyond the Boulevards
abstract: Away from the center of the city, the languages swirl and you can see the future of Paris.
lead_paragraph: PANTIN, France — I live just outside Paris, beyond the Périphérique, the eternally clogged ring road that separates the City of Light from its suburban areas of darkness. My neighborhood is in Pantin, where the infamous northeastern suburbs — the banlieues — begin. When I told one Parisian where I lived during casual chatter at a dinner party in the chic Marais quarter, he actually stepped away from me and blurted: “Quelle horreur!” But it isn’t a horrible place. And it’s where, for better or worse, a new France is being forged.

headline: Dear Governor Christie
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here’s a don’t-do list for a possible presidential run in 2016.
lead_paragraph: I KNOW, governor, I know: It’s still too early for presidential speculation, you’re just focused on the job at hand and any talk of 2016, while flattering, is purely hypothetical.

headline: How I Helped Teachers Cheat
abstract: Students aren’t the only ones who cut corners. Teachers do it, too, and for the exact same reasons.
lead_paragraph: FROM 2001 to 2010, I worked as an academic ghostwriter, helping students cheat in college and grad school. Inevitably, over a decade there were a few unsatisfied customers.

headline: Manfred Rommel, Son of German Field Marshal, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Rommel, a three-term mayor of Stuttgart, was a liberal voice in postwar West Germany, supporting immigrant rights and strengthening the city’s Jewish population.
lead_paragraph: Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was a hero of Hitler’s Germany, the legendary “Desert Fox” who seized the world’s attention with his daring tactics in North Africa from 1941 to 1943.

headline: Civility Need Not Be Excluded From the Culture of the N.F.L.
abstract: As the situation with the Miami Dolphins was escalating, Calvin Hill recalled the rigors of his N.F.L. rookie-hood, and not with particular fondness.
lead_paragraph: As the situation with the Miami Dolphins was escalating, Calvin Hill recalled the rigors of his N.F.L. rookie-hood, and not with particular fondness.

headline: New York City Asks Court to Vacate Rulings on Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
abstract: The Bloomberg administration, in a push to erase a federal judge’s rulings on police stop-and-frisk practices, asked a federal appeals court on Saturday to vacate her decisions, which had ordered sweeping reforms.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration, in its most aggressive push yet to erase the stain of a judge’s rulings on police stop-and-frisk practices, asked a federal appeals court on Saturday to vacate her decisions, which had ordered sweeping changes including the appointment of a monitor.

headline: The Oklahoma Model for American Pre-K
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the need for a national pre-K program similar to Oklahoma’s terrific model.
lead_paragraph: As readers know, one of my hobby horses is the need for early childhood education as the most cost-effective way to break the cycles of poverty in America. But the issue never gets much traction, and one reason is the perception that it’s politically hopeless: Republicans would never go for such a program. My Sunday column tries to push back at the assumption that it’s hopeless and notes that one of the leaders in providing pre-K in America is–not Massachusetts, not New York, not some other blue state, but reliably red Oklahoma. It’s all the more surprising because Oklahoma spends less per pupil on education than almost any other state, and pays its teachers near the bottom. This is not a state that believes in lavish spending on schooling. Yet, quite remarkably, it provides universal high-quality pre-K, with a ratio of no more than 10 students per staff member, and all teachers have a college degree.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 10
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey handily won re-election on Tuesday, and will continue his victory lap with an appearance on four of this week’s Sunday shows. Some Republicans are looking to the governor as the future of their party, especially after such a strong win in a Democratic state.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey handily won re-election on Tuesday, and will continue his victory lap with an appearance on four of this week’s Sunday shows. Some Republicans are looking to the governor as the future of their party, especially after such a strong win in a Democratic state.

headline: Bye-Lines
abstract: In which Alan Olschwang takes his leave.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes what you need on a Sunday is a nice, mellow solve, and this puzzle by Alan Olschwang fits the bill. No big surprises, not too hard, and a theme that falls fairly easily if you know the speakers of these exit lines. Even if you don’t, the crossings are kind, and the Bye-Lines are easy to solve.

headline: New China Cities: Shoddy Homes, Broken Hope
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Series']
abstract: China’s government-led urbanization, meant to solve one problem, may be creating a new set of troubles that could plague Chinese cities for generations.
lead_paragraph: HUAMING, China — Three years ago, the Shanghai World Expo featured this newly built town as a model for how China would move from being a land of farms to a land of cities. In a dazzling pavilion visited by more than a million people, visitors learned how farmers were being given a new life through a fair-and-square deal that did not cost them anything.

headline: Dissatisfaction and Dysfunction in a Model for China’s Urbanization
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Unemployment', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: As China pushes ahead with government-led urbanization, Huaming might be an example of another transformation: the ghettoization of China’s new towns.
lead_paragraph: As China pushes ahead with government-led urbanization, Huaming might be an example of another transformation: the ghettoization of China’s new towns.

headline: Hawaii Nears Approval of Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The House of Representatives on Friday passed a bill legalizing gay marriage; it needs final approval from the State Senate, which has already a similar bill.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — The State House of Representatives passed a bill late Friday to legalize same-sex marriage, all but ensuring that Hawaii will soon join 15 other states and the District of Columbia in allowing gay couples to wed.

headline: Texas Youth Is Named M.V.P. of American League
abstract: Jeffrey Xiong of the Dallas Destiny demonstrated a maturity in his decision-making that allowed him to dominate each phase in many of his games.
lead_paragraph: When the United States Chess League began playing in 2005, there were eight teams — and some basic questions. Would the league be able to keep itself afloat financially? And would enough elite players participate to make it a success?

headline: Richard Witkin, 95, Witness to the History of Aviation, Dies
abstract: Mr. Witkin worked for The Times for three decades and was part of the team that won a Pulitzer for coverage of the Challenger disaster.
lead_paragraph: Richard Witkin, a longtime aviation reporter for The New York Times who shared a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 for coverage of the Challenger space shuttle disaster, died on Thursday in Marlborough, Mass. He was 95.

headline: Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required)
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States International Relations', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: When the president travels and needs to handle sensitive information, he ducks into a security tent set up by aides to shield himself from secret cameras and listening devices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama travels abroad, his staff packs briefing books, gifts for foreign leaders and something more closely associated with camping than diplomacy: a tent.

headline: Priceless Moment for Pirates, but $632,500 for the Uniform
abstract: The uniform Bill Mazeroski wore when he hit the winning home run in the 1960 World Series sold for $632,500 at an auction.
lead_paragraph: For more than a half-century, Bill Mazeroski kept the Pittsburgh Pirates uniform he wore when he hit the home run to win the 1960 World Series in a cedar chest in his Pennsylvania home. He opened it once to make sure moths had not eaten through it. This year, Mazeroski decided to sell it and other memorabilia.

headline: Aided by Army of ‘Vapers,’ E-Cigarette Industry Woos and Wins Europe
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Eluding restrictions, e-cigarette sellers outgunned not just the tobacco companies but also pharmaceutical companies that make competing products for people trying to stop smoking.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Facing a decision on whether to impose tight restrictions on a booming market for electronic cigarettes, members of the European Parliament received a pleading letter in September that was signed by thousands of former smokers worried that “the positive story of e-cigarettes may be about to come to an abrupt halt.”

headline: Elderly Woman’s Killing Lays Bare Myanmar’s Religious Divisions
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Monasteries and Monks']
abstract: The stabbing death of a helpless 94-year-old woman is a stark symbol of the breadth of anti-Muslim feelings in a Buddhist-majority country.
lead_paragraph: THABYU CHAING, Myanmar — Paralyzed from the waist down, Daw Aye Kyi was too heavy for her daughter and granddaughter to carry into the surrounding jungle when a Buddhist mob stormed through this rice-farming village hunting for Muslims.

headline: Tours Open at the Penitentiary of New Mexico
abstract: In 36 hours, 33 inmates were killed and more than 200 were injured in February 1980.
lead_paragraph: In 36 hours, 33 inmates were killed and more than 200 were injured in February 1980.

headline: For Riot Site in New Mexico, a Gift Shop but No Ghost Stories
abstract: The site of one of the nation’s deadliest prison riots, the Penitentiary of New Mexico, has reopened its doors as a surprisingly popular tourist attraction.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — When it came time to organize the celebrations for New Mexico’s centennial last year, Gov. Susana Martinez turned to the members of her cabinet for suggestions. The Corrections Department secretary, Gregg Marcantel, a burly former Marine just months into the job, was stumped. What could the state’s troubled prison system, faced with a high rate of recidivism and drastic budget cuts, possibly have to offer?

headline: Debating a New Pope, Faith and Doctrine
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Some American Catholics in the church’s conservative wing say Pope Francis has left them feeling abandoned and deeply unsettled.
lead_paragraph: Some American Catholics in the church’s conservative wing say Pope Francis has left them feeling abandoned and deeply unsettled.

headline: Conservative U.S. Catholics Feel Left Out of the Pope’s Embrace
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Conservative Catholics say Pope Francis’ recent comments about abortion and gay marriage are muddying doctrine to appeal to the broadest possible audience.
lead_paragraph: SMYRNA, Ga. — When Pope Francis was elected in March, Bridget Kurt received a small prayer card with his picture at her church and put it up on her refrigerator at home, next to pictures of her friends and her favorite saints.

headline: Storied Party of Mandela Faces South Africa Unrest
abstract: Twenty years after the African National Congress swept to power in apartheid’s wake, discontent with its leaders is creating an opening for a new political party.
lead_paragraph: MARIKANA, South Africa — When Alton Dalasile got his first job as a miner in the late 1980s, he immediately joined the National Union of Mineworkers, a powerful organization that not only fought for workers’ rights but also battled the brutal system of racial segregation known as apartheid. When his union’s political ally, the African National Congress, was on the ballot in 1994 in South Africa’s first fully democratic election, Mr. Dalasile enthusiastically cast his ballot for Nelson Mandela, the country’s first black president.

lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Venezuelan authorities on Saturday released an American journalist who had been detained and questioned by military intelligence officials.

headline: As Washington Keeps Sinking, Governors Rise

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Washington these days is the symbol of governmental failure, rocked by a shutdown, legislative paralysis and the disastrous debut of President Obama’s health care program. Public opinion of Mr. Obama and members of Congress is on a steady decline.

headline: Jack Mitchell, Photographer of the Arts, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Mitchell, who took thousands of portraits of dancers, musicians, writer and other artists, was known for his ability to tease character studies from his photo sessions.
lead_paragraph: Jack Mitchell, whose bulging photographic portfolio of actors, writers, painters, musicians and especially dancers describes a pictorial history of the arts in the late 20th century, died on Thursday at his home in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. He was 88.

headline: Losses Follow Crowded Races, but That’s Fine
abstract: Hordes of ambitious candidates mean than many will not be victorious, but in such cases, those individuals often make comebacks or land fine in other roles.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Take It From One Who Knows: Race Cars Are Loud
abstract: Bun B, the Houston rapper and racing aficionado, gives his advice on getting the most out of the Formula One U.S. Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: Knowing something about automobiles is part of Bun B’s job description. “Houston’s hip-hop culture is largely defined by the car culture,” he said. But while Houston’s car scene is based on heavily customized automobiles called slabs (originally an acronym for “slow, loud and bangin’”), his latest passion focuses on a different, faster sort of car.

headline: Concerns as Austin Residents Drill New Wells
abstract: As more Austin residents drill wells to offset the drought, officials and environmentalists grow concerned that it will negatively impact groundwater supplies.
lead_paragraph: With what has been described as the worst drought in recorded history punishing parts of Texas, Attorney General Greg Abbott found a way to keep watering his yard without risking fines or incurring huge monthly bills: he drilled his own well.

headline: Pacers’ Boldness Underscores the Nets’ Shortage of It
abstract: Showing the confidence that comes with being the N.B.A.’s lone unbeaten team, Indiana handed the still-hesitant Nets their first home loss.
lead_paragraph: There could hardly have been a less opportune time for the Nets, a team still trying to find itself and forge a unified identity, to encounter the Indiana Pacers, a club so obviously comfortable in its own tough skin.

headline: Calls Grow to Shut Down the Pegasus Pipeline for Good
abstract: While ExxonMobil says it has no timeline for reactivation, some Texans are banding together to oppose the pipeline’s return.
lead_paragraph: GUN BARREL CITY — For more than eight decades, Jim Howell was hardly one to cause a political ruckus. But this spring, he realized that a crude-oil superhighway ran through his backyard, just two feet below his patchy lawn and seven feet beyond a newly built porch.

headline: Alabama Reminds Everyone It’s No. 1
abstract: The Crimson Tide did not look invincible — there were mistakes early in the game — but they showed they could seize control when it counted.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Alabama Coach Nick Saban jumped toward his quarterback, held on tight, let go, turned toward the home tunnel at Bryant-Denny Stadium and began to jog.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 10, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 10, 2013.

headline: Woman Shot Near Campus in New Jersey
abstract: The police said that the woman was shot in the arm while inside her car, outside her father’s house. She fled in her car onto the campus of the small university, where the crime was reported.
lead_paragraph: A gunman shot a 27-year-old woman in the arm near Kean University’s campus in Union Township, N.J. on Sunday night, before fleeing into the surrounding streets.

keywords: ['Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: Typhoon Haiyan delivered a crippling blow to the country’s midsection and appeared to have brought a heavy loss of life to cities, towns and villages.
lead_paragraph: CEBU, Philippines — Three days after one of the most powerful storms ever to buffet the Philippines, the scale of the devastation and the desperation of the survivors were slowly coming into view.

headline: At a Swim Meet, a Ribbon for Everyone
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Swimming']
abstract: When I volunteered to write the ribbons at my 10-year-old’s swim meet, I had no idea I’d be helping write a ribbon for every child in every race.
lead_paragraph: My 10-year-old recently joined a swim team, which holds meets at municipal swim centers around town. At one recent meet, after we parked and made our way through a sea of speedo- and goggle-clad children, the coach walked up to the gathered group of parents.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Soma Water Filter
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a design object with a purpose (and a good cause).
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Shots Fired Into Crowd at Party in Houston Suburb, Killing Two
abstract: At least 20 others were injured after gunmen began shooting at a young woman’s 18th birthday celebration.
lead_paragraph: CYPRESS, Tex. — A house party packed with teenagers and young adults in this Houston suburb turned deadly on Saturday evening when gunfire erupted, the authorities said, killing two high school students and injuring at least 20 other partygoers who were either shot or hurt as they hopped over fences or jumped out of second-story windows in a frantic rush to escape.

headline: Pressure Mounts to Return Nazi-Looted Art
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: As more reports emerged about a German art dealer’s shady business with the Nazis, there were calls for the authorities to do more to return lost artworks to their rightful owners.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The mysterious discovery of 1,400 artworks apparently collected by a German dealer under the Nazis continued to ripple disturbingly through Germany and the art world on Sunday, prompting reports of a deal with Hitler’s propaganda chief and calls for Germans to do more to return lost works to Jewish heirs.

headline: Casting a Lifeline to Disabled Veterans
abstract: New York City members of Project Healing Waters Fly Fishing, a nonprofit that uses the sport as rehabilitative therapy for veterans, meet twice a month to build rods, tie flies, make friends and go fishing.
lead_paragraph: Todd Ford whisked back his fly-fishing rod, and then flung it forward, the plastic line slicing through the air. He might have been in Montana, if not for a distinctly urban scene: a view of One World Trade Center, Coney Island’s Wonder Wheel and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, as tankers cruised through Lower New York Bay.

headline: Iran Balked at Language of Draft Nuclear Deal, Western Diplomats Say
abstract: Toward the end of a marathon negotiating session, some diplomats believed that only a handful of words appeared to separate the two sides.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As Secretary of State John Kerry and foreign ministers from other world powers sought to work out an interim agreement to constrain Iran’s nuclear program, the Iranian government’s insistence on formal recognition of its “right” to enrich uranium emerged as a major obstacle, diplomats said Sunday.

headline: A Strong Start for ‘Thor: The Dark World’
abstract: The movie sold $86.1 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, adding to an overseas box-office total of $240.9 million for the Disney-owned Marvel Studios.
lead_paragraph: Fabio and his Magic Hammer, a.k.a. “Thor: The Dark World,” sold $86.1 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, adding to an overseas box-office total of $240.9 million and continuing a hot streak for the Disney-owned Marvel Studios. Starring Chris Hemsworth as the titular hammersmith, “Thor: The Dark World” cost an estimated $170 million to make and another $100 million to market. Reviews were on the soft side – the weakest of any self-produced Marvel movie to date – but audiences gave the film an A-minus score in exit polls, which usually bodes well for continued strength.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Sundance) AMADEUS (1984) The 18th-century court composer Antonio Salieri (F. Murray Abraham, in an Oscar-winning performance) confesses to a deadly rivalry with Mozart (Tom Hulce, above) — and even snatches “a bit of divinity” from Mozart on his deathbed before trying to pass off the music as his own — in this adaptation of Peter Shaffer’s play by the director Milos Forman. “The glimpses of the operas are so good that one wants to see more,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “They include ‘The Marriage of Figaro,’ about which the Emperor complains that ‘there are too many notes,’ ‘The Abduction From the Seraglio’ and ‘The Magic Flute,’ and, in one of the film’s most imaginative, most hallucinatory sequences, a parody version of ‘Don Giovanni,’ whose obscenities, of course, delight the now ailing Mozart.” Mr. Forman, who earned an Oscar for best director, he said, “has preserved the fascinating heart of Mr. Shaffer’s play, and made it available to millions who might never enter a legitimate theater. Well done.”

headline: Incognito Tries to Add Context to His Statements
abstract: The suspended Miami lineman Richie Incognito said he went too far in his comments to teammate Jonathan Martin, but the exchanges were in the context of their friendship.
lead_paragraph: In his first extended comments since he was accused of bullying a teammate, Richie Incognito said that he never intended to hurt Jonathan Martin, a fellow offensive lineman with the Miami Dolphins, and that his way of motivating Martin had been misinterpreted.

headline: Graham Sticks With Threat to Block Nominees
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham said he would hold up administration nominations until survivors of the Benghazi attack were made available to Congress, despite the retraction of a news report that provoked Republicans’ renewed demands.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham on Sunday stood by his threat to block all nominations by the Obama administration until Congress was granted access to all the survivors of the attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi, Libya, even as the news report on which Republicans based their latest demands was being retracted.

headline: A Note On Hysteresis And Monetary Policy
abstract: It’s a case against tightening, not for it.
lead_paragraph: After I published Friday’s column, featuring the Wilcox et al estimates of the long-term damage done by the Great Recession (“hysteresis”, in the econ jargon), several people at the IMF research conference — Christy Romer in particular — told me that they were worried that this stuff might give ammunition to Fed hawks, who will say “See, there isn’t that much slack in the economy, so it’s time to tighten.” Actually, something like this has happened in the UK fiscal debate, so it’s a real issue.

headline: Aerial Views of Devastation in the Philippines
abstract: For the first time since Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, aerial views are showing the extent of the damage in some parts of the country, cut off because of downed communication lines.
lead_paragraph: Aerial views of areas hard hit by Typhoon Haiyan show the extent of the destruction across the central Philippines, where emergency management officials say they fear as many as 10,000 people died just in the city of Tacloban in one of the most powerful storms recorded.

headline: Robbery Attempt Preceded Ice Rink Shooting, Police Say
keywords: ['Ice Skating', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A 16-year-old was in custody after someone approached a 20-year-old man, demanded his winter jacket and when he was refused, returned and opened fire.
lead_paragraph: It was a crisp Saturday night, the skaters jumping onto the freshly groomed ice in the oasis of Bryant Park in Midtown, Frank Sinatra and Billie Holiday in the background. Nearby, a wedding party was in full tilt at the Bryant Park Grill; vendors were cleaning up their stalls.

headline: With Victory Over Arsenal, United Shows Its Mettle
abstract: Robin van Persie's header in the first half, followed by tough defense, was enough to undo league-leading Arsenal.
lead_paragraph: Manchester United is heading back toward the top of the Premier League it won last season. The change of team management after so many years, and the march of Arsenal through the opening two months of the campaign, had suggested a tough transition for the champion.

headline: Learning How to Die in the Anthropocene
abstract: Many thinkers have argued that studying philosophy is learning how to die. If that’s true, then we have entered humanity’s most philosophical age.
lead_paragraph: I.

abstract: The reborn New York Cosmos on Saturday night won the N.A.S.L. championship, beating Atlanta, 1-0.

lead_paragraph: The editors of Home Fires recently invited readers to send their recollections and photographs of members of the United States Armed Forces in acknowledgment of Veterans Day. Below is a selection of those remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves. Last year’s Lives During Wartime post can be read here.

headline: For Knicks, a Slow Start and a Bad Ending

headline: To Win Now, Nets Take Time to Learn What Works
abstract: Coach Jason Kidd has an eye on the playoffs next spring as he limits the minutes of his veterans and experiments with players’ roles.
lead_paragraph: Jason Kidd is taking the long view on the Nets’ supposed short window. Teams with rosters as old and expensive as the Nets’ $103.1 million collection of battle-tested veterans are often said to be in “win now” mode. But for the Nets, who dropped to 2-5 with Saturday night’s 102-97 loss to the Indiana Pacers, “now” does not refer as much to this moment as it does to spring 2014.

abstract: One of the most powerful typhoons ever recorded has laid waste to cities, towns and fishing villages and has left an untold number of deaths across the central Philippines.

headline: The Remnants of a Culture’s Heart and Soul
abstract: Jewish documents rescued from a flooded intelligence building in Iraq a decade ago are now on view in “Discovery and Recovery,” an exhibition at the National Archives in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — These are not the weapons of mass destruction that the American Mobile Exploitation Team Alpha was seeking in Iraq during the spring of 2003. But the books and manuscripts that the team found in a flooded basement of Saddam Hussein’s secret police headquarters — now on display for the first time at the National Archives here — look like victims of some form of ordnance.
