headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 11
abstract: European Union trade negotiators and their counterparts from the United States are expected to start a second round of talks aimed at reaching a landmark trans-Atlantic accord to lower tariffs and harmonize regulation.
lead_paragraph: TRADE TALKS European Union trade negotiators and their counterparts from the United States are expected to start a second round of talks in Brussels on Monday aimed at reaching a landmark trans-Atlantic accord to lower tariffs and harmonize regulations. The talks, scheduled to last until Friday, follow reports of the United States spying on German Chancellor Angela Merkel, which prompted some lawmakers to demand that the talks cover privacy protection. Ms. Merkel has said that privacy should be dealt with separately from the trade talks to help ensure a deal can be reached to spur growth and create jobs.

headline: To Grow, Twitter Looks Outside Its Own Walls
abstract: Twitter is counting on millions of websites to link to the service and is encouraging independent developers to find creative new uses for its platform.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Twitter to justify the high valuation of its stock, the micro-messaging company must spread the gospel of tweeting far beyond its current active user base of 232 million accounts.

headline: Conductor and Orchestra Arrive Together
abstract: The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra’s weekend performances celebrated the inaugural of Louis Langrée as the venerable ensemble’s 13th music director.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — “You cannot become great if you’re not willing to sacrifice,” Maya Angelou told the audience at Music Hall here on Friday evening, an hour before she took the stage as the narrator in Copland’s stirring “Lincoln Portrait.”

headline: Not Just Another Dull Day at the Government Office
abstract: In “The Wrong Mans,” a spy-comedy series on Hulu, two losers stumble into a dark, spiraling farce.
lead_paragraph: Give James Corden the right material, and he can make anything funny. He demonstrates this repeatedly in “The Wrong Mans,” his new spy-comedy series for the BBC and Hulu. Air bag exploding in his face? Funny. Sobbing when told to throw away a new cellphone? Funny. (“I don’t want to go back to Nokia!”) Looking both directions at an intersection in a getaway car? Funny.

headline: A City Built on a Paradox: Cooperative Individualism
abstract: Russell Shorto, the acclaimed writer about New Amsterdam, turns his attention to the original city, in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: One of the best-known fables about the Dutch is the story of the boy who wards off disaster by putting his finger in a leaky dike. As Russell Shorto points out in his new history of Amsterdam, this tale was made up by an American (Mary Mapes Dodge, who had never been to Holland when she wrote her 1865 book, “Hans Brinker, or The Silver Skates,” in which the account of the boy’s wondrous feat appears). And it is a nonsensical story in the Netherlands, where heroism is often a communal effort.

headline: Making Sure Miles Stays Forever Young
abstract: Miles Davis’s son, daughter and nephew are managing his estate and marketing his catalog cautiously, while intending to keep his music in front of a new generation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Miles Davis died here more than 20 years ago, but in some ways he remains as much a presence as ever, and not just because recordings continue to be issued under his name. A book of his paintings and drawings was published last week, a biopic about him is in the works, a stamp with his image circulates, and a museum exhibition devoted to his life is traveling the world.

headline: War Theater, Repurposed
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Theater', 'Art', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Military veterans with an artistic bent are turning to groups and programs that help them navigate the world of performing arts.
lead_paragraph: His musical pitch, vocal range or favorite aria did not come up much when B. R. McDonald, a tenor, was kicking down doors and jumping out of planes in Iraq and Afghanistan as a member of the Army’s Joint Special Operations Command.

headline: Finding a Groove, or a Few Dozen; Map Is Optional
abstract: Jazz and Colors, more a transcendentalist experiment than a jazz festival, took place around Central Park on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: There is a long-running late-August festival in the northern Netherlands called Zomer Jazz Fietstour. It runs 12 hours, features a few dozen bands and takes place in barns and churches spread out around Groningen. You need to bicycle from one to another, and you are given suggested routes based on musical style or region. So idealized, so humane: Only in Europe, right?

headline: More ‘Downton Abbey’ Is Ordered Up
abstract: The “Masterpiece” series will return to PBS for a fifth season, the network announced on Sunday. The fourth season begins in the United States in January.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “Downton Abbey” can rest easy: The popular British “Masterpiece” series about aristocrats and their servants in the early 20th century will return to PBS for a fifth season, the network announced on Sunday.

headline: A Night of Surprising Revelations and ‘If Onlys’
abstract: The Suzanne Farrell Ballet, based at the Kennedy Center in Washington, revived a Balanchine rarity, “Pas de Dix,” in memory, Ms. Farrell said, of Maria Tallchief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s impressive to find one muse paying tribute to another. The choreographer George Balanchine’s muses were his ballerinas. Many of his ballets were designed as vehicles for them. When new, they seemed principally to celebrate what was most splendidly singular about them. Paradoxically, though, these same works in due course became vehicles for many dissimilar ballerinas that followed. If you’ve seen a piece danced by its first-cast ballerina, subsequent performances make you love the way the ballet still retains something of her essence and feel how irreplaceable she is. Yet, the piece also becomes something else, a vehicle for the dancer of today.

headline: ‘City on Fire,’ a Debut Novel, Fetches Nearly $2 Million
abstract: Garth Risk Hallberg’s novel took the publishing industry by storm last week and provides evidence of a resurgence of long fiction.
lead_paragraph: Donna Tartt’s novel “The Goldfinch” has 771 pages. “The Luminaries” by Eleanor Catton, winner of the 2013 Man Booker Prize, is 834 pages long. And then there is “City on Fire,” the 900-page debut novel that took the publishing industry by storm last week.

headline: A Mixed Up Quote
abstract: Play “who said that?” in this Monday puzzle from Elizabeth C. Gorksi.

headline: Brooklyn Philharmonic Seeks Financial Help
abstract: The Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra is trying to avoid bankruptcy, Crain’s reported.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra is trying to avoid bankruptcy, Crain’s reported. The orchestra is seeking a major cash infusion or a merger partner, according to “sources close to the institution” who would not disclose a timetable or how much the orchestra needs. The orchestra has no staff and few financial assets, having played its only concert of the 2012-13 season in June. The contract for its artistic director, Alan Pierson, was not renewed. Richard Dare stepped down last year as the orchestra’s chief executive and managing director to become president and chief executive of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. He resigned in January — nine days after starting in the new job — citing a 1996 case in which he was charged with an “attempted lewd act upon” a 15-year-old girl, whom he later married. “Despite the Brooklyn Philharmonic’s tremendous artistic successes over the last couple of years, the orchestra continues to experience financial difficulties,” Jack Rainey, the board’s chairman, told Crain’s in a statement. “The board of directors is considering all options.”

headline: A Britten Opera Benefit
abstract: Benjamin Britten’s opera “Noye’s Fludde” (“Noah’s Flood”) will be performed to benefit a school for blind musicians, the Filomen M. D’Agostino Greenburg Music School.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten’s opera “Noye’s Fludde” (“Noah’s Flood”) will be performed to benefit a school for blind musicians, the Filomen M. D’Agostino Greenburg Music School. The school is run by Lighthouse International, which provides services for people with vision impairment. The opera — presented by Lighthouse in partnership with Arts at the Park, which puts on artistic events at Park Avenue Christian Church — will be directed by Sarah Meyers, a Metropolitan Opera veteran, and conducted by Dr. Samuel Wong, an ophthalmologist who made his New York Philharmonic debut in 1990, stepping in for Leonard Bernstein. The production will feature professional artists and the youth and adult choirs of the music school and Park Avenue Christian Church. Performances are scheduled for Friday and Saturday at Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 East 86th Street, Manhattan.

headline: Awards for Modernism
abstract: Docomomo US, a nonprofit conservation organization dedicated to structures and projects of the modern movement, is now inviting submissions for the first Modernism in America Awards.
lead_paragraph: Docomomo US, a nonprofit conservation organization dedicated to structures and projects of the modern movement, is now inviting submissions for the first Modernism in America Awards. The awards will honor the documentation, preservation and reuse of modern buildings, structures and landscapes in the United States or in a United States territory. The categories are Design, Inventory/Survey and Advocacy. James Polshek, the founding partner of Polshek Partnership Architects — now Ennead — and former dean of the Columbia’s Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, will serve as the jury chairman. Nominations must be submitted by Jan. 15. Winners are to be announced in March at the Docomomo US National Symposium in Houston. “In the last 10 years, the appreciation of modern architecture in the United States has changed and gone from hideous to handsome,”  Theodore Prudon, the president of Docomomo US, said in a statement, adding that his organization was “delighted” to be “instrumental in changing those perceptions.”

headline: Art Fair in SoHo
abstract: The fair, art & design new york, will showcase ceramics, wood, textiles, jewelry, glass, sculpture, contemporary painting and photography.
lead_paragraph: A new art and design fair is coming to SoHo. The fair, art & design new york, will showcase ceramics, wood, textiles, jewelry, glass, sculpture, contemporary painting and photography. Produced by Urban Expositions, the fair is slated to run May 8 to 11 at 82 Mercer Street, with Donna Davies as its director. The fair will present similar materials and galleries as seen at the Sculpture Objects Functional Art and Design Fair in Chicago, while expanding the range of disciplines.

headline: Curry Stone Prizes Are Awarded
abstract: The Curry Stone Foundation has named three winners of its 2013 Curry Stone Design Prize.
lead_paragraph: The Curry Stone Foundation has named three winners of its 2013 Curry Stone Design Prize: Hunnarshala of Bhuj, India; Proximity Designs of Yangon, Myanmar; and Studio TAMassociati/Emergency  of Venice and Milan, Italy. (Emergency is an international nongovernmental organization that treats injured civilians in war zones). The awards ceremony was held last week at the Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco.

headline: Bystanders Shot by the Police Face an Uphill Fight to Win Lawsuits
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: New York City is taking a more aggressive stance against people who have been wounded by police bullets, often moving to have the cases thrown out before trial.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Empire State Building in Midtown one mild morning in the summer of 2012, the crowd consisted of tourists and office workers — and a solitary gunman who was fleeing the site of a murder. As the police closed in, the gunman drew his .45-caliber handgun, and two officers opened fire, discharging 16 shots in all.

headline: The Greatest President
abstract: Representations in textbooks, news reports and other media, along with the passing of generations, have influenced views of United States presidents over time.
lead_paragraph: Representations in textbooks, news reports and other media, along with the passing of generations, have influenced views of United States presidents over time.

headline: Heartache To a Beat, Or Several
abstract: Polica, a Minneapolis band that emerged from Gayngs, a soft-rock collective, brought its sad messages and complicated rhythms to Webster Hall on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Inexorable beats and looming heartache fill the songs of Polica, a band from Minneapolis that performed at Webster Hall on Friday night. Its music opens up wide spaces to expose tidings of desire, separation, longing, bitterness and resolve: breakup songs that absolve no one.

headline: No Quick Fixes for China’s Overwhelmed Organ Transplant System
abstract: China has vowed to end its reliance on executions for transplant organs, but public distrust has slowed development of a donation system.
lead_paragraph: Suffering from bile duct cancer and with no family to support him and little money for treatment, Xu Bao, 35, vowed that if he suffered an early death he would give something back to society. He decided that he would donate his corneas to fellow Chinese waiting for transplants.

headline: A Brazilian Boom Town of ‘Eternal Beauty’ Faces Its Troubled Side
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Transit Systems', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Salvador has experienced a surge in violent crime, chaotic traffic, and the metamorphosis of once-elegant seaside districts into crime-ridden areas.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — Baroque architectural gems grace this city. Musicians enthrall audiences with high-octane performances reflecting Salvador’s status as a bastion of Brazil’s popular culture. Luxury residential towers overlook a stunning harbor. The industrial park on the city’s outskirts contains cutting-edge plants opened by Ford and other multinational corporations.

headline: Nitro Circus, Extreme Athletics Brand, to Merge With Touring Company
abstract: The high-octane entertainment brand will announce that the separate entities that produced the live shows and television programs are becoming one company.
lead_paragraph: One of the highlights of any Nitro Circus show comes when Aaron Fotheringham, an extreme wheelchair athlete, careers down the megaramp and does a double back flip in midair, landing 50 feet away.

headline: Removing Fuel Rods Poses New Risks at Crippled Nuclear Plant in Japan
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis']
abstract: A plan to move radioactive fuel to safer storage at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant is a critical step in a long decommissioning process that has already had serious setbacks.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was the part of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant that spooked American officials the most, as the complex spiraled out of control two and a half years ago: the spent fuel pool at Reactor No. 4, with more than 1,500 radioactive fuel assemblies left exposed when a hydrogen explosion blew the roof off the building.

headline: Using Humor to Talk About Birth Control
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A campaign guides young African-American women in making contraceptive choices.
lead_paragraph: FEW things may be less comfortable to talk about with one’s parents than sex and birth control, and with that in mind, a new public service campaign hopes to offer guidance through a series of ads and online videos.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry for the Week of Nov. 11
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: China’s President Steps Boldly Backward
abstract: When it comes to acting on pledges for economic and political reform, President Xi Jinping displays a confusing agility.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to acting on pledges for economic and political reform, President Xi Jinping displays a confusing agility.

headline: Big Data’s Little Brother
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Start-ups are gathering data and analyzing it much faster than was possible even a couple of years ago, aiming to project economic trends from seemingly unconnected information.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — David Soloff is recruiting an army of “hyperdata” collectors.

headline: Storm Track Veers Away From Vietnam
abstract: After plowing through the Philippines, Typhoon Haiyan took a right turn over the South China Sea on Sunday, avoiding the central coast of Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: After plowing through the Philippines, Typhoon Haiyan took a right turn over the South China Sea on Sunday, avoiding the central coast of Vietnam, where hundreds of thousands of people had been evacuated to emergency shelters. Instead, it made landfall early Monday much farther north, near the Chinese border.

headline: South Florida Faces Ominous Prospects From Rising Waters
abstract: Long battered by hurricanes and prone to flooding from intense thunderstorms, Florida is the most vulnerable state in the country to the rise in sea levels.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — In the most dire predictions, South Florida’s delicate barrier islands, coastal communities and captivating subtropical beaches will be lost to the rising waters in as few as 100 years.

headline: BlackBerry’s Woes Draw Canada’s Contrarian Mogul Into Spotlight
abstract: The saving of BlackBerry may represent a patriotic calling to V. Prem Watsa, But he is not used to dealing in as public an arena as the company does.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the first weekend of November, V. Prem Watsa, the Canadian immigrant success story and chairman of Fairfax Financial Holdings, was huddled in the offices of his Toronto law firm, Torys, trying to salvage the biggest bet of his career.

headline: Daring to Complain About Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Has Obamacare made it un-P.C. to be concerned by a serious burden on a middle-class family’s well-being?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — THE Anthem Blue Cross representative who answered my call told me that there was a silver lining in the cancellation of my individual P.P.O. policy and the $5,400 annual increase that I would have to pay for the Affordable Care Act-compliant option: now if I have Stage 4 cancer or need a sex-change operation, I’d be covered regardless of pre-existing conditions. Never mind that the new provider network would eliminate coverage for my and my son’s long-term doctors and hospitals.

headline: Smith Returns, but His Game Does Not
abstract: The Knicks’ J. R. Smith missed eight of nine shots, committed four turnovers and spent the fourth quarter on the bench in his regular-season debut.
lead_paragraph: The loudest roar at Madison Square Garden on Sunday was not produced by a Carmelo Anthony jumper or a strong defensive effort by the Knicks. There were few such moments in their embarrassing 120-89 loss to the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Danger Persists for Reporters in Pakistan, Despite Vow to Protect Them
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Five journalists have died so far this year in Pakistan, and by some accounts, the dangers of reporting in the nation have been intensifying.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The killers were waiting for Ayub Khattak, a small-town reporter in northwestern Pakistan, as he returned to his house one evening in October. They gunned him down just outside his door.

headline: N.C.A.A. Dodges a Bullet, but Change Is on the Way
abstract: The latest ruling in O’Bannon vs. N.C.A.A., in which athletes’ compensation is at stake, leaves both sides claiming victory.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, after United States District Judge Claudia Wilken made her latest ruling in O’Bannon v. the N.C.A.A., two men involved in the matter spoke with each other by telephone. One was Ed O’Bannon, a former U.C.L.A. basketball star; the other, Sonny Vaccaro, the sneaker marketing executive turned perpetual N.C.A.A. antagonist.

headline: The Vets We Reject and Ignore
abstract: We turn our backs on hundreds of thousands of veterans who have “bad paper” and thus do not qualify as veterans under federal law.
lead_paragraph: TODAY, we honor the nation’s 22 million veterans, including more than 2.5 million who served in Iraq, Afghanistan and other fronts in the war against Al Qaeda. But we are turning our backs on hundreds of thousands of veterans who were discharged “under conditions other than honorable” and so do not qualify as veterans under federal law.

headline: New Hope for Homeless Vets
abstract: Homelessness is on the decline among veterans, but it’s urgent to accelerate our efforts at a time when federal support for housing investments is in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: Each Veterans Day we lament the number of men and women who have ably served in uniform but find themselves lost, broken and homeless once out of it. Their stories are tragic and seemingly endless. For all the well-intentioned talk about meeting the needs of homeless veterans, it remains a slow and difficult process that sometimes fails.

headline: Venezuelan Soldiers Deployed to Stores
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The socialist government dispatched soldiers to a major chain of electronic goods stores, ordering prices slashed there and in other shops it has accused of gouging.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Christmas shopping season has started with a jolt here, with the socialist Venezuelan government dispatching soldiers to “occupy” a major chain of electronic goods stores, ordering prices slashed there and in other shops that it has accused of price gouging.

headline: Marrying Companies and Content
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The New York-based company Contently has developed a roster of writers and journalists for hire and a software application that helps companies tell their own stories.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Contently, a hot little company, held a buzzy conference at the Bowery Hotel on a very of-the-moment topic.

headline: Many Black New Yorkers Are Seeing de Blasio’s Victory as Their Own
abstract: In postelection interviews, dozens of black New Yorkers said Bill de Blasio’s personal touch and biracial family had affected them deeply.
lead_paragraph: A black janitor in Brooklyn almost shouted out the name when asked about his vote in the mayoral race. Bill de Blasio, he said, “knows my struggle.”

headline: The Plot Against France
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: It’s another case of ideology posing as economic analysis.
lead_paragraph: On Friday Standard & Poor’s, the bond-rating agency, downgraded France. The move made headlines, with many reports suggesting that France is in crisis. But markets yawned: French borrowing costs, which are near historic lows, barely budged.

headline: Conservative Republicans Recoil at the Notion That Christie Is the Party’s Savior
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Grass-roots activists, especially members of the Tea Party, distrust Gov. Chris Christie’s adherence to the party’s principles and resent his favor within the mainstream media.
lead_paragraph: Time magazine splashed Chris Christie’s profile on its latest cover. High-profile Republicans, including the only female Hispanic governor in the nation, are urging him to run for president. MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” program seems to be anointing him the savior of the Republican Party.

headline: High and Low Premiums in Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Millions will be eligible for no-premium policies, and others will pay more for new and better coverage.
lead_paragraph: The debate over the effect the Affordable Care Act will have on individuals and families who buy their own policies has mostly been waged in anecdotes. Supporters of the law point to grateful individuals who were previously unable to get insurance or paid exorbitant premiums but found affordable coverage on the new health insurance exchanges. Critics counter with frustrated people who liked their old policies but will now be forced to buy a more comprehensive policy and pay a higher premium for it.

headline: Same Time, Same Channel? TV Woos Kids Who Can’t Wait
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: In their efforts to attract children, television networks are starting to show programs online before they appear on old-fashioned TV.
lead_paragraph: When Eric Nelson’s 6-year-old daughter, Charlotte, and 10-year-old son, Asa, discover that they cannot rewind or fast-forward a TV show, they are perplexed — and their father is, too. It is hard to explain the limitations of live television to children who have grown up in an on-demand world.

headline: New Faces for a Hobbled Commission
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Editorials', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The confirmation of two new members to the Federal Election Commission, one of the most dysfunctional agencies in Washington, offers a ray of hope.
lead_paragraph: The Senate’s confirmation of two new members to the Federal Election Commission, one of the most dysfunctional and politically riven agencies in Washington, offers a ray of hope. The work of the commission has been stymied for months thanks to a standoff engineered by obstinate Republicans.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Airs Apology on Benghazi
abstract: The CBS newsmagazine issued a rare retraction and apology for its report on an attack on Americans in Libya, saying it was misled by a source.
lead_paragraph: Lara Logan was scheduled to deliver a report on Sunday’s “60 Minutes” about disabled veterans who climb mountains. Instead, she appeared in front of the newsmagazine’s trademark black backdrop and issued an apology.

headline: Broncos Win, but Not Without Raising Doubts for Playoffs
abstract: The absence of Broncos Coach John Fox, who is on leave because of heart surgery, comes at a critical time for the team as it approaches tougher opponents.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — If doctors took away his cellphone in the days immediately after Broncos Coach John Fox had heart surgery, they surely must have demanded that he give up control of the television remote Sunday as he sat at home watching the Broncos’ 28-20 victory over the San Diego Chargers.

headline: Low-Stress Voting
abstract: New York and other states with outdated election schedules should provide a two-week voting period instead of cramming it all into one day.
lead_paragraph: Voting should be easy, convenient and efficient — no lines, and no panic about choosing between voting or being late to work.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 10, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Time to Pause
abstract: The city’s ambitious vision for Midtown East cannot be rushed.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who leaves office at midnight on Dec. 31, has been urgently pushing a plan to build new commercial towers in Manhattan around Grand Central Terminal. The idea is to demolish outdated buildings and erect modern office buildings to compete with London or Singapore. New York could use more top-flight office space, but the proposal to rezone 73 blocks in East Midtown needs work.

headline: Border War Brewing for the Olympics
abstract: American and Canadian women have a great respect for one another, but the hockey rivals relish the opportunity to mix it up, though women’s hockey prohibits body checking.
lead_paragraph: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — Kacey Bellamy and Courtney Birchard were hockey teammates and close friends at the University of New Hampshire. The friendship endures, Bellamy said, “but we definitely know our boundaries. We’re not afraid to mix it up with each other on the ice, absolutely.”

headline: A Word That Turned Her Life Around: ‘Mom’
abstract: Once a high school truant with an anxiety disorder, Analeida Serrano was inspired by her daughter to take control of her life and to start working toward her G.E.D.
lead_paragraph: After she started high school, Analeida Serrano began to experience an anxiety disorder triggered by situations like crowded classrooms.

headline: Vox Media Buying Curbed.com Network of Sites
abstract: Vox Media recently raised $34 million in new investment capital, helping give it the money to buy the Curbed, Eater and Racked sites.
lead_paragraph: Vox Media, a company with three strong digital brands, including the technology site The Verge, is adding to its portfolio. The company plans to announce on Monday that it is buying Curbed.com L.L.C., which runs three web publications that deliver in-depth neighborhood coverage, with attitude, of real estate, dining and retailing.

headline: Latino Comedian Returns to Where It All Began
abstract: Mike Robles, who has hosted comedy shows around the country, carved his own path to stardom, which started with interviewing strangers and pulling pranks in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: The bodega cat knew trouble was brewing in the Torres Family Deli-Grocery as it slunk past the bags of plantain chips and boxes of Goya crackers. Sure enough, two men lunged at each other, grunting and grabbing as they fell to the scuffed tile floor near the glassed-in counter.

headline: Salvaging Obama
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States International Relations', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A to-do list for a presidency in distress.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is under water. His approval in the polls is low and sinking, his signature initiative is staggering from a combination of incompetence and sabotage, his foreign policy is a jumble. Congress is a Bermuda Triangle where the most elementary White House business disappears. The public is numbed and disgusted. Allies are theatrically furious about eavesdropping. Put it this way:

headline: For the Want of Real Leaders, N.F.L. Culture Will Stay Lost
abstract: Teams like the Miami Dolphins tend to stay true to a code of brotherhood, even if it taints their reputation or possibly hurts others.
lead_paragraph: By now we know what Richie Incognito is accused of doing to his Miami Dolphins teammate Jonathan Martin. Name-calling. Bullying. Threats. What we don’t know is the truth of what happened between them, or who is going to fix the cruel locker room culture that the situation has exposed.

headline: Talk of Penalty Is Missing in Ads for Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The state and federal health insurance exchanges are emphasizing benefits to sell the Affordable Care Act’s products, but playing down the fees that Americans must pay if they fail to buy.
lead_paragraph: New York’s health exchange slogan is “Today’s the Day.” Minnesota has enlisted Paul Bunyan. Oregon held a music contest, and California stresses the “peace of mind” that will come with insurance.

headline: Reining In Manning to Role of Game Manager
abstract: The continuing struggles of Eli Manning at quarterback may cause Giants Coach Tom Coughlin to take a more conservative approach on offense.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was a moment frozen in poses of stunning failure, coach and quarterback wearing now-familiar expressions of utter exasperation. Hands on hips, Tom Coughlin stared at a hangdog-looking Eli Manning like a disbelieving father whose son has just backed the car out of the driveway and into a tree.

headline: ‘Twelfth Night’ and ‘Richard III’
abstract: Scenes from the two productions now running in repertory on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the two productions now running in repertory on Broadway.

headline: Boys Will Be Boys (and Sometimes Girls)
abstract: All the characters are not what they seem in Tim Carroll’s staging of “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III,” running in repertory on Broadway at the Belasco Theater.
lead_paragraph: The man dressed as a woman dressed as a man declares, with understandable agitation, that disguise is truly “a wickedness.” But don’t ask anyone lucky enough to be at the Belasco Theater, home to a peerless production of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night,” to agree with him. I mean her. I mean him.

headline: Film on Love and Gang War in Puerto Rico Is Coming to New York
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Theater', 'Movies', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: “For Love in the Projects,” a film set in Puerto Rico’s largest public housing project, is being shown this week at three City University of New York colleges.
lead_paragraph: On the sixth day of filming, the housing project’s managers decided to paint.

headline: Prosecuting Executives for Wall Street Crime
abstract: Can prosecutors win criminal convictions and prison sentences, instead of just fines, against Wall Street wrongdoers?

headline: Health Website Tests a Tycoon and Tinkerer
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: With no hands-on technology experience and a tight deadline, the entrepreneur Jeffrey D. Zients is leading the effort to fix HealthCare.gov.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey D. Zients, a multimillionaire entrepreneur and management consultant, joined the Obama White House in 2009 with a mandate to streamline the federal bureaucracy. A year later, he issued a prescient warning.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 8, 2013
abstract: This week, Joe discusses a new era in New York City politics.
lead_paragraph: This week, voters elected Bill de Blasio as New York City’s new mayor by a decisive margin. Can he deliver on his promises? He campaigned on raising the taxes of the wealthy to pay for pre-kindergarten classes, providing more affordable housing and rejecting how Mayor Bloomberg has run the city for the past 12 years. This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine consider how successful the new mayor might be in enacting his agenda.

headline: Leonard Herzenberg, 81, Immunologist Who Revolutionized Research, Dies
abstract: Dr. Herzenberg, who developed a device to better examine cells, helped facilitate stem cell research and advance the treatment of cancer and other illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Herzenberg was in his lab at Stanford University one day in the early 1960s, laboriously counting cells under a microscope. His eyes hurt. “There’s got to be some kind of machine that can do this,” he remembered muttering.

headline: The Streets of Salvador
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Transit Systems', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: In what may serve as a cautionary tale for other cities in the developing world, the Brazilian boom town’s rising prosperity exists alongside a darker reality.
lead_paragraph: In what may serve as a cautionary tale for other cities in the developing world, the Brazilian boom town’s rising prosperity exists alongside a darker reality.

headline: Mystery of a 257-Year-Old Cannon Lingers
abstract: A Revolutionary War cannon surrendered by the British after the Battles of Saratoga in 1777 somehow disappeared about 1961. Now it’s back at the Saratoga National Historical Park.
lead_paragraph: STILLWATER, N.Y. — It sits now in its rightful home, after a strange journey along the East Coast, its whereabouts a mystery even as it passed through an amusement park, various collectors’ hands and an art museum in Alabama.

headline: For 2014, G.O.P.’s Challenges Stem From Within
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In the battle over the Republican Party’s ideological future, a number of races could alter the party’s complexion in the House — and Washington’s ability to govern.
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, Pa. — Art Halvorson makes for an unlikely Republican primary challenger to a six-term incumbent like Representative Bill Shuster. He is a newcomer to this quiet corner of south-central Pennsylvania who retired here after a long Coast Guard career.

headline: Anya Hindmarch: Building a Bag Brand
abstract: Suzy Menkes sits down with the accessories designer to discuss the evolution of her brand and her design inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes sits down with the accessories designer to discuss the evolution of her brand and her design inspiration.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Five of the top albums sold in Canada the week ending Nov. 3 were also on the United States top 10 list.
lead_paragraph: Five of the top albums sold in Canada the week ending Nov. 3 were also on the United States top 10 list.

headline: Building a Brand, One Bag at a Time
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: In London, Anya Hindmarch sees the fun and serious side of her purse business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The shop window has a flock of baby chicks apparently skittering by bold handbags. Inside, there are purses shaped like crumpled potato chip bags and beach totes with smiley suns and the words “Have a Nice Day.”

headline: On Field and on Sideline, Changes Bring Same Result for Texans
abstract: With Coach Gary Kubiak and running back Arian Foster absent because of health problems, Houston fell to its seventh straight defeat.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The understudy Wade Phillips played an N.F.L. head coach on Sunday, and in some respects, it was as if nothing had changed since the last time he inhabited the role. Phillips, relieved of his lead position with a one-win Dallas Cowboys team three Novembers ago, was again at the helm of an underachieving Texas team, a Super Bowl contender gone bad.

headline: Textbooks Reassess Kennedy, Putting Camelot Under Siege
abstract: In the 50 years since his assassination, the image of John F. Kennedy has shifted from tragic hero to flawed leader.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The President John F. Kennedy students learn about today is not their grandparents’ J.F.K.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Parking regulations in New York City for Veterans Day.
lead_paragraph: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Giants Stretch Streak
abstract: The Giants defeated the Raiders, 24-20, at MetLife Stadium, continuing a modest comeback from an 0-6 start with their third win in a row.
lead_paragraph: The Giants defeated the Raiders, 24-20, at MetLife Stadium, continuing a modest comeback from an 0-6 start with their third win in a row.

headline: In Detroit, Protests of Shooting of Woman Who Sought Help
abstract: Civil rights groups protested this weekend after a young black woman was shot on the porch of a suburban home earlier this month, as she apparently sought help after she had car trouble.
lead_paragraph: Civil rights groups protested in Detroit this weekend after a young black woman was shot on the porch of a suburban home earlier this month, as she apparently sought help after she had car trouble.

headline: Behind E-Commerce Spree, a Day for ‘Bare Branches’
abstract: In China, Nov. 11 is “Bare Branch Day” or “Singles Day,” when unmarried Chinese celebrate their status. It’s also become an online shopping festival.
lead_paragraph: China’s burgeoning, one-day e-commerce festival goes by several names — Bare Branch Day, Singles Day (in English), the Double Eleventh. Observed every year on Nov. 11, it’s roughly the equivalent of Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined, with a “Not Valentine’s Day” thrown in for good measure. A festival aimed at the unmarried, this year it’s expected to clock up sales — on mostly discounted online goods — of about 30 billion renminbi, or $5 billion, the state media estimated.

headline: Encouraging Paid Employment
abstract: While public assistance programs may always be susceptible to opportunism, they can – and often do – encourage paid employment, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Rethinking ‘Term Pregnancy’
abstract: A pregnancy that is shorter or longer than full term can sometimes be less than ideal for the infant, and occasionally for the mother.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has roasted a turkey knows that if you take it from the oven too soon, it will not have cooked through, and if you leave it in too long, it will be dry and tough.

headline: Warnings on Children’s Drugs Found to Help Curb Misuse
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hospitals', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Safety measures by the makers of children’s cough and cold medicines have decreased emergency visits by toddlers with suspected medical problems after using these drugs, government researchers found.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, amid mounting concern that infant cough and cold medicines were unsafe and misused, manufacturers voluntarily withdrew products intended for children younger than 2. The makers revised the labels on the rest of the medicines, which now warn parents that they should not be given to children younger than 4.

headline: Evolving Portraits of J.F.K.
abstract: While textbook writers have been consistent in describing President John F. Kennedy’s charisma and ability to inspire the country, they have become more critical of his handling of issues from civil rights to the Cuban missile crisis and the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: While textbook writers have been consistent in describing President John F. Kennedy’s charisma and ability to inspire the country, they have become more critical of his handling of issues from civil rights to the Cuban missile crisis and the Vietnam War.

headline: Postal Service to Make Sunday Deliveries for Amazon
abstract: The plan covers the New York and Los Angeles metro areas and is expected to expand, and it offers the Postal Service a chance to take profitable business away from rivals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The cash-short United States Postal Service, which has failed to win congressional approval to stop delivering mail on Saturdays to save money, has struck a deal with the online retailer Amazon.com to deliver the company’s packages on Sundays — a first for both, with obvious advantages for each.

headline: Word of the Day | repute
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: repute •\ri-ˈpyüt\• noun and verb

headline: Gun Violence in American Movies Is Rising, Study Finds
abstract: Violent encounters with guns occur, on average, more than twice an hour in the best sellers in PG-13 and R-rated movies, according to a study set for publication in Pediatrics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A study set for publication in the December issue of Pediatrics confirms what some of Hollywood’s sharpest critics have suspected: The level of gun violence in the top-selling PG-13 movies has been rising, and it now exceeds that in the most popular R-rated films.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 3-9
abstract: Sometimes, to surpass the competition, an athlete must strive for elevation, literally.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, to surpass the competition, an athlete must strive for elevation, literally.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) CRISIS HOTLINE: VETERANS PRESS 1 (2013) Since 2001, more veterans have committed suicide than have died in combat in Iraq and Afghanistan, according to the United States Department of Veterans Affairs. The Veterans Crisis Line in Canandaigua, N.Y., receives more than 22,000 calls each month from former soldiers who are contemplating ending their lives because of the psychological wounds of war and the challenges of returning to civilian life. In this documentary in honor of Veterans Day, Ellen Goosenberg Kent examines the traumas endured by veterans, and the hotline’s trained responders, above, who provide support in the hope of saving lives.

headline: China’s One-Day Shopping Spree Sets Record in Online Sales
abstract: Chinese consumers were taking to the Internet in record numbers for an annual 24-hour online sale that has ballooned into the world’s biggest e-commerce event.
lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — Unmarried men across China used to spend Nov. 11 lamenting their single status with a drink. Now that unofficial holiday has become the world’s largest online shopping event.

headline: Game to Watch: Pacers Streak Toward Chicago
abstract: Indiana (7-0) is off to its best start; as for the Bulls, Derrick Rose remains a work in progress.

headline: Woman Shot Near Campus in New Jersey

headline: The Blackout That Exposed the Flaws in the Grid
keywords: ['Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: As this Retro Report recalls, 50 million people in the United States and Canada lost power on Aug. 14, 2003. But steps are being taken to reduce the risk of a future large-scale collapse.
lead_paragraph: On a late Thursday afternoon in the summer of 2003, everything turned off. As this week’s Retro Report video illustrates, in the span of a few minutes, the biggest power outage in United States history brought swaths of the Northeast, the Midwest and Canada to a standstill. Around 50 million people were left without power. In the days and weeks that followed, reporters and investigators raced to pinpoint the source of the outage, while larger questions swirled about the stability of the power grid in the 21st century. Here, a Times reporter who covers energy technology reflects on that day and the changes that resulted.

Let’s say I get to enter the age and sex (and maybe whether they smoke) of the prospective employee and any others in their family. Then I get a number right then and there that tells me what this will do to my insurance rates.”

headline: Markets Evolve, as Does Financial Fraud
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commodities', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Regulators and investors face the challenge of finding the fine line between permissible trading and market manipulation.
lead_paragraph: It is usually the case that there are not new frauds, just new avenues for deception. As the financial world has evolved into a high-speed race to trade assets while investment strategies are kept secret, both regulators and investors face the challenge of finding the fine line between permissible trading and manipulation aimed at generating unfair profits.

headline: Struggle for Survival in Philippine City Shattered by Typhoon
abstract: Destroyed buildings lined every road of Tacloban, the city hit hardest by the typhoon, and many streets were still so clogged with debris that they were barely discernible.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Decomposing bodies still lie along the roads, like a corpse in a pink, short-sleeve shirt and blue shorts facedown in a black, muddy puddle 100 yards from the airport. Just down the road is a church that was supposed to be an evacuation center but is littered with the bodies of those who drowned inside.

headline: Snapshots From the Fall Art Season in London
abstract: A show at the Victoria & Albert Museum focuses on Chinese Painting while the Tate Britain showcases the work of Vija Celmins.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The tiny figures are painted in brushstrokes thinner than a hair — a bride dressed in festive red, merchants with their wares, would-be bureaucrats studying for a state exam in a state pavilion — set against a bay, a stand of trees. They are part of “Prosperous Suzhou,” a vast panorama of urban life painted in 1759 by Xu Yang, one of the many works on view in “Masterpieces of Chinese Painting 700-1900” at the Victoria & Albert Museum here through Jan. 19.

headline: Bloody End for Iranian Rockers Seeking Musical Freedom in U.S.
abstract: The gunman also killed himself, the police said. Two of his victims were in a rock band called the Yellow Dogs, made up of other Iranian expatriates.

Growing up together in Tehran, they had found a sound: part punk, part garage rock, part their own invention.

Executives backdate options. We often hear the excuse, “Everyone else was doing it, so I didn’t think it was wrong.”

headline: The Francis Era: Synthesis or Civil War?
abstract: Can Francis-era Catholicism move beyond its post-Vatican II internal conflicts?
lead_paragraph: My colleague Laurie Goodstein had a good piece yesterday about conservative Catholics who feel unsettled by Pope Francis’s approach to the papal office, which seems like a good hook for returning, a month later, to my own take on the Francis experiment. In that piece, I talked a bit about the idea of a “religious center” — meaning a way of being religious that’s simultaneously modern and devout, engaged with contemporary realities but still rooted in a recognizably Biblical worldview – and argued that since the 1960s it’s become harder for believers of any traditional faith to claim that kind of ground. The tendency, instead, has been toward either toward a kind of separatism and retrenchment on the one hand, or accommodation and then often dissolution on the other – and this has been true for Jews and Protestants as it has been for Catholics.

headline: Introducing: Capitalizing on China

Make it with fresh roasted pumpkin, or use canned pumpkin. I am finding small “pie pumpkins” in supermarkets, and they’re perfect for the job.
