lead_paragraph: FOR decades, cities and states that needed more cash for their workers’ pensions have turned to local taxpayers, the municipal bond market or even the workers themselves. Now those options appear to be drying up.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 5-11, 2013
abstract: A devastating typhoon, a trove of lost art, and problems in the N.F.L.: can you answer these 10 questions correctly?
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: For $99, Eliminating the Mystery of Pandora’s Genetic Box
abstract: Anne Wojcicki, the co-founder and chief executive of 23andMe, the DNA testing start-up, discusses the future of genetics and health care.
lead_paragraph: IF DNA is destiny, then Anne Wojcicki is in the right business.

headline: On the Ground in Tacloban
abstract: The Times’s Keith Bradsher reported on the devastation in Tacloban, the Philippines, days after Typhoon Haiyan ripped through the city.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Keith Bradsher reported on the devastation in Tacloban, the Philippines, days after Typhoon Haiyan ripped through the city.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Wanting to give credit to the creator of an iPad commercial, and even more ad burn-out feedback.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: The Addy Awards get a new name, and MediaLink’s chief executive, Michael Kassan, will present daily radio reports in New York on advertising and media.
lead_paragraph: American Advertising Federation, Washington, renamed its annual Addy Awards competition as the American Advertising Awards. James Edmund Datri, president and chief executive of the organization, said he hoped that local chapters would still call the awards that are presented to winners Addy awards.

headline: Fans and Friends React to the Shooting Deaths of Iranian Band Members
abstract: Reactions made it onto social media sites as fans, friends and musicians woke to news of the shooting deaths of members of the band Yellow Dogs.
lead_paragraph: Early Monday, a rock musician in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, killed three other musicians before taking his own life, the police and neighbors said. Two of the victims were members of a rock band of Iranian expatriates called the Yellow Dogs. The gunman was another Iranian-American musician, the police said.

headline: Slowing the Revolving Door Between Public and Private Jobs
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Countless prosecutors, regulators and congressional aides swap their government résumés for seven-figure salaries at law firms and lobbying shops.
lead_paragraph: It has been called “corrupt,” “corrosive” and “hazardous to our health.” Yet, Washington’s revolving door spins on.

headline: Chanel, Self-Appointed Guardian of Paris’s Artisan Workshops
abstract: Thanks to the rapid industrialization of the fashion world, the city’s old-world handcraft ateliers were facing extinction. Then Chanel stepped in to save the day.
lead_paragraph: When fashion’s Old World specialty ateliers were on the verge of extinction, Chanel came to the rescue. Now it’s ushering them into the future.

headline: A Jolt to Complacency on Food Supply
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Food', 'Corn', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The negative effects of global climate change on agriculture are expected to get worse, experts say, raising deep concerns about the global food supply in the decades to come.
lead_paragraph: For a look at what climate change could do to the world’s food supply, consider what the weather did to the American Corn Belt last year.

headline: For Better Performance, Hedge Funds Seek the Inner Trader
abstract: The industry is increasingly turning to self-help programs, sometimes referred to as “mindware” products, to try to improve its game.
lead_paragraph: In the hedge fund industry, as in sports, performance is everything.

headline: Giving People a Glimpse of What Their Pets See
abstract: Nature’s Recipe is giving“collar cameras” to influential pet owners, and resulting photos are posted online.
lead_paragraph: FORGET about a bird’s-eye view. A leader in pet foods is introducing a digital campaign for a principal brand that promises to provide views from the dog’s- and cat’s-eye perspective.

headline: Braves Plan to Leave Turner Field for Suburbs
abstract: The proposed $672 million stadium would be built in suburban Cobb County and would be paid for by the team and the county.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Braves said Monday that they will leave Turner Field in four years for a ballpark they plan to build in the wealthy northern suburbs where most of their fans live. The move follows one already planned by the N.F.L.’s Atlanta Falcons, who have said that they will stay downtown but will trade their current home in the Georgia Dome for a retractable-roof stadium to be built nearby at a cost of $1.2 billion.

headline: Aaron Glick Awarded T Fellowship for Theater Producers
abstract: The T Fellowship, administered by Columbia, aims to support emerging theatrical producers through a stipend and mentoring.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Glick, a theater producer whose productions have included the PigPen Theater Company’s Off Broadway staging of “The Old Man and the Old Moon,” has been awarded a T Fellowship, a one-year program meant to support the development of emerging producers.

headline: Cruise Lines Are Ready for Some Football
abstract: Carnival Cruise Lines has a promotion-focused partnership with the New Orleans Saints, and Anheuser-Busch will take over a Norwegian Cruise Line ship for the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, it seems as if major cruise lines have been harnessing the star power of every kind of celebrity to sell more voyages. Some feature food from Top Chefs, entertainment from American Idols or even a chance to sail the Caribbean with the members of the band Kiss.

headline: 20 Million in Mideast to Get Polio Vaccine
abstract: Health officials will try to get polio vaccines to more than 20 million children across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Health officials will try to get polio vaccines to more than 20 million children across the Middle East to contain a major outbreak there, the World Health Organization and Unicef announced last week.

headline: Fighting Across the Rappahannock
abstract: The story of the soldiers from Maine who beat Robert E. Lee in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Clark basked in the warmth of a budding romance on a cold autumn day in 1863. His friend and fellow lieutenant in the Union Army, Solomon Russell, had fallen for a Southern belle in war-torn Virginia. On the morning of Nov. 7, 1863, the officers left their camp in Warrenton to call upon her. They made their way to the home of the widow Rosina Dixon and found the focus of Russell’s desire: the 15-year-old Anna. Whatever words passed between the Yankee officer and rebel maiden went unrecorded, though Clark referenced the encounter years later in his reminiscences, noting that Russell “was deeply in love” with Anna.

headline: Injuries to Players Raise Questions on Athlete I.P.O. Plan
keywords: ['Football', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Sports Injuries', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Sunday was a bad day for Fantex, the fledgling company promoting initial public offerings of National Football League stars, as its first two prospects were sidelined.
lead_paragraph: Sunday was a bad day for Fantex, the fledgling company promoting initial public offerings of National Football League stars.

headline: Determining the Victims of Insider Trading
abstract: The Justice Department’s prosecution of SAC Capital Advisors raises the question of who the victims of a violation are.
lead_paragraph: The guilty plea hearing last week in the Justice Department’s prosecution of SAC Capital Advisors raised an interesting question about the law of insider trading: Just who are the victims of a violation? A provision of the federal securities laws gives those who traded at the same time as the insider a right to sue for a violation, but the Justice Department said they are not victims of the crime.

headline: Giving Foreign Clients a Piece of New York’s Luxury Real Estate
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Gennady Perepada, who prefers the term international real estate consultant, makes it his job not just to find his clients apartments but also to bend New York to their will.
lead_paragraph: It takes a certain kind of person to regard luxury real estate in New York as cheap, maybe even embarrassingly cheap when compared with other global capitals. If such people hail from the former Soviet Union, and want to add a Manhattan address to a portfolio that might already include homes in London or Dubai or St. Tropez, they might seek out a real estate agent who appreciates their unusual perspective. They might seek out Gennady Perepada.

headline: Notes From a Storm-Wrecked Land
keywords: ['Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Social Media']
abstract: Closing windows and reassuring loved ones in other countries.
lead_paragraph: QUEZON CITY, Philippines — ON Wednesday, two days before Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, I assigned the short story “Fredo Avila,” by Gina Apostol, to my introduction to literature class at Ateneo de Manila University. It’s set in the writer’s hometown, Barugo, in the eastern province of Leyte.

headline: Adding Pounds, Then New Knees
abstract: New figures strongly suggest that obesity is the most likely reason for the rise of knee replacement surgeries in younger patients.
lead_paragraph: In his mid-forties, Charles Carroll, a letter carrier in Shrewsbury, Mass., started taking anti-inflammatory medicine for his achy knees. Despite his young age, osteoarthritis had begun to settle in.

headline: Obama Speaks on Veterans Day
abstract: The president delivers remarks at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The president delivers remarks at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.

headline: Choosing to Chew Gum
abstract: Chewing sugarless gum after a meal can help prevent tooth decay, the American Dental Association has said.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is chewing gum bad for you?

headline: Gliders in the Ocean Deep, Autism in an Infant’s Gaze, Martin Cruz Smith’s Life With Parkinson’s
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health', "Parkinson's Disease", 'Oceans and Seas', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Autism']
abstract: Autonomous robots take to the seas to investigate currents, fish and climate change; a new study uses eye-tracking techniques on infants to look for early signs of autism; the author of “Gorky Park” talks about living with a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease for the last 18 years.
lead_paragraph: Autonomous robots take to the seas to investigate currents, fish and climate change; a new study uses eye-tracking techniques on infants to look for early signs of autism; the author of “Gorky Park” talks about living with a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease for the last 18 years.

headline: Getting Less Touchy on Windows 8, and Adjusting the iOS Mail App
abstract: Turning off Windows 8 multitouch gestures and turning off unused mailboxes in iOS 7’s mail app.
lead_paragraph: Less Touchy

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Gay Talese and Juliette Lewis
abstract: The legendary journalist and the Oscar-nominated actress take on Saint Laurent roller skates, Sylvester Stallone as an artist and more.
lead_paragraph: The legendary journalist and the Oscar-nominated actress take on Saint Laurent roller skates, Sylvester Stallone as an artist and more.

headline: Martin Cruz Smith Reveals a Twist in His Tale
abstract: Deep brain stimulation therapy has offered hope to Martin Cruz Smith, the acclaimed author of taut thrillers like “Gorky Park,” who hid his diagnosis of Parkinson’s for years, fearing judgment and pity.
lead_paragraph: It is probably no accident that the pivotal object in Martin Cruz Smith’s newest detective thriller, “Tatiana,” is a notebook nobody can read.

headline: How to Help Philippines Typhoon Victims
abstract: A list of contact information for some organizations that plan to provide relief to victims of the typhoon in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Tuesday, 5:44 p.m. | As the full scale of the devastation wrought across the islands of the Philippines over the weekend by Typhoon Haiyan came into fuller view on Monday, governments around the world have pledged aid to the victims. The Pentagon has dispatched an advance team of 90 marines and sailors, and U.S.A.I.D. has pledged emergency shelter and hygiene materials and 55 tons of food. The American Embassy in Manila has donated $100,000 for water and sanitation assistance.

headline: BlackBerry’s Turnaround Starts All Thumbs
abstract: The big questions are about John Chen holding the top two jobs at the troubled smartphone maker and his commuting from California.
lead_paragraph: BlackBerry’s turnaround is starting out all thumbs. The $85 million worth of stock handed to the company’s new boss, John Chen, over five years at least provides the right incentives. But the struggling Canadian company surely needs more attention than one man doing both top jobs, especially if he’s commuting from California.

headline: Single Tooth Tells of Long-Extinct Platypus
abstract: Scientists have identified an ancient species of platypus, its diet and habitat, all from the discovery of a single fossil tooth.
lead_paragraph: Based on the discovery of a single tooth, researchers say they have identified an ancient species of giant platypus. The finding provides new clues about the lineage of the modern platypus. “The fossil record is very, very patchy for the platypus, and these are a unique group of mammals,” said the lead researcher, Rebecca Pian, a vertebrate paleontologist at Columbia University and the American Museum of Natural History. Unlike most mammals, they lay eggs instead of giving birth to live offspring; their snouts are covered with electroreceptors that can detect underwater prey; and the male has a venomous spur on its hind feet.

headline: When One Kitchen Isn’t Enough
abstract: For big-name chefs tending to culinary empires large and small, the urge (and often pressure) to expand from a single, signature restaurant can be irresistible.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When Tony Maws designed the open kitchen at Craigie on Main, the celebrated restaurant he opened here five years ago, he positioned his workstation to serve as a kind of welcome mat.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Gay Talese and Juliette Lewis
abstract: The legendary journalist and the Oscar-nominated actress opine on Saint Laurent roller skates, Sylvester Stallone as an artist, the rapper Iggy Azalea and more.
lead_paragraph: The legendary journalist, known for his expertise in crafting the celebrity profile, and the Oscar-nominated actress, who will star alongside Meryl Streep and Julia Roberts in the forthcoming film adaptation of Tracy Letts’s Pulitzer-winning play, “August: Osage County,” take on Iggy Azalea, a feather-tipped ballpoint pen, high-top roller skates and more.

headline: A Winter Innovation: The Airport Coat Check
keywords: ['AIRPORTS', 'Business Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Coats', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: With cabin storage at a premium in crammed airplanes, Frankfurt Airport in Germany has responded with winter-coat service for passengers.
lead_paragraph: IT’S getting cold in the Northern Hemisphere, and that means we are about to enter the Winter Campaign in the overhead bin wars.

headline: In Hookups, Inequality Still Reigns
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Medicine and Health', 'Sex', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Even as young women are becoming equal partners in the hookup culture, they are less likely to experience orgasm during uncommitted encounters than in serious relationships, studies show.
lead_paragraph: Natasha Gadinsky, 23, says she doesn’t have any regrets from her years in college. But the time she hooked up with a guy at Brown University does come close.

headline: Tracking the World’s Biggest E-Commerce Event
abstract: Chinese consumers were expected to spend more than $5 billion Monday for Singles’ Day, which is considered the world’s biggest e-commerce event.
lead_paragraph: Chinese consumers were expected to spend more than $5 billion Monday for Singles’ Day, which is considered the world’s biggest e-commerce event.

headline: The Old-Fashioned, in Song and Dance
abstract: The song “I’m Old Fashioned” wasn’t about the cocktail, but it’s a standard worth revisiting (and a good excuse to marvel at Fred Astaire’s singing voice).
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:15 p.m. | My Drink column this month was partially inspired by the song “I’m Old Fashioned,” by Jerome Kern and Johnny Mercer. It debuted in the 1942 romantic comedy “You Were Never Lovelier,” in a total charmer of a song-and-dance routine.

headline: After Near Miss on Iran, Kerry Says Diplomacy Is Still the Right Path
abstract: As the prospect of a nuclear deal with Iran becomes more real, Secretary of State John Kerry is having to fend off those who want to pre-empt it — like Israel and Iran hawks in Congress.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Secretary of State John Kerry came up a few disputed words short of closing a landmark nuclear deal with Iran on Sunday in Geneva. Now he is defending the diplomacy that led to that near miss against a rising chorus of critics at home and abroad.

headline: Tidying Up Your Financial Life
abstract: Three steps can help people wrangle the chaos of their finances into something far more manageable.
lead_paragraph: From buying a home to paying for college, our financial decisions seem more complex, and it often seems as if things are far beyond our control. It leads to a feeling of anxiety. Plus, we’re so busy making money, trying to make ends meet, that it seems all but impossible to manage it in any meaningful way. Who has the time to track a monthly budget?

headline: A ‘Bully’ Defying the Bullies of His Era
abstract: In “Bully Pulpit,” Doris Kearns Goodwin examines Theodore Roosevelt’s friendship-turned-rivalry with William Howard Taft and his way of harnessing the press to challenge monopolies and advance his vision.
lead_paragraph: The interplay between personality and politics, temperament and leadership is one of the key themes animating Doris Kearns Goodwin’s telling books about Abraham Lincoln (“Team of Rivals”), Franklin D. Roosevelt (“No Ordinary Time”) and Lyndon B. Johnson (“Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream”). The same is true of her sprawling new book, “The Bully Pulpit,” which gives us revealing portraits of Theodore Roosevelt and his close friend, handpicked successor and eventual bitter rival, William Howard Taft.

headline: The Read Around: Jesmyn Ward
abstract: Ms. Ward discusses her memoir, “Men We Reaped.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a new weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Jesmyn Ward talks about her memoir, “Men We Reaped,” and the challenge of writing about people she has known and loved.

headline: No Need to Fumble for Reading Glasses
abstract: Snakes can optimize their vision by controlling the blood flow in their eyes when they perceive threats.
lead_paragraph: Snakes can optimize their vision by controlling the blood flow in their eyes when they perceive threats, a new study from the University of Waterloo shows. Kevin van Doorn and Jacob Sivak of the university’s science faculty discovered that the visual blood flow patterns of the coachwhip snake changed depending on its surroundings. And instead of eyelids, snakes have clear scales called spectacles, which work like windows, covering and protecting their eyes. The findings were published in the latest issue of The Journal of Experimental Biology.

headline: Acquitted Israeli Politician Returns to Job as Foreign Minister
abstract: Avigdor Lieberman had long been dogged by corruption charges and accusations that some of his actions were undiplomatic.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Avigdor Lieberman, the powerful Israeli nationalist politician whose blunt talk has often stirred outrage at home and abroad, was reinstated on Monday as the country’s foreign minister. Mr. Lieberman, who was acquitted last week of corruption charges that had dogged him for more than a decade, was back at the diplomatic helm on Monday night after a stormy debate in Parliament and a vote confirming his reappointment.

headline: Exploring the Ocean
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Research', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Underwater drones are changing the way scientists study the sea.
lead_paragraph: Underwater drones are changing the way scientists study the sea.

headline: Ocean Drones Plumb New Depths
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Research', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Weather', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Research teams are deploying data-gathering gliders to study the Atlantic’s many mysterious underwater movements.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — Five miles offshore from the Golden Nugget casino, Michael F. Crowley, a marine scientist at Rutgers University, heaves three lifeboat-yellow drones off the back of his research vessel.

headline: The Rush to Coin Virtual Money With Real Value
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Bitcoin’s emergence has brought a field of competitors. One payment system, Ripple, serves as a platform for currencies both digital and real.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:46 p.m. | If cash is king, virtual cash may be the crown prince in waiting.

headline: Long-Term Benefits of Music Lessons
abstract: A new study reports that older adults who took lessons at a young age can process the sounds of speech faster than those who did not.
lead_paragraph: Childhood music lessons can sometimes leave painful memories, but they seem to carry benefits into adulthood. A new study reports that older adults who took lessons at a young age can process the sounds of speech faster than those who did not.

headline: Science Bookshelf
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Top-selling nonfiction titles based on the sciences.
lead_paragraph: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.”

headline: Not Quite Laverne and Shirley
abstract: “The Mutilated,” a rarely seen Tennessee Williams comedy, is being boisterously revived in a production starring the quirky team of Penny Arcade and Mink Stole.
lead_paragraph: Celeste Delacroix Griffin is having a lousy day. True, she’s been sprung from the slammer just in time for Christmas Eve, after that little shoplifting incident. But it’s been a quick roll downhill from there for this seedy vagabond from “The Mutilated,” a rarely seen Tennessee Williams comedy being boisterously revived at the New Ohio Theater in a production starring the quirky team of Penny Arcade and Mink Stole.

headline: Fifth Avenue, 11:38 A.M.
abstract: Veterans lined Fifth Avenue for the Veteran’s Day parade.

headline: In College Admissions, Social Media Can Be a Double-Edged Sword
abstract: As more colleges find and judge applicants’ social media posts, parents wonder whether their high-school-aged children should censor their online activities during the admissions process.
lead_paragraph: When I wrote my Technophoria column this weekend about how some college admissions officers have occasionally identified social media posts that negatively affected applicants’ chances of acceptance, I assumed the phenomenon would not come as news to the parents of high school students.

headline: No Health Insurance? Just Drink.
abstract: Generation Opportunity hosted a tailgate party to dissuade students from signing up for insurance through an exchange.
lead_paragraph: This is the strangest P.R. campaign yet against the Affordable Care Act. Generation Opportunity, the Koch-funded group behind the Creepy Uncle Sam ads, is throwing tailgate parties to “educate” young people about the exchanges. Read: To convince young people to forgo health insurance.

headline: Walkabout: Garbage Piling Up in Madrid; Easing Travel for Passengers with Disabilities
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: A Mess in Madrid Travelers to Madrid may want to pack a pair of thigh-high boots: a strike by city sanitation workers has entered its seventh day, leading to some nasty trash pileups. (Bloomberg)

headline: When Healers Get Too Friendly
abstract: Doctors are warned not to get too close to patients, but it can be hard to restrain from helping in what may seem small ways but can have large repercussions.
lead_paragraph: It takes only a moment to step over the line, especially when no one knows exactly where the line is. In my case, it started with a visit from my old friend the activist.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Philippines, Virginia, France and Serbia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Philippines, Virginia, France and Serbia.

headline: A Marathoner’s Many Hurdles
abstract: Idrissa Kargbo of Sierra Leone has an audacious goal of becoming an elite marathoner, though he has more than a few obstacles to overcome.
lead_paragraph: Idrissa Kargbo, a coffee deliverer from Sierra Leone, dreams of becoming one of the best runners in the world. It is an audacious goal.

headline: An Accidental Cattle Ranch Points the Way in Sustainable Farming
abstract: The TomKat Ranch sells grass-fed beef, but it began as a way to try to get carbon back into the soil.
lead_paragraph: PESCADERO, Calif. — When Tom Steyer first learned that his wife, Kat Taylor, wanted to sell beef from the cattle herd on their ranch here, he rolled his eyes.

headline: Quinoa Hush Puppies: A Healthful Twist on a Southern Staple
abstract: Market Table’s version of hush puppies, with a side of spicy aioli, makes a perfect nosh.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: A New Political Party Aims to Save Socialism, and the Constitution, in China
abstract: Wang Zheng has chosen Bo Xilai, the fallen politician who is now serving a life sentence for corruption and abuse of power, as the party’s chairman.
lead_paragraph: “A lot of people have been applying to join. I can’t keep up with the applications,” said Wang Zheng, a scholar who on Nov. 6 did something unusual. She announced the establishment of a new political party in China, where the Communist Party holds all power and tolerates no opposition outside of it.

headline: East and West, Mingling in One Man’s Body
abstract: Akram Khan brought his solo “Desh” to the White Light Festival last week.
lead_paragraph: As a child in London, enthralled by Michael Jackson, Akram Khan wasn’t as interested in his Bangladeshi heritage as his parents might have liked. But he was serious about one thing: dance. After mastering the classical Indian form Kathak, he went to college and mastered Western contemporary forms. Inside his body, the collision of these ways of moving made him move in a way that was thrilling to behold. It was also a timely metaphor for second-generation immigrant identity and multiculturalism. Mr. Khan danced with astonishing speed, and his fame and the scale of his productions grew apace.

headline: Boardrooms Rethink Tactics to Defang Activist Investors
abstract: After trying to ignore shareholder activism, companies are realizing that preparation and engagement can bring better results.
lead_paragraph: Executives and board members used to fear hostile bids above all else. In response, they devised defense mechanisms like poison pills and staggered boards to thwart attacks.

headline: Early Beatles on the BBC, Bantering and Bluesy
abstract: A new collection of recordings on British radio, “On Air — Live at the BBC Volume 2,” filled with chat and covers of American songs, shows what made the band tick.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1971, one of the first Beatles bootlegs turned up, packaged in a white sleeve with “The Beatles — Yellow Matter Custard — Previously Unreleased Studio Material” rubber-stamped across it. It offered an odd lineup of tracks (performances of Ray Charles’s “I Got a Woman”; Buddy Holly’s “Crying, Waiting, Hoping”; Carl Perkins’s “Sure to Fall (in Love With You)”; Arthur Alexander’s “Shot of Rhythm and Blues”), 14 in all, in decent, if slightly tinny, quality.

headline: Plan to Finance Philanthropy Shows the Power of a Simple Question
abstract: Several ideas about using financial instruments and a for-profit approach in the world of nonprofits are now taking hold.
lead_paragraph: What if?

headline: Marty Ehrlich and Luscious Jackson Have New Albums
abstract: The jazzman Marty Ehrlich leads a large ensemble on “A Trumpet in the Morning,” and with “Magic Hour,” Luscious Jackson has its first album in 14 years.
lead_paragraph: LUSCIOUS JACKSON

headline: Honoring Female Pioneers in Science
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Science and Technology', 'Mathematics', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: An exhibition offers little-known details on extraordinary women like Florence Nightingale, Hertha Ayrton and Sophie Kowalevski.
lead_paragraph: Florence Nightingale, a statistician? Marie Curie, driving to the front during World War I to X-ray wounded soldiers?

headline: Colbert Recites the Gettysburg Address
abstract: Stephen Colbert is among the celebrities who are encouraging Americans to memorize Lincoln's famous speech.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert is among the celebrities who are encouraging Americans to memorize Lincoln's famous speech.

headline: Three Days of Dancing, Starring D.J.s
abstract: A range of Williamsburg venues were part of the sixth Brooklyn Electronic Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Dance music has its hegemonies, its mainstream history, but in the last few years especially, mutation has complicated and diversified that narrative. Now in its sixth year, the Brooklyn Electronic Music Festival has been an incubator for these styles, often capturing rising D.J.s and producers before they make wide impact.

headline: Surveillance Leaves Writers Wary
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A survey by the writers’ organization PEN American Center has found that a large majority of its members are deeply concerned about the extent of government surveillance of email and phone records.
lead_paragraph: A survey by the writers’ organization PEN American Center has found that a large majority of its members are deeply concerned about recent revelations regarding the extent of government surveillance of email and phone records, with more than a quarter saying that they have avoided, or are seriously considering avoiding, controversial topics in their work.

headline: The Quiet Before the Shots
abstract: An ambitious program at Symphony Space on Friday looked at the day before John F. Kennedy’s assassination.
lead_paragraph: Next to birthdays of prominent public figures, nothing engenders mass reflection and artistic endeavor as readily as big, round anniversaries of historical milestones. We’re just 10 days away from one such date: Nov. 22, the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination in Dallas, which after half a century continues to take a dramatic toll on the collective American psyche.

headline: The Gettysburg Address, as Recited by Colbert and You
abstract: The filmmaker Ken Burns is starting a web project to encourage Americans to recite the Gettysburg Address.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Ken Burns has found one way to bring together Republicans and Democrats in this politically divided time: Ask them to recite the Gettysburg Address, which Abraham Lincoln delivered on Nov. 19, 1863, at the dedication of the cemetery at the Civil War battlefield. The website Learn the Address features videos of notable names reciting the speech, including all the living American presidents and dozens of celebrities like Taylor Swift, Usher, Steven Spielberg, Uma Thurman, Shane Victorino and Bill O’Reilly. Other well-known reciters include Stephen Colbert and Gabrielle Giffords.

headline: Estonian Master, Through Lens of Compatriots
abstract: Arvo Pärt’s mystical luminosity was paired with Sibelius and Mozart at the White Light Festival on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: If any artist is emblematic of the spirit manifest in Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival, it might be Arvo Pärt. An Estonian composer based in Berlin for much of his career, Mr. Pärt achieved wide renown in the mid-1980s through a series of recordings on the German label ECM. His rise to prominence was also abetted by the conductor Neeme Järvi, a countryman whose continued advocacy was evident in a festival concert by the Estonian National Symphony Orchestra and the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening.

headline: Watch Out for Falling Space Junk and Asteroids
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: India hopes to join the exclusive Mars club, and a newly discovered dinosaur from the T. rex family.
lead_paragraph: Fiery chunks of a European satellite fell from the sky, the latest in a parade of what scientists worryingly call “uncontrolled entries.” And new research showed that asteroids like the one that exploded over Russia in February will probably hit Earth more often than previously expected. All in all, not a bad week to begin a long journey to Mars.

headline: The Universe’s End
abstract: Letter to the editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 8-10, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A Texas company has made the world’s first metal gun using a 3D printer. The fully functioning, semi-automatic .45-caliber pistol made by Austin-based Solid Concepts is modeled on on the Browning 1911 firearm. It’s been safely fired 50 times, and as for accuracy, the gun was able to strike a target bull’s-eye at more than 30 yards.

headline: Two Weeks That Kindle Hope
abstract: American Ballet Theater closed its fall season on Sunday; now it remains to be seen which dancers will make advances in the spring season.
lead_paragraph: No ballet ensemble has a soul more divided than that of American Ballet Theater. Some people think it’s one of the world’s greatest companies; others think it’s not really a company at all. Both arguments make sense, and they largely correspond to which side of Lincoln Center Plaza the troupe is playing.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Eyes Sixth Title
abstract: Jimmie Johnson bolsters his Nascar Sprint Cup series points lead, and Marc Márquez becomes the youngest rider to win a MotoGP title.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Harvick won the battle, but Jimmie Johnson may have won the war on Sunday in Nascar’s Sprint Cup Series race at Phoenix International Raceway. On the white flag lap, Harvick passed the leader, Carl Edwards, who was running out of fuel, and then held on for the final lap to take the checkered flag. Kasey Kahne came in second. Johnson was third, earning a decisive number of points in the quest for his sixth Sprint Cup season title.

headline: From the Philippines to Haiti, Disaster Recovery is a Way of Life
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Earthquakes', 'Floods', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'MANILA (PHILIPPINES)', 'Population', 'Poverty', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis', 'Typhoon Bopha (2012)', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Typhoons']
abstract: From the Philippines to Haiti, recovering from disasters becomes the norm, not the exception.
lead_paragraph: For many millions of people living in the planet’s poorest, most populous places, a state of recovery from what used to be called “natural” disasters has become the norm, not some exceptional circumstance. The central Philippines, now reeling from the impact of Typhoon Haiyan, a super storm if ever there was one, are just the latest place in which huge human losses follow a disaster that, in a rich country, would almost assuredly mainly exact a financial toll. See Keith Bradsher’s wrenching reports here and here for details on the damage. And the immediate search and rescue efforts are just a warmup for years of relocation, recovery and rebuilding.

headline: Supper Club to Reopen With ‘Carnal’ Take on ‘Magic Flute’
abstract: “Queen of the Night” will relaunch the Diamond Horseshoe in the basement of the Paramount Hotel.
lead_paragraph: A famed theater-district supper club will reopen on New Year’s Eve with a high-tech “carnal” reimagining of “The Magic Flute” that aims to blur the lines between the audience and the performers. “Queen of the Night” is created by Randy Weiner, a founder of The Box burlesque space on the Lower East Side and a producer of the smash success “Sleep No More” downtown. Like “The Donkey Show,” the disco adaptation of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” that Mr. Weiner created with his wife, Diane Paulus, in 1999, “Queen of the Night” puts the audience into the middle of a reconfigured classic theater piece – in this case Mozart’s opera.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
abstract: The Renaissance wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosities — a personal collection of fabulous, rare, sometimes grotesque relics — inspires tableaus of the season’s most opulent baubles and fanciful curios.

headline: Germany to Form Task Force on Looted Art
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: German authorities are reacting to calls to release information quickly about paintings, many looted, that were discovered in Munich.
lead_paragraph: After an avalanche of criticism at home and abroad, the German government announced late Monday it will establish a task force to investigate, “as quickly and as transparently as possible,” the provenance of a cache of more than 1,400 artworks that are suspected of being traded or looted during the Nazis’ reign and that are now in the hands of authorities in Bavaria.

headline: The Only Certainty Is That He Won’t Show Up
abstract: Of all the existential questions raised by Samuel Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot,” one that persists is the correct pronunciation of the name.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Godot never appears because everyone is mispronouncing his name.

headline: Welcome, in Mandarin
abstract: Spending abroad by Chinese travelers is growing, reaching $102 billion last year. Hoteliers have responded with customized service and perks.
lead_paragraph: Mandarin television channels. Congee rice porridges. Smoking rooms.

headline: He Struts, but His Comb Is Trembling
abstract: “Year of the Rooster,” a play about cockfighting at the Ensemble Studio Theater, gives a rooster a complex interior life.
lead_paragraph: “Year of the Rooster” at the Ensemble Studio Theater isn’t merely entertaining. It’s astonishingly entertaining, partly because the playwright, Eric Dufault, is only in his mid-20s and partly because who would have thought that a barnyard bird could make such an intriguing stage character?

headline: Art Matters | Bruce Weber on the Intimacy of Portraiture
abstract: How do you take a picture of someone that tells a meaningful story? The legendary image maker shares his philosophy.
lead_paragraph: As Bruce Weber releases a new installment of his ‘All-American’ photo anthology and a box set of his films, he reflects on the intimacy of taking pictures.

headline: In Music Piracy Battles, Lyrics Demand Respect Too
abstract: A new push by the National Music Publishers Association will challenge websites that publish lyrics without licenses.
lead_paragraph: When the forces of the music industry go after websites for using copyrighted content without permission, that content tends to come in the form of MP3 files or YouTube videos.

headline: Lennon’s School Detention Sheets Head to Auction
abstract: Detention papers from John Lennon’s school days are set to be auctioned.
lead_paragraph: John Lennon always described himself as a cut-up during his school years, an authority-baiting revolutionary in the making. But even keeping in mind the wisecracking assertiveness he cultivated during the Beatles years, and beyond, you always suspected that he was exaggerating.

headline: Crystal Bridges Museum Conducts Ambitious Survey of Contemporary American Art
abstract: Curators from the Crystal Bridges Museum in Arkansas are scouring the country for a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art.
lead_paragraph: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the institution founded in Bentonville, Ark., by Alice L. Walton, the Walmart heiress, is only two years old. But it has embarked on a mission that even more established museums might fear to take on: a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art, formed by visits to hundreds of artists’ studios, large and small, successful and almost unheard-of, across the country.

headline: For an Upgrade, Skip the Vegetarian Meal
abstract: Rachel Shelasky is the president and founder of Hollywood Fourth, a promotional apparel company.
lead_paragraph: I’M an entrepreneur in the promotional clothing and products business. That entrepreneurial spirit is in my blood.

headline: Art Survey Planned
abstract: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art is planning a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art.
lead_paragraph: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the institution founded in Bentonville, Ark., by Alice L. Walton, the Wal-Mart heiress, is only two years old. But it has decided to set out on a mission even more established museums might fear: a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art, formed by visits to hundreds of artists’ studios across the country. The resulting show, “State of the Art,” will bring together the work of 100 artists for a show that will open on  Sept. 13 and continue through  Jan. 5, 2015. For the last several months, the museum’s president, Don Bacigalupi, and an assistant curator for special projects, Chad Alligood, have been traveling by plane and car to almost every part of the country, relying on an initial list of 10,000 artists, to find works they will include in the show. They have visited more than 400 studios and artists so far, in dozens of cities, but also in rural places so small that the roads to them have not shown up on the curators’ GPS devices. “We’ve come to recognize that many extraordinary artists may be known in their own locales, but have yet to emerge on the national stage,” Mr. Alligood said. “Their work, however, deserves consideration from a national audience.” “State of the Art” could be seen as a traditionalist alternative to a show like the Whitney Biennial, but there are currently no plans to make it a recurring event.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Messaging Apps Threaten Facebook, and $4 Toast
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the Web include an argument for why the tech industry is to blame for overpriced toast. Plus, examining the popularity of messaging apps like WhatsApp, which are attracting Facebook’s users.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: ‘Godot’ Variations
abstract: A look at different interpretations of Samuel Beckett’s play.
lead_paragraph: A look at different interpretations of Samuel Beckett’s play.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Subtweets Kerry
abstract: After Secretary of State John Kerry insisted that it was unfair to blame his French counterpart for scuttling a deal on the Iranian nuclear program, Iran’s chief negotiator, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, pushed back on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Mark Landler reports, Secretary of State John Kerry insisted on Monday that it was unfair to blame last-minute objections from his French counterpart, Laurent Fabius, for scuttling a potential deal with Iran over its nuclear energy program last weekend in Geneva. “The French signed off on it, we signed off on it,” Mr. Kerry said of the final proposal presented to Iran’s negotiating team. “There was unity, but Iran couldn’t take it.”

headline: Sounds That Fly on Digital Wings
abstract: On Thursday evening, the Miller Theater presented a composer portrait of Rand Steiger that showed how viscerally affecting computer-processed music can be.
lead_paragraph: Spatial music has been around for over 400 years, with composers from Gabrieli to Stockhausen exploiting the acoustic effect that results from separating performers in space. Technological advances of recent decades have made it possible to move sound about a room — and even enhance, distort or multiply it as it travels about — while keeping the musician rooted in place.
