headline: Maneuvering Begins as Three Yankees Rebuff Offers
abstract: The fates of Curtis Granderson, Hiroki Kuroda and Robinson Cano are uncertain after all three turned down initial offers from the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: In an off-season filled with uncertainty, the Yankees passed the first phase with no surprises as three players turned down qualifying offers from the team. The Yankees had made the offers — set by Major League Baseball at $14.1 million — to Robinson Cano, Curtis Granderson and Hiroki Kuroda.

headline: Silent Sentinels at Center of Lithuanian Debate on Bygone Era
abstract: In the capital, Vilnius, statues that trumpet Communism, an ideology rejected by Lithuania more than two decades ago, have drawn anger, but some see a value in preserving them.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Watching over one of this city’s busiest thoroughfares are the sentinels of a loathed regime.

headline: For de Blasio, Contract Talks Offer Problem
abstract: New York’s next mayor, Bill de Blasio, is considered a friend of labor, but a looming deficit means he won’t be able to be as friendly as municipal unions might like.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has promised all sorts of assistance to ease Bill de Blasio’s transition, but the mayor has nonetheless bequeathed one particularly thorny, potentially explosive issue to his successor: New York City’s 300,000 municipal workers are angry that their contracts expired years ago, and they are demanding more than $7 billion in retroactive pay to make up for their years without a regular raise.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Montréal, Quebec; Pennsylvania; Madrid
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Salon des Métiers d’Art de Montréal, Quebec More than 400 regional artisans will gather at Place Bonaventure in Montreal from Dec. 6 to 22 to display their latest creations. Established in 1955, the event is described by its organizers as “the most important annual professional crafts exhibition in Canada.” Jewelry, musical instruments, games, toys, kitchen utensils, office accessories and other utilitarian and decorative objects (above) are among the original crafts for sale.

headline: Etsy’s Industrial Revolution
abstract: Almost nothing has been truly handmade for thousands of years.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — HAND-KNIT sweaters? Hand-thrown pots? How about quilts stitched on a sewing machine? In an age when artisanal items can be sold at a premium, what products should qualify as “handmade”?

headline: Ex-Mob Boss Gotti Stabbed on Long Island
abstract: John A. Gotti, who once led the Gambino organized crime family, is believed to have been wounded in a pharmacy parking lot in Syosset, but he was not cooperating with investigators.
lead_paragraph: John A. Gotti, the former boss of the Gambino crime family, was stabbed in the stomach over the weekend in Syosset, N.Y., the authorities said on Monday.

headline: The Extra Legroom Society
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Health Clubs']
abstract: It’s not just airplanes. Increasingly, America is a land with precise microclimates of exclusivity.
lead_paragraph: For our time off together around Christmas, my siblings, their children and I recently began plotting an excursion to the Six Flags amusement park in the Los Angeles area. The discussion turned quickly from roller coasters to perks. To status. To just how high we’re prepared to fly in this service-obsessed, luxury-laden, class-fractured era of ours.

headline: Saudi Arabia: MERS Virus Found in Patient’s Pet Camel
abstract: The discovery of the virus that causes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in a camel belonging to a recent human victim adds credence to the theory that the virus originates in bats but can reach humans through camels.
lead_paragraph: The virus that causes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome — an often-lethal lung disease related to SARS — has been found in a pet camel belonging to a recent human victim, Saudi Arabia’s Health Ministry announced Monday. The discovery adds credence to the prevailing theory that the virus originates in bats but usually reaches humans through camels. In three earlier clusters of MERS cases, the first patient to fall ill in each was reported to have had contact with a sick camel. Although antibodies to the disease had been found in camels before, the virus itself had not. Genetic tests will be done, the ministry said, to see if the camel’s strain is identical to that found in the patient, a 43-year-old man in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, who is still hospitalized. MERS has killed 64 people since it was first isolated a year ago, 53 of them in Saudi Arabia. It can also spread from human to human, but seems to do so less readily than SARS — severe acute respiratory syndrome — did.

headline: Skeptics See Euro Eroding European Unity
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'Recession and Depression', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: As economic troubles drag on, critics say the currency is doing more harm than good to the dream of a unified Europe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s slow emergence from its second recession in the last five years is raising new questions about whether the euro currency is doing more harm than good.

headline: City’s Plan to Relocate 2 Agencies Stirs Anger
abstract: Residents and businesses say their neighborhood shouldn’t have to absorb the disruptions of people going to the Probation Department and summons court.
lead_paragraph: The city official attempted a half smile as the baby was held before him, her tiny feet dangling in little pink striped socks. But her mother was in no mood for niceties.

headline: Russia: Four Are Sentenced for Airport Attack
abstract: A Moscow court on Monday sentenced three men to life in prison and a fourth man to 10 years for their role in the 2011 suicide bombing at the Domodedovo airport.
lead_paragraph: The Moscow Regional Court sentenced three men on Monday to life in prison for their role in the 2011 suicide bombing at the Domodedovo airport in Moscow that killed 37 people and wounded 172, the court said. The men, Bashir Khamkhoyev and the brothers Islam and Ilez Yandiyev, were convicted of providing explosive materials to the bomber, Magomed Yevloyev, 20, and for organizing his stay in Moscow before the January attack. A fourth man, Akhmed Yevloyev, the bomber’s brother, was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Doku Umarov, the leader of an Islamist terrorist group carrying out an insurgency in the country’s North Caucasus region, later claimed responsibility for the bombing. Mr. Umarov, who remains a fugitive, has since called on his followers to disrupt the 2014 Winter Olympics, which Russia will host in Sochi, a resort city on the edge of the turbulent region.

headline: Problems With Federal Health Portal Also Stymie Medicaid Enrollment
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Tens of thousands of low-income people have been prevented from signing up for Medicaid even though they are eligible, federal and state officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Problems with the federal health insurance website have prevented tens of thousands of low-income people from signing up for Medicaid even though they are eligible, federal and state officials say, undermining one of the chief goals of the 2010 health care law.

headline: Boycotting Israeli Universities, Part Two
abstract: The rightness or wrongness of an action has nothing to do with the moral status of the actor who performs it.
lead_paragraph: The responses to my column on the call by some academics to boycott Israeli universities in the name of academic freedom were impassioned and polarized. I was pleased to find more readers than usual on my side, but one argument favored by those who agreed with my negative view of the boycott is, I think, beside the point. That is the argument that the boycott is wrong because it is selective, because it singles out Israel when there are so many other countries in the world whose policies and actions are just as bad or worse. Actually, this is not an argument; it is a debating point (as some who offer it know): it is a form of reductio ad absurdum, the rhetorical trick of extending an opponent’s claim until it yields an absurd result, in this case the absurd result that follows if we are required to break off relations with universities housed in nations whose human rights record we find questionable: on this reasoning, we would have to break off relationships with everyone and there would be no academic exchange at all.

headline: An Author Reveals a Twist in His Tale
abstract: Martin Cruz Smith, author of thrillers like “Gorky Park,” recently revealed his diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease, which he hid for years.
lead_paragraph: Martin Cruz Smith, author of thrillers like “Gorky Park,” recently revealed his diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease, which he hid for years.

headline: Russia: Greenpeace Detainees Are Transferred
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: Russia’s prison authorities began transferring 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship from Murmansk to St. Petersburg on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s prison authorities began transferring 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship from Murmansk to St. Petersburg on Monday, nearly two months after they were arrested following a protest at an offshore oil rig in the Arctic. The move came a day after Foreign Minister Frans Timmermans of the Netherlands, where the ship is registered, expressed hope for a diplomatic resolution to the case but indicated that it could still be weeks away. Russia’s investigative committee explained the transfers by saying that the courts in Murmansk did not have jurisdiction over the hooliganism charges the 30 face and that the investigating body in charge of the case was in St. Petersburg. The Netherlands has appealed to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea for the release of the crew and the ship. The court’s decision is scheduled for Nov. 22, but Russia has said it would not accept its jurisdiction in this case.

headline: New York Looks to Cut Emissions by Private Trash Haulers
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Air Pollution', 'Fuel Efficiency']
abstract: About 8,300 private collection trucks would have to meet   federal emissions standards by 2020, three years after the deadline for the city’s fleet, under the plan.
lead_paragraph: As aging garbage trucks rumble down the streets of New York, their fumes draw protests from residents and environmental advocates and raise concerns about asthma and other health effects.

headline: Why Do Female Chefs Get Overlooked?
abstract: Why do female chefs rarely win the adulation and recognition of male chefs?

headline: Michelle Obama Edges Into a Policy Role on Higher Education
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education (K-12)', 'First Ladies (US)', 'Community Colleges']
abstract: The first lady, after years of evangelizing exercise and good eating habits, will begin an initiative on Tuesday that seeks to increase the number of low-income students who attend college.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama, after nearly five years of evangelizing exercise and good eating habits, will begin a new initiative on Tuesday that seeks to increase the number of low-income students who pursue a college degree. The goals of the program reflect the first lady’s own life and will immerse her more directly in her husband’s policies.

headline: In Challenge, Former Rebels in Libya Form Own Oil Company
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The rebels’ establishment of a regional oil company to sell crude from oil fields and port terminals they occupy was seen as a symbolic move, but it was another escalation of tensions.
lead_paragraph: Former rebels who fought the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and are now challenging Libya’s shaky central government have announced the creation of their own oil company to sell crude from oil fields and port terminals they currently occupy.

headline: List of 25 Artworks Seized in Germany Released
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: A partial list of artwork that was lost since World War II and seized in Munich was posted on a German website.
lead_paragraph: The German authorities early Tuesday released a list of 25 of the 1,400 or so works of art the authorities confiscated from a Munich apartment said to be that of the son of a dealer who had been hired to acquire artworks for the Nazis during World War II.

headline: Lawyer for Ukraine Opposition Leader Is Questioned
abstract: The chief defense lawyer for the imprisoned opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko was questioned on suspicion that he had beaten his former wife.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Ukraine on Monday questioned the chief defense lawyer of the main political opposition figure, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, on suspicion that he beat his former wife, a development that a spokeswoman for Ms. Tymoshenko called “absurd” and just another example of the government abusing its prosecutorial powers.

headline: Where Credit Is Due
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Collateralized Debt Obligations', 'National Debt (US)', 'Payday Loans']
abstract: Starting from a simple loan, credit markets have featured many innovations as well as costly crises.
lead_paragraph: Starting from a simple loan, credit markets have featured many innovations as well as costly crises.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Gets Early Start on Pushing for a 2016 Clinton Campaign
abstract: The Ready for Hillary “super PAC” is resisting expensive television ads to promote Hillary Rodham Clinton in favor of building an email list of her supporters.
lead_paragraph: In the 2008 presidential primary campaign, Mitch Stewart devoted himself to defeating Hillary Rodham Clinton, overcoming the advantages of a well-funded Democratic front-runner through grass-roots organizing, and propelling Barack Obama to victory.

headline: Emotions High at  a Celebratory Lunch for the Met’s  James Levine
abstract: James Levine of the Metropolitcan Opera was welcomed back after a two-year absence with speeches, arias, and reminiscences by several generations of Met singers.
lead_paragraph: James Levine was wrapping up his remarks at the Metropolitan Opera Guild’s “Welcome Home, Jimmy!” lunch on Monday, which celebrated his return to the Met after an injury sidelined him for two years, when, with a flourish, he ripped his prepared text in two.

headline: De Blasio Honors Soldiers and Notes His Family’s Military Service
abstract: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio pointed out that all four of his children’s grandparents were directly involved in the war effort during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Switching gears from the political to the ceremonial, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio saluted America’s soldiers on Monday, while enthusiastically marching in his first official parade since his landslide victory last week.

headline: The Next Step in Stop-and-Frisk
abstract: The full appellate court should review the ill-advised decision to remove Judge Shira Scheindlin from the case.
lead_paragraph: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit created a public-policy crisis earlier this month when it stayed the remedies ordered by Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court to correct civil rights violations associated with the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policy. And by wrongly removing Judge Scheindlin from the case, the panel sent a chilling message to district court judges who challenge the practices of the police and other government entities. Instead of letting this matter linger, the full court should agree to review the panel’s ruling.

headline: An Overdue Ban on Trans Fats
keywords: ['Trans Fatty Acids', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Cholesterol', 'Editorials', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: This long-awaited move should save thousands of lives and potentially billions of dollars in medical and economic costs a year.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is moving to ban virtually all artificial trans fats from the American food supply. This long-awaited move should save thousands of lives and potentially billions of dollars in medical and economic costs a year.

headline: A Media Services Agency Rides the Health and Wellness Wave
abstract: Horizon Media is starting a unit to plan and buy all kinds of media for health and wellness companies.
lead_paragraph: THE largest independent media services agency in advertising is expanding its purview again, this time into the booming field of health and wellness marketing.

headline: Running in the Dazzle of Neon
abstract: Some find the trend obnoxious, but bright shoes and gear are becoming ubiquitous on running circuits around the world.
lead_paragraph: As fall marathon season unfolds, tens of thousands of runners thud along trails across the country.

headline: Redefining the Minimum Wage
abstract: Workers at Seattle’s airport seek substantially higher hourly pay, and they deserve to get it.
lead_paragraph: Business has been brisk at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, with a record number of passengers spending record amounts of money eating and shopping. But for an estimated 6,500 workers at the airport and its nearby hotels, car rental agencies and parking lots, the activity has not translated into economic security, let alone prosperity. Wages for airport-related jobs average an estimated $11 an hour, ranging from less than $10 an hour for airline contractors, like baggage handlers and cabin cleaners, to about $13 an hour for car-rental employees.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks: Unfinished, but Alive
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Energy', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Opponents of a negotiated agreement with Iran have no better answers on how to resolve a breakdown in confidence.
lead_paragraph: The inconclusive negotiations over the weekend on Iran’s nuclear program were disappointing, but two critical points have mostly been ignored. First, diplomacy takes work, and agreements rarely flow seamlessly from beginning to end. Second, if all those inveighing against any deal — namely members of Congress, Israel and Saudi Arabia — see the weekend results as a new opportunity to sabotage it, what is the alternative?

headline: New Consoles on the Way, but Gaming Isn’t the Same
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)']
abstract: Sales of a new generation of consoles could be dented by tablets, smartphones and Facebook, which offer games at lower prices.
lead_paragraph: The new video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft about to hit store shelves are almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year. The uncertainty for the games business is: What happens after Santa leaves?

headline: Jury to Decide How Much More Samsung Must Pay Apple in Patent Case
abstract: A new trial expected to start this week will determine how much Samsung has to pay for an important suit it lost.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Samsung Electronics lost an important patent battle with Apple last year. A new trial expected to start this week will determine how much Samsung has to pay for that loss.

headline: After Ugly Campaign, Finding Little Grace in Brooklyn District Attorney’s Exit
abstract: Last week, the lame duck Charles J. Hynes demoted two prosecutors who wanted to drop charges against a Hasidic whistle-blower and fired one who had complained about the office’s transparency.
lead_paragraph: Sam Kellner, a voluble whistle-blower against child sexual abuse in Brooklyn’s Hasidic community, received a much-dreamed-of phone call last week.

headline: U.N. Relief Official to Help Coordinate Aid Efforts
abstract: Valerie Amos sought to take charge of the relief efforts in the Philippines as governments mobilized to rush supplies to the victims of the storm.
lead_paragraph: The top United Nations relief official flew to the Philippines on Monday to help lead the global response to the powerful typhoon that killed thousands and upended the lives of nearly 10 million people in the country’s midsection. International aid groups mobilized to rush food, water and sanitation supplies to the victims, a struggle in the face of impassable roads, obliterated seaports and severely damaged airstrips.

headline: Unlearning Gun Violence
abstract: Can shootings be reduced by treating the problem with methods and strategies associated with disease control?
lead_paragraph: In 1995, an epidemiologist named Gary Slutkin returned to the United States from Africa where he had spent the previous decade helping Africans stem the spread of diseases like tuberculosis, AIDS and cholera. “I was exhausted,” he said in a TED Talk earlier this year. “I wanted to come home and take a break.”

headline: Djokovic Wins Final, but It’s Not Last Word
abstract: Novak Djokovic beat Rafael Nadal in the finale of the ATP World Tour Finals on Monday, and now new debate may emerge over who should end the season as No. 1.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a year-end tennis championship that was played amid debate over playing surfaces, host cities and the length of a drug suspension, perhaps a new debate will emerge over who should end the season as No. 1.

headline: Typhoon in Philippines Casts Long Shadow Over U.N. Talks on Climate Treaty
keywords: ['Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: In Warsaw, United Nations delegates suggested that a warming planet had turned Typhoon Haiyan, considered one of the strongest storms to make landfall on record, into a lethal monster.
lead_paragraph: The typhoon that struck the Philippines produced an outpouring of emotion on Monday at United Nations talks on a global climate treaty in Warsaw, where delegates were quick to suggest that a warming planet had turned the storm into a lethal monster.

headline: Oklahoma: Senator’s Son Dies in Crash Near Tulsa
abstract: Dr. Perry Inhofe, the son of Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, was killed in a plane crash on Sunday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Perry Inhofe, the son of Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma and ranking member of the Armed Services Committee, was killed in a plane crash on Sunday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed Monday. Aaron Sauer, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board, said at a briefing on Monday that only one person was on board the twin-engine plane when it crashed in Owasso,. The plane had taken off from Salina, Kan., and was approaching the Tulsa airport for landing at the time, he said.

headline: Yellow Dogs, Iranian Band, Earned Fans Through Intensity and Promise
abstract: The Yellow Dogs were far from undiscovered; they had appeared in an award-winning film and been profiled on CNN and in Rolling Stone.
lead_paragraph: For most aspiring young rock stars, the night two years ago when a music critic walked into a music club in Brooklyn and laid eyes and ears on the intense, dark-haired foursome on the stage might have been their first significant break.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 11, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Knicks Scrimmage Hard and Seek Answers
abstract: With members of the front office watching, the Knicks held a tough practice a day after a 31-point loss to the Spurs that dropped them to 2-4.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks reconvened Monday morning at their practice facility, and none of their planned activities turned out to be much fun.

headline: Friday, Nov. 8, 2013
abstract: Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms ever to make landfall, hit the Philippines and began to cut a path of destruction through several islands.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms ever to make landfall, hit the Philippines and began to cut a path of destruction through several islands.

headline: Saturday, Nov. 9, 2013
abstract: The day after Typhoon Haiyan swept through the Philippines, the bodies began to be recovered, and the displaced survivors tried to figure out what to do next.
lead_paragraph: The day after Typhoon Haiyan swept through the Philippines, the bodies began to be recovered, and the displaced survivors tried to figure out what to do next.

headline: Monday, Nov. 11, 2013
abstract: Aid crews struggled to get to survivors three days after a storm that was feared to have left tens of thousands of people dead.
lead_paragraph: Aid crews struggled to get to survivors three days after a storm that was feared to have left tens of thousands of people dead.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 12, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 12, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Some of them were able to hold on, some were lucky and lived, but most did not.”

headline: Filipinos in U.S. Feel Helpless as They Try to Contact Kin
abstract: More than 300,000 Filipinos live in Southern California, and many were busy arranging relief aid as they waited for word from relatives in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the typhoon hit the Philippine city of Ormoc on Friday, Joy Malinao scrambled to get in touch with her brother, who still lives there. But communications in the area were dead.

headline: Behind New York’s New Antismoking Law, a Persistent Councilman
abstract: Cancer deaths among relatives stirred Councilman James F. Gennaro of Queens to push, and push some more, for raising the legal age to buy cigarettes to 21.
lead_paragraph: A judge had just struck down New York’s limits on large sugary drinks last March when a fairly obscure city councilman, James F. Gennaro, cornered Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his health commissioner near the refrigerator at Lucky’s Cafe on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Revitalized Line Boosts Rangers’ Offense
abstract: The line combination of Derek Stepan, Chris Kreider and Mats Zuccarello has provided a huge offensive boost for the surging Rangers.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault is tinkering daily to carve an identity for his new team. Perhaps his best move early in his first season has been a line combination one would not have predicted in September.

headline: Great Expectations for Female Lawyers
abstract: Twelve years after being interviewed by The New York Times Magazine, five women, who all started their law careers at Debevoise & Plimpton, reflect on ambition, leadership and success.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years after being interviewed by The New York Times Magazine, five women, who all started their law careers at Debevoise & Plimpton, reflect on ambition, leadership and success.

headline: ‘Great Expectations for Female Lawyers’
abstract: Twelve years after being interviewed by The New York Times Magazine, five women, who all started their law careers at Debevoise & Plimpton, reflect on ambition, leadership and success.
lead_paragraph: On the bright summer morning of Sept. 9, 2001, I picked up the newspaper from my Brooklyn doorstep, just as I did every Sunday. I was 29, newly wed and relocated from Paris.

headline: Misery Did Not Work, but Vanity Saved Him
abstract: Drugs made John Cox feel numb to the struggles he endured growing up gay. Now he has embraced the doctrine of Narcotics Anonymous.
lead_paragraph: As a child, John Cox, 44, did not like getting dirty; he did not like to roughhouse; he did not like a lot of the activities that other boys seemed to love.

headline: Giants Face Big Decision Over Nicks’s Future
abstract: Hakeem Nicks has been a productive receiver in recent years, but with no touchdowns this season, he may be losing value to the team.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Midway through the second quarter of the Giants’ victory over the Oakland Raiders on Sunday, the second-year wide receiver Rueben Randle broke to the back of the end zone, where Eli Manning lofted a delicate touch pass over a defender.

headline: Kermit Moore, Cellist, Conductor and Composer, Is Dead at 84
abstract: Mr. Moore was concerned with music rooted in the black experience and renowned for championing the work of 20th-century composers.
lead_paragraph: Kermit Moore, a cellist, conductor and composer who in all three capacities was concerned with music rooted in the black experience, died on Nov. 2 in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: A New Firm Sets Out to Secure Women’s Votes for a Vulnerable G.O.P.
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Three political strategists are opening a consulting firm to help Republican candidates better tailor their messages to women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of deliberating over how to better appeal to Hispanic and other minority voters, some Republicans believe their party is overlooking another dire demographic challenge: women.

headline: Corrections: November 12, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 12, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Domo Arigato
abstract: Mike Doran doubles down on this alliterative Tuesday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Today’s constructor, Mike Doran, created an alliterative theme with one sucker punch of an ending. I was able to waltz through most of the theme answers except for the last one, and I think you’ll see what I mean after you solve it.

headline: Alderson Delivers More Laughs, but Few Definitive Answers
abstract: When asked what he has done thus far in the off-season, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson responded with a joke.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Sandy Alderson stood there grinning, surrounded by a group of reporters in a hotel lobby Monday night, at the start of the annual general managers’ meetings. The off-season the Mets had pointed toward, the one their fans had been waiting for, was getting going. Alderson was asked what he had done thus far.

headline: Insurers Press for Way Around Healthcare.gov
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Senior White House officials say the administration is open to ways in which insurers can handle more enrollments and has stepped up efforts to make that possible.
lead_paragraph: Some major health insurers are so worried about the Obama administration’s ability to fix its troubled health care website that they are pushing the government to create a shortcut that would allow them to enroll people entitled to subsidies directly rather than through the federal system.

headline: One Step Forward, One Step Back
abstract: Maria Hassabi’s dance work “Premiere,” a glacially paced piece of choreography, was presented at the Kitchen in Chelsea as part of Performa 13.
lead_paragraph: The double doors part to reveal five dancers, looking right at you, drenched in bright white light. From left to right, they are Robert Steijn, Biba Bell, Hristoula Harakas, Andros Zins-Browne and the choreographer, Maria Hassabi.

headline: Spying Scandal Alters U.S. Ties With Allies and Raises Talk of Policy Shift
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Revelations about the N.S.A. surveillance efforts in Europe are resulting in unprecedented backlash, and some wonder if it is more important to collect data on allies or to be able to work with them.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Just as European and American negotiators resumed work on a groundbreaking trade accord meant to tie their two continents closer together, René Obermann, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, the German telecommunications giant, told a cybersecurity conference in Germany on Monday that his company was working to keep electronic message traffic from “unnecessarily” crossing the Atlantic, where it could fall into the hands of the National Security Agency.

headline: New York City Putting Bus Routes Out for Bid
abstract: Months after a bitter strike by drivers, the Bloomberg administration said that new contracts for 4,100 school bus routes would save $400 million over several years.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration said on Monday that the city would save $400 million over several years by awarding new contracts for thousands of school bus routes, the focus of a bruising fight with the drivers’ union and a monthlong strike this year.

headline: Mauritania Confronts Long Legacy of Slavery
abstract: Mauritania abolished slavery decades ago, but by some measures, it still has the highest prevalence of the practice in the world, and the government has created an agency to wipe out “vestiges” of the problem.
lead_paragraph: BOUTILIMIT, Mauritania — The protesters gathered in front of the low-slung police station, yelling “No to Slavery” and “Freedom.” They had come from across the country to demand the arrest of a family accused of holding a slave since childhood, but they elicited little more than dispassionate stares from the police officers sitting silently before them. The subprefect of the district went to take a nap in the afternoon heat.

headline: Bishops Are Urged to Expand Priorities
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In his final address as president of American Roman Catholic bishops, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan urged them to help Christians who are persecuted overseas.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, in his final address as president of the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops, called on them Monday to take up the cause of Christians in places like Iraq, Syria, Nigeria and India who are persecuted and killed for their faith.

headline: Messages to and From Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan
abstract: Journalists covering the devastation of Typhoon Haiyan deliver messages from survivors to loved ones as people all over the world struggle to find out what happened to their friends and relatives.
lead_paragraph: Updated 7:35 a.m., Nov. 12 The messages to loved ones from survivors of Typhoon Haiyan were scrawled on paper plates and scraps of paper. Jiggy Manicad collected them as he reported on the devastation from Tacloban for a Philippines television station and took them back to Manila on Sunday. When GMA News broadcast and posted them online, he delivered what some families, unable to reach friends and relatives since Friday, were desperate to hear.

headline: 3 People Are Killed in Car Crashes
abstract: The accidents took place Monday in Queens and East Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed on Monday in car crashes in Queens and East Harlem, the police said.

headline: Wisconsin Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Collective Bargaining Law
abstract: Wisconsin’s top court on Monday heard arguments on the constitutionality of a 2011 law that all but eliminated collective bargaining for most public employees.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments on the constitutionality of a 2011 law that all but eliminated collective bargaining for most public employees.

headline: Nets Polish Up Their Brooklyn
abstract: Before a coming three-game trip, the Nets held an open practice at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn, and learned some history about the borough they now call home.
lead_paragraph: The Nets are beginning their second year as Brooklyn tenants, and their effort to blend in took them to a far corner of the borough Monday.

headline: Back and Forth in Undecided Virginia Attorney General Race
abstract: Mark R. Herring, the Democrat, edged ahead of Mark D. Obenshain, the Republican, on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In the week since Election Day, the lead in Virginia’s razor-thin, still undecided attorney general’s race has seesawed. First the Democrat, Mark R. Herring, was up by 32. Then the Republican, Mark D. Obenshain, went ahead by 55 as of Saturday night. He was ahead by 17 Sunday night.

headline: After Watching Rivals, Jets Turn Focus to the Bills
abstract: Rex Ryan exhorted to players to build on last week’s victory over the Saints and to focus on the short term, on Sunday’s game at Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets’ bye week over, Willie Colon returned to the team’s practice facility Monday feeling revitalized, a little Bahamian sand in his dreadlocks, and thinking about advice he considers relevant at this point in the season. Colon spent seven years in Pittsburgh, where his coach, Mike Tomlin, would tell the Steelers, “There’s no reason to look into your neighbor’s house.”

headline: Pictures of Typhoon Haiyan’s Wrath
abstract: Typhoon Haiyan, which cut a destructive path across the Philippines, is believed by some climatologists to be the strongest storm to ever make landfall.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Haiyan, which cut a destructive path across the Philippines, is believed by some climatologists to be the strongest storm to ever make landfall.

headline: Official at Health Site Says He Didn’t Know of Potential Risk
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace, Henry Chao, told congressional investigators that he was not aware of tests that indicated potential security flaws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace has told congressional investigators that he was not aware of tests that indicated potential security flaws in the system, which opened to the public on Oct. 1.

headline: Early Phillips Auction Draws Solid Sales for Contemporary Pieces
abstract: Pop artists brought the evening’s top prices, including Andy Warhol’s “Nine Gold Marilyns (Reversal Series),” that a New York dealer purchased for $8 million.
lead_paragraph: This week’s high-stakes contemporary art auctions got off to a solid, though unexciting, start at Phillips on Monday night. Although there were some disappointments, there were also some record prices for artists, including the Japanese avant-garde painter Kazuo Shiraga; the American installation artist, performance artist and sculptor David Hammons; as well as some of today’s trendier names, like Jacob Kassay, Nate Lowman and Lucien Smith.

headline: A Face-Off Outside Dallas in the Escalating Battle Over Texas’ Gun Culture
abstract: A meeting of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America was interrupted by a peaceful protest by armed members of Open Carry Texas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A small meeting of a group seeking tougher gun laws was interrupted Saturday at a suburban Dallas restaurant when the woman who helped organize it saw something outside that startled her: at least two dozen men and women in the parking lot with shotguns, hunting rifles, AR-15s and AK-47s.

headline: Poverty, Government and Social Class
abstract: Government measures of poverty use outdated methodology and make it impossible to determine where best to apply resources, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | vigor
abstract: This word has appeared in 174 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: vigor •\ˈvi-gər\• noun

headline: Destroying in Order to Build
abstract: As the populations of many former industrial cities dwindle, buildings are being razed rather than raised to better position the cities for growth.
lead_paragraph: As the populations of many former industrial cities dwindle, buildings are being razed rather than raised to better position the cities for growth.

headline: Blighted Cities Prefer Razing to Rebuilding
abstract: Baltimore and other postindustrial cities are destroying vacant buildings, rather than restoring them, in hopes of stabilizing neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Shivihah Smith’s East Baltimore neighborhood, where he lives with his mother and grandmother, is disappearing. The block one over is gone. A dozen rowhouses on an adjacent block were removed one afternoon last year. And on the corner a few weeks ago, a pair of houses that were damaged by fire collapsed. The city bulldozed those and two others, leaving scavengers to pick through the debris for bits of metal and copper wire.

headline: Intersection: New York City Union Square
abstract: Cara Araneta, 32, said the style of Union Square is a “mix of uptown and downtown.” Her personal wardrobe is influenced by men’s wear and Wong Kar-wai films.
lead_paragraph: Cara Araneta, 32, said the style of Union Square is a “mix of uptown and downtown.” Her personal wardrobe is influenced by men’s wear and Wong Kar-wai films.

headline: Iranian Musicians Shot Dead in Brooklyn
abstract: The Iranian indie band the Yellow Dogs fled Tehran so that they could live and play their music free of fear and repression. But in New York, two of the band's members met sudden, violent deaths.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian indie band the Yellow Dogs fled Tehran so that they could live and play their music free of fear and repression. But in New York, two of the band's members met sudden, violent deaths.

headline: With Hard Sell, Big-Ticket Art Comes to Auction
abstract: This week’s art auctions in New York offer the largest number of high-priced contemporary artworks to come on the market at one time.
lead_paragraph: The pressure to sell was so great that Christie’s used the word “masterpiece” three times in the first three paragraphs of its catalog essay promoting a Francis Bacon triptych that it hopes to auction on Tuesday for at least $85 million.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:30 A.M. (Sundance) SWIMMING POOL (2003) An icy English mystery writer (Charlotte Rampling, above) in a midcareer rut is plunged into hot water under the Mediterranean sun when her editor’s wanton teenage daughter (Ludivine Sagnier) and then a dead body show up at a vacation home in France in this thriller directed by François Ozon. “ ‘Swimming Pool,’ Mr. Ozon’s first English-language film (with a bit of French thrown in for local color), is simultaneously a thoroughly mannered, mischievously artificial confection and an acute piece of psychological realism,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Whose psychology, and which reality, remain ambiguous even after the tart, delicious final twist.” The movie, he added, “is alluringly insubstantial, like the light and air of the Luberon. You can’t hold onto it, but it lingers in your senses and plays tricks with your memory.”

headline: Michigan: Autopsy Shows Fatal Wound to the Face
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Self-Defense', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: An autopsy report classified the fatal shooting of Renisha McBride in a Detroit suburb as a homicide. Her family believes she was seeking help after an accident when she was shot.
lead_paragraph: Renisha McBride, a 19-year-old black woman whose death in a Detroit suburb has sparked protests from civil rights groups, was killed by a shotgun wound to the face, but not at close range, according to an autopsy report released Monday that ruled it a homicide. Ms. McBride was killed Nov. 2 on the porch of a home in Dearborn Heights. Her family believes she was seeking help after an accident. Demonstrators have called for the arrest of the homeowner, who is white, but no charges have been brought. The Wayne County prosecutor is expected to review evidence this week.

headline: Google Glass Will Expand Its Features Into Music
abstract: Glass can now be used to search for songs, scan through saved playlists and listen to music in high fidelity.
lead_paragraph: To sell Glass, its augmented-reality form of eyewear, Google has already tried to make it a fashion accessory and a must-have video device for any parent or sky diver. Now it is also presenting this $1,500 piece of wearable technology as a way to interact with music.

headline: Germany’s Lack of Reciprocity
abstract: Adjustment in a low-inflation eurozone: mission impossible?
lead_paragraph: Huge tensions over the ECB rate cut, with a split on the board and many German economists protesting. As usual, a lot of it is about the perception that those lazy southern Europeans are getting a free ride:

headline: News Quiz | November 12, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Israel Increasingly Courting China as an Ally
abstract: Israeli officials hope to win China to their side in dealings with Iran, Syria and the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: As an Israeli diplomat, Dore Gold has sat down with his country’s prime ministers, United States presidents and Palestinian negotiators, all in search of that elusive solution to the Middle East conflict.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 12, 2013
abstract: Answer this question about Veterans Day.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Seeking Mao’s Matrimonial Blessing
abstract: Dozens of couples converged on Mao Zedong’s hometown to exchange wedding vows, weeks before the country will celebrate the 120th anniversary of his birth.
lead_paragraph: Shaoshan, the birthplace of Mao Zedong, is no stranger to visitors: Last year, 8.5 million tourists journeyed to this small, county-level city in the mountains of Hunan Province. But on the morning of Nov. 10, with just over a month until the highly anticipated 120th anniversary of the chairman’s birth, Shaoshan hosted a new kind of pilgrim: 50 couples from across China who came to the city to participate in a “Collective Red Wedding.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy
abstract: What do aides set up for President Obama when he travels abroad?
lead_paragraph: In “Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required),” Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt write about security precautions that the president and other senior officials must take when traveling abroad.

headline: Iranian Official Faults Kerry and France for Breakdown in Talks
abstract: In posts on Twitter, Iran’s foreign minister challenged Secretary of State John Kerry and French officials over the failure of nuclear talks in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Iranian foreign minister turned to a Twitter account late Monday to challenge Secretary of State John Kerry over the failure of weekend talks in Geneva to produce agreement on Tehran’s nuclear program.

headline: Rising Despair as Officials Struggle to Get Aid to  Typhoon Victims
abstract: Philippine officials found themselves on the defensive Tuesday over the pace of relief efforts as the plight of survivors of Typhoon Haiyan became increasingly precarious.
lead_paragraph: CEBU, the Philippines — An American aircraft carrier headed to the Philippines on Tuesday on an emergency mission to help victims of Typhoon Haiyan as the situation on the islands became increasingly desperate, with food and water supplies running low and bodies lying uncollected in the streets of at least one devastated city.

headline: Mayor Ed Lee: ‘Tech Workers Are Not Robots’
abstract: The mayor of San Francisco on the Twitter economy.
lead_paragraph: One of your first encounters with San Francisco city government was when you fought against the demolition of an S.R.O. hotel.  Four chains of people wrapped their arms around the block to prevent its destruction. Horses came in, nightsticks, everything. We never allowed the development to happen, by the way.

headline: Shale’s Effect on Oil Supply Is Forecast to Be Brief
abstract: A report by the International Energy Agency predicts that so-called light tight oil will peak around 2020, then plateau.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The boom in oil from shale formations in recent years has generated a lot of discussion that the United States could eventually return to energy self-sufficiency, but according to a report released Tuesday by the International Energy Agency, production of such oil in the United States and worldwide will provide only a temporary respite from reliance on the Middle East.

headline: Switzerland’s Proposal to Pay People for Being Alive
abstract: The simplest welfare program imaginable: an income for everyone, no strings attached.
lead_paragraph: This fall, a truck dumped eight million coins outside the Parliament building in Bern, one for every Swiss citizen. It was a publicity stunt for advocates of an audacious social policy that just might become reality in the tiny, rich country. Along with the coins, activists delivered 125,000 signatures — enough to trigger a Swiss public referendum, this time on providing a monthly income to every citizen, no strings attached. Every month, every Swiss person would receive a check from the government, no matter how rich or poor, how hardworking or lazy, how old or young. Poverty would disappear. Economists, needless to say, are sharply divided on what would reappear in its place — and whether such a basic-income scheme might have some appeal for other, less socialist countries too.

headline: Do You Worry Colleges or Employers Might Read Your Social Media Posts Someday?
abstract: How careful are you online?
lead_paragraph: Facebook, Twitter and other social media sites have become an integral part of teenage culture. Yet the snarky comment or inappropriate picture we share with our friends just might not project the image we want the rest of the world to see, especially as we get older. How careful are you online?

headline: Checking In to a New Life in America
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A refugee’s first night in the United States, usually spent in a quintessentially American environment — the nondescript airport hotel room — can be an experience of exhaustion, fear, anxiety and wonder.
lead_paragraph: “The rooms and the corridors are all the same,” said the photographer Gabriele Stabile, “but the stories that inhabit these rooms are all different.”

headline: Indonesia Central Bank Increases Rate, Again
abstract: The central bank on Tuesday raised its benchmark rate by a quarter percentage point to help contain the country’s current-account deficit for the fifth time since June.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s central bank made a surprise move on Tuesday to contain the country’s current-account deficit by raising its benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percentage point, to 7.5 percent.

headline: China’s Leaders Urge More Market Control of Economy
abstract: Chinese Communist Party leaders vowed on Tuesday to push through changes that will give market competition a “decisive role” in allocating resources, and announced the formation of a new committee to oversee national security.
lead_paragraph: Chinese Communist Party leaders emerged from a four-day conference on Tuesday with vows to push through changes that will give market competition a “decisive role” in the economy and a plan to establish a new committee to oversee national security.

headline: New York Today: A Hispanic Police Commissioner?
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: jockeying for top cop, robot head bangers and actual snow.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:34 p.m. | Heard of Rafael Piñeiro?

headline: Quebec's Tea Party Moment
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Government Employees', 'Discrimination']
abstract: By outlawing religious attire, Quebec's legislature would present further hurdles to the province's immigrants.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — In Quebec, Canada’s second most populous province, the governing Parti Québécois plans to prohibit government employees from wearing “overt and conspicuous” religious symbols while on the job. Everyone from judges to teachers would have to doff their hijabs, kippas, niqabs, turbans and outsize crucifixes. Day care centers would be forbidden to serve kosher or halal foods. Government workers would be allowed to cover their faces only for weather-related — not religious — reasons.

headline: Rineke Dijkstra’s Moments of Photographic Transformation
abstract: The Dutch photographer likes to capture people when they’re right on the edge of a transition.
lead_paragraph: For last weekend’s article about the impact earlier puberty is having on the Leipzig boys choir, we asked the Dutch photographer Rineke Dijkstra to take pictures of the singers. She has a longstanding interest in what she calls “moments of transformation” in people. Her past projects have included, for example, a series of portraits of Almerisa, a Bosnian girl she has photographed every couple of years since meeting her at a refugee center in the Netherlands nearly 20 years ago, as well as Olivier, whose training as a French Foreign Legion officer she documented over several years. This time, in addition to taking pictures of members of the boys choir, Dijkstra also made a short film of some of them rehearsing Mendelssohn’s  “Jauchzet dem Herrn, alle Welt.”

headline: Another Blow for Dolphins’ Already Shaky Line
abstract: A suspect unit was made even worse by the losses of guard Richie Incognito and tackle Jonathan Martin in the storm of controversy.
lead_paragraph: Off the field, the Richie Incognito-Jonathan Martin dispute has dominated the headlines in Miami. On the field, the absence of the two players allowed the Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ defensive line to dominate the Dolphins’ offense on Monday night.

headline: Daily Report: New Consoles Enter a Changed Gaming Market
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Consumer Behavior', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Xbox (Video Game System)']
abstract: Sony’s PlayStation 4 and Microsoft’s Xbox One are almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year, but whether they can reverse a general trend toward mobile games remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: Consoles have been the thumping heart of the video game industry for decades. But the new PlayStation 4 from Sony and the Xbox One from Microsoft, both almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year, will enter a landscape reshaped by tablets, smartphones and Facebook, all of which provide games at a lower price and in greater abundance, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims Who Can’t Get Aid, or Get Out
abstract: International officials expressed worry that bottlenecks and delays could prevent emergency supplies from reaching millions of victims for days.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Increasingly desperate survivors of Typhoon Haiyan mobbed the shattered airport here on Tuesday, begging for food, water or a flight to escape the chaotic aftermath of the storm, which flattened this city of 220,000 last week and ravaged vast swaths of the country’s midsection.

headline: Murder in Goa Shakes Tourist Paradise
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Police', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A Nigerian man’s murder in Goa draws attention to the underbelly of the coastal paradise.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, you have moved to Goa! You must be having so much fun.” This is the first reaction from most of my friends, who instantly picture me sitting on a beach and sipping beer in my home state.

headline: Business for Sale: Would You Pay $170,000 for This Restaurant?
abstract: This type of business is sometimes called a “lifestyle business.” Such businesses can provide a nice living for the owner, but they are not likely to be sold for a high price when it’s time to leave.
lead_paragraph: In my posts, I occasionally take a look at businesses for sale, which can offer interesting lessons for both buyers and sellers. For this post we’ll look at a restaurant that’s on the market in Florida’s Tampa Bay area. As with my earlier posts on businesses for sale, I have no stake in the sale of the business. Nor do I certify that any of the information provided by the broker, Paul Gorny, is accurate.

headline: Cornelius Gurlitt Seen Headed to Munich Airport
abstract: Mr. Gurlitt had 1,400 artworks, possibly looted during the Nazi era, stashed in his Munich home.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH – Cornelius Gurlitt, the 80-year-old recluse who kept roughly 1,400 artworks hidden in his Munich home, left his apartment building Tuesday and took a taxi to the airport, witnesses said. It was not clear where he was heading. A woman who escorted Mr Gurlitt to the taxi and then drove off with him appeared to be Ozlem Gezer, an investigative journalist for Der Spiegel, Germany’s leading news magazine. The magazine declined to comment.

headline: Obama Nominates Treasury Official as Top Derivatives Regulator
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: President Obama nominated Timothy G. Massad, who oversaw the unwinding of the government’s bailout program, to succeed Gary Gensler at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
lead_paragraph: Timothy G. Massad swept up the mess of the last financial crisis.

headline: South Africans Didn't Die for This
abstract: The nation is losing sight of its founding ideals 20 years after apartheid.
lead_paragraph: Cape Town — There’s a reason photographers like to take pictures of Cape Town, South Africa’s second largest city, from out over the Atlantic Ocean. From this vantage point, cerulean waters give way to a long line of luxurious sea-facing apartments that hug the Atlantic seaboard. Others nestle on the cliffs of Bantry Bay and overlook the sandy beaches of Clifton. To the left, the harbor, city center and manicured parks nestle at the foot of city’s most famous peak, Table Mountain.

headline: The Poverty and Population Factors Behind Vast Typhoon Losses
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Typhoons']
abstract: A detailed look at how poverty and population density worsened the losses in the Philippines typhoon.
lead_paragraph: I encourage you to read every word in Seth Borenstein’s excellent Associated Press overview of the factors behind the vast toll in the central Philippines from Typhoon Hainan — most of which are related to population density and poverty in a disaster hot spot. Here’s an excerpt and link:

headline: More Style Choices
abstract: In our recent stylebook revisions, we have accepted as standard a few forms that until now were still treated as colloquial or informal. In some cases, these changes just formalize what we had already been doing in practice.
lead_paragraph: In our recent stylebook revisions, we have accepted as standard a few forms that until now were still treated as colloquial or informal. In some cases, these changes just formalize what we had already been doing in practice.

headline: In Performance: Brian Cross of ‘The Snow Geese’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from Sharr White’s new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
lead_paragraph: Sharr White’s new play “The Snow Geese” stars Mary-Louise Parker as a World War I-era widow dealing with her fractious family after the death of her husband. In this scene her 18-year-old son, Arnold, played by Brian Cross, chastises his mother for the family’s questionable financial decisions. The show, directed by Daniel Sullivan, continues through Dec. 15 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Obama’s Pick to Lead Trading Commission
abstract: President Obama will nominate Timothy G. Massad to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. | An idea to use a for-profit approach in the world of nonprofits is now taking hold. That’s just one among several new concepts DealBook examines in its special section on innovation.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will nominate Timothy G. Massad as the new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Tuesday, choosing a senior Treasury Department official to run an agency that polices some of Wall Street’s riskiest activity, Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Protess report in DealBook. Mr. Massad, if confirmed by the Senate, would succeed Gary Gensler, who is credited with turning one of Wall Street’s laxest regulators into one of its most aggressive.

headline: The Gun Report: November 12, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, four members of the Texas chapter of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America held a lunch meeting in Arlington, and nearly 40 armed members of Open Carry Texas, a gun rights advocacy group, waited outside. Police monitored the incident at the Blue Mesa Grill, but took no action because state law allows people to openly carry guns.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Shinola Macbook Sleeve
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: leather cover-ups for your most beloved personal devices.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

lead_paragraph: With more Manhattan office space at its disposal, Nomura of Japan seems intent to keep trying to fill it.

keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Men and Boys', 'Movies', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: An actor wears police uniform for a film in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, and finds the attitude of men change radically.
lead_paragraph: On an August afternoon I arrived in Varanasi for the shooting of a film. I was returning to the fabled city after eight years.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A veteran of the Pier 79 impoundment lot took poetic satisfaction at the useless anger of people waiting to retrieve their towed cars.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Diller on Banks, Snowden and His Broadcasting Start-Up
abstract: Barry Diller, the IAC chief who was the leadoff speaker at DealBook’s Opportunities for Tomorrow Conference on Tuesday, touched on more than a few hot-button topics.
lead_paragraph: Barry Diller is not known to be particularly shy about speaking his mind. And as the leadoff speaker on Tuesday at DealBook’s Opportunities for Tomorrow Conference, he held true to form.

headline: Trouble for the Contraception Mandate
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Three federal circuit courts have ratified the view that secular, profit-making employers can claim a religious exemption from the A.C.A.
lead_paragraph: With a ruling on Friday by the Seventh Circuit, a total of five federal circuit courts have weighed in on religious challenges to the health care law’s contraception mandate.

headline: U.N. Appeals for $301 Million Toward Typhoon Relief
abstract: The appeal for emergency assistance came a day after the top United Nations relief official flew to the Philippines to help lead the global response.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations appealed Tuesday for $301 million in emergency assistance to help millions of people in the Philippines affected by the typhoon that struck on Friday.

headline: Lawsuit Over Sale of Dia Artwork Is Withdrawn
abstract: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation opposed to selling several notable pieces from its collection are dropping a lawsuit filed last week.
lead_paragraph: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation who have been vehemently opposed to the organization’s decision to raise money by selling several notable pieces from its collection have decided to withdraw a lawsuit filed last week to block the sale. The founders, Heiner Friedrich and Fariha de Menil Friedrich, said in a statement through their lawyers Tuesday morning that while they consider the sale “utterly wrong” and “against Dia’s mission,” the foundation is “our precious child, and we do not wish to continue to oppose it through legal action.”

headline: The Wild Feathers Pay Tribute to Tom Petty’s ‘Listen to Her Heart’
abstract: Tom Petty’s song gets new rhythms and twists in a cover version by the Wild Feathers.
lead_paragraph: al Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Michigan Senator Critical of ‘Continuing Litany of Deception’ on Wall Street
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Senator Carl Levin, a member of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, pointed to what he saw as broad, deep-seated “cultural failures” on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Senator Carl Levin has some choice words for Wall Street.

headline: To Honor an Artist in Miami Beach, Sandals and a T-Shirt
abstract: The Fontainebleau Miami Beach will honor the artist Tracy Emin’s show with limited edition beach towels, sandals, and a T-shirt.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Emin, one of Britain’s most prominent contemporary artists, will have her first United States museum exhibition beginning on Dec. 4 – the day before the start of Art Basel Miami Beach — at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami.

headline: The Inequality of Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Poverty', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Weather']
abstract: The typhoon that ravaged the Philippines underscores what many development experts say is a cruel truth about climate change: It will hit the world’s poorest the hardest.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Haiyan has left an estimated 10,000 dead and hundreds of thousands homeless in the Philippines. And it has once again underscored for many development experts a cruel truth about climate change: It will hit the world’s poorest the hardest.

headline: Fighting to Stop an Entitlement Before It Takes Hold, and Expands
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: One reason Republicans are fighting so hard to stop President Obama’s health law now is that it may be impossible to do so once it is established.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Underlying fierce Republican efforts to stop President Obama’s health care law and the White House drive to save it is a simple historical reality: Once major entitlement programs get underway, they quickly become embedded in American life. And then they grow.

headline: Justices Weigh Role Drug Played in a Fatal Cocktail
abstract: At issue for the Supreme Court is the extent to which the drug a defendant sold factored into a death. A mandatory 20-year sentence is being appealed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joshua Banka’s prodigious appetite for drugs killed him. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court considered whether to hold a drug dealer who had sold heroin to Mr. Banka responsible for his death.

headline: A Fine or Do Time?
abstract: A bill to get the ultra-Orthodox into the Israeli army may founder because of a dispute over how to sanction draft-dodgers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Knesset is nearing a moment of truth: It has to vote by the end of the month whether to finally draft ultra-Orthodox men into the Israeli army. A proposed law that would lift a long-standing exception allowing Haredi men to avoid military service while they studied the Torah seemed all but ready to pass. Until a last-minute dispute over what to do with anyone who tries to dodge their duty.

headline: Scion of Art Family, in Court, Admits Role With a Gambling Ring
abstract: Hillel Nahmad, who was charged in a racketeering case with reputed Russian mobsters, is likely to get no more than 18 months in prison.
lead_paragraph: Hillel Nahmad, the jet-setting scion of a family whose gallery is a pivotal force in the art market, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a single federal gambling charge, part of a sweeping racketeering indictment handed up in the spring that also charged several reputed Russian mob figures.

headline: After Hours | At Performa, Ryan McNamara’s Pop-Rock Haunted House
abstract: For the 13th edition of the performance-focused biennial in New York, the artist Ryan McNamara has created a melange of dance choreography and musical references featuring a disorienting surprise for attendees.
lead_paragraph: The artist Ryan McNamara has become known in recent years for twisting uber-familiar pop references into his party-ready performance pieces. At Robert Wilson’s annual Watermill Benefit in 2011, he and a partner sang “Islands in the Stream,” the Dolly Parton-Kenny Rogers duet, while buried up to their necks in the ground. At the 2010 Whitney Biennial he transformed a corner of the museum into a karaoke jam called the Whitney Houston Biennial. McNamara billed “MEƎM: A Story Ballet About the Internet, the elaborate, multidancer piece he created for this year’s Performa festival as “a choreographic exploration of the online world as a space of engagement.”

headline: Justice Dept. Clears Merger of 2 Airlines
abstract: US Airways and American Airlines reached a settlement with the Justice Department that will allow the two companies to go forward with their merger.
lead_paragraph: After months of setbacks and delays, the merger of American Airlines and US Airways to create the world’s largest airline became all but certain on Tuesday after the airlines reached a settlement with the Justice Department just two weeks before a scheduled trial.

headline: Image of the Day: November 12
abstract: A drill performed by Indian Air Force Personnel in Goalpara, Assam.

headline: Bishops Select Two Leaders Who Reflect New Tone Set by Pope
abstract: The nation’s Roman Catholic bishops on Tuesday chose as leaders of the bishop’s conference two prelates not known as “cultural warriors.”
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The nation’s Roman Catholic bishops on Tuesday chose as leaders of the bishop’s conference two prelates whose pastoral approach evokes the new tone for the church set by Pope Francis.

headline: A Husband’s Fertility Journey
abstract: Motherlode’s fertility diarist Amy Klein’s husband, Solomon, answers questions about his experience with I.V.F., miscarriage and being part of such a public experience.
lead_paragraph: After asking about how I’m doing with I.V.F., my friends and family always want to know, how is Solomon handling this? Although my husband considers himself a private person, he agreed to answer some questions.

headline: Today in Small Business: Tracking Online Ads
abstract: Loans to veterans in New Jersey are up. Six tools to track online ads. Free products from Google.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Make It Whiskey in a Barrel, Neat
abstract: More bars are in the market for proprietary whiskey, a product they can call their own, and are buying it by the barrel.
lead_paragraph: The old-fashioned served at Middle Branch, a stylish two-tier cocktail bar in Midtown Manhattan, is unlike any other old-fashioned in the world. It’s not the recipe that makes it special, or the house-made cherry or the custom ice, or the way the bartender prepares the drink. It’s the whiskey: Elijah Craig bourbon.

headline: Loeb Discusses His Strategy, Discloses Stake in FedEx
abstract: “I can’t think of a time in our experience where we misstepped,” Daniel S. Loeb, the manager of Third Point Capital, said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:22 p.m. | Despite a public scolding from George Clooney, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb does not have too many regrets about his activist investment strategy.

lead_paragraph: The brewmaster of Brooklyn Brewery shares his packing list for a visit to Stockholm.

headline: Drinking Beer in Sweden
abstract: Advice from Garrett Oliver, of Brooklyn Brewery, which will open a Stockholm brewery in February.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1980s, before microbrew was even a term, let alone a trend, in the United States, Garrett Oliver, a brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, began creating beer in his home in New York City just so he could drink something other than the “thin, fizzy yellow liquid” that bars served at the time.

abstract: For 6Wunderkinder and other start-ups in Europe, the backing of American venture capitalists is an important indicator that their companies are able to move beyond their local roots.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – For many European start-ups, connections to Silicon Valley are still viewed as a sign of success.

lead_paragraph: The last full-time employee in the tallest building in Rhode Island has grown accustomed to the 26 stories of emptiness.

headline: Pivotal Steps Up to the Cloud
abstract: Pivotal announced it would offer a product that can serve as a means to write applications to work on a number of so-called public clouds.
lead_paragraph: Pivotal, the company that EMC formed to build applications in the cloud computing era, is starting to deliver the goods. Now we’ll see if there’s a market for what it wants to sell.

headline: Storied Providence Skyscraper, Now Empty, Seeks a Future
abstract: The Industrial Trust building, which once announced Rhode Island’s capital as a Gotham of industry, now nags at the city’s sense of self-worth.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The last full-time employee in the tallest building in Rhode Island has grown accustomed to the 26 stories of emptiness. He doesn’t even hear the absence anymore — that silent roar of business not transacted.

headline: How Do We Judge Books Written Under Pseudonyms?
abstract: Francine Prose and Daniel Mendelsohn on what readers’ and critics’ reactions say about works written behind a false name.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Daniel Mendelsohn on what readers’ and critics’ reactions say about pseudonymous works.

headline: First Snow, 8:30 A.M.
abstract: New York saw its first snow of the season on Tuesday morning. Its appearance was brief, but our photographers were quick to the draw.
lead_paragraph: New York saw its first snow of the season on Tuesday morning, as small flakes fluttered from the sky during the morning commute. There was no accumulation, and temperate sidewalks and above-freezing air temperatures quickly turned the flakes into a mere memory. Fortunately, our photographers were quick on the draw.

headline: By a Spire, Manhattan Regains a Title From Chicago
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Sears Tower (Chicago)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: An official arbiter declared a mast part of the building, making the skyscraper higher than the Willis Tower, formerly the Sears Tower, in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: For four decades, Chicagoans have been able to one-up New Yorkers on at least one measure: The City of the Big Shoulders had the tallest building in the United States.

headline: Rubenstein Not Planning a Retirement Party Just Yet
abstract: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and co-chief executive of the Carlyle Group, and David Bonderman, founding partner at TPG Capital, discussed the future of private equity, not succession plans at their firms.
lead_paragraph: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and co-chief executive of one of the world’s largest private equity firms, the Carlyle Group, may be 64 years old, but he says he doesn’t plan to retire soon.

headline: YouTube Cleaning Up Its Comments
abstract: Soon YouTube comments will be less obscene, and possibly less revealing.
lead_paragraph: It’s sometimes a little frightening to read the comments on a YouTube video.  Let’s say you’ve just watched a cat video and want to find out how others responded to that moment when one kitten massaged another. You scroll down and find … a large helping of inanity as well as racism, sexism, anti-Semitism, homophobia and pure nonsense. It’s well known that the YouTube comments section is a virtual septic tank. In the immortal words of BuzzFeed: “YouTube IS the room with the million monkeys and the million typewriters.”

headline: Obama in Bind Trying to Keep Health Law Vow
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: White House officials are struggling to make good on President Obama’s promise that Americans can keep their insurance coverage without undermining the new health law or adding unaffordable costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under intense bipartisan pressure to answer mounting consumer complaints about the botched health care rollout, White House officials are struggling to make good on President Obama’s promise that Americans can keep their insurance coverage without undermining the new health law or adding unaffordable costs.

headline: Despite Bumps, Tire Deal Still Makes Sense

lead_paragraph: The buyout of Cooper Tire and Rubber hasn’t gone flat yet.

headline: Not Giving In to Age or Rangers, Brodeur Tops Lundqvist
abstract: Martin Brodeur stopped 33 of 35 shots, and Dainius Zubrus scored the winning goal with 2 minutes 55 seconds left in regulation to lift the Devils over the Rangers at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: The old guy still has it. Martin Brodeur was superb in goal Tuesday night in a long line of duels with Henrik Lundqvist. He robbed Ryan Callahan and Derek Stepan alone in front, headed away a batted shot from Chris Kreider, got into a brief slap fight with Mats Zuccarello and all night long looked like a goalie far younger than his 41 years.
