headline: ‘Steel Hammer’ and ‘The Christians’ Planned for Humana Festival
abstract: Now in its 38th year, the festival is scheduled to run Feb. 26 to April 6 in Louisville, Ky.
lead_paragraph: “Steel Hammer,” a new play built around the composer Julia Wolfe’s kaleidoscopic set of variations on the folk song “John Henry,” is among the works to be performed at the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., next year.

headline: What’s In It | Pumpkin Flavor
abstract: Pumpkin-flavored products are on pace to have their best sales year yet. But the industry’s biggest secret about these products is that there is often little or no pumpkin in them.
lead_paragraph: Pumpkin-flavored products are on pace to have their best sales year yet. But the industry’s biggest secret about these products is that there is often little or no pumpkin in them.

headline: That Pinch of Pumpkin
abstract: Pulling back the curtain on what is arguably one of the most mysterious, and misunderstood, flavors in processed foods.
lead_paragraph: THE FLAVOR CALLED PUMPKIN is surging toward a record season in processed foods, with Mars introducing Pumpkin M&Ms, Planters dusting “pumpkin spice” on its almonds and Starbucks bringing back its annual Pumpkin Latte. Sales of last year’s pumpkin offerings climbed nearly 20 percent to more than $290 million, Nielsen reports, and people in the flavor business say the trend has a powerful demographic wind at its back: strong popularity among millennials.

headline: Fairy Tale Opera Leads to Fairy Tale Career Break
abstract: Christine Goerke will sing the role of Brünnhilde when the Metropolitan Opera revives its Robert Lepage production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle in the 2018-19 season.
lead_paragraph: The machine is coming back to the Metropolitan Opera, which plans to mount a revival of Robert Lepage’s high-tech, polarizing and glitch-prone “Ring” cycle in the 2018-19 season to showcase its next Brünnhilde: the soprano Christine Goerke. She was offered the role after her breakout success last week in Strauss’s fairy tale opera “Die Frau Ohne Schatten.”

headline: ‘Silent Night,’ Pulitzer Winner, to Air on PBS
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning opera by Kevin Puts will be shown on PBS in December.
lead_paragraph: “Silent Night,” the opera by Kevin Puts that won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 2012, will have its television premiere on Dec. 13, when PBS broadcasts a performance by the Minnesota Opera, recorded during the work’s world-premiere run in 2011.

headline: A Quiet Release for the iPad Mini
abstract: It has been evident that Apple was struggling to make enough iPad Mini tablets for the coming holiday season.
lead_paragraph: The release of Apple’s new iPad Mini on Tuesday lacked the finesse of a typical Apple product release. It also lacked a lot of the pomp.

headline: Twitter Introduces Tool to Make Collecting and Sharing Tweets Easier
abstract: Twitter introduced a tool, called custom timelines, that allows users to easily collect and share tweets on any subject they want.
lead_paragraph: Twitter introduced a tool Tuesday, called custom timelines, that allows its users to drag and drop tweets to form custom lists of Twitter messages on whatever topic interests them.

headline: To Top JPMorgan Deal Maker, Mergers Still Look Strong
abstract: James B. Lee Jr., JPMorgan Chase’s vice chairman and chief deal maker, argues that the number of big deals disclosed in 2013 is the largest it’s been in years.
lead_paragraph: Many in the deal sector have been pessimistic about a recovery in the business of mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Program Seeks to Nurture ‘Data Science Culture’ at Universities
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A new partnership is intended to foster the sharing of data analysis ideas and methods across different academic disciplines.
lead_paragraph: The modern flood of data comes in a many forms — sensor data, genomic data, web click streams and credit card transactions, to name a few. The disparate data sources are often called “silos,” suggesting the challenge of mingling different data sets to generate insights.

headline: Rich Risotto, Full-Bodied Wine
abstract: A sumptuous chardonnay, rather than a whipsaw Chablis or other lean example.
lead_paragraph: A dish this rich requires a similarly broad, full-bodied wine, like a sumptuous chardonnay, something from the Côte de Beaune, Pouilly-Fuissé, California or Oregon, even Australia, rather than a whipsaw Chablis or other lean example. Within that group, the best choices would be textured and mineral rather than overtly oaky or flamboyantly fruity.

headline: Michelle Obama Talks Education
abstract: The first lady, Michelle Obama, spoke to students at Bell Multicultural High School in Washington about the importance of education.
lead_paragraph: The first lady, Michelle Obama, spoke to students at Bell Multicultural High School in Washington about the importance of education.

headline: Fink Worries About Implications of Health Care Law
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: Laurence Fink, the chief of BlackRock, said the financial effect of the Affordable Care Act was potentially more significant than the “noise about whether the website works or not.”
lead_paragraph: Many Americans are worried about how their health care will change under the Affordable Care Act. Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, one of the largest money management firms, is worried about those worries.

headline: Poets Remember Seamus Heaney
abstract: Paul Muldoon, Lucie Brock-Broido and Paul Simon were among those who read from Mr. Heaney’s work at Cooper Union’s Great Hall.
lead_paragraph: When Seamus Heaney died in August, at 74, he was hailed as a poet of unusual grace and humility, an ambassador for poetry whose reach stretched far beyond the rural Ireland of his most famous verse. And since then, the tributes have kept coming, most recently on Monday night at Cooper Union’s Great Hall, where some 20 poets and friends gathered to read favorite Heaney poems to a packed house.

headline: When Facing Activist Investors, Fight Has Gone 24/7
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: During a panel on investor activism, corporate advisers noted that Twitter and modern technology has changed the nature of boardroom battles.
lead_paragraph: When Carl C. Icahn sought to oppose a buyout of Dell this year, he turned to his classic playbook, issuing impassioned proclamations to shareholders.

headline: What Should Hillary Fear?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An anti-Wall Street insurgency? Or a health care dilemma?
lead_paragraph: Noam Scheiber’s big New Republic essay on the idea of an Elizabeth Warren challenge to Hillary Clinton in 2016 is an illuminating window into the liberal mind circa 2013 and a fascinating political portrait-cum-psychobiography of Warren herself. What it is not, however, is a convincing argument that the presumptive Democratic nominee has anything significant to fear from a Warren candidacy right now, let alone that the Massachusetts Senator is anything like a “nightmare” for Team Clinton. Dave Weigel does a good job highlighting one of the key factors that Scheiber’s analysis (rather oddly) leaves out: The demographics of the Democratic primary electorate, which made the Obama insurgency different from pretty much every liberal primary insurgency before it:

lead_paragraph: I’ve been a fan of Moleskine notebooks for years because of their rugged appearance and warm textures, which invite me to jot my thoughts down. But with the advent of smartphones, carrying the notebooks around seemed redundant because I could make notes digitally. So I ditched the notebooks for a smooth, cold iPhone.

headline: The View From Saturn
abstract: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft looked back from the shadow of Saturn to take a picture that sweeps 405,000 miles across the planet and the inner solar system. For perspective, the Earth is 898 million miles away.
lead_paragraph: On July 19, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft looked back from the shadow of Saturn to take a picture of the ringed planet in all its glory and indeed the entire inner solar system. Knowing that the Earth would also be in the field of view — the third time that our planet has sat for its portrait from the outer solar system, Cassini’s managers asked everyone to smile. Apparently, many of us did, although you might not be able to pick yourself out of the cosmic crowd in this image released by NASA and the Cassini team on Tuesday.

headline: How the Word ‘North’ Affects Prices
abstract: The area’s population, historically dominated by blacks, has diversified at an even faster clip than Central Harlem as a whole.
lead_paragraph: The moment Gary Davis popped his head out of the subway station on Central Park North and Lenox Avenue in 2004, he understood he was looking at an extraordinary spot. An architect and real estate developer, he had been invited to the block by a lawyer for the owner of a two-story corner building there, and though Mr. Davis recalls not being “very excited about Harlem,” he was quick to see the site’s potential. He then sent a photographer 120 feet above the street in a bucket attached to a crane arm; the resulting pictures showed breathtaking panoramic views of Central Park and miles beyond.

headline: Philadelphia Schools See Cash in Old Classrooms
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Appraisals and Valuation (Property)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Education (K-12)']

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The financially troubled school district here is seeking buyers for more than two dozen school buildings that it shuttered last summer in one of the country’s biggest school closing programs.

headline: Dance Moves From the Deep Sea
abstract: Sushi Dojo is a fresh newcomer in the East Village; Kurumazushi is a veteran of the Midtown sushi scene.
lead_paragraph: Disco music with raw fish in the East Village may not strike you as a winning formula unless you remember when Avenue A had what was probably the only sushi bar in the city with a mirror ball and a D.J. booth. Everybody called it Disco Sushi, and I loved it for reasons that had nothing to do with the food. I had eaten enough good sushi to know I couldn’t afford it. But cold rice, fake wasabi and sinewy fish mattered much less when vinyl records and the mirror ball were spinning, the tables were filling up with musicians waiting for a 1 a.m. gig at Brownies, and we were all on our third round of sake bombs.

headline: Murder in the Midwest
abstract: How a killing and subsequent trial in 1863 Indianapolis exposed the tensions that ran through Civil War America.
lead_paragraph: The shooting occurred about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Aug. 4, 1863, “halfway between sundown and dark,” as one witness described it. The day had been a typically hot one in Indianapolis, but a rain shower in the early evening cooled the air and knocked down the dust. Residents came out of their houses and shops onto the streets. Others ate their suppers or relaxed on their porches after a long day of work.

headline: Experts Reshape Treatment Guide for Cholesterol
abstract: The guidelines from the nation’s leading heart organizations will fundamentally reshape the use of cholesterol-lowering statin medicines now prescribed for a quarter of Americans over 40.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s leading heart organizations released new guidelines on Tuesday that will fundamentally reshape the use of cholesterol-lowering statin medicines, which are now prescribed for a quarter of Americans over 40. Patients on statins will no longer need to lower their cholesterol levels to specific numerical targets monitored by regular blood tests, as has been recommended for decades. Simply taking the right dose of a statin will be sufficient, the guidelines say.

headline: When Doctors Share With Their Patients
abstract: Doctors often “self-disclose” to patients in an attempt to empathize. But contrary to what might be expected, such self-disclosures often turned out not to be helpful in addressing patients’ concerns or building rapport.
lead_paragraph: At our very first visit, I was overwhelmed by all of the issues my new patient faced. She was nearly 300 pounds and her diabetes was raging out of control. She had asthma, but smoked to ease her anxiety. Her obesity severely limited her mobility, but the constant stress in her life led her to overeat.

headline: In Sweden, the Fika Experience
abstract: What the Swedes call fika, the combination of coffee and usually some sort of sweet snack, is a way of life.
lead_paragraph: Coffee is a way of life in Sweden. It is not simply a beverage you grab to go, or something used for a jolt in the morning. Coffee is an experience.

headline: 3 Things to Know About the New Cholesterol Guidelines
abstract: The new message is don’t chase target cholesterol numbers, know your heart risk, and — if you need drug therapy — use statins. These principles should guide your discussions with your doctor.
lead_paragraph: The American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association just released new cholesterol guidelines to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular risk –- and the change from the previous version, last updated in 2004, is profound. Here are three things you need to know about these new guidelines.

headline: Miki Naftali

headline: No R.S.V.P.? In Rajasthan, India, No Worries
abstract: Wedding crashing is a way to see the culture at its most ceremonial, and colorful.
lead_paragraph: In the tiniest of tailor shops in Udaipur, in the northwestern Indian state of Rajasthan, a squad of tailors chaotically fussed over me. It was the peak of autumn wedding season in 2011 and I was being fitted for a sherwani, the traditional Indian garment worn among Rajput aristocracy at Rajasthan weddings. My friend Dianne was standing in a nest of chiffon and georgette, trying on colorful saris. She was debating between the sequined turquoise and the glittery hot pink.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At a memorial service for the federal security official who was killed in a shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. promised Tuesday that federal officials would work to hold those responsible accountable and to “prevent tragedies like this from happening ever again.”

headline: Reworking Their Soviet Past
abstract: “Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here” is a portrait of the two artists on the occasion of their return to the former Soviet Union for a string of exhibitions of their work in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: The celebrated Conceptual artist Ilya Kabakov, now 80, has spoken extensively about his idea of the “total installation,” an art form that can bear some resemblance to a meticulously dressed movie set. It’s an idea that the art critic and filmmaker Amei Wallach confronts head-on in “Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here,” a dynamically shot documentary that keeps journeying into the Soviet past as it is remembered and reworked by Mr. Kabakov and his wife and partner, Emilia.

headline: In Europe, Thousands of Requests for Facebook Data
abstract: Richard Allan, the director for public policy for Facebook in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, said the company received 8,500 requests from the European Union affecting 10,000 user accounts during the first six months of this year.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Online surveillance by the United States was the main subject of a hearing on Monday evening organized by the European Parliament’s civil liberties committee. But one of the more noteworthy parts of the session was a presentation by a senior Facebook employee who described demands by European Union governments.

headline: Live Nation Nears a Deal for Managers of Music Acts

lead_paragraph: Live Nation Entertainment, the giant concert company that includes Ticketmaster, is in advanced negotiations to buy the management companies behind U2 and Madonna, according to several people with direct knowledge of the talks.

abstract: After his 30 carries for 115 yards and one touchdown in Week 10, the Giants’ Andre Brown will be picked up in most fantasy leagues heading into Week 11.
lead_paragraph: Those pesky bye weeks are finally coming to an end soon as fantasy football’s homestretch nears. While you cannot afford to look too far ahead if you’re just trying make the playoffs, a smart owner will keep an eye on the waiver wire with those important fantasy playoff weeks in mind.

abstract: Mary Lambert found fame with the hip-hop duo Macklemore & Ryan Lewis on the gay rights anthem “Same Love,” but she is reclaiming that song’s message in her own tender music and poetry.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The day in May 2012 that Mary Lambert received the phone call inviting her to collaborate with the hip-hop duo Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, she popped a bottle of Champagne with a saber, kissed the picture of President Obama in her house here, and set to work.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: David Karp, the 27-year-old founder of Tumblr, may be a creature of the tech world. But he has had a rapid education in the ways of Wall Street.

headline: A Public Memorial Set for Lou Reed
abstract: A service honoring Mr. Reed is scheduled for Thursday at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: For fans of Lou Reed who want to pay tribute to the hard-edged singer, guitar and songwriter who died on October 27: There will be a memorial for him on Thursday at Lincoln Center. A message on Mr. Reed’s Facebook page announced that there would be “a gathering open to the public – no speeches. No live performances, just Lou’s voice, guitar music & songs – playing the recordings selected by his family and friends.” The memorial is scheduled to last three hours, starting at 1 p.m., at the Paul Milstein Pool and Terrace at Lincoln Center.

headline: Essential Roast Turkey
abstract: There are many ways to prepare a turkey, says Melissa Clark, but none of them will make a better bird than if you rub it down with salt and put it in the oven.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to prepare a turkey, says Melissa Clark, but none of them will make a better bird than if you rub it down with salt and put it in the oven.

headline: Dia’s Auction of Artworks Is to Proceed
abstract: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation have dropped a lawsuit that would have blocked sales by Dia at Sotheby’s on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation, who oppose the auction of notable pieces from its collection, have withdrawn a lawsuit filed last week to block the sale. The founders, Heiner Friedrich and Fariha de Menil Friedrich, said in a written statement through their lawyers on Tuesday morning that while they consider the sale “utterly wrong” and “against Dia’s mission,” the foundation is “our precious child, and we do not wish to continue to oppose it through legal action.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing a well-financed insurgency in Afghanistan, the United States has struggled for years to cut off the main contribution American taxpayers make to Taliban coffers: the hiring of Afghan contractors with ties to the insurgents.

lead_paragraph: Chegg, a start-up focused on textbook rentals and academic services, priced its initial public offering on Tuesday at $12.50 a share, exceeding expectations.

headline: A Lively Requiem, Without the What-if-He’d Lived
abstract: Bernard Labadie led the New York Philharmonic on Friday in a performance of Mozart’s Requiem, relying on Robert Levin’s idiomatically sensitive edition of the work.
lead_paragraph: There’s no getting around the fact that the first third of Mozart’s Requiem — the part he composed and orchestrated in full — is better than what follows. If this final masterpiece, written in the months leading up to his death in December 1791, had been a secular cantata, no doubt subsequent generations would have trimmed off the latter movements, in which Mozart’s pupil Franz Xaver Süssmayr filled in the bits left incomplete to the best of his modest abilities. But a Requiem is a liturgical unit that demands to be performed in full — no matter how dull the Sanctus.

headline: Stuffing With Mushrooms and Bacon
abstract: Learn to make this fast and delicious stuffing recipe.
lead_paragraph: Learn to make this fast and delicious stuffing recipe.

headline: From USA, a Mystery Series Shot in Old Jerusalem
abstract: USA plans to announce a deal for a new TV drama, “Dig,” centering on archaeological discoveries in Jerusalem’s Old City.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, executives at the USA Network have stood on the sidelines, watching cable dramas like AMC’s “Breaking Bad” and Showtime’s “Homeland” collect the critical raves and awards. Now they want to get into the game.

headline: Love, Like a Bombing Plot, Is Complicated
abstract: “The English Bride” is a mystery involving love, a bomb and a guessing game.
lead_paragraph: The line between truth and lies is nicely blurred in “The English Bride,” a mystery wrapped in a love story — or the other way around — by Lucile Lichtblau, at 59E59 Theaters. And three solid performances keep the interest level up, despite the limits of the play’s structure.

headline: The King of the Strip Evades Revenge
abstract: In Michael Mayer’s Rat Pack “Rigoletto,” the main character is a hanger-on to the enabling crowd that tends to the Duke, the king of the strip.
lead_paragraph: A lot of news was made on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera, most of it good, when the Rat Pack “Rigoletto,” Michael Mayer’s glitzy, inventive production of the Verdi classic, returned. It included the company debuts of a fast-rising young conductor and an impressive soprano, and two veteran artists brought significant roles from their repertory to the Met.

headline: Back Injury Puts Football Player on I.P.O. Delayed List
abstract: Fantex, the start-up promoting I.P.O.’s of National Football League stars, said that it was putting off its stock offering of Arian Foster, the running back for the Houston Texans. He was placed on injured reserve.
lead_paragraph: Some companies cancel initial public offerings for lack of demand. Others are delayed because regulators require more disclosure.

headline: In L.A., Lari Pittman Takes on American Violence and Identity
abstract: In a new show at Regen Projects, the veteran artist presents numerous surreal tableaus that critique established power dynamics.
lead_paragraph: Three large paintings that Lari Pittman refers to as “flying carpets” serve as cornerstones of his new exhibition, “From a Late Western Impaerium,” at Regen Projects in Los Angeles. Like all of the work he has produced during his nearly four-decade career, these pieces are vibrant and ornate, crammed edge to edge with references both historical and contemporary. “Flying Carpet With a Waning Moon Over a Violent Nation” contains five large circles with cross hairs, which seem to be targeting a soft-focus landscape. They’re interspersed with dangling nooses. The implied violence of the composition represents the “effects of advanced capitalism,” according to Pittman. “I hate to sound so old-school Marxist about it,” he adds.

headline: The Book of Revelation, With Some Teeth to It
abstract: The choreographer Angelin Preljocaj finds inspiration in the last book of the New Testament for his sex-and-symbology work “And then, one thousand years of peace.”
lead_paragraph: The French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj has been careful to clarify that his 2010 dance “And then, one thousand years of peace” is not a literal reading of the Book of Revelation. Rather, it is an impressionistic rendering of the emotions and sensations evoked by reading the New Testament’s finale. In its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this past weekend, the dance seemed to reveal one thing: Mr. Preljocaj finds the Apocalypse a turn-on.

headline: Bank Records Sought in Offshore Tax Inquiry
abstract: A federal judge gave the government permission to seek data from five Wall Street banks on American clients suspected of hiding assets at an unrelated Caribbean bank.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge gave the government permission to seek data from five Wall Street banks on American clients suspected of hiding assets at an unrelated Caribbean bank.

headline: A Park for Moscow With New York Roots
abstract: A team headed by the New York design studio behind the High Line has won an international competition to build a park in the shadow of the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: A team headed by the New York design studio behind the High Line has won an international competition to build a park in the shadow of the Kremlin. The team, led by Diller Scofidio & Renfro, presented a concept for the park, in the Zaryadye neighborhood of Moscow, that was based on the theme of “wild urbanism,” with descending terraces reflecting Russia’s four typical land types: tundra, steppe, forest and wetlands. The renovation of the park is the latest in a series of beautification efforts under Mayor Sergei S. Sobyanin, who has invested heavily in expanding green space in the city amid demands from Moscow’s increasingly vocal middle class. The 13-acre lot has stood vacant since 2006, when the Rossiya Hotel, a landmark of Soviet Moscow, was demolished.

headline: Fiddling That Inspired a Piano Quintet
abstract: Gilles Vonsattel and the Danish String Quartet performed a complex Peter Lieberson work last Thursday at the Kaplan Penthouse for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: During a postconcert talk in the Kaplan Penthouse, the pianist Gilles Vonsattel spoke about the difficulty of bringing character to complex and difficult music like Peter Lieberson’s Piano Quintet (2001).

headline: Fallon, Nearing ‘Tonight’ Debut, Says He Has First Guest in Mind
abstract: Jimmy Fallon, the host of NBC’s “Late Night,” said preparations had already begun for his ascension to “The Tonight Show” in February, starting with a longer, Leno-style monologue.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Fallon, host of “Late Night” and soon to be host of NBC’s “Tonight” show, has been making the rounds of the network’s affiliates in advance of his ascension in February to the chair now held by Jay Leno, the top-rated host in late night. On Tuesday, he took a quick break to offer some early thoughts on the coming transition. Among them:

headline: Adobe Breach Inadvertently Tied to Other Accounts
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: As researchers sift through data from a security breach at Adobe, they are discovering that people have may have inadvertently shown hackers passwords for bank accounts, email, Facebook and home garage door codes on the Adobe website.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ammon Bartram, a software engineer and co-founder of SocialCam, was talking to a friend about a recent security breach at Adobe in which hackers were able to gain access to tens of millions of encrypted passwords and email addresses.

headline: The College Premium
abstract: The growth of the earnings gap between college and high school graduates slowed in the last decade, after expanding sharply over the previous 20 years. The long rise followed a dip in the supply of college graduates, especially among men.
lead_paragraph: The growth of the earnings gap between college and high school graduates slowed in the last decade, after expanding sharply over the previous 20 years. The long rise followed a dip in the supply of college graduates, especially among men.

headline: Republicans Again Reject Obama Pick for Judiciary
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: The nomination of Cornelia T. L. Pillard fell short of clearing the necessary 60-vote threshold, the third time in two weeks a White House nominee has stalled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s latest choice to fill one of the vacancies on a powerful appeals court went down in a filibuster on Tuesday as Senate Republicans blocked another White House nominee — the third in two weeks — and deepened a growing conflict with Democrats over presidential appointments.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Said to Agree to $4 Billion Settlement Over Hip Implants
abstract: The deal, among the largest payouts ever for product liability claims, would settle thousands of lawsuits over the company’s all-metal replacement hip.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson has tentatively agreed to a settlement that could reach up to $4 billion to resolve thousands of lawsuits filed by patients injured by a flawed all-metal replacement hip, said two lawyers briefed on the plan.

headline: Extended Stay America Prices I.P.O. at $20 a Share
abstract: The hotel operator priced its initial public offering on Tuesday at $20 a share, in the middle of its expected range. At that price, the company will have raised $565 million and will be valued at $4 billion.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders seem to have given Extended Stay America a warm, but not luxurious, welcome to the public markets.

headline: Mascara Ads: Thick Lashes, Fine Print
abstract: Cosmetics companies are panned for using eyelash inserts in mascara ads for fuller looks.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, thanks in part to the rise of Latisse, the prescription drug that promises longer eyelashes, and the refinement of false lashes, a full fringe around the eyes has come to be one of beauty’s holy grails. Which may be why, when it comes to advertising, mascara marketers have been laying it on a bit thick.

headline: Using Hurricane Sandy as a Lesson for Future Elections
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Voting and Voters', 'States (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2012']

lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy prompted elected officials to consider many ideas to prepare for storms, as varied as building protective dunes and fortifying subway stops.

lead_paragraph: Late Monday, after he posted a series of tweets blaming divisions among Western allies for the failure to strike a deal over Iran’s nuclear program last weekend, the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, went on state television in Tehran to discuss the state of the negotiations.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Confessions of a Fake Web Traffic Buyer, and the False Promise of Classroom Technology
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the web include going inside of advertising technology fraud and a report of how tablets and technology may not be the revolutionary educational tools we thought them to be.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Jarrett Promises Outreach to Business Leaders
abstract: Valerie Jarrett, a senior adviser to President Obama, pointed out that “millions of Americans” have already benefited from the health care law.

headline: William Pollack Dies at 87; His Vaccine Saved Infants
abstract: Dr. Pollack, a medical researcher, helped develop a vaccine for a blood disorder commonly called Rh disease.
lead_paragraph: William Pollack, a medical researcher who helped develop a vaccine that virtually eradicated a disease once responsible for 10,000 infant deaths a year in the United States, died on Nov. 3 in Yorba Linda, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Czech Politician Faces Claims of Aiding Secret Police
abstract: Andrej Babis, a billionaire who was a surprise kingmaker in recent elections, denies allegations that he was an agent for the reviled Czechoslovak secret police.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Andrej Babis, a populist billionaire who handed out doughnuts to voters at subway stations, emerged as a surprise kingmaker in the recent Czech elections by fashioning himself as a self-made outsider who would stamp out corruption and sleaze.

headline: Let Them Eat Cake
abstract: Sometimes those demanding sacrifice from others should consider appearances.
lead_paragraph: No doubt demands to hold down wages and expenses are perfectly reasonable in many instances.

headline: John Tavener Dies at 69; Composer With Eye on God
abstract: Mr. Tavener, a composer informed by Orthodox Christianity, was heard throughout the world in his elegy, performed at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales.
lead_paragraph: John Tavener, a British composer known for his meditative, sometimes passionate sacred works and colorfully scored orchestral pieces — including the popular cello concerto “The Protecting Veil,” and the haunting “Song for Athene,” which was performed at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales — died on Tuesday at his home in Child Okeford, in southern England. He was 69.

headline: Born in Protest, a Soccer Team Hailed by the People and the Government
abstract: Mouloudia, founded nearly 100 years ago and Algeria’s most popular soccer team, was a force in the war for independence from France and is a powerful political tool.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — They have a reputation for smashing everything in their wake. Their nickname is the Chnawa, literally “the Chinese,” a politically incorrect reference not only to their large numbers but also to their reputation as an unstoppable horde.

headline: The Passion (and the Politics) of an Algerian Soccer Team
abstract: Mouloudia Algiers, called the beating heart of the nation, is deeply tied to Algeria’s history and politics. The club is by far the most popular team in the country.
lead_paragraph: Mouloudia Algiers, called the beating heart of the nation, is deeply tied to Algeria’s history and politics. The club is by far the most popular team in the country.

headline: At $142.4 Million, Triptych Is the Most Expensive Artwork Ever Sold at an Auction
abstract: The 1969 triptych, “Three Studies of Lucian Freud,” sold for $142.4 million at Christie’s, described as the highest price ever paid for an artwork at auction.
lead_paragraph: It took seven superrich bidders to propel a 1969 Francis Bacon triptych to $142.4 million at Christie’s on Tuesday night, making it the most expensive work of art ever sold at auction. William Acquavella, the New York dealer, is thought to have bought the painting on behalf of an unidentified client, from one of Christie’s skyboxes overlooking the auction.

headline: Private Donors’ Funds Add Wild Card to War in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The flow of millions of dollars in private money to extremist fighters has added an unpredictable factor to the war, analysts say, exacerbating divisions in the opposition.
lead_paragraph: AL SUBAYHIYAH, Kuwait — The money flows in via bank transfer or is delivered in bags or pockets bulging with cash. Working from his sparely furnished sitting room here, Ghanim al-Mteiri gathers the funds and transports them to Syria for the rebels fighting President Bashar al-Assad.

lead_paragraph: Ray Venezia, master butcher and Fairway Market meat consultant, shows how to carve a turkey.

headline: Federal Regulators Unveil Rules on Their Sometime Proxies, Bank Consultants
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Consultants', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency has adopted rules for how banks employ the groups sometimes called Wall Street’s “shadow regulators.”
lead_paragraph: Private bank consultants, long known as Wall Street’s shadow regulators, are now facing some regulation of their own.

headline: Bloomberg Says News Service Did Not Kill Articles on China
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Bloomberg News, a unit of the company owned by Michael R. Bloomberg, was accused of withholding articles that were unflattering to Chinese officials.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday insisted that Bloomberg News, which he owns, did not censor itself by killing two articles related to China. But he also asserted that, for at least a couple more months, he is not involved with the news service because of his role as mayor.

headline: In Court, Baldwin Tells of Stalker ‘Out of Hitchcock’
abstract: At the harassment trial of Genevieve Sabourin, Alec Baldwin testified she had arrived uninvited at his East Hampton mansion in March 2012 and ruined his marriage proposal.
lead_paragraph: Alec Baldwin can always be counted on to give a good performance, whether on television or on the witness stand, and his testimony in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday was no exception.

headline: When the Police Enter a Home
abstract: Warrantless searches of “the center of the private lives of our people” should be strictly limited by the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: The home is “at the very core” of the Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable government intrusion, as the Supreme Court has said repeatedly. It is where a person’s expectation of privacy is greatest.

headline: New U.N. Brigade’s Aggressive Stance in Africa Brings Success, and Risks
abstract: The Force Intervention Brigade routed rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a departure from peacekeepers’ usually passive approach.
lead_paragraph: KIWANJA, Democratic Republic of Congo — When Martin Kobler, the newly appointed United Nations representative, arrived this summer for his first visit to this small but strategic town, armed members of the M23 rebel group lined the airstrip, silently watching him land and disembark. Their presence sent an unmistakable message: the rebels, not Congolese officials, controlled Kiwanja.

headline: Hands Off the Ball, or Risk a Technical Foul
abstract: The N.B.A. has put new emphasis on a longstanding rule that prohibits players from holding the ball or redirecting it after a successful field goal. It is known as the delay-of-game penalty.
lead_paragraph: Professional basketball players can contort their bodies like acrobats and power through defenses like bulldozers, but many of these athletes have found themselves completely flummoxed this season by a rule so fundamental that it sounds as if it were designed for third graders: Leave the ball alone.

headline: Agony in the Philippines
keywords: ['Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Global Warming', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Editorials', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: After one of the worst typhoons on record hit the country, many are offering aid, but relief efforts are hampered by the scale of the damage.
lead_paragraph: Five days after one of the worst typhoons on record hit the Philippines, the magnitude of the catastrophe is barely captured in the preliminary statistics: nearly 2,000 people listed as dead and many thousands more missing; more than 600,000 people displaced; countless homes and roads crushed by surging water.

headline: A Living Wage in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Living Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Editorials', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The government should raise the minimum pay for garment workers and index it to inflation.
lead_paragraph: The government of Bangladesh is expected to soon announce an increase in the minimum wage for workers in the country’s clothing factories, which are big suppliers to Western retailers like Walmart and H&M. Its decision could improve the lives of millions of families that struggle to eke out an existence on as little as the equivalent of about $38 a month, the current minimum wage.

headline: Fairness for College Athletes
abstract: The amateur model in college sports is in serious trouble, with a federal district judge certifying a class-action suit against the N.C.A.A.
lead_paragraph: The amateur model in college sports is in serious trouble, with a federal district judge on Friday certifying a class-action suit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Under N.C.A.A. rules, student athletes may not receive compensation — a policy that effectively blocks players from entering into group licensing agreements. The N.C.A.A., however, sells the names and images of players for use in game footage, photographs and video games.

headline: Tribe Claims Approval for Martha’s Vineyard Casino, Reviving Fight
abstract: State and local governments have maintained that the tribe, the Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (Aquinnah), forfeited its right to build a casino on the Vineyard in the 1980s when it agreed to a land settlement.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — An Indian tribe on Martha’s Vineyard said Tuesday that it had obtained approval from a federal agency to open a casino on tribal land on the resort island, but others challenged that conclusion and said the tribe had no such authority.

headline: Goodbye, Boston; Hello, Manager of the Year
abstract: Terry Francona, who helped the Cleveland Indians improve by 24 games and reach the playoffs for the first time in six years, was named American League manager of the year on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: In his eight eventful seasons with the Boston Red Sox, Terry Francona never received a first-place vote for the Manager of the Year award. This was mostly a function of the way voters judge managers, rewarding those perceived to do more with less. The Red Sox always had high payrolls and thus high expectations.

headline: Missouri’s Governor Calls for End to Contest of Incentives
abstract: The governor, Jay Nixon, urged an end to incentives that lure jobs from one state to the other, rather than luring new jobs to the region.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The long-running competition for jobs between Kansas and Missouri that has elicited all manner of battlefield imagery about arming and disarming, border wars and turf battles now has Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri signaling for a new one: truce.

headline: Stop Penalizing Poor College Students
keywords: ['Pell Grants', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Tuition', 'Community Colleges', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Income']
abstract: The way the Pell grant program is designed makes it harder for low-income students to graduate on schedule.
lead_paragraph: THE Pell grant program is the federal government’s main strategy for helping low-income students finish college, but the way the program is designed makes it harder for those same students to graduate on schedule.

headline: End of Proposal to Raise Skyline on the East Side
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration is withdrawing its proposal to rezone a 73-block area with glass towers after facing opposition from a City Council with a more liberal vision.
lead_paragraph: Opposition in the City Council and an incoming mayor intent on imposing a more liberal vision have dealt a fatal blow to the Bloomberg administration’s final plan to recast the New York City skyline with a new crop of office towers in East Midtown that would rise higher than the Chrysler Building.

headline: What About US?
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Iran nuclear deal that the Obama team is trying to forge now is fundamentally in the United States’ interest.
lead_paragraph: It goes without saying that the only near-term deal with Iran worth partially lifting sanctions for would be a deal that freezes all the key components of Iran’s nuclear weapons development program, and the only deal worth lifting all sanctions for is one that verifiably restricts Iran’s ability to breakout and build a nuclear bomb.

headline: Rethinking Parent-Teacher Conferences
abstract: Should schools bring parents in more often? Less often? Or try a whole new approach?

headline: Starbucks to Pay Kraft $2.75 Billion, Ending Broken-Deal Dispute
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Coffee', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: The disagreement centered on the way Starbucks broke off its long-term relationship with Kraft three years ago over Kraft’s objections.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks said on Tuesday that it would pay Kraft Foods $2.75 billion, ending a long-running spat over an agreement the two food titans had for distribution of Starbucks packaged coffee in grocery stores.

headline: Most Federal Storm Aid Still Undistributed in New Jersey
abstract: The numbers come on top of complaints about bureaucracy and a lack of transparency in Gov. Chris Christie’s recovery efforts after Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: As the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy approached, the Christie administration had distributed only about a quarter of the $1.2 billion that the federal government had awarded to help New Jersey homeowners and renters recover from the storm.

headline: As the Living Receive Aid, Bodies Remain Uncollected in the Philippines
abstract: Although the authorities have been criticized for not doing more to collect remains, the dead were not considered carriers of germs that can infect the living.
lead_paragraph: The corpses of Typhoon Haiyan, which have been part of the ravaged landscape of the central Philippines for days and nauseated survivors as they walk past, are among the stark images from the disaster that struck last week. But medical experts say the unburied dead are not a significant public health hazard.

headline: Scorned by His Fellow Musicians, a Refugee From Iran Was Looking to Kill
abstract: Ali Akbar Mohammadi Rafie, who killed three men from his homeland on Monday and then took his own life, had grown increasingly isolated before the shootings.
lead_paragraph: They were so tight-knit that some thought they were brothers, and in a way, they were: Fleeing Iran together to pursue music and art in Brooklyn, the bandmates of the Yellow Dogs and their friends had formed a fraternity of Iranian expatriates who lived, sang and cooked together.

headline: Doping Rules Are Tougher Only if Applied
abstract: The World Anti-Doping Agency’s decision to change its ban for athletes caught doping from two years to four has focused attention on the diligence of countries’ drug testing programs.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The World Anti-Doping Agency, the organization that oversees the antidoping effort in Olympic sports, is set to adopt a new set of rules when it meets here this week for its World Conference on Doping in Sport.

lead_paragraph: Your guide to the year’s most important meal, with our best recipes, videos, techniques and tricks.

abstract: President Xi Jinping wants to shift the economy away from heavy polluting industries, volatile social divisions and state-driven infrastructure spending.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping of China emerged from a Communist Party leadership conference on Tuesday with a mandate to give the market a “decisive role” in the world’s second-largest economy and to consolidate new decision-making authority in his own hands.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve over the next four years, has championed the idea that the Fed can stimulate the economy simply by speaking clearly.

abstract: The investigation into the health law rollout has turned into a nasty public relations war that will be on full display at Wednesday’s hearing of the House oversight committee, chaired by Representative Darrell Issa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Darrell Issa has long been known on Capitol Hill as one of the most aggressive — some would say overzealous — thorns in the side of Obama administration, using his seat as chairman of the House oversight committee to trumpet any missteps that can be traced to the White House.

headline: Rivals Unite in Jordan’s Surprising World Cup Run
abstract: Jordan’s soccer team is two games from qualifying for the World Cup with a roster that reflects the country’s schism between East Bank Jordanians and citizens of Palestinian origin.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Jordan’s royal past, present and future look down on the grass field at Amman International Stadium from all angles. Below huge color portraits of King Abdullah II, his father, King Hussein, and his teenage son, the crown prince, the national soccer team’s players trained Tuesday ahead of the game of their lives: a World Cup intercontinental playoff against Uruguay, the South American champion, on Wednesday night.

lead_paragraph: It is the first tower completed on the original World Trade Center site.

headline: Iran Talks Face Resistance in U.S. Congress
abstract: The Obama administration is trying to stop efforts in Congress to impose new sanctions on Iran that the White House fears could derail negotiations in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After having come tantalizingly close over the weekend to an agreement to freeze Iran’s nuclear program, the Obama administration is gingerly weighing a threat to the talks potentially more troublesome than the opaque leadership in Tehran: Congress.

headline: House Stalls Trade Pact Momentum
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Nearly half of the members of the House of Representatives have signed letters signaling opposition to “fast track” authority for a trade pact with Pacific Rim nations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is rushing to reach a new deal intended to lower barriers to trade with a dozen Pacific Rim nations, including Japan and Canada, before the end of the year.

headline: The Joy of Cooking
abstract: Put on your chef’s hat for this Wednesday puzzle by Jean O’Conor.
lead_paragraph: We’re up to Wednesday already and now we’re cooking with oil, as Jean O’Conor serves up a puzzle with a full recipe inside. The recipe’s instructions are broken up into five parts with the sixth and final theme answer revealing the mystery dish. So let’s gather round the TABLE and get started.
