headline: Funny, How Gravity Pulls Us, and the Safety Net Is an Illusion
abstract: With Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon in the leading roles, Samuel Beckett’s “All That Fall” comes to the New York stage.
lead_paragraph: The most liberating laughter to be heard these days cascades from 59E59 Theaters, where a staged version of Samuel Beckett’s radio play “All That Fall” opened on Tuesday night. That raucous, wide-open sound comes from the mighty throats of two of the finer actors on the planet, Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon.

headline: Why Is This Thing Called Love?
abstract: Marlane Meyer’s comedy-drama “The Patron Saint of Sea Monsters,” at Playwrights Horizons, explores the seemingly inexplicable romance between a doctor and an unemployed jar factory worker.
lead_paragraph: Is there a patron saint of befuddled theatergoers? Had I known of one, I would probably have been fervently praying at intervals throughout “The Patron Saint of Sea Monsters,” a wayward, Gothic comedy-drama by Marlane Meyer that opened on Tuesday night on Playwrights Horizons’ smaller stage.

headline: Kjell Qvale Dies at 94; Married U.S. to Sports Cars
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'International Trade and World Market', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: Mr. Qvale imported the MG from England in the late 1940s and helped start an American sports car craze that he later nurtured by bringing in Aston Martins, Austin-Healeys, Jaguars and even Rolls-Royce.
lead_paragraph: Kjell Qvale, who fell in love with a forest-green, wire-wheel MG sports car in the 1940s and went on to become one of the earliest American importers of European cars, ultimately selling a million automobiles as a distributor and dealer, died on Nov. 1 in San Francisco. He was 94.

headline: Protecting Your Children’s Credit, Even Before They Have Any
abstract: Children’s personal information is valued by identity thieves because there typically isn’t a credit file with the data, so they can create a false one.
lead_paragraph: IF you want to make sure your personal information isn’t at risk from identity thieves, you can ask to have a security freeze placed on your credit file at the three major credit bureaus — Experian, Equifax and TransUnion. That prevents lenders or credit card companies (that you aren’t already doing business with) from gaining access to the information and in effect shuts down the chance of unauthorized credit being issued.

headline: The Day My Son Went Missing
abstract: Even as an advocate for children with autism, I couldn’t keep my own son safe.
lead_paragraph: NOW in its sixth week, the search for Avonte Oquendo, a 14-year-old boy from Queens with autism, is shining a light on the issue of wandering among people with autism. On Oct. 4, Avonte managed to slip away after lunch from his school in Long Island City — even though he was known to wander during classroom transitions.

headline: Around the World for a Ticket to the World Cup
abstract: Over the next week, 22 teams playing 17 matches will compete for the final 11 spots in the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The qualifying process for next year’s World Cup, which began almost unnoticed more than two years ago with Belize’s 5-2 victory over Montserrat, will conclude over the next week with 22 teams playing 17 matches for the final 11 spots.

headline: World Cup Playoffs on TV
abstract: Twenty-two teams, 17 games, 11 spots in next year’s World Cup in Brazil are up for grabs over the next week.
lead_paragraph: Submitted for your approval (and viewing pleasure) a list of the various outlets that will be carrying the final week of qualifying matches for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil (a handful of friendlies, including the United States’ games at Scotland and Austria are not included here).

headline: Egypt: Government Delays Ending State of Emergency and Curfew
abstract: Egypt’s interim government said a state of emergency, as well as a nighttime curfew, would remain in place until it had received formal notice of a judicial ruling Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Egypt’s interim government said that it would abide by a judicial ruling on Tuesday ending a three-month state of emergency, which was imposed after the authorities stormed two Islamist sit-ins in August. Late Tuesday, however, the government said the state of emergency, as well as a nighttime curfew, would remain in place until it had received formal notice of the decision. The curfew and the state of emergency were aimed at curbing demonstrations by supporters of President Mohamed Morsi, who was ousted by the military in July. Human rights activists have expressed concern that the military-backed government intends to simply replace the state of emergency with legislation aimed at stifling dissent, including an antiterrorism law, as well as a protest law that rights groups have warned would essentially criminalize demonstrations.

headline: Mobster’s Trial Opens in ’97 Killing of Officer
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said Joel Cacace violated a Mafia rule when he ordered hit men to kill Officer Ralph C. Dols.
lead_paragraph: It is among the strongest tenets of the Mafia code: Never kill a police officer. But a prosecutor told jurors in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday that a former mobster ordered his hit men to do just that.

headline: New U.N. Rights Council Members Are Elected
abstract: The United Nations General Assembly elected China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Vietnam, Cuba and nine others to fill seats on the Human Rights Council.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations General Assembly elected China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Vietnam, Cuba and nine others on Tuesday to fill 14 seats for three-year terms on the 47-member Human Rights Council, the body that evaluates and investigates the rights records of United Nations member states. Western rights groups were particularly offended that China, Russia and Saudi Arabia won seats even though those countries have refused to allow the council’s investigators to examine complaints of abuse. The council, based in Geneva, has often been accused of hypocrisy and double standards, depending on the countries targeted for investigation. The other nations chosen on Tuesday were Algeria, Britain, France, the Maldives, Macedonia, Mexico, Morocco, Namibia and South Africa.

headline: Massachusetts: Hearing in Marathon Bombing Case
abstract: Government prosecutors said that United States Attorney Carmen Ortiz would recommend to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. this week whether the marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev should face the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: Government prosecutors said Tuesday that United States Attorney Carmen Ortiz would recommend to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. this week whether the marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev should face the death penalty. Mr. Tsarnaev faces 30 charges related to accusations that he worked with his older brother, Tamerlan, to detonate bombs at the marathon on April 15, killing three people and injuring more than 260. (Tamerlan Tsarnaev was killed after a firefight with the police). Prosecutors asked Judge George A. O’Toole Jr. of Federal District Court for a fall 2014 date for Mr. Tsarnaev’s trial, which they estimated would take 90 days, but Judge O’Toole declined to set a start date. Mr. Tsarnaev’s defense lawyers argued that prosecutors were withholding evidence, including information about a 2011 triple murder in Waltham to which Tamerlan Tsarnaev has been linked. Judge O’Toole took that matter, and a motion that would ease some prison restrictions on Mr. Tsarnaev, under advisement.

headline: Holyfield’s Mansion Is a Home Sale Heavyweight
abstract: Saddled with debt, the retired world champion boxer is forced to put a behemoth on the market.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ga. — Immense and opulent, the home seems fit for a king. Its address leaves no doubt about the identity of its longtime owner and resident: 794 Evander Holyfield Highway.

headline: Some State Insurance Exchanges Continue to Battle Technical Problems
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Six weeks into the rollout of the health care law, some of the online insurance exchanges run by states are confronting serious issues that mirror those of the larger federal exchange.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks into the rollout of President Obama’s new health care law, some of the online insurance exchanges run by states are continuing to have serious technological problems, often mirroring the issues plaguing the much larger federal exchange.

headline: Weisbrod Brings Long Résumé to Advise the Mayor-Elect
abstract: Carl Weisbrod will co-lead Bill de Blasio’s transition team after being a central figure in changing the face of Times Square and the financial district.
lead_paragraph: Carl Weisbrod can barely walk a block in Times Square without being hailed by an old friend.

headline: Experience has Taught Jones Austin the Power of Community
abstract: Jennifer Jones Austin co-chairs the transition team with a vantage point informed by both the establishment and the left that also characterizes Bill de Blasio’s career.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, 2001, Jennifer Jones Austin, six months pregnant, emerged from the subway with her 3-year-old daughter, Kennedy, to find that one tower of the World Trade Center had fallen.

headline: Don’t Call Her a First Lady; Brown’s Wife Is His Top Aide
abstract: Anne Gust Brown, a lawyer by training, is often relied upon to predict what her often unpredictable husband, Gov. Jerry Brown of California, is thinking.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Anyone who spends time with Gov. Jerry Brown is familiar with his penchant for referring to philosophers, Latin or an obscure tome he has recently read, often in the same sentence. A speaker who uses what he deems an imprecise word should be prepared to listen to a soliloquy on its meaning.

headline: Ahead of Yellen’s Confirmation Hearing
abstract: Before Janet L. Yellen can take the helm of the Federal Reserve, she will have to field questions on the Fed’s stimulus plans and maintain that its policies are working.
lead_paragraph: Before Janet L. Yellen can take the helm of the Federal Reserve, she will have to field questions on the Fed’s stimulus plans and maintain that its policies are working.

headline: Executives Talk Goalies and Overtime
abstract: Fights between goaltenders and modifying the overtime format will be on the agenda when the N.H.L.’s general managers reconvene in Florida in the spring.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Two things are clear after the N.H.L.’s general managers meeting Tuesday: Fights between goaltenders and modifying the overtime format will be on the agenda when they reconvene in Florida in March.

headline: A Senator Lays Out His Positions on the Military, Very Carefully
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul spoke Tuesday at the Citadel in Charleston, S.C., sharing his opinions on military intervention, the Pentagon and cutting waste in the armed forces.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — A few months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, President George W. Bush came to the Citadel, the military college here, to lay out his plans to reconfigure the armed forces for his interventionist posture known as the Bush Doctrine.

headline: Hugs and Kisses Bridge an Emotional Distance
abstract: After being abused and stalked by her children’s father, Kim Lemon got help to protect her family and became a better mother along the way.
lead_paragraph: Kim Lemon worked hard to stay in her Brooklyn apartment, even after the father of her three children slammed her head into one of its crumbling walls. But then the man returned, threatening to do worse.

headline: Two Prep School Stars Meet, and a College Rivalry Gets Under Way
abstract: Basketball fans caught a glimpse of perhaps the next great individual basketball rivalry when Duke’s Jabari Parker and Kansas’s Andrew Wiggins faced each other Tuesday in the State Farm Champions Classic.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Next March will mark the 35th anniversary of the 1979 N.C.A.A. title game between Larry Bird’s Indiana State Sycamores and Magic Johnson’s Michigan State Spartans. The game remains one of the few instances when the undisputed top two players in college basketball competed against each other, and it is the highest-rated televised college basketball game ever.

headline: What if Race No Longer Matters in City Politics?
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Income Inequality', 'Population', 'Minorities', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The mayoral election in Boston offers clues about the future of the Democratic Party and the 2016 campaign.
lead_paragraph: The most significant development in the mayoral election in Boston earlier this month was hardly discussed: the absence of open racial animosity.

headline: Colorful History of a Power Hotel in Beijing
abstract: The Jingxi Hotel, where Chinese leaders met this week, has a colorful history hosting some of the most important gatherings in modern Chinese history.
lead_paragraph: To the untrained eye, the Jingxi Hotel, with its box-like, Soviet-style architecture dating to the late 1950s, is just like any number of buildings that line Beijing’s central east-west boulevard. But beneath its deceptively gray and drab exterior, the Jingxi may be the most concentrated unofficial seat of power in China: For the last four days, it was the site of the Third Plenum of the Communist Party’s Central Committee, where Chinese leaders tried to hammer out a reform agenda for the coming decade and beyond.

headline: The Fading Light
abstract: John Ashbery’s evocation of listlessness inspires the French artist Xavier Veilhan.
lead_paragraph: John Ashbery’s evocation of American ennui inspired the French artist Xavier Veilhan to create a paean to loved ones blurred in memory.

headline: Word of the Day | awry
abstract: This word has appeared in 218 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: awry •\ə-ˈri\• adverb and adjective

headline: Doctors Identify a New Knee Ligament
abstract: Surgeons in Belgium have identified a new knee ligament, damage to which may help explain why some common A.C.L. injuries are so unstable and slow to recover.
lead_paragraph: Last month, knee surgeons from the University Hospitals Leuven in Belgium announced that they had found a new knee ligament, one that had not previously been specifically identified despite untold numbers of past knee dissections and scans. This surprising announcement, in The Journal of Anatomy, should improve our understanding of how the knee works and why some knee surgeries disappoint and also underscores the continually astonishing complexity of human anatomy.

headline: The Slow Death of the Employer Mandate
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A Massachusetts precedent indicates that when business is given time to mount opposition, an employer mandate for health coverage may not be viable, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Eliot H. Lumbard, 88, Dies; Pursued Mob Leaders
abstract: Mr. Lumbard drew new attention to organized crime after pursuing mob figures who were found to be meeting together in a rural New York town in 1957.
lead_paragraph: Eliot H. Lumbard, a New York prosecutor and law-enforcement leader who helped expose organized crime through his investigation of the infamous Apalachin meeting of mob leaders in 1957, died on Nov. 6 in Nashua, N.H. He was 88.

headline: Logistical Hurdles Paralyze Relief Effort at the Center of a Typhoon’s Fury
abstract: In the devastated Philippine town of Tacloban, aid is piling up with no way to deliver it, fuel is plentiful but merchants are too fearful to sell it, and disposal of the dead is halted by gunfire.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Typhoon gridlock threatened rescue operations in the most devastated part of the Philippines on Wednesday, with aid piling up but few ways to distribute it, plentiful gasoline but no merchants willing to sell it, and an influx of emergency volunteers but no place to house them.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: NOON (HBO2) LOVE, MARILYN (2012) Actors and various contemporaries recite from recently discovered diaries and letters written by Marilyn Monroe, above, in what David DeWitt, writing in The New York Times, called “a respectful love letter to Monroe,” who is presented by the director, Liz Garbus, “as a sexpot, feminist and Tennessee Williams heroine come to life, noble in her respect and need for a sensitive, considerate humanity.” Some, like Glenn Close, Viola Davis and Uma Thurman, nail their readings. Others, like Ben Foster, “get a bit cringe-worthy,” Mr. DeWitt said. “But the intelligence and dynamism of Ms. Garbus’s approach could hardly fail to make you appreciate Monroe’s growth as an actor.” The documentary includes footage of Monroe performing or giving interviews. “More so,” Mr. DeWitt added, “you’ll have sympathy for the hard-working woman whose self-improvement lists included exhortations of things she ‘must’ do and ‘never’ should do.”

headline: Afghan Opium Cultivation and Production Seen Rising
abstract: Poppy cultivation and production hit record levels this year, and programs to counteract them have floundered, a new United Nations study said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite years of international effort to reel back Afghanistan’s opium culture, cultivation and production hit record levels this year, and programs to counteract them have floundered, according to a new United Nations study.

headline: China’s Vow on Market Gets Tepid Reception in Asia
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: President Xi Jinping’s investor-friendly talk after a key leadership meeting failed to impress the Asian business community, with complaints that it was long on goals but short on details.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Asian business community’s initial reaction on Wednesday to the highly anticipated pronouncement of China’s Communist Party leaders on how to overhaul China’s economy was basically this: “long on goals and short on details,” “broad-brushed,” falling “some way short” of expectations.

headline: News Quiz | November 13, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: New Bravo Deal Means More of Andy Cohen
abstract: The network extended Mr. Cohen’s late-night talk show for two years and gave his production company a deal to develop new prime-time programming.
lead_paragraph: Andy Cohen is the most identifiable talent on the Bravo cable channel, thanks to his successful weeknight talk show, “Watch What Happens Live.” But while talk-show host has been his public identity, he also has worked full time as one of the top corporate executives at Bravo.

headline: China Elected to United Nations Human Rights Council
abstract: Saying it would “oppose pressure and confrontation” on the United Nations Human Rights Council and advance the cause of human rights, China was elected to it for a three-year term along with Cuba, Saudi Arabia and Russia.
lead_paragraph: China has won a seat on the United Nations Human Rights Council for three years starting in January 2014, one of 14 countries chosen to join the 47-member council on Tuesday, the United Nations said. It was selected in a “single, secret ballot” by 176 of 193 nations in the organization’s General Assembly, according to a press release.

headline: Staying on the Farm
abstract: As urbanization creeps up, the reasons farmers resist leaving their fields include not just disputes over compensation, but also attachment to their ancestral lands and local deities.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, a common story in China has been of “nail houses” — of homeowners who refuse to leave their houses even as the rest of their neighborhood is torn down. Often these are solitary holdouts, and their houses look like a nail sticking up on a board.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 13, 2013
abstract: Can you calculate the number of applications that are submitted to colleges and universities through the Common Application?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Fun Facts About Female Science Pioneers
abstract: According to a new exhibition, “Extraordinary Women in Science and Medicine,” what were some of the “deeply entrenched biases” female pioneers in science had to overcome?
lead_paragraph: In “Honoring Female Pioneers in Science,” Denise Grady writes about a new exhibit full of “tantalizing and little-known details.”

headline: Typhoon Haiyan and the Climate Talks
abstract: Pushing for a stronger treaty on climate change, some participants are arguing that global warming is responsible for the strength of the typhoon that struck the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Pushing for a stronger treaty on climate change, some participants are arguing that global warming is responsible for the strength of the typhoon that struck the Philippines.

headline: Chinatown Surprise
abstract: The oddest (and best) dish at Spicy Village makes for extraordinary home cooking.
lead_paragraph: On the advice of two friends, I wandered one day into Spicy Village, in Manhattan’s Chinatown, a restaurant that politeness prevents me from describing as anything other than “modest.” I stopped by a couple of years ago to have the not-at-all-bad $2 pork sandwich, a pile of sloppy-Joe-ish pork served on light, crisp bread baked by the proprietors — Wendy Lian and her husband, Ren Fu Li — but I rarely thought of it again.

headline: What Is the Value of Stolen Art?
abstract: Making money from stolen paintings — particularly famous ones — is not a straightforward matter.
lead_paragraph: Making money from stolen paintings — particularly famous ones — is not a straightforward matter, and those who try to do so fall broadly into two categories. The first, most common type is the naïf, who steals a painting but has laid few plans beyond the theft itself. He soon discovers that the painting’s notoriety has rendered it toxic, and he can’t sell it. The work of art becomes burdensome and worthless — to him at least. A more sophisticated criminal, on the other hand, recognizes that a pilfered masterpiece is a unique commodity and that in order to profit from it, he needs to think more like a derivatives trader than a pickpocket.

headline: Sikh Farmers in Stalin’s Birthplace
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Photography', 'Sikhs and Sikhism']
abstract: Sikhs from India farming in the former Soviet republic of Georgia make up an arresting visual and cultural juxtaposition that the photographer Ivor Prickett could not resist exploring.
lead_paragraph: When Ivor Prickett first heard that hundreds of Sikh farmers were moving from northern India to the former Soviet republic of Georgia, all sorts of images came into his head. He had spent time with ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a disputed breakaway region, and had trouble picturing Sikhs mixing easily.

headline: What Would You Outsource if You Could?
abstract: If you could pay someone to do up to three tasks for you on a regular basis, what would you choose? Why?
lead_paragraph: A recent column in The Times Magazine argues that we shouldn’t consider paying someone to do tasks for us to be a privilege reserved only for royalty or oil sheikhs. Instead, economists say it might be worth our money to free up some time spent on drudgery to be used instead for activities that can advance our educations or careers.

headline: Final Innings for a Cricket Giant
abstract: Sachin Tendulkar will play his final test for India starting Thursday, exiting as a player who carried the expectations of a nation for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: The Indian cricket star Sachin Tendulkar’s ability to generate mind-numbing statistics has survived to the very end of his prodigious career. When tickets for his 200th and final five-day test match went on sale on Monday, 19.7 million hits within the first hour crashed the website selling them.

headline: New York Today: Skyward
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: a peek inside 4 World Trade Center, frigid weather and an extremely expensive painting.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:33 a.m. | This morning, Mayor Bloomberg will cut a ribbon and declare 4 World Trade Center open for business.

headline: U.S. Investigates Anti-Semitism Claims at Pine Bush Schools
abstract: The office of a federal prosecutor, Preet Bharara, said it was looking into whether the New York State district had discriminated against students.
lead_paragraph: The United States attorney’s office for the Southern District of New York has opened a civil rights investigation into allegations of anti-Semitic harassment of children in the Pine Bush Central School District.

headline: Where the Gods Live On ... and On
abstract: India lacks a tradition of graceful retirement. Just look at Sachin, its famous cricket star.
lead_paragraph: A POPULAR Indian historian once remarked to me that India is a country where men don’t age well, and of no one is this observation truer than of Sachin Ramesh Tendulkar, a man who is, at 40 years and some 200 days, the oldest member of India’s cricket team.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Indian Army Chief Gen. Vijay Kumar Singh
abstract: Former Indian Army Chief Gen. Vijay Kumar Singh on India-Pakistan relations and corruption in the Indian military establishment.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Vijay Kumar Singh was the chief of the Indian Army from March 2010 to May 2012. His tenure ended on a bitter note after a dispute over his date of birth and consequent date of retirement from the military service. Mr. Singh disagreed with the Indian government and went to the Supreme Court of India, where he lost his case.

headline: New Chinese Panel Said to Oversee Domestic Security and Foreign Policy
abstract: China’s new national security committee, which is expected to be led by President Xi Jinping, will deal with cybersecurity, relations with Tibet and unrest in the Xinjiang region, Chinese experts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s new national security committee is mainly based on the Washington model. It will put at the disposal of the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, a highly empowered group of security experts who can work the levers of the country’s vast security apparatus — and presumably respond more nimbly than the country’s multilayered party, police and military bureaucracies have been known to do.

headline: U.S. Offers Reward in Wildlife-Trade Fight
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'ANIMALS', 'United States International Relations', 'Rhinoceroses', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Ivory', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Smuggling']
abstract: In what officials said was the first time such a reward had been offered, the State Department said it was targeting a syndicate based in Laos.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Taking a page from the battle against international drug cartels, the United States announced on Wednesday a $1 million reward for information to help dismantle one of Asia’s largest wildlife-trafficking syndicates.

headline: Microsoft Abolishes Employee Evaluation System
abstract: The company said it was ending a longstanding practice called “stack ranking,” which required managers to grade their subordinates on a bell curve. In its place, Microsoft says it will use a more flexible system that encourages better collaboration among employees.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE – Imagine getting a grade-point average, but instead of being judged by a teacher who has worked with you throughout the year, you are evaluated by a bunch of teachers, some of whom may not know you very well.

headline: Attack on Israeli Worsens Tensions With Palestinians
abstract: The killing of the soldier, reportedly by a Palestinian teenager, injected further uncertainty into peace talks, already in deep crisis over Israeli settlement plans in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian teenager fatally stabbed a 19-year-old Israeli soldier on a bus in northern Israel on Wednesday, according to the police, shocking Israelis who have grown unused to such killings in their cities and further clouding a peace process that was already severely strained by Israeli settlement plans in the West Bank.

headline: Airline Merger on Track to Close
abstract: The merger of American Airlines and US Airways now appears all but certain. | A 9-year-old girl may change the way nonprofits are run. | Fantex, the start-up promoting initial public offerings of football stars, said it was putting off its stock offering of Arian Foster.
lead_paragraph: The planned merger of American Airlines and US Airways became all but certain on Tuesday after the airlines reached a deal with the Justice Department two weeks before a scheduled trial, Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew report in The New York Times. The deal, coming after months of setbacks and delays, paves the way for the creation of a third major global airline that can compete with United Airlines and Delta Air Lines.

headline: The Gift at an Ending
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Baby Boomers', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: My mother at the extraordinary age of 99 was “winding down” and faraway. But then my husband, a doctor, sat down at her bedside and started cracking jokes.
lead_paragraph: On a morose Sunday afternoon, my husband and I arrived at my mother’s apartment. Earlier that morning we had received “the call.” “This is it,” my sister said. “Mom’s in a coma.” The family had assembled in a somber vigil.

headline: Damien Hirst and Alexander McQueen, Together at Last
abstract: To commemorate the 10th anniversary of the brand’s iconic skull scarves, the artist designed 30 kaleidoscopic styles based on a butterfly motif.

abstract: Since 2005, the bassist for the band Franz Ferdinand has captured over 320 images of himself in hotel rooms around the world. Here are a few of his greatest hits.

headline: The Gun Report: November 13, 2013
abstract: The victims of gun violence I have written about in this space have been strangers. On Monday, that changed.
lead_paragraph: The victims of gun violence we write about in this space are strangers. We feel for their plight and empathize with their loved ones, but we do not know them. That changed for me on Monday, when I pulled up the Times homepage and read about the death of someone I knew.

headline: A Moment of Love, Before a Goodbye
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A final embrace on his birthday before she went abroad is made more memorable by a pot salesman.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Petrobras of Brazil Sells Peruvian Unit to Chinese Company
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The sale by Petrobras of its Peruvian subsidiary, Petrobras Energia Peru, to the China National Petroleum Company for $2.6 billion, is aimed at shoring up Petrobras’s balance sheet.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – Brazil’s state-controlled oil company Petrobras announced on Wednesday that it was selling all of its Peruvian subsidiary, Petrobras Energia Peru, to the China National Petroleum Company for $2.6 billion.

headline: Hector Sants Resigns From Barclays
abstract: Barclays says Hector W. Sants will not return to his post as compliance chief after taking a leave of absence because of exhaustion and stress last month.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:38 a.m. |

headline: ‘Fifty Shades’ Film Release Is Pushed to 2015
abstract: Universal Pictures said its adaptation of the best-selling erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey” would be moved to February 2015. The film was initially scheduled for Aug. 1.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The movie masses will have to wait a little longer for “Fifty Shades of Grey.”

headline: Motorola to Offer Moto G Smartphone Aimed at Emerging Markets
abstract: The company, now owned by Google, will begin selling a $180 smartphone called the Moto G in markets like Brazil, Chile and Peru, where the appeal of a low-cost device should be high.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, is still trying to find its niche in the smartphone market.

headline: The Fallen Hero of Serbian Tennis
abstract: Viktor Troicki has struck bottom after being barred from tennis for failing to provide a mandatory blood sample for a doping control in April.
lead_paragraph: The first time Serbia was in a Davis Cup final, Viktor Troicki won the decisive match in Belgrade and experienced what he still calls “the biggest moment” of his life.

headline: Bank of England Hints at Rate Increase, Citing Recovery
abstract: Britain’s inflation is slowing and unemployment is down, signaling an economic recovery that is gaining speed, the central bank said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it might consider raising interest rates earlier than previously expected because Britain’s economic recovery was gaining speed.

headline: Germany’s Neighbors Admonish It Over Surplus
abstract: The country, which has often criticized other European nations about their debts and lack of competitiveness, now finds its own economic policy under attack.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Germany, which has often scolded other countries for accumulating too much debt and not being competitive enough in the global economy, now finds its own economic policy under heavy attack.

headline: Daily Report: Motorola’s Low-End Smartphone Faces Challenges
abstract: The new phone, the relatively bulky and expensive Moto G, will lack access to Google’s app store in China, the largest of the markets for cheaper handsets.
lead_paragraph: Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, is still trying to find its niche in the smartphone market, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: An Entrepreneur Who Manufactures Entrepreneurs
abstract: A personality test is the first step for a student applying to the Founder Institute, which offers a kind of entrepreneurial immersion education.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom holds that some 90 percent of start-ups fail. After years of observation, Adeo Ressi — a serial entrepreneur who founded TheFunded.com, an online community where entrepreneurs rate investors; Methodfive, a website developer; and Total New York, which became AOL Digital Cities — concluded that the high failure rate was the result of the wrong people starting businesses and not getting the right training.

headline: How I Made My Biggest Mistake in China (So Far)
abstract: An unwitting breach of etiquette gained the writer a reputation for being conceited and self-important — which she’s heard from many people with no firsthand knowledge of the situation.
lead_paragraph: Every book on doing business in China touts the importance of building personal connections and “guanxi.”

headline: Ukraine Delays Bill to Free Ex-Leader
abstract: The Ukraine Parliament’s postponement of a bill to free the jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, threatens to derail negotiations for closer ties with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a move that could derail plans for Ukraine to sign political and free trade agreements with the European Union this month, the country’s Parliament on Wednesday postponed consideration of a bill that would free the jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, and allow her to seek medical treatment in Germany.

headline: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 2
keywords: ['Genealogy', 'Archives and Records', 'Baby Boomers', 'Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Slavery', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist, discusses “memory holes” created by the Holocaust, record-keeping systems and other issues related to genealogy.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers’ questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members. Part 1 of her answers is here. [Update: Part 3 is here. Part 4 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

headline: Is This the Way to Teach Entrepreneurship?
abstract: The Founder Institute claims to have flipped the failure rate of the start-ups it works with to 10 percent, from 90 percent generally.
lead_paragraph: The Times has just published a conversation with Adeo Ressi, who created the Founder Institute. In the conversation, Mr. Ressi reports that more than 1,000 aspiring entrepreneurs have graduated from his start-up incubator, each with a new company idea. Of those companies, about 10 percent have failed and 15 percent have gone dormant, Mr. Ressi said, while the rest are moving forward.

headline: In Experienced Hands
abstract: Grandmothers and grandfathers are at the center of the action in two new picture books.
lead_paragraph: Compared with parents, who are sometimes stressed, distracted and short of sleep, grandparents are, at least by reputation, a relaxed and indulgent set; tolerant of youthful enthusiasm and well rested at last after their own adventures in child rearing.

headline: Attacks Across Iraq Kill Dozens
abstract: At least 27 people were killed on Wednesday in a series of bomb blasts and gunfire attacks that stretched to the northern cities of Tikrit and Mosul and to the regions west of Baghdad and Falluja.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A series of bomb blasts and gunfire attacks swept Iraq on Wednesday, mostly targeting Shiites who were marking one of their holiest religious events.

headline: Image of the Day: November 13
abstract: Widows in Bhubaneshwar, Odisha, observing the Hindu festival of Kartik Poornima.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Dior Scorpio Necklace
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a zodiac pendant that makes for a personal gift.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Former Lobbyist Becomes Biden Chief of Staff
abstract: Steve Ricchetti, a senior aide to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., will become his chief of staff in December, the administration said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Steve Ricchetti, a former lobbyist and Clinton administration veteran, will replace Bruce Reed as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s chief of staff next month, the White House announced Wednesday.

headline: Zombies in His Past, Now Onto Cops
abstract: After leaving “The Walking Dead” following a dispute with the show’s network, Frank Darabont is returning to television with “Mob City,” which includes the “Walking Dead” co-star Jon Bernthal.
lead_paragraph: In preparing for “Mob City,” a fictional look at the seedy underbelly of 1940s-era Los Angeles and his first new television series in three years, Frank Darabont has had to excise other favorite TV shows and movies from his regular cultural diet.

headline: Residents Suing to Stop ‘Fortresslike’ Plan for World Trade Center
keywords: ['World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A group in Lower Manhattan says that the Police Department’s plan will leave the center in “isolation” and the area around it “as impervious to traffic as the Berlin Wall.”
lead_paragraph: To the question, “How much security apparatus is needed on city streets?” the agencies charged with guarding public safety seem to answer, “As much as we say.”

headline: 1929: Seal on The Loose in Paris
abstract: From The New York Herald.
lead_paragraph: The New York Herald dedicated a fair amount of space to the smaller, curious events in its pages. When a seal escaped onto the streets of Paris, the “most serious of frivolous newspapers” reported on an argument between bystanders:

headline: ‘Maxed Out’ Author Thought Readers Would Critique Her Ideas. Instead, They Judged Her Choices.
abstract: Like many women, I found being a full-time mother with a full-time job impossibly stressful. But many readers thought that by setting better boundaries with my boss, or having a more can-do attitude, I could have made the plague of overwork affecting millions of mothers magically disappear.
lead_paragraph: When KJ Dell’Antonia’s article about my book, “Maxed Out: American Moms on the Brink,” was published on Motherlode last week (“Being a Working Mother Means Always Having to Say You’re Sorry“), I was thrilled to see it generating passionate discussion in the comments section. This is, after all, the main reason I wrote “Maxed Out” — to get people talking about the structural issues holding women back in their careers and their lives.

headline: Memory of a Mass Killing Becomes Another Casualty of Egyptian Protests
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The military-backed government’s efforts to extinguish the memory of Rabaa al-Adawiya, the worst mass killing in Egypt’s history, are extensive.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The police arrested the girls, interrogated them for hours, and then strip-searched and detained them for 10 days. They were charged with serious crimes, including endangering national security, for what the authorities regarded as an act of subversion: passing out yellow balloons.

headline: Off the Coast of Chile, an Island Getaway
abstract: Lemuy Island, in the Chiloé Archipelago, is 37 square miles of hills, farms, dirt roads and ocean views.
lead_paragraph: With only the vaguest of plans, I pulled my rental car onto the ferry to Lemuy Island, 37 square miles of hills and farms and dirt roads and ocean views. As I headed out from the main island of the Chiloé Archipelago, off the Chilean coast, I had a simple agenda for that afternoon: drive around, visit one of the old wooden churches the islands are famous for, see what else happens.

headline: Live Music Gains as a Hotel Amenity
abstract: From guitars in rooms to full-on concerts in the lobbies, hotels are making music a major amenity.
lead_paragraph: From guitars in rooms to full-on concerts in the lobbies, hotels are making music a major amenity.

headline: Schools That Separate the Child From the Trauma
abstract: Punishing children for misbehavior they don’t know how to control only adds to their suffering.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I reported on the damaging effects that prolonged stress can have on young children who lack adequate protection from adults. Over the past 15 years, researchers have learned that highly stressful — and potentially traumatic — childhood experiences are more prevalent than previously understood. Now scientists are shedding light on the mechanisms by which they change the brain and body. These insights have far-reaching implications for schools, where it’s still standard practice to punish children for misbehavior that they often do not know how to control. This is comparable to punishing a child for having a seizure; it adds to the suffering and makes matters worse.

headline: Why Stay in High School, When You Could Be Out Drinking?
abstract: Ed Bullins’s “In the Wine Time,” a drama from 1968, is full of bad advice for its orphaned young hero.
lead_paragraph: Coarse language, loose women, good-for-nothing men and rampant alcoholism are all dragging down Derby Street, the skid row of an unnamed Northern industrial city. So, unfortunately, is terrible direction.

headline: Classical Playlist: Andras Schiff, Janine Jansen, Rebekah Heller and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: In Britain, an Unlikely Call to Redistribute Cultural Capital
abstract: A British think tank published a report arguing that cultural institutions like the Royal Opera House and the British Museum should be relocated outside of London.
lead_paragraph: Imagine planning a trip to Britain with a stop to hear a new opera by Mark-Anthony Turnage at a newly built version of the Royal Opera House, not in Covent Garden, but in Liverpool. And from there, you might drive northeast to savor antiquities at the British Museum, which will have painstakingly rebuilt Sir Robert Smirke’s grand Greek Revival building in Morpeth, the county seat of Northumberland.

headline: Roundup: Staff Departures, an ‘Incorrect Promise’ and More
abstract: A variety of items from the public editor’s desk.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a roundup of items from all over that may be interesting to Times readers and to the readers of this blog:

headline: Health Website Official Tells of White House Briefings
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As lawmakers tried to find out how much the White House knew about defects in the federal health insurance website, the chief digital architect for the marketplace said he had provided status updates to the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace said Wednesday that he met periodically with White House aides to discuss the status of the website over the last three years, but he said the meetings focused narrowly on specific technical issues and therefore gave the president no clear warning of the disaster that ensued on Oct. 1.

headline: Out of Europe’s Long Jobs Crisis, Voices of the Young
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment', 'Youth', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The Times asked young people in Europe to share their stories about how the crisis has affected their lives. Here is a selection of the responses.
lead_paragraph: The Times asked young people in Europe to share their stories about how the crisis has affected their lives. Here is a selection of the responses.

headline: Murder as Musical Punch Line
abstract: “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater, finds the comedy (and the song) in serial homicide.
lead_paragraph: It’s a surprisingly fertile season on New York stages for witty variations on the nail biter, what with Beth Henley’s Southern Gothic “The Jacksonian,” the musical “Murder for Two” and John Pollono’s comic thriller “Small Engine Repair.”  Now comes another show to remind us, as Alfred Hitchcock was so fond of doing, that dark and deadly intrigue need not be deadly serious.

headline: Does Individual Insurance Work?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Or did insurers inevitably rescind coverage, pre-Obamacare, as soon as you got sick?
lead_paragraph: Amid this week’s hints that the federal exchange still won’t be anywhere close to functional on December 1st, Matt Yglesias offers the latest noble attempt to explain to Americans losing their individual-market coverage why they’re actually better off paying higher premiums for new, Obamacare-era plans. Instead of focusing on the more comprehensive benefits that the new plans offer, he takes a different tack — suggesting that most people with cheapish individual-market coverage didn’t really have insurance at all:

headline: An Old Guitar Finds New Life on the Internet
abstract: A quaint web series puts a funky old guitar in the hands of funky young musicians and asks them to pluck out a tune.
lead_paragraph: Connor Millican and Corey Pane, two friends from Connecticut who were playing music together and dabbling in video production, had an idea: They wanted to put a funky old guitar in the hands of some funky young musicians and ask them to pluck out a tune. While the players would vary, the guitar would be the constant, becoming a shared tool between artists with different styles and methods.

headline: Reviewing Opera Fan Fiction
abstract: Opera devotees offered their own elaborate fantasies about what happens to favorite characters after the curtain goes down.
lead_paragraph: The premise behind my article “Liberating the Librettos” was that opera-lovers inevitably become so involved with the stories of our favorite operas that we cultivate elaborate fantasies about what happens to the characters after the curtain goes down. My conviction was borne out by the insight, thoughtfulness and wit of the many comments that readers, all fellow opera-lovers, sent in.

headline: Video: ‘Annie Hall,’ the Sequel
abstract: Seen at New York City’s Union Square, Cara Araneta’s style influences include Woody Allen and Wong Kar-wai.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Cara Araneta, 32, a brand designer, was strolling along Broadway in Union Square with a friend, her hands tucked into the pockets of her high-waist jeans. Not that far from Midtown and with the East Village only a couple of blocks away, Union Square is a “mix between uptown and downtown,” Ms. Araneta said. “You see a lot of young people hanging out, like skateboards, that kind of N.Y.U. school vibe, and then you see businesspeople coming here for lunch or going to work.”

headline: Skiers Tame the Magic Kingdom
abstract: In this first episode of Behind the Line, Ian McIntosh and Sage Cattabriga-Alosa make first descents in the Neacola Mountains of Alaska.
lead_paragraph: In this first episode of Behind the Line, Ian McIntosh and Sage Cattabriga-Alosa make first descents in the Neacola Mountains of Alaska.

headline: Video: Skiers Tame the Magic Kingdom
abstract: In this first episode of Behind the Line, produced by Teton Gravity Research, Ian McIntosh and Sage Cattabriga-Alosa make first descents in the Neacola Mountains of Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Ruscha’s Archives Go to the Ransom Center in Texas
abstract: The archives of the Pop Art master Ed Ruscha will be kept and made available for researchers at the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas in Austin.
lead_paragraph: The Harry Ransom Center, a museum and research library at the University of Texas, Austin, has acquired the archives of Ed Ruscha, the prolific Pop Art master who is best known for his quirky thematic photography books, like “Twentysix Gasoline Stations” (1963) and “Every Building on the Sunset Strip” (1966), and for his word paintings, in which words are manipulated in ways that transform their meanings or suggest amusing tangential underpinnings.

headline: Woman Accused of Stalking Alec Baldwin Takes Stand to Give Her Side
abstract: Before Genevieve Sabourin testified that there had been a romance with Alec Baldwin, she made several outbursts and was ordered to jail for 30 days for contempt of court.
lead_paragraph: A woman accused of stalking Alec Baldwin took the witness stand on Wednesday to tell her story, saying Mr. Baldwin seduced her on a romantic New York date in February 2010, then wrote her for months afterward suggesting he cared for her.

abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners has hired Jonathan Prather, a managing director within Goldman Sachs’s global industrials group, as a partner in its advisory business.
lead_paragraph: Perella Weinberg Partners has hired Jonathan Prather, a managing director in Goldman Sachs’s global industrials group, as a partner in its advisory business.

headline: Chegg Falls in Debut, but Chief Remains Ebullient
abstract: As of midday on Wednesday, shares in the company, which primarily rents textbooks via its website, were down 20 percent below their initial public offering price.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:56 p.m. |

headline: At Bloomberg, Special Code Keeps Some Articles Out of China
abstract: Editors at Bloomberg News use a code to keep articles on Chinese politics and social issues away from the eyes of powerful people in China who might be offended, Bloomberg employees say.
lead_paragraph: It is called Code 204. Editors at Bloomberg News append it to an article to ensure that it does not appear on Bloomberg financial data and news terminals in mainland China. Little known outside Bloomberg, the system has been in place for more than two years, and it is used regularly to keep articles on Chinese politics and social issues away from the eyes of powerful people in China who might be offended, Bloomberg employees say.

headline: Hotel Review: Rosa Et Al Townhouse in Porto
abstract: In a city with plenty of soulless chains and hostels, the attention to detail and standout cuisine at this tastefully decorated six-room hotel make a stay memorable.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Listen Up | Three Indie Music Fixtures Venture Out on Their Own
abstract: Members of the bands Rhye, The National and Gang Gang Dance are readying solo albums this fall.
lead_paragraph: This fall, individual members of three of indie music’s most inventive bands release their own solo projects that push the limits of their signature sounds.

headline: Which iPad? It Depends. What Do You Want to Do?
abstract: The iPad Mini complements Apple’s already best-in-class tablet offerings, so deciding which one to get boils down to what you will use it for.
lead_paragraph: Apple is now selling the new iPad Mini, the smaller brother of the pleasing iPad Air, which I reviewed a couple of weeks ago. Somehow, Apple has squeezed all of the Air’s capabilities into the Mini — and by doing that, Apple has made the process of choosing an iPad easy.

headline: Coffey to Join Kramer Levin in a Return to Law Practice
abstract: Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel is expected to announce on Thursday that it has hired John P. Coffey, known as Sean, to be the chairman of its complex-litigation group.
lead_paragraph: John P. Coffey stood behind the lectern in a federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan this summer, firing off pointed questions and composing hand-drawn diagrams to defend his client, the former Goldman Sachs trader Fabrice Tourre.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Is Reviewing Discredited Benghazi Report
abstract: In a brief statement, the program says the review — which had not been mentioned before — began “the moment we confirmed there was an issue in our story.”
lead_paragraph: “60 Minutes” announced on Wednesday that it was conducting an internal review of its now discredited report on the terrorist attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Great Beauty’
abstract: Paolo Sorrentino narrates the opening sequence of his film.
lead_paragraph: The latest film from Paolo Sorrentino follows a journalist (Toni Servillo) in Rome as he reflects on his life. The film, much like its lead character, wanders around the city and focuses on many of its landmarks. In this video, Mr. Sorrentino narrates a look at the opening sequence, which suggests that the city can be so stunning to take in, that it can be deadly.

headline: Senator Joe Manchin: In His Own Words
abstract: In selections from a recent interview with Jonathan Weisman, Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, talks about sticking to his principles and the worst that can happen to a politician.
lead_paragraph: In selections from a recent interview with Jonathan Weisman, Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, talks about sticking to his principles and the worst that can happen to a politician.

headline: A Lesson From Grandfather
abstract: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia told The Times's Jonathan Weisman in a recent interview that he first learned the importance of financial responsibility when he was just a child.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia told The Times's Jonathan Weisman in a recent interview that he first learned the importance of financial responsibility when he was just a child.

headline: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims
abstract: Even as an enormous global aid effort gathered momentum, international officials expressed concern that delays could prevent supplies from reaching survivors of Typhoon Haiyan for days.
lead_paragraph: Even as an enormous global aid effort gathered momentum, international officials expressed concern that delays could prevent supplies from reaching survivors of Typhoon Haiyan for days.

headline: Dropbox Aims at Business
abstract: The popular online storage service is introducing a business version. To this increasingly crowded field, Dropbox brings some interesting security and management features, a large developer community, and perhaps most powerfully, a different take on enterprise software: The company has control, but the worker is the center of attention.
lead_paragraph: Dropbox, an online storage service that has gained 200 million consumers in five years, is heading to the office.

headline: Stand-Alone Food Section Faces Demise in Bay Area
abstract: Though the Bay Area cares greatly about food and wine, The Chronicle plans to fold the section into its lifestyle coverage by February, staff members say.
lead_paragraph: In the food-obsessed Bay Area, The San Francisco Chronicle’s food section has been as much of a city institution as the cable car, and to many San Franciscans, more useful. Over the years it has won many awards and developed a dedicated following.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Secrets of Sriracha
abstract: Trans fats and small businesses. Sheryl Sandberg shares a must-see video on sexism. The Washington, D.C. start-up scene is thriving. The Wahlberg family restaurant becomes a reality TV show.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A High Five and a Handshake for Aether and Icebreaker
abstract: Performance wear and activewear may have little to do with actual fashion. But style oozes into the crevices.
lead_paragraph: A theory I toy around with is that the most attractive people wear the ugliest workout clothing. Maybe it’s because beautiful people have to give less thought to what they swaddle their glorious forms in, or maybe it’s because if you’re inclined to think about how good your athletic gear looks, you probably aren’t getting the maximum use out of it, or getting the item that’s designed for maximum use.

headline: Senator Manchin Takes On Democratic Party Leaders in Pursuit of a Middle Ground
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The latest gambit by Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia was an attempt to delay key parts of President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In late August, Senate Democrats gathered on a conference call with President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, to hear why the administration had to respond militarily to a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government.

headline: App Smart: Teaching Kids Math
abstract: Children can learn math skills, from addition to algebra, through an array of apps for tablets and smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Children can learn math skills, from addition to algebra, through an array of apps for tablets and smartphones.

headline: With Apps, Children Can Play the Game of Math
abstract: Apps in the form of games can help instill basic and complex math skills in children without them realizing they are being taught.
lead_paragraph: My 5-year-old son recently explained to my 3-year-old son that they were two years apart. Three years old plus 2 years old equals 5 years old, he explained.

headline: OTB, a Bar in Williamsburg
abstract: In Brooklyn, OTB serves hearty drinks and bar food, with an emphasis on reasonably priced burgers and seafood.
lead_paragraph: A string of less scene-y bars has opened up in Williamsburg, one of the latest being OTB, on a sleepy stretch of Broadway next to the Williamsburg Bridge. Unlike its rowdier neighbors on the north side, this place is notable for what it lacks: hype, high prices and members of the maligned social subset that begins with the letter H.

headline: In Statement From Prison, Morsi Accuses Egypt’s Military Leaders of Treason
abstract: Mohamed Morsi, the former Islamist president of Egypt, heaped scorn on his opponents in the military-backed government and tried to rally his beleaguered supporters.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In a statement he dictated from prison and made public through his lawyers on Wednesday, Mohamed Morsi, the former Islamist president of Egypt, accused his opponents in the military-backed government of treason and warned that Egypt would “not recover” from its crisis until the “coup” that removed him from power was reversed.

headline: Police Say Spy Found in Bag Probably Died by Accident
abstract: The London police said that Gareth Williams, a British intelligence analyst whose naked body was found in a sports bag in August 2010, probably locked himself in the bag.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The bizarre death of a British intelligence analyst whose body was discovered inside a sports bag in a bathtub was called a probable accident by the London police on Wednesday, an inconclusive ending to one of the most puzzling investigations in recent years.

headline: Toronto Mayor Admits to Buying Drugs
abstract: At a Toronto City Council meeting, Mayor Rob Ford said he bought illegal drugs in the last two years. When asked if he had an addiction to illicit drugs, the mayor said “absolutely not.”
lead_paragraph: At a Toronto City Council meeting, Mayor Rob Ford said he bought illegal drugs in the last two years. When asked if he had an addiction to illicit drugs, the mayor said “absolutely not.”

headline: Global Warming, College and Partisanship
abstract: College has a significantly larger impact on how Democrats understand climate change than on Republicans.
lead_paragraph: It’s well known that Democrats and political independents are more likely than Republicans to believe that global warming is mainly due to human activity. But here’s something from the latest Pew poll on climate change: College has a significantly larger effect on Democrats’ understanding of the issue than on Republicans’.

headline: Tables Turned, Victims’ Relatives Get Their Chance at Bulger
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Racketeering and Racketeers']
abstract: At the sentencing hearing for James (Whitey) Bulger, grieving widows and fatherless children stepped forward, many to curse the man who had robbed them of their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — David Wheeler stood in the well of a federal courtroom here Wednesday, gesturing toward James (Whitey) Bulger, the elderly man who was once the overlord of the Boston underworld and who had ordered his father’s murder.

headline: New Catfish Inspections Are Posing a Problem for a Pacific Trade Pact
keywords: ['Fish Farming', 'Catfish', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American catfish farmers say the additional program is vital for safety. Vietnam says it is nothing more than a trade barrier in disguise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A curious hurdle is threatening to complicate efforts by the United States to reach a major trade agreement with 11 Pacific nations by the end of the year: catfish.

headline: Wylie Dufresne's Turkey Hash
abstract: Wylie Dufresne, the owner of WD-50, doesn’t contribute to Thanksgiving dinner; he makes breakfast the next day. He shows Mark Bittman how he makes his fried eggs and turkey hash.
lead_paragraph: Wylie Dufresne, the owner of WD-50, doesn’t contribute to Thanksgiving dinner; he makes breakfast the next day. He shows Mark Bittman how he makes his fried eggs and turkey hash.

headline: Goldman Sachs Promotes 280 to Managing Director
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Executive Compensation', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Promotions are up 5 percent over last year, when the Wall Street firm named 266 employees managing director.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has promoted 280 executives to managing director, one step down from the brass ring of partner. Promotions are up 5 percent over last year, when the firm named 266 employees managing director.

headline: The East Village: To Escape the Sirens
abstract: To Jeff Greenspan, peace and quiet are important in a home.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until the summer — his first in a large one-bedroom at Seventh Avenue and 14th Street — that Jeff Greenspan realized how noisy his home was. Maybe the racket came through the air-conditioner vents. Sirens shrieked by in an endless parade.

headline: Finance Lessons, From the World of Art Auctions
abstract: The $142 million sale of Francis Bacon’s triptych of Lucian Freud has a matching, perhaps a bit tenuous, trio of lessons for the broader world of finance, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The record-busting $142 million sale on Tuesday by Christie’s of Francis Bacon’s triptych of Lucian Freud – not to mention the unprecedented New York auction total of almost $700 million – shows a contemporary art market in heady territory. It’s possible, if a bit tenuous, to extract a matching trio of lessons for the broader world of finance.

headline: Ask Well: Table Salt or Sea Salt?
abstract: The differences between table salt and sea salt explained, both in nutrition and taste.
lead_paragraph: The differences between table salt and sea salt explained, both in nutrition and taste.

headline: President Aquino on Typhoon Aftermath
abstract: A sample of President Benigno S. Aquino III’s statements on Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: A sample of President Benigno S. Aquino III’s statements on Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines.

headline: Remixing a Pulitzer Prize-Winning Work
abstract: Caroline Shaw’s “Partita” is available for remixing in a fund-raising project for New Amsterdam Presents.
lead_paragraph: New Amsterdam Presents, the feisty alt-classical label and concert-presenting organization that the composers William Brittelle, Judd Greenstein, and Sarah Kirkland Snider started in 2007, is collaborating with the Q2 Music web page on an unusual fund-raising project for the company. Every Wednesday for eight weeks, starting Nov. 13, Q2 will stream a remix of Caroline Shaw’s “Partita,” for which she won the Pulitzer Prize this year. The streaming tracks are freely available, but if you want to download one, or all eight, the page provides a link to New Amsterdam’s fund-raising page, where you can make a donation (the amount is not specified, but it is tax deductible) and download the tracks.

headline: We’re Buds, Right? It’s Hard to Tell.
abstract: “How to Make Friends and Then Kill Them” follows the uneasy interplay among three friends.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible for the characters in a play to wrest control of it from the playwright? “How to Make Friends and Then Kill Them,” a very dark comedy by Halley Feiffer at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, starts out intriguingly but eventually spirals out of control, the three characters in it seeming as if they are trying to make you regret attending.

headline: A Swan Leaps Off the Page and Onto the Stage
abstract: “Ballerina Swan” is a stage adaptation of Allegra Kent’s children’s book about a swan who wants to dance.
lead_paragraph: A swan puppet makes an early appearance in certain versions of “Swan Lake,” illustrating the heroine’s ensnarement at the hands of an evil magician. It’s a big moment in the narrative, obviously, but that bird has it easy compared with Sophie, who carries on her feathered wings the entire production of “Ballerina Swan,” a children’s book by the former ballerina Allegra Kent that has been turned into a children’s dance-theater work by Making Books Sing.

headline: Egyptian Soccer Star Banned for Expressing Sympathy With Massacred Islamists
abstract: An Egyptian soccer player has been suspended by his team because he celebrated an important goal by raising four fingers in the air, in a gesture of sympathy with Islamist protesters killed by the security forces in August.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Thursday, 2:03 p.m. | Just days after he scored a crucial goal to clinch the African Champions League title for his club, Al Ahly of Cairo, an Egyptian soccer player has been suspended by the team and put up for sale because of the way he celebrated his strike, by raising four fingers in the air.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,300,000
abstract: This week’s offerings include a 1903 house in New Jersey, a stone cottage near Dallas and a midcentury modern near Detroit.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, N.J.

abstract: A 1903 house in New Jersey, a stone cottage near Dallas and a midcentury modern near Detroit are featured this week.
lead_paragraph: A 1903 house in New Jersey, a stone cottage near Dallas and a midcentury modern near Detroit are featured this week.

headline: Only 106,000 Pick Health Insurance Plans in First Month
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: New data also show that in the first month of open enrollment, 26,794 signed up through the problem-plagued federal exchange, HealthCare.gov, and the rest through state exchanges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just over 106,000 people picked health plans in the first month of open enrollment through the state and federal insurance marketplaces established by the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s health secretary said Wednesday, a fraction of the administration’s initial estimate for enrollment during that period.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing Matchups of Top Wide Receivers
abstract: A better way to use favorable matchup statistics for wide receivers is to focus on the top receiver from each team, or what fantasy football owners call an WR1.
lead_paragraph: One of the most-used metrics in predicting fantasy football performance is matchup analysis (player versus opposing defense). A particular team gives up a certain amount of fantasy points per game to this position, which is presumed to be a relevant statistic when deciding which player to start that week.

headline: Teaching About the Typhoon in the Philippines
abstract: In this lesson, we offer several ideas for talking and teaching about Typhoon Haiyan in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Please preview this Times video as there are many graphic images.

headline: NBCUniversal Takes Full Ownership of Sprout Cable Network
abstract: The company, which a year ago owned 40 percent of the network, said it had bought out two partners, PBS and HIT Television Ventures.
lead_paragraph: The NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired full ownership of the fast-growing preschool cable network PBS Kids Sprout, signaling its intent to more aggressively build up its children’s and family entertainment business, which already encompasses theme parks and movies.

headline: Health Care Enrollment Numbers
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: The Department of Health and Human Services released the number of people who have enrolled in the health insurance market place in November.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jenna Wortham reviews Good Eggs, a new food shopping website that delivers locally sourced farmer’s market products right to your door.

headline: Elegance in Auction Country at the Arizona Concours d’Élégance
abstract: The state is famous for its automotive auction season, so a few collectors banded together to create an Arizona concours to raise money for Make-a-Wish.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — It’s not as if Kevin Cornish didn’t have enough to keep him busy. He’s an executive with a company that consults with hospitals, pharmaceutical manufacturers, health insurers and others in the industry on issues including legislation and litigation.

headline: Red Bulls Wrap-Up: Coach Looks Ahead
abstract: Mike Petke, in a teleconference call on Wednesday, looked back on the 2013 M.L.S. season and ahead to the 2014 one.
lead_paragraph: A week after the Red Bulls’ season came to an abrupt end in the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs, Coach Mike Petke on Wednesday took part in what is likely to be his final teleconference call this year with reporters.

headline: Good Eggs, a Virtual Farmer’s Market, Delivers Real Food
abstract: The website and delivery service lets you order products online from local farmers and artisanal food producers.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my father was fond of ordering steaks through the mail. When they arrived, my sister and I gleefully danced around the icy packages and argued over who got to open them. I can still remember marveling at the novelty of meat arriving in the same pile as regular letters, and our amazement that it tasted as good as — if not better than — the beef we purchased in the supermarket.

headline: New Rules for Dolphin-Watching
abstract: The Six Senses Laamu resort in the Maldives has new policies for guides on its dolphin-watching trips.
lead_paragraph: As part of its sustainability program, the Six Senses Laamu resort in the Maldives has adopted a code of conduct for its dolphin-watching trips.

headline: Eminem Tops Album Chart; Lorde Signs a Deal for Songs
abstract: “The Marshall Mathers LP 2” by Eminem sold 792,000 copies, the second-highest weekly tally for any album this year.
lead_paragraph: If you bought an album last week, there is a 1 in 7 chance that it was “The Marshall Mathers LP 2,” by Eminem.

headline: Till Baby Comes, Keep Smiling
abstract: A model who had a hard time finding work while pregnant decided to start an agency of her own.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Puuuush!”

headline: A Chef in the Field | Cauliflower
abstract: One of the last plants still standing in fields this time of year, cauliflower makes for an unexpectedly delicious, gluten-free alternative to couscous.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Bloomberg Issues Final Letter Grades for New York Schools
abstract: The announcement was accompanied by a sense of  acquiescence as the city prepares to hand over the school system to Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio, who has pledged to do away with the ratings.
lead_paragraph: Nothing came to epitomize the era of education reform under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg like the A-through-F letter grades he gave New York’s schools.

headline: Sotheby’s Contemporary Evening Sale
abstract: Notable works for sale at Wednesday night’s contemporary evening auction at Sotheby’s in New York.
lead_paragraph: Notable works for sale at Wednesday night’s contemporary evening auction at Sotheby’s in New York.

headline: The Traditional Chorus That Keeps Bach Young
abstract: The 800-year-old St. Thomas Boys Choir of Leipzig, Germany, performed at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: To comprehend the legacy of the St. Thomas Boys Choir of Leipzig, consider this: When Bach became its music director, called Thomaskantor, in 1723, this eminent institution had already been around for 511 years. Last year, the choir celebrated its 800th anniversary. Currently it is finishing an American tour, presenting 11 concerts over 16 days.

headline: E.U. Identifies Problems in Its Members’ Economies
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: The warnings by economic policy chiefs to Germany, France and 14 other countries are largely advisory, and are unlikely to result in the fines allowed for in European rules.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top economic policy chiefs, invoking new oversight tools, warned Germany, France and 14 other member countries on Wednesday to address problems with their economies.

headline: Holding Joy Close, and Age at Bay
abstract: For several members of Garth Fagan Dance, the program at the Joyce Theater insists that age is truly just a number.
lead_paragraph: “No Evidence of Failure” sounds like a phrase from an accident report in which the remains of a crashed vehicle give no clue as to what went wrong. At the Joyce Theater on Tuesday it was the title of a dance celebrating something that has gone mysteriously right: how the 51-year-old dancer Natalie Rogers, who returned to the Garth Fagan Dance company last year after an eight-year break, can still look so amazing.

headline: Book Deal or No Book Deal
abstract: “Masterpiece” is a new Italian reality show in which writers compete to have their work published.
lead_paragraph: “Masterpiece” is a new Italian reality show in which writers compete to have their work published.

headline: Tired Metaphors? Ciao, Contestant!
abstract: “Masterpiece,” a new Italian reality show in which writers compete to have their work published, may feel crass. Then again, novels normally get short shrift on television.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — A novelist craves solitude. Reality TV craves intrusion. So, what happens when writing becomes a broadcast spectacle?

headline: A Hostile Bank Takeover
abstract: The government of Bangladesh has played its trump card in its long-running campaign against Grameen Bank and its founder, Muhammad Yunus.
lead_paragraph: The government of Bangladesh has played its trump card in its long-running campaign against Grameen Bank and its founder Muhammad Yunus. Last week, legislators passed a law that effectively nationalizes the bank, which pioneered the idea of making small loans to poor women, by wresting control of it from the 8.4 million rural women that own a majority of its shares.

lead_paragraph: A clip from the documentary.
