lead_paragraph: A clip from the documentary "Whoopi Goldberg Presents Moms Mabley," airing on HBO Nov. 18.

headline: A Writer Thrives in Two Cultures
abstract: Daniel Alarcón, raised and educated in America, has a new novel, “At Night We Walk in Circles,” which is set in his native Peru, where he is known for works in Spanish.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2010 the novelist Daniel Alarcón was included on The New Yorker’s “20 Under 40” list of promising young American writers. Three years earlier his name had appeared on a similar list of Latin American novelists, the “Bogotá 39,” but as a Peruvian.

headline: Carlyle-Backed Brazilian Tour Operator Plans Stock Offering
abstract: A Brazilian tour operator backed by the Carlyle Group could raise as much as 1 billion reais ($428 million) for its existing shareholders through a planned offering.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – A planned stock offering of a Brazilian tour agency and operator backed by the Carlyle Group could raise as much as 1 billion reais, or $428 million, for its existing shareholders, according to a filing on Wednesday.

headline: Navigating the Constraints on Reporting from China
abstract: A comparison of China to Nazi Germany raises the question of how journalists based in China can continue to write compelling stories about an important but authoritarian country without suffering repercussions.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘I ask myself why I stay on here,’’ William L. Shirer wrote in Berlin on Sept. 20, 1940, as World War II deepened and Nazi censorship of his CBS radio broadcasts became intolerable.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Inspires Famous Imitators
abstract: Other celebrities have started websites to offer their version of the good life.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Gwyneth Paltrow, the actress everyone loves to hate (or so it seems sometimes), decided she wanted to be more than just an actress. She started a “nourishing” website called Goop to pass along her wisdom of the good life.

headline: With Enrollment Slow, Some Democrats Back Change in Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Congressional Democrats are increasingly expressing support for allowing Americans to retain the insurance coverage they are losing because of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anxious congressional Democrats are threatening to abandon President Obama on a central element of his signature health care law, voicing increasing support for proposals that would allow Americans who are losing their health insurance coverage because of the Affordable Care Act to retain it.

headline: Keynesian Economics and the Journals
abstract: Who are the authorities here?
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong takes on John Cochrane again; I don’t have the heart or the time to do a full takedown myself. But I do want to make five points.

headline: Always an Air of Sorrow, Even in Songs of Love
abstract: Daniel Woolhouse played his first show in the United States at the Mercury Lounge, playing his album “Life After Defo.”
lead_paragraph: Daniel Woolhouse set the tempo early on Tuesday night. Wearing a ski cap and black T-shirt, he sat down on the Mercury Lounge stage behind a pair of keyboards, pressed a couple of buttons, and there was that bass: sticky, gritty, creepy, oozy.

headline: The Crazy Lower Bound
abstract: The Ted Cruz spike in the distribution.
lead_paragraph: John Holbo makes a really interesting point — it’s a bit subjective, but I suspect that smart political scientists could find a way to quantify it.

headline: The Lederer Memorial Trophy in London
abstract: All top players like to receive an invitation to the Lederer Memorial Trophy. It is a most enjoyable weekend, with a social atmosphere and top-level bridge.
lead_paragraph: All top players like to receive an invitation to the Lederer Memorial Trophy in London. It is a most enjoyable weekend, with a social atmosphere and top-level bridge.

headline: Going Backstage at a $50 Million Benefit Concert
abstract: A documentary about last year’s benefit concert for Hurricane Sandy victims recalls the rapid efforts that led to the concert’s creation and the backstage maneuverings.
lead_paragraph: The documentary filmmaker Amir Bar-Lev has made features about the fog of war and the follies of the fine art world, but he had always wanted to make a movie about a music scene. Last year he was given that chance and then some.

headline: A Rugged Tablet, but Not for Consumers
abstract: NEC’s “ruggedized” tablet computer is one more example of a shift by second-tier electronics companies away from the very competitive consumer market.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Would you try this with any tablet, be it an Apple iPad, Microsoft Surface or Samsung Galaxy? Dunk a tablet computer into a bucket of water and keep it submerged for half an hour? NEC, the Japanese electronics company, says you could do it with the NEC Shieldpro H11A tablet. It also says you could drop it from a five-foot height onto a concrete floor.

headline: A Star’s Tale Reveals Lore of Old Hollywood
abstract: Victoria Wilson’s lengthy “A Life of Barbara Stanwyck” covers only part of the life of its subject but teems with anecdotes about sex roles in the emerging film industry.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Wilson’s gargantuan biography of Barbara Stanwyck manages to fill 860 glittering pages of text with only the first half of Stanwyck’s story. It ends after “Stella Dallas” (1937) but before “The Lady Eve” (1941) is even a twinkle in Preston Sturges’s eye. And it ends with a cliffhanger, creating eager anticipation for Ms. Wilson’s concluding volume. What kind of Parkinson’s law, about how work expands to fill available time, can possibly have expanded the Stanwyck story to these proportions?

headline: A Corporate ‘Upstairs Downstairs’ With an Express Elevator to Bed
abstract: In a new workplace comedy, an underling and an overling become involved.
lead_paragraph: In “Ground Floor,” a workplace sitcom that begins Thursday on TBS, Bill Lawrence oddly duplicates the template of “Cougar Town,” the successful series he helped create in 2009.

headline: Distortion and Reverberation as a Force of Nature
abstract: My Bloody Valentine ended its tour in New York on Tuesday with its leader, Kevin Shields, declaring that there would be no more shows “for a long time.”
lead_paragraph: My Bloody Valentine brought its gorgeous onslaught to Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night — its last show, the band’s guitarist and leader Kevin Shields announced onstage, “for a long time.” It was the end of the tour associated with “m b v,” this Irish band’s first album since 1991, which it released in February. My Bloody Valentine’s sense of timing is entirely its own.

headline: Roll With It, Baby
abstract: At Crazy Legs in Brooklyn, a weekly dance party on wheels attracts all manner of skaters.
lead_paragraph: It was 10 p.m., and the floor of the basketball court in a Bedford-Stuyvesant Salvation Army center was a blur of roller skate-powered counterclockwise motion.

headline: Roller Skating Goes Underground
abstract: A dance party on wheels attracts even roller disco denizens who never gave up.
lead_paragraph: A dance party on wheels attracts even roller disco denizens who never gave up.

headline: Reading a Violinist From the Arm, Not Fingers
abstract: The violinist Joshua Bell ranged from Tartini’s “Devil’s Trill” Sonata to Stravinsky at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Casual observers tend to concentrate on a violinist’s left arm: the one, in most cases, with the hand moving crazily up and down the fingerboard, fingers moving like little pistons. But it’s the right arm — the one with the bow — that makes music, finessing a series of notes into colors and phrases poetic or piquant.

headline: Yellen to Back Stimulus Plan in Remarks to Senators
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The job market and the economy are “performing far short of their potential,” Janet Yellen says in remarks prepared for her Senate confirmation hearing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years, plans to tell senators at her confirmation hearing on Thursday that continuing the Fed’s enormous stimulus campaign is the best way to revive the economy and hasten the program’s end.

headline: April Bloomfield's Clam Chowder
abstract: Mark Bittman describes April Bloomfield’s clam chowder dish as a “very fall, New England dish.” She demonstrates how to make this coarse-chopped soup.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman describes April Bloomfield’s clam chowder dish as a “very fall, New England dish.” She demonstrates how to make this coarse-chopped soup.

headline: Lou Reed’s New York Was Hell or Heaven
abstract: Lou Reed’s work remains a window into a city that was, and into his personal evolution.
lead_paragraph: He wrote about hustlers, drag queens and speed freaks, and about the ordinary dreamers, misfits and down-and-outers who populated the hotels and nighttime streets of New York City — native-born New Yorkers like himself, and all the lost or marginal seekers who came to the city to become somebody else or take a walk on the wild side. Pearly Mae, who “can’t tell the night from the day”; Jackie, who thought “she was James Dean for a day”; the small kid standing by the Lincoln Tunnel, “selling plastic roses for a buck”; the “druggy downtown kids who spray-paint walls and trains.”

headline: Chihuahuas Catch a Flight to Their New Homes
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Dogs']
abstract: Virgin America will fly Chihuahuas in need of new homes from California to the East Coast in a partnership with the San Francisco Animal Care and Control organization.
lead_paragraph: Virgin America offered a group of California Chihuahuas a lift to the New York area on Wednesday, the fifth time the airline has assisted the San Francisco Department of Animal Care and Control with getting dogs to new homes on the East Coast.

headline: André Soltner's Pumpkin Soup
abstract: For Thanksgiving, André Soltner prepares a version of pumpkin soup that he watched his mother make over 75 years ago. The creamy soup is served in a pumpkin and garnished with croutons.
lead_paragraph: For Thanksgiving, André Soltner prepares a version of pumpkin soup that he watched his mother make over 75 years ago. The creamy soup is served in a pumpkin and garnished with croutons.

headline: Rachel Comey Aims for a Bigger Slice of Fashion’s Pie
abstract: Though a name to the Brooklyn actress set, Ms. Comey has had no ordaining profile in Vogue or rich investors.
lead_paragraph: One brisk afternoon this fall, a few weeks after Rachel Comey showed her spring collection at a dinner in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a few fans dropped by her studio on lower Broadway to browse the new designs.

headline: Fashion’s Royalty Pays Tribute to Its Successors
abstract: A celebrity-filled dinner marks 10 years of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards.
lead_paragraph: The designer Tom Ford has cultivated a hedonistic image, but who knew that among those to have seen him naked is Anna Wintour. When Mr. Ford was vacationing on St. Barts in the early 1990s, Ms. Wintour was staying near the nude beach, and — whoops — there she was when he sauntered by in the buff.

headline: Paper Dolls With Military Stories to Tell
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Veterans', 'Uniforms', 'Dolls', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Art']
abstract: An artist uses donated military uniforms to help women in the military tell of their experiences.
lead_paragraph: The story of American women can be told through paper dolls.

headline: William T. Vollmann: The Self Images of a Cross-Dresser
abstract: The author and National Book Award winner on cross-dressing and his feminine side.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — As far as writers go, William T. Vollmann is a man’s man. In pursuit of a story, he has roughed it with the mujahedeen in Afghanistan and survived a land mine explosion in Bosnia. He singed his eyebrows off and nearly froze to death exploring the magnetic North Pole. In Thailand, he rescued a teenage girl from sex slavery by kidnapping her from a pimp.

headline: An Ensemble, in Its 15th Season, Reimagines and Interprets
abstract: The new-music ensemble counter)induction opened its 15th season with a program titled “Correspondent.”
lead_paragraph: Character pieces, a staple of romantic repertory, traverse a range of often blissful or atmospheric moods and scenes. But there are no dreamy moments in Bernhard Gander’s “Schlechtecharakterstücke” (“Bad Character Pieces”), a savagely wry, contemporary take on the genre.

headline: The Homey Side of Louis Kahn
abstract: George H. Marcus, an art historian, on the architect’s few but important house designs.
lead_paragraph: The architect Louis Kahn, who died in 1974, is known for his spare, geometric institutional work like the Salk Institute for Biological Study in the La Jolla section of San Diego and the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. The 2003 documentary ”My Architect,” directed by his son, Nathaniel Kahn, highlighted those buildings, along with Kahn’s romantic life. The architect had three children, with three different women, two of whom were professional collaborators. A new book, “The Houses of Louis Kahn” (Yale University Press, $65), provides an architectural bridge between the personal and the professional stories, focusing on the nine houses Kahn completed, and designs for two dozen more. The story told by the authors, George H. Marcus and William Whitaker, is one of warm client relations, attention to the smallest domestic detail and a philosophical search for the best arrangement of rooms to call home. Mr. Marcus, an adjunct assistant professor in the history of art at the University of Pennsylvania, spoke about it by phone late last month. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: Factory Farming, From an Animal Point of View
abstract: “Speciesism,” a documentary written and directed by Mark Devries, explores animal rights and factory farms.
lead_paragraph: Part philosophy lecture, part animal-rights exposé, “Speciesism: The Movie” is a painfully gauche, galumphing attack on factory farming, meat eating, animal experimentation and human supremacy. So many evils, so little time.

headline: Opening Statements in Damages Phase of Patent Trial
abstract: Apple’s and Samsung’s lawyers gave their opening statements in a trial to determine the remaining damages that Samsung will have to pay Apple for infringing on patents.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE — Apple and Samsung Electronics this week started the second round of their big patent battle in California. The trial, which is to determine the remaining damages that Samsung will have to pay Apple for infringing on patents, so far feels like Groundhog Day.

headline: A Holiday Home to Take Home
keywords: ['Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Christmas', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Bronson van Wyck and Celerie Kemble open a pop-up shop in an Upper East Side townhouse.
lead_paragraph: The banisters of the townhouse at 19 East 75th Street are wrapped in magnolia leaf garlands, and a peek into parlor floor windows reveals a home decked out for the holidays. Except that everything in this home is for sale. It is the Holiday Works, a pop-up shop filled with new and vintage items designed or sourced by Bronson van Wyck, an event planner, and his good friend the interior designer Celerie Kemble. Some goods, like Mr. van Wyck’s salad dressings and napkin sets, are cash-and-carry. Others, like a bar cart from Ms. Kemble’s new furniture line for Henredon, must be ordered. But the indisputable stars are two glittering Christmas trees decorated by Mr. van Wyck, which can be assembled in one’s home by the so-called Van Wyck Elves (prices start at $17,500). “It is meant to be bewitching and engaging,” Ms. Kemble said of the shopping experience. Information: 212-861-6160 or theholidayworkshop.com.

headline: For D.I.Y.’ers, Designer Hardware
abstract: Aluminum and bronze A-Joints, along with furniture pieces they hold together, are for sale at Matter.
lead_paragraph: When Henry Wilson, a 28-year-old Australian designer, ordered hardware online for a sawhorse he was building, he was so disappointed with the quality that he decided to make his own.

headline: Bringing Beauty to Hand
abstract: Classic flatware by the mid-century Danish designer Kay Bojesen is back in production.
lead_paragraph: The Danish designer Kay Bojesen, who was born in 1886 and died in 1958, believed that objects must be nice to hold and a pleasure to look at. Trained as a silversmith at Georg Jensen, he created a flatware pattern in 1938 that won the grand prize at the 1951 Milan Triennale, a biennial design showcase. It has been called Grand Prix ever since. Mr. Bojesen’s granddaughter, Susanne Bojesen Rosenqvist, lately reintroduced the pattern, which has been in and out of production since its inventor’s death. Ms. Rosenqvist, who said she has eaten with her grandfather’s utensils ever since she could hold a spoon, praised details like the small hump between the knife’s shaft and blade, which supports your forefinger when you cut, and the spoon’s milled edges, designed to capture drips. A five-piece place setting in stainless steel is $150 from Anise, 212-933-1406 or kaybojesen.dk.

headline: Deals on Pillows, Rugs and Sofas
abstract: Bargains at Kartell, Andrew Morgan Collection, Liora Manné and Bobby Berk Home.
lead_paragraph: During Kartell’s warehouse sale, through Monday, floor samples and some new pieces are up to 70 percent off (the Masters chair by Philippe Starck, originally from $269, is now from $161); 39 Greene Street (Broome Street); 212-966-6665; kartell.com.

headline: In the Belly of the Blue Whale
abstract: Andy Romanoff displays more than 200 of his photos of the Pacific Design Center in West Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, Andy Romanoff, a photographer, was invited to show at a gallery in the Pacific Design Center and became fascinated by the massive Cesar Pelli-designed complex, which opened in 1975 in West Hollywood. “I think everybody in L.A. knows the Blue Whale,” Mr. Romanoff said, using the center’s nickname. “But very few people know the inside. There’s a Wolfgang Puck restaurant, a gym — it’s this secret city.”

headline: The Nanny Recipes: Skip the Microwave
abstract: A chef-run consulting service teaches nannies there’s more to cooking than mac and cheese.
lead_paragraph: Like other 5-year-olds, Erela Yashiv likes pizza and cupcakes and detests food that contains “green specks” of vegetables.

headline: A Dancer Tries Out Many Moves
abstract: A dancer juggles a busy love life in “Sex, Love & Salsa.”
lead_paragraph: If it weren’t already taken, “How to Be a Player” would probably be a better title for this movie about a 29-year-old Queens man named Julian whose womanizing ways are filmed for an instructional video. In “Sex, Love & Salsa,” Julian (Adrian Manzano) is a salsa-dancing stalker of dance floors and a crusher of hearts. He can’t settle for one woman, so he juggles a few: a naïve free spirit played by Sofia Rodriguez; an older woman (Susan Quinn) who’s also a friend and wants a baby; and a confident salsa dancer, played by the talented Gabrielle Ruiz, who initially (and wisely) resists his overtures.

headline: Brought to Your Knees by a Wood Floor
keywords: ['Floors and Flooring', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Wood and Wood Products']
abstract: Refinishing floors takes heavy equipment and a high tolerance for pain and imperfection.
lead_paragraph: I finally understand how pregnant women feel when others bombard them with birthing horror stories, because I recently attempted the home-improvement equivalent of childbirth: refinishing wood floors.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Philippines, Spain, India and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Philippines, Spain, India and Afghanistan.

headline: Home Wireless Network Keeps the Snoops Away
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Community wireless mesh networks are gaining popularity because they are cheap to build and under the users’ control.
lead_paragraph: LIKE most people, Kim Thomas has a broadband connection at home that she uses to check email, surf the Internet and stream music and video.

headline: Cindi Leive: Nonstop Days, a Red Carpet Night
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: For Glamour’s editor, handing out awards is not as simple a job as it may seem.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour magazine, was sitting in a mostly empty Carnegie Hall, discreetly sipping a smuggled-in container of coffee. She had just run through a rehearsal of her speech onstage for the magazine’s annual Women of the Year Awards due to start in a few hours, and was debating with a handful of her staff members the merits of using the word “Gaga-licious” in reference to the honoree Lady Gaga.

headline: Art Is Hard to See Through the Clutter of Dollar Signs
abstract: As buyers pay more and more for art, the relationship between the work and the money it draws raises questions.
lead_paragraph: As our troubled age becomes ever more gilded, art auction prices soar with bone-numbing regularity. A new high-water mark was reached on Tuesday, when a 1969 triptych by the British painter Francis Bacon sold for $142 million while the Christie’s auction in which it was featured took in $692 million. Both figures exceeded recent highs: One arrived in spring 2012, when Edvard Munch’s “The Scream” sold for $119 million at Sotheby’s; the other came last spring, when a Christie’s auction total reached $492 million. It seems that people really, really like art these days.

headline: Scenes From the Health Care Hearing
abstract: Obama administration officials, including the chief technology officer of the United States, testified before Congress about the progress being made to fix the online health insurance exchange.
lead_paragraph: Obama administration officials, including the chief technology officer of the United States, testified before Congress about the progress being made to fix the online health insurance exchange.

headline: Another Day, Another Catalog Shoot
abstract: Westport? So ’90s. TriBeCa? Over. Brownstone Brooklyn is ground zero for aspirational living now. Just count the ads.
lead_paragraph: Westport? So ’90s. TriBeCa? Over. Brownstone Brooklyn is ground zero for aspirational living now. Just count the ads.

headline: It’s That Brownstone. Again.
keywords: ['Brownstones', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Westport? So ’90s. TriBeCa? Over. Brownstone Brooklyn is ground zero for aspirational living now. Just count the ads.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Reid Boyer’s photographs are arresting explorations of the evidence of family life and privilege: the domestic litter on a white marble bathroom sink; a patchwork of bright green sod in an expansive, lozenge-shaped backyard; a teenage girl with an inscrutable expression, a Parcheesi game laid out before her on an Indian print-covered table flanked by yellow Eames chairs.

headline: Bar Carts: Wheels With a Buzz
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: Whether classic or contemporary, the bar cart is a good way to keep the cocktails rolling.
lead_paragraph: When a guest orders a martini at Dukes Bar in London, the 105-year-old establishment once frequented by Ian Fleming where the “shaken not stirred” line is said to have originated, a barman will prepare the drink tableside using provisions from a cart. If the guest is especially lucky, the barman will be Alessandro Palazzi, who has been the bar manager for seven years.

headline: Destruction and Dazed Survivors Found in Remote Philippine Areas
abstract: Five days after Typhoon Haiyan struck, the authorities were reaching remote areas of the central Philippines that were hard hit by the storm.
lead_paragraph: Updated 1:35 p.m., Nov. 14 The effects of Typhoon Haiyan’s destructive path on remote areas of the central Philippines are being pieced together as the authorities, journalists and relief workers are finally reaching hard-hit small towns and island fishing villages in eastern Samar Province.

headline: Tax Wizardry Accomplished With an Offbeat Merger
abstract: Tax avoidance mechanisms are mostly legal and take advantage of rules written in the days when assets were tangible and difficult to move.
lead_paragraph: It used to be easier to avoid paying corporate taxes. Back in the 1990s, many corporations used tax shelters that had little economic substance other than to dodge tax liability. Aggressive enforcement actions by the Internal Revenue Service, coupled with changes in accounting and reporting requirements, have combined to make these shelters unattractive to most companies.

headline: Carlyn Cerf de Dudzeele: A Legend Who’s Unafraid to Say So
abstract: The fashion stylist has no use for cookbooks, an approach that also applies to her work.
lead_paragraph: TRENDS? PFFT. They mean nothing to Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele. She prefers the staying power of a Chanel jacket, an Hermès Birkin bag and jeans. Like Manolo Blahnik pumps, navy turtlenecks or little black dresses by Azzedine Alaïa, “these things are never démodé,” she said in her Gallic gargle, “never, never, neverrh!”

headline: Spotless Where Others Go Topless
abstract: A fastidious Brazilian gets the house of his dreams, with ocean views and not a speck of dust in sight.
lead_paragraph: For years, Alex Lerner, the host of a Brazilian television show, has taken vacations on St. Barts, where he and his friends rented a house. Eventually, he decided he wanted to live the same way he did on vacation when he was at home.

headline: Purist Paradise
abstract: A fastidious Brazilian gets the house of his dreams, with ocean views and not a speck of dust in sight.
lead_paragraph: A fastidious Brazilian gets the house of his dreams, with ocean views and not a speck of dust in sight.

headline: Should I Place Furniture in Storage?
abstract: Advice on repairing or redecorating a home before selling.
lead_paragraph: Q. Should I put some of my furniture in storage to make my apartment look bigger?

headline: Famed Austin Nightclub Is Sold
abstract: Antone’s, best known as a home of the blues, was bought by a consortium including a National Geographic scientist and a former member of the Dave Matthews Band.
lead_paragraph: Antone’s, a nightclub in Austin, Tex., that played a big part in establishing that city’s reputation as one of the nation’s centers of live music, has agreed to be bought by a consortium including a National Geographic scientist and a former member of the Dave Matthews Band.

headline: ‘Anchorman’ Spoof of 1970s TV News Is Basis for Newseum Exhibition
abstract: The exhibition, based on the 2004 film “Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy,” recalls an era of heavily sprayed hair, huge egos and newsrooms with little racial and gender diversity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I don’t know how to put this, but I’m kind of a big deal. ... People know me. ... I’m very important. Uh, I have many leather-bound books, and my apartment smells of rich mahogany.”

abstract: H&M opens in Times Square; Yael Sonia comes to SoHo.

headline: Tax Authorities in Italy Put Apple Under Investigation
abstract: The inquiry, still in an early stage, continues a trend by Italian prosecutors of paying more attention to the tax filings of big international companies.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian prosecutors have opened an investigation into whether Apple paid all its taxes in the country, an official in Milan said on Wednesday.

headline: Winners and Losers From Stimulus
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'National Debt (US)', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Savings']
abstract: A study from the McKinsey Global Institute examines the effects of quantitative easing by central banks in the United States and Europe, finding the policy to have been a double-edged sword.
lead_paragraph: As Wall Street tries to gauge when the Federal Reserve might start tapering its stimulus program, a new study from the McKinsey Global Institute illustrates just how deep the impact of such efforts has been since 2007. But it also makes clear that the benefits haven’t been distributed equally.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Snapchat Spurn, and Yahoo to Shed Sandwich.com
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include a report that Snapchat, a photo-messaging service, rejected a $3 billion offer from Facebook. Plus, Yahoo auctions off old domains, including sandwich.com.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Syrian Forces Recapture Damascus Suburb From Rebels
abstract: State news media showed government troops entering Hujeira, the latest in a string of suburbs south of Damascus where the government has made inroads in recent days.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government forces recaptured a suburb south of Damascus on Wednesday and continued battles to push insurgents out of long-held territory outside the northern city of Aleppo, in what appeared to be a major push to gain ground ahead of proposed internationally sponsored peace talks.

headline: Caution: Danger in the Traffic Lanes
abstract: When bikes, cars and pedestrians mix — or don’t.

headline: Marianne Williamson, New-Age Guru, Seeks Congressional Seat
abstract: Ms. Williamson, a best-selling author and spiritual workshop leader, is seeking donations as she challenges Representative Henry A. Waxman in California.
lead_paragraph: REDONDO BEACH, Calif. — Many in the audience at Marianne Williamson’s appearance here the other night thought they had come to a book signing: They arrived at the Mysterious Galaxy bookstore clutching her texts, expecting a lecture on the journey to inner peace.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']

lead_paragraph: A State Supreme Court justice ordered the Brooklyn district attorney’s office on Wednesday to produce any documents regarding wrongdoing alleged by inmates, witnesses, lawyers and others against a former homicide detective who is the subject of a wide-ranging review.

keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont writes that a funding requirement mandated by Congress is responsible for most of the agency’s financial difficulties.

abstract: The firm called off a question-and-answer session with a senior executive after Twitter users complied with its request for queries with a stream of ribald questions and hostile jokes.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase helped take Twitter public last week. But on Wednesday evening, the banking giant got a taste of the social network’s power — in a very negative way.

abstract: A reader says that certain countries don’t belong on a United Nations panel on human rights.

abstract: A professor says Iran needs to renounce reprocessing of spent fuel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Court Considers ‘Neutrality Agreements’ Between Unions and Employers
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments in a case with possible implications for deals made in order to ease unionization efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a major labor case that, depending on how it is resolved, could hamper the ability of unions to mount successful campaigns to organize workers.

headline: Crayons Down. Now Dig Into That Healthful Parfait.
abstract: A new anti-obesity initiative by the Children’s Museum of Manhattan and the National Institutes of Health seeks to teach children under 5 to enjoy fruits and vegetables daily.
lead_paragraph: The 22 children in a Head Start class in East Harlem shopped for plastic carrots and tomatoes at their own version of a New York City green cart, counted backward from five with a picture of blueberries, and jumped up and down to a song about bananas.

headline: Jewish Aid to the Philippines
keywords: ['Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee writes that its efforts to get aid to survivors of the typhoon are motivated by a historical debt to the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Don’t Give More Patients Statins
abstract: New guidelines widely expand the category of who should take statins.
lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology issued new cholesterol guidelines that essentially declared, in one fell swoop, that millions of healthy Americans should immediately start taking pills — namely statins — for undefined health “benefits.”

headline: Todd Christensen, Record-Setting Tight End, Dies at 57
abstract: Mr. Christensen was a tight end for the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders who made five Pro Bowl teams and played on two Super Bowl champions.
lead_paragraph: Todd Christensen, a sticky-fingered, record-setting tight end for the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders who made five Pro Bowl teams and played on two Super Bowl champions, died on Wednesday in Murray, Utah, near Salt Lake City. He was 57.

headline: Raising a Sick Daughter Was Hard Enough, Then They Lost Their Jobs
abstract: Life for the McSween family, normally filled with doctor’s appointments, lab tests and operations for their sick 7-year-old, was turned upside down when both parents’ income dried up.
lead_paragraph: When Megan McSween learned her second-grade class was scheduled to take a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge, she was ecstatic.

headline: Obamacare and Character
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In politics, the confidence of the public counts, and the White House can’t afford to lose more of it.
lead_paragraph: The president’s job approval numbers have hit new lows. That’s actually not the worst news in a new round of polling. The worst news — or what the White House should find most worrisome — is that the president’s character has taken a hit.

headline: Boehner Rules Out Negotiations on Immigration
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner said House Republicans had little interest in turning to immigration legislation that divided their party, and his stance meant the fight would be pushed into 2014.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Signaling an end to the push for major immigration legislation this year, Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday ruled out negotiations between the House and the Senate on an expansive immigration overhaul similar to one approved by the Senate with bipartisan support in June.

headline: M.T.A. Sees Smaller Fare Increases in ’15 and ’17
abstract: An improved financial outlook, aided by higher than expected passenger and real estate revenues, suggest transit fare and toll prices would go up by 4 percent, down from 7.5 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that it expected to scale back fare and toll increases planned for 2015 and 2017, potentially tempering the effects of what has become an unwelcome biennial ritual for riders.

headline: Four Marines Are Killed in Camp Pendleton Accident
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Marines were killed while they were clearing unexploded ordnance at an artillery range at the base outside San Diego, military officials said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Four Marines were killed Wednesday in an accident during maintenance of an artillery range at a base outside San Diego, military officials said.

headline: State Dept. Calls Group in Nigeria Terrorists
abstract: The State Department has designated Boko Haram, a homegrown Islamist movement in Nigeria, as a terrorist group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Wednesday branded Boko Haram, the homegrown Islamist insurgent movement in Nigeria that has ties to Al Qaeda’s regional affiliate in North and West Africa, as a foreign terrorist organization.

headline: Three Students Are Shot Near Pittsburgh School
abstract: Mayor Luke Ravenstahl said the shooting of the teenagers minutes after school was dismissed appeared to be “a targeted incident” rather than a random spree.
lead_paragraph: Three students were shot near a Pittsburgh high school minutes after dismissal on Wednesday, and police officers who surrounded two nearby homes took six people into custody for questioning.

headline: Jets Consider Adding Reed at Safety
abstract: Jets Coach Rex Ryan acknowledged discussing Ed Reed, who became a free agent on Wednesday after clearing waivers, with General Manager John Idzik, but it is unclear whether there will be a reunion.
lead_paragraph: Coach Rex Ryan said he was pleased with the Jets’ safeties. Pleased enough to pass up a chance to add perhaps the best safety ever, Ed Reed?

headline: Car Mechanic Dreams Up a Tool to Ease Births
abstract: An Argentine car mechanic adapted a method to retrieve a cork from a wine bottle to develop a device that could be used to save a baby stuck in the birth canal.
lead_paragraph: The idea came to Jorge Odón as he slept. Somehow, he said, his unconscious made the leap from a YouTube video he had just seen on extracting a lost cork from a wine bottle to the realization that the same parlor trick could save a baby stuck in the birth canal.

headline: Bring Me a Case
abstract: The Supreme Court presents itself as the passive recipient of legal disputes. But it is actually an active participant in shaping its own destiny.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wasn’t persuaded last week by a petition that asked the Supreme Court to review the fairness of the settlement of a lawsuit against Facebook. He joined his eight colleagues in deciding against hearing the case. No big deal there. The case, Marek v. Lane, was one of nearly 300 appeals the justices turned down upon their return from a two-week recess.

headline: New Cholesterol Advice Startles Even Some Doctors
abstract: For patients and doctors, new guidelines that include the elimination of target levels for “bad cholesterol” represent a surprising change in perspective.
lead_paragraph: Steven L. Zweibel has been taking a statin drug to lower his cholesterol for seven years. It has worked, and he has suffered no problems or side effects.

headline: Lin Is Better Off (and Better)
abstract: Jeremy Lin, whom the Knicks allowed to leave to join the Rockets two years ago, is thriving in a supporting role alongside James Harden and Dwight Howard.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — No one, least of all Jeremy Lin, would be so presumptuous to call it a last laugh. But it is fair to say that Lin has earned, at the expense of his former team and its impetuous owner, a well-timed chortle.

headline: Serving Life for This?
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: In America, nonviolent offenses are getting grotesque punishment.
lead_paragraph: So you’re a judge, and Sharanda P. Jones comes before you for sentencing for conspiracy to distribute crack cocaine.

headline: Kerry and Biden Ask for Room to Reach a Nuclear Deal With Iran
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. pressed senators to give the Obama administration breathing room to reach an accord with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. pressed senators on Wednesday to give the Obama administration some breathing room to reach an accord with Iran to freeze its nuclear programs, warning that a new round of sanctions could mean war instead of diplomacy.

headline: California Health Exchange Beats All Others in Enrollment, Officials Say
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: About 2,000 people are enrolling in private health care plans daily through the state’s website, officials said, a rate that has picked up considerably over the past few weeks.
lead_paragraph: In its first month of business, California’s insurance exchange enrolled more people than any other state-run exchange and more than the federal exchange serving 36 states, which has been paralyzed by technological failures.

headline: Iran and Western Powers Clash Over Why Nuclear Talks Failed
abstract: The United States says Iran was unwilling to agree to a unified proposal, while Iran says France thwarted progress.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Less than a week before the next round of nuclear talks in Geneva, it is still not clear why the last round failed, and who exactly walked away from the deal. Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, has laid the blame on the Western powers, saying they were divided. He says he has little to do now but wait for the world powers to get their act together.

headline: No Complete Games but a Cy Young Award
abstract: The Tigers’ Max Scherzer, who went 21-3 with 2.90 earned run average and 240 strikeouts, won the A.L. Cy Young Award despite not ever having pitched a complete game in his career.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Tigers’ Max Scherzer did something on Wednesday that no starting pitcher had ever done before. He won a Cy Young Award before registering his first career complete game.

headline: Brazil: Forensic Team Exhumes Leader’s Remains
abstract: A team began exhuming the remains of João Goulart, the Brazilian president ousted in a 1964 coup supported by the United States, to examine whether he was poisoned by spies.
lead_paragraph: A team of forensic experts on Wednesday began exhuming the remains of João Goulart, the Brazilian president ousted in a 1964 coup supported by the United States, to examine whether he was poisoned by spies while living in exile in Argentina. The authorities carried out the exhumation in São Borja, a city in southern Brazil, at the urging of Mr. Goulart’s family. They are seeking to examine a claim by a former Uruguayan intelligence operative that Mr. Goulart was assassinated by agents of Operation Condor, a joint campaign by South American military dictatorships in the 1970s and ’80s to eliminate political dissidents. Mr. Goulart had long been thought to have died from natural causes. Officials said that his remains would be flown to the capital, Brasília, to undergo testing.

headline: Imbruvica, Drug to Treat Blood Cancer, Gains F.D.A. Approval
abstract: The drug has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration to treat relapses of a rare blood cancer called mantle cell lymphoma.
lead_paragraph: A new cancer drug that has attracted considerable attention from doctors and investors won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday.

headline: Texas University’s Race Admissions Policy Is Debated Before a Federal Court
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The Supreme Court had sent the case brought by a white applicant against the University of Texas at Austin back to a lower court, instructing it to apply a greater degree of scrutiny to the race-conscious admissions program.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — An affirmative-action program at the University of Texas at Austin that takes applicants’ race into account was unnecessary because the campus had achieved a “critical mass” of minority students, lawyers for the white applicant who sued the university told a federal appeals court here on Wednesday in a case with high stakes for the future of race-conscious admissions policies at public colleges and universities.

headline: Saudi Arabia Officially Rejects U.N. Security Council Seat
abstract: By rejecting the seat it won last month, Saudi Arabia cleared the way for a replacement country to be chosen, diplomatic officials said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has officially rejected in writing the United Nations Security Council seat it won last month, clearing the way for a replacement country to be chosen, diplomatic officials said Wednesday.

headline: From Practice Squad to Starter
abstract: Scott Tolzien has been thrust into a starting role for Green Bay after injuries to Aaron Rodgers and Seneca Wallace.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY — Until two weeks ago, Green Bay Packers quarterback Scott Tolzien dressed in the N.F.L.’s version of a bus station, the auxiliary locker room at Lambeau Field reserved for the practice squad. Occupants change weekly. Anonymity is never a problem.

headline: Council Asks Toronto Mayor to Step Down Temporarily
keywords: ['Mayors', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Prostitution', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: A court also released documents documents that painted a salacious picture of a combative, drunken mayor who assaulted staff members and entertained suspected prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Shortly after Toronto’s City Council voted Wednesday to ask Mayor Rob Ford to step down temporarily, a court released documents that painted a salacious picture of a combative, drunken mayor who assaulted staff members and entertained suspected prostitutes.

headline: Les Brown, Pioneer in Television Journalism, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Brown founded and edited a groundbreaking magazine that followed the growth of the broadcast medium and produced an authoritative encyclopedia about it.
lead_paragraph: Les Brown, who was one of the first journalists to cover television comprehensively from its early days, reporting on it for The New York Times, founding and editing a groundbreaking magazine about the industry and producing an authoritative TV encyclopedia, died on Nov. 4 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: HSN Joins With Univision to Reach the Hispanic Market
abstract: The shopping network and Spanish language TV network have signed a three-year deal to increase sales to Hispanic consumers.
lead_paragraph: HSN, the home shopping network, is turning its sights toward Hispanic consumers with the announcement of a new e-commerce partnership with Univision Communications that will begin on Thursday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 13, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Europe’s (Low) Inflation Problem
abstract: Making things impossible for Spain.
lead_paragraph: Just a quick chart that I think illustrates the problem of German non-reciprocity especially clearly.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Climate of Fear
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Censorship', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'News and News Media', 'Editorials']
abstract: Commonwealth leaders must address human rights violations and denial of press freedoms that is undermining democracy in the country.
lead_paragraph: Since the end of Sri Lanka’s civil war in 2009, the government of President Mahinda Rajapaksa has had a record of serious human rights violations and failed to provide accountability for wartime abuses.

headline: An Unwise Airline Merger
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Justice Department’s approval of the American Airlines-US Airways deal may hurt consumers.
lead_paragraph: In August, the Justice Department’s antitrust division filed a lawsuit to block the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, which would create the world’s largest airline and concentrate 80 percent of the domestic air-travel business in the hands of four companies.

headline: A New Alliance on Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'States (US)', 'State Legislatures', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Editorials']
abstract: Inspired by impatience with Congress and the Canadian Parliament, states and provinces are taking it upon themselves to do something.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to compensate for the failure of central governments to address the dangers of climate change with comprehensive national policies, cities, states and regions have developed their own strategies to rein in emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. California’s ambitious plan aims to reduce emissions 80 percent by 2050 by requiring cleaner cars, more energy-efficient buildings and renewable fuels. Nine northeastern states have joined in a regional trading program aimed at reducing power-plant emissions.

headline: Resistance to Marriage Equality
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Editorials']
abstract: States are flouting federal law by refusing to process benefits of same-sex spouses in the National Guard.
lead_paragraph: “This is wrong.” That was Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s blunt response late last month to states defying his order in August that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given full spousal and family benefits, including health care coverage and housing allowances, on an equal, nondiscriminatory basis.

headline: At a Philippine Hospital, Survivors Face Quiet Despair
abstract: The main hospital in Tacloban, the Philippine city that bore the brunt of Typhoon Haiyan, lacks the supplies to help the wounded, with some just left to die.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Richard Pulga, a 27-year-old farmer with thick black hair and a gentle manner, has been lying on a hard steel bed in a dark hallway of the main hospital here since Saturday with a shattered lower right leg, abdominal pain and his right eye filling with blood.

headline: Future Unclear for Towers on East Side
abstract: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio pledged to work with the City Council to rezone the area around Grand Central Terminal after the demise of the Bloomberg administration’s plan.
lead_paragraph: The day after the Bloomberg administration withdrew its plan for a swath of glass towers in Midtown because of an absence of support in the City Council, a developer, David W. Levinson, was fielding phone calls at his office near Carnegie Hall.

headline: Does My Virginity Have a Shelf Life?
abstract: At 35, I’ve been holding out for so long, how can I change now? And yet I have doubts.
lead_paragraph: When I was 20, one of my close friends was killed in a car crash. At the funeral, as I watched her coffin carried down the aisle, another friend leaned over to whisper: “At least she wasn’t a virgin.”

headline: Twisting and Turbulent Case for Formula One Chief
abstract: Bernie Ecclestone, accused of fraud in the 2006 sale of Formula One’s commercial rights, is at the center of a London case that has overshadowed the sport’s 19-race championship.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As 11 Formula One teams prepared recently to head for Austin, Tex., where the penultimate round of this year’s 19-race championship will take place Sunday, it was not the domination of the German driver Sebastian Vettel, winner of 11 of this year’s races and a strong favorite in Austin, that spurred the most fevered talk among grand prix racing insiders.

headline: The Art of Senate Stoppage
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: We need a new leader of the Federal Reserve Board, people, but, first, Senator Lindsey Graham needs to hear more testimony about the 2012 attack in Benghazi.
lead_paragraph: When we’re choosing a leader for the nation’s central banking system, one of the important things to consider is whether Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has heard enough testimony about the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Federal Panel Softens Tone on Judge It Removed From Stop-and-Frisk Case
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The appeals panel complimented Judge Shira A. Scheindlin, but continued to block her decision that had imposed sweeping changes on the police.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan that had abruptly removed Judge Shira A. Scheindlin from New York City’s high-profile stop-and-frisk litigation and questioned her conduct in the case issued a lengthy explanation on Wednesday, saying it had made “no findings of misconduct, actual bias or actual partiality” by the judge.

headline: Bernanke the Teacher, Talking to Teachers
abstract: In a question-and-answer session, the Fed chief continues to pursue his goal of explaining monetary policy to the general public
lead_paragraph: Janet Yellen will take the stage Thursday morning in what is effectively her debut as the Federal Reserve’s new leader. But the job still belongs to Ben S. Bernanke, who on Wednesday night held a low-key question-and-answer session with teachers.

headline: Philippines’ President Faces Growing Anger
abstract: Filipinos are losing patience with Benigno S. Aquino III after he apparently was caught off guard by the scope of the calamity wrought by a typhoon.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Five days after a devastating typhoon swept through the midsection of this impoverished island nation, Filipinos are losing patience with the slow relief effort, increasingly angry with their president, Benigno S. Aquino III, a popular figure who has until now navigated multiple crises during his three years in office.

headline: Rejecting Billions, Snapchat Expects a Better Offer
abstract: Snapchat, a social media service, has become one of the most sought-after businesses in the technology industry.
lead_paragraph: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media service run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif.

headline: Giants, With a History of Losing to Backups, Are Wary of Tolzien
abstract: In the last decade, the Giants have repeatedly faced backup quarterbacks and lost, from Philadelphia’s Nick Foles last month to Cincinnati’s Jon Kitna in 2004.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants on Sunday will face quarterback Scott Tolzien, who threw his first N.F.L. pass just a few days ago. If this bodes well for the Giants, they are not buying it.

headline: Yes, You’ve Heard the Joke Before, but That’s Exactly the Point
abstract: Billy Crystal returns to Broadway with lots of familiar material in a revival of “700 Sundays,” his one-man show about growing up on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Songs can get stuck in your head, but what about jokes?

headline: Should Politicians' Spouses Shape Policy?
abstract: Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, have always worked as a team. But are there pitfalls for voters and officials when a spouse is a formal adviser?

headline: Echo Chamber
abstract: Tom McCoy riffs on self-references in his debut puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Tom McCoy, a college freshman, makes his debut today with a crossword full of clever INTERPLAY between the clues. Certain items have an echo, like the duplicate entries about 007 (the ALIAS for British spy extraordinaire James BOND), and the repetition of “knight,” with clues about a knight’s title (SIR) and activity (QUESTING.)

headline: JPMorgan’s Fruitful Ties to a Member of China’s Elite
abstract: A contract shows that JPMorgan Chase’s relationship with the daughter of China’s former prime minister points to its strategy for building influence in China.
lead_paragraph: To promote its standing in China, JPMorgan Chase turned to a seemingly obscure consulting firm run by a 32-year-old executive named Lily Chang.

headline: From the Shadows, a Rebel Group Vexes Paraguay
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The Paraguayan People’s Army is evolving from a ghostlike irritant for the authorities into a broader security threat.
lead_paragraph: The Paraguayan People’s Army is evolving from a ghostlike irritant for the authorities into a broader security threat.

headline: Guerrillas Step Up Campaign in Paraguay
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Attacks on Police', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The Paraguayan People’s Army, a shadowy rebel group, is evolving into a broader security threat as it carries out attack after attack on police and army posts.
lead_paragraph: TACUATÍ, Paraguay — The guerrillas appeared at dusk.

headline: Lawyer Concedes Mistakes in Chevron Case
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: In testimony prepared for delivery in court next week, Steven Donziger is as defiant as ever, even as he acknowledges mistakes.
lead_paragraph: For the last month, Chevron has presented a parade of witnesses against Steven R. Donziger, the freelance lawyer who has been suing the company for 20 years over pollution of the Ecuadorean Amazon jungle. One after another, the witnesses, including some of his closest allies and financiers who are now estranged from his cause, have testified that Mr. Donziger committed witness tampering and fraud.

headline: Nash Skates, but Return to Rangers Is Not Set
abstract: The star forward Rick Nash looked great in his first practice with the Rangers since sustaining a concussion Oct. 8, but he implied that it might be a while before he returns to the lineup.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rick Nash, symptom-free, looked great in practice Wednesday, his first with his Rangers teammates since sustaining a concussion in a game at San Jose on Oct. 8.

abstract: The race for consumers’ dollars has prodded more retailers to open their doors on Thanksgiving, a day before the traditional start of the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers and college students can spend only so much time cooped up with their families on a holiday like Thanksgiving.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, November 14, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t have any money, I’ve lost everything, even my house is gone. That’s what is on my mind.”

headline: India: Official Criticized for a Reference to Rape
abstract: During a public debate on gambling, one of India’s top law enforcement officials remarked that arguing to legalize betting is “like saying if you can’t prevent rape, enjoy it.”
lead_paragraph: One of India’s top law enforcement officials drew criticism on Wednesday for making an offhand reference to rape during a public debate on gambling, remarking that arguing to legalize betting is “like saying if you can’t prevent rape, enjoy it.” In a country newly sensitized to sexual violence, the remarks by Ranjit Sinha, director of the Central Bureau of Investigation, immediately echoed on Twitter and were covered by television news channels. Some activists called on Mr. Sinha, who heads a bureau supervising corruption and other grave crimes, including rape and murder, to step down. Mr. Sinha swiftly released a statement of apology: “I regret any hurt caused, as the same was inadvertent and unintended,” it read, explaining that he was condemning such reasoning, and adding, “I reiterate my deep sense of respect for women and commitment to gender issues.”

headline: After Strong Growth in First Half of 2013, the Japanese Economy Hits a Snag
abstract: Preliminary figures released on Thursday indicated that growth in Japan’s gross domestic product slowed to an annualized rate of 1.9 percent in the third quarter of 2013.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — After a surprising spurt of strong growth in the first half of the year, the Japanese economy seems to be running out of steam as exports and consumer spending show signs of weakening.

headline: IBM to Announce More Powerful Watson via the Internet
abstract: Companies, academics and individual software developers will be able to use Watson at a small fraction of the previous cost.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Welcome to the age of supercomputing for everyone.

headline: Concession in Airline Merger Is Criticized
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'AIRPORTS', 'Bankruptcies', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Analysts and consumer advocates questioned the terms of a deal that the Justice Department had reached with US Airways and American Airlines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department announced in August that it had filed suit to block the proposed merger of US Airways and American Airlines, it maintained that airline consolidation had gone too far and the proposed merger would lead to higher fares for consumers.

headline: Up in the Air
abstract: Developer SL Green Realty had hoped to build a massive structure across from Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: Developer SL Green Realty had hoped to build a massive structure across from Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Secret Service Officer Is Demoted From Presidential Detail
abstract: Ignacio Zamora Jr., a supervisor, was removed from President Obama’s security detail after being accused of leaving a bullet in a woman’s hotel room, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Secret Service supervisor has been removed from President Obama’s security detail and demoted after being accused of leaving a bullet in a woman’s room at a luxury hotel near the White House this year, senior federal law enforcement officials said Wednesday.

headline: Redfin Raises $50 Million in Latest Financing Round
abstract: The online real estate brokerage has raised $50 million in a new round of mezzanine capital, led by Tiger Global Management and T. Rowe Price.
lead_paragraph: While the online home information space may be crowded, investors seem to believe that Redfin has a good chance of standing out.

headline: Grisly Warhol Painting Fetches $104.5 Million, Auction High for Artist
abstract: The Warhol, “Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster),” is one of only four double-paneled car crash paintings that Warhol created in 1963 and the last of its size left in private hands.
lead_paragraph: One of Andy Warhol’s more powerful and provocative images — a lifeless body amid the gruesome wreckage of a car crash — sold for $104.5 million at Sotheby’s contemporary art auction on Wednesday night, making it the highest price ever paid at auction for the Pop artist.

headline: Boras Has a Few Zingers, and a Few Free-Agent Stars, for the Mets
abstract: The agent Scott Boras, whose clients include Jacoby Ellsbury, Shin-Soo Choo and Stephen Drew, has made a point in recent years to tweak the Mets, and did so again Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Scott Boras entered the hotel lobby here Wednesday afternoon like a rock star, mobbed by reporters. He was about to give what has become his annual unofficial address at the general managers meetings, discussing his clients and baseball in general. One of the first questions posed to him was about the Mets.

headline: Shaking Up Strategy, Knicks Shake Off Woes and Hawks
abstract: Carmelo Anthony played 40 minutes and scored 25 points and Andrea Bargnani scored 20 points and had a season-high 11 rebounds as the Knicks beat the Hawks in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Knicks arrived here accompanied by their usual turbulence. Starting guard Iman Shumpert, perhaps the player with the most upside on the roster, was mentioned in trade rumors. The team’s owner, James L. Dolan, guaranteed a win onstage with his blues band, and the team’s toughness on defense was questioned without the injured Tyson Chandler. Coach Mike Woodson was receiving blame for the team’s uneven start.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Colts (6-3) at Titans (4-5)
abstract: This could be the game for Trent Richardson to gain some traction for the Colts. Tennessee has a soft run defense, ranked 21st in the N.F.L., and has yielded the second-most rushing touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

headline: Fair-Housing Case Is Settled Before It Reaches Supreme Court
abstract: The settlement over a development plan in Mount Holly, N.J., will leave open the question of whether claims under the Fair Housing Act require proof of intentional discrimination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A housing discrimination case scheduled to be heard by the Supreme Court next month has been settled, the parties announced Wednesday night. Civil rights groups, wary of a Supreme Court ruling that they feared could weaken protections for victims of housing discrimination, welcomed the development.

headline: N.F.L. Week 11 Game Probabilities: Can Chiefs Finish Undefeated?
abstract: The Chiefs’ formula for success includes solid defense and a low-risk offense, but the biggest factor in their success might be scheduling luck.
lead_paragraph: One of the interesting things to do with game probabilities is estimate the likelihood that a team will finish undefeated. Coming off their bye week, the undefeated Kansas City Chiefs have seven games remaining. Winning all of those games is extremely unlikely, especially considering they have yet to face the formidable Denver Broncos.

headline: Tailored for Travel
abstract: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets — perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.
lead_paragraph: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets — perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.

headline: A Pioneering Collaborator of Le Corbusier Finally Gets Her Due
abstract: The French designer Charlotte Perriand, who created furnishings, interiors and buildings, is being recognized at Design Miami this December for her ahead-of-the-curve sensibility.
lead_paragraph: As an homage to Charlotte Perriand’s creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernist’s never-realized designs.

headline: Sizing Up the Fiscal Future
abstract: Long-term forecasts of America’s fiscal health are not reliable and should not prompt overreaction, but the need to control health care costs is clear, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Nets, Continuing Skid in Sacramento, Offer No Excuses
abstract: The Nets dropped their third straight game, as Marcus Thornton, with 24 points, led the host Kings to their first victory in six games.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — For weeks, the Nets seemed willing to tie their poor play to their newness as a group. The process of adjusting to a new system, to new teammates, justified their string of surprising losses, and few could challenge them on that point.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS (2010) Michael Douglas, below, returns as the reptilian Gordon Gekko who, after eight years in prison, has landed in the spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf portrays the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekko’s fans and the live-in love of Gekko’s daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume. “To the question ‘What went wrong?’ the film offers an answer that is both irrefutable and unsatisfying: human nature,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And yet, he added, something vital here works. The director, Oliver Stone, “is not the man to explain Wall Street, or to stoke public indignation at its crimes,” he said. “But no one else could turn it into a show like ‘Wall Street.’ ”

headline: Boeing Workers Reject Labor Deal in Washington State
abstract: The move raises the chance that Boeing will move assembly of the new 777X jet from the Seattle area, the company’s traditional manufacturing base.
lead_paragraph: Members of a union representing thousands of Boeing employees voted late Wednesday to reject a controversial labor deal that would have cut compensation but have kept assembly of the company’s new 777X jets in Washington State, raising the chance that Boeing will move more production away from its traditional manufacturing base in the Seattle area.

headline: News Quiz | November 14, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: China Moving to End Some Cosmetics Testing on Animals
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Rabbits']
abstract: Chinese animal rights advocates are buoyed by news the government is moving toward ending the mandatory testing of cosmetics on animals, in line with growing international norms.
lead_paragraph: “YES!” wrote Hou Xiaomu, an animal lover, on Weibo, about the news that China’s food and drug authorities are moving toward ending the testing of cosmetics on animals. About 300,000 animals — rabbits, mice and others —  may be used each year in testing cosmetics here, Humane Society International estimates.

headline: Northern Chinese Brace for Smog Spike as Winter Heating Kicks In
abstract: On Friday, coal-fired heating systems will be turned on in much of northern China, a major factor in worsening air pollution.
lead_paragraph: Harbin — a metropolis in China’s northeastern reaches — made international headlines last month when it experienced air pollution so abysmal that the government closed all schools and officials urged the city’s 11 million residents to stay indoors as visibility dropped to just 10 meters, roughly the width of a typical traffic intersection.

headline: Japan Honors Chinese Student for Heroism
abstract: Yan Jun’s rescue of a Japanese boy from drowning, at risk to his own life, came at a difficult time in relations between China and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan has honored a Chinese student for his “courageous act” in rescuing a Japanese boy from drowning, a bright spot in an otherwise tense period in diplomatic relations.

headline: Chinese Rights Campaigner Held Hunger Strike, Lawyer Says
abstract: Yang Maodong was detained by the police in early August on allegations of “assembling a crowd to disrupt order in a public place.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A prominent human rights campaigner in southern China won his first meeting with a lawyer on Thursday after more than three months in detention and said he had been on a hunger strike, one of his lawyers said.

headline: Overshadowed by Tacloban, Other Devastated Philippine Cities Fear Aid Will Not Come
abstract: In Ormoc, more than 90 percent of the structures are said to have been destroyed or damaged, and food shortages are becoming an increasing problem.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — While relief efforts for Typhoon Haiyan have been focused on the Philippine city of Tacloban, aid groups say other cities in Leyte Province have also suffered vast devastation, with residents facing increasing dangers with the passage of time.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Political Editor of Open Magazine Hartosh Singh Bal
abstract: Mr. Bal spoke about his unexpected termination from the magazine.
lead_paragraph: Hartosh Singh Bal, the political editor of Open magazine, announced on Wednesday that he had received a letter of termination. It was the second high-profile sacking within the Indian media in the space of a month; in late October, Siddharth Varadarajan resigned as editor-in-chief of The Hindu, an influential daily newspaper, when the paper’s owners told him he would be replaced.

lead_paragraph: Use context clues to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.
