lead_paragraph: In “By a Spire, Manhattan Regains a Title From Chicago,” Patrick McGeehan and Charles V. Bagli write about the new tallest building in the United States.

headline: Euro Zone Economy Stalls as Germany and France Backtrack
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Output slowed in Germany, Europe’s largest economy, and declined in France, the statistical agency of the European Union reported.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The euro zone economy marked time in the third quarter of the year, growing just 0.1 percent from the second quarter, a report on Thursday showed, disappointing hopes that a full-fledged recovery was finally taking hold after five years of recession and stagnation.

headline: A Civil Rights Photographer, and a Struggle, Are Remembered
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Organized Labor', 'Photography', 'Strikes']
abstract: By chronicling the Delano grape strike in California in the 1960s, Jon Lewis exposed the harrowing story of labor behind the fruits and vegetables that Americans consumed without thought.
lead_paragraph: Jon Lewis shot thousands of archetypical civil rights photographs in the late 1960s: a picket line snaking along the horizon, children playing in squalor, activists huddled in a strategy session. What makes these photographs different is their location and the subjects. Taken in central California and not in the Jim Crow South, they depict farm laborers of Mexican and Filipino descent, the vanguard of the historic Delano grape strike.

headline: When the Doctor Disappears
abstract: Some patients want their physicians with them until the very end. But often that’s not how it works out.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Daniel Geynisman felt as if he had abandoned his patient, a sickening sensation.

headline: God Called Them to Adopt. And Adopt. And Adopt.
abstract: When responding to a calling to take in foster children, how do you know when you’ve done enough?
lead_paragraph: Misty and her husband, Jon, arrived at a house near Denver one day several years ago to pick up the two boys who would become their sons. A dirt yard led to a screen door dangling from its hinges. Inside, grime coated the linoleum steps to the living room, where a kind, if overwhelmed, single foster mother introduced Misty and Jon to Shon, 2 ½ years old, and his 9-month-old brother, Cory. She gave the couple a tiny suitcase with a broken zipper, a few borrowed clothes — some too big, others too small — and a piece of advice: Don’t touch Shon’s head or lift your hands near him. He will cower. Then she handed Jon a huge bag of frozen fish sticks. The kids love them, she said.

headline: How Important Are Parent-Teacher Conferences?
abstract: Student Opinion | How much do you believe parent-teacher conferences benefit students?
lead_paragraph: A recent Room for Debate feature presented a variety of views on the value of parent-teacher conferences.

headline: New York Today: Cabs of a Different Color
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: a taxi for the boroughs, plenty of sunshine and a young lover for an aging bear.
lead_paragraph: Updated 2:50 p.m. | A strange species of transport is appearing around the city: taxi cabs painted a sickly sour-apple green.

headline: Iceland Is Building a National Team to Watch
abstract: Iceland, with a population of about 325,000, will become the smallest country ever to qualify for the World Cup finals if it can get past Croatia.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With all due respect to Cristiano Ronaldo and Zlatan Ibrahimovic, whose egos go head to head for Portugal against Sweden on Friday, the good folks of Iceland will not even glance at the score coming from Lisbon.

headline: China Increases Aid to Philippines
abstract: After criticism that its initial donation was too small, China will  provide $1.4 million in relief supplies, the state news agency said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has announced that it is increasing its humanitarian assistance to typhoon victims in the Philippines, after international groups and a Chinese newspaper criticized an initial government donation of $100,000 as too meager.

headline: French Muscle, American Cheese
abstract: France sees American wavering and retreat in the Middle East, and warns of the danger of a "strategic void."
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French-American relations, often a study in how close love can be to hatred, have taken an interesting turn of late. The cheese-eating surrender monkeys of France, in the phrase from “The Simpsons,” have become the world’s meat-chomping enforcement tigers. As for the United States, it has, in the French view, gone a touch camembert-soft.

headline: Ravaged by Typhoon, Philippines Faces Threat of Serious Diseases
abstract: Illnesses that thrive in tropical, fetid environments, where sewage and water supplies intermingle, could form what doctors fear is the disaster’s second wave.
lead_paragraph: The aftermath of the Philippines typhoon is now threatening the country with outbreaks of debilitating and potentially fatal diseases, including some thought to have been nearly eradicated, because of a collapse in sanitation, shortages of fresh water and the inability of emergency health teams to respond quickly in the week since the storm struck, doctors and medical officials said Thursday.

headline: Slowdown in Japan Raises the Pressure on Abe
abstract: Exports and consumer spending displayed signs of weakening after strong growth in the first half of the year, a government estimate on Thursday showed.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is now under more pressure to deliver on his much-promoted effort to improve the country’s long-term growth prospects, after a government estimate on Thursday showed that the economy had slowed in the quarter that ended in September.

headline: What the Proposed Crowdfunding Rules Could Cost Businesses
abstract: A small business that elects to raise money from the masses should prepare for a lifetime of disclosure and fees, if recently proposed rules from the Securities and Exchange Commission take effect.
lead_paragraph: A small business that elects to raise money from the masses should prepare for a lifetime of disclosure and fees. According to the recently proposed rules from the Securities and Exchange Commission, a crowdfunded company will have to file annual reports until either all of its crowdfunded securities have been bought out, it goes public or it is dissolved.

headline: India Pays Homage as Its Greatest Cricketer Nears Retirement
keywords: ['Bowling', 'Careers and Professions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cricket (Game)', 'Stadiums and Arenas']
abstract: Over five days, India will hold its breath as it bids farewell to Sachin Tendulkar, its greatest, and most beloved, sporting hero.
lead_paragraph: Long before Sachin Tendulkar arrived at the Eden Gardens cricket ground in Kolkata for the penultimate cricket match of his career, a wax statue of the greatest Indian cricketer was placed outside the Indian dressing room. The statue reproduced an image embedded in the psyche of every Indian cricket fan. It was the gesture the 40-year-old Mr. Tendulkar adopted whenever he reached a scoring landmark: cricket bat raised in one hand, helmet in the other.

headline: What to Watch For at the Yellen Hearing
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In questioning by the Senate Banking Committee, Janet L. Yellen, the nominee to lead the Federal Reserve, is likely to be asked about the direction of monetary policy and the outlook for regulation of big banks.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen is widely expected to win confirmation as the Federal Reserve’s first chairwoman. Her appearance before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday morning is mostly a chance for senators to probe what kind of leader she will be.

headline: Daily Report: Snapchat Waits for a Better Offer Than Facebook’s
abstract: The rising social media platform, popular with teenagers, rejected a buyout offer worth billions of dollars because its founders believe making a deal now would leave billions more on the table.
lead_paragraph: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media platform run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif., Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: The Jon Stewart of Egypt Is Gagged
abstract: The military-backed government is no more tolerant of political satire than the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When the Egyptian comedian Bassem Youssef came back on the air late last month, everyone wondered whether he would have the courage to mock the army and its leader, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, as he once did the Islamists and former President Mohamed Morsi — and whether he’d get away with it.

headline: Hezbollah Chief Says His Forces Will Stay in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the militant group, was addressing tens of thousands of followers marking a major Shiite religious holiday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The head of Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militant group whose armed followers are fighting in Syria on the side of President Bashar al-Assad, pledged on Thursday that his forces would remain there as long as necessary.

headline: Former German President Goes on Trial
abstract: Christian Wulff resigned in 2012 after prosecutors began investigating allegations that he accepted bribes and favors from businessmen.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For the first time in modern German history, a former president, Christian Wulff, went on trial on Thursday in a state court in Hanover, charged with illegally accepting favors while he was governor of the state of Lower Saxony.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Member of China’s Elite Tied to JPMorgan
abstract: To promote its standing in China, JPMorgan Chase turned to a consulting firm run by the only daughter of Wen Jiabao. | JPMorgan Chase got a very negative taste of Twitter’s power. | Snapchat has joined the list of tech companies with no money coming in but multiple sky-high takeover offers. | Multinational corporations are avoiding taxes by moving intellectual property overseas.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN’S TIES TO A MEMBER OF CHINA’S ELITE  |

headline: Amy Errett of Madison Reed, on Finding Your Genius
abstract: The chief executive and co-founder of a provider of in-home hair color talks about her company’s weekly cocktail hour and discussions on emotional words.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Amy Errett, chief executive and co-founder of Madison Reed, a provider of in-home hair color, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Food and Fuel Prices Push Indian Inflation Higher
abstract: The October inflation reading of 7 percent means levels remain uncomfortably high for policy makers trying to battle sluggish growth.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India’s benchmark inflation rate increased to 7 percent in October, the highest in eight months, driven primarily by higher fuel and food prices, according to government data released on Thursday.

headline: European Banking Unity Is No Easy Target
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As finance ministers gathered in Brussels to discuss how to  fix sick banks, a German report indicated why a uniform remedy might be hard to achieve.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Low interest rates have a dark side, the German central bank warned on Thursday, sounding a gloomy note as European finance ministers gathered in Brussels to discuss the politically tricky question of how to share responsibility for fixing sick banks.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: ‘The Rise and Fall of Paramount Records, Volume One (1917-1927)’
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: the ultimate gift for the music lover.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Hungry and Panhandling
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A man on a Downtown Brooklyn street is pretty pushy.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Holidays: A Bit More Giving, a Bit Less Getting
abstract: There are many ways to teach children to be generous without denying them the usual pile of gifts.
lead_paragraph: Some people react to my obsession with parenting, money and values by assuming that it has little to do with them. Take my friends in a low-key Midwestern state, who are both public-sector employees. Wasn’t this topic, they wondered, something that only affluent suburban parents or private-school people needed to worry about?

headline: Storied French Piano Manufacturer to Close
abstract: The company was founded in 1807 by Ignaz Pleyel, who studied with Josef Haydn.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ending an era on a mournful chord, Pleyel, the storied French piano manufacturer whose pianos were once favored by Frédéric Chopin and Maurice Ravel, has announced that it will close its workshop after two centuries of production.

headline: Air France-KLM Signals Wavering Faith in Alitalia
abstract: The French-Dutch airline says it will not take part in a plan to inject 300 million euros into the faltering Italian flag carrier.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Air France-KLM, the French-Dutch airline, said Thursday that it would not take part in a plan to inject 300 million euros into Alitalia, arguing that the faltering Italian flag carrier was not prepared to take sufficient steps to reduce its mounting debt.

headline: Homeless Kids in Rough Schools
abstract: The census of homeless school children has grown dramatically in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Working-aged adults who lost their jobs, homes and savings to the recession will have a difficult enough time establishing normal lives when the economy rights itself. The trauma will be especially deep and long lasting for the burgeoning population of children who were driven into homelessness — or even given up by their parents — when the world turned upside down in the Great Recession of 2008.

headline: Yellen’s Confirmation Hearing
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the nominee to succeed Ben S. Bernanke as chief of the Federal Reserve, faces questioning from the Senate Banking Committee.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testified Thursday before the Senate Banking Committee at a hearing on her nomination to succeed Ben S. Bernanke as Fed chief. In her opening statement, released by the Fed on Wednesday, Ms. Yellen made the case for the Fed’s current stimulus program, declaring, “I believe that supporting the recovery today is the surest path to returning to a more normal approach to monetary policy.” A running account of the hearing follows.

headline: Knee or Hip Replacement Cuts Heart Risks
abstract: For people with severe arthritis, knee or hip replacement may have an added benefit: a reduction in the risk for cardiovascular disease.
lead_paragraph: For people with severe arthritis, knee or hip replacement may have an added benefit: a reduction in the risk for cardiovascular disease.

headline: Census Shows Shift in New York’s Population Dynamic After Recession
abstract: The city’s net outflow generally remains lower than it was before the recession began, and immigration has surged to nearly 10-year highs, according to new data from the Census Bureau.
lead_paragraph: The recession, which officially ended in 2009, affected New York City’s population dynamic in two ways. People who might have left the city didn’t, in part because they couldn’t sell their homes or weren’t lured to jobs elsewhere. Also, the influx of foreigners from abroad slowed.

headline: Can We Outgrow Growth (as the Metric That Matters)?
abstract: Can the world shift meaningfully from pursuing growth for its own sake? A U.N. discussion.
lead_paragraph: I’m running a discussion this morning at the United Nations focusing on a core issue on this blog: “Do We Have to Outgrow Growth?”

headline: Groups Mobilize to Aid Democrats in ’14 Data Arms Race
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: Without the Obama campaign’s vaunted technological muscle, Democrats are trying to get up to speed for the midterm elections and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Liberal and Democratic-leaning groups, facing difficult midterm elections next year without the technological muscle of the Obama campaign behind them, are preparing a major effort to improve their data infrastructure.

headline: Ireland Is to Exit Its Bailout, and Without a Safety Net
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The country said that it opted against first seeking a precautionary credit line.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ireland announced on Thursday that it would make a clean break from its international bailout program next month and do it without first seeking a precautionary credit line.

headline: Starboard Joins Fight Over Fate of Compuware
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The hedge fund disclosed on Thursday that it owns a 5 percent stake in the business software maker as it urged the company to consider a sale or other changes.
lead_paragraph: Compuware has already spent the better part of the year fending off one activist shareholder. Now, it faces another.

headline: With Bulls, It’s No Walk in the Park
abstract: Images from the Great Bull Run in Conyers, Ga., which included an event called the Tomato Royale.
lead_paragraph: Images from the Great Bull Run in Conyers, Ga., which included an event called the Tomato Royale.

headline: Running of the Bulls Comes to America
abstract: Thousands risked themselves during the Great Bull Run, an Americanized version of Spain’s running of the bulls.
lead_paragraph: Thousands risked themselves during the Great Bull Run, an Americanized version of Spain’s running of the bulls.

headline: Crime Boss Bulger Gets 2 Life Terms and Is Assailed by Judge for His ‘Depravity’
abstract: James (Whitey) Bulger, Boston’s most notorious gangster, was sentenced for crimes including 11 murders, racketeering, extortion and money laundering, and will most likely end his days behind bars.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — James (Whitey) Bulger, Boston’s most notorious gangster, was condemned on Thursday to spend the rest of his life in prison, receiving two life sentences plus five years.

headline: For Thrill Seekers, a Bull Run With a Different Hook
abstract: The Great Bull Run, operated by two young lawyers who had wearied of their profession, offers thrill seekers opportunities to “grab life by the horns.”
lead_paragraph: CONYERS, Ga. — The 600 runners were limbering up for what they had been assured would be “the most awesome adventure” of their lives. And what might that be? They were paying for the opportunity to be chased around a dusty, quarter-mile track by an angry herd of stampeding bulls.

headline: Obama Moves to Avert Cancellation of Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Obama, bowing to pressure, said insurers could temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled. But there is no guarantee that insurers will do so, or that the states will allow the renewals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, trying to quell a growing furor over the rollout of his health care law, bowed to bipartisan pressure on Thursday and announced a policy reversal that would allow insurance companies to temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled under the new law because they did not meet minimum standards.

headline: Players, Here’s the Drill
abstract: David Harewood, Orlando Bloom and other actors tell how they meet the technical demands of performing Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: Less than an hour before he was due to roar onto the stage on a motorcycle in “Romeo and Juliet,” Orlando Bloom strode along the gilded balcony of the Richard Rodgers Theater, contorting his mouth and making peculiar noises. “Imagine managing an imaginary menagerie,” he said so fast that the words blurred together, then repeated the tongue twister, more complex this time. He fluttered his lips like a horse, exhaling.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Forever – Is Composed of Nows –’
abstract: Emily Dickinson is the subject of this Poetry Pairing, which features her poem “Forever – is composed of Nows –” and the article “Enigmatic Dickinson Revealed Online” by Jennifer Schuessler.
lead_paragraph: This Poetry Pairing pays tribute to Emily Dickinson (1830-86) and the scholars and archivists whose efforts ensure the poems, letters and other materials she left behind are preserved and accessible. We pair her poem “Forever – Is Composed of Nows –” with the article “Enigmatic Dickinson Revealed Online” by Jennifer Schuessler.

headline: In Our Pages: November 15
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1938: Rich Jews Told to Pay Fines

headline: What Makes a Great Shakespearean?
abstract: When it comes to Shakespeare, most actors are merely players. What does it take to become a master?
lead_paragraph: Tastes in acting, as in everything else, certainly vary, but a great Shakespearean performance is easy to spot. You know one when you see one, although it’s probably more accurate to say that you know one when you don’t see one: when the language no longer feels remote, when the humanity of the actor and the character seem indivisible, when the emotion being expressed is no longer veiled by poetic phrasing but revealed by it, creating a shock of recognition in your own heart.

headline: Some Help on the Nonrefundable Front
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Reservations (Airlines, Hotels, Etc.)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Roomer website allows users to buy and sell reservations, helping travelers deal with non-refundable bookings.
lead_paragraph: Nonrefundable hotel rates — they’re often the downfall of the thrifty traveler. While cheaper rates can be alluring, there is almost nothing more maddening than paying for a room you are not sleeping in owing to circumstances beyond your control.

headline: Amy Tan: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The Valley of Amazement” and “The Joy Luck Club” fantasizes about catching up on reading in prison: “No email, no useless warranties, . . . no invitations to fund-raisers.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The Valley of Amazement” and “The Joy Luck Club” fantasizes about catching up on reading in prison: “No email, no useless warranties, . . . no invitations to fund-­raisers.”

headline: Robert Plant Produces a Documentary Series About Malian Music
abstract: The former Led Zeppelin frontman has assembled footage of his visit to a music festival in 2003 into a new series to be published online.
lead_paragraph: When the singer Robert Plant visited Mali to perform at the Festival in the Desert, in 2003, he brought a video camera and documented Malian life, both in towns and in the desert, as well as the festival itself. Mostly, Mr. Plant was the cameraman; on occasion, Logan, his son, took over. Also with Mr. Plant on the trip, and seen in the footage, were Justin Adams and Skin Tyson, who both played bass and guitars in Mr. Plant’s band at the time, the Strange Sensation. (With Mr. Plant, formerly of Band of Joy, Led Zeppelin, the Honeydrippers and others – including, most recently, a new version of Band of Joy – you really can’t tell the players without a scorecard.)

abstract: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets — perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.
lead_paragraph: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets — perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Remember when there was no safer play in fantasy football than Tom Brady? He may be that player again, but he has his work cut out for him in Week 11 against the Carolina Panthers.

abstract: Children’s Day celebrated in India.

headline: A Sign of Desperation in Facebook’s Snapchat Offer
abstract: There’s a disquieting element about a company spending billions for a simple application it could almost certainly have replicated for next to nothing.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s Snapchat bid shows triple the desperation. The social network paid $1 billion for no-revenue Instagram a little over a year ago. Now, it’s said to be dangling as much as $3 billion to lure a mobile app that sends self-destructing digital images. Facebook’s apparently escalating need to buy off marauders at its moat suggests its defenses may be scalable.

headline: Siding With Google, Judge Says Book Search Does Not Infringe Copyright
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Authors Guild said it disagreed with the decision and planned to appeal. Google said it was “delighted” with the outcome.
lead_paragraph: Google’s idea to scan millions of books and make them searchable online seemed audacious when it was announced in 2004. But fast-forward to today, when people expect to find almost anything they want online, and the plan seems like an unsurprising and unavoidable part of today’s Internet.

headline: Furniture by Lockwood de Forest and His Peers
abstract: Museums like the Cooper-Hewitt and Olana will be showing 19th-century furniture by masters of the craft.
lead_paragraph: The plutocrats of 19th-century New York relied on a handful of furniture makers who all knew one another. The connections among patrons and artisans have become more traceable in recent months, since rooms full of original commissions — with Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Moorish and Egyptian motifs — are being reassembled around the country. “It’s the most incredibly interlocking society,” Sarah D. Coffin, the lead decorative arts curator at the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, said in an interview. She was leafing through images of works by Lockwood de Forest and his cousin-in-law and business partner Louis Comfort Tiffany, made for the museum building’s first owner, Andrew Carnegie.

lead_paragraph: TKTK

headline: On Philippines Relief, Comparing the U.S. and China
abstract: China initially donated a paltry $100,000 to the rescue effort.
lead_paragraph: American marines landed in the Philippines this week, the vanguard of an operation to help thousands of desperate victims of the worst typhoon in recent decades. The United States is also sending an aircraft carrier, other ships, 5,000 sailors and $20 million, just to start. Meanwhile, China, the world’s second largest economy and the rising power that so many countries in Asia fear, initially donated a paltry $100,000 to the rescue effort. According to Xinhua, it then bumped the number to $1.4 million, still pretty meager.

headline: Reed, Not Ready for End, Joins Jets and Reunites With Ryan
abstract: The Jets on Thursday signed Ed Reed, 35, a nine-time Pro Bowler who was released by Houston. He was coached by Rex Ryan in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Ed Reed, a nine-time Pro Bowl safety, did not have the right uniform number, the right shoes at practice, or the right look for his first on-camera interviews as a member of the Jets.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Player Tiers
abstract: Applying an algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data reveals natural tiers and clusters within the data.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Travel Guide: Chicago for Kids
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Museums', 'AQUARIUMS', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: With friendly museums, tours and trolleys, the city is easy to visit with children. Don’t stick to downtown, there’s much more to discover beyond.
lead_paragraph: Much of Chicago is surprisingly easy to visit with children, maybe even too easy. There is an array of kid-friendly museums, shops, shows, trolleys and tours, centrally located and positioned so close that they require little transportation or street smarts. And you will get few dirty looks when someone spills something or throws a tantrum. Chicago is used to that.

headline: Backing Off  ‘Wanting It All’  From a Spouse
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Women and Girls', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Deborah Anna Luepnitz, a couples therapist, says an unhappy spouse can benefit by realizing that “sometimes what is lacking in your partner is what you lack yourself.”
lead_paragraph: In last week’s Unhitched, Ed and Arlene Petty discussed some of the issues that led to their divorce after 28 years of marriage, including her feelings of discontent after their last child left for college (“When Nest Emptied, Discontent Entered”). As a follow-up, we asked a couples therapist about the role of expectations in a marriage. Did you face a similar issue in your divorce? Or were you faced with other challenges? If so, we’d like to hear from you for this series.

headline: The Great Writ, North and South
abstract: Was Jefferson Davis really a better protector of habeas corpus than Abraham Lincoln?
lead_paragraph: During the Civil War both the federal and Confederate governments had to deal with a pressing question far from the battlefield: how to balance the rights enshrined in their respective constitutions against effectively fighting the war.

headline: For Filipino Workers Abroad, ‘There Is Nothing Worse Than the Waiting’
abstract: Many domestic workers from the Philippines are still waiting for news of families left behind in areas struck by Typhoon Haiyan.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I read about the typhoon was actually on Facebook. Posted on one of my friend’s status updates was something about the wind getting stronger in our part of the Philippines. After that, all of my friends began to panic.

headline: Speculation, Spoilers and Sequels: Making Inferences to Predict What Happens Next
abstract: In this lesson, students will apply inferencing skills to create comics, videos, or “missing chapters” showing what happens after their favorite literary works end.
lead_paragraph: Overview | How do great authors build suspense and keep us engaged? What skills do readers need to make predictions? In this lesson, students will discuss how they “read” their favorite television shows in order to make predictions about what will happen, then apply these skills to speculate about what happens to literary characters after their favorite novels or plays end. Finally, they will use the inferences they gain through close reading to create imagined futures for these characters in comic strips, next chapters, letters, journals or videos.

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing part of Amazon’s sprawling online empire, is known for its globe-spanning system of millions of computer servers, data storage systems and complex software, estimated to be five times larger than 14 other cloud computing providers combined.
