headline: Poems Against Loss: Joan Naviyuk Kane Talks About ‘Hyperboreal’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Ms. Kane’s new book won the 2012 Donald Hall Prize in Poetry.
lead_paragraph: The poems of Joan Naviyuk Kane are lyrical blasts from a far northern landscape of history and myth. From the first lines of her second book, “Hyperboreal,” just published by the University of Pittsburgh Press, Ms. Kane transports us: “Arnica nods heavy-headed on the bruised slope./Peaks recede in all directions, in heat-haze,/Evening in my recollection.” The poet Arthur Sze, who picked the book for the 2012 Donald Hall Prize in Poetry, calls her poems “vivid, disturbing and mysterious.” Ms. Kane, 36, is Inuit/Inupiaq and lives a few miles from where she grew up in Anchorage. Her family originally came from King Island and Mary’s Igloo, Alaska. Recruited by Harvard, she attended the university as an undergraduate, and then earned an M.F.A. from Columbia. Below are excerpts from an email interview.

headline: In Yellen Hearing, Senators Push for Fed Changes
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senators raised few questions about the qualifications of Janet L. Yellen, the nominee for Federal Reserve chairwoman, but criticized the central bank’s policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The questions that Janet L. Yellen faced on Thursday from senators considering her nomination to lead the Federal Reserve made two things fairly clear: The job is hers, and it’s not going to be easy.

headline: Woman, Guilty of Stalking Alec Baldwin, Gets 6-Month Term
abstract: Genevieve Sabourin, an aspiring actress who said she had a brief affair with the actor three years ago, was sentenced to 210 days in jail.
lead_paragraph: After a week of courtroom drama, featuring a star turn from Alec Baldwin and tearful histrionics from a woman accused of stalking him, it was a judge who had the last and defining word on Thursday: guilty on all charges.

headline: They Call Me ‘Dr. Kevorkian’
abstract: As one of the only doctors I know who straddles the worlds of intensive care and palliative care, I am struck by how many of my colleagues are surprised, even disturbed, by this pairing.
lead_paragraph: The patient had a severe pneumonia of advanced AIDS. He’d been lying in our intensive care unit for three weeks, a breathing tube thrust into his raw airway, his face a mixture of pain and resignation. His weakened lung tissue had popped in several areas, requiring chest tubes to drain the pockets of pressurized air. He looked like a sea creature with multiple tentacles.

headline: Yellen’s Opening Remarks
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, at her confirmation hearing before Congress to become the Federal Reserve’s first chairwoman, defended the Fed’s steps to spur economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, at her confirmation hearing before Congress to become the Federal Reserve’s first chairwoman, defended the Fed’s steps to spur economic growth.

headline: Skal
abstract: Inside the Nordic restaurant where the cooking tilts toward Noma.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Nordic restaurant where the cooking tilts toward Noma.

headline: Following Nordic Tracks
abstract: At Skal, the menu reads like a bistro’s in places. The chef’s fondness for his ingredients may explain the depth of flavor he coaxes from vegetables.
lead_paragraph: At Skal, three little smelt lie in a chipped bowl, crispy tails flipped upward. You expect crunch and maybe a whiff of the sea, nothing more. But what you get is subtler and stranger: a texture like sopped bread and a burst of brine, both from within (the smelt are stuffed with capers) and without (a splash of apple cider vinegar after the smelt are dusted with rye flour and fried).

headline: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Running a Fabulous French Chateau
abstract: The interior designer Timothy Corrigan has spent years overseeing the restoration of a 40,000-square-foot estate in the Loire Valley. Here’s how he keeps tradition alive.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Corrigan works hard when he’s home in Los Angeles, but no less so when he’s on vacation at his chateau in France’s Loire Valley. For the past four years, the interior designer has overseen a meticulous restoration of the 40,000-square-foot country house he purchased there in 2004 for an undisclosed amount, driven by his passion for what the French call l’art de vivre. Most people who could live this way today opt for convenience instead. But recently, “Downton Abbey” has ignited a fascination with how estates like this one, which was built between 1760 and 1764 and has hosted everyone from Voltaire to Lee Radziwill, operate in the modern world. (It’s the subject of Corrigan’s new book, “An Invitation to Chateau du Grand-Lucé: Decorating a Great French Country House,” $65.) Here’s a look at how Corrigan keeps tradition alive, and at what cost.

headline: In Iraq, a Day of Religious Observance, and of Blood
abstract: A wave of attacks against Shiite Muslims killed at least 47 people and wounded dozens as they were marking the holy day of Ashura.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A wave of attacks against Shiite Muslims in Iraq killed at least 47 people and wounded dozens on Thursday, security officials said, as they were marking the holy day of Ashura, which commemorates the killing of Imam Hussein, a grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, 1,300 years ago.

headline: Wolf to Dog: Scientists Agree on How, but Not Where
abstract: A new study points to Europe, not East Asia, the latest chapter in a debate that shows the challenges of  piecing together the history of a species.
lead_paragraph: Where did dogs come from? That simple question is the subject of a scientific debate right now. In May, a team of scientists published a study pointing to East Asia as the place where dogs evolved from wolves. Now, another group of researchers has announced that dogs evolved several thousand miles to the west, in Europe.

headline: New Interactive Tool Helps Track Earth’s Forests
abstract: Researchers working with Google have created a way to monitor the gains and losses of  forest cover using a dozen years of satellite images.
lead_paragraph: As carbon emissions build and environmentalists grow more certain of the consequences, scientists have been searching for more precise ways to track the state of Earth’s vast expanses of forest.

headline: Google Employees Speak Out About Government Spying
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The Google lawyer who oversees national security requests testified before Congress Wednesday, while in an unofficial capacity, Google security engineers lambasted the government for surveillance.
lead_paragraph: Google’s canned responses to reports of government spying have ranged from “concerned” to “outraged.” But some of its employees have been more outspoken.

headline: A Touch of the Toxic, for Good or Ill
abstract: An exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History explores poison from many points of view, from the world of literature and history to the world of science and medicine.
lead_paragraph: Vampire bat saliva and a zebra longwing butterfly, devil’s gardens and fossilized fish teeth, golden-frog secretions and the sap of a manchineel tree: Pity the poor witches of Shakespeare’s “Macbeth” who had to settle for “tooth of wolf” and “tongue of dog.” Their boiling caldron makes an appearance in an exhibition opening Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History — “The Power of Poison“ — and so do they, black robed and stirring the pot as green smoke rises. But they don’t possess even a fraction of the esoteric ingredients the museum has assembled for this elaborate show, nor do they have the museum’s powers to brew something so alluring out of such potentially grim material.

headline: Hotels, a Place to Lay Your Head, or Bury It in a Book
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: To serve guests with time to read, hotels build a literary trove just outside their rooms.
lead_paragraph: Traditional brick-and-mortar bookstores have proved vulnerable to e-books and the web, but many new hotels aim to distinguish themselves with old-fashioned pages that guests can actually turn, housing libraries that range from historic collections to trendy ones.

headline: Dylan Joins France’s Legion of Honor
abstract: Bob Dylan was presented with France’s highest prize on Wednesday, the latest in a long string of awards.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan added a new ribbon and pendant to his bucket of medals on Wednesday, when he was awarded the Legion of Honor, France’s highest prize, in a ceremony in Paris. The award was presented by the French minister of culture, Aurélie Filippetti, who praised him as an inspiration for young listeners who crave justice and independence, the BBC reported.

headline: Fairy Tale Ending in the Horror Realm
keywords: ['Movies', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Chester Novell Turner, who briefly made horror movies in the 1980s, is being cheered by fans at sold-out screenings and is the subject of a DVD boxed set.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, when the home-video revolution turned backyard directors into VHS auteurs, Chester Novell Turner lived his childhood dream of making horror movies. He bought a video camera, borrowed money from his mother and enlisted the help of buddies, a girlfriend and a preacher to make two ultra-low-budget movies that looked as if they were shot in a basement, because, in some cases, they were. “Black Devil Doll From Hell” was about a kindly woman who is raped by a ventriloquist’s dummy; “Tales From the Quadead Zone” was a trilogy of shorts that featured a killer clown and the ghost of a dead child. As word slowly spread about Mr. Turner’s gritty movies with African-American casts — a rarity in the very white horror world — bootleg copies of his films spread like crazy along the VHS underground.

headline: Obama Calls for Patience in Iran Talks
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama argued against a plan to impose new sanctions against Iran while negotiators sought a six-month agreement to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama made a vigorous appeal to Congress on Thursday to give breathing space to his efforts to forge a nuclear deal with Iran, and the prospects for an interim agreement may have improved with the release of a report by international inspectors who said that for the first time in years, they saw evidence that the Iranians have put the brakes on their nuclear expansion.

headline: A Traumatized City Begins to Bury Its Dead
abstract: A group of firefighters lowered unidentified bodies into a mass grave outside Tacloban on Thursday, six days after the city was heavily damaged by Typhoon Haiyan.
lead_paragraph: A group of firefighters lowered unidentified bodies into a mass grave outside Tacloban on Thursday, six days after the city was heavily damaged by Typhoon Haiyan.

headline: Jeter Prepares to Turn a Page and Publish Many Others
abstract: Jeter Publishing, whose first books are expected to be released in 2014, provides a partial answer to fans who have wondered what Derek Jeter plans to do once he retires from baseball.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter, nearing the final act of a storied athletic career, is ready to talk about his life after baseball. He wants to be a book publisher.

headline: A Feast for the Senses at the R Lounge in Times Square
abstract: The R Lounge at Two Times Square, with its glowing panorama and solid drinks, reminds you of why you love living in New York — or would, if you moved there.
lead_paragraph: IT was hard to decide just which was the most memorable sight to be seen from the R Lounge, the second-level bar at the Renaissance Hotel that provides a “wow” of a panorama of Times Square.

headline: The Gun Report: November 14, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: There is no official set of criteria or definition for a mass shooting, but the F.B.I. considers mass murder to be a spasm of violence perpetrated by one person that takes at least four lives in the same location. By that metric, we’ve already had several just this month. And if the wounded are counted, the tally grows even higher.

headline: Obama’s Health Care Promise
abstract: Did the president lie when he said that Americans who like their policies would be able to keep them?
lead_paragraph: There are important questions about whether the fix President Obama offered today for Americans whose insurance policies were cancelled will help them, whether it will hinder the broad goals of the health insurance reform law, and whether it will satisfy the opponents of reform.  We will start to address them later on the editorial page.

headline: Getting Up to Speed With an Apple TV, and Ditching Android Widgets
abstract: For its latest set-top box, Apple recommends an Internet connection of at least 2.5 megabits per second. Plus, how to shed the “Recommended for You” notification on Android.
lead_paragraph: Q. How fast does my Internet connection have to be to stream movies on an Apple TV?

headline: Outsourcing Chores: The Economic Impact
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Outsourcing']
abstract: The positive effect on economic growth would most likely overstate the benefits, because of the way gross domestic product is measured.
lead_paragraph: My It’s the Economy column last Sunday explained how you too can live like an economist: by outsourcing lower-value services in order to give yourself more time to work, do rewarding things with your children or otherwise play. Outsourcing household production usually smacks of something only a hedge-fund billionaire or perhaps the Monopoly Man would do, but it is probably a good investment for plenty of middle-class people, too, since doing so can improve their future expected earnings.

headline: Selections From Obama on Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: President Obama announced a fix to his signature health care law that will allow existing customers to keep their insurance plans.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced a fix to his signature health care law that will allow existing customers to keep their insurance plans.

headline: The Console as Concierge
keywords: ['PlayStation (Video Game System)', 'Xbox (Video Game System)', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Sony’s PlayStation 4, due out on Friday, and Microsoft’s Xbox One, coming in one week, accelerate the game console’s shift to multipurpose machine.
lead_paragraph: THE video game console is dead, and the body has been cold for a long time. Sure, Sony and Microsoft are releasing what everyone describes as new game consoles, but the term is a misnomer. The Sony PlayStation 4, released on Friday, and Microsoft’s Xbox One, due next Friday, are game consoles in the same way that the iPhone is a telephone.

headline: From Roman Gladiators to Marauding Goblins
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)', 'Xbox (Video Game System)']
abstract: Games designed for PlayStation 4 and the Xbox One offer some interesting twists.
lead_paragraph: Here are quick looks at a few games available on the new video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
abstract: As an homage to Charlotte Perriand’s creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernist’s never-realized designs.
lead_paragraph: As an homage to Charlotte Perriand’s creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernist’s never-realized designs.

headline: Train in India Hits Elephants Crossing Track
abstract: The train was crossing through a so-called elephant corridor in West Bengal’s Jalpaiguri district, where collisions are frequent. Five of the animals were killed.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A passenger train speeding through northeast India barreled into a herd of elephants as they crossed a set of tracks late Wednesday, killing five. Their bodies were scattered in pieces, so the authorities were at first unable to count them and reported that seven had died.

headline: Young African Writers Hold Forth in Brooklyn
abstract: The Dweck Center for Contemporary Culture at the Brooklyn Public Library will present readings by emerging African-born writers on Saturday at its central location.
lead_paragraph: The Miser has always felt that New York’s public libraries constitute the kind of cultural and civic asset that’s so obviously valuable yet often taken for granted. In a city of world-class art institutions, museums, performance halls, film festivals and athletic stadiums, some of the most vital programming unfolds among the stacks, as it were, in branches across the five boroughs, and is typically free and open to the public.

headline: Speculation Looms Over Sale of Cohen’s Artworks at Auction
abstract: The answer to the whispered question at art auctions this week — “How’s Steve’s stuff selling?” — in the wake of the guilty plea by Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors.
lead_paragraph: It was a question whispered throughout this week’s contemporary art auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s: “How’s Steve’s stuff selling?”

headline: Things Didn’t Go as Planned
abstract: In the wake of the Great Recession, Alan Greenspan questions fundamental assumptions about economic forecasting.
lead_paragraph: Alan Greenspan is one of the most famous living economists. But he is not what you would call an economist’s economist.

headline: Kljestan Seeks to Impress U.S. With His Play, Not His Mustache
abstract: United States midfielder Sacha Kljestan, who had to defend his mustache in a recent Champions League game, is trying to find playing time with the national team at a loaded position.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Furry facial hair seems to be a perpetual topic in American sports these days, but it also has its moments in the spotlight abroad. During a recent Champions League game between Paris St.-Germain and Anderlecht, United States midfielder Sacha Kljestan, who is a mainstay for the Belgian team, found himself chirping back and forth with the P.S.G. star Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

headline: 50 Years Later, CBS and Grammys to Commemorate Beatles’ Appearance on ‘Ed Sullivan’
abstract: CBS said it would broadcast a two-hour special on Feb. 9, the date the Beatles made their live American television debut in 1964.
lead_paragraph: The 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first visit to the United States is shaping up to be nearly as noisy as the original event, but without crowds of screaming fans congregating at Kennedy Airport and the Plaza Hotel and, of course, without the Beatles themselves. CBS announced on Thursday that it would show a two-hour special, “The Night That Changed America: A Grammy Salute to the Beatles,” on Feb. 9 at 8 p.m. – the same date and time slot (and on the same network) as “The Ed Sullivan Show,” on which the Beatles made their live American television debut. The show will include covers of Beatles songs by current stars (none of which have been announced) in performances to be taped Jan. 27.

headline: Heroes and Crusaders
abstract: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s “Bully Pulpit” is built around two relationships: one between the reformist politicians Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft, and the other between power and the press.
lead_paragraph: If you find the grubby spectacle of today’s Washington cause for shame and despair — and, really, how could you not? — then I suggest you turn off the TV and board Doris Kearns Goodwin’s latest time machine. Let her transport you back to the turn of the 20th century, to a time when this country had politicians of stature and conscience, when the public believed that government could right great wrongs, when, before truncated attention spans, a 50,000-word exposé of corruption could sell out magazines and galvanize a reluctant Congress. The villains seemed bigger, too, or at least more brazen — industrial barons and political bosses who monopolized entire industries, strangled entire cities. And “change” was not just a slogan. “There are but a handful of times in the history of our country,” Goodwin writes in her introduction, “when there occurs a transformation so remarkable that a molt seems to take place, and an altered country begins to emerge.” The years covered in this book are such a time. It makes a pretty grand story.

headline: At Memorial for Lou Reed, Just Music
abstract: There were no speeches at a memorial for Lou Reed held at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Lou Reed lived what was often a loud rock ‘n’ roll life filled with loud rock ‘n’ roll songs. So it was only fitting that an outdoor memorial service held in Manhattan on Thursday began with an unannounced burst of guitar feedback, startling pigeons and passers-by alike, before it coalesced into the opening chords of his song “The Blue Mask,” on which Mr. Reed defiantly sang, “I loathe and despise repentance.”

headline: Attack Ravages Power Grid. (Just a Test.)
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: An unprecedented continental-scale war game was intended to determine how prepared the nation is for a cyberattack against electric systems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In windowless rooms from here to California, nearly 10,000 electrical engineers, cybersecurity specialists, utility executives and F.B.I. agents furiously grappled over 48 hours with an unseen “enemy” who tried to turn out the lights across America. The enemy injected computer viruses into grid control systems, bombed transformers and substations and knocked out power lines by the dozen.

headline: In Bordeaux, Art, Music — and Dance Parties
abstract: Novart, Bordeaux’s biennial art and performance festival, will showcase the work of Michael E. Smith–and there will be dance parties open to the public as well.
lead_paragraph: Bordeaux may largely be known for its wine and history, but under the city’s classical facade, a vibrant contemporary art and performance community, fleeing the high cost of living in Paris, has established itself.

headline: Danny Bowien’s Thanksgiving Pastrami
abstract: Hanukkah and Thanksgiving coincide this year, so the chef Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese Food and Mark Bittman demonstrate how to make holiday pastrami, no smoker necessary.
lead_paragraph: Hanukkah and Thanksgiving coincide this year, so the chef Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese Food and Mark Bittman demonstrate how to make holiday pastrami, no smoker necessary.

headline: Philippine Official Fired for Estimate of 10,000 Dead From Typhoon
abstract: A senior police commander was fired for telling reporters last weekend that the death toll from the typhoon that devastated the nation could exceed 10,000.
lead_paragraph: As the desperate search for survivors continued in the Philippines on Thursday, a senior police commander was fired for telling reporters last weekend that the death toll from the typhoon that devastated the nation could exceed 10,000, according to a government news agency.

headline: He Wrote Himself a Ticket to New York
abstract: John Pollono brings his dark comedy play “Small Engine Repair” to New York from Los Angeles, with himself as star.
lead_paragraph: John Pollono said he was knee deep writing a play about 19th-century Boston, the art of dueling and the myriad rules that govern such gunplay, when it suddenly occurred to him to lighten up.

headline: Harmony Hammond
abstract: Ms. Hammond was on the front lines of the feminist and lesbian art movement in New York in the early 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Gray Associates

headline: Songs of Experience, the Two-Hearted Kind
abstract: Jazz at Lincoln Center contributes to the four-singer, four-dancer revue of Stephen Sondheim tunes, “A Bed and a Chair,” at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Hey, all you hard-core Stephen Sondheim devotees, bet you can’t place this immortal lyric from the musical theater’s master of the mot juste: “Skeedoobeeeewahoowapawayskeebopooeee.”

headline: Eileen Quinlan: ‘Curtains’
abstract: Ms. Quinlan mixes portraiture, cameraless photography and performance to mesmerizing effect in her latest solo show.
lead_paragraph: Miguel Abreu Gallery

headline: Cyprien Gaillard: ‘Today Diggers, Tomorrow Dickens’
abstract: Mr. Gaillard’s first exhibition at the Gladstone Gallery includes giant, slightly altered, out-of-context ready-mades arrayed in a pristine space.
lead_paragraph: Gladstone Gallery

headline: Brad Kahlhamer: ‘A Fist Full of Feathers’
abstract: The paintings in Mr. Kahlhamer’s show spin out references to contemporary Native American and postpunk urban culture.
lead_paragraph: Jack Shainman Gallery

headline: Malerie Marder: ‘Anatomy’
abstract: Ms. Marder specializes in the tricky photographic terrain where sociology and slumming and intimacy and voyeurism meet and overlap.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Tonkonow

headline: Alison Elizabeth Taylor: ‘Surface Tension’
abstract: Ms. Taylor’s latest solo show at James Cohan offers a useful lesson in how not to organize one.
lead_paragraph: James Cohan Gallery

headline: A Haitian Boy’s Needless Death From Diabetes
abstract: On World Diabetes Day, a plea to create universal test strips that will work in any available glucometer.
lead_paragraph: JEAN-PAUL was 12 when he died. A diabetic, he might well have lived if not for a tragically simple problem, common in rural Haiti: the glucose test strips available did not match the only glucometer we had access to in our rudimentary district hospital.

headline: A Spectator’s View of J.F.K.’s Funeral Procession
abstract: Donald Hughes, a retired builder in North Carolina, offered us a look at his photographs of President Kennedy’s funeral procession, which have never been published before.
lead_paragraph: With the 50th anniversary of President Kennedy’s assassination approaching, Donald Hughes, a retired builder in North Carolina, thought someone might be interested in a roll of film he took back when he was a high-school senior. He got in touch with a photographer friend of his in New York, Chris Verene, who in turn reached out to us. We were indeed interested.

headline: How the Russians Discovered America
abstract: “Glorious Misadventures” is Owen Matthews’s tale of Russia’s fantasies of annexing the West Coast of what is now the United States.
lead_paragraph: Since 1981, Russian theatergoers have thrilled to the throbbing romance and power chords that have put the rock opera “Juno and Avos” on course to overtake “The Fantasticks” in a decade or so as the world’s longest-running musical. A cross between “Eugene Onegin” and “Madama Butterfly,” it tells the story of Nikolai Rezanov, a courtier and adventurer in the Napoleonic era, and his doomed love for the fetching Conchita Arguello, finest flower of the Spanish mission in San Francisco. The album of the show’s songs, on its release, sold 10 million copies.

headline: Police Shoot Man Fleeing With Gun in Wisconsin Children’s Hospital
abstract: The police had confronted the man to arrest him on a weapons charge at the suburban Milwaukee hospital.
lead_paragraph: Police in a Milwaukee suburb shot and wounded a man brandishing a handgun inside a children’s hospital on Thursday after officers had tried to arrest him on a warrant inside the hospital’s neonatal care unit, the authorities said. No one else was injured during the shooting.

headline: Rap Genius Says It Will Seek Licenses for Lyrics
abstract: After being called out by a publishers’ group, Rap Genius revealed that it already had a deal with Sony/ATV Music Publishing and would pursue other deals.
lead_paragraph: Rap Genius, a website that was accused by music publishers on Monday of reprinting thousands of song lyrics without permission, revealed that it had a major licensing deal all along — and also indicated that the site was likely to pursue more such deals in the future rather than fight with publishers over copyright.

headline: Rogers Reflects on Season in the Spotlight as a Gay Athlete
abstract: Robbie Rogers, a midfielder with the Los Angeles Galaxy, talked about his decision to come out publicly and his excitement about the future.
lead_paragraph: Robbie Rogers generally prefers to avoid reminiscing. Even this week, as he considered all that had happened over the past 12 months — his decision to announce his sexual orientation, his brief retirement and his return to soccer as the first openly gay male athlete in a prominent North American professional league — he interspersed his memories with sizable dollops of excitement about what lies ahead.

headline: Record Label Owner Playing Along With Tech
keywords: ['Music', 'Disc Jockeys', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Sean Glass, founder of Win Music and a frequent D.J. at tech events, sees Internet services as the future of an industry it devastated.
lead_paragraph: When Alan Chan, the chief executive of Bre.ad, a link-shortening service, gave himself a 30th-birthday party in October, the event took place on a Sunday night — hangovers be damned — in a stylish loft in SoHo. Mr. Chan, who had just sold Bre.ad to Yahoo, had arranged, in the extravagant manner of the New York City tech world, for the Sugarhill Gang, an ’80s-era hip-hop group, to perform. Equally in keeping with local start-up fashion, he had also arranged for his gathering to be managed musically by the D.J. and independent-record-label owner Sean Glass.

headline: Kimberly-Clark to Spin Off Health Care Unit
abstract: The business that would be separated focuses on selling surgical and anti-infection products and medical devices for pain management, respiratory and digestive health.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly-Clark said on Thursday that it would pursue a potential spinoff its health care business, becoming the latest company to slim down its operations to help bolster its stock price.

headline: Health Law Rollout’s Stumbles Draw Parallels to Bush’s Hurricane Response
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s problem-plagued rollout of the Affordable Care Act has led to comparisons of the Bush administration’s response to Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Barack Obama won the presidency by exploiting a political environment that devoured George W. Bush in a second term plagued by sinking credibility, failed legislative battles, fractured world relations and revolts inside his own party.

headline: John Oliver to Leave ‘The Daily Show’ to Host Weekly Show on HBO
abstract: Mr. Oliver was widely praised this summer, when he filled in for Jon Stewart. His new show will have many of the same satirical elements.
lead_paragraph: John Oliver has turned his widely praised stint this summer filling in for Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show” into a regular program of his own on HBO.

headline: Full Transcript of Obama’s News Conference on Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The following is the complete transcript of President Obama’s statements on Thursday about the health law rollout.
lead_paragraph: The following is the complete transcript of President Obama’s press conference on Thursday in Washington. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service.)

headline: Northern Illinois Says It Belongs With the Best
abstract: Led by quarterback Jordan Lynch, the undefeated Huskies, ranked 15th in the B.C.S. standings, have their sights set on another bowl game after defeating Ball State on national television.
lead_paragraph: DeKALB, Ill. — Three weeks ago, Northern Illinois opened the Chessick Practice Center, a $9.5 million building with a full-size indoor turf field that will help its football team cope with Midwestern winters and perhaps further its rise from an anonymous team on the prairie to a national powerhouse.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: the female orgasm, knee ligaments and birthing babies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: the female orgasm, knee ligaments and birthing babies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Virtual Money Draws Notice of Regulators
abstract: New York’s financial services superintendent will conduct a hearing on the feasibility of methods making the virtual currency market more like that for more traditional money.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:15 p.m. | New York’s top financial regulator is looking at issuing a “BitLicense” for businesses that conduct transactions in virtual currencies like bitcoin.

headline: Chicago Said to Weigh Suit Over Marketing of Painkillers
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Subpoenas']
abstract: Lawyers for the city are investigating whether the benefits of the drugs, known as opioids, were overly promoted while their risks were underplayed.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the city of Chicago are investigating marketing claims by producers of narcotic painkillers as a prelude to a possible lawsuit against them, according to interviews and a court filing.

headline: Information on Art Trove to Start Going Online
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: German authorities, trying to speed the identification of some of 1,400 works apparently lost during the Nazi era, said that they would soon begin posting information online.
lead_paragraph: German authorities, trying to speed the identification of some of 1,400 works apparently lost during the Nazi era, said that they would soon begin posting information on 590 of those with questionable provenances on the website lostart.de, a database of art looted or missing since World War II. “Publication will start next week,” according to a statement issued by the Culture Ministry that quoted Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, who spent decades in government service helping to run cultural institutions in Germany and who was appointed to lead a group of art experts tasked with researching the history of the works. So far 25 works have been posted. “Possible rightful claimants can now more quickly identify missing art works and in relevant cases make their claims heard,” the statement said. Such news is welcome to claimants like David Toren, an 88-year-old New Yorker who recognized one of the works, a painting by Max Liebermann, as having once hung in the home of a great-uncle. State prosecutors took possession of the art in February from the apartment of Cornelius Gurlitt as part of a tax case.

headline: Modern Love | Broken Heart Doctor
abstract: After Thomas Hooven graduated from medical school, his girlfriend of 12 years ended their relationship. It was only three weeks before they planned to marry.
lead_paragraph: After Thomas Hooven graduated from medical school, his girlfriend of 12 years ended their relationship. It was only three weeks before they planned to marry.

headline: Wines for Thanksgiving: Mixing Without Trying to Match
abstract: Look for wines — at least a white and a red — that are versatile and nimble enough to go well with a diversity of dishes.
lead_paragraph: When I first came to The New York Times nearly 30 years ago (good God!), I worked with an editor who kept a file labeled “How We Did It Last Time.” Inside were detailed instructions for covering events that occurred regularly but infrequently, like elections. Rather than trying to reconstruct his procedures every time, he simply kept careful track of best practices and pulled out the file when necessary.

headline: Hyperbole and a Book
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Allie Brosh, whose blog “Hyperbole and a Half” attracts as many as five million readers a month, has published her first book.
lead_paragraph: Allie Brosh, whose blog “Hyperbole and a Half” attracts as many as five million readers a month, has published her first book.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Court Orders German Firm to Pay Victims of Defective Breast Implants
abstract: A court in Toulon, France, said the German quality-control company TUV Rheinland had “failed its obligation” to check the implants before issuing safety certificates.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Thursday ordered a German quality-control company to compensate 1,600 victims of defective breast implants made by a French company about $4,000 each, according to news reports.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Philippines, Iran, Gaza and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Philippines, Iran, Gaza and Turkey.

headline: Nursing a Wound in an Appropriate Setting
abstract: Left by his fiancée, a doctor rebuilds himself in the company of his patients.
lead_paragraph: I started my pediatrics residency on the cardiology unit, which was appropriate: my heart had a giant hole in it. Just after I graduated from medical school, as I was moving into my fiancée’s New York apartment, she ended our relationship. We went out to dinner that night, and after we came home, she told me we were through.

headline: A Little Bit of Everything in One Place
abstract: “The Salon: Art & Design” at the Park Avenue Armory has art and antiques from what seems to be every period and place, from Bactrian sculptures to new, exploding furniture.
lead_paragraph: “The Salon: Art & Design,” the smart young fair at the Park Avenue Armory this weekend, is doing an excellent job of splitting the difference between the auction-house randomness and white-cube-gallery control. As its title suggests, it is wide open in terms of material — art, craft, design, antiques from any period or place can be found here. It is up to the dealers to provide the focus, which they do. This means controlled diversity. You can bounce from concentrated views of French Art Deco to early Modern art to pre-Columbian ceramics in one aisle.

headline: A Nibble to Keep the Wine Company
abstract: Gougères, little savory French cream puffs seasoned with cheese, can be offered to guests alongside a glass as they arrive for Thanksgiving dinner.
lead_paragraph: At the Thanksgiving wine tasting, we started on the drinks before the food was served. There’s a good chance we’ll do that at home, too. But with the idea of offering guests a little something alongside a glass as they arrive for Thanksgiving, enough to take the edge off without spoiling appetites, I’ll serve gougères, little savory French cream puffs seasoned with cheese. Mine, enriched with cranberries and Cheddar, will pay homage to New England instead of Paris. I’ve made them already. They’re in the freezer, and they’ll be warmed in the oven before I enlist a granddaughter to pass them from a napkin-lined basket.

headline: Playing at DOC NYC
abstract: Select images from films in this documentary festival.
lead_paragraph: Select images from films in this documentary festival.

headline: Power Doses of a Rapper’s Idiosyncratic Religion
abstract: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis brought electric energy to their show at the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: As much as Macklemore is a rapper, he is a motivational speaker, a preacher, a confessor, a scold. In almost every case, his yarn-spinning has a higher purpose, his stories vehicles for universal morals. He presents himself as someone to root for, and in so doing, he’s rooting for you, and everyone else, too.

headline: Love Child of a Renaissance Spirit
abstract: The Choir of Men and Boys at St. Thomas Church and the Fretwork ensemble presented a program of mostly Renaissance works.
lead_paragraph: “My Days” is the title of a program of mostly Renaissance works for voices and viols that was presented Tuesday at St. Thomas  by that church’s Choir of Men and Boys and the wonderful English viol consort Fretwork. It’s also the title of an arresting new work by Nico Muhly, a touching declaration of fraternity with the great Elizabethan composers that had its United States premiere that evening.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: California Shuts Down Sites Mimicking State Insurance Marketplace
abstract: The California attorney general’s office has shut down 10 websites that mimicked state’s official health insurance marketplace.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—The California attorney general’s office has shut down 10 websites that mimicked state’s official health insurance marketplace, the attorney general, Kamala Harris, announced Wednesday.

headline: Guidelines Help Heirs Assume and Modify Loans
abstract: New strategies aimed at keeping lenders from foreclosing on homes when borrowers’ next of kin want to assume the loan.
lead_paragraph: New guidelines from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau are aimed at preventing mortgage servicers from unnecessarily foreclosing on homes after a borrower dies.

headline: When a Deal Goes Bad, Blame the Ratings
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Collateralized Debt Obligations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: A suit by the trustee for two Bear Stearns funds contends that managers relied on ratings by the major credit agencies in purchasing risky securities just before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Did you make an incredibly bad decision during the great credit bubble?

headline: Task Force to Study Crime on Indian Reservations
abstract: The Justice Department named the 12 members who will hold meetings around the country to find ways to combat a surge of violence on Indian reservations.
lead_paragraph: A special Justice Department task force will hold a series of public meetings around the country to study the scope and impact that exposure to violence has on Native American and Alaska Native children, the Justice Department said.

headline: Alexander Payne on 'Nebraska'
abstract: The director discusses his film featuring Bruce Dern and Will Forte.
lead_paragraph: The director discusses his film featuring Bruce Dern and Will Forte.

headline: The Real and Surreal of War Photography
abstract: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Spending Hours on the Co-op Board Minutes
abstract: A co-op board’s minutes provide buyers and their lawyers with the best window into the inner workings of a building.
lead_paragraph: The standard advice to apartment buyers is to make sure someone reviews the board minutes. But why? What’s in the minutes that is so important? It turns out to be quite a bit.

headline: Poignant Images, With Posterity the Ultimate Winner
abstract: The Brooklyn Museum exhibition “War/Photography: Images of Armed Conflict and Its Aftermath” features images of global conflicts since the 1840s.
lead_paragraph: In a photograph shot by Spencer Platt in Lebanon in 2006, the spectacle of five attractive, fashionably dressed young people in a glossy red convertible occupies the foreground. By surrealistic contrast, the immediate background is filled with the smoking wreckage of bombed buildings, where a few pedestrians pass by. While the title obliquely explains, “Beirut Residents Continue to Flock to Southern Neighborhoods,” the impression you get is of obnoxious rich kids out for a sensation-seeking drive.

headline: ‘The Shadows Took Shape’
abstract: The cultural movement called Afrofuturism is the subject of a new show at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The cultural movement called Afrofuturism is the subject of a new show at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

headline: Going Beyond Blackness, Into the Starry Skies
abstract: “The Shadows Took Shape,” at the Studio Museum in Harlem., explores contemporary art through the lens of the interdisciplinary cultural movement Afrofuturism.
lead_paragraph: One day in the late 1930s, Herman Blount, an African-American music student in Alabama, had an unusual experience.

headline: Don’t Do Me Like That
abstract: Addressing matters of fake concert tickets, window seats on a plane, a mother’s fondness for the lottery and an empty room.
lead_paragraph: For 40 years, my wife and I have been best friends with another couple. We all like concerts, so I tried to buy tickets for Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. The event was sold out, but I found four tickets for $900 on Craigslist. With my friend’s permission, I bought them. On concert night, he gave me a check for $450 just before we learned the tickets were fake. I handed back his check, never expecting him to take it. But he did, then suggested we split the loss on his pair for $225. I’d like to tell him I’m disappointed in him. He saw the tickets and approved all my actions. Thoughts?

headline: Where Bulgari’s Rare Baubles Come to Life
abstract: Bulgari opened the doors of its Rome headquarters and nearby laboratory to T for a rare look at how its one-of-a-kind and limited collections of jewelry come together.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Hoofbeats by the Sea
abstract: Will Rawls dives deep into the folklore of the Balkans, with “The Planet-Eaters,” at the Chocolate Factory.
lead_paragraph: Does folk dance have a place in contemporary culture? The intriguing question came to the choreographer Will Rawls after a 2008 life-changing trip to the Balkans. While there, he began thinking about using folklore as a way to discover, in him, a new kind of dancer that could embody both the present and tradition.

headline: An Orange-Haired Dynamo and Friends Grow Up
abstract: A somewhat-changed Paramore still followed Hayley Williams’ energetic lead with its new songs at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Fist pumping, head banging, Finger pointing, high kicking, jumping, racing around the stage and leading arena singalongs, Hayley Williams was in her element when Paramore performed on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden. She was the petite, orange-haired, perpetually animated embodiment of the narrator of her songs, who faces down and joyfully overpowers one frustration after another, moving from complaints and sarcasm to self-empowerment.

headline: The Muse of Goethe, Intensified
abstract: “Faust,” the concluding installment of the “Men of Power” tetralogy, is Alexander Sokurov’s freehanded adaptation of Goethe’s great allegorical drama.
lead_paragraph: In the end credits, a note identifies “Faust,” Alexander Sokurov’s brooding, hallucinatory, freehanded adaptation of Goethe’s great allegorical drama, as the concluding installment of a four-film sequence, the “Men of Power” tetralogy that also includes “Moloch” (1999), “Taurus” (2001) and “The Sun” (2005). Those movies are intimate and unsettling visits with some of the chief monsters of the 20th century: Hitler, Lenin and Hirohito. What links them is a lust for power at once madly destructive and profoundly lonely. While Mr. Sokurov does not exactly express sympathy for these devils, he refuses to view them as anything other than human.

headline: What Should Airlines Do About Children With Peanut Allergies?
abstract: Decisions about limiting the exposure to nuts on airlines are often left to the discretion of an individual flight crew, and they are not always willing to comply.
lead_paragraph: Lianne and Joshua Mandelbaum never step on an airplane without six vials of injectable epinephrine and a bottle of liquid Benadryl. That’s because Joshua, who is 8 years old, is deathly allergic to peanuts. If exposed to them, he can go into anaphylactic shock. But even with the injectable epinephrine, he needs to be rushed to the hospital for emergency care. This makes flying scary; there aren’t many long-term medical options at 35,000 feet in the sky.

headline: We Interrupt This Generation ...
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: President John F. Kennedy’s assassination changed TV, and the industry is mounting a 21-gun salute to commemorate the man and the moment.
lead_paragraph: Life was pre-empted on Nov. 22, 1963.

headline: A Madwoman Lets It Rip
abstract: The Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci presented the American premiere of “Era la Notte” at the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci has concentrated her career in Europe. Each appearance she makes in America, like her New York recital debut last year at Alice Tully Hall, is coveted by opera fans familiar with her intelligent and charismatic artistry.

headline: Key Brazilians in Graft Case Must Go to Jail, Court Says
abstract: More than 20 people, including top legislators, senior governing party figures, officials at Banco do Brasil and businessmen, were originally sentenced more than a year ago.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s highest court has ruled that the powerful figures in the governing Workers Party convicted in a vast vote-buying scheme must soon start their prison terms, a surprising twist in a country where corrupt lawmakers have long been sheltered from punishment.

headline: You May Already Be a Winner. Or Not.
abstract: “Nebraska,” Alexander Payne’s fourth film set at least partly in his home state, stars Bruce Dern, Will Forte and June Squibb in a comedy that gets under a cantankerous older man’s skin.
lead_paragraph: It may or may not be a coincidence that Alexander Payne’s new film, “Nebraska,” shares its name with Bruce Springsteen’s austere album from 1982. Nebraska is a roomy state, and Mr. Payne, born and raised in Omaha, has set three of his previous features at least partly in it (“Citizen Ruth,” “Election” and “About Schmidt”). But to my ear, at least, a specific Springsteenian echo announces itself early and deepens as this movie winds from Billings, Mont., across the Badlands and toward Lincoln, stopping for a while in the tiny and fictitious hamlet of Hawthorne. Beyond the folky intonations of the fiddle-and-guitar waltz (by Mark Orton) that accompanies the opening images (shot by Phedon Papamichael) and beyond the bleak beauty of the images themselves, there is something in the movie that brings to mind the haunting last line of the album’s title track: “Sir I guess there’s just a meanness in this world.”

headline: Four Eccentric Senators as Capitol Hill Roomies
abstract: “Alpha House,” a political comedy written by Garry Trudeau, and the first original TV series from Amazon, follows four Republican senators who share a townhouse near the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing not funny about Washington.

headline: The 2014 Whitney Biennial Is Taking Shape
abstract: Officials overseeing the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art are discussing how the event will unfold beginning in March.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced nearly a year ago that a trio of outside curators would be organizing the 2014 Biennial, each taking a floor of the museum. Each brings a different set of eyes and interests to the show.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Futility of Unplugging, and How to Get Censored on China’s Twitter
abstract: Thursday’s highlights from around the Web include an investigation into how content is censored on Sina Weibo, a popular Chinese social network. Plus, an argument for why the notion of unplugging doesn’t exist anymore.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Women Taking Over Farms, Learning the Lay of the Land
abstract: The number of women operating farms in Texas is growing, and so are opportunities for them to learn the business, from cash-flow management to networking.
lead_paragraph: AMARILLO — DeDe Cummins’s family has farmed in the Texas Panhandle for a century, but no one expected her to have any interest in the work.

headline: Prospecting for Dollars
abstract: Developers with projects in cities around the world are turning their marketing dollars toward New York.
lead_paragraph: International buyers are known for spending big money in New York, be it the woman from China who spent more than $6 million on a home for her toddler at the skyscraper One57, or the daughter of Dmitry Rybolovlev, the Russian potash magnate, who used a trust to pay $88 million for an apartment at 15 Central Park West.

headline: Hedge Fund Moguls Suddenly Turn Eyes to FedEx
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb, George Soros and John Paulson disclosed new positions in FedEx on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Daniel S. Loeb may have broken the news of his firm’s position in FedEx earlier this week, but it turns out that at least two his fellow hedge fund moguls had the same idea in the third quarter.

headline: Would You Like Fries With Those Spicy Pork McBites?
abstract: The new pork treat is in line with the overall global strategy of Western chains tailoring their menus to local tastes.
lead_paragraph: With competition heating up in China’s $174 billion dollar fast-food market, McDonald’s is seeking to up its game by capitalizing on the country’s increasingly voracious appetite for pigs. The result? Spicy Pork McBites.

abstract: A brief malapropism about the Fed’s dual mandate.
lead_paragraph: There were a lot of high points in today’s Senate confirmation hearings, but my favorite may be one particular malapropism about half of the Federal Reserve’s dual mandate. Here’s the excerpt:

headline: The Glory of Rome, the Sweetness of Life
abstract: In “The Great Beauty,” a sybaritic writer, now 65, considers the essence of Rome and his place in it.
lead_paragraph: The first time you see Jep Gambardella, the Roman sensualist magnificently, poetically adrift in “The Great Beauty,” he has a cigarette clenched in the center of his big, bared, ocher-stained teeth. People are surging all around him, their bodies pulsating to music that has transformed a multitude into an organism that beats like a heart. As he sways amid this delirium, Jep smiles with welcoming arms and lidded eyes, an attitude that brings to mind one of those marble saints scattered around Rome forever locked in rapture. And then Jep joins the dance, surrendering to a throng that, in absorbing him, turns an orgiastic reverie into something like a religious communion.

headline: Cancer Agency Is Back in Business, Writing Checks
abstract: With a 2012 moratorium lifted, the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas is again handing out grant money, some of it approved more than a year ago.
lead_paragraph: More than 10 months after state leaders halted grant operations at the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas, known as Cprit, amid allegations of cronyism and misspent money, the $3 billion enterprise is getting back to the business of fighting cancer, with restructured leadership.

headline: West Bank: Palestinian Family’s Home Is Set on Fire
abstract: Hebrew graffiti outside suggested that the arson was an act of revenge for the fatal stabbing of an Israeli soldier by a Palestinian teenager the day before.
lead_paragraph: Assailants burned the entrance of a Palestinian family’s home in the West Bank village of Sinjil early Thursday. Hebrew graffiti sprayed on a stone wall outside suggested that the arson was an act of revenge by Jewish extremists for the fatal stabbing of an Israeli soldier by a Palestinian teenager the day before. The graffiti read “Regards from Eden, revenge!” apparently a reference to Eden Atias, the soldier who was stabbed on a bus in northern Israel. The house, belonging to the Dar Khalil family, which has no known connection with the stabbing, was set on fire as the parents and five children slept inside. They escaped without serious injury. The Israeli police said an investigation was underway. Also Thursday, Israeli warplanes attacked two concealed rocket launchers in northern Gaza after two rockets fired from Gaza landed in southern Israel, according to the military. No injuries were reported on either side.

headline: Pork Belly, Yes; Popovers, No
abstract: The owners of JW’s Public House want diners to savor their “upscale comfort food” without filling up on bread, so they serve a less-filling dish of pickled vegetables instead.
lead_paragraph: Comfort is a warm popover and not a pickled vegetable, if you ask me.

headline: Last Shipment of Nuclear Fuel From Russian Bombs Heads to U.S.
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: Dignitaries in St. Petersburg, Russia, commemorated the end of the Megatons to Megawatts program as uranium made from warhead cores left for Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The final shipment of civilian nuclear reactor fuel made from Soviet atomic bombs left port for the United States on Thursday, ending a post-Cold War program that has been a long-running boon for the American nuclear power industry.

headline: Wisconsin Governor Seeks to Extend Medicaid
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: “We want to make sure nobody falls through the cracks,” said Gov. Scott Walker, citing the troubled rollout of the new federal health care law.
lead_paragraph: Blaming an “abysmal” rollout of the new federal insurance market, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said on Thursday that he would ask the Legislature to allow thousands of low-income residents to remain in the state’s Medicaid program until April 1 — a three-month extension.

headline: Flavors of Portugal on a Cozy Scale
abstract: Brasa Grille, conceived for takeout, serves Portuguese dishes, like grilled cod, in a snug setting in Chatham.
lead_paragraph: The pleasures of eating in the large and lively restaurants of Newark’s Ironbound section are available on a more intimate scale at Brasa Grille, a Portuguese restaurant in Chatham that has attracted regulars since it opened in 2008.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 15-21
abstract: A guide to a range of cultural events in New York, including discussions, film screenings and exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Iranian New Wave 1960s-1970s Film Series (through next Friday) When his documentaries about life in Iran under the pro-Western shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, focused too much on the poverty he saw, Kamran Shirdel — originally commissioned by the government to make these films — was expelled, and forced to leave some work behind. Four of his short films — several completed after the Islamic Revolution of 1979 — will be screened on Wednesday, starting at 6:30 p.m., at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.

headline: Instead of Mail, Delivering Tasty Morsels
abstract: Post 154’s menu of tasty entrees and small plates, many with Latin accents, light up a renovated space in Westport, Conn.
lead_paragraph: If you have not been to Westport recently, you might be surprised to find that its old limestone-and-brick post office, which opened in 1935 on the town’s main thoroughfare, is now a snappy new restaurant, called Post 154, that fairly rocks in prime time.

abstract: With a stuffed primary ballot, it will be expensive and difficult for Texas Republicans to win any real attention from voters.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Europe’s Remarkable Achievement
abstract: Surpassing the 1930s!
lead_paragraph: After sort-of decent growth in the second quarter, Europe’s austerity advocates rushed to proclaim that their policies were bearing fruit. After the latest numbers, which show growth stalling, not so much.

headline: Cameroon: French Priest Kidnapped
abstract: There has been no claim of responsibility, but the Nigerian Islamist militant groups Boko Haram and Ansaru are known to operate in the region, near the border with Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: A French priest was abducted from a monastery in the far north of Cameroon late Wednesday night, the French government and a witness said. There has been no claim of responsibility, but the Nigerian Islamist militant groups Boko Haram and Ansaru are known to operate in the region, near the border with Nigeria. The French government formally advises its citizens to avoid the area, “given the terrorist risk and the risk of kidnapping,” said Romain Nadal, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, in a statement. The priest, identified by the government as Georges Vandenbeusch, was taken by “bandits” who had unsuccessfully sought to open a monastery safe, according to Henri Djongyang, a priest who said he witnessed the kidnapping, which he recounted on the French radio station Europe 1. A French family of seven was kidnapped in the region in February and held for two months by Boko Haram fighters.

headline: Wine and Food Pairings at Thanksgiving
abstract: The winemaker Christopher Tracy at Channing Daughters Winery has released three savory vermouths to fit in at the holiday table.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for Thanksgiving aperitifs, the innovative winemaker Christopher Tracy at Channing Daughters Winery has released three savory vermouths. These nonvintage fortified wines, which contain neutral grape brandy and honey, are named VerVino Variation One, Variation Two and Variation Three.

abstract: Responses to a news article from Richard M. Daley, a former mayor of Chicago, Karen Freeman-Wilson, the mayor of Gary, Ind., and the Baltimore Community Foundation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Venezuela, Campaign Takes the Form of a Fire Sale
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro is trying to quell frustration with the economy ahead of municipal elections by forcing retailers to slash prices.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The transportation minister appeared on live television from an auto-parts store, trumpeting prices that had been slashed in half, at least. A top regional official, broadcasting from another shop, boasted that prices of toys and other goods had been cut to the bone. From an appliance store, the commerce minister called on shoppers to buy washers and dryers at new, low-low prices.

headline: A Reprieve for Midtown
abstract: A reader is grateful that a proposal to raise the East Midtown skyline was dropped.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fortuneteller in Manhattan Is Sentenced to 5 to 15 Years in Prison
keywords: ['Fortune Telling', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena']
abstract: A judge gave the fortuneteller, Sylvia Mitchell, more prison time than prosecutors had requested, saying she had preyed on especially vulnerable people.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Mitchell, the Manhattan fortuneteller whose ornate Greenwich Village parlor and air of uptown sophistication attracted well-to-do, distraught clients who preferred the finer things in life, was sentenced to five to 15 years in prison on Thursday, a month after a jury convicted her of grand larceny.
