lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Government in Egypt Eases Restrictions
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Curfews']
abstract: The interim government lifts a state of emergency and a nighttime curfew after three months — an indication of its confidence in its control of the country.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim government lifted a state of emergency as well as a nighttime curfew late Thursday, signaling its growing confidence in its ability to impose security after the unrest that followed the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi in July.

headline: Surrender, Oblivion, Survival
abstract: In Tacloban, history is our tsunami. And in our seaside shelters, we keep watching the tide return to the Philippines once again.
lead_paragraph: HADLEY, Mass. — TACLOBAN is my city. I grew up directly facing the Pacific Ocean, on the Philippines’ eastern shore, which takes the brunt of the yearly monsoons. Geography and history provide the textbook nickname of Leyte and Samar, the provinces hardest hit by Haiyan: “The Typhoon Path.”

headline: Law Says Hudson River Park Is Allowed to Sell Air Rights
abstract: The measure signed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will let the park on the West Side of Manhattan collect some much-needed revenue.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed into law the bill that will let Hudson River Park, the popular but financially beleaguered greensward on the West Side of Manhattan, sell development rights in order to collect much-needed revenue.

headline: C.I.A. Collects Global Data on Transfers of Money
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The agency is secretly collecting bulk records of international money transfers, under the same law that the National Security Agency uses for its phone record database, according to  government officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency is secretly collecting bulk records of international money transfers handled by companies like Western Union — including transactions into and out of the United States — under the same law that the National Security Agency uses for its huge database of Americans’ phone records, according to current and former government officials.

headline: Who’s Right on the Stock Market?
abstract: Is it possible to regularly beat the stock market averages? Robert Shiller, one of this year’s Nobel Prize-winning economists, has it right.
lead_paragraph: IF you’ve been wondering whether it’s possible to regularly beat the stock market averages — a natural question with the market at an all-time high — you didn’t get any guidance from the Nobel Prize committee this year: Two of the winning economists disagree on that perennial issue.

headline: High Price of Barely Getting By
abstract: In Laurie Collyer’s “Sunlight Jr.,” Naomi Watts and Matt Dillon play unmarried lovers with no way out of the minimum-wage working class.
lead_paragraph: The unmarried lovers in Laurie Collyer’s “Sunlight Jr.” are young working-class Americans buffeted by woe. The feisty, resilient Melissa (Naomi Watts) has a minimum-wage job at the convenience store that gives the movie its name. Her live-in boyfriend, Richie (Matt Dillon), a former TV repairman, has subsisted on disability benefits since a motorcycle accident left him in a wheelchair. Their home is a shabby motel somewhere in west central Florida.

headline: Chief’s Vision for Morgan Stanley Is Showing Some Success
abstract: The bank’s stock is up 59 percent this year, reflecting its growing skill at avoiding the sort of squalls that battered it in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Thunderclouds were gathering in April when James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, went for a run on the beach on Amelia Island in Florida after attending a closed-door meeting of the bank’s top stockbrokers. After just a few miles, the storm began to pick up speed, prompting Mr. Gorman to turn around and head for safety.

headline: A Scrapbook of a Memorable Night for Rock
abstract: The documentary “12-12-12” goes behind the scenes at the Concert for Sandy Relief, with Bruce Springsteen, the Rolling Stones and Kanye West.
lead_paragraph: The rock documentary “12-12-12,” directed by Amir Bar-Lev and Charlie Lightening, is a sustained adrenaline rush. Looking back nearly a year to the night rock’s elder statesmen gathered at Madison Square Garden for a concert to raise money for victims of Hurricane Sandy, it shows what celebrities and corporate honchos can accomplish when they pool their energies for the greater good. The actor Tony Danza, who appears briefly in the film, cites the phrase on the United States seal, “E pluribus unum” (“Out of many, one”), as defining the spirit of the event.

headline: Giants Cornerback Fighting the Image of Being Too Small
abstract: Trumaine McBride has played for five teams in six N.F.L. seasons, always battling the idea that at 5 feet 9 inches he can’t defend against the league’s taller receivers.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ defensive coordinator, Perry Fewell, gave Trumaine McBride, a well-traveled sixth-year cornerback, the opportunity to start in place of the injured Corey Webster five games ago. It was not a decision that left Fewell feeling comfortable.

headline: Under My Thumb
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A dispiriting conflict in Seattle shows exactly why the middle class is having trouble getting ahead.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — This is how the middle class dies, not with a bang, but a forced squeeze. After a global corporation posts record profits, it asks the state that has long nurtured its growth for the nation’s biggest single tax break, and then tells the people who make its products that their pension plan will be frozen, their benefits slashed, their pay raises meager. Take it or we leave. And everyone caves.

headline: Bonds Backed by Solar Power Payments Get Nod
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'United States Economy']
abstract: SolarCity, a leading installer of solar-power systems in the United States, received a low investment-grade rating for the bonds, which will help finance its rapid expansion.
lead_paragraph: Over the decades, Wall Street has used many assets to back up the bonds it sells, including car loans, life insurance policies and future royalties on David Bowie’s music. Now, in a milestone of sorts for the emerging solar industry, the finance wizards are embracing a new kind of security, this one backed by solar electricity payments.

headline: On a Mission Within Earshot of a War, Armed With Paint
abstract: A group of graffiti painters from several countries gathered in the disputed region to add color to a building’s ruins.
lead_paragraph: GOLAN HEIGHTS — The graffiti painter known as Col Wallnuts likes to use exploding bursts of color, hiding the abstract letters that form his tag, or street name, so only he can find them. Last week, he applied his paint on concrete canvases that had themselves been exploded, often amid the sound of bombs detonating not far away in the Syrian civil war.

headline: ‘A Bubble Around My Heart’
abstract: In “Bubble Boy,” a musical at Hamilton Stage for the Performing Arts, a teenager with an impaired immune system travels across the country for true love.
lead_paragraph: You’ll forget many of the songs the moment you leave “Bubble Boy,” a musical being given its world premiere by the American Theater Group in Rahway. Still, when you look back on this likable and lightweight show, you’ll probably remember the good time you had when you first heard them.

headline: The Money Trap
abstract: Will inflation phobia tear Europe apart after the establishment of a common currency was supposed to unite the Continent?
lead_paragraph: When Greece hit the skids almost four years ago, some analysts (myself included) thought that we might be seeing the beginning of the end for the euro, Europe’s common currency. Others were more optimistic, believing that tough love — temporary aid tied to reform — would soon produce recovery. Both camps were wrong. What we actually got was a rolling crisis that never seems to reach any kind of resolution. Every time Europe seems ready to go over the edge, policy makers find a way to avoid complete disaster. But every time there are hints of true recovery, something else goes wrong.

headline: U.S. Dancer Quits the Bolshoi, Complaining of Bribery
abstract: Joy Womack, an American dancer at the prestigious Bolshoi Ballet, says she was told she would have to pay a $10,000 bribe to get a solo role.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A young dancer from Texas who last year joined the Bolshoi Ballet after graduating from its training academy here has quit the storied company after alleging that she was denied opportunities to perform and ultimately told she would have to pay a bribe of $10,000 to get a solo role.

headline: Hazily Hoping for an Easy Hit
abstract: In “Junction,” a group of four addicts attempt what they hope will be an easy, impromptu robbery. Oops.
lead_paragraph: Dope-sick and out of cash, four meth addicts embark on an impromptu robbery in an upscale neighborhood. Their dealer, Tai (Anthony Ruivivar), needs a television as a birthday gift for his mother; in return, David (Tom Pelphrey) — the most rational of the meth heads and the group’s designated driver — will score some product, along with Tai’s unpredictable good will.

headline: Kalaparusha Maurice McIntyre, Tenor Saxophonist, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. McIntyre was a founding member of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians and occasionally performed in face paint and tribal costume.
lead_paragraph: Kalaparusha Maurice McIntyre, a saxophonist who was a founding member of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a pioneering Chicago avant-garde coalition, died on Saturday in the Bronx. He was 77.

headline: Fatal Shooting of Black Woman Outside Detroit Stirs Racial Tensions
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Self-Defense']
abstract: Relatives and friends say they believe that Renisha Marie McBride, 19, was merely seeking help at a stranger’s house when she was shot in the face. The authorities say the homeowner thought she was trying to break in.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN HEIGHTS, Mich. — Shortly before 1 a.m. on Saturday, Nov. 2, a young woman, just a year out of high school, crashed the car she was driving along a residential street on Detroit’s west side.

headline: Clothes That Do Away With the Attaché Case
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Science and Technology', 'Smartphones', 'Tablet Computers', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: The latest high-tech clothes have endless pockets, allowing them to double as small carry-on bags.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Whether you are a business executive flying between neighboring cities or across multiple time zones, it is easier than ever to travel light.

headline: A Most Valuable Player With an Invaluable Platform
abstract: The Pirates’ Andrew McCutchen is the first African-American player to win an M.V.P. award since 2007, and he has a chance to make an impact on the declining numbers of African-American players in baseball.
lead_paragraph: By the end, they had all left the postseason stage: Brandon Phillips and Michael Bourn, Coco Crisp and Justin Upton, David Price and Andrew McCutchen, Carl Crawford and Prince Fielder. The World Series arrived, and all the African-American stars in the playoff field were gone.

headline: Is Nuclear Power the Answer?
abstract: A group of climate scientists want environmentalists to see nuclear power as a way to combat climate change. Are they on to something?

headline: Obama Selects Health Policy Advocate as Surgeon General
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Surgeon General (US)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: President Obama nominated Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, an early supporter and grass-roots advocate for the Affordable Care Act, as surgeon general on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, an early supporter and grass-roots advocate for the Affordable Care Act, as surgeon general on Thursday.

headline: Lockheed Will Cut 4,000 Jobs by 2015
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In response to government spending reductions, the nation’s largest military contractor said it would also close several plants.
lead_paragraph: Lockheed Martin said on Thursday that it would cut 4,000 jobs and close several plants in response to reductions in government spending.

headline: F.C.C. Smartphone App Gauges Speed of User’s Network
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Wireless Communications', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones']
abstract: The app, available free for phones on the Android operating system, will allow the Federal Communications Commission to map data transmission speeds and perhaps spur improvements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released its first smartphone app, a free program that allows consumers to measure the broadband speed they are getting on their mobile devices and to determine whether it is as fast as wireless companies say.

headline: Union’s Rejection Puts Future Home of Boeing 777X in Doubt
abstract: After machinists in the Seattle area voted no on a contract extension tied to a new jet, Boeing said it would consider other places for the project.
lead_paragraph: Which state might get the thousands of coveted jobs producing Boeing’s planned 777X airliner seemed up for grabs on Thursday after Boeing’s machinists in Washington State overwhelmingly rejected a contract extension that the company said was pivotal to future production in the Puget Sound area.

headline: A Health Care Fix
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Facing political furor, President Obama corrects earlier statements and offers a way to let some people keep their current insurance policies.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has come up with a modest fix for a self-inflicted political wound: his repeated — and wrong — assertions that Americans would be able to keep their health insurance plans if they wanted to under the health care reform law.

headline: Jacqueline Kennedy’s Smart Pink Suit, Preserved in Memory and Kept Out of View
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'First Ladies (US)']
abstract: The bloodstained clothing worn by Jacqueline Kennedy on the day her husband was assassinated has been kept from public view since 1963, and it will remain so for many more years.
lead_paragraph: On the plane back to Washington, in her pink Chanel suit, caked with her husband’s blood, Jackie Kennedy resisted all suggestions from aides that she clean herself up. Instead, she just said, “Let them see what they’ve done.”

headline: Incognito Files Grievance Over Suspension by Dolphins
abstract: Richie Incognito, accused of bullying teammate Jonathan Martin, has filed a noninjury grievance against the Miami Dolphins challenging his suspension for conduct detrimental to the team.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Richie Incognito, accused of bullying Jonathan Martin, his teammate on the Dolphins’ offensive line, has filed a noninjury grievance against the Miami Dolphins challenging his suspension for conduct detrimental to the team. Under the N.F.L.’s collective bargaining agreement, an independent arbitrator hears all noninjury grievances, and Incognito has asked that his be heard as soon as possible.

headline: British Press Freedom Under Threat
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Editorials']
abstract: A chilling inquisition aimed at The Guardian over publishing leaks highlights how, unlike the United States, Britain has no constitutional guarantee of a free press.
lead_paragraph: Britain has a long tradition of a free, inquisitive press. That freedom, so essential to democratic accountability, is being challenged by the Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government of Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: Closeted High School Romances
abstract: In “Geography Club,” high school students form a front organization for what is really a gay support group.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 10 years since the publication of Brent Hartinger’s teenage novel “Geography Club,” and the new film adaptation of the book mostly serves to underscore just how far the culture has come in acknowledging the pressures faced by gay high school students. Television shows like “Glee” and “Pretty Little Liars” have given such students and their struggles a weekly spotlight, and documentaries like the searing “Valentine Road” have explored the issues in far more depth than “Geography Club” does.

headline: Turkey Moves to Silence Dissenters, but With One Eye on Its Image Abroad
abstract: Turkey has mounted a balancing act, analysts say, of cracking down on critics of the government, but not so hard as to damage the country’s image abroad.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Late one night last summer, at the height of antigovernment demonstrations sweeping Turkey, a group of protest leaders rushed to the home of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Ankara, the capital, to negotiate a solution to the growing crisis.

headline: Saul Kagan, Who Won Holocaust Restitution, Is Dead at 91
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Reparations', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Mr. Kagan was the founding director of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, which sought reparations for the Nazi genocide against European Jews.
lead_paragraph: Saul Kagan, a former refugee who for decades led the Jewish service organization that was primarily responsible for securing more than $70 billion in restitution for Holocaust survivors and their heirs, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: The Stop-and-Frisk Case Takes Another Turn
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: An appellate panel reaffirmed a hasty and ill-considered decision to remove the presiding judge and to halt her remedies for the program’s civil rights violations.
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit embarrassed itself again on Wednesday by reaffirming a hasty and ill-considered decision last month to remove the presiding judge from the court battle over New York City’s stop-and-frisk program and to stay her remedies for the policy’s civil rights violations.

headline: U.S. Investigates Currency Trades by Major Banks
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency']
abstract: Investigators say groups of traders from several major banks may have influenced currency benchmarks to benefit their employers — actions that may not have been illegal but do highlight lax regulation.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:56 p.m. | From their desks at some of the world’s biggest banks, traders exchanged a series of instant messages that earned them the nickname “the cartel.”

headline: Retailers Less Than Cheerful Over Christmas Sales
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Company Reports', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Big retailers don’t expect this Christmas shopping season to be very lucrative after budget battles and the shutdown have lowered consumer confidence and the willingness to buy.
lead_paragraph: As the holiday shopping season accelerates with aggressive deals, Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer, joined other companies in painting a gloomy picture of consumer spending for the rest of the year.

headline: Obama Proposal Worries Insurers and Regulators
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Many insurers and state regulators fear that President Obama’s policy reversal to delay the cancellation of policies for a year without penalties might damage the new insurance marketplace.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s effort to quiet a political uproar by suggesting on Thursday that consumers should be allowed to keep their current health plans met significant resistance from many insurers and state regulators, who said they had not been consulted in advance about the proposal, doubted it could work and feared it might seriously damage the new insurance marketplace.

headline: Not Even Marcos Family Is Spared Residents’ Ire
abstract: Some of the blame for the slow relief efforts after Typhoon Haiyan is falling on Imelda Marcos and her family, who have long been revered in Tacloban, the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Look around this once-gracious city by a horseshoe-shape bay and it is still possible to imagine it before the mass deaths and devastation of last Friday’s typhoon, when it was a jewel of the Pacific thanks in good part to a local girl who became a global celebrity: Imelda R. Marcos, the flamboyant former first lady of the Philippines.

headline: Bobbie Handman, a Medal of Arts Winner, Dies at 85
abstract: Ms. Handman was a behind-the-scenes force in Democratic politics, a theater preservationist and the first person to be awarded the National Medal of Arts for advocacy.
lead_paragraph: Bobbie Handman, a behind-the-scenes force in Democratic politics, a theater preservationist and the first person to be awarded the National Medal of Arts for advocacy, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Airlifting Big Cats From Circus Hell
abstract: The documentary “Lion Ark” follows a team of rescuers as they track down lions exploited in Bolivian shows.
lead_paragraph: “Lion Ark,” a spunky account of a perilous rescue mission, has a ragtag rhythm that befits the mercurial behavior of its hulking hairy stars. Following a group from Animal Defenders International as it conducts the 2010 roundup and relocation of 25 captive lions illegally held in traveling circuses in Bolivia, this warmhearted documentary from Tim Phillips makes “Born Free” look like a beast story for babes.

headline: A Marijuana Stash That Carried Little Risk
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Marijuana', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Minorities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: While scores of people are arrested on marijuana charges every day in the city, the laws apparently don’t apply to middle-aged white guys.
lead_paragraph: Walking down Eighth Avenue a few weeks ago, I made sure my backpack was fully zipped shut. Inside was a modest stash of pot, bought just an hour or so earlier. A friend knew someone in that world, and after an introduction, then a quiet, discreet meeting, I was on my way to the subway. Never before had I walked through Midtown Manhattan with it on my person. There were four cookies in vacuum-sealed pouches — “edibles” is the technical term — and then a few pinches of what was described as “herb.”

headline: This Week’s Movies: Nov. 15, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Nebraska,” “The Great Beauty” and “Faust.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Nebraska,” “The Great Beauty” and “Faust.”

headline: Asia Rivalries Play Role in Aid to the Philippines
abstract: The foreign aid for the survivors of Typhoon Haiyan is shaping up to be a monumental show of international largess — and a dose of one-upmanship directed at China.
lead_paragraph: CEBU, the Philippines — The American aircraft carrier George Washington has arrived, its 5,000 sailors and 80 aircraft already busy ferrying relief supplies to storm-battered survivors, and the United States has committed an initial $20 million in humanitarian assistance. Japan is dispatching a naval force of 1,000 troops, in what officials say is that country’s largest ever disaster-relief deployment. Also on the way: the Illustrious, a British aircraft carrier stocked with transport planes, medical experts and $32 million worth of aid.

headline: Knicks’ Smith Raises Eyebrows in Twitter Feud With the Pistons’ Jennings
abstract: In an escalating series of posts on his Twitter account, J. R. Smith appeared to threaten the Pistons’ Brandon Jennings for picking on his younger brother, Chris, a guard with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: In the hours between Wednesday’s victory over the Atlanta Hawks and Thursday’s game against the Houston Rockets, the Knicks’ J. R. Smith somehow found the time to take on another opponent: Brandon Jennings of the Detroit Pistons.

headline: Europe Moves to Keep Its Corporate Trade Data Secret
keywords: ['Industrial Espionage', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Intellectual Property']
abstract: Poor protection of proprietary information has harmed many European companies, but the authorities in Brussels are proposing a tough new law.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union plans to propose rules this month aimed at creating its first broad protection of trade secrets and setting penalties for those who try to profit from them illegally.

headline: Under Fire, Brooklyn Deputy Prosecutor Will Retire
abstract: Michael F. Vecchione had been a friend and right-hand man to District Attorney Charles J. Hynes, who was defeated for re-election.
lead_paragraph: Michael F. Vecchione, a longtime friend and top deputy of the Brooklyn district attorney, will retire from the office on Dec. 12, becoming the first in what is likely to be a wave of high-ranking deputies leaving as the district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, prepares to step down.

headline: $122 Million in 2012 Spending by Koch Group
abstract: Americans for Prosperity, founded by the billionaires David and Charles Koch, spent tens of millions of dollars in ads in a bid to defeat President Obama and Democrats in Congress, documents show.
lead_paragraph: A political nonprofit group founded by the billionaire industrialists David and Charles Koch spent $122 million during 2012, according to documents filed with the Colorado secretary of state, putting it among the biggest election spenders in the country.

headline: Message From Yellen Is Full Speed Ahead on the Stimulus
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the president’s nominee to lead the Federal Reserve, made investors confident that the central bank would stick with policies that have sent shares soaring.
lead_paragraph: When Janet L. Yellen speaks, Wall Street listens — and investors liked what they heard on Thursday.

headline: $1 Million Medallions Stifling the Dreams of Cabdrivers
abstract: New York City auctioned off 200 new medallions, permits to operate a yellow cab, for more than $200 million.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the New York City yellow cab has powered the consummate immigrant story — a tale of a new arrival who becomes a driver, a driver dogged enough to eventually become his own boss.

headline: A Digital Performance That Moves You — Literally
abstract: “Meem: A Story Ballet About the Internet,” with choreography by Ryan McNamara, is part of the Performa 13 biennial taking place all over New York.
lead_paragraph: When a show is called “Meem: A Story Ballet About the Internet,” it’s not surprising that many things happen at once. The immersive production, choreographed by the performance artist Ryan McNamara for the Performa 13 biennial, places a cast of more than 18 dancers all over the Connelly Theater in the East Village: onstage, in the wings, in the balcony, in the foyer, like so many open tabs and windows in your browser. What is surprising, perhaps, is that the audience is seated.

headline: Questions for a New Class of Cholesterol Drugs
abstract: A promising new class of cholesterol-lowering drugs known as PCSK9 inhibitors is being developed.
lead_paragraph: New guidelines governing the use of cholesterol-lowering medicines are a huge change for doctors and a vast number of patients, but the impact on the drug industry is expected to be less tumultuous.

headline: Team Owners Approve Funding for Expanded Use of Instant Replay
abstract: Bud Selig, long a replay opponent, says he expects the plan to be in effect for the 2014 season, which he has said will be his last as commissioner.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Bud Selig’s father, Ben, once told him: Life is but a series of adjustments.

headline: A Push Away From Burning Coal as an Energy Source
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coal', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The Tennessee Valley Authority planned to close a total of eight electricity-generating units at three plants in Alabama and Kentucky, significantly cutting the emissions of greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: The Tennessee Valley Authority sharply accelerated a shift away from coal as an energy source on Thursday, saying it would shut down eight electricity-generating units that together will burn nearly a fifth of its coal this year.

headline: Corrections: November 15, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 15, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Dangers Ahead for Climate, and Now for People
abstract: “Water,” from the British companies Filter Theater and Lyric Hammersmith, pours creative light and sound into a multicharacter tale about the environment.

headline: Performing Without a Net
abstract: This Friday puzzle marks a creative debut from David Woolf.
lead_paragraph: The famous acrobatic troupe the Flying Wallendas made a name for themselves on the circus circuit by staring down the PERILS of performing without a NET. You might feel just as cavalier if you use a pen to take on this challenging Friday puzzle from David Woolf, the constructor who makes his debut today with a wild carnival of creativity.

headline: Fractious Family Indulging the Dream of a Child
abstract: “Little Miss Sunshine,” a musical adaptation of the popular indie film, centers on a frazzled family’s road trip to a children’s beauty pageant in California.
lead_paragraph: The new musical “Little Miss Sunshine” opens with an emotional cloudburst. As the fractured family at the center of the show gathers for dinner, just about everyone has a grim comment to make on the state of existence.

headline: David Tepper Giving Carnegie Mellon a $67 Million Gift
abstract: The hedge fund billionaire’s donation brings his total giving to Carnegie Mellon in the last decade to more than $125 million.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, giants of America’s Gilded Age started the educational institutions that later became Carnegie Mellon University.

headline: Answering Questions About Health Savings Accounts
abstract: Some explanations about the several similar-sounding options and the new provision for carrying $500 over to the next year.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Your Money Adviser addressed the ins and outs of workplace health care spending options, including flexible spending plans and health savings accounts. Many workers were happy to hear about changes in workplace flexible-spending plans that will allow them to carry over $500 from one year to the next. Previously, any balance in the accounts had to be forfeited.

headline: Millennials With Boomer Angst
abstract: With its reunion theme, “The Fall of 1980” revisits the theme of youthful idealism diminished by middle-age cares.
lead_paragraph: “The Fall of 1980” is a feature-length filmed fiction, but it’s a stretch to call this videotaped acting exercise a movie. Written and directed by a New York University graduate, Ryan Lonergan, and mostly starring other N.Y.U. graduates, it’s essentially a modern version of “The Big Chill” without the banging oldies soundtrack or competent actors.

headline: Survivor of Shooting Rampage Recalls Struggle With Killer
abstract: Pooya Hosseini, who lived in the Brooklyn home where three Iranian musicians were killed, told of chatting with Ali Akbar Mohammadi Rafie and wrestling over his gun.
lead_paragraph: The first sound — a muffled pop — caused little alarm. It had come from somewhere on the third floor of a home in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, shared by musicians from Iran.

headline: As Nets Stumble, Garnett’s Actions Are Quieter Than Words
abstract: Kevin Garnett, who turned 37 in May and is in his 19th professional season, has been a vocal leader for the Nets, but his contributions on the court have been far quieter.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Kevin Garnett arched himself over Mason Plumlee during a timeout here Wednesday night and barked loud encouragement and instruction at Plumlee, a rookie, for several intense seconds. Even from afar, it was clear that this was a one-way conversation.

headline: A Shorter Selling Season, So Marketers Take Risks
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'E-Commerce', 'Christmas', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: In one of the most competitive marketing seasons of the year, retailers like Lexus, Sharper Image and Kohl’s are making changes to longstanding campaigns.
lead_paragraph: THEY say the holiday season is the Super Bowl of shopping because so much of retailers’ annual revenue — and profit — comes in during the run-up to Christmas. This year, marketers worried about the wobbly economy and wary of consumer sentiment are borrowing tactics from Super Bowl advertising, introducing campaigns in traditional, digital and social media that are stuffed with celebrities, surprises and schmaltz.

headline: Long Shadow of an All-Powerful Neighbor
abstract: “The Great Fallacy” turns an analytical lens on the United States relationship with Puerto Rico and Puerto Ricans.
lead_paragraph: “The Great Fallacy,” Paco Vázquez’s dense, lively new film about economic and sociological issues in Puerto Rico, eschews the storytelling form of many contemporary documentaries in favor of an instructive crash course in radical politics. It is propaganda, an educational tool and a practical manifesto for empowerment of the poor and the disenfranchised.

headline: Ban on Former Inmates in Public Housing Is Eased
abstract: The New York City Housing Authority will begin a pilot program next month that aims to help recently released prisoners reunite with their families.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Housing Authority will ease its ban on recently released prisoners and allow some of them to live in public housing as part of a pilot program set to start next month.

headline: A Rampage With No Rhyme or Reason
abstract: The documentary “Long Island Railroad Massacre” returns to the 1993 killings aboard a commuter train and catches up with those affected.
lead_paragraph: Unfolding with stripped-down simplicity, Charlie Minn’s “Long Island Railroad Massacre” details a 20-year-old American tragedy whose essential elements — one deeply disturbed gunman and many innocent victims — have become dismayingly common.

headline: The School of Arthur Danto
abstract: The philosopher Arthur Danto, a singular thinker and stylish writer, transformed the field of philosophical aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: Each semester for a quarter-century, as I’ve geared up to teach one text or another by Arthur Danto, I’ve introduced him – as I did in my class on beauty on Thursday, Oct. 24 – as “our greatest living philosopher of art.” By the time we reconvened the next Monday, that statement was false; Danto died on the 25th at age 89, completing a transition from the idiosyncratic to the canonical.

headline: A Dead Father’s Presence, and a Daughter’s Challenge
abstract: Julie Vann is doing well at her high school, but worries about how her mother and little sister will get by if she goes off to college.
lead_paragraph: Every evening, Julie Vann and her little sister carefully set the dinner table for four. The aroma of spiced curry permeates the halls of the small two-bedroom Bronx apartment, the very apartment their parents moved into after fleeing the brutal assault of Cambodia’s Khmer Rouge more than 35 years ago.

headline: The Genius Behind the Subversive Squiggles
abstract: “Dear Mr. Watterson” pays tribute to the creator of “Calvin and Hobbes.”
lead_paragraph: It’s not entirely clear what documentaries larded with fawning testimonials aim to achieve. A professional seal of approval for the cautious? Reassurance for fans secretly gnawed by doubt? Peer pressure?

headline: Insurer Charged With Theft From a Charity
abstract: Joseph Ross was arrested on Wednesday and charged with helping a longtime Jewish community leader loot more than $7 million from the Metropolitan New York Council on Jewish Poverty.
lead_paragraph: The owner of a Long Island insurance company has been charged with helping a longtime Jewish community leader loot more than $7 million from one of the city’s most influential social service organizations and pocketing at least $1 million himself, according to a criminal complaint filed in the case.

headline: Dispute Jeopardizes New Posting System for Japanese Players
abstract: Small-market teams tried to put into effect a rule that would inhibit big-market teams from spending large sums on prospective Japanese stars like the ace pitcher Masahiro Tanaka.
lead_paragraph: A last-minute dispute placed the new posting system for Japanese players in jeopardy as small-market teams in Major League Baseball tried to put into effect a rule that would inhibit big-market teams, particularly the Yankees, from spending large sums on prospective Japanese stars like the ace pitcher Masahiro Tanaka.

headline: Bad Deathbed Advice, Indeed
abstract: In “Charlie Countryman,” a young American travels whimsically to Romania, where he falls in love with a tough young woman married to a gangster.
lead_paragraph: Hearing such avowals earnestly delivered by the besotted title character of “Charlie Countryman” to his tough Romanian dream girl, you don’t know whether to laugh or to wince. Maybe both. The feature debut of Fredrik Bond from a screenplay by Matt Drake, this catastrophe of a movie zigzags drunkenly between action-adventure and surreal comedy with some magical realism slopped over it like ketchup.

headline: Reuniting as Grown-Ups, Kind Of
abstract: Long-forgotten rivalries and attractions simmer in “The Best Man Holiday,” about onetime college friends reuniting in their late 30s.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Malcolm D. Lee gathers the crew of friends from his 1999 debut, “The Best Man,” for a Christmas reunion. In this follow-up, the struggling author Harper (Taye Diggs) and the football god Lance (Morris Chestnut) are wary former pals. Julian (Harold Perrineau) discovers that his wife, Candy (Regina Hall), has a past, preserved in a video online. And it’s not immediately apparent why anyone still puts up with the troublemaking television diva Shelby (Melissa De Sousa).

headline: HUD Storm-Protection Competition Will Narrow Ideas Big and Small
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: Winners of a federally sponsored competition could have an inside track to billions of dollars in Hurricane Sandy relief money.
lead_paragraph: One project aims to raise parts of Lower Manhattan, put in a protective barrier that could double as a community center or an art installation, and sink the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive underground and cover it with a lush park.

headline: New Building Codes Passed After Lessons From Hurricane Sandy
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'City Councils', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: The City Council approved new requirements that were expected to make buildings more sustaining during emergencies.
lead_paragraph: Acting on the recommendations of a task force convened after Hurricane Sandy, the City Council on Thursday approved new requirements that were expected to make buildings more sustaining during emergencies and prevent some of the hardships that New Yorkers endured after the storm last year.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 14, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Inquiry Focuses on Ammunition After Blast Kills 4 Marines at Camp Pendleton
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Marines who died in an explosion at Camp Pendleton this week were clearing live ordnance from a training area, military officials said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Four Marines who died at Camp Pendleton this week were killed by an explosion while clearing live ordnance from a training area, military officials said Thursday.

headline: How to Beat Rockets? Foul Howard and Wait for the Clank
abstract: Dwight Howard is often fouled intentionally late in games, and with good reason: Entering Thursday, he had missed 50 of 96 free-throw attempts.
lead_paragraph: It would be one thing if the Houston Rockets’ Dwight Howard, after being fouled, would step to the line, calmly bend his knees and make free throws with consistency. But he does not. So opposing teams, looking for a low-risk way of getting the ball back, keep hacking Howard on purpose.

headline: Devils Overcome Poor Start and Regain Successful Formula
abstract: Improved play from Martin Brodeur and a defensive unit that has shrugged off a number of injuries have boosted the fortunes of a traditionally successful franchise.
lead_paragraph: Consistent play from Martin Brodeur, a stingy defense and two-way forward play that provided balanced and timely scoring made up a formula that helped the Devils win three Stanley Cups between 1995 and 2003.

headline: His Roots in Italy, de Blasio Now Has Fans There
abstract: Bill de Blasio has become something of a sensation in Italy, but the country has long been a singular force in shaping his life, and an identity he claimed as his family was falling apart.
lead_paragraph: SANT’AGATA DE’ GOTI, Italy — Pictures of Bill de Blasio and his family are plastered on bulletin boards around town. City officials will soon anoint him an honorary citizen. A sponge cake, filled with hazelnut and white chocolate, has been named in his honor.

headline: No Charges Against Cabby in Crash Injuring Tourist
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The lawyer representing the family of Sian Green, whose left leg was severed in the Midtown Manhattan crash, said they were shocked and disappointed that no charges would be filed against Faysal Himon.
lead_paragraph: No charges will be filed against the cabdriver who crashed onto a pedestrian plaza in Midtown Manhattan in August and pinned a British tourist, severing her left leg just below the knee, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Top Givers to the Philippines, and China
abstract: After criticism of China’s initial offer of a $100,000 cash donation, the country beefed up its contribution to the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: After criticism of China’s initial offer of a $100,000 cash donation, the country beefed up its contribution to the Philippines.

headline: Verizon to Pay City for Cost Overruns
abstract: Verizon has agreed to pay New York City at least $50 million for falling behind schedule in developing software for the new 911 system that then failed to meet city standards.
lead_paragraph: Verizon has agreed to pay New York City at least $50 million because of software cost overruns associated with the city’s 911 system, city officials said on Thursday.

headline: De Blasio’s International Booster
abstract: More than a century after Giovanni de Blasio left Sant’Agata de’ Goti, in Italy, for America, residents there are celebrating the election of his grandson, Bill, as the next mayor of New York.
lead_paragraph: More than a century after Giovanni de Blasio left Sant’Agata de’ Goti, in Italy, for America, residents there are celebrating the election of his grandson, Bill, as the next mayor of New York.

headline: In Myanmar, Retracing George Orwell’s Steps
abstract: A writer visits Yangon, the country’s former capital city, and finds echoes of the colonial past that inspired “Burmese Days.”
lead_paragraph: In Myanmar, a long-isolated nation now opening up to the world after decades of brutal military rule, one still finds romantic echoes of the former British colony that inspired the young author to pen his first novel, ‘Burmese Days.’

headline: The Well-Composed Life of Faye Toogood
abstract: With her unexpected arrangements of objects, the furniture and interior designer brings the English countryside to her London house.
lead_paragraph: The designer Faye Toogood finds exceptional beauty in unexpected arrangements of objects, and uses them to create installations for fashion houses — and her own house.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 15, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, November 15, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “He made the American dream come true. But he didn’t forget his roots. It’s a message of hope for us all.”

headline: Word of the Day | immutable
abstract: This word has appeared in 50 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: immutable •\(ˌ)i(m)-ˈmyü-tə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Anthony’s Burst Falls Short in Chaotic Final Moments
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored 45 points and grabbed 10 rebounds against the Rockets, but his potentially game-tying 3-pointer with five seconds remaining was waved off.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of a three-hour slugfest, Carmelo Anthony had done everything he could for the Knicks. He had scored on layups and on turnaround jumpers. He had rebounded and defended. At Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, nobody on the Houston Rockets could stop him. They tried, and they failed.

headline: Xi, in ‘Godfather’ Mold, Looks Assertive and Even Imperial
abstract: One year after taking leadership of the party, Xi Jinping is looking like an assertive president who sits well above his six colleagues on the Politburo Standing Committee, a sharp contrast to his predecessor, Hu Jintao.
lead_paragraph: The president of China, Xi Jinping, has admitted to watching “The Godfather,” and this week he proved he could be a shrewd student of one of that film’s themes: the art of amassing and applying power in a small, secretive circle of men.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:45 P.M. (Sho2) OUT OF SIGHT (1998) In this slick noir caper directed by Steven Soderbergh and based on the novel by Elmore Leonard, Jack Foley (George Clooney, above), the most charming bank robber you will ever meet, escapes from prison to join his partner (Ving Rhames) for one last heist: to rob the home of their former prison mate (Albert Brooks). Along the way they cross paths with Karen Sisco (Jennifer Lopez), a federal marshal who becomes caught between attraction and professional responsibility when she and Jack begin to wonder what could happen if only they had different occupations. “The hard-boiled beauty of the cinematography (by Elliot Davis, who has shot three previous Soderbergh films) brings out the story’s own innate color and creates a warmly inviting backdrop for the central star-crossed romance,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “The film’s sleek moodiness and visual sophistication are so effective that there’s even a scene here that makes Detroit look like the most romantic city in the world.”

headline: News Quiz | November 15, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: ‘Hearts Throbbed, Minds Wavered’ as Tendulkar Began Final Match
abstract: The final five-day test match for Sachin Tendulkar prompted a full meltdown of ecstatic prose, as scribes all over the country tried to capture the final bittersweet moments of the cricket giant’s career.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Even under ordinary circumstances, India’s newspaper writers are not known for bottling up their emotions. But the last cricket outing of Sachin Tendulkar this week prompted a full meltdown of ecstatic prose, as scribes all over the country tried to capture the final bittersweet moments of a career that has provided one of India’s most satisfying plotlines of the last two decades.

headline: A Computer Academy in France Defies Conventional Wisdom
abstract: Internet mogul Xavier Niel believes his new college, called 42, will produce graduates who are more employable, but some educators criticize its nontraditional methods.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a nation of schools typically christened with sensible acronyms or the names of dead Frenchmen, 42 seems an odd title for an institution of higher learning. But then, Xavier Niel’s new technology academy hardly aims to be conventional.

headline: Beijing Talks Up Economic Reform
abstract: Shares in Shanghai and Hong Kong rose as a Communist Party official said that the broad policy statements issued this week would yield significant change.
lead_paragraph: After a Chinese Communist Party leadership meeting issued its eagerly anticipated communiqué on economic restructuring this week, the first reaction in stock markets appeared to be lamentation and derision. Investors who had waited for bold reforms instead read a turgid set of slogans.

headline: Relief Proceeds Slowly in Philippines, Where a Death Toll Remains Unclear
abstract: The search for bodies continued in Tacloban and nearby cities and towns as thousands of residents remained hungry and homeless.
lead_paragraph: TANAUAN, the Philippines — For Teoderico Canales and her family, survival after Typhoon Haiyan has literally meant living in a pigsty. Their only water comes from a pump next to a small river where many people drowned.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Nov. 15, 2013
abstract: Can you add the missing punctuation to a sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: Reading the sentence in this Editing Practice question aloud can help you place the missing punctuation.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Skateboarding Thrills in New York City
abstract: Who are the Concrete Kings?
lead_paragraph: In an article from October, “Despite Hazards, Street Skateboarding Thrives,” Winnie Hu writes about skateboard culture in New York City.

headline: French-Iranian Relations
abstract: The ayatollahs express their dismay over the failed nuclear talks.
lead_paragraph: The ayatollahs express their dismay over the failed nuclear talks.

headline: What Would You Invent to Make the World a Better Place?
abstract: What problem would you try to address, either in your community or around the world?
lead_paragraph: An auto mechanic invented a tool to make births safer. He literally dreamed it up one night after watching a YouTube video about how to extract a lost cork from a wine bottle. If all goes well, doctors hope the inexpensive device might save lives — potentially millions of them.

headline: Beauty in the Everyday
abstract: The photographs of Saul Leiter, who is the subject of a new film, depict gorgeous, poignant and fleeting moments in New York City.
lead_paragraph: There is something so poignant about Saul Leiter’s work that looking at it can feel like taking a dart to the heart. Drenched in luxuriant, saturated colors, the images instantly transport the viewer into the photographer’s shoes: peeping from beneath an awning to a snow-swept street, or through a befogged cafe window, weeping with condensation, to a man taking pause on a wintry sidewalk. Intimate and empathetic, Mr. Leiter’s photographs relay what all New Yorkers know about their roaring, daunting home: that life in the city is filled with stolen glimpses and fleeting, quietly personal and often gorgeous moments.

headline: Albania Won’t Aid in Destruction of Syria’s Chemical Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The decision dealt a blow to Washington’s efforts to find a country prepared to undertake the politically sensitive disarmament project.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The international chemical weapons watchdog agency approved a plan for the elimination of Syria’s chemical arms on Friday that calls for most of the arsenal to be destroyed outside the country, despite another refusal by one of the countries approached to help with the disposal.

headline: Chinese Youth Sues Over Alleged Police Torture
abstract: After Yang Zhong, 16, was taken away by police on suspicion of “spreading online rumors,” he says they tortured him. Now he’s suing for 7 renminbi, one for each day of detention, and an apology.
lead_paragraph: When the police detained Yang Zhong, 16, for the crime of “spreading online rumors” after he raised questions on his Sina Weibo account about the mysterious death of a local karaoke club manager, they took him to their headquarters in Zhangjiachuan, in the northwestern province of Gansu.

headline: In Economic Review, Italy and Spain Get Warnings on Debt and Deficit
abstract: Europe’s top economic official said the two countries risked missing debt and deficit targets.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The top European economics official warned Italy and Spain on Friday that they risked missing important debt and deficit targets in the first such review of national budget plans for 13 countries in the euro zone.

headline: New York Today: Hey, Mr. Mayor-Elect
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: Taking the public’s pulse for Bill de Blasio, moody weather, and an exhibit on the “Power of Poison.”
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:29 p.m. | An unusual structure has gone up on Canal Street in Manhattan.

headline: Week 11 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: Looking to stay perfect, Kansas City may catch a break because Peyton Manning further injured his ankle, making him even slower on his feet than usual.
lead_paragraph: Chiefs (9-0) at Broncos (8-1)

headline: Japan Backs Off From Emissions Targets, Citing Fukushima Disaster
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Kyoto Protocol', 'Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Tokyo’s decision to no longer adhere to its plan could complicate efforts to forge a global climate change pact.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan took a major step back on Friday from earlier pledges to slash its greenhouse gas emissions, saying a shutdown of its nuclear power plants in the wake of the Fukushima disaster had made previous targets unattainable. The announcement cast a shadow over international talks underway in Warsaw aimed at fashioning a new global pact to address the threats of a changing climate.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Scanning of Books for Search Upheld by Court
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A judge dismissed a lawsuit by the Authors Guild that claimed making books searchable was a violation of copyright laws.
lead_paragraph: Google’s idea to scan millions of books and make them searchable online seemed audacious when it was announced in 2004. But fast-forward to today, when people expect to find almost anything they want online, and the plan seems like an unsurprising and unavoidable part of today’s Internet, Claire Cain Miller and Julie Bosman report.

headline: Why Doctors Don’t Take Sick Days
abstract: We power through illness at the risk of infecting our patients.
lead_paragraph: THE bottle of Maalox sat perched on the triage desk in the emergency room. It was mint flavor, or maybe lemon — I don’t recall exactly — but it shimmered temptingly. I had just finished with a new admission, and my stomach had been groaning ominously for hours. It was after midnight, the whole night was still ahead of me, and I was getting desperate. I scribbled the last of my medication orders and snagged the Maalox bottle, popping the top and chugging two revolting capfuls on my way to the elevator.

headline: The Banality of Robbing the Jews
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: Stripping Jews of their belongings was an essential part of the effort to destroy them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The recent discovery of more than 1,400 prized paintings in the Munich residence of Cornelius Gurlitt, an art collector whose father collaborated with the Nazis, has brought the pillage of the Jews back into the limelight. Yet the bulk of anti-Semitic looting during World War II was at once much more banal and more widespread.

headline: Berkshire Buys $3.45 Billion Stake in Exxon Mobil
abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s firm owned roughly 40 million shares of Exxon Mobil at the end of September, less than 1 percent of the oil giant’s 4.4 billion outstanding shares.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Berkshire Hathaway took a stake valued at $3.45 billion in Exxon Mobil in the third quarter, the latest major addition to the portfolio controlled by the legendary value investor Warren E. Buffett, according to a regulatory filing late Thursday.

headline: Obama Health Care Fixes Give Small Businesses Time to Assess
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Many companies are choosing to renew existing policies so they can put off assessing the new Affordable Care Act-compliant policies.
lead_paragraph: For small businesses grappling with how the Affordable Care Act would affect their health insurance plans, the announcement on Thursday from the White House, delaying the transition to new rules by as much as two years, may come as welcome relief.

headline: Chill Out, 1 Percenters
abstract: Concern about Bill de Blasio’s intention or ability to spoil the party for the city’s affluent is misplaced.
lead_paragraph: IT’S not full-blown panic yet, but a discernible angst is descending over New York City’s affluent residents, who are worried about the coming mayoralty of Bill de Blasio.

headline: China to Ease Longtime Policy of 1-Child Limit
abstract: The Communist Party also said that it would end a much-criticized “re-education through labor” system and institute economic reforms.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government will ease its one-child family restrictions and abolish “re-education through labor” camps, significantly curtailing two policies that for decades have defined the state’s power to control citizens’ lives, the Communist Party said Friday.

headline: There’s Life in AMC’s ‘Hell on Wheels,’ Even After Move to Saturday
abstract: The network ordered a new season of the cowboy drama — something not necessarily expected when it was switched to Saturday nights.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, cable drama can survive outside Sunday night: AMC announced Thursday that it had ordered a new season of its cowboy drama “Hell on Wheels,” which was moved to Saturday nights this season.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Ratings of Four Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The rating agency said there was less likelihood of a widespread bailout of banks by the United States government as there was during the financial crisis five years ago.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The rating agency Moody’s lowered its credit ratings late Thursday for four major United States banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, reflecting a belief that the institutions would not receive the same level of government support in another financial meltdown.

headline: Currency Trades Draw U.S. Scrutiny
abstract: Federal investigators suspect that a group of traders at big banks shared a mission to alter the price of foreign currencies. | A three-year effort by James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, is showing some success. | David A. Tepper is giving $67 million to Carnegie Mellon University. | Three hedge fund moguls built positions in FedEx.
lead_paragraph: U.S. INVESTIGATES CURRENCY TRADES BY BIG BANKS  |  Federal investigators suspect that a group of traders at some of the world’s biggest banks shared a mission to alter the price of foreign currencies, the largest and yet least regulated market in the financial world, Ben Protess, Landon Thomas Jr. and Chad Bray report in DealBook. “Much like companies that rigged the price of vitamins and animal feed, the traders were competitors that hatched alliances for their own profits, federal investigators suspect.”

headline: What Makes a Martyr?
abstract: A debate in Pakistan highlights the pitfalls of mixing politics and religion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Because they die fighting in defense of Islam, they are guaranteed a place in heaven. Most major roads, hospitals and bridges in Pakistan are named after them. They are the martyrs, or shaheed.

headline: Yellen Impresses, but Fed’s Powers Are Finite
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Interest Rates', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Janet Yellen offered thoughtful responses to the Senate Banking Committee, but her confirmation hearing underscored that repairing the economy is beyond the Fed’s power to achieve by itself, even under a dynamic leader, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Choosing a Life Built Just for Two
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Families and Family Life', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Baby Boomers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Textiles']
abstract: Jeanne Petrick, one of 13 siblings, and her husband of 38 years, Robert, chose not to have children. “If you have kids the dynamics change,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

lead_paragraph: HELSINKI – In Europe’s crowded technology scene, cities are eager to differentiate themselves from local rivals.

lead_paragraph: Jos. A. Bank said on Friday that it had withdrawn its $2.3 billion takeover bid for Men’s Wearhouse after failing to entice the company into merger talks ahead of a Thursday deadline.

lead_paragraph: Samuel Barnett performs a scene as Viola from “Twelfth Night,” now on Broadway at the Belasco Theater.

headline: In His Likely Final Innings, Tendulkar Does Not Disappoint
abstract: The cricket star scored 74 runs in the first innings of his last test match on Friday, helping his team recover from a potentially tricky position after the loss of two early wickets.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — In what is likely to be his final innings in cricket, the Indian star Sachin Tendulkar didn’t disappoint his 33,000 screaming fans at Wankhede Stadium on Friday as he scored 74 runs in the first innings of his last test match, helping his team recover from a potentially tricky position after the loss of two early wickets.

headline: China’s Economic Plans ‘Ambitious,’ U.S. Treasury Secretary Says

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Treasury Secretary, Jacob J. Lew, described China’s declaration that market competition should have a decisive role in the country’s economy as an “ambitious reform agenda,” according to remarks on Friday by the secretary to the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping.

lead_paragraph: Scholars are fighting to revive the work of the Mexican artist José Clemente Orozco.

headline: Mexico’s Not-So-Favorite Son
abstract: The painter José Clemente Orozco has always been less revered than his countryman Diego Rivera, but now many scholars are pushing for Orozco to be seen with fresh eyes.
lead_paragraph: GUADALAJARA, MEXICO — For years, the rains came and the mural buckled. Near the edges of the colorful illustrated dome inside the Jalisco state legislature here, paint faded and fell from the last mural José Clemente Orozco completed before he died.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Nebraska,’ ‘The Great Beauty’ and ‘Faust’

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on Alexander Payne’s bittersweet comedy “Nebraska,” Paolo Sorrentino’s “The Great Beauty” and Alexander Sokurov’s version of “Faust.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: How to Explain That Lost Job
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Careers and Professions', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Honesty is the best policy when telling a prospective employer about an ambiguous ending to a previous job. But that doesn’t mean “I was fired!” is the best icebreaker.
lead_paragraph: My 27-year-old daughter was fired from a job under confusing circumstances. She had been hired as a project coordinator for a construction management firm. Although she had no background in the field, the company was aware of this and willing to train her. She had a rocky start with a project manager but then was reassigned and had an excellent working relationship with her new manager. At a review she was told, “This job will be yours in a year unless you choose to leave.” Six weeks later, she was terminated, and told she lacked the necessary “skill set.” The project manager she had worked with took a new job elsewhere shortly thereafter. In all, my daughter was there 10 months.

headline: Around the World, Inflation Is Falling to Levels Not Seen for Years
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: In the United States, the core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, is at 1.2 percent over the last 12 months — one of the reasons the Fed may continue to buy bonds.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN inflation, which has seemed to some conservative economists to be an impending threat ever since the Federal Reserve began to buy large quantities of government securities, appears to be falling to levels lower than any seen in recent years. There are similar declines in many European countries.

lead_paragraph: In the United States, inflation as measured by the personal consumption expenditures deflator has fallen to under 1 percent.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Friday reported a $5 billion net loss for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, a significant improvement over last year, when the agency reported a record $15.9 billion loss.

lead_paragraph: In Myanmar, a long-isolated nation now opening up to the world after decades of brutal military rule, one still finds romantic echoes of the former British colony that inspired the young author to pen his first novel, ‘Burmese Days.’

headline: Skills Practice | Making Arguments Through Art
abstract: In this lesson, students investigate how illustrations complement Times Opinion pieces, then they create their own original artwork to go with a piece they select..
lead_paragraph: The New York Times regularly commissions artists and cartoonists to create work to accompany Opinion pieces. How do illustrations like the one above add meaning to a text, while grabbing readers’ attention at the same time? What can students infer about the argument being made in an Op-Ed article by looking at the illustration alone?

abstract: This week, Doris Kearns Goodwin discusses “The Bully Pulpit”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; N. Gregory Mankiw talks about Alan Greenspan’s “Map and the Territory”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: House Approves Bill That Allows Policy Renewals
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Defying a veto threat, 39 Democrats joined Republicans in approving the measure, which goes further than the fix that President Obama had previously announced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House approved legislation on Friday that would allow insurance companies to renew individual health insurance policies and sell similar ones to new customers next year even if the coverage does not provide all the benefits and consumer protections required by the new health care law.

headline: The Comedy Pioneer in the Floppy Hat
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Movies', 'Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)']
abstract: “Whoopi Goldberg Presents Moms Mabley” is a documentary recalling the influential and groundbreaking comic whose career was largely unfilmed.
lead_paragraph: With her toothless grin, floppy hat and tell-it-like-it-is persona, Moms Mabley may be one of the most influential comedians you don’t know. She rose to fame in the early decades of the 20th century on the chitlins circuit — the collection of stages around the country that employed black entertainers during segregation — and she would go on to a career that spanned more than 50 years. In that time, she pushed beyond racial and gender barriers, but she drew mainstream attention only starting in the 196os (she died in 1975) and little of her work has survived on film or video. That hasn’t deterred Whoopi Goldberg.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s ‘Bully Pulpit’
abstract: This week, Doris Kearns Goodwin and N. Gregory Mankiw.
lead_paragraph: This week, Doris Kearns Goodwin and N. Gregory Mankiw.

lead_paragraph: As the holiday season approaches, helping guests keep up regular exercise and a balanced diet is a priority for a number of hotels.

headline: What Obamacare Needs Now …
keywords: ['Insurance', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why deregulation might be a better response to cancellations and rate shock than “grandfathering” existing plans.
lead_paragraph: … is not at all the same as what freaking-out Congressional Democrats think they need politically, and what the president tried to provide to them yesterday. That’s because all of the “if you like your plan, you keep your plan” ideas in the wind right now, including the White House’s pledge yesterday to allow/pressure insurers to temporarily extend plans that don’t meet the new law’s specifications, are likely to either do nothing meaningful at all to halt the flood of cancellations, or else exacerbate the threat to Obamacare’s viability that the busted website has created, by siphoning off precisely the healthy, lower-risk enrollees the new system needs to be sustainable.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Believer
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Flannery O’Connor’s journal addressed to God was written when she was a 20-year-old student at the Iowa Writers’ Workshop.
lead_paragraph: This slender, charming book must be approached with a special tact. To read it feels a little like an intrusion on inwardness itself. The volume contains, alongside a lightly corrected transcription, a facsimile of the Sterling notebook in which Flannery O’Connor, just 20 years old, began a journal addressed to God. Written in her neat hand, it is reproduced complete with the empty final pages (her concluding words are “there is nothing left to say of me”) and not omitting a bit of musical notation floating on the inside of the back cover. The prayers, attempts at prayer and meditations on faith and art contained in it were written in 1946 and 1947, while O’Connor was a student in Iowa. The brilliance that would make her fictions literary classics is fully apparent in them.

headline: G.E. Announces Plans to Take Retail Finance Unit Public
abstract: General Electric formally disclosed its plans to hold an initial public offering of its North American retail finance unit on Friday, as part of an effort to shrink its enormous finance arm.
lead_paragraph: General Electric formally disclosed its plans to hold an initial public offering of its North American retail finance unit on Friday, as part of an effort to shrink its enormous finance arm.

headline: Uncommon Prayers
abstract: Few modern writers address the subject of supplication, even briefly, with the seriousness of Flannery O’Connor.
lead_paragraph: Flannery O’Connor always stood out among 20th-century writers for her spiritual questing, more reminiscent of Kierkegaard and Dostoyevsky than of her peers. The discovery of a prayer journal she kept in her early 20s only reinforces her apartness. (Marilynne Robinson reviews “A Prayer Journal” this week.)

headline: Jewish Identities
abstract: New books by Jeffrey S. Gurock, Seth Lipsky, Dianne Ashton and Derek J. Penslar.
lead_paragraph: JEWS IN GOTHAM  New York Jews in a Changing City, 1920–2010  By Jeffrey S. Gurock  New York University Press, $45.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHY READ MOBY-DICK?,  by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Penguin, $13.) Philbrick, whose “In the Heart of the Sea: The Tragedy of the Whaleship Essex” recounted the real-life inspiration for Herman Melville’s shipwreck, now gives readers an enthusiastic shove toward the “one book that deserves to be called our American bible.” He broaches the novel thematically, with compact, often quirky essays on topics like landlessness, sharks and chowder.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE LUMINARIES,  by Eleanor Catton. (Little, Brown, $27.) In her Booker Prize winner, a love story and mystery set in New Zealand, Catton has built a lively parody of a 19th-century novel, while creating something utterly new for the 21st.

headline: Twists of Faith
abstract: Richard Rodriguez reckons with sexuality and religion in these soul-searching essays.
lead_paragraph: In “Hunger of Memory,” the 1982 book that made him one of the most prominent Hispanic essayists in America, Richard Rodriguez wrote: “I wanted to forget that I had a body because I had a brown body.” In “Darling,” his new essay collection, he claims this body in all its difficulties. “Flesh is a complicated medium for grace,” he writes, exploring the importance of physical bodies in a digital era, the importance of brownness (“Brown has always been the sum of our breathing and eating and moving about”) as well as the importance of complication itself — the possibilities embedded in resistance, those experiences of refusal that shape our intimacies and our yearnings.

headline: Riddle Wrapped in a Mystery
abstract: Arkady Renko turns to a translator’s cryptic notebook while investigating two deaths in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: It’s a spooky feeling, if you’re a translator who loves bicycling and word games and likes traveling to Russia, to open a book and encounter, in the very first chapter, a translating, cycling crossword fanatic who is plucked from a Kaliningrad beach by a homburg-hatted butcher, hurled into a carcass-strewn meat van and never heard from again. (Note to self: Avoid Kaliningrad.) At the time he was nabbed, the translator was carrying a notebook he’d used at a session of multilingual, high-stakes business negotiations. His abductor, flipping through the pages, was infuriated to find them filled with illegible doodles — stars, bugs, cats and spirals — the translator’s own private code. “Let the birds read it,” the butcher declared, flinging the notebook into the wind. Local children later found it in the sea grass.

headline: Compulsive Behavior
abstract: Four linked stories explore characters’ bottomless needs and stubborn weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: If folklorists are to be believed, the postnuptial tradition obliging the bridegroom to carry his bride over the threshold of their first home has less to do with ensuring the couple’s good luck and more to do with maintaining the bride’s good name. Apparently the custom spread from ancient Rome throughout medieval Europe as a politically fraught pantomime of chastity’s death at the marriage altar: The new wife, presumably reluctant to relinquish her virginity, had to be physically transported into her new matrimonial setting by her impatient husband.

headline: Running Battles
abstract: Pat Conroy’s family memoir centers on his father, the inspiration for “The Great Santini.”
lead_paragraph: It’s a rare memoir that begins by telling you it’s been told several times before, but that’s the case with “The Death of Santini.” The very title of Pat Conroy’s latest book, alluding to his novel “The Great Santini,” affirms that the abusive fighter pilot at the center of that story and the father mourned here are essentially one and the same. To dispel any lingering doubt, Conroy announces at the outset that the fictions he has spun over his long, celebrated literary career aren’t really fictions. They’re diamonds hauled up to earth and into the light of day from the dark and bottomless mine of his Southern clan: the tyrannical patriarch, the wounded matriarch, their seven self-destructive sons and daughters. We’ve met their alter egos and avatars, those of us who’ve supped contentedly on Conroy’s big-flavored prose through the years. In “The Death of Santini,” he more or less acknowledges that we’ll simply be reintroduced to them by their real names.

headline: Weight Loss Surgery Raises Some Pregnancy Risks
abstract: Women who have undergone bariatric surgery are more likely to deliver premature and low birth weight babies, a large new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Women who have undergone bariatric surgery are more likely to deliver premature babies and those with low birth weight, a large new study shows.

headline: On the Market in Miami
abstract: Properties include a waterfront contemporary; a Mediterranean revival; a downtown condo; an oceanfront condo; and a waterfront Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: Properties include a waterfront contemporary; a Mediterranean revival; a downtown condo; an oceanfront condo; and a waterfront Mediterranean.

headline: Without a Trace
abstract: “Critical Mass,” Sara Paretsky’s new V. I. Warshawski novel, involves a character inspired by the brilliant but unsung Austrian physicist Marietta Blau.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of women among the ranks of genre authors, but not many like Sara Paretsky, whose intellectually lively mysteries featuring her gutsy Chicago private eye, V. I.
