Warshawski, are fired by political causes and feminist social issues. Her latest, CRITICAL MASS (Putnam, $26.95), hits a nerve with its historical back story about a Viennese atomic physicist named Martina Saginor, “a great scientist who had a gender handicap” and disappeared during World War II — a character inspired by the brilliant but unsung Austrian physicist Marietta Blau.

headline: Close Calls
abstract: The characters in Russell Banks’s stories flirt with transgression but are ultimately resigned to their safer lives.
lead_paragraph: “Never been there myself,” a bartender tells a customer looking for exotic sex in Russell Banks’s incisive new collection of stories, “A Permanent Member of the Family.” “But I’ve heard no matter what you’re into you can find it behind the Green Door.”

headline: Battle-Shocked
abstract: Wounded at the start of Grant’s Overland Campaign, a soldier faces recovery in a military hospital.
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise Dennis McFarland chose the Battle of the Wilderness as the contextual scaffolding for his searing, poetic and often masterly new Civil War novel, “Nostalgia.” The intense three-day campaign, fought in Northern Virginia in May 1864, was the first showdown between the armies of Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee, and the casualties on both sides were staggering. It marked the beginning of Grant’s Overland Campaign, a strategy that eventually led to the sieges of Petersburg and Richmond and the defeat of the Confederacy. Yet details of the battle remain as shrouded as the thick forests in which it occurred. There were few brilliant maneuvers, few heroes remembered by history, and no clear winner. What a perfect setting, then, for a novel exploring the chaos of war and the confounding disorientation of its aftermath.

headline: Crushing Tons of Ivory, Wildlife Service Sends Signal to Smugglers
abstract: American wildlife officials illustrate their effort to crush ivory smuggling by crushing six tons of confiscated tusks and trinkets.
lead_paragraph: Updated below, 11:39 a.m. | The United States Fish and Wildlife Service on Thursday dropped six tons of confiscated ivory tusks and trinkets into a rock crusher near Denver, turning contraband that officials estimated was worth tens of millions of dollars into rubble.

headline: Upper Atmospherics
abstract: Richard Holmes looks at pioneering generations of European and American balloonists.
lead_paragraph: “The fact is, we are much more afraid of life than our ancestors,” Robert Louis Stevenson is heard remarking in “Footsteps” (1985), Richard Holmes’s sideways memoir of the “adventures of a Romantic biographer.” This feeling that the present is a time less adventurous in spirit than the past runs through Holmes’s vast body of work; in “Falling Upwards,” about balloonists and ballooning, it rises and spreads like a jet of fire-heated helium, making the new book at once lighter than Holmes’s other books and harder to read straight through.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Doris Kearns Goodwin, whose “Bully Pulpit” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4, has again found up-to-the-minute relevance in history; this time, in the Progressive Era.
lead_paragraph: Now and Then: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s book “The Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4. One key to Goodwin’s popularity as a historian has been her ability to spot overlaps between contemporary politics and the distant past — or even to create those overlaps herself, through the strength of her storytelling; when Barack Obama tapped his primary opponents Joe Biden and Hillary Clinton for important posts in his administration, he cited Goodwin’s account of Lincoln’s cabinet, “Team of Rivals,” as one influence.

headline: Strong Proof
abstract: Two books examine the increase in female drunkenness and the potential reasons for it.
lead_paragraph: At a party for Ms. magazine’s 40th birthday, the Canadian writer Ann Dowsett Johnston waited for an audience with Gloria Steinem, hoping to cull wisdom for her research on women and alcohol. “Alcohol?” Steinem said to Johnston, looking “dismissive.” “Alcohol is not a women’s issue.”

headline: People of the Book
abstract: The purchase of a Quran helped Thomas Jefferson develop an attitude of religious tolerance.
lead_paragraph: Divining a man’s beliefs from the books in his library is a perilous business. And when that man happens to be Thomas Jefferson, it’s like trying to staple vinaigrette to the ceiling. The third president, an omnivorous bibliophile, owned perhaps as many as 10,000 titles. He also was a reticent man of infinite contradictions, as well as a cunning politician. Could any one of this Delphic founder’s many books account for his most enduring contributions to liberal democracy? The answer, it seems, is yes.

headline: Blood Debt
abstract: In Robert Stone’s novel, several characters feel responsible for a young woman’s death.
lead_paragraph: Robert Stone, lapidary in his prose, is continent also in his output. Graham Greene is in some ways his most natural antecedent, but Stone has produced far fewer books. Almost all are memorable: “Dog Soldiers,” “A Flag for Sunrise,” “Outerbridge Reach,” “Damascus Gate.” He tackles a genre — frequently the thriller but, in the case of his latest book, the campus novel — and twists it to his purposes in ways that surprise and provoke. A subtle writer, he demands an attentive reader as he explores, through superficially familiar narratives, substantial themes.

headline: New York Observer
abstract: Roger Rosenblatt has always loved to stroll around his city and ponder what he sees.
lead_paragraph: To enter the world of this wonderful memoir is to leave the dull certainties of home and go wandering. The author’s destination is always the great wide world Out There, and through his sharp, compact prose, Roger Rosenblatt takes the reader with him. He is, after all, what some 19th-century Parisians called a flâneur, a stroller sauntering through anonymous crowds in the noisy, greedy, unscripted panoramas of the city.

headline: Who Made That Redskins Logo?
abstract: It wasn’t the first time that professional sports co-opted American Indian culture. (And it wasn’t the last.)
lead_paragraph: When the newly formed Boston Redskins traveled to Chicago’s Soldier Field to play the Bears on Oct. 1, 1933, the visiting players were barely recognizable. The owner, George Preston Marshall, ordered team members to smear themselves with face paint before going out onto the field. His was the first pro-sports team to co-opt an American Indian identity with such fervor: The Redskins’ halftime band marched in tribal regalia; the coach wore feathers on the sideline; and Marshall had an Indian-head logo printed across the center of their uniforms.

headline: Today in Small Business: Health Care Fixes
abstract: Running more than one business at a time. New S.B.A. measures for veterans. Businesses that don’t back up data.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Road Trip in Western China
abstract: From Kashgar to Tashkurgan in the southern crescent of Xinjiang.
lead_paragraph: From Kashgar to Tashkurgan in the southern crescent of Xinjiang.

headline: Let Go of the College Essay, and Let Your Teenager Speak for Herself
abstract: Nothing is so deadly to the necessary college memoirist’s perspective as Mom or Dad, no matter how loving, leaning down to read over one’s shoulder.
lead_paragraph: Recently I told the story in the Wall Street Journal of a father who offered me, an independent college applications counselor, a $10,000 check to write his son’s college essays. Never mind that his son was standing right there. I didn’t take the check. Instead I took the boy: We fled his father’s Midtown Manhattan office and went for a walk, along sidewalks crowded with people who had gone to Ivy League colleges, non-Ivy League colleges and no colleges at all, to the park, where we could really talk.

headline: In Our Pages: November 16
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1888 Chamberlain’s Wedding

headline: A Few Tips on Trident Management
abstract: Sam Claflin talks about his role as the trident-wielding Finnick Odair in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.”
lead_paragraph: Before it was announced who would play the muscly, green-eyed, trident-wielding Finnick Odair in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” the second installment of the film adaptation of Suzanne Collins’s post-apocalyptic trilogy, fans made it clear that picking the right actor was serious business. (“One Does Not Joke About Finnick’s Casting” was the title of one of many obsessed Tumblr pages.) Sam Claflin, 27, won the part, which still seems to be sinking in for this classically trained British actor. Pre-Finnick, his biggest credits were minor roles in “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” and “Snow White and the Huntsman.” Now he has a more central role in a thriving power franchise. When he’s done promoting “Catching Fire,” he’ll begin shooting “Mockingjay,” the final chapter of the “Hunger Games” series, which is being split into two parts.

headline: Taking the High Road
abstract: An expedition along the Karakoram Highway in western China offers a rare look at unspoiled pockets of a country undergoing a building binge.
lead_paragraph: For a few disconcerting moments, the gridlock that ensnared our minivan on the highway linking China to Pakistan sent my mind reeling to the countless hours I’d wasted on Beijing’s perpetually congested, smog-choked ring roads.

headline: Conductor’s Prize Goes to Jeffrey Milarsky
abstract: Mr. Milarsky will be presented with the prize at a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra that he is conducting Friday night.
lead_paragraph: The Ditson Conductor’s Award, a prize for distinguished contributions to American music, given annually by Columbia University, will be presented to the conductor and percussionist Jeffrey Milarsky at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, during a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra that Mr. Milarsky is conducting. The $5,000 award, which was established in 1945, will be presented by the pianist Gilbert Kalish, the head of the Ditson advisory committee.

headline: High Schoolers Against the Redskin Name
abstract: The controversy over the Redskins name is playing out at a Pennsylvania high school.
lead_paragraph: Such mainline media as Slate and Mother Jones have stopped using the name of Washington’s professional football team, finding “Redskins” a racist slur for all its rah-rah fondness among hometown fans at kick-off time. No less offended, the editorial board of the student newspaper at Neshaminy High School in Bucks County, Penn., has voted to banish the word from their pages, arguing that it’s time for their own Neshaminy Redskins (10-and-1 and a state powerhouses) to be called something less insensitive toward genocidal history. “The word ‘Redskin’ is racist and very much so,” the board explained in its decision to drop the name from editions of The Playwickian. “It is not a term of honor, but a term of hate.”

headline: Submit Your Real Estate Questions
abstract: Send your questions, share your stories and tell us what topics interest you most.
lead_paragraph: Got an upstairs neighbor who thinks there’s nothing wrong with coming home at 3 a.m. and hurling her three-inch heels across the uncarpeted hardwood floor? Or maybe you’re wondering if your co-op can really just decide to ban pets and tell you to find a new home for your 55-pound bulldog. Or you want to know what to do about the next-door neighbor who installed an eight-foot fence that you’re certain has veered into your backyard.

headline: Vivien Leigh, Before Tara Called
abstract: In “The Vivien Leigh Anniversary Collection,” Cohen Media Group assembles four of her early films, before “Gone With the Wind” made her world famous.
lead_paragraph: David O. Selznick’s much-publicized search for the star of “Gone With the Wind” culminated in early 1939 when he presented to the world one Vivien Leigh.

headline: N.Y. State Comptroller Invests in Lerer-Backed Tech Company
abstract: The New York State comptroller’s office said on Friday that it had invested in a website backed by Kenneth Lerer, the veteran venture capitalist, as it continues to support homegrown technology companies.
lead_paragraph: The New York State comptroller’s office said on Friday that it had invested in a website backed by Kenneth Lerer, the veteran venture capitalist, as it continues to support homegrown technology companies.

headline: Out of Economic Chaos, an Indie Spirit Is Forged
abstract: Their nation’s fiscal crisis forced Greek filmmakers to innovate financially; it also may have inspired a new cinematic wave of unrest.
lead_paragraph: Konstantinos Kontovrakis was a programmer for the Thessaloniki Film Festival until 2009, when he quit to become a film producer. Unfortunately, that was the year “the whole mess started,” as Mr. Kontovrakis put it. He meant the Greek economic crisis that continues to send shivers through the global economy. “Since then, I haven’t made a lot of money.”

headline: Murder Charge in a Shooting on Doorstep
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Self-Defense', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The prosecutor rejected a claim of self-defense in the shooting death of a young black Detroit woman by a white suburban homeowner.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After a two-week investigation, the prosecutor here charged a white suburban homeowner on Friday with second-degree murder in the killing of an unarmed young black woman. The prosecutor rejected the man’s assertion that he had been acting in self-defense when he opened his front door and fired a shotgun at the woman through a locked screen door, striking her in the face.

headline: A Daring Film, Silenced No More
abstract: Preservationists are working to restore Richard Oswald’s 1919 German film, “Different From the Others,” the earliest known full-length feature to showcase gay characters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The dark tale begins with a concert violinist infatuated with a young student and ends with blackmail and suicide. In between there are visits to bars and brothels, brawls in swanky digs, creepy shakedowns and a cameo by Oscar Wilde. It sounds like a slightly experimental indie project. In reality, the movie, “Different From the Others,” opened in the summer of 1919 to sold-out houses across Germany.

headline: 36 Hours in Chianti, Italy
abstract: There’s made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture and contemporary art worth a detour.
lead_paragraph: There’s made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture and contemporary art worth a detour.

headline: Volkswagen Announces Global Recall of 2.6 Million Vehicles
abstract: Exterior lighting problems have prompted VW to recall a number of Tiguans in the United States as part of the worldwide action.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen will recall about 62,000 Tiguan sport utility vehicles from the 2009-11 model years because they can lose exterior lighting, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The action is part of a worldwide 2.6 million vehicle recall for lighting and transmission problems, Volkswagen announced Thursday morning in Germany.

headline: Coach’s Career: Heights to Depths, and Everything in Between
abstract: Jeff Jagodzinski’s career has had it all, including a head coaching job at Boston College, stops in the N.F.L. and a stint in an N.A.I.A. program. He was also fired twice in one year.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The zigzag of a chart tracking the career of a typical football coaching lifer tends to mirror the charts that record the long-term performance of the stock market. For the coach, the line’s overall ascent is periodically interrupted by a flat line or a downturn, reflecting the inevitable firing or nonrenewal of a contract.

headline: Sizing Up the Better Business Bureau, and Its Rivals on the Internet
abstract: The venerable business rating organization has online competitors, and all work a little differently.
lead_paragraph: OVER the years, when writing about subjects as varied as driving schools and air duct cleaners, I’ve given the seemingly benign advice to check out companies with the Better Business Bureau.

headline: Footage of Death Plays On in Memory
abstract: A. O. Scott looks at Abraham Zapruder and his place in the evolution of film.
lead_paragraph: Before Nov. 22, 1963, Abraham Zapruder was an ordinary citizen of Dallas: a 58-year-old prosperous manufacturer of women’s clothing who had arrived in the city from Russia by way of Brooklyn. If that day had unfolded differently, that is most likely what he would have remained. But like a small but growing number of Americans at the time, he was also a home-movie hobbyist. With his receptionist, Marilyn Sitzman, as location scout and technical support, Zapruder took his 414PD Director Series Bell and Howell 8-millimeter camera to a spot on Elm Street, not far from his office, hoping to film the presidential motorcade as it drove past.

headline: 36 Hours in Chianti, Italy
abstract: Among the vineyards and olive groves are high-fashion and artisanal shops, sculpture gardens and Etruscan sites.
lead_paragraph: Stretching between Florence and Siena in the heart of Tuscany, the Chianti wine region is the romanticized Italy of daydreams: terra-cotta-roofed towns, wine-soaked dinners and vineyards stitching sun-dappled hillsides. But hidden amid Chianti’s winding roads and rolling hills are some surprisingly modern attractions. There’s made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture, and contemporary art worth a detour. Certainly, there are copious amounts of red wine waiting to be drunk, but don’t expect kitschy straw-wrapped bottles or pizza-parlor reds. Today Chianti vintners are producing excellent, nuanced wines that are worthy of these scenic surroundings.

headline: Streaming and Cable Deal for ‘The Simpsons’
abstract: The series, which has more than 500 episodes, has been widely syndicated but not on cable TV. The price was expected to approach $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: In one of television’s biggest syndication deals, “The Simpsons,” the longest-running scripted show in TV history, will finally be moving to cable television — and, not too surprisingly, it is staying in the family.

headline: Movie Review: 'Nebraska'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Nebraska."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Nebraska."

headline: Jury Finds Pipe Maker Defrauded Governments
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Local Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Three years after a whistle-blower’s original complaint, a federal jury in California has found JM Eagle to be responsible for selling defective PVC pipes to municipalities across the country.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in California found on Thursday that the nation’s largest maker of plastic pipe defrauded states and municipalities over a decade by knowingly selling them defective pipe for use in their drinking water, firefighting, irrigation and other essential public systems.

headline: Movie Review: 'Faust'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Faust."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Faust."

headline: Movie Review: 'The Great Beauty'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews the movie "The Great Beauty."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews the movie "The Great Beauty."

headline: Kelly Attacks Mayoral Candidates for Criticizing Police Dept.
abstract: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, in an interview with Playboy magazine, said the candidates were “pandering” when they criticized the Police Department, particularly its stop-and-frisk tactics.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said he “resented” the way the Democratic candidates for mayor criticized him and the Police Department while they were campaigning, according to an interview in Playboy magazine that was released this week.

headline: How Do You Teach Kids to Eat Well When You’re Not With Them?
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Baby Boomers', 'Snack Foods', 'Food']
abstract: Seeking advice from parents whose children made healthy eating choices in the school cafeteria and beyond to college.
lead_paragraph: “You are what you eat, from your head down to your feet!” Growing up in the 1970s, I had the benefit of having “Time for Timer’s” advice on healthy eating drummed into me weekly during Saturday morning cartoon binges. I may endlessly “hanker for a hunka, a slab, a slice, a chunka” cheese, but I also knew that no kid could survive on sugar alone, because “all those motors in your body need a lot of fuel to go on,” like a healthy breakfast and a balanced snack.

headline: Photography Fair Arrives in Paris
abstract: The 17th edition of Paris Photo, which runs through Sunday under the dome of the Grand Palais, includes 136 international galleries from 24 countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If light is the key ingredient of photography, there was no lack of it at the Paris Photo preview earlier this week. The 17th edition of the annual photography fair, which runs through Sunday under the dome of the Grand Palais, includes 136 international galleries from 24 countries.

headline: ValueVision Rejects Demands From Activist Investor
abstract: The Clinton Group has been agitating for change at the top for more than two weeks and has called for an overhaul of the board.
lead_paragraph: ValueVision, the Internet and television shopping network, has rebuffed demands from the activist investor Clinton Group to overhaul its board, saying that the investor has no legal basis to make those demands.

headline: Traveling to Find Your Roots
abstract: Vacation planners and genealogical websites help families research their ancestors.
lead_paragraph: It was lunchtime at the Outlaws’ Shack in Poiana Brasov, a mountain resort in Transylvania, and we were washing down chunks of kashkaval cheese and peasant bread with sips of tsuica, a Romanian plum brandy. At a neighboring table, a man picked up a red onion and bit into it as if it were an apple — something I had seen only my father do.

headline: Image of the Day: November 15
abstract: Golfer Gaganjeet Bhullar in action at the Australian Masters golf tournament in Melbourne.

headline: And the Crowd Goes ... Well, You Know
abstract: Lady Gaga’s strategy at the new H&M Times Square store: to inject her wayward artistry into a staunchly corporate setting.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga’s strategy at the new H&M Times Square store: to inject her wayward artistry into a staunchly corporate setting.

headline: Lady Gaga Drops In at H&M and the Crowd Goes ... Well, You Know
abstract: Lady Gaga promoted “Artpop,” her latest album, at the opening of H&M’s Times Square store.
lead_paragraph: LADY GAGA’S ARRIVAL on Wednesday night atop a pink Skyline sightseeing bus was cheeky, all right. Fanning out her waist-length hair and wearing a paint-streaked H&M cat suit, she worked the public like a flaxen Cleopatra waving from her barge.

headline: The Gun Report: November 15, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: * The first 3D-printed gun, the “Liberator .380,” the design of which is widely available online, could emerge as a national security threat when a law banning undetectable firearms expires next month. The Undetectable Firearms Act, first passed in 1988, requires guns to have enough steel to set off a metal detector, but the Liberator uses only the smallest bits of metal for ammunition and a firing pin the size of a roofing nail. Some senators have proposed an updated version of the bill that would ban the design, manufacture, sale, import, export and possession of the plastic guns. The blueprint for the Liberator .380 has been downloaded 100,000 times since it was designed last year. “The fact that anyone with the right equipment can make a fully-functioning weapon from their own home with the click of a mouse is a truly frightening concept,” Sen. Bill Nelson said in a statement.

headline: Restaurant Report: State-Run Food Shop No. 37 in Hanoi
abstract: This establishment aims to recreate the period of government canteens, with diners issued ration coupons, and servers authentically brusque.
lead_paragraph: The dining scene in Hanoi has flourished in recent years. Travelers can feast on international fare like sushi and tapas, as well as on innovative takes on Vietnamese cuisine. But this tiny restaurant, which opened in the fall of 2012, evokes a simpler time: the decade starting in 1976, when the state controlled the economy so tightly that restaurants were barred from having names, and privately owned businesses were illegal.

headline: Love in the Time Before the Internet
abstract: ‘The Most Happy Fella,’ a story about a farmer captivated by a young waitress, closes the 50th anniversary season of Goodspeed Musicals.
lead_paragraph: It’s been noted that in the age of cellphones, the romance between Romeo and Juliet would not end in tragedy. But add the Internet to the plot of “The Most Happy Fella,” and the romance never happens. An immigrant farmer might still be captivated by a young, pretty hash-house waitress on his visit to San Francisco. He might still leave a piece of jewelry — although it wouldn’t be a tie pin — as a tip, along with a charmingly effusive love note.

headline: A Road Trip Through Alexander Payne’s Nebraska
abstract: The director shares his favorite local haunts with the novelist Kurt Andersen, who also happens to be a native Nebraskan.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Air Pollution as a Heart Threat
abstract: An increasing number of studies link air pollution not just to cancer, but to cardiovascular disease as well.
lead_paragraph: Bit by bit over the past few decades, scientists have been building a new understanding of the ways that air pollution threatens human health. Much of their attention has been focused on lung diseases, including cancers. With good reason, it turns out: just last month, the World Health Organization declared air pollution to be one of the planet’s most dangerous environmental carcinogens.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s ‘Bully Pulpit’
abstract: Ms. Goodwin discusses her new book about the Progressive era.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Bill Keller reviews Doris Kearns Goodwin’s “Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism.” Mr. Keller writes:

headline: The Impossible Refugee Boat Lift to Christmas Island
abstract: More than a thousand refugees have died trying to reach Christmas Island. But faced with unbearable conditions at home, they keep coming.
lead_paragraph: By LUKE MOGELSONMore than a thousand refugees have died trying to reach Christmas Island. But faced with unbearable conditions at home, they keep coming.Photographs by JOEL VAN HOUDT

headline: Exclusive | 18 East 74th Street
abstract: An opulent seven-story Neo-Renaissance-style mansion built in 1871 is about to enter the market at $34 million.
lead_paragraph: An opulent seven-story Neo-Renaissance-style mansion built in 1871 is about to enter the market at $34 million.

headline: Upper East Side Mansion, Ornate, Yet Cozy
abstract: A seven-story limestone house exudes an unexpected aura of coziness along with its grandeur.
lead_paragraph: An extravagantly appointed Upper East Side mansion that recalls the gravitas and gilding — if not quite the square footage — of Highclere Castle, which became a character in its own right on the PBS series “Downton Abbey,” is poised to enter the market at $34 million.

headline: Deflating Tesco’s Blow-Up Friend
abstract: A-Rod reality TV; rejected baby names; Bellamy Young’s leonine streak.
lead_paragraph: A-Rod reality TV; rejected baby names; Bellamy Young’s leonine streak.

headline: Window Displays of Affection
abstract: Impromptu memorials to J.F.K.
lead_paragraph: Over the three days that followed the assassination of John F. Kennedy 50 years ago, 250,000 people viewed his flag-draped coffin in the Capitol Rotunda; dignitaries from more than 100 countries visited Washington to attend the funeral, procession and burial service at Arlington National Cemetery. On the eve of Kennedy’s burial, Dan Budnik, a photographer for Magnum at the time, was walking around downtown Washington and taking note of the framed portraits of the president that had been placed in store windows, often incongruously among office furniture or mannequins. “People were trying to figure out how to honor the fallen president,” says Budnik, who is now 80. “They incorporated the tragedy. I was just taken by the aspect of turning commercial into memorial. I was very moved by the individual gestures.” ﻿Julie Bosman

headline: Window Displays of Affection
abstract: Impromptu memorials to J.F.K.
lead_paragraph: Impromptu memorials to J.F.K.

headline: The 11.3.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: BROCCOLI’S EXTREME MAKEOVER

headline: What Cynthia Ozick Taught Me About My Grandfather
abstract: She appears to know my lineage better than I do.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Ozick and I have long differed on the name of my grandfather. Every decade or so, we run into each other at some New York gathering, and after exchanging pleasantries, I say, again, that the first name of my paternal grandfather, an immigrant from Ukraine, was Kusel (pronounced k’SEEL.) She informs me, once more, that it was Yekutiel, a name I’d never heard before I met her. Our discussions have always been cordial. Considering the fact that she is someone who is celebrated for her erudite essays as well as for her novels, she has been admirably free of condescension. I would compare the tone of our disagreement to a respectful difference in interpretation by two scholars — or maybe between one scholar and another person.

headline: Put Me in, Coach — I’m Ready to Pay
abstract: Rain man of his own mind.
lead_paragraph: My granddaughter is being asked to pay more than $2,000 to be on a traveling sports team. The coach of her high-school team, who also coaches the unaffiliated traveling team, is asking for the payment as a condition of my granddaughter’s participation on the regular high-school squad. Is this unethical behavior by the coach? Is it proper for the person paying the fee (me) to bring this issue to the attention of the school system? How do I avoid retribution by the coach against my granddaughter? CHET M., ORINDA, CALIF.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Milwaukee; Jasper, Alberta; California
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Exposed! Harley-Davidson’s Lost Photographs, 1915-1916, Milwaukee More than 50 black-and-white photographs documenting the early years of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company are on display through Jan. 1, in Milwaukee at the Harley-Davidson Museum. The photos, printed from a collection of more than 400 fragile glass-plate negatives, provide a glimpse back nearly 100 years ago and include employee portraits, depictions of the company’s 1916 racing team and images used for marketing.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Reports Increased Traffic Deaths
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Automobiles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Traffic deaths were up in 2012 over 2011, but the federal  agency says they are still near historic lows.
lead_paragraph: More people died on United States roads in 2012 than in 2011, according to a report from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Motorcyclist and pedestrian deaths each increased for the third year in a row, and deaths of bicyclists reached the highest level in six years. Over all, however, traffic deaths continue to be at historic lows.

headline: Gut-Wrenching
abstract: A woman suffers bouts of extreme abdominal pain that come and go and come again.
lead_paragraph: A woman suffers bouts of extreme abdominal pain that come and go and come again.

headline: Analyzing Obama on Health Care in The Times
abstract: Questions of whether the president lied and whether a comparison with Hurricane Katrina is warranted.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for Michael Shear’s news analysis on Friday’s front page to cause what he termed “an email and Twitter explosion” for the White House correspondent.

headline: Printed Books Are Alive and Sometimes Weird
abstract: For “New York Bound: International Book Art Biennial,” artists responded to a request for unconventional ideas about the book as an object.
lead_paragraph: The news about books today is often centered on the shift from print to digital, from paper to electronic devices. At the Islip Art Museum, entirely different kinds of transformations are on display, and none of them are electronic.

headline: Above, Below and Around Paris, on Foot
abstract: The Petite Ceinture, an abandoned track circling the city, offers intrepid hikers a rare perspective.
lead_paragraph: We drew a deep breath before entering the tunnel. The garbage strewn around the entrance was about as inviting as the prospect of walking nearly a mile under one of Paris’s most famous parks not knowing what, or whom, to expect. We were in the heart of the city, but completely removed from it.

headline: Facebook Reasserts Posts Can Be Used to Advertise
abstract: The company says it made more clear that postings and other personal data can be used in advertising on the site and reiterated that includes information from teenage users.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you post something on Facebook, let there be no doubt that it can end up as an ad shown to your friends and acquaintances.

headline: Seeing and Being Seen, Across Millenniums
abstract: A museum invites viewers to record their reactions to portraits by artists as diverse as Pablo Picasso, Diane Arbus and Lucas Cranach the Elder.
lead_paragraph: Faces are everywhere at the Katonah Museum of Art. Some gaze boldly across the galleries, cheery, confrontational, sly; others turn aside, pensive and enigmatic. All hold stories of humanity, a gathering of characters, cultures and colors.

headline: Video: ‘Hyperbole,’ Comedy and Angst
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: Allie Brosh, the Hyperbole and a Half blogger, talks about her art on the occasion of her first book being published.
lead_paragraph: Allie Brosh’s blog, Hyperbole and a Half, has a devoted following, attracting as many as five million readers a month. Her first post, in July 2009, had no pictures at all, but her drawings have become increasingly prominent. Although they’re somewhat crude, they reflect raw emotion and seamlessly blend comedy and pain. Ms. Brosh tells stories about her childhood, her life in Oregon with her husband and two dogs, and her struggles with depression, which caused a 19-month hiatus from her blog that ended in May.

headline: Forbes Says It Is for Sale
abstract: The media company, which includes Forbes magazine and a growing digital presence, said it had hired Deutsche Bank to seek offers.
lead_paragraph: Forbes Media, which publishes Forbes magazine and has been making an extensive push into digital media and native advertising, is up for sale, the company confirmed in an email to the staff Friday morning.

headline: On the Path to Personalization: Part 1
abstract: This is the first in a series of posts exploring the underlying technology of our new recommendations engine.
lead_paragraph: This is the first in a series of posts exploring the underlying technology of our new recommendations engine. The second post is here.

headline: More Cities Consider Using Eminent Domain to Halt Foreclosures
abstract: Several cities are weighing the purchase of mortgages from underwater homes — by force if necessary — to curb foreclosures and falling property values.
lead_paragraph: New cities are joining the effort to head off home foreclosures by using a twist on the power of eminent domain, despite threats of financial retaliation from Wall Street and Washington.

headline: Glafkos Clerides, Greek Cypriot Leader Who Sought Unification, Is Dead at 94
abstract: Mr. Clerides, the president of Cyprus from 1993 to 2003, was a frustrated peacemaker in futile talks with Turkish Cypriots to reunify their long-divided island.
lead_paragraph: Glafkos Clerides, the president of Cyprus from 1993 to 2003, who as leader of his nation’s Greek Cypriot majority was a frustrated peacemaker in futile talks with Turkish Cypriots to reunify their long-divided Mediterranean island, died on Friday in Nicosia, the capital. He was 94.

headline: Antidoping Lab’s Flaws Put Olympics in a Bind
abstract: If the laboratory in Moscow loses its accreditation from the World Anti-Doping Agency, the Sochi Games will be without a competent drug-testing facility in the country.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Less than three months before the opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics, the antidoping laboratory in Russia charged with conducting drug screenings at those Winter Games has been deemed unreliable and may lose its authority to test Olympic athletes.

headline: Predicting a Fall’s Aftermath
abstract: Why do some older adults manage to recover from falls while others never do?
lead_paragraph: For an elderly person, a bad fall can mark the difference between between walking and wheelchair, between living in one’s own home and moving to a nursing home. It can be a life-changing event.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
abstract: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.
lead_paragraph: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

headline: Baffling About-Face in American-US Airways Merger
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The settlement that ended the Justice Department’s lawsuit against the airlines left many antitrust experts with questions.
lead_paragraph: Did the Justice Department cave?

headline: New Grove Dictionary Broadens Scope on American Music
abstract: The new edition of the Grove Dictionary of American Music is twice the size of the previous edition.
lead_paragraph: For classical music fans and scholars – and increasingly, for those devoted to other musical genres, including non-Western forms as well as jazz and popular music – the various editions of the Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians have been the principal resource for generations. Originally published in 1878 as a four-volume set, edited by Sir George Grove (but without his name in the title), the Grove took a huge leap with its sixth edition, which was so thoroughly revamped that when it appeared in 1980, “New” was added to the title. The current New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, published in 2001, fills 29 volumes.

headline: Finding Strength in Humility
abstract: Genuine humility is a reflection of neither weakness nor insecurity, the author writes. Instead, it implies self-confidence, and it gives leaders permission to acknowledge their limitations and learn from them.
lead_paragraph: Humility doesn’t get much respect in the corporate world. How often do you hear a leader say publicly, “I’m sorry, I got that wrong,” or, “I didn’t do that very well,” or even something as simple as, “I don’t know.”

headline: General Electric Finally Gets Past the Jack Welch Era
abstract: The spinoff of GE Capital’s North America retail finance business will help the company focus on its core businesses.
lead_paragraph: General Electric is finally putting the ghost of its former chief executive Jack Welch out to pasture. On Friday, the conglomerate said it intended to spin off its North America retail finance business. That will help return GE Capital to its roots of lending to midmarket companies and its parent’s industrial concerns.

headline: Houseful of Handfuls
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Peter Newman, the producer, and Antonia Dauphin, a casting agent, live at 1 Fifth Avenue, no stranger to Hollywood types.
lead_paragraph: One Fifth Avenue, the 27-story Art Deco apartment tower built in the late 1920s at the corner of Eighth Street, has a reputation as a Hollywood building. The directors who’ve called it home include Brian De Palma, Paul Mazursky, Ira Sachs and Tim Burton. It’s no wonder that Peter Newman, a film producer and a professor at New York University, and Antonia Dauphin, a casting agent who is about to direct her first feature, are so comfortable there.

headline: In Brooklyn, Friday Night Rites
abstract: Catland, an intentionally dusty and dim bookstore in Bushwick, welcomes visitors for ritual ceremonies, alchemy workshops and author readings.
lead_paragraph: They moved to the beat of a drum in the backyard, flames jumping from a caldron set in a circle drawn in the dirt. One by one they placed pieces of paper into the fire — with words of a burden they wanted to shed — and watched sparks rise into the Brooklyn night sky.

headline: Art Matters | From Matmos, a Musical Libretto Performed by Random Strangers
abstract: The experiment by the veteran sonic experimentalists was a commission for the Dia Art Foundation.
lead_paragraph: “There’s something suspicious about the work we do,” said Drew Daniel of the Baltimore experimental duo Matmos, “because it has an eerie ability to seem alien.” Daniel and Martin Schmidt, his partner in creativity and in life, are known for pulling sounds from unorthodox sources: squishing organs on operating tables, rats pattering across cages, rose petals being crushed. To create the sounds for their last album, “The Marriage of True Minds,” the duo conducted a Ganzfeld experiment — a parapsychological technique used to test for ESP — on subjects in Baltimore and Oxford, England. Participants were asked to lie on the floor, cover their eyes with Ping-Pong balls and listen to blasting white noise, then describe what they saw in their mind’s eye. “We’ve had some ideas that other people may object to or find a little odd,” Daniel admitted.

headline: Fewer Choices in the Air
abstract: The merger between American Airlines and US Airways comes after airlines have struggled for decades, cutting costs and slimming down service to turn around a trend of diminishing profits.
lead_paragraph: The merger between American Airlines and US Airways comes after airlines have struggled for decades, cutting costs and slimming down service to turn around a trend of diminishing profits.

headline: Programmers Find New Way to Navigate Health Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Three people who struggled to use HealthCare.gov have founded HealthSherpa, a minimalist website that tells consumers what plans are available in their area.
lead_paragraph: The stumbling rollout of the federally run online health exchange has frustrated tens of thousands of Americans and sent some looking for alternative sources of information on where they can buy health insurance, and what it will cost them, under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Abuse Accusations Overshadow Commonwealth Meeting in Sri Lanka
keywords: ['Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'Sinhalese (Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The prime ministers of Canada, India and Mauritius stayed away from the summit meeting to protest the treatment of Tamils during the civil war.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Sri Lanka’s president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, tried to pre-empt criticism of his government’s human rights record on Friday as he welcomed leaders of Commonwealth countries to a summit  meeting in the Sri Lankan capital, Colombo, that was overshadowed by persistent allegations of state-sponsored abuse during a long civil war by the Sinhalese-dominated government against ethnic Tamils.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 15, 2013
abstract: This week, Joe discusses Janet Yellen, who is poised to become the new head of the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Janet Yellen is poised to become the new head of the Federal Reserve. If she is confirmed by the Senate, she would arguably become the most powerful woman in the U.S. economy, with the power to keep interests rates low, prevent inflation and attack unemployment. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss Yellen’s confirmation hearing, as well as what’s going on at the regional Federal Reserve banks.

headline: Vocal Instructor Commands ‘Enough Nonsense,’ Sing!
abstract: Maria Zhorella, 98, is a relentless taskmaster of a vocal instructor who is called a singer’s secret weapon and who as a young soprano in Austria helped rescue Jews.
lead_paragraph: Maria Zhorella recently turned 98, and if only she would just slow down and give her vocal students a break.

headline: Their Harmony Is Loud and Clear
abstract: A long and winding romance with a punk rocker is just what the future doctor ordered.
lead_paragraph: Huai-Bin Mabel Ko is someone who revels in the chance to find beauty in places others would never think to look.

headline: Zulily Surges in Market Debut
abstract: Shares in the retailer, which focuses on flash sales of products for children and mothers, rose more than 70 percent in their market debut on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:15 p.m. | It may not be a globally popular social network or a highly regarded human resources software company. But Zulily is finding plenty of demand from investors all the same.

headline: Bring On the Juggling Act
abstract: The office-bound mom playing “straight man” to the stay-at-home dad in the clown’s suit.
lead_paragraph: Even before they were married in 1999, Terry Williams and Patrick Cashin had an understanding about who would be their future children’s primary caretaker.

headline: Bill Moyers Will Stay on TV
abstract: After announcing that “Moyers & Company” would end in January, the host and his producers received an outpouring of support and lined up new funding.
lead_paragraph: The fans of Bill Moyers spoke, and he listened. Mr. Moyers announced late last month that his public television show “Moyers & Company” would end with the Jan. 3, 2014, program. But on Friday, the program’s executive producer, Judy Doctoroff, told a meeting of public television officials that the program would stay on the air after all, after receiving “thousands of heartfelt and well-written messages saying ‘don’t go.’ ” New funding was also lined up, she said.

headline: The Story of Manhattan’s Rectangular Street Grid
abstract: A question about the history of Manhattan’s rigid right-angled street grid.
lead_paragraph: Q. When did Manhattan’s rectangular street grid first begin appearing?

headline: Isay Weinfeld Exhibition in TriBeCa
abstract: The show, “A to Z,” is devoted to multifaceted career of Brazilian architect, designer and filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Isay Weinfeld, an architect, designer and filmmaker for 40 years, has built a following in his native Brazil. But now his reputation should ripple with the opening of the first show in the United States devoted to his multifaceted career. Called “A to Z,” the exhibition is on view through Dec. 1 at Espasso, a TriBeCa showroom of Brazilian design.

headline: Amazon Bares Its Computers
abstract: In an unusually detailed presentation, one of the brains behind Amazon Web Services described how it was remaking computers for a global scale.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — However big and ambitious you think Amazon’s plan to run the world’s computing may be, you should probably think bigger.

headline: Reading, Walking and More Reading for Writer
abstract: Pete Hamill, a journalist and novelist, takes long walks in between reading the newspaper and reading in bed.
lead_paragraph: If you are an attentive walker in New York City, any block might open up to you as a story: about the immigrants who once lived there, about the forces that moved them, about the direction of change and the people driving it. Pete Hamill, 78, the journalist and novelist, provided the language for many of those stories. So it is only fitting that for him, Sunday is a day of long walks, starting from the apartment in TriBeCa that he shares with his wife, Fukiko Aoki Hamill, 65, a writer. The paperback edition of his most recent book of short fiction, “The Christmas Kid: And Other Brooklyn Stories,” was published last month.

headline: Hell’s Kitchen Real Estate: Hot
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Not so long ago, Hell’s Kitchen drowsed in the shadow of nearby Midtown. But now residential projects popping up left and right.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, Hell’s Kitchen drowsed in the shadow of nearby Midtown. But now residential projects popping up left and right.

headline: Hell’s Kitchen: Sizzling
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Not so long ago, Hell’s Kitchen drowsed in the shadow of nearby Midtown. But now the area is truly hot, with residential projects popping up left and right.
lead_paragraph: In the race to develop the West Side of Manhattan, Hell’s Kitchen can seem the tortoise to the Hudson Yards hare. Yet if Hudson Yards suddenly seems to be going up all at once, its neighbor to the north has been moving ahead in slow, deliberate steps, year after year.

headline: U.S. Appears More Open to Finance Discussions in Trade Talks With Europe
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The chief negotiators for both the United States and the European Union said they would hold a special session on financial services on Nov. 27.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — American negotiators appear to be softening their resolve to keep financial services out of trans-Atlantic trade talks with the European Union.

headline: Big Ticket | A Limestone ‘Swan’ for $26 Million
abstract: A turnkey townhouse features a classic exterior and a thoroughly modern interior.
lead_paragraph: An ugly duckling townhouse that was the beneficiary of an ambitious $10 million neo-Roman makeover to restore its original 1879 panache with a striking facade of imported Italian limestone and a cornice that hides a rooftop soaking pool sold for $26 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The annual taxes on the 20-foot-wide property are $110,000.

headline: Convoluted Language Makes Cooper Tire Deal Harder to Execute
abstract: A judge’s ruling related to the provisions of a deal for Cooper Tire to sell itself to an Indian rival brings up an interesting debate about the language of merger agreements, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Cooper Tire is facing more legal issues in its snarled deal with Apollo Tyres Ltd. of India.

headline: Gluten-Free Pies for Thanksgiving
abstract: Thanksgiving is coming up and what is Thanksgiving without pie? If your guests can’t eat gluten, here are five pies they will still enjoy.
lead_paragraph: I’m by no means a gluten-free girl, and not much of an expert when it comes to gluten-free cooking. But Thanksgiving is coming up and what is Thanksgiving without pie? Since many of you may be stuck when it comes to pies and gluten-free family members and guests, I decided to tackle a gluten-free pie crust this week.

headline: For Some Aid Workers, Rescues Must Wait as Bodies Are Removed
abstract: Volunteers from the Philippine Red Cross searched for bodies in Tacloban as thousands of residents remain hungry and homeless.
lead_paragraph: Volunteers from the Philippine Red Cross searched for bodies in Tacloban as thousands of residents remain hungry and homeless.

headline: General Motors Recalls 2013-14 Chevrolet Malibus Over Electrical Problems
abstract: More than 14,000 2013 Malibus and 43,000 2014 Malibus will be recalled for malfunctions affecting power seats and windshield defrosters.
lead_paragraph: General Motors will recall 14,909 Chevrolet Malibus from the 2013 model year in the United States equipped with the eight-way power front seat and passenger seat option. G.M. says that in certain vehicles, the wiring harness may wear against the frame. If this happens, the insulation of a circuit on the wiring harness may become worn through to the conductor and a short to the grounded seat frame may occur.

headline: An Ice Rink Opens in Brooklyn
abstract: The ice skating rink at McCarren Park, north Brooklyn’s “first and only” outdoor skating rink, opened today. It will be open through January, seven days a week.
lead_paragraph: The ice skating rink at McCarren Park, north Brooklyn’s “first and only” outdoor skating rink, opened today. The rink is nestled atop the beach plaza at the center of the pool area. It will be open through January, from 11 a.m. to 10 p.m., seven days a week.

headline: Raising Healthy Eaters, with SNAP or American Express
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Income Inequality', 'Parenting']
abstract: Stark contrasts in income (from chef-taught nannies to food stamps), but one thing in common: parents struggle to teach their children to make healthy choices in a world of caloric excess.
lead_paragraph: A study in contrasts:

headline: Claudia Fleming's Apple Crumb Crostata
abstract: When Claudia Fleming was at Gramercy Tavern, she was known for her all-American desserts. Mark Bittman invited her to share her Thanksgiving specialty: apple crumb crostata with bacon toffee.
lead_paragraph: When Claudia Fleming was at Gramercy Tavern, she was known for her all-American desserts. Mark Bittman invited her to share her Thanksgiving specialty: apple crumb crostata with bacon toffee.

headline: A ‘Downton’ Weekend in Georgia
abstract: The Sea Island resort’s “Downton Abbey” program in January will have series star Allen Leech as its host.
lead_paragraph: Sea Island resort in Georgia is celebrating the Jan. 5 debut of the fourth season of the British series “Downton Abbey” with a weekend inspired by the series and hosted by Allen Leech, who plays the character of Tom Branson, the outspoken former family chauffeur and widower of Lady Sybil.

headline: Probe May Help Solve Riddle of Mars’s Missing Air
abstract: Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution, or Maven for short, is to spend at least a year observing the Martian atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s next mission to Mars aims to answer one question: What happened to the air that once made the surface habitable?

headline: Cutting the Heart Out of Health Reform
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s hard to fathom why 39 Democrats voted for a bill that would allow people to retain substandard individual health care policies.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to be mad at President Obama over health care reform – the broken website, the confusing choices, his false promise that everyone could keep their current plans.

headline: A New Era for Progressives
abstract: The growth of progressive politics is tied to the Working Families Party, which is extending its reach beyond the city.
lead_paragraph: On the corner of Canal and Varick Streets at the moment sits a 15,000-square-foot plastic tent, one that required a week’s worth of construction, the kind of edifice that typically at this time of year is given over to the sale of hand-knit scarves and tiny things made of wood. The purpose of this particular tent is outside the scope of holiday crafts: The project, called Talking Transition, was developed by a consortium of nonprofit groups, including the Revson Foundation, to allow New Yorkers to voice their opinions about what sort of direction the city should take in the aftermath of Bill de Blasio’s victory in the mayor’s race.

headline: Review: 2014 Kia Sorento
abstract: A vehicle refresh normally means a new grille and taillights. Kia gives the 2014 Sorento an entirely different chassis structure, a new engine and an improved suspension. Who does that?
lead_paragraph: A vehicle refresh normally means a new grille and taillights. Kia gives the 2014 Sorento an entirely different chassis structure, a new engine and an improved suspension. Who does that?

headline: Seventh Heaven
abstract: The polished seventh-generation Corvette Stingray is a world-class sports car that, unlike its brutish, twitchy predecessor, requires no compromises.
lead_paragraph: The polished seventh-generation Corvette Stingray is a world-class sports car that, unlike its brutish, twitchy predecessor, requires no compromises.

headline: Weekend Reading: JPMorgan’s Strategy in China
abstract: The daughter of China’s former prime minister used an alias while working for JPMorgan Chase. In fairness, we should reveal that DealBook comments anonymously under the pseudonym of Bargain Literary Work.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of China’s former prime minister used the alias “Lily Chang” while working for JPMorgan Chase. In fairness, we should reveal that DealBook sometimes comments anonymously under the pseudonym of Bargain Literary Work.

headline: Simon & Schuster & Jeter
abstract: Derek Jeter. Nose in a book, head in the game.
lead_paragraph: At one point this past baseball season, Derek Jeter, out injured, revealed that he wasn’t watching Yankees games regularly. He didn’t have the Extra Innings package, he said, and the games were blacked out in Tampa. (Why the YES Network would say NO to Tampa like that, I have no idea.) Now we know what he might have been doing instead of watching TV — reading manuscripts!

headline: 22-Year-Old Wins a Big Game in Chess Championship
abstract: Magnus Carlsen of Norway leads 3 to 2 against the titleholder, Viswanathan Anand, the champion since 2007.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Carlsen has already accomplished more in his brief career as a chess player than almost anyone in the game’s history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Philippines, Nepal, Myanmar and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Philippines, Nepal, Myanmar and India.

headline: A Bird of Courage and Success
abstract: Back from the brink of extinction in the Northeast, turkeys are now relatively abundant, and some dwell in Manhattan, on Staten Island and in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: If Benjamin Franklin had gotten his way, a gold-plated turkey would have presided atop every flagpole where the American bald eagle now stands. Franklin considered the bald eagle a “bird of bad moral character,” while the turkey was “a much more respectable bird,” and “though a little vain and silly, a Bird of Courage.”

headline: The Well-Concealed Newness of the Kia Sorento
abstract: Automakers typically wait a few years to update a vehicle’s underpinnings, but Kia made major – albeit hard to see – changes to the Sorento for 2014. Here’s a video review.
lead_paragraph: In the hypercompetitive automotive industry, a car is often produced for four to six years, getting an update halfway through its life. Visually, this is the “new grille and taillights” phase. While full sheet metal overhauls are expensive, a new schnoz and back end can be done efficiently. These cosmetic revisions are a good way to ignite new sales.

headline: Bated Breath, as a Baton Is Raised for a Specialty
abstract: After canceling a date there last March, the San Francisco Symphony gave a delayed performance of Mahler’s Ninth Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco Symphony canceled an East Coast tour in March because of a players’ strike, one event that went by the board was a Carnegie Hall performance of Mahler’s Ninth Symphony, to have been led by the ensemble’s music director, Michael Tilson Thomas. The loss disappointed many, since this combination of orchestra and conductor is typically potent in Mahler.

headline: Modern Love Child of a Renaissance Spirit
abstract: The Choir of Men and Boys at St. Thomas Church and the Fretwork ensemble presented a program of mostly Renaissance works on Tuesday, along with the premiere of Nico Muhly’s “My Days.”
lead_paragraph: “My Days” is the title of a program of mostly Renaissance works for voices and viols that was presented Tuesday at St. Thomas  by that church’s Choir of Men and Boys and the wonderful English viol consort Fretwork. It’s also the title of an arresting new work by Nico Muhly, a touching declaration of fraternity with the great Elizabethan composers that had its United States premiere that evening.

headline: In the Air | Lush Landscapes
abstract: Gardens, with their lavish greenery and the endless variety of flowers, have long been a source for inspiration for artists, poets and designers alike.
lead_paragraph: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

headline: Compromise May Be Near for Iran Nuclear Deal, U.S. Official Says
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American officials appear to be seeking a solution in which Iran would be allowed to enrich uranium at the low level of 3.5 percent during an interim agreement and also under a comprehensive accord.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Obama administration official said on Friday that a solution could be found for one of the major stumbling blocks to an agreement that would freeze Iran’s nuclear program, and that the accord might be achieved next week.

headline: Blurring Beginnings and Endings and Politics
abstract: Hofesh Shechter Company performed a premiere of “Sun” at the Howard Gilman Opera House at BAM.
lead_paragraph: Hofesh Shechter’s “Sun” is cheeky. First the voice of the Israeli-born choreographer, a popular success in Britain, announces that before starting, his company will show a bit of the ending, “so that you know everything is going to be just fine.”

headline: In the Air | Strange Paradise
abstract: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.
lead_paragraph: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

headline: One-Track Mind
abstract: Unlike the latest Corvette, the 2013 SRT Viper has no need for refinements like an automatic transmission or decent gas mileage. It puts speed above all other considerations.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the latest Corvette, the 2013 SRT Viper has no need for refinements like an automatic transmission or decent gas mileage. It puts speed above all other considerations.

headline: Boy Detective, Gilded New York and Best-Dressed Man
abstract: Books about a curious boy growing up in Gramercy Park; the lavish homes and belongings of early philanthropists; and well-dressed criminals.
lead_paragraph: That Roger Rosenblatt’s “The Boy Detective” (Ecco) has no table of contents will make perfect sense to readers who follow the meandering path that constitutes his charming memoir of growing up around Gramercy Park. Categorizing his musings would be too confining.

headline: Stingray Returns With Styling à la Mode
abstract: The new Corvette Stingray’s ambitions are loftier than the previous Corvette, a point underscored by the return of the Stingray name. If Porsche made this car,  it would cost $125,000.  But this is a Chevy with a starting price of $51,995.
lead_paragraph: Imagine, if you will, that an unnamed manufacturer just released an all-new sports car. It rockets from 0 to 60 miles per hour in 3.8 seconds, pulls more than one lateral g on the skid pad and has a carbon-fiber hood and roof. The interior includes dual high-resolution screens, top-quality materials and the option of racing seats. The manual transmission, with 7 forward speeds, will execute rev-matched downshifts, and it’s mounted at the rear of the car for optimal weight distribution.

headline: The Viper Strikes Back
abstract: After a three-year absence, the Viper has returned. And all  you need to know about it is that the car prioritizes speed and the ability to set the lowest lap times on any given track.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, I entered the Spectre 341 Challenge, a terrifying 5.2-mile hill climb outside Virginia City, Nev. The official results show Lou Gigliotti winning with his 700-horsepower Chevrolet Corvette ZR1, and second place going to Steve Millen, a legendary rally racer, in a 620-horsepower Nissan GT-R. But Mr. Gigliotti’s ’Vette wasn’t really the quickest car on the mountain that weekend.

headline: Lincoln Joins the Crossover Party
abstract: Ford took another step toward revitalizing its moribund Lincoln brand when it unveiled a production version of  its new small crossover utility, the MKC.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor took another step toward revitalizing its moribund Lincoln division in Manhattan on Wednesday when it unveiled a production version of a new small crossover utility, the MKC.

headline: Tortured Souls
abstract: Beckett comes to Irish Repertory Theater, with puppet, at that.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Beckett has been everywhere this season: a Hoi Polloi production of three short plays in Brooklyn; a take on “All That Fall” at the 59E59 Theaters; and versions of “Waiting for Godot” at the Castillo Theater and now in previews on Broadway, at the Cort.

headline: Hacker Receives 10-Year Sentence for ‘Causing Mayhem’
abstract: Jeremy Hammond, a member of the hacking group Anonymous, was sentenced in Federal District Court in New York to 10 years in prison for breaking into government computer servers.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in New York on Friday delivered a 10-year prison sentence to Jeremy Hammond , a prominent member of the hacking group Anonymous who pleaded guilty earlier this year to breaking into the computer servers of a string of corporations, government agencies and law enforcement advocacy groups.

headline: French Say Kidnapped Priest Was Moved to Nigeria
abstract: The priest, who was seized in Cameroon, appears to have been taken by militants who are lashing out at France for financial and ideological reasons.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — The kidnappers of a French priest seized in northern Cameroon shouted for joy and fired celebratory shots in the air, one of his church superiors there said Friday, but only after crossing the border into Nigeria, in a region rife with members of the Islamist sect Boko Haram.

headline: At Auction, Masterpieces of the Drivable Kind
abstract: An auction on Thursday is being billed as the first high-end car auction in New York City in more than a decade and aims to raise the aesthetic regard for automotive design.
lead_paragraph: With paintings and sculptures selling for record prices in recent weeks, it makes sense for auction houses to market cars as artworks, too. That would seem to be at least part of the logic behind a coming sale by Sotheby’s and RM Auctions ambitiously titled “Art of the Automobile.”

headline: Tiptoeing Around the Music Video
abstract: The choreographer Susan Marshall has not failed to notice the dance boom in recent popular culture.
lead_paragraph: The music video is in black and white. It consists entirely of women dancing in high heels, wearing identical, flesh-hugging outfits that expose their upper thighs. It is not Beyoncé’s “Single Ladies,” probably the most famous dance video of this century. It is “Stop,” by the choreographer Susan Marshall.

headline: Weaponized Keynesianism, Historical Edition
abstract: Military spending is just a form of spending.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, I showed that Europe is at this point doing worse — at least as measured by industrial production, and probably in terms of overall output — than it did in the Great Depression.

headline: ‘Art of the Automobile’
abstract: A look at a few of the prized lots from the coming New York sale of high-end cars by Sotheby’s and RM Auctions.
lead_paragraph: A look at a few of the prized lots from the coming New York sale of high-end cars by Sotheby’s and RM Auctions.

headline: A Seminar on Suspense, in Service of the Blues
abstract: The blues musician Gary Clark Jr. performed at the Apollo Theater with the guitarist Eric Zapata, the bassist Johnny Bradley and the drummer Johnny Radelat, and some guests.
lead_paragraph: Gary Clark Jr. began his encore at the Apollo Theater on Thursday night in an air of pensive solitude, perched on a chair with a harmonica and his guitar. Unhurried, calmly self-possessed, he drifted through “In the Evening (When the Sun Goes Down),” in an arrangement that subtly acknowledged Big Bill Broonzy and Lightnin’ Hopkins, among other stewards of that song. “It’s so lonesome when your lover’s not around,” he sang in a soft, clear voice, trusting that pitiful line to do its own work.

headline: Tripleheader to Open Show Season
abstract: Three international salons — in Los Angeles, Tokyo and Guangzhou, China — are opening more or less on top of one another. The potential complications for automakers, as they allocate manpower and new models over several time zones, is staggering.
lead_paragraph: As 2013 is winding down, a fresh season of auto shows is booting up. Three big international salons — in Los Angeles, Tokyo and Guangzhou, China — are opening this week more or less on top of one another.

headline: Friday Night Music: More San Fermin
abstract: A bit of beauty after a hard week.
lead_paragraph: I know, it’s only Friday afternoon, but I’m deeply jet lagged, and ready to collapse.

headline: If It All Doesn’t Fit, Build a Bigger Box
abstract: Classical record labels continue to flood the market with multi-CD sets, even as that market seems to be shrinking.
lead_paragraph: The classical-music recording industry is collapsing. Right? That’s what we’ve heard.

headline: The Space Shuttle That Fell to Earth
abstract: William Hurt stars as the physicist Richard Feynman in “The Challenger Disaster,” the Science Channel movie about the 1986 crash.
lead_paragraph: “The Challenger Disaster,” the Science Channel’s first dramatic feature film, tries hard to make the search for those faulty O-rings into a pulse-quickening thriller along the lines of “All the President’s Men.” That it succeeds as well as it does can be credited largely to William Hurt, who manages to make the physicist Richard P. Feynman interesting all over again.

headline: Trying to Outrace Scientific Advances
abstract: J. H. Wyman’s new series on Fox, “Almost Human,” trafficks in the realm of future realism by modeling its ideas on existing technologies.
lead_paragraph: Before he created the futuristic TV cop show “Almost Human,” J. H. Wyman faced a recurring challenge as producer of the sci-fi series “Fringe.” Actual scientists continually spawned projects that rivaled the wildest imaginary ones dreamed up in the writers’ room.

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Lupita Nyong’o’s Fashion
abstract: Ms. Nyong’o, a sure bet for a supporting actress Oscar nomination for her role in “12 Years a Slave” has emerged as a red carpet star.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Nyong’o, a sure bet for a supporting actress Oscar nomination for her role in “12 Years a Slave” has emerged as a red carpet star.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Christie’s Highest Art Bid Ever, Tim Gunn’s New Series and H&M’s New Lady Gaga-Christened Flagship
abstract: Plus, the winners of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Award, Drake and Rihanna’s $17,000 outing, the most expensive gem ever sold at auction and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 9 – 15

headline: The Cautionary Tale of an Investment Adviser Gone Astray
keywords: ['Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Mark Spangler, an investment adviser, preached the doctrine of acting in his clients’ best interest. But his actions put the lie to his beliefs.
lead_paragraph: IN the world of Ponzi schemes, Mark Spangler was a small-time crook. But his early career, as a respected investment adviser in Seattle and onetime head of a national adviser organization that pushes its members to act in their clients’ best interest, gives his recent conviction on 32 criminal counts a twist.

headline: An Elusive Mystery Man of Music
abstract: “Who Is William Onyeabor?” includes highlights from the 1970s and ’80s albums of the electro-funk musician William Onyeabor.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday night, a boisterous crowd jammed into Buka, a Nigerian restaurant in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, spilling out onto Fulton Street. This wasn’t the restaurant’s usual weekend clientele, primarily expat Nigerians already familiar with specialties like goat-head stew and giant land snails. Instead, the throng had gathered for a record-release party, listening to African-flavored D.J. sets by Steve Shelley, formerly of Sonic Youth, and Lizzi Bougatsos of Gang Gang Dance. Just past the bar, revelers took turns posing for selfies standing next to a six-foot-high cardboard cutout of an imposing man in a disco-era cream-colored tuxedo.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o Impresses on the Red Carpet
abstract: The “12 Years a Slave” actress has become a favorite for designers.
lead_paragraph: WHO Lupita Nyong’o
