abstract: Subjects include the season’s first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the season’s first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.

headline: An Interrogation Routine of Real Cop, Robot Cop?
abstract: In “Almost Human,” a new drama series on Fox, a human police officer is paired with a robot partner.
lead_paragraph: In the future, your artificial limbs and joints will talk to you. Holographic gizmos will augment all those desktops, laptops and tablets we’re so fond of. And proper balance will be everything.

headline: The Devil Is Running for a Seat in Parliament
abstract: Nana Kwaku Bonsam, a fetish priest who spent a year in the Bronx, was the subject of a Metropolitan cover article in July and has returned home to run for Parliament.
lead_paragraph: A radio talk show broke the news on Oct. 28: Nana Kwaku Bonsam will run for a seat in the Parliament of Ghana in 2016.

headline: Visiting the Island of the Dead
abstract: A cemetery on an island off the Bronx, where prison inmates bury as many as 1,500 bodies a year, has long been off limits to visitors, but mourners are pressuring the city to open it up.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, the first snow flurries of the season fell on New York’s potter’s field, drifting down into an open trench, dusting the dirt next to hundreds of corpses in bare wooden caskets.

headline: Excerpt: 'Almost Human'
abstract: The new futuristic cop show on Fox pairs a detective with an android.
lead_paragraph: The new futuristic cop show on Fox pairs a detective with an android.

headline: Women Gain in Some STEM Fields, but Not Computer Science
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Minorities', 'Science and Technology', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A new report shows that women receive a majority of bachelor’s degrees in psychology, biosciences and social sciences, but still a small minority of computer science and engineering degrees.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I wrote about ways to get more women interested in computer science. One of the points that came up frequently in my reporting is that some other STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) have actually been quite successful attracting more women. A report this week from the National Science Foundation lays out these trends nicely:

headline: Inspiration Is Everywhere, Even in the Bargain Bin
abstract: The producer and songwriter Dev Hynes talks about collaborators and influences, as he prepares to release “Cupid Deluxe,” his new album.
lead_paragraph: Even if you don’t know Dev Hynes’s name, you’ve likely heard his music. At 27, Mr. Hynes has been an in-demand producer and songwriter for years, recording tracks for the Chemical Brothers, Sky Ferreira, Florence and the Machine and Solange. He’s also been in the studio with Britney Spears, Kylie Minogue, Jessie Ware and Grace Jones.

headline: Will Play for Health Care (at Least at One Music Event)
abstract: An expansion of the O+ Festival, in San Francisco this weekend, features the usual array of concerts — and the unusual form of payment: health care for the artists.
lead_paragraph: The O+ Festival in San Francisco this weekend would seem a typical indie arts event, with performances by local musicians and displays of funky art. But in a twist that highlights a longstanding problem in the creative economy, the artists involved will be paid not in cash but rather in something they may need just as badly: health care.

headline: Students Try to Occupy Bulgarian Parliament Building
abstract: The action was the latest of a series of angry demonstrations against the center-left government of Prime Minister Plamen Oresharski.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Student protesters tried but failed to occupy the Bulgarian Parliament building here on Friday, then marched through the city center and broke through four police cordons in the latest of a series of angry demonstrations against the center-left government of Prime Minister Plamen Oresharski.

headline: Blithely Crossing the Boundary Between Country and Hip-Hop
abstract: The Nashville hitmakers Florida Georgia Line (Tyler Hubbard and Brian Kelley) filled a show at Best Buy Theater with hip-hop covers.
lead_paragraph: Country as a genre is both reverent and historically minded, so of course Florida Georgia Line, a young band that’s quickly emerged as a reliable hitmaker after several journeyman years, peppers its shows with covers.

headline: Where Witches Dance in Bushwick
abstract: Catland, a store and event space, draws Wiccans, pagans and devotees of occult books and full-moon rituals.
lead_paragraph: Catland, a store and event space, draws Wiccans, pagans and devotees of occult books and full-moon rituals.

headline: Death After the Typhoon: ‘It Was Preventable’
abstract: During five days in a Philippine hospital, a 27-year-old farmer and family breadwinner received virtually no care and died, in essence, of a broken leg.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Richard Pulga lay on a hard steel gurney for five days with only a saline drip after being seriously injured in the typhoon that devastated his country.

headline: A Book Fair That Grew, Propelling the Arts in Miami
keywords: ['Miami Book Fair International', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Fairs']
abstract: The Miami Book Fair International, opening on Sunday and going on 30, was founded in dark days for the city, lending crucial momentum to other cultural efforts.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Three decades ago, the notion of a book fair in this city seemed wildly implausible.

headline: The Payoff in Waiting to Collect Social Security
abstract: The longer a person of retirement age puts off collecting Social Security, the more money he or she will collect annually — much like buying an annuity.
lead_paragraph: If an insurance salesman offered a product with a guaranteed income of nearly 7 percent for life, it would be foolish not to question whether it was too good to be true.

headline: A Place for Work and Introspection
abstract: “This Is My Office” is a semiautobiographical solo play in which a man contemplates the complicated relationship he had with his father.
lead_paragraph: His name is Andy Bragen, and welcome to his office. He is a playwright, and good thing you’re here, because there’s a story he wants to tell about an artist’s residency he got: nine months in a Lower Manhattan office to do with as he wished.

headline: Amber Batchelor: Mayor of Women’s Hoops
abstract: On Sunday mornings, Amber Batchelor clears the men off a basketball court on the Upper West Side and runs one of the only all-female pickup games in the city.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday mornings, Amber Batchelor clears the men off a basketball court on the Upper West Side and runs one of the only all-female pickup games in the city.

headline: Michael Chu: Mayor of New Arrivals
abstract: Michael Chu runs a small travel agency in Queens but spends most of his time helping members of the community deal with landlords, government agencies and employers.
lead_paragraph: Michael Chu runs a small travel agency in Queens but spends most of his time helping members of the community deal with landlords, government agencies and employers.

abstract: Charts of the unemployment rate.
lead_paragraph: Charts of the unemployment rate.

abstract: Joel A. Rosenthal, the first living jeweler to have a retrospective at the Met, will present 400 pieces in a single 3,000-square-foot gallery.
lead_paragraph: Joel A. Rosenthal, the first living jeweler to have a retrospective at the Met, will present 400 pieces in a single 3,000-square-foot gallery.

headline: Young and Educated in Europe, but Desperate for Jobs
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Youth', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: High unemployment in countries like Spain, Portugal and Greece is hitting young people hardest as they take jobs below their skill level and seek work abroad.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Alba Méndez, a 24-year-old with a master’s degree in sociology, sprang out of bed nervously one recent morning, carefully put on makeup and styled her hair. Her thin hands trembled as she clutched her résumé on her way out of the tiny room where a friend allows her to stay rent free.

headline: For JPMorgan, $4.5 Billion to Settle Mortgage Claims
abstract: The payout is separate from the tentative $13 billion settlement that JPMorgan Chase reached with the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: The checks from JPMorgan Chase just keep on coming as the nation’s largest bank works to move beyond its mortgage-related troubles.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Winter Fashion Begins
abstract: The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight.
lead_paragraph: The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight.

headline: A Master’s Bubbles and Panels, in Depth
abstract: Art Spiegelman’s comics and other art are the focus of a retrospective at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In museums, we look all the time at drawings, prints and illustrated books from the past, art forms that entertain us with stories but also embody history. Modern comics, at their best, do this too, often with immense sophistication. Do we see them in museums? Hardly ever.

headline: Responding to a Typhoon on the Web
abstract: Two readers who live in the Philippines and are reckoning with the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan describe the aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Every week, readers of The New York Times share thousands of comments in response to our reporting. What you keep telling us is that your fellow readers can be as illuminating as the news articles we produce. So we’re working on new ways to highlight your most notable comments, and introduce you to the readers behind them.

headline: For a Jeweler, All That Bedazzles
abstract: Joel A. Rosenthal is the first living jeweler with a retrospective, “Jewels by JAR,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Every decade or so, when Joel A. Rosenthal comes out of his velvet-lined shell in Paris to show his magnificent jewels, as he will do starting Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the same chorus of words appear.

headline: American Contract Bridge League Qualifier
abstract: The North American Open Pairs Flight A final takes place next March, in the two days before the Spring North American Championships get into full swing in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: The North American Open Pairs Flight A final takes place next March, in the two days before the Spring North American Championships get into full swing in Dallas.

headline: Snapchat, How Quickly You Have Grown
abstract: In May 2012, Evan Spiegel, a co-founder of SnapChat, couldn’t comment because he was wrapping up school projects at Stanford. Just 18 months later, Mr. Spiegel is turning down multibillion dollar acquisition attempts.
lead_paragraph: While some might have been shocked this week by the multi-billion dollar offers the start-up Snapchat turned down, I found something else entirely perplexing about the valuation of this little company: just how quickly it grew.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
abstract: The designer Faye Toogood finds exceptional beauty in unexpected arrangements of objects, and uses them to create installations for fashion houses — and her own house.
lead_paragraph: The designer Faye Toogood finds exceptional beauty in unexpected arrangements of objects, and uses them to create installations for fashion houses — and her own house.

headline: A View Inside the Art World
abstract: The author Henry Alford attended the record-breaking auctions of modern art at Christie’s and Sotheby’s, but to watch, not buy.
lead_paragraph: The author Henry Alford attended the record-breaking auctions of modern art at Christie’s and Sotheby’s, but to watch, not buy.

headline: For First Time, E.P.A. Proposes Reducing Ethanol Requirement for Gas Mix
abstract: The proposal marks the first time the Environmental Protection Agency has taken steps to slow down the drive to replace fossil fuels with renewable forms of energy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday proposed reducing the amount of ethanol that is required to be mixed with the gasoline supply, the first time it has taken steps to slow down the drive to replace fossil fuels with renewable forms of energy.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Understanding Candy Crush Addictions, the Rise of Twitter Bots and #SFBatkid
abstract: Friday’s highlights from around the Web include an examination of the psychology at play that makes the mobile game Candy Crush so popular. Plus, the evolution of bots, which increasingly do more than issue spam.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Winter Fashion Begins
abstract: The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight.
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Park was a shower of golden leaves, a backdrop for the Veterans Day Parade. The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight. Men’s coats with brass buttons echoed the military theme, as did trench coats (but not cyclamen-pink fur). Black offset the leaves. Braided scarves from Loopy Mango appeared, too.

headline: House Tour | Faye Toogood
abstract: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.
lead_paragraph: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.

headline: Washington Comes Out
abstract: Ten percent of adults in the District of Columbia identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender, nearly three times the national average. What makes the city such a gay-friendly place?
lead_paragraph: Ten percent of adults in the District of Columbia identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender, nearly three times the national average. What makes the city such a gay-friendly place?

headline: Player Ratings: Scotland (0), U.S. (0)
abstract: Rating the performance of U.S. players in an international friendly match against Scotland.
lead_paragraph: No Clint Dempsey. No Landon Donovan. Nothing at stake, in terms of a result.

headline: Performance Art That Looks a Lot Like Theater
abstract: Two very different works for the Performa 13 festival: Alexandre Singh’s “The Humans,”  and Jérôme Bel and Theater Hora’s “Disabled Theater.”
lead_paragraph: Alexandre Singh’s “The Humans” has its ups and downs, but it is still one of the outstanding achievements of the Performa 13 performance art biennial. Commissioned in collaboration with the Witte de With Center for Contemporary Art in the Netherlands, it is less performance art than classical theater with all the benefits of a highly skilled, well-rehearsed cast.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 15
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the season’s first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the season’s first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.

headline: Out in D.C.
abstract: The capital as the backdrop of a thriving gay scene.
lead_paragraph: The capital as the backdrop of a thriving gay scene.

headline: Think Big
abstract: No matter where the journey takes us, T tries to broaden how we see things and to make sense of the cultural moment we live in.
lead_paragraph: I had the odd coincidence of reading Lawrence Osborne’s piece on Burma — in which he examines the country today alongside the one George Orwell wrote about in his first novel, “Burmese Days” — at the same time my husband happened to be reading Orwell’s “1984” aloud to our children.

headline: The Gayest Place in America?
abstract: Gone is the closeted, often intolerant Washington; the capital is now perhaps the gayest place in the nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — My earliest sense of what it meant to be gay in the nation’s capital came more than a decade ago when I was a summer intern. I was a few blocks from Union Station when a congressman walked by and gave the reporters I was standing with a big, floppy wave hello.

headline: Oops. I Left My Millions at Home.
abstract: An interloper attends the blockbuster Christie’s and Sotheby’s auctions, and has a very good time.
lead_paragraph: Behold the swirl. At the brunch last Sunday at Christie’s auction house for bidders and attendees of this past Tuesday’s history-making sale of postwar and contemporary art, hundreds of well-dressed art lovers sipped Champagne and nibbled party food while standing just inches from canvases, some of them valued for millions of dollars.

headline: The ‘Biggie’: A Tainted Status Symbol
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Coats', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: A desire for fashionable symbols can lead to violence, as an attempted theft of a parka in Bryant Park showed.
lead_paragraph: The rise in violent fashion-related crime has coalesced around the growing cachet of streetwear and fashion’s embrace of celebrity culture — as the crowd skating at the Bryant Park ice rink on Nov. 9 can readily attest to.

headline: Justices to Revisit Securities Fraud Suits
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear a case that could make it harder for investors to win class actions, and also will consider when the police could be sued for using excessive force.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed Friday to hear a case that could make it harder for investors to win class-action lawsuits for securities fraud. The court also agreed to consider when police officers could be sued for using excessive force to stop fleeing suspects.

headline: Jay Z’s Blueprint Didn’t Call for This
abstract: The rapper-turned-corporate-conglomerate faces collateral damage after complaints of racial profiling at Barneys.
lead_paragraph: This is how it usually happens.

headline: Together, at Home and at Work
abstract: For couples working together, the rules for getting along at home may not transfer to the office. Experts give advice.
lead_paragraph: I spent much of the last six months helping my wife with a rare professional opportunity. When friends heard how many days, nights and weekends we spent in the same room, they had the same reply: “Whoa! When are you getting divorced?”

headline: Beheading in Syria Is Called a Mistake
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Jihadists in Syria beheaded a half-conscious man believed to be an enemy combatant and a Shiite — only to find that he was a rebel fighter, too.
lead_paragraph: It was a deadly case of mistaken identity set against the chaotic, sectarian backdrop of the Syrian conflict.

headline: T’s Winter Travel Issue
abstract: The latest issue of T takes us to many destinations in many different ways.
lead_paragraph: The latest issue of T takes us to many destinations in many different ways. In our cover story, we provide a relaxed, versatile wardrobe with clean lines that are tailor-made for travel. Sometimes travel can simply be a state of mind; lovely interiors can transport a home. The designer Faye Toogood brings the English countryside to her London house, with her unexpected arrangements of objects. These days, travel envy happens with a few clicks. Instagram offers a fresh means to peek into others’ carefully curated lifestyles all around the world. Next, we travel to France by way of Miami; the designer Charlotte Perriand, who created furnishings, interiors and buildings with Le Corbusier, is being recognized at Design Miami this December for her ahead-of-the-curve sensibility. Sometimes it’s all about the journey — Alexander Payne shares his love for the wholesomeness of hometown Nebraska in a road trip with the novelist Kurt Andersen. In Montana, the investment banker-turned-hunter Georgia Pellegrini offers a weekend retreat for urban women like herself to get in touch with their primitive selves. Last but not least, Lawrence Osborne travels to Myanmar to search for the inspirations behind George Orwell’s books. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Tennessee Pastor Disputes Wildlife Possession Charge by State
abstract: Andrew Hamblin, a snake-handling minister and a reality television star, described his not-guilty plea on Friday to a wildlife-possession charge as a “fight for freedom of religion.”
lead_paragraph: JACKSBORO, Tenn. — In a mix of old-time religion, modern media and Tennessee law, a 22-year-old preacher who has become a reality television star because of his experience in handling poisonous snakes pleaded not guilty on Friday to illegally keeping dozens of them that he and his congregants routinely touch during worship services.

headline: Former Marcos Aide Is Stricken at Her Conspiracy Trial
abstract: Vilma Bautista, who once worked for Imelda Marcos and is accused of selling artwork she did not own, was taken to the hospital on Friday with chest pains.
lead_paragraph: A former aide to Imelda Marcos who is accused of selling a Monet masterpiece that she did not own was wheeled out of court during the prosecution’s closing arguments on Friday morning after experiencing chest pains and nausea.

headline: Immigrants Closely Tied to Military Get Reprieve
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The policy will allow immigrants in the United States illegally who are close relatives of active military troops and veterans to stay and move toward becoming permanent residents.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration issued a new policy on Friday that will allow immigrants in the United States illegally who are close relatives of active military troops and veterans to stay and move toward becoming permanent residents.

headline: She Doesn’t Expect Anything, and Hasn’t Been Disappointed
abstract: Even after she found her cat dead and mutilated, Mary Lou Ritter, who is homeless, remains cleareyed and chipper.
lead_paragraph: There is a photograph taped to the front of a building on Eighth Avenue in Chelsea that gives pause to people walking by. It shows a smiling old woman holding a striped cat. But any warm feelings fade upon reading a handwritten sign below.

abstract: Messages released on Friday offer some of the first evidence of which federal officials had at least some knowledge of the troubles plaguing HealthCare.gov months before its start-up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior federal officials involved in building the HealthCare.gov website were deeply concerned this summer about delays as well as weaknesses in the quality and size of the contractor teams assigned to parts of the project, emails released by congressional investigators on Friday show.

lead_paragraph: Addiction experts protested loudly when the Food and Drug Administration approved a powerful new opioid painkiller last month, saying that it would set off a wave of abuse much as OxyContin did when it first appeared.

headline: Libya Protest Turns Deadly as Militias Open Fire
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Dozens of people were killed in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, setting off some of the worst violence there since the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi almost three years ago.

headline: Off the Court, a Film’s Lens on Asian-American Faith

headline: African Call to Delay Kenyans’ Trials Fails at U.N.
abstract: The International Criminal Court’s charges of crimes against humanity has led to tension with the African Union.

headline: Tough Way to Lose a Friend
abstract: He was a sweetheart, genuinely funny, and a drunk.
lead_paragraph: Every writer knows that unless you were born gifted with either supreme confidence or outsize ego, handing in your work holds, in some cases, admitted terror. If that’s too strong, at least fairly high anxiety. Even if what you wrote seems unusually good to you, part of you is vulnerable to the suggestion that you may have laid an egg. A bad one. As W.C. Fields might have put it as your editor, “Sadly, my little lad, you have contrived in this instance to produce a specimen of odoriferous hen fruit.”

Meggs, a state attorney for Florida’s Second Judicial Circuit, said he was not certain how a sexual assault complaint from almost a year ago involving Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston had just crossed his desk, but he promised he would “get to the bottom of it.”

headline: Brazil: Arrests Begin in Vote-Fraud Case
abstract: The federal police began arresting a dozen powerful political figures, bankers and businessmen convicted in a vast vote-buying scandal that surfaced more than eight years ago.
lead_paragraph: The federal police on Friday began arresting a dozen powerful political figures, bankers and businessmen convicted in a vast vote-buying scandal that surfaced more than eight years ago. More than a year ago, Brazil’s highest court set the prison sentences for officials from the governing Workers Party, but the court’s consideration of appeals in the landmark corruption trial and what appeared to have been bureaucratic problems had delayed sending those found guilty in the scheme to prison. It is rare for high-profile Brazilian politicians convicted of crimes to serve time in prison. But this week the Supreme Federal Tribunal ruled that the convicted officials must soon start their prison terms. On Friday, José Genoino Guimarães Neto, a legislator who is a former president of the Workers Party, turned himself in at a police building in São Paulo and thrust his fist in the air in an act of defiance.

lead_paragraph: A day after they were caught off guard by President Obama’s proposal to prevent cancellation of insurance policies for millions of Americans, top executives of some of the biggest insurance companies emerged from a meeting at the White House on Friday, expressing mixed feelings about whether the idea could work in every state.

They have dined in Mexican cafes near Puerto Vallarta, navigated the Paris Metro and hiked the alpine foothills of the Matterhorn.

headline: Canada: Toronto Council Curbs Mayor
abstract: A special session of the Toronto City Council removed Mayor Rob Ford’s power to appoint some city officials, after he admitted using crack cocaine and binge drinking.
lead_paragraph: After Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto, a self-confessed crack cocaine user, binge drinker and impaired driver, refused to step down, the Toronto City Council began stripping away his powers on Friday. A special session of the Council removed the mayor’s power to appoint the members of the city’s executive committee as well as the deputy mayor. It also transferred any powers Mr. Ford would have as mayor during a declared emergency to the deputy mayor. On Monday the Council will consider measures to eliminate the budget and staff for Mr. Ford’s office. Mr. Ford said he would challenge the sanctions in court. The Council has no legal means to remove the mayor from office.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

lead_paragraph: David N. Redden recited the opening of the 23rd Psalm the way he had memorized it as a child: “The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want. He maketh me to lie down in green pastures.”

headline: France: 4 Said to Recruit for Syrian War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: Authorities have arrested four men suspected of involvement in a network sending fighters to Syria to join radical Sunni Islamist groups, the Paris prosecutor’s office said.
lead_paragraph: French authorities near Paris have arrested four men suspected of involvement in a network sending fighters to Syria to join radical Sunni Islamist groups operating there, the Paris prosecutor’s office said Friday. The domestic intelligence service said three of the men had fought in Syria alongside the Nusra Front, which has links to Al Qaeda, and returned to France, said Agnès Thibault-Lecuivre, a spokeswoman for the prosecutor’s office. The fourth man is believed to be the network’s organizer. All four were to be charged on Friday with conspiring to commit “terrorist acts,” Ms. Thibault-Lecuivre said. More than 100 French residents or citizens are fighting in Syria, French officials say.

lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii signed a bill that will allow same-sex couples to marry in the state, starting Dec. 2. The measure, ending a two-decade legal and political battle, caps a remarkable year of progress toward ensuring the basic civil rights of gay Americans.

headline: Starting Over After Hurricane Sandy

lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Sandy approached, Joseph Duodu, his wife and two daughters evacuated from their home on the Rockaway Peninsula and drove to a motel on Queens Boulevard. The family had packed only an overnight bag with a change of clothes because they thought they would be back home the next day. They ended up living in the motel for five months.

headline: The Little Agency That Could
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: The best regulator in Washington calls it quits after two huge wins.
lead_paragraph: One of the big criticisms of the original team of financial regulators brought in by President Obama is that too many of them had worked in Bill Clinton’s Treasury Department. That, of course, was the Treasury Department run by Robert Rubin and then by Lawrence Summers — an agency with a bias toward deregulation. Those regulators had supported the elimination of Glass-Steagall, the 1930s law that separated investment banks from commercial banks, and were disinclined to regulate derivatives, “those financial weapons of mass destruction,” as Warren Buffett liked to call them.

headline: The Rise of the Union Leagues
abstract: How support for emancipation became a litmus test for loyalty.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1863, a group of ardent Republicans in Centralia, a railroad town in south central Illinois, sought to revive the moribund local party newspaper. Needing an editor, they poached one from nearby Sparta. John W. Fletcher, a western New Yorker then 44 years old, was their man. On May 28 he took up his pen for the new weekly, The Centralia Sentinel.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:25 P.M. (Flix) MALLRATS (1995) A couple of recently dumped ne’er-do-wells (Jason Lee and Jeremy London) try to get over their girlfriends (Shannen Doherty and Claire Forlani) by wandering around the local mall. Writing in the The New York Times, Janet Maslin said this comedy, written and directed by Kevin Smith, “mixes clever bits and an appealing quirkiness (which goes a long way) with gross-out practical jokes, needless repetition and obvious padding, since it has no real plot.” She added: “Mr. Lee’s Brodie has the grunge and surliness to give him credibility here, but he also has a sweet, funny indignation over life’s little outrages, which are actually this film’s most heartfelt concerns.”

headline: Variety: Ancient Philosophy
abstract: An acrostic about a philosopher king from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s curious that two of the most memorable villains in fiction share a fondness for Marcus Aurelius. In Richard Connell’s 1924 short story “The Most Dangerous Game,” General Zaroff, the unhinged sophisticate who hunts humans on his island, unwinds at the end of the night with a bottle of chambertin and the writings of Aurelius. In “The Silence of the Lambs,” Hannibal Lecter quotes from The Meditations during a cellblock interrogation: “First principles, Clarice. Simplicity. Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each particular thing ask: what is it in itself? What is its nature? What does he do, this man you seek?”

headline: Answer to Blindness Was Hidden in the Genes
abstract: Jasmine Carrero grew up severely myopic and eventually went legally blind, but she didn’t discover why until her son lost sight in one of his eyes.
lead_paragraph: Jasmine Carrero has big doelike eyes, an almond-shaped face and a willowy frame that she calls boyish. She also has Stickler syndrome, a group of genetic disorders whose hallmarks are these elongated features; it is responsible not just for the elegant tapering fingers possessed by nearly everyone in her family, but also for the family’s history of blindness.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew Kolodny, the president of Physicians for Responsible Opioid Prescribing, describes the pharmacology of buprenorphine and the drug’s effect at the brain’s receptor level.

headline: Shawn Schneider
abstract: Over the past two years, Shawn Schneider, 38, has been taking buprenorphine to maintain his sobriety after an addiction to painkillers.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two years, Shawn Schneider, 38, has been taking buprenorphine to maintain his sobriety after an addiction to painkillers.

headline: Melissa Iverson
abstract: Melissa Iverson was transformed after doctors put her on buprenorphine following a psychotic break.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Iverson was transformed after doctors put her on buprenorphine following a psychotic break.

abstract: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.
lead_paragraph: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Jeffrey T. Junig discusses the questions he asks himself when it comes to discharging patients from addiction treatment programs.

headline: The Pacers’ Perfect Beginning Will Not Guarantee Them a Happy Ending
abstract: Indiana began its season on a 9-0 streak, but of the 13 teams that have started at 10-0 or better, only three have won the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: When an N.B.A. team starts the season on an unbeaten run, curiosity always kicks in. What is the longest streak without a loss to start the season? What does a soaring start say about a team’s chances when the playoffs arrive six months down the road?

headline: Painting Pickett’s Charge
abstract: The surprising story behind the most famous portrait of Gettysburg.
lead_paragraph: Like other Northern states, Pennsylvania had much business to attend to in the weeks and months that followed the end of the Civil War: there were regiments to be dissolved, soldiers to be mustered out, and wounded, widowed and orphaned to be provided for.

headline: Addiction Treatment With a Dark Side
abstract: High hopes for buprenorphine, an effective treatment for opioid addiction, have been tempered by a messy reality: health complications and deaths, unscrupulous doctors and a reputation as a street drug.
lead_paragraph: For Shawn Schneider, a carpenter and rock musician, the descent into addiction began one Wisconsin winter with a fall from a rooftop construction site onto the frozen ground below. As the potent pain pills prescribed for his injuries became his obsessive focus, he lost everything: his band, his job, his wife, his will to live.

headline: Don’t Mess With My ‘Sacred Values’
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'International Relations', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Research', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: In negotiations, cash bargains aren’t always acceptable.
lead_paragraph: ACCORDING to news reports, a key factor in last weekend’s diplomatic impasse over Iran’s nuclear program was Iran’s insistence on what President Hassan Rouhani has called its “right” to enrich uranium. “National interests are our red line,” he declared, echoing earlier statements by other Iranian leaders.

headline: Reining in Payday Lenders
keywords: ['Payday Loans', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Credit and Debt', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is finally moving to reform a predatory system.
lead_paragraph: At some point — soon, we hope — the Federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will issue regulations for the payday lending industry. The bureau took an important step in that direction when it announced earlier this month that it would begin collecting complaints from borrowers who may have been hit with unreasonable fees, unauthorized withdrawals from their checking accounts or other abuses. The bureau should rein in all of these practices, but its most important task is to ensure that the loans are affordable — which means requiring lenders to determine in advance that the borrower has the ability to repay.

headline: My Education, Repossessed
abstract: I dreamed the government repossessed my education.
lead_paragraph: Like many post-grads, I’ve been struggling for years to keep up with my student loan payments. I can just about make it each month, with some modest sacrifices. For instance, doing my own dental work. But last night I had a terrible dream. In it, I fell so far behind in my payments that the government decided to move against me. They could have taken legal action, but they did something much more diabolical: They repossessed my education.

headline: Prudence or Cruelty?
abstract: Taxpayers help foot the bill for fancy dinners on Capitol Hill, while Congress cuts food subsidies for the poorest Americans. Talk about injustice.
lead_paragraph: WHEN members of Congress debate whether to slash the food stamp program, they should ask if they really want more small children arriving at school having skipped breakfast.

headline: Sentenced to a Slow Death
abstract: A report highlights thousands of prisoners serving life without parole for nonviolent crimes.
lead_paragraph: If this were happening in any other country, Americans would be aghast. A sentence of life in prison, without the possibility of parole, for trying to sell $10 of marijuana to an undercover officer? For sharing LSD at a Grateful Dead concert? For siphoning gas from a truck? The punishment is so extreme, so irrational, so wildly disproportionate to the crime that it defies explanation.

headline: Something for Barack and Bibi to Talk About
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'United States International Relations', 'Books and Literature', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: To understand Israel today requires acknowledging several truths, including the good, bad, pretty and ugly.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel spoke on the phone for 90 minutes the other day. Wow — 90 minutes! I wonder if Obama has ever spoken to John Boehner for 90 minutes?

headline: China’s New Agenda
keywords: ['Forced Labor', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Beijing’s leaders signal a readiness for some personal freedoms and further economic reforms, all under firm one-party rule.
lead_paragraph: In one of several surprising and potentially welcome shifts in policy, China’s leaders announced Friday that they would relax China’s draconian one-child policy and end its brutal “re-education through labor” camps. They also outlined several ambitious economic initiatives that could make the country more hospitable to private enterprise in the coming years.

headline: The Three Burials of Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Welfare (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The health care law has yet another brush with death.
lead_paragraph: THE first time Obamacare seemed finished, doomed, doornail-dead, the voters of Massachusetts played the would-be executioner. In January 2010, they sent a pickup-driving Republican to the Senate to fill Ted Kennedy’s seat, apparently depriving the health care bill of its crucial 60th vote and sending Democrats scrambling for a Plan B.

headline: More Fun With Bill and Hill
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How much pre-presidential plotting goes into Bill Clinton’s post-presidential interventions?
lead_paragraph: BEFORE President Obama administered his fix to the Affordable Care Act last week and even before it was clear that he was leaning that way, Bill Clinton piped up, opining that Obama should honor his claim that Americans with insurance they liked could keep it. This advice wasn’t exactly solicited. And inasmuch as it gave detractors of Obama and Obamacare a fresh cudgel, it wasn’t terribly helpful, either.

headline: Billy Collins
abstract: The best-selling poet is a fan of Geoff Dyer and Natalie Wood, but not of social media.
lead_paragraph: Billy Collins is a best-selling poet who served as poet laureate of the United States from 2001 to 2003. His latest collection of poetry is “Aimless Love.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Academia’s Two Tracks
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Tenure', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Are adjuncts better teachers than tenure-track faculty?
lead_paragraph: Are adjuncts better teachers than tenure-track faculty?

headline: Waiting to See if Ukraine Tilts East or West
abstract: The European Union and Russia are pulling Ukraine in two directions, and the outcome may depend on the fate of a jailed former prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Curiously, the ferocious tug-of-war between Russia and the European Union over Ukraine has come down to whether Yulia Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister who is serving a seven-year prison sentence, is freed in the next few days.

headline: You’re So Self-Controlling
abstract: Is our sense of time, not our lack of willpower, the real issue?
lead_paragraph: WHAT do you do if, when you get to a subway platform, you see that it is already packed with people? Do you join the throngs to wait for the train, or do you shake your head and seek an alternative way to get where you’re going?

headline: The Insanity of Our Food Policy
keywords: ['Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Poverty', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How America’s agricultural programs increase inequality at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: American food policy has long been rife with head-scratching illogic. We spend billions every year on farm subsidies, many of which help wealthy commercial operations to plant more crops than we need. The glut depresses world crop prices, harming farmers in developing countries. Meanwhile, millions of Americans live tenuously close to hunger, which is barely kept at bay by a food stamp program that gives most beneficiaries just a little more than $4 a day.

headline: To Fight Obesity, a Carrot, and a Stick
abstract: Giving the poor financial incentives to buy healthier food works.
lead_paragraph: Childhood obesity, at long last, may have peaked — even among the poor, where the problem is most prevalent. Between 2008 and 2011, according to a study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 19 states and territories saw a small but significant drop in obesity rates among low-income preschoolers.

headline: Alzheimer’s Anxiety
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease is scary, but that’s no reason to waste money on a test that really doesn’t help.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — ALMOST every day I worry about whether my parents have Alzheimer’s. My dad is 86 and my mother is about to turn 80. Just because of their age they are at high risk for the disease, and I constantly wonder if their forgetfulness is “normal” or a sign of the worst.

headline: Recovery and Reconstruction
abstract: The rural hinterland of the Philippines has been largely left to fend for itself since Typhoon Haiyan hit.
lead_paragraph: The rural hinterland of the Philippines has been largely left to fend for itself since Typhoon Haiyan hit.

headline: Kidd Is Finding His Coaching Style (the Suit and Tie Are Just the Start)
abstract: Jason Kidd, who never hesitated as a player to share his basketball knowledge, is growing into his new role with the Nets as they face increasing pressure to win.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — It has yet to feel natural seeing Jason Kidd fastened inside a coach’s workday attire. His players have joked that his suit jackets look too tight. His neckties never seem to hang at a proper length. If, somehow, these represent conscious sartorial decisions, they are unusual ones.

headline: I Was a Portrait by Francis Bacon
abstract: Let my soul remain twisted, but give me back the fiction of my face.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — MY bookshelves have a bad habit: They eat books. Especially the books I care most about. My books seem to vanish, and where they’ve gone nobody knows. So I find myself buying the same book, once, twice, even three times in certain cases. One night not long ago, around midnight, I set out, unsuccessfully, to find the book of David Sylvester’s interviews with the painter Francis Bacon. I wanted to verify a quote I use frequently that I suspected might be his, a quote that exemplifies my view of life in general and, sadly, also the less-than-Apollonian way I run my own:

headline: More Freedom on the Airplane, if Nowhere Else
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration’s move to allow electronic devices throughout a flight highlights the grindingly slow process of removing government regulations.
lead_paragraph: It is sometimes the small events that reveal the really big problems lurking beneath the surface. That’s the case with the Federal Aviation Administration’s recent decision to grant airlines the liberty of allowing the use of electronic devices during takeoff and landing.

headline: The City With a Death Wish in Its Eye
abstract: Dallas must reckon with its role in John F. Kennedy’s murder.
lead_paragraph: FOR 50 years, Dallas has done its best to avoid coming to terms with the one event that made it famous: the assassination of John F. Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. That’s because, for the self-styled “Big D,” grappling with the assassination means reckoning with its own legacy as the “city of hate,” the city that willed the death of the president.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 17
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Social Media', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “There were times I thought we got slapped around unjustly. This one is deserved. It’s on us.”

headline: Ground-Shaking Noise Rocks N.F.L., and Eardrums Take Big Hit
abstract: National Football League teams are racing this season to secure the title of loudest outdoor stadium in the world, but all that noise can come with a serious cost.
lead_paragraph: National Football League teams are racing this season to secure the title of loudest outdoor stadium in the world.

headline: A Talk With Lars Peter Hansen, Nobel Laureate
abstract: One of three Nobel recipients this year, the University of Chicago professor has been recognized for creating advanced techniques in econometrics, enabling researchers to create better mathematical models.
lead_paragraph: Lars Peter Hansen, an economist at the University of Chicago, is one of three winners of this year’s Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, along with Eugene F. Fama, a fellow professor at the University of Chicago, and Robert J. Shiller, a professor at Yale.

headline: Lars Peter Hansen, the Nobel Laureate in the Middle
abstract: The economist who shared this year’s Nobel in economic science with Eugene Fama and Robert Shiller will not let himself be drawn into the debate between them.
lead_paragraph: Lars Peter Hansen understands why he is being asked, but he isn’t comfortable with the question. “Are financial markets efficient or irrational?” repeats Professor Hansen, a University of Chicago economist. “I don’t really know how to answer that.”

headline: Why Food Stamps Are a Great Investment
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the importance of food stamps to fight malnutrition and hunger right here in America.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the issue of food stamps, subject of a forthcoming battle on Capitol Hill. The program will be cut, but it’s unclear by how much. My column argues that it would be short-sighted, as well as cruel, to slash the program, for a couple of reasons. First, almost two-thirds of recipients are children, elderly or disabled. Second, particularly with the children who are recipients, the malnutrition is real and there is mounting evidence that it has long-term effects that leave those children less equipped to succeed at school and live productive lives. I’m particularly swayed by the NBER study that my column cites and links to, indicating that when children under five get food stamps, their long-term health outcomes are better, and they are less likely to end up on welfare. Read the column, but I’d also encourage you to read the study.

headline: In a North Face Jacket, a Reversible Appeal
abstract: The successful maker of jackets and other outdoor gear keeps walking the tightrope between exclusivity and the mass market.
lead_paragraph: It started when I bought a North Face jacket.

headline: Secular Stagnation, Coalmines, Bubbles, and Larry Summers
abstract: Virtue as vice: The new normal?
lead_paragraph: I’m pretty annoyed with Larry Summers right now. His presentation at the IMF Research Conference is, justifiably, getting a lot of attention. And here’s the thing: I’ve been thinking along the same lines, and have, I think, hinted at this analysis in various writings. But Larry’s formulation is much clearer and more forceful, and altogether better, than anything I’ve done. Curse you, Red Baron Larry Summers!

headline: Child’s Play in a Day’s Work
abstract: A quality assurance supervisor for Radio Flyer, the toy company, says he completed his first design project at the age of 6, working with a basketball hoop in his home.

headline: Syrian Government’s Forces Gain, but a Siege War Goes On
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Assad government has made gains, and the momentum has tipped, however slightly, in its direction even while the nation remains badly fractured.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government forces have recently ousted rebels from a string of suburbs outside Damascus, threatening their yearlong control of territory south of the capital city, cutting supply lines and surrounding strongholds that one fighter called their “last castle” in the area.

headline: Reaching for Silicon Valley
abstract: Georgia Tech longed to build a start-up culture, but it says a professor took it too far. Three years later, he is battling the university in court.
lead_paragraph: Joy Laskar was not what you’d typically think of as a threat to public safety.

lead_paragraph: An incomplete, eclectic list of university-spawned companies and innovations.

abstract: The number of people who have been unemployed for short periods has fallen close to its pre-recession level, but high rates of long-term unemployment persist.
lead_paragraph: The number of people who have been unemployed for short periods has fallen close to its pre-recession level, but high rates of long-term unemployment persist.

headline: Caught in a Revolving Door of Unemployment
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Some economists fear that the long-term unemployment crisis affecting millions of Americans might be a permanent change, with far-reaching and damaging consequences.
lead_paragraph: On a cold October morning, just after the federal government shutdown came to an end, Jenner Barrington-Ward headed into court in Boston to declare bankruptcy.

headline: Alex Calderwood, Creator and Face of the Unconventional Ace Hotel Chain, Dies at 47
abstract: The quirky vintage interiors of Mr. Calderwood’s hotels influenced the industry and became the backdrop for countless Instagram pictures.
lead_paragraph: Alex Calderwood, a founder of the Ace Hotel chain, whose quirky vintage interiors influenced the industry and became the backdrop for countless Instagram pictures, died on Thursday in London. He was 47.

headline: Success of Chinese Leader’s Ambitious Economic Plan May Rest on Rural Regions
abstract: The success of an economic overhaul could hinge on policy battles over land, money and a fiscal system that has bred public discontent and financial hazards.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s Communist Party has burnished President Xi Jinping’s plans for an economic overhaul with exultant propaganda about a historic turning point. But the success of his proposals, and the long-term health of the Chinese economy, could rest on policy battles reaching down into thousands of towns and villages over land, money and a misshapen fiscal system that has bred public discontent and financial hazards.

headline: New Syrian Refugees Descend on Lebanon
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Refugees poured into Arsal, Lebanon, amid reports that a battle was beginning along the Syrian border.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Refugees poured into Arsal, a Lebanese town in the Bekaa Valley near Syria, on Saturday amid reports that a battle was beginning along the mountainous border, a sign that the government was broadening its offensive against rebel strongholds.

headline: For Yankees’ Sabathia, It Appears Less (Weight) Is Less (Success)
abstract: There is a theory in some baseball circles that C. C. Sabathia’s diminished performance the last two seasons is because of significant weight loss.
lead_paragraph: Theories about C. C. Sabathia’s declining performance the last two seasons include the effect of his heavy workload — an average of 227 innings over 16 seasons — and his operation for bone chips in his pitching elbow after the 2012 season.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: For Jets’ Hill, Receptions Are a Waiting Game
abstract: The production of Stephen Hill, a wide receiver, has dwindled recently, leaving Coach Rex Ryan feeling “a little frustrated.”
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It happens all the time to Stephen Hill. He will be leaning over his pregnant fiancée, talking to her belly, when their dog, a Shih-poo named Boss, bounds over to compete for his attention. Boss barks. Boss snatches a toy and drops it at their feet. Boss barks some more.

headline: Week 11 Matchup: Jets (5-4) at Bills (3-7)
abstract: When Geno Smith shredded Buffalo for 331 yards and 2 touchdowns on Sept. 22, the Bills played without two starters: safety Jairus Byrd and cornerback Stephon Gilmore. Both are now healthy.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: With Dominating Offense, Princeton Trounces Yale and Gains Share of Ivy Title
abstract: The Tigers, who have one of the highest-scoring offenses in the nation, can claim an Ivy League title for the first time since 2006.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Princeton clinched at least a share of its first Ivy League title since 2006 and re-established a long if inconsistent football tradition with a 59-23 homecoming victory against Yale on Saturday.

headline: Challenger Takes Lead Over World Chess Champion
abstract: Magnus Carlsen won his second straight game over Viswanathan Anand. He now leads 4 points to 2, with 6.5 points needed to clinch the title.
lead_paragraph: For more than three years, Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, has been the uncrowned king of chess. It appears increasingly likely that within the next few days, he will officially wear the crown of world champion.

headline: For U.S., Scotland Game Was Chance to Evaluate Young Talent
abstract: The United States national team played an exhibition game against Scotland that seemed meaningless to just about everyone but a few American players.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — While much of the soccer world focused on the critical European World Cup qualifying playoff matches Friday night, the United States national team played an exhibition game here that seemed meaningless to just about everyone but a few American players.

headline: Foles’s Resilience Fortifies What Was a Fragile Position
abstract: Just when it appeared Philadelphia had no one capable of leading Coach Chip Kelly’s high-octane offense, Nick Foles, 24, asserted himself with surprising force.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Michael Vick retreated to the end of Philadelphia’s bench after aggravating his strained left hamstring in the second quarter of the Eagles’ defeat against the Giants on Oct. 27, it seemed more than a game would be lost.

headline: Stretching Field Has Been Challenging for Manning and the Giants
abstract: On Sunday against visiting Green Bay, the Giants hope an improved running game will give Eli Manning more time to throw down the field.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants were nursing a 13-10 lead against the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field when Eli Manning launched a desperation pass toward Hakeem Nicks in the left side of the end zone on the last play of the second quarter.

headline: Runoff Vote Is Completed in Maldives
abstract: The half brother of a former leader of the island nation appears to have been elected president, ending a tumultuous process.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The half brother of a former leader of the Maldives appears to have won that country’s runoff election for president on Saturday, defeating a popular favorite and ending a tumultuous voting process halted three times by court orders.

headline: Vowel Play
abstract: Julian Lim packs a lot of vowels into this Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: If part of your Sunday morning routine is to sit down to solve the crossword over a cup of tea, you might have a hint to one of today’s clues right under your nose. That’s because a lot of popular breakfast blends include tea grown in ASSAM, a state in northeastern India known for its heavy rainfall and, as a result, prodigious tea output. English breakfast tea, a blend, includes Assam’s offerings. The region comes up today at 42 Down, one of several clues about Indian geography.

headline: With Braves Set to Move, a Broader Look at Atlanta
abstract: With the Atlanta Braves moving to the suburbs, a civic conversation is examining whether the change is a blow to the city or a signal of a new era for the region.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A collective gasp rose here last week when the Atlanta Braves announced that they were moving to the suburbs. The franchise, after all, has been not only a sports team, but also a mirror of Atlanta’s aspirations.

headline: Fossil-Fuel Emissions by Country
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The debate over how to address the effects of climate change intensified at a United Nations meeting, but determining each country’s responsibility is a complicated task.
lead_paragraph: The debate over how to address the effects of climate change intensified at a United Nations meeting, but determining each country’s responsibility is a complicated task.

headline: A Russian GPS Using U.S. Soil Stirs Spy Fears
keywords: ['Global Positioning System', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Navigation', 'Satellites']
abstract: American spy agencies fear that allowing monitor stations in the United States for Russia’s version of GPS could compromise American intelligence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the view of America’s spy services, the next potential threat from Russia may not come from a nefarious cyberweapon or secrets gleaned from the files of Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor now in Moscow.

headline: William Weaver, Influential Translator of Modern Italian Literature, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Weaver’s work embraced the highest echelons of modern Italian fiction, nonfiction, poetry, prose and opera librettos, translating relatively obscure works along with international best sellers.
lead_paragraph: William Weaver, whose translations of works by modern masters like Italo Calvino, Umberto Eco and Primo Levi helped lift Italian literature to prominence among readers of English, died on Tuesday in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: How Do Hurricanes Happen?
abstract: We explain how hurricanes form — and grow — when cold and warm air merge.
lead_paragraph: We explain how hurricanes form — and grow — when cold and warm air merge.

headline: Growing Clamor About Inequities of Climate Crisis
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Weather', 'Global Warming', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The devastation in the Philippines has revived the debate over how to address the disproportionate effects of climate change on poorer countries, an issue that has gained momentum but faces daunting challenges.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Following a devastating typhoon that killed thousands in the Philippines, a routine international climate change conference here turned into an emotional forum, with developing countries demanding compensation from the worst polluting countries for damage they say they are already suffering.

headline: Relief Supplies Pour Into Philippines, but Remote Areas Still Suffer
abstract: While hard-hit urban areas are finally getting adequate supplies, the rural hinterland has been largely left to fend for itself in the week since Typhoon Haiyan hit.
lead_paragraph: QUINAPONDAN, the Philippines — Day after day, the mayor of this storm-shattered town makes the two-hour drive past flattened villages and splintered palm groves to the nearest functioning airport, where he begs for provisions from those who run the relief supply staging area for eastern Samar Island.

headline: Joaquín Hernández Galicia, Oil Workers Chief, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Hernández Galicia led a union of 200,000 workers employed by Mexico’s huge state-owned oil company, Pemex, and they revered him for the generous benefits he won for them.
lead_paragraph: Joaquín Hernández Galicia, a sometimes brutal Mexican power broker who earned the loyalty of his country’s vast army of oil workers as both their union boss and benevolent patriarch and who was later imprisoned, some say unjustly, died on Nov. 11 in Tampico, Mexico. He was 91.

headline: Keith Bradsher Answers Readers’ Questions on the Philippines
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'News and News Media', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Mr. Bradsher, a Times reporter covering the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, answered readers’ questions about doing his job under difficult conditions and the relief efforts underway.
lead_paragraph: Keith Bradsher, the Hong Kong bureau chief for The New York Times, has been reporting on the aftermath of the powerful typhoon that hit the Philippines on Nov. 8, mostly from Tacloban, the city that was flattened when the storm made landfall. Mr. Bradsher answered a selection of readers’ questions, submitted via Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Life After Exoneration: Building a Business, and Helping Others

abstract: When the state paid Christopher Scott for his wrongful conviction and more than a decade behind bars, he turned the money into his dream business and help for other exonerated prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Scott planned it all from an uncomfortable state prison bed at the Coffield unit in East Texas, where he would kick back, listen to R & B and daydream:

headline: A Legal Case Waits as Florida State’s Winston Drives Another Rout
abstract: Jameis Winston, looking unaffected by the emergence of a year-old accusation of sexual assault, completed 19 of 21 passes for 277 yards and 2 touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Jameis Winston walked into his postgame news conference Saturday night without the look of someone carrying a burden. His suit fit loosely, he wore flip-flops, his shirttail was out, and his smile was wide. He looked at ease as he sat in a metal folding chair surrounded by reporters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 16, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for Nov. 16 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Long Shot for Governor Is Suddenly a Presence in the Polls
abstract: Lisa Fritsch, 38, is way behind Attorney General Greg Abbott in the governor’s race, but she has pulled ahead of other Republicans in the polls.
lead_paragraph: She is barely a blip in the polls, and the odds of her securing the Republican nomination for Texas governor are viewed as vanishingly small. But Lisa Fritsch, a conservative activist, author and former radio show host, suddenly has bragging rights among second-tier candidates trying to make a respectable showing against the primary favorite, Attorney General Greg Abbott.

headline: In Fracas on Health Coverage, Some Democrats Feel Exposed

Ms. Davis, Democrat of Fort Worth, had filed to run for governor of Texas two days earlier. “The sacrifices you’ve made on behalf of each of us will not be forgotten,” she said. “I will make sure to fight that we do a better job, a dramatically better job.”

headline: For Son of a Nazi-Era Dealer, a Private Life Amid a Tainted Trove of Art

headline: My Father Didn’t ‘Know Best.’ How Will I?

lead_paragraph: I’m sure he thought he was doing the right thing. Father knows best and all that. Or at least better than his 3-year-old son. And his 3-year-old son was afraid of the dark and had to get over it.

headline: Exiting President Reflects on Georgia
abstract: In an interview last month, in the waning days of his presidency, Mikheil Saakashvili boasted that Georgia was closer to becoming an established democracy.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Mikheil Saakashvili, now the former president of Georgia, was still working his famously late nights, apparently intent on squeezing every last minute from the final days of his term. In an interview late last month that began after midnight and could well have stretched until dawn, Mr. Saakashvili boasted that in his decade in office, Georgia had made huge strides toward becoming an established democracy. He profanely dismissed allegations of heavy-handedness and authoritarian abuses, and voiced regret that he had not spent more money on education and less on weapons.

headline: What’s on Sunday

Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said that Ms. Silverstone “makes a delectable teen queen in ‘Clueless,’ a candy-colored, brightly satirical showcase for her decidedly visual talents.” Ms. Heckerling “finds herself on friendly territory with the worst Californian academic talent this side of Ridgemont High,” Ms. Maslin wrote. “Surfer burnouts held center stage in that earlier comedy of Ms. Heckerling’s, but this time she has gone hilariously upscale.”

headline: Shifting Gears to Explore the Realm of the Oboe

lead_paragraph: Rarely will I spare a thought for a different orchestra while awaiting a performance by the New York Philharmonic. Comparisons are pointless; best to be fully in the moment. Still, glancing through the program notes before a Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, I couldn’t help but reflect on the state of the Minnesota Orchestra, now locked in an acrimonious, costly conflict between management and players.

lead_paragraph: On Nov. 23, 1963, a Time Lord from the planet Gallifrey landed his blue police box in a British junkyard, and the universe has never been the same. This week, the BBC celebrates the 50th anniversary of “Doctor Who,” ranked as the most successful science-fiction television series by Guinness World Records, as it prepares for the arrival of the Twelfth Doctor (Peter Capaldi) in this year’s Christmas special.

headline: One Composer, Two Boroughs
abstract: Embracing a landscape where cross-genre collaboration is the rule, the contemporary chamber music series Ear Heart Music continues its season at Roulette.
lead_paragraph: Embracing a landscape where cross-genre collaboration is the rule, the contemporary chamber music series Ear Heart Music continues its season at Roulette on Monday with the Brooklyn dance company Skybetter & Associates, joined by the new Ear Heart Music Ensemble in works set to music by Johann Johannsson, Henryk Gorecki and David Lang. (8 p.m., 509 Atlantic Avenue, near Third Avenue, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, roulette.org, 917-267-0363.)

headline: Gathering What Another Spills
abstract: The Other Israel Film Festival runs through Thursday at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The image of people scavenging in trash heaps to survive has enticed documentarians before and resulted in memorable films like Lucy Walker’s “Waste Land,” about a dump outside Rio de Janeiro. But “Good Garbage,” which shows on Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan as part of the Other Israel Film Festival, has an added dimension. The dump pickers it looks in on are Palestinians from the city of Yatta, and the trash heap they work, in the Hebron Hills, includes the discards of more prosperous Israelis.

headline: An Ode to Joy, Choreographically
abstract: Mark Morris’s “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” returns to Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Mark Morris created “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” during the three years his company was resident at the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels. It was 1988, he was 32 and, for the first time, had an 1,100-seat opera house, an orchestra and a costume department at his disposal. He used it all with relish. “L’Allegro,” which returns to Lincoln Center this week, wasn’t immediately acclaimed by the local critics. (Mr. Morris’s biographer, Joan Acocella, quotes one review: “Where is the profundity?”) But it has become Mr. Morris’s most famous piece, celebrated for its innocence, exuberance and how it suggests the physical embodiment of ideal worlds. The work is set to the 1740 Handel oratorio from which it takes its title, and which uses the texts of Milton’s “L’Allegro” and “Il Penseroso,” portraits of the joyful and contemplative minds. Filled with nymphs and shepherds, gods and humans, hunters and lovers, the dance is beautiful, lavish and funny. It is, as Ms. Acocella writes, “a hymn to the unity of poetry, music and dance.” (7:30 p.m. Thursday to Saturday, David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600, davidhkochtheater.com.)

headline: Ravaged Philippine City Ponders a Grim Road Ahead
abstract: Guiuan escaped the deadly storm surge that hit Tacloban, but it was still devastated and faces an uncertain recovery despite the arrival of international aid.
lead_paragraph: GUIUAN, the Philippines — The Swedish Air Force brought German relief workers. The Australians delivered hulking pallets of water and food. The United States Navy dispatched so many supplies-laden Ospreys, Seahawks and C-130s on Sunday that the commanding officer in charge of the airport here lost count.

headline: A New Home for Recycling
