headline: A Grace Note for a Gritty Business
abstract: The new Sims Municipal Recycling Facility opening soon in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, promises to reduce recycling costs and create jobs, all in a pleasing waterfront structure.
lead_paragraph: Recycling in New York is a scrappy business. Billions have gone toward building water tunnels, power plants, subways and sewage treatment facilities, but little toward an infrastructure of recycling. In turn, New Yorkers have been slow to separate bottles and cans the way they flip a light switch or swipe a MetroCard: Recycling remains less an everyday fact of life than a do-good option, like tipping the mail carrier at the holidays.

headline: On the Ark, Two by Two, Creatures (and Performers) Great and Small
abstract: Benjamin Britten’s “Noye’s Fludde,” an opera that includes child performers, was presented by Lighthouse International and Park Avenue Christian Church.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten loved composing pieces for children, not just for children to enjoy but also to perform. There is no better example that “Noye’s Fludde” (“Noah’s Flood”), a 60-minute opera based on a 15th-century mystery play, written for amateurs, especially children, with professionals mixed in. This telling of the biblical story was first performed in 1958 at Orford Church in Suffolk, England. It was presented as part of Britten’s Aldeburgh Festival with artists from the English Opera Group along with a large local cast, including a children’s choir.

headline: Scores of Tornadoes Slam Midwest States
abstract: Severe storms carved paths of destruction through the Midwest on Sunday, destroying towns, killing at least six people and causing thousands of power failures.
lead_paragraph: Severe storms moved through the Midwest on Sunday, leveling towns, killing at least six people in Illinois and injuring dozens more, and causing thousands of power failures across the region.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Element of Surprise
abstract: The Suns and the Bobcats are off to unexpectedly good starts, making for an intriguing matchup in Charlotte.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Washington Insurance Official Is Ousted
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The District of Columbia’s commissioner, William P. White, had posted a statement disagreeing with President Obama’s reversal on canceling insurance policies.
lead_paragraph: The insurance commissioner for the District of Columbia was dismissed from his job just a day after he publicly questioned a decision by President Obama to reverse a provision of the Affordable Care Act, a person with knowledge of the events said on Sunday.

headline: After Night of Fun and Games, Jets Find Game Is No Fun
abstract: The Jets, after going to an arcade Saturday night, were crushed by the Bills as Geno Smith committed four turnovers and the secondary allowed two long touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — The night before the Jets’ first game in two weeks, Coach Rex Ryan addressed his players and canceled their offensive and defensive meetings. He had a surprise: a trip to Dave & Buster’s for some arcade fun.

headline: Bitcoin Scandal Reflects Popularity of Virtual Currency in China
abstract: Restrictions on Chinese citizens’ ability to trade in their own currency, the renminbi, have contributed to the embrace of digital alternatives.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 26, the website of Global Bond Limited, a Chinese exchange platform for bitcoins, the booming digital currency, suddenly went dead. Then, without warning, GBL’s roughly 500 remaining investors were kicked out of the company’s official QQ group, a social media platform that the company was using for investor relations. By nightfall, the scale of the swindle was made public – 25 million renminbi, or $4.1 million – making it one of the largest bitcoin fraud cases since the currency’s inception four years ago.

headline: Playing in Six Hearts After West Leads a Diamond
abstract: Some players have an eye for a good deal for a column.
lead_paragraph: Some players have an eye for a good deal for a column. One is Karen Allison of Las Vegas, a winner of five national championships and a silver medal in the 1994 McConnell World Women’s Teams Championship.

headline: Carol Channing to Celebrate ‘Hello, Dolly!’ Anniversary
abstract: Carol Channing is set to return to the stage for a one-night engagement commemorating the 50th anniversary of the opening of “Hello Dolly.”
lead_paragraph: Carol Channing, above, is set to return for a one-night engagement commemorating the 50th anniversary of the opening of “Hello, Dolly!” The event’s producer, Daniel Nardicio, announced on Sunday that the transgender performer Justin Vivian Bond would host the celebration on Jan. 20 at Town Hall in Manhattan, and that it would include filmed celebrity tributes, footage from Ms. Channing’s career and video questions submitted in advance. Tickets go on sale on Monday. Ms. Channing, 92, was previously interviewed by Mr. Bond in August at the Ice Palace in Cherry Grove, on Fire Island, as part of Mr. Nardicio’s Icon Series.

headline: A Rookie Going Through Initiation With the Nets Is Proving to Be an Inspiration
abstract: Center Mason Plumlee is playing more and performing better as the Nets struggle with early-season injuries.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With reporters crammed around him, the Nets rookie Mason Plumlee was a dozen words into his first response when the discussion was punctured from afar.

headline: A Glittery Prelude to Oscars’ Big Night
abstract: The Governors Awards banquet, in its fifth year, was held on Saturday and has become a place for Oscar hopefuls to be seen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Dark horses. Underdogs. Some who would be thrilled just for a nomination.

headline: Warnings of New Turmoil as Pakistan Pursues a Treason Case for Musharraf
abstract: The government said it had asked the Supreme Court to establish a panel to try Gen. Pervez Musharraf on accusations that he subverted the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s government said Sunday that it was initiating a treason prosecution of the country’s former ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, in what would be a groundbreaking, if politically charged, assertion of civilian supremacy over the powerful Pakistani military.

headline: Turning Sleuth, With Reliable Dog in Tow
abstract: In “The Good Boy,” Theresa Schwegel’s latest Chicago-based novel, a boy and a dog find trouble.
lead_paragraph: Theresa Schwegel is an Edgar-winning crime writer whose Chicago police stories are more nuanced and impassioned than most books of their genre. None of that has brought her much attention, and neither will the nondescript title of her fifth novel, “The Good Boy” — until readers figure out what it means. The story is well-woven enough to contain three contenders for “Good Boy” honors.

headline: Bacardi Campaign Focuses on Resilience, Rather Than Rum
abstract: A new advertising campaign chronicles the tumult Bacardi has weathered since it was introduced in Cuba in 1862.
lead_paragraph: IT is the time of the year when Bacardi typically promotes its recipe for holiday punch, but a new advertising campaign is instead promoting how the rum brand rolls with the punches.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 18
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'States (US)']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Optimism Outlasted a Lifetime of Horrors
abstract: The Czech writer Ivan Klima’s new book, a memoir, begins in a Nazi camp and ends with the Velvet Revolution of 1989.
lead_paragraph: The Czech writer Ivan Klima’s new book, a memoir, is called “My Crazy Century.” It begins in 1941, when together with his family Mr. Klima, who until then hadn’t even been aware that he was Jewish, was imprisoned in the Nazi camp at Terezin, and it concludes with the Velvet Revolution of 1989, ending years of dictatorship and repression. “Sometimes, it was funny crazy,” Mr. Klima said last week, while visiting New York. “But mostly, it was crazy crazy.”

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 18
abstract: Retailers including Target, J.C. Penney and Home Depot, will report earnings, with a look to the holiday shopping season.
lead_paragraph: SAC TRIAL Jury selection is scheduled to begin Tuesday in the trial of Michael S. Steinberg, the most senior employee at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors indicted in insider trading. Federal prosecutors have accused Mr. Steinberg of trading on secret information about technology companies. Though SAC has been at the center of the government’s insider trading investigation for years, Mr. Steinberg is the first former SAC employee to stand trial. Six others, including the fund itself, have pleaded guilty.

headline: A Kentucky Singer Faces Down a Manhattan Crowd
abstract: Sturgill Simpson and his band toyed around with bluegrass, Southern rock and the hard country of the 1970s, at Hill Country in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: There is no end to the variety of night life in New York, but it remains an open question whether this city could ever be home to a genuine honky-tonk. Native to the South, that would be loosely defined as part bar, part performance venue, part staging ground for a battle royal. The music matters, but it’s only one element of the tapestry.

headline: A Love Affair That Burned for Centuries, at Least in Song
abstract: The Orlando Consort brought a program of early music, both sacred and earthly, to the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.
lead_paragraph: At a concert of late medieval and early Renaissance vocal music presented in a church, you might expect to hear churchy music. And there was much of that in the second half of the Orlando Consort’s program at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square on Saturday evening, presented by the Miller Theater.

headline: History Comes to Life With Tweets From Past
abstract: Historical projects on Twitter aim to recreate events like Kristallnacht and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: LIKE watching a building collapse in slow motion, a Twitter account run by a group of German historians provides hour-by-hour updates of the horrors of Kristallnacht, which culminated in a night of anti-Jewish terror 75 years ago in Nazi Germany that plunged the country on a path to the Holocaust.

headline: Tapping Unseen Forces in the Dungeon
abstract: The choreographer Arturo Vidich, collaborating with Maximilian Balduzzi, employed novel contraptions and effects in his piece at the Abrons Arts Center on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Underground Theater at the Abrons Arts Center often goes by affectionate characterizations like “dungeon” and “cave.” Its subterranean aura, murky lighting and pockmarked concrete walls ensure that whatever happens will seem a little bit creepy. So it was a fitting location for Arturo Vidich’s “142241,” a duet (or quartet, if you count the audience participants) that attempted, as a news release put it, “to tune in to the invisible worlds that influence this world, if you believe in that sort of thing.”

headline: To the Sounds of Stevie Wonder, a Dance Baptism for a New Theater
abstract: Ronald K. Brown’s Evidence company was the first dance troupe at BRIC’s new performance space, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: BRIC House, the snazzily redesigned headquarters of BRIC, the venerable Brooklyn arts organization, opened last month, but it wasn’t until Wednesday night that the building’s flexible performance space had its first dance show. There couldn’t have been a better first choice than the Brooklyn company of Ronald K. Brown. This is dancing that consecrates. The warmth and artistry and infectious joy made this house into a home.

headline: Put Another Layer On
abstract: The return of Edgar Fontaine.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Greetings! Did everyone have a good week? Thanks again to Tom “Trust Me, He’s Dapper” Gaffney for the chance to take some much-needed R&R.

headline: Offense, Not Defense, May Be the Knicks’ Biggest Concern
abstract: Lackluster in stopping opponents from putting up points this season, New York has also experienced a marked drop in scoring efficiency.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Knicks elevated Mike Woodson to head coach after the March 2012 dismissal of Mike D’Antoni, Woodson has preached defense, toughness and rebounding. These are terms that resonate with Knicks fans, who cherished the gritty success of the teams led by Pat Riley and Jeff Van Gundy. After a 110-90 home loss to the Atlanta Hawks on Saturday, Woodson and the Knicks returned to the theme of defensive identity.

headline: Former President of Chile Poised to Regain Her Seat
abstract: A former president’s campaign promises, on education, health, social security and taxes, proved attractive in a nation of stark inequality.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Michelle Bachelet, who was president of Chile from 2006 to 2010, far outpolled her opponents for the office in the general election on Sunday, after campaigning on promises of major changes in education, health, social security and taxes. But she fell short of the majority needed to avoid a runoff election in December.

headline: In the Maelstrom of Harlem’s Gentrification, and Nothing Is Sacred
abstract: Keith Josef Adkins’s “The Last Saint on Sugar Hill” is having its New York premiere at the National Black Theater in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: We should not like Napoleon, a vicious Harlem landlord.

headline: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ to Get a CBS Spinoff
abstract: CBS has ordered a pilot for a spinoff, “How I Met Your Dad.”
lead_paragraph: The CBS comedy “How I Met Your Mother” may be ending this spring, but the show could continue at least in spirit: CBS has ordered a pilot for a spinoff, “How I Met Your Dad.” The development was first reported by Deadline.com and was confirmed by the series creators Carter Bays and Craig Thomas on their Twitter feeds. Mr. Bays said the show would feature a new setting and new characters. The pilot will put a female spin on the original concept and is to be written by Emily Spivey, who created the NBC comedy “Up All Night.” It’s no surprise that CBS want to keep “How I Met Your Mother” going in some form. The ninth and final season has averaged 8.2 million total viewers this fall and has remained among the 10 highest-rated broadcast programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the category most cherished by advertisers. It is also the third highest-rated comedy in that demographic, finishing behind only “The Big Bang Theory” on CBS and “Modern Family” on ABC.

headline: Fresh Life via Netflix for ‘The Killing’
abstract: “The Killing,” the twice-canceled AMC cop drama, has been renewed — this time by Netflix — for a fourth season.
lead_paragraph: “The Killing,” the twice-canceled AMC cop drama, has been renewed — this time by Netflix — for a fourth season. Netflix announced that this six-episode season would be a streaming exclusive and would be made available simultaneously around the world; AMC is not involved in the deal. The first three seasons are already available on Netflix, and the company said that the fourth would be the last one. The principal creative team and cast are set to return, including the series creator and show runner, Veena Sud, and its stars Mireille Enos and Joel Kinnaman. “The Killing” was canceled by AMC for the first time in July 2012 after its second season, but it was resurrected in January for a third season. It returned with little fanfare both critically and in the ratings — the last three episodes of Season 3 on AMC hovered around 1.5 million total viewers — and was promptly canceled again in September. “The Killing” was originally based on the Danish series “Forbrydelsen.”

headline: Facebook, Still Dominant, Strives to Keep Cachet
abstract: The swift rise of upstarts like Snapchat suggests a changing reality for how — and where — people like to spend their time.
lead_paragraph: When Evan Spiegel peered into a crystal ball to divine a future for his company, Snapchat, he did not see Facebook.

headline: A Tiny Label Is Behind an a Cappella Group’s Success
abstract: Madison Gate Records, a little-known unit of Sony Pictures, signed Pentatonix after the five-member group won the television talent show “The Sing-Off.”
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — If you stopped 100 people on the manicured Sony Pictures lot here and asked them to point you toward Shelly Bunge’s office, they would most likely give you the same blank stare. Who?

headline: Larger Prize for Tucker Award
abstract: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation said on Sunday that it had increased the size of the cash prize given to the winner of the annual Richard Tucker Award to $50,000 from $30,000.
lead_paragraph: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation said on Sunday that it had increased the size of the cash prize given to the winner of the annual Richard Tucker Award to $50,000 from $30,000. As previously announced, the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard is the 2013 recipient at the ceremony, scheduled for Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center; this year is the centenary of Tucker’s birth. The award goes to an artist considered on the verge of a major international career. Ms. Leonard is a regular at the Metropolitan Opera and has recently performed in productions of Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” and Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites.”

headline: Disney Struggles to Make Its Free Gaming Apps Pay
abstract: Mobile games are a major growth opportunity, and analysts say a recent flop underscores the challenges Disney faces in a shifting marketplace.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two months ago, Disney released a sequel to Where’s My Water?, a hit smartphone game about a showering alligator. Hopes were high: Disney had pointed to the original game as evidence of overdue traction in mobile gaming.

headline: In Charge of the Macy’s Parade, but Not the Thanksgiving Dinner
abstract: Amy Kule, the executive producer of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, said being the maestro has kept her out of the kitchen on the holiday for 17 years.
lead_paragraph: Amy Kule spent a couple of afternoons with Maureen O’Hara in the late 1990s.

headline: A Lesson From Cuba on Race
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Post-revolutionary Cuba responded to racial inequality more effectively than any country in the Americas. But racism proved more persistent.
lead_paragraph: In a recent article for The Stone, Gary Gutting posed a challenge. He urged readers to  look “past the outrage on race” provoked by the Trayvon Martin case and to focus on what he aptly described as the “deeper issue” that sustains the edifice of racial inequality — our unjust economic system. Under this system, people compete for basic goods and services in what seems to be a fair and non-discriminating market. But since they enter this market from vastly different social circumstances, competition is anything but fair. Those who already possess goods have a much better chance of renewing their access to them, whereas those who don’t have little chance of ever getting them.

headline: The Real Mayors of New York
abstract: Voters elected Bill de Blasio, but New York has always been a city of unofficial mayors.
lead_paragraph: Voters elected Bill de Blasio, but New York has always been a city of unofficial mayors.

headline: Suzanne Bianchi, 61, Who Analyzed Family Time, Dies
abstract: Professor Bianchi, a social scientist, upended conventional wisdom suggesting that working women were shortchanging their children.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne M. Bianchi, a social scientist who explored the changing landscape of late-20th-century American families, tracing how divorce, the shrinking gender gap and women’s careers affected children, parents and their households (“Is Anyone Doing the Housework?” was the title of one of her papers), died on Nov. 4 in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 61.

headline: Estimating Risk
abstract: New guidelines recommend statins for people whose risk of a heart attack or stroke in the next 10 years is 7.5 percent or higher. But calculators to estimate a person’s 10-year risk may overestimate the actual risk of heart attack or stroke, according to an analysis of three large studies.
lead_paragraph: New guidelines recommend statins for people whose risk of a heart attack or stroke in the next 10 years is 7.5 percent or higher. But calculators to estimate a person’s 10-year risk may overestimate the actual risk of heart attack or stroke, according to an analysis of three large studies.

headline: At 70, Still Fighting to Live Independently
abstract: Even while facing many medical problems, James Leak has taken literacy classes, battled to preserve his mobility and kept his apartment in Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: James Leak turned 70 last week, but he only recently started learning to read and write.

headline: Afghan Talks at Impasse Before Vote, Officials Say
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet, Afghan officials said both sides had refused to budge on American insistence that United States troops retain the right to enter Afghan homes.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite recent optimism about talks over a future American military presence here, two senior Afghan officials said on Sunday that the negotiations were at a profound impasse, days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet to seek popular support for a deal.

headline: Extension of Benefits for Jobless Is Set to End
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As many as 4.8 million people could be affected by expiring benefits through 2014, and there is little sign that Congress will act before it adjourns in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unless Congress acts, during the last week of December an estimated 1.3 million people will lose access to an emergency program providing them with additional weeks of jobless benefits. A further 850,000 will be denied benefits in the first quarter of 2014.

headline: Rescuing the Philippines
abstract: Aid to typhoon victims comes in at a trickle.
lead_paragraph: Aid to typhoon victims comes in at a trickle.

headline: An Inadvertent Paean to Jerry Bruckheimer, From the Studio That Ousted Him
abstract: Jerry Bruckheimer and Disney agreed in September to part ways, in the wake of his “Lone Ranger” flop. But a giant new book, from Disney Editions, was already in the works.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s not just a matter of size, though a new coffee-table retrospective of Jerry Bruckheimer’s film and television career — “Jerry Bruckheimer: When Lightning Strikes, Four Decades of Filmmaking” — certainly has heft.

headline: Pressure Builds to Finish Volcker Rule on Wall St. Oversight
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The push to reshape financial oversight hinges on negotiations in the coming weeks over the so-called Volcker Rule, a regulation that strikes at the heart of Wall Street risk-taking.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, currently stumbling through the health care overhaul, has reached a critical stage in its other signature effort: reining in Wall Street.

headline: Vote on Alcohol Sales Divides a Utah Town Where Few Drink
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Referendums']
abstract: Hyde Park’s alcohol restrictions had long been in line with the teachings of the Mormon Church, but the town recently voted to allow sales.
lead_paragraph: HYDE PARK, Utah — When a convenience store chain approached city officials here last year about selling beer, people knew a fight was coming.

headline: From Winless Start to Winning Streak, Giants Have Climbed Back Into Division Race
abstract: After opening 0-6, the Giants continued their improbable run to respectability with a fourth consecutive win to move within sight of first place in the N.F.C. East.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants had a fourth-quarter lead but Green Bay had whittled the edge to a single touchdown. As the Packers’ offense took over again, a tension was developing inside MetLife Stadium, the kind of unease that has dogged a season that began with comprehensive, aggregate failure.

headline: The Lasting Legacy of John F. Kennedy
abstract: Nearing the 50th anniversary of his assassination, readers discuss the 35th president’s influence.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Path
abstract: Amanda Rogers, 32, became addicted to painkillers after both her mother and stepfather died from overdoses. Now, she is stable in her recovery and taking buprenorphine daily.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Rogers, 32, became addicted to painkillers after both her mother and stepfather died from overdoses. Now, she is stable in her recovery and taking buprenorphine daily.

headline: Todd Smith
abstract: Todd Smith on taking buprenorphine after an addiction to painkillers.
lead_paragraph: Todd Smith on taking buprenorphine after an addiction to painkillers.

headline: N.B.A. Will Try to Avoid Repeat of Fashion Faux Pas at Garden
abstract: The Knicks and the Hawks experienced the sports equivalent of a wardrobe malfunction Saturday night, showing up in similar uniforms.
lead_paragraph: It did not take long on Saturday night for fans and commentators at Madison Square Garden to realize something was amiss between the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks. Their uniforms looked alike. Too alike.

headline: The Existential Stress of Waiting for ...
abstract: Readers respond to an Arts pages article.

headline: Joellen Trippett
abstract: In a therapy session at Chestnut Ridge, Joellen Trippett explains how her life has changed since becoming a buprenorphine patient and why she never wants to return to a life of addiction.
lead_paragraph: In a therapy session at Chestnut Ridge, Joellen Trippett explains how her life has changed since becoming a buprenorphine patient and why she never wants to return to a life of addiction.

headline: Dr. Carl R. Sullivan III
abstract: Dr. Sullivan explaining how he gauges a patient’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sullivan explaining how he gauges a patient’s recovery.

headline: Sea Level Rise in Florida
abstract: Tabitha Cale of Audubon Florida writes that Everglades restoration is critical to mitigating the effects of climate change in South Florida.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At Forums, New York State Education Commissioner Faces a Barrage of Complaints
abstract: John B. King Jr. has become a sounding board for crowds of parents, educators and others who equate his name with all they consider to be broken in schooling today.
lead_paragraph: He has been shushed, booed, called imperious and mocked as the incomprehensible teacher who bleated on and on in Charlie Brown’s classroom.

headline: Hypocrisy About Drugs
abstract: Tony Newman of the Drug Policy Alliance responds to a column by Nicholas D. Kristof.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Women Who Are Lawyers: Expectations and Realities
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Doc tracing the lives and careers of 21 women interviewed in a 2001 article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dr. Allan Clark
abstract: Dr. Allan Clark discussing how his experience with addiction has helped him relate to his patients.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Allan Clark discussing how his experience with addiction has helped him relate to his patients.

headline: At Clinics, Tumultuous Lives and Turbulent Care
keywords: ['Buprenorphine (Drug)', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Series']
abstract: In some areas, an unregulated clinic scene has sprung up for buprenorphine, a drug used to treat addiction, and it can pose a turbulent setting for patient care.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The patient is an addict. His doctor is an addict, too. Over the last decade, both men hit their own versions of rock bottom. For the patient, it was the concrete floor of a jail where he writhed in withdrawal. For the doctor, it was the food stamp office where, his career as a child psychiatrist in tatters, he ashamedly sought help.

headline: Developing a Fax Machine to Copy Life on Mars
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Science and Technology', 'Mars (Planet)']
abstract: DNA sequencing and DNA synthesis are becoming faster and cheaper, and J. Craig Venter wants to use the technology to bring Martian life to Earth.
lead_paragraph: MOJAVE NATIONAL PRESERVE, Calif. — J. Craig Venter, the maverick scientist, is looking for a new world to conquer — Mars. He wants to detect life on Mars and bring it to Earth using a device called a digital biological converter, or biological teleporter.

headline: Toy Story
abstract: America is still the birthplace of inventions. But for how long?
lead_paragraph: MY model American entrepreneur of the moment is Cheong Choon Ng. He has not attracted a $3 billion bid from Facebook, like the young inventors of the photo-sharing service Snapchat. Wall Street is not cooking up an I.P.O. But Ng is a star in my household. He is the creator of the Rainbow Loom, which in the middle-schooler market is the hottest device not called iSomething. If you have noticed that half the children in America — and a fair number of adults — seem to be sporting bracelets that are braids of brightly colored rubber bands, then you have seen the fruits of the Rainbow Loom.

headline: Crashing the Boards and Cracking the Books
abstract: Members of the United States women’s ice hockey team juggle practices with studies or other work as they prepare for the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — Her Olympic hopes seemingly extinguished, Kate Buesser’s idea of mucking it up in the corners involved a lobster boat, not hockey.

headline: West Faces Challenge in Moving Syrian Chemical Arms Through Battlefields
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: A plan to move more than 600 tons of precursor chemicals out of Syria in vehicles is raising concerns that such a convoy would present a slow-moving target for Syrian opposition groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A plan announced over the weekend for getting the bulk of Syria’s chemical weapons out of the country in coming weeks has raised major concerns in Washington, because it involves transporting the weapons over roads that are battlegrounds in the country’s civil war and loading them onto a ship that has no place to go.

headline: A Permanent Slump?
abstract: The new normal for our economy may be a state of mild depression.
lead_paragraph: Spend any time around monetary officials and one word you’ll hear a lot is “normalization.” Most though not all such officials accept that now is no time to be tightfisted, that for the time being credit must be easy and interest rates low. Still, the men in dark suits look forward eagerly to the day when they can go back to their usual job, snatching away the punch bowl whenever the party gets going.

headline: Week After Shooting, Life Goes On at Bryant Park
abstract: A week after a teenager was charged with shooting two skaters, people were still taking their children and friends to the crowded rink.
lead_paragraph: The line outside the Bryant Park skating rink on Saturday night was at least 100 deep, the soon-to-be skaters waiting their turn as a seemingly endless flow of people circumambulated the ice, racing, kissing, all bathed in a pink light.

headline: At U.S.C., the Cookie Doesn’t Crumble; It Bonds
abstract: The interim coach Ed Orgeron has brought back sweets to the training table, and a winning team to the field, giving momentum to his candidacy as Southern California’s next coach.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It started with dessert. When Ed Orgeron stepped in as the interim coach at Southern California after Lane Kiffin was fired in late September, one of the first moves he made was restoring sweets to the football team’s training table.

headline: Lincoln’s Sound Bite: Have Faith in Democracy
abstract: For all of its famous brevity, the Gettysburg Address is not so simple or compact as it seems.
lead_paragraph: The surprisingly short story of the Gettysburg Address is that it was a surprisingly short speech — 270 words or so — delivered by Abraham Lincoln as part of the dedication ceremonies for the Soldiers’ National Cemetery at Gettysburg, on Nov. 19, 1863, four and a half months after the climactic battle of the American Civil War.

headline: Where St. Nicholas Has His Black Pete(s), Charges of Racism Follow
keywords: ['Santa Claus', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Discrimination', 'Christmas']
abstract: In Dutch tradition, Peter, portrayed by people in blackface makeup, sports outlandish Renaissance costumes, with thick red lips and frizzy hairdo wigs or fake dreadlocks.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — St. Nicholas entered Amsterdam twice this weekend.

headline: Lesson Is Seen in Failure of Law on Medicare in 1989
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Law and Legislation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elderly']
abstract: Older voters rebelled when Medicare benefits were expanded at the cost of higher premiums, and some lawmakers who were involved see parallels today.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Angry Americans voice outrage at being asked to pay more for health coverage. Lawmakers and the White House say the public just doesn’t appreciate the benefits of the new health law. Opponents clamor for repeal before the program fully kicks in.

headline: For Assaulted Veterans, a Second Battle
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Sex Crimes', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Often victims of sexual assault have to convince the V.A. that they are disabled and entitled to compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder.
lead_paragraph: For military veterans, the trauma of rape, sexual assault or sexual harassment can be as devastating as combat wounds. But these injuries, while real, are often invisible, and the circumstances behind them shrouded in secrecy and denial. The men and women who endure such crimes often have to fight a second battle, to convince the Department of Veterans Affairs that they are disabled and entitled to compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety and other afflictions resulting from service-connected sexual violence.

headline: A Deep-Water Diver From Brooklyn Dies After Trying for a Record
abstract: Nicholas Mevoli was competing at Vertical Blue, a championship event in the sport of free diving, where he was attempting to achieve his second American record.
lead_paragraph: LONG ISLAND, Bahamas — As Nicholas Mevoli lay on his back, floating in the azure sea, attempting to relax, his exhales were audible. The countdown had begun, and he prepared to dive into Dean’s Blue Hole, hoping to reach 72 meters on a single inhalation, with no fins or supplemental oxygen. He began sipping the air, attempting to pack as much oxygen in his lungs as possible.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: For most cooks, Thanksgiving is the most complicated meal of the year.
lead_paragraph: For most cooks, Thanksgiving is the most complicated meal of the year.

headline: Lincoln at Gettysburg Long Ago
abstract: Lincoln’s speech, spoke our thoughts and gave them language so moving that they continue to resound all these years later.
lead_paragraph: Garry Wills once wrote that “all modern political prose descends from the Gettysburg Address,” which was read aloud by a bareheaded man, exhausted and ill, before a black-suited crowd 150 years ago. Mr. Wills chose the right word: “descends.” Lincoln’s speech is the pinnacle of American civic utterance. His words honoring the dead at Gettysburg on Nov. 19, 1863, do what words are only rarely able to do. They invoke an eloquent silence.

headline: Libyan Official Abducted Amid Unrest in Capital
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The City Council in Tripoli, where the deputy intelligence chief was seized, called a general strike to demand that militias leave the city.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The deputy chief of Libya’s intelligence service was abducted from the parking lot of the airport in Tripoli on Sunday afternoon as a standoff between militias and a general strike against militia rule virtually shut down the city.

headline: Princeton University Considers Use of Foreign Meningitis Vaccine
abstract: The university’s leaders are contemplating a stronger step to halt an outbreak that has hospitalized seven people: distributing a vaccine not approved for use in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Fearing the spread of a meningitis outbreak that has caused seven people at Princeton University to be hospitalized this year, university officials have warned students to stop sharing drinks and to avoid kissing. Bright orange posters urge students to “keep healthy and carry on,” and red cups labeled “Mine. Not Yours” serve as reminders not to share drinks at parties.

headline: The Shame of American Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: People in the United States pay more and get less than citizens in other advanced countries.
lead_paragraph: Even as Americans struggle with the changes required by health care reform, an international survey released last week by the Commonwealth Fund, a research organization, shows why change is so necessary.

headline: Thailand’s Latest Troubles
abstract: A politically motivated amnesty bill threatens the government’s future.
lead_paragraph: Thailand is again on the verge of political turmoil. An ill-conceived amnesty bill pushed through the lower house of Parliament by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra earlier this month brought many thousands of demonstrators for and against the government into the streets of Bangkok, putting the country’s fragile democracy in peril.

headline: Bomb at Base Kills at Least 31 Syrian Troops
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The attack, one of the deadliest against government soldiers in recent months, came as an offensive against rebels continued on three fronts.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 31 Syrian troops, including four senior officers, were killed on Sunday in a bombing that collapsed a building on a government military base just north of Damascus, the Syrian capital, an antigovernment monitoring group said. It was one of the deadliest attacks on government soldiers in recent months.

headline: Just for Chiefs Fans, a Welcome Taste of Kansas City in Queens
abstract: A Kansas City-style barbecue joint on 44th Drive has become a headquarters for fans of a surprisingly successful team, who couldn’t find a place to watch Chiefs game last season.
lead_paragraph: Few bar-stool debates are more tiresome than arguments over which team’s fans have suffered the most. But it’s hard to imagine a season much worse than the one Kansas City Chiefs fans endured last year. On the field, the team had the N.F.L.’s worst record; off it, a starting linebacker killed his girlfriend before shooting himself in front of the coach and general manager.

headline: Design Contest Seeks Just the Right Chair for Battery Park
abstract: The Battery Conservancy will pay for prototypes of the five finalists, and the sitting public next spring will help select the winner.
lead_paragraph: One looks like a pale blue flower with five round petals. Another evokes a piece of playground equipment. A third shape shifts as needed — upright chair one direction, chaise longue the other. They are designs for a movable, stackable, weatherproof chair, one of which will eventually grace a new three-acre green at the Battery, the 22-acre park at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Iraq Bombings
abstract: Officials said that 44 people were killed and over 100 were hurt in explosions — some set off by suicide bombers — that targeted public spaces and security checkpoints.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Explosions targeting public markets and security checkpoints killed 44 people across Iraq on Sunday, including 20 in a northern Turkmen-dominated city, and wounded over 100, police and medical officials said.

abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Risk Calculator for Cholesterol Appears Flawed
abstract: An online calculator meant to help doctors assess treatment options appears to overestimate risk, so much so that it could mistakenly suggest that millions more people are candidates for statin drugs.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the nation’s leading heart organizations released a sweeping new set of guidelines for lowering cholesterol, along with an online calculator meant to help doctors assess risks and treatment options. But, in a major embarrassment to the health groups, the calculator appears to greatly overestimate risk, so much so that it could mistakenly suggest that millions more people are candidates for statin drugs.

headline: Bumping Off Kin, a Song in Your Heart
abstract: This delightful show turns the Alec Guinness movie classic “Kind Hearts and Coronets” into a musical, with Jefferson Mays in eight roles.
lead_paragraph: Serial killers may be all the rage on bookshelves and television screens — so ubiquitous, you’d think they made up a major demographic of the world population — but they are comparatively rare in the peppier precincts of musical theater. Now, after a long dry spell, Broadway has a deadly sociopath to call its own. Please give a hearty welcome to Monty Navarro, the conniving killer who helps turn murder most foul into entertainment most merry in the new musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 17, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Revolution Will Have Live Music
abstract: For nearly a decade, members of the Rude Mechanical Orchestra have provided musical accompaniment to rebellious street events in New York City and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Among the shouts and chants from a picket line on the Upper East Side on a recent evening were a few sounds of a less discordant nature: the thump of a bass drum, the toot of a trombone, the melodious drone of a clarinet.

headline: Inland, No Aid for Survivors of Typhoon
abstract: While international relief workers and Philippines Department of Health workers are now scouring neighborhoods up and down the coast, they are nowhere to be seen in the interior.
lead_paragraph: JARO, Philippines — Even as a major international aid effort has begun to take hold around the coastal city of Tacloban, the situation grimly differs just a few miles inland, where large numbers of injured or sick people in interior villages shattered by Typhoon Haiyan more than a week ago have received no assistance.

headline: When Medical Experts Disagree
abstract: How should doctors and patients react to the latest findings that come out about health concerns? How do you know whom to trust?

headline: Start-Up Leaders Recall Choice to Cash In or Stay Independent

lead_paragraph: Nine start-up founders recounted the moment they had to decide whether to sell or stay independent — when the money was on the table and the future was unpredictable.

headline: Rangers Have Lots of Chances but Don’t Capitalize on Any of Them
abstract: The Rangers’ struggling offense could not produce a goal against the Los Angeles Kings, despite having two separate two-man advantages.
lead_paragraph: For all their strong play of late, the Rangers still have trouble beating good teams. Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, they took 37 shots against the Los Angeles Kings and sometimes dominated the game. But they could not produce a goal against the Kings, the 2012 Stanley Cup champions, despite having two separate two-man advantages, and lost, 1-0.

headline: French Leader Assures Israel He Will Keep Pressure on Iran
abstract: President François Hollande arrived in Israel for a three-day visit as world powers prepared to resume talks with Tehran on its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As France and other world powers prepared to resume talks with Iran this week on its disputed nuclear program, the French president, François Hollande, arrived in Israel on Sunday for a three-day visit and was warmly embraced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has been conducting a lonely campaign against a deal he calls “bad” and “dangerous.”

headline: Pakistan Has Export Plans for Jet Fighter Produced With China
abstract: At the Dubai Airshow, the Pakistan Aeronautical Complex, which jointly produces the JF-17 fighter with a Chinese company, made clear its ambitions to sell the jet to other countries.
lead_paragraph: The market for the JF-17 fighter appears to be expanding in unexpected ways. At the Dubai Airshow, which opened on Sunday, the Pakistan Aeronautical Complex had a freshly minted example on display, complete with an array of Chinese-made missiles and bombs.

headline: Giants-Packers Replay, Nov. 17
abstract: A look at the Giants’ 27-13 victory over the Green Bay Packers at MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: A look at the Giants’ 27-13 victory over the Green Bay Packers at MetLife Stadium.

abstract: Anal fissures, or tears in the anal opening, are not exactly a topic for cocktail party conversation, but the condition is quite common.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1 P.M. (TMC) THE FRIGHTENERS (1996) Michael J. Fox, left, stars as Frank Bannister, a private detective who can see and interact with ghosts in this spook fest directed by Peter Jackson. Frank normally uses his paranormal skills to cheat the unsuspecting people of a small town out of their money. But when he is blamed for a series of mysterious deaths, he searches for the real killer and ends up face to face with the grim reaper. “With material for a half-dozen different movies here, Mr. Jackson has no trouble keeping ‘The Frighteners’ spinning,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Phantoms skitter across the screen in record numbers, and Mr. Fox presides over the story with dependable skill.”

headline: Role of Smoking Cited in China’s Rising Lung Cancer Deaths
abstract: Deaths from lung cancer in China have risen by 465 percent in the past 30 years, experts said at a medical meeting in Beijing over the weekend.

headline: Brazilian Stories and Selfies Through a Pinhole
abstract: For ten years, Tatiana Altberg has taught children in Rio how to build pinhole cameras from cans to document the world around them.
lead_paragraph: Tatiana Altberg stressed the basics when she began teaching photography to children in a Rio de Janeiro favela. Using cans that would have otherwise been tossed out, she showed them how to make pinhole cameras to illustrate the fundamentals of optics.

headline: Celebrating Elsa Schiaparelli
abstract: The granddaughter of the legendary couturier is readying an auction of some of her clothing and personal items.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I would come in and she would be in her bed, with all these heart-shaped, shocking pink pillows,” the actress Marisa Berenson said about her grandmother Elsa Schiaparelli, the great couturier of the 1930s. “She had beautiful skin and beautiful shoulders and sexy nighties that were all embroidered.

headline: How Good Are You at Waiting for What You Really Want?
abstract: How much time do you give something to happen before you give up on it?
lead_paragraph: A cookie before dinner, news that is sure to affect your future, an invitation to spend time with a new friend or love interest: it can be hard to wait for the things you want.

headline: Bill Gates Can’t Build a Toilet
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: High-tech $1,000 bathroom gadgets won’t help the world’s poor.
lead_paragraph: IN addition to eradicating polio in India and starting the personal computer revolution, the Seattle Superman of our age has managed to make going to the bathroom a cause célèbre. Five years ago, if I’d told people I worked on toilets, they would have surely assumed I was a plumber. Now, they exclaim: “Oh! Isn’t Bill Gates into that?”

headline: Challenge for the Government: 4 Million Are Displaced, and Hunger Grows
abstract: As the Philippines begins to clean up after the worst typhoon in memory, it is faced with a huge problem of feeding and housing its displaced population.
lead_paragraph: BASEY, the Philippines — When Typhoon Haiyan hit this coastal town, residents ran for Saint Michael the Archangel Church. Now, 10 days later, more than 100 of them remain.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Lloyds Banking Group said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its asset management arm to Aberdeen Asset Management in stock and cash deal worth up to 660 million pounds, or $1.06 billion.

abstract: What you need to know for Monday: passions over the Thanksgiving Day parade, wildly erratic weather and testing opponents keep their children home.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:02 p.m. | Coming to the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade: the float fracas.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Luke Mogelson on the Risks of a Refugee Voyage
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article — who spent three days aboard a boat with migrants trying to reach Australia — explains how the piece came together.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | Luke Mogelson, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about Afghan and Iranian migrants attempting to reach Australia from Indonesia by boat. He last wrote for the magazine on the Afghan National Army. He is the co-founder and editor of an online magazine called Razistan.

headline: The Sleeper Cell That Wasn’t
abstract: Six days after 9/11, the F.B.I.’s raid on a Detroit sleeper cell signaled America’s resolve to fight terrorism. But, despite a celebrated conviction, there was one problem — they’d gotten it wrong.
lead_paragraph: Six days after 9/11, the F.B.I.’s raid on a Detroit sleeper cell signaled America’s resolve to fight terrorism. But, despite a celebrated conviction, there was one problem — they’d gotten it wrong.

headline: The Demise and Afterlife of the ‘Detroit Sleeper Cell’ Case
abstract: A week after Sept. 11, three men were accused of plotting terror, but the case became a cautionary tale about connecting dots where they might not exist.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of the “Detroit Sleeper Cell,” the first terrorism trial after 9/11. Here, a reporter who covers terrorism for The Times recalls the charged atmosphere at the time and the consequences for the Justice Department.

headline: Hooligans, Hooligans, Everywhere
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Yet another way for the Kremlin to punish anyone who disturbs its sense of the social order.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There are many hooligans in Russia, apparently, and judging by the way the state deals with them, they are extremely dangerous people. With jail sentences averaging three years and potentially reaching seven, they are treated as though they pose a greater threat to Russian society than drunk drivers and possibly as great a threat as murderers, who get sentences in the same range.

headline: A Start-Up That Wants to Be the ‘Anti-Yelp’
abstract: Goodsnitch gives customers a quick way to recognize outstanding service or an outstanding employee, and it gives businesses an opportunity to gain valuable customer feedback.

headline: A Conversation With: Novelist Tash Aw
abstract: The author of “Five Star Billionaire” spoke to India Ink about contemporary China, societies in transition and capitalism in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Tash Aw is a writer of Malaysian origin who was born in Taiwan, grew up in Kuala Lumpur and currently resides in London. He is the author of “The Harmony Silk Factory” (2005), which won the Whitbread Book Award, given to authors based in Britain and Ireland, as well as the Commonwealth Writers’ Prize, and of “Map of the Invisible World” (2009). His most recent novel, “Five Star Billionaire,” which was released this year, was placed on the long list for the Man Booker Prize, Britain’s top literary award. The book captures the changes sweeping across China through the lives of five Malaysian-Chinese immigrants who move to Shanghai in pursuit of the Chinese dream.

abstract: The City Council in Tripoli, where the deputy intelligence chief was seized, called a general strike to demand that militias leave the city.

Geithner is joining Warburg Pincus as president. | A snub by Snapchat underscores the changing perception of Facebook in the tech industry. | The checks from JPMorgan Chase keep on coming.

lead_paragraph: TSURU, Japan — As the world’s fastest train raced through central Japan, former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York hoisted his 6-foot-5 frame into the aisle and marveled at the smoothness of the ride.

headline: Daily Report: For Start-Up Leaders, to Sell or Hold Is a Tough Call
abstract: Nine start-up founders recounted the moment they had to decide whether to sell or stay independent — when the money was on the table and the future was unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: Were the young founders of Snapchat, a mobile-messaging start-up, delusional for turning down a multibillion-dollar buyout offer? Greedy to think they might get more later? Or courageous to chase their dreams?

headline: Top U.N. Official Warns of Coal Risks
abstract: Most of the world’s coal needs to stay in the ground to limit greenhouse gas emissions, the United Nations’ top climate change official told coal executives.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Most of the world’s coal needs to stay in the ground if greenhouse gas emissions are to be held in check, the United Nations’ top climate change official said Monday in a speech to coal industry executives here in Poland, one of the most coal-dependent nations on Earth.

headline: High Winning Bid for Photo by Mao’s Wife
abstract: Maoist-era art is attracting soaring prices as private collectors and public museums in China face off at auction.
lead_paragraph: A black-and-white photograph of a landscape snapped by Mao Zedong’s fourth wife, Jiang Qing, has sold for 391,000 renminbi, or $64,000, about 20 times the presale estimate, at Huachen Auctions in Beijing. The unexpectedly high price provides another sign of a bullish market for Mao-era art, driven by the competition among private collectors and public museums and libraries that are seeking to enhance their holdings.

headline: Tibetan Monastery’s Prayer Hall Lost in Fire

lead_paragraph: The main prayer hall of a 16th-century Tibetan Buddhist monastery burned to the ground in a fire set off by a short circuit in an electrical appliance, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

headline: The New Keynesian Case for Fiscal Policy (Wonkish)
abstract: Not hard if you actually read the stuff.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a bit funny on the academic front being a Keynesian during a Keynesian crisis. Much of the academic profession decided more than 30 years ago that the whole thing was nonsense and what we needed was an equilibrium model of the business cycle. By the time the utter failure of the equilibrium project became apparent, you had a whole generation of economists who knew that Keynesianism of any form was nonsense based on what they had heard somewhere, so they didn’t read any of the stuff, old or new — and were flabbergasted to learn that there was in fact an extensive New Keynesian literature that provided a justification for fiscal policy at the zero lower bound.

headline: Justices Reject Challenge to N.S.A. Program
abstract: The unusual challenge to the collection of millions of domestic telephone records had been filed directly to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned away an unusual challenge to a National Security Agency surveillance program.

abstract: The Fukushima Daiichi cleanup enters a new phase as TEPCO begins moving fuel rods from a damaged reactor building.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a quick update on efforts to clean up the tsunami-damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant complex. (I’ll be following up with a post on efforts to track the radioactive material that flowed into the Pacific Ocean after the calamity and clarify its implications for public and ecosystem health.)

headline: Fuel Removal Underway at Crippled Plant in Japan
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: The removal of fuel at the No. 4 reactor of the Fukushima Daiichi plant, which could take until the end of 2014, would remove a major safety risk.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The operator of the crippled Fukushima Daiichi power plant on Monday began removing nuclear fuel assemblies from a storage pool atop one of the site’s blown-out reactor buildings, a delicate yet critical operation that could help reduce risks at the plant.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Police officers fanned out in the French capital on Monday in search of the man responsible for a shooting at a newspaper headquarters that left one man gravely wounded and the city on edge.

abstract: You’ve seen these questions around the Internet for some time. Now corporate customers will be able to make some sense of them.
lead_paragraph: Corporations have a few questions for you. And then a few more. That trend is likely to increase, thanks to the way they are trying to make sense of your every move.

headline: New Prize Goes to Author of Book on Vietnam
abstract: Fredrik Logevall, author of “Embers of War: The Fall of an Empire and the Making of America’s Vietnam,” wins the first American Library in Paris Book Award.
lead_paragraph: Fredrik Logevall has won the first American Library in Paris Book Award for his “Embers of War: The Fall of an Empire and the Making of America’s Vietnam.” The library was founded and originally run by American expatriates in Paris in 1920, with books that had been sent by American libraries to soldiers fighting in World War I. It plans to offer the $5,000 award annually for what its jury considers the most distinguished book of the year about France or the encounters between France and the United States.

headline: Power Still Out for Thousands After Tornadoes Pound Midwest
abstract: Illinois was hit especially hard by tornadoes that tore through the Midwest on Sunday, killing at least six people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Ill. — As the sky went black and sirens wailed, Ella and Phil Bolam lay together in a bedroom closet, pillows covering their heads, as the storm passed and “the house went away,” Ms. Bolam said.

headline: Dried Porcini Consommé
abstract: A refreshing and light soup that can be an appetizer or full first course.
lead_paragraph: I could drink this refreshing consommé for lunch every day. It makes a very light and satisfying appetizer soup or first course.

headline: Puréed Mushroom Soup
abstract: This soup is made without cream, but still tastes very rich.
lead_paragraph: Thick and creamy, with no cream, this tastes so much richer than it is. I use a small amount of milk to thin out the soup, but you can also use stock to thin it, if you don’t want to include any dairy.

headline: Walkabout: Europe Is Expected to Loosen Restrictions on Electronic Devices
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Power Up Passengers with smartphones and music players flying on European airlines will no longer have to turn off their device on take-off and landing. That’s just one of the new rules being developed by the European Aviation Safety Agency that will be published by the end of the month. (Bloomberg)

headline: Tate Britain Completes Renovation
abstract: The newly designed sections shown on Monday include a centerpiece spiral staircase beneath the ceiling dome in the entrance, which opens up access to public spaces above and below.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The $72 million renovation of the Tate Britain museum by the architectural firm Caruso St. John is complete, “on time and on budget,” said Penelope Curtis, the director of the museum, at a showing on Monday, the day before the museum will open its new areas to the public.

headline: Powerfully Wrong
abstract: More on the debasement gang.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong continues the pile-on over Barry Ritholtz’s roll of dishonor — the people who signed the currency debasement letter and haven’t shown any sign of learning anything from being completely wrong.

headline: Alex and the Button Lock
abstract: Can you help Alex open a simple lock?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was featured in Round 1 of the U.S.A. Mathematical Talent Search, a monthlong open-book competition open to all middle- and high-school students in the United States.

headline: New Leader Is Named for ArtPlace America
abstract: Jamie L. Bennett will become the executive director of ArtPlace America, a two-year-old organization that advocates art and cultural projects in community development.
lead_paragraph: ArtPlace America, an organization that awards grants in the hope of encouraging what it calls “creative placemaking” – that is, the inclusion of arts and cultural projects in community development and renovation plans – has appointed Jamie L. Bennett to be its executive director, starting in January.

headline: Presumed Innocent, but Caged in Court
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Long avoided by courts in the United States, locked docks are widely used elsewhere, even in cases where the defendants do not seem particularly dangerous.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Under the Russian Constitution, Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, the star dancer charged with arranging an acid attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, is innocent until proven guilty. But in court, Mr. Dmitrichenko sits in a locked iron cage, guarded by security officers and, at times, a nasty-looking dog.

headline: Measuring the Might of Haiyan
abstract: Without a flight into a storm, its exact strength is difficult to gauge. Forecasters said Typhoon Haiyan would pack winds of up to 195 miles an hour, but the top measured speeds were closer to 150 m.p.h.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Haiyan, which ravaged the Philippines earlier this month, might have been one of the strongest tropical cyclones ever to hit land, but its exact strength was a matter of dispute. Forecasting agencies said it would pack winds of up to 195 miles (about 315 kilometers) an hour, but meteorologists in the Philippines said that top measured speeds were closer to 150 m.p.h., or 240 k.p.h.

headline: A Dirty Secret Lurks in the Struggle Over a Fiscal ‘Grand Bargain’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Social Security (US)', 'Medicare']
abstract: Neither Republicans nor Democrats want to take even the actions they demand of the other side for a long-sought agreement on the nation’s fiscal future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long-sought bipartisan “grand bargain” on the nation’s fiscal future is not going to happen this year, and probably not for the rest of President Obama’s term. There is the simple, familiar reason. And then there is the dirty secret.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: What’s the story with Philadelphia cream cheese and silver? And ad fatigue already with the Domino’s Pizza online ordering commercial.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Ketchum acquired Icon International Communications of Singapore and Pete Naylor was named to an Interactive Advertising Bureau publisher-in-residence program.
lead_paragraph: Nathy Aviram joined McCann Erickson New York as executive vice president and director of integrated production. He assumes duties from Diane Hill, who had been senior vice president and director of integrated production; she left to return to BBDO New York, where she had previously worked, and is now senior vice president and group executive producer there. Mr. Aviram has worked for agencies that include TBWA/Chiat/Day New York and Y&R New York. McCann Erickson New York is part of the McCann Erickson Worldwide division of the McCann Worldgroup, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Before the Wedding, the Histrionics (but Not the Bride’s)
abstract: Helen Sneed’s “Fix Me, Jesus,” at Abingdon Theater, delves into a panic attack.
lead_paragraph: The cause of Annabell Armstrong’s latest panic attack seems petty: Annabell (a frenetic Polly Lee) is at Neiman Marcus in Dallas, and she cannot find the perfect dress for a cousin’s wedding. But as Helen Sneed’s 95-minute play explains again and again, her histrionics are but a manifestation of a lifetime of accumulated anxieties and emotional traumas, as evidenced by the memories that wander, unwanted, into the store’s dressing room.

headline: The Power of Two (Extra Wonkish)
abstract: Simple is good.
lead_paragraph: This seems to be wonk Monday. But anyway, one commenter raised what may have been a complaint about my tendency to do New Keynesian models that say they have infinite horizons, but whose analysis always seems to boil down to just two periods, “now” and “forever after”.

headline: With More Indictments, New Clues in A.T.M. Robbery Case
abstract: The authorities indicted six more people in connection with a global network that looted $45 million from bank machines last spring.
lead_paragraph: When eight men from Queens were indicted last spring as part of a global network that looted $45 million from A.T.M.'s, an unanswered question was what happened to the money.

headline: The Read Around: Terry McMillan
abstract: Ms. McMillan, the author of “Who Asked You?,” says, “If I wanted you to know exactly what I thought about things, I’d write nonfiction.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Terry McMillan, the author of “Waiting to Exhale” and, most recently, “Who Asked You?,” talks about why she prefers writing in the first person, how she gets to know her characters and why it’s important for writers to be diverse readers.

headline: Quitting the N.F.L.: For John Moffitt, the Money Wasn’t Worth It
abstract: John Moffitt, who walked away from about $1 million in salary from the 9-1 Broncos, said continuing to play for money was likely to injure him further and deepen his gloom.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — John Moffitt chugged mugs of black coffee and talked almost giddily about how, the week before, he called John Elway, the head of football operations for the Denver Broncos, to tell him he was quitting the National Football League, leaving behind the money and the fame, but also the constant pain and the danger.

headline: The V.A. and Sexual Trauma
abstract: Survivors of sexual trauma are far less likely than other veterans to have their disability benefits approved.
lead_paragraph: An editorial in today’s Times cites disheartening discrepancies in how the Veterans Affairs Department handles disability claims involving post-traumatic stress disorder. According to a report released this month by advocates for women and men who were sexually harassed and attacked while serving in uniform, survivors of sexual trauma are far less likely than other veterans to have their disability benefits approved.

headline: Surveillance Video of Suspected Paris Gunman
abstract: Investigators in Paris said that surveillance camera video of a man who menaced the editor of a television news channel in the French capital last week might show the same man who shot a newspaper journalist on Monday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Scott Sayare reports, French police are scouring Paris for a gunman who shot a journalist at the headquarters of the newspaper Libération on Monday morning. The same man is suspected of shooting at a bank in another part of the French capital 90 minutes later, and of having menaced an editor at a television news channel late last week.

headline: Confused About Holiday Travel? Submit Your Questions Here
abstract: We’re soliciting questions on holiday travel.
lead_paragraph: The Wednesday before Thanksgiving is one of the busiest travel days of the year, according to the Department of Transportation. And no matter how you’re getting to grandmother’s house – by air, rail or road – you probably have a few nagging questions that could get answered in the form of a rude awakening on the road. In order to reduce the number of known unknowns, we’d like to answer your questions about holiday travel before you set off.

headline: Vegetarian Too Young
abstract: Inspired by a “Charlotte’s Web” read-aloud, my daughter became a vegetarian at age 4. Three years later, I’m wondering if I let her make a choice she wasn’t ready for.
lead_paragraph: When my daughter chose to become a vegetarian at age 4 after I read her “Charlotte’s Web,” I thought it was a passing phase, much like needing to receive a confidential sprinkle of fairy dust on her way to school. Her pediatrician approved her nutritional plan without hesitation, and we have Hindu friends whose children have been vegetarian from birth, so the idea hardly seemed radical in our household, where we consumed a modest amount of meat to begin with.

headline: A Hurdle to Winding Down a Failing Global Bank
keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: United States and European regulators want to standardize derivatives contracts to help cross-border banks fail smoothly. It’s a reminder of how much work still needs to be done to end “too big to fail,” the author says.
lead_paragraph: A seemingly small derivatives detail could sink global bank wind-down plans. American and European regulators want to standardize contracts to help cross-border lenders fail smoothly. If the problem isn’t fixed, investors could undermine financial stability by calling in swaps. It’s a reminder of how much work still needs to be done to end “too big to fail.”

headline: In Washington State, Selling to the Sellers With a Lighthearted Touch
abstract: A campaign that spoofs the image of Seattle as a nirvana for the noncommercial encourages agencies to produce more commercials there.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in the movie “Written on the Wind” when a character played by Robert Stack tells a character played by Lauren Bacall, “You advertising people, so clever with words.” But just how clever do advertising people have to be when creating advertising aimed at other advertising people?

headline: Congress and Courts Weigh Restraints on N.S.A. Spying
abstract: As the Supreme Court rejected one challenge, congressional critics of the spy agency’s vast data collection efforts stepped up pressure to force more disclosure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional critics of the National Security Agency program that collects the telephone records of millions of Americans stepped up their efforts as the Supreme Court on Monday turned away an unusual challenge to the scope of the surveillance.

headline: ‘Here Lies Love’ Cast to Reunite for Benefit Performance
abstract: The cast of David Byrne’s musical about Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos will reunite for one night in New York, with proceeds to aid relief efforts in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: David Byrne is reconvening the cast of “Here Lies Love,” his immersive musical about Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, for a single performance on Nov. 25 at Terminal 5 to raise money for relief efforts in the Philippines in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, which struck on Nov. 8. All proceeds from the performance will be donated to Doctors Without Borders, the Paris-based physicians group.

headline: More Explorations in Space
abstract: With or without Kepler, several satellites, intended to identify nearby exoplanets, are in the works in the coming years.
lead_paragraph: With or without Kepler, the quest for habitable real estate in the galaxy will go on.

headline: Former Marcos Aide Is Convicted in Attempted Sale of Missing Paintings
abstract: It took jurors only three hours to convict Vilma Bautista on conspiracy and tax fraud charges stemming from the sale or attempted sale of the paintings, which disappeared in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Vilma Bautista was patient. She waited more than a quarter of a century before discreetly trying to sell the paintings she had in her New York apartment: Impressionist masterpieces that had once hung on the walls of a townhouse used by Imelda Marcos.

headline: New Plan for a Disabled Kepler
abstract: A plan to keep Kepler hunting for planets would have the spacecraft skipping around the sky, observing any one spot for up to 80 days.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — The little spacecraft that could may still have some life left in it.

headline: Real Honor for Fake Newsman
abstract: Emerson College in Boston will rename its School of Communication – for one day.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of journalists have received honorary degrees. But Ron Burgundy, the bumbling fictional television newsman played by Will Ferrell in “Anchorman,” will go one better next month when the Emerson College School of Communication is temporarily named after him.

headline: Medical Care Improves in Storm-Hit Areas, Though Many Are Still Out of Reach
abstract: A week and a half after Typhoon Haiyan struck, more health workers are tending to the injured and some supplies are getting through to the interior.
lead_paragraph: PALO, the Philippines — Rosalina Doyola, a cheerful 22-year-old with an accounting degree and an air of youthful confidence, woke up on Monday morning in a field hospital tent, lucky to have kept both her legs.

headline: 3 From Greenpeace Ship Free on Bail in Russia
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: A court in St. Petersburg ordered the release of three Russian citizens from a Greenpeace International ship seized during a protest against oil drilling in September.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A court in St. Petersburg on Monday granted bail to three of 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship seized during a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic in September. Some see this as a first sign of leniency in an investigation that could continue through the Olympic Games that Russia is hosting in Sochi.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 15-17, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: No charges will be filed in the shooting death of a 13-year-old girl at a friend’s home in Las Vegas, Nev., in June. Brooklynn Mohler was shot when her friend was holding a gun, which had been retrieved from a kitchen cabinet, and it accidentally discharged.

headline: G.M.’s Opel Unit Reaches Deal to Close a German Plant
abstract: The company had previously said it would close its factory in Bochum in 2014, but the new agreement with workers could stave off labor action against the move.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The Opel unit of General Motors said on Monday that it reached a preliminary agreement with workers to close a factory in Bochum, Germany, at the end of next year, another example of the effort by hard-pressed European automakers to slowly close superfluous manufacturing plants.

headline: Lady Gaga Concert Prompts Fine for Russian Concert Agency
abstract: A St. Petersburg court fined a Russian concert agency after ruling that Lady Gaga’s concert there promoted homosexuality and alcohol consumption.
lead_paragraph: The Russian concert agency that presented a Lady Gaga concert in St. Petersburg in December has been fined 20,000 rubles – the equivalent of $614 – because, a St. Petersburg court ruled, Lady Gaga’s show promoted homosexuality and alcohol consumption.

headline: Arguments for Trusting the Data
abstract: Despite the evidence, we still like to go with our gut.
lead_paragraph: Why don’t we trust data? More to the point, why don’t we act on what data tells us?

headline: Scores Killed in Tribal Clashes in Darfur
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Nearly 200 people have died in the last three weeks in fighting between members of the Salamat and the Messeiriya tribes, officials say.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Nearly 200 members of two Arab tribes that signed a peace treaty in July were killed in fighting in southwest Darfur over the past three weeks, a local tribal chief said.

headline: Sochi Games’ Doping Lab Provisionally Suspended
abstract: The Russian laboratory charged with conducting drug tests at the Sochi Games will have its accreditation suspended if it does not make operational improvements by Dec. 1.
lead_paragraph: The Russian laboratory that has been assigned the task of processing drug tests for the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi will have its accreditation suspended for six months if it does not make operational improvements to ensure its reliability by Dec. 1.

headline: Pacers Have Built a Consistent (if Imperfect) Winner
abstract: Early returns show that the Pacers, a team that pushed the Miami Heat to seven games in the Eastern Conference finals last season, are every bit as formidable this year.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Several hours before his Indiana Pacers met the Chicago Bulls Saturday night at United Center, General Manager Kevin Pritchard lounged in a courtside folding chair during the afternoon shootaround.
