abstract: The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported that a Walmart in Ohio is organizing a Thanksgiving drive for needy workers.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported on Monday that a Walmart in Canton, Ohio is organizing a food drive for its employees.

abstract: Mr. Adler has taken the affable-neighborhood-retiree gig to a whole new level with the Kew Gardens Musicians.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Adler has taken the affable-neighborhood-retiree gig to a whole new level with the Kew Gardens Musicians.

headline: Obama’s First-Term Finance Team: Where Are They Now?
abstract: Some of the top financial government officials appointed in the Obama administration’s first term have moved into the private sector, while others are taking on new posts in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Timothy F. Geithner’s move to the private equity firm Warburg Pincus is a big shift by a finance official from the Obama administration’s first term to the private sector.

headline: In Store | Balenciaga’s Newest, Oldest-Looking, Store
abstract: On Mercer Street, the new flagship is an extension of Alexander Wang’s debut runway collection for the brand and feels like it has been there for decades.
lead_paragraph: With its dark green Verde Ramegiatto marble walls and a skylight ceiling covered with a lattice metal inlay, the new Balenciaga flagship in SoHo feels like it has been around for centuries. Alexander Wang designed it that way, working closely with his longtime friend and collaborator, the interior designer Ryan Korban, to turn the bilevel space on Mercer Street into something that felt like it had already stood the test of time. “I wanted to mix modern and classical materials to create a timeless space,” said Wang, who cited historic museums as inspiration for the store, his first as the brand’s creative director. The interiors are also a testament to Wang’s point of view for the brand, full of references to his debut collection for Balenciaga, which took place on a faux marble runway back in February. Even the chairs that dot the grand, open floor plan — which also includes several intimate rooms that each house different kinds of goods (ready-to-wear in one room, shoes in another, etc.) — have been upholstered in the same black “caviar” embroidery he applied to gowns in the fall 2013 collection. Combined with the sofas, they seem to beg shoppers to stay awhile. “I thought back to the time of the couture salon presentations in the Cristobal Balenciaga era, when clients had the luxury of time to view fashion in a leisurely way, but with an elevated sense of ceremony,” Wang said. The Balenciaga flagship opens on Nov. 22; 148 Mercer Street; (212) 206-0872.

headline: The Dow, Adjusted for Inflation
abstract: Today’s nominal high in the Dow Jones industrial average still falls short of the inflation-adjusted peak in 2000.
lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones industrial average broke through 16,000 on Monday for the first time on record — well, at least in nominal terms. If you adjust for inflation, technically the highest level was on Jan. 14, 2000 (both for closing price and intraday trading):

abstract: As the Philippines begins to clean up after the worst typhoon in memory, it is faced with the huge challenge of feeding and housing its displaced population.
lead_paragraph: As the Philippines begins to clean up after the worst typhoon in memory, it is faced with the huge challenge of feeding and housing its displaced population.

abstract: Scenes from the aftermath of the tornadoes that caused widespread destruction across the Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the aftermath of the tornadoes that caused widespread destruction across the Midwest.

headline: Filming of Movie Won’t Close Clearwater Aquarium
abstract: The Clearwater Marine Aquarium has reversed its decision to close on weekends during the filming the movie “Dolphin Tale 2.”
lead_paragraph: After turning away scores of disappointed visitors, the Clearwater Marine Aquarium,  in Clearwater, Fla., has reversed its decision to close weekends during the filming of “Dolphin Tale 2” and will also remain open during  the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays.

headline: Sleep Therapy Seen as an Aid for Depression
abstract: The first of four studies on the special relationship between sleep and depression suggests that when antidepressants and insomnia therapy are used together, recovery happens faster.
lead_paragraph: Curing insomnia in people with depression could double their chance of a full recovery, scientists are reporting. The findings, based on an insomnia treatment that uses talk therapy rather than drugs, are the first to emerge from a series of closely watched studies of sleep and depression to be released in the coming year.

headline: A Business Traveler’s View of the Latest Airline Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Business Travel', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Is the combination of American Airlines and US Airways a good deal for corporate travel consumers? Let’s look at the raw, naked economics.
lead_paragraph: WHEN discussing the airline business, Michael Boyd uses the term “raw, naked economics” as if it ought to be followed by a shriek off a movie screen.

headline: A Cold War Fought by Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: New evidence shows that female aggression helps explain peer pressure to meet standards of physical appearance and sexual conduct.
lead_paragraph: How aggressive is the human female? When the anthropologist Sarah B. Hrdy surveyed the research literature three decades ago, she concluded that “the competitive component in the nature of women remains anecdotal, intuitively sensed, but not confirmed by science.”

headline: Monday Motorsports: A Week of Triumph, Tragedy and Controversy
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Racing', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'United States Grand Prix (Auto Race)', 'Motorcycle Racing']
abstract: Jimmie Johnson clinches his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship, and Dario Franchitti announces the end of his IndyCar driving career.
lead_paragraph: Jimmie Johnson clinched his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship with a ninth place finish in the season finale on Sunday at Homestead-Miami Speedway. Matt Kenseth finished the season in the runner-up position, 19 points behind Johnson, with a second-place finish in the race, behind the winner, Denny Hamlin. Dale Earnhardt Jr. took third in the race.

headline: A Singapore Crew Cut to Get Past the Hair Police
abstract: Ole Henriksen is a skin cosmetician who manufactures of his own line of skin care products.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been flying regularly for about 40 years. I’m 62 years old, or, as I prefer, 62 years young, and fly once a week. I have a line of skin care products named after me, and that means that I have to meet with people, do events, find new avenues for business in the United States and abroad, and even travel so I can keep up with the trends and learn new things.

headline: Sony Entertainment Is Said to Hire Bain & Company for Cost-Cutting
abstract: The company is said to seek $100 million in cuts after criticism from the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb, whose hedge fund owns 7 percent of Sony.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sony Entertainment, under pressure to make its moviemaking operation more profitable, has hired Bain & Company to help it identify $100 million or more in additional overhead cuts, a move that would almost assuredly result in layoffs, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: A Conversation With Leander Kahney, Author of ‘Jony Ive’
abstract: Leander Kahney, the author of several books about Apple, took on the challenge of analyzing Apple through the lens of the design process used by Jonathan Ive, the company’s head of design.
lead_paragraph: Jony Ive, the designer behind some of Apple’s most successful products, became even more important to Apple after the death of Steve Jobs.

headline: Inequality of Feelings
abstract: Letter to the editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Agriculture as Solution
abstract: Letter to the editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Fennel and Lemon Turn Swordfish Into a More Complex Meal
abstract: Swordfish can take a lot of heat, just as long as you’re gentle with the flame.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Zimmerman Is Charged With Aggravated Assault
abstract: George Zimmerman, who was acquitted in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager, was arrested after a dispute with his girlfriend, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Barely four months after he was acquitted in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager that spurred demonstrations across the country, George Zimmerman was arrested on Monday in Florida following a dispute with his girlfriend, the authorities said.

headline: Watchful Eye in Nursing Homes
abstract: Family members are turning to hidden cameras to help confirm suspected abuse in nursing homes, but their use raises legal and ethical questions about liability and privacy rights.
lead_paragraph: A pretty nightie, a new lipstick, a fresh toothbrush: Doris Racher noticed that small things she had bought for her 96-year-old mother, Eryetha Mayberry, a dementia patient at a nursing home in Oklahoma City, had been disappearing. Ms. Racher assumed the culprit was another resident who sometimes wandered into her mother’s room and fell asleep in her bed.

headline: German Chancellor Makes Plea for Ukraine
abstract: Angela Merkel threw her weight behind efforts by the European Union to forge closer partnerships with Ukraine and five other countries.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel demanded on Monday that Russia allow its onetime subjects — particularly in Ukraine — to exercise the sovereign right to make alliances as they choose.

headline: Toronto Mayor Knocks Over City Council Member at Meeting
abstract: Mayor Rob Ford knocked over a City Council member during a tense special session called to debate a motion that would strip him of almost all mayoral powers.
lead_paragraph: The embattled Toronto mayor, Rob Ford, knocked over a City Council member during a tense special session on Monday called to debate a motion that would strip him of almost all mayoral powers, according to The Globe and Mail, a Toronto newspaper. The meeting came after a string of reports that included an admission by Mr. Ford that he bought and used crack cocaine while in office.

headline: Cheneys Defend Elder Daughter in Feud on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney and his wife said the feud pained them, but supported Liz Cheney, whose opposition to same-sex marriage has prompted criticism from her sister, Mary, who has a same-sex spouse.
lead_paragraph: Breaking their silence about the public feud between their two daughters, former Vice President Dick Cheney and his wife, Lynne, said Monday that the situation had pained them, but offered some political cover for their elder child, who is seeking a United States Senate seat in Wyoming.

headline: A Rare Sample of a Much Saltier Time
abstract: Seawater from a crater at the bottom of Chesapeake Bay offers a rare glimpse of the North Atlantic 100 million to 145 million years ago.
lead_paragraph: Seawater retrieved from a crater deep under Chesapeake Bay is 100 million to 145 million years old, researchers say, offering a rare glimpse of ancient ocean conditions in the North Atlantic.

headline: Vienna Visit Is a Home Game for a U.S. Assistant
abstract: Andreas Herzog, a former Austrian pro who is now one of Jurgen Klinsmann’s top assistants, will be at home when the United States national team plays a friendly in Vienna on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Almost everywhere that the United States national soccer team goes, Coach Jurgen Klinsmann is the most recognized member of the traveling party. Whether it is San Pedro Sula or Sarajevo, Klinsmann, a World Cup-winning striker with Germany, is catnip for soccer fans, autograph-seekers and admirers.

headline: In Performance: Zachary Quinto
abstract: Zachary Quinto as Tom in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie,” on Broadway at the Booth Theater.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Quinto as Tom in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie,” on Broadway at the Booth Theater.

headline: Officials Were Warned About Health Site Woes
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A report prepared in late March by an outside management consultant said a “lack of transparency and alignment on critical issues” was threatening progress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Obama administration officials, including several in the White House, were warned by an outside management consultant early this year that the effort to build the HealthCare.gov site was falling behind and at risk of failure unless immediate steps were taken to correct the problems, according to documents released by House investigators.

headline: Not Much of an Appetite at 80
abstract: A lack of interest in eating among older adults can stem from a range of issues, including depression and the side effects of medication.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why would I totally lose my appetite at the age of 80, with no apparent medical problems?

headline: After Hours | An Irishman’s Inner Marcel Proust
abstract: “Souvenir,” an hourlong one-man show, pays homage to “Remembrance of Things Past,” 100 years later.
lead_paragraph: Bush Moukarzel’s first line in the one-man play “Souvenir,” now playing at the Abrons Arts Center in New York, is, “For a long time, I went to bed early.” It’s also the very famous first line of Marcel Proust’s “Remembrance of Things Past,” published a century ago this year. Moukarzel’s hourlong piece, which was a sold-out hit in Dublin and London for the theater company Dead Centre, aims not so much to relive Proust’s epic, seven-volume story of social climbing, desire and memory as to distill its yearning, nostalgic essence into fragments of narrative and images. When the show begins, Moukarzel is running on a treadmill, his back to us, instantly conjuring images of being borne back ceaselessly into the past (or, stuck in the present). A giant diptych of Proust hangs overhead. Everywhere, there’s a clutter of half-opened packing boxes, marked cheekily with labels like “Mum,” “Apologies, “Bacon,” “Broken Glass” and (inevitably) “Madeleines.”

headline: Celtic Paths, Illuminated by a Sundial
abstract: In “The Discovery of Middle Earth,” a historian posits that the Celts relied on the sun’s arc in the sky to map their migrations.
lead_paragraph: BEWCASTLE, England — The road leading north from Carlisle through the low, windswept hills stretching to the Scottish border traces Hadrian’s Wall, once a remote outpost of the Roman Empire. Nearby is the tiny outcropping of Bewcastle, where a broken Celtic cross with one of the oldest sundials in England stands in a lonely churchyard.

headline: New Scrutiny for Medical Devices
abstract: Some products like machines that deliver CPR have never undergone rigorous premarket approval by the federal agency, which even plans to remove many from high-risk status.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Schneider’s heart stopped beating late last year while the Minneapolis paramedic was out on an emergency call. Another medic performed CPR for a few minutes, and then used a medical device that delivered cardiac compressions mechanically for 64 minutes, until Mr. Schneider’s heart started beating normally on its own.

headline: Bill on Drug Compounding Clears Congress a Year After a Meningitis Outbreak
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Meningitis', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Drugstores']
abstract: About a year after tainted drugs from a compounding pharmacy caused a fatal meningitis outbreak, legislation passed the Senate without opposition.
lead_paragraph: A bill that would give the Food and Drug Administration more power to police compounding pharmacies passed its final hurdle in Congress on Monday, in what experts said was an important step to a safer drug supply in the United States.

headline: Jay Z and Barneys Announce Substantial Changes in Their Partnership
abstract: Jay Z requested a “leadership role” at Barneys New York regarding the issue of racial profiling.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, Barneys New York and Jay Z reaffirmed their plans to go ahead with a collaboration that involves, among other things, the introduction of a fragrance this Wednesday, but announced some substantial changes in their partnership.

headline: ‘Baddest Man on the Planet’ (and His Vulnerable Side)
abstract: The boxer Mike Tyson has written a memoir about his life of celebrity, excess and despair that is a splashy hodgepodge, by turns exhausting and fascinating.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Mike Tyson lived a life without brakes.

headline: For a Tenor’s Centennial, Celebrating His Legacy With a Cast of Opera Stars
abstract: An outstanding group of opera singers paid tribute to Richard Tucker at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A dream team of opera singers assembled at Avery Fisher Hall for the Richard Tucker Gala on Sunday, an evening that included Stephanie Blythe, Joyce DiDonato, Renée Fleming, Susan Graham and Eric Owens. But before any of them sang a note, it was the voice of Tucker that filled the hall in a recording of “Thine Alone,” in which cantorial ardor and classical training blended into that combination of polish and popular appeal that made him one of the best-loved tenors of his time.

headline: A Historical Elephant’s New Identity
abstract: A 255-year-old elephant fetus on which Carl Linnaeus based his taxonomy of Asian elephants was actually African, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: In 1752, King Adolf Fredrik of Sweden acquired a remarkable curiosity: an elephant fetus preserved in a jar. It did not take long for a fellow Swede, the famed naturalist Carl Linnaeus, to pay an eager visit to Drottningholm Palace to examine the withered specimen.

headline: Healthy Trips to Exotic Places
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: When traveling with children, it helps to be prepared for bites, infections, even cars without seatbelts.
lead_paragraph: Long ago, I carried two seatbelts in my luggage. When the car that we rented for a month to drive around Turkey had no seatbelts in the back, as my husband and I had been warned, we took the two in my baggage to a body shop, paid to have them installed, and strapped our children in.

headline: U.N. Agency Seeks Details on American Held in Iran
abstract: The United Nations human rights agency is looking at the circumstances behind the continued incarceration of Amir Hekmati, who has not been charged.
lead_paragraph: The family of Amir Hekmati, a former American Marine who has been incarcerated in Iran for more than two years even though his espionage conviction was overturned, has been contacted by the United Nations for details on his case, Mr. Hekmati’s sister said Monday.

headline: Exploring Spirituality, and Ending on a Prayer
abstract: A Tallis Scholars concert on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, part of the White Light Festival, included work by John Tavener, who died last week.
lead_paragraph: The British composer John Tavener, who died last week at 69, frequently collaborated with the Tallis Scholars, the superb a cappella ensemble founded and conducted by Peter Phillips. It seemed fitting that as an encore to the group’s impressive concert of Renaissance and contemporary music on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, it offered a Tavener work as a tribute: his setting of the Lord’s Prayer.

headline: Hearing What Radiohead Has Inspired
abstract: Alarm Will Sound played a Steve Reich premiere based on Radiohead on Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie, Tortoise, the Orb, Sufjan Stevens, Dan Deacon: The list of pop and rock performers and groups who have shown the composer Steve Reich’s influence is lengthy and continuing. On Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Reich turned the tables, as Alarm Will Sound presented the New York premiere of his “Radio Rewrite,” based on two songs by the British rock band Radiohead. The performance was part of this adventurous new-music ensemble’s season-long residency, which includes formal events like this one, as well as unusual programs, like a pop-up concert that would unfold without warning in the museum’s Charles Engelhard Court on Monday at noon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Illinois and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Illinois, the Philippines, Pakistan and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Illinois, the Philippines, Pakistan and France.

headline: Clues to the Origins of Big Cats
abstract: A new set of fossils, ranging from four million to six million years old, and thought to be the oldest ever found, belonged to a previously unknown species.
lead_paragraph: A newly discovered set of big-cat fossils, believed to be the oldest ever found, belonged to a previously unknown species, and may help solve a longstanding mystery about the origins of big cats likes tigers, leopards and lions, researchers say.

headline: An Old Chinese Novel Is Racy Reading Still
abstract: An American scholar reveals the novel “Plum in the Golden Vase,” famous for its pornography, as an encyclopedia of imperial Chinese life.
lead_paragraph: When David Tod Roy entered a used-book shop in the Chinese city of Nanjing in 1950, he was a 16-year-old American missionary kid looking for a dirty book.

headline: Serving a Challenging Meal by Starting Off Easy
abstract: Leon Botstein led the American Symphony Orchestra in a program that showed unusual sides of the composer Elliott Carter.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to ambitious, fearless orchestral programming, there is Leon Botstein, the music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, and then there is everyone else. Say what you will about Mr. Botstein’s esoteric tastes, professorial inclinations or limitations as a conductor. It’s all been said before, endlessly, and it’s not indicative of the edifying experiences his concerts tend to be for anyone whose tastes extend past the safety zone in which most other orchestras huddle.

headline: Israelis Embrace French President for Iran Position
abstract: The warm Israeli greetings for visiting President François Hollande of France reflected their deep shared suspicion of Iran’s nuclear intentions.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President François Hollande’s trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories, like all state visits, was planned months ago. But coming days before France and other world powers prepared to resume the nuclear talks with Iran in Geneva, the three-day visit that started on Sunday could not have come at a more opportune time for Israel — or for France, according to some Israeli officials.

headline: Question Fed Policy? Sure. Audit It? No.
abstract: Rand Paul’s very bad idea.
lead_paragraph: Mike Konczal has a very good piece on why Rand Paul’s proposal that the Fed be “audited” is a bad idea. You should read it; I’d just like to offer a complementary take.

headline: Reptilian Smarts
abstract: New research is showing that lizards, turtles and snakes are more intelligent than previously believed.
lead_paragraph: New research is showing that lizards, turtles and snakes are more intelligent than previously believed.

headline: Coldblooded Does Not Mean Stupid
abstract: Recent research revealing that reptiles’ brains are less primitive than previously thought could offer new insights on cognitive evolution.
lead_paragraph: Humans have no exclusive claim on intelligence. Across the animal kingdom, all sorts of creatures have performed impressive intellectual feats. A bonobo named Kanzi uses an array of symbols to communicate with humans. Chaser the border collie knows the English words for more than 1,000 objects. Crows make sophisticated tools, elephants recognize themselves in the mirror, and dolphins have a rudimentary number sense.

headline: Broader Pool of Madoff Victims to Benefit From Fund
abstract: So-called indirect investors, representing about 70 percent of all the claims filed, are eligible for compensation from a $2.35 billion fund collected by the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: The largest category of victims in the vast Ponzi scheme run by Bernard L. Madoff — those who lost cash through accounts with various middleman funds — will be first in line for compensation from a $2.35 billion fund collected by the Justice Department.

headline: Crossing the Ocean to Discover the Personal
abstract: New releases from Blood Orange, Daughtry and Randy Weston and Billy Harper.
lead_paragraph: The work of Devonté Hynes radiates a thorough, passionate, forgetting-to-eat-or-sleep love for the last 30 years of pop. His current project, Blood Orange, is a trans-Atlantic notion of urban dance music from the early ‘80s to the early ‘90s: freestyle, Prince ballads, Janet Jackson’s “Control,” Neneh Cherry. It reads now, on balance, as a New York sound. But it’s a New York as experienced by an outsider, exotic and blurry, with an indeterminate time stamp.

headline: An Earlier Exodus Amid Climate Change
abstract: Birds are migrating earlier and earlier each year, and scientists have long suspected that climate change is responsible.
lead_paragraph: Birds are migrating earlier and earlier each year, and scientists have long suspected that climate change is responsible. A new study by researchers at the University of East Anglia in England shows that individual birds migrate like clockwork, but nesting and hatching are happening earlier as a result of warmer temperatures, and this appears to be linked to the advancing of overall migration patterns.

headline: Eli's Championship M.O.
abstract: The Giants play some horrible football, then string together some wins and make the playoffs. William C. Rhoden has seen this movie twice before. It always ends with a Super Bowl victory parade.
lead_paragraph: The Giants play some horrible football, then string together some wins and make the playoffs. William C. Rhoden has seen this movie twice before. It always ends with a Super Bowl victory parade.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: Eli’s Championship M.O.
abstract: The Giants play some horrible football, then string together a series of wins and qualify for the playoffs. We’ve seen this movie twice before, and it always ends with a Super Bowl victory parade.

headline: Need Condo Cleaned? Consider the Superintendent’s Family
abstract: Though not on the payroll, spouses and nephews are among those available to residents, at a cost, sometimes to everyone’s benefit, and sometimes not.
lead_paragraph: When Ilir Topalli gets that yearly Christmas card from the management of the small Upper East Side building where he has lived for 10 years, the one that gently nudges residents to tip the staff, it contains the names of the superintendent, the doorman and the porter who trudges out with the trash. Also listed is someone who is not on the co-op’s payroll: the superintendent’s wife, who is the de facto housekeeper for many of the apartments.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Love and Math’
abstract: The preface to a new book on mathematics — a subject woven into the very existence of our lives that’s embraced by very few of us.
lead_paragraph: There’s a secret world out there. A hidden parallel universe of beauty and elegance, intricately intertwined with ours. It’s the world of mathematics. And it’s invisible to most of us. This book is an invitation to discover this world.

headline: Brilliance Triumphs Over Rejection
abstract: In the former Soviet Union, Edward Frenkel was denied admission to the best mathematics program because he was a Jew. But as he recounts in “Love & Math,” the now-renowned mathematician didn’t let that stop him.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, when he was 16, Edward Frenkel was subjected to a malicious interrogation. Already a brilliant budding mathematician, he had applied for admission to “Mekh-Mat” at Moscow State University, the top mathematics program in the Soviet Union. But when he attended the critical oral entrance exam, his dream of becoming a professional mathematician came crashing down.

headline: Vibrating Along With Live Music
abstract: Gina Gibney’s “Dividing Line” has its premiere at Gould Hall.
lead_paragraph: Some dancers execute movement; others breathe it. In Gina Gibney’s “Dividing Line,” which had its premiere run from Thursday through Saturday at Gould Hall, Amy Miller fell into the second category.

headline: A Romantic Evening
abstract: A premiere by David Ludwig was part of the program when the violinist Benjamin Beilman and the pianist Yekwon Sunwoo played at Carnegie Hall on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: When David Ludwig wrote his “Swan Song” for violin and piano, he wanted to evoke the ghosts of 19th-century composers. He was particularly inspired by Schubert’s Fantasy for Violin and Piano, which opens with an elegiac melody over bustling piano figurations. The title of Mr. Ludwig’s contemporary reimagining refers to Schubert’s “Swan Song” cycle, written shortly before Schubert died of syphilis at 31.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: On Google’s Driverless Car, and Poking Fun at Downed YouTube
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the web include a tale of Google’s quest to take the steering wheel out of your hand. Plus, reaction to YouTube’s site being down and an argument for why young people aren’t the harbingers of the next big thing.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Hurricanes and Climate, Helping Stuck Babies, Changing Forests
keywords: ['Saturn (Planet)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Global Warming', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: A typhoon prompted questions about a possible link between natural disasters and a warming planet. A mechanic comes up with a baby extricator. A new tool helps track the state of the forests.
lead_paragraph: The typhoon that struck the Philippines this month prompted questions about a possible link between natural disasters and a warming planet. Delegates at the United Nations talks in Warsaw on a global climate treaty were quick to make the connection. And the head of the United Nations’ meteorological agency cited Australia’s severe summer heat and raised water levels around the Philippines as among the effects, reported ABC News. Still, most scientists remained cautious, saying there was not enough data to draw a direct connection.

headline: Pynchon Won’t Be Surfacing for National Book Awards
abstract: The author, who has avoided being photographed throughout his life, is among five finalists in fiction. His publisher said he won’t be at the event.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, the publishing industry will gather in black tie for the National Book Awards, where some of the most prestigious literary prizes in the business will be handed out.

headline: YouTube Website Goes Down
abstract: YouTube, one of the world’s most popular websites, went offline for a short period for many of its viewers on Monday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: YouTube, the world’s third most popular website, went down for a short period on Monday, giving the millions of people who depend on the service for videos of news and kittens a heavy sense of withdrawal.

headline: Obama Pick for Court Is 3rd in a Row Blocked by Republicans
abstract: In blocking Judge Robert L. Wilkins’s nomination, Senate Republicans on Monday denied President Obama his third pick in recent weeks to fill a vacancy on the nation’s most powerful and prestigious appeals court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Monday blocked President Obama’s third consecutive nominee to the country’s most powerful and prestigious appeals court and insisted they would not back down, inflaming a bitter debate over a president’s right to shape the judiciary.

headline: On View | An Artist’s Dueling Landscapes
abstract: The sculptor Halsey Rodman goes from the streets of New York to the California desert and back again between now and next summer.
lead_paragraph: What do the streets, storefronts and bodegas of South Williamsburg, Brooklyn, have to do with the deserts of southern California? It’s a question that the sculptor Halsey Rodman, who grew up in Davis, Calif., has been considering a lot lately, with two related projects in these radically opposed environments.

headline: Maria Bartiromo to Leave CNBC for Fox Business
abstract: Ms. Bartiromo, the anchor of CNBC’s “Closing Bell,” will join the Fox Business Network and Fox News next week.
lead_paragraph: Maria Bartiromo, one of the first women to become a star on television by reporting on business news, is leaving her longtime home at CNBC for its rival, the Fox Business Network.

headline: U.S. Poised to Announce $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
abstract: The deal with JPMorgan Chase over its mortgage practices, expected as soon as Tuesday, will detail how a $13 billion payout will be divvied up.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is set to announce a $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over the bank’s questionable mortgage practices in the run-up to the financial crisis, people briefed on the deal said on Monday, as prosecutors and the bank hashed out the final details of the deal.

headline: Commercial Breaks That Keep a Story Going
abstract: Target and ABC are teaming up for a holiday campaign using characters from three ABC sitcoms — “The Middle,” “Back in the Game” and “Modern Family.”
lead_paragraph: A YEAR after an innovative marketing effort for the Christmas shopping season brought together Target and ABC, the retailer and the network are teaming up again.

headline: Slowdown in Carbon Emissions Worldwide, but Coal Burning Continues to Grow
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Experts said the world remains far from meeting international goals on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Global emissions of carbon dioxide are slowing somewhat from the rapid pace of the last decade, new figures show, but growth in coal burning continues to outstrip the growth in other forms of energy, and experts said the world remains far from meeting international goals on climate change.

headline: Inmate Buses Sit at Rikers; New York City Courts Stalled
abstract: The buses that were supposed to take prisoners to court never left the jail, apparently a result of a job action by correction officers angry over a trial of two guards charged with misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of New York City corrections buses that were supposed to take prisoners to court on Monday never left Rikers Island, grinding many criminal courts in the city to a near halt.

headline: Researchers Work to Add More Anonymity to Bitcoin
abstract: Are people who buy and sell illegal wares online really anonymous? Some people say most online transactions leave a trail of digital breadcrumbs that point back to their real identity. But some researchers are trying to create extensions that change that.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week, Disruptions: A Digital Underworld Cloaked in Anonymity, I noted that the Deep Web, or Dark Internet, had mushroomed in recent years because of a growing belief that it was possible to remain anonymous online.

headline: Princeton University to Use Foreign Vaccine
abstract: The meningitis vaccine, which has been approved in Europe and Australia, is expected to be available on campus at no cost in early December.
lead_paragraph: Princeton University plans to offer students a meningitis vaccine not usually approved for use in the United States in an attempt to prevent an outbreak at the school from spreading, officials said on Monday.

headline: Dropbox Is Said to Seek $250 Million in Funding, Doubling Its Valuation
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data Storage', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Start-ups']
abstract: A five-year-old San Francisco start-up that allows users to access stored documents via the web is seeking funding that would value it at more than $8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Online storage, once a backwater of the Silicon Valley technology scene, is suddenly a hot commodity.

headline: Bloomberg Lays Off Staff in Sports and Culture
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'News and News Media', 'Culture (Arts)']
abstract: The news agency plans to focus more on finance and government.
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg News started laying off and reassigning employees on Monday, seeking to emphasize areas that promote growth and focus more on core subjects like finance and government.

headline: Cause of Gas Leak That Killed 2 Colorado Miners Is Sought
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Carbon Monoxide', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Inspectors said the two men died of carbon monoxide poisoning Sunday at a mining site in southwestern Colorado that has had a troubled safety record.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Federal mine safety inspectors on Monday were trying to determine the cause of an accident that killed two miners and injured 20 others near the mountain town of Ouray in southwestern Colorado.

headline: Egyptian Protesters Destroy Tahrir Square Monument Erected by Interim Government
abstract: Hours after the military-led government dedicated a memorial to the uprisings that toppled two authoritarian presidents in two years, protesters swarmed the monument.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Tuesday, 9:56 a.m. | Just hours after Egypt’s military-led interim government tried to cement its claim to revolutionary legitimacy — with the dedication of a memorial to the uprisings that toppled two authoritarian presidents in two years — protesters swarmed the monument in the center of Tahrir Square on Monday night and defaced it, chanting, “The revolution’s returned to Tahrir.”

headline: Plan to Redevelop South Street Seaport Includes Marina and 50-Story Tower
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The Howard Hughes Corporation, which controls the South Street Seaport under a lease with the city, says it wants to enliven the area and establish a destination for both tourists and New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: South Street Seaport, an often-neglected corner of Manhattan dedicated to enshrining New York’s seafaring past, has been battered by storms, recessions and poor management.

headline: A Lifesaving Treatment, and a Killer
abstract: Readers discuss the benefits and drawbacks of using buprenorphine for opioid addiction.

headline: TV Series Will Focus on N.H.L. Players in Olympics
abstract: Producers will track teams and leading players for a seven-hour series focusing on the Sochi Games and five outdoor stadium games during the league’s regular season.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L., once ambivalent about breaking up its 2013-14 season to enable players to participate in the 2014 Sochi Olympics, has come to embrace the break in its schedule. The league announced Monday that it has hired producers to make a seven-hour series that will track teams and players through the Olympics and five outdoor stadium games.

headline: At Swarovski’s New Outpost, a Look on the Bright Side
abstract: At Swarovski’s new store in Brooklyn, there is the promise of limited editions, exclusivity, uniqueness, insider access, perks, privileges and V.I.P. treatment.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, I believed that Swarovski was just a manufacturer of rhinestones, or “bling”: used to jazz up cellphone cases, waxed bikini lines and other assorted fripperies that began to emerge in developed countries as the previous millennium waned.

headline: As the 50th Anniversary Nears, Dallas Reflects
abstract: Readers from Dallas respond to a Sunday Review article about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Raising the Cigarette-Buying Age to 21
abstract: Dr. Steven M. Safyer of Montefiore Medical Center hails the legislation that will raise the age for buying cigarettes in New York City to 21.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jefferson in Quebec
abstract: Quebec’s ministers for democratic institutions and the Montreal region respond to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Google to Pay $17 Million to Settle Privacy Case
abstract: The case involved Google’s bypassing of privacy settings in Apple’s Safari browser to use cookies to track users and show them ads.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google agreed on Monday to pay $17 million to 37 states and the District of Columbia in a wide-reaching settlement over tracking consumers online without their knowledge.

headline: Colorado Governor Proposes Strict Limits on Greenhouse Gas Leaks From Drilling
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Methane', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: The new rules proposed by Gov. John W. Hickenlooper, a Democrat, would exceed existing federal regulations on emissions of methane and other gases from well sites.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper of Colorado proposed on Monday tough new limits on leaks of methane and other gases from well sites and storage tanks. Supporters called the limits, which would exceed existing federal rules, the most sweeping in the nation.

headline: Cheney Family Values
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Liz Cheney’s stated opposition to gay marriage smacks of calculation and callousness.
lead_paragraph: If Liz Cheney, whose bid for the Senate has always had a stench of extreme opportunism, wants to discuss traditions and values, I’m all for it. Let’s start here: Isn’t there a tradition of close-knit family members’ taking care not to wound one another? Is there not value in that?

headline: Yankees Set to Resume Cano Negotiations, With Sides Still Far Apart
abstract: The free-agent second baseman Robinson Cano is reportedly still seeking a 10-year deal for $310 million, figures the Yankees are said to be unwilling to meet.
lead_paragraph: Hal Steinbrenner said last week at the owners meetings in Orlando, Fla., that the Yankees would resume negotiations this week with the free-agent second baseman Robinson Cano. But it does not seem as if there is a great deal to talk about, at least not yet.

headline: New Market Benchmarks Show a Lack of Options
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A consensus of professional strategists became convinced months ago that compared with bonds, stocks were a good bet.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rallied past two psychological barriers Monday morning, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average over 16,000 and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index beyond 1,800 for the first time, as investors still saw opportunities in the market.

headline: Alabama Judges Retain the Right to Override Juries in Capital Sentencing
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Capital Punishment', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The Supreme Court turned down a challenge to a law that allows judges in Alabama to send a defendant to death row despite a jury’s recommendation of life in prison.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned down a challenge to an unusual Alabama capital-sentencing practice that has sent 95 defendants to death row despite jury determinations calling for life sentences.

headline: Many Wheels, but No Place to Ride Them
abstract: Dirt bike and A.T.V. enthusiasts find it hard  to find places to ride without interference from the authorities.
lead_paragraph: Dirt bike and A.T.V. enthusiasts find it hard  to find places to ride without interference from the authorities.

headline: Kenya: New Details on Mall Attackers
abstract: The attackers behind the siege of the Westgate shopping mall had been living in Nairobi and plotted the attack for several months, a Western official briefed on the investigation said.
lead_paragraph: The attackers behind the siege of the Westgate shopping mall that left more than 60 people dead in September had been living in Nairobi and plotted the attack for several months, a Western official briefed on the investigation said Monday. Kenyan officials say they believe they have determined the identities of the four attackers who stormed the mall. All four of the men are Somali citizens, though one of the men, previously identified as Hassan Abdi Dhuhulow, grew up in Norway. Remains recovered from the mall that are believed to be those of the attackers are still undergoing forensic testing at an F.B.I. laboratory, the Western official said. A Somali militant group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility for the attack. The four men entered the country from Somalia in June and lived in Nairobi’s Somali neighborhood, Eastleigh. Kenyan authorities initially said that up to 15 assailants were involved in the attack, but only four are visible on mall surveillance tapes. Four other men have been charged as accomplices.

headline: For New York City’s Dirt Bikers, There Is No Place to Ride
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES (ATV)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: Complaints about noisy dirt bikes and reckless driving by riders who disobey laws are increasing, with more than 200 cases reported this summer alone.
lead_paragraph: The young man tore down the asphalt, the roar of his dirt bike trailing like a comet’s tail. When it seemed he could not go any faster, he went higher, hauling the bike into a near-vertical wheelie but never slowing down. A dozen other riders crisscrossed his path, their own front wheels aloft to the perfect fall sky.

headline: Venezuela: Former Bank Official Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
abstract: The executive, María de los Angeles González, 55, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, suggesting there could be further revelations about corruption at the government-controlled bank, the Economic and Social Development Bank of Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: A former executive at a Venezuelan bank pleaded guilty in a New York federal court on Monday to charges stemming from a scheme in which she took bribes in exchange for steering millions of dollars of the bank’s business to an American brokerage firm. The executive, María de los Angeles González, 55, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, suggesting there could be further revelations about corruption at the government-controlled bank, the Economic and Social Development Bank of Venezuela, known as Bandes. A plea agreement signed by Ms. González indicated that the corruption she was involved in went much further than previously revealed and that she admitted involvement in several other payoff schemes at Bandes and another government-run bank where she worked as an officer, Industrial Bank of Venezuela. The agreement said that the charges that Ms. González pleaded guilty to carried sentences totaling up to 55 years in jail. Ms. González was arrested in Miami in May.

headline: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints
keywords: ['World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In Lower Manhattan, the security continues to be very tight — too tight for some New Yorkers who remember living in a more freewheeling city.
lead_paragraph: When United Airlines Flight 175 hit the South Tower, the windows in Mark Scherzer’s apartment collapsed inward in a fine spray of glass shards. Then the tower collapsed and a metal beam flew in, true as an arrow. Dust, inches thick, covered his floors, bed and shelves.

headline: Chile: Former President’s Coalition Kept in Check
abstract: Former President Michelle Bachelet was unable to elect enough lawmakers from her coalition to pass sweeping political proposals, but she still may be able to push through many of her social and economic policies if she is elected.
lead_paragraph: Former President Michelle Bachelet, a socialist who is favored to win a runoff election in December against a conservative candidate, Evelyn Matthei, was unable to elect enough lawmakers from her coalition to pass sweeping political proposals, but she still may be able to push through many of her social and economic policies if she is elected. Although the conservative Alliance bloc lost a considerable number of representatives in the lower house, its members retained their seats in the Senate, making it difficult for Ms. Bachelet’s New Majority coalition to pass constitutional amendments or overhaul the electoral system. Ms. Matthei’s far-right party, the Independent Democratic Union, suffered a serious blow in the lower house, losing nine of its 38 seats, while the Communist Party doubled its seats to six. Fewer than half of Chile’s potential 13.5 million voters turned out for the presidential election, the first one after voting was made voluntary.

headline: Egypt: Security Official Assassinated
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Gunmen killed a senior Egyptian security official whose responsibilities included investigating Muslim extremists, the Interior Ministry said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Gunmen killed a senior Egyptian security official whose responsibilities included investigating Muslim extremists, the Interior Ministry said Monday. The official, Lt. Col. Mohamed Mabrouk, was driving to work in Cairo on Sunday when gunmen fired on it, striking him seven times, according to state media. In September, the interior minister survived when a bomb blew up his convoy. Shootings of lesser security officers around the country have become a near daily occurrence, especially in the relatively lawless Sinai. Egyptian officials have attributed the attacks to Islamist extremists retaliating for the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and the repression of his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood. Colonel Mabrouk had been involved in the investigation and arrests of senior Brotherhood members in recent months, state media reported.

headline: Quickly Gaining Value
abstract: The price of a bitcoin on an exchange that converts them to dollars rose to $780 on Monday, a meteoric gain from its beginnings in 2010.
lead_paragraph: The price of a bitcoin on an exchange that converts them to dollars rose to $780 on Monday, a meteoric gain from its beginnings in 2010.

headline: Prosecutor in Racially Charged Shooting Case Near Detroit Is No Stranger to Spotlight
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Kym L. Worthy, who is viewed as meticulous, blunt and unshakable — sometimes to a fault — is prosecuting the fatal shooting of a black woman by a white man in a Detroit suburb.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For two weeks, the pressure on the prosecutor’s office here steadily grew.

headline: Regulators See Value in Bitcoin, and Investors Hasten to Agree
abstract: Federal officials told a Senate hearing that virtual currencies like bitcoin offered real benefits for the financial system.
lead_paragraph: The virtual currency bitcoin took a big step toward the mainstream on Monday as federal authorities signaled their willingness to accept it as a legitimate payment alternative.

headline: Central African Republic Stirs Concern
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, raised the possibility that thousands of international peacekeeping troops in Africa might have to be temporarily redeployed in the Central African Republic, one of the most unstable on the continent.
lead_paragraph: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, raised the possibility on Monday that thousands of international peacekeeping troops in Africa might have to be temporarily redeployed in the Central African Republic, one of the most unstable on the continent. In a dire report, Mr. Ban said an African Union force that was set to assume peacekeeping and security responsibilities in the Central African Republic might not be ready in time for its December deployment schedule. If there were a “precipitous deterioration,” Mr. Ban said, the United Nations could respond by moving soldiers from neighboring peacekeeping missions, like those in the Democratic Republic of Congo or Sudan, with the approval of the Security Council and countries contributing troops. Outside Bangui, the capital, government authority is nonexistent, Mr. Ban said, and clashes between rebels and their opponents have become increasingly brutal and sectarian. “This cycle, if not addressed now, threatens to degenerate into a countrywide religious and ethnic divide, with the potential to spiral into an uncontrollable situation, including atrocity crimes, with serous national and regional implications,” he said.

headline: Syd Field, Who Wrote the Book on Writing Screenplays, Dies at 77
abstract: Thanks to Mr. Field, a teacher who wrote the definitive guide to screenwriting, the term “plot points” is in the filmmaking vocabulary.
lead_paragraph: The term “plot point” appeared in The New York Times fewer than 10 times during the century or so before 1979. Since then, it has appeared more than 200 times.

headline: Despite Storms and Injuries, Bears Stay on Playoff Track
abstract: The Bears rallied to a 23-20 overtime victory Sunday, and their 6-4 record is good enough for a share of the N.F.C. North lead.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — Monday morning dawned sunny and bright in the Chicago area, a day after a series of tornadoes touched down across Illinois and high-powered wind and heavy rainfall pummeled the city.

headline: A New G.O.P. Excuse for Doing Nothing
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The stumbles in the rollout of the Obama administration’s health reform are frustrating, but they are not a broad indictment of government.
lead_paragraph: With unrestrained glee, Republicans are using the calamitous debut of the Affordable Care Act as their latest justification for undermining all of health care reform. But they’re not stopping there. The Obama administration’s fumbling is apparently a good excuse for them to do nothing on immigration reform, on a budget agreement, and on any other initiative coming out of the White House.

headline: Barbara Park, Author of Junie B. Jones Series, Dies at 66
abstract: Ms. Park’s best-selling books starred a sassy grade schooler with an imperfect grasp of English grammar who always found herself in some sort of predicament.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Park, whose children’s books starring Junie B. Jones, a 6-year-old dispenser of abundant opinions, Runyonesque wisecracks and dubious syntax, have sold tens of millions of copies and delighted all but the most grammatically puritanical parents and teachers, died on Friday at her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 66.

headline: The Internet: A Welcome Distraction
abstract: My writing brain has been waiting for something exactly like the dizzyingly overfull, warp-speed web.
lead_paragraph: Every time somebody says to me, “It’s so impressive how you manage to get writing done despite being on Facebook/Twitter/etc. all the time,” I cringe. I’ve been hit by a backhanded compliment. I’m surfing, tweeting and emailing — leaving my digital prints everywhere and probably picking up some nasty computer viruses — while serious writers are working pristinely, heroically beyond the clutches of the Internet.

headline: Death Meted Out by Politicians in Robes
abstract: In Alabama, a bizarre arrangement allows elected judges to override a jury verdict of life in prison and unilaterally impose a death sentence.
lead_paragraph: In nearly all of the 32 states that permit capital punishment, a jury makes the final decision on whether a defendant will live or die. Not so in Alabama, where elected judges may override a jury verdict of life in prison and unilaterally impose a death sentence.

headline: Europeans Fault American Safety Effort in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)']
abstract: An official from a European group of retailers claimed that American retailers were trying to avoid paying for safety improvements at factories and criticized an inspection effort by Walmart.
lead_paragraph: Tensions broke into the open on Monday involving two large groups of retailers — one overwhelmingly American, the other dominated by Europeans — that have formed to improve factory safety in Bangladesh.

headline: Flawed Gauge for Cholesterol Risk Poses a New Challenge for Cardiologists
abstract: Outdated data used to create an online risk calculator will make fixing the tool difficult, raising concerns that patients will be skeptical of new treatment guidelines.
lead_paragraph: This week, cardiologists learned that a new online calculator meant to help them determine a patient’s suitability for cholesterol treatment was flawed, doubling the estimated risk of heart attack or stroke for the average patient. But fixing it would not be easy, because it is based on older data, and heart attack and stroke rates today are much lower than in decades past, meaning that people are at less risk than might be expected from historical extrapolations.

headline: Cholesterol Guidelines Under Attack
abstract: Potential flaws in a new risk calculator may put millions on statin drugs unnecessarily.
lead_paragraph: Patients in good cardiovascular health would be well advised to stay away for now from following the cholesterol guidelines issued last week by the nation’s two leading heart organizations.

headline: She Vanquished a Cruel Addiction, but Challenges Remain
abstract: After Della Murray kicked a crack cocaine habit, she wrestled with bouts of depression and has struggled to make ends meet.
lead_paragraph: Della Murray just didn’t care.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: There’s something quite odd about the developing narrative about Timothy F. Geithner’s move, because it is hard to argue Mr. Geithner ever spun through the revolving door even once.
lead_paragraph: Within 24 hours of Timothy F. Geithner’s announcement on Saturday that he would join Warburg Pincus, the private equity firm, a parade of naysayers emerged, almost like clockwork, to criticize the former Treasury secretary’s move as a prime example of the evil of the government’s revolving door.

headline: Labor Panel Finds Illegal Punishments at Walmart
abstract: Walmart denied the accusations and said it would defend itself, asserting that its actions were “legal and justified.”
lead_paragraph: Walmart illegally disciplined and fired employees over strikes and protests, the National Labor Relations Board said on Monday.

headline: Are We Alone in the Universe?
abstract: Don’t believe the latest hype about life on other planets.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — THE recent announcement by a team of astronomers that there could be as many as 40 billion habitable planets in our galaxy has further fueled the speculation, popular even among many distinguished scientists, that the universe is teeming with life.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Advice for the power players at Hollywood’s coming round of black-tie galas: Don’t leave your seat to table-hop.

headline: Police Give New Meaning to ‘Taped Confession’
abstract: The police wanted to ensure that the suspects would not be able to collude on their statements before they could be interrogated.
lead_paragraph: Taped confessions are increasingly common in Chinese police stations. But inventive police officers in Huizhou, far southern China, added a singular twist: literally taping up the would-be confessors.

headline: A Diver’s Rise, and Swift Death, at the Limits of a Growing Sport
abstract: Nicholas Mevoli’s rise from novice to record-holder in little more than a year serves both as an inspiration and as a dire warning to divers whose stars rise as the depths they reach plunge.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Mevoli saved money from an assortment of jobs to pay for the bottomless pursuit of holding his breath and sinking his body as far as possible into the ocean.

headline: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The disagreement between American and Israeli leaders over a proposed deal to freeze Iran’s nuclear program is about more than negotiating tactics — it reflects a clash of fundamental goals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To the Israeli government, the preliminary deal with Iran that the Obama administration is trying to seal this week is a giveaway to a government that has spent two decades building a vast nuclear program. It enshrines the status quo — at a time when the Iranians are within reach of the technical capability to build a bomb — and rewards some unproven leaders with cash and sanctions relief.

headline: Police Say Officer Killed Man Who Threatened With Knife

headline: Giants Volunteer for Extra Cowboys Preparation

lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, the Giants were obliged to go to the team’s practice complex for only a weight-lifting session. Then the players were free to do as they wanted. Since Tuesday is their customary day off, the Giants were staring at what amounted to almost a two-day break from practice, meetings or film study.

lead_paragraph: A casual reunion of three longtime buddies slouching unprofitably through their 30s ultimately betrays a darker purpose in “Small Engine Repair,” a raw, funny and well-tooled new play written by and featuring John Pollono, who is making an impressive, double-barreled Off Broadway debut.

headline: His Honor? Toronto’s Mayor Rampages On, to City’s Shame
abstract: Despite the bizarre antics of Mayor Rob Ford, most notably his use of crack, he will likely remain at the helm of Canada’s largest city until his term ends next year.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The end did not come for Rob Ford, the mayor of this city, when he proclaimed his proclivity for oral sex on live television.

headline: Hollande’s Assertive Role in Foreign Policy Is a Good Fit for France
abstract: President François Hollande of France is building a far more confident image abroad than at home, a striking contrast that shows how much his nation values a role in world affairs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the past few weeks, President François Hollande of France has been booed at a solemn national ceremony and forced to retreat on an element of his economic agenda. He has seen his nation’s credit rating downgraded and watched as his already-low public support continued to erode.

headline: Another Website, Another Problem for Obama
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Some supporters who tried to log in to hear the president defend his health care law could not hear him because the website of the group behind the call failed to work for them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some supporters who tried to log in to hear President Obama defend his embattled health care law on Monday night were unable to hear him because the website of the group behind the call, Organizing for Action, failed to work for them.

headline: Libération Under Fire
abstract: A lone shooter has turned our newspaper’s office in the middle of Paris into a bloody crime scene.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Here at Libération, we have blood in the hall. A war zone in the middle of Paris, right by the Place de la Republique. In 2013.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: A somewhat revamped version of the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is planned for Las Vegas in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The $75 million Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the most expensive theatrical production in history, will close in early January after months of declining ticket sales, one of the lead producers said on Monday night. A somewhat revamped version of the show is being planned for Las Vegas in 2015, according to the producer, Jeremiah J. Harris.

headline: Stop Animal Circus Shows, Advocates Tell Government
keywords: ['ACROBATS AND ACROBATICS', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ANIMALS', 'Circuses', 'Tigers']
abstract: Animal rights advocates are trying to stop performances by Bengal tigers, Asian elephants and chimpanzees at a major, government-backed circus show, saying they are cruel.
lead_paragraph: With Bengal tigers, Asian elephants, chimpanzees, parrots and poodles among dozens of animals due to perform at an international circus in southern China starting on Wednesday, more than 30 animal rights organizations have petitioned the government, a partner in the event, to cancel the shows because of cruelty to the animals.

headline: Felton Is Missing Shots, and Those He Guards Are Not
abstract: Hampered by a strained hamstring, point guard Raymond Felton is shooting below his career average and struggling defensively.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Raymond Felton was a spectator for most of Monday’s practice. He sat on a training table next to Tyson Chandler, whose fractured right leg was no longer encased in a protective boot. This counted as progress for the Knicks, whose training facility has doubled as a sanitarium this season.

headline: Fracking’s Achilles’ Heel
abstract: Colorado’s new rules will help fulfill the promise of natural gas.
lead_paragraph: It’s not very often that someone starts his career as a geologist and then winds up as governor, but John Hickenlooper, the governor of Colorado, can make that claim. “We had fracking when I was a working geologist in 1981,” he told me on Monday. “It was very primitive. What really changed the world is when we got horizontal drilling. It was a technique that allowed you to recover a lot more natural gas.”

headline: Songs of Remembrance for Voices Now Silenced
abstract: Mourners gathered on Monday at a Brooklyn bar where the band Yellow Dogs used to rehearse to remember three Iranian musicians who were killed by a fellow Iranian last week.
lead_paragraph: The photos showed them as they had been: Arash Farazmand, 28, bent over his drums; his brother, Soroush Farazmand, 27, with his guitar; their friend and roommate, Ali Eskandarian, 35, smiling as he sang into a microphone. Candles burned below their names, illuminating messages of love and remembrance left for them in English and Persian: “I love you”; “thank you for the beautiful moments”; three hearts.

headline: A Talk That Stirred Fear of Antigay Bias Is Postponed at a Bronx High School
abstract: Cardinal Spellman High School had scheduled a retired priest to address parents about the issue of same-sex attraction.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Pope Francis spoke compassionately about gay people last summer — saying, “Who am I to judge?” — Roman Catholics around the world have debated the meaning of his words.

headline: Billy Hardwick, Hall of Fame Bowler, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Hardwick, the first of only six bowlers to win the sport’s triple crown, was a right-handed bowler with a fluid style, far smoother than many of today’s power players.
lead_paragraph: Billy Hardwick, the first bowler to win all three of the most prestigious Professional Bowlers Association tournaments, or the triple crown, died Saturday near his home in Bradenton, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Natural Disasters or 'Acts of God'?
abstract: When the law and people of faith refer to an event as an "act of God," is that constructive or a distraction?

headline: In Middle of Mexico, a Middle Class Rises
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Series', 'Automobiles']
abstract: In the mostly poor state of Guanajuato, long known as one of the country’s main sources of illegal immigrants to the United States, a new Mexico has begun to emerge.
lead_paragraph: GUANAJUATO, Mexico — A decade ago, Ivan Zamora, 23, might have already left for the United States. Instead, he graduated in May from a gleaming new university here, then moved on to an engineering internship at one of the many multinational companies just beyond the campus gates.

headline: With His Career Winding Down, Iginla Focuses on Winning a Stanley Cup
abstract: Jarome Iginla, now in his 17th season, has joined the Boston Bruins in his pursuit of a Stanley Cup championship, which has eluded him.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Jarome Iginla calls it “the driver.” It has nothing to do with golf clubs or chauffeurs, but instead refers to a mind-set, a laserlike pursuit of the missing item on an almost certain Hall of Fame résumé: a Stanley Cup title.

headline: Latest Release of Documents on N.S.A. Includes 2004 Ruling on Email Surveillance
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'E-Mail', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Obama administration on Monday made public a trove of documents, including a court ruling that approved a program to track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration released hundreds of pages of newly declassified documents related to National Security Agency surveillance late Monday, including an 87-page ruling in which the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court first approved a program to systematically track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.

headline: John Edwards Revisits His Past, Hanging Law Shingle Again
abstract: The path back for Mr. Edwards began when his legal troubles ended last year. Prosecutors had charged him with misusing nearly $1 million in campaign donations.
lead_paragraph: Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer.

headline: Casting Light on Little-Known Story of Albania Rescuing Jews From Nazis
keywords: ['Rescues', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A national creed called besa obligates Albanians to provide shelter and safe passage for anyone seeking protection.
lead_paragraph: There were a handful of European nations where the Nazi killing machine sputtered, but few seem more remarkable and less illuminated than Albania.

headline: Nets Start Fast but Lose Momentum and the Game
abstract: The Nets are winless when being outscored in the third quarter, which was the case in their defeat Monday to the Portland Trail Blazers.
lead_paragraph: Up and down the Nets’ fortunes have bobbed through the early part of this season. Good vibes have remained ephemeral. Success has been fleeting.

headline: Sticking With Quarterback Grows More Risky for Ryan
abstract: With 20 turnovers in his first 10 games, Geno Smith has had the same troubles as Mark Sanchez did in his rookie year, testing Rex Ryan’s capacity for tolerance.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan has been burdened with turnover-prone quarterbacks during his tenure as the Jets’ coach, and he has handled them with incredible patience. Only once, after the Week 15 mess in Tennessee last year, has he benched the starter.

headline: After N.S.A. Disclosures, Yahoo Moves to Encrypt Internal Traffic
abstract: Google, Yahoo and other technology companies are feverishly enabling new security features in an effort to assure users that they are doing everything possible to secure their data.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the revelations of Edward Snowden, technology companies are feverishly enabling new security features in an effort to assure users, particularly abroad, that they are doing everything possible to secure their data from hackers and the National Security Agency.

headline: Medicare Part D: Republican Budget-Busting
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ten years ago, Republicans closed ranks to push through Medicare coverage for prescription drugs, misleading the public while adding billions to the federal deficit, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | defrock
abstract: This word has appeared in five New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: defrock •\(ˌ)de-ˈfräk\• verb

headline: Hawkins Leaves Mets for Rockies
abstract: LaTroy Hawkins, 40, followed Marlon Byrd’s lead, becoming the latest Met to play well enough to price himself out of the team’s plans.
lead_paragraph: LaTroy Hawkins, 40, followed Marlon Byrd’s lead, becoming the latest Met to play well enough to price himself out of the team’s plans. Hawkins agreed to a one-year, $2.5 million contract with the Colorado Rockies, and will have a chance to be the team’s closer, according to a source with knowledge of the negotiations. In 72 relief appearances with the Mets, Hawkins compiled a 2.93 earned run average and had 13 saves.

headline: Another Animated Take on Bloomberg News
abstract: The suspension of a prize-winning reporter has provided more inspiration for the animators at Next Media of Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Next Media Animation of Taiwan is staying at the vanguard of coverage of the Bloomberg News self-censorship saga. It has posted its second take on the scandal — which, of course, Bloomberg says is not a scandal. Top Bloomberg editors have denied killing a story on a Chinese tycoon and his ties to Communist Party leaders for political reasons, despite accounts from several Bloomberg employees that that was the case.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:45 P.M. (IFC) JACKIE BROWN (1997) Pam Grier, above, stars as Jackie Brown, a flight attendant who makes ends meet by smuggling money from Mexico to the United States for a gun dealer named Ordell Robbie (Samuel L. Jackson) in this adaptation of the book “Rum Punch,” by Elmore Leonard, written for the screen and directed by Quentin Tarantino. When she is caught by a government agent (Michael Keaton), Jackie seeks to escape her menial existence with the help of a kindly bail bondsman (Robert Forster). “Among the best news about the film is that Samuel L. Jackson’s role is even splashier than the one he had in ‘Pulp Fiction’ and that his performance is even more of a treat,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “The film more than justifies its long, happy stretches of simply watching Ordell work his scams on the unsuspecting.”

headline: News Quiz | November 19, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: India’s Chief Climate Change Negotiator Ravi Shankar Prasad
keywords: ['Energy Efficiency', 'Foreign Aid', 'Global Warming', 'International Relations', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Mr. Prasad spoke about India’s expectations from the annual United Nations climate change conference in Warsaw, Poland.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Poland — The annual United Nations climate change conference, which runs from Nov. 11 to 22, started with an emotional appeal from the Philippine negotiator Yeb Sano, who declared that he would be fasting “until a meaningful outcome is in sight” in the wake of the  “staggering” devastation from Typhoon Haiyan in his country.

headline: Beirut Bombs Strike at Iran as Assad’s Ally
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The attack appeared to broaden the violent pattern of division across the Middle East linked to the civil war in Syria, where Iran has emerged as a powerful ally of the government side.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A double bombing struck the Iranian Embassy compound in Beirut on Tuesday, in the deadliest assault on Iran’s interests since it emerged as the most forceful backer of the Syrian government against an armed insurgency. The frontal attack struck a symbol of the country’s powerful influence in Lebanon and neighboring Syria.
