abstract: Answer this question about the Gettysburg Address.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Tweets From the Past Make History Come Alive
abstract: How is “historical tweeting” different from “live tweeting”?
lead_paragraph: In “History Comes to Life With Tweets From Past,” Noam Cohen writes about current “historical tweeting” projects.

headline: Chinese Nobel Winner Appealing Subversion Conviction
abstract: A court in Beijing sentenced Liu Xiaobao to 11 years in prison  for advocating wide-ranging political changes that sought greater democracy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned Chinese dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, will challenge his 2009 conviction on subversion charges in court, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Dutch Firm to Spin Off Drug-Making Business in $2.6 Billion Deal
abstract: The life and materials sciences company Royal DSM said on Tuesday that it would form a joint venture with the New York private equity firm JLL Partners.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Dutch life and materials sciences company Royal DSM said on Tuesday that it would spin off its pharmaceutical manufacturing business into a $2.6 billion joint venture with the New York private equity firm JLL Partners.

headline: What Does Cancer Smell Like?
abstract: Why scientists are putting stock in an electronic nose.
lead_paragraph: On a lab bench in Philadelphia sits a tiny box lined with nearly invisible nanotubes and gold. A clear plastic pipe runs through it, and a thicket of pins, each sprouting a red or blue wire, protrudes from its end. As air from the pipe wafts over the nanotubes, electrical signals surge out of the box along the wire threads. The whole apparatus is situated near a vial of blood, “sniffing” the air above it through the pipe.

headline: Why Is Turkey Cheaper When Demand Is Higher?
keywords: ['Turkeys', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: It’s a trend that seems to defy Econ 101: In early November, the price of frozen whole turkeys drops. Economists can’t agree on why.
lead_paragraph: When you do your Thanksgiving shopping this week, you will encounter two vastly different options for the centerpiece: an expensive heritage, organic, antibiotic-free, freshly killed turkey; or a relatively cheap, mass-produced, rock-solid-frozen bird. The frozen birds are a pretty attractive deal — especially because this time of year, they are unusually cheap. According to government data, frozen whole-turkey prices drop significantly every November; over the last decade, retail prices have fallen an average of 9 percent between October and November.

headline: Has Facebook Lost Its Edge?
abstract: What evidence do you see that the site is still going strong — or that its popularity is fading?
lead_paragraph: Last week Facebook offered billions of dollars to buy Snapchat, the social media app that lets users send posts that disappear shortly after being viewed. When the yet-to-be-profitable upstart refused the whopping 10-digit offer, many have started asking the same question: Is Facebook losing its edge? What do you think?

headline: Josef Koudelka: Formed by the World
abstract: Josef Koudelka has traveled the globe, photographing on his own terms. But as he puts the world in his viewfinder, the world shapes him in return.
lead_paragraph: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: For Young Typhoon Survivors, Return of Play Is a Sign of Hope
abstract: While food and water remain scarce more than a week after Typhoon Haiyan, aid groups have begun setting up areas where children can try to have a little fun.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — At a typhoon refugee center on Samar Island in the Philippines, the traumatized children have slowly begun adjusting to their new normal.

headline: U.S. Budget Battles Seen as a Global Drag on Growth
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development forecast cited risks from another fiscal crisis in Washington and cooling emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Nervousness about United States monetary policy and fears of a budget and borrowing breakdown in Washington are creating a bigger drag on the global economy than expected, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned on Tuesday. The report was a more pessimistic view of global growth than six months ago.

headline: Daily Report: Dropbox Said to Seek $250 Million in New Funding
abstract: If successful, the new funding round would double the online data-storage company’s valuation, to more than $8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Online storage, once a backwater of the Silicon Valley technology scene, is suddenly a hot commodity, Quentin Hardy and David Gelles report.

headline: New York Today: Beware of Leaves
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: foliage and trains don’t mix, chilly sunshine and Spider-Man’s final flights.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:53 a.m. | Every year around this time, a silent menace threatens the region’s transit system.

headline: Voter Turnout in Nepal Is Heavy Despite Violence
abstract: Maoists in two areas disrupted the election of a body charged with writing a constitution, but the majority of citizens are said to have cast ballots.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Voters crowded polling stations across Nepal on Tuesday, defying attempts by a powerful Maoist group and other parties to disrupt or prevent new elections for an assembly to write a new constitution.

headline: Can ‘Right-Wing’ Grandparents’ Views on Homosexuality Be Changed?
abstract: A mother finds herself caught in a Thanksgiving quandary involving her parents and her lesbian daughter.
lead_paragraph: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Assessing a Kevin O’Leary Investment on ‘Shark Tank’
abstract: Total Merchant Resources is another player in the alternative-lending industry. But small-business borrowers now have less expensive options.
lead_paragraph: Recently, when I sat down to watch the ABC reality show “Shark Tank” with my children, I was surprised to see a merchant cash advance lender, Total Merchant Resources, pitching the Sharks. Typically, the companies that present on the show offer a unique service or product. Instead, Total Merchant Resources is a “me too” player in the highly commoditized and competitive alternative-lending industry.

headline: Storm Brings Flooding and Destruction to Sardinia
abstract: The Italian government declared a state of emergency on the island on Tuesday after a torrential rainstorm killed at least 16 people.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Streets and fields were flooded, homes and cars were submerged, and at least 16 people were killed on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia after 17 inches of rain — half a year’s worth — pummeled the island over a 24-hour period.

headline: ‘Take Me to the River,’ From Al Green to Song Dogs
abstract: The song Al Green co-wrote and recorded became a big Talking Heads hit and has been covered by Annie Lennox and a new band, Song Dogs.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Edwards Opens Law Firm
abstract: John Edwards is opening a new law practice. | The Justice Department is set to announce the final details of a $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase. | Dropbox is seeking $250 million in financing. | Timothy F. Geithner’s new job presents less of a conflict than many critics claim.
lead_paragraph: “Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer,” Peter Lattman and Kim Severson write in DealBook. “Now, Mr. Edwards is returning to his roots and opening a new law practice. The plaintiffs’ firm, Edwards Kirby, reunites him with his former partner, David F. Kirby, and includes on its payroll his eldest daughter, Cate Edwards.”

headline: Fujifilm Finds Niche With Old-Style Cameras That Mask a High-Tech Core
abstract: Fujifilm’s line of compact, mirrorless cameras has attracted a following by digital photographers looking to lighten their load.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Like many professional photographers, Irwin Wong, who shoots pictures for Japanese magazines, relies on digital single-lens reflex cameras for the bulk of his work — “bulk” being the operative word.

headline: My Mother, the Secret Communist
keywords: ['Communism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Baby Boomers', 'Children and Childhood', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: My mother never spoke of her activism and forbade my father to speak of it, but it doubtless left its indelible impression on her and me.
lead_paragraph: In 1928, my mother, Mary, dropped out of Hunter College to enter the family business: the domestic and international advancement of communism.

headline: International Style
abstract: By coincidence, the timing of our stylebook revisions dovetailed with the rebranding of our global editions as The International New York Times. As part of that integration, our colleagues in Paris, London and Hong Kong have made a Herculean effort to adopt our stylebook and largely eliminate the variations and exceptions The Herald Tribune had maintained.
lead_paragraph: This week, a few more highlights from the recent revisions in The Times’s stylebook.

headline: In Performance: Zachary Quinto of ‘The Glass Menagerie’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from the Tennessee Williams play, now on Broadway at the Booth Theater.
lead_paragraph: In the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams’s memory play “The Glass Menagerie,” Zachary Quinto plays Tom Wingfield, an aspiring writer and warehouse worker — and the play’s narrator — who lives in a cramped St. Louis apartment with his mother, Amanda, and his sister, Laura. In this scene, Tom talks about watching couples at a dance hall across from their home. The show, directed by John Tiffany, continues through Feb. 23 at the Booth Theater.

headline: China Offers Hospital Ship to the Philippines
abstract: Widespread criticism of China’s slow response to the devastation in the Philippines from Typhoon Haiyan has awakened the Chinese authorities to the damage done to the country’s image.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:04 a.m. ET | After an outsized international effort to help the Philippines that has been notable for China’s slow response, it appears the Chinese authorities are trying to reverse the damage to their country’s image.

headline: After 3 Fires, Safety Agency Opens Inquiry Into Tesla Model S
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Batteries']

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A federal safety investigation of the Tesla Motors electric Model S sedan announced on Tuesday comes at a critical juncture for the car and the company.

headline: No Money, and a Growing Line at Starbucks
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A line at Starbucks seethed as a customer tried to pay for his espresso using his iPhone app.

headline: Mapping Bitcoin
abstract: An American expatriate has made a site that maps all the bitcoin trades in real time. One striking thing is China’s nonstop participation, outstripping all of Europe. The map’s creator says it shows bitcoin is a truly borderless currency. It may also be a sign of a bubble.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin, the popular Internet currency, is on the map in more ways than one.

headline: Obstruction of Gossip
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: A famous Israeli singer is being investigated for unlawful sexual relations. Everyone knows who he is, but no one is allowed to say.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Nov. 20, 2013 | The singer mentioned in this post can now be named; the gag order has been lifted. He is Eyal Golan.

headline: Guwahati’s Cosmetic Development
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Floods', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media', 'Parenting', 'Rain', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Television']
abstract: The author writes about the changes that his hometown has undergone over the years.
lead_paragraph: “I come from Guwahati—a small town in the northeastern part of India,” I used to tell my friends in Minnesota, until one person asked me how large is Guwahati. When I answered, he looked at me shocked, “A small town of only 1.4 million people?” I smiled sheepishly because it was partly true, and partly untrue. Untrue because I had grown up believing that my Guwahati is a small town. True because, nowadays even I suspect that during my absence over the years—like a young girl in a large family — Guwahati has as if stealthily grown up without my notice.

headline: The Geezers Are Not Alright
abstract: Getting the facts on retirement right.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post editorial board wants to cut Medicare and Social Security. That has been its consistent position as long as I can remember. And what it advocates, always, are cuts in benefits, not costs — that is, while it may give lip service to efforts to control health-care costs (which seem to be going surprisingly well, in one of the untold success stories of Obamacare), what it has pushed repeatedly are things like a rise in the Medicare age. These are the kind of moves that are considered serious inside the Beltway. And as you might imagine, the Post has gone wild over recent suggestions that Social Security should be expanded, not cut.

headline: Changing Coaches Has Improved Fortunes in N.F.L.
abstract: Coaching hires typically takes years to evaluate, but all eight new coaches in the league are either exceeding expectations or providing hope for the future.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. teams are rarely patient. Owners and general managers are more apt to replace a struggling coach than to support him. This past off-season, eight teams switched coaches, not including New Orleans, which welcomed the return of Sean Payton after his one-year suspension. A coaching hire typically takes years to evaluate, but through 12 weeks, all eight coaches are either exceeding expectations or providing hope for the future.

headline: Carriers Reject a ‘Kill Switch’ for Preventing Cellphone Theft
abstract: Lawmakers in San Francisco and New York are pushing cellphone makers to adopt a so-called kill switch that would allow users to deactivate a phone after it had been stolen. But the cellphone carriers are not on board.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in San Francisco and New York are pushing cellphone makers to adopt a so-called kill switch that would allow users to deactivate their phone remotely, discouraging criminals from stealing phones. But the cellphone carriers are not on board.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Uniform Wares Watch
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: the gift of time.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Sunday Style in Johannesburg
abstract: At the Maboneng Precinct in South Africa’s largest city, locals find style inspiration from their parents and African prints worn in a modern way.
lead_paragraph: At the Maboneng Precinct in South Africa’s largest city, locals find style inspiration from their parents and African prints worn in a modern way.

headline: Progressive Caucus Seeks to Influence Race for New York Council Speaker
abstract: Brad Lander, a Democrat from Brooklyn, is a leader of the group, which has committed to voting as a bloc and is trying to limit the power of the speaker’s office.
lead_paragraph: The populist groundswell that swept Bill de Blasio to victory in New York’s mayoral election is reshaping the City Council as well, with a cadre of fiercely liberal council members demanding a voice in choosing that body’s next speaker.

headline: The ‘Catch an Illegal Immigrant’ Game
abstract: It’s wonderful when righteous anger finds a means of expression shrewder than outrage.
lead_paragraph: The chapter of Young Conservatives of Texas at the University of Texas at Austin is planning on doing a silly thing on Wednesday. It has announced a game it calls “Catch an Illegal Immigrant,” in which students will walk around campus with the words “Illegal Immigrant” pinned to their clothing. People who spot and escort these students back to Y.C.T. will be given a $25 gift card.  The organization says it means to provoke a thoughtful discussion of a hot-button issue, but that is just a straight-faced put-on for what is really a sophomoric provocation.

headline: Another Taylor Rule
abstract: It’s always time to raise rates.
lead_paragraph: Or at least it seems to be a new rule — namely, pick whatever price index makes the point you want, even if it’s not at all the price index you would normally use.

headline: Chairman of Co-Operative Group Resigns Amid Scandal
abstract: Len Wardle resigned on Tuesday, after a former top executive of the British conglomerate’s banking business was said to have been filmed buying illegal drugs.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:05 p.m. | LONDON – The chairman of the British food and financial services conglomerate Co-operative Group resigned on Tuesday amid media reports that the former top executive of its banking business was purportedly caught on video buying illegal drugs.

headline: Waging War on a Shoestring
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The theme at a conference on security challenges was self-inflicted wounds to military readiness.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Ca. – The four-star commander of all Air Force combat jets earned an audible gasp from the audience of national security specialists with his disclosure about American vulnerabilities brought on by the spending stalemate back in Washington.

headline: Photo of Palestinian Mother Was the Wrong Choice
abstract: Times editors agree that the photo choice represented an error in judgment.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of readers wrote to me in recent days to protest the prominent use of a photograph that accompanied an article in The Times last Thursday.

headline: Report Documents a Rise in Fatal Shootings by New York City’s Police Officers
abstract: A rise in deadly shootings coincided with the highest number of officers wounded by gunfire in the line of duty since the late 1990s, a Police Department report found.
lead_paragraph: A knife-wielding man shot dead by New York police officers in the doorway of his Harlem apartment. An officer struck by a bullet in the base of his skull. A marked police van rattled by seven bullets as a group of officers sat inside.

headline: Whom or What Are Literary Prizes For?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'National Book Awards']
abstract: Daniel Mendelsohn and Jennifer Szalai on the mystery and appeal of book awards.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Jennifer Szalai on the value of literary prizes.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2013: Find Your Favorites
abstract: Every year at Well, we take the turkey off the table and shift our culinary focus to the delicious fruit and vegetable side dishes, main dishes, appetizers and desserts that make the Thanksgiving meal so special.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, Well pays tribute to the best part of the Thanksgiving table — the vegetable side dishes!

headline: Grace Club Gets a Redesign by Thom Filicia
abstract: The Grace Club in the Turks & Caicos will get a makeover by the designer Thom Filicia.
lead_paragraph: Grace Bay Club, an upscale hotel in the Turks & Caicos, is giving itself a 20th-birthday present: a remodeling job by the celebrated designer Thom Filicia.

headline: Image of the Day: November 19
abstract: Bharatiya Mahila Bank is India’s first state owned women’s bank.

headline: A Short Sneak Peek at a New Robert Mitchum Documentary
abstract: The filmmaker Bruce Weber showed 30 minutes of footage from a work in progress about Robert Mitchum.
lead_paragraph: For the last 12 years, by his own count, the photographer and filmmaker Bruce Weber has been assembling a documentary about Robert Mitchum, the movie star (and sometime recording artist) who died in 1997. It sounds like a natural counterpart to Mr. Weber’s gossamer 1988 masterpiece, “Let’s Get Lost,” about the jazz trumpet player Chet Baker.

headline: U.S. Striker Keeps Eye on His Next Target
abstract: Terrence Boyd is hoping a game in Austria, where he makes his living, will help pave a path to Brazil next summer.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The United States national soccer team will conclude its 2013 schedule with an exhibition against Austria on Tuesday. The result of the game will be of little consequence, but for many players it will be an important opportunity to make a case to be on next year’s World Cup roster.

headline: Israel Rejects Bid to Free Suspected Qaeda Operative
abstract: Israel’s Supreme Court ruled that a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian detainee held for more than three years without trial was too dangerous to release.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected an appeal for the release of a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian who has been held in Israel without trial for more than three years, accused by the Israeli authorities of being a biological weapons expert in the service of Al Qaeda.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Equity in the Workplace
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Paid Time Off', 'Discrimination', 'Family Leaves']
abstract: A letter writer urges legislative actions to close the gender gap. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Typhoon Haiyan’s Epicenter
abstract: The Times’s Andrew Jacobs travels to Guiuan, on Samar Island, the Philippines, where residents are trying to resume normal life amid the devastation.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Andrew Jacobs travels to Guiuan, on Samar Island, the Philippines, where residents are trying to resume normal life amid the devastation.

headline: On YouTube, Iranian Minister Says ‘Join Us’ in Ending Crisis
abstract: The foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, has repeatedly sought to set the tone and context of continuing meetings with world powers on Iran’s nuclear energy pursuits through video and social media.
lead_paragraph: As soft piano music plays in the background, the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, strides through a vast, elegant hallway, skips down carpeted steps and pushes through glass-paneled doors. Then, seated, he looks directly at a video camera and asks: “What is dignity? What is respect? Are they negotiable? Is there a price tag?”

headline: The Other Gettysburg Address
abstract: Edward Everett, who spoke before Lincoln delivered his famous speech, has been unfairly forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Even before the address was given, Americans knew that a great speech was coming, and that it would come at Gettysburg. The battle had been so comprehensive, and its result so profound, that a lasting statement was needed to mark the burial of the dead. That the final resting place of the soldiers was in the North, conveniently close to media outlets, only added to the logic of a solemn utterance for the ages. Accordingly, an invitation went out to the person most likely to give it.

headline: Johnson & Johnson in Deal to Settle Hip Implant Lawsuits
keywords: ['Medical Devices', 'Implants', 'Hips', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The plan, submitted to a judge for approval, would pay an estimated 8,000 patients who have been forced to have the flawed all-metal artificial hip replaced.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson and lawyers for patients injured by a flawed hip implant announced a multibillion-dollar deal on Tuesday to settle thousands of lawsuits, but it was not clear whether the deal would satisfy enough claimants.

headline: Night Falls, and 5Pointz, a Graffiti Mecca, Is Whited Out in Queens
abstract: Some artists called it a mass desecration, but the buildings’ owner, Jerry Wolkoff, said he would erect a wall where painters could work again.
lead_paragraph: Graffiti is often denounced as vandalism, but the deliriously festooned, sprawling warehouses at the western edge of Queens rose far above that. Blanketed with giddy images, drawing street artists from around the world, 5Pointz was a decades-old legal haven considered both a “United Nations of Graffiti” and a semi-rebellious statement in a city some feel is growing too antiseptic. “Save 5Pointz,” the infamous British street artist Banksy urged in his final message to New Yorkers, after he wrapped his monthlong spree clandestinely decorating the city’s streets in October.

headline: From the Makers of Bonobos, a Shopping Site for the Ladies
abstract: Ayr.com, a new online women’s wear destination, launches today with two lines of stylish skinny jeans.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, men have been ordering pants from Bonobos.com, trying them on at home and returning them if they don’t fit. It was a way of shopping that fit the lifestyle of 20- and 30-somethings: without ever setting foot in a store or having to pay shipping costs. Today, the team behind Bonobos introduces Ayr.com, the women’s version of their successful men’s wear clearing house. Initially, the site will offer two styles of denim: skinny jeans ($175) and a cigarette leg ($165), each available in either a light or a dark wash. “I like to say you could do yoga in these jeans,” said the design director Jac Cameron, a veteran of Calvin Klein and Madewell. “I wanted to recreate a silhouette working with the stretch of the fabric to create a jean that molds to the body as you wear it.”

headline: Dallas, 50 Years After an Assassination
abstract: Half a century after President John F. Kennedy was killed, the city has been coming to grips with the worst moment in its history.
lead_paragraph: Half a century after President John F. Kennedy was killed, the city has been coming to grips with the worst moment in its history.

headline: Contest Aims for a Cleaner-Burning Wood Stove
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Ovens and Stoves', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Twelve teams are competing in Washington to find ways to get twice as much heat out of a log of firewood while producing cleaner smoke.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only blocks away, the Energy Department manages the search for quarks and NASA scours the heavens for Earth-like planets. But inside a big white tent on the National Mall, the focus is on something simpler: oak, ash and elm, and how to make them heat a house with as little pollution as possible.

headline: Four Principal Dancers at City Ballet to Retire
abstract: Jenifer Ringer, Janie Taylor, Sébastien Marcovici, and Jonathan Stafford will all retire during the 2014 winter and spring seasons.
lead_paragraph: Four principal dancers with New York City Ballet — Jenifer Ringer, Janie Taylor, Sébastien Marcovici and Jonathan Stafford — will retire during the 2014 winter and spring seasons, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: 50 Years Later, a Changed Dallas Grapples With Its Darkest Day
abstract: Painful memories of the angry anti-Washington culture that flourished in Dallas when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated have resurfaced.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — When President John F. Kennedy’s motorcade left the airport here shortly before noon on Nov. 22, 1963, the man seated in the lead car was the county sheriff, Bill Decker, 65, a storied Texas lawman who led the hunt for Bonnie and Clyde. Fifty years later, the badge belongs to Lupe Valdez, 66, the daughter of Mexican migrant farmworkers. She is the only sheriff in America who is an openly gay Hispanic woman. Voters re-elected Sheriff Valdez, a Democrat, to a third term last year.

headline: Monty Python Troupe to Reunite for Live Shows
abstract: The five surviving members of Monty Python, the influential British comedy troupe, plan to announce that they will reunite for their first live shows in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: A certain Norwegian Blue parrot is still dead, nearly 44 years after it shuffled off its mortal coil and joined the choir invisible in a famous television comedy sketch. But there is life yet in Monty Python, the singularly influential British troupe, whose surviving members are to announce this week that they will join together for their first live performances in more than a decade.

headline: ‘Selfie’ Trumps ‘Twerk’ as Oxford Dictionaries Word of the Year
abstract: “If it’s good enough for the Obamas and the pope, then it’s good enough for Word of the Year.”
lead_paragraph: “Selfie” — defined as “a photograph that one has taken of oneself, typically one taken with a smartphone or webcam and uploaded to a social media website” — has beaten out “twerk,” “bitcoin” and other comers to claim the title of Oxford Dictionaries 2013 Word of the Year.

headline: An Art Teacher Preserves the History of Harlem, While Creating Her Own Legacy
abstract: Alice Mizrachi, 36, an artist and teacher, is helping her students find a passion for art while also making sure that the Harlem art culture “lives in a rich and authentic way.”
lead_paragraph: She was only 6 years old and a first grader at a Catholic school in Harlem. But stepping into an art class at St. Aloysius taught by Alice Mizrachi steered Chayse Sheppard’s life at a young age in ways she did not fully appreciate until she was older.

headline: Today in Small Business: Turkey Shortage?
abstract: An end-of-year checklist for business owners. A pillow made for cuddling. Keeping the holiday season festive and productive.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Our Pages: November 20
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1913: Dog Rescues Starving Lost Pet

headline: Nash’s Return From Concussion Isn’t Enough as Rangers Fall to Bruins
abstract: After missing 17 games, Rick Nash failed to jump-start the Rangers’ lethargic offense.
lead_paragraph: Tuukka Rask and his Boston teammates were too much for the Rangers and a returning Rick Nash to surmount Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, where the Bruins skated to a 2-1 victory.

headline: Afghans Demand That U.S. Admit Military Errors
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Apologies']
abstract: Afghan officials said a long-term security pact could be reached with the United States if President Obama acknowledged military mistakes and vowed not to repeat them.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Months of fraught negotiations and public posturing over how a long-term American military force could remain in Afghanistan have suddenly come down to a demand for a single personal gesture: a display of contrition by President Obama for military mistakes that have hurt Afghans.

headline: Start-Up Founders Look Beyond the Usual Options of Selling or Going Public
abstract: Start-up founders are finding new ways to remain independent, like recapitalizing their companies or bootstrapping them. But while some see advantages to remaining independent, others have benefited from selling.
lead_paragraph: Successful tech entrepreneurs eventually face a choice, known in Silicon Valley as an exit: either sell their start-ups to bigger companies or take them public. As we wrote on Monday, that decision can be painful and personal. And like Snapchat’s rejection of Facebook’s billion-dollar offer, it is often a high-stakes bet.

headline: Who’s Putting a Roof Over Parents’ Heads
abstract: A nationwide study by Trulia, the real-estate Web site, finds that parents from India, Vietnam and Haiti are the most likely to live with their adult children, as are American-born seniors of Hispanic or Asian descent.
lead_paragraph: Do you really need that in-law suite?

headline: Virginia Political Figure Stabbed as Son Takes Own Life, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: R. Creigh Deeds, who was defeated in 2009 for governor, was in fair condition and his son was dead after what was described as “an attempted murder-suicide.”
lead_paragraph: State Senator R. Creigh Deeds, a leading Virginia political figure who ran unsuccessfully for governor in 2009, was stabbed repeatedly on Tuesday at his home during an altercation with his son, who then apparently took his own life, the authorities said.

headline: Senator Offers Overhaul of Corporate Tax Code
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A proposal from Max Baucus, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, seeks to start the process of lowering corporate tax rates while slowing the flow of jobs and money abroad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the powerful Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday released a long-awaited plan to overhaul the tax code for multinational corporations, trying to jump-start an effort to stem the flow of jobs and money abroad.

headline: The Illusions of Employer-Based Health Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Why the popularity of employer-based coverage is not a case for its desirability.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column closed with a warning to conservatives that Obamacare — at least in some form — may turn out to be more durable than its disastrous rollout would seem to suggest, because the nature of the welfare state means that even programs that don’t live up to their promises can be awfully hard to dislodge. (As a case in point, see the outcome of the weekend’s House election in Louisiana, where the anti-establishment, right-wing, “Duck Dynasty”-endorsed winner was also … in favor of Obamacare’s Medicaid expansion.)

headline: McKinsey & Company Report on the Health Care Law and the Website
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A report by McKinsey & Company warned in March that HeathCare.gov was at risk of failure.
lead_paragraph: A report by McKinsey & Company warned in March that HeathCare.gov was at risk of failure.

headline: S.E.C. Official Charged With Making False Statements
abstract: Steven Gilchrist, a compliance examiner in the New York office of the S.E.C., was charged by federal prosecutors with making false statements about stock holdings that he wasn’t allowed to own under ethics rules.
lead_paragraph: A Securities and Exchange Commission official was criminally charged on Tuesday with making false statements about stock holdings that he wasn’t allowed to own under the agency’s ethics rules.

headline: Caring for Aging Parents, Even From a Distance
keywords: ['Elder Care', 'Families and Family Life', 'Medicine and Health', 'Elderly']
abstract: Adult children who have overseen their parents’ care say that besides physical and emotional strains, there are financial effects that can include a loss of job mobility.
lead_paragraph: THROUGH the 1990s, Patrick Quirke’s career was sailing along. Every few years, he would be promoted at the transportation company where he worked and move to another city. He said he had every reason to believe that he would be promoted to the company’s headquarters in a few more moves. Then, his parents’ health started to decline.

headline: John Hodgman to Highlight Under the Radar Festival
abstract: The 10th annual showcase of experimental theater is scheduled from Jan. 8 to 19.
lead_paragraph: John Hodgman of “Daily Show” and Apple commercials fame, is heading downtown as a first-time participant in the Under the Radar festival, the Public Theater’s annual program of experimental works, which runs Jan. 8 to 19.

headline: Police Station Is Attacked by the Shabab in Somalia
abstract: At least 28 people were killed and many were wounded when the militant group staged an attack in Beledweyne, near the Ethiopian border.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Attackers from the Shabab militant group assaulted a police station in a Somali town north of Mogadishu on Tuesday, leaving at least 28 people dead and scores more wounded.

headline: A Bob Dylan Video 47 Years in the Making
abstract: Columbia, Mr. Dylan’s record label, has released an interactive web video for his 1965 hit “Like a Rolling Stone.”
lead_paragraph: Promotional video clips were hardly unknown when Bob Dylan released “Like a Rolling Stone” as a single in 1965, but Mr. Dylan never made one for the song. Now Columbia, his record label, is making up for that oversight with a newly produced web video for the song, mainly to promote “The Complete Album Collection, Volume 1,” a 47-CD set that includes all of Mr. Dylan’s studio albums, six live sets and a two-disc rarities compilation. But in the process, the company is redefining the way promotional clips are viewed.

headline: The Gun Report: November 19, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A California law prohibiting anyone convicted of domestic violence from possessing a gun is a legitimate and constitutional measure to keep firearms out of the wrong hands, a federal appeals court has ruled.

headline: Wheelies: The Turbo Honda Edition
abstract: Honda unveils a series of turbocharged engines, and a California Lamborghini owner ties up traffic driving around with a bear in the passenger seat.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Grace Kelly on J.F.K.: An Animated Interview
abstract: The latest installment on the clever “Blank on Blank” web series features Grace Kelly reminiscing about John F. Kennedy not long after the president was assassinated.
lead_paragraph: In keeping with the (rightfully) bottomless wellspring of Kennedy retrospectives this month, the web series “Blank on Blank” made its own contribution today with an excerpted interview with Grace Kelly recorded not long after the president’s assassination. Set to video and accompanied by the animation of Patrick Smith, Princess Grace speaks of Kennedy’s fashion sense and youthful optimism, and she strains to find meaning in the tragedy that had just played out in front of the world.

headline: What Is Harry Reid Waiting For?
abstract: For the third time in as many weeks, Senate Republicans have blocked a judicial nominee to the D.C. Circuit.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in as many weeks, Senate Republicans have blocked a judicial nominee to the second most powerful court in the country, and for the third time it is not because they doubt his qualifications — how could they? He’s a sitting district court judge who was unanimously confirmed by the Senate just three years ago. Nor is it because they fear he harbors an extreme ideology.

headline: Perks Ease Way in Health Plans for Lawmakers
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Government Employees']
abstract: While millions of Americans struggle with the federal insurance exchange, members of Congress and their aides have all sorts of assistance to help them parse their options and enroll.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress like to boast that they will have the same health care enrollment experience as constituents struggling with the balky federal website, because the law they wrote forced lawmakers to get coverage from the new insurance exchanges.

headline: Antiquated Trades Endangered in a Rapidly Changing Myanmar
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Typewriters and Typewriting']
abstract: In every society, professions disappear in the name of progress. But Myanmar’s rapid modernization has accelerated that process for roadside phone shops, rubber stamp businesses and other trades.
lead_paragraph: In every society, professions disappear in the name of progress. But Myanmar’s rapid modernization has accelerated that process for roadside phone shops, rubber stamp businesses and other trades.

headline: As Myanmar Modernizes, Old Trades Are Outpaced by New Competitors
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Typewriters and Typewriting']
abstract: Businesses are forced to adapt, or risk disappearing, in a country where the pace of change has been compressed into months, not decades.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — For years they poured out their hearts on the broken pavements of Myanmar’s cities and towns, young lovers desperate for privacy yet with no choice but to use what the Burmese call roadside phone shops.

headline: Handset Unit Nearly Sold, Nokia Now Looks to an Uncertain Future
abstract: Shareholders approved a $7.2 billion sale of Nokia’s cellphone business to Microsoft, leaving the company with its networking and mapping units, and its patents.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — Nokia’s shareholders took a major step on Tuesday to reshape the company, voting overwhelmingly in favor of selling the company’s handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion.

headline: Opposition Voiced to Return of Klimt Work to Heirs of Former Owner
abstract: Two groups speak out against an effort by heirs of the former owner of Gustav Klimt’s “Beethoven Frieze” to have the work returned to them.
lead_paragraph: Two groups connected to the Secession building in Vienna, where Gustav Klimt’s monumental “Beethoven Frieze” is housed, have spoken out against a claim by heirs of its former owner to recover the artwork. Last month heirs of the Lederer family, Jews who owned the four-ton frieze before the Nazis’ annexation of Austria in 1938, filed a claim with Austria’s Art Restitution Advisory Board, arguing that after World War II the government had in effect used its power to grant export licenses to compel the family to sell the work at a cut-rate price to the state.

headline: Living in Island Park, L.I.
abstract: Though pummeled by Hurricane Sandy, this affordable South Shore community is rebounding.
lead_paragraph: Though pummeled by Hurricane Sandy, this affordable South Shore community is rebounding.

headline: Island Park: Sandy as Mother of Reinvention
abstract: An affordable Nassau County enclave rebounding from the ravages of Hurricane Sandy, thanks to a network of close-knit, multigenerational families.
lead_paragraph: Last year, two days after Hurricane Sandy walloped the islet of Island Park, Rosmarie T. Bovino, the school superintendent, along with her principals and teachers, walked the square mile of the school district to see what each of its families needed. Though the two schools, the administration building and the public library had been devastated, Dr. Bovino, who calls the schools “the heart of the village,” wanted to “make sure the children had food to eat.”

headline: An Odd Spinoff by Royal DSM
abstract: The benefits of a $2.6 billion tie-up with a private equity firm are hard to fathom, the author says. And DSM cedes control of the unit without reducing its economic exposure.
lead_paragraph: Royal DSM has come up with an odd formulation to solve its drug-production headache. The company, which is the world’s biggest vitamin maker, is merging its DSM Pharmaceutical Products business with a private equity-backed rival.

headline: Israeli Military Stalls a College Career
abstract: Tom Maayan, a sophomore point guard at Seton Hall, learned on Monday that his exemption from the Israeli military is for only 120 days and that he is expected back by Jan. 2.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — For months, Tom Maayan had been the focal point of an international tug of war, pitting the Israeli military against a major American university, while clouding what looked to be a bright basketball career. But when Maayan, a sophomore at Seton Hall, returned to the bustling campus here Aug. 16, after five months of army service in Upper Galilee, the northern Israeli province where he was raised, it was with a sense of relief.

headline: Grand Vision for Former Home of Walter Reed Hospital
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Mixed-Use Developments', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Local officials in Washington have picked developers for a $1 billion plan to build homes, stores and offices on the old campus of the historic Army hospital.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The boxy Brutalist hospital built in the late 1970s stands virtually vacant, as do brick buildings erected during World War I, officers’ quarters dating to the 1920s or before, and myriad other structures that together make up the former Army medical center named for Walter Reed, the physician who linked mosquitoes to yellow fever at the turn of the 20th century.

headline: Pratt Institute Celebrates Four Leaders in Design and Culture
abstract: Pete Hamill, James Turrell, David Easton and Margaret Russell were honored at Pratt Institute’s Legends 2013 gala benefit.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 11, more than 350 people, including the singer Judy Collins, attended Pratt Institute’s Legends 2013 gala benefit, which honored four eminences in design and culture and raised nearly $800,000 for student scholarships. Held at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in New York, the event was hosted by Ted Allen, of the Food Network series “Chopped.” The honorees were the writer Pete Hamill; the artist James Turrell; David Easton, an interior designer; and Margaret Russell, the editor in chief of Architectural Digest.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in SAC Insider Trading Trial
abstract: The first group of potential jurors included a member of Occupy Wall Street member and people who had been investigated by the S.E.C.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:36 p.m. | Selection of a 12-member jury from a pool of about 100 people began on Tuesday at the insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager.

headline: Now With High-Tech Gifts for the Holidays
abstract: The New York holiday tradition of the “Radio City Christmas Spectacular” returns, with floating orbs, game consoles and the enduring Rockettes.
lead_paragraph: For a moment, you might think you’re in Oz. Nine huge, shining, transparent spheres rise into the air and drift inexorably toward you, as if nine versions of Glinda the Good Witch were about to burst forth.

headline: Taking Aspirin at Night May Boost Heart Benefits
abstract: If you take a daily aspirin to ward off heart attacks and stroke, it may be more effective if you take it right before bed.
lead_paragraph: Millions of adults take an aspirin every morning to ward off heart disease. But a new study suggests that the pills might be most effective if taken right before bed.

headline: Will Forte on the Glories of the Great Plains
abstract: The actor, who co-stars in the new film “Nebraska,” talks about road tripping with Bruce Dern, eating in Omaha and encountering a beauty he “wasn’t prepared to see.”
lead_paragraph: In the new film “Nebraska,” Will Forte plays the dutiful son to Bruce Dern’s curmudgeonly father who is convinced he has become a sweepstakes millionaire.

headline: In Extracting Deal From JPMorgan, U.S. Aimed for Bottom Line
abstract: The case against JPMorgan may set a precedent for cases against other major banks and industries like health care, where fines have been growing.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:44 p.m. | When Tony West arrived in a Justice Department conference room to put the finishing touches on a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase, he saw a familiar number flash on his cellphone.

headline: Jostens Agrees to Buy Rival in Commemorative Paraphernalia
abstract: American Achievement, which sells its products under brands like Balfour, ArtCarved and Keepsake, is being sold by the private equity firm Fenway Partners.
lead_paragraph: Jostens, a seller of yearbooks and class rings to students across the United States, is looking to gain a bigger piece of the business of school spirit.

headline: Calico, Google Health Venture, Names New Hires
abstract: The two-month old company said it hired Hal Barron as president for research and development and David Botstein as the chief scientific officer.
lead_paragraph: The new Google-backed venture to extend the human lifespan has hired away the head of global product development from Roche, the pharmaceutical giant, as well as a noted molecular biologist from Princeton.

headline: Brenda Fryson: Mayor of Stoops
abstract: Brenda Fryson manages a long list of community organizations, committees and revitalization and development projects from a home office she calls “The War Room.”
lead_paragraph: Brenda Fryson manages a long list of community organizations, committees and revitalization and development projects from a home office she calls “The War Room.”

headline: The Bats Blog Is on the Move
abstract: This blog’s regular features, including live game analysis, news and notes from Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and others, can now be found on the baseball section of our website.
lead_paragraph: Thank you for visiting Bats. This blog’s regular features, including live game analysis, news and notes from Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and others, and other coverage, can now be found on the baseball section of our website. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely baseball news.

headline: Holiday
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Charlotte Zolotow, Author of Books on Children’s Real Issues, Dies at 98
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The more than 70 books written by Ms. Zolotow, an editor as well as an author, were highlighted by pictures from some of the 20th century’s finest illustrators.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Zolotow, a distinguished author and editor of children’s books whose work — both her own titles and those of the writers in her stable — offered even the youngest readers a forthright view of emotionally fraught subjects like anger, envy and death, died on Tuesday at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 98.

headline: Devon Said to Be Near Deal to Buy GeoSouthern for $6 Billion
abstract: The deal, if completed, comes as energy companies are seeking to shore up their positions in shale formations rich in oil.
lead_paragraph: Devon Energy is near a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energy, a privately held oil and gas driller, for about $6 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Craig Bierko Won’t Return to ‘Matilda’
abstract: The actor said he is not healing quickly enough from a shoulder injury to assume the “physically demanding role.”
lead_paragraph: Weeks after announcing a lengthy medical leave from the plum role of Miss Trunchbull in “Matilda the Musical,” Craig Bierko has bowed out of the Broadway production entirely.

headline: Senate Majority Leader Backs Gillibrand on Military Assault Measure
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Harry Reid threw his support behind the bill, sponsored by Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York, which would give military prosecutors the power to decide which sexual assault cases to try.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, on Tuesday threw his support behind a measure that would give military prosecutors the power to decide which sexual assault cases to try, rather than commanders.

headline: Murdoch Divorce Said to Be Almost Final
abstract: A hearing on the dissolution of Rupert and Wendi Deng Murdoch’s 14-year marriage is scheduled for Wednesday morning in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch and Wendi Deng Murdoch are negotiating the final details of their divorce settlement, a deal that will officially end the 14-year marriage of the media mogul and his third wife, according to people with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Relief Efforts Improve in Storm-Hit Areas
abstract: Medical care is beginning to take hold, with 62 foreign or Filipino medical teams now working in areas with the most damage.
lead_paragraph: Medical care is beginning to take hold, with 62 foreign or Filipino medical teams now working in areas with the most damage.

headline: Bipartisan Assent to Hold Off New Iran Sanctions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: One concession came from President Obama’s Tuesday meeting with Senate leaders on Iran; a vote to impose new sanctions will be delayed until after talks in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a meeting with Senate leaders on Tuesday, President Obama failed to sway critics of his effort to sign an interim nuclear deal with Iran. But in a modest concession, they agreed to hold off on a vote to impose new sanctions on Iran until after talks in Geneva later this week.

headline: Making ‘Healthy’ Treats of Halloween Leftovers
abstract: On the one hand, I don’t want to waste what’s left of the Halloween candy. On the other, I don’t want the pumpkin buckets decorating my Thanksgiving table. Whole Wheat Leftover Halloween Candy Oatmeal Cookies were the perfect solution.
lead_paragraph: Am I the only one with Halloween candy still hanging around the house?

headline: No Budget, Because HealthCare.gov
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Republicans are back to pursuing their goal of doing nothing.
lead_paragraph: After they were blamed for causing a disastrous shutdown, many Republicans seemed to want to get the year’s budget fights behind them. As of a few weeks ago, some of them seemed open to relieving the sequester, which is widely hated by lawmakers in both parties, and Congressional appropriators thought they had a chance to enact real spending bills instead of running the government with yet another continuing resolution.

headline: Update for a Global Medical App
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mobile Applications', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: HTH Worldwide’s mPassport application has been updated to include more translations of drug names and medical terms.
lead_paragraph: HTH Worldwide, which offers health insurance and other products to those travelling internationally, has made updates to its mobile application, mPassport, adding more translations of drug names and medical phrases and providing regional health alerts.

headline: $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
abstract: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department finalized a $13 billion settlement, punctuating a long legal battle over the risky mortgage practices that became synonymous with the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department finalized a $13 billion settlement, punctuating a long legal battle over the risky mortgage practices that became synonymous with the financial crisis.

headline: Piora
abstract: Inside the West Village restaurant where Korean flavors dart in and out of the menu.
lead_paragraph: Inside the West Village restaurant where Korean flavors dart in and out of the menu.

headline: A Marriage of Ingenuity
abstract: Piora is the perfect match for the talents of Chris Cipollone.
lead_paragraph: You can put up with mediocre food in a restaurant that has other things going for it. When an exciting chef works in a terrible dining room, though, you feel the way you do when a friend hooks up with somebody you can’t stand. You may visit the two of them once or twice to savor the full extent of the new partner’s awfulness, but then you run for cover while you await the end.

headline: Monetary and Fiscal Implications of Secular Stagnation
abstract: Austerity is still bad!
lead_paragraph: Since I gave Larry Summers’s endorsement of secular stagnation theory a plug, I’ve been getting a lot of commentary in various forms. Some of it is the usual Keynes-hatred and/or incomprehension, and not worth going into. But there are also some questions/complaints that call for some serious further exegesis.

headline: Mini’s 3rd-Generation Hardtop Shows Subtle Aesthetic Changes
abstract: The visual changes in Mini’s 2015 hardtop coupe are subtle, but significant transformation lurks below the small car’s skin.
lead_paragraph: Next year’s calendars are already out, including one called Pug Mugs, which displays police-style headshots of adorable dogs. Mini could produce a calendar like that, now that the bulldog of cars has unveiled its third generation since BMW rolled out the first of the reborn Minis 13 years ago.

headline: Kids These Days: They’re All Older Than 50
abstract: This television season, many shows — including “Mom,” “Dads” and “The Crazy Ones” — are treating their characters over 50 as particularly immature.
lead_paragraph: When did “mature” get so immature?

headline: Woman Says Zimmerman Choked Her During Fight
abstract: George Zimmerman’s girlfriend did not immediately report the attack, but disclosed it during an inquiry into a confrontation that led to Mr. Zimmerman’s arrest on Monday in Apopka, Fla.
lead_paragraph: George Zimmerman, whose February 2012 killing of an unarmed black teenager propelled him to the center of an emotional national debate about self-defense laws, choked his girlfriend during an argument this month, a Florida prosecutor said on Tuesday.

headline: How the Safety Net Held Up in the Recession
keywords: ['Food Stamps', 'Medicaid', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A study finds that spending on programs including food stamps, Medicaid and unemployment benefits increased by 18 percent between 2007 and 2010 as families slipped down the income ladder.
lead_paragraph: Finally, some kind words for government. Robert A. Moffitt, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, says in a new paper that the country’s social safety net did a good job during the recession, expanding by half a trillion dollars.

headline: Ronaldo’s 3 Goals Carry Portugal to World Cup Berth
abstract: A second-half hat trick by Cristiano Ronaldo took Portugal to the World Cup finals with a 4-2 aggregate victory in its World Cup playoff against Sweden on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The original pool of hopefuls had 207 teams, a diverse group of soccer nations ranging from minnows to monoliths that nonetheless had a common destination in mind. Now, more than 800 qualifying matches later, the field of 32 teams that will take part in the World Cup next year in Brazil is all but complete.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 12: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
abstract: This is the part of the season where coldblooded owners are rewarded for dropping disappointing stars and picking up hot waiver wire unknowns.
lead_paragraph: As if the 2013 N.F.L. season were not strange enough, we are now at the point where 4-6 is a respectable record in the A.F.C. Unfortunately, 4-6 will probably not get you into your fantasy football playoffs, so it is time to buckle down with leagues a few weeks away from the postseason.

headline: Enduring Nazi Law Impedes Recovery of Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Museums', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: A 1938 law under which the Nazis seized artworks could make it difficult for German museums to recover looted pieces discovered in the apartment of a dealer’s son.
lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — Wolfgang Büche was amazed this month when a watercolor seized by the Nazis from the small museum in this eastern city, where he is the curator, reappeared, part of a vast trove uncovered in a Munich apartment.

headline: Gotham West Market, a New Food Hall, Opens on the West Side
abstract: An ambitious 10,000-square-foot market at the ground level of a blocklong residential project, and more restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Vatican Unveils Revamped Catacombs Museum
abstract: The new excavations and restorations of the catacombs of Priscilla in Rome can also be viewed online.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Celebrating the meeting of ancient and modern worlds, the Vatican on Tuesday presented a revamped museum of antique funerary remains in Rome, while inviting the rest of the world to peek inside that space by computer.

headline: One Bach Influencing the Other
abstract: The music of Johann Christoph Bach and his cousin Johann Sebastian was on Arcangelo’s program at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: In his new book, “Bach: Music in the Castle of Heaven,” the conductor John Eliot Gardiner persuasively expands our sense of the influence that the brilliant composer Johann Christoph Bach (1642-1703) may have had on his young cousin Johann Sebastian (1685-1750). The two men’s music, Mr. Gardiner writes, shares a “subtle blend of intense subjectivity and polyphonic distance.”

headline: Hotel Review: The Graham Hotel in Washington, D.C.
abstract: This boutique property, reopened in May, pairs modern, tranquil rooms with a roof deck that offers panoramic views.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Guild & Company in Burlington, Vt.
abstract: This year-old steakhouse gets its beef from a nearby farm and extends the locally sourced theme to its cocktail list.
lead_paragraph: As a restaurant concept, “farm-to-table steakhouse” comes off as so buzzwordy that it’s like a “Portlandia” sketch begging to be written. So perhaps it’s not incidental that Guild & Company, which executes the conceit with unfussy charm, sits along the outskirts of Burlington, Vt., the East Coast’s best facsimile of that tongue-in-cheek television utopia.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Lebanon, the Philippines, Nepal and Egypt.

headline: Mike Lee and the Republican Opportunity

abstract: The promise of a conservatism that reaches for a different center than the one the Beltway CW embraces.
lead_paragraph: One of my recurring themes in this space is the weakness of the Republican Party’s policy agenda; another is the limitations of the Bloombergist/“donorist” style of moderation that’s regularly offered as the obvious direction for the G.O.P. to take. So I’m grateful to Ron Fournier of National Journal for taking on the first issue in a way that lets me talk, at length, about the second. Here’s Fournier, attacking Republicans for remaining “the party of zilch” amid the Obama administration’s recent flailings:

headline: France Is Heading to Brazil and Can Make Amends

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Defying the bitterly low expectations of a populace that had largely written them off as prima donnas, the French national soccer team defeated Ukraine, 3-0, on Tuesday night and secured a place at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

In the midst of a victory tour after winning the 2013 Man Booker Prize for her second novel, “The Luminaries,” Ms. Catton had not yet fully adjusted to being an object of attention, or even to being allowed to stay in a fancy hotel, as she described it.

The closing follows a sharp decline in ticket sales because of competition from hotter musicals and a lack of star attractions in the cast.

headline: Son of Israel, Caught in the Middle

lead_paragraph: “If you want everyone to love you,” Saul Bellow wrote, “don’t discuss Israeli politics.” Yet when Bellow went to Israel for several months in 1975 to research a nonfiction book, all he did was talk politics — and everything else. It was what he loved best about Israel, the “gale of conversation.”

lead_paragraph: PETER KREUTZER is, in many ways, an ideal patient. Mr. Kreutzer, a 57-year-old Brooklyn writer, is in good health, eats well and follows his doctor’s instructions.

headline: Medicaid Help Without Falling Into Poverty
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Nursing Homes', 'Income', 'Home Health Care', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Changes in Medicaid rules have helped some elderly couples cope financially with the illness or nursing home care of one spouse without resorting to an old strategy: divorce.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Colin Sandler was in high school in the mid-1980s, her grandparents legally separated after 45 years of marriage. This was not because their marriage was troubled, but because her grandfather had fallen ill and medical bills threatened to consume their entire life savings and all their income, leaving Ms. Sandler’s grandmother penniless.

headline: Private Exchanges Rise as Health Care Options
abstract: Other trends include plans with higher deductibles and programs that offer financial incentives for employees to take steps to improve their health.
lead_paragraph: THE troubled rollout of the federal health insurance marketplace this fall has given the word “health exchange” a bad name. Nonetheless, some companies are choosing to offer their employees health benefits via private exchanges — online insurance marketplaces that are separate from the federal system.

headline: Planning for a Future in the Face of Terminal Illness
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Nursing Homes', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: People who have terminal diseases are living longer. Experts say simple strategies can make the most of the money at hand for those with foresight.
lead_paragraph: PATRICK SKELDON, a commercial airline pilot, started having trouble walking in the autumn of 2003. His doctor thought he had a vitamin deficiency and prescribed supplements. When those didn’t work, the doctor referred him to a neurologist. The next year, he was told he had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, more commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s disease. He was 59.

headline: You Plan Your Retirement, Then You Get the Health Bill
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elderly', 'Retirement', 'Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Nursing Homes', 'Medicare', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Elder Care']
abstract: The share of medical costs shouldered by retirees is growing, highlighting the need to save a lot more now.
lead_paragraph: JEFF STRACK, a 61-year-old sales manager in Charlotte, N.C., enjoys his work and is in good health. But the prospect of paying for health costs after he retires weighs on him.

headline: How Doctors Die: Showing Others the Way
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elder Care']
abstract: One way that doctors stand out from the general population is in advance planning for the end of life, something that is gradually finding acceptance.
lead_paragraph: BRAVE. You hear that word a lot when people are sick. It’s all about the fight, the survival instinct, the courage. But when Dr. Elizabeth D. McKinley’s family and friends talk about bravery, it is not so much about the way Dr. McKinley, a 53-year-old internist from Cleveland, battled breast cancer for 17 years. It is about the courage she has shown in doing something so few of us are able to do: stop fighting.

headline: For Those at Death’s Door, a Case for ‘Life Panels’
keywords: ['Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Death and Dying', 'Financial Planners', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide']
abstract: A financial planner proposes “life panels,” chosen in advance, for people whose quality of life and mental capacity have  deteriorated.
lead_paragraph: AT the beginning of 2012, my mother was 95 years old. She lived in an assisted-living center, with hospice care, in a hospital bed 24/7. She was hollow-eyed and emaciated. Though she had moments of clarity, she was confused, anxious and uncomfortable. Her quality of life was minimal, at best. And the cost to keep her in this condition had risen to close to $100,000 a year.

headline: ABC Shuffles Its Prime-Time Lineup
abstract: The network has struggled most in the ratings this fall, and it announced five new series as it canceled “Betrayal.”
lead_paragraph: ABC, the network that has struggled most in the ratings this fall, announced a series of changes to its prime-time schedule Tuesday, which included the addition of five new series and the cancellation of one flop. The network also unveiled a new entrant in its long-running effort to fashion a hit comedy in the half-hour following its biggest hit, “Modern Family.”

headline: Art Matters | Art, Underground Music and Basketball Collide in Queens

One was provided by Future Brown — a new D.J. supergroup made up of the genre-bending artists and musicians Fatima Al Qadiri; Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda of Nguzunguzu; and J-Cush of Lit City Trax. The second, which synced well with the first, came from the steady bounce of basketballs.

headline: California: Los Angeles Airport Shooting Suspect Leaves Hospital
abstract: Paul A. Ciancia, 23, accused of killing a federal agent at the Los Angeles International Airport, was released from a hospital Monday and taken to a federal holding facility, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of killing a federal agent at Los Angeles International Airport was released from Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center on Monday and taken to a federal holding facility, the authorities said Tuesday. The suspect, Paul A. Ciancia, 23, is believed to have opened fire in the crowded terminal on Nov. 1, killing Gerardo I. Hernandez, 39, a Transportation Security Administration agent, and wounding two others. A spokesman for the United States attorney’s office said that “no details about his custody status or location are being released at this time.” Mr. Ciancia led police officers through a chase in the terminal and was shot in the head and leg. He was listed in critical condition for more than 10 days, and federal investigators were not able to question him. Mr. Ciancia could face the death penalty if convicted.

headline: A New Party Challenges the One That Has Run India for Most of Its History
abstract: As elections approach in India, a new political party, Aam Aadmi, dedicated to the common man and to eliminating corruption, hopes to end the Congress Party’s long dominance.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Snaking down one of this city’s dusty back streets on a recent afternoon was a line of auto-rickshaws, the motorized buggies that course through this city by the tens of thousands, carrying ordinary citizens on their daily rounds. Unless you looked closely, you could miss the fact that they were part of a political insurgency.

keywords: ['Travel Agencies and Agents', 'Online Advertising', 'Celebrities', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cricket (Game)', 'Travel and Vacations']

headline: Jane Pratt Fitzpatrick, 89, Savior of Pre-Revolutionary Inn, Dies
abstract: Mrs. Fitzpatrick kept the Red Lion Inn from being torn down to make way for a gas station in Stockbridge, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Jane Pratt Fitzpatrick, who with her husband saved the Red Lion Inn, the pre-Revolutionary hostelry in Western Massachusetts immortalized by Norman Rockwell in his painting “Stockbridge Main Street at Christmas,” died on Nov. 9 at her home in Stockbridge. She was 89.

headline: Beware Marauding Carp
abstract: The grass carp is poised to disrupt the ecology of the Hudson River and New York’s other inland waters.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, researchers demonstrated that a Eurasian species of fish, the grass carp, had begun reproducing in Lake Erie. This may not sound like alarming news, but unless we take steps to prevent its spread, this animal is poised to disrupt the ecology of the Hudson River and New York’s other inland waters.

headline: Bringing an End to a Senseless Policy
abstract: China’s population control policy has caused demographic problems and deprives older people of support from children.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — CHINA announced last week that it would loosen its famous “one-child” policy, enforced since 1980. The world’s most controversial birth-control policy, initially imposed as an emergency measure at the start of the economic reforms of Deng Xiaoping, seems to finally be on its way out, more than a generation later.

headline: Doctors Say Heart Drug Raised Risk of an Attack
abstract: Cardiologists who reported on a clinical trial said the company making the drug failed to turn over data that showed it didn’t work.
lead_paragraph: Cardiologists have accused a small drug company of withholding data from a clinical trial showing that the company’s drug, meant to reduce the risk of heart attacks, increased the risk instead.

headline: Energy Dept. Is Told to Stop Collecting Fee for Nuclear Waste Disposal
keywords: ['Nuclear Wastes', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Because the program that the fee was set up to finance is no longer in operation, people should not have to keep paying for it, an appeals court ruled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that the Energy Department must stop collecting fees of about $750 million a year that are paid by consumers and intended to fund a program for the disposal of nuclear waste. The reason, the court said, is that there is no such program.

headline: Vonn Crashes While Prepping for Return
abstract: Lindsey Vonn’s World Cup comeback from major knee surgery may have been delayed by a training crash Tuesday in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn’s World Cup comeback from major knee surgery may have been delayed by a training crash Tuesday in Colorado. Vonn, the reigning Olympic downhill champion, was being evaluated by a team orthopedist after the crash, the United States Ski Team said. The team did not disclose what kind of injury Vonn had sustained.

headline: Mentally Ill, and Jailed in Isolation at Rikers Island
abstract: A report looks into the effects of solitary confinement at the campus of jails and how it can be a basket into which society drops the disruptive mentally ill.
lead_paragraph: From the annals of Rikers Island comes a document titled, “Three Adolescents With Mental Illness in Punitive Segregation in Rikers Island.” Punitive segregation means solitary confinement for 23 hours a day. Schoolwork, if it comes, is passed through a slot in the cell door. Toothpaste is available once a day.

headline: N.S.A. Spying Scandal Hurts Close Ties Between Australia and Indonesia
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Indonesia has taken offense at reports that its close trading partner, Australia, used its embassies in Asia to collect intelligence.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The relationship between Indonesia and Australia, Pacific neighbors with a long history of cooperation and trade, has in recent years been marked by disagreements on a range of issues, including human rights, terrorism and asylum seekers. But relations reached a new low over the weekend over the latest bombshell from the surveillance scandal involving a third country, the United States.

headline: As Trader’s Trial Begins, Name of One Insider Stands Out
abstract: Information that came from a source at Dell’s headquarters led to insider trading charges against eight people, including Michael S. Steinberg, a former SAC trader whose trial began Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: From his cubicle at Dell’s headquarters in Round Rock, Tex., Rob Ray shared insights about the computer maker that ricocheted across the country, reaching a trust company in California, a mutual fund in Manhattan and hedge funds in New York and Connecticut.

headline: Koch Brothers’ Group Uses Health Care Law to Attack Democrats
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Americans for Prosperity is targeting three of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats who are up for re-election next year, as well as three House Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity, the political group backed by the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, is targeting three of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats who are up for re-election next year. The group’s efforts are part of a new $3.5 million attack advertising campaign that hammers lawmakers for supporting President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Russians and Bach, With Equal Keyboard Energy
abstract: The pianist Olli Mustonen brought his intensity to Shostakovich, Rachmaninoff and Bach at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: After playing Shostakovich’s Piano Sonata No. 2 in B minor at Zankel Hall last Tuesday evening, the pianist Olli Mustonen wiped the sweat from his brow and looked at the audience with an expression that hovered between exhaustion and resignation. He had just offered an impassioned rendition of this tormented piece, composed in 1943 after Shostakovich had been evacuated during the Siege of Leningrad. The composer dedicated the work to an important mentor, his teacher Leonid Nikolayev, who had died the previous year. Mr. Mustonen played the opening movement’s frenzied surges with powerful clarity, beautifully contrasting them with the yearning melody that unfolds between demonic outbursts. He brought a searching insight to the second movement Largo, with an emotionally subdued character that offers a respite between the angst of the outer movements. Mr. Mustonen’s judicious use of pedal and vivid touch created an impressive range of colors in the turbulent concluding section, in which a ruminative melody unfurls over rumbling bass chords and later, in the left hand, under intense right-hand patterns.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Calls for Transforming the Technology Used by Phone Systems
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Tom Wheeler, said the agency would move the nation’s century-old network of circuits, switches and wires toward an Internet-based system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans could soon be one step closer to getting that videophone they were promised in the 1960s.

headline: A Municipal Bankruptcy May Create a Template
abstract: Jefferson County, Ala., will ask a federal court on Wednesday to approve its plan for exiting bankruptcy, including court oversight for a period of 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Jefferson County, Ala., which just became the first municipality to tap the public bond markets while bankrupt, will go to court on Wednesday to seek approval for its plan to exit bankruptcy by the end of this year.
