abstract: In the long run, the deal Secretary of State John Kerry is trying to forge with Iran is good for us and our allies. Here are the reasons.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — The Middle East once again proves that if you eat right, exercise regularly and don’t smoke, you’ll live long enough to see everything, including a day when the Jews controlling Jerusalem and the Sunni Saudi Custodians of the Great Mosques of Mecca and Medina would form a tacit alliance against the Shiite Persians of Iran and the Protestants of America — with the Hindus of India and the Confucians of China also supporting America, sort of, while the secularist French play all sides.

headline: Vladimir Putin Clings to the Past
abstract: Former Soviet republics must be free to develop economic and political relations with any foreign nation they choose.
lead_paragraph: The former republics of the Soviet Union have been sovereign, independent countries for almost 22 years, free to develop economic and political relations with any foreign nation or trading bloc they choose. That point appears to have eluded President Vladimir Putin of Russia, who is doing everything he can to prevent these countries from developing closer ties with Europe — even threatening to cut off the gas that one country needs to get through the winter.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The protesters’ numbers were small, compared with the millions who have marched through Egypt’s streets in recent months. And at one point, a soccer game on television seemed more urgent than the chants.

headline: Family’s Tenacity and Wealth Put Skakel at Cusp of Freedom
abstract: Michael C. Skakel was convicted in 2002 of murdering Martha Moxley, 15, in 1975. Since then his family has spent millions of dollars working to free him.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — Since Michael C. Skakel’s conviction in 2002 in the 1975 murder of his Greenwich neighbor Martha Moxley when they were both 15, Mr. Skakel and his family have spared no expense in their efforts to clear his name.

headline: Advertisements for the Common Core
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'National Assessment of Educational Progress', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Editorials']
abstract: Students in states with tougher standards have already shown marked improvement in reading and math scores.
lead_paragraph: The country is engaged in a fierce debate about two educational reforms that bear directly on the future of its schoolchildren: first, teacher evaluation systems that are taking hold just about everywhere, and, second, the Common Core learning standards that have been adopted by all but a few states and are supposed to move the schools toward a more challenging, writing-intensive curriculum.

headline: The Expiring Ban on Plastic Guns
abstract: A federal ban on the manufacture, sale, import or possession of guns that are undetectable by metal detectors and X-ray machines should be renewed.
lead_paragraph: Even after the Newtown, Conn., massacre, Republican opponents of reasonable firearms restrictions in Congress blocked proposals for strengthened background checks and other steps to make future gun tragedies less likely. Now the question is whether anti-gun-control extremists will allow a federal ban on the manufacture, sale, import or possession of guns that are undetectable by metal detectors and X-ray machines to expire on Dec. 9.

headline: Citing Fed’s Efforts, Bernanke Says U.S. Economy Is Growing Stronger
abstract: In a speech in Washington, the central bank’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said that even as the stimulus wound down, efforts would remain in place to keep interest rates low.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few months of scrambled economic data have not altered the Federal Reserve’s basic view that the American economy is gaining strength, nor its intention to start pulling back soon from its stimulus campaign, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Tuesday evening.

headline: Sounds From the Sky
abstract: Coming across dozens of birds (maybe a group of geese? a crowd of crows?) is a reminder that what we see may not be what we expected based on what we heard.
lead_paragraph: Among the phrases I have never trusted are the collective nouns associated with animals — a murder of crows, a scurry of squirrels, that sort of thing. They turn up mostly when people are making lists of collective nouns associated with animals, and their roots — if they have roots — are usually never mentioned. All in all, they reek of a kind of linguistic cleverness I find far too cute. Plus, they’re all too easy to make: a puddle of poodles, a terrine of terriers, a rumpus of reptiles, etc.

headline: JPMorgan Settlement Offers Look Into Mortgage Machine
abstract: After months of wrangling, the bank agreed to a statement of facts with the government that provides new details into how it assembled mortgage securities sold from 2005 through 2008.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department reached a record $13 billion settlement on Tuesday, wrapping up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Street’s mortgage machine before the financial crisis, when it churned out billions of dollars in securities that later imploded.

headline: A Mother’s Pain Fed That of Her Daughter
abstract: As Khalilah Hyde-Peyrefitte was preparing for life after college, she could not find a job, and her mother was destitute and depressed after separating from her abusive husband.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Khalilah Hyde-Peyrefitte was bustling around the 20th floor of a towering office building in Midtown Manhattan, greeting colleagues with a wide, beaming smile. A small-business coordinator for McKissack & McKissack, a construction and design firm, she has the bearing of any bright, ambitious, recent college graduate, enthusiastic and eager to excel. But Ms. Hyde-Peyrefitte, 21, also carries the weight of the pain and disillusionment she had to overcome.

headline: In Places Like North St. Louis, Gunfire Still Rules the Night
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Residents of areas like North St. Louis, where drugs, poverty and gunfire beget a cycle of violence, scoff when they hear officials declare that their cities are safer.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The unmistakable pop of a gunshot ricocheted through the park in the humid air, and Montez Wayne could only hope that the bullet did not have his name on it. He sprang from his seat beneath a sprawling bald cypress, ready to make his move.

When you went to school dances where I lived, you did the Hustle and other disco horrors when you were in public but — if you were to be considered a teen of good taste — when you got home, it was Jackson Browne who lived on your turntable*.

lead_paragraph: Just a few days after President Obama said that millions of consumers should be able to keep their old insurance plans for another year — even if they did not meet the requirements of his health care law — he is finding support among states that would not exactly be described as allies.

Donziger, asserting that he tampered with witnesses and bribed an Ecuadorean judge. On Tuesday, the company’s lawyers confronted Mr. Donziger in a Manhattan federal courtroom.

headline: Pierce, Now Surrounded by Scorers, Seeks a Role
abstract: Paul Pierce shouldered the scoring burden in Boston last season, but his role with the Nets has changed, and he said that trying to find his niche each night has caused him some problems.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Three weeks ago, after the Nets secured a galvanizing victory at home over the Miami Heat, Kevin Garnett bestowed upon his longtime teammate Paul Pierce the nickname Picasso, reasoning that every night on the court, Pierce seemed to produce affecting artistry — “a beautiful painting,” Garnett said.

abstract: Typhoon Haiyan has focused an unflattering spotlight on the Philippine military, an overstretched, poorly funded force that has been criticized for its late arrival to the disaster zone.
lead_paragraph: GUIUAN, the Philippines — As American cargo planes and military helicopters zipped across the sky above this decimated city, ferrying badly needed supplies to typhoon survivors, Philippine soldiers were working with what little they had — relying on motorcycles and boats to ferry messages between the army’s provincial headquarters and stricken municipalities along the eastern coast of Samar, some of them more than a hundred miles away.

headline: Cano to the Mets? Unlikely at His Price
abstract: Even if Robinson Cano would fit nicely into the Mets’ batting order behind David Wright, it seems a dinner between Cano’s representatives and the Mets front office was just that, dinner.
lead_paragraph: If the Mets were going to puff out their chests and declare themselves spenders this off-season, they might as well act like it, at least once in a while. So on Monday night, Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager; Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer, and John Ricco, the assistant general manager, met for dinner in Manhattan with Jay Z and associates and listened to their pitch on Robinson Cano, the Yankees second baseman who has become the highest-priced item on baseball’s free-agent market.

headline: The Obamacare Crisis
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How profound are the political implications of putting people’s well-being in the hands of bureaucrats armed with inadequate technological expertise?
lead_paragraph: Health care as a necessity comes only after food, shelter and income security. The mismanagement of the website HealthCare.gov and the cancellation of millions of policies pushes an underlying question out into the open: Is the federal government capable of managing the provision of a fundamental service through an extraordinarily complex system?

headline: Knicks, Running Out of Options, Fall Short Again
abstract: The Knicks, who fell to the Pistons for their third straight loss, have experienced more problems than wins in their first 10 games, from injuries and old age to tweets and trade rumors.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — By the time Coach Mike Woodson called a timeout after an emphatic Andre Drummond dunk, there was not much left in the Knicks’ tank. They trailed the Detroit Pistons by 15 points with 9 minutes 20 seconds remaining as Woodson sat in the huddle. There was time for a comeback, but around Woodson, the options were limited.

headline: A Brutal Feud Emerges in Uzbekistan’s Fractured First Family
abstract: A family power struggle has put the political future of Gulnara Karimova, the eldest daughter of Uzbekistan’s strongman president, in doubt.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Truth be told, Gulnara Karimova, the eldest daughter of the strongman leader of Uzbekistan, never did seem particularly well qualified to succeed her father at the head of their impoverished and troubled Central Asian nation.

headline: Canada: Doctor Convicted of Molesting Female Patients
abstract: An anesthesiologist at a Toronto hospital, Dr. George Doodnaught, was convicted on Tuesday of sexually molesting 21 women after sedating them.
lead_paragraph: An anesthesiologist at a Toronto hospital was convicted on Tuesday of sexually molesting 21 women after sedating them. Once he had put the women, who ranged in age from 25 to 75, into a state of semi-consciousness, Dr. George Doodnaught kissed and groped them and, in comes cases, forced them to perform sexual acts. Justice David McCombs of the Superior Court of Ontario said that expert witnesses effectively refuted claims by Dr. Doodnaught’s lawyers that the women were suffering from sexual hallucinations brought on by anesthesia drugs. Dr. Doodnaught will be sentenced early next year and faces another hearing about his medical license.

headline: Russia: Judges Grant Bail to Nine Greenpeace Activists
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Bail', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The rulings came a day after three Russian crew members from the ship, the Arctic Sunrise, were also granted bail.
lead_paragraph: Russian judges in St. Petersburg granted bail to nine more crew members of a Greenpeace International ship who were arrested in September after a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic, all of them foreigners. The rulings came a day after three Russian crew members from the ship, the Arctic Sunrise, were also granted bail, though the detention of yet another activist, Colin Russel of Australia, was extended until February, as the investigation into the protest against an off-shore oil rig in the Pechora Sea continues.

headline: Venezuela: Assembly Hands More Powers to President
abstract: The National Assembly voted to give President Nicolás Maduro decree powers for one year, which will allow him to create laws on his own, without going through the legislative process.
lead_paragraph: The National Assembly on Tuesday voted to give President Nicolás Maduro decree powers for one year, which will allow him to create laws on his own, without going through the legislative process. The so-called special powers permit Mr. Maduro, a socialist, to make laws aimed at fighting corruption and regulating the economy, but critics say that in practice those areas are broad enough that there may be few limits over the reach of his decrees. Many Venezuelan presidents have been given similar decree powers, including Mr. Maduro’s predecesor and mentor, Hugo Chávez, who died in March. Mr. Maduro, who is grappling with runaway inflation and severe shortages of many basic goods, has said that he will quickly move to create a law widening price controls and capping business profits.

headline: Zimbabwe: Sanitation Crisis Causes New Cholera Risk
abstract: Millions of Zimbabwe residents are at risk of waterborne diseases because of a water and sanitation crisis in the capital, Harare, Human Rights Watch said in a report.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Zimbabwe residents are at risk of waterborne diseases including a resumption of cholera because of a water and sanitation crisis in the capital, Harare, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Tuesday. The report, issued five years after cholera killed more than 4,000 Zimbabweans and sickened 100,000, described a collapse in water and sanitation services. Residents must often drink from shallow, unprotected wells befouled by sewage, according to the report, which was based on research conducted over the last two years.

headline: U.S. Player Ratings: Austria (1), U.S. (0)
abstract: Player ratings from the United States men’s soccer team’s 1-0 loss to Austria on Tuesday in a friendly.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — On a cold night at Ernst Happel Stadium, the United States men’s national soccer team ended its 2013 year Tuesday with a sloppy exhibition loss against an Austria team that failed to qualify for the World Cup.

headline: The Labor Market and Labor Policy Since Kennedy
abstract: President Kennedy’s short administration seemed to embrace wider-ranging possibilities for economic policy than any president since, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Mother’s Exercise May Boost Baby’s Brain
abstract: A growing scientific consensus suggests that the benefits of exercise can begin to accumulate even before someone is born.
lead_paragraph: If a woman is physically active during pregnancy, she may boost the development of her unborn child’s brain, according to a heart-tugging new study of expectant mothers and their newborns. The findings bolster a growing scientific consensus that the benefits of exercise can begin to accumulate even before someone is born.

headline: What’s On Wednesday

Kennedy through the eyes of the 1963 Dallas Cowboys and Roger Staubach, then a college quarterback for Navy. Other former players, including the defensive tackle Bob Lilly, the linebacker Lee Roy Jordan and the tight end Pettis Norman; the Cowboys’ longtime personnel chief Gil Brandt; Dan Rooney, the chairman of the Pittsburgh Steelers; and the historian Michael Beschloss weigh in.

headline: Xi Puts Himself at Center of China’s Economic Makeover

headline: Property Taxes Hoped to Curb China’s Real Estate Excesses
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Property Taxes', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: With other measures failing to halt rising prices in cities, some Chinese are hoping that a hinted-at property tax can rein in the real estate market. But opposition is likely among the wealthy and powerful.
lead_paragraph: Housing prices in China’s major cities continue to soar, according to a report released by the National Bureau of Statistics on Monday. With the exception of Wenzhou, in the eastern province of Zhejiang, housing prices rose in 69 of the 70 major cities in the survey during the first 10 months of 2013. In 21 cities, prices jumped more than 10 percent, and in 26 cities, they climbed by 8 percent to 10 percent. Shanghai and Beijing topped the list, with increases of 21.4 percent and 21.2 percent, respectively.

headline: A Small-Scale Thanksgiving

lead_paragraph: Christmas persecutes the lonely and rejected, the New York newspaperman Jimmy Cannon wrote in a syndicated column in 1962. Perhaps it does. But the holiday holds nothing on Thanksgiving.

headline: How Is Hamid Karzai Still Standing?
abstract: Enemies left, enemies right, and then there’s his family. Building an Afghan legacy is even more complicated than it appears.
lead_paragraph: The Karzai family graveyard lies a few miles outside Kandahar, on the edge of the village of Karz. On the day I drove there, burned-out cars stood rusting by the sides of the road, children splashed through open drains and bullet holes riddled the mud walls opposite checkpoints. Amid all this, the graveyard stood out — gleaming, immaculate. Straggling bougainvillea and mulberry trees blossomed over the calligraphic tiles topping the cream-colored walls. Through the double gates were lines of cypresses. In the middle stood a domed enclosure containing the graves of the clan elders.

headline: The Search for the Lost Marines of Tarawa
keywords: ['Missing in Action', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Seventy years after three of the bloodiest days in modern American history, the battle continues to bring the missing men back home.
lead_paragraph: We had been on the island for about an hour when we found the first skeleton. It was a pile of yellow bones tucked inside a cardboard box. Mark Noah squatted down for a look. He is a stocky man of 48, with a light buzz of blond hair and the wind-beaten eyes of a lifelong outdoorsman. Since 2008, he has been traveling to the tiny Pacific atoll of Tarawa to search for the remains of more than 500 Marines who died there in World War II. Sometimes locals dig up their bones and leave them in his storage locker.

headline: Bomb Attacks Kill Dozens in Baghdad
abstract: A series of apparently coordinated bombings killed at least 42 people and wounded more than 90, raising fears of mounting sectarian strife.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A wave of apparently coordinated bombings hit bakeries and public markets in Baghdad on Wednesday, killing at least 42 people and wounding more than 90, many of them as they rushed to shop during a break in heavy rainstorms, according to the police, residents and medical officials.

headline: New York Today: J.F.K. in the Bronx
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: J.F.K.’s local roots, more cold weather and a hearing on racial profiling of shoppers.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:05 p.m. | Let us now visit the house where a 10-year-old John F. Kennedy lived.

headline: Toyota Shows Off Fuel-Cell Automobile
abstract: The car, which Toyota calls the FCV concept car, was one of several fuel-cell vehicles expected to be introduced soon, including models from Honda and Hyundai.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hydrogen-powered cars are finally being readied for their Prius moment — at least, that is what promoters of the environmentally friendly technology hope.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at 6 a.m.
abstract: Iranian nuclear talks resume in Geneva; reaction to the painting over of a graffiti mecca in Queens; and love among sea slugs.
lead_paragraph: Iranian nuclear talks resume in Geneva; reaction to the painting over of a graffiti mecca in Queens; and love among sea slugs.

headline: A Different Kind of Mating Dance
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Research', 'Science and Technology', 'Reproduction (Biological)']
abstract: A sea slug from the Great Barrier Reef has been caught on video in a mating behavior so extreme that it appears to be a scientific first.
lead_paragraph: A sea slug from the Great Barrier Reef, so small that one would never notice it with the naked eye, has been caught on video in a mating behavior so extreme that it appears to be a scientific first.

abstract: Iranian nuclear talks resume in Geneva; reaction to the painting over of a graffiti mecca in Queens; and love among sea slugs.

headline: Ethan Koh: Inspired by Home
abstract: The designer behind Ethan K sits down with Suzy Menkes to discuss the inspiration behind his handbags.
lead_paragraph: The designer behind Ethan K sits down with Suzy Menkes to discuss the inspiration behind his handbags.

headline: How One Small Business Got Big
abstract: Fresh out of college, Rebecca Cenni went from one staffing agency to another seeking a job. No one hired her, she said, because she wanted way too much money, lacked typing skills and didn’t know how to use a computer.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners were joined by a guest, Rebecca Cenni, who founded Atrium Staffing in 1995. Atrium is a staffing and payroll firm with about 130 employees, $140 million in annual sales, and offices in New York, Boston, San Francisco, Pittsburgh, and four cities in New Jersey. Ms. Cenni talked about the challenges of growing and managing her business, offering insights she has gained since starting Atrium at age 23.

headline: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 3
keywords: ['Genealogy', 'Archives and Records', 'Baby Boomers', 'Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Slavery', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, discusses tracing an ex-slave businessman,  unearthing  pre-Ellis Island  names and other issues related to genealogy.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers’ questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members. Part 1 of her answers is here. Part 2 is here. [Update: Part 4 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

headline: Cost Aside, JPMorgan May Have a Good Deal
abstract: The $13 billion figure reached with the Justice Department may represent political theater as much as a real attempt to right wrongs.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase on Tuesday agreed to a mortgage settlement that will cost the bank $13 billion, a large number that will bolster the government’s claims that justice was done.

headline: The Two Lucknows During Muslim Holy Month
abstract: During the festival of Muharram, the differences between Old and New Lucknow could not be starker.
lead_paragraph: The raised sign for Avadh Point on Victoria Road in Old Lucknow is missing two letters, the “O” and the “I.” The “D” in Avadh also hangs precariously, as if it is ready to become the third. The three-story building was constructed in 2005, but it stands dilapidated, walls thinning and paint peeling, as if it is as old as the Awadh culture it’s named after.

headline: Crime and No Punishment
abstract: The Mexican government’s answer to drug violence is more troops and more bullets but less justice.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On the night of Jan. 30, 2010, in the border city of Ciudad Juárez, in a neighborhood called Villas de Salvarcar, a birthday party full of teenagers was interrupted by a commando. A group of about a dozen barged in shooting and ended up killing 15 people and wounding 10.

headline: Daily Report: Nokia Considers Its Uncertain Post-Handset Future
abstract: With the $7.2 billion sale of its handset unit to Microsoft nearly complete, the company must now determine how best to use its networking and mapping units, and its patents.
lead_paragraph: Nokia’s shareholders took a major step on Tuesday to reshape the company, voting overwhelmingly in favor of selling the company’s handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion, Mark Scott reports.

headline: Deal May Be Near as New Iran Nuclear Talks Open
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The talks in Geneva follow an attempt two weeks ago to clinch a deal that would put a brake on Iran’s nuclear program in return for limited sanctions relief.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Senior diplomats from six world powers and Iran opened a new round of talks on Wednesday in Geneva amid expectations that they were closing in on an agreement to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program.

headline: A Gift From Steve Jobs Returns Home
abstract: An Apple II that spent the last 33 years in Katmandu, Nepal, most of it packed away in a hospital basement there, was a rare symbol of the charity of Steven P. Jobs.
lead_paragraph: On a recent night at an elegant Beaux-Arts ballroom in San Francisco’s financial district, Laurene Powell Jobs received a computer with an unusually rich history. Around 1980, Ms. Powell Jobs’s husband, Steven P. Jobs, donated the computer to a nonprofit organization, the Seva Foundation, to help the group manage data from its efforts to restore sight in the developing world.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Glimpse Into JPMorgan’s Mortgage Machine
abstract: A JPMorgan Chase settlement offers a rare glimpse into Wall Street’s mortgage machine before the financial crisis. | A former Dell employee at the center of an insider trading case has not been accused of wrongdoing. | An Alabama county’s unusual plan to exit from bankruptcy may create a template. | Devon Energy is near a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energy for about $6 billion.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN SETTLEMENT OFFERS LOOK INTO MORTGAGE MACHINE  |  The record $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department on Tuesday wraps up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Street’s mortgage machine before the financial crisis, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

headline: Cooperating Witness a Key in SAC Insider Trading Case
abstract: There is no way to know how the government’s cooperating witness in the trial of Michael S. Steinberg will come across to the jury.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has had a perfect record in winning insider trading cases since it began its most recent campaign in 2009. Now, it will put that record to the test as the trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, begins this week. The case will highlight the crucial issue in most white-collar crime prosecutions: What did the defendant know about the illegal nature of the transactions?

headline: Giving a Subway Hog the Business
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Subways']
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A businessman pulled a rider off a crowded A train so he could take her place.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Republican Leads San Diego Mayor’s Race
abstract: Kevin Faulconer, a Republican councilman, led a field of 11 candidates vying to succeed Bob Filner, who resigned amid a sexual harassment scandal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A year after Bob Filner became the first Democratic mayor of San Diego in two decades, Republicans feel they are poised to reclaim the city’s top office.

headline: High Losses for Penney, but Shares Jump
abstract: Despite a bigger-than-expected quarterly loss, shares were up 8.4 percent on news that sales declines slowed and the holiday season brings the prospect of rising profit margins.
lead_paragraph: J. C. Penney may have reported a bigger-than-expected loss on Wednesday, but investors say they are seeing signs that the retailer’s business is improving.

headline: Too Old to Get Rich?
abstract: Tips guaranteed to make you less poor.
lead_paragraph: I wonder why nobody has ever asked me to write a personal finance column, given that I’ve done so well in this area. The mortgage on my apartment is paid off. I have no debts. I have enough money in the bank that I can live decently until 93, unless I’m flattened by a truck and the hospital doesn’t take my secondary insurance:

headline: White Supremacist Convicted of Several Murders Is Put to Death in Missouri
abstract: Joseph P. Franklin, who shot Larry Flynt and Vernon E. Jordan Jr., killed at least eight people between 1977 and 1980 in what were described as hate crimes.
lead_paragraph: Joseph P. Franklin, a white supremacist who killed at least eight people in a shooting spree from 1977 to 1980 and confessed to being the sniper who wounded the Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt and the lawyer and civil rights activist Vernon E. Jordan Jr., was executed on Wednesday, the Missouri Department of Public Safety said.

headline: Polish Prime Minister Replaces Top Cabinet Officials
abstract: The prime minister, Donald Tusk, changed several ministers, including the finance and environment ministers, as his country is hosting a climate conference.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland on Wednesday overhauled his cabinet apparently in an effort to bolster his flagging poll numbers, replacing Poland’s top finance official and changing environment ministers in the middle of a United Nations climate conference his country is hosting.

headline: Devon Clinches Deal for GeoSouthern Assets
abstract: Buying GeoSouthern’s holdings in the Eagle Ford shale formation in southern Texas will bolster Devon’s position in one of the most popular fields in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:59 p.m. | Devon Energy, an independent drilling company, reached a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energy’s holdings in southern Texas for $6 billion, the two companies announced on Wednesday, in the biggest takeover in the oil and gas industry this year.

headline: Political Questions About the Jobs Report
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Did Census Bureau employees fake unemployment data in a way that could have altered the official jobless rate and aided President Obama’s re-election campaign? It seems unlikely.
lead_paragraph: With the economy dominating the campaign for the White House last fall, did the government cook the books to make the unemployment rate move lower and help President Obama’s re-election chances? Was manipulation responsible for lowering the unemployment rate to 7.8 percent in September 2012 from 8.1 percent in August, a big deal when the numbers came out in October 2012, just weeks before the election?

headline: Spike Lee, Still Gliding to Success
abstract: Spike Lee puts his signature on a cult classic with “Oldboy,” a prototypical revenge film starring Josh Brolin.
lead_paragraph: “Rage doesn’t have to fester for years, but revenge?” the director Spike Lee said, as he rapidly autographed 50 movie posters in a downtown Manhattan hotel suite. “That stuff takes time. It’s the oldest staple of films, in stories. It goes back to the Bible.”

headline: Gina Cecala: Mayor of the Block
abstract: Gina Cecala, 82, sits sentinel in front of a building in Little Italy, bantering with mail carriers, delivery people, beggars, friends and strangers.
lead_paragraph: Gina Cecala, 82, sits sentinel in front of a building in Little Italy, bantering with mail carriers, delivery people, beggars, friends and strangers.

keywords: ['World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']

lead_paragraph: The World Trade Center’s best-kept secret has finally come to light.

headline: Frederick Sanger, 95, Twice a Nobel Laureate and a Genetics Pioneer, Dies
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Science and Technology', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: Dr. Sanger, a British biochemist, showed how amino acids link together to form insulin in 1958, and invented a method of “reading” molecular letters that make up the genetic code in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Sanger, a British biochemist whose discoveries about the chemistry of life led to the decoding of the human genome and to the development of new drugs like human growth hormone, earning him two Nobel Prizes, a distinction held by only three other scientists, died on Tuesday in Cambridge, England. He was 95.

headline: Image of the Day: November 20
abstract: People in Kochi, Kerala, exercising and taking a walk along the Fort Kochi beach.

headline: The State of Obamacare
abstract: Not as bad as you may have heard.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t been writing about the healthcare.gov thing, for the simple reason that I have nothing to say. What’s going on isn’t a policy question: we know from the states with working exchanges (including California) that the underlying structure of the law is workable. Instead, it’s about an implementation botch, which is an incredible mess, and reflects very badly on Obama. But the future of the reform depends not on policy per se but on whether the IT issues can be fixed well enough soon enough, a subject on which I have zero expertise.

headline: Today in Small Business: 577 Million Vacation Days
abstract: The owner of a restaurant chain is sentenced to prison for tax evasion. How a small-business exemption could undermine an online sales tax. Are we in a tech bubble?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Rolling Stones to Tour in Australia and New Zealand
abstract: The next leg of the Rolling Stones 50th-anniversary tour will take them to Australia and New Zealand in the spring.
lead_paragraph: Even before the Rolling Stones played what appeared to be the finale of their 50th anniversary tour, at Hyde Park in London on July 13, word was spreading among Stones fans that the band would reconvene after a hiatus, and Stones-related web pages buzzed with speculation about where the concerts would be: Germany, the Netherlands, Finland and Norway were all floated as likely, as were both North and South America.

headline: British Regulators Said to Be Reviewing Gold Benchmarks
abstract: The review by Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority is the latest area of focus by regulators on whether traders manipulated a variety of financial benchmarks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Regulators in Britain are reviewing whether global benchmarks tied to gold trading were improperly influenced as part of a wide-ranging investigation of potential manipulation of the $5 trillion-a-day currency market, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

headline: Feeling For | At Long Last, a Perfectly Designed Tote
abstract: A new line from the New York company Maharam includes features covetable bags from top designers like Jasper Morrison and Konstantin Grcic.
lead_paragraph: I am on a perpetual quest for the perfect tote bag. My dream bag is boxy, so that nothing gets lost. It feels substantial, with handles that are sturdy but not clunky-looking. It has a couple of pockets, including one with a zipper. And it has no logos. Such a bag is not, I can assure you, available on every street corner.

headline: Consecrating Hallowed Ground
abstract: The story behind Gettysburg National Cemetery.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2013, a small army of Civil War re-enactors, a well-known Lincoln impersonator, federal government representatives, the governor of Pennsylvania and its two senators, its congressional representative and a host of municipal officials gathered at the Gettysburg National Cemetery to mark the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s famous address.

headline: DeVos Institute of Arts Management to Relocate to the University of Maryland
abstract: The University of Maryland will become the new home of the DeVos Institute of Arts Management next fall when Michael Kaiser, its founder and the current president of the Kennedy Center in Washington, relocates the organization to the university.
lead_paragraph: Michael M. Kaiser’s arts management institute is moving from the Kennedy Center in Washington to the University of Maryland and Mr. Kaiser is moving with it — four months earlier than his originally announced departure.

headline: Top Japanese Court Stops Short of Nullifying 2012 Vote
abstract: In a widely watched ruling, Japan’s Supreme Court said inequities in district size needed a remedy but did not deem the parliamentary elections invalid.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a widely watched ruling, Japan’s Supreme Court on Wednesday called last year’s parliamentary elections out of compliance with the Constitution because of inequalities in the size of voting districts, but stopped short of declaring the results invalid.

headline: Ann Demeulemeester Leaves Her Company
abstract: “A new time is coming both for my personal life and the brand,” Ms. Demeulemeester wrote in a handwritten letter announcing her decision.
lead_paragraph: Ann Demeulemeester, one of the Antwerp Six designers who brought an original, if gloomy, look to fashion in the 1980s, has decided to leave her company, she said on Wednesday.

keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Cats', 'Dogs', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Helping Paws Visitor Program run by the Maui Humane Society in Hawaii offers visitors the chance to spend afternoons with the shelter’s dogs and cats–and to escort animals off the island for adoption.
lead_paragraph: Miss Fido while on vacation? In Hawaii, the Maui Humane Society offers two new fixes for pet-lonely travelers: afternoon visits with the shelter’s cats and dogs, and the opportunity to escort a pet off the island for adoption.

headline: Social Security and Secular Stagnation
abstract: Social Security may hurt saving. Good!
lead_paragraph: A brief thought inspired by the suddenly prominent debate over secular stagnation.

headline: States Are Left to Decide on Health Plan Change
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: State insurance commissioners met with President Obama and said insurers and states would have to decide to extend noncompliant health plans for one more year.
lead_paragraph: A group of state insurance commissioners emerged from a meeting with President Obama and other federal officials on Wednesday saying that state regulators would continue to decide on their own whether to go along with his recent proposal to let consumers keep older insurance plans for an extra year, even if the plans did not comply with regulations under the new health care law.

headline: The 1950s, Roiling Under the Surface
abstract: A. R. Gurney’s latest effort, “Family Furniture,” having its premiere at the Flea, is set during a transformative summer.
lead_paragraph: For more than five decades, the prolific playwright A. R. Gurney (“The Dining Room,” “Love Letters” and many more) has been a probing storyteller, peeking behind curtains into the homes of families — many of them white Anglo-Saxon Protestant, upper-class types living the lifestyle of the country club set.

headline: In Obama’s Pick to Lead a Financial Regulator, an Enigma
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Timothy G. Massad has been nominated to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, but little is known about his views on regulation of derivatives.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has nominated Timothy G. Massad to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. If you thought, “who?” — well, that may be the point.

headline: Florida Congressman in Cocaine Case Will Take a Leave of Absence
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Representative Trey Radel, a Republican, was sentenced to probation after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor charge stemming from his purchase of cocaine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, announced late Wednesday that he would take a leave of absence from office after pleading guilty earlier in the day to a misdemeanor charge stemming from his purchase of cocaine here last month. He was sentenced to one year of probation.

lead_paragraph: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.
