headline: A Snowboard Legend Explores the Obscure
abstract: In the first episode of Higher Unplugged, a new series by Teton Gravity Research, snowboarder Jeremy Jones reveals why he has abandoned iconic peaks for obscure terrain.
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of Higher Unplugged, a new series by Teton Gravity Research, snowboarder Jeremy Jones reveals why he has abandoned iconic peaks for obscure terrain.

headline: A Dublin Neighborhood Pushes Its Boundaries
abstract: Temple Bar, south of the Liffey River, is stretching beyond its tourist-destination status, adding attractions like a secret cocktail bar.
lead_paragraph: The cobbled quarter of Temple Bar has long maintained its tourist-destination status with overpriced pints of Guinness and a reputation for wild bachelor parties. While these traits endure, entrepreneurs have begun to reclaim the historic streets flanking the south side of the Liffey River. Now, locals are being lured back into the compact neighborhood. The common theme is pushing boundaries, from a secret cocktail bar to restaurants showcasing flavors beyond the typical Irish canon. With fallen prices and available real estate from the economic downturn, the heart of city center Dublin is experiencing a creative revival.

headline: Finding a Luxurious Home Away From Home
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: With more adults in the United States choosing to stay in vacation rentals, sites are increasingly catering to travelers looking for posh accommodations.
lead_paragraph: Websites like Airbnb and Couchsurfing have long helped travelers save money by renting and swapping their homes (or merely their couches) rather than pay for hotels. But as the sharing economy evolves, and as luxury travel grows, rental and home swap sites are increasingly catering to travelers with the desire (and budget) for a more sumptuous home away from home.

headline: Amid the New, Glasgow Looks to the Past
abstract: A wave of nostalgia is sweeping Glasgow, touching everything from restaurants to museums, even as the city’s skyline becomes more studded with starchitecture.
lead_paragraph: In September, the Foster and Partners-designed Hydro arena opened to much ado in Glasgow’s gritty Docks area. The translucent ultramodern building — Wi-Fi-enabled for up to 12,000 users — glowed a thousand colors and beamed spotlights up and down the River Clyde. Outside, vendors hawked rainbow wigs and tartan clan mugs. Inside, live Twitter feeds scrolled across 145 oversize high-definition screens. Rod Stewart opened the space with a bang of a show that brought out plaid-clad Glaswegians and their teenage children (and grandchildren). Mr. Stewart closed with a ripping “Da Ya Think I’m Sexy?” but rather than a crooner’s finale, it seemed more like a question the newly tarted-up city was asking itself.

headline: Times Announces Changes in Washington
abstract: Carolyn Ryan, currently heading the paper’s political coverage, will be the new bureau chief, succeeding David Leonhardt, who will head up a new venture on data and analytical reporting.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times on Wednesday announced a reorganization of its Washington bureau, including the elevation of Carolyn Ryan to bureau chief and the start of two new ventures.

headline: Another American Citizen Is Arrested in North Korea
abstract: The detainment of an 85-year-old Korean War veteran from California comes almost a year after the arrest of a Korean-American missionary who is still being held.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An 85-year-old American veteran of the Korean War was detained in North Korea last month as he was about to depart after having visited the country on a tourist visa, his son said on Wednesday.

headline: Italian Oil Giant Eni Plans to Sell Gas Field in Russia
abstract: The sale of fields on Russia’s Yamal Peninsula comes as other Western companies are moving in the opposite direction, seeking to explore in the far north.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Eni, the Italian oil company, said on Wednesday that it intended to sell its stake in a natural gas field in the far north of Russia for about $2.9 billion and focus instead on a subsea pipeline and another Arctic Ocean venture.

headline: For Some, Paying Sales Commissions No Longer Makes Sense
abstract: To many in competitive sales, switching to straight salary is blasphemy. But with pricing and policies readily available online, some see commissions as an impediment.
lead_paragraph: At the start of 2012, ThoughtWorks, a software company based in Chicago, decided to upend one of the sacrosanct principles of sales. It eliminated commissions and placed its entire sales force, a team of 40 stretching across 12 countries, on straight salary.

headline: Bronx Tale of a BB Gun and Infamy in the Making
abstract: Until now, a grandfather’s recollection of an encounter with a future assassin has been a story shared mostly among members of the Jacobs family in New York.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years ago, a seventh grader at the East Midwood Hebrew Day School in Brooklyn needed to complete a social studies assignment, something along the lines of what was it like in the olden days. She set down a cassette tape recorder in front of her saba, her grandfather, and pressed a button.

headline: Can You Attract Top Sales Representatives if You Don’t Pay Sales Commissions?
abstract: ThoughtWorks of Chicago and RJMetrics of Philadelphia have chosen opposing approaches.
lead_paragraph: An article just published in The Times looks at companies that have decided to stop paying sales commissions to its sales representatives.

headline: Thompson Finds Job at Old Office
abstract: William C. Thompson Jr., the former New York City comptroller who waged an unsuccessful bid for mayor, is returning to his positions at Siebert Brandford Shank & Company L.L.C.
lead_paragraph: William C. Thompson Jr., the former New York City comptroller who this year waged an unsuccessful bid for mayor, announced on Wednesday that he was returning to the municipal bond underwriting firm where he had previously worked.

headline: Rodriguez Walks Out of Hearing and Pleads Case on Radio
abstract: The Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez said he was “disgusted” with the process, in part because the arbitrator had refused to order Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, to testify.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez, locked in a fight with Major League Baseball over his 211-game doping suspension, slammed down his hand and walked out of his arbitration hearing Wednesday morning, saying he was “disgusted with this abusive process.”

headline: Student Crossword | Under the Sea: Marine Life
abstract: You can learn more about marine life by playing our crossword, either online or in print.
lead_paragraph: Learn more about marine life by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Wall Street Could Benefit From Tax Proposal
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Law and Legislation', 'Taxation']
abstract: A proposal by Senator Max Baucus to revise international tax rules would help financial services firms that tend to have high effective tax rates, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Changes to the tax code always create winners and losers. An ambitious plan to revise the system for taxing multinational corporations, released on Tuesday by the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Max Baucus, would hit technology companies and large pharmaceutical companies especially hard. Companies like Pfizer, Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Microsoft have become masters at reducing their tax liability in the United States by shifting income overseas.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Investor Continues to Push for Deal With Jos. A. Bank
abstract: Eminence Capital unveiled a presentation trumpeting the benefits of a merger of the men’s suit retailers and pressed for a special meeting of its fellow investors.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest investors in Men’s Wearhouse made clear on Wednesday that it saw no better future for the retailer than a merger with its smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank.

headline: Jaguar Introduces F-Type Coupe With a Laser Show
abstract: Lasers, spotlights and all sorts of British food and drink accompanied the unveiling of the new Jaguar F-Type Coupe on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities, such as Simon Cowell and Adam Carolla, gathered with a horde of largely unknown journalists Tuesday night to greet the new Jaguar F-Type Coupe, which the automaker unveiled at an event near the Los Angeles Auto Show.

headline: The Chronicles of C. S. Lewis Lead to Poets’ Corner
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: Though he is not known for his poetry, the writer and theologian C. S. Lewis will be getting a memorial stone on Friday in the Poets’ Corner in Westminster Abbey.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — C. S. Lewis was a noted polymath: philosopher, theologian, professor, novelist, children’s writer, literary critic, lecturer. But he was not much of a poet.

headline: In Westchester, an End to Elevator and Subway Commutes
abstract: Eric and Megan Zinger wanted to move from New York to the suburbs.
lead_paragraph: Megan Zinger tried her very best to be a city mouse.

headline: On Day of Symbolism, Honoring Kennedy, and Successor He Inspired
abstract: At a ceremony bestowing the Medal of Freedom, an honor created by John F. Kennedy, President Obama recognized an unusually star-studded list of 16 people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing wordlessly before a flickering flame, their faces etched in the sunlight slanting through a canopy of thinning trees, two Democratic presidents came together Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery to honor the memory of a third.

headline: App Smart: Making Art With a Stylus
abstract: The Times’s Kit Eaton reviews painting and sketching apps where using a stylus, instead of just your finger, can come in quite handy.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Kit Eaton reviews painting and sketching apps where using a stylus, instead of just your finger, can come in quite handy.

headline: The Unemployment Rate at Full Employment: How Low Can You Go?
abstract: As the Federal Reserve tries to calibrate the unemployment target in its monetary policy, it can afford to aim for a far lower rate without inviting an unacceptable level of inflation, two economists write.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. Dean Baker is a co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research. They are the authors of “Getting Back to Full Employment: A Better Bargain for Working People,” being published this week.

headline: 24,000-Year-Old Body Shows Kinship to Europeans and American Indians
abstract: The genome of a boy indicates that Europeans reached farther east across Eurasia than previously assumed, and that Native Americans may be descended from a mix of Western Europeans and East Asians.
lead_paragraph: The genome of a young boy buried at Mal’ta near Lake Baikal in eastern Siberia some 24,000 years ago has turned out to hold two surprises for anthropologists.

headline: Painting With a Stylus, Despite What Steve Jobs Said
abstract: Human fingers work fine on touch screens for most purposes, but a stylus may bring out your inner artist.
lead_paragraph: When he introduced the iPhone and iPad, Steven P. Jobs asserted the touch-screen devices didn’t need a stylus because humans come with 10 great touch-screen controllers sticking out of our palms: fingers. He was proved right, and most new smartphones and tablets don’t require a stylus to work their touch screen.

headline: Q. & A. | Kathleen Hanna on Love, Illness and the Life-Affirming Joy of Punk Rock
abstract: The riot grrrl legend, the subject of the documentary “The Punk Singer,” reflects on her early days with Bikini Kill, battling Lyme disease and life with husband Adam Horovitz of the Beastie Boys. Plus: see an exclusive clip from the film here.
lead_paragraph: As the incendiary lead singer of the band Bikini Kill, Kathleen Hanna became the most famous face of the riot grrrl movement, the early-’90s feminist counterpart to grunge. (She coined the phrase “smells like teen spirit,” which her friend Kurt Cobain would make famous.) Later, she moved from the Pacific Northwest to New York City, where she fronted the socially conscious dance-rock outfit Le Tigre, and most recently she founded the band the Julie Ruin, which released the kinetic record “Run Fast” in September.

headline: Albuquerque Rejects 20-Week Abortion Ban
abstract: When voters are asked to weigh in on reproductive rights issues directly, the results often go counter to the restrictive trend at the legislative level.
lead_paragraph: Earlier in 2013, the House proposed a ban on abortion after 20 weeks, and twelve states have gone ahead and enacted such bans. But when Americans are asked if legislators should be spending their time restricting the abortion window, most respondents say no. And the more Americans hear about what a 20-week bans really entail, the more they grow wary of them.

headline: Russia Revokes License of a Bank With Ties to Putin
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Master Bank, which has a cousin of President Vladimir V. Putin on its board, could require the largest bailout in recent years. Its managers have been accused of siphoning off assets.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s central bank on Wednesday revoked the license of a midsize Russian bank, Master Bank, and accused its management of siphoning off assets in insider deals, in one of the larger bank failures here in recent years.

headline: Broadcasters’ Fight Against Aereo Doesn’t Serve Their Interests
abstract: Too often, media content producers seem to fear technological shifts that ultimately help them grow, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The latest TV industry technophobia is just as repetitive as a 1980s rerun. American broadcasters, including Walt Disney-owned ABC, have garnered support in their Supreme Court bid to shut down the online video start-up Aereo. The arguments echo those used 30 years ago when networks tried to block the VCR, after which business boomed. For a creative profession, media firms sure can lack imagination.

headline: Egyptian Nazi Will No Longer Participate at Georgetown Conference
abstract: The university withdrew its invitation to Ramy Jan, a founder of the Egyptian Nazi Party, a group that promotes Arab racial supremacy, to address a conference next month in Washington on the future of Egypt .
lead_paragraph: Georgetown University has come under fire for inviting a founder of the Egyptian Nazi Party to a conference planned for December on the future of Egypt, which will feature a keynote speech by Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota, the first Muslim member of the United States Congress, and Dalia Mogahed, a former adviser to President Obama.

headline: Aid Distribution and Rebuilding in the Philippines
abstract: Food and water remain scarce, but aid is beginning to reach typhoon-affected areas.
lead_paragraph: Food and water remain scarce, but aid is beginning to reach typhoon-affected areas.

headline: Turkey Economics, Annotated
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Turkeys']
abstract: Some charts and research looking at why prices fall during periods of peak demand for products like turkeys and TVs.
lead_paragraph: My It’s the Economy column for this Sunday looks at an economic puzzle: why whole frozen turkey prices typically fall just when demand is highest, around Thanksgiving. Below I’ve compiled some of the data and theory that went into my reporting for those interested in digging a bit deeper into turkey economics.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Giants quarterback Eli Manning leads the list of who figures to be hot among fantasy scorers in Week 12.
lead_paragraph: Eli Manning, we just can’t quit you.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Explores the Obscure
abstract: In the first episode of “Higher Unplugged,” a new series by Teton Gravity Research, the snowboarder Jeremy Jones reveals why he has abandoned iconic peaks for obscure terrain.
lead_paragraph: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: The Gun Report: November 20, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.

headline: Illegal Immigrants Are Divided Over Importance of Citizenship
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Congress’s efforts on immigration have foundered over naturalization for those in the United States illegally. Yet many immigrants say they would settle for less.
lead_paragraph: Glendy Martínez is waiting anxiously to see if Congress will ever pass legislation to allow immigrants like her, without papers, to stay in the country legally. But frankly, she says, she does not care if it will include any promise of citizenship.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Is the Man...’
abstract: The director Michel Gondry narrates a scene from his animated documentary interview with Noam Chomsky, “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?”
lead_paragraph: The director Michel Gondry narrates a scene from his animated documentary interview with Noam Chomsky, “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?”

headline: Fed Looks for Other Ways to Aid Economy
abstract: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee wrestled at its most recent meeting with ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials, many of them reluctant to continue the Fed’s economic stimulus campaign in its current form, wrestled at their most recent meeting with other ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.

headline: What You Get For … $2,500,000
abstract: Properties include a Garden District house in New Orleans, a converted barn in Connecticut and a midcentury modern in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Properties include a Garden District house in New Orleans, a converted barn in Connecticut and a midcentury modern in Los Angeles.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
abstract: Homes include a Garden District house in New Orleans, a converted barn in Connecticut and a midcentury modern in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Dad Was a Film Giant, Mum Was Mona Lisa. Perfect, Right?
abstract: In “A Story Lately Told,” Anjelica Huston describes growing up in an exotic family and amid movie and literary royalty in Ireland, London, Paris and New York.
lead_paragraph: Anjelica Huston grew up in such a bedazzlingly beautiful place that she couldn’t see beyond its magic. At least that’s the impression created by “A Story Lately Told,” the first half of Ms. Huston’s life story. In this charm-filled but often oddly opaque book, she writes of life at St. Clerans, the grand estate in County Galway, Ireland, full of pets, flowers, exotic treasures and her parents’ famous friends. Ms. Huston presents lovely inventories of the things that made St. Clerans special, but she never says much about the elephant in the room.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?’
abstract: The director Michel Gondry narrates a sequence from his animated documentary interview with Noam Chomsky.
lead_paragraph: For his new documentary, the director Michel Gondry interviewed the linguist and philosopher Noam Chomsky. The interview blends live-action footage and animated sequences — many of them drawn by Mr. Gondry. In this video, Mr. Gondry narrates an early sequence in which he asks Mr. Chomsky about his first memory.

headline: The True Accountability in the JPMorgan Settlement
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: While criminal fines and civil penalties make for big headlines, the Justice Department also negotiated some relief for homeowners who suffered from JPMorgan’s mortgage practices.
lead_paragraph: The watchword in the Justice Department’s $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over the sale of questionable mortgage-backed securities is “accountability.” References to accountability appear 11 times in the news release detailing the resolution of federal and state cases against the bank over how it packaged faulty mortgages and sold them to investors.

headline: Tribune Company to Cut 700 Newspaper Employees
abstract: Tribune, which is making itself into a broadcast company, said the layoffs would affect mostly the business side of the newspapers.
lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, will lay off 700 employees at those newspapers and the six others it owns, it said in memos to the staff on Wednesday.

headline: Fighting Hearing Loss From the Crowd’s Roar
abstract: The noise at football games and other events is enough to cause permanent damage and to increase the likelihood of future damage. A few simple steps may help minimize the risks.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this fall, Seattle Seahawks fans at CenturyLink Field broke the world record for loudest stadium crowd with a skull-splitting 136.6 decibels.

headline: Global Fund Suspends 2 Mosquito Net Makers
abstract: A spokesman for the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria said he was confident no shortage of nets would develop.
lead_paragraph: The two top producers of mosquito nets for the war on malaria have been temporarily banned as suppliers by a global disease-fighting fund after admitting that they paid bribes to health officials in Cambodia.

headline: Afghan Migrants in Iran Face Painful Contradictions but Keep Coming
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The nearly three million Afghan migrants in Iran have few rights and are often deported multiple times. But they keep returning, because they still find better education and job opportunities there.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — They have few rights, can be arrested on sight and deprived of a trial, and are often deported four, five or more times — and no sooner are they across the border than they head back.

headline: 10 Awesome Geek Gifts for Girls
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Gifts', 'Parenting', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Toys', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Nothing is more depressing than to be the sister who gets the sparkly sweater while your brother unwraps his remote control building kit.
lead_paragraph: There’s lots of online love for this GoldieBlox commercial (hat tip to Katy Waldman at Slate), with its Rube Goldberg use of dozens of pink toys and renegade rewrite of the Beastie Boys’ “Girls” song:

headline: Paul Ryan, Marxist
abstract: Or maybe he has been trolling after all.
lead_paragraph: Groucho Marxist, that is.

headline: House Hunting in Sweden
abstract: Although vacation-home prices remained steady in Sweden during the downturn, very few homes have changed hands in the last three to four years.
lead_paragraph: Although vacation-home prices remained steady in Sweden during the downturn, very few homes have changed hands in the last three to four years.

headline: House Hunting in ... Sweden
abstract: Although vacation-home prices remained steady in Sweden during the downturn, very few homes have changed hands in the last three to four years.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM TIMBER HOME IN STOCKSUND

headline: Lady Gaga Hits No. 1
abstract: Gaga’s “Artpop” knocked Eminem off the top of the album chart, but the big winner of the week may be the Universal Music Group.
lead_paragraph: The big winners on the music charts this week: Lady Gaga, Lorde and the Universal Music Group.

headline: Rob Ford, America’s Mayor
abstract: Toronto’s mayor galvanized the news-as-entertainment loop long existing between the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: The senior Washington correspondent of Canada’s CBC News, Neil Macdonald, has been dutifully filing on the serial misbehavior of Toronto’s crack-smoking, binge-drinking mayor, Rob Ford, finding comfort in the fact that Mr. Ford at least has toppled Canada’s “reputation for monotonous, self-effacing reserve.”

headline: After Another Knee Injury, Duration of Recovery for Vonn Is Uncertain
abstract: The injury, to Lindsey Vonn’s anterior cruciate ligament in her right knee, the same ligament she tore in February, caused her to suspend her return to downhill skiing indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: In February, days after she sustained the first major knee injury of her career, Lindsey Vonn vowed to return to ski racing in record time. To Vonn, rehabilitating her reconstructed right anterior cruciate ligament became another competition — and she sped past every milestone in her recovery.

headline: New Minibar Offerings: Handbags and Jewlery
abstract: Minibars at the Quin hotel in New York include handbags, cuff links, and candles.
lead_paragraph: The Quin, a new luxury art-themed hotel on Manhattan’s West Side, has a unique take on the minibar. In addition to a traditional fridge with snacks and drinks, the 208 rooms have a “provisions cabinet” selling high-end items like jewelry, handbags and cuff links.

headline: 23 Weeks Pregnant, With ‘No Good Choices’
abstract: I was 23 weeks pregnant when the doctor said four words that changed three lives: “The heart looks abnormal.”
lead_paragraph: I was 23 weeks pregnant with my first child when we had our anatomic ultrasound here in Chile. In a darkened examination room, the doctor drew the wand over my belly, and our beautiful baby appeared on screen. His body flickered of his own volition, and I squeezed my husband’s shoulder in relief. The doctor measured the circumference of our baby’s head, drew digital white lines down each limb, and examined the kidneys, stomach and spine. He confirmed the gender of our boy and sent his heartbeat to travel across the bottom of the screen at 142 beats per minute.

headline: Republican Talking Points on Obamacare
abstract: The House Republicans’ response to the Affordable Care Act is increasingly organized and orchestrated, including collections of stories about people who say they were harmed by the health care law.
lead_paragraph: The House Republicans’ response to the Affordable Care Act is increasingly organized and orchestrated, including collections of stories about people who say they were harmed by the health care law.

headline: Presidential Medal of Freedom Awarded
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Presidential Medal of Freedom']
abstract: President Obama presented the award to 16 Americans, including former President Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: President Obama presented the award to 16 Americans, including former President Bill Clinton.

headline: De Blasio Talks With 3 Candidates for Police Commissioner
abstract: New York’s mayor-elect said he spoke with former Commissioner William J. Bratton; Philip Banks III, the Police Department’s top chief; and the first deputy commissioner, Rafael Pineiro.
lead_paragraph: Breaking several days of silence, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio offered a glimpse on Wednesday into his efforts to form a new administration, acknowledging that he had met with three leading contenders for New York City’s next police commissioner.

headline: Pact May Extend U.S. Troops’ Stay in Afghanistan
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said emphatically that there was no discussion of an American apology to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan or to his nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Wednesday that the United States and Afghanistan had finalized the wording of a bilateral security agreement that would allow for a lasting American troop presence through 2024 and set the stage for billions of dollars of international assistance to keep flowing to the government in Kabul.

headline: ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Will Close on Dec. 8
abstract: David Leveaux’s production, starring Orlando Bloom and Condola Rashad, will have played 93 regular performances.
lead_paragraph: The producers of “Romeo and Juliet” have announced that the show, which was the Broadway debut of Orlando Bloom (“Lord of the Rings”), will close on Dec. 8, more than a month earlier than had been previously planned.

headline: Where Does JPMorgan’s $13 Billion Go?
abstract: The money will flow to a range of government authorities, some more obscure than others.
lead_paragraph: They were some of the biggest losers in the 2008 financial crisis: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, federal taxpayers, state pension funds, credit unions and, of course, homeowners.

headline: Talking Health Insurance Over Thanksgiving Dinner
abstract: The president’s urging Americans to “have the talk” this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a hypothetical scenario: You’re the president. You’ve just botched the roll out of what should have been your signature accomplishment, a major reform of the health insurance system. The public’s hopping mad because you said anyone who liked his insurance plan would be able to keep it, but that wasn’t true.

headline: In an Attack Ad, an Alaskan Voter Is Really an Actress From Maryland
abstract: Senator Mark Begich, the target of the ad, calls it an illegitimate attack from outsiders who have no business getting involved in Alaska politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – In a tough new advertisement from the Koch brothers-backed Americans for Prosperity, an unnamed woman looks directly into the camera and upbraids Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska.

headline: E.C.B. Nominates New Banking Regulator
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The governing council of the European Central Bank nominated Danièle Nouy to lead a new agency that will act as a central overseer over banking regulations across the euro zone.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The governing council of the European Central Bank nominated Danièle Nouy on Wednesday as head of the new central bank regulator for the euro zone. With the move, the council fills one of the most prominent job openings in Europe while answering criticism that it has no women in senior leadership positions.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Kaufmann Mercantile Ceramic Growler
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: something for the beer-drinking, environmentally conscious types.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Emblematically Yours
abstract: Logo culture reaches the next frontier as design elements for fashion.
lead_paragraph: Logo culture reaches the next frontier as design elements for fashion.

headline: Surveillance Camera Captures Embassy Blast in Beirut
abstract: Video released on Wednesday showed the first of two deadly explosions at the Iranian Embassy in Beirut the day before.
lead_paragraph: As the death toll continued to rise from the double bombing at the Iranian embassy compound in Beirut on Tuesday, surveillance video was released showing the moment of the first explosion. The footage was posted online by Al Mayadeen television, which highlighted what it identified as one of the explosives-laden vehicles used in the attack. It was also broadcast by Al Manar television and LBCI.

headline: Video: Fashion Diversity in Africa
abstract: Sporting overalls and arms covered in tattoos, Spleef Mczaul was recently walking along the street in the Maboneng Precinct in Johannesburg.
lead_paragraph: Sporting overalls, yellow tinted glasses and arms covered in tattoos, Spleef Mczaul was recently walking along the street in the Maboneng Precinct in Johannesburg. Mr. Mczaul, who is opening a vintage store in the area, credits the neighborhood for bringing diversity in fashion to South Africa. “It’s people from different places coming together,” Mr. Mczaul said. “You’ll see someone who is wearing an English coat but with an African-print T-shirt.”

headline: J.F.K. Through the Pages of The Times
abstract: Fifty years after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, a new book showcases The Times’s coverage of his era.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, a new book showcases The Times’s coverage of his era.

headline: Right Stuff? The Library Thinks So, and Buys It
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The New York Public Library is acquiring Tom Wolfe’s manuscripts, research materials, letters and other papers for $2.15 million.
lead_paragraph: Tom Wolfe has long been a gleeful scourge of New York’s cultural institutions and the people who make them hum, from novelty-seeking museum curators and the mandarins of The New Yorker to the Wall Street buckaroos and “social X-ray” wives who swan around at all those galas.

headline: AT&T and Verizon Pressed to Detail Roles in U.S. Surveillance Efforts
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Privacy', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Shareholder resolutions are demanding more disclosure about the companies’ role in handing over customer data to the government.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders are putting AT&T and Verizon Wireless on notice: Tell the public more about the companies’ role in government surveillance efforts or risk a ding to the bottom line.

headline: Scene City: Balenciaga Opens a Marbled Store in SoHo
abstract: Alexander Wang, Julianne Moore and others unveil the brand’s flagship store in New York.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang, Julianne Moore and others unveil the brand’s flagship store in New York.

headline: The Return of Logo Culture
abstract: The recent rise in logos is in part a rejection of the anti-capitalist, grunge, no-logo 1990s.
lead_paragraph: There are 17 logos on Heron Preston’s signature long-sleeve T-shirt: M&Ms and Trix; Google and Remington; Home Depot, huge, on the back; Nascar, upside down, on the front.

headline: John F. Kennedy Presidential Library
abstract: The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston emphasizes Kennedy as a president whose promise was cut short.
lead_paragraph: The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston emphasizes Kennedy as a president whose promise was cut short.

headline: Recalling Kennedy’s Death, or Life
abstract: Museums at John F. Kennedy’s assassination site in Dallas and his presidential library approach their subject in different ways.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Looking through the window next to the sniper’s perch, you can just make out the grassy knoll through the trees’ branches. It seems inconsequential, mundane — certainly not as imagination pictured it. A “knoll”? There are no rolling English hillocks in Dealey Plaza. There is a one-way, three-lane road that curves under an overpass, with plots of lawn on either side.

headline: After Kennedy Tragedy, Finding Solace in Art
abstract: Six watercolors that are part of a show of John Singer Sargent paintings at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, have special meaning to John F. Kennedy’s family.
lead_paragraph: In 1961, Jacqueline Kennedy created the office of the White House curator, transforming the nation’s most famous residence for the first time into a collecting art institution, which it remains to this day. But that same year, she also reached out for a handful of artworks that would come to play a profoundly personal role in her life before and after her husband’s death.

headline: Developing Nations Stage Protest at Climate Talks
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Global Warming', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)']
abstract: Representatives from China and a collection of developing countries known as the Group of 77 walked out of the talks to protest what they consider inadequate financial support from wealthy countries.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The United Nations climate talks here are bogging down over the old divide between rich and poor nations on the question of who should pay when climate-related disaster strikes, with developing nations staging a symbolic walkout early Wednesday in protest at what they consider inadequate financial support from wealthy countries.

headline: Who Do You Want to Be (Besides a Playful Codger)?
abstract: In “Every Day a Visitor,” the residents of a retirement home decide to play an all-encompassing game, and in certain ways, it saves their lives.
lead_paragraph: Ending up in a retirement home could be joyous — if you’ve always wanted to relive dorm life and would like it even better with everybody having gotten cranky and lost both their youthful good looks and their hearing. (“You have to say everything twice in this place.”) And with no choice about which drugs you take or when. Richard Abrons apparently gave this prospect some thought before writing “Every Day a Visitor,” which Woodie King Jr.’s New Federal Theater is presenting at the Clurman Theater with a colorful, lovable and mostly mature cast.

headline: For Sale: Digital Camera. Estimated Price: $500,000 to $750,000.
abstract: A one-of-a-kind Leica designed by Marc Newson and Apple’s Jony Ive is part of an auction to be held to benefit RED, the charity founded by Bono and Bobby Shriver.
lead_paragraph: Are you in need of a new digital camera? I have a deal for you. It’s a one-of-a-kind Leica that will cost an estimated $500,000 to $750,000. What about a new Mac computer? I know where you can pick one up for about $60,000. Need some new headphones? I have a deal on those, too. A pair of solid rose gold iPod earbuds for about $25,000.

headline: Improvising in Total Darkness
abstract: The JACK Quartet performed Georg Friedrich Haas’s String Quartet No. 3 at the Clark Studio Theater in a show not for those afraid of the dark.
lead_paragraph: Darkness enveloped me as I listened to the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas’s String Quartet No. 3 on Tuesday night at Lincoln Center’s Clark Studio Theater. This is the way the composer intended for the piece to be performed. As much as I was engrossed by the music, the performance by the JACK Quartet and the rare experience of hearing music with others in darkness, I could not help feeling that some uncomfortable assumptions were being made for this event, called “In the Dark,” part of the center’s White Light Festival.

headline: Bodies That Spin, Sway and Swerve in Shadows
abstract: Complexions Contemporary Ballet highlighted two works, “Flight” and “Recur,” at its opening-night performance at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: In Complexions Contemporary Ballet, dancers kick their legs to make a show of it. They swivel their hips with insouciance. Their swaying bodies might look as if they’re about to tip over, until a breath — irritatingly visible in a heaving chest — forces them upright. They are skilled technicians. The issue with Complexions, led by the founding artistic directors Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, is how far the repertory is from actually being contemporary.

headline: Michael Cappelletti and His One-No-Trump Opening
abstract: Cappelletti, who died on Nov. 14, at 71, amassed 24,317.23 master points, placing him 49th on the lifetime list.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cappelletti of Alexandria, Va., died on Nov. 14, at 71. In national championships, he won the 1967 Master Mixed Teams and the 2013 Leventritt Silver Ribbon Pairs and had seven seconds. He amassed 24,317.23 master points, placing him 49th on the lifetime list.

headline: Memoir to Musical: Five-Year Journey
abstract: Lisa Kron and Jeanine Tesori had their work cut out for them with “Fun Home,” a musical version of Alison Bechdel’s memoir.
lead_paragraph: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has presented his share of complicated new musicals. But “Fun Home,” he said, was in a class by itself.

headline: Techies Striving for the Next Big Thing
abstract: In “Betas,” which will stream on Amazon, a four-man crew is trying to start a stalker-friendly “social-networking” app in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: “Betas” represents such an amalgam of digital story lines — it’s about a Silicon Valley start-up, and it’s bankrolled and hosted by an Internet behemoth, Amazon — that it’s tempting to review it as if it were a new app rather than an online comedy. Such as: While it lacks some features found in big-budget television sitcoms, and it can be glitchy when it comes to racial and sexual humor, it provides a better user experience than a majority of online series. A solid three-and-a-half stars.

headline: Roasted Turkey Stock
abstract: Julia Moskin makes roasted turkey stock adapted from a recipe by Suzanne Goin of A.O.C. restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin makes roasted turkey stock adapted from a recipe by Suzanne Goin of A.O.C. restaurant.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The Philippines and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from The Philippines, Virginia, Lebanon and Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The Philippines, Virginia, Lebanon and Bulgaria.

headline: Food Stamp Spending and Caseload Are Declining, Report Says
abstract: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities said the number of people on food stamps was declining month to month in about half the states and increasing incrementally in the other half.
lead_paragraph: The money spent on food stamps and the number of people who receive them are declining as the economy has improved, according to a report released Wednesday, even as the program remains a source of contention in congressional negotiations to complete a five-year farm bill.

headline: Ballet Dancers as Brands
abstract: Increasingly, star dancers like Natalia Osipova, aware of the brevity of their time in the spotlight, are switching among companies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They are the new jeté set.

headline: Empowering Girls to Build the Future
abstract: GoldieBlox, a toy company, produced a commercial featuring three young girls that turn an average home into a massive, magical contraption.
lead_paragraph: GoldieBlox, a toy company, produced a commercial featuring three young girls that turn an average home into a massive, magical contraption.

headline: What’s He Really Like? Check the Lulu App
abstract: Lulu, a female-friendly social networking app, lets users anonymously review their male Facebook friends, with scores appearing under a rated man’s profile picture.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, after Alexandra Amin, an assistant at Warner Brothers, broke up with an agent she had been dating for a year, her friend told her about a new, free, female-friendly social networking app that lets women anonymously review men who are their Facebook friends.

headline: Making Turkey Stock With Suzanne Goin
abstract: Post your questions about making stock with your Thanksgiving turkey bones.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Nov. 25, 2013

headline: For Alexander Wang, a SoHo Housewarming Party
abstract: Celebrities including Julianne Moore, but no Kanye, celebrated the opening of Balenciaga’s vast new store.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Alexander Wang, the new designer for Balenciaga, arrived for the opening of its SoHo store at 148 Mercer Street. It was heavy on the Italian green marble and limestone.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at 6 p.m.
abstract: President Obama awards Medals of Freedom; a study compares daily quizzes with exams; and a 'real' mayor of New York City.
lead_paragraph: President Obama awards Medals of Freedom; a study compares daily quizzes with exams; and a 'real' mayor of New York City.

headline: Egypt’s Revolution Was ‘Stolen’ by Muslim Brotherhood, Kerry Says
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry argued that Egypt’s 2011 revolution was started by tech-savvy young people with no ideological aims before being “stolen by” the Islamists who took power in democratic elections.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry argued on Wednesday that Egypt’s 2011 revolution was started by tech-savvy young people with no ideological aims before being “stolen by” Islamists from the Muslim Brotherhood, who behaved autocratically after winning parliamentary and presidential elections.

headline: The New York Times Minute
abstract: President Obama awards Medals of Freedom; a study compares daily quizzes with exams; and a “real” mayor of New York City.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Rupert and Wendi Murdoch Reach a Divorce Settlement
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation and 21st Century Fox, and Wendi Deng Murdoch agreed to end their 14-year marriage.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch and Wendi Deng Murdoch appeared in court Wednesday morning and announced they had reached a divorce settlement, an agreement that effectively ends the 14-year marriage of the media mogul and his third wife.

headline: Building Luxury Villas for Poor Neighbors
abstract: A rich man’s gift to family and friends in his home village has won admiration as an unusually generous act of filial piety.
lead_paragraph: When 26-year-old Tang Guo left his hometown in Sichuan Province for the neighboring province of Yunnan in 1993, all he had was 2 renminbi in his pocket and, as Mr. Tang put it, a willingness to “eat bitterness,” a Chinese term for resilience and toughness. Twenty years later, Mr. Tang is the head of a real estate construction group with 20 subsidiaries and fixed assets worth more than 2 billion renminbi, or about $328 million.

headline: Art Furniture: A Form-Function Twofer
abstract: It’s not just interesting to look at, you can also sit on it, shower with it or admire yourself in it.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Behun is an interior designer with the eye of a gallerist. “The way I look at things,” she said, “designing a space is an exercise in curating: the chairs, the lamps and all that stuff is sculpture.”

headline: Sales at DDC, Park Avenue Garage and Others
abstract: Bargains on furniture, accessories and rugs.
lead_paragraph: DDC has opened a temporary outlet shop, with furniture and decorative accessories discounted up to 70 percent (the Andersen sofa by Rodolfo Dordoni for Minotti, originally $11,935, is $8,354); 33 East 33rd Street, 212-685-0800, ddcnyc.com.

headline: At 89, a Pioneering Street Photographer Finally Gets His Due
abstract: Saul Leiter, whose painterly urban scenes in the 1940s and ’50s are highly regarded by aficionados, is the subject of a new documentary and monograph.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}
