abstract: Bored with the L.B.D.? Here is the L.B.J. for holiday parties this year.
lead_paragraph: Bored with the L.B.D.? Here is the L.B.J. for holiday parties this year.

headline: Time to Take the Leap
abstract: The black jumpsuit is replacing the little black dress.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the L.B.D. — so simple, so sensible, so ... snoozy. This holiday season, may we suggest the L.B.J.?

headline: Do As He Says, Not As He Does
abstract: The landscape architect Thomas Rainer defends his garden.
lead_paragraph: The landscape architect Thomas Rainer defends his garden.

headline: He’ll Try Anything
abstract: Yes, even banana plants. The landscape architect Thomas Rainer defends his garden.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Don’t look at the garden in the pictures. This is no place Thomas Rainer wants exposed to the world.

headline: City (Manchester) in the City (N.Y.)
abstract: Manchester City released a short video of its players in some New York locales as the club promoted the coming launch of New York City F.C.
lead_paragraph: What do Brooklyn Bridge Park, the High Line, Yankee Stadium and Rucker Park have in common, besides being part of the fabric of New York City?

headline: What Would Sister Parish Do?
abstract: The beauty of a boxy apartment is that you can do anything you want with it, including turning it into an homage to the most celebrated decorators of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: The beauty of a boxy apartment is that you can do anything you want with it, including turning it into an homage to the most celebrated decorators of the 20th century.

headline: The Peak of Chic: Borrowing From the Best
abstract: As Jennifer Boles discovered, the beauty of a boxy apartment is that you can do anything you want with it.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Boles lives in a two-bedroom apartment in a brutalist high-rise on Peachtree Road. This stark, bunkerlike setting is worth noting because Ms. Boles, 41, is the creator of the Peak of Chic design blog, a love letter to — nay, an epic poem in celebration of — the sort of effusive, ebullient and, yes, very traditional decorating practiced by Dorothy Draper, Nancy Lancaster, Albert Hadley and Sister Parish, among other 20th-century greats. A more stark contrast between Ms. Boles’s highly embellished, high-gloss interiors, with their faux finishes, leopard prints, tufted wallpaper and Porthault sheets, and the building’s gritty concrete skin can hardly be imagined.

headline: Ryan McGinley, the Pied Piper of the Downtown Art World
abstract: Mr. McGinley, impresario of a set of young downtown artists, is a sort of new-day Warhol.
lead_paragraph: The social orbit surrounding the photographer Ryan McGinley can sometimes feel like the world’s most exclusive nightclub, populated by good-looking and talented 20-somethings, who with their perfect skin and classic faces all seem to have walked out of a Kerouac novel, an idyllic Midwestern town or an American Apparel ad.

headline: Catering to the Masses: A New Edition of ‘Cooking for Crowds’
abstract: Merry White’s 1974 classic is updated to speak to today’s anxious hosts.
lead_paragraph: In Merry White’s Boston high school, lunch was a class called Gracious Living, where all the food was beige and served by maids, and pepper was considered “too heating for young ladies.” “From then on,” she writes in the foreword to the new 40th-anniversary edition of her 1974 classic, “Cooking for Crowds” (Princeton University Press, $29.95), “my life has been a search for the heat and pleasure of food.” Her book, made up of recipes she collected as the caterer for the Harvard Center for European Studies, suggested a new way of entertaining, with self-serve spanakopita, petite shrimp quiche and that savior of the anxious cook, the casserole that can be made a day ahead. Edward Koren’s woolly illustrations set the tone: vegetables are our friends, and food tastes best in groups. Even though pesto and vindaloo are no longer exotic, during the holidays her attitude (and her meatballs) may be what every stressed-out host needs.

headline: Belated, Yes; Forgotten, No: A Tribute to Dan Kiley
abstract: An exhibition in Boston celebrates the life and work of the well-known landscape architect.
lead_paragraph: “Imagine not celebrating the 100th anniversary of the architect Mies van der Rohe’s birth,” said Charles Birnbaum, the founder of the Cultural Landscape Foundation. But in September 2012, that’s precisely the fate that befell Dan Kiley, the seminal postwar landscape architect behind the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial in St. Louis, featuring Eero Saarinen’s Gateway Arch, and Patterns, the garden of the du Pont home in Wilmington, Del.

headline: A Loft That’s a Real Showplace
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The president of an Italian design retailer offers to furnish your New York home if you let him live there for a year.
lead_paragraph: When Diego Paccagnella, the president of Design-Apart, a company that sells custom Italian furnishings, wanted to display samples in New York, he found someone in Manhattan with a 2,600-square-foot loft who was willing to move out for a year and give it to him rent-free. Mr. Paccagnella; his wife, Livia; and their 16-month-old son, Giulio (all at top right), moved in and redecorated the apartment as a live-in showroom. In a year, the Paccagnellas will move out, leaving about a half-million dollars in furnishings for the owners to keep, while they find and redo another New York home.

headline: Treasures, but Only to You?
abstract: When a parent dies, selling the apartment can be the easy part.
lead_paragraph: A few months after my mother died in 2011 at the age of 93, I put her Manhattan apartment on the market and was lucky enough to have a deal within days. The buyers were paying cash and seemed certain to be approved by the co-op board.

headline: Should Americans Fear Their Furniture?
keywords: ['Furniture', 'Chemicals', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Movies', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: James Redford and Kirby Walker on their HBO documentary “Toxic Hot Seat” and the carcinogenic flame retardants found in many furnishings.
lead_paragraph: The pet hairs and red wine stains on sofas across America, it turns out, should be the least of our concerns. The real issue is what is in the foam cushions we curl up on every day: up to two pounds of flame retardants.

headline: Soaking Up the Local Color
abstract: The Watermark collection from Tilevera includes tiles dipped in indigo.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Osburn began making colorful tiles to brighten up a mostly beige-dominated industry nearly 30 years ago. And though in recent years she has been selling other artists’ designs, she has returned to her creative roots with the Watermark Collection for Tilevera, her artisan tile company. Inspired by Japanese techniques, she produced the ombré-stained tiles by placing unglazed porcelain into a cup of indigo and waiting for the dye to be absorbed.

headline: Should I Install Professional-Style Appliances?
abstract: Advice on repairing or redecorating a home before selling.
lead_paragraph: Q. Would putting professional-style appliances in my kitchen increase my home’s value?

headline: The Nakeds Next Door
abstract: Life in the big city sometimes means having neighbors without inhibitions — or window shades.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Sessoms has never been so ready for winter. Cold weather brings the promise of several months without awkward sightings of the neighbors whom her family refers to as the Nakeds.

headline: How Smart Is Your Smoke Alarm?
abstract: The Times’s Jenna Wortham considers whether the bang is worth the buck for a combination smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector called Nest Protect.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jenna Wortham considers whether the bang is worth the buck for a combination smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector called Nest Protect.

headline: Ad Takes Off Online: Less Doll, More Awl
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Toys', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The extensive Rube Goldberg machine in a viral video ad from a start-up toy company called GoldieBlox has a simple goal: show girls they can become engineers.
lead_paragraph: Who said girls want to dress in pink and play with dolls, especially when they could be building Rube Goldberg machines instead?

headline: A Smart Smoke Alarm That Keeps Its Cool
keywords: ['Smoke Detectors', 'Carbon Monoxide', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: The newest product offering from the company that came up with the smart thermostat combines smoke and carbon monoxide detection in a pleasing, intuitive package.
lead_paragraph: The last apartment I lived in was a certifiable fire hazard. It was mostly my fault — I ripped out the smoke detector my landlord had installed because it was so sensitive that even a steamy shower would set off its earsplitting beeping.

headline: A Camera That Offers Instant Gratification and Prints
abstract: The Fuji Instax Mini 90 Neo Classic offers printed pictures, but at a steep price.
lead_paragraph: It’s great to see party pictures instantly on your smartphone, but you can’t easily hang those shots on your refrigerator or tuck one into the frame of a mirror. You can order prints, of course, if you don’t mind waiting.

headline: Money Traders Fret Over Possible U.S.-Iran Pact
keywords: ['Iranian Rial (Currency)', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: For most of the last decade, particularly since Western financial sanctions began to bite hard two years ago, the dollar has been king around Tehran’s currency bazaar.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Sitting atop a bronze statue in the center of Tehran’s modest Manoucheri Square, where a group of illegal money changers gathers every day, a bald man waved a thick stack of dollar bills, as dozens of others shouted figures and numbers.

headline: Paul Sevigny Brings a New Bar to TriBeCa
abstract: Paul’s Baby Grand, at the Tribeca Grand hotel, offers summery cocktails and dance-friendly evenings.
lead_paragraph: Could this be (another) new Beatrice Inn? Since being silenced by griping neighbors in 2009, Paul Sevigny’s fashionable West Village bar has been endlessly imitated: Pyongyang door policies, shabby chic furniture, swirls of celebrities and downtown dirtbags. Paul’s Baby Grand, his first solo offering since Beatrice closed, has rejiggered an auxiliary space at the Tribeca Grand hotel into a lounge-like spiritual successor (albeit a smaller and less decadent incarnation).

headline: Fall Fashion, It’s all About the Details
abstract: Designers sprinkle pearls all over; Nike is introducing an update of its FuelBand bracelet; a shearling collar adds style and a new collection of winter-white shirts.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are upon us — time to break out the pearls. They may have shed their patrician pedigree some time ago, but this season the makeover is almost decadent, though in the nicest way: a fat pearl hiding under the sole of Nicholas Kirkwood pumps; a single strand attached to dresses at Valentino; pearls as trim running up and down and around tailored Alexander McQueen separates. In jewelry, they’re affixed in surprising new ways to necklaces, rings and cuffs by Aurélie Bidermann, Delfina Delettrez and others. Earlier this year, everyone was head over heels about the Dior pearls worn as a single earring, on the back and front of the earlobe. Now, for resort, they come in pretty pink and bright blue. Seriously, they could become a girl’s best friend.

headline: Robert Bowie, 104, Adviser to Truman, Eisenhower, Johnson and Carter, Dies
abstract: Robert R. Bowie, a Harvard foreign policy expert, was an analyst on the Cold War, national security and conflicts around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Robert R. Bowie, a Harvard foreign policy expert who served four postwar administrations as an adviser on the Cold War, national security and conflicts around the globe, died on Nov. 2 in Towson, Md. He was 104.

headline: Condom Contest Produces 812 Ideas for Improvement
keywords: ['Condoms', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Plastics', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Contests and Prizes']
abstract: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is seeking to decrease unintended pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases with “a next-generation condom.”
lead_paragraph: The condom of the future might be made of cow tendon or fish skin. It might have “shape memory” to instantly mold to a specific man. Or it might come with pull tabs so a man could slip it on with little fuss.

headline: In October, a Day for the New York City Subway’s Ridership Record Book
abstract: On Oct. 24, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, 5,985,311 subway rides were taken in the city, the most since daily record-keeping began 28 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The weather was mild on the subway system’s perfect day — clear skies to coax New Yorkers outdoors, paired with a breeze that discouraged long walks.

headline: Readers React to Death of a Diver, and an Image of Him
abstract: Times readers debated the ethics of a photograph of the free diver Nicholas Mevoli and the merits of extreme sports.
lead_paragraph: When the free diver Nick Mevoli, 32, emerged Sunday from an attempt at diving 72 meters below the ocean surface in the Bahamas, the photographer Lia Hyun-Joo Barrett caught him in a frame. In the photo, Mr. Mevoli, accompanied by three safety divers, looks startled, his eyes bulging.

headline: John Varvatos: His Runway Has a Backbeat
abstract: It’s obvious John Varvatos likes musicians; he even features them in his ads.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday night around 7, the designer John Varvatos was in his Chelsea showroom, about to head up to Harlem with a few staff members and his wife, Joyce. They were going to the Apollo Theater, where the guitarist Gary Clark Jr. was on the bill.

headline: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 21 in New York City
abstract: The first Balenciaga store designed since Alexander Wang became creative director opens Friday, across the street from the brand’s first dedicated men’s boutique in the Americas.
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: Raw Sewage and Anger Flood Gaza’s Streets as Electricity Runs Low
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Shortages', 'Palestinians', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: A shortage of electricity and cheap diesel fuel from Egypt led the Hamas government to shut down Gaza’s lone power plant, which caused sewage stations to stop working.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Raw sewage has flooded streets in a southern Gaza City neighborhood in recent days, threatening a health disaster, after a shortage of electricity and cheap diesel fuel from Egypt led the Hamas government to shut down Gaza’s lone power plant, causing a pump station to flood.

headline: New Approach to Treating Cholesterol
abstract: Doctors and patients react to several articles about new guidelines for prescribing statins.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Andris Nelsons to Conduct During Tanglewood’s 2014 Season
abstract: Mr. Nelsons will head to the Tanglewood Festival in 2014 after an injury forced him to cancel appearances this year.
lead_paragraph: His efforts to make it there last summer were thwarted by injury. But Andris Nelsons will head to the Berkshires this summer for his first appearances at the Tanglewood Festival since he was named the music director designate of the Boston Symphony Orchestra  — with plans to conduct music by Dvorak, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Rolf Martinsson and Christopher Rouse.

headline: Applicants Find Health Website Is Improving, but Not Fast Enough
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Navigators helping people enroll for health insurance through the federal website report some improvements, but many clients are still left frustrated by hurdles.
lead_paragraph: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — Tilda Elias had reason to be optimistic when she opened the HealthCare.gov website on Monday, ready to help her first client of the week find health insurance. Technicians had made fixes to the online insurance exchange over the weekend. Even more promising, her client, Giovanna Romano, had managed to complete an online application at home with no problems.

headline: The Dog on the Plane: Annoyance or Helper?
keywords: ['Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Blindness']
abstract: Readers discuss whether emotional support and service animals should be allowed on planes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Not Your Grandmother’s Skin Care?
abstract: Think again. New lines promoting old family recipes are proving both popular and profitable.
lead_paragraph: As you gaze exasperatedly around the Thanksgiving table next week, perhaps you should consider that Aunt Sue or Granny Esther may be a potential font of beauty wisdom.

headline: Philip Glass Is Among the Offerings at Nashville’s New Contemporary Arts Center
abstract: Oz, a new multidisciplinary contemporary arts center in a former cigar warehouse, is scheduled to open in February.
lead_paragraph: Nashville has long been the capital of a particular strain of country music, and lately the Nashville Symphony has established a reputation for adventurousness (but only narrowly avoided foreclosure proceedings on its spiffy new hall).

headline: Reusing Historic Buildings
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: The National Trust for Historic Preservation and the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation respond to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Dissident’s Daughter, on Rights and Reform in China
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Solitary Confinement']
abstract: The daughter of Wang Bingzhang, a political prisoner, is skeptical of announced reforms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shaping Bushy Eyebrows
abstract: Here are a few new products to help prune them.
lead_paragraph: Thanks in part to the model Cara Delevingne, bushy eyebrows are finding favor this season. Here are a few new products to help prune and shape them.

headline: How Bush Let Iran Go Nuclear
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: It is George W. Bush, not President Obama, who is to blame for our dire situation with Iran.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN and Iranian negotiators yesterday began a second round of talks in Geneva, seeking a deal on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Firefighters Are Injured in Major Fire in the Bronx
abstract: Fire officials said 175 firefighters responded to the call late Wednesday morning at the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market and were able to stop the blaze from spreading.
lead_paragraph: A fire tore through a section of the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx late Wednesday morning, destroying crates of tropical fruit and leaving several firefighters injured.

headline: Campaign Seeks to Recruit Top Students to Become Teachers
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The campaign uses video spots and radio announcements that portray teaching as creative and compelling a career as medicine, acting or engineering.
lead_paragraph: If you can’t do, teach. The three best things about teaching? June, July and August.

headline: The Truth About Tornadoes
abstract: Global warming is real. But it is not causing more twisters.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — DOES global warming weaken tornadoes?

headline: Bus Stoppage Said to Target Rikers Inmate
abstract: What was apparently a job action that stranded dozens of correction buses on Rikers Island kept a complaining witness from his court date.
lead_paragraph: When an apparent job action by city correction workers stranded dozens of city correction buses at Rikers Island this week, hundreds of inmates failed to make their scheduled court appearances — including one man of particular interest.

headline: Frequent Tests Can Enhance College Learning, Study Finds
abstract: Short quizzes at the start of each class increased attendance and performance, an experiment showed.
lead_paragraph: Grading college students on quizzes given at the beginning of every class, rather than on midterms or a final exam, increases both attendance and overall performance, scientists reported Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hitting Stop on Winamp, and Snapchat’s Women
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the web include the announced shutdown of a once-icon media player. Plus, Snapchat’s chief executive said that 70 percent of his service’s users are women.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Kazakhstan’s Bet on Rail
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroads', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The Central Asian nation began tapping its oil fields in September, using the sovereign wealth to finance its growing rail empire that serves the big Chinese and Russian markets.
lead_paragraph: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — The railroad locomotive factory here on the outskirts of the capital of Kazakhstan is one of the most modern in the world, with huge yellow overhead cranes and a work force of 1,100. An engine factory being built next door will soon make some of the world’s most fuel-efficient 12-cylinder diesel engines.

headline: The Public Needs a Nap
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: I know the holidays are coming up, people! But we have to get to the bottom line of this filibuster problem in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: One of the many problems with the Senate filibuster rule is that it requires us to think about the Senate filibuster rule.

headline: Yankees’ Best Deal Might Be Letting Cano Go
abstract: Instead of meeting the salary demands of Robinson Cano, whose productivity is in decline, the club could use the money to pick up some free agents while scouting for bargains.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have gotten nine excellent seasons and one championship from Robinson Cano. They have paid him about $58 million. Now he wants that much again, and about $250 million more, for a decade that almost certainly will not be as productive.

headline: Representative Meng Is Mugged on Capitol Hill
abstract: Representative Grace Meng of Queens was robbed on Tuesday night in Washington by a person who hit her in the back of the head and stole her purse as she fell, her office said.
lead_paragraph: Representative Grace Meng was robbed this week in Washington by a person who hit her in the back of the head and stole her purse as she fell, she said on Wednesday.

headline: Voting via Twitter, Choosing Jennifer Lopez’s Route to an Awards Show
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'AMERICAN MUSIC AWARDS', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Social Media', 'Music']
abstract: A Kohl’s campaign to air during the American Music Awards on Sunday will let viewers tweet their votes, in real time, on how Ms. Lopez should get to the stage.
lead_paragraph: HEADING into the shopping frenzy of Thanksgiving week, Kohl’s is featuring one of its collection celebrities, Jennifer Lopez, in a social media campaign involving a series of commercials that will air during the American Music Awards on Sunday.

headline: Aid Groups Get Strong Response to Philippines Appeals
abstract: The United Nations has already raised $129 million, about half the amount it requested in an emergency appeal last week to provide disaster relief in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations relief agency has elicited a strong response so far to an emergency financing appeal for overcoming the Philippines typhoon disaster, receiving nearly half the amount requested in the week since the effort was begun, a humanitarian aid database reported in an update on Wednesday.

headline: When Children Are Traded
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abandonment', 'Foster Care']
abstract: A black market of vulnerable kids is thriving and drawing pedophiles. It’s emblematic of how our society neglects children.
lead_paragraph: A few ads offering free children on the Internet:

headline: JPMorgan Pays
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Editorials', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A $13 billion settlement, the largest ever between government officials and a single company, resolves mortgage claims and puts other banks on notice.
lead_paragraph: The long-awaited $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over allegations of misrepresentation in the sale of mortgage securities is hardly a cure-all for the damage inflicted on homeowners, investors and the economy by fraud, predation and other wrongdoing during the bubble. It is, however, a likely precursor of similar payouts from other banks, and it provides at least some cash for investors and a measure of relief for struggling homeowners and communities. Where it falls short is in its failure to hold individuals accountable.

headline: United States Can Spy on Britons Despite Pact, N.S.A. Memo Says
abstract: The classified draft document, provided by Edward J. Snowden, disclosed the protocols of spying among the “Five Eyes” countries: the United States, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency is authorized to spy on the citizens of America’s closest allies, including Britain, even though those English-speaking countries have long had an official non-spying pact, according to a newly disclosed memorandum.

headline: Skakel Lawyers May Have Challenge Winning Bail
abstract: Judge Gary J. White, who once upheld the prison sentence for Michael C. Skakel, will preside at Mr. Skakel’s attempt to win bail now that his murder conviction has been overturned.
lead_paragraph: When Michael C. Skakel appears in Stamford Superior Court on Thursday to make the case that he be released on bail while prosecutors try to get his 2002 murder conviction reinstated, Judge Gary J. White is the man he will have to persuade.

headline: Senate Democrats Poised to Block Filibusters of Presidential Picks
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A vote on what is known on Capitol Hill as the “nuclear option” would further erode what little bipartisanship exists in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats are on the verge of moving to eliminate the use of the filibuster against most presidential nominees, aides and senior party leaders said Wednesday, a move that would deprive Republicans of their ability to block President Obama’s picks for cabinet posts and the federal judiciary and further erode what little bipartisanship still exists in the Senate.

headline: Libya’s Resurgent Violence
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: Feuding, and heavily armed, militias threaten the promise of political reconciliation in the country.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, officials in the transition government in Libya spoke of making progress toward integrating rival militias into a cohesive security force that could stabilize the country as it seeks to become a democracy.

headline: Germany, Austerity’s Champion, Faces Some Big Repair Bills
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Germany, once known for autobahns and efficiency, is facing an aging infrastructure that, if left unaddressed, could undermine economic growth.
lead_paragraph: PADERBORN, Germany — When inspectors decided a few months ago that the aging bridge over the Kiel Canal in northern Germany was too weak for heavy truck traffic, Holger Dechant, hired to deliver giant wind turbines to the other side, was at a loss.

headline: A Brash Young Talent Finds New Focus With Dallas
abstract: Tyler Seguin, traded from the Boston Bruins over the summer, has benefited from working with the Stars’ new, but experienced, coach and a skilled linemate.
lead_paragraph: For a while, Tyler Seguin seemed like the N.H.L.’s answer to Justin Bieber: a young, talented Canadian whose reported partying sometimes overshadowed his performances.

headline: Ex-U.S. Attorney to Join Davis Polk Law Firm in Washington
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Legal Profession', 'United States Attorneys']
abstract: The prosecutor, Neil MacBride, will start in Davis Polk & Wardwell’s white-collar criminal defense practice early next year.
lead_paragraph: Neil H. MacBride, the former United States attorney in Alexandria, Va., will join Davis Polk & Wardwell as a partner, the firm will announce on Thursday.

headline: Warrantless Surveillance Continues to Cause Fallout
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Terrorism', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A terrorism case in Oregon involving warrantless wiretapping and a letter from three United States senators to the solicitor general cause a stir.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has notified a Somali-American man who was convicted this year of trying to detonate a bomb in Portland, Ore., that his trial included evidence derived from warrantless wiretapping, a move that could disrupt plans to sentence him next month.

headline: Major Retailers Agree to Inspection Standards in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Two groups representing dozens of American and European retailers agreed to uphold considerably tougher standards on garment factories in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: Two groups of retailers — one dominated by American companies, the other by European brands — announced on Wednesday that they had agreed on joint inspection standards for thousands of garment factories in Bangladesh as part of their effort to improve workplace safety there.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 20, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Texas Women and Abortion Rights
abstract: In an alarming ruling, the Supreme Court turned away an emergency application to block a new law that impedes access to safe and legal abortion care in the state.
lead_paragraph: In an alarming 5-to-4 ruling, the Supreme Court turned away an emergency application to block a new Texas law that is impeding access to safe and legal abortion care in the state. The ruling leaves in place an order by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit that allowed the law go into effect while it considers an appeal.

headline: Active and Improvising, Kerry Is Taking On Tough Problems
abstract: John Kerry may be poised to begin delivering a major goal President Obama has long sought: an agreement with Iran to curb its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Kerry has made no secret of his ambitions as secretary of state. On a visit to the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem last March, he watched as two bearded patriarchs pleaded with President Obama to bring peace to the Holy Land. Clasping their hands, Mr. Kerry said, “I’m going to work as hard as I can to get it done.”

headline: Beneath the Virgin Prairie
abstract: Bacteria taken from virgin soil are a reminder of what was lost and gained when the sod was broken.
lead_paragraph: Even if you have stood on a remnant of virgin prairie, it is hard to imagine what was lost when the tallgrass prairie was plowed. Settlers were staggered by the scope of the prairies, and they were more amazed by the richness of the soil. The biomass of roots beneath the ground was as dense and tangled as the biomass on top. And when the prairies were plowed, everything changed — the ecosystem, the structure of the soil, and, as it turns out, the microorganisms living in the soil.

headline: A Lure to the Classroom
abstract: A public service campaign to recruit a new generation of teachers features ads that compare teaching to careers like medicine, acting and engineering.
lead_paragraph: A public service campaign to recruit a new generation of teachers features ads that compare teaching to careers like medicine, acting and engineering.

headline: SAC Trader Had ‘Secret Pipeline’ of Information, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Opposing portrayals of Michael S. Steinberg, a former trader at SAC Capital, emerged during opening statements at his criminal insider trading trial in Federal District Court.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Steinberg is “successful, steady, serious,” said a lawyer for the most senior employee at SAC Capital Advisors to be charged with insider trading. And unlike the hard-charging billionaires who rule Wall Street’s top hedge funds, Mr. Steinberg was a history and philosophy major who started at SAC as a low-level clerk, the lawyer said.

headline: Rodriguez Isn’t the Only One Who’s Had Enough
abstract: Alex Rodriguez said he was fed up on Wednesday, echoing the sentiments of fans who have lived through too many of his off-the-field dramatics.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez walked out of his own arbitration hearing on Wednesday, saying that he was “disgusted with this abusive process” and that “the absurdity and injustice just became too much.”

headline: Barneys and Macy’s No-Shows at a City Hearing
abstract: New York City council members had no one to question about allegations that shoppers at the two Manhattan stores have been racially profiled.
lead_paragraph: The City Council hearing was notable for its absences: No representative from Barneys New York or Macy’s appeared on Wednesday to discuss accusations of racial profiling against shoppers at their Manhattan stores. Nor did anyone show up from the Police Department, which has been criticized by black shoppers who have been detained at the stores.

headline: Anti-Abortion Forces Reassess Their Tactics After Ballot Defeat in Albuquerque
abstract: One strategy turned on the mistaken belief that Hispanics, who make up almost half the population in the New Mexico city, would be receptive to the referendum.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — The decisive defeat of a municipal ballot measure here that sought to ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy left anti-abortion forces conceding that some of their tactics had backfired and that they had less support among Catholic Hispanic voters than they had expected.

headline: November 22, 1963
abstract: Will we ever know the truth about the Kennedy assassination? In a film by Errol Morris, Josiah “Tink” Thompson returns to what has haunted him for 50 years: Frame #313 of the Zapruder film.
lead_paragraph: Will we ever know the truth about the Kennedy assassination? In a film by Errol Morris, Josiah “Tink” Thompson returns to what has haunted him for 50 years: Frame #313 of the Zapruder film.

headline: A Novel Scorned
abstract: “Gone With the Wind” was my “Twilight.”
lead_paragraph: When I was in middle school, I read Margaret Mitchell’s epic romance, “Gone With the Wind.” Not once. Not twice. But continuously. Each time I finished the novel, I began again, flipping open the broken-spined paperback so many times the book split in half, yielding two portable sections of text. I preferred a break of at least several hours between readings, but sometimes compulsion forced me to begin again only moments after finishing it.

headline: Reconciling a Sport’s Violent Appeal as a Fighter Lies in a Coma
abstract: As a Russian heavyweight named Magomed Abdusalamov lay unconscious in a Manhattan hospital, people involved in the sport tried to explain opportunity and risk in boxing.
lead_paragraph: Three men sat inside a Manhattan diner. Their fighter, the Russian heavyweight Magomed Abdusalamov, remained in a medically induced coma at Roosevelt Hospital, across the street.

headline: ‘November 22, 1963’
abstract: In a short film, Josiah “Tink” Thompson, who has been investigating the Kennedy assassination for nearly 50 years, looks to the photographic evidence. Will we ever know the truth?
lead_paragraph: A brief résumé. Josiah “Tink” Thompson, the subject of this Op-Doc, graduated from Yale in 1957, became a demolitions expert and frogman for the Navy, and then returned to Yale to get his Ph.D. on the Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard.

headline: Colombia: President, a U.S. Ally, Seeks Another Term
abstract: President Juan Manuel Santos announced that he would run for re-election, saying that he wanted to finish the work he started in seeking a peace deal with the country’s largest rebel group.
lead_paragraph: President Juan Manuel Santos announced Wednesday that he would run for re-election, saying that he wanted to finish the work he started in seeking a peace deal with the country’s largest rebel group. “When you see the light at the end of the tunnel you don’t go backwards,” Mr. Santos, one of the closest allies of the United States in Latin America, said on television. “We will finish the job.” The negotiations with the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, have advanced slowly, and there are still significant obstacles to an agreement to end the nearly 50-year-old conflict.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 21, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, November 21, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t expect you to understand. I mean, how many people go to work and say, literally say, ‘I might die tonight.’ But that’s boxing.”

headline: Navy Was Warned of Contractor at Center of Bribery Inquiry
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Defense Contracts']
abstract: The Navy awarded $200 million in contracts to Leonard Glenn Francis, even after several ship crews and contracting officials had filed complaints about him.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Glenn Francis, a wealthy Malaysian contractor at the heart of one of the United States Navy’s largest bribery scandals in decades, seemed to have stepped right off the set of “Casablanca.”

headline: In a Shelter, and Striving to Help a Child
abstract: Juana Rosario brought her granddaughter to the United States to get specialized medical help for the girl, but the family, with scant income, is living in a city homeless shelter.
lead_paragraph: The last few years have been traumatic ones for Juana Rosario, who has been living in the New York City shelter system since 2010, alongside her husband and her disabled granddaughter, Amy Germosen Rosario. But as nightmarish as the experience has been, she prefers it to going back home to the Dominican Republic.

headline: Racism in the Age of Obama
abstract: Have racial tensions in the U.S. changed since Obama was elected? For better or for worse?

headline: Corrections: November 21, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 21, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Ready for Publication
abstract: A soothing puzzle by Jules P. Markey.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:28 p.m. | Congratulations to puzzle master Will Shortz, who celebrates 20 years as editor of The New York Times crossword puzzle today!

headline: In Her Room, With a View Based on Recollections
abstract: In Meghan Kennedy’s “Too Much, Too Much, Too Many,” a daughter tries to draw her mother out of her room, where she’s been bunkered since her husband died.
lead_paragraph: A grieving widow immures herself in her bedroom, surrounded by little more than stacks of overdue library books and her aching memory, in “Too Much, Too Much, Too Many,” a subdued but affecting new play by Meghan Kennedy that opened on Wednesday night at the Roundabout Underground’s Black Box Theater.

headline: Bloomberg Lured Donors for New York Programs
abstract: A report commissioned by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s foundation found that the administration had attracted $1.4 billion in noncity financing for public programs.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is well known for tapping his own fortune to fill in gaps in the city’s resources, whether spending millions of dollars to renovate Gracie Mansion or keeping the kitchen in the City Hall bullpen stocked with healthy snacks for his staff.

headline: AARP Releases Free Health Cost Calculator
abstract: The organization’s online health-costs calculator will help those nearing retirement get a better picture on how much health care will cost.
lead_paragraph: William Martin, a financial adviser with Aequus Wealth Management in Chicago, counsels clients to plan for health costs in retirement. “There’s a high probability I’ll live into my 90s,” said Mr. Martin, 52, noting that he’s in good health and his grandparents lived into their 90s. “So I need to plan for that.”

headline: U.S. Says Dozens of Americans Have Sought to Join Rebels in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: American intelligence officials say dozens of Americans have traveled or tried to travel to Syria to fight with the rebels against the government since 2011.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dozens of Americans have traveled or tried to travel to Syria to fight with the rebels against the government of President Bashar al-Assad since 2011, American intelligence officials said Wednesday.

headline: Carnegie Mellon Bringing Sciences Programs to Brooklyn
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The university plans to offer graduate education in emerging media and game design, as well as four more fields, at an outpost campus in Steiner Studios.
lead_paragraph: Joining a club that already includes Cornell University, New York University and Columbia University, Carnegie Mellon University on Wednesday became the fourth institution of higher learning — and the first from out of state — to announce plans for an applied sciences program in New York City.

headline: Mr. McAllister Goes to Washington, and He Is Wowed
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Vance McAllister’s improbable journey began after he won by a landslide in a special vote for a congressional seat from Louisiana. “Wow, wow,” he marveled upon gazing at a chandelier in the Old House Chamber.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vance McAllister, a 39-year-old college dropout and Army veteran, managed to vanquish a formidable Republican opponent backed by the party’s establishment, win a special election in Louisiana’s Fifth District in a 20-point landslide, and score an endorsement from the star of “Duck Dynasty.”

headline: European Parliament Votes to Choose Single Meeting Site
abstract: The move reflects frustration with monthly commutes between Brussels and Strasbourg, France, that many see as a waste of money.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Parliament voted on Wednesday to choose a single meeting place, showing its frustration with monthly commutes between Brussels and Strasbourg, France, that are seen by many lawmakers and citizens as a colossal waste of money and an embarrassment at a time of painful austerity across the European Union.

headline: A Newly Minted Congressman Visits His Office
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Representative Vance McAllister, the newest member of the House, arrived in the nation’s capital for the first time on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Representative Vance McAllister, the newest member of the House, arrived in the nation’s capital for the first time on Wednesday.

headline: For Nalbandian, a Supporting Role in the Era of Federer and Nadal
abstract: David Nalbandian, one of the most complete players of any era and who announced his retirement in October, is officially bidding farewell this week with two exhibition matches.
lead_paragraph: In tennis, much more often than not, it does not work out as planned.

headline: ‘We’ve Got to Make Government Work’
abstract: The Times’s Ashley Parker interviewed Louisiana’s newest representative, Vance McAllister, hours after he arrived to start his first term.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Ashley Parker interviewed Louisiana’s newest representative, Vance McAllister, hours after he arrived to start his first term.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Saints (8-2) at Falcons (2-8)
abstract: The 2012 Saints were bad, and the 2012 Falcons were quite good. In 2013, those roles have reversed, and the struggling Falcons seem to stand little chance to beat the Saints.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

headline: Patenting Their Discoveries Does Not Pay Off for Most Universities, a Study Says
abstract: A new Brookings Institution study shows that while some research universities earn big money on blockbuster patents, most of the institutions earn nothing.
lead_paragraph: Universities try to cash in on discoveries — gene splicing, brain chemistry, computer-chip design — but the great majority of them fail to turn their research into a source of income, according to a new study from the Brookings Institution.

headline: Familiar Scenes: Star Hurts Ankle, and Nets Stagger
abstract: After losing Deron Williams to another ankle injury, the Nets again wilted in the third quarter against the Bobcats as they fell for the sixth time in seven games.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Nets revisited recurring themes of this young season Wednesday night on the way to a dispiriting 95-91 defeat to the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: G.O.P. Maps Out Waves of Attacks Over Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Republican strategists say they intend to keep Democrats on their heels through a multilayered, sequenced assault on President Obama’s signature legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The memo distributed to House Republicans this week was concise and blunt, listing talking points and marching orders: “Because of Obamacare, I Lost My Insurance.” “Obamacare Increases Health Care Costs.” “The Exchanges May Not Be Secure, Putting Personal Information at Risk.” “Continue Collecting Constituent Stories.”

headline: Great Effort by Knicks, for 47 Minutes
abstract: Carmelo Anthony had 30 points but shot just 10 of 28 from the field for the Knicks, while the Pacers’ Paul George scored 21 of his game-high 35 points in the fourth quarter and overtime.
lead_paragraph: When Coach Mike Woodson met with his players Wednesday morning, he reminded them that nobody was running away with the Atlantic Division. The Philadelphia 76ers were planted atop the standings with a losing record. Everybody else was clustered beneath them with similarly dismal marks.

headline: ‘Good Lord Bird’ Is Surprise Winner for National Book Award in Fiction
abstract: James McBride, who wrote “The Good Lord Bird,” was considered an underdog. George Packer also won for “The Unwinding.”
lead_paragraph: James McBride won the National Book Award on Wednesday night for “The Good Lord Bird,” an irreverent, sharp-eyed novel narrated by an escaped slave. It was published by Riverhead Books, part of Penguin Random House.

headline: Diane Disney Miller, 79, Keeper of Walt’s Flame, Dies
abstract: Mrs. Miller, the last surviving child of Walt Disney, co-founded a museum dedicated to the memory of her father as a human being rather than a brand.
lead_paragraph: Diane Disney Miller, Walt Disney’s last surviving child, who stood up for Frank Gehry’s spectacularly abstract design for the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and co-founded a museum dedicated to the memory of her father as a human being rather than a brand, died on Tuesday in Napa Valley, Calif., where she had a home. She was 79.

headline: Great Lakes Recover Substantial Water Levels
abstract: Water levels in the Great Lakes, which reached historic lows earlier this year, have recovered because of heavy snowfall and spring rains, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: Water levels in the Great Lakes, which reached historic lows earlier this year, have recovered substantially because of heavy snowfall and spring rains, government scientists said. Lakes Michigan and Huron saw a 20-inch rise this year—nearly twice the normal amount, said Keith Kompoltowicz, who monitors the lakes for the Army Corps of Engineers. Levels remain below long-term averages in some of the lakes, and it is hard to predict whether the gains will hold, said Drew Gronewold, a hydrologist with the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: Online Courses Attract Degree Holders, Survey Finds
abstract: About 80 percent of people who enrolled in a massive open online course from the University of Pennsylvania had already earned a bachelor’s degree, according to a survey.
lead_paragraph: About 80 percent of people who enrolled in a massive open online course, or MOOC, from the University of Pennsylvania had already earned a bachelor’s degree, according to a survey of 34,000 students who had at least started one of the 24 courses the university offered on the Coursera platform. Although Coursera’s founders have presented their MOOCs as a way to democratize higher education by making it available online, free, to anyone in the world, the Penn survey found that in the United States and developing countries alike, most Coursera students were well educated, employed, young and male. Penn’s courses account for 20 percent of Coursera’s enrollment.

headline: Inside the Winbot 730, a Robotic Window Cleaner
abstract: The cleaning device figures out the size of your window mirror and then cleans the surface on its own.
lead_paragraph: The cleaning device figures out the size of your window mirror and then cleans the surface on its own.

headline: Gray Gets a Feminine Makeover
abstract: The shade is a staple of men’s cold-weather wardrobes — especially when it comes in flannel — but it’s increasingly well suited for women as well.
lead_paragraph: Gray flannel, a fabric usually reserved for men — in a banker’s suit or a hunter’s henley — has been reimagined for the everyday woman. When combined with leather, it can transform an ordinary baseball cap into a chic topper for any outfit, a basic tablet case into a handsome clutch or a simple duffel into a prim carryall. A basic flannel skirt gets dressed up when paired with punklike jewelry in gray tones. Other gray materials can offer similar impact to flannel as well. Pony hair, as seen on these elegant Chanel loafers, is a feminine alternative that is well suited for ladies who lunch. The ombré effect on this neoprene knit sweater from Proenza Schouler offers a contemporary riff on the idea of gray flannel that looks as at home on the streets as it does surf-side.

headline: Limiting the Fed
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: To be credible, calls to reduce the responsibilities and powers of the Federal Reserve need to be accompanied by ceilings on the size of banks, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Birth Control Pills May Raise Eye Risks
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Estrogen', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Glaucoma', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Women who use birth control pills for several years or longer may want to consider having their eyes checked more regularly as they get older, as a new study suggests the pills may double their lifetime risk of developing glaucoma.
lead_paragraph: Women who use oral contraceptives for several years or longer may want to consider having their eyes checked more regularly as they get older. New research suggests that the pills may double their lifetime risk of developing glaucoma, a degenerative eye disease that can cause blindness if left untreated.

headline: Word of the Day | argot
abstract: This word has appeared in 11 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: argot •\ˈär-gət, -(ˌ)go\• noun

headline: Tigers Trade Fielder for Kinsler
abstract: The Tigers on Wednesday traded Prince Fielder to the Texas Rangers for second baseman Ian Kinsler, pending physical exams for both players.
lead_paragraph: When the Detroit Tigers signed Prince Fielder to a nine-year, $214 million contract in January 2012, it was considered a swift, bold move intended to bring the aging owner Mike Ilitch a World Series championship.

headline: Week 12 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Strange Math for Jets
abstract: The Jets have scored 183 points and allowed 268 on their way to a 5-5 record. That’s a net point difference of -85, which is second worst in the league.
lead_paragraph: Pythagoras was an ancient Greek mathematician and philosopher. The New York Jets are a modern professional football team. And they don’t seem to agree.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (IFC) EYES WIDE SHUT (1999) A doctor (Tom Cruise), enraged by the desire of his wife (Nicole Kidman, above, with Mr. Cruise) for another man, embarks on an odyssey of sexual temptation in this final film by Stanley Kubrick, inspired by Arthur Schnitzler’s “Traumnovelle” (“Dream Story”). Open-ended vignettes star Sydney Pollack as the unsavory host of a lavish Christmas party, Alan Cumming as a conspiratorial hotel concierge, Rade Sherbedgia as the proprietor of a costume rental shop, and Leelee Sobieski as his naughty daughter. “There is consolation for having to read the words ‘The End’ on the posthumous work of Mr. Kubrick: this astonishing last film is a spellbinding addition to the Kubrick canon,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Despite some abrupt editing in a work that the director never lived to fine-tune, the film moves effortlessly, and it goes straight under the skin. Its powerful and lingering resonance attests to a final compassion and profundity in Mr. Kubrick, the body-and-soul commitment of Mr. Cruise and Ms. Kidman, and the Rorschach-like ability of this material to envelop audiences in ways unexplained and unexpected.” She added: “ ‘Life goes on,’ Mr. Pollack’s character says cynically late in the film. ‘It always does, until it doesn’t.’ Along with that sentiment, Mr. Kubrick left one more brilliantly provocative tour de force as his epitaph.”

headline: A Conversation With: Author Gaiutra Bahadur
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Forced Labor', 'Grandparents', 'Indian-Americans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Slavery', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Ms. Bahardur spoke about the story of her great-grandmother, an indentured woman, which forms the crux of her new book.
lead_paragraph: In “Coolie Woman,” the Guyanese-American journalist Gaiutra Bahadur excavates the forgotten story of her great-grandmother Sujaria and a quarter of a million women like her who left eastern India in the mid-1800s as indentured labor. The book, which was released last week in the United States and last month in India, is deeply personal yet assiduously researched. From the treacherous sea voyage to the colonial outpost of British Guiana to the sexual privileges conferred on indentured women as the scarcer sex, Ms. Bahadur reconstructs the “coolie” woman’s fate in astonishing detail.

headline: News Quiz | November 21, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Prosecutors Detail Attempt to Sway South Korean Election
abstract: South Korean politics have been rocked by accusations that the country’s spy agency conducted an online campaign to help elect Park Geun-hye president.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Agents from the National Intelligence Service of South Korea posted more than 1.2 million Twitter messages last year to try to sway public opinion in favor of Park Geun-hye, then a presidential candidate, and her party ahead of elections in 2012, state prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Drone Strikes a Seminary in Pakistan
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The attack, which is said to have killed Haqqani militants, comes during a stretch of growing political outrage over U.S. airstrikes in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Missiles believed to have been fired by an American drone struck an Islamic seminary in northern Pakistan on Thursday, in a rare strike outside the country’s volatile tribal regions.

headline: Lu Xun Letter Sold for More Than $1 Million
abstract: A letter that Lu Xun, one of China’s most venerated writers, wrote to a friend in 1934 sold for about three times its asking price.
lead_paragraph: China is flush with cash, but even so, some Chinese are marveling at the price of a letter auctioned in Beijing this week at the China Guardian fall auctions: a 220-character missive by Lu Xun, one of the country’s most venerated writers.

headline: Suspect Held in Shooting at a Paris Newspaper
abstract: Officials say the man arrested served four years in prison for his role as an accomplice in the shooting deaths of three police officers and a taxi driver in 1994.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After a two-day manhunt, the French police arrested a man they believe was responsible for a shooting this week at a newspaper office in Paris and gunfire at a bank headquarters nearby, the authorities announced late Wednesday night.

headline: As Labor Camp Prisoners Are Released, Questions Remain
abstract: Local governments in Shanghai and Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, announced earlier this week that they had released all the people previously held at their “re-education through labor” camps.
lead_paragraph: Local governments in Shanghai and Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, announced this week that they had released all detainees previously held at their “re-education through labor” camps. The news comes shortly after the central government declared its intention to abolish the labor-camp system – known in Chinese as laojiao – news that came in the report of the Third Plenum, the leadership meeting that wrapped up on Nov. 12.

headline: On the Roach to Riches
abstract: Some Chinese farmers have found a potentially lucrative business in raising cockroaches.
lead_paragraph: “The industry of raising cockroaches has a bright future,” said Wang Fuming, a farmer in Shandong Province.

headline: Glossy Men’s Magazines Piggyback on Change
abstract: New titles, some spinoffs of well-known women's brands, are reportedly outperforming traditional male magazines.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Fashion spreads shot on location in Europe, news on the latest luxury accessories, articles on personal development and skin care. If you think this sounds like the contents of a women’s magazine, then you haven’t read Elle Men Hong Kong, featuring the Asian pretty boy actor Aarif Rahman on the November cover.

headline: Britain Investigates Reports of Citizens’ Deaths in Syria
abstract: The British Foreign Office is looking into reports that four Britons died while fighting on the side of Islamic militants opposed to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amid growing evidence that dozens of Americans have traveled or sought to travel to Syria to join rebel forces, the British Foreign Office said on Thursday that it was investigating reports that several Britons had died there while fighting on the side of Islamic militants opposed to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 21, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the word that best completes the sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: Use context clues and your knowledge of word parts to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | 24,000-Year-Old Body May Reveal New Clues About Native Americans’ Ancestry
abstract: How do these findings challenge previous assumptions about the ancestry of Native Americans?
lead_paragraph: In “24,000-Year-Old Body Shows Kinship to Europeans and American Indians,” Nicholas Wade writes about a study published this week that may reveal new clues about Native Americans’ ancestry.

headline: Credit Suisse to Wall Off Swiss Banking Business
abstract: The move, known as “ring fencing,” is designed to protect the Zurich bank’s retail customers and shield the overall bank from another financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Swiss bank Credit Suisse said Thursday that it planned to separate its retail and private banking business in its home market from its riskier investment banking and trading operations in Britain and in the United States.

headline: J.F.K. Through the Pages of The Times
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Photography', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: Fifty years after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, a new book showcases The Times’s coverage of his era.
lead_paragraph: After the twin towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001, Todd Purdum, then one of the senior political reporters in the Washington bureau of The Times, began reciting, “America wept tonight, not alone for its dead young president, but for itself.” The words belonged not to him but to James Reston, who wrote them on deadline late in the day on Nov. 22, 1963. Reston, known as Scotty, had assembled some of the best talent ever known to journalism in The Times’s Washington bureau: Tom Wicker, Anthony Lewis, Max Frankel, Russell Baker and others, all of whom had covered the presidency of John F. Kennedy, when Washington was the epicenter of everything.

headline: Preview: 'Out of the Furnace'
abstract: Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe in a clip from the film.
lead_paragraph: Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe in a clip from the film.

headline: Work, Women and Caregiving
abstract: Women who provide care are far less likely to be in the work force, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Trying to hold onto a job while caring for a family member is a tough juggling act. Caregivers sometimes have to arrive late or leave early, cut back to part-time work, and decline travel or promotions.

headline: What Are Your Thanksgiving Traditions?
abstract: Does your family serve the same meal every year? Do you have any favorite dishes? Describe.
lead_paragraph: Turkey, stuffing, gravy and cranberry sauce: These are the quintessential Thanksgiving foods that grace the holiday dinner table. Still, each family has its own history and brings its own customs to the holiday season.

headline: Casey Affleck Should Be More Famous
abstract: Why isn’t he? Blame Casey Affleck.
lead_paragraph: Before Casey Affleck started filming “Out of the Furnace” last year, he felt, professionally speaking, as if he’d lost his way. Five years earlier, in 2007, he had two breakout roles: “Gone Baby Gone,” directed by his older brother Ben, and “The Assassination of Jesse James By the Coward Robert Ford,” in which he played the coward, Robert Ford, and for which he received an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor. In the years following, though, he had starred in only two live-action films (and provided a voice for the cartoon “ParaNorman”). His most recent and notorious creative project was in 2010, when he poured his heart, brain and wallet into “I’m Still Here,” a passion project he made with his brother-in-law and close friend, Joaquin Phoenix. The hoax-documentary purported to chronicle Phoenix’s real-life personal implosion, as he supposedly made the switch from acting to a rap career. The film not only met with many terrible reviews but actually seemed to enrage the media. Dana Stevens of Slate had a not untypical critical reaction: “The worst thing about ‘I’m Still Here’ is the fact that it exists.”

headline: Philippine City’s Residents Describe Rifling of Stores
abstract: People who took items from merchants justified their actions as a result of a desperate situation after their city had been hit by Typhoon Haiyan.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — By the time Bjorn Racaza joined the crowds rummaging through Robinsons Department Store, he thought he was too late. It was around 6 p.m. on Nov. 10, two days after Typhoon Haiyan destroyed much of this city of 235,000, and the plundering of its largest department store — some of it for necessities, some of it not — was in full fury.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Hopes that the euro zone could be emerging from years of torpor suffered another setback on Thursday when an indicator of economic activity in the region slipped unexpectedly and suggested that France could be sliding back into recession.

headline: A Time for Courage
abstract: Willy Brandt on his knees admonishes us to move beyond petty calculation.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — It being the 100th anniversary of Willy Brandt’s birth, the image has been much present in Germany: the former chancellor on his knees in the Warsaw ghetto in the silent act that defined German shame for the Holocaust. As Brandt later said, “Carrying the burden of the millions who were murdered, I did what people do when words fail them.”

headline: China’s Highest Court Seeks to Curtail Abuses of Justice
abstract: The court issued demands that judges bar confessions obtained through torture and avoid applying the death penalty when the evidence is shaky.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s highest court issued demands on Thursday that judges bar confessions obtained through torture and avoid applying the death penalty when the evidence is shaky. The directive was unlikely on its own to curb such abuses, but reflected a growing official recognition of the need to stop gross injustices, experts said.

lead_paragraph: Orlando Bloom performs a scene from the new Broadway production of Shakespeare’s “Romeo and Juliet.”

headline: Signs of Aging, Even in the Embryo
abstract: New research indicates that senescent cells, those that stop dividing, play an important role at both the dawn and dusk of life.
lead_paragraph: In 1961, two biologists named Leonard Hayflick and Paul Moorehead discovered that old age is built into our cells. At the time, many scientists believed that if healthy human cells were put in a flask with a steady supply of nutrients, they would multiply forever. But when Dr. Hayflick and Dr. Moorehead reared fetal human cells, that’s not what they found. Time and again, their cells would divide about 50 times and then simply stop.

headline: At Least 32 Killed as Truck Explodes at Iraqi Market
abstract: The blast at a fruit and vegetable market in Saadiya, north of Baghdad, came a day after a wave of explosions that convulsed the capital.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Explosives hidden under fruit and vegetables aboard a delivery truck detonated in a crowded market selling fresh produce north of Baghdad on Thursday, killing 32 people and wounding dozens a day after a wave of car bombings convulsed the capital, according to medical and police officials.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dueling Portraits of SAC Trader

MacBride, a former United States attorney, is joining Davis Polk & Wardwell. | Losers in the 2008 financial crisis are on the receiving end of JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion settlement. | President Obama’s choice to lead the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is an enigma.
lead_paragraph: DUELING PORTRAITS OF SAC TRADER  | According to his lawyer, Michael S. Steinberg is “successful, steady, serious.” According to federal prosecutors, Mr. Steinberg, the most senior employee at SAC Capital Advisors to be charged with insider trading, tapped into a corrupt insider trading conspiracy to make “big money” for himself. He also, prosecutors claim, pushed a lower-level employee at SAC to provide “edgy” and illegal information about technology companies, Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

I have received emails containing this question in its various iterations at least three or four times a week since I started writing this column, and according to my research, it’s also the most frequently asked question in a teacher’s day-to-day life.

headline: Remembering the Gettysburg Address
abstract: Why was Lincoln’s famous speech overlooked for so long?
lead_paragraph: John Hay woke with a severe hangover on the morning of Nov. 19, 1863. As one of Abraham Lincoln’s closest White House aides, Hay had spent the previous evening drinking copiously with the disparate crew of journalists and politicians who converged on the small town of Gettysburg, Penn., for the dedication of a new national cemetery later that day. A bystander remembered seeing the presidential party arrive after a long train ride from Washington, “a straggled, hungry set. Lincoln, with that weary smile … Seward, with an essentially bad hat; John Hay, in attendance upon the president, and much to be troubled by the correspondents, handsome as a peach, the countenance of extreme youth.”

headline: Merely Players? Not These Actors
abstract: Readers of The New York Times were more than happy to share the greatest Shakespearean performance they had ever seen or heard.
lead_paragraph: Readers of The New York Times with long memories — many of them frequent visitors to London — were more than happy to share the greatest Shakespearean performance they had ever seen or heard. But they also found acting to savor on screens, large and very small. Here’s an edited sampling of their responses. For more, go to nytimes.com/theater.

(“The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford.”)

headline: Striking Where Myth Meets Moment
abstract: “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” the second film in the series, brings back Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss Everdeen, but has a new director, Francis Lawrence.
lead_paragraph: When “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” opens, its lethally resourceful teenage heroine, Katniss Everdeen, is crouching in a forest, surveying a terrain as pristine as the one once scouted by American Indians. However pastoral, this isn’t the forest primeval but the very edge of free land outside the impoverished zone in which Katniss (Jennifer Lawrence) and her relatives, friends and the other starved souls labor for Panem, the authoritarian state built on the ruins of North America after a catastrophic war. It’s here that she hunts game to feed her family and where this startlingly new pioneer — with her bow and arrows, leather jacket and boots, primitive individualism and totally awesome strength of character — was forged.

headline: Typhoon Revives Debate on U.S. Food Aid Methods

abstract: The Obama administration and some lawmakers say the disaster in the Philippines underscores the need for flexibility to buy less expensive food closer to the areas where disasters occur.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Typhoon Haiyan slammed into the Philippines, the United States Agency for International Development swung into action: A ship filled with rice positioned in Sri Lanka was sent powering toward the devastated island nation as 55 tons of high-energy biscuits were airlifted from Miami. As much as $100 million more in food aid, the bulk of it from the United States, will still be needed in the coming months for the estimated 2.5 million people displaced by the storm.

headline: New York City Opera to Auction Instruments and Other Items
abstract: The opera company won permission to auction off its remaining assets earlier this week from Judge Sean H. Lane of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: One harpsichord, used, a veteran of many a recitative. A five-octave celesta. A whole percussion-section worth of instruments, including drums, a gong and even a cowbell.

headline: Pacers and George Pass Knicks on Their Way Up
abstract: Six months after Indiana beat the Knicks in the playoffs, it is obvious that the Pacers and their young star Paul George have taken a leap forward while New York has regressed.
lead_paragraph: The crowd at Wednesday’s game between the Knicks and the Pacers at Madison Square Garden appeared to sense how much had changed since the teams met in the playoffs in May. Then, the Knicks were the higher seed, second in the East, and Carmelo Anthony was widely considered the best player in the series. Most of the players from that series remain on their teams, but six months after the Pacers bruised and bullied the Knicks on the way to a six-game series victory, the dynamic between the teams has irreversibly changed.

headline: A Drive Around Los Angeles in the BMW i3
abstract: In a city with a few electric vehicle charging ports, the BMW i3 is a perfectly reasonable and fun way to get around.
lead_paragraph: Depending on who you are, looking at the BMW i3 electric car will make you either love it or hate it. Its peculiar proportions and appearance, as with other odd-shape cars, seem to be polarizing. Something about it recalls the basic look of a Honda Element, but it is uniquely BMW and its fuel economy is much more impressive.

headline: Treasury Seeks an Exit From G.M. by Year End
abstract: The move allows the government to finally sever ties to the bailed-out automaker a few months sooner than expected.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Thursday that it would sell its remaining shares in General Motors by year’s end, allowing the government to finally sever ties to the bailed-out automaker a few months sooner than expected.

headline: Young Immigrants Write Software to Highlight Lack of Legal Status
abstract: Fwd.us, an advocacy group, is holding a Silicon Valley hackathon in which 20 young people who entered the country illegally as children are spending a day writing software that promotes the cause of overhauling the immigration system. The so-called dreamers are being advised by big-name backers of immigration legislation, including Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Reid Hoffman of LinkedIn.
lead_paragraph: Can 20 young programmers, all of them brought to the United States illegally as children, hack an immigration overhaul out of its deep freeze in Congress?

headline: Listening to the Beatles’ ‘White Album’ 100 Times, All at Once
abstract: The conceptual artist Rutherford Chang, who collects vinyl copies of the Beatles’ 1968 double album, has produced a recording layering the sound of 100 of them.
lead_paragraph: When the conceptual artist Rutherford Chang presented his idiosyncratic art show “We Buy White Albums” at the Recess Gallery in SoHo in January, he told a visitor that the exhibition was only part of the project. The exhibition seemed plenty, really: Mr. Chang transformed the gallery into a mock record shop in which the only discs on display were copies of “The Beatles” — the 1968 double-disc set popularly known as the “White Album” because of its stark cover.

headline: Get Excited! The Movies Issue Is Coming!
abstract: A short trailer for this year’s Movies Issue, with videos going online on Monday, Nov. 25.
lead_paragraph: First came 14 actors acting. Then there were villains, followed by heroines. This year, they speak! Watch the trailer below for the 2014 Movies Issue, coming Monday to a web site near you.

headline: Russian ‘Fertilizer War’ Appears to Wind Down
abstract: The release from Belarussian custody of the director of the Russian potash fertilizer mining company Uralkali could lead to the return of a price-fixing cartel for potash fertilizer.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — What was good news on Thursday for the chief executive of a Russian fertilizer company may be bad news for farmers around the world.

headline: An Icy Observatory Detects Neutrinos From Far, Far Away
abstract: Over two years, the IceCube Neutrino observatory in Antarctica detected 28 neutrinos from outside our solar system, the first detected since 1987.
lead_paragraph: At the bottom of the world, an observatory embedded in ice and designed to catch bountiful but elusive subatomic particles could give astronomers a brand-new look at the universe.

headline: The Gun Report: November 21, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The N.R.A. has sued San Francisco, Calif., claiming the city is violating citizens’ constitutional right to possess arms with a new ordinance that bans the possession of high-capacity gun magazines. The suit, brought on behalf of the San Francisco Veteran Police Officers Association and four individual gun owners, is in response to a measure expanding an existing ban on sales of large-capacity gun magazines. Starting Dec. 8, it gives owners of those magazines 90 days to turn them over to police.

headline: Shostakovich, the Early Years
abstract: Vladimir Jurowski will conduct the Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The maestro Vladimir Jurowski, 41, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, has been winning praise for his performance of Strauss’s “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” at the Met. But before the run ends (on Tuesday at 7:30 p.m.), Mr. Jurowski will conduct the Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center.

headline: Reversals of Fortune
abstract: Dirk Bogarde has never been more sinister than in his role of Hugo Barrett, in the 1963 movie “The Servant.”
lead_paragraph: With his insinuating heavy-lidded gaze and a contemptuous smirk, Dirk Bogarde has never been more sinister than in his role of Hugo Barrett, the manservant who takes over the life of Tony (James Fox), a young aristocrat, in the 1963 movie “The Servant.” The first of three collaborations between the director Joseph Losey and Harold Pinter, who adapted the screenplay from a novelette by Robin Maugham, “The Servant” is a high point of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s 10-film series Comedies of Menace and Quiet Desperation, which focuses on movies written or adapted by Pinter.

headline: Alabama Pardons 3 ‘Scottsboro Boys’ After 80 Years
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The last of the nine black men falsely convicted of raping two white women in 1931 died years ago, but the case long hung over the state.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — More than 80 years after they were falsely accused and wrongly convicted in the rapes of a pair of white women in north Alabama, three black men received posthumous pardons on Thursday, essentially absolving the last of the “Scottsboro Boys” of criminal misconduct and closing one of the most notorious chapters of the South’s racial history.

headline: Remembering a Tragedy
