abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s atrium will project a work by the British artist Isaac Julien, “Ten Thousand Waves.”
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s atrium has been home to any number of weird, wild and wacky goings-on. There was the time the performance artist Marina Abramovic sat there for 700 hours, and another when someone played a baby-grand piano from inside a hole that had been cut into it. There was also an installation of hazelnut pollen, and even a giant garage sale.

headline: Sustaining Martha Graham
abstract: “Surreal Graham,” presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company, sticks around for an added performance on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Performa 13, the monthlong festival of cross-disciplinary performance, officially wraps up this weekend. But at least one of its programs keeps on going: “Surreal Graham,” presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company, which sticks around for an added performance on Monday.

headline: Hands-On Journey in Smithsonian
abstract: Last month, the Smithsonian Channel enlisted celebrities to help tell the deeper stories behind some pieces from its collection.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the Smithsonian Institution has been feeling underappreciated lately. Sure, millions of people visit its museums each year, but they are seeing only a fraction of the material in its collections, and walking past a musty uniform or ancient airplane sometimes doesn’t convey the living history behind it. Last month, the Smithsonian Channel enlisted celebrities to help tell the deeper stories behind some pieces from its collection in the engaging three-part “Civil War 360,” and now ordinary museum visitors assume that role in “Seriously Amazing Objects,” which begins on Monday at 8 p.m. on the channel.

headline: Turning Corners, Guitar in Hand
abstract: Trixie Whitley’s not one for established formats
lead_paragraph: Trixie Whitley could easily have done straightforward roots-rock on “Fourth Corner” (Strong Blood), the debut album she released in January. She has the pedigree, as the daughter of the bluesman Chris Whitley, and she has the voice, which holds smoke and sorrow, exhortation and ache. But she’s not one for established formats. Her mother is Belgian, and Ms. Whitley spent years in Europe, in theater and dance troupes, before settling in New York in her teens. She was a member of Black Dub, led by the producer Daniel Lanois, and her own songs move between confession and conundrum, with shades of Fiona Apple and Alicia Keys. For “Fourth Corner,” she collaborated with the keyboardist-composer Thomas Bartlett on songs that were orchestrated with string sections and gusts of guitar reverb and distortion. Onstage, with her electric guitar, her music can be cathartic. (7:30 p.m. Saturday, Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

headline: The Filibuster’s Power to Block Nominees
abstract: Chart showing the proportion that have been used on high-level nominations and table of the nominees currently awaiting confirmation.
lead_paragraph: Chart showing the proportion that have been used on high-level nominations and table of the nominees currently awaiting confirmation.

headline: Herbert Mitgang, Wide-Ranging Author and Journalist, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Mitgang, a longtime reporter and editor for The New York Times, told of mountains of F.B.I. and C.I.A. records squirreled away on America’s most well-known writers.
lead_paragraph: Herbert Mitgang, an author and journalist whose wide-ranging work included Abraham Lincoln biographies and an exposé of the F.B.I.’s bulging files on America’s most renowned writers — John Steinbeck’s dossier was 800 pages long — died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Would You Buy the Nest Protect? Readers Respond
abstract: Some pointed out the smoke alarm could prove to be challenging for people with color blindness, while others complained the device was too expensive.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Added more reader comments

headline: Partisan Fever in Senate Likely to Rise
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Republicans will no doubt try to exact revenge against the Democrats who humiliated them with the strong-arm move to limit filibusters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will get a short-term lift for his nominees, judicial and otherwise, but over the immediate horizon, the strong-arm move by Senate Democrats on Thursday to limit filibusters could usher in an era of rank partisan warfare beyond even what Americans have seen in the past five years.

headline: Afghan Gathering Steeped in Tradition, and Consent
abstract: The loya jirga taking place in Afghanistan is part of a venerable institution in which representatives of Afghan tribes discuss issues of concern.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The loya jirga is a venerable Afghan institution in which representatives of Afghan tribes are summoned, in the absence of formal government, to discuss issues of concern. Afghan rulers used them to ratify their rule whenever they seized power or expanded territory, because if there is one defining characteristic of a loya jirga, it is that it rarely says no.

headline: Subway in London Plans to Run 24 Hours
abstract: Starting in 2015, the London Underground will be open all night. But most ticket offices will close, costing 750 people their jobs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London Underground is facing one of the most drastic overhauls in its 150-year history. Starting in 2015, its trains will start running throughout the night, and most of its ticket offices will be replaced by upgraded machines or turnstiles that accept contactless bank cards as part of a plan meant to bring the world’s oldest subway system “into the 21st century.”

headline: Spending More and Getting Less for Health Care
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The authors of “The American Health Care Paradox” explore why the richest country in the world doesn’t have the best health and why it takes more than health care to make a country healthy.
lead_paragraph: The patient, lean and in his 60s, was in the hospital for the second time in a month with blood sugar levels that were out of control and he was not happy. Despite the nurses’ earnest attempts to cheer him up, he scowled and insisted that all he needed was for us to “fix it” so he could go back home.

headline: A Coed Vision of Professional Basketball
abstract: John Howard’s vision for his Mixed Gender Basketball Association includes 4-point shots and lineups whose men-to-women ratio changes from quarter to quarter.
lead_paragraph: WEST ORANGE, N.J. — When Heather LaCasse heard of a proposed coed professional basketball league, she passed the information to her boyfriend, Jean Marcellus, and suggested he try out. As an inducement, she promised to keep him company on the drive from the Bronx to New Jersey.

headline: At Toronto Aquarium, Jellyfish Get a Tank of Their Own
keywords: ['AQUARIUMS', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The new Ripley’s Aquarium of Canada in Toronto has more than 16,000 marine animals.
lead_paragraph: Ripley’s Aquarium of Canada, now the largest indoor aquarium in the country, opened last month with more than 1.5 million gallons of salt- and freshwater habitats housing 16,000 marine animals spanning more than 450 species of fish, invertebrates and one reptile, the green sea turtle.

headline: France Investigating Ikea on Spying Allegations
abstract: French prosecutors are looking into charges that three Ikea France executives had personal data collected on employees and customers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Prosecutors have placed three senior Ikea executives in France under investigation amid allegations that they authorized illegal spying on employees and customers.

headline: Why Harry Reid Had to Use the ‘Nuclear Option’
abstract: Republicans have filibustered a record number of executive-branch nominees.
lead_paragraph: The Senate voted 52-48 on Thursday to eliminate use of the filibuster on executive and most judicial nominees (not including the Supreme Court).

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Hunger Games’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.”

headline: A Trading Tactic Is Foiled, and Banks Cry Foul
keywords: ['Credit Default Swaps', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: When the Commodity Futures Trading Commission clarified reporting disclosure rules, financial institutions that had found a way around the regulations were brought up short. An outcry ensued.
lead_paragraph: What country are you in? Where is your business located? In what country did your trade take place?

headline: Bonfire of My Vanity
abstract: Camouflaging my age always started with my hair, but then I had a misadventure at the salon, and things changed.
lead_paragraph: Hello, 56!

headline: Obama Supports Filibuster Legislation
abstract: The president makes a statement in favor of the change in filibuster rules.
lead_paragraph: The president makes a statement in favor of the change in filibuster rules.

headline: The State of Israel
abstract: In “My Promised Land,” the journalist Ari Shavit reflects on the entirety of the Israeli experience.
lead_paragraph: Too much of the discourse on Israel is a doubting discourse. I do not mean that it is too critical: Sometimes it is, sometimes it isn’t. I mean that the state is too often judged for its viability or its validity, as if some fundamental acceptance of its reality is pending upon the resolution of its many problems with itself and with others. About the severity of those problems there is no question, and some of them broach primary issues of politics and morality; but Israel’s problems are too often combined and promoted into a Problem, which has the effect of emptying the Jewish state of its actuality and consigning it to a historical provisionality, a permanent condition of controversy, from which it can be released only by furnishing various justifications and explanations.

headline: Democracy Returns to the Senate
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Fed up with endless blockades by Republicans, a majority finally ends the filibuster on nominations.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Senate Republicans have refused to allow confirmation votes on dozens of perfectly qualified candidates nominated by President Obama for government positions. They tried to nullify entire federal agencies by denying them leaders. They abused Senate rules past the point of tolerance or responsibility. And so they were left enraged and threatening revenge on Thursday when a majority did the only logical thing and stripped away their power to block the president’s nominees.

headline: Jury Tells Samsung to Pay Apple $290 Million
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The decision restores part of the damages awarded by a jury earlier this year in the long-running patent struggle between the companies.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE — A jury on Thursday said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple $290 million more in damages for violating patents, putting an end to one chapter in the long-running patent struggle between the two tech companies.

headline: More Works From German Art Trove Are Shown
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Authorities in Germany released images of works by Munch and Toulouse-Lautrec that were among a trove found in the Munich apartment of Cornelius Gurlitt.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German authorities on Thursday released images of dozens of graphics by Edvard Munch, Max Liebermann and Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec that were among a trove of art stashed for decades in a Munich apartment, bringing to 79 the number of works now identified to the public.

headline: There’s a Flag on the Commercial
abstract: Here’s a sampling of the most common infractions when it comes to N.F.L. ads
lead_paragraph: It’s not just the impetuous, bone-crunching hulks on the playing field who commit reckless penalties. The networks and advertisers are often delinquent, too. Here’s a sampling of the most common infractions when it comes to N.F.L. ads:

headline: Sacked by the Media Blitz
abstract: The marketers think they know the men who are watching pro football games, but at least one man doesn’t see himself when watching those commercials.
lead_paragraph: The most chilling words heard on any National Football League telecast are: “We’ll return right after these messages.”

headline: Mario Testino Returns to His Roots
abstract: The famed fashion photographer spent five years documenting colorful Peruvian fashion in the city of Cusco.
lead_paragraph: The famed fashion photographer Mario Testino has captured the most popular cultural icons, like the British royal family and Lady Gaga, and shot ad campaigns for the biggest names in fashion, like Gucci and Valentino. But for the photographic exhibition “Alta Moda” (“high fashion” in Spanish), on view through March 29 at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in New York, Testino turned his lens away from haute couture and toward a less recognized facet of fashion history.

headline: He Loves New York, but Can’t Drink There
abstract: The 19-year-old Jake Bugg, whose new album is titled “Shangri La,” talks about working with Rick Rubin and opening for the Rolling Stones.
lead_paragraph: For an old soul like Jake Bugg, recording at Sun Studio in Memphis was an ideal fit. “It’s got the old asbestos walls and pictures of Johnny Cash up,” Mr. Bugg, the 19-year-old British singer-songwriter, said excitedly of the space that helped give birth to rock ’n’ roll in the 1950s. “It’s just crazy to think that I was playing my guitar and singing a song in the same spot that all those guys would have been as well, all those years ago. I felt very inspired.”

headline: American, Now Held, Part of Rising Number Visiting North Korea
abstract: Merrill Newman, 85, traveled to the most closed society in the world, which keeps its people in poverty and is an enemy of the United States.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Merrill Newman is 85 and suffers from a heart ailment, but that did not deter him from fulfilling his wish to return to North Korea, where he fought as a young man, his family and friends say.

headline: An Island Outpost for China’s Maritime Claims
abstract: The remote island of Yongxing in the South China Sea may seem like a tropical paradise, but it carries great political significance for Beijing.
lead_paragraph: A 16-hour boat ride from the Chinese province of Hainan and dependent on supplies shipped in from outside, Yongxing Island, in the South China Sea, may seem an improbable location for any business.

headline: A Stillbirth’s Living Silver Linings
abstract: I didn’t set out to tell my four children about their stillborn sister during our 10-minute ride to school.
lead_paragraph: This morning, I sent four children off to school trying to wrap their heads around the idea that without a tragedy, their happy lives would be much different — maybe not so happy, or maybe they wouldn’t exist at all.

headline: Voicing Vietnam
abstract: Bryan Cranston reads Tim O’Brien’s stories chronicling his wartime experiences.
lead_paragraph: “Often in a true war story there is not even a point, or else the point doesn’t hit you until 20 years later, in your sleep, and you wake up and shake your wife and start telling the story to her, except when you get to the end you’ve forgotten the point again.”

headline: Maine Hires Firm to Study Medicaid System, to Democrats’ Ire
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Officials in Maine have hired a consulting firm — one with Republican ties and a history of suggesting cost cuts — to study the state’s Medicaid system, to include evaluating the cost of expanding the program under President Obama’s Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Maine have hired a consulting firm to study the state’s Medicaid system, to include evaluating the cost of expanding the program under President Obama‘s Affordable Care Act, a move Gov. Paul R. LePage has in the past rejected.

headline: Ellary’s Greens
abstract: Inside the West Village restaurant closing the divide between good for you and delicious.
lead_paragraph: Inside the West Village restaurant closing the divide between good for you and delicious.

headline: Witnesses at Hearing Urge Congress to Enlist Antidoping Agency and Save Horse Racing
abstract: A congressional hearing on Thursday focused on legislation that would give the United States Anti-Doping Agency the authority to set and enforce antidoping standards in the sport.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Anti-Doping Agency is the last and best hope to return safety and integrity to the troubled sport of thoroughbred racing, members of the industry told Congress at a hearing Thursday.

headline: Graphic Novels
abstract: New books by Paul Pope, John Lewis, Jordan Mechner and Gris Grimly.
lead_paragraph: BATTLING BOYWritten and illustrated by Paul Pope  First Second, cloth, $24.99; paper, $15.99. (Ages 8 to 16)

headline: Letters: State of the Art
abstract: Readers respond to recent illustrations, essays about Aldous Huxley and more.
lead_paragraph: State of the Art

headline: In Pursuit of Health and Happiness
abstract: Ellary’s Greens, which opened in the West Village in April, is not so much a restaurant as dining rehab.
lead_paragraph: “Free detox shots!” the waitress called out as she sashayed through the dining room, a tray of tiny glasses at her shoulder. The liquid in them was jungle green and wobbled. It tasted of kale and salvation, with celery and lemon for a bright-eyed, bushy-tailed finish. I downed it and waited for the world to change.

headline: Tax Proposal for an Economy No Longer Rooted in Manufacturing
abstract: Under current law, the value of assets like machinery or livestock can be written off for tax purposes. But what about assets like patents or salaries and training for employees?
lead_paragraph: A tax proposal released on Thursday by the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus, addresses a topic that tends to make my students’ eyes glaze over: cost recovery.

headline: Micron Shares Rise After Praise From Einhorn
abstract: David Einhorn, in disclosing that his firm, Greenlight Capital, owned a stake in Micron Technology, described the company as one of the survivors of the market for memory chips.
lead_paragraph: Micron Technology can officially call itself a member of the David Einhorn club.

headline: Puerto Ricans Molded by New York
abstract: November is Puerto Rican Heritage Month in New York, and free films and readings abound.
lead_paragraph: November is Puerto Rican Heritage Month in New York, giving the city a chance to recognize the ways figures like the Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the Knicks star Carmelo Anthony, the cultural historian Arturo Alfonso Schomburg and the founders of the Nuyorican poetry movement have shaped and been shaped by New York. And the Miser, being the Miser, after all, is happy to note that a number of the programs tied to the celebration are free and open to the public.

headline: David Webb’s Jewelry on Sale and for Show
abstract: Several New York auctions and fairs will showcase the work of David Webb, a jeweler whose clients included the rich and famous.
lead_paragraph: AN ORNATE LEGACY,

headline: Valérie Blass
abstract: Ms. Blass, a Canadian sculptor of considerable talent who has shown in Canada since 1992, is making her New York gallery debut.
lead_paragraph: Parisian Laundry Projects

headline: Obama Campaign Veterans Start New Advertising Venture
abstract: A second set of members of President Obama’s 2012 advertising and data team have formed a firm to work for political clients, businesses and nonprofit organizations.
lead_paragraph: A few months after members of President Obama’s 2012 advertising and data teams came together to start a new firm called AMG that would bring some of his campaign’s technical savvy to corporate America, a rival faction of advertising and data strategists say they are starting a competing effort.

headline: Refurnishing a 65-Room House, Piece by Piece
abstract: A goal was set to acquire 100 artifacts and works of art to celebrate the centennial of the purchase of an estate by William Robertson Coe, bringing the total to around 500.
lead_paragraph: An upscale tag sale appears to be underway in the cavernous limestone rooms of Coe Hall mansion, run by the Planting Fields Foundation in Oyster Bay. But no prices are listed.

headline: Collecting, Simply for the Joy of It
abstract: Dorothy and Herbert Vogel, two patrons of modern art, evoke the faded ideal of acquisition as a noble pursuit.
lead_paragraph: Collecting and investing have eclipsed many other aspects of art, particularly in recent weeks as auction prices soared to absurd levels. When one work sells for $142.4 million, as a Francis Bacon triptych did this month, it prompts questions not only about the cultural and monetary value of art, but also about the unequal distribution of wealth and how such wealth is acquired in the first place. This is why the collectors, and not just the works, in “Many Things Placed Here and There: The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection at the Yale University Art Gallery” are important within the greater history of contemporary art.

headline: A Broken Copier, and Other Calamities
abstract: A two-character play by David Jenkins explores the banalities of the workplace and the inherent blandness of corporate life.
lead_paragraph: “You. Are not. Special.” So Stan, a 50-ish office drone, informs his young co-worker in a scene from “middlemen” at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. “You are not important. I know, your parents told you differently, but they were lying. If you were never born, if you had never existed at all,” things would have turned out the same way, he says, acknowledging that the same holds true for him.

headline: Ex-Journal Tech Writers Are Close to Deal With NBCUniversal
abstract: Kara Swisher and Walter Mossberg, founders of AllThingsD, have been looking for a new partner after leaving The Wall Street Journal this year.
lead_paragraph: The technology writers Kara Swisher and Walter Mossberg, founders of the conference and media business All Things Digital, appear to have found a new home.

headline: Katherine Bernhardt and Youssef Jdia: ‘Holiday Services’
abstract: Ms. Bernhardt and Mr. Jdia collaborated on collage-paintings that use rough-edged scraps of cheap fabric, images of models and pieces of damaged rugs.
lead_paragraph: The Hole

headline: Liam Gillick / Louise Lawler
abstract: In their first collaboration, Liam Gillick and Louise Lawler stay within their comfort zones but manage to nudge us out of ours.
lead_paragraph: Casey Kaplan

headline: Rosemarie Trockel
abstract: This exhibition of new work by the internationally admired German conceptualist Rosemarie Trockel has three parts, one good, two not so good.
lead_paragraph: Gladstone

headline: Barbara Probst
abstract: For most of her career, Ms. Probst has used two of photography’s features — often considered flaws — as springboards for her work.
lead_paragraph: Murray Guy

headline: A New Holiday Face
abstract: Addressing matters of awkward Thanksgiving habits, immature friends, exercise scheduling and hotel accommodations.
lead_paragraph: I have officially started to dread Thanksgiving. Every year, I drive several hours to my childhood home to celebrate the holiday with my immediate family: my parents, an older brother and a younger sister. Within 30 seconds of being in the same room, we all assume our old roles. My brother was the brain, my sister was the jock and I was the troublemaker — but I’m not anymore. Do you have any ideas for short-circuiting those same old dynamics this year? It’s really demoralizing for me.

headline: Listen Up | A Brooklyn Disco Orchestra Unleashes Its Inner Barbarian
abstract: The Brooklyn disco outfit Escort, known for its big, singalong choruses and even bigger onstage lineup, gets primitive in a new live video.
lead_paragraph: “Dance music played with live instruments has become really popular — it’s not just underground anymore,” says Eugene Cho, the keyboardist of the Brooklyn-based band Escort. Indeed, thanks to the surprise Top 40 success of Daft Punk’s “Get Lucky,” club grooves evoking the time before computer-made beats have reached mass consciousness anew. Escort, however, has been flying that flag for over half a decade. Founded by Cho and the guitarist Dan Balis, the band hails itself as “Brooklyn’s finest disco orchestra” — mixing mirror-ball rhythms and funky cowbell syncopation with club-ready choruses, as heard on the single “Barbarians,” from their forthcoming sophomore album, out next year. The song’s lush textures call to mind Studio 54 classics mixed with the legendary producer Trevor Horn’s work in the mid-1980s with Frankie Goes to Hollywood. “It’s not reasonable to expect everyone who listens to us to know the last 30 years of dance-music history,” Cho says. “We want what we do to translate broadly.”

headline: National Gallery Acquires a van Honthorst Masterwork
abstract: While it doesn’t own a Caravaggio, the National Gallery of Art is acquiring works by artists who painted in his style, including “The Concert,” a painting by Gerrit van Honthorst.
lead_paragraph: A MERRY DUTCH CONCERT, CAPTURED BY A MASTER

headline: Photographers Protest White House Restrictions
abstract: Photographers who cover President Obama are angry over what they say is the White House’s increasing practice of excluding them from events and then releasing its own photos or video.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A mutiny has erupted among photographers who cover President Obama over what they say is the White House’s increasing practice of excluding them from events involving the president and then releasing its own photos or video.

headline: Nasty Nuns Can’t Shake a Faith
abstract: Stephen Frears’s “Philomena” follows a Irishwoman forced to give up her son for adoption in the 1950s and the freelance reporter who helps her search for him.
lead_paragraph: In “Philomena,” Judi Dench’s portrayal of a stubborn, kindhearted Irish Catholic trying to discover what became of the toddler she was forced to give up as a teenager is so quietly moving that it feels lit from within. A major theme of this film from Stephen Frears is forgiveness. Ms. Dench’s Philomena Lee glows with the radiance of someone serene in her faith despite inhumane treatment by the church. That she makes you believe her character has the capacity to forgive provides the movie with a solid moral center.

headline: Rescued London Women Say They Were Held 30 Years
abstract: A Malaysian woman, 69, an Irish woman, 57, and a British woman, 30, were freed from a house in the Lambeth district in South London in October.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London police announced Thursday that three women had been rescued from a city home where they claim to have been held against their will for about 30 years, and that a married couple who lived there had been arrested.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘My Work Is Very Difficult to Understand’
abstract: A look at the work of the German artist Isa Genzken, the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of the German artist Isa Genzken, the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: No, It Isn’t Supposed to Be Easy
abstract: Isa Genzken’s career, now the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, has been distinguished by wild stylistic diversity and emotional ups and downs.
lead_paragraph: The German artist Isa Genzken once conducted a minute-long video interview with a fellow artist and titled it, “Why I Don’t Do Interviews.”

headline: Carlin’s Daughter Writing Memoir
abstract: Kelly Carlin, the only child of the comedian George Carlin, will write a memoir of her relationship with her father.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Carlin, the only child of the comedian George Carlin, will write a memoir of her relationship with her father, her publisher said Thursday. St. Martin’s Press, part of Macmillan, acquired “A Carlin Home Companion” from Ms. Carlin, left, who said that the book developed from her one-woman show by the same name. “The man you knew as George Carlin, I called Dad,” Ms. Carlin said in a statement. “I want to offer readers a rare glimpse of the George Carlin they’ve never seen or heard about before.” The book is expected to be released in fall 2015.

headline: Assembling Brash Wholes From Scraps
abstract: “Isa Genzken: Retrospective,” at the Museum of Modern Art, devotes space to a groundbreaking artist of assemblage.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s grand, sometimes grating 40-year survey of the German sculptor Isa Genzken is a disturbance in the force of the New York art world. It counters the season’s trend of big retrospectives devoted to male artists and increases from a paltry four to a still paltry five the number of full-dress sixth-floor retrospectives the Modern has bestowed upon women since taking back its expanded building nine years ago.

headline: Records Are Dying? Not Here
abstract: The record store Rough Trade NYC prepares to open in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: BUZZSAWS were buzzing, hammers were hammering, and a sea of empty display racks awaited their wares one morning this week in a cavernous storefront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It was a typical scene of retail construction in every way except for what was coming: a record store.

headline: Rough Trade NYC
abstract: A new branch of a London record store is scheduled to open Monday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A new branch of a London record store is scheduled to open Monday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food links from near and far.
lead_paragraph: The largest wholesale cut in SNAP since 1964, when Congress passed the first Food Stamp Act, is driving one in every seven Americans to seek out food pantries. Meanwhile, the median wage is plummeting, and more than 50 Walmart workers and supporters were arrested in downtown Los Angeles last week as they sat in the street protesting the retailer’s “poverty wages.”

headline: A Silent Partner to Share the Path of Love
abstract: When crisis struck, my only friend in this foreign land did not even speak my language.
lead_paragraph: “I have the chance to go to Japan for a year,” I told my boyfriend, Randy.

headline: A Portrait Painted in Heavy Strokes
abstract: In “Breakfast With Lucian,” Geordie Greig paints a portrait of Lucian Freud, one of the most important painters of modern Britain, as a man who was mostly cruel, loutish and self-centered.
lead_paragraph: Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon were rivals as well as friends. That scratching sound you hear is Freud clawing at his coffin at the news last week that Bacon’s 1969 portrait of him, a triptych titled “Three Studies of Lucian Freud,” went for $142.4 million, making it the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction.

headline: With Pitchfork Review, a Music Site Plants a Flag in Print
abstract: The influential music website next month will publish a print magazine with long-form features and selections from the website.
lead_paragraph: After 17 years as the definitive online publication about alternative music, Pitchfork is joining the tweedy world of print with a new quarterly journal.

headline: With Dad in Jail, a Family Carries on
abstract: Michael Winterbottom’s family drama “Everyday” chronicles a working-class family in a Scottish village while the father is in prison.
lead_paragraph: Michael Winterbottom’s elusive family drama “Everyday” was filmed in two-week periods around Christmas over five successive years in a rural Scottish village. Its central character, Karen (Shirley Henderson), is a lean, intense working-class woman whose husband, Ian (John Simm), is serving time for an unspecified drug-related crime.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Philippines, India, Pakistan and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Philippines, India, Pakistan and Nepal.

headline: The Ultimate Pinup Queen, With a Peek at the Sad Side
abstract: “Bettie Page Reveals All” a documentary from Mark Mori, uses a Page voice-over stitched together from audio interviews in presenting the legendary pinup girl’s not-all-happy story.
lead_paragraph: In the more than 50 years since the all-American pinup Bettie Page hung up her trusty riding crop, her life has morphed into unlikely legend and a surprisingly durable brand. Bettie mania has gone high with a Florida museum exhibition of images snapped by Bunny Yeager, and it’s also gone predictably low, with an endless parade of Bettie-related paraphernalia from T-shirts to handbags, lunchboxes, poker chips, beauty products, light-switch plates and a line of shoes that the licensee describes as “catering to the Rockabilly, Pin-Up and Burlesque genres.”

headline: Delinquency Rates on the Decline
abstract: The number of borrowers seriously behind in their mortgage payments continues to drop, the result of an improved economy.
lead_paragraph: As the economy improves, the number of borrowers who are seriously behind on their mortgage payments continues to decline. The enhanced outlook is such that even those in delinquency are feeling more optimistic about their circumstances and homeownership in general.

headline: As SAC Shrinks, Its Operations Chief Departs
abstract: The departure of Sol Kumin underscores the transformation of SAC Capital Advisors to a symbol for corporate crime.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, before the financial crisis and before federal authorities began listening to traders’ phone calls, the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was in aggressive expansion mode. And a charismatic young executive named Sol Kumin played an important role in its rise.

headline: When How It Looks Matters More Than What It Says
abstract: Two exhibitions at the Drawing Center showcase the look of writings and drawings above the meanings.
lead_paragraph: As you read this, you’re probably not paying much attention to what the letters look like. More likely, you’re focusing on the words and sentences that the letters spell, and what they are saying. Some artists, however, have made it their business to direct attention to what letters, words, sentences, texts and books look like more or less apart from what they mean. Nine of these are in “Drawing Time, Reading Time,” a thought-provoking show at the Drawing Center.

headline: Verdict in Apple-Samsung Damages Trial
abstract: A jury said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple nearly $290 million in damages for violating patents.
lead_paragraph: A jury said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple nearly $290 million in damages for violating patents.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: How the Original 1 Percent Showed Off
abstract: Two exhibitions now in New York have much to say about the imbalance of money and taste in the Gilded Age of the late 1800s.
lead_paragraph: The staggering sums spent on art at last week’s auctions were interpreted by dealers and critics alike as evidence of a new Gilded Age. At such a moment, it may be useful to take a hard look at the old one, the late-19th-century period defined by the aggressive buying sprees of a few newly minted industrialists.

headline: Europeans Stray From the Vine
abstract: Wine consumption in the United States has been growing, but Europeans are drinking a lot less of it.
lead_paragraph: A recent article in Newsweek bemoaned that Italians, particularly younger Italians, are drinking less wine today than they did five years ago. Fifty years ago, they consumed about twice as much annually. All this, even though no country makes more wine than Italy (which exports a great deal of it, especially to the United States).

headline: A Quiz and a Drink
abstract: Scenes from a pub quiz at Dempsey’s, an East Village bar.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a pub quiz at Dempsey’s, an East Village bar.

headline: An Abstractionism Shaped by Wounded Ideals
abstract: A new Ad Reinhardt show devotes one room to his graphic designs, another to his photography, and a third to his magnetic last paintings.
lead_paragraph: In recent years some of our big Chelsea galleries have given us what are basically museum shows. From Gagosian, a while back, came an invaluable retrospective of Piero Manzoni, followed by a survey of late Monet paintings that felt like an impossible dream. David Zwirner now enters the modern-old-masters lists with “Ad Reinhardt,” a trenchant centennial tribute to a classic American artist, and one of the best exhibitions in or out of a gallery this fall.

headline: Challenging Questions on Tap
abstract: Promoting the American version of the TV trivia-game show “The Chase,” a British champion sampled a range of contests at bars in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: The Beast could not conquer Astoria, thanks in part to a too-hasty guess about a pornographic cat and bad advice about a Mets pitcher. He could not conquer the East Village, where trivia sharks were lying in wait. But he did emerge from Social Bar in the theater district as, for one night at least, king of the inconsequential and obscure.

headline: Now From a Global Village, the Vienna Choir Boys
abstract: The Vienna Boys Choir has expanded the reach of its members, traveling this season with singers from, among other places, Russia, South Korea and Congo.
lead_paragraph: The Westchester County campus of Purchase College may not be known for its geological formations. But when the 24 members of the Vienna Boys Choir arrive on campus for their holiday show at the college’s Performing Arts Center on Dec. 7, they will find themselves searching for stones, which promise to play a memorable role in the show.

headline: Weighing Costs for the Many Who Hold Sway
abstract: A case about paying lobbyists and one about a political player’s influence on lawmakers draw attention to the concept of allowing such hearings to be open to the public.
lead_paragraph: Be careful what you wish for. The closed hearings into the political activities of a conservative group in Austin are slowly coming into the open.

headline: JetBlue Joins PreCheck Program
abstract: JetBlue has joined the roster of airlines that are part of the Transportation Security Administration’s PreCheck screening program.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration said Thursday that JetBlue Airways would join its roster of airlines participating in its PreCheck airport security program. JetBlue is the ninth airline to be included, joining Southwest, which announced its participation last week, Alaska, American (which now also includes US Airways), Delta, Hawaiian, United and Virgin America.

headline: Star Types and Stereotypes
abstract: Beyond Lucy Liu and Maggie Q’s success as female leads on television, Asian-American actresses often play characters shaped to reflect longstanding stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: The CW series “Nikita” begins its fourth and final season on Friday — an abbreviated run to tie up story lines, as the reluctant assassin Nikita stands falsely accused of killing the president — and while there’s still a chance, I’d like to celebrate a small but significant milestone. For six more weeks, two of the strongest and most interesting female leads on television are being played by Asian-American actresses.

headline: Showing That They’re Glad to Be Live, and Alive
abstract: Susan Marshall & Company’s “Play/Pause,” performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is a sort of deconstruction of music videos.
lead_paragraph: The tools of “Play/Pause,” a New York premiere by the choreographer Susan Marshall that is inspired by music videos, build over time. At first, the stage is bare except for a large, standing piece of plywood, on which Luke Miller places strips of gaffers tape. Ching-I Chang scrapes a microphone on its surface. Christopher Adams pulls on a silver-sequined sock — a nod to Michael Jackson’s glove? — and, standing, lashes out an arm while lunging forward.

headline: In Oil and Gas Country, Water Recycling Can Be an Extremely Hard Sell
keywords: ['Water', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Hydraulic Fracturing']
abstract: As the drought continues, companies that handle hydraulic fracturing are considering the benefits of water recycling, given the relatively high cost of the process.
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND — Standing on a sprawling ranch where drilling rigs, cranes and bobbing stripper wells form a makeshift skyline, Jimmy Davis is not thinking solely about sucking up oil. It is not the only precious liquid that is pumped from under the land that he manages.

headline: Eclecticism Intact After a 17-Year Interlude
abstract: Mazzy Star promoted its first album since the 1990s in a concert on Wednesday at Terminal 5 in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Mazzy Star was a throwback to a throwback when it performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night, touring behind its first album in 17 years. When the band emerged in 1990, its singer and lyricist, Hope Sandoval, and its guitarist and composer, David Roback, wrote songs that looked back to the 1960s, using selective memories of folk-rock and psychedelia to define its own sparse, pensive songs. Now — when newer bands from Beach House to the xx have also embraced the still-waters-run-deep aesthetic — Mazzy Star harks back to its earlier self.

headline: The New York Times Minute
abstract: Moves on the filibuster in Washington; Michael C. Skakel is freed in Connecticut; and Monty Python to perform again.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Animating the Mind of Chomsky
abstract: The French filmmaker Michel Gondry studies Noam Chomsky in “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?”
lead_paragraph: An easygoing, sometimes tough-going meander through the world of ideas, the animated documentary “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?” finds the French director Michel Gondry playing wide-eyed student to none other than Noam Chomsky. They’re a charmingly unpredictable, appealing match. Mr. Gondry, best known for films like “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and “The Green Hornet,” has occasionally dipped into documentary, with titles like the expansive “Dave Chappelle’s Block Party” (in which the comic hosts a rocking Brooklyn block party) and the considerably more hermetic “The Thorn in the Heart” (about Mr. Gondry’s aunt and her son).

headline: Still Restless, 50 Years On
abstract: “An Adventure in Space and Time” tells how “Doctor Who” was created at the BBC in 1963.
lead_paragraph: The 50th anniversary of “Doctor Who” is being celebrated all week on BBC America, with episode marathons, documentaries and “The Day of the Doctor,” a stand-alone story uniting the 10th and 11th Doctors (David Tennant and Matt Smith) that is being broadcast around the world on Saturday.

headline: High Court May Clarify Rule on Impairment and Death Penalty
abstract: The United States Supreme Court’s ruling in a Florida case could answer a decade-old question in Texas and other states about who is exempt from execution.
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court’s ruling in a Florida death penalty case, in which an inmate argued that his intellectual disability made him exempt from execution, could help answer a decade-old question in Texas and other states about how to establish whether an inmate is too severely impaired to be subject to the death penalty.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 21 at 6 p.m.
abstract: Moves on the filibuster in Washington; Michael C. Skakel freed in Connecticut; and Monty Python to perform again.
lead_paragraph: Moves on the filibuster in Washington; Michael C. Skakel freed in Connecticut; and Monty Python to perform again.

headline: Love Machines
abstract: In “The (curious case of the) Watson Intelligence,” now at Playwrights Horizon, Madeleine George explores how people have tried to circumvent the uncertainty of relationships with technology.
lead_paragraph: It’s the stuff of science-fiction fantasy, but also of high-tech reality: a personal helper robot with the power to process language and the capacity to learn over time, its responses ever more tailored to the needs of its master.

headline: Rethinking Further War
abstract: Juilliard Opera and the period-instrument ensemble Juilliard415, conducted by Julian Wachner, are presenting a joint production of Handel’s “Radamisto.”
lead_paragraph: In a rich history of preposterous endings in opera, Tiridate’s awakening to the good and true in “Radamisto” ranks high.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: 'The Commons of Pensacola'
abstract: Sarah Jessica Parker and Michael Stahl-David in a scene from Amanda Peet's new play at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Jessica Parker and Michael Stahl-David in a scene from Amanda Peet's new play at City Center.

headline: F.C.C. to Weigh Allowing Cellphone Use on Flights
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission’s plan is already opposed by many passengers and by flight attendants, although some airlines in Asia and Europe already offer cell service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that it would consider changing its rules to permit the use of cellphones and other wireless-data devices during airline flights. If approved, the change is certain to delight some passengers but frustrate many others.

headline: How Do They Like It? Loud
abstract: Revel has hard surfaces that pump up the volume, but that doesn’t seem to bother most of the diners.
lead_paragraph: At Revel, an elegant restaurant that opened in early September in Garden City, most of the reveling is going on at the back of the place. Patrons going in the front door on Franklin Avenue see a smallish, somewhat modest dining room and a sign directing them to the hostess station in the rear dining room.

headline: Singing of the Cartels, and Investigating Them
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Music', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Shaul Schwarz’s documentary examines the folk-style music that romanticizes Mexico’s drug trade, and visits the war-torn city Ciudad Juárez.
lead_paragraph: “With an AK-47 and a bazooka on my shoulder/Cross my path and I’ll chop your head off/We’re bloodthirsty, crazy and we like to kill.”

headline: Lest a Pesky Stable Move In
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Zoning']
abstract: Reaction to plans for an apartment house above Park Avenue Christian Church is a reminder of the neighborhood’s history.
lead_paragraph: Amos Pinchot would be indignant. So would Reginald De Koven and Lewis Gouverneur Morris and Edward Stettinius. They were all well-to-do townhouse owners at Park Avenue and 85th Street a century ago, and would have been dismayed by the prospect of an apartment house above the 1911 Park Avenue Christian Church, at the southwest corner of the intersection. They all relied on a network of deed restrictions designed to prevent just that kind of thing.

headline: Fatherhood, Supersized
abstract: In “Delivery Man,” Vince Vaughn plays a sperm donor who learns he has sired more than 500 children.
lead_paragraph: As artificial as the inseminations it celebrates, “Delivery Man” is a soggy comedy more focused on stimulating your tear ducts than your funny bone.

headline: Vince Prices Above Its I.P.O. Range as Fashion Stays Hot With Investors
abstract: The fashion retailer priced its stock sale at $20 a share, a dollar above its expected range. At that price, investors valued the clothing store chain at $726 million.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is still hot on Wall Street judging by Vince Holding’s initial public offering.

headline: Love Among the Gas Pumps
abstract: A gas station looms large in “Detroit Unleaded,” a soft-spoken Arab-American romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Detroit Unleaded” is about as gentle as comedies come these days, commendably so. Rola Nashef, the director, who was born in Lebanon and raised in Michigan, wasn’t interested in the slapstick and vulgarity that pass for humor in most films. By avoiding those noisy distractions and staying within the confines of her sparse story, she has created a surprisingly affecting examination of one aspect of the Arab-American experience: the dissonance between American hookup culture and home-country traditions.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Litigating in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, and Snapchat Video Depositions
abstract: Thursday’s highlights from around the web include the inside story of the only private lawyer to have argued before the secret foreign intelligence court. Plus, why do companies always seem to leave out a founder from the creation story (and stock options)?
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Enemies, Abroad and at Home
abstract: “JFK: A President Betrayed” considers the hostile opposition John F. Kennedy faced in trying to shift American foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Early in his presidency, John F. Kennedy feared that in the face of a conflict he might not be in full control of the warmongering operatives in his government. The nuclear threat was palpable, and, as Cory Taylor explains in his well-researched documentary “JFK: A President Betrayed,” Kennedy had learned his lesson with the Bay of Pigs invasion. (According to the film, narrated by Morgan Freeman, he blamed himself for not asking the C.I.A. the right questions.)

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Homemade Polish Feast at Bargain Prices
abstract: Staropolska is a friendly place with a touch of sass. The portions are huge, the cooking is robust and the recipes are family.
lead_paragraph: New Britain, a Polish-American stronghold for many decades, hosts a handful of Polish restaurants with medieval-sounding names: Cracovia, Belvedere, Fatherland, Staropolska. It was at the last of these that I whiled away several pleasurable evenings recently, enjoying the robust delights of Central European cooking “Tu Jadamy Jak U Mamy” — the way your mother used to do it.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: James Murdoch Joins Board of Media Company Vice
abstract: The appointment was part of a deal by 21st Century Fox, where Mr. Murdoch is an executive, to buy a 5 percent stake in Vice.
lead_paragraph: James Murdoch, a 21st Century Fox executive and the son of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, has joined Vice Media as a director, two people with knowledge of the appointment said on Thursday.

headline: Cafes Powered by Coffee and Good Cheer
abstract: Open morning to night, three spots in Westchester and Rockland Counties take coffee seriously yet have strong appeal for foodies.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a time when a foodie’s working vocabulary did not include “zeppole,” “macaron,” “pour over” and “panini.” Halfhearted interpretations of these abound; it’s harder to find places that get them just right.

headline: A Place, and Prescription, of One’s Own
abstract: In “Home,” a mentally ill resident of a New York group home tries to find a place of his own.
lead_paragraph: Jack, the hero of Jono Oliver’s debut feature, “Home,” is balancing his dosage of antipsychotic medicine while seeking an apartment in New York for less than $600 a month. This seemingly impossible hunt is endured with humor and sensitivity, as well as minute pangs of suffering, thanks to a stunning performance from Gbenga Akinnagbe (Chris Partlow in “The Wire”) in the story of Jack’s efforts to leave a group home where he’s lived for many years.

headline: An Uptick in the Hiring of Women for Tech Jobs
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: There are signs that tech companies are hiring more women, but women appear to still represent far fewer than half of all new hires in the industry.
lead_paragraph: There are signs that tech companies are hiring more women, but women still appear to make up far less than half of all new hires in the industry.

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View of Liberation
abstract: “Die Narbe” (“The Scar”) is an aerially photographed documentary about the Berlin Wall’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: Burkhard von Harder’s “Die Narbe” (“The Scar”) bears witness to the legacy of the Berlin Wall in rather literal-minded fashion by filming the wall’s perimeter from a helicopter. Far from tapping Germany’s especially rich and haunted interplay between architecture and memory, the movie suggests, most immediately, that not all aerial photography is equal.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to classic rock, folk-pop, blues, hip-hop and more in the New York.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Record High for Number of Jobs in New York City
abstract: The city has added 313,000 jobs since the bottom of the last recession, a gain of 8.5 percent, the Labor Department reported.
lead_paragraph: More than a month after the partial shutdown of the federal government, the New York State Labor Department issued some good news on Thursday about employment in New York City.

headline: FIFA Plans Final Test of Vanishing Spray
abstract: Referees at next month’s Club World Cup will use a spray to stop defensive walls from cheating forward on free kicks. The World Cup could be next.
lead_paragraph: After approving a high-tech solution to goal-line controversies for use at the World Cup in Brazil, FIFA inched closer this week to a low-tech solution for a problem that usually arises farther from the goal.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Working Around Keystone XL, Suncor Energy Steps Up Oil Production in Canada
abstract: The petroleum producer has raised its capital spending to $7.45 billion next year, more than earlier estimated.
lead_paragraph: Suncor Energy, Canada’s top petroleum producer, announced on Thursday that it would expand its oil production in 2014 by 10 percent in another sign that the Obama administration’s delay in approving the Keystone XL pipeline extension is not holding back growth in the western Canadian oil sands fields.

headline: In Texas, Inmates and Officers Swelter
abstract: We have climate-controlled hog barns and overheated prisons.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. — IN August, right around the time when the Texas summer heat was at its brutal worst, the state’s prison system finalized a bid to replace its aging swine-production facilities with six new climate-controlled modular barns, at a cost of $750,000.

headline: Excerpt From ‘Radamisto’
abstract: John Holiday and Virginie Verrez perform “Se teco vive il cor,” a part of Juilliard Opera’s presentation of Handel’s “Radamisto.”
lead_paragraph: John Holiday and Virginie Verrez perform “Se teco vive il cor,” a part of Juilliard Opera’s presentation of Handel’s “Radamisto.”

headline: As Syrian War Grinds On, a New Flock of Refugees Takes Flight
keywords: ['Pigeons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Many Syrian men who have fled to Turkey, Lebanon or Jordan to escape the war have taken their passion for pigeon collecting with them.
lead_paragraph: HACIPASA, Turkey — At an unmarked border crossing here in this village in southwestern Turkey, soldiers were interrogating four Syrian men trying to walk into this country one recent morning. Three, after a few animated minutes, were let in.

headline: Cuomo on the Radio
abstract: Since taking office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has granted interviews to a select few radio hosts. His appearances with Fredric U. Dicker stopped abruptly following Mr. Dicker’s criticism of the governor’s gun-control legislation in January.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has granted interviews to a select few radio hosts. His appearances with Fredric U. Dicker stopped abruptly following Mr. Dicker’s criticism of the governor’s gun-control legislation in January.

headline: The South’s New Lost Cause
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: What we could see in 10 years is a Mason-Dixon line of health care, with the poor on one side treated as charity cases in hospital emergency rooms.
lead_paragraph: Before he was immortalized for saving the union, freeing the slaves and giving the best political speech in American history, Abraham Lincoln was just an unpopular new president handed a colossal crisis. Elected with 39.7 percent of the vote, Lincoln told a big lie in his inaugural address of 1861.

headline: Iran’s Nuclear Program
abstract: The Anti-Defamation League objects to Thomas L. Friedman’s assertion that an “Israel lobby” is swaying lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Manhattan Alleys, Dogs on Rat Hunts Find Bags of Fun
abstract: Humans on the rat patrols say their energetic little ratters are doing what comes naturally, while combining sport and public service.
lead_paragraph: It was well after nightfall. The pack of dogs was split into two groups and was led to opposite ends of a desolate alley in downtown Manhattan.

headline: For a Tapas Cafe in Princeton, Some Baby Steps
abstract: The operators of Despaña Princeton have been planning events like flamenco performances to help residents get to know the restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Bruno Romero opened the tapas cafe and market Despaña Princeton, a spinoff of the eight-year-old Despaña SoHo in Manhattan, because of parallels he sensed in the two communities.

headline: Defendants in a Cage
abstract: A judge writes that this practice implies guilt and should be curtailed.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: News Cycle Delusions
abstract: Obamacare will work, or it won’t. That’s all.
lead_paragraph: Today’s big event was the filibuster busted, and I have absolutely nothing original to say. So instead let me say something about the GOP planned attack on Obamacare — also not original, but maybe blunter than you’ll read elsewhere.

headline: Tom Wolfe’s Papers
abstract: A reader weeps at the thought of the books that the New York Public Library could have been bought with the $2.15 million acquisition.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Conservative View of Pope
abstract: A conservative Catholic responds to a front-page article, “Conservative U.S. Catholics Feel Left Out of the Pope’s Embrace.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Flipping the Holiday Switch
abstract: The period holiday film “The Christmas Candle” is a parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.
lead_paragraph: The residents of the English village Gladbury in the period holiday film “The Christmas Candle” might as well be bustling about in a snow globe for all their dimples, yuletide obsession and quaint, consumptive coughs. This film — adapted by John Stephenson, a former vice president and creative supervisor of Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, from the book by the prolific preacher Max Lucado — relates the weak-tea parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.

headline: ‘Impact’ Investing
abstract: Judith Rodin, the president of the Rockefeller Foundation, discusses “the growing excitement over innovative finance and philanthropy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rape Charge Is Set for Boy Held in Death of Teacher
abstract: A grand jury indicted Philip Chism for murder, aggravated rape and armed robbery in connection with the killing of his math teacher at Danvers High School, about 20 miles north of Boston.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A 14-year-old boy accused of killing his teacher was charged on Thursday with having raped her as well.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Egyptian Classics, and Some Surprises
abstract: King Tut offers Egyptian dishes and touches of Algeria, with fresh ingredients. And the couscous is house-made.
lead_paragraph: King Tut, subject of museum exhibitions, reverential documentaries and one very silly song by Steve Martin, now has a restaurant named after him in New Jersey. A glance at the website gave an impression of sumptuousness, but the restaurant is in a strip mall, its front windows looking out across Highway 22 in Lebanon.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A guide to the visual arts in New York City and selected regional institutions.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Children’s Book Fair

headline: U.S. Unveils Letters Insurers Must Send About Health Plans
abstract: The letters that insurers will be required to send to those seeking to renew a health plan warn that such plans will not “provide all of the rights and protections of the health care law.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said last week that the Affordable Care Act would not stop Americans from keeping their health insurance plans, even if those plans did not meet minimum standards set by the health care law.

headline: Expanding Social Security
keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Retirement', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Increases in the program won’t happen soon. But it’s a good sign that the idea finally is on the table.
lead_paragraph: For many years there has been one overwhelming rule for people who wanted to be considered serious inside the Beltway. It was this: You must declare your willingness to cut Social Security in the name of “entitlement reform.” It wasn’t really about the numbers, which never supported the notion that Social Security faced an acute crisis. It was instead a sort of declaration of identity, a way to show that you were an establishment guy, willing to impose pain (on other people, as usual) in the name of fiscal responsibility.

headline: U.S. and China Find Convergence on Climate Issue
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States International Relations', 'Global Warming', 'Kyoto Protocol', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: With China having recently surpassed the United States as the world’s largest emitter of greenhouse gases, the countries are finding that their interests increasingly overlap, officials say.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Discord and rivalry between Beijing and Washington have factored in international discussions of global warming since the United Nations climate treaty was established in 1992, contributing to the foundering of the 2009 talks in Copenhagen and much rough sailing since.

headline: A Nightmare of a One-Night Stand
abstract: A lesbian’s unexpected sexual coupling with a strange man has horrific ramifications.
lead_paragraph: The moral of “Contracted,” Eric England’s slight but intelligently assembled horror movie, is hard to miss. After Samantha (Najarra Townsend), a lesbian, meets a man at a party and uncharacteristically has hazy, unprotected sex with him in a car, she awakens the next day with an advancing case of — you remember “World War Z,” right? Let’s call this V.D.Z. Living at home in a fractious relationship with her mom (Caroline Williams) and applying to college, Samantha soon finds to her disgust that her eyes are growing opaque; teeth, fingernails and clumps of hair are coming off; a nasty lesion is growing on her lip; and her appetite for human flesh is mounting.

headline: An Old Town With New Problems
abstract: “It’s Better to Jump” allows Arab residents to express their concerns about the gentrification of their city, part of which is a Unesco World Heritage site.
lead_paragraph: The ancient city of Acre, Israel, speaks — or at least an Arab subset of its population does — in “It’s Better to Jump.” Gentrification spurred by public policy and private investment is on the march in this walled town (also known as Akka) on the country’s northern coast, leading its longstanding Arab residents to fear a loss of identity. Artists, teachers, a restaurateur and a Brown University professor say their piece, politely but firmly, in this rambling talking-heads documentary directed by Gina M. Angelone, and Patrick Alexander Stewart and Mouna B. Stewart, who are husband and wife.

headline: An Unusual Health Care Worker
abstract: A dirt-poor Texas family hires a secretive handyman to care for a son with cerebral palsy in the drama “This Is Where We Live.”
lead_paragraph: A man of few words is drawn to a family with few blessings in “This Is Where We Live,” a dusty drama about soldiering on without giving in.

headline: An Urban Hunt
abstract: A group of dog owners who take their pets to Lower Manhattan to kill rats say the activity provides mental stimulation for their dogs.
lead_paragraph: A group of dog owners who take their pets to Lower Manhattan to kill rats say the activity provides mental stimulation for their dogs.

headline: The Way They Used to Race (and Die)
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Monaco Grand Prix (Auto Race)']
abstract: Frank Simon has restored and updated Roman Polanski’s 1971 documentary about the race driver Jackie Stewart at the Monaco Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: The combination of fast cars, gorgeous men and Monte Carlo sounds a lot like heaven, but Frank Simon’s “Weekend of a Champion” will appeal mostly to motor-racing enthusiasts and movie archaeologists. Covering four days in May 1971, when the director Roman Polanski accompanied the Formula One champion Jackie Stewart to the 29th Monaco Grand Prix, this newly restored and updated documentary offers a minor sidebar to two major careers.

headline: Home for the Dollar Days
abstract: In “Cold Turkey,” the adult children returning for a family Thanksgiving all hope their father can give them some money.
lead_paragraph: It might be time for a moratorium on movies in which a family gathers for a revelatory holiday meal. “Cold Turkey” has some fine actors who put effort into their roles, but it’s getting harder and harder to care about or laugh at adult characters who have botched up their affluent lives and are still obsessed with events from childhood.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 22-28
abstract: A guide to museum events, fairs, parades, film festivals, literary talks and other cultural events.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade (Thursday) Sometimes even balloons need a makeover. Snoopy, Woodstock and SpongeBob SquarePants will be sporting new looks as they float along with the other balloon characters, bands, clowns and marchers that are part of this year’s 87th holiday spectacle.

headline: A Director’s Own Christmas Miracle
abstract: The director Kasi Lemmons has made a big-screen version of Langston Hughes’s musical “Black Nativity” starring Angela Bassett and Forest Whitaker.
lead_paragraph: “Black Nativity,” an unapologetically feel-good musical about a family’s Christmas miracle, is a stark stylistic departure from Kasi Lemmons’s signature film as a director, the brooding 1997 indie hit “Eve’s Bayou.” But Ms. Lemmons said that “in a weird way” the two films are not dissimilar: Both examine complicated families and belief in things unseen through a child’s perspective.

headline: Master of Sightless Sword Play
abstract: “Zatoichi: The Blind Swordsman,” a box set from the Criterion Collection, assembles the 25 films starring Shintaro Katsu as a samurai.
lead_paragraph: I was never quite sure what to make of Zatoichi and his backhanded sword grip. Again and again, he would fight, taking down a platoon of opponents with such lightning speed that the slashes could not even be seen, and the victims would stand, stunned, for a few seconds before pitching over dead. Again and again, I wondered: How had he done it? And how could he have done it?

headline: ‘Kennedy Has Been Shot’: Memories From Nov. 22, 1963
abstract: Of the 314 million Americans alive today, 26 percent were at least 5 years old when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. A selection of them recalled the moment they heard the news.
lead_paragraph: It is a moment we cannot forget. On the afternoon of Nov. 22, 1963, people were doing ordinary things: walking to classes, pumping gas or talking politics. For many of the 26 percent of Americans alive today who were at least 5 years old when they heard the news of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination, it was a time of outrage and grief. Those who were young schoolchildren tend to recall not so much the news itself, but its vivid effect on teachers or parents. Some adults sought refuge in a quiet pastime. And for a few, like me, the demands of work deferred the personal impact.

headline: Homeless Tally Taken in January Found 13% Rise in New York
abstract: The results of an annual count, newly released by the federal housing department, showed that New York continued to go against a national trend.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s homeless population increased by 13 percent at the beginning of this year as it continued to buck a national trend, new federal statistics show.

headline: Finding Events to Attend, on a Whim
abstract: The events listed on Yplan range from concerts and comedy shows to meet-the-author events and beer tastings.
lead_paragraph: There are myriad ways of keeping track of goings-on in New York City: newsletters like The Skint, listings in magazines or newspapers or, increasingly, the growing collection of event apps on smartphones.

headline: Princess Marie-Chantal Talks Shop
abstract: Suzy Menkes sits with Princess Marie-Chantal of Greece to discuss her children’s brand and working with her father, Robert Miller, the duty-free retail pioneer.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes sits with Princess Marie-Chantal of Greece to discuss her children’s brand and working with her father, Robert Miller, the duty-free retail pioneer.

headline: Sex, Violence and R Ratings
abstract: What is important when it comes to rating movies for audiences both young and old?

headline: 2 Lions, Their Birth Hailed by Gaza, Die Within Days
abstract: The two cubs, welcomed as a triumph over the hardships of occupation and a symbol of Palestinian resistance, lived only a few days.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — The military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, hailed the birth of two lion cubs at a zoo here this week as a triumph over the proverbial hardships of life in this Palestinian coastal enclave.

headline: Rodriguez’s Strategy: Sound and Fury
abstract: The noise Alex Rodriguez and his team have been making has been successful in diverting attention from accusations that he used drugs to an investigation he says has been abusive.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez sang his innocence aria to Mike Francesa at WFAN on Wednesday, and you could not help wondering what the next step in his media tour would be.

headline: This Week's Movies: Nov. 22, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?” and “Philomena.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?” and “Philomena.”

headline: Frank Wood Still Promoting Bands After 40 Years
abstract: Mr. Wood, 58, who has been a fixture of the downtown music scene, began booking bands at his New Jersey high school for school events, including a young Bruce Springsteen.
lead_paragraph: Frank Wood, bar band impresario, lays claim to “the best rock ’n’ roll Rolodex in town.”

headline: James H. Steele, Pioneer in Veterinary Public Health, Dies at 100
abstract: Dr. Steele helped establish mass vaccination and prevention programs in the United States and abroad for diseases that pass from animals to people.
lead_paragraph: James H. Steele, a veterinarian whose pioneering efforts to prevent the spread of disease from animals to people led him to be called “the father of veterinary public health,” died on Nov. 10 in Houston. He was 100.

headline: Derelict in Detroit, and Hard to Sell
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Bankruptcies', 'Auctions', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Two winning bidders failed to complete the purchase of a long-abandoned Packard plant on 40 acres on the city’s east side, but a third bidder could still come through.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It is the ultimate abandoned building in the city that has become America’s unofficial capital of blight.

headline: Under Investigation, Utah Attorney General Resigns
abstract: John Swallow, facing questions about whether he had committed widespread ethics violations, maintained his innocence but said the fight to clear his name had become too costly.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Utah’s embattled attorney general, John Swallow, resigned Thursday amid persistent questions about whether he had committed widespread ethics violations, saying the legal fight had become too costly.

headline: Witnesses in Trading Trial Give Peek at SAC’s Operations
abstract: SAC’s chief financial officer said that portfolio managers were rewarded special “Cohen tag bonuses” for ideas that translated into windfall gains.
lead_paragraph: The insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former senior employee of SAC Capital Advisors, offered a glimpse inside the wildly successful hedge fund on Thursday as the first two witnesses took the stand.

headline: Service Members Left Vulnerable to Payday Loans
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Payday Loans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Officials say many predatory lenders have steadily found ways around the Military Lending Act, a law that was meant to stop them.
lead_paragraph: Petty Officer First Class Vernaye Kelly winces when roughly $350 is automatically deducted from her Navy paycheck twice a month.

headline: Navy Moves Against 7th Official in Expanding Bribery Scandal
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Defense Contracts']
abstract: The Navy suspended Capt. David W. Haas, who has been linked to a criminal investigation of ship-supply contracts in the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: The Navy said Thursday that it had taken action against a seventh Navy official linked to a criminal investigation of ship-supply contracts in the Pacific.

headline: Bloomberg Says He’ll Leave de Blasio No Deficit
abstract: After his administration projected a $2 billion budget shortfall in June, Michael R. Bloomberg said his successor, Bill de Blasio, would inherit a balanced budget for the next fiscal year.
lead_paragraph: The financial picture that New York City’s next mayor will face just got a little brighter.

headline: Conducting From the Piano Bench
abstract: Jeremy Denk, who was recently named Musical America’s instrumentalist of the year, said the dual role of a conductor and soloist has its challenges and benefits.
lead_paragraph: After Itzhak Perlman resigned as the Westchester Philharmonic’s artistic adviser and primary conductor in the middle of the 2010-11 season, the orchestra began relying on guest conductors and soloists who lead from their chairs. That is likely to change. According to Joshua Worby, the philharmonic’s executive director, who has been involved in negotiations in recent weeks, the orchestra hopes to install two new conductors soon.

headline: Before Oct. 1, a Scramble to Fix Health Site
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'E-Mail', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Emails released Thursday revealed that federal officials, seeing that the HealthCare.gov website was failing tests in September, scrambled to make fixes before the site went live.
