lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials, seeing that the HealthCare.gov website was failing tests in the days before it was supposed to go live, expressed alarm as they realized that if they did not get the problems fixed they were going to be responsible for a public relations disaster, emails released Thursday evening by congressional investigators showed.

headline: Bidding for Super Bowl Trip, Fans Attempt an Option Play
abstract: Taking a cue from Wall Street, an options exchange has developed for tickets to big football games as well as for complementary services and events.
lead_paragraph: With the one-loss Broncos and Seahawks atop their conferences, fans in Denver and Seattle have good reasons to start dreaming about attending Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium in February.

headline: Justice Not Served: Inmate Buses Grounded by Correction Officers
abstract: On the day a witness was to testify against two correction officers, there was no vehicle to take him from Rikers Island to court.
lead_paragraph: All day Monday, Jose Camillo sat in the criminal courthouse on Staten Island waiting for his 17-year-old son, Joseph, to go before a judge. Late in the day, he heard why Joseph had not appeared: The correction officers had refused to leave Rikers Island with the people who were due in court.

headline: Another Banking Scandal
keywords: ['Currency', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Editorials']
abstract: Multiple investigations are underway into currency market manipulation.
lead_paragraph: As financial investigations go, it literally can’t get any bigger than this: The world’s biggest banks are now being investigated for rigging the world’s biggest market.

headline: When Utility Power Became Accessible for All of New York City
abstract: A historian of New York’s electric power said that by the early 1900s, homes and businesses in the Con Ed territory could obtain utility power if they wanted it.
lead_paragraph: Q. By what year did all homes and businesses in New York City have access to utility power?

headline: Aw-Shucks Leader Lifts Giants With a New Scowl
abstract: Eli Manning, known for his amiable personality over his 10-year career with the Giants, has become more demonstrative during the team’s four-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Maybe it is the beard that Eli Manning has grown in the last month. Maybe it is all the early-season losing, six defeats in the first six games. Maybe it is the interceptions, 17 of them, including at least eight that have not been his fault.

headline: Man Indicted in the Killing of ‘Baby Hope’
abstract: The man accused of raping and smothering Baby Hope changed his story as he was being interrogated by the police, according to a document released during his indictment.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of raping and smothering the little girl who became known as Baby Hope changed his story several times as he was being interrogated by the police, according to a court document released on Thursday.

headline: All That Glitters Online
abstract: Bitcoins and other virtual currencies could be subject to government regulation, which might bring them into the financial mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Proponents of digital currencies like bitcoins say these currencies provide greater security, lower costs and more stability than traditional forms of money like dollars and euros. But in the real world, bitcoins seem mostly to serve people engaged in illegal activities or speculation.

headline: Michael Weiner, Peacemaking Leader of Baseball Union, Dies at 51
abstract: Mr. Weiner forged agreements with baseball club owners that enhanced drug testing and brought years of labor peace to the game after decades of strife.
lead_paragraph: Michael Weiner, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, who forged agreements with the club owners that enhanced drug testing and brought years of labor peace to the game after decades of strife, died on Thursday at his home in Mansfield Township, N.J. He was 51.

headline: Café Grumpy Delights Coffee Zealots
abstract: Café Grumpy has effortlessly reproduced the ambience of the flagship cafe in Brooklyn, known for its pour-over coffee and detailed descriptions of beans, with its fifth location.
lead_paragraph: You have to admire the brass of Café Grumpy, a chain that recently opened its fifth location, on West 39th Street in the garment district, right in the heart of one of the most coffee-shop-saturated ZIP codes in New York. But since it arrived in August, this Grumpy has been consistently filled.

headline: California Encouraged by Health Plan Enrollment
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Youth', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Nearly 80,000 people have enrolled in health plans through California’s online marketplace, at a rate of several thousand a day in November — a sizable increase over a month ago.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 80,000 people have enrolled in health plans through California’s online marketplace, at a rate of several thousand a day in November — a sizable increase over a month ago, state officials said on Thursday.

headline: Health Law Is Dividing Republican Governors
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Governors (US)', 'Medicaid', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Republicans in Washington are planning to use the troubled new health law against Democrats in next year’s midterm elections, but the Affordable Care Act is increasingly dividing their party, too.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Republicans are planning to use the troubled health law against Democrats in next year’s midterm elections, but the Affordable Care Act is increasingly dividing their party, too.

headline: Elegant Chocolate to Go, and to Make
abstract: Tache, on the Lower East Side, sells chocolate in exotic flavors, and also holds classes. The aroma is free.
lead_paragraph: Tache, on the Lower East Side, sells chocolate in exotic flavors, and also holds classes. The aroma is free.

headline: Hitting the Sweet Spot for Bonbons
abstract: The exotic aromas of Tache Artisan Chocolate, owned by Aditi Malhotra, entices lingerers, as well as students, to take a chocolate-making class.
lead_paragraph: One recent Saturday afternoon at Tache Artisan Chocolate, a newish store on Broome Street, a tall, magnetic-looking man named Sean John made his way to the counter of the crowded shop. Mr. John, 38, was a regular; he owns Spur Tree, a Jamaican bar and restaurant around the corner. Before he could order his usual coffee (Ethiopian blend), the owner of Tache, Aditi Malhotra, thrust a tray in front of him. It was a new concoction she was working on: dark chocolate truffles flavored with fennel and mango. “Tell me what you think,” she said.

headline: Outcast Mother’s Death, and Questions About Jewish Sect’s Sway Over Children
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Hasidism', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Deb Tambor, whose death may have been a suicide, had forsaken the Hasidic Jewish world in which she was raised and married, leading to the estrangement of her young children.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGETON, N.J. — Abe Weiss came home on the last Friday in September to find the lifeless body of his girlfriend, Deb Tambor, on the bedroom floor of their ranch house here.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 21, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Kennedy’s Death, a Turning Point for a Nation Already Torn
abstract: The 50th-anniversary reverie has obscured the fact that by 1963, America had already become a divided, dangerous place, with intimations of anarchic disorder.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, the nation seems to be experiencing a kind of fairy tale about itself, alternately bright and dark.

headline: Corrections: November 22, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 22, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Scottish King, Bewitched and Bewildered
abstract: Character takes a back seat in Jack O’Brien’s new production of “Macbeth,” starring Ethan Hawke, at the Vivian Beaumont.
lead_paragraph: It’s the Witches’ world. Macbeth just lives in it.

headline: An Audit of Family Assets
abstract: Blythe Danner and Sarah Jessica Parker are a mother and daughter with emotional and financial issues at their feet in “The Commons of Pensacola,” by the actress Amanda Peet.
lead_paragraph: A gaping emotional sinkhole opens under the stylish boots of Becca, a struggling actress portrayed by a well-known one, Sarah Jessica Parker, in the new play “The Commons of Pensacola” by Amanda Peet — another actress, of course, here making a creditable debut as a playwright with this Manhattan Theater Club production.

headline: Joy to the World
abstract: A Friday themeless by Patrick Berry that starts out tough and Scrabbly, but eventually yields.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — For some solvers, it’s the high Scrabble count letters (X, Q, Z, V and J) that make a crossword puzzle more exciting. For others, it’s the twisty, mind-bending cluing and showstopping entries. Luckily for us, we’ve got a bit of both today, courtesy of Patrick Berry.

headline: Turning Pro at 16 and Finding Work Isn’t So Bad
abstract: Lydia Ko, who turned pro in October, got off to a solid start at Tiburon Golf Club with a one-under-par 71 and is seven strokes behind the leader, Sandra Gal.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — In anticipation of her professional debut, Lydia Ko met with Phil Mickelson last week during a visit to the Callaway headquarters in California. Ko, a South Korean-born New Zealander, is ranked fifth in the world and would have made nearly $1 million in prize money had she turned pro at the start of the year.

headline: The Unrepentant Killer Across the Divider
abstract: David Goodell fled a New Jersey halfway house to murder his former girlfriend, and later, from prison, contacted a reporter, asking to meet.
lead_paragraph: The letter sat on my desk like a dead bird. Just seeing my name written in that familiar handwriting with the capital letters and the loops sent me backing away.

headline: Forget TV; to Spread Word, Cuomo’s on Radio
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose brother is an anchor on CNN, seems more at home with an older medium.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was ready to talk. It was the morning after Election Day, and voters across New York State had just approved his proposal to expand casino gambling.

headline: Scrutiny Over Bronx Councilman’s Demands for Ice Center Plan
abstract: Fernando Cabrera of the Bronx was said to have requested that the center’s developer pay $100,000 annually to an organization associated with the councilman.
lead_paragraph: Bronx residents stand to benefit from new jobs, education programs and even free skating under an ambitious plan to redevelop the Kingsbridge Armory into a nine-rink ice center. But now a Bronx councilman is facing questions about whether he sought to benefit from the ice center, too.

headline: Jets’ Reed Goes From Ultimate Win to Winless Season
abstract: After walking away a champion with the Ravens at the end of last season, safety Ed Reed’s two teams this season have yet to win a game with him in the lineup.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Since Ed Reed walked off the Superdome turf last February, purple confetti clinging to his beard, every week has ended in darkly familiar fashion. The uniform has changed (twice). The results, through eight games he has played, have not. Reed is winless.

headline: Planning for the Arrival of Cinderella
abstract: For Bill Schermerhorn, creative director of Macy’s Parade and Entertainment Group, work at this time of year continues even on a day of rest.
lead_paragraph: If you see a life-size dragon flying in the New York City sky on Thursday, chances are you’ve had either too much family time or sudden exposure to the work of Bill Schermerhorn. If it’s the former, take a deep breath and a bite of stuffing; if the latter, strap in: After Toothless the dragon adds its name to the list of balloons that have appeared in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, there are still miles of floats, cheerleaders, dancers and marching bands to come, all choreographed and curated by Mr. Schermerhorn, the creative director of Macy’s Parade and Entertainment Group. “I’m the storyteller,” he said. Mr. Schermerhorn, 53, lives in Hell’s Kitchen with his partner, Dan Dutcher, a publicist.

headline: Vanities, and Hungry New Yorkers
abstract: The New York Public Library’s acquisition of Tom Wolfe’s papers for $2.15 million, largely with private funds, represents more than twice the amount of the biggest individual gift ever made to the city’s food bank.
lead_paragraph: This past week the New York Public Library acquired the papers of Tom Wolfe for the sum of $2.15 million. The material, which fills about 190 boxes and includes correspondence between Mr. Wolfe and his tailor, was paid for largely with a private donation, and while the figure is hardly exorbitant in the realm of cultural philanthropy, which vastly outpaces social-service philanthropy, it represents more than twice the amount of the biggest gift ever made by an individual to the Food Bank for New York City. The all too obvious irony is that it is just this sort of fracture in the city’s psychology that might find trenchant expression in a piece of writing by Tom Wolfe.

headline: Plans for College, Made More Likely With a Laptop
abstract: Xavier Cruz, 14, enjoys school, but found it hard to research topics without a computer at home. Now, through the Neediest Cases Fund, he has one.
lead_paragraph: The journey from home to school is an effortless walk for Xavier Cruz, 14, who just strolls around the corner and down the block. But considering where he is going, he may as well be traveling to another world.

headline: Font of Natural Energy in the Philippines, Crippled by Nature
keywords: ['Geothermal Power', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: A superstorm consistent with some scientists’ warnings about climate change has done tremendous damage to an island that is one of the world’s biggest success stories of renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: ORMOC, the Philippines — Clouds of steam surge from fissures in the earth along the beds of mountain streams here that splash down slopes carpeted with coconut palm forests, hints of the enormous source of renewable energy that lies underground.

headline: New Territory, and New Challenges, for HBO in Macau Prizefight
abstract: The Pacquiao-Rios fight has presented a complex tangle of logistical problems for HBO as it prepares for the event, its first pay-per-view broadcast originating outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — The boxing match between Manny Pacquiao and Brandon Rios will start at the usual time in the United States (Saturday, around midnight Eastern), will be broadcast on HBO pay-per-view and will look, if all goes well, identical to any other major prizefight.

headline: Sylvia Browne Dies at 77; Self-Proclaimed Psychic
abstract: Ms. Browne, who appeared on “Larry King Live” and other shows, said she could speak to the dead and claimed to have helped police find murder suspects and their victims.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Browne, a self-proclaimed psychic who claimed to be able to see into the past, the future and the afterlife — and who saw many of her books ascend best-seller lists — died on Wednesday in San Jose, Calif. She was 77.

headline: Relearning the Ropes

lead_paragraph: HBO is navigating logistical challenges as it prepares for its first pay-per-view boxing event originating outside the United States.

headline: Clamoring to Put the City Back in the Game
abstract: The Knicks and the Nets are 3-8 this season, and the question for the moment is not which team is better, but which one is worse.

headline: Louis D. Rubin Jr., Publisher, Scholar and Champion of Southern Writers, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Rubin, a man of letters who helped found Algonquin Books, was devoted to the practice and promotion of American Southern writing.
lead_paragraph: Louis D. Rubin Jr., whose wide-ranging career as a man of letters — he was a teacher, novelist, essayist, editor and publisher, among other things — was devoted to the practice and promotion of American Southern writing, died on Nov. 16 in Pittsboro, N.C. He was 89.

headline: A Silent Part of History
abstract: The honor guard that stood watch over President John F. Kennedy’s coffin hold a special yet nearly unseen place in America’s story.
lead_paragraph: The honor guard that stood watch over President John F. Kennedy’s coffin hold a special yet nearly unseen place in America’s story.

headline: African Rebel Leader Said to Be Considering Surrender
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Child Soldiers']
abstract: There are reports that Joseph Kony, who has been indicted by the International Criminal Court, might be ill and ready to turn himself in.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Speculation has increased in recent days that the elusive rebel commander Joseph Kony might negotiate his surrender, ending a long, murderous rampage

headline: A Leader ‘Both Brilliant and Humble’
abstract: Michael Weiner served just under four years as the head of the baseball players union, but made an indelible mark, earning praise for his kindness, intelligence and compassion.
lead_paragraph: The word was reasonable, and it was applied to Michael Weiner, over and over, long before he became the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

headline: Once at Kennedy’s Side, Now at One Another’s
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Fifty years after President John F. Kennedy’s death, many of the men who took part in his funeral are reuniting for a second, and possibly final, time.
lead_paragraph: ALLEN, Tex. — In the early morning darkness of Saturday, Nov. 23, 1963, at approximately 04:30 hours, Tim Cheek, a 20-year-old Marine assigned to body bearer duty, was one of eight enlisted men to carry President John F. Kennedy’s coffin, first into the East Room of the White House, and then back out the next afternoon; up the steps to the Capitol Rotunda and then down the next morning; into St. Matthew’s Cathedral and, then, out to the horse-drawn caisson waiting in the street.

headline: Intel’s Recovery Realization
abstract: Intel executives made a startling admission: that the company’s fixation on personal computers blinded it to the reality that transistors are getting more dense and computing intelligence is traveling to ever-smaller things.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In the temple of technology, Intel has confessed to straying from the true path. That may prove to be the start of salvation for the company, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, but at a price that is yet to be known.

headline: Scandal Tarnishes a British Bank’s Reputation
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: A series of incidents involving Paul Flowers, the Co-operative Bank’s former chairman, has embarrassed the bank and many politicians in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s Co-operative Bank once prided itself on being a beacon of ethical standards in a financial sector blamed for the country’s economic problems.

headline: A Conservative Alternative to Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Some conservatives propose to abolish both employer-based health coverage and Medicaid, relying on a private market with subsidies, a plan that seems politically and structurally unrealistic, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Thomas Rees, Plastic Surgeon Who Treated Africa, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Rees, an innovative New York practitioner, helped found the Flying Doctors Service of East Africa, which helps provide medical care and save lives in the African bush.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas D. Rees, an innovative New York plastic surgeon who helped found the Flying Doctors Service of East Africa, a charity that employs a fleet of small planes to provide medical care and save lives deep in the African bush, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 86.

headline: As Holidays Approach, Retailers Fight for Sales
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: A budget-conscious consumer mind-set is expected to hurt holiday sales.
lead_paragraph: Major retailers are bracing for a tough holiday season, reflected again this week in the gloomy third-quarter earnings issued on Thursday by Target and Sears. Target’s earnings dropped 46 percent from a year ago, dragged down by a costly expansion in Canada and a bleak outlook for consumer spending in the United States. The company also lowered its forecast for the year.

headline: Taking on the Task of 5: A Party Veteran on Xi Jinping
abstract: Bao Tong, an official who was purged in 1989, is an astute observer of Chinese politics and offers his take on the Communist Party’s plans to revitalize the economy and strengthen its authority.
lead_paragraph: Bao Tong was an important official in China during the tumultuous changes of the 1980s. He was a political secretary to Zhao Ziyang, the prime minister and then Communist Party chief, who oversaw the market reforms of that decade. But Mr. Zhao was purged in 1989, after falling out with Deng Xiaoping and party hard-liners over how to deal with student-led protests in Tiananmen Square, and Mr. Bao was purged with him.

headline: Running Away From Japanese Cars in Chongqing
abstract: The recent upsurge in anti-Japan sentiment is spreading to the young, with the public shaming of a Chinese couple by their 14-year-old daughter, who ran away after they purchased a Japanese car.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a 14-year-old girl in the southwestern megalopolis of Chongqing reportedly ran away from home for three days to protest her parents’ new car purchase.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 22, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, November 22, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “You leave no footprints. No one is watching you, but you’re part of history.”

headline: News Quiz | November 22, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Relatives Mystified by Fate of American Held in North Korea
abstract: Merrill Newman, 85, traveled to the most closed society in the world, which keeps its people in poverty and is an enemy of the United States.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Merrill Newman is 85 and has a heart ailment, but that did not deter him from fulfilling his wish to return to North Korea, where he fought as a young man, his family and friends say.

headline: Death Toll Rises in Supermarket Collapse in Latvia
abstract: The number of people killed reached 51, and officials said hope was fading for at least 25 more victims believed to be trapped in the rubble.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The number of people killed in Riga, Latvia, when the roof of a crowded supermarket suddenly collapsed, reached 51 on Friday, and officials said hope was fading for at least 25 more victims believed to be trapped in the rubble.

headline: A Karnataka Dance Moves With Modern Times
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Art', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Dancing', 'Folk Music', 'Language and Languages', 'Music', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Theater', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: As Yakshagana, a 700-year old dance-drama, evolves, a constant debate rages between tradition and change, and how far to go with both.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE — In a quiet Bangalore home, a group of middle-aged women are learning to walk, talk and dance like men. Only a decade ago, they might have been scoffed at; today the mixed audience of men, women and children cheers them on. They are learning Yakshagana, a 700-year old dance-drama that originated in the coastal regions of Karnataka.

headline: Chinese Stealth Drone Makes First Flight
abstract: According to state-run media, the Lijian, or “Sharp Sword,” combat drone made its first flight of about 20 minutes on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Yet another Chinese drone variant has taken wing — and this one might be stealthy.

headline: Latin Grammys Get Earnest (Showgirls Aside)
abstract: There was no overwhelming winner at this year’s Latin Grammys, with Marc Anthony awarded best record and Draco Rosa best album.
lead_paragraph: Where did the pizazz go?

headline: Bitcoin Gets a Cautious Nod From China’s Central Bank
abstract: The deputy governor of China’s central bank said there were no plans to recognize the digital currency, but he added that Chinese citizens were free to participate in the Bitcoin market.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Chinese government issued its most direct statement to date on the legitimacy of Bitcoin, the thus-far-unregulated digital currency that has taken China, the United States and other countries by storm in recent months.

headline: Pipeline Blast Kills 35 in Eastern China
abstract: The blast in the industrial city of Qingdao erupted in a leaking crude oil pipeline operated by Sinopec, a major Chinese state oil refiner.
lead_paragraph: An explosion in a ruptured oil pipeline killed at least 35 people on Friday in Qingdao, a seaside city in eastern China, where the blast cracked apart streets, upended cars and sent a funnel of smoke into the air, according to Chinese news media reports and photos.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Senate Votes to Limit Filibusters
abstract: Why is this procedural move called the “nuclear option”?
lead_paragraph: In “Landmark Senate Vote Limits Filibusters,” Jeremy W. Peters writes about the most fundamental shift in the way the Senate functions in more than a generation.

headline: No Release in Sight for Film Exploring China’s Violence
keywords: ['Cannes International Film Festival', 'Censorship', 'Movies', 'Three Gorges Dam (China)', 'Venice International Film Festival']
abstract: “A Touch of Sin,” the new film by the celebrated art house director Jia Zhangke, won a best screenplay award at Cannes in May. When it will be shown in China, however, is anybody’s guess.
lead_paragraph: When Jia Zhangke screened his new movie, “A Touch of Sin,” for a small group of journalists in his office last August, he said the film would make a round of foreign film festivals in the autumn and then, if all went well, be released on Nov. 9 in China. Now, with winter approaching, there is still no indication that the film will be shown in Chinese theaters.

headline: Institutional Care: Cue the Laugh Track
abstract: HBO begins a series about a dysfunctional geriatric rehab center.
lead_paragraph: I’m sure the creators of “Getting On,” the HBO series that premieres Sunday night, see it as a blisteringly dark comedy about a dysfunctional geriatric rehab center, with characters and plot devices exaggerated for the sake of laughs.

headline: Why Aren’t More Girls Choosing to Pursue Careers in Math and Science?
abstract: Do you think the problem is that parents, teachers and society in general do not encourage girls to enter these fields? Or is it just not seen as “cool” for girls to excel in math and science?
lead_paragraph: Natalie Angier wrote in September about the paradox of why girls who were equally competent and confident as boys in science and mathematics still chose not to enter the STEM fields — science, technology, engineering and math. The statistics are baffling. For example, women earned 37 percent of computer science degrees in 1985, yet only 18 percent in 2010. And only one-fifth of physics Ph.D.’s in this country are awarded to women.

headline: Being Seen Inside an Unseen World
abstract: Gerard H. Gaskin’s photos of the vibrant, underground house ballroom scene, celebrated by mostly gay and transgender black and Latino men, have earned him recognition as a “Trinidadian Andy Warhol.”
lead_paragraph: A young man painted in blue fixes his eyes on the photographer before him. But before the portrait is made, he peeks in the mirror, retouches his lipstick and brushes away a few strands of white and blue hair from his face. He spent weeks preparing his wig and outfit — a shimmering handmade gown of plastic shower curtains and yellow buttons — all in hopes of taking home the title, and maybe some money, as “Butch Queen Bizarre.”

headline: N.S.A. Memo Authorizes U.S. Spying on British Citizens
abstract: A draft classified document states that, under specific circumstances, the American intelligence agency may spy on citizens of Britain without that country’s consent or knowledge.
lead_paragraph: A draft classified document states that, under specific circumstances, the American intelligence agency may spy on citizens of Britain without that country’s consent or knowledge.

headline: Pneumonia Is New Threat to Storm-Battered Philippines
abstract: Torrential rain and a rapid alternation of chilly breezes and sweltering heat have contributed to outbreaks of pneumonia in areas hit by the typhoon.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Two weeks after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the east-central Philippines, a new problem has emerged: pneumonia.

headline: Why India Is Going to Mars
abstract: The red planet isn’t just about horoscopes. We can live with superstition, and science.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — IF you want to marry in India and are looking for a bride or groom, normally you need to consult an astrologer, to learn whether the position of the planet Mars is favorable on your birth chart. If not, you may find it difficult to get the match of your choice. Lately, some employers have been trying this as well, matching their horoscopes with those of their prospective employees; companies are also comparing horoscopes with their clients for good fortune.

abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: tough times for local sports fans, a weather grab bag, and dogs go rat hunting.

headline: South Korea Is Expected to Buy Lockheed Fighter Jets
abstract: New requirements announced on Friday effectively leave the American contractor’s F-35A stealth jet as the only viable option.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Friday announced revised requirements for a new generation of fighter jets it plans to buy, effectively leaving Lockheed Martin’s F-35A stealth jet as the only viable bidder for the country’s largest arms acquisition program ever.

headline: Kia, Toyota and Porsche Issue Recalls
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Nearly 80,000 Kia minivans will be recalled for a potential steering system problem; Toyota and Porsche issue recalls for electrical problems.
lead_paragraph: Kia will recall nearly 80,000 Sedona minivans from the 2006-12 model years because of a problem that could cause steering failure, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Toyota and Porsche will also conduct smaller recalls, according to reports the two companies filed with the agency.

headline: Why the Swiss Scorn the Superrich
abstract: In Switzerland, the land of farming and social modesty, another referendum targets excessive pay.
lead_paragraph: WINTERTHUR, Switzerland — Abroad, Switzerland may be best known for its smart ski resorts and discreet banking services for the superrich, but the Swiss themselves are remarkably allergic to the trappings of conspicuous wealth.

headline: The Year the Monarch Didn’t Appear
keywords: ['Bees', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Insects', 'Biodiversity', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: The precipitous loss of native vegetation across the United States has led to a dramatic decline of insect populations.
lead_paragraph: ON the first of November, when Mexicans celebrate a holiday called the Day of the Dead, some also celebrate the millions of monarch butterflies that, without fail, fly to the mountainous fir forests of central Mexico on that day. They are believed to be souls of the dead, returned.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Awarded $290 Million in Patent Dispute With Samsung
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The jury’s decision puts to an end one chapter in the two companies’ long-running legal battle, though it will not significantly affect either company’s pocketbook.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Thursday said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple $290 million more in damages for violating patents, putting an end to one chapter in the long-running patent struggle between the two tech companies, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: A Stroll Around the World
abstract: Walking across the world, a writer discovers Car Brain.
lead_paragraph: ON THE GULF OF AQABA, Jordan — I AM walking across the world. In January I set out on foot from Herto Bouri, an early site of Homo sapiens fossils in the Rift Valley of Ethiopia, to retrace the pathways of the first anatomically modern humans who colonized the planet at least 60,000 years ago. My finish line is in Tierra del Fuego, at the chilly tip of South America, the last nook of the continents settled by our ancestors. This long ramble will last seven continuous years. It will span 21,000 miles. (I have logged about 1,700 miles to date.)

headline: 1963: Art Buchwald ‘We Weep’
abstract: The columnist Art Buchwald remembers President John F. Kennedy with a poem.
lead_paragraph: We weep for our President who died for his country.We weep for his wife and for his children.We weep for his mother and father and brothers and sisters.We weep for the millions of people who are weeping for him.We weep for Americans, that this could happen in our country.

headline: On a Day It Can Never Escape, Dallas Tries to Heal
abstract: Thousands joined to honor President John F. Kennedy in a tribute leaders hoped would also help heal a city long stigmatized by his death.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — At the precise minute when shots rang out at a downtown plaza here 50 years ago Friday, more than 5,000 people paused in silent tribute at the place where this city and the nation were forever changed by the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Chennai’s Love for Chess and Its Champion
abstract: In the southern Indian city of Chennai, chess and Viswanathan Anand do not need an introduction.
lead_paragraph: As the Indian grandmaster Viswanathan Anand was losing ground to Magnus Carlsen of Norway in the battle for the title of world chess champion in Chennai, Mr. Anand’s hometown, the agony in the city was palpable.

headline: Ukraine Blames I.M.F. for Halt to Agreements With Europe
abstract: Ukraine’s prime minister said his government’s decision to walk away from the pacts was based on fiscal imperatives, and ultimately prompted by the I.M.F.’s overly harsh terms for an aid package.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Mykola Azarov of Ukraine told enraged opposition lawmakers on Friday that his government’s decision to walk away from far-reaching political and trade agreements with the European Union was based on fiscal imperatives, and ultimately prompted by the International Monetary Fund’s overly harsh terms for an aid package.

headline: Service Members Trapped in Cycle of Debt
abstract: Nearly seven years after the Military Lending Act went into effect, government authorities say the law has gaps. | The chief operating officer of SAC Capital Advisors is leaving, underscoring the firm’s transformation. | The move by Senate Democrats to limit filibusters lowers a hurdle for executive nominees, including Janet L. Yellen.
lead_paragraph: SERVICE MEMBERS VULNERABLE TO PAYDAY LOANS  |  Congress tried in 2006 to shield military members from payday loans, which come with double-digit interest rates and can plunge customers into debt. But nearly seven years after the Military Lending Act went into effect, government authorities say the law has gaps that threaten to leave hundreds of thousands of service members across the country vulnerable to potentially predatory loans, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. Authorities say the law has not kept pace with high-interest lenders that focus on servicemen and women, both online and near bases.

headline: Central Bank Chief Urges European Unity
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Mario Draghi’s comments came amid increased concern that European leaders have lost the will to address underlying flaws in the euro zone and instead are blaming each other for the economic stagnation.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, issued a plea for European unity on Friday and criticized what he said was a “nationalistic tone” in the reaction to recent central bank policy moves.

headline: Acer’s New Chairman Follows a Familiar Tech Path
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Tablet Computers']
abstract: A second executive shake-up this month brings back Stan Shih, who said he would work for no pay as he tries to reorient the company toward mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Another computer entrepreneur has returned to lead a company that he founded after it fell on hard times.

headline: A 50-Year Timesman Recalls ‘the Most Exciting Moment I’ve Had’
abstract: One month after being hired, Robert Semple experienced the story of a lifetime in the Kennedy assassination
lead_paragraph: Robert B. Semple Jr. had been at The Times for only a single month when the event of a newsman’s lifetime – the assassination of President John F. Kennedy – made itself known to him in the form of a radio announcement. He was getting ready to drive to New Haven for a weekend with friends and had stopped at a carwash.

headline: Son of Israeli Ex-President Takes Helm of Labor Party, Urging Peace
abstract: Isaac Herzog, the son of former President Chaim Herzog, urged “bold steps” toward peace with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Isaac Herzog, the son of a former president, took the helm of Israel’s Labor Party and thus Parliament’s opposition on Friday, vowing to restore the party’s historic focus on promoting peace with the Palestinians and to mount a vigorous challenge to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-leaning government.

headline: Ripped From the Headlines and Applied to the Classics: Ideas for Pairing Fiction and Nonfiction
abstract: So you’re teaching “Huck Finn” — or any other classic work of literature — and you want students to see for themselves that the ideas in it are still relevant. Also, you’re well aware that the Common Core standards want teachers across the curriculum to include more nonfiction. Where do you start?

headline: Chevron Has Second Thoughts on British Project
abstract: The American oil giant said it was reconsidering whether to proceed with developing a big deepwater field off the coast of Scotland, citing high costs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American oil giant Chevron said Friday that it was putting its flagship British deepwater development project under review, saying high costs might not make it viable to continue.

headline: Great Years for Nadal and Murray, One Wincing Moment for Djokovic
keywords: ['Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'French Open (Tennis)', 'Australian Open (Tennis)']
abstract: Despite all of Novak Djokovic’s earthly achievements in 2013, the year will belong in the history books and the memory banks to Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray.
lead_paragraph: As it turned out, the Davis Cup final that ended Nov. 17 with the Czech Republic beating Serbia was in perfect harmony with the rest of the tennis season.

headline: Trying to Redefine ‘Full-Time Work’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Some lawmakers think “full time” in the health care law should mean 40 hours, rather than 30 hours per week.
lead_paragraph: As if the Affordable Care Act weren’t having enough problems, a bipartisan Senate foursome is now asking that a bill to weaken the employer mandate be included in any budget agreement that comes out of the Senate in the coming weeks.

headline: Restoring Brian De Palma in British and U.S. Versions
abstract: Twilight Time took one path toward remastering Brian De Palma’s “The Fury” for a limited-edition Blu-ray; Arrow, in Britain, took a different approach.
lead_paragraph: Overheatedly lurid and clinically chilly at the same time, the 1978 telekinesis-and-paranoia thriller “The Fury” is, for both devotees of its director, Brian De Palma, and hard-core horror fans (two groups that intersect more than a bit), something of a classic.

headline: Silent Fellow Travelers
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A set of small coincidences kept placing two New Yorkers together one day, from downtown to uptown.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Europe at Ease With Eyes in the Sky
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Industrial Espionage']
abstract: Despite general skittishness about electronic surveillance, European officials seem more open to civilian drones than regulators in the United States.
lead_paragraph: GROSSMITTEL, Austria — Deep within a secluded Austrian military training ground here, an odd, shark-shaped machine hovered just above a stand of windswept pines.

headline: When Thought Experiments Encounter the Unthinking
abstract: Lack of humor can be fatal.
lead_paragraph: No, John Maynard Keynes didn’t think that burying bottles full of cash in coalmines was the best way to end the Great Depression.

headline: Del Toro Shares His Curiosities
abstract: The filmmaker Guillermo del Toro’s new book offers a tour of his notebooks and his many collectibles.
lead_paragraph: Opening “Cabinet of Curiosities,” the filmmaker Guillermo del Toro’s oversize new book, is akin to bouncing around inside his hallucinatory brain. In addition to densely illustrated pages from notebooks for movies like “Hellboy” and “Pan’s Labyrinth,” it also includes pictures of Bleak House, where del Toro works and stores hundreds of artworks, figurines and props. “Catholics go to church, Jews go to temple,” del Toro writes. “I come here.”

headline: Points of Entry
abstract: The wrangling over poetry’s accessibility is often a proxy for a centuries-old squabble between people who like their poems plain-looking and people who like them a little more rococo.
lead_paragraph: At any given moment, millions of people in this country are happily not reading poems, and dozens of poets are happy to say they don’t care. “I have never been one of the people who feel it essential to increase the audience for poetry,” the former poet laureate Louise Glück remarked several years ago. “The people who need it find it.” Variations on this sentiment are fairly common among poets and critics across the aesthetic spectrum, and for the most part that’s to be expected. Every activity generates experts, and experts typically have little time for novices. This is no less true of poetry folk than of photographers or pastry chefs.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ALL GONE: A Memoir of My Mother’s Dementia. With Refreshments,  by Alex Witchel. (Riverhead, $16.) In this unflinching memoir, Witchel, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, describes how her once vibrant mother slowly began “disappearing in plain sight.” With its cast of vibrantly portrayed relatives and recipes passed down by Witchel’s mother and grandmother, “All Gone” is “a powerful affirmation of family bonds,” Maggie Scarf wrote in the Book Review.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BULLY PULPIT: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism,  by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $40.) Historical parallels in Goodwin’s latest time machine implicitly ask us to look at our own age.

headline: British Police Say ‘Invisible Handcuffs’ Restrained Women for 30 Years
abstract: Officers described the case of three women who said they were held against their will in South London as “complicated and disturbing.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Police detectives investigating the case of three women who claim to have been held against their will for 30 years said Friday that the victims had been brainwashed and imprisoned by “invisible handcuffs” in an unremarkable house in South London.

headline: What’s in Store
abstract: Ann Patchett has found gratification in an unexpectedly successful union and in her new bookshop.
lead_paragraph: I hope it will not sound disrespectful if I say that I read this book for fun. Yes, I was assigned to review it, and, yes, I assembled all my usual reviewer’s equipment (note cards, pen, critical faculties) before sitting down to read. But when I got to the end of the book, I realized I hadn’t taken a single note. I had been so engaged by Ann Patchett’s multifaceted story, so lured in by her confiding voice, that I forgot I was on the job.

headline: Even Madder Men
abstract: Michael Kimmel reports on men who, after a series of economic and political shifts, feel emasculated and humiliated.
lead_paragraph: The characters populating Michael Kimmel’s new book, “Angry White Men,” are familiar types: Rush Limbaugh’s ditto­heads, neo-Nazis, wife beaters, rampaging shooters and the divorced rageaholics of the men’s rights movement. Crowded together under one banner, they make for a scary and unpleasant lot: full of fury and blaming everyone but themselves for their problems. Mostly, they blame women: ex-wives, would-be girlfriends, the phantom black women who stole their jobs. The editor of a men’s rights website proclaims, “The real question here is not whether these women deserve the business end of a right hook, they obviously do, and some of them deserve one hard enough to leave them in an unconscious, innocuous pile on the ground.”

headline: Clang Went the Trolley
abstract: Two books center on an enduring thought experiment and the moral consideration it raises.
lead_paragraph: You are walking near a trolley-car track when you notice five people tied to it in a row. The next instant, you see a trolley hurtling toward them, out of control. A signal lever is within your reach; if you pull it, you can divert the runaway trolley down a side track, saving the five — but killing another person, who is tied to that spur. What do you do? Most people say they would pull the lever: Better that one person should die instead of five.

headline: O Radiant Future!
abstract: Eleven dystopic fables by the early Soviet writer Sigizmund Krzhizhanovsky.
lead_paragraph: The stories in this collection by the early Soviet writer Sigizmund Krzhizhanovsky are nearly as fantastic as the crashing combination of consonants at the beginning of his surname. In one, the reflection of a man in his girlfriend’s eye vanishes down the dark corridors of her pupil and falls into a deep well, where it joins the lonely, miserable reflections of her previous lovers. There the reflections debate their mistress’s charms and caprices, as well as their own deficiencies of character. And they plot their escape. The hero of another story, a writer, composes a tale about a hermit whose prayers temporarily close all the cracks in the world — potholes, mountain gorges, facial wrinkles, even “the cranial seams hidden under the skin on people’s heads.” After reading the yarn to some indifferent friends, the writer is visited by an enthusiastic scientist, a reincarnation of the German philosopher Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, who claims that reality itself, the entire space-time continuum, is no less cracked than our everyday world, riddled with gaps and intermittencies.

headline: Serious Listening
abstract: Don’t limit yourself to thrillers and romances; audiobooks offer a great way to take in literary fiction too.
lead_paragraph: We’re used to it.

headline: To Hear Her Tell It
abstract: Meryl Streep gives voice to the Mother of Jesus in Colm Toibin’s “The Testament of Mary.”
lead_paragraph: Doesn’t it seem inevitable that Meryl Streep would one day play the mother of Christ? Lord knows she’s played just about everybody and everything else: a Holocaust survivor, a chilly Australian housewife who lost a baby to a dingo, Margaret Thatcher and Isak Dinesen and Karen Silkwood, a ­Prada-wearing devil, a nun with a mean ax to grind, and, coming soon to a thea­ter near you, the devouring Oklahoma mama of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play “August: Osage County.”

headline: Soup to Start
abstract: Small servings of soup are a great way to start off a Thanksgiving meal without filling people up.
lead_paragraph: View our searchable database of over 600 vegetarian Thanksgiving recipes.

headline: Speaking Gobblefunk
abstract: On newly released CD sets, British actors read stories by the children’s author Roald Dahl.
lead_paragraph: With “Matilda” romping on Broadway, it’s time to reconsider the collected works for children by that English rapscallion, Roald Dahl. Shall we throw tomatoes or roses? Dahl has been tagged variously as a champion of children, an anti-Semite, a panderer of low and crude humor, an acerbic writer of adult short stories who went slumming in kiddie-book land and found it paid well. He’s beloved by millions. I never quite knew why until now.

headline: ‘Norma’ Times Nine: An Operagoer’s Report
abstract: A reviewer attends nine performances of Bellini’s “Norma,” to compare different seating spots at the Met.
lead_paragraph: A little over a month ago, I was up in the Balcony section of the Metropolitan Opera watching a performance of Bellini’s “Norma.” It’s not a part of the Met I spend much time in anymore, but when I was young, I sat for many nights in my favorite spot at the center of the balcony’s front row. From up there, I would feel like the captain at the bow of a ship, the empty space of the theater sprawling out beneath me, and the proscenium looming fearsomely high ahead.

headline: Up in the Aerie, a Ballet Lover’s Perch
abstract: The Times’s chief dance critic revisits his early dance-viewing perch.
lead_paragraph: Americans call them “the nosebleeds.” We British know them as “the gods.” They’re the top tiers of the world’s major opera houses, and during my first years of dancegoing in the 1970s and ’80s in London, those cheap seats were where I spent most of my time. (Friends used to suggest that I should just string up a hammock at Covent Garden and spend the night there, too.) When I first visited New York, standing room at the back of the fourth ring of the New York State Theater was where I occupied every evening.

headline: Worst-Laid Plans
abstract: The women in Laura van den Berg’s story collection are mired in secrecy and deception.
lead_paragraph: The enigmatic women in Laura van den Berg’s strange and lovely new story collection, “The Isle of Youth,” yearn for secure, uncomplicated lives. Luckily for us, instead of clarity and predictability they end up with secrets and doubts. These characters — magician’s assistants, gumshoes, gangsters, twin sisters, abandoned wives and light-fingered daughters — all hope to understand the mysterious world, but they find it hard enough just to understand themselves.

headline: Dead Poet Society
abstract: A deceased writer’s devotees are drawn to an author awarded a residency at her former home.
lead_paragraph: This short, funny and often beautifully written novel — completed in the early 1970s but just now being published — provides an excellent occasion for remembering the weird wisdom and genuine talent of Janet Frame, who died in 2004 after a startlingly diverse life. Born and raised in New Zealand (her mother worked as a maid for Katherine Mansfield’s family, her father for the railroad), Frame developed a youthful love of poetry that sustained her through several years spent in and out of psychiatric hospitals — until the publication of her first book, a collection of stories called “The Lagoon,” in 1951. ­(After her receipt of a major literary award, her doctor sensibly decided against giving her a lobotomy.)

headline: In Full Swing
abstract: Bill Bryson chronicles one season in American history, when Lindbergh flew, Babe Ruth hit and Calvin Coolidge vacationed.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, one magnificent season can define an era. At least, that’s the view in trade publishing of late, where “year” books have become something of a mania: “19__: The Year Our World Changed/Began/Ended/Learned to Love the Macarena.” But it’s not hard to argue that the apogee of the wild ride America took in the 1920s came in the summer of 1927.

headline: Before the Sun Rose
abstract: The second volume of Ernest Hemingway’s letters shows him beginning to make his way in Paris.
lead_paragraph: In the Paris spring of 1925, a young American writer sent a letter to his new publisher in which he assessed his ­chances in the literary marketplace. The only commercial magazine to which he had as yet sold a story was a German number that wanted to translate a piece about a matador, but he nevertheless told Horace Liveright he hoped to become a valuable “property.” Most readers found modern literature too difficult, and he knew that some wonderful books had been commercial failures; Liveright himself had published more than a few of them. Still, his own collection of stories was different, and he felt he had a “good gambling chance to sell.” For his work, he thought, would “be praised by highbrows and can be read by lowbrows. There is no writing in it that anybody with a high school education cannot read.”

headline: Secret History
abstract: Graham Robb contends that the druids’ engineering feats rivaled those of the Romans.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago, I was part of a team excavating an ancient Greek temple on the beautiful island of Paros. For nearly a thousand years, worshipers at this spot had built walls, knocked them down, dug holes and burned offerings to their gods, leaving behind baffling, ambiguous remains. One day, as I was staring at the dirt in a heat-induced daze, a younger student commented how hard it was to make sense of it all. I could only agree, but as we chatted, I realized — to my deep embarrassment — that we were talking about entirely different things. I was obsessing over the technicalities of decoding this complex deposit, while he wanted to know what it had felt like to stand there 2,500 years earlier, sacrificing to alien gods. I had allowed the intricacies of archaeological methods to blind my imagination.

headline: Bygone Bipartisanship
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Chris Matthews recalls a long-ago era in Washington politics.
lead_paragraph: Ever since our national politics dissolved into a miasma of polarization and strident punditry — which means either the Clinton pseudoscandals or the John Adams administration, depending on your historical reference point — Washington pontificators have waxed wistful for gentler times. In the glow of nostalgia, even ideologues and scoundrels come to resemble civic-minded statesmen who put aside partisanship to broker compromises.

headline: Wine Cellar, Well Aged, Is Revealed in Israel
abstract: Where rulers of a Middle Bronze Age city-state once feasted, researchers have found one of civilization’s oldest and largest wine cellars.
lead_paragraph: Digging this summer at the ruins of a 1700 B.C. Canaanite palace in northern Israel, archaeologists struck wine.

headline: Their Honors
abstract: What mayors can contribute: views from the academy and the trenches.
lead_paragraph: Digging last summer through a 2,600-year-old layer of cinders in Ashkelon, Israel, hammered home to me the arguments that Benjamin R. Barber musters in his latest book. “If Mayors Ruled the World: Dysfunctional Nations, Rising Cities” is not about the distant past. But the connections among ancient Mediterranean seaports like Ashkelon, or later among Hanseatic League members in Northern Europe, resonate in his thesis that modern cities are best poised to meet the challenges posed by the global economy.

headline: Remembering Egerton, Who Knew the Power of the Southern Table
abstract: John Egerton, the Nashville writer, understood the region’s history and food.
lead_paragraph: John Egerton, the Nashville writer who authored a definitive book on Southern food and history, used to tell a tale on me: He said that when I first visited his office back in 1996, he caught me casing the joint. The way he told it, he returned from the bathroom to find me running my fingers down the spines of his books, riffling through his files, making his ideas my own.

headline: Image of the Day: November 22
abstract: Children, on a roadside in New Delhi, having an early morning meal.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Mike Tyson, whose memoir “Undisputed Truth” is at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list, once mused in an interview with Larry King: “Love is like a game, love is competition.”
lead_paragraph: The Boxer: In recent years, the former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson has shown up in the Book Review mostly as a metaphor rather than a subject in his own right. We’ve had references to a Mike Tyson of capitalism (Friedrich von Hayek), a “kind of intellectual Mike Tyson” (angry feminists) and a couple of Mike Tysons of women’s tennis (the Williams sisters) — even, impressively but mysteriously, “the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers.”

headline: Off the Charts: Stars of 2000 Burned Out
abstract: The Standard & Poor’s index of 500 stocks traded above 1,800 this week for the first time ever. But after adjusting for inflation, the index still remains well below where it was in 2000.
lead_paragraph: The Standard & Poor’s index of 500 stocks traded above 1,800 this week for the first time ever. But after adjusting for inflation, the index still remains well below where it was in 2000.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Provisions Scissors
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: everyday shears that look nice on display.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: A Record Market Is Not All That It Seems
abstract: It is hard to compare today’s stock market with the one in 2000, as measured by the S.&.P 500, and not just because of inflation.
lead_paragraph: THE stock market flirted with historical highs this week, with the Dow Jones industrial average trading over 16,000 and the Standard & Poor’s 500 exceeding 1,800 for a time.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,’ ‘Philomena’ and ‘Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?’
abstract: Times critics on “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?” and “Philomena.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the latest “Hunger Games” film, the drama “Philomena” and the documentary “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: A Reason to Root for Dubai on the Hudson
abstract: The trouble isn’t that Manhattan is changing. The trouble lies in what exactly it’s starting to become.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that if you lived in Greenwich Village, one thing you could count on was that a black reflective-glass office tower was not going to be built next door. Well, after half a lifetime of wanting to live in Greenwich Village, I now do, and a black reflective-glass office tower has, in fact, been built next door. It’s part of a cluster of shiny futuristic-looking things that surround the old Cooper Union building like enemy spaceships. Emerging from the closest subway stop, at Astor Place, you can be forgiven for wondering how you ended up in downtown Houston.

headline: U.N. Talks on Climate Near End
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'International Relations']
abstract: Poorer nations called for the creation of a system that would compensate them for climate-related damages, but wealthy countries offered a weaker alternative.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The United Nations climate conference ambled toward a conclusion on Friday, with delegates saying that the meeting would produce no more than a modest set of measures toward a new international agreement two years from now. As usual, the biggest dispute was over money.

headline: Brazil Raises $9.1 Billion in Privatizing 2 Airports
abstract: Brazil’s government privatized two major airports, raising a total of 20.8 billion reais ($9.1 billion) on Friday, as the country makes infrastructure upgrades ahead of next year’s World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:31 p.m. |

headline: Dealer Fees for Arranging Car Loans Are Drawing Scrutiny From U.S.
abstract: Consumer advocates and regulators are concerned that the ability of dealers to decide how much to charge for arranging a loan has led to discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:13 p.m. | When Pedro Lantigua, a 32-year-old truck driver from Oklahoma City, decided to trade in his vehicle last summer, he walked into his local dealership and drove off with a brand-new Chevrolet Silverado. Like millions of Americans, he agreed to a loan arranged by the dealer.

headline: Who Said Girls Can’t Jump?
abstract: First there was the struggle to make women’s ski jumping an Olympic sport. Now the American team just wants to win.
lead_paragraph: First there was the struggle to make women’s ski jumping an Olympic sport. Now the American team just wants to win.

headline: Is It O.K. to Force-Feed Prisoners?
abstract: Starvation rights.
lead_paragraph: I believe medical professionals should act ethically. However, I’m not sure it’s unethical to force-feed prisoners on hunger strike. Setting aside the issues associated with incarceration (and Guantánamo Bay in particular), is it ethical to allow a prisoner to die of starvation, even if that is his/her choice? Or is it more ethical to force-feed them? Most suicides are, at least in part, caused by depression or other mental-health issues. I also realize that prisoners choosing starvation may be making a political statement, and it might be unethical to squelch their political speech. What do you think? SHELLEY MARKS, LOS ANGELES

headline: Desperately Seeking Christy
abstract: What happened when I “secreted” a ’90s supermodel.
lead_paragraph: It was 2007, and like anyone else with a yoga mat and a DVR set to record “Oprah,” my sister, Donna, and I were reading “The Secret,” the best-selling self-help book by Rhonda Byrne that espoused the cosmic “law of attraction.” Filled with the usual platitudes of the genre, it also held out this tantalizing promise: Whatever you desired — a better relationship, a fatter paycheck — you could draw into your life with the magnet of your mind. You just had to concentrate on what you wanted as if it were already on its way.

headline: The 11.10.2013 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE COACH WHO EXPLODED

headline: Who Made That 3-D Printer?
abstract: Printed objects in the palm of your hand.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, an engineer named Chuck Hull approached his boss with an idea: to build a machine that printed out objects you could hold in your hand. His manager discouraged him — after all, the company produced UV lamps, not “Star Trek” replicators. But eventually the two men reached a compromise: Hull would dedicate himself to the company’s lamps by day; at night he’d cobble together his dream machine.

headline: In Love With a Selfie
abstract: A nice neighborhood in prison; Robert Irvine, too dumb for the navy.
lead_paragraph: A nice neighborhood in prison; Robert Irvine, too dumb for the navy.

headline: Motörhead’s Lemmy Kilmister: ‘I’m Paying for the Good Times’
abstract: The 67-year-old rocker on heavy metal, harmony and health.
lead_paragraph: I know you are having some health issues, and you just canceled Motörhead’s European tour. How are you feeling?  I just feel really down. I’ll never get a job again. I’m paying for the good times, I suppose. It’s a mixture of all the things I ever did — and I did plenty.

abstract: This week, Ari Shavit talks about “My Promised Land”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Ann Patchett discusses “This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: How Could One Thoughtless Driver Take This Child?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Parenting', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: On Saturday, Nov. 2, a driver in a hurry in Brooklyn killed my son’s friend, and I am angry.
lead_paragraph: Early in the afternoon on Saturday, Nov. 2, Anthony Byrd, 59, narrowly missed two pedestrians walking along a tree-lined Brooklyn street, crashed into a parked car, jumped the curb and hit another vehicle. He turned, police said, sped the wrong way down a one-way street and mounted the curb again, this time pinning 9-year-old Lucian Merryweather under his 5,000-pound S.U.V. Lucian was killed instantly.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel
abstract: This week, Ari Shavit and Ann Patchett.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ari Shavit and Ann Patchett.

headline: The Gun Report: November 22, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago today, President John F. Kennedy was shot to death in Dallas, Tex. Though conspiracy theories abound, the Warren Commission found that Lee Harvey Oswald owned the rifle that was used to fire the shots from the sixth floor window of the Texas School Book Depository building. And Oswald procured that rifle through a mail-order ad in the February 1963 issue of the N.R.A.’s American Rifleman magazine.

headline: In Search of Woody Guthrie’s America
abstract: From Coney Island to the Pacific Northwest, Los Angeles to Oklahoma, visiting a collection of places that formed notable chapters in the folk singer’s life.
lead_paragraph: The Pacific Northwest is one of my favorite spots in this world, and I’m one walker that’s stood way up and looked way down acrost aplenty of pretty sights in all their veiled and nakedest seasons. The Pacific Northwest has got mineral mountains. It’s got chemical deserts. It’s got rough run canyons. It’s got sawblade snowcaps. It’s got ridges of nine kinds of brown, hills out of six colors of green, ridges five shades of shadows, and stickers the eight tones of hell.

headline: Seeking Authenticity in Italy’s Tiny Neighbor
abstract: San Marino, a 24-square-mile country surrounded by Italy, may appear puzzling at times, but there are rewards to be found in trying to figure it out.
lead_paragraph: The jagged peaks of the Apennines? Vertiginous. The shimmering Adriatic? Azure to turquoise. The hearty cuisine of Emilia-Romagna? As delicious as ever. It all might sound like an ideal Italian vacation. But if you’re enjoying the gorgeous scenery and a great sangiovese in the tiny Republic of San Marino, please don’t start talking about how much you love traveling in Italy.

lead_paragraph: I was 7 years old when John F. Kennedy was assassinated 50 years ago today — in 3rd grade at P.S. 183 in New York City, newly arrived in the United States after an early childhood spent overseas.

abstract: A choreographer of Indian dance and the directors of two visual arts institutions have been appointed to the National Council on the Arts.
lead_paragraph: Three new members – a choreographer of Indian dance, and the directors of two visual arts institutions – have been appointed to the National Council on the Arts, a panel that advises the National Endowment for the Arts on grant requests and policy guidelines, and recommends nominees for the National Medal of Arts. The appointments were made by President Obama, and have been confirmed by the Senate.

headline: Big Investment Banks Still Need to Cut
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Given banks’ double-digit cost of capital, the bulge bracket is still frittering away shareholders’ money, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Big has been bad for shareholders in investment banks. That’s according to a report published by the consulting firm McKinsey this week. The 13 largest investment banks made an average return on equity of just 8 percent last year — below the 10 percent achieved by the next 200. Given banks’ double-digit cost of capital, the bulge bracket is still frittering away shareholders’ money. More cuts are needed.

headline: Individuals Find Ideas in the Institutional Investment World
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Endowments', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Some wealthy investors are exploring investment policy statements, which are used by foundations to create parameters for how securities are bought and sold.
lead_paragraph: MAYBE the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index crossing 1,800 this week is a sign of a stock market bubble, or maybe the companies that compose it will continue to grow. There are arguments for both, but the correct answer will be clear only at some point in the future.

headline: An Ex-Mouseketeer’s Journey Back to Christianity From Paganism
abstract: The pop singer-songwriter Teo Bishop, also known as Matt Morris, shocked Pagans last month by re-embracing Christianity.
lead_paragraph: They’re an august alumni association, the Mouseketeers of “The All New Mickey Mouse Club,” which ran from 1989 to 1996 on the Disney Channel. Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake top the charts. Keri Russell was Felicity. Christina Aguilera stars with CeeLo Green on “The Voice.” Ryan Gosling starred with his own abs in “Crazy Stupid Love.”

headline: Closing Time in Willets Point
abstract: The city could use eminent domain to clear out Willets Point in Queens, which supports hundreds of businesses, to clean up the area.
lead_paragraph: The city could use eminent domain to clear out Willets Point in Queens, which supports hundreds of businesses, to clean up the area.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in New Orleans; Philadelphia; Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Réveillon Dinners, New Orleans Dozens of restaurants in New Orleans plan to celebrate the region’s culinary past with the annual Creole holiday tradition of Réveillon (French for “awakening”), a ritual said to date to the 1800s, when a lavish meal was served to break the fast after midnight Mass on Christmas Eve. Nearly 50 of the city’s restaurants, including Restaurant R’evolution, above, will serve Réveillon prix fixe dinners the entire month of December, featuring food similar to what the Creole families who began the custom enjoyed.

headline: Mets Start Spending, Sort Of
abstract: The Mets reached for some potential by signing outfielder Chris Young, but it might signal they are out of the running for bigger-ticket free agents.
lead_paragraph: The Mets have signed a free-agent outfielder, but it is not Jacoby Ellsbury or Nelson Cruz or Curtis Granderson or Shin-Soo Choo, or even Carlos Beltran. Instead, they have agreed to a one-year, $7.25 million deal with 30-year-old Chris Young, who was once considered a potential star with the Arizona Diamondbacks but hit just .200 last season with the Oakland Athletics.

headline: Big Ticket | Luxury Lodging for $17.3 Million
abstract: A 4,207-square-foot four-bedroom apartment commands the entire eighth floor at 18 Gramercy Park South.
lead_paragraph: With just a few full-floor units and the distinctive maisonette remaining at the luxury condominium reinvention of a historic Salvation Army lodging house for women at 18 Gramercy Park South, the sale for $17,300,067.50 of the 4,207-square-foot residence that commands the entire eighth floor was the most expensive of the week, according to city records.

headline: Greece Says It Is on Track to Repay Bailout
abstract: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras, meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, is seeking to ease the terms for securing more rescue funds.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece, meeting on Friday with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, said that his country was poised to return to economic stability and was “on track” to repay its international creditors.

headline: Condos That Fund a Brooklyn Park
abstract: The first entirely new residential development designed to help finance Brooklyn Bridge Park’s operations and maintenance is scheduled to be complete by late 2015.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Bridge Park has transformed a once-neglected slice of the Brooklyn waterfront into bustling parkland, and now, to continue the public-private venture that created the park, pilings are being driven for the first entirely new residential development designed to help finance its operations and maintenance.

headline: Getting to the Bottom of a Digital Lollipop
abstract: A team of researchers at the National University of Singapore are trying to build a digital lollipop that can simulate taste.
lead_paragraph: How many licks does it take to get to the bottom of a digital lollipop? That’s the question you could soon be asking yourself thanks to a team of researchers at the National University of Singapore who are trying to build a digital lollipop that can simulate taste.

abstract: The investment is the latest by Fireman Capital, a five-year-old firm that has scored several big hits in recent years.
