headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2 P.M. (Showtime) STAGE BEAUTY (2004) In this high-end costume drama about theater in 17th-century England, directed by Richard Eyre and based on a play by Jeffrey Hatcher, Billy Crudup, above, portrays Ned Kynaston, among the last of the old-school female impersonators and a specialist in doomed Shakespearean heroines. Claire Danes is Maria Hughes, who starts out as his stage-struck dresser and later becomes his rival as women are allowed to appear onstage. Rupert Everett hams it up as King Charles II; and Tom Wilkinson is Othello to Ned’s Desdemona. “For about two-thirds of its length ‘Stage Beauty’ is propelled by a complex and fascinating set of ideas about sexual identity and theatrical performance,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But as it rushes toward an upbeat ending, the movie at once recoils from this notion and bizarrely succumbs to its logic. In disowning drag and in straightening out Ned Kynaston, ‘Stage Beauty’ — absurdly for a work that professes to revel in the love of theater — takes a literal-minded stand for the straight and narrow in both sex and art.”

headline: Dazzling Juliets Light the Stage of Royal Ballet
abstract: Natalia Osipova and Evgenia Obraztsova bring their light to Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet” with the Royal Ballet.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Natalia Osipova, well known in New York from many prestigious appearances with American Ballet Theater, gave a superlative first performance on Thursday as a new member of the Royal Ballet, dancing the heroine of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet.” For at least five years, Ms. Osipova has proved the most sensational ballerina dancing today; while other ballerinas equal or surpass her in style, beauty and artistry, none cause such excitement.

headline: After Hours | Wild West Zombies Walk Into a Burlesque Show
abstract: The artist Marian Vitale’s riotous Performa commission, which runs for two more nights in Long Island City, Queens, is a chic meditation on the disappearance of the American frontier.
lead_paragraph: For several years, the artist Marianne Vitale has been making rugged sculptures from repurposed materials that walk a line between critique and chic. On one hand, her bridges, structures, train-track crossings and headstones serve as a mournful meditation on the disappearance of the old frontier America; on the other, they resemble the kinds of old-timey, artisanal home furnishings sold in hipster meccas like Brooklyn and Silver Lake.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The State of Israel
abstract: Ari Shavit discusses his new book, “My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Leon Wieseltier reviews Ari Shavit’s “My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel.” Mr. Wieseltier writes:

headline: Timeline Provides Details for a Grisly Crime Against a Teacher
abstract: Court papers released Friday offer a few clues about the life of a 14-year-old suspect in the killing of a teacher in Danvers, Mass.
lead_paragraph: DANVERS, Mass. — On the morning of Oct. 22, Philip Chism, a 14-year-old student and soccer player, took a ski mask, gloves, multiple changes of clothes and a box-cutter with him to school, according to the police.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Anomalous Harmony, Present and Past
abstract: Billie Joe Armstrong and Norah Jones, an unexpected duo, have combined for “Foreverly,” a rerecording of an unusual album by the Everly Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Darkness delivered sweetly: That’s what drew together the improbable partnership of gentle-voiced Norah Jones and pop-punk arena rocker Billie Joe Armstrong, who leads Green Day. They decided to remake, of all things, an entire album from 1958: the Everly Brothers’ “Songs Our Daddy Taught Us” (Cadence).

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: The Day the World Stopped Turning
abstract: “As the World Turns,” which was interrupted the day John F. Kennedy was assassinated, has become the memory uniting its viewers.
lead_paragraph: As usual, on that Friday afternoon, Mable Snodgrass, a 19-year-old first-time mother, was at home in Echols, Ky., watching “As the World Turns.” Ten minutes in, at about 12:40 p.m., the soapy drama was bubbling. Nancy Hughes, played by Helen Wagner, had just told Grandpa (Santos Ortega) that her son, Bob, had invited his ex-wife, the scheming Lisa, and their young son, Tom, to Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Shedding Their Skins
abstract: New albums and mixtapes from Laurel Halo, Young Dolph, Ian Isiah, Upset and the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Laurel Halo

headline: A Spur in the Filibuster Fight: A Court’s Workload and Politics
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In blocking three nominees to an appeals court, Republicans said the court had an insufficient workload, though experts said the real issue was the ideological balance of the court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The overhaul of the Senate’s filibuster rules was prompted, surprisingly, by an argument about judicial productivity.

headline: Colleagues Remember Journalist Missing for One Year in Syria
abstract: At least 30 journalists are now missing in Syria and believed to have been kidnapped. Fifty-two journalists have been killed since the start of the Syrian conflict in March 2011, and 24 more have been kidnapped but released.
lead_paragraph: A year has gone by since James Foley, an American freelance journalist working for GlobalPost, was kidnapped near the town of Taftanaz in chaotic and war-torn northern Syria as he drove toward the Turkish border at the end of a reporting trip. It happened during Thanksgiving festivities in the United States, and he has not been heard from since.

headline: Cornell Star Finds Inspiration in His Sister’s Courage
abstract: Jeff Mathews’s inner strength has a role model — sibling Katie, who suffered severe injuries in a 2006 car accident and is a quadriplegic.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Mathews has set 44 Cornell and 17 conference records, more than any other quarterback in Ivy League history. Entering this season, he was projected by some analysts as a mid- to late-round N.F.L. draft pick, and professional scouts have been attending his games since his sophomore year, a rarity for a player in the league.

headline: Families: A Slide Show
abstract: Every year, American families are becoming more diverse and their makeup more complex. The Times asked readers to share a favorite photograph and tell us what makes their family special. Here is a selection of the responses.
lead_paragraph: Every year, American families are becoming more diverse and their makeup more complex. The Times asked readers to share a favorite photograph and tell us what makes their family special. Here is a selection of the responses.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Toll Confirms Storm Is One of Philippines’ Deadliest
abstract: A jump in the number of dead Friday, to more than 5,200, showed that Typhoon Haiyan had reached the levels of Tropical Storm Thelma in 1991.
lead_paragraph: CEBU, Philippines — The official death toll for Typhoon Haiyan has exceeded 5,200, confirming that the devastating storm was one of the Philippines’s deadliest ever recorded.

headline: A Rare Convergence of Thanksgiving and Hanukkah
abstract: Next Thursday, on the second night of Hanukkah, Jews across the United States will be lighting menorahs after their Thanksgiving feasts, playing the dreidel game between forkfuls of pumpkin pie and exchanging gifts after the football game is over.
lead_paragraph: View our searchable database of over 600 vegetarian Thanksgiving recipes.

headline: Cellphone Calls on Planes? Flight Attendants Say No
abstract: The Association of Flight Attendants-CWA is opposed to a proposal from the Federal Communicatiions Commission that would allow cellphone calls on flights.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission received immediate pushback on a proposal  on Thursday for cellphone use during flights from the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA.

headline: Spotify Raises $250 Million, Valuing It at $4 Billion
abstract: The investment was made by Technology Crossover Ventures. Also, the streaming music service Pandora reported an increase in revenue for the quarter.
lead_paragraph: Spotify, the subscription music service, has completed a $250 million financing round that values the company at more than $4 billion, according to a person with knowledge of the deal.

headline: A Closer Look at China’s ‘You First’ Stance in Climate Treaty Talks
keywords: ['Coal', 'Natural Gas', 'Nuclear Energy', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: A top climate strategist for the Chinese government explains the country’s stance on global warming.
lead_paragraph: While I was in Beijng last month to talk about online communication and climate change at a conference organized by Yale and Renmin University, I visited with Zou Ji, the deputy director of China’s National Center for Climate Change Strategy.

headline: Judges Decline to Reverse Stop-and-Frisk Ruling, All but Ending Mayor’s Fight
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The move all but ends the Bloomberg administration’s ability to legally contest a judge’s order against the policing practice.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel on Friday denied a request by lawyers for New York that it overturn a judge’s sweeping ruling on the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices, all but ending the Bloomberg administration’s ability to legally challenge the ruling.

headline: A Lena Dunham Locale
abstract: The TriBeCa duplex loft that took a star turn in Ms. Dunham’s feature “Tiny Furniture” is poised to enter the market at $6.25 million.
lead_paragraph: The eclectic TriBeCa duplex loft that took a star turn in Lena Dunham’s career-launching indie feature, “Tiny Furniture” (after its owners, who happened to be her parents, allowed her to film there), is poised to enter the market at $6.25 million. The imaginatively renovated living-and-studio space is in a former textile factory at 16 Desbrosses Street.

abstract: The TriBeCa duplex loft that was featured in a Lena Dunham movie is set to be listed at $6.25 million.
lead_paragraph: The TriBeCa duplex loft that was featured in a Lena Dunham movie is set to be listed at $6.25 million.

abstract: It’s not exactly English.
lead_paragraph: What we have here is a problem of communication.

abstract: Just FYI.
lead_paragraph: And got a great deal.

headline: Raffling a Picasso for $135
abstract: Picasso’s grandson is raffling a work for only $135.
lead_paragraph: A bit of almost century-old Picasso will be coming to New York next month, and someone could end up owning it for only $135.

headline: Today In My U.S. Grant Obsession
abstract: Chattanooga!
lead_paragraph: Just so I don’t forget, an important anniversary this weekend. The Food Network is 20 years old!

abstract: Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario discuss the opening of Rough Trade NYC, a branch of the famed London music shop.
lead_paragraph: This week: the advent of Rough Trade NYC.

headline: Prison for a State Chemist Who Faked Drug Evidence
abstract: The defendant, Annie Dookhan, tainted thousands of cases and threw the Massachusetts legal system into disarray.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — They were called “Dookhan defendants,” and there were thousands of them.

headline: Powerful Rebel Groups in Syria Announce Creation of Umbrella Alliance
abstract: While some rebels and opposition activists hailed the group’s formation as a major step forward, it remained unclear if it reflected a true reorganization of forces.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Seven of Syria’s most powerful rebel groups said that they had forged a new Islamic force seeking to topple the government of President Bashar al-Assad and replace it with an Islamic state.

headline: Shares of Vince Surge in Market Debut
abstract: Shares of Vince, the fashion retailer owned by Sun Capital Partners, jumped more than 40 percent in their debut on the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:18 p.m. |

headline: After Their First Dance, a Lifetime of Music
abstract: Gifts for music-loving newlyweds, from a speaker that fits into a shower head to a puppy-shaped radio designed by an artist.
lead_paragraph: Gifts for music-loving newlyweds, from a speaker that fits into a shower head to a puppy-shaped radio designed by an artist.

headline: New Obstacle to a Nuclear Deal: Taunts From Iran’s Ruler
abstract: As Secretary of State John Kerry noted, what might otherwise have been dismissed as harmless name-calling by Iran’s leader is deeply distressing to some Israelis, since he has previously made “very disturbing assertions regarding the Holocaust.”
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Michael Gordon reports, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that “inflammatory” statements against Israel and the United States this week from Iran’s ruling cleric, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, could make reaching an agreement over the Iranian nuclear program more difficult.

headline: Kerry to Join Iran Nuclear Talks, in Sign of Progress
abstract: Negotiators may be near an accord that would impose a temporary freeze on the country’s nuclear program, but disagreements remain.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Secretary of State John Kerry planned to fly to Geneva on Friday to join the talks on imposing a temporary freeze on Iran’s nuclear program, a sign that the negotiations are edging close to an agreement.

headline: In Store | Handsome Wallets for the Minimalist at Heart
abstract: Streamlined leather goods by Vianel, previously only available online, are in stock at select Barneys New York locations by Monday.
lead_paragraph: In September, Vianel introduced a line of simple, streamlined wallets that were only available on its website (including same-day delivery service in New York City, where the brand is based). By Monday, and just in time for holiday shopping, fans of the handsome but affordable leather goods can stop into one of the 11 Barneys New York locations nationwide that will now carry them. In addition to offering Vianel’s signature cardholders, Barneys will also introduce the company’s newest styles: bifold and zip wallets, a zip pouch and folding card holders. “Our design revolves around the phrase ‘luxury is simplicity,'” says Andrew Brooks, C.E.O. of Vianel. “Why carry more than you need?” Each of the unisex, minimalist designs are branded simply with a tiny gold logo, and trimmed with an extra pop of color — cobalt blue, dove gray, oxblood — on the sides. $195 to $710; select Barneys locations and barneys.com next week.

headline: Kate Baldwin’s Après-Theater Spot
abstract: Kate Baldwin’s other stage is the house she shares with her husband and young son in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Kate Baldwin’s other stage is the house she shares with her husband and young son in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Extra Time to Sign Up for Health Coverage
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: People will have eight more days, until Dec. 23, to sign up for health insurance coverage taking effect on the first day of 2014.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would give people eight more days, until Dec. 23, to sign up for health insurance coverage that takes effect on Jan. 1 under the new health care law.

headline: Her Après-Theater Spot
abstract: Kate Baldwin’s other stage is the house she shares with her husband and young son in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Kate Baldwin moved to a new apartment, a light, airy rental in a Park Slope brownstone, late this summer, precisely one week before rehearsals began for “Big Fish,” the Broadway musical she stars in with Norbert Leo Butz.

headline: Weekend Reading: Banks Worried They Might Be Next
abstract: After JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion mortgage settlement emerged, Jamie Dimon said that “it could’ve been somebody else.” Who is next on the list?
lead_paragraph: After JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion mortgage settlement emerged this week, Jamie Dimon held a conference call with analysts. “It could’ve been somebody else,” the bank’s chief executive said. Who is next on the list?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Nothing Gold Can Stay
abstract: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one another’s highly individual style of dress.
lead_paragraph: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one another’s highly individual style of dress.

headline: Review: 2014 Ford Fiesta
abstract: Some people won’t drive anything less than a luxury car. Others just need the luxury of driving. The refreshed 2014 Ford Fiesta offers budget buyers a slice of the good life. For a price.
lead_paragraph: Some people won’t drive anything less than a luxury car. Others just need the luxury of driving. The refreshed 2014 Ford Fiesta offers budget buyers a slice of the good life. For a price.

headline: Vonn Does Not Rule Out a Return in Two Weeks
abstract: Lindsey Vonn withdrew from next week’s World Cup races in Beaver Creek, Colo., on Friday, but she left open the possibility of racing the next week at Lake Louise resort in Canada.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn on Friday officially withdrew from next week’s World Cup ski races in Beaver Creek, Colo., but in a surprise, she left open the possibility that she would race the next week when the women’s World Cup moves to the Lake Louise resort in Canada.

headline: Love, Blown on Course by a Storm
abstract: A couple return to the city where they met to be married before old friends and colleagues.
lead_paragraph: There was an unacknowledged matchmaker involved in the romance of Marie La France and Ken Jackson: New Orleans.

headline: Embracing, Not Resenting, Their Differences
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Baby Boomers', 'Dating and Courtship']
abstract: Sheema Karp was born in Pakistan, and her husband, Ken, was raised Jewish. They’ve thrived since marrying at age 21, always with an eye toward the future.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: A Short Drive in the 2015 Audi A3 E-tron
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Los Angeles Auto Show']
abstract: As more automakers get into the plug-in hybrid game, each one has a different approach. Audi’s offering works well and looks good.
lead_paragraph: Driving any car in the rush hour traffic that coats Los Angeles roads like a viscous layer of hair gel is a chore. You could have the fastest, fanciest, most cool looking car in the world, and you’d still be sitting in the same motoring morass as someone perched behind the wheel of a dented ’92 Toyota Corolla.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Nothing Gold Can Stay
abstract: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one another’s highly individual style of dress.
lead_paragraph: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one another’s highly individual style of dress, who pause on their way to work to inquire of their clothes. The tradition may vanish, as one member of the group is moving to California. At times, they spontaneously try on one another’s look. Last week, nature provided a backdrop only it could create. In Central Park, a “Brigadoon” mist settled over the lake, and cascades of willows framed the Bow Bridge. All over the city, the ginkgo tree proved once again as the leaves fell that Manhattan streets are indeed paved with gold.

headline: An Upscale Bounty, and a Thankful Shopper
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: With competition in high-end supermarkets heating up, there’s never been a better time to shop for the Thanksgiving meal. But which store offers the best deal?
lead_paragraph: Since opening its first store in Austin, Tex., in 1980, Whole Foods Market has transformed the way Americans shop for food and eat at home — at least those who live in mostly affluent urban areas. When a branch opened in my neighborhood — theretofore a culinary desert — I wandered wide-eyed through what seemed a paradise of offerings tended by an eager and informed staff.

headline: Choosing Child Care When You Go Back to Work
abstract: A primer on what to expect on prices and tax breaks, as well as advice on how to approach the decision.
lead_paragraph: The largest financial commitment that many new parents make is also the most emotional: choosing a full-time caregiver for your child as you head back to work.

headline: Holiday Finds Congress Well Short of Goals
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: The Senate vote to end filibusters for most presidential nominees is just one symptom of the deep level of dysfunction coursing through Congress less than a year before midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The landmark Senate vote this week to end the minority party’s ability to filibuster most presidential nominees is just one symptom of the deep level of dysfunction coursing through the 113th Congress as the year before midterm elections draws to a close.

headline: Warned on Budget, Italy Is Given Leeway by E.U.
abstract: As finance ministers from the European Union met in Brussels, Italy’s prime minister warned that “ayatollahs” in Europe were helping to kill the country’s chances of recovery.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After Italy rebuffed warnings about its budget, euro-area finance ministers late Friday agreed to give the country additional opportunities to show it can make savings and bolster revenue.

headline: Indulging in Miso After the Holiday Feast
abstract: To counteract the effects of traditionally heavy, rich fare, lean toward vegetables and fish. Adding miso boosts the flavor.
lead_paragraph: I don’t fast after the Thanksgiving Day eat-a-thon and the long weekend of continued feasting and indulgence; perhaps I should.

headline: Twitter Toughening Its Security to Thwart Government Snoops
abstract: Fear of government snoops has led Twitter to be the latest company to make the encryption on its communications much harder to crack.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, hardly anyone, save for cryptographers, had heard of Perfect Forward Secrecy. Now, some customers are demanding it, and technology companies are adding it, one by one, in large part to make government eavesdropping more difficult.

headline: The End of Willets Point
keywords: ['Eminent Domain', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Relocation of Business', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The city is about to begin clearing an area in Queens it calls blighted, but in the tangle of junkyards and auto shops, many people have made a life.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to drive past Willets Point, the 62-acre tangle of auto shops, car parts and grease-covered mechanics tinkering with automobiles, that sits hard by the Unisphere of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Passing by is far easier than driving through: The streets that cross each other at odd angles here in the glossy shadow of Citi Field look as if they had been blasted by land mines. They are pooled with dark, oil-slicked water or rutted with knee-deep holes that suck in a car’s tires. The chalkboard scrape of chassis meeting pavement sounds through the air here with the regularity of a bell tolling the hour.

headline: Heart in Mouth, for a Taxing Rarity
abstract: Alan Gilbert led the New York Philharmonic in a challenging Britten program on Thursday, with replacements related to a tenor’s illness creating some suspense.
lead_paragraph: Before beginning a Britten program on Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic, the conductor Alan Gilbert welcomed the audience at Avery Fisher Hall to what he called the orchestra’s “small part in the worldwide celebrations” of the towering British composer in the year of his centennial. The concert took place the day before what would have been the actual anniversary of his birth. Britten died in 1976.

headline: A Dallas Concert Honors a Loss That’s 50 Years Old
abstract: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra remembers the assassination of President John F. Kennedy with a premiere, “The World Is Very Different Now,” among a concert of other elegiac works.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — As many have been reminded or have learned anew in recent days, the visual imagery surrounding the life and legacy of John F. Kennedy, who is often called the first television president, is mightily potent. Whether at work, at play or at rest, whether facing crisis or tragedy, whether flirting or consoling, the man exuded charisma and magnetism, enough so to spawn the myth of a Camelot on Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Remembering President Kennedy in Dallas
abstract: Dallas gathers to mourn on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: Dallas gathers to mourn on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Bach and His Italian Kin
abstract: Concerto Köln played two “Brandenburg” Concertos and some Italian works at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many of the great composers of his time, Bach stayed put. In his 65 years, he never left a relatively small corner of Germany, even as Handel, his countryman, traveled to Italy and England and Vivaldi, born in Venice, died in Vienna.

headline: A Here-Comes-Trouble Homecoming
abstract: In “The Preacher and the Shrink,” at the Beckett Theater, a young woman moves back home and soon accuses a young minister in her father’s church of molesting her.
lead_paragraph: Back in her Pennsylvania hometown, with her latest letters of rejection in hand — from a publishing house, from her husband seeking divorce — Connie (Adria Vitlar), an English professor and poet, is a mess. As she tells Alexandra (Dee Hoty), the psychiatrist she is seeing, “It was a mistake coming back here without knowing why I was coming.”

headline: Leftovers for Breakfast
abstract: Wylie Dufresne makes turkey hash by foraging through the remnants of Thanksgiving dinner for things that go well with eggs.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always had fond memories of cooking Thanksgiving.

headline: Principal Auctioneer of Sotheby’s Is Leaving Post
abstract: Tobias Meyer has been the public face of Sotheby’s for nearly 20 years both as its principal auctioneer and worldwide head of its contemporary art department.
lead_paragraph: Tobias Meyer, the chief auctioneer for Sotheby’s, has been the public face and a deal-making catalyst for one of the world’s most powerful auction houses.

headline: Caring for the Aging, but Ignoring the Rules
abstract: The new HBO comedy “Getting On,” starring Laurie Metcalf, aims to depict a true, if irreverent, look at elder care in a California hospital.
lead_paragraph: The rules for depicting the frail elderly on television are fairly clear: it must be done with a gauzy somberness. Dementia and nursing homes and such are something to be whispered about and handled with kid gloves rather than considered a fact of life.

headline: An Early Start for Cyber Deals
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Some hotels and resorts are offering deals to travelers before Cyber Monday on Dec. 2.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:33 p.m. | It seems Cyber Monday can’t come soon enough for some hotels and resorts this year. Many are getting into the holiday spirit early, offering discounted rooms, spa vouchers and lots and lots of free drinks to travelers before they’ve even had a chance to cook their turkey.

headline: Bhutan Goes Electric
abstract: The tiny mountainous country that popularized the concept of gross national happiness is planning to replace conventional cars with electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Bhutan, the tiny mountainous country that popularized the concept of gross national happiness, is planning to replace conventional cars with electric vehicles in what could be an interesting, albeit not easily repeatable, experiment for the rest of the world to watch.

headline: Actors on Actors Who Act Shakespeare
abstract: In excerpts from interviews and published memoirs, noted Shakespearean actors talk about some of their own favorite performers.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare fans have no qualms about debating which Hamlet or Lady Macbeth was better than the rest. Last week Charles Isherwood asked: What makes a master Shakespearean actor? This week readers weighed in with their picks for the best Shakespearean performance they’d ever seen or heard.

headline: Pumpkins Beyond Halloween
abstract: André Soltner makes a soup the way his mother would, getting creative with the serving piece.
lead_paragraph: There was a little farm near where we lived, in Alsace, France, in a small town by the name of Thann, where we got our pumpkins. My mother would make soup just this same way; she served it in the pumpkin, too. We kids looked forward to it every year.

headline: Questions on Drone Strike Find Only Silence
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Faisal bin Ali Jaber, who lost two relatives in a drone strike, struggled to pierce a veil of secrecy and anonymity during a visit to Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing on the marble floor just outside the House chamber, Faisal bin Ali Jaber looked lost in the human river of hard-charging lobbyists, members of Congress and staffers. It is not every day that a victim of American drone strikes travels 7,000 miles to Washington to look for answers.

headline: The Art of Burning Rubber vs. Steady Wins the Race
abstract: Two standup specials, by Bill Cosby on Comedy Central and Sarah Silverman on HBO, offer a study in contrasts and food for thought on comedians’ career arcs.
lead_paragraph: Television viewers who enjoy a study in contrasts will be served a doozy on Saturday night: stand-up comedy specials by Bill Cosby on Comedy Central and Sarah Silverman on HBO.

headline: Breslin and Son of Kennedy Gravedigger Recall the Famous Job
abstract: Clifton Pollard, the man who dug a grave for President Kennedy, became part of history through Jimmy Breslin’s now-famous column.
lead_paragraph: “Clifton Pollard was pretty sure he was going to be working on Sunday,” is the way that Jimmy Breslin’s famous gravedigger column begins, kicking off a poignant account of Mr. Pollard digging President Kennedy’s grave at Arlington National Cemetery shortly after the assassination in 1963.

headline: Audit Board Finds Flaws in Reviews by Deloitte
abstract: A regulator said that Deloitte & Touche, for the second consecutive year, had failed to correct deficiencies in its audit procedures to its satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: The regulator of accounting firms in the United States said on Friday that Deloitte & Touche, for the second consecutive year, had failed to correct deficiencies in its audit procedures to its satisfaction.

headline: Corporate Incubators Popping Up in Europe
abstract: The programs from big corporations, which offer start-ups with office space, contacts with prospective clients and often early-stage investment, can have advantages for both sides.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – In an Art Deco office block on a side street in central London, groups of 20-something programmers and engineers sat hunched over laptops in teams of three or four people.

headline: Bringing Life to Museums’ Collections
abstract: Museums around the world are celebrating the automobile. New venues have opened dedicated to autos, others have been renovated, and fine art institutions have even discovered the popular appeal of the car.
lead_paragraph: Amid all the reports of a groundswell of disdain for car culture among young people, it may seem that the automobile is entering its twilight.

headline: Car Museums Get a Makeover
abstract: Instead of being relegated to dark corners as curious relics, automobiles are now receiving the kind of display and attention once reserved for fine art.
lead_paragraph: Instead of being relegated to dark corners as curious relics, automobiles are now receiving the kind of display and attention once reserved for fine art.

headline: A Deal Defended by Cathy Chen
abstract: An instructive deal defended by Cathy Chen of East Meadow, N.Y., who is a tai chi instructor on ships.
lead_paragraph: Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., teaches on several bridge cruises each year. So he has a good eye for an instructive deal. The one in the diagram is based on a deal defended by Cathy Chen of East Meadow, N.Y., who is a tai chi instructor on ships.

headline: Chowder With an American Accent
abstract: A hearty fish chowder to evoke the warmth and comfort of family and friends.
lead_paragraph: Fish chowder is the type of dish you may find in England at a country pub or in a fishing village. But the addition of Quahog clams and intensely flavorful Long Island sweet corn makes this particular chowder unmistakably American, and, with its hearty vegetables, bacon, potatoes and cream, a great dish for the Thanksgiving table. It also reminds me of what I give thanks for every year: the warmth and comfort of family and friends, who gather around the pot with their bowls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Virginia, the Philippines, China and Bahrain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Virginia, the Philippines, China and Bahrain.

headline: Brisket Barley Soup
abstract: If there was no room for Hanukkah on the Thanksgiving table, you can get a taste of brisket in this hearty winter soup.
lead_paragraph: If there was no room for Hanukkah on the Thanksgiving table, you can get a taste of brisket in this hearty winter soup.

headline: Brisket Is Coming to Dinner, in a Soup
abstract: Since Hanukkah and Thanksgiving come on the same day, the turkey wins. Later in the week, the brisket ends up in the soup.
lead_paragraph: When Hanukkah and Thanksgiving merge at our family table this year, we will keep the turkey and lose the brisket — at least for that one night.

headline: Loved by a King, but Doomed by a Hermit
abstract: Teatro Grattacielo presented the opera “Sakùntala” on Tuesday at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center for the Performing Arts.
lead_paragraph: When Puccini died in 1924, he left only sketches for the finale of his opera “Turandot.” A parade of prominent Italian composers were proposed and rejected before Franco Alfano was finally picked to complete it.

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Sandra Bullock’s Fashion Choices
abstract: Ms. Bullock, 49, has managed to clamber out of the conventional rom-com rut with gutsy roles that display a surprising versatility.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Bullock, 49, has managed to clamber out of the conventional rom-com rut with gutsy roles that display a surprising versatility.

headline: Pastrami on Thanksgiving Turns Heads
abstract: It easily feeds a large crowd and, since it isn’t your typical Thanksgiving centerpiece, it will be a conversation starter.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving pastrami: I know it’s not traditional, but it is impressive, delicious and bountiful. Hear me out on this one.

headline: At Super Bowl, New York and New Jersey Will Be Top Rivals
abstract: The Super Bowl in February will be held in New Jersey, at MetLife Stadium, but New York City will be the center of attention.
lead_paragraph: For $9,199, a football fan can buy a sideline-seat-and-hotel-room package to the Super Bowl next year. The seat will be in New Jersey, where the game will be played. But the hotel room will be in New York, where “Super Bowl Boulevard” will stretch from Herald Square through Times Square with a temporary theme park and a 180-foot-tall toboggan slide.

headline: TimesOpen Hack Day 2013
abstract: Read about our fourth annual Hack Day.
lead_paragraph: Our fourth annual Hack Day drew more than 80 participants who created about 30 projects, many of which used APIs supported by representatives from Bitly, DocumentCloud, Mashery, NYPL Labs, Sunlight Foundation, Twilio and our very own NYT Developers. Together they taught, hacked and answered questions. By demo time, 23 projects were ready to show.

headline: Chat With Eric Asimov About Holiday Drinks
abstract: The chief wine critic for The Times answered questions in a Twitter chat on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Eric Asimov, wine critic for The Times, answered some of your questions in a Twitter chat on Monday, Nov. 25, at 1 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: An Arty Home for Jazzy Sets
abstract: “Nation Time,” a jazz show presented in concert with the Christopher Wool retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum, featured Arto Lindsay, Richard Hell, Joe McPhee and the Scandinavian group the Thing.
lead_paragraph: Music, as subject or spirit, doesn’t leap out of Christopher Wool’s wordy, designy, process-oriented paintings and silk-screen works. But sometimes it lives as a reference in the text and titles. One black-and-white stencil painting in his retrospective exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum says “You Make Me,” which is the incomplete outburst written in felt-tip pen on Richard Hell’s chest on the cover of the album “Blank Generation.”

headline: Mavis Batey, Allied Code Breaker in World War II, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'German Language', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Mrs. Batey volunteered to be an army nurse after Britain declared war on Germany in 1939, but was instead assigned to the top-secret Allied effort to decipher codes.
lead_paragraph: After Britain declared war on Germany in September 1939, Mavis Lever, an 18-year-old British university student, volunteered to be an army nurse. Instead, because of her expertise in the German language, she was referred to the intelligence services.

headline: Every Picture Tells Anjelica Huston’s Story
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Books and Literature', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Movies']
abstract: Anjelica Huston offers insight into her life and her recently released memoir, “A Story Lately Told.”
lead_paragraph: In a sea of Santa Monica whites and tans, it was hard not to stare at the formidably chic woman with the dancer’s posture dressed in head-to-toe black.

headline: Treats Magazine Throws a Party
abstract: Mr. Shaw threw the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Shaw threw the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday.

headline: The Last Days of Willets Point
abstract: Newer developments will soon replace the stream of auto repair shops that have long lined and defined Willets Point. Those who work there see the city-planned upgrade as a threat to their livelihood.
lead_paragraph: Newer developments will soon replace the stream of auto repair shops that have long lined and defined Willets Point. Those who work there see the city-planned upgrade as a threat to their livelihood.

headline: Tale as Old as Time, With Video Projections
abstract: “La Belle et la Bête,” a retelling of the fairy tale at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, features video projections and dialogue to furrow your brow.
lead_paragraph: The divided self assumes ravishing forms in “La Belle et la Bête,” a show out of Montreal that is as lovely to look at as it is hard to listen to. Individuals split and multiply as if by enchanted atomic fission in Lemieux Pilon 4D Art’s modern retelling of that eternal favorite of blind date recaps, “The Beauty and the Beast,” which runs through Saturday at the Howard Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Strong Rules on Fracking in Wyoming Seen as Model
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Water Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: The state, a big energy producer, has enacted strong disclosure laws on hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, to protect air and water quality.
lead_paragraph: In energy-friendly Wyoming, oil and gas companies are getting a clear message: Drill, baby, drill — but carefully.

headline: The Future Is Here. Are Customers?
abstract: The two major auto shows that have just opened, in Los Angeles and in Tokyo, are awash in dozens of technologically advanced vehicles that have moved beyond design studies and are ready for purchase.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As another auto show season opened Wednesday with nearly simultaneous press previews at big salons in Los Angeles and Tokyo, followed closely by an exhibition in Guangzhou, China, the message from automakers to potential customers seems to be: The future is here.

headline: 2013 Los Angeles Auto Show
abstract: Highlights from the press previews in Los Angeles, which helped kick off another season of auto shows.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the press previews in Los Angeles, which helped kick off another season of auto shows.

headline: An Orb of Trash Floats Down the Gowanus
abstract: Harvest Dome 2.0 is a floating orb made out of 450 cast-off umbrella frames, suspended over a ring of soda bottles.
lead_paragraph: The spindly skeletons of discarded umbrellas are a common sight after rainy days. But the collection that drifted down the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn on Friday was something else. The brainchild of the husband-and-wife firm SLO Architecture, Harvest Dome 2.0 is a floating orb made out of 450 cast-off umbrella frames, suspended over a ring of soda bottles.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Morris’s company performed his masterwork, “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Heralding the Holidays With an Apple Crostata
abstract: This flaky dessert doesn’t require a dish or pie pan.
lead_paragraph: When I saw my mother making her apple turnover, I knew company was coming. I also knew the dough scraps would be my treat. She’d roll them in sugar and cinnamon and bake them, and we’d enjoy the light, buttery morsels together with a cold glass of milk.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 22 at 6 p.m.
abstract: Magnus Carlsen is crowned the new chess champion; Clive Staples Lewis is honored today; and the oldest wine cellar.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Carlsen is crowned the new chess champion; Clive Staples Lewis is honored today; and the oldest wine cellar.

headline: Kaleidoscope of Introspection, Joy and Pastoral Tranquility
abstract: The Mark Morris Dance Group performed his masterwork “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” choreographed 25 years ago, on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, Mark Morris was given the break most choreographers only dream of: a three-year residency at the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels, where money and resources flowed like water. He could choreograph his heart out, and he did, creating one of those rare, euphoric dances that make life worth living.

headline: Fuel Cells at Center Stage
abstract: Toyota, General Motors, Hyundai, Honda and Mercedes-Benz are promising to sell fuel-cell cars in the next few years, making it clear that hydrogen will be part of their future.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, CALIF. — Like thick-rim glasses, Doc Martens and so many other things that fell out of favor only to spring back to popularity years later, fuel-cell cars have resurfaced.

headline: Head of Hawaii Insurance Exchange Steps Down
abstract: In a statement, the departing director, Coral Andrews, alluded to some of the problems the Hawaii exchange has faced but did not explain why she was stepping away.
lead_paragraph: The executive director of Hawaii’s state health care exchange announced her resignation on Friday amid delays in getting the insurance marketplace off the ground.

headline: Past Perfect
abstract: An enormous potato latke evokes the spirit of Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: After living in what must have seemed like every neighborhood in three boroughs — Coney Island, the South Bronx, East Flatbush, Spanish Harlem (as it was then called), the Lower East Side — my mother’s parents, in their oldish age, settled in Astoria, which is where I spent almost all the Thanksgivings of my childhood.

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']

lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission rushed on Friday to send Americans a message: “Don’t blame us!”

headline: As the Clothes Come Off, the Magazines Dress Up
abstract: In a sudden surge of upscale pornography, Treats is among several erotic publications that aim to titillate and provoke.
lead_paragraph: It was the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday. Young, almost-but-not-quite-A-list celebrities like Derek Hough, Russell Simmons, Aaron Paul, Jeremy Piven and Ryan Seacrest mingled among a crowd of barely clad, voluptuous women (some who performed fire-throwing tricks in Indian-themed, barely there costumes) while occasionally flipping through copies of an erotic magazine featuring more barely clad (or not clad at all) women on its glossy pages.

headline: The Return of the Tight Squeeze
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Books and Literature', 'Lingerie and Underwear']
abstract: The revival of the corset leads one aficionado to declare, “It’s like a hug that lasts all day.”
lead_paragraph: When Sarah A. Chrisman received a blue silk rose-patterned corset from her husband, a librarian and bicycle-shop manager, for her 29th birthday, she reluctantly allowed him to lace her into it. She believed then, she said recently, that corsets “deformed, broke bones, tortured and killed.”

headline: Stars, Yes, but Not Michelin
abstract: The Griddle Cafe is a Los Angeles hot spot for chowing down and catching glimpses of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Chateau Marmont was still passed out. The only activity on the nearby RockWalk, where Tommy Lee’s paw prints are set in cement, came from a pair of pigeons. Nary a needle was buzzing at Tattoo Mania.

headline: An Art and Design Auction You Might Actually Be Able to Afford
abstract: In Long Island City, Queens, the longtime appraiser Michael Capo has opened Beaux-Arts Auction, with an eclectic inventory made up largely of finds from liquidated estates.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 40 years as one of New York’s most revered generalist appraisers, Michael Capo has opened an auction house, Beaux-Arts Auction, in Long Island City, Queens, which hit the ground running in October with a first sale that brought in $250,000. The inventory is made up largely of finds from liquidated estates, ranging from antique furniture to contemporary art, making it a dream destination for interior designers and collectors. Capo founded Beaux-Arts, which sits in a sprawling 7,500-square-foot gallery, with his longtime friend Marc Lester, a Sotheby’s veteran who specializes in French and European furniture.

headline: Ex-Credit Suisse Executive Sentenced in Mortgage Bond Case
abstract: Kareem Serageldin, who led a group at Credit Suisse that traded in mortgage-backed securities, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday for inflating the value of bonds as the housing market collapsed.
lead_paragraph: A former top executive at the Credit Suisse Group was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday for inflating the value of mortgage bonds as the housing market collapsed.

headline: Katie Couric Is Said to Be Close to Taking a Job at Yahoo
abstract: The negotiations with Yahoo are said to be in the late stages. They are independent of Ms. Couric’s syndicated talk show, whose future is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Katie Couric is “in the late stages” of negotiations to leave her job as a special correspondent at ABC News for a new, as-yet-undefined role at Yahoo, an executive with knowledge of the talks said on Friday evening.

headline: A Momentum Powered by Sudden U-Turns
abstract: The Pacifica Quartet and the pianist Marc-André Hamelin performed Leo Ornstein’s 1927 Piano Quintet on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: Stormy. Stunning. Visionary. Heroic. Those were some of the words that lingered in my mind after the Pacifica Quartet’s Tuesday evening concert of works by Leo Ornstein and Beethoven at Zankel Hall. And I wasn’t thinking about Beethoven.

headline: 3 Found Guilty in CityTime Corruption Trial
abstract: The convictions involved New York City’s scandal-plagued payroll modernization project.
lead_paragraph: Three men who a prosecutor said had gotten “unbelievably rich” at the expense of New York City through a scandal-marred payroll modernization project were convicted on Friday in a federal corruption trial in Manhattan.

headline: The Thrill of Breathlessness
abstract: A diving death is a reminder that sometimes young people need to register the cold scorch of fear to feel truly alive.
lead_paragraph: FREMANTLE, Australia — NEWS of Nicholas Mevoli’s death during a free-diving competition at Dean’s Blue Hole in the Bahamas earlier this week has shocked the sport’s devotees and touched many of us who spend time in the water holding our breaths. Doubtless some readers will have been puzzled as to why a young man put his life at such unnecessary risk in the first place.

headline: What the Filibuster Rule Changes, and What It Doesn't
abstract: What are the likely effects of the Senate's decision to limit filibusters?

headline: The Long Goodbye
abstract: From Joan Didion to Andrew Sullivan, there have been multiple generations of writers who can’t quit New York without leaving behind a letter of bittersweet farewell.
lead_paragraph: “New York was no mere city,” Joan Didion wrote in her landmark 1967 essay, “Goodbye to All That,” explaining why she abandoned her adopted home of New York, seemingly for good, at the age of 29. “It was instead an infinitely romantic notion, the mysterious nexus of all love and money and power, the shining and perishable dream itself.”

headline: Founder of Reddit and the Internet’s Own Cheerleader
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)', 'Start-ups', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Media']
abstract: Alexis Ohanian has unflagging optimism about the good the web can do.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Ohanian bounded through the offices of Maker’s Row, a start-up in Brooklyn that pairs small businesses with manufacturers. At 6-foot-5, dressed in a gingham shirt and jeans, Mr. Ohanian was, in more ways than one, the big man on campus.

headline: Biographies of the Famous Don’t Skimp on the Details
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Forget all that talk about shrinking attention spans. Lengthy biographies like those of Barbara Stanwyck, Norman Mailer and Ted Williams have been making bookshelves sag.
lead_paragraph: The book industry faces many challenges these days, but a rising cost of paper does not appear to be one of them. That, at least, is the conclusion to be drawn from the recent spate of plus-size biographies — tree-killer volumes pushing 1,000 pages — that have been making bookshelves sag.

headline: Life of Stanwyck Is an Aerobic Read
abstract: Despite its 1,000 pages, Victoria Wilson’s life of Barbara Stanwyck is a page turner.
lead_paragraph: THE FIRST VOLUME of Victoria Wilson’s “A Life of Barbara Stanwyck: Steel-True, 1907-1940” ends as Europe erupts in war. Stanwyck herself would probably point out, with a laconic smile, that bigger things were happening than motion pictures.

headline: Fighter of Corruption in Nigeria Considers Next Steps
abstract: Nuhu Ribadu, who has been celebrated inside Nigeria and beyond for his five-year tenure as chief of an anticorruption unit, has not ruled out a bid for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — The cash was handed over in large sacks containing $15 million in $100 bills, bags so heavy that the stoop-shouldered civil servant needed help carrying them.

headline: Veteran Union Activist Fasts to Support Rights for Illegal Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Organized Labor', 'Hunger Strikes']
abstract: Eliseo Medina says he wants to “touch the heart” of Speaker John A. Boehner and make him act on immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a teenage grape picker, Eliseo Medina learned political action at the feet of Cesar Chavez. In 1968, he watched Mr. Chavez hold a 25-day water-only fast that helped transform the farm workers’ union into a nationally known force.

headline: Editor in India, Known for Investigations Into Corruption, Is Accused of Rape
abstract: Rape and sexual assault charges have been filed against Tarun Tejpal, the editor of Tehelka, a liberal-minded magazine that has influenced a generation of young Indian journalists.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police in the coastal state of Goa filed charges of rape and sexual assault on Friday against Tarun Tejpal, the editor of a liberal-minded magazine that has influenced a generation of young Indian journalists with its exposés of corruption and abuse of power.

headline: U.S. Retailers Decline to Aid Factory Victims in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Walmart, Sears, Children’s Place and other American companies that were selling goods produced at the site of two disasters are not joining in efforts to compensate victims’ families.
lead_paragraph: One year after the Tazreen factory fire in Bangladesh, many retailers that sold garments produced there or inside the Rana Plaza building that collapsed last spring are refusing to join an effort to compensate the families of the more than 1,200 workers who died in those disasters.

headline: N.S.A. Report Outlined Goals for More Power
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: The top-secret document described strategies to keep pace with rapidly changing technology and stay ahead of adversaries in intelligence collection.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials at the National Security Agency, intent on maintaining its dominance in intelligence collection, pledged last year to push to expand its surveillance powers, according to a top-secret strategy document.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagram Messaging, and Room Reservations Courtesy of Twitter
abstract: Friday’s highlights from around the web include a new feature from Instagram that may be seen as an answer to Snapchat. Plus, people can now book hotel rooms with one chain by tweeting to @Loews_Hotels with the hashtag #BookLoews.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Phillip Lim: The Chinese-American Dream
abstract: Suzy Menkes sits down with Phillip Lim and Wen Zhou, his business partner, to discuss the influence that heritage has had on their brand.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes sits down with Phillip Lim and Wen Zhou, his business partner, to discuss the influence that heritage has had on their brand.

headline: Norwegian, 22, Takes World Chess Title
abstract: Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, defeated Viswanathan Anand, 43, of India, the titleholder since 2007, and he did not lose a game in the best-of-12 series.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Carlsen, the 22-year-old Norwegian who has been the most dominant chess player since 2010, finally broke through on Friday to win the game’s most important title, the world championship, for the first time.

headline: Japan: Governor of Tokyo Embroiled in Loan Scandal
abstract: The governor of Tokyo, Naoki Inose, received a half-million dollars from a hospital operator involved in an election-fraud case.
lead_paragraph: Two months after winning the 2020 Olympics for his city, the governor of Tokyo has become embroiled in a scandal over a half-million dollars that he received from a hospital operator involved in an election-fraud case. The governor, Naoki Inose, has struggled to explain why he took the money from the Tokushukai hospital chain during his campaign to become governor in December. On Friday, he described the money as a personal loan that he hurriedly paid back in September, shortly after prosecutors raided the company in connection with the fraud case. Speculation has focused on whether the money was intended to facilitate the construction of a hospital in Tokyo; it appears to have no connection to the successful Olympic bid, which also took place in September.

headline: Gynecologists Run Afoul of Panel When Patient Is Male
keywords: ['Anal Cancer', 'Doctors', 'Men and Boys', 'Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Dr. Elizabeth Stier’s patients last year included about 110 men with a high risk of anal cancer. It’s the “men” part that the American Board of Obstetrics and Gynecology objected to.
lead_paragraph: About two months ago, Dr. Elizabeth Stier was shocked to learn that she would lose a vital credential, board certification as a gynecologist, unless she gave up an important part of her medical practice and her research: taking care of men at high risk for anal cancer.

headline: A Complex Love Story, Complete With Bells and a Ring
abstract: Since Manny Pacquiao saved his marriage, since he turned to God and Bible study and away from his vices, he has not performed like a fighter of the decade.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — Manny Pacquiao’s last fight ended with him facedown on the canvas, his arms tucked awkwardly underneath him, his body limp. His wife, Jinkee, was hysterical. She bolted toward the ring and fell into the arms of Pacquiao’s promoter and sobbed.

headline: Lincoln Looks South of the Border
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: France’s intervention in Mexico caught the attention of the American president in 1863.
lead_paragraph: In July 1863, just weeks after the twin Union victories at Gettysburg and Vicksburg, Abraham Lincoln turned his attention to the Rio Grande borderlands of Confederate Texas. On July 31, the president wrote Francis P. Blair Sr., one of his most powerful supporters, “Yesterday I commenced trying to get up an expedition for Texas. I shall do the best I can.” By November, 6,000 Union troops had landed in South Texas.

headline: A Players-Only Meeting? That Can’t Be Good News
abstract: The players-only meeting, a staple of losing teams everywhere, has remained an enduring tradition in professional sports, much to the disappointment of countless coaches.
lead_paragraph: When Chuck Daly was coaching the Orlando Magic in the late 1990s and his team was mired in a rough patch, he learned that a couple of his players were itching for a players-only meeting. Eric Musselman, one of his young assistants, recalled how Daly recruited him to relay a message to Horace Grant: permission denied.

headline: A Gamble in Iran Talks: Easing of the Sanctions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: President Obama’s critics — in Congress, the Arab world and Israel — argue that he has the strategy backward in negotiating a freeze of Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its delicate negotiations with Iran over freezing its nuclear program, the Obama administration is gambling that the gradual relaxation of punishing sanctions will whet Tehran’s appetite for greater economic relief, inducing the country’s leaders to negotiate a further deal to roll back its nuclear progress.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: The Dow Jones Industrial average closes above 16,000, the former presidential contender John Edwards opens a law office and European companies develop new drones.
lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones Industrial average closes above 16,000, the former presidential contender John Edwards opens a law office and European companies develop new drones.

headline: Marines Toughen Rules for Makers of Licensed Clothing
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: Clothing produced by a company licensed to make Marine Corps clothing was found in the rubble of a factory fire in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: The Marine Corps trademark licensing office has adopted tougher production standards for manufacturers that produce clothing items like sweatshirts emblazoned with Marine mottos or insignia, after the corps was stung by the discovery of a licensed company’s designs in the rubble of a factory fire in Bangladesh a year ago.

headline: Saturday’s Games to Watch
abstract: Baylor, which plays Oklahoma State, is 9-0 for the first time and in the running for its first outright Big 12 Conference title since 1980 when Mike Singletary was playing linebacker.
