headline: Obama’s Bay of Pigs
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Bay of Pigs Invasion (1961)']
abstract: J.F.K. learned from his mistakes. Can President Obama do the same after the disastrous rollout of Obamacare?
lead_paragraph: This week, when we are remembering John F. Kennedy, I’d like to touch briefly on the greatest fiasco of his presidency: the Bay of Pigs invasion. No sooner had Kennedy taken the oath of office than he discovered that the Pentagon and C.I.A. were preparing to send 1,500 Cuban exiles to invade Cuba. Though they would be greatly outnumbered by Cuban troops, the American military and the C.I.A. assumed that once the attack began, the Cuban people would rise up and overthrow Fidel Castro.

headline: Fears of Violence Loom Over Honduran Elections
abstract: In a country where the rule of law has all but shriveled, Hondurans head to the polls in hopes of electing a president who will bring stability and security.
lead_paragraph: In a country where the rule of law has all but shriveled, Hondurans head to the polls in hopes of electing a president who will bring stability and security.

headline: Racial Abuse Is Alleged at San Jose State University
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Hate Crimes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Assaults']
abstract: The university was grappling with accusations that three white students verbally and physically abused a black freshman.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Students at San Jose State University were grappling on Friday with accusations that three white students repeatedly abused a black freshman verbally and physically, calling him names referring to slavery and putting a bicycle lock around his neck.

headline: Political Doubt Poses Risk to Honduras, Battered by Coup and Violence
keywords: ['Elections', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Just four years from a coup, the elections for president and Congress on Sunday promise to be close, raising concerns that the losing parties may not honor the results.
lead_paragraph: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — When police officers arrived last week after the murder of Felipe Nery Aguilar and his daughter Gladys, they seized on what appeared to be a clue: a childish scribble on a broken television set. A message from local gangs, the officers figured, demanding protection money, known here as a “war tax.” Case closed.

headline: Responding to a Meningitis Outbreak
abstract: The importation of a vaccine is a good example of how two agencies can collaborate to reach a sensible solution.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine approved for use in Europe and Australia but not in the United States will be imported to help quell an outbreak of bacterial meningitis at Princeton University. This is a good example of how two federal agencies — the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration — can collaborate to reach a common-sense solution to protect the public’s health.

headline: Climbing Out of Albany’s Swamp
abstract: Public financing of state campaigns could soon be on the table.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly promised to “clean up Albany,” a vow that topped his priority list when he ran for office in 2010. Last January, he took the next step and proposed public matching funds for smaller campaign donations, a system that has worked remarkably well in New York City.

headline: Surveillance Goes on Trial
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Editorials', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: An A.C.L.U. lawsuit finally exposes the National Security Agency’s data sweep to opposing arguments.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot that was ordinary about the hearing in Courtroom 20B of the Manhattan federal courthouse on Friday morning: a team of lawyers at the plaintiff’s table, spectators in the gallery. What was extraordinary was the defendant, the United States government, and the lawsuit it is facing over the National Security Agency’s seven-year-old, once top-secret phone-surveillance program, which until this week it never had to defend in open court.

headline: Leave an Idea, Take an Idea
abstract: Thousands of New Yorkers have engaged in the “Talking Transition” project, offering suggestions to the mayor-elect on stickers and postcards.
lead_paragraph: Saturday is the last day for New Yorkers to give Bill de Blasio, the mayor-elect, a piece of their mind under the big white “Talking Transition” tent on Canal Street and Avenue of the Americas. Since the Nov. 5 election, inside that tent, in mobile tents that roamed the boroughs and online at talkingtransitionnyc.com, thousands have offered suggestions on stickers and postcards; sent emails; taped videos; and attended forums on topics like “food justice,” affordable housing and immigrant integration.

headline: Comparing Child Care Costs
abstract: Full-time child care is a large expense, but the cost varies regionally and by state with some scattered outliers among the highest.
lead_paragraph: Full-time child care is a large expense, but the cost varies regionally and by state with some scattered outliers among the highest.

headline: Texas Education Board Flags Biology Textbook Over Evolution Concerns
abstract: The State Board of Education delayed final approval of a widely used biology textbook because of concerns raised by one reviewer that the book presents evolution as fact rather than mere theory.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Board of Education on Friday delayed final approval of a widely used biology textbook because of concerns raised by one reviewer that it presents evolution as fact rather than theory.

headline: Iran Would Eliminate Stock of Some of Its Enriched Uranium Under Deal
abstract: Western officials say a proposed agreement would force the dilution or other conversion of 20 percent enriched uranium.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under the proposed six-month deal that six major powers are negotiating with Iran in Geneva, Iran would eliminate its current stock of uranium enriched to 20 percent by diluting it or turning it into fuel rods or oxide powder, forms that are unusable for weapons, senior Western officials said Friday.

headline: A Rural Retreat in China
abstract: The Times's Edward Wong visits the quiet town of Dali, where writers, artists and other residents have found an idyllic escape from the crowded cities of eastern China.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Edward Wong visits the quiet town of Dali, where writers, artists and other residents have found an idyllic escape from the crowded cities of eastern China.

headline: Tension and Flaws Before Health Website Crash
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Interviews and documents offer new details into how the rollout of President Obama’s signature program turned into a major humiliation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a sultry day in late August, a dozen staff members of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services gathered at the agency’s Baltimore headquarters with managers from the major contractors building HealthCare.gov to review numerous problems with President’s Obama’s online health insurance initiative. The mood was grim.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 23, 2013.
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, November 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “It really puts a human face on the term ‘collateral damage.’”

headline: Police Unsure if Random Attacks Are Rising Threat or Urban Myth
abstract: The New York police are trying to determine if teenagers are picking targets and trying to knock them out with one punch, or if such attacks have always occurred.
lead_paragraph: Fear swept through Borough Park, Brooklyn, as soon as the news got out: A young man was randomly assaulted by strangers early Friday morning, and the attack was possibly part of the so-called Knockout Game.

headline: Singing Arias and Splitting Uprights, a Raven Knows How to Enhance a Score
abstract: Justin Tucker, a second-year place-kicker for the Baltimore Ravens, maintains a captive audience in the locker room, his bass-baritone regaling opera-deficient teammates.
lead_paragraph: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Justin Tucker’s right leg swung swiftly into the football’s gut, and he watched the ball travel straight and far before smashing off a seat deep in the second deck.

headline: North Korea Confirms It Is Holding U.S. Citizen
abstract: North Korea’s confirmation broke nearly four weeks of silence by the country’s authorities about the detained American, Merrill Newman, 85, of Palo Alto, Calif.
lead_paragraph: The State Department said Friday that North Korea had confirmed that it was holding an American citizen, whom family and friends have identified as an octogenarian veteran of the Korean War inexplicably detained there last month as he was concluding an officially approved nine-day tour of the country.

headline: Corrections: November 23, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 22, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for Nov. 22, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Slam Dunk
abstract: A puzzle on which to crunch by Frederick J. Healy.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well. If you thought you were going to relax with the crossword puzzle this weekend, you were clearly wrong. This is a “rock ’em, sock ’em” puzzle if ever I saw one, with a bit of obscurity and variance thrown in to keep us humble.

headline: For the Love of the Game
abstract: Columbia football’s long history of losing seasons, and long rides to the field, do not deter players from coming out for practices and games.
lead_paragraph: Columbia football’s long history of losing seasons, and long rides to the field, do not deter players from coming out for practices and games.

headline: Columbia Football’s Dogged Futility
abstract: Columbia, 0-9 going into Saturday’s season finale against Brown, wins at many things, but for generations it has been unable to solve the football riddle.
lead_paragraph: Way uptown, at its gleaming new field house on the northern tip of Manhattan, Columbia is trying to win at football — really, it is — even though it may appear otherwise.

headline: Wind Energy Company to Pay $1 Million in Bird Deaths
abstract: Duke Energy pleaded guilty to violating a law protecting migratory birds, and will pay its fines to conservation groups.
lead_paragraph: Duke Energy agreed on Friday to pay $1 million in fines as part of the Justice Department’s first criminal case against a wind power company for the deaths of protected birds.

headline: Pentagon Releases Strategy for Arctic
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations', 'Global Warming', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Speaking at a security forum, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel outlined the United States’ priorities and concerns, like economic competition and melting ice caps, in the region.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a shrinking northern ice cap sets the stage for increased competition over natural resources, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Friday released the Pentagon’s first “Arctic Strategy,” intended to safeguard American security interests and the region’s environment.

headline: A New Dispute Emerges in Brooklyn Prosecutor’s Office
abstract: The office of District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn, who was ousted by voters after 24 years, fired an assistant who forwarded embarrassing emails about his campaign that BuzzFeed published.
lead_paragraph: The last several months have unfolded tempestuously for Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. He faces accusations that his office handled a series of wrongful convictions in murder cases, one of which has resulted in a $150 million lawsuit. He was criticized for allowing his office to be the focus of a television show. And he lost a primary and a lopsided general election, forcing him out after 24 years.

headline: Despite the Evidence, Trainers Deny a Doping Problem
abstract: For years, many in horse racing have acknowledged that the use of performance-enhancing drugs has eroded the sport’s popularity and its bottom line.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, representatives of the horse-racing industry told Congress that thoroughbred racing’s drug problem was a myth. On Thursday afternoon, a report by the California Horse Racing Board revealed that Bob Baffert, a Hall of Fame trainer, had been giving every horse in his barn a thyroid hormone without ever checking to see if any of them had thyroid problems.

headline: Urbanites Flee China’s Smog for Blue Skies
abstract: China is undergoing a surprising reverse migration: As millions leave to find work in the cities, some well-educated urban dwellers are relocating to small towns.
lead_paragraph: DALI, China — A typical morning for Lin Liya, a native of Shanghai transplanted to this ancient town in southwest China, goes like this: See her 3-year-old son off to school near the mountains; go for a half-hour run on the shores of Erhai Lake; and browse the local market for fresh vegetables and meat.

headline: Vern Mikkelsen, Hall of Famer Who Won Four Titles With the Lakers, Dies at 85
abstract: Mikkelsen, a six-time N.B.A. All-Star known for his tough defense and rebounding, helped pioneer the position of power forward.
lead_paragraph: Vern Mikkelsen, a Hall of Fame forerunner of the modern-day power forward who helped lead the Minneapolis Lakers to four N.B.A. championships in the early 1950s, died on Thursday at his home in Wayzata, Minn. He was 85.

headline: John Egerton, Who Lent Spice to Social Justice, Dies at 78
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Mr. Egerton, a Southern writer, used Southern cooking both as a means to understand the culture and to achieve racial reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: John Egerton understood that the American South was a region of contradictions, holding both savagery and sweetness, churchgoers and evildoers, good cooking and bad.

headline: ‘Completely Different’ Giants Eager for Rematch With Cowboys
abstract: The Giants enter their rematch against Dallas at MetLife Stadium believing that their season-opening 36-31 loss to the Cowboys proved nothing about the superiority of either team.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants enter their rematch against Dallas at MetLife Stadium believing that their season-opening 36-31 loss to the Cowboys proved nothing about the superiority of either team.

headline: Rev. T. J. Jemison, Civil Rights Leader Who Organized Early Boycott, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Jemison organized what is considered the civil rights movement’s first large-scale bus boycott, and was a founding member of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. T. J. Jemison, a civil rights pioneer who organized a 1953 bus boycott in Baton Rouge, La., that foreshadowed the one set off by Rosa Parks in Montgomery, Ala., and who went on to lead the nation’s largest black Baptist organization into liberal political activism, died on Nov. 15 in Baton Rouge. He was 95.

headline: Kerry Opposes Afghan Delay on Security Deal
abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s threat not to sign the pact until next year threatened relations between Washington and Kabul, a State Department spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry talked with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Friday to express displeasure with his plan to put off signing the two countries’ security deal until next year, and a State Department spokeswoman said the delay threatened relations between Washington and Kabul.

headline: After Conviction, Focus Turns to Ownership of Marcos Artwork
keywords: ['Art', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Four masterpieces at the center of the successful prosecution of Imelda Marcos’s former personal secretary are also the subject of multiple claims of ownership, including by the Philippine government.
lead_paragraph: The criminal trial concerning four Impressionist masterpieces once owned by Imelda Marcos may have ended this week with a jury’s quick conviction of her former personal secretary, but a more daunting question remains: What happens to the artwork?

headline: ‘Trouble Don’t Last Always’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Change is hard and often messy, and the Affordable Care Act means change.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old Gospel song called “Trouble Don’t Last Always.” My mother has repeated that phrase so often that the words are written on my consciousness.

headline: Flyers Rescue Season Behind Interim Coach and a Few Good Bounces
abstract: The Flyers, undefeated in their last six games, have figured out Coach Craig Berube’s aggressive system of forechecking and appear to have turned around a season that started poorly.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — On Nov. 1, one month into the N.H.L. season, the Philadelphia Flyers lost to the Alex Ovechkin-less Washington Capitals, 7-0. They took nearly three times as many penalty minutes as shots, and goalie Ray Emery attracted criticism by leaving the crease to fight Washington’s Braden Holtby. The Flyers’ record fell to 3-9, and their star center Claude Giroux still had not scored a goal.

headline: Experts Say Poaching Could Soon Lead to a Decline in the Rhino Population
abstract: Economics is driving the destruction of the animals in Africa and Asia, where the horns are seen as luxury items.
lead_paragraph: After two decades of gains, the world’s population of rhinoceroses is being killed off by poachers at such a high rate that conservationists fear the deaths could soon surpass the number of rhinos that are born each year.

headline: Garnett Has Impact, but Not the Right Kind, in a Rout
abstract: Kevin Garnett was involved in a third-quarter altercation with Kevin Love as the Timberwolves dealt the Nets their fourth straight loss and seventh in eight road games.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Nights like Friday are when leadership matters in the N.B.A. Four injured players were out for the beleaguered Nets, including their leading scorer Brook Lopez. The situation demanded that the veterans with the championship rings, Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce, assert themselves. Especially Garnett, facing the Minnesota Timberwolves, the franchise where he spent his first 12 seasons.

headline: Argument Escalates to Stabbing at Kennedy Airport
abstract: Two men having a dispute inside the airport on Friday moved to a parking lot, where one slashed the other in the face, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man was stabbed in the face during a dispute in a parking lot at Kennedy International Airport on Friday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Led by Veterans (in Early 20s), UConn Nips Indiana
abstract: With 10 lead changes in the second half, Shabazz Napier and Ryan Boatright led Connecticut past an athletic and young Indiana team to win the 2K Sports Classic at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: It is a year featuring one of the deepest and most advanced freshman classes in memory, and Connecticut can seem a bit like a creaky wooden vessel in a flotilla of speedboats. The Huskies do not have that transcendent newcomer. They are led by that most arcane and passé of figures: the upperclassman.

headline: Bloomberg Wants Restaurants to Compost
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he was proposing a bill that would require restaurants that generate more than a ton of food waste a week to separate their food waste from the rest of their garbage.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is slowly bringing New Yorkers around to the idea of recycling their food scraps, is trying to expand his composting campaign by bringing it to large restaurants.

headline: After a Long Silence, Dolan Speaks
abstract: The status of Coach Mike Woodson, his relationship with Isiah Thomas and his decision to replace Glen Grunwald were discussed. The decision to let Jeremy Lin depart was not.
lead_paragraph: On March 13, 2012, The New York Times published a story by Howard Beck that noted it had been exactly five years since James Dolan, the Knicks’ owner, had consented to any sort of interview with the reporters who covered his often inept team.

headline: Marines at Kennedy’s Funeral Stand Together Again
abstract: The Marines who were body bearers, served on death watch or marched in the days after the president’s assassination gathered for a reunion in Texas.
lead_paragraph: ALLEN, Tex. — Fifty years without seeing someone is a long time to remember a name, and when Bob DeBardelaben saw Tom Tallick at a reunion here of the Marines who served at President John F. Kennedy’s funeral, he could not.

headline: A Chance to Spend a Bit of Summer in the Country
abstract: Since Taylor Dale’s mother died in 2008, the 9-year-old has been looked after by aunts, one of whom received help to send Taylor to summer camp.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the living room of her two-bedroom apartment in the Marble Hill section of the Bronx, Kathleen Hicks, a former messenger service dispatcher, turned up her right wrist. The name Nancy is tattooed, in cursive, on the pulse point.

headline: A Strategy for Surveillance Powers
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A National Security Agency mission statement provides a glimpse of agency officials’ goals before the Snowden leaks upset their political calculus.
lead_paragraph: A National Security Agency mission statement provides a glimpse of agency officials’ goals before the Snowden leaks upset their political calculus.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) IDENTITY THIEF (2013) Melissa McCarthy stars as a crazed kewpie doll of a thief sometimes named Diana who wreaks havoc on a milquetoast, Sandy Patterson (Jason Bateman), after stealing his identity just as he lands a job insuring his upward mobility. After leaving his wife (Amanda Peet) and their kids in their meager apartment, Sandy heads toward Diana’s home in Florida to regain control over his life. But she’s not about to give up the spoils easily. “From the moment Diana comes on screen in ‘Identity Thief,’ sugar-talking Sandy out of his information while she’s slurping a soda, Ms. McCarthy owns the movie,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The character may be drawn in broad strokes, but Ms. McCarthy slips between the saucy and the demonic with exquisite effortlessness, fluttering her lashes and flashing her dimples one minute, unleashing her inner Medusa the next.”

headline: China Claims Air Rights Over Disputed Islands
abstract: The Chinese government warned that it claimed the right to possibly take military action against aircraft that enter a newly declared “air defense identification zone,” which covers sea and islands also claimed by Japan.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government on Saturday claimed the right to identify, monitor and possibly take military action against aircraft that enter a newly declared “air defense identification zone,” which covers sea and islands also claimed by Japan and threatens to escalate an already tense dispute over some of the maritime territory.

headline: Karzai Insists U.S. Forces Killed Civilians in a Raid
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: After announcing he would delay signing a deal he had agreed to, Hamid Karzai began a new quarrel with Americans, over a recent raid.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the second time in less than a week, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has picked a high-profile fight with his American allies, in the midst of a grand council that he convened to support a long-term security agreement with the United States.

headline: New Musical Partnership in China
abstract: Sino American Global Entertainment, a partnership with IMG Artists in the United States and China Arts and Entertainment Group, aims to create new paths for performances and marketing in both countries.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest, but least-tapped markets for classical music and dance — as both an importer and exporter — is China. So this week IMG Artists, a major representative of classical musicians in the West, announced a new partnership with the China Arts and Entertainment Group, a huge arts and entertainment company in China.

headline: Bubblephobia and Monetary Policy
abstract: Perversity in Sweden.
lead_paragraph: How do you know that monetary policy is too loose? The textbook answer is that excessively expansionary monetary policy shows up in rising inflation; stable inflation means money is neither too loose nor too tight. This answer has, however, come under challenge from both sides. One side — the side I’m on, and I’m pretty sure the side Janet Yellen is on, says that at low inflation rates this rule breaks down: the Phillips curve isn’t vertical, even in the long run, at low inflation (perhaps thanks to downward nominal wage rigidity), so stable inflation at a low level is consistent with an economy operating well below potential.

headline: Egypt Expels Turkey’s Ambassador, Further Fraying Diplomatic Ties
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Egypt cited “provocative” criticisms by Turkey, and Turkey announced reciprocal steps.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt announced on Saturday that it was downgrading its diplomatic relations with Turkey and expelled the Turkish ambassador because of “provocative” criticisms of Cairo by Turkey’s prime minister, a spokesman for Egypt’s foreign minister said.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 22, 2013
abstract: This week, Joe discusses the multitude of Obamacare glitches, which is also the subject of his column today.
lead_paragraph: Healthcare.gov launched more than seven weeks ago and the program’s problems keep piling up, as hundreds of thousands of people received notifications that their current coverage is being cancelled. There are also concerns over the website’s security. Last week, President Obama announced a fix. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine consider if these changes put the entire law at risk and what the uncertainty means for consumers and businesses. Plus, a look at the recent JPMorgan settlement, which forced the bank to shell out a record $13 billion.

lead_paragraph: 1938: S.S. Vows ‘Fire and Sword’

abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a photo adventure for both children and adults.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: After Two Decades, a Shrinking Salary at a Job She Loved
abstract: Nicole Bouchotte, a 61-year-old school bus matron, began making $210 less per month after she and her co-workers went on strike this year and her hours were later scaled back.
lead_paragraph: Police cars were blocking the entrance to the bus yard in Brooklyn when Nicole Bouchotte, 61, arrived at work one day last January. It was at that moment, so early on a cold weekday morning that the sun had yet to rise, that she learned that her union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, was on strike.

headline: Arsenal’s Giroud Receives a Gift
abstract: Southampton goalkeeper Artur Boruc tried to outsmart Arsenal’s Olivier Giroud, but instead lost the ball as Giroud scored.
lead_paragraph: Buried deep inside nearly every goalkeeper in the world is a skillful field player fighting to get out. At least that is a theory shared by most of the world’s goalkeepers.

headline: Variety: A New Diagramless
abstract: Paula Gamache offers us a new diagramless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’ll tell you exactly where I had trouble: PARIPASSU.

headline: Syrian Rebels Seize Control of Oil Field From Assad
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A group of rebel brigades captured a large oil and gas field from government forces, opposition activists said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A group of Syrian rebel brigades, including an affiliate of Al Qaeda, seized a large oil and gas field from government forces on Saturday, opposition activists said, further depriving the government of President Bashar al-Assad of the resources it needs to remain solvent.

headline: Teams Are Learning to Keep Their Best Players Off the Market
abstract: The Boston Red Sox’ strategy from last winter — shorter deals with higher average annual salaries — may be wiser than 10-year deals for players in their 30s.
lead_paragraph: When the Detroit Tigers traded Prince Fielder to Texas last week, they still owed him a staggering $168 million. Only one player had ever been traded with more money still owed to him: Alex Rodriguez, from Texas to the Yankees in 2004.

headline: $62 Million in Sales at ‘Art of the Automobile’ Auction
abstract: The much-publicized sale, held jointly by RM Auctions and Sotheby’s and billed as the first major collector-car auction in New York City in a decade, was an experiment in presenting vehicles as art objects.
lead_paragraph: A red Ferrari endurance-racing car that was on display in the lobby of Sotheby’s on the Upper East Side of Manhattan was the top sale in a closely watched auction on Thursday. The 1964 Ferrari 250 LM, which was been given a presale estimate of $12 million to $15 million, sold for $14.3 million including the buyer’s premium.

headline: Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States and five other world powers announced an accord that would temporarily freeze Tehran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping deal.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States and five other world powers announced a landmark accord Sunday morning that would temporarily freeze Iran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping agreement.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: In Golf, South Koreans Find a New Model for Success
abstract: Led by Inbee Park, the L.P.G.A. Player of the Year, South Koreans have 108 L.P.G.A. tour victories.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — Se Ri Pak was the prototype, engineered by her father to be a mentally strong, mechanically sound golfing machine. His blueprint, in which he streamlined Pak’s existence by eliminating any activity not conducive to shooting low scores, was widely copied by other South Korean fathers of young daughters after Pak won the first of 25 titles on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

headline: Lakers’ Nash Shares Aches of His Elders
abstract: As Steve Nash prepares to turn 40, it is the stretching, pulling and activating of the most ancillary muscles, almost like daily physical therapy, that will determine how he finishes his career.
lead_paragraph: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — As Lakers guard Steve Nash speaks in such a clinical manner about nerve root irritation, proper alignment, asymptomatic discomfort and musculature default patterns, listening to him requires a quick reminder that he is a basketball player and not a Pilates instructor.

headline: Lynn Good of Duke Energy, on Effective Leaders
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: The chief executive of Duke Energy says managerial skill is about “whether you can be effective in leading a diverse team.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with   Lynn J. Good, chief executive of Duke Energy, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Cowboys See a Chance to Move Past Troubles
abstract: One bye week may not be enough time to cure what ails the Dallas Cowboys, who appear as enigmatic as ever before their showdown with the Giants on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — One bye week may not be enough time to cure what ails the Dallas Cowboys, who appear as enigmatic as ever before their showdown with the Giants on Sunday.

headline: Almanacs Foresee a Super Bowl to Test Fans’ Resolve, and Snow Gear
abstract: In voting to reward the Jets and the Giants with hosting Super Bowl XLVIII, N.F.L. owners sparked a host of prognostications, some of which call for Snowmaggedon on game day.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. owners met near Dallas three years ago and chose to hold Super Bowl XLVIII in New Jersey, it was a balmy 90 degrees and dry as a bone. The 80,000 fans who attend the game in February may be happy if it is half as warm.

headline: Haitian Photographer Wins Major U.S. Copyright Victory
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Photography', 'Social Media', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a victory for photographer rights, a New York court awarded Daniel Morel $1.2 million after finding two photo agencies improperly used his photos of Haiti’s earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Photographers have struggled financially over the last decade as millions of images have been taken and published on the Web without proper attribution or compensation. And when photographers try to pursue copyright violators, it is often difficult and expensive. On Friday, the Haitian photographer Daniel Morel won a major copyright victory after a four-year fight over images he had originally sent out via social media.

headline: Eli Manning’s Footballs Are Months in Making
abstract: Each N.F.L. team has 12 to 20 balls a game that have been prepared according to the preferences of its starting quarterback.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Eli Manning drops back to throw his first pass Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, the football in his hands will be as familiar as an old friend.

headline: For Sale: Craggy Isle Where Olympic Rocks Are the Stars
abstract: Ailsa Craig, an uninhabited 200-acre island off the Scottish coast, is the source of a distinctive granite put to use every four years for Olympic curling.
lead_paragraph: AILSA CRAIG, Scotland — This stunning volcanic island has been part of Scottish legend for a thousand years, its sugarloaf profile decorating Scottish bank notes and memorialized in a Keats sonnet.

headline: In Immigration Battle, Advocates for Overhaul Single Out Republicans
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Representative Scott Tipton, a Republican of Colorado, rode a Tea Party wave to Congress, but now faces the pressure of his district’s demographics.
lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — Representative Scott Tipton, Republican of Colorado, entered his town hall meeting and quickly began greeting the assembled crowd, including those who did not necessarily share his political views.

headline: Ed Reed’s Film Study Class Is Mesmerizing an Eager Acolyte
abstract: Josh Bush has trailed Ed Reed ever since Reed joined the Jets, watching him on the practice field and in meeting rooms and during one-on-one tutorials.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Josh Bush had but one request soon after being drafted by the Jets in 2012. Bush, a safety, asked his position coach, Dennis Thurman, to put him in touch with Ed Reed, whom he had coached in Baltimore. No way, Thurman said. As much as Bush stood to learn from Reed, he was not ready — not yet.

headline: Unsettled in Goal, U.S. Keeps Looking
abstract: U.S. hockey officials will select from a at least a half-dozen candidates three N.H.L. goaltenders who will be on the roster for the Sochi Olympics in February.
lead_paragraph: They fan out to the N.H.L.’s 30 rinks across the continent, a small group of hockey executives watching game after game, deciding which players might represent the United States at the Sochi Olympics. Of those decisions, none will be more crucial than picking the goaltenders.

headline: Bodies Still Being Found Weeks After Philippine Storm
abstract: Weeks after a typhoon devastated a chunk of the Philippines, bodies continue to be found amid the piles of debris, gruesome reminders of tragedy.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — A solemn procession walked down the main coastal road here Saturday morning through a light but steady rain, carrying a piece of plywood with a black object securely fastened on top with yellow packaging tape: a body bag holding the remains of Athena Mae Pelingon, age 3.

headline: Saddled Together
abstract: Marley Stone and Timothy Bourke often go head to head at equestrian competitions, but their friendly rivalry on the field hasn’t affected their romantic relationship.
lead_paragraph: Marley Stone and Timothy Bourke often go head to head at equestrian competitions, but their friendly rivalry on the field hasn’t affected their romantic relationship.

headline: How Can We Jump-Start the Struggle for Gender Equality?
keywords: ['Gender', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: To speed up a slowing move to equality, men will need to move into professions that are traditionally female.
lead_paragraph: For several decades women’s success in the labor market was so breathtaking, so propulsive, that full gender equality seemed inevitable.

headline: When the Weather, Too, Was Memorable
abstract: With two almanacs forecasting a snowy Super Bowl at MetLife Stadium in February, it is worth noting that important sporting events often take place in weather that is less than ideal.
lead_paragraph: With two almanacs forecasting a snowy Super Bowl at MetLife Stadium in February, it is worth noting that important sporting events often take place in weather that is less than ideal.

headline: Big Games in the Great, Unforgiving Outdoors
abstract: As New York prepares for the first Super Bowl to be played outdoors in a cold climate, reporters from The New York Times share their tales of meteorologic misery.
lead_paragraph: Some weather prognosticators are warning that the first outdoor Super Bowl in a winter environment could morph into the Snow Bowl. But conducting sporting events in extreme weather is nothing new. Reporters from The New York Times share their tales of meteorologic misery.

headline: In Defense of a Loaded Word
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Language and Languages', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'English Language']
abstract: Banning the “n-word” is itself a double standard, ignoring the fact that context is everything.
lead_paragraph: MY father’s name is William Paul Coates. I, like my six brothers and sisters, have always addressed him as Dad. Strangers often call him Mr. Coates. His friends call him Paul. If a stranger or one of my father’s friends called him Dad, my father might have a conversation. When I was a child, relatives of my paternal grandmother would call my father Billy. Were I to ever call my father Billy, we would probably have a different conversation.

headline: Puddleglum and the Savage
abstract: Two deaths were overshadowed by the death of J.F.K.
lead_paragraph: THEY died in their homes, not from an assassin’s bullet, and in their 60s, not in their prime. When C. S. Lewis collapsed in his Oxford bedroom, the presidential motorcade was leaving Love Field. When Aldous Huxley requested a final shot of LSD, a TV set in the next room had just blared the news that the president had been shot. And then the coincidence of two of modernity’s keenest critics dying on the same November day was lost in a storm of headlines and public grief.

headline: Why the Y?
keywords: ['Chromosomes', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: In a battle of the sexes 200 million years in the making, the willful Y chromosome fights to hold its ground.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — EVEN sitting in an M.I.T. classroom made me feel smarter.

headline: Christopher Kimball
abstract: The bow-tied chef whose work influences countless Thanksgiving feasts reveals a passion for the Grateful Dead and rabbit hunting.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Kimball is the bow-tied and bespectacled chef and founder of America’s Test Kitchen, which produces television and radio shows of the same name and publishes Cooks Illustrated magazine.

headline: Right vs. Left in the Midwest
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Minnesota and Wisconsin are good places to compare modern progressivism and the new right.
lead_paragraph: MINNESOTA and Wisconsin share much more than bone-chilling winters: German and Northern European roots; farming; and, until recently, a populist progressive tradition stretching back a century to Wisconsin’s Fighting Bob La Follette and the birth of Minnesota’s Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party.

headline: After Changes, How Green Is The Times?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: After the paper discontinued its Green blog earlier this year, environmental coverage in recent months has declined.
lead_paragraph: EARLY this year, The Times came under heavy criticism from many readers who care deeply about news coverage about the environment — especially climate change.

headline: Oh, Brother! Big Brother Is Back
abstract: Deal-making with Iran is quite a shock to the whole Middle East system.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — I’VE never been in a big earthquake, but I know what one feels like now, having spent this past week in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. The American-led interim negotiations in Geneva to modestly loosen some sanctions on Iran in return for some curbs on its nuclear program — in advance of talks for an end to sanctions in return for an end to any Iranian bomb-making capability — has hit the Sunni Arab world (and Israel) like a geopolitical earthquake. If and when a deal is struck, it could have a bigger impact on this region than anything since the Camp David peace treaty and Iran’s Islamic Revolution in the 1970s combined to reorder the Middle East.

headline: Taking Our Selfies Seriously
abstract: Introducing the Oxford Dictionaries word of the year.
lead_paragraph: “Selfie” is the newly crowned champion word of the year by Oxford Dictionaries. It means a photograph taken of oneself by oneself but usually not for oneself — rather for the whole world — on a cellphone camera.

headline: Danger Lurks in That Mickey Mouse Couch
keywords: ['Flame Retardants', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Children and Childhood', 'Furniture', 'Television', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Chemicals']
abstract: The corporate boondoggle that may threaten the health of our children.
lead_paragraph: RESEARCHERS this summer purchased 42 children’s chairs, sofas and other furniture from major retailers and tested them for toxic flame retardants that have been linked to cancer, birth defects, diminished I.Q.’s and other problems.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Helping Women ‘Lean In’
abstract: Readers discuss promoting gender equality at work and home.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss promoting gender equality at work and home.

headline: A Most Expensive Book
abstract: The true value of what Sotheby’s is auctioning off.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE first English-language book printed in the New World is scheduled to be auctioned on Tuesday by Sotheby’s of New York. It’s expected to command between $15 million and $30 million — more than anyone, anywhere, has ever paid for a printed book.

headline: Art Makes You Smart
abstract: Museum visits increase test scores, generate social responsibility and increase appreciation of the arts by students.
lead_paragraph: FOR many education advocates, the arts are a panacea: They supposedly increase test scores, generate social responsibility and turn around failing schools. Most of the supporting evidence, though, does little more than establish correlations between exposure to the arts and certain outcomes. Research that demonstrates a causal relationship has been virtually nonexistent.

headline: Bringing Back My Real Self With Hormones
keywords: ['Hormones', 'Pituitary Gland', 'Brain', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: For some people — more than you think — the ability to fine-tune hormones and neurochemicals is the key to a successful adult life.
lead_paragraph: IN my early 30s, for a few months, I altered my body chemistry and hormones so that I was closer to a man in his early 20s. I was blown away by how dramatically my thoughts changed. I was angry almost all the time, thought about sex constantly, and assumed I was the smartest person in the entire world. Over the years I had met guys rather like this.

headline: $13 Billion, Yes, but What Took So Long?
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In reaching its big settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department seemed to rely largely on facts that have been known for years.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of pre-deal chatter about its $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department finally nailed it down last week. And for the first time, the department provided a glimpse of the investigatory findings upon which the settlement was based.

headline: More ‘Stand Your Ground’ Fantasizing
abstract: Ohio moves one step closer to enacting a dangerous gun law.
lead_paragraph: Ohio’s Republican-controlled Legislature is aiming to enact a Stand Your Ground gun law, despite pleas from urban government leaders that this would only compound the risks in inner-city neighborhoods where gun mayhem hits hardest. The measure, approved by the Ohio House and sent to the Senate, would eliminate the traditional requirement that a person prudently retreat in the face of danger before resorting to deadly force. It would make Ohio the latest of more than a score of other states following the foolhardy lead of Florida — where the first Stand Your Ground law has proved to be rife with risks to public safety and effective law enforcement.

headline: The Long Goodbye in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama has yet to make the case for an extended commitment by American troops.
lead_paragraph: From his first campaign for the White House, President Obama has vowed to end more than a decade of war, bring the troops home and put America on a less militaristic footing. He has reduced the forces in Afghanistan from about 100,000 in 2010 to about 47,000 today and has promised that all American and international combat forces will be out by the end of 2014.

headline: An Oasis of Groceries
abstract: A novel, nonprofit supermarket sets up shop in the middle of a food desert.
lead_paragraph: CHESTER, Pa.

headline: Curing Insomnia to Treat Depression
abstract: Studies yield highly promising results from therapy for sleeplessness.
lead_paragraph: Psychiatrists have long thought that depression causes insomnia, but new research suggests that insomnia can actually precede and contribute to causing depression. The causal link works in both directions. Two small studies have shown that a small amount of cognitive behavioral therapy to treat insomnia, when added to a standard antidepressant pill to treat depression, can make a huge difference in curing both insomnia and depression in many patients. If the results hold up in other studies already underway at major medical centers, this could be the most dramatic advance in treating depression in decades.

headline: No Phones on My Plane, Please
abstract: If flying weren’t uncomfortable enough, the F.C.C. is re-examining the ban on cellphone use.
lead_paragraph: The new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission wants to review and possibly get rid of the agency’s “outdated and restrictive rules” banning cellphone calls on planes. To which, most travelers would rightly ask: Why?

headline: Are Kids Too Coddled?
abstract: Tougher education standards like the Common Core may require a tough love that some parents and educators don’t like.
lead_paragraph: AT a middle school near Boston not long ago, teachers and administrators noticed that children would frequently return from a classmate’s weekend bar mitzvah with commemorative T-shirts, swag that advertised a party to which many fellow students hadn’t been invited.

headline: A Growing Chill Between South Korea and Japan Creates Problems for the U.S.
abstract: The current tensions are an increasingly vexing problem for the Obama administration as it struggles to present a united front in dealing with a rising China and a nuclear North Korea.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the courtly world of diplomacy, the meeting between Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea was something of a shock.

abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “No firm, no matter how profitable, is above the law, and the passage of time is no shield from accountability.”

headline: Forgotten Killer Among the Korean ‘Erased’
abstract: A book is a requiem for the thousands of young men from both Koreas who were trained as secret fighters of the Cold War, and then disowned by North and South.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — He was one of North Korea’s deadliest secret agents.

headline: In the Health Law, an Open Door for Entrepreneurs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act makes it easier for some people to start their own companies — including a mini-industry to help navigate the law itself.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since the health insurance marketplaces of the Affordable Care Act went online, a well-publicized ripple of alarm and confusion has permeated the ranks of small-business owners. But less well known is the response of another contingent: newcomers to entrepreneurship who see the legislation as a solution to the often insurmountable expense of getting health insurance. Some even view the Affordable Care Act itself as a business opportunity.

headline: Swatting at a Swarm of Public Relations Spam
keywords: ['Public Relations and Publicity', 'Spam (Electronic)', 'E-Mail', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Why would any company pay to blanket reporters with email they didn’t ask for and almost surely don’t want? The Haggler tries to find out.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler typically starts his column with a complaint, and this time it’s the Haggler’s turn to complain. Specifically, the Haggler would like to complain about the complaints he’s getting.

headline: In Fed Policy, the Exit Music May Be Hard to Hear
abstract: The Federal Reserve may not be able to rely on past experience in deciding when to end its extraordinary policies of the past few years.
lead_paragraph: Is it time for the Federal Reserve to start its exit from the extraordinary set of policies it has pursued over the past few years? That crucial question is on the minds of the nation’s central bankers, as well as the stock and bond traders who follow the Fed’s every move.

headline: A Bitcoin Puzzle: Heads, It’s Excitement. Tails, It’s Anxiety.
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Currency', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Governments and investors are struggling to get a grip on the future of the virtual currency — not to mention its present.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin isn’t ready for popular consumption, and it may never be.

headline: McMansions Are Making a Comeback
abstract: Home sizes and prices have been creeping up again, reaching highs that have surpassed their pre-recession peaks.
lead_paragraph: When the housing bubble burst in 2007, there was a glut of unsold inventory on the market, and the size of newly built homes began to shrink. In both 2008 and 2009, Census Bureau figures show, the median size of a new home was smaller than it had been the previous year. It seemed that after more than a decade of swelling domiciles, the McMansion era was over. But that conclusion may have been premature.

headline: Beyond 3-D Printers’ Magic, Possible Legal Wrangling
abstract: In a new paper, two law professors warn that the rise of three-dimensional printing could set off lawsuits like those seen over music file-sharing.
lead_paragraph: When reports first appeared that computers could produce three-dimensional objects — from toys to auto parts to household items — it sounded like a page from a science fiction novel.

headline: Invasion of the Annual Reviews
abstract: Some companies are turning to more rigid evaluations of their employees, though others are shunning formal reviews entirely.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know many people who look forward to performance evaluations — on the giving or the receiving side.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 24
abstract: Two stories are vying for the top slot on the Sunday shows this week – the so-called “nuclear option” in the Senate that would limit filibusters, and nuclear talks between Iran and top international diplomats.
lead_paragraph: Two stories are vying for the top slot on the Sunday news shows this week – one about the so-called “nuclear option” in the Senate that would limit filibusters, and the other the nuclear talks between Iran and Western nations. The potential fallout for both issues is equally dominating on the political panels this week, with in-depth discussion from experts on which sides may come out on top.

headline: Finding Greener Pastures for a Career
abstract: An alpaca farmer on Martha’s Vineyard says: “My heart belongs to this island and these animals. They are home to me.”

headline: For Chess, a Would-Be White Knight
abstract: A colorful entrepreneur named Andrew Paulson wants to turn chess into the world’s next mass-market spectator sport, complete with commentators who dissect the action and show potential moves.
lead_paragraph: If chess were storytelling, Andrew Paulson would be the undisputed world champion, the Bobby Fischer of raconteurs.

headline: Pittsburgh Center Honoring Playwright Finds Itself Short on Visitors and Donors
abstract: The $42 million August Wilson Center for African American Culture appears to be a victim of mismanagement by its senior staff and board of directors, who failed to find a wide enough audience and donor base.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The bank has sued to foreclose. The city’s philanthropic groups, with names like Mellon and Heinz, have withdrawn support. The $42 million August Wilson Center for African American Culture, a bow-front building inspired by a Swahili sailing ship, is high and dry.

headline: Two Gunshots on a Summer Night
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The death of a woman in Florida, and the flawed investigation that ruled it a suicide, raise concerns about how police departments handle accusations of domestic violence that involve officers.
lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — News of the shooting arrived via police radio as Deputy Debra Maynard and two other officers were sipping late-night coffee at the Hess gas station, a brightly lit outpost on a slumbering stretch of Dixie Highway on St. Augustine’s south side.

headline: Departments Slow to Police Their Own Abusers
keywords: ['Police', 'Domestic Violence', 'Gun Control', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The International Association of Chiefs of Police promotes model rules regarding domestic violence, but agencies have been slow to adopt them.
lead_paragraph: When the police chief in Tacoma, Wash., shot and killed his wife in a parking lot after years of abusing her, the shock from that event 10 years ago mobilized national support for a more aggressive response to domestic violence in police households.

headline: How Black Friday Got Its Start
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: The history of “black” days of the week has generally been dour, a far cry from today’s day of joyous commercial excess and great deals.
lead_paragraph: The word “black” in front of a day of the week has almost never meant anything good.

abstract: For all the sophisticated algorithms involved in same-day delivery, many of the services ultimately come down to the delivery guy.
lead_paragraph: There’s a hot new job in tech: delivery guy.

abstract: Olympic curling stones come from rare granite quarried on the island of Ailsa Craig, an uninhabited Scottish island. It can be yours for $2.4 million.

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Today we get to play that game we all know and love, “Sing Along with Gary and Will.”

abstract: Delegates agreed to the outlines of a system for pledging emissions cuts and supported a new treaty mechanism to tackle the human costs of global warming.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Two weeks of United Nations climate talks ended Saturday with a pair of last-minute deals keeping alive the hope that a global effort can ward off a ruinous rise in temperatures.

headline: Study Suggests Link Between Dread Pirate Roberts and Satoshi Nakamoto
abstract: Two Israeli scientists have written a paper that suggests a link between Ross William Ulbricht, who was recently arrested as the operator of the Internet black market Silk Road, and the anonymous inventor of bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Two Israeli computer scientists say they may have uncovered a puzzling financial link between Ross William Ulbricht, the recently arrested operator of the Internet black market known as the Silk Road, and the secretive inventor of bitcoin, the anonymous online currency, used to make Silk Road purchases.

headline: Pivotal World Title Game Wasn’t the One Played Last
abstract: When Magnus Carlsen won Game 9 in the World Championship series, it became a foregone conclusion that he would grab the title.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Carlsen was crowned champion of the chess world on Friday after the 10th game in his best-of-12 title series with the defending titleholder, Viswanathan Anand. But it was the previous game that basically clinched it for him.

headline: An Unrelenting Crisis
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: At 300,000 one year ago, Syrian refugees now total 2.1 million, and the United Nations predicts their numbers could swell to 3.5 million by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: At 300,000 one year ago, Syrian refugees now total 2.1 million, and the United Nations predicts their numbers could swell to 3.5 million by the end of the year.

headline: Syria Seen as Most Dire Refugee Crisis in a Generation

abstract: The Syrian war has created a refugee crisis bigger than the one unleashed by the Rwandan genocide, and humanitarian groups and governments say they expect it to go on for years.
lead_paragraph: KILIS, Turkey — As the boom of shelling resounded along Turkey’s border with Syria here on a recent afternoon, Zakaria Deeb had nowhere left to run.

keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Demonstrators at a rally in Peshawar on Saturday vowed to stop NATO supply trucks unless the attacks ended.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Thousands of people gathered Saturday in the northwestern city Peshawar to protest American drone strikes inside Pakistani territory and vowed to stop NATO supply trucks unless the attacks stopped.

headline: Captain of Seized Greenpeace Ship Speaks From Russia
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The American captain said the Russian commandos who boarded the ship in September were coldly professional at first, but then plundered the crew’s alcohol supply.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian commandos who boarded a Greenpeace ship in the Arctic two months ago were coldly professional at first, pointing automatic weapons at terrified crew members and forcing them to kneel.

headline: Adrienne Asch, Bioethicist and Pioneer in Disability Studies, Dies at 67
abstract: Professor Asch was a vocal opponent of prenatal testing and abortion to select children free of disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Adrienne Asch, an internationally known bioethicist who opposed the use of prenatal testing and abortion to select children free of disabilities, a stance informed partly by her own experience of blindness, died on Nov. 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

headline: The Delivery Showdown
abstract: A business reporter for The Times tests eBay’s new same-day delivery service.
lead_paragraph: A business reporter for The Times tests eBay’s new same-day delivery service.

headline: Don’t Dare Call the Health Law ‘Redistribution’

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rebecca M. Blank was a top candidate in 2011 to lead President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, but then the White House turned up something politically dangerous.

headline: Are You Sitting Down? On a Couch?
abstract: Readers post their comments on my column about flame retardants lurking in our couches.
lead_paragraph: If you typically read the Sunday paper on a couch, you might want to move before reading my Sunday column. Your couch probably has flame retardants embedded in the foam, theoretically to prevent fires. In fact, flame retardants don’t help much with fire prevention (although they do rack up $5 billion in sales for chemical companies that make flame retardants).

headline: Custody Battle Raises Questions About the Rights of Women
abstract: After a brief affair with the skier Bode Miller left her pregnant, a former firefighter moved across the country, prompting a battle over parental rights and legal jurisdiction.
lead_paragraph: When Bode Miller, the Olympic ski star known for daring Alpine racing, met Sara A. McKenna in San Diego last year through the high-end matchmaker Kelleher International, they were both professing interest in finding a marriage partner, she recalls.

abstract: Prince Amukamara has emerged as the Giants’ best cover cornerback and several injuries have forced Trumaine McBride into the other starting cornerback post.

headline: Women in Domestic Slavery Case Lived in a ‘Collective’ With Suspect, Police Say
abstract: Two of three women who say they were held for 30 years in a London home had lived in a group with a suspect in the case, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Two of three women who say they were held as domestic slaves for 30 years in a London home had previously lived in a political “collective” with a suspect in the case, a police commander leading the investigation said on Saturday.

headline: Week 12 Matchup: Jets (5-5) at Ravens (4-6)
abstract: The task of thwarting Baltimore’s dynamic pass rushers falls to D’Brickashaw Ferguson and Austin Howard, who are coming off one of the worst performances by the Jets’ line this season.

headline: Ticket Led by Women Shows Where Democrats Pin Hopes
abstract: With Wendy Davis and Leticia Van de Putte running for governor and lieutenant governor, the Democrats are depending in part on female voters for a Texas turnaround.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Leticia Van de Putte’s announcement on Saturday that she is running for lieutenant governor, adding a second woman to a ticket led by State Senator Wendy Davis, is enhancing Texas Democrats’ hopes that they could see their first statewide victory since 1994.

headline: What Ethnic Diversity Looks Like: Fort Bend
abstract: Fort Bend has been called the most ethnically diverse county in America, with a population that comes close to an equal division among blacks, whites, Asians and Latinos.
lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND — Nikhil Sabharwal of Toronto stood outside a hotel, next to a cart piled with luggage, holding a tall stick decorated with gold garland, a bhangra dance prop from an Indian wedding he had attended here. Steps away, at a coffee shop, a woman wearing a hijab sat near the spot where, minutes earlier, Lynne Gabriel, a fashion blogger of Filipino descent, had posed for photos for her website.

headline: A Traditionalist and an Upstart, Both Powerful
abstract: John Cornyn and Ted Cruz, the Republican senators from Texas, differ in style, how they got to Washington and, sometimes, ideology. By contrasting paths, though, they have gained immense influence.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: The Kimbell’s Stylish, Sustainable New Addition
abstract: The Kimbell Art Museum’s new addition, the Renzo Piano Pavilion, bears the name of its architect and demonstrates the happy coexistence of sustainability and physical beauty.
lead_paragraph: The architect behind the expansion of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth is so famous that his name has been affixed to the project like a brand: the addition, which will be unveiled on Wednesday, is called the Renzo Piano Pavilion.

headline: Selling That New-Man Feeling
abstract: Tired? Listless? Testosterone therapy is in fashion, but critics say it’s based on unclear science — and driven by marketing.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon a few months ago, a 45-year-old sales representative named Mike called “The Dr. Harry Fisch Show,” a weekly men’s health program on the Howard Stern channel on Sirius XM Radio, where no male medical or sexual issue goes unexplored.

headline: Yankees Are Said to Be Near $85 Million Deal for Braves’ McCann
abstract: Moving to close an infield void, the Yankees are said to be close to signing catcher Brian McCann to a five-year deal.
lead_paragraph: With uncertainty about all their infielders, the Yankees acted Saturday to solidify their catching position, agreeing in principle with Brian McCann on a five-year deal worth more than $82.5 million.

headline: Badgers Add to Streak, Shutting Down Rivals
abstract: Wisconsin’s defense forced a season-high three turnovers and limited Minnesota to 185 yards, helping the Badgers win Paul Bunyan’s Axe for the 10th straight year.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — All week, Minnesota Coach Jerry Kill had warned his players about Wisconsin’s new-look defense. The 3-4 base installed by the defensive coordinator Dave Aranda, whom the first-year head coach Gary Andersen had brought with him from Utah State, made the Badgers unique in the Big Ten and even more formidable than usual, Kill said.

headline: Suspect Charged in Attack on Jewish Man in Brooklyn
abstract: Prosecutors said the attack was connected to a game in which assailants try to knock victims out with one punch, but a lawyer for the suspect said his client had never heard of the game.
lead_paragraph: An attack on a Jewish man in Brooklyn on Friday morning was not connected to the so-called Knockout Game, where assailants try to knock someone out with one punch, a lawyer for the man charged in the case said on Saturday. But prosecutors said the victim heard the suspect, Amrit Marajh, 28, of Brooklyn, and his friends talking about the game. During the altercation, prosecutors said, Mr. Marajh said to the victim, “I’ll knock you out.”

headline: West Looms as Knicks Keep Going South
abstract: The Knicks’ struggles continued and this time, they could not contain Washington’s high-octane point guard, John Wall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Coach Mike Woodson spoke with Carmelo Anthony for a few minutes after Friday’s practice. There was no great significance to the meeting, according to Woodson, who always looks for opportunities to chat with his players. But with Anthony, who has endured more downs than ups this season, Woodson said he felt it was important “just to see where his head was.”

headline: College Football Around the Country
abstract: Teams, players and games that stood out in the thirteenth week of college football.
lead_paragraph: JERICK MCKINNON The Georgia Southern quarterback ran for a late 14-yard touchdown, helping the visiting Eagles stun Florida, 26-20, for the Gators’ first loss to a Football Championship Subdivision team. McKinnon finished with 125 yards rushing.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 23, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Step, if Modest, Toward Slowing Iran’s Weapons Capability
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: The interim deal brings the Obama administration a step closer to its ultimate goal: lengthening the time it takes Iran to build a weapon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The interim accord struck with Iran on Sunday interrupts the country’s nuclear progress for the first time in nearly a decade, but requires Iran to make only a modest down payment on the central problem.

headline: Sleep Therapy Is Expected to Gain a Wider Role in Depression Treatment
abstract: Scientists say that cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia can double the likelihood of recovery, and powerfully complement antidepressant drugs.
lead_paragraph: An insomnia therapy that scientists just reported could double the effectiveness of depression treatment is not widely available nor particularly well understood by psychiatrists or the public. The American Board of Sleep Medicine has certified just 400 practitioners in the United States to administer it, and they are sparse, even in big cities.

abstract: Top-ranked Michigan State withstood a hot start and a late charge by Oklahoma to win the championship game of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Top-ranked Michigan State looked shaky Saturday but withstood a hot start and a late charge by Oklahoma to dispel any upset fantasies with an 87-76 victory in the championship game of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic at Barclays Center.

headline: In a Powerful Comeback, Pacquiao Batters Rios Through 12 Rounds
abstract: A one-sided bout left Brandon Rios swollen and bloodied and was likely to quiet the calls for Manny Pacquiao’s retirement.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — Say this for Brandon Rios: he hardly ever backed away.

headline: Oklahoma State Ends Baylor’s Unbeaten Run
abstract: Baylor’s hope for an unbeaten season crumbled against Oklahoma State’s defense, which held the Bears’ offense to a field goal in the first half.
lead_paragraph: STILLWATER, Okla. — The snap was low and left of Baylor quarterback Bryce Petty and bounded hard down the frigid field. Cornerback Tyler Patmon finally scooped it up, and as he raced 78 yards for a touchdown, he raised his hand to his face mask, as though hushing any talk that Oklahoma State’s trouncing of Baylor was an upset.

headline: In South Korea, Delays Drag a Project to Build Homegrown Fighter Jets

lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Facing the threat of North Korea and feeling squeezed by China and Japan on its flanks, South Korea has always dreamed of a “self-reliant” defense force.

headline: Elders Back Security Pact That Karzai Won’t Sign
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Leaders who had gathered in Kabul asked President Hamid Karzai on Sunday to sign the agreement promptly, but Mr. Karzai said that he wanted to continue negotiations.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An angry President Hamid Karzai, at times openly hostile to his American allies, on Sunday rejected the final recommendation of a four-day Afghan grand assembly that he should promptly sign a security agreement with the United States.

headline: Israeli Leaders Denounce Geneva Accord
abstract: Officials said that they were not bound by the agreement on Iran’s nuclear program and that Israel would be ready to defend itself without assistance from allies.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Having failed to stop Sunday’s signing of a nuclear deal between Iran and six Western powers despite a relentless campaign of criticism, Israeli leaders say their mission now is to ensure that, as several put it, this first step is not the last step.

headline: Far From My Tree
abstract: I wish my musician son would go to college. But that’s what I want for him. That’s not what he wants for himself.
lead_paragraph: My eldest son is 20 years old, lives in a house crammed with seven scrabbly roommates, works part time in a restaurant kitchen, doesn’t drive, is a vegetarian, and has homemade tattoos etched into his thighs.

lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Tens of thousands of people marched through downtown Kiev on Sunday to protest the government’s decision last week to abandon far-reaching political and free trade agreements with the European Union and instead focus on improving economic ties with Russia.

lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry offered a robust defense of the interim nuclear agreement with Iran on Sunday, rejecting comparisons to North Korea and insisting that the deal would make Israel and Persian Gulf allies of the United States more secure, not less so.

headline: Police in India Plan to Question Editor Over Sexual Assault Accusation
abstract: Police officials from Goa are investigating whether the editor, Tarun Tejpal, an anticorruption crusader, sexually assaulted a colleague.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Police officials from the coastal state of Goa in India were expected to question the magazine editor Tarun Tejpal on Sunday to investigate charges that Mr. Tejpal, a prominent anticorruption crusader, had sexually assaulted a staff journalist in a hotel elevator.

headline: Already Anticipating ‘Terminator’ Ethics
abstract: Amid rapid advances encouraged and funded by the Pentagon, roboticists are facing questions about the purposes of what they are designing.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — What could possibly go wrong?

abstract: While opinion polls showed widespread dismay about huge executive paychecks, many Swiss were uncomfortable with a rigid, government-imposed salary cap.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Despite opinion polls showing widespread dismay about huge executive paychecks, Swiss voters on Sunday rejected severe limits on executive pay.

headline: New Cape Town Museum to Focus on Contemporary African Art
abstract: The institution will be known as the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa, in honor of the German art collector Jochen Zeitz, who is providing the museum’s founding collection.
lead_paragraph: A new museum that will house the largest collection of contemporary African art on the continent, will open in 2016 in the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront in Cape Town, it was announced last week.

headline: Praise in Iran All the Way to the Top, Where Efforts Reportedly Preceded a President
abstract: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who is said to have allowed secret preliminary talks, called the deal a success and praised the Iranian negotiators.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The smiling started early in Tehran on Sunday, when President Hassan Rouhani kissed a young schoolgirl in an Islamic head scarf before dozens of cameras, signaling that Iran’s future had taken a new turn.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) CAROL BURNETT: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Ms. Burnett, the 16th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony, taped Oct. 20. In addition to 11 years as the host and earlobe-tugging star of her CBS variety show, Ms. Burnett, above, has appeared in the films “Annie” and “Noises Off,” the television show “Glee” and the Broadway musical “Once Upon a Mattress.” She has also written three best sellers, including her autobiography “One More Time,” and received 12 People’s Choice Awards, eight Golden Globes, six Emmy Awards, a Horatio Alger Award, a Peabody Award and an Ace Award. She was also given the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President George W. Bush in 2006, was named a Kennedy Center honoree in 2003 and was inducted into the Television Hall of Fame in 1985. Among the friends and colleagues cheering her here are Julie Andrews, Lucie Arnaz, Tony Bennett, Tim Conway, Tina Fey, Rashida Jones, Vicki Lawrence, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Martin Short and Rosemary Watson. “I can’t believe I’m getting a humor prize from the Kennedy Center,” Ms. Burnett said when learned she would receive the distinction. “It’s almost impossible to be funnier than the people in Washington.”

headline: If Only the Pants Fit Right
abstract: “Lies My Father Told Me,” a musical adapted from a film of the same name, is a coming-of-age story of a Jewish boy in Montreal.
lead_paragraph: The 1975 Canadian movie “Lies My Father Told Me” was a charmer. A coming-of-age story by Ted Allan, about his early-20th-century poverty-saturated Jewish childhood in Montreal, the film was an Oscar nominee even. And now it’s a musical.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s foreign minister on Sunday refused to recognize China’s newly claimed air defense zone over disputed islands, signaling that Japan would not back down as tensions increased in the maritime dispute.
