headline: Longer-Term Deal With Iran Faces Major Challenges
abstract: The six-month interim plan agreed to over the weekend is intended to allow time to pursue a more comprehensive deal on Iran’s nuclear program, one that will require much tougher choices by each side.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Obama administration’s successful push for an accord that would temporarily freeze much of Iran’s nuclear program has cast a spotlight on the more formidable challenge it now confronts in trying to roll the program back.

headline: Vettel Adds Brazil to His Winning Streak
abstract: German driver ends Formula One season by collecting ninth victory in a row and gaining his 13th triumph of the season.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO — The ear-shattering, screaming orchestra of 22 of the world’s most powerful normally-aspirated, 2.4 liter, V8 engines howled around a Formula One racetrack for the last time in competition on Sunday.

headline: Patriotic Hold Music
abstract: Obamacare faces the Muzak.
lead_paragraph: Via Josh Marshall: While John Boehner was staging his publicity stunt, supposedly demonstrating that it was impossible to sign up for Obamacare, a representative of the DC health exchange was trying to reach his office to complete the transaction. After 35 minutes on hold, listening to “patriotic hold music“, the representative gave up.

headline: Obama on the Iran Accord
abstract: President Obama hailed the agreement reached on Nov. 24 between six world powers and Iran on its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: President Obama hailed the agreement reached on Nov. 24 between six world powers and Iran on its nuclear program.

headline: Bid Farewell to Memories Forever Present
abstract: “Regular Singing,” the final installment of Richard Nelson’s Apple Family cycle of plays, takes place on the day of the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination.
lead_paragraph: Like many an American of a certain age, Barbara Apple found herself on Friday trying to reconstruct exactly what happened on that Friday a half-century earlier when President John F. Kennedy was killed. Her tools of investigation weren’t copies of the Zapruder tapes or charts that graphed a bullet’s trajectory.

headline: My Lawn Guyland Roots Are Showing (Silly)
abstract: Metal, medal, meddle, whatever.
lead_paragraph: I see that some commentators were wondering why, in an earlier post, I wrote “pedal to the medal” instead of “pedal to the metal”. The answer is, typing fast, and writing what I heard in my head. The truth is that sometimes, usually when I’m tired, I do hear myself referring to a bottle of water as a boddle of oo-waugh-duh — gotta get the three-syllable pronunciation there.

headline: A Bandleader Pulls Teachable Moments From Afro-Latin Crosscurrents of Jazz
abstract: Bobby Sanabria’s Multiverse Big Band had its first extended engagement at a major New York jazz club.
lead_paragraph: “Whoever told you mambo died in the 1950s hasn’t been paying attention,” Bobby Sanabria inveighed from behind a drum kit. He was closely surrounded by 18 other musicians. Directly behind him stood the singer and percussionist Hiram Remón. Inches to his right, sat the conga player Orestes Abrantes, wearing earplugs to protect himself against Mr. Sanabria’s crash cymbal.

headline: Jets’ Dreams Crash Into Harsh Reality in Loss to Ravens
abstract: Geno Smith was ineffective, the offense could not convert on third down and the secondary yielded two deep completions as the Jets bungled their way to a second consecutive loss.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Justin Tucker, the Ravens’ kicker, lined up for a 26-yard field goal Sunday. The snap was solid. The hold was, too. And when he booted the ball through the uprights, the scoreboard at M&T Bank Stadium might as well have flashed: “Ravens Win! Ravens Win!”

headline: Traveling With John Brown Along the Road to Literary Celebrity
abstract: James McBride, the surprise winner of the National Book Award for “The Good Lord Bird,” was instantly elevated to a level of literary celebrity that he has yet to enjoy throughout a long career in writing.
lead_paragraph: James McBride was so sure that his novel “The Good Lord Bird” was not going to win the National Book Award that in the final moments before the prize was announced last Wednesday at a black-tie dinner in Manhattan, he barely looked up from his plate of apple mille-feuille.

headline: Bridging Playboy and Activist
abstract: “Gori Tere Pyaar Mein,” a Hindi musical, concerns the divide between a playboy architect (Imran Khan) and an activist (Kareena Kapoor), and a construction project that unites them.
lead_paragraph: The star of the new Hindi musical romance “Gori Tere Pyaar Mein,” Imran Khan, uncannily resembles a combination of Vince Vaughn and Cary Grant in his portrayal of the self-centered playboy, Sriram. With his classically handsome yet rounded face and his cocksure swagger, Mr. Khan seems to meld those two actors physically. The character he plays, an architect who is reminiscing to his fiancée (Shraddha Kapoor) about a past romance with a feisty activist named Dia (Kareena Kapoor, no relation to Shraddha), is also like Grant at his most roguishly charming and Mr. Vaughn at his most frustratingly caddish.

headline: Defying Conventional Wisdom at a Florida Regional
abstract: The axioms of the game are intended to guide less experienced players, although a primary reason bridge retains its worldwide appeal is that there are so many exceptions to these “rules.”
lead_paragraph: The axioms of the game are intended to guide less experienced players, although a primary reason bridge retains its worldwide appeal is that there are so many exceptions to these “rules.”

headline: Solemn Day Recalled by Strings and Heartstrings
abstract: The Dallas Symphony and the Brentano String Quartet were among the performers commemorating the anniversary of the John F. Kennedy assassination.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — One casualty of the cold front that swept through here on Thursday night was music.

headline: Meeting Village Ostracism With Repressed Rage
abstract: David Robertson, conducting the St. Louis Symphony and Chorus and an ideal cast of singers headed by the superb tenor Anthony Dean Griffey, led an extraordinary concert performance of “Peter Grimes.”
lead_paragraph: In the penultimate scene of Britten’s opera “Peter Grimes,” vengeance grips the townspeople of the Borough, a fishing village on the east coast of England. The strange, volatile Grimes, a fisherman and loner who disdains the gossipy talk of “interferers,” as he calls practically everyone, has disappeared, and there is no trace of the boy who had been working, miserably, as Grimes’s apprentice. The residents suspect that for the second time Grimes is responsible for the death of an apprentice. This is not just mob psychology. There are telltale clues: the boy’s jersey has washed ashore, and Grimes has a history of abuse.

headline: Graham Rarities Demonstrate Their Impact Beyond Explanations
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company, participating in the Performa 13 festival, staged two works, “Hérodiade” and “Spectre — 1914,” that suggest Surrealism’s influence on Graham.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the Martha Graham Dance Company has made an effort to set the work of its founder in context with themed programming and spoken introductions. Sometimes helpful in offering entrances to forbidding and foreign-seeming terrain, these strategies also tend to focus attention on our distance from the context in which Graham’s work spoke for itself, our sad separation from the great artist who required no introduction.

headline: Knicks’ Chris Smith Starts Anew Amid Accusations of Nepotism
abstract: Playing with the Erie BayHawks, a Development League team, Chris Smith has an opportunity to show Knicks fans that he belongs in the N.B.A. because of his skills, not his brother.
lead_paragraph: ERIE, Pa. — On the first shot of his professional basketball career, Chris Smith, the younger brother of J. R. Smith, took a handoff, squared up, dribbled left with a defender on his hip, elevated and fired. The ball clanged off the side of the rim. Beyond the hoop, two inflatable playhouses shook with children bouncing inside.

headline: For a Hero, Being Flat Can Have Its Advantages
abstract: In the Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds, the protagonist can meld onto flat surfaces.
lead_paragraph: A boy named Link has a sword, a shield and pounds of perseverance. In his world, no problem is unsolvable.

headline: ‘Catching Fire’ Wins at Weekend Box Office
abstract: The second installment of the “Hunger Games” franchise set a November box-office record with its opening weekend in North America.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The “Hunger Games” movie franchise became a full-fledged cultural phenomenon over the weekend, broadening its appeal by age and by gender with its second installment, and setting a November box-office record.

headline: Nets’ Lethargy Spreads: Even Boos Lack Vigor
abstract: A broken record of frustration drones on for the Nets, whose lackadaisical loss to the Pistons was their fifth straight loss and their eighth in nine games.
lead_paragraph: Asked early Sunday afternoon to characterize the tone in the Nets’ organization, Billy King was succinct. “It’s frustration,” he said.

headline: Hercules and the Rival Studios
abstract: Two big-budget movies about the mythological figure, from different studios, are scheduled for release next year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A herculean custody battle is simmering in Hollywood.

headline: A Randy Royal in Britain Survived Mum’s Shadow
abstract: Jane Ridley’s “Heir Apparent” is a welcome new biography of Edward VII, who succeeded Queen Victoria on the British throne.
lead_paragraph: In her welcome new biography of Edward VII, who succeeded Queen Victoria on the British throne, Jane Ridley explains how this firstborn son managed to spend time in court — and not the kind of court royalty is supposed to frequent. Bertie, as this Prince of Wales was familiarly known for the first 59 years of his life, was a renowned crinoline chaser, and many efforts were made to keep his name out of matrimonial cases. Nevertheless, he ended up on the witness stand when Charles Mordaunt, who had been so angry at his wife for having male visitors that he shot her ponies, petitioned for divorce.

headline: Half Siblings Linked by a Mystery Father
abstract: In “Generation Cryo,” half siblings — all offspring of a sperm-donor father — find one another.
lead_paragraph: Single mothers, happily married couples with sterile men, gay couples: They all turned to the California Cryobank in the early 1990s to buy what they couldn’t provide on their own. And they were successful, conceiving children with the sperm that came in the mail in an ice-cold tank.

headline: In Quest to Revive Goaltending Career, DiPietro Views Obscurity as an Ally
abstract: Goalie Rick DiPietro, who did not meet expectations after signing a $67.5 million contract with the Islanders, has struggled in the A.H.L. but is happy to be out of the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN TRAIL, N.C. — The Long Island mansion that Rick DiPietro bought in the heyday of his career with the Islanders is on the market. These days, he is downsizing. Home, for now, is a room at a Residence Inn in suburban Charlotte, N.C., a place where hockey is about as popular as surfing in Winnipeg.

headline: Mario Tries to Rescue His Console
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Wii (Video Game System)', '3-D Devices and Effects']
abstract: The Wii U console has been slow to catch on after a year, but Super Mario 3D World could make it popular.
lead_paragraph: I now have the brand-new Sony PlayStation 4 and Microsoft’s even newer Xbox One under my television set, but I spent the weekend with the Nintendo Wii U instead.

headline: Start of a Bumper Sticker
abstract: The sign of things to come, with Kevin G. Der.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you drive where I drive, you spend a lot of time sitting in bumper-to-bumper traffic, and the only decent reading material while you’re waiting to take your foot off the brake is often the rear bumper of the car ahead of you. That’s after you take note of the car owner’s family make up, which is prominently displayed on the window (Father sticker, mother sticker, various and sundry children and pets, etc.)

headline: Top Editor at Mental Floss Has Some Spicy Credentials
abstract: The facts and trivia magazine announced last week that Jessanne Collins, a former editor at Playgirl, was promoted to editor in chief.
lead_paragraph: To the underpaid, well-educated magazine scribes hoping for a break in an industry with little growth opportunity, there is hope.

headline: Bloomberg’s Empire
abstract: The financial data and news company Bloomberg L.P. is three times as large as it was when Michael R. Bloomberg left to become mayor of New York City twelve years ago. As he prepares to leave office, the organization is at a crossroads.
lead_paragraph: The financial data and news company Bloomberg L.P. is three times as large as it was when Michael R. Bloomberg left to become mayor of New York City twelve years ago. As he prepares to leave office, the organization is at a crossroads.

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)']
abstract: An American Airlines bankruptcy ruling, and a looming deadline for the federal health insurance website.
lead_paragraph: SHOPPING SEASON Thanksgiving week is one of the biggest and busiest weeks of the year for retailers. More than 139 million people shopped from Thursday through Sunday of Thanksgiving week last year, according to the National Retail Federation. Traditionally, the holiday shopping season begins on Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving, but this year many retailers will be open and offering deals on Thanksgiving Day, including Macy’s, J. C. Penney and Toys ‘R’ Us.

headline: Netanyahu on Nuclear Accord with Iran
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said his country was not bound by the nuclear deal between global powers and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said his country was not bound by the nuclear deal between global powers and Iran.

headline: Iran’s Online Diplomacy Discomfits Israel
abstract: Iran’s new embrace of public diplomacy, which helped pave the way for a deal over its nuclear program, has closed a previously wide gap to Israel.
lead_paragraph: As Sweden’s foreign minister, Carl Bildt, noted in the wake of the interim deal on Iran’s nuclear program reached in Geneva on Saturday, the effort by Tehran’s negotiating team to explain and justify the country’s push for atomic energy behind closed doors was accompanied by a public diplomacy campaign conducted online.

abstract: A law professor says pardons should be used more liberally to counter draconian sentences. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Merkel’s Quest for Consensus
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel still lacks a new coalition government two months after winning re-election, and patience is wearing perilously thin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — More than two months after she triumphed in national elections, Chancellor Angela Merkel still has no new government. Even in a nation attuned to much political theater before dueling parties reach consensus, patience is wearing perilously thin.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Two of the West’s Best
abstract: The Thunder and the Spurs, who will play in Oklahoma City on Wednesday, are ranked in the top 10 in offensive and defensive efficiency.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Grimm ‘Snow White’ Coming to Lincoln Center
abstract: The Joyce Theater Foundation plans to announce on Monday that it will present the New York premiere of “Snow White” with choreography by Angelin Preljocaj.
lead_paragraph: The Joyce Theater Foundation plans to announce on Monday that it will present the New York premiere of “Snow White” with choreography by Angelin Preljocaj. Performed by Mr. Preljocaj’s French dance company, Ballet Preljocaj, and based on the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, not the 1937 animated Disney film, the production is scheduled for a six-performance run from April 23 to 27 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. Mr. Preljocaj recently choreographed a new work for the New York City Ballet and Ballet Preljocaj completed a run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music during its Next Wave Festival this month.

headline: Once Cable’s King, Malone Aims to Regain His Crown
abstract: John C. Malone, the chairman of Liberty Media, is working behind the scenes to gain control of Time Warner Cable, seeking a second act in an industry he once dominated.
lead_paragraph: John C. Malone made a fortune wiring American homes for cable television in the 1980s and 1990s. Known as the King of Cable, he sold TCI — once the country’s largest cable operator — to AT&T for $48 billion in 1999.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 25
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Shazam Deal Aims to Tie Songs Fast to Products
abstract: Marketers are only now beginning to deploy music as a very direct conduit to the things they sell, but a deal between an audio-recognition app and the Mindshare agency is a step forward.
lead_paragraph: The choice of song has long been critical to a commercial’s success — think Volkswagen and Nick Drake’s “Pink Moon” back in 1999, or, more recently, Fiona Apple singing “Pure Imagination” in a stirring Chipotle ad.

headline: Triplets’ Arrival Was Joyful, but Also Strained Family
abstract: Tiffany Knox-Floyd and Wendell Floyd grapple with unemployment even as they scramble to feed, clothe and provide for four children.
lead_paragraph: The story of Tiffany Knox-Floyd and Wendell Floyd began eight years ago, in a scene straight out of a romantic comedy.

headline: Iowa in the Amazon
abstract: How we increase the global food supply over the next few decades will determine agriculture’s sustainability.
lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, one of my graduate students showed me a Google Earth image that changed my view of the world. On a photo showing all of South America, I could clearly see a single soybean farm in the Brazilian state of Mato Grosso. My first thought was that a farm that big, sitting on the edge of the Amazon, must be an environmental disaster. But when it comes to agricultural sustainability, all is not what it seems.

headline: The Weinstein Company, Seeking Hits, Shifts to TV
abstract: The heavy investment in the production and sale of TV series mirrors changes occurring elsewhere in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Oscar season approaches fever pitch, Harvey Weinstein, master of the movie awards game, is talking about ... television.

headline: The Untold Story of Military Sexual Assault
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: When institutions like the military do not validate the experience of the rape survivor, the perpetrators get to continue their criminal behavior without consequence.
lead_paragraph: IT was 1974, and I was 19 years old, serving in the United States Air Force, and I thought I was the only one.

headline: Relaxing China’s One-Child Policy
abstract: The Chinese government announced that it will ease restrictions on the number of children couples can have.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government announced that it will ease restrictions on the number of children couples can have.

headline: Fred Kavli, Benefactor of Science Prizes, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Kavli, a California physicist raised in Norway, established $1 million awards and 17 institutes that finance university research.
lead_paragraph: Fred Kavli, a physicist who left Norway for California as a young man and made millions manufacturing sensors for appliances, automobiles and aircraft, then late in life began donating much of his fortune to science, establishing a major prize he intended to rival the Nobel, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Life Inside a PlayStation
abstract: Would a law providing for treatment of Internet gaming addiction actually help players to recover?
lead_paragraph: BUSAN, South Korea — In October 2012, my wife and I arrived in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bushwick and unpacked our suitcases. We had ended a two-year stay in New York and flown back to Korea in June, but returned to America for five weeks to promote the publication of my novel “Black Flower” in English.

headline: In Urban War for Peace and Quiet, Soundproofers Are Busier Than Ever
abstract: In an effort to muffle the throbbing and thundering New York City soundtrack, noise specialists are busier than ever as residents search for quiet.
lead_paragraph: Erez Zohar was desperate. The neighbors’ air-conditioners outside his $1.2 million condo hummed and rattled around the clock through the summer and into the fall. His patio, larger than the living room, was unusable. Nights with the windows open were impossible.

headline: Whales and Anchovies
abstract: A spike in the anchovy population in California's Monterey Bay has made for exciting wildlife viewing as humpback whales, dolphins, sea lions and pelicans swarm to feed on the small fish.
lead_paragraph: A spike in the anchovy population in California's Monterey Bay has made for exciting wildlife viewing as humpback whales, dolphins, sea lions and pelicans swarm to feed on the small fish.

headline: Developers Draft Casino Plans, Signaling Fight for New York’s Licenses
abstract: Early signs suggest there will be a fight — even if the scale of some of the proposals is modest, and Las Vegas companies remain on the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: Aspiring casino developers are proposing ice-skating rinks and championship golf courses. They are promising fashionable restaurants and cocktail bars. And they are working to arrange the financing to pay for it all.

headline: Overlook the Value of Interns at Great Peril
abstract: Some major publishers are dropping their unpaid internship programs in the face of complaints, but they might be missing the point.
lead_paragraph: Last week, The New York Post ran the kind of heart-rending article tabloids excel at. A young woman, new to New York, found herself pushed beyond what she could bear, forced to work by a big bad corporation for a compensation of exactly zero.

headline: Looking Into the Black Box
abstract: Why is understanding the way the world works valuable in itself, above and beyond the engineering know-how that it brings?
lead_paragraph: Here is something that might be worth selling your soul for: a magic black box that answers accurately any question you have about things to come. Who will be president in four years’ time? At what prices will the stock market close next Friday? What will be the precise position of the planets at midnight on that same day? When will I die?

headline: With Extra Anchovies, Deluxe Whale Watching
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'ANCHOVIES', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: For almost three months, Monterey, Calif., and nearby coastal areas have played host to a mammoth convocation of sea life that local scientists say is unprecedented in their memories.
lead_paragraph: MONTEREY, Calif. — It began with the anchovies, miles and miles of them, their silvery blue bodies thick in the waters of Monterey Bay.

headline: Rake the Leaves? Some Towns Say Mow Them
abstract: Officials in some New York counties say mulching leaves in place improves soil quality, saves municipal transport costs and has other environmental and safety benefits for communities.
lead_paragraph: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y. — They have been burned, blown into piles, raked into bags and generally scorned by homeowners everywhere. Fall leaves — so pretty on the trees, such a nuisance when they hit the ground — have long been a thing to be discarded. But now some suburban towns are asking residents to do something radical: Leave the leaves alone.

headline: Medicaid Expansion Faces Major Logistical Challenges Among the Homeless
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Homeless Persons', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Housing advocates say the Medicaid expansion included in the health care law could reduce homelessness significantly, but there are obstacles to reaching and enrolling homeless people.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a back room at the Franciscan House of Mary and Joseph, one of the largest homeless shelters in Chicago, a social worker named Sheena Ward guided Terry Cannon through a Medicaid application.

headline: Global Reach on Display as L.P.G.A. Ends Year
abstract: As the women’s game becomes more global, with six countries represented in the world top-10 rankings, the competition is becoming deeper and fiercer.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — The winner of the Titleholders on Sunday got to fire a cannon, but before Shanshan Feng of China did the honors, women’s golf sent a loud shot reverberating through the sports landscape.

headline: Drones Offer Journalists a Wider View
abstract: Remotely controlled aircraft have provided valuable images of events that are difficult to reach, including the recent typhoon in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: The best way to film the destruction wrought by Typhoon Haiyan in Tacloban, the Philippines, said Lewis Whyld, a British photographer, was from the air.

headline: As Legal Graffiti Walls Disappear, Street Artists Ponder Future
keywords: ['Graffiti', 'Murals', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Art', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The loss of spaces like those on West Farms Road in the Bronx and 5Pointz in Queens has some painters wondering whether there will be an increase in illegal tagging.
lead_paragraph: The masked artist hovering over the Bronx sidewalk is but a phantom. The cinder block wall on West Farms Road near East 172nd Street, which for years was a gallery of graffiti murals, is gone, too. It has been replaced by a blue wooden barrier festooned with demolition permits and a sign hawking “CHEAP DIVORCE.”

headline: Close Vote Raises Tensions in Honduras
abstract: Hondurans went to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president at the end of a long campaign that has cracked open the ossified politics of one of Latin America’s poorest countries.
lead_paragraph: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Honduras appeared headed toward days of political tension Sunday as the two leading candidates each declared they had won the presidency.

headline: In Bitcoin’s Orbit: Rival Virtual Currencies Vie for Acceptance
abstract: Bitcoin is not alone. The virtual universe has spawned a few dozen alternatives, with varying reserves, computer mining requirements and privacy.
lead_paragraph: For many people, bitcoin seems like something from the day after tomorrow.

headline: Inmate Dies After Falling Down Stairs at Manhattan Court
abstract: Officials are investigating how Apolinar C. Solis, a Rikers inmate facing a drug charge last week, fatally fell inside the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building.
lead_paragraph: After spending a month in custody on Rikers Island, Apolinar C. Solis arrived at the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building last Wednesday to appear before a judge on charges of drug possession.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: According to Experian Marketing Services, shoppers anticipating Black Friday deals drove searches up 232 percent in the week that ended Nov. 16, compared with the same period in 2012.
lead_paragraph: According to Experian Marketing Services, shoppers anticipating Black Friday deals drove searches up 232 percent in the week that ended Nov. 16, compared with the same period in 2012.

headline: Bitcoin Believers
abstract: While regulators debate the pros and cons of bitcoins, this volatile digital currency inspires the question: What makes money, money?
lead_paragraph: While regulators debate the pros and cons of bitcoins, this volatile digital currency inspires the question: What makes money, money?

headline: California, Here We Come?
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If Obamacare can work in a state of 38 million people, it can work in America as a whole.
lead_paragraph: It goes without saying that the rollout of Obamacare was an epic disaster. But what kind of disaster was it? Was it a failure of management, messing up the initial implementation of a fundamentally sound policy? Or was it a demonstration that the Affordable Care Act is inherently unworkable?

headline: How to Do Right by the Disabled
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Treaties', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Senate can redeem itself by ratifying an international treaty for the disabled.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago the Senate fell five votes short of ratifying an international treaty that would improve protections for the disabled. It was an ignoble spectacle as the opponents rebuffed Bob Dole, a former colleague and disabled veteran, who came to the Senate floor to lobby for it. The Senate now has a chance to redeem itself.

headline: The Changing Mission
keywords: ['Gentrification', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: San Francisco's technology industry is booming. As housing costs increase some worry that the city's colorful neighborhoods, like the Mission, are at risk of losing their character.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco's technology industry is booming. As housing costs increase some worry that the city's colorful neighborhoods, like the Mission, are at risk of losing their character.

headline: Bulls Bluffing Their Way Through the Loss of a Star
abstract: The Bulls looked like a team still reeling from the news that they could be without Derrick Rose for another season in their loss to the Clippers on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tom Thibodeau, who preaches toughness above all else, was not about to get out of character. So as he was asked to contemplate what life would be like for his basketball team without Derrick Rose — again — it did not require much thought.

headline: Signs of Change in News Mission at Bloomberg
abstract: Bloomberg faces newsroom layoffs, a shift in emphasis back to financial news and skepticism from the business side that investigative journalism might not be worth the potential problems it could create for terminal sales.
lead_paragraph: Champagne flowed last Monday night as Hong Kong’s business elite gathered with top Bloomberg L.P. executives at a dinner for 100 guests at a cultural center in a former British colonial military complex.

headline: Little Rock Moves On
abstract: Litigation in one of the most explosive desegregation struggles in the country may be nearing an end.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court ordered an end to racial segregation in public schools in 1954, there was no foretelling what its mandate for integration “with all deliberate speed” would come to mean. In Little Rock, Ark., the site in 1957 of one of the most explosive desegregation struggles, it has come to mean decades of litigation that may now be nearing an end.

headline: Technology Boom Breeds Hostility
keywords: ['Gentrification', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Resentment toward San Francisco’s tech workers has grown as many blame them for soaring housing prices and widening income disparities.
lead_paragraph: Resentment toward San Francisco’s tech workers has grown as many blame them for soaring housing prices and widening income disparities.

headline: Backlash by the Bay: Tech Riches Alter a City
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gentrification', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Affordable Housing', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: As the largess from tech companies has flowed into San Francisco, some residents say their workers are driving up housing prices and spoiling the city’s bohemian identity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If there was a tipping point, a moment that crystallized the anger building here toward the so-called technorati for driving up housing prices and threatening the city’s bohemian identity, it came in response to a diatribe posted online in August by a young Internet entrepreneur.

headline: Under Pressure, N.C.A.A. Weighs Momentous Changes
abstract: Court cases involving concussions and the paying of student-athletes, and calls for changes in the organization’s structure and practices, could drastically alter college sports.
lead_paragraph: After years of stalemate, uncertainty and bureaucratic delay, the N.C.A.A. is facing the possibility of seismic change on multiple fronts that could reshape the world of college sports.

headline: Conrad Susa, 78, Composer and Teacher, Dies
abstract: Mr. Susa, the writer of five operas, showed wide range even while hewing to the classical.
lead_paragraph: Conrad Susa, a composer for the voice, for the theater and for the operatic stage, where voice and theater converge, died on Nov. 21 at his home in San Francisco. He was 78.

headline: Sticking by a Murderous Brother, and Paying for It Dearly
abstract: William Bulger was a lawyer, a powerful politician and a university president, but he is likely to be remembered for his refusal to inform on his brother, James (Whitey) Bulger.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For more than 40 years, power and influence fit William M. Bulger like a tailored suit, and his résumé expanded with accomplishment: up from the projects to become a lawyer, the longest-serving president of the State Senate, the president of the University of Massachusetts, a consummate Democratic power broker and a cultural lion in Boston.

headline: Nuclear Accord With Iran Opens Diplomatic Doors in the Mideast
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The preliminary accord reached with Iran is a seminal moment for President Obama, but experts say seeking a broader diplomatic opening could alter other American calculations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, whose popularity and second-term agenda have been ravaged by the chaotic rollout of the health care law, the preliminary nuclear deal reached with Iran on Sunday is more than a welcome change of subject.

headline: Getting to Yes With Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The temporary deal will make the world safer, for now.
lead_paragraph: The interim nuclear deal between Iran and the major powers is an important step toward resolving the increasingly dangerous dispute over Iran’s progress on production of a nuclear weapon. President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran deserve credit for resisting fierce domestic opposition and a 30-year history of animosity between the two countries to get to this point.

headline: On Thanksgiving, Cooking Lessons for Life
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Editorials', 'Editorial Observer', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Forty years of a shared life, boiled down to a few simple instructions. From the archive, 2013.
lead_paragraph: On the first night, my father made chicken piccata. Flour and lemon, bouillon cubes, the funny-looking hammer. He had no idea what he was doing.

headline: Is It a Pollock?
abstract: A retired New York police detective used forensics to determine that a controversial painting is a Jackson Pollock work. Critics says science has its limits and cannot determine true authorship.
lead_paragraph: A retired New York police detective used forensics to determine that a controversial painting is a Jackson Pollock work. Critics says science has its limits and cannot determine true authorship.

headline: A Real Pollock? On This, Art and Science Collide
abstract: Questions over the authenticity of a painting attributed to Jackson Pollock have pitted a forensics specialist against a top scholar. The clash of opinions may be worth millions.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 60 years, a small painting with swirls and splotches of red, black and silver has stood as a symbol of enmity between two women: Lee Krasner, Jackson Pollock’s widow, and Ruth Kligman, his lover.

headline: Giants’ Winning Streak Ends and Hopes Are Dented
abstract: The Dallas victory was a serious blow to the Giants’ scant playoff chances. They are now two games behind both the Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After losing their first six games of the season, the Giants attacked the next several weeks knowing there was little margin for error.

headline: Court Confronts Religious Rights of Corporations
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Supreme Court will decide whether to hear an Obama administration appeal of a lower court’s ruling that a company could restrict contraception insurance coverage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hobby Lobby, a chain of crafts stores, closes on Sundays, costing its owners millions but honoring their Christian faith.

headline: Less Than American
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The case for compromise on a path to citizenship.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, it seemed the debate over immigration reform was all about borders. Politicians competed to offer the most draconian solutions — higher fences, longer fences, electrified fences, armies of guards, fleets of drones, moats and crocodiles. Never mind that the Border Patrol had already more than doubled in a decade. Never mind that many of those here illegally never hopped a fence but simply overstayed a student or tourist visa. The nativist mythology has us under siege from relentless hordes striding toward Arizona on, in the fevered imagination of Tea Party Congressman Steve King, “calves the size of cantaloupes because they’re hauling 75 pounds of marijuana across the desert.” To pacify the border neurotics, authors of the bill that passed the Senate last summer included $46.3 billion to militarize our southern flank.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 24, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: What We've Learned From Nafta
abstract: Has Nafta proved to be a success that the United States should try to replicate more widely or the type of trade agreement that should be avoided in the future?

headline: Peter B. Lewis, Philanthropist Who Led Progressive Auto Insurance, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Lewis turned the small insurance firm co-founded by his father into one of the nation’s largest auto insurance companies by insuring high-risk drivers and high-end sports cars.
lead_paragraph: Peter B. Lewis, who turned the 100-employee insurance firm co-founded by his father into one of the nation’s largest auto insurance companies, the Progressive Corporation, by insuring high-risk drivers and high-end sports cars, and who became an outspoken and sometimes quarrelsome supporter of liberal causes and the arts, died on Saturday at his home in Coconut Grove, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Welker Attends Bittersweet Reunion
abstract: Wes Welker, now with the Denver Broncos, spent six successful seasons with the New England Patriots and Tom Brady, and remains a popular player.
lead_paragraph: In a matchup of Peyton Manning and Tom Brady, the undeniable story line at Gillette Stadium on Sunday night in the game between the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots was the return of wide receiver Wes Welker.

headline: ‘No Man’s Land’ and ‘Waiting for Godot’
abstract: Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart star in new productions on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart star in new productions on Broadway.

headline: A Playwright’s Journey, Mapped From the Inside
abstract: “How I Learned What I Learned,” a memoir in monologue written and originally performed by August Wilson, is now being delivered by Ruben Santiago-Hudson.
lead_paragraph: The rough but fertile terrain from which August Wilson’s great body of work grew is explored in “How I Learned What I Learned,” a memoir in monologue written and originally performed by the playwright in 2003. It is now being delivered by Ruben Santiago-Hudson, an actor and director with long experience of Wilson’s plays.

headline: Filling the Existential Void
abstract: Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart star in repertory productions of Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land” and Samuel Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot” at the Cort Theater.
lead_paragraph: My, how they do go on, these two. In the absurdly enjoyable revivals of Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land” and Samuel Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot,” which opened in repertory on Sunday at the Cort Theater, Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart make a most persuasive case for conversation as both the liveliest and loneliest of arts.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 17-23
abstract: Reflecting on the duality of sports: We soar or stumble; it’s us versus them, elegant or humble. It ends with a win or loss (except when it’s a tie).
lead_paragraph: Reflecting on the duality of sports: We soar or stumble; it’s us versus them, elegant or humble. It ends with a win or loss (except when it’s a tie).

headline: An Illusion of Postseason Promise Heads for the Exits
abstract: A loss to the Cowboys on Sunday left the Giants on the verge of elimination from playoff contention. It was also a microcosm of their year so far.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was eerily quiet inside a frigid MetLife Stadium on Sunday evening as the clock wound down to what felt like two seconds left in a largely confounding and now deflated season. Most fans stood and no doubt prayed for a Giants miracle, or one of those trademark Cowboys debacles. Some headed toward the exits rather than watch Dallas’s Dan Bailey line up for a 35-yard field goal.

headline: Sutton Foster to Star in Roundabout Theater Revival of ‘Violet’
abstract: Ms. Foster will play a disfigured woman on a journey to meet her father in the Roundabout Theater Company’s Broadway production of the 1997 musical “Violet.”
lead_paragraph: Roundabout Theater Company may end up competing against itself in the Tony Award race for best musical revival this spring. Roundabout announced on Sunday that it would team up with several commercial producers to mount a Broadway run of the 1997 musical “Violet,” with Sutton Foster, a two-time Tony Award winner, starring as a disfigured woman on a journey to meet a televangelist faith healer.

headline: The Single-Payer Alternative
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A single-payer system of health insurance would be more consumer-friendly, as well as more cost-effective than the Affordable Care Act, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: 家居| 第五大道上的宫殿
abstract: 室内设计师霍华德·斯拉特金让《纽约时报-国际生活》的萨拉·拉芬·科斯特洛参观了他在第五大道上宫殿似的公寓。

headline: Lifesaving Flu Drugs Fall in Use in Children
abstract: Prompt use of antiviral medications can save the lives of flu-stricken children — yet the drugs are being used less frequently than they once were, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: The flu can lead to serious complications, even death, in children, but relatively few studies have assessed the effectiveness of antiviral treatments in young patients hospitalized with the infection.

abstract: Despite a late rally, the Giants missed an opportunity to advance in the N.F.C. East standings with their loss to the Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: Despite a late rally, the Giants missed an opportunity to advance in the N.F.C. East standings with their loss to the Cowboys.

headline: In Report, 63% Back Way to Get Citizenship
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: A new poll found strong support for citizenship for 11.7 million undocumented immigrants in the United States, just as Congress appeared to be shifting away from that approach.
lead_paragraph: A consistent and solid majority of Americans — 63 percent — crossing party and religious lines favors legislation to create a pathway to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally, while only 14 percent support legal residency with no option for citizenship, according a report published Monday by the nonpartisan Public Religion Research Institute.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (Showtime 2) THE WOMAN IN THE FIFTH (2012) Tom Ricks (Ethan Hawke), an American writer down on his luck in Paris, embarks on a relationship with the enigmatic Margit (Kristin Scott Thomas, above with Mr. Hawke), who slinks up to him, lights a cigarette and announces that she was her husband’s muse in this psychological thriller directed by Pawel Pawlikowski. But can she help Tom, who has had writer’s block since the publication of his first book? “Although Mr. Pawlikowski often shows Mr. Hawke in medium and long shots, the actor draws you close,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “There’s anguish in Tom’s face that speaks of a terrible fragility and that leavens the story’s mysterioso proceedings with a real, recognizable humanity.” In “The Words” (2012), at 9, Dennis Quaid plays Clay Hammond, a successful author whose new novel tells the story of Rory Jansen (Bradley Cooper), a writer turned supervisor at a literary agency who comes upon an unsigned manuscript in a satchel that his wife (Zoë Saldana) gave him and decides to pass the work off as his own. And a star is born. Then an old man (Jeremy Irons) approaches Rory in Central Park and reveals his identity, and Rory’s eyes widen with alarm. Despite a compelling performance by Mr. Irons, this first feature film directed and written by Brian Klugman and Lee Sternthal “is a clever, entertaining yarn that doesn’t bear close scrutiny,” Stephen Holden wrote in The Times.

headline: Evacuation Questions After China Pipe Blast
abstract: A deadly explosion in the city of Qingdao came seven hours after initial reports of a leak in a pipeline, prompting some news outlets to ask why a more thorough evacuation had not been carried out.
lead_paragraph: A deadly explosion in the city of Qingdao came seven hours after initial reports of a leak in a crude pipeline, prompting some Chinese media outlets to ask why a more thorough evacuation had not been carried out. Those questions emerged as President Xi Jinping visited the coastal city to console people injured in the blast. He ordered a nationwide inspection of oil and gas pipelines and called on state-owned enterprises to ensure the safety of their projects.

headline: The Bard of the Tea Stall
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Police', 'Sidewalk Cafes', 'Theater', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Laxman Rao of Delhi offers something that most tea sellers, known as chai wallahs, do not – books that he has written and published himself.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Laxman Rao’s roadside tea stand in New Delhi sells the same items as most tea stalls in India, like various types of cookies, crispy fried snacks called namkeen and sweet milky tea. But Mr. Rao also offers something that most tea sellers, known as chai wallahs, do not – books that he has written and published himself.

headline: News Quiz | November 25, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: U.S. Embassy Stocks Up on Air Purifiers
abstract: American officials have ordered thousands of air purifiers for their employees as a way to blunt the hazards and the fears that come with Chinese smog.
lead_paragraph: Companies and institutions employing foreigners in China are starting to realize that to keep workers in the cities, they need to make changes to the way they operate. Based on anecdotal evidence, air pollution, more than anything else, is driving expatriate workers away from China, or dissuading those outside China from taking postings here. News reports of various rounds of  “airpocalypse” descending on Chinese cities have not helped.

headline: An Immigrant’s Dream, Detained
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Deportation', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: As the United States deports record numbers of immigrants, John Moore looks at a newly opened detention center.
lead_paragraph: The Adelanto Detention Facility in California is designed like a federal prison, with cells, common areas and recreation centers. The 1,200-bed center keeps some detainees in “segregation cells,” for disciplinary reasons, and many of those are solitary confinement, where guards pass meals through openings in the bars.

headline: How Are You and Your Parents Alike and Different?
abstract: How is your relationship with your parents affected by differences, or the lack thereof, between you?
lead_paragraph: There is an old adage: the apple doesn’t fall too far from the tree. It suggests that children are a lot like their parents, or that they eventually end up with values and goals similar to their parents’.

headline: Courses Offer Help in Decoding the Third Plenum
abstract: Chinese universities are offering cram courses on deciphering the Communist Party’s recently unveiled Third Plenum reform plan, suggesting that foreigners are not the only ones scratching their heads.
lead_paragraph: Having trouble deciphering the Chinese Communist Party’s recently unveiled Third Plenum reform plan? You’re not alone.

lead_paragraph: Reactions to the Iran nuclear deal; C.S.I. meets Jackson Pollock; and a whale bonanza.

headline: India’s Negotiator Says Climate Treaty Talks ‘Partial Success’
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Kyoto Protocol', 'Temperature', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Typhoon Bopha (2012)', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Ravi Shankar Prasad said the United Nations climate change conference kept the pathway open for a global climate treaty to be finalized in 2015.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Poland  — After more than 35 hours of continuous discussions, Ravi Shankar Prasad, one of India’s lead negotiators, described the United Nations climate change conference as “a partial success” for keeping the pathway open for a global climate treaty to be finalized in 2015.

headline: New York Today: Roots of Thanksgivukkah
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: How Thanksgiving and Hanukkah came together in 1789, chilly weather and an auction of Ed Koch’s correspondence with luminaries.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:18 p.m.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Mireille Silcoff on the Women Who Will Soar at the Olympics
abstract: Once you are a female American ski jumper, what is the ember inside you that keeps you caring, year after year, about that millimeter change you need to make in hip pivot, or pinkie angle?
lead_paragraph: Mireille Silcoff, a columnist for The National Post in Canada, wrote this week’s cover story about the U.S. Women’s Ski Jumping Team. Earlier this year she wrote for the magazine about how cool it is to be old.

headline: Protesters Raid Compound of Thai Finance Ministry
abstract: Crowds also entered the Foreign Ministry grounds, in the latest escalation of a battle between supporters and opponents of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters raided the compound of Thailand’s Finance Ministry and entered the grounds of the Foreign Ministry on Monday, in the latest escalation of a long-running battle between supporters and opponents of Thaksin Shinawatra, the billionaire former prime minister, whose party has a commanding majority in Parliament.

headline: Week 12 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Brady Wins Battle of Arm Strength in Wind
abstract: In the latest showdown between Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, Manning was clearly affected by the 20-mile-per-hour winds in Gillette Stadium.
lead_paragraph: It was White Knuckle Sunday in the N.F.L. Seven games were decided in the final seconds. Or, technically, six games, as the Packers-Vikings contest was too close to be decided at all. But before going there, let’s start with the most anticipated and entertaining game of Week 12.

headline: Israel's Iran Dilemma
abstract: The best Iran deal that could be had reorders the map of the Middle East and compels Israel to think again.
lead_paragraph: The era of traumatized alienation is over. The United States and Iran have embarked on a new phase in their relationship. It is marked by bilateral negotiations, handshakes, smiles, side-by-side flags and significant compromise, including United States acquiescence to a “mutually defined enrichment program” for Iran in any long-term agreement and an Iranian commitment that “under no circumstances” will it “ever seek or develop any nuclear weapons.”

headline: Love Canal: A Legacy of Doubt
abstract: Thirty-five years after Love Canal became a symbol of the dangers of toxic waste in residential neighborhoods, the legal and medical issues there are still playing out.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-five years after Love Canal became a symbol of the dangers of toxic waste in residential neighborhoods, the legal and medical issues there are still playing out.

headline: Love Canal and Its Mixed Legacy
abstract: The environmental scandal in upstate New York that led to the creation of the Superfund law is still causing dismay for local residents.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Retro Report video looks at the story that began 35 years ago when toxic chemicals leaking from an old landfill thrust a upstate New York community called Love Canal into the national headlines. Here, the environmental writer Andrew C. Revkin looks at the mixed legacy.

headline: Daily Report: Virtual Currencies Seek to Challenge Bitcoin
abstract: Several species of electronic money are striving to emerge from the shadow of bitcoin and gain widespread acceptance by offering varying degrees of anonymity and ease of use.
lead_paragraph: With mounting interest from prominent investors and growing acceptance from regulators, bitcoin — either the new gold or the next Dutch tulip craze, depending on who is being asked — is at the center of the virtual money universe. Yet there are dozens of digital alternatives, like PeerCoin, Litecoin and anoncoin, whose backers point to advantages they say their currencies have over bitcoin, Nathaniel Popper reports.

headline: Talks on Ending Syria’s Civil War to Begin in January
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: The aim is to create a transitional government based on mutual consent, though the Syrian government and the opposition are still far apart on what that would mean.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — After months of delay, the United Nations said Monday that Syria’s government and the opposition would hold their first negotiations aimed at ending that country’s civil war in Geneva on Jan. 22. But the precise agenda for the negotiations, as well as a complete list of participants, remained unresolved.

headline: Casualties of Kashmir’s Unrest Live in the Dark
keywords: ['Blindness', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Doctors', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Firearms', 'Hospitals', 'Men and Boys', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police', 'Ramadan', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Numerous young men in Kashmir have lost one or both of their eyes after being fired at by the Indian troops and police with pellet guns.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR — On an October afternoon I drove to Bemina, a middle-class area in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian-administered-Kashmir. An acquaintance led me to a spacious double-storied house to meet Hayat Ashraf Dar, 21, who is one of the numerous young men in Kashmir who have lost their eyesight after being fired at by the Indian troops and police with pellet guns. Most of the injured have lost one eye. Mr. Dar had lost both.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 25, 2013
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a New York Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. Live moderation is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Update: Nov. 26, 2013

headline: Seven Conclusions About Small-Business Health Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Small Business', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Paul Downs has spent the past few weeks immersed in the new world of health insurance. His conclusion: The new system is a mess — but a vast improvement over the previous mess.
lead_paragraph: In my recent posts, I have told the story of how I started to explore my options for renewing my insurance this year. It’s been my habit in writing for this blog to try to convey useful information, derived from my experience as an ordinary small-business owner, in the form of narrative episodes.

headline: Lending Practices at R.B.S. Condemned in Two Reports
abstract: The British bank principally owned by the government said that it had hired a law firm to examine its lending practices.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royal Bank of Scotland, the British bank principally owned by the government, said on Monday that it had hired a law firm to examine its lending practices after government reports criticized its operations, including claims that it pushed some business clients into serious financial difficulties.

headline: Malone Aims to Shake Up Cable TV
abstract: John C. Malone, once called the King of Cable, is back on the prowl in the industry he helped create. | While bitcoin draws mounting interest, dozens of digital alternatives are emerging. | The top lawyer at JPMorgan Chase has a bad taste in his mouth. | Apple is buying an Israeli start-up that makes motion-detection chips.
lead_paragraph: John C. Malone, whose success wiring American homes for cable television in the 1980s and 1990s earned him the nickname King of Cable, is back on the prowl in the industry he helped create, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. Mr. Malone, 72, now the chairman of Liberty Media, is working behind the scenes to gain control of Time Warner Cable, the country’s second-largest cable operator by subscribers, behind Comcast.

headline: Revisiting Love Canal
abstract: Love Canal had bigger impacts on environmental policy than human health, followup studies show.
lead_paragraph: I have a piece on the Booming blog of The Times looking back at the complicated environmental and political legacy of the Love Canal toxic waste site 35 years after state and federal officials declared an environmental emergency there. (Click on Google Maps to get the lay of the land.) My piece accompanies the latest video from Retro Report, a valuable new journalism project revisiting old stories to see which news elements held up, and which turned out to be unjustified. Here’s an excerpt and a link to the rest:

headline: Carlyle Raises $13 Billion for U.S. Buyouts
abstract: The Carlyle Group said on Monday that it had raised its sixth fund dedicated to buyouts in the United States – its first such fund since the dark days of 2008.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group has a new $13 billion war chest for leveraged buyouts in the United States.

headline: Election Results in Nepal Signal a Political Right Turn
abstract: The first set of results from last week’s vote suggested that the country had swung sharply to the right, and would soon have closer ties with India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nepal’s dominant Communist party was routed, the country’s politics swung sharply to the right and India’s influence in Nepal is likely to soar after the first set of results from last week’s election was finalized on Monday.

headline: Young and Uninsured, in Charts
abstract: New Census Bureau maps and charts show how many Americans age 19 to 34 were uninsured in 2012, and where they lived.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Census Bureau released some nice charts about the young and uninsured — that is, the folks that insurance companies are now falling over themselves to sign up because young people are cheap (and can be charged premiums higher than are actuarially fair in order to subsidize older people).

headline: Chrysler’s Stock Sale Is Delayed Until 2014
abstract: Its parent company, Fiat, will have more time to negotiate the purchase of a 41.5 percent stake held by a union health care trust.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler will not move forward with an initial public offering until next year at the earliest, giving its parent company, Fiat, more time to negotiate the purchase of a 41.5 percent stake held by a union health care trust.

headline: Beastie Boys Fight Online Video Parody of ‘Girls’
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Music', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: On Monday, the band released an open letter to GoldieBlox, a San Francisco-area start-up that makes toys and games designed to encourage girls to learn about science and technology.
lead_paragraph: Over a music career of more than 25 years, the Beastie Boys evolved from a goofy rap trio to a conscientious band with more nuanced positions on politics and art.

headline: Japan Answers China’s Warnings Over Islands’ Airspace
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan called China’s declaration of an air defense zone over a disputed group of islands in the East China Sea an unacceptable effort to change the status quo.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Matching China’s stern language with warnings of his own, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan vowed on Monday to defend his nation’s airspace after China declared an air defense zone over a disputed group of islands in the East China Sea.

headline: Couple Convicted of Murdering Teen Daughter and Domestic Help
abstract: The verdict in the trial of the parents of 13-year-old Aarushi Talwar is a turning point in a lurid case that has riveted the nation for the past five years.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A Noida couple were convicted on Monday of murdering their only child and their servant in a lurid case that has riveted the nation for the past five years.

headline: Nowhere Near The Exit
abstract: Full speed ahead, Ms. Yellen.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker is annoyed with Greg Mankiw — not for the first time — for suggesting that the time for a Fed exit strategy may be drawing near. Dean focuses mainly on Greg’s use of what he considers a misleading wage number, but the problem runs deeper.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Closes Out History-Making Formula One Season
abstract: Sebastian Vettel ties Michael Schumacher’s record for 13 victories in a season, and Stéphane Ortelli and Laurens Vanthoor win the F.I.A. GT series.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Vettel ended the 2013 Formula One campaign in dominant fashion on Sunday at the season finale in Brazil, scoring a strong victory over his Red Bull Infiniti teammate, Mark Webber, and Ferrari’s Fernando Alonso. Vettel, 26, had already secured his fourth straight World Championship; Alonso was a distant runnerup in the points battle.

headline: Militia in Benghazi Flees After Deadly Gun Battle
abstract: The fighting followed the deaths of at least 43 people in Tripoli this month and came as rival factions flex their muscles ahead of a bid to elect a constitutional assembly.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A militia in Benghazi, Libya, tied to the killing of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens fled its headquarters on Monday after an hourslong gun battle with a local military unit, a potential turning point in a continuing struggle between Islamists and their foes for control of the city.

headline: Putin’s Dead Poets Society
abstract: When Russia’s president decides to take over literature.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When President Vladimir Putin had finished talking, Tolstoy took the floor. He thanked Dostoyevsky, Lermontov, Sholokhov and Pasternak. Unfortunately, he said, Pushkin had fallen ill and could not fly in from his home in Belgium. “Pushkin is in the hall,” said Tolstoy, meaning that he was with them in spirit.

headline: The Reason Why
abstract: Good news from Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: Terrific piece in the WaPo on how Kentucky’s rural poor are being helped by Kynect, the state’s version of Obamacare, which has had a picture-perfect rollout.

headline: ScienceTake: The Fungus Highway
abstract: One fungus, Neurospora crassa, has a highly efficient traffic system to spread nuclei among its filaments as it grows. Human highway designers, take note.
lead_paragraph: One fungus, Neurospora crassa, has a highly efficient traffic system to spread nuclei among its filaments as it grows. Human highway designers, take note.

headline: 1963: Speech, Never Delivered, Stressed America’s Mission
abstract: In the aftermath of President Kennedy’s death, The New York Herald published excerpts from his last speech, never delivered.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — President Kennedy died from an assassin’s bullets without being able to deliver his warning—that in today’s world, freedom could be lost without a shot being fired, by ballots as well as by bullets.

headline: What the Convertible Debt Boom Means for Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Credit and Debt', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Distressed companies will be able to coast for a while on their existing funding. But eventually all that debt will come due, and then we’ll find out what happens.
lead_paragraph: So the word is that convertible debt issuance is at a record high. On one level, that is totally predictable.

headline: New Law in Egypt Effectively Bans Street Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The law is the latest evidence of a return to authoritarianism in the aftermath of the military takeover in July.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-backed government has issued a law that all but bans street protests by applying jail time or heavy fines to the public demonstrations that have felled the last two presidents and regularly roiled the capital since the Arab Spring revolt.

headline: Food Matters | In Paris, Two Bourgeois Butchers Duke It Out for Steakhouse Supremacy
abstract: Hugo Desnoyer and Yves-Marie Le Bourdonnec, who own their own restaurants and supply some of Paris’s top chefs, are at the forefront of the city’s new “haute boucherie.”
lead_paragraph: From couture to cuisine, Parisians have a passion for top-of-the-line everything, which now includes “haute boucherie.” Its two stars are Hugo Desnoyer and Yves-Marie Le Bourdonnec, who are duking it out for billing as the city’s best butcher. Desnoyer’s newest shop — his first to include an on-site table d’hôte with fabulous steaks and an extensive wine list — is housed in the same 16th Arrondissement building where he began his career 25 years ago, and he supplies some of the area’s most exalted chefs: Pascal Barbot and Pierre Gagnaire, whose restaurants both have three Michelin stars.

headline: Blackberry Chief Removes Some Top Executives
abstract: The troubled smartphone maker said its chief operating officer and chief marketing officer were gone from the company. The chief financial officer has been replaced.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — In his first move since becoming acting chief executive of BlackBerry, John S. Chen has removed several senior executives at the troubled smartphone maker, the company said Monday.

headline: A Public Memorial for Julie Harris
abstract: Christopher Plummer, Hal Holbrook and Cherry Jones are among those who will gather to pay tribute to Ms. Harris at a New York City theater on Dec. 3.
lead_paragraph: The actress Julie Harris, who died on Aug. 24 at 87, will be remembered by colleagues and friends at a memorial celebration at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater,  242 West 45th Street, on Dec. 3 at noon.

headline: Times Names a New Editor of Video Content
abstract: Bruce Headlam, editor of the media desk at The New York Times, was named managing editor of video content development by Jill Abramson, executive editor.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Headlam, editor of the media desk at The New York Times since 2008, has been named managing editor of video content development. He will succeed Richard L. Berke, who recently left The Times to join Politico.

headline: At an SAC Parade Party, All Blown Up but Nowhere to Go
abstract: At a balloon-inflation party sponsored by SAC Capital Advisors on Saturday before an annual parade in Stamford, Conn., the mood was decidedly low-key.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — In finance, balloons are classic symbols of both growth and collapse. So when SAC Capital Advisors, the embattled hedge fund run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, sponsored a balloon-inflation party on Saturday in its hometown, Stamford, Conn., it was a particularly striking image.

headline: Apple Buys 3-D Sensor Company PrimeSense
abstract: PrimeSense’s innovations contributed to the early development of Kinect, Microsoft’s motion-sensing camera, and Apple has demonstrated interest in the technology.
lead_paragraph: Apple has purchased the motion sensor company PrimeSense, an Israeli firm that gained prominence from its early work on Microsoft’s Kinect.

headline: Mashed Potato and Broccoli Raab Pancakes
abstract: A delicious way to use mashed potatoes, whether they be leftovers or freshly mashed.
lead_paragraph: Use leftover mashed potatoes from Thanksgiving for these, or just steam up some potatoes and mash (that is what the nutritional values here are based on, not on your buttery leftover Thanksgiving mashed potatoes). Whichever way you go, the mixture is very quickly thrown together.

headline: Mashed Potato and Cabbage Pancakes
abstract: Vegetable pancakes with a sweet and comforting flavor.
lead_paragraph: These have a sweet, comforting flavor. They are quick to mix up, using either leftover mashed potatoes from your Thanksgiving dinner, or potatoes that you have cut up and steamed for 20 minutes.

headline: Leek, Kale and Potato Latkes
abstract: Delicious cumin-scented latkes laced with crispy kale.
lead_paragraph: I love the way the kale crisps when you fry these cumin-scented latkes.

abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1888: Emperor Uses ‘I’ In Speech

headline: Gunman Scare at Yale Believed to Be a Hoax
abstract: A 911 call about a person with a gun led to a campus lockdown on Monday, but a search yielded no one with a weapon, the police said.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Yale University began the day Monday with a campus lockdown and swarms of law enforcement officials, but ended it with sighs of relief as reports of a gunman appeared to be a hoax.

abstract: Weather comparison for the past 11 Super Bowl sites and MetLife Stadium, site of this year’s Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Weather comparison for the past 11 Super Bowl sites and MetLife Stadium, site of this year’s Super Bowl.

abstract: Key weather statistics from 47 Super Bowls (data from the closest major airport).
lead_paragraph: Key weather statistics from 47 Super Bowls (data from the closest major airport).

abstract: State assembly elections in progress in the central state of Madhya Pradesh.

headline: F.D.A. Orders Genetic Testing Firm to Stop Selling DNA Analysis Service
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration sent a warning letter to 23andme, which sells a $99 personal genome testing kit, saying the company had not proved that the product worked.
lead_paragraph: In a crackdown on genetic testing that is offered directly to consumers, the Food and Drug Administration has demanded that 23andMe immediately cease selling and marketing its DNA testing service until it receives clearance from the agency.

headline: Russia May Seek to Reclaim Rachmaninoff Estate
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin ordered his government to look into buying the archive and Swiss estate of the emigre composer.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has ordered his government to look into buying the archive and Swiss estate of the emigre composer and pianist Sergei Rachmaninoff, continuing an effort to reclaim and repatriate Russian cultural legacy.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 25 at 12 p.m.
abstract: Syrian peace talks announced; drones for journalists; and the fungus highway.
lead_paragraph: Syrian peace talks announced; drones for journalists; and the fungus highway.

headline: Obama Signals a Shift From Military Might to Diplomacy
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The announcements of an interim nuclear deal with Iran and a conference on Syria’s civil war were vivid statements that diplomacy has again become the centerpiece of American foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The weekend ended with the first tangible sign of a nuclear deal with Iran, after more than three decades of hostility. Then on Monday came the announcement that a conference will convene in January to try to broker an end to the civil war in Syria.
