headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet 2013
abstract: This year several celebrities wore pieces straight off the runway including Rihanna in Jean Paul Gaultier couture and Lady Gaga in Versace.
lead_paragraph: This year several celebrities wore pieces straight off the runway including Rihanna in Jean Paul Gaultier couture and Lady Gaga in Versace.

headline: Gold Bars
abstract: Can you decipher this gold bar puzzle?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was created at the Unsolved K-12 Conference, a recent event focused on identifying 13 unsolved problems in mathematics (one problem for each grade) that could be used to spur creative thinking and collaboration in elementary school math education. (The conference was held Nov. 15-17 in Banff, Alberta.) The puzzle, which was created by conference participants and edited by frequent Numberplay contributor Joshua Zucker, is the following:

headline: Listen Up | In the California Desert, a One-of-a-Kind Music Venue Blossoms
abstract: A former saloon in the tiny village of Pioneertown, Calif., has become an intimate spot to hear major acts like Spiritualized and Lucinda Williams, as well as up-and-comers.
lead_paragraph: Ten years since taking over a desert saloon in Pioneertown, Calif., two New Yorkers have transformed it into an oasis of indie rock and a breeding ground for music stars.

headline: American Dreamer on 42nd Street Who Fled From a Deal
abstract: Louis Gritsipis, a Greek immigrant, didn’t just turn down an offer for his diner’s building in Manhattan; he ran away from the conference.
lead_paragraph: A four-story white stucco building, with its fire escapes painted baby blue crisscrossing the windows set in lemon-yellow sills, stands stubbornly at the western end of 42nd Street.

headline: The Battles of Chattanooga
abstract: Was the Union victory at Chattanooga the beginning of the end for the South?
lead_paragraph: For the North, the autumn of 1863 was a season of shattered hopes. The fall of Vicksburg and victory at Gettysburg in July had raised expectations of an end to the war before the New Year. But the Army of the Potomac had not followed up on its success, and Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant saw his army carved up to support peripheral operations. Then in September, Gen. Braxton Bragg’s Army of Tennessee defeated the Army of the Cumberland at Chickamauga, 12 miles southeast of Chattanooga, Tenn., stopping the North’s progress toward Atlanta.

headline: The Health Care ‘Distraction’ Conspiracy
abstract: Senator John Cornyn said the deal with Iran was an attempt to distract attention from the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Two things happened last week that had nothing to do with the Affordable Care Act. This, Republicans say, is proof of a devious Democratic conspiracy to distract the American people from the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Monty Python Reunion Adds Four More Shows
abstract: Tickets to the first Monty Python reunion performance next year in London sold out quickly, and the troupe added four more dates.
lead_paragraph: The 20,000 tickets to Monty Python’s reunion show at the O2 Arena in London, scheduled for July 1, were snapped up in just under 45 seconds — faster than an exasperating debate at the comedy troupe’s argument clinic — the show’s organizers told the BBC on Monday. They also announced that the run would be extended.

headline: When Good People Do Bad Things
abstract: Several recent cases raise the issue of what companies can do to ensure that employees do not cave in to pressure to engage in misconduct.
lead_paragraph: At the sentencing hearing for Kareem Serageldin, a former senior executive at Credit Suisse, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Federal District Court in Manhattan pointedly asked why someone in such a position would engage in misconduct. As DealBook reported, the judge asked, “Why do so many good people do bad things?”

headline: Leaving ABC News, Couric Describes Move to Yahoo as ‘Being of the Moment’
abstract: Katie Couric said that her decision to join Yahoo as its “global news anchor” came after the new chief executive, Marissa Mayer, reached out to her.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo announced on Monday that it had signed the longtime network news star Katie Couric for a new position as the “global anchor” of its still-formative news operation.

headline: Sure-Footed Real Salt Lake Reaches M.L.S. Final
abstract: Discipline and defense helped Real Salt Lake eliminate the Portland Timbers and advance to Major League Soccer’s championship game.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Real Salt Lake’s players and coaches climbed atop a small makeshift stage at midfield for a trophy celebration after dispatching the Portland Timbers in Sunday’s M.L.S. Western Conference final. A machine sprayed red confetti in the air.

headline: Obama’s Visiting Security Adviser Tells Karzai to Sign Agreement
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Susan E. Rice told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to sign a security agreement or potentially face the complete pullout of American troops by the end of 2014, officials said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Monday to stop his delay in signing a security agreement or potentially face the complete and final pullout of American troops by the end of 2014, according to American and Afghan officials.

headline: New Springsteen Album Coming in January
abstract: “High Hopes,” an album by Bruce Springsteen that includes studio recordings of songs that have been part of his stage set, is due out on Jan. 14.
lead_paragraph: The drill for rock stars usually goes like this: record an album’s worth of new material and release it, then take the songs on tour, recording the shows for what, these days, is the inevitable live album. Bruce Springsteen has been tinkering with that formula in recent months, making new studio recordings of songs that have been part of his stage set for ages but were never released on studio albums. The result, “High Hopes,” is due out on Columbia on Jan. 14. He announced the album on Twitter on Sunday evening.

headline: A Succession at Walmart Puts an Insider at the Helm
abstract: C. Douglas McMillon, a longtime company executive who is now president of Walmart International, will succeed Michael T. Duke, who has been Walmart’s chief since 2009, the company said.
lead_paragraph: As Walmart enters a fiercely competitive holiday season while still hampered by sluggish sales, the company’s board announced on Monday that Michael T. Duke, its chief executive, would retire early next year and a longtime executive, C. Douglas McMillon, would replace him.

headline: Government Abuse Drives Eritreans to Flee, U.N. Says
abstract: An investigator said deprivation of freedom and security, and the desire to feel protected, was pushing 2,000 to 3,000 people to leave Eritrea every month.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Severe government abuse, not harsh living conditions, is driving thousands of Eritreans to flee their country every month and risk their lives trying, often by precarious means, to reach other countries, a United Nations investigator said Monday. Her assertion puts a spotlight on an exodus that resulted in tragedy last month when hundreds of migrants, many of them Eritreans, drowned as they tried to cross the Mediterranean to Italy.

headline: Why a Times Photo Remains Online After Criticism
abstract: Except to correct factual errors, The Times rarely changes or deletes published material.
lead_paragraph: After I wrote last week about a photograph of a Palestinian mother, many readers and many other observers complained that – since two senior editors agreed it was not a good choice for dominant art with the story about an Israeli soldier’s death – it was wrong for The Times to not remove the photo online.

abstract: The year's best performers star in 11 original (very) short films directed by Oscar-winning cinematographer Janusz Kaminski.
lead_paragraph: The year's best performers star in 11 original (very) short films directed by Oscar-winning cinematographer Janusz Kaminski.

headline: Video: Testing the Ford Fiesta, a Small Car With Large Ambitions
abstract: If you enjoy driving, or simply won’t tolerate commuting in a cocoon of hard plastic, the subcompact Fiesta may be worth its premium price.
lead_paragraph: For those who simply want a basic transportation appliance for commuting and grocery getting, Ford’s refreshed 2014 Fiesta is not the usual cheap and cheerful economy car. If you navigate the maze of competitors, models and available features, you may find that the Fiesta is often a more expensive set of wheels in a category where a couple hundred dollars makes a real difference. The roomier Nissan Versa Note is a full $600 less. For newlyweds, that’s a couple of rooms of IKEA furniture.

headline: For Kidd, Being a Player Was a Lot Easier
abstract: Jason Kidd had a huge body of work to draw on as a new addition to the Knicks last season, but he has nothing but his assistants’ advice to fall back on as the Nets’ rookie coach.
lead_paragraph: Jason Kidd had dribbled up and down N.B.A. courts for two decades when he opted to join the Knicks last year at age 39.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Ratings Names New President
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: Neeraj Sahai, who has been head of Citigroup’s securities and fund services business since 2005, will succeed Douglas Peterson, who became president and chief executive of McGraw Hill Financial.
lead_paragraph: A Citigroup executive has been named president of Standard & Poor’s Ratings Service.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Aesop Intensity Kit
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a package of grooming products for men.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Basketball Bulletin, Updated: Both Ships Be Sinking
abstract: Micheal Ray Richardson’s famous words could be used to describe the Knicks and Nets’ 2013-14 season so far. Is there any reason for hope?
lead_paragraph: So, how many Knicks or Nets fans can honestly say they saw this coming?

headline: Making a Scene
abstract: The actors who gave the year’s best performances star in one-line films created by the Oscar-winning cinematographer Janusz Kaminski.
lead_paragraph: The actors who gave the year’s best performances star in one-line films created by the Oscar-winning cinematographer Janusz Kaminski.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Similar Geico voices, and another ad burnout rant.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide were honored recently.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Arnon joined ActionX, New York, in a new post, vice president for advertising sales. He had been running his own company, Moment Zero, and before that was at Google and Apple.

headline: In Time for Thanksgiving, Storm System Heads East
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Rain', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Weather', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Delays (Transportation)']
abstract: As millions of Americans prepare to travel ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday, winter storm warnings were in effect in large parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: A storm system that has caused at least eight deaths across the West and Midwest is headed east and expected to bring snow, rain and strong winds that may disrupt Thanksgiving travel over a large area of the country, forecasters said Monday.

headline: If You Love Your Art, Ads Declare, Set It Free
abstract: A commercial real estate company, Brookfield Office Properties, has started a digital campaign showcasing artists worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Efforts by a commercial real estate company to support the arts are going online to observe 25 years of cultural initiatives, with a campaign that encourages artists to share their work digitally.

headline: Inquiry in Cover-Up of Ohio Rape Yields Indictment of Four Adults
abstract: The superintendent in the school system of Steubenville, Ohio, was among those indicted on Monday by a grand jury investigating the cover-up of a 2012 rape.
lead_paragraph: Four adults in the school system of Steubenville, Ohio, including the superintendent, were indicted Monday by a grand jury looking into the cover-up of a rape that drew national attention and outrage because students recorded it on social media but did not alert the authorities.

headline: What We Do Now When We’re Not Watching Movies
abstract: A graphic analysis.
lead_paragraph: A graphic analysis.

headline: The Unforgettables
abstract: 11 actors who gave defining performances this year, 14 top screenwriters and one legendary filmmaker create a portfolio of cinematic moments.
lead_paragraph: 11 actors who gave defining performances this year, 14 top screenwriters and one legendary filmmaker create a portfolio of cinematic moments.

headline: Did This Movie Have to Be a Movie?
abstract: Or would it have worked just as well as a series or webisodes?
lead_paragraph: Or would it have worked just as well as a series or webisodes?

headline: The Big Picture Strikes Back
abstract: Think TV is where all the action and ambition is? This year proves there are some things the movies still do better.
lead_paragraph: Like a character who develops a discreet but noticeable cough at the end of the first act, the movies have been dying for a long time. The latest chapter in their decline — which began, depending on who is telling the story, with the introduction of sound, the rise of television, the fall of the old studios, the spread of home video or the arrival of the Internet — was written earlier this year.

headline: Lights, Camera and, for the First Time, Dialogue
abstract: For reasons both technical and aesthetic, the magazine’s annual great-performers portfolio has traditionally favored sight over sound. Until this year.
lead_paragraph: Movies exist, above all, to exalt the human face, and movie stars are people whose faces possess the mysterious power to make us look at them and want to keep looking. This is less a matter of beauty or of sexual magnetism than of individuality, of specialness. We like watching them pretend partly because we think we can see through the disguise. Their particular, paradoxical art is to bring credibility to the artifice. They are always themselves, even as their identities change from one role to the next. Seeing is believing.

headline: 5 Movies You Need(ed) to See in Theaters
abstract: Big screen. Big crowd. Endless trailers and stale popcorn. Sometimes the theater experience is irreplaceable.
lead_paragraph: As I argue in this year’s Movies Issue, sometimes the theater experience is irreplaceable. These five movies are proof.

headline: In Myanmar, Newly Free Media Struggle to Turn a Profit
abstract: Private print publications face competition from state-run dailies and the Internet and are having a hard time finding advertisers and qualified reporters, the editors say.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s journalists celebrated this year when the government lifted a five-decade ban on private newspapers.

headline: New Left-Wing Party in Honduras Cries Foul
abstract: Juan Orlando Hernández had a lead over Xiomara Castro, whose party, Libre, said it would contest the results, setting the stage for unrest.
lead_paragraph: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Nine dejected foot soldiers of a would-be revolution were sitting on the stoop of a local campaign headquarters in the Colonia Kennedy neighborhood on Monday afternoon, drinking soda out of small plastic cups and debating what comes next.

headline: Stroke Identified as Cause of Chef Trotter’s Death
abstract: The medical examiner said neither drugs nor alcohol contributed, nor did recent travel.
lead_paragraph: The chef Charlie Trotter died of a stroke linked to high blood pressure, a medical examiner’s report on his death earlier this month has found.

headline: Oil Prices Dip on Iran Deal, but Exports May Not Rise
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Easing tensions with Tehran could bring more of its oil and natural gas to global markets, but analysts didn’t see much change in market fundamentals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Oil prices dipped and stocks around the world rose on Monday after the news of an agreement to temporarily freeze Iran’s nuclear program, but few specialists expected any significant change to consumer energy prices, at least in the short term.

headline: A Top Nasdaq Executive Steps Down
abstract: Eric Noll, who oversaw Nasdaq’s trading operations in the United States, was seen as one of the leading candidates to succeed Robert Greifeld as chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:15 p.m. | One of the top executives at Nasdaq OMX, Eric Noll, is leaving the company to lead the brokerage firm ConvergEx Group.

headline: Liz Cheney’s New Ad
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Her daughters talk up the family’s Wyoming roots.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Cheney family erupted in a public spat over gay marriage. It started with Mary Cheney, who is a lesbian, criticizing her sister, Liz Cheney, who is running for a Senate seat in Wyoming and opposes same-sex marriage. Then Dick Cheney, the former vice president, and his wife jumped into the fray, defending “Liz’s many kindnesses.”

headline: Walkabout: Medellin, Reimagined; The New ‘Longest Flight in the World’
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Medellin, the city once known as the murder capital of the world and home to cartel boss Pablo Escobar, has undergone a decade-long campaign to soften its image and appeal to travelers. The urban renewal has not only cut down on crime, but led to several inventive strides in architecture, technology, fashion and, of course, night life. (Bloomberg)

headline: Posters Elicit German Tips Concerning Nazi Crimes
abstract: The Simon Wiesenthal Center, which runs the campaign, has passed information about four people to the authorities for further investigation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A poster campaign by the Simon Wiesenthal Center intended to identify aging Germans who might have participated in Nazi crimes has yielded information about four people, including a woman who might have been a guard at Auschwitz, that has been passed to the authorities for further investigation, the group said Monday.

headline: Revisiting Kevin O’Leary and the Cash Advance Industry
abstract: A business owner who makes his living as a loan broker says there are times when a loan is not the best option for a struggling business.
lead_paragraph: My recent blog post about Kevin O’Leary’s investment in Total Merchant Resources — an alternative lender that charges high interest rates in return for quick access to capital — brought a response from Sean Murray, chief executive of Merchant Processing Resource. In his comment, Mr. Murray suggested that I yearn “for the glory days of 10-year loans at 8 percent interest for local mom and pop shops.” Mr. Murray, who says on his LinkedIn profile that he has been responsible for placing more than $100 million in loans to small businesses, went on to defend the merchant cash advance industry.

headline: New Study Finds U.S. Has Greatly Underestimated Methane Emissions
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Research']
abstract: A new study measuring levels of heat-trapping methane across the United States reveals the need for better government monitoring.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:53 p.m. | A comprehensive new study of atmospheric levels of methane, an important greenhouse gas released by leaky oil and gas operations and livestock, has found much higher levels over the United States than those estimated by the Environmental Protection Agency and an international greenhouse gas monitoring effort. The paper, “Anthropogenic emissions of methane in the United States,” is being published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: Whooping Cough Study May Offer Clue on Surge
abstract: Scientists said a finding — that baboons vaccinated against the illness could still carry and spread it — could provide insight on the increase in the incidence of the disease.
lead_paragraph: Baboons vaccinated against whooping cough could still carry the illness in their throats and spread it, research published in a science journal on Monday has found. The surprising new finding has not been replicated in people, but scientists say it may provide an important clue to a puzzling spike in the incidence of whooping cough across the country, which reached a 50-year high last year.

headline: Cutting Through Financial Noise to a Well-Balanced Portfolio
abstract: Tips on questions to ask in building the right mix of investments.
lead_paragraph: It’s a noisy world for investors. Whether it is the debate about when the Federal Reserve will taper its bond purchasing or what it means if the Dow pushes past the 16,000 mark, it’s easy to get caught up in the noise and think our best bet is to react to the news as it comes. Who needs a plan? Just follow the ticker tape at the bottom of the TV screen.

headline: Chilling Look at Newtown Killer, but No ‘Why’
abstract: Almost a year after Adam Lanza killed 26 children and adults in a Newtown, Conn., elementary school, an investigative report shed new light on his internal life and complicated relationship with his mother.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — Adam Lanza spent the final months of his life mostly alone in his bedroom. His windows were covered with black trash bags. He was preoccupied with violent video games and created a spreadsheet of some of the worst massacres in American history.

headline: State’s Attorney’s Report on Sandy Hook Elementary School Shootings
abstract: Read the official public report on the Dec. 14, 2012, rampage in Newtown, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Read the official public report on the Dec. 14, 2012, rampage in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Country Singer Dies After Nashville Bar Brawl
abstract: Wayne Mills was fatally shot after a dispute in a Nashville bar early Saturday morning, the police said.
lead_paragraph: It was an unusually rough weekend for country music. An after-hours bar brawl in Nashville on Saturday left the singer and guitarist Wayne Mills dead of a gunshot wound to the head. And members of Willie Nelson’s band, including his longtime drummer, Paul English, were injured when the band’s tour bus crashed into an overpass pillar on a highway near Sulphur Springs, Tex., also in the wee hours of Saturday.

headline: In Delay of Chrysler I.P.O., Fiat May Have Gained Upper Hand
abstract: The autoworkers’ union probably needs Chrysler to be valued at $18 billion to make an initial public offering worthwhile, but recent price talk has fallen short of that.
lead_paragraph: Fiat may have slipped into the driver’s seat. An autoworkers’ fund that owns 41.5 percent of Chrysler has been pushing for an initial public offering of the company as part of talks with its Italian partner. Chrysler’s board has decided to delay the stock sale until next year, suggesting Fiat’s negotiating position has improved.

headline: The Read Around: Bill Bryson
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Bill Bryson, the author of “One Summer: America, 1927,” talks about his “intense desire to go out and see more of the world.”
lead_paragraph: Bill Bryson, the author of “One Summer: America, 1927,” talks about his “intense desire to go out and see more of the world.”

headline: Microbes May Add Special Something to Wines
abstract: Researchers have found that grape varieties in different regions carry distinctive patterns of fungi and bacteria, which may play a role in making a wine unique.
lead_paragraph: Terroir is a concept at the heart of French winemaking, but one so mysterious that the word has no English counterpart. It denotes the holistic combination of soil, geology, climate and local grape-growing practices that make each region’s wine unique.

headline: In Store | In London, a Cult Fashion Boutique With Lofty Aspirations
abstract: The Shoreditch shop Hostem is in an expansionary mode, with a women’s wing joining its men’s wear offerings this week, and a rooftop event space set to open next spring.
lead_paragraph: Since opening in 2010 in a Victorian building on Redchurch Street in London’s Shoreditch district, the men’s wear boutique Hostem has become a favorite for its bold, deconstructed offerings from designers like Ann Demeulemeester, Rick Owens and Visvim, as well as its striking, somewhat Dickensian interiors. Earlier this year, the store expanded into the basement to open its Chalk Room, designed by the local artists James Russell and Hannah Plumb (a.k.a. JamesPlumb), who created a series of haunting assemblages to showcase bespoke pieces by the likes of the avant-garde tailor Geoffrey B. Small and the luggage company Globe-Trotter.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 19-25, 2013
abstract: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: A Holocaust Opera Is Coming to New York
abstract: Mieczyslaw Weinberg’s 1968 opera “The Passenger” will come to New York as part of the Lincoln Center Festival in July.
lead_paragraph: “The Passenger” will make its belated arrival in New York this summer, when the Lincoln Center Festival and the Park Avenue Armory present Mieczyslaw Weinberg’s 1968 opera about the Holocaust, which was not performed during his lifetime.

headline: Heart Attack Pain Similar for Men and Women
abstract: A new study found that too much has been made of gender differences in chest pain, the hallmark symptom of heart disease.
lead_paragraph: Women are more likely than men to die after a heart attack, and some researchers have suggested a reason: Doctors may be misdiagnosing women more often because their symptoms differ from those experienced by men.

headline: Jones Energy Buys Assets in Anadarko Basin
abstract: The deal comes as exploration and production companies are snapping up assets amid a new energy boom. It is the largest deal yet for Jones, which went public earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Jones Energy, an oil and gas company with a $1.3 billion market value, is buying about $200 million worth of producing and undeveloped fields in Texas and Oklahoma from a private seller, according to people briefed on the transaction.

headline: M.L.S. and Red Bulls Release 2014 Schedule
abstract: Major League Soccer will open its 2014 season with nine matches the weekend of March 8 and 9.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, Major League Soccer has announced the schedule for its next season before the completion of its current one.

headline: Less Need to Worry About Inflation
abstract: Inflation concerns have been diminished by the reduced bargaining power of many workers, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 22-24, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The images are jarring: a young father hoisting his baby son heavenward, an HK45 semi-automatic pistol holstered to his hip. A 16-year-old girl, blond and angelic, posing with her handgun. A couple and their six children, at least two of whom are visibly packing heat.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Libya, Thailand, Ukraine and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Libya, Thailand, Ukraine and Indonesia.

headline: Soon, Obamacare Will Become Benghazi
abstract: What happens as things get better.
lead_paragraph: OK, I just created an Obamacare account for myself (if I broke any laws, please, it was just investigative journalism). I went all the way through the process at healthcare.gov, stopping before the final step of actually applying (I don’t qualify, of course, because Princeton provides insurance), just to see how hard it was. And the answer is that it was no problem at all, with no delays.

headline: Client Conflicts Undermine Planned Merger of 2 Law Firms
abstract: Client conflicts were among the issues that scuttled the deal between Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe and Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman.
lead_paragraph: The biggest proposed law firm merger of the year has collapsed.

headline: The Read Around: Bill Bryson
abstract: Mr. Bryson, the author of “One Summer: America, 1927,” talks about his “intense desire to go out and see more of the world.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, Bill Bryson, the author of “A Walk in the Woods” and, most recently, “One Summer: America, 1927,” talks about getting work done on planes, his “intense desire to go out and see more of the world” and the one subject “no one wants me to write a book about — readers or publishers or anyone.”

headline: Albums From Destroyer, Kellie Pickler and Danielle Bradbery
abstract: Two former TV contestants, Kellie Pickler of “American Idol” and Danielle Bradbery of “The Voice,” have new albums, as does Dan Bejar’s Destroyer.
lead_paragraph: DANIELLE BRADBERY

headline: Christmas Abbott’s Nascar Workout
abstract: Workout tips from a Nascar pit crew member and gym owner.
lead_paragraph: Workout tips from a Nascar pit crew member and gym owner.

headline: The Workout: A Woman in Nascar
abstract: Christmas Abbott, one of the first women to become a full-time member of a Nascar pit crew, talks about how she stays fit for the job.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t think auto racing is a physically demanding sport, just ask a member of a team’s pit crew. This high-stakes job requires strength, speed and precision, as workers change 90-pound tires in a matter of seconds. We asked Christmas Abbott, 32 and one of the first women to become a full-time member of a Nascar crew, to take us through the pit crew workout.

headline: Scene City: Auction Fever Continues for Bono’s (Red) Charity
abstract: Jonathan Ive and Marc Newson teamed up for a design auction at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Ive and Marc Newson teamed up for a design auction at Sotheby’s.

headline: The Happy Results of a Speedy Shift
abstract: The “Magic Flute” now at the Los Angeles Opera shows the good things that can happen when a company shakes up its production schedule.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Who knew that the star of Mozart’s “The Magic Flute” could be a gangly black cat? In the Los Angeles Opera’s irresistible new production, which opened on Saturday at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion here, the mischievous bird catcher Papageno has traded feathers for a feline that leaps from tree to tree, fends off angry dogs and gets captured in a bell jar, radiating charisma all the while.

headline: A Company-Worthy Ginger Cake with Molasses and Stout
abstract: Grated fresh ginger root, along with a dash of black pepper and cloves, imbues The Marrow’s ginger stout cake with intense spiciness.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Death Interrupted, Just by Making a Phone Call
abstract: Ballet Hispanico’s program at the Apollo Theater Saturday included dances for skulls, immigrants and men with hats.
lead_paragraph: It always causes a stab of panic — that moment when you’re watching a show, and a cellphone goes off. Could it be yours? During an otherwise silent moment in the Ballet Hispanico performance at the Apollo Theater on Saturday, a phone in the audience kept ringing, and Mario Ismael Espinoza, his face painted like a skull from the Mexican Day of the Dead, stopped dancing to hiss in its direction. How awkward.

headline: For a Professor, a Messy Affair
abstract: In “Death of the Black-Haired Girl,” a professor’s world is shaken when his student-lover is killed.
lead_paragraph: Robert Stone’s fast-paced new novel, “Death of the Black-Haired Girl,” does not take place in one of those hot, volatile places (Vietnam or Central America or the Middle East) where so many of his earlier characters sought adventure, oblivion or redemption. It takes place in a small New England town, where history is more personal than political.

headline: Gallery | Why Grannies Make the Best Fashion Models
abstract: Tim Walker, the British fashion photographer who usually takes portraits of bright young things, has captured the magic of the octogenarian set.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Clouds Gather on the Lake
abstract: A. R. Gurney’s “Family Furniture” is a tender, sepia-toned play about a traumatic passage in the lives of a tight-knit, well-bred clan.
lead_paragraph: The forecast is distinctly cloudy along the shores of Lake Erie, at least for the visitors from Buffalo in A. R. Gurney’s newest play, “Family Furniture,” which opened on Sunday night at the Flea Theater. In this tender, sepia-toned play about a traumatic passage in the lives of a tight-knit, well-bred clan — the latest in a long series of plays by Mr. Gurney detailing the manners and mores of the social milieu he was raised in — a sense of dangerous change seems to hang threateningly in the atmosphere, like a thunderstorm that just won’t burst.

headline: Not So Fast: Italian Church Is Halted on Its Way to PS1
abstract: The artist Francesco Vezzoli had planned a dismantled church as the center of his New York show, before Italian authorities stopped the shipment.
lead_paragraph: It was a typically elaborate, provocative move by the Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli in a career full of them: He had contracted to buy the ruins of an old deconsecrated church in the southern Italian town of Montegiordano and had planned to ship them to New York, brick by brick, for exhibition in the courtyard of MoMA PS1. His videos would be shown inside.

headline: 14 Screenwriters Writing
abstract: A celebration of the people who wrote the best words we heard on-screen this year.
lead_paragraph: Screenwriters famously get no respect. It probably doesn’t help that one of the most famous quotes about the trade boils down to money, competition and idiots. Herman J. Mankiewicz, in an often-cited telegram sent from Hollywood to his fellow writer Ben Hecht, promised: “Millions are to be grabbed out here, and your only competition is idiots. Don’t let this get around.”

headline: A Wink Toward Tradition in a Modern Evening
abstract: 21c Liederabend, a festival of song that was part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival, opened on Friday at the Harvey Theater.
lead_paragraph: Successful entrepreneurs know that there’s an art to naming a new venture. You need to get your point across quickly, clearly and with nuance. Beth Morrison and Paola Prestini, the impresarios behind 21c Liederabend, nailed this straightaway when they started the biennial performance series in 2009: “21c” proclaims modernity. “Liederabend,” a 19th-century German term meaning “song night,” labels the package neatly, while hinting at Romantic notions of intimacy and literary depth.

headline: Flea Theater To Open Three-Stage Complex
abstract: The Off Off Broadway theater will break ground on its new $18.5 million home on Dec. 5.
lead_paragraph: The Flea Theater in Lower Manhattan plans to break ground Dec. 5 on an $18.5 million theater complex at 20 Thomas Street that will include three theaters along with offices and costume and scene shops.

headline: Distant Cousins, Conferring in Different Dialects
abstract: The Sachal Jazz Ensemble and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra explored themes that cross cultures at the Rose Theater Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: Jazz and Pakistani music aren’t complete strangers to each other, as long as you relate Pakistani music to the rest of South Asian music. Think about John Coltrane playing “India” in 1961, and consider that some of the most promising or accomplished improvisers in the United States today — Vijay Iyer, Rudresh Mahanthappa, Rafiq Bhatia and the Karachi-born Rez Abbasi, for instance — come from South Asian families. But musicians living in Pakistan and playing jazz, or something like it: that’s rarer.

headline: An Author Dives Into Pink Floyd
abstract: The playwright Tom Stoppard’s new work is a one-hour radio play, “Darkside,” for which he has written text to go over the music of “The Dark Side of the Moon.”
lead_paragraph: In his 2006 hit play, “Rock ’n’ Roll,” the British playwright Tom Stoppard examined the relationship between music and politics, shuttling back and forth between England and Czechoslovakia over a 25-year period. Now, in a new work, a one-hour radio play called “Darkside,” he has narrowed his focus to a single famous album, Pink Floyd’s “The Dark Side of the Moon.”

headline: Control and Nuance, With a Brazilian Flavor
abstract: The pianist Nelson Freire offered Villa-Lobos, as well as Chopin and Granados, in a concert for Lincoln Center’s Great Performers series on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian pianist Nelson Freire often includes works by his compatriot Villa-Lobos in his programs. After an enthusiastically received performance at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, part of Lincoln Center’s Great Performers series, he offered Villa-Lobos’s “A lenda do caboclo” as an encore, as well as a poetic rendition of Chopin’s Nocturne in D flat (Op. 27, No. 2).

headline: For Young Ensembles, an Entrepreneur and an Audience
abstract: David Lang, who holds the Debs Composers Chair at Carnegie Hall, brought young ensembles together for “New Voices, New Music” on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcoming the audience from the Zankel Hall stage brightly on Wednesday night, the composer David Lang said that when Carnegie Hall presented him with a range of possible activities to undertake as the newest holder of its Debs Composers Chair, he had responded that he wanted to do them all.

headline: In Performance: ‘Regular Singing’
abstract: Jon DeVries and Maryann Plunkett in “Regular Singing,” the final Apple Family play, set on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: Jon DeVries and Maryann Plunkett in “Regular Singing,” the final Apple Family play, set on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy.

lead_paragraph: In a management shake-up at the world’s second-largest concert promoter, A.E.G. Live has parted ways with its longtime chief executive, Randy Phillips.

headline: In Store | Billy Reid Brings Easy Style to the Big Easy
abstract: The designer opens his 10th store, imbued with his usual Southern hospitality, on Magazine Street in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: New Orleans is an excellent destination for food and drink, but finding a stylish frock there can be like tracking down ripe tomatoes out of season. The newest Billy Reid shop, nestled among a cluster of antiques stores on a charming corner of Magazine Street, aims to fix that. “There’s a palpable energy in this town right now,” the fashion designer explained between sips of a bourbon cocktail and bites of duck liver pâté at the store’s opening party last weekend. “There are just a lot of positive vibes here.” The New Orleans store is his 10th to open in 9 years, joining locations in Nashville, Atlanta, Austin and New York.

lead_paragraph: The first sign that something was amiss at Great Kills Park, on Staten Island, came in 2005 when a police flyover of New York City detected a positive reading for radioactive material there.

headline: Storm Threatens to ‘Clobber’ Thanksgiving Travel Plans
abstract: A storm that has already claimed the lives of at least a dozen people is moving east and expected to create havoc for many holiday travelers.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:05 a.m., Tuesday A powerful storm blamed for at least 12 deaths in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and California since late last week is moving up the East Coast, threatening to disrupt Thanksgiving holiday travel plans for drivers and travelers at some of the nation’s busiest airports.

headline: Egyptians Vow to Fight New Protest Ban
abstract: While a new law banning protests in Egypt was roundly mocked online, activists immediately applied for a permit to test it, by organizing a protest against the measure.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, the military-backed government that came to power in Egypt after mass demonstrations issued a new law that effectively banned mass demonstrations on Sunday.

keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Demolition', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia building contractor was charged with murder on Monday in connection with a building collapse in June that killed six people and injured 13 others, the Philadelphia district attorney’s office said.

headline: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 23 People
abstract: A series of bombings and shootings on Monday left at least 23 people dead and more than 20 wounded, Iraqi security officials and medical workers said.
lead_paragraph: A series of bombings and shootings on Monday left at least 23 people dead and more than 20 wounded, Iraqi security officials and medical workers said. Just after sunset, an explosion at a market in central Baghdad killed 12 people, the police said. Earlier, a suicide bomber attacked a police checkpoint north of Baghdad, killing three police officers and two civilians. South of Baghdad, two militia members were killed by a roadside bomb. Another militia member was killed by a bomb attached to his car in Salahuddin Province, north of Baghdad, while a roadside bomb near a high school in the region killed a woman. In Baghdad, a bomb blew up a truck driver and gunmen killed a Ministry of Justice employee. More than 300 Iraqis have been killed this month in similar attacks.

headline: The Heartbreaker That is Tony Romo
abstract: The Cowboys quarterback has the team in position to make the playoffs. But William C. Rhoden notes that history tells us Tony Romo will eventually disappoint Dallas fans.
lead_paragraph: The Cowboys quarterback has the team in position to make the playoffs. But William C. Rhoden notes that history tells us Tony Romo will eventually disappoint Dallas fans.

headline: Ten Former N.H.L. Players Sue League Over Head Injuries
abstract: The players, who were in the league in the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s, filed their suit in federal court on Monday, which comes about three months after the N.F.L. agreed to settle a similar case.
lead_paragraph: Ten former N.H.L. players sued the league Monday for negligence and fraud, saying the sport’s officials should have done more to address head injuries but instead celebrated a culture of speed and violence.

headline: The Vatican: Putin Meets the Pope
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with Pope Francis in the Vatican on Monday, and their first encounter was primarily focused on the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with Pope Francis in the Vatican on Monday, and their first encounter was primarily focused on the Middle East. They emphasized “the need to bring an end to the violence” in Syria, ensuring humanitarian assistance to Syrians affected by the fighting while seeking ways to find a “peaceful solution to the conflict,” the Vatican said in a statement. They also touched on “the life of the Catholic community in Russia,” according to the Vatican, but the Holy See spokesman, the Rev. Federico Lombardi, said that the “ecumenical question” between the Roman Catholic and Orthodox Churches, whose relationship has been tense since the two churches divided nearly 1,000 years ago, was not discussed.

headline: ‘Why Care About the N.S.A.?’
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Computers and the Internet', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Corporations']
abstract: This Op-Doc video explains why ordinary Americans should be concerned about online surveillance.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans and people around the world, I was deeply disturbed to hear the revelations of Edward Snowden about N.S.A. surveillance, which is an affront to the United States Bill of Rights. But as a filmmaker who has made a number of documentaries about technology and online activism, I can’t say that Snowden’s revelations came as a surprise. Some concerned citizens have long understood that powerful digital technologies can be abused to carve away at civil liberties.

headline: Report Retraces Six Minutes of Horror, and Every Step a Gunman Took
abstract: A report released by Connecticut authorities on the Sandy Hook killings recreated the sequence of events that morning in minute detail.
lead_paragraph: At 9:30 a.m. on Dec. 14, in Room 9 of Sandy Hook Elementary School, the principal, psychologist, and other staff members had gathered for a meeting about student placement.

headline: Suit Accuses Rikers Officers of Illegal Strike
abstract: The purpose of the work slowdown that sidelined 33 buses, the lawsuit suggests, was to prevent one particular inmate from testifying against two correction officers.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for New York City filed a lawsuit on Monday against the correction officers’ union, accusing it of an illegal strike last week that prevented hundreds of inmates on Rikers Island from reaching court.

headline: Jean Banchet, Chef Who Translated French Cuisine, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Banchet’s traditional French cooking helped turn the Chicago suburbs into a global destination for food-lovers in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Jean Banchet, a dashing chef whose traditional French cooking helped make the Chicago suburbs a global destination for food lovers in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Sunday at his home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Virginia: Democrat Certified as Attorney General
abstract: Mark R. Herring, a Democrat, was certified by the State Board of Elections as Virginia’s next attorney general on Monday, but he may face a recount.
lead_paragraph: Mark R. Herring, a Democrat, was certified by the State Board of Elections as Virginia’s next attorney general on Monday, but he may face a recount in a race he won by just 165 votes out of 2.2 million cast. Both Mr. Herring and his Republican opponent, Mark D. Obenshain, have formed transition committees. Mr. Obenshain, who has 10 days to request a recount, issued a statement calling the Nov. 5 vote “the closest statewide election in modern Virginia history.” He said the choice to press a recount “is not one to be made lightly.” Both sides have lawyers at the ready for a recount battle. There is a “nuclear option”: to contest the election, which would throw it into the state House of Delegates. Republicans hold a majority there.

headline: Israelis See Ticking Clock, and Alternate Approaches, on Iran and Palestinians
abstract: To some, Israel’s differing approach to the Iran nuclear negotiations and to peace talks with the Palestinians is a sign of hypocrisy. Others say it is an existential necessity.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli leaders on Monday condemned the interim deal on Iran’s nuclear program as an exercise in appeasement by the Western powers and a delaying tactic by Iran. Yet many of them see the same strategy of interim confidence-building steps as the only realistic route to resolving their long-running conflict with the Palestinians.

headline: Emissions of Methane in U.S. Exceed Estimates, Study Finds
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Air Pollution', 'Global Warming']
abstract: A new analysis of man-made emissions of the greenhouse gas in the United States showed they were about 1.5 times higher than prevailing estimates.
lead_paragraph: Emissions of the greenhouse gas methane due to human activity were roughly 1.5 times greater in the United States in the middle of the last decade than prevailing estimates, according to a new analysis by 15 climate scientists published Monday in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: New Clues May Change Buddha’s Date of Birth
abstract: At a temple in Nepal that contains a pillar documenting a homage at the Buddha’s birthplace, researchers determined that lower structures were erected as early as the sixth century B.C.
lead_paragraph: In traditional narratives, Queen Maya Devi, the mother of Buddha, gave birth to him while holding on to a branch of a tree in a garden at Lumbini, in what is now Nepal. Accounts vary as to when this occurred, leaving uncertain the founding century of one of the world’s major religions.

headline: Cage Fighter Who Faked Death Is Sentenced in Armed Robbery
abstract: Charles Rowan, a Michigan fighter, was sentenced to 17 ½ to 40 years in prison for robbing a gun store a month after he tried to escape a drug debt by convincing everyone that he had died.
lead_paragraph: Charles Rowan, a low-level cage fighter in Michigan who faked his death to escape a debt to a drug dealer, was sentenced Monday to 17 ½ to 40 years in prison after having pleaded guilty to armed robbery.

headline: After Six Million Miles in the Air, Few Complaints
