lead_paragraph: I HAVE traveled my entire career, and now I am traveling more than ever. All these miles for business have helped shape my worldview. I think anyone who travels learns a lot about different cultures, and that’s never a negative.

headline: Poor Field Conditions Confounding Teams in Moscow
abstract: Having top talent playing on badly worn fields is a problem for teams in Champions League games in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When Bayern Munich’s players enter the modest Khimki Arena here for a UEFA Champions League match on Wednesday, their biggest concern might not be the Russian cold or hostile fans or even their opponent, CSKA Moscow. It might be the stadium’s worn and weary playing surface.

headline: Vestas Hopes to Bring Wind Power to World
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A project called Wind for Prosperity aims to start supplying low-cost power to rural populations around the globe.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, solar energy has emerged as a solution for powering places that lack sufficient electricity, frequently remote areas in developing nations where conventional fuel can be expensive.

headline: Bumps in the Road to New Cholesterol Guidelines
abstract: Some doctors said a panel issuing guidelines for avoiding cholesterol risks had ignored part of the available data, and they asserted it should have first released a draft report to allow for comments.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a moment of triumph. An august committee had for the first time relied only on the most rigorous scientific evidence to formulate guidelines to prevent heart attacks and strokes, which kill one out of every three Americans. The group had worked for five years, unpaid, to develop them. Then, at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association, it all went horribly awry.

headline: In Campaign, Cash Flowed Circuitously
abstract: New York City’s mayoral race saw a spasm of unregulated campaign money, most of it unleashed by wealthy Democrats and unions, which are now under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Well, thank God. We stumbled out of the mayoral election without watching the conservative Koch brothers grab our little liberal darlings out of their beds, paint them red and register them as Republicans.

headline: Egypt’s Government Struggles to Gain Footing as Dissent Grows
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Constitutions']
abstract: It has become harder for officials to blame the Muslim Brotherhood for all the nation’s problems, nearly five months after it was swept from power.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When the new military-backed Egyptian government lifted a nationwide state of emergency more than 10 days ago, it seemed to be proclaiming a momentary victory in the battle with its principal foe, the Muslim Brotherhood, whose regular protests had begun to wither.

headline: No Way Out: ‘12 Years a Slave’
abstract: The film, unlike the memoir on which it is based, withholds from the audience an outlet for either its hope or its sympathy.
lead_paragraph: (Readers beware: This column includes a detailed discussion of the film’s plot. -- The Editors.)

headline: China’s Coercive Play
abstract: A plan to control disputed air space over the East China Sea increases risk of confrontation with Japan.
lead_paragraph: China’s decision to impose a new air defense zone over a wide swath of the East China Sea is at odds with its claim to want a peaceful resolution to territorial disputes over a group of islands there. The announcement is a highly provocative move that has increased tensions and could make direct conflict with Japan more likely.

headline: Mets Send Holiday Cheer, and Mixed Messages
abstract: The Mets’ inclusion of Lucas Duda in their holiday e-card, as well as their pass on a deal with shortstop Jhonny Peralta, might signal how much the team is willing to spend in the free-agent market.
lead_paragraph: The Mets sent their holiday video e-card Monday featuring eight players — the franchise’s pillars among them — along with Mr. and Mrs. Met, some cartoon backdrops and a flurry of animated snow.

headline: New Jersey Goes All In, Online
abstract: Internet gambling goes live in the state, and for gamblers with addiction problems, going broke has just become infinitely easier.
lead_paragraph: Internet gambling goes live in New Jersey on Tuesday. It’s the biggest expansion of the casino business in the state since the 1970s. For gamblers with addiction problems, the process of tapping a paycheck and maxing out a credit card has just become infinitely easier.

headline: Caring for Others Was the Right Move to Defeat the Blues
abstract: Unemployed and demoralized, Shawna Simmonds enrolled in a nursing assistant program and realized she was a natural-born caregiver.
lead_paragraph: There were days when Shawna Simmonds did not want to leave her bed. But it was a sagging spirit, not indolence, that kept her under the covers. Unemployment had left her demoralized.

headline: Helpful Definitions for Modern Authors
abstract: When your publicist acts as your mom, your mom acts as your audience and your audience acts as your reviewer.
lead_paragraph: You, Author: Act as Book’s Publicist, responsible for promotion.

headline: A Glimmer of Sense on Guantánamo
abstract: The Senate defeated an amendment that would have extended the existing transfer restrictions of the detainees.
lead_paragraph: The Senate, in a little-noticed but positive move, voted last Tuesday to give President Obama new leeway to move toward closing the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Defining, and Raising, a ‘Healthy Eater’
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Eating Disorders', 'Parenting']
abstract: Is it more important to require that your children eat healthy foods all of the time, or to teach them how to make their own healthier choices some of the time?
lead_paragraph: “You are what you eat, from your head down to your feet!”

headline: Bulls’ Rose to Miss Another Year After Knee Injury
abstract: After missing all of the 2012-13 season while he recovered from an injury to his left knee, Rose now finds his 2013-14 season over after just 10 games.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The somber news was delivered in a terse statement from the Chicago Bulls on Monday afternoon. “Earlier this morning, Chicago Bulls guard Derrick Rose underwent successful surgery to repair his previously torn medial meniscus in his right knee,” it read.

headline: End the N.S.A. Dragnet, Now
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Search and Seizure', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: A Senate reform bill doesn’t go far enough.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE framers of the Constitution declared that government officials had no power to seize the records of individual Americans without evidence of wrongdoing, and they embedded this principle in the Fourth Amendment. The bulk collection of Americans’ telephone records — so-called metadata — by the National Security Agency is, in our view, a clear case of a general warrant that violates the spirit of the framers’ intentions. This intrusive program was authorized under a secret legal process by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, so for years American citizens did not have the knowledge needed to challenge the infringement of their privacy rights.

headline: ID Verification Lagging on Health Care Website
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Many people have had their applications cast into limbo after they uploaded copies of driver’s licenses, Social Security cards and voter registration cards to HealthCare.gov.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days before the Obama administration’s self-imposed deadline to fix the troubled federal health insurance website, officials said Monday that they were aware of another problem that has prevented thousands of people who were unable to verify their identity from shopping for health plans.

headline: The Charity Swindle
abstract: Where did $100 million go? Not to the needy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — BY all outward indications, the U.S. Navy Veterans Association was a leader in the charitable community. Founded in 2002 to provide support to Navy veterans in need, the charity recorded astonishing financial success. In its first eight years, it raised around $100 million in charitable contributions, almost all of it through a direct marketing campaign. The organization, headed by Jack L. Nimitz, boasted of 41 state chapters and some 66,000 members.

headline: At Auction, Bids Are Placed on Vestiges of Koch Era
abstract: An auction of letters and other memorabilia belonging to Edward I. Koch, who died in February, drew many fans of the loquacious city leader.
lead_paragraph: How’s he doing? Even in death, not bad.

headline: The North Carolina Five
abstract: Only the N.C.A.A. would criminalize behavior it should encourage.
lead_paragraph: The Uniform Athlete Agents Act was a bill drafted 13 years ago at the urging of the N.C.A.A. The drafters were members of something called the Uniform Law Commission, whose job it is to propose model legislation that the states can then adopt if they so choose. Today, 41 states have the law, or some variant of it, on their books.

headline: A Debate Over Paying Board Nominees of Activist Funds
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Executive Compensation', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The dispute around director compensation is the latest front in the war of influence between activist hedge funds and corporate boards.
lead_paragraph: When executives serve on a company’s board, they are often handsomely compensated.

headline: The State’s Findings on Newtown
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings', 'Editorials', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A portrait of a disturbed young man obsessed with weapons emerges from the official report from Connecticut officials on the school massacre.
lead_paragraph: One of the painful anomalies in the state’s official report about December’s school massacre in Newtown, Conn., is the evidence that while Adam Lanza, the shooter who murdered 20 children and six adults, was the object of his mother’s great and continuing concern, it did not stop her from writing a check so he might obtain his own pistol in a family already well stocked with firearms.

headline: Frustration From a Deal on Flawed Hip Implants
abstract: Some patients say the real winners in the $2.5 billion settlement are Johnson & Johnson and the plaintiffs’ lawyers, who will get about a third of the money.
lead_paragraph: Patients injured by a flawed hip implant sold by Johnson & Johnson have directed their anger at myriad places over the years. The regulatory system that allowed the product’s sale. The company that repeatedly denied problems with the device. Even the doctors who implanted the hips.

headline: Judge Is Asked to Toss Out Conviction in ’90 Killing of Tourist
abstract: In his motion for a new trial, Johnny Hincapie, one of seven men convicted of stabbing Brian Watkins, cites a coerced confession and witnesses who placed him elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: A decades-old murder case that galvanized public outrage over violent crime in New York was resurrected on Monday, as lawyers for one of the men convicted at trial say they have unearthed new evidence that proves their client was not involved in the attack.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 25, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Obama Speaks About Immigration Overhaul
abstract: President Obama made the case for changes in immigration policy in a speech in San Francisco during which a man heckled him.
lead_paragraph: President Obama made the case for changes in immigration policy in a speech in San Francisco during which a man heckled him.

headline: N.S.A. May Have Hit Internet Companies at a Weak Spot
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Computer Security', 'Data Centers']
abstract: Security experts said they believe that government spies bypassed Google and Yahoo and targeted the fiber-optic cables that connect their data centers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The recent revelation that the National Security Agency was able to eavesdrop on the communications of Google and Yahoo users without breaking into either company’s data centers sounded like something pulled from a Robert Ludlum spy thriller.

headline: To Offset Risks Inside, Blazers Star Improves His Outside Shooting
abstract: Playing point guard in the N.B.A. is a physically demanding job, and Damian Lillard knew he needed ways to preserve his career.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Damian Lillard has always had a dependable midrange game, but he spent time developing it over the summer. He was coming off his rookie season with the Portland Trail Blazers, and the league had delivered its hard lessons.

headline: Conservative Leads Effort to Raise Minimum Wage in California
abstract: Ron Unz, who rose to fame by promoting a ballot initiative that essentially eliminated bilingual education in California, is taking on a goal that has stymied liberals.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ron Unz, a Silicon Valley millionaire, rose to fame by promoting a ballot initiative that essentially eliminated bilingual education in California. He went on to become publisher of The American Conservative, a libertarian-leaning magazine.

headline: Obama Calls for Quick Action on Immigration, and So Does a Heckler
abstract: A young man who was part of a White House-approved backdrop yelled that President Obama had “a power to stop deportation for all undocumented immigrants.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — President Obama is often heckled, but it is rare for a guest who is part of a White House-approved backdrop to shout out a protest while the president is in mid-speech.

headline: U.S. Relations With Iran Thaw, and  Allies Shiver
abstract: If the United States continues to become more engaged with Iran, how would that affect relations with other allies in the region?

headline: F.D.A. Lifts Some Restrictions on Avandia
abstract: Doctors said the move was unlikely to breathe new life into the diabetes drug, which has been largely discredited in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration removed some restrictions on the prescribing and use of the diabetes drug Avandia on Monday, saying that new research showed the drug did not increase the chances of heart attacks.

headline: Brooklyn Pantry Struggling to Help Fill Gap Left by Federal Cuts to Food Stamps
abstract: Last week, staff members at the pantry run by the Bed-Stuy Campaign Against Hunger had feared that at the rate people were lining up for food, the pantry would be bare before the weekend.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of last week, panic set in at the food pantry in Brooklyn run by the Bed-Stuy Campaign Against Hunger.

headline: Intellectual Property Protection
abstract: Don Gagliardo and Zhouquin “C.C.” Burnikel mark up your puzzle for you.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Now, here’s a puzzle you can learn something from. I do love it when that happens. Usually, there are only one or two words that I might not know in any given puzzle, but today, the whole theme was a learning experience.

headline: Alec Reid, Northern Ireland Priest Who Helped Broker Peace Accord, Dies at 82
abstract: Father Reid served as a secret peace broker between Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, and contacts in the British and Irish governments.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Rev. Alec Reid, an unassuming Roman Catholic priest who played a quiet but crucial role in clandestine negotiations that led to the historic Good Friday peace accord in Northern Ireland in 1998, died here on Friday. He was 82.

headline: Officers Are Told Race Can Be a Factor in Street Stops, but Not the Only One
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: With a new law in effect that expands the types of suits that can be filed over profiling, the New York Police Department gave officers guidelines for stop and frisk.
lead_paragraph: The warnings had been dire: A law broadening the types of lawsuits that can be filed over accusations of police profiling would make New York City less safe. It would cut into terrorism investigations and anti-gang initiatives and make police officers wary of stopping suspects on the street.

headline: New Pitch for Health Initiative: Mind Your Mom. Get Insured.
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Parenting', 'Youth']
abstract: To encourage enrollment by the young Americans who are crucial to the success of the Affordable Care Act, insurers are appealing to their primary health care advisers: their mothers.
lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration’s health overhaul sputters in its opening weeks, insurers and advocacy groups are pursuing a new strategy in the quest to get millions of young people to sign up for health insurance: They’re appealing to their mothers.

headline: Skateboarding Twins Execute a Career 180 in Turning to Tennis
abstract: Nic and Tristan Puehse had a steep learning curve, but two years into their tennis adventure, the twins appear to have traded one obsession for another.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Nic and Tristan Puehse spent six years sailing through the air with the greatest of ease, bending on their skateboards like yogis on mats. They had a clothing contract with Nike before their eighth birthdays, and by the age of 12, they were performing difficult feats like the stalefish.

headline: Reinventing Rio de Janeiro
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2016)', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Ports', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Cable Cars and Trams']
abstract: With the World Cup and the Olympics bearing down on Rio within the next three years, officials here are struggling to reinvent this onetime third-world city with a first-world economy.
lead_paragraph: With the World Cup and the Olympics bearing down on Rio within the next three years, officials here are struggling to reinvent this onetime third-world city with a first-world economy.

headline: A Divided Rio de Janeiro, Overreaching for the World
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2016)', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Ports', 'Soccer']
abstract: Progressive ideals are running up against age-old, intractable problems in Rio de Janeiro, where class difference and corruption are nearly as immovable as the mountains.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The bumpy ride in the rickety van heads up the steep hill into Morro da Providência, this city’s oldest favela. Last stop: a small, silent square with a hardware shop, bar and pair of young policemen in armored gear toting machine guns, patrolling the still-unopened cable-car station that the city has recently built. The port spreads out below.

headline: Nicks’s Absence Against the Cowboys Adds to His Perplexing Season
abstract: Hakeem Nicks spent last week insisting he was going to play against the Cowboys, but on game day, the Giants did not even let him warm up to see if he could play.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Hakeem Nicks, struggling through a middling, enigmatic season, spent all of last week insisting he was going to play against the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday. On game day, the Giants not only kept him out of uniform, they did not even let him warm up in the hours before kickoff to see if he could play.

headline: As Homeless Line Up for Food, Los Angeles Weighs Restrictions
abstract: Facing an uproar from homeowners in a county that has one of the worst homeless problems in the nation, two members of the City Council have called for the city to ban the feeding of homeless people in public spaces.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They began showing up at dusk last week, wandering the streets, slumped in wheelchairs and sitting on sidewalks, paper plates perched on their knees. By 6:30 p.m., more than 100 homeless people had lined up at a barren corner in Hollywood, drawn by free meals handed out from the back of a truck every night by volunteers.

headline: U.S. and Saudis in Growing Rift as Power Shifts
abstract: Although Saudi Arabia remains a close American ally, the nuclear accord with Iran is the culmination of a slow mutual disenchantment that began at the end of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was a time when Saudi and American interests in the Middle East seemed so aligned that the cigar-smoking former Saudi ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, was viewed as one of the most influential diplomats in Washington.

headline: Dispute Erupts in India Over Surveillance by Candidate
abstract: Government eavesdropping on a woman in India has been traced to Narendra Modi, Gujarat State’s chief minister, and it has spurred a discussion of the state’s use of surveillance.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In a set of telephone transcripts and recordings that were published by an Indian website this month, high-ranking intelligence and security officers from the western state of Gujarat can be heard reporting back on an unusual assignment: covertly tracing every movement of a young woman, meticulously documenting her contacts with men. Their findings were passed to another high-ranking official they referred to as “Saheb.”

headline: Corrections: November 26, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 26, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: ‘One-Trick Pony’ Offense Nags Jets
abstract: The Jets’ approach has become almost predictable, with a heavy reliance on the running game to minimize Geno Smith’s impact that is noticeable.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — There was a splash of good news that came out of Sunday’s mauling in Baltimore, Rex Ryan said.

headline: James Rensenbrink, 81, Dies; Founded Aquarian Weekly
abstract: Mr. Rensenbrink’s Aquarian Weekly claimed to be one of the last independent alternative papers in the country and one of the oldest continuously published ones.
lead_paragraph: When James Rensenbrink started an alternative newspaper in 1969, its mission — speaking truth to power, debunking corporate journalism, promoting rock ’n’ roll, publishing sex tips and drug advice that no mainstream newspaper would — made it like a thousand other alternative papers in that high-water-mark counterculture year.

headline: Popping the Question, Tuhao-Style
abstract: Expensive marriage proposals in China have been criticized online using a newly coined word.
lead_paragraph: How many pairs of shoes does it take to reach a Chinese girl’s heart? According to Xu Pengjie, a 28-year-old restaurant owner in Chengdu, the answer is 1,001.

headline: The Changing American Family
abstract: Same-sex parents. Cohabiting couples. Voluntary kin. Children with parents in prison. Immigrant-Americans. What we thought of as the typical American family is being rapidly redefined. It is more diverse than it was even half a year ago.
lead_paragraph: American households have never been more diverse, more surprising, more baffling. In this special issue of Science Times, NATALIE ANGIER takes stock of our changing definition of family.

headline: Franco and O’Dowd Confirmed for ‘Of Mice and Men’ on Broadway
abstract: James Franco and Chris O’Dowd will make their Broadway debuts in a production of John Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men.”
lead_paragraph: James Franco (“127 Hours”) and Chris O’Dowd (“Bridesmaids”) will make their Broadway debuts as George and Lennie in John Steinbeck’s play “Of Mice and Men,” with performances starting March 19 at the Longacre Theater, the lead producer, David Binder, announced Monday. The two stars had been in negotiations with Mr. Binder for the last few months, and he has also lined up one of the few Broadway theaters still available for the spring season.

headline: Effective Corporate Tax Rates
abstract: Tax reform is needed to end the practice of many American corporations of stashing cash abroad, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | aversion
abstract: This word has appeared in 146 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: aversion •\ə-ˈvər-zhən, -shən\• noun

headline: Lakers Finalize Deal With Bryant With Eye on 2014 Free Agents
abstract: Kobe Bryant and the Los Angeles Lakers finalized a two-year contract extension that all but ensures he will end his career with the team.
lead_paragraph: Kobe Bryant and the Los Angeles Lakers finalized a two-year contract extension Monday that all but ensures Bryant will end his career with the team.

headline: Typhoon Haiyan Through the Lens of China’s 2008 Quake
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Earthquakes', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Typhoons']
abstract: The Philippine typhoon took far fewer lives than the 2008 Sichuan earthquake in China, but the magnitude of the disaster in some ways seemed greater in the typhoon.
lead_paragraph: Around the time I visited my second mass grave for victims of Typhoon Haiyan, I concluded this disaster was different. I had covered a catastrophic natural disaster before, the 2008 earthquake in China’s Sichuan Province that left nearly 90,000 dead or missing.

headline: Super Bowl First: A U.S. Telecast With Spanish Announcers
abstract: The Super Bowl, which has never before been televised in Spanish in the United States, will air on Fox Deportes.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 2, when Fox Sports carries Super Bowl XLVIII from MetLife Stadium, so will Fox Deportes, the Spanish-language network that is also part of 21st Century Fox. The Super Bowl has never before been televised in Spanish in the United States.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FX) WANTED (2008) A meek cubicle drone (James McAvoy, above) is initiated into a secret society of assassins known as the Fraternity to avenge the murder of his father in this ultraviolent action-thriller directed by Timur Bekmambetov. Morgan Freeman plays the organization’s leader, and Angelina Jolie portrays an amoral if fashionably turned-out killer. “Mr. Bekmambetov, a Russian filmmaker who has earned a cult following with his razzly-dazzly thrillers ‘Day Watch’ and ‘Night Watch,’ certainly proves here that he knows how to use every blunt tool of the bullying trade: flashy effects, zippy cuts, simulated death, walls of sound, wheels of steel and, in between the bullets and blood, a hot mama to make the brother-to-brother, man-on-man action less worrisome,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Wanted’ is a goof, then, and for a short stretch a pretty diverting one.”

headline: Knicks Drop Sixth Straight, Falling in Portland
abstract: The Trail Blazers took an early 22-point lead and responded to every run from the Knicks, who were led by Carmelo Anthony’s 34 points and 15 rebounds.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Before Monday night’s game, one of the television sets inside the visitors’ locker room at the Moda Center was tuned to an N.F.L. game. This did not please Amar’e Stoudemire, the veteran Knicks forward who was sprawled on the floor studying film of the Trail Blazers. He wanted the football turned off. Why was it even on?

headline: A Conversation With: Prabhat Jauhari, C.E.O. of Mumbai Private Security Firm
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Gun Control', 'Police', 'Rescues', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Mr. Jauhari spoke about how people’s perception about security has changed in the five years since the terror attacks in Mumbai.
lead_paragraph: Prabhat Jauhari is the chief executive officer of Tops Air Rescue and Topsline Life Response Services, the first private emergency response service in Mumbai, which was started by Topsgrup in 2004. The Topsline crew, which is trained in rescue and evacuation operations, worked with the Mumbai police during the terror attacks of Nov. 26, 2008, to rescue over 150 people.

headline: Qualcomm Investigated Under Antitrust Law
abstract: The timing of the inquiry has led some to question whether the Chinese government may be trying to gain leverage for its upcoming royalty negotiations with the American company.
lead_paragraph: Qualcomm, the San Diego-based mobile chip maker, has become the target of an antitrust investigation led by the National Development and Reform Commission, China’s top economic planning body — a disclosure that sent Qualcomm shares tumbling 1.5 percent and raised concerns about the company’s prospects in its fastest-growing market.

headline: News Quiz | November 26, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 26, 2013
abstract: Answer this question about presidential assassinations.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Bayer in Bid to Acquire Norwegian Cancer Drug Firm
abstract: The offer by Bayer of Germany is 27 percent above Algeta’s closing share price on Monday. The companies are partners in a new prostate cancer drug.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Norwegian cancer drug maker Algeta said on Tuesday that it had received a preliminary offer to be acquired by the German drug giant Bayer for about $2.4 billion.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Whales, Sea Lions and Dolphins Congregate for Anchovy Feast
abstract: When have you seen something incredible in nature?
lead_paragraph: In “With Extra Anchovies, Deluxe Whale Watching,” Erica Goode reports on a rare convocation of sea life off the California coast.

headline: Ukraine in Turmoil After Leaders Reject Major E.U. Deal
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Tens of thousands of protesters have demanded that the country shake off its post-Soviet identity and move into the orbit of a more prosperous Europe.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Yuri V. Lutsenko, a onetime field commander of Ukraine’s 2004 Orange Revolution, looked out across the tens of thousands of people who gathered on Sunday to protest the government’s decision to back away from a far-reaching political and trade deal with the European Union. Standing onstage under an ash-streaked sky, Mr. Lutsenko felt a powerful sense of déjà vu — and a deep need to apologize.

headline: Scots Propose Independence With Pounds and Passports
abstract: The proposal, 670 pages long, is part of an effort by Scottish authorities to answer many questions about the implications of a referendum next year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Behind in the opinion polls, Scottish Nationalists who are seeking independence from Britain in a referendum next year set out their wish list for a new nation on Tuesday, but made several assertions about their future relations with Britain and international partners that are sharply disputed.

headline: Mind the Gap
abstract: Running a global city is tough — and that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: At the not-yet-completed One57, a luxury residential tower off Central Park, the unsold floor-through apartments are going for $53 million and up. The penthouse sold for more than $90 million. One57 will be the tallest residence in the Western Hemisphere (until another luxury high-rise on Park Avenue is completed in 2015), and on a clear day, residents on the top floors should be able to just make out the South Bronx.

headline: The Final Frontier, in Photographs
abstract: Twin exhibitions throw together both scientific and fictitious depictions of space, from the 19th century to the present.
lead_paragraph: There it is — the whole shebang. Or what’s left of the Big Bang, if you want to be precise and scientific about it. The trippy scene, all fall colors and gray splotches, was built from data captured by NASA’s Spitzer Space Telescope and puts in visual form the remaining background light from when the universe was less than one billion years old.

headline: Do We Need Art in Our Lives?
abstract: Should viewing art be part of every child’s education? Does it make us smarter or expose us to new ways of seeing the world?
lead_paragraph: Do we need art in our lives? Should viewing art be part of every child’s education? Does it make us smarter or expose us to new ways of seeing the world?

headline: A New Way to Report Fraud
abstract: The Senate Special Committee on Aging has started a consumer hotline designed to help track scams targeting the elderly.
lead_paragraph: The letters arrive almost daily, on official-looking letterhead from a supposed charity, or from the J.M.D. Major Cash Disbursement Office. More blatantly, letters sometimes come from an outfit called Mountains of Money. They announce that the 85-year-old man to whom they’re addressed has won a prize — the amount seems to hover around $11,000 — and explain that to claim it, he has to fill out a form, often complete with a “verification code,” and send it in with a check for $6 or $7.

headline: China to Send ‘Jade Rabbit’ Rover to the Moon
abstract: The mission was described as one of the most difficult to date for China’s space program.
lead_paragraph: China will send an unmanned rover to the moon in early December, a spokesman for the Commission of Science, Technology, and Industry for National Defense said on Tuesday. The lunar probe will be called the Yutu, or Jade Rabbit, a name that comes from a Chinese myth about a white rabbit that lives on the moon and was selected in an online poll.

headline: Demonstrations in Bangkok Raise Concerns About Stability of Thailand
abstract: In a country that has become less governable amid a bitter political rivalry, protesters disrupted operations at several government ministries.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s governing party accused protesters on Tuesday of fomenting anarchy and trying to overthrow the government after thousands of people swarmed the streets of Bangkok, besieging crucial ministries and threatening to take their campaign nationwide.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 26 at 6 a.m.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — It took a while for people to notice, but once they did, the news spread like wildfire: The World Health Organization had said that about half of new H.I.V. cases in Greece were “self-inflicted” as a way to get state benefits.

headline: Noted Philosopher Moves to N.Y.U. — and Beyond
abstract: Kwame Anthony Appiah will divide his time between New York and the university’s international sites, including its degree-granting branches in Abu Dhabi and Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: The philosopher Kwame Anthony Appiah, known for his wide-ranging and accessible writings on cosmopolitanism, identity and global ethics, will be leaving Princeton for New York University at the end of the year.

headline: In Performance: Jon DeVries and Maryann Plunkett of ‘Regular Singing’
abstract: Maryann Plunkett and Jon DeVries in a scene from Richard Nelson’s “Regular Singing,” part of his four-play Apple Family series.
lead_paragraph: The works in Richard Nelson’s four-part Apple Family Plays are each set on a specific day in recent American history: election days of 2010 (“That Hopey Changey Thing”) and 2012 (“Sorry”); the 10th anniversary of 9/11 (“Sweet and Sad”) and the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy (“Regular Singing”). In this scene from “Regular Singing,” Barbara, a schoolteacher (played by Maryann Plunkett), and her uncle, Benjamin, a retired actor dealing with memory loss (portrayed by Jon DeVries), discuss an article about the assassination in The New York Times. Scenes from the four plays, which are being performed in repertory at the Public Theater through Dec. 15, are in this In Performance video player.

headline: Tricky Little Things
abstract: Tiny as they are, misplaced commas form an outsize blot on a sentence. In the spectrum of grammatical lapses, they seem particularly amateurish.
lead_paragraph: Tiny as they are, misplaced commas form an outsize blot on a sentence. In the spectrum of grammatical lapses, they seem particularly amateurish.

headline: Behind the Scenes of The Movies Issue
abstract: Janusz Kaminski explains his process in making the 11 films as part of the magazine’s Movies issue.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we teased the 2013 Movies Issue with a 15-second Instagram video. This time, we aren’t teasing. You can watch all 11 original films that Janusz Kaminski created for the magazine, each of which contains a line of dialogue written by one (or a team) of the best screenwriters of the year. Watch how it all came together in the video shown here, and get more backstage insight from this slide show.

Kimball and Smith carefully tiptoe about exactly what happened, and so will I — I hear stuff, but it’s second- or third-order hearsay, and not reliable.

headline: Daily Report: N.S.A. May Have Tapped Internet Cable Links
abstract: The National Security Agency may have been able to eavesdrop on Google and Yahoo users by infiltrating a weak spot in the Internet giants’ security: the fiber-optic cables that connect data centers around the world.
lead_paragraph: The recent revelation that the National Security Agency was able to eavesdrop on the communications of Google and Yahoo users without breaking into either companies’ data centers sounded like something pulled from a Robert Ludlum spy thriller. How on earth, the companies asked, did the N.S.A. get their data without them knowing about it?

headline: Pakistan Breaks Ground on Nuclear Plant Project With China
abstract: The project is expected to be a major step in meeting Pakistan’s growing energy crisis.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Tuesday ceremonially broke ground on a $9.59 billion nuclear power complex to be built in Karachi with China’s help, seeking to ease Pakistan’s long-running energy crisis and signaling a new step by China in becoming a top nuclear supplier.

headline: France Adds Troops in Central African Republic
abstract: The French defense minister, announcing that France would increase its force to 1,000 troops, said that the African country “is in collapse.”
lead_paragraph: In a bid to stem deepening chaos in the Central African Republic, where brutal government-affiliated militia groups have been pillaging and burning villages, the French defense minister announced on Tuesday that France would increase its deployment of troops there to about 1,000.

headline: California Myths
abstract: Gotta keep up, people.
lead_paragraph: Among the many vituperative reactions I had to yesterday’s column, one recurred a lot — namely, the assertion that California’s rising enrollment in Obamacare would bankrupt the state, which is already a fiscal basket case.

abstract: Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen on the continuing controversy over Hannah Arendt’s classic study of the nature of evil.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen on why Hannah Arendt’s “Eichmann in Jerusalem” remains contentious fifty years after it was first published.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Military Vehicles', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Amid the awards and decorations on display in the Pentagon office of Ashton B. Carter, the departing deputy secretary of defense, is a metal bearing, larger than a golf ball, which wears the scars of battle.

headline: Another Turnaround by Arians, This Time in Arizona
abstract: Bruce Arians, who was the A.P. coach of the year as the Colts’ interim coach last season, is only one reason the Arizona Cardinals are 7-4 and riding a four-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Arians is doing it again. A year ago, he helped turn the Indianapolis Colts from the worst team in the N.F.L. to a playoff team. Hired as the team’s offensive coordinator, he was named the Associated Press coach of the year after Chuck Pagano, who was found to have leukemia, took a leave of absence. The Arizona Cardinals hired Arians as their head coach after firing Ken Whisenhunt, and Arians is again a viable candidate for the award.

headline: What I Needed to Understand About Health Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Small Business']
abstract: A business owner says he realized this fall that if he spent time digging into his health insurance options, he might make a better choice. With luck, he hoped, he might even lower his costs.
lead_paragraph: I have bought health insurance for my workers since 1994, and since then I’ve spent well over a million dollars paying premiums. I have always found it to be troubling that I was given sole authority to make the choice as to what kind of coverage we would offer, and to a certain extent, how much it would cost. Was I doing a good job? I never heard any complaints about the policies I chose, even when I moved us into an HMO in the late ’90s, when I made my workers contribute to their plan costs in 2005, and when rates skyrocketed in the years after that.

headline: To Help Typhoon Survivors, Go Local
abstract: Guest blogger Mari Kuraishi urges readers to fund smaller scale, on the ground relief efforts in the wake of Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago I watched the footage of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, willing myself not to start imagining what else was going on that I couldn’t see or read about.  As a Japanese national living in the States, I was struck by the well-meaning experts who discouraged the public from donating to the relief efforts.  Journalists questioned the logic of individuals giving to a wealthy country like Japan, and philanthropic advisors encouraged donors to give to organizations that could redirect funds to other more pressing needs outside of Japan after the initial relief effort. It was understandable, perhaps—the fog of disaster makes it hard to immediately know how much is “needed,” or what help is needed, even where.

headline: New Jersey’s ‘Mutinous 33rd’
abstract: The story of John Toffey, a Garden State soldier who won the Medal of Honor at Chattanooga.
lead_paragraph: John Toffey was sick with fever. The Union lieutenant had been ill for days and not able to attend to his duties. An Army surgeon in Chattanooga, Tenn., examined the 19-year-old officer on the evening of Nov. 22, 1863, and handed him a permit to go into the hospital.

headline: Pope Sets Down Goals for an Inclusive Church, Reaching Out ‘on the Streets’
abstract: Francis said women must play an increasingly important role in the church, but that letting women be priests was “not a question open to discussion.”
lead_paragraph: In his first nine months as leader of one billion Roman Catholics, Pope Francis has parceled out glimpses of his vision for remaking the church — in homilies and news conferences, interviews and offhand remarks to visitors.

headline: A Fresh Look at America’s Gas Lands
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Energy and Power', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: A filmmaker from Finland tries to get beyond polarization and propaganda and provide a clear-eyed view of the many meanings of fracking in shale country.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been meaning to post for awhile on “Gas Rush Stories,” a series of simple, but captivating short films on America’s gas drilling boom made by Kirsi Jansa, a Finnish video journalist currently living in Pittsburgh.

headline: American Family Redefined
abstract: What’s a normal American family? Whatever it wants to be.
lead_paragraph: If the Burnses (with a family of 4 children from three earlier marriages) seem atypical as an American nuclear family, how about the Schulte-Waysers, a merry band of two married dads, six kids and two dogs? Or the Indrakrishnans, a successful immigrant couple in Atlanta whose teenage daughter divides her time between prosaic homework and the precision footwork of ancient Hindu dance; the Glusacs of Los Angeles, with their two nearly grown children and their litany of middle-class challenges that seem like minor sagas; Ana Perez and Julian Hill of Harlem, unmarried and just getting by, but with Warren Buffett-size dreams for their three young children; and the alarming number of families with incarcerated parents, a sorry byproduct of America’s status as the world’s leading jailer. Read more in The Changing American Family in Science Times.

headline: At Least 30 Haitians Die After Boat Capsizes
abstract: The fatal accident is the latest in a series of shipwrecks involving Haitian migrants, who pay smugglers to ferry them to the United States in often unseaworthy vessels.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — At least 30 Haitians who tried to sail to the United States were found drowned on Tuesday after their overloaded boat ran aground off the Bahamas and capsized, several days after fishermen tipped off Bahamian military authorities about the vessel.

headline: Pat McKillen, the Newest to Relive Bob Dylan’s ‘Like a Rolling Stone’
abstract: An interactive music video of Bob Dylan’s “Like a Rolling Stone” comes out, and the newest cover is by a Chicago singer-songwriter, Pat McKillen.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: A Well-Aged White Wine to Cosset Miso-Glazed Fish
abstract: For a dish rich in umami, you’ll need a wine that won’t wilt before it.
lead_paragraph: This is a dish rich in umami, and you need a wine that won’t wilt before it, preferably on the savory rather than fruity side. The ideal choice would be a well-aged white, like a 15-year-old grand cru Chablis, with just the right amount of richness and minerality to cosset the fish. Other options include a white Bordeaux from Pessac-Léognan or an older dry riesling with amplitude.

headline: Take-Two Interactive Buys Back Icahn Stake
abstract: The publisher of the Grand Theft Auto game series agreed to buy Carl C. Icahn’s stake for $203.5 million. The sale also compelled the resignations of three board members he was allowed to appoint.
lead_paragraph: Take-Two Interactive Software announced on Tuesday that it had bought back the stake held by Carl C. Icahn, compelling the resignations of three board members he was allowed to appoint.

headline: Rodriguez Amends Suit, Adding Claims About Selig
abstract: The updating came after Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, was not required last week to testify at Alex Rodriguez’s suspension hearing.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez’s lawyers updated their lawsuit against Major League Baseball on Tuesday, adding new claims about the conduct of baseball’s commissioner, Bud Selig, in defending his 211-game suspension of Rodriguez, the Yankees’ third baseman.

headline: Feeling For | A Parisian-Style Retreat in the Heart of Greenwich Village
abstract: Once a favorite of Jack Kerouac, the recently reopened Marlton Hotel in Greenwich Village is a must-visit for both its lodgings and its libations.
lead_paragraph: The Marlton House, built in 1900 and later a haven for Jack Kerouac and his crew, reopened this fall as the Marlton, a Parisian-inspired 107-room boutique hotel in the heart of Greenwich Village, just off Washington Square Park. It offers the same cool, casual elegance as the Bowery Hotel, a few blocks across town, but at a fraction of the price. The similarities to the Bowery are no surprise, as the Marlton is the work of the hotelier Sean MacPherson (also a developer of the Maritime and the Jane), who has once again created a hotel that feels as if it wasn’t designed just to sleep but also to sidle up to the bar in a dignified way and watch the P.Y.T.’s come and go. It’s the kind of place you could easily visit for afternoon tea with a parent on one of the plush sofas, or rendezvous with your lover for a martini followed by a trip to one of the small yet charming rooms, where the bed is the main attraction and finishing details are not overlooked. If you’re not in the mood for libations — and with creations like the Marvelous Sour (recipe below), the Marlton has taken steps to make sure that never happens — there is an espresso bar in the lobby that makes raw almond cappuccinos and gluten-free, vegan breakfast cookies. Coming soon will be a 98-seat restaurant in the rear of the lobby, Café Marlton, which will serve breakfast, lunch and dinner. As a longtime neighbor of the building the Marlton now occupies, I can safely say it’s the best recent addition to the neighborhood where charm reigns supreme.
