headline: Battling Flames in Forests, With Prison as the Firehouse
abstract: States like Arizona, California and Nevada are relying more on cheap, dependable prison crews as cuts shrink professional firefighting forces and wildfires burn bigger, hotter and longer.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — The men cluster in a tight pack, identities obscured by fire-resistant Nomex clothes, each one anonymous except for the color of his helmet: red for corrections officers, blue and yellow for inmates.

headline: Most New York Voters Happy With Cuomo, Poll Finds
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who faces re-election next year, is viewed favorably by 62 percent of state voters, according to Quinnipiac University.
lead_paragraph: With no declared Republican candidate, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is approaching his re-election year with an enviable approval rating and a comfortable advantage against one potential opponent, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

headline: A $100 Weekend in Santiago, Chile
abstract: Soup, sandwiches and a sofa are just three parts of a budget-friendly stay in the Chilean capital.
lead_paragraph: “My sofa is very comfortable,” boasted Marcos, the pony-tailed, Iron Maiden-loving Chilean who had met me at the centrally located Parque O’Higgins metro stop in the Chilean capital of Santiago and was walking me to his place. “I sometimes sleep on it myself.” When you have just $100 to spend all weekend, any place will do — but his worn-in black leather sofa, paired with a thick comforter for warmth and a snow-white cat named Ixi (named for Itchy, the “Simpsons” cartoon mouse) for company, turned out to be a dream.

headline: Barnes & Noble Reports Profit, but Sales Decline 8%
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Barnes & Noble Nook', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Sales were hurt by the Nook division, where revenue fell 32 percent, to $109 million.
lead_paragraph: Barnes & Noble reported tepid sales in its bookstore and digital divisions for its most recent quarter, reflecting an overall weak publishing climate and flattening demand for e-books.

headline: Chico Hamilton, Drummer, Bandleader and Exponent of Cool Jazz, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Hamilton, from the Los Angeles area, had a subtle and melodic approach that made him ideally suited for the refined, understated style that came to be known as cool jazz.
lead_paragraph: Chico Hamilton, a drummer and bandleader who helped put California on the modern-jazz map in the 1950s and remained active into the 21st century, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Justices to Hear Contraception Cases Challenging Health Law
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to hear cases on whether corporations may refuse to provide insurance coverage for birth control based on the religious beliefs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a pair of cases on whether corporations may refuse to provide insurance coverage for contraception to their workers based on the religious beliefs of the corporations’ owners.

headline: U.S. Sends Two B-52 Bombers Into Air Zone Claimed by China
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Officials said the United States military would continue to assert its right to fly through what it regards as international airspace after a recent Chinese claim to an “air defense identification zone.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defying China, two long-range American bombers flew through contested airspace over the East China Sea, days after the Chinese announced they were claiming the right to police the sky above a vast area that includes islands at the center of a simmering dispute with Japan.

headline: Down the Instagram Rabbit Hole
abstract: Discovery of one great Instagram photographer leads to the discovery of another one, then another . . .
lead_paragraph: Stacey Baker, magazine photo editor and Instagram dynamo, has been getting so much attention for her portraits of women’s legs that she gets approached by fans offline. One time a tourist spotted her taking a “legs” shot and asked, “Are you @stace_a_lace?” The woman had worn special tights that day on her visit to New York hoping to be photographed.

headline: From the Beatles to Lorde, Musicians Offer Songs for Philippine Relief Album
abstract: Proceeds from “Songs for the Philippines,” a 39-track compilation, will go toward relief efforts in the country.
lead_paragraph: More than three dozen musicians representing a broad range of pop styles — from the Beatles, Bob Dylan, U2 and Earth, Wind and Fire, at the classic end, to Lorde, Beyoncé, Justin Bieber and Katy Perry, among more recent hit makers — have contributed recordings to “Songs for the Philippines,” a 39-track compilation assembled to raise money for relief efforts in the country, which was devastated by Typhoon Haiyan on Nov. 8.

headline: Words of Love, Pain, Protest and Motown
abstract: Bartlett’s Familiar Black Quotations is not only the most comprehensive book of quotations from black thinkers, but it also possesses a potent and sweeping narrative arc covering 5,000 years.
lead_paragraph: Zora Neale Hurston (1891-1960) was probably the first great African-American food writer. She regularly hauled her appetites into her prose.

headline: Brazil Is Entranced by a Tale of Love, Taxes and Bribery
abstract: How did an $82,000-a-year tax inspector amass a fortune said to be about $8 million? Prosecutors offer an explanation.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — There were the boxes of Cuban cigars, which cost about $500 each at a shop in Vila Nova Conceição, one of the most exclusive districts of São Paulo, and the $2,260 bottles of Vega Sicilia Único, a legendary Spanish red. Throw in a Porsche Cayenne, speedboat jaunts to tropical islands and all-night soirees with high-end escorts, and what do you get?

headline: Taking a Break From I.V.F.
abstract: A break from fertility treatment is a chance to return to normal, but it’s hard to appreciate a phase of life you’re trying to leave behind.
lead_paragraph: “It’s all downhill from here.”

headline: Now Screening | Brought to You by Kenneth Cole, an Inside Perspective on the Battle Against AIDS
abstract: The fashion designer produced the new HBO documentary “The Battle of AmfAR,” about Elizabeth Taylor and the physicist Mathilde Krim’s efforts to fight the disease by founding the global AIDS research nonprofit.
lead_paragraph: “There is this pervasive sense out there that we have solved AIDS and that it’s not a crisis anymore,” says the designer Kenneth Cole, who is also chairman of the board of AmfAR, the Foundation for AIDS Research. “But AIDS is alive as it ever was. There are people living their lives recklessly and irresponsibly, and people need to understand that AIDS is still devastating, absent of a cure.”

headline: The Pope’s Take on Capitalism
abstract: In his first major piece of writing, Pope Francis called unfettered capitalism a “new tyranny.”
lead_paragraph: From the moment of his election, there have been signs that Pope Francis was going to be a very different sort of pontiff. It started with his decision to live in modest quarters instead of the palatial papal apartments, and continued with his tolerant comments about homosexuality and his complaint that the Roman Catholic Church had an unhealthy “obsession” with issues like abortion.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Dusts Off the Pac-Man Defense
abstract: The typical result of these battles is a combination of the warring companies. The question is, who becomes the management and which set of shareholders, if any, receive a premium?
lead_paragraph: Deal aficionados have a Thanksgiving present. Men’s Wearhouse has turned the tables on Jos. A. Bank Clothiers, offering to acquire the company, which had previously bid to acquire Men’s Wearhouse. What fun!

headline: Children’s Tablet Teaches Reading, Writing and Texting
abstract: VTech has created a safe zone for texting with its latest learning tablet, the InnoTab 3S.
lead_paragraph: Children, being the curious little monkeys they are, are keen to mimic their parents, but some activities, like texting, run the risk of exposing children to potential harm. Fear not, worried parents: VTech has created a safe zone for texting with its latest learning tablet, the InnoTab 3S.

headline: Tough Week at the Broadway Box Office
abstract: “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder,” which has drawn good reviews, saw modest sales, like some other new musicals this fall.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder” opened last week to some of the best reviews of the fall, but now comes the hard part: increasing its ticket sales.

headline: Lou Brissie, an All-Star and War Hero, Dies at 89
abstract: Brissie achieved his dream and inspired people with disabilities by making the major leagues after suffering devastating leg injuries in World War II.
lead_paragraph: Lou Brissie, who suffered devastating leg wounds in World War II but went on to become an All-Star pitcher with the Philadelphia Athletics and a symbol of perseverance for the disabled, died on Monday in Augusta, Ga. He was 89.

headline: Ford Discloses Two New Recalls for the 2013 Escape
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Fire hazards from possible oil and fuel leaks are cited for the 1.6-liter 4-cyinder engine.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 140,000 of its 2013 Escape crossovers in the United States because of a problem with the 1.6-liter EcoBoost 4-cylinder engine that has caused 13 fires, the automaker has told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, according to a report from the automaker posted Tuesday on the safety agency’s website.

headline: LED Lights, and an App to Control Them
abstract: TCP has a system that lets you control your home lights with an Apple or Android app.
lead_paragraph: The price of long-lasting LED bulbs is dropping rapidly — they are usually under $10, and they last many, many times as long as regular incandescent bulbs while using far less electricity.

headline: A D.J. Booth in Your Pocket
abstract: Monster, known for its audio cables and headphones, this month introduced the GO-DJ, a portable turntable and mixer.
lead_paragraph: Monster has found a way to shrink the D.J. booth into a pocket-size device. The company, known for its audio cables and headphones, this month introduced the GO-DJ, a portable turntable and mixer.

headline: Restaurant Report: Esquina Mocotó in São Paulo
abstract: One of the most recognizable faces in Brazilian cuisine opened this spot in May, right next door to a restaurant that he has transformed over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Mocotó, José Oliveira de Almeida’s restaurant in the Vila Medeiros neighborhood of São Paulo, opened in 1974. Over the past decade, his son, Rodrigo Oliveira, has transformed the unassuming neighborhood restaurant and bar into one of the most famous in the country, making him one of the most recognizable faces in Brazilian cuisine. For years he has fought off offers to open another restaurant in the city’s wealthier southern districts. Instead, he opened Esquina Mocotó in May, right next door.

headline: New Draws for Diners in a Sonoma County Town
abstract: Petaluma, 40 miles north of San Francisco, has been elevated to a culinary destination worthy of a visit.
lead_paragraph: Forty miles north of San Francisco, Petaluma has had a long and storied past as a prolific Sonoma County farm town — in 1907, it was known as a “City of a Million Hens,” turning out more than 120 million eggs that year (it was where the egg incubator was invented). To this day, it yields a cornucopia of food for top Bay Area restaurants from lauded producers like Cowgirl Creamery, Lagunitas Brewing Company and Liberty Ducks. But with several restaurant openings in recent years, Petaluma itself has lately been elevated to a culinary destination worthy of a visit.

headline: Prominent Egyptian Activists Detained for Protesting Under New Law
abstract: Video posted online showed police officers aiming a water cannon directly at protesters, including several prominent activists, who were chanting against Egyptian military rule outside the upper house of Parliament in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:57 p.m. | Using new powers to stifle dissent granted this week by Egypt’s military-backed government, riot police officers dispersed a peaceful protest outside the Parliament in Cairo on Tuesday and detained several prominent activists.

headline: Aerolineas Argentinas to Restore Flights to J.F.K.
abstract: Aerolineas Argentinas will begin offering flights between Kennedy International Airport and Buenos Aires on Dec. 16.
lead_paragraph: As many international airlines expanded to take advantage of Argentina’s post-peso crisis tourist boom, the country’s own national airline, Aerolineas Argentinas, seemed to go in reverse, even discontinuing its flight between New York’s Kennedy International Airport and Buenos Aires’ Ezeiza airports in 2008.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Partying Like It’s 1999 Once More
abstract: A heady stew of technology, entrepreneurs and venture capitalists is simmering again, but along with the rich payouts and soaring valuations is an undercurrent of concern.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — These are fabulous times in Silicon Valley.

headline: Ask Well: Nighttime Urination
abstract: A reader asks: How normal is it to get up and urinate three times a night?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: ‘Leave of Absence’ for Lara Logan After Flawed Benghazi Report
abstract: The leaves for the CBS correspondent and her producer follow an internal report that criticized her reporting methods for the segment on “60 Minutes.”
lead_paragraph: The CBS News correspondent Lara Logan and her producer, Max McClellan, made serious errors in an Oct. 27 report on the attack on the American compound in Benghazi, Libya, and will take leaves of absence, the network announced on Tuesday. Four Americans died in the Sept. 11, 2012, attack, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

headline: The Obamacare Worm Turns
abstract: It’s happening already.
lead_paragraph: Image taken down by request

headline: In a Time of Need, the Vice President Plays to His Strengths
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Following Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for a week shows how much he is talking to discouraged Democrats and covering the distracted president’s bases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking to longshoremen, local politicians and health care activists last week in Houston, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. variously quoted his grandfather Ambrose Finnegan, his father, Joe Sr., and the poet William Butler Yeats. “Joey,” he recalled his grandfather hollering, “keep the faith!”

headline: Making San Francisco Accessible to More Than the Tech Elite
abstract: San Francisco is a boomtown by nature. But the latest tech boom has some differences, and has raised questions about who is to blame for its downsides.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco is having an identity crisis. As we wrote about in a front-page article that appeared Monday, the prospering of tech companies has been accompanied by evictions, rising prices and growing resentment.

headline: Inquiry of JPMorgan’s Asia Hiring
abstract: Federal investigators and Hong Kong and British authorities are examining JPMorgan Chase’s hiring practices in Asia. The case began as an inquiry into the bank’s hiring of the sons and daughters of China’s elite.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators and Hong Kong and British authorities are examining JPMorgan Chase’s hiring practices in Asia. The case began as an inquiry into the bank’s hiring of the sons and daughters of China’s elite.

headline: 16 Recipes for Thanksgiving Leftovers
abstract: Chances are you’ll have a helping (or four) of leftovers after the feast. Here we offer a few suggestions for recipes to put that extra turkey, cranberry sauce and squash to good use.
lead_paragraph: Chances are you’ll have a helping (or four) of leftovers after the feast. Here we offer a few suggestions for recipes to put that extra turkey, cranberry sauce and squash to good use.

headline: ‘All the Way,’ With Bryan Cranston, Sets Broadway Opening Date
abstract: The play will open at the Neil Simon Theater, more typically a home for big-budget musicals.
lead_paragraph: The producers of “All the Way,” Robert Schenkkan’s play about Lyndon B. Johnson’s tumultuous first year as president, are banking on the star power provided by Bryan Cranston in the lead role, announcing a Broadway opening date in a theater usually occupied by big-budget musicals.

headline: Syrian Rebel Group Skeptical of Talks
abstract: The planned international conference on ending Syria’s civil war encountered its first obstacles, a day after it was announced in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A planned international peace conference aimed at ending the civil war in Syria faced its first hurdles on Tuesday, as the head of the main opposition coalition said the group had not yet decided whether it would attend and the leader of the group’s military arm said his forces would keep fighting regardless.

headline: Alec Baldwin’s Show on MSNBC Is Canceled
abstract: The actor had been suspended since Nov. 15 after conceding he had made a gay slur in a confrontation with a photographer.
lead_paragraph: The actor Alec Baldwin’s short-lived show on MSNBC has been terminated, less than two weeks after he was suspended for making a gay slur in a confrontation with a photographer seeking to get pictures of him with his wife and baby.

headline: An Article About New Yorkers Who Go Hungry Signals a New Focus on Inequality
abstract: The Times will pay more attention to the gap between rich and poor in its home city.
lead_paragraph: At a time of year when many are preparing to eat until bursting, it’s especially sobering to read the article in Tuesday’s Times about the number of New Yorkers who go hungry on a regular basis – one in five children throughout the city and nearly half the children in the Bronx.

headline: An ‘Unimaginable Milestone’ for an American Hostage in Iran
abstract: The Obama administration urged Iranian officials to help secure the release of a private investigator and former F.B.I. agent, Robert A. Levinson, who went missing in 2007.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of its diplomatic success over Iran’s nuclear program, the Obama administration on Tuesday urged Iranian officials to help secure the release of a former F.B.I. agent who went missing in 2007 in Iran.

headline: The Gun Report: November 26, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Adam Lanza, the Newtown gunman, covered the windows in his room with black garbage bags. He changed his clothes multiple times a day and refused to eat unless his food was arranged in a special way on his plate. Though his bedroom was on the same floor as his mother’s in their Connecticut home, he only communicated with her by email, and he barred her from entering his room. He collected news clips about mass killings, including a couple from this newspaper. The only time he did bond with anyone else was when his mother took him shooting.

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave’ and ‘Nebraska’  Lead Indie Spirit Awards
abstract: The awards honoring more independent efforts in movies have some overlap with Oscar front-runners.
lead_paragraph: The Film Independent Spirit Awards, which typically highlight non-blockbuster cinema, announced nominees on Tuesday. As usual, they include many films that are also on the path to the Academy Awards. The hopefuls for best feature include “12 Years a Slave,” “All Is Lost,” “Nebraska,” “Inside Llewyn Davis” and “Frances Ha.”

headline: Market Report
abstract: Victorian style is back, streamlined and laced with military references.
lead_paragraph: Victorian style is back, streamlined and laced with military references.

headline: A More Sensible Suit Deal
abstract: The estimated cost savings from Men’s Wearhouse buying its smaller rival Jos. A. Bank Clothiers — rather than a deal with Jos. A. Bank as the acquirer — could cover nearly the entire purchase price.
lead_paragraph: Turning a suit deal inside out has revealed a silver lining. After fending off a hostile bid from Jos. A. Bank Clothiers, Men’s Wearhouse is now proposing to buy its smaller rival for $1.2 billion. The estimated cost savings could cover nearly the entire purchase price, and the combined company would be less indebted. Structured this way, the transaction is more sensible.

headline: A School Where Cooks Learn to Be Farmers, a Project for White Corn and More
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Bacon', 'Corn', 'Pickles and Relishes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Restaurants', 'Food']
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Nov. 26.
lead_paragraph: To Harvest: A School’s Big Crop of Savings

headline: Country Music Deal Pairs Clear Channel and CMT
abstract: The radio giant has been competing with Cumulus over country music and a partnership with the cable TV channel offers access to a prominent brand.
lead_paragraph: With country music ascendant as one of the strongest genres in the music business, the radio giant Clear Channel Communications has announced a partnership with the country cable television channel CMT that will involve cross-promotion on the two companies’ various media platforms, and Clear Channel taking over the distribution of a popular CMT radio show.

headline: The Simone Opens on the Upper East Side
abstract: Chip Smith, who cooked at Le Midi in Greenwich Village last year, is catering to the sensibilities of the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: New Rules Would Rein In Nonprofits’ Political Role
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Political Action Committees', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The Obama administration’s proposals would curtail political activity by tax-exempt nonprofit groups, a significant change for one of the fastest-growing sources of campaign spending.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Tuesday moved to curb political activity by tax-exempt nonprofit organizations, with potentially major ramifications for some of the biggest and most secretive spenders in American politics.

headline: Sanchez Says He Wants to Stay With Jets
abstract: Mark Sanchez, speaking publicly Tuesday for the first time since shoulder surgery Oct. 8, proclaimed his desire to return to the Jets next season.
lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — Mark Sanchez predicted Tuesday that he would be “better than ever” when his football career resumed. And he insisted the Jets would reap the benefits.

headline: Somtum Der
abstract: Inside the East Village Thai restaurant where papaya salad is made to order in eight variations.
lead_paragraph: Inside the East Village Thai restaurant where papaya salad is made to order in eight variations.

headline: Spice of Life? It Depends on the Variety
abstract: Keep a fire extinguisher nearby for Somtum Der’s specialty.
lead_paragraph: Many restaurants station an employee near the door who can make or break your evening. At Somtum Der in the East Village, that person is not a host who may banish you to a table in the frozen wastes of Siberia but a cook who can set your mouth on fire with the flavors of northeastern Thailand.

headline: Printing From an Android Tablet
abstract: There are several options to help you print documents from your Nexus tablet. And making the web appear bigger in your browser is a breeze.
lead_paragraph: Android Tablet

headline: Judge Orders Release of Sandy Hook 911 Recordings
abstract: Judge Eliot D. Prescott of Superior Court in New Britain, Conn., said there was no legal basis to keep the tapes secret.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut judge ruled on Tuesday that the police must release recordings of the 911 calls made from Sandy Hook Elementary School during the shooting last year that left 20 children and six adults dead.

headline: Good May Come on Heels of Bad and Ugly for Knicks and Nets
abstract: Anyone writing them off has not been paying attention to the Eastern Conference, where nine teams with losing records have made the playoffs during the past 10 seasons.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. season is still in its infancy, but it feels like ages ago when the Nets were celebrated for adding two potential Hall of Famers and the Knicks received at least a few pats on the back for acquiring a sweet-shooting 7-footer who was once a No. 1 overall pick.

headline: Messi or Ronaldo?
abstract: How do you choose who you think is the greatest soccer player in the world? Read on.
lead_paragraph: After Cristiano Ronaldo’s third goal against Sweden in the World Cup qualifying playoffs in Stockholm, the camera panned the crowd. The Swedish fans had a look of despair. It wasn’t even anger or frustration, simply pure despair. It was what I imagine the ancient Greeks looked like in myths when tragedy struck at the hands of the gods — pained, but resigned to the fact that the destruction was not the work of an Earthly power.

headline: Florida Governor Calls for Congressman to Quit After Arrest
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott added his voice to calls for Representative Trey Radel, a fellow Republican, to resign from Congress after pleading guilty last week to buying cocaine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Rick Scott of Florida added his voice Tuesday to calls for Representative Trey Radel to resign from Congress after pleading guilty to cocaine-related charges here last week.

headline: Westchester Square, the Bronx: Stay Awhile
abstract: A slow revival is taking place in this Bronx area with early American roots; a neighborhood business-improvement group is working to attract more of the daily commuters passing through.
lead_paragraph: Look past signs of the modern era in Westchester Square — cars zipping along the Hutchinson Parkway, No. 6 trains clattering on elevated tracks and traffic stalled on Westchester Avenue — and you can glimpse its origins as a Colonial-era village.

headline: The Silent-Era Shostakovich
abstract: Vladimir Jurowski, the Russian conductor, led the Juilliard Orchestra in some of Shostakovich’s earliest, rarest compositions on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: When prominent conductors visit New York for important engagements with local institutions, their schedules are usually very full. So it says good things about the priorities of the Russian maestro Vladimir Jurowski that while in New York to conduct a six-performance run of Strauss’s “Die Frau Ohne Schatten” at the Metropolitan Opera, he made time to work with the Juilliard Orchestra on an adventurous Shostakovich program. That concert took place on Monday at Alice Tully Hall, the night before Mr. Jurowski’s final “Frau” at the Met. The hall was packed.

headline: Ryan McNamara Wins Performa 13 Prize
abstract: The artist Ryan McNamara received the Malcolm McLaren Award, given for the “most innovative and thought-provoking performance” during the performance art biennial.
lead_paragraph: Performa 13, the fifth iteration of New York’s performance art biennial, concluded its three-week run on Sunday with a Grand Finale celebration during which the artist Ryan McNamara received the second Malcolm McLaren Award. Sponsored by the Vinyl Factory and accompanied by a $10,000 cash prize, the award was established in 2011 to honor the British artist, musician, clothing designer and impresario Malcolm McLaren, who died that year. According to a Performa statement, it is given “to an artist who demonstrates the most innovative and thought-provoking performance during the biennial.”

headline: In Fashion | Four Young Designer Duos to Watch
abstract: These up-and-coming stars have discovered that, when it comes to launching a new label, two heads are better than one.
lead_paragraph: A new wave of inventive fashion labels prove there is magic in collaboration.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Afghanistan, the Philippines and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Afghanistan, the Philippines and Japan.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 13: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
abstract: At this point in the season, assuming you have your starters locked in, it’s best to look at some high-upside players who might be able to make a major impact down the stretch.
lead_paragraph: For most fantasy football owners, we’re a week from the beginning of the fantasy playoffs. With bye weeks finally over, the time for adding positional depth is over. It’s time to worry about who will be starting, not what type of bench depth you might be able to use in a trade or during a bye week.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Earnings Top Expectations, but Revenue Falls
abstract: The company reported $1.41 billion in net income for the fourth quarter, in contrast to a $6.85 billion loss a year ago.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard reported stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, telling analysts it was making great strides from its woeful position of 26 months ago, when Meg Whitman took over as chief executive.

headline: Online Help to Pick a Car and Make the Down Payment
abstract: Automakers and dealers are turning to social networks to develop better ways to attract younger, first-time car buyers.
lead_paragraph: When Lindsay Frandsen thought about registering for gifts for her wedding, she realized that what she and her husband really needed was a car.

headline: In Beverly Hills, Suites Celebrate a Milestone
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: To celebrate the city’s 100th birthday, Beverly Hills hotels will feature suites that will pay tribute to a storied past.
lead_paragraph: Five Beverly Hills luxury hotels have found a way to celebrate the city’s 100th birthday in keeping with its legendary image.

headline: New York Philharmonic Considering a New Concertmaster
abstract: Erin Keefe, the concertmaster of the moribund Minnesota Orchestra, is one of the candidates being considered to become concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: Could the moribund Minnesota Orchestra’s loss become the New York Philharmonic’s gain?

headline: W.H.O. Estimate of Swine Flu Deaths in 2009 Rises Sharply
abstract: The World Health Organization funded the research, which found that related consequences of the flu pushed the toll to about 400,000.
lead_paragraph: About 203,000 people around the world died of flu and respiratory problems during the 2009 H1N1 “swine flu” pandemic, according to a new study funded by the World Health Organization.

headline: Alfred Feld, Goldman’s Longest-Serving Employee, Dies at 98
abstract: Alfred Feld started out at the Goldman Sachs offices at 30 Pine St. in Lower Manhattan in 1933 as a messenger in the mail department. He made $624 a year. In 1948, he became a stock broker.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Feld, the longest-serving employee at Goldman Sachs, with more than 80 years of service at the Wall Street bank, died on Monday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 98.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Black Nativity'
abstract: Kasi Lemmons narrates a scene from her musical, featuring Jennifer Hudson and Jacob Latimore.
lead_paragraph: Kasi Lemmons narrates a scene from her musical, featuring Jennifer Hudson and Jacob Latimore.

headline: No Rain on Her Parade
abstract: Ann Hampton Callaway was well served in her show on Sunday by her hard-won ability to let loose and swing without self-conscious effort.
lead_paragraph: Ann Hampton Callaway was in full command of her vocal powers at Sunday’s opening-night performance of her show “Songs I Wish I’d Written,” at 54 Below. Those powers are so broad and meticulously cultivated that Ms. Callaway has sometimes succumbed to the understandable temptation to show off her technique like a peacock displaying its colors. For all the wonders of her fluting high notes and precisely rendered quasi-improvisatory jazz inventions, and her skill at instrumental imitation, such pyrotechnics are extras best held in reserve and released sparingly.

headline: Breadlines Return
abstract: Demand at all of New York City’s food pantries and soup kitchens has spiked since federal food stamps were cut.
lead_paragraph: The Great Recession was the worst downturn since the Great Depression.  And yet, throughout the recent decline and today’s sluggish recovery, conditions have never seemed as bad as they were in the 1930s. Breadlines, for example, have not been commonplace.

headline: An Evolution Makes Itself Quite Clear
abstract: Juilliard String Quartet performed the New York Premiere of Jesse Jones’s “String Quartet No. 3” and works by Beethoven and Schubert at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Chemistry can be a fast process, but that seldom tends to be the case among musical ensembles, where the term also connotes the end result of that process: a state of grace formed among individuals bonded together as an aggregate. If at the start of a concert by the Juilliard String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night I was unsure that the vital transformation had occurred yet, by evening’s end I was convinced that it had begun in earnest.

headline: It Can Be Hard to Live Up to History
abstract: In its season at Sadler’s Wells, the Stuttgart Ballet featured works by eight living choreographers who owe a debt to John Cranko, who died in 1973.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Is Stuttgart the hub of ballet choreography in Continental Europe? There was cause to think so from reading the biographies of the nine choreographers featured last week in “Made in Germany,” a three-hour program of 13 works with which the Stuttgart Ballet opened its season here at Sadler’s Wells.

headline: Who Knew That Greek Festival Had Such Legs?
abstract: The new play “And Away We Go,” at the Pearl Theater, is Terrence McNally’s love letter to theater through the centuries.
lead_paragraph: Terrence McNally plants a big kiss on his lifelong love — the theater — in his latest play, “And Away We Go,” a time-traveling romp set backstage during epochal moments in the history of drama over a couple of millenniums. As smooches go, this one is wet — which is to say lavishly affectionate — and sloppy, meaning overstuffed and halfway to haywire. Nevertheless, fellow adorers of theater will find much to divert them in Mr. McNally’s frolicsome valentine to the glorious, maddening, demanding (insert your own clichéd adjective here) world of footlights, spotlights and ghost lights.

headline: Chance Encounter Goes Viral; Cyberbullying Is Next
abstract: A woman whose chance behavior goes viral online discovers the consequences when she’s subject to cyberbullying in “Caught in the Web,” a Chinese film directed by Chen Kaige.
lead_paragraph: Chen Kaige, who remains best known for directing the Cannes prizewinner “Farewell My Concubine,” shouldn’t be faulted for attempting a state-of-the-nation look at China today with his new movie, “Caught in the Web.” But this story of cyberbullying and its discontents, though harboring flinty truths and staffed with popular domestic stars, is a messy collision of strained portrayals, semi-comic incidents and tear-jerking tactics.

headline: Christmas in Harlem, and O Come, All Ye Songs
abstract: The musical “Black Nativity,” set mostly in contemporary Harlem, is directed by Kasi Lemmons.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it takes just one thing — a gesture, a look, the quality of light on a face — to fall for a movie. For me, that moment came in the musical “Black Nativity,” when several characters, including a young couple — Jo-Jo and his very pregnant companion, Maria (Luke James and Grace Gibson) — sing a sharply reworked “Silent Night.” “They say this is your punishment for such poor judgment,” Maria sings on a cold Harlem night. “How you gonna feed it?” That line slips by quickly, but with that two-letter word — “it” — the movie ferociously closes the gap between one homeless child born into poverty and all the forgotten rest.

headline: A ‘Pool Party’ That’s Also an Art Project
abstract: “Pool Party,” a 23-minute web video from the installation artist Ed Fornieles, turns the conventions of reality TV inside out in highly entertaining ways.
lead_paragraph: The British performance and installation artist Ed Fornieles loves to make a mess. In 2011, he sowed disorder on social media by using dozens of fake accounts to enact the Facebook meta-drama “Dorm Daze.” Earlier this year, for his exhibition “Despicable Me 2,” an ode to the fictional Gen Y goddess Britney Rivers, he cluttered Mihai Nicodim Gallery in Los Angeles with totems of modern-day adolescence, including glitter, hearts, confetti and snapshots. And most recently, for a benefit at the New Museum in New York, he wrought chaos by hiring outlandish performers to attend as guests and mingle with the paying attendees, satirizing the conventions of the charity gala.

headline: The New York Times Minute
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear cases that test President Obama’s health care law; the pope’s compassionate vision; and a special visitor.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: In the End, It’s Not About the Food
abstract: Paying attention to guests, on Thanksgiving or at any dinner party, is the whole point of having people over.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In Canada, where I’m from, Thanksgiving is over already. We celebrated on your Columbus Day, and if it offers any solace as you grow increasingly (or maybe just a little bit) anxious in these final hours, ours turned out fine.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 26 at 6 p.m.
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear cases that test President Obama’s health care law; the pope’s compassionate vision; and a special visitor.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court will hear cases that test President Obama’s health care law; the pope’s compassionate vision; and a special visitor.

headline: From the Heat of Royal Passion, Poof! It’s Permafrost
abstract: “Frozen,” from Disney, departs a bit from the company’s traditional princess formula.
lead_paragraph: A beautiful princess with magical powers that she can’t control; an adorable snowman, with buck teeth and a carrot for a nose, who longs to sunbathe because no one ever told him that heat melts ice; a picture-perfect prince who is revealed to be a scheming, opportunistic cad.

headline: Risky Investment Vehicle With High Yields Gains Prominence
keywords: ['Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Business development companies are publicly traded and return big dividends, making them attractive to small investors. But they also come with high risk.
lead_paragraph: Congress and investors seem to love investment firms known as business development companies.

headline: From a Bronx Apartment’s Oven, a Gingerbread Colossus Rises in Queens
abstract: A New York chef has built the world’s largest edible gingerbread village. It is on display at the New York Hall of Science in Queens.
lead_paragraph: To call it a village would seem to diminish its Lilliputian sprawl, seeing as how it encompasses 164 structures and weighs in at slightly more than 1.5 tons, including a stuporous 2,240 pounds of icing.

headline: You Can Check Out Any Time You Like, but ...
abstract: Spike Lee reinterprets Park Chan-wook’s film “Oldboy,” with Josh Brolin starring.
lead_paragraph: The question that propels “Oldboy,” Spike Lee’s kinetic and colorful new movie, is “Why?” Why has somebody — for a long time, we don’t know who — taken the trouble to kidnap Joe Doucett (Josh Brolin), an alcoholic advertising executive, and lock him up in a fake hotel room for 20 years? Why has Joe been framed for a murder and then, after making a mental journey to madness and back, set free?

headline: Sicilian Art on the Do-Not-Travel List
abstract: A look at some of the important artworks that have been banned for travel by Sicily’s regional government.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the important artworks that have been banned for travel by Sicily’s regional government.

headline: Citing Inequity, Sicily Bans Loans of 23 Artworks
abstract: A policy shift, largely unnoticed outside Italy, reflects growing concerns by Sicilian officials that their most important treasures are too often out of the country.
lead_paragraph: Sicily’s regional government has set a travel ban on 23 of the island’s most important artworks, a decree that says such works, many of which were recently lent to museums in the United States and elsewhere, should not circulate abroad except under extraordinary circumstances.

headline: Bassem Youssef on the Muslim Brotherhood
abstract: For Mr. Youssef, an Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, all of Egypt is paying the price for the Muslim Brotherhood’s failure to rule and the subsequent military takeover.
lead_paragraph: For Mr. Youssef, an Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, all of Egypt is paying the price for the Muslim Brotherhood’s failure to rule and the subsequent military takeover.

headline: Georges Lautner Dies at 87; Prolific French Film Director
abstract: Mr. Lautner made over 40 films starring Jean-Paul Belmondo, Alain Delon and others, and specialized in comedy and crime.
lead_paragraph: Georges Lautner, a prolific French director who specialized in comedy and crime — often in the same movie — and became an audience favorite in his home country, died on Friday in Neuilly-sur-Seine, on the outskirts of Paris. He was 87.

headline: S.E.C. Takes Aim at Swiss Company and Detroit Money Market Fund
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Weatherford International, accused of wide-ranging business violations overseas, struck a $250 million settlement.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a pair of enforcement actions on Tuesday, accusing a Swiss company of bribery and a Detroit money market fund of fraud.

headline: Excerpts From a Talk With Bassem Youssef
abstract: For Mr. Youssef, a popular Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, his program is a mirror for developments in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: For Mr. Youssef, a popular Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, his program is a mirror for developments in Egypt.

headline: Where Film Marries Video Game
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: “Fort McMoney,” a documentary in the form of an online video game, examines the effects the oil industry has had on Fort McMurray, Alberta.
lead_paragraph: While filming a documentary about divisive oil refinery ventures in the subzero cold of Fort McMurray, Alberta, the director David Dufresne said he wasn’t considering only pollution in that Canadian boomtown or the vast tar sands beneath its frozen ground. He was also thinking deeply about technology, about making a new kind of hybrid media, a docugame.

headline: Bassem Youssef on Self-Censorship
abstract: For Mr. Youssef, an Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, self-censorship is an inevitable consequence of prevailing limits on free speech.
lead_paragraph: For Mr. Youssef, an Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, self-censorship is an inevitable consequence of prevailing limits on free speech.

headline: Bassem Youssef on Egypt in the News
abstract: For Mr. Youssef, a popular Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, the lesson learned is that no one can predict how events will unfold in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: For Mr. Youssef, a popular Egyptian satirist whose television show was recently suspended, the lesson learned is that no one can predict how events will unfold in Egypt.

headline: Down in the Bayou, Mellow They’re Not
abstract: “Homefront,” with Winona Ryder, James Franco and Jason Statham, packs plenty of drugs and violence into its Louisiana setting.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says Thanksgiving like a beat-’em-up written by Sylvester Stallone in which Jason Statham gets to knock the stuffing out of James Franco. If you think that’s a spoiler, you’ve either never seen an audience-pandering movie or the poster for “Homefront,” which shows a snake-eyed Mr. Franco glowering, in what appears to be hell, under an image of the stern-looking Mr. Statham overlaid with an American flag and embracing a child. The movie is as blunt an instrument as the poster, but it’s also crammed with enough moving parts and unexpected distractions (Winona Ryder as a “meth whore”) to make it an indefensibly enjoyable piece of exploitation hackwork.

headline: Malls Work on Their Security, but Keep It in the Background
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Operators are stepping up measures like cooperation with police agencies and installation of closed circuit television, and even enlisting shoppers, while trying to keep malls welcoming places.
lead_paragraph: As millions of Americans descend on the country’s shopping malls this week for the holiday shopping season, few may notice new security measures intended to prevent violence like the recent shooting at a mall in Paramus, N.J., that left a gunman dead and terrified thousands of shoppers.

headline: Gary dos Santos, Mayor of Strawberry Fields, Dead at 49

lead_paragraph: Gary dos Santos, 49, a John Lennon devotee and a fixture in Strawberry Fields in Central Park, died Monday night at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan from complications from leukemia, said his companion, Lisa Page.

headline: City Erred in Putting Shelter Rules Into Effect, Court Rules
abstract: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled against a policy that imposes stricter requirements for sheltering homeless adults.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration violated city rules in trying to carry out a policy that imposes stricter requirements for sheltering homeless adults, New York State’s highest court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: A Couple Living in a State of Nostalgia
abstract: “Cousin Jules,” first released 40 years ago, is a documentary that follows an elderly couple living in a French village.
lead_paragraph: Modern documentary filmmaking has been often defined by speed and portability. That was true in the late ’50s and early ’60s, when lightweight machinery helped give birth to the cinéma vérité and direct cinema movements, and it is certainly true today, when smartphones and tiny digital cameras turn everyday life into a collective vérité project.

abstract: A list of abbreviated schedules and closings in observance of the holiday.

lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — President Obama tried to escape the controversy over the rocky rollout of his health care program by heading to Hollywood on Tuesday and focusing on one of the United States’ most thriving industries: entertainment.

headline: Cardinals Put Aside Sentiment and Redesign a Perennial Contender
abstract: The team’s swift and shrewd moves mean only left fielder Matt Holliday and catcher Yadier Molina are projected to be in the same spots on opening day as they were in early September.
lead_paragraph: When the St. Louis Cardinals clinched their latest trip to the World Series last month at Busch Stadium, General Manager John Mozeliak told the crowd what made this pennant special.

headline: Young Signed, but Mets Fans and Wright Are Still Waiting
abstract: David Wright says he is “pretty impatient” with the Mets’ off-season plans, one piece of which fell into place with the announcement that outfielder Chris Young had signed a $7.25 million deal.
lead_paragraph: David Wright, the Mets’ captain, made the rounds of radio interviews in recent days, letting it be known that after five straight losing seasons he was just as anxious as all those tortured Mets fans wondering what Sandy Alderson, the general manager, would do to improve the team.

headline: From Hurricane Sandy’s Muck, Salvaged Bits of Staten Island Lives
abstract: A local cleanup campaign in New Dorp, Staten Island, rescued hundreds of photos and other mementos that are now visible on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: One photo is a crackled black-and-white of a clean-shaven man in a dark uniform, smiling next to a woman in a curly brunette bob wearing what looks like nurse attire.

headline: Voters in SeaTac, Wash., Back $15 Minimum Wage
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Referendums']
abstract: A measure giving the city the highest minimum wage in the nation has passed narrowly, but opponents vow to keep fighting it.
lead_paragraph: SEATAC, Wash. — After weeks of ballot counting, elections officials said on Tuesday that voters in this small city south of Seattle had in fact approved by 77 votes the highest municipal minimum wage in the nation, $15 an hour, more than twice the federal minimum.

headline: Much Ado About Bitcoin
abstract: The Internet currency is a digital gold rush perfectly emblematic of the present.
lead_paragraph: FOR the obsessive followers of the volatile virtual currency bitcoin, the price of a single bitcoin at the time their fixation began holds undue significance. I know one bitcoin cost around $9 when I first stumbled on it in the summer of 2011. That was before I single-handedly sent the price of bitcoin soaring.

headline: Jurors Deadlock in Harlem Police Officer’s Trial

abstract: The jury deadlocked on the most serious charges against Jose Tejada, a New York police officer accused of robbing drug dealers.
lead_paragraph: A New York police officer who was charged with participating in a robbery crew that targeted drug dealers was convicted on Tuesday of two counts of obstruction of justice, but a mistrial was declared on the more serious robbery charges after the jury was unable to resolve its deadlock.

headline: Venture Capital Investment Rises

abstract: The statement from the American Board of Obstetrics and Gynecology eased restrictions announced in September, which said that gynecologists could lose their board certification if they treated men.
lead_paragraph: A professional group that certifies obstetrician-gynecologists reversed an earlier directive and said on Tuesday that its members were permitted to treat male patients for sexually transmitted infections and to screen men for anal cancer.

headline: A Bird Whose Life Depends on a Crab
keywords: ['Crabs', 'Birds', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A bird’s future depends on a creature that survived the dinosaurs.
lead_paragraph: GLOUCESTER, Mass. — HORSESHOE CRABS have been around for 475 million years, making them among earth’s oldest animals. They emerge from waters along the Eastern Seaboard during the high tides of full and new moons each May and June to spawn and lay their eggs on sandy beaches. The world’s largest population is concentrated in the Delaware Bay off the coasts of New Jersey and Delaware.

headline: Comet Nears Sun, Offering Planetary Clues
abstract: A comet that spent the first 4.5 billion years of its existence in the farthest reaches of the solar system will almost graze the furnace of the sun on Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: A comet that spent the first 4.5 billion years of its existence in the farthest reaches of the solar system will almost graze the furnace of the sun on Thursday.

headline: I.M.F. Shifts Its Approach to Bailouts
abstract: The International Monetary Fund is advocating a more aggressive approach to debt restructuring that would shift some pain to the private sector, and away from German-style austerity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund, convinced that Europe erred in forcing debtor countries like Greece and Portugal to bear nearly all the pain of recovery on their own, is pushing hard for a plan that would impose upfront losses on bondholders the next time a country in the euro area requests a bailout.

headline: Judge Says Statements by Bin Laden’s Son-in-Law Can Be Used in Terrorism Case
abstract: A judge ruled that despite the contention of lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, he had been read his rights before an F.B.I. interrogation and his statements had been voluntary.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan declined on Tuesday to suppress statements made to the authorities by a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who is charged with conspiring to kill Americans.

headline: New Boom in Subprime Loans, for Smaller Businesses
abstract: Wall Street has grown frustrated by low returns on other forms of debt and turned instead to riskier but more lucrative bets on ever-smaller companies.
lead_paragraph: A small, little-known company from Missouri borrows hundreds of millions of dollars from two of the biggest names in Wall Street finance. The loans are rated subprime. What’s more, they carry few of the standard protections seen in ordinary debt, making them particularly risky bets.

headline: Another Challenge to the Health Care Law
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Corporations', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: The Supreme Court should protect women’s access to affordable contraception when it rules on two cases.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after it upheld the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act, the Supreme Court has set the stage for a showdown over the law’s requirement that employer health plans cover birth control. It agreed on Tuesday to hear two cases challenging the mandate, each brought by a secular, profit-making company seeking an exemption on religious grounds. They are among a slew of lawsuits seeking similar exemptions. Lower federal appellate courts have split on the question, creating a need for a decisive ruling from the Supreme Court that rejects the specious religious liberty claims.

headline: N.F.L. Concussion Case Offers Clues for Hockey Lawsuit
abstract: In the suit by 10 former N.H.L. players against the league for negligence and fraud, both sides will probably draw lessons from the N.F.L.’s concussion cases.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. agreed in August to pay $765 million to settle a lawsuit filed by thousands of retirees who said that the league had failed to disclose the dangers of repeated head trauma, it largely ended one legal challenge and invited others.

headline: Escalating Debt
abstract: Ever since the recession hit in 2008, the debt burden of most European nations has risen sharply. Particularly vulnerable countries like Greece and Portugal have been forced to impose further austerity measures and turn to their neighbors and the International Monetary Fund for bailouts to help manage their finances.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the recession hit in 2008, the debt burden of most European nations has risen sharply. Particularly vulnerable countries like Greece and Portugal have been forced to impose further austerity measures and turn to their neighbors and the International Monetary Fund for bailouts to help manage their finances.

headline: The War on Thanksgiving
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Editorials']
abstract: Consumerism has encroached on the day itself, with retailers opening even earlier than in past years to get a bigger jump on Black Friday.
lead_paragraph: In 1939, Thanksgiving was supposed to fall on Nov. 30, but President Franklin Roosevelt, on the advice of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, pushed it forward a week to extend the holiday gift-buying season. That delighted business owners but upset traditionalists, like the selectmen of Plymouth, Mass., who felt that celebrating early meant “sacrificing the real significance of the day for the purpose of satisfying commercial interests.”

headline: Sifting Through the Irish Troubles
abstract: Suggesting that it’s time to limit prosecutions for acts committed before the peace accord of 1998 fails miserably on the scales of justice.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Larkin of Northern Ireland has stirred passionate controversy with his suggestion that the passage of time makes it counterproductive to continue investigating the sectarian raids and military operations that took more than 3,500 lives during the Troubles, the violent conflict in Northern Ireland that lasted more than a generation.

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama and Congress fail to act on passing reform, and the suffering of families continues.
lead_paragraph: President Obama made the case for immigration reform again on Monday, in a speech in San Francisco that seemed mostly directed to Republicans in Congress, who aren’t listening.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: A Japanese auto parts company agreed to pay a $120 million fine and plead guilty to charges that it fixed prices, becoming the latest supplier charged in the Justice Department’s sweeping antitrust investigation of the auto parts business, the department said on Tuesday.

headline: Enjoy the Parade, and Don’t Forget to Thank Your Friendly Sewer Workers
abstract: Forecasts are calling for two to four inches of rain by Thursday morning, and sewer workers will be scooping out tons of street sludge from basins across New York City.
lead_paragraph: By midmorning Tuesday, the sewer workers had taken apart five catch basins along Central Park West near the American Museum of Natural History. Then they scooped out street sludge that had been trapped in a kind of holding vault, where it had steeped for two or three years in about four feet of water.

headline: Book Published in 1640 Sets a Record at Auction
abstract: Printed in 1640 by Puritans in Massachusetts, the Bay Psalm Book — one of only 11 known to exist — goes for over $14 million.
lead_paragraph: It already held a record as the first book printed in English in North America. Now it holds two: It is also the most expensive book ever sold at auction.

abstract: The worlds of Jane Austen and pro football have more in common than you would think.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I dreamed of Peyton Manning.

lead_paragraph: The star witness in the federal government’s insider trading prosecution of Michael Steinberg, once a senior trader at SAC Capital Advisors, told a federal jury on Tuesday why he was cooperating with prosecutors and testifying at the trial.

headline: Strong Winds May Ground Biggest Balloons at Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: Winds of at least 23 miles per hour, with gusts up to 45 m.p.h., are expected on Thursday, threatening some of the most celebrated balloons at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: The fate of the world’s most famous balloons is up in the air.

lead_paragraph: This month at a symposium at Georgetown University on Afghan women, Secretary of State John Kerry praised his predecessor, Hillary Rodham Clinton, whom he referred to as “Madam Secretary-Senator-First-Lady-Everything.”

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Some 1,200 graduate assistants at New York University and the Polytechnic Institute of N.Y.U. in Brooklyn are scheduled to vote on Dec. 10 and 11 on whether to join the union.
lead_paragraph: For eight years, hundreds of graduate students at New York University have been at war with the school’s president, John Sexton, over his 2005 decision to stop recognizing the labor union that once represented more than 1,000 of the university’s graduate teaching and research assistants.

headline: New Birth Control Label Counters Lawsuit Claim
keywords: ['Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Women and Girls', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Changes to the labeling of a European emergency contraception pill may play a role in two cases the Supreme Court will hear.
lead_paragraph: European health authorities have made two significant changes to the label of an emergency contraception pill that is equivalent to Plan B One-Step. One of the changes could be relevant to two cases that the Supreme Court added to its docket on Tuesday.

headline: Pulling a More Diverse Group of Achievers Into the Advanced Placement Pool

lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Every year, more than 600,000 academically promising high school students — most of them poor, Latino or black — fail to enroll in Advanced Placement courses, often viewed as head starts for the college-bound.

headline: Merrell Williams Jr., Paralegal Who Bared Big Tobacco, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Williams leaked mountains of internal documents in 1994, fueling lawsuits that resulted in an industry payout of billions of dollars to pay smokers’ medical bills.
lead_paragraph: Merrell Williams Jr., a former paralegal who leaked mountains of internal documents of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company in 1994, fueling lawsuits that resulted in an industry payout of billions of dollars to pay smokers’ medical bills, died on Nov. 18 in Ocean Springs, Miss. He was 72.

headline: Knicks Owner Is Singing the Blues, and So Is His Team

lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — “Hello everybody!” James L. Dolan shouted into the microphone in front of about 100 people who had arrived early at the Amway Center for an Eagles concert.

headline: Resurrecting His Master’s Mouse Voice

lead_paragraph: Starting with “Steamboat Willie” in 1928, Walt Disney provided the high-pitched, enthusiastic tones of Mickey Mouse for at least 100 shorts, maybe more. Now make that at least 101.

headline: Finding Holiday Good Will in Glasses of Juice
abstract: Welch’s, the grape juice maker, is encouraging users of the Vine video-sharing app to participate in a promotion it has created to distribute the company’s products to impoverished American families.
lead_paragraph: WELCH’S most essential ingredient comes from vines, so it’s fitting that for a new cause-marketing effort the grape products brand is turning to Vine, the mobile app for sharing six-second video clips.

headline: Jury Acquits Mobster in ’97 Killing of Officer
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Joel Cacace, a former consigliere of the Colombo crime family, had been accused of ordering a murder that is against mob rules.
lead_paragraph: A former consigliere of the Colombo crime family was acquitted on Tuesday of the 1997 murder of a New York police officer. It was the second time a federal jury rejected arguments from prosecutors that leaders of the crime family ordered the killing.

headline: What Does Black Friday Mean for You?
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The Times would like to hear from readers about their holiday shopping plans.
lead_paragraph: “Black Friday,” the day after Thanksgiving, has traditionally been the kickoff for the holiday shopping season, when Americans wake up in the pre-dawn hours (or never go to sleep) and race to malls and stores for the best deals. But in recent years, the holiday gift-buying countdown has been stretched even longer, with many retailers offering bargains on best-selling items days, even weeks, in advance of Black Friday.

headline: Retailers Seek Partners in Social Networks
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Social Media', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Brick and mortar stores like Target and Walmart are engaging heavily with social networks, notably Pinterest, to clinch holiday sales.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — “Showrooming” is no longer a bad word.

headline: Home Sweet Home, Spoiled by Mold and Tight Quarters
abstract: Sheila Cherry has been a resident of the Ralph J. Rangel Houses, in Harlem, since 1990, but the tight quarters and conditions in her bedroom have made it hard to live there.
lead_paragraph: As a grandmother, Sheila Cherry hews to the classic model. Her face lights up when she refers to her five grandchildren; she calls them her babies; she can easily recount their stories.

headline: Shumpert, Knicks Starter, Struggles to Return to Relevance
abstract: Once considered the player with the most upside on the team, Iman Shumpert has taken several big steps backward this season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Knicks escaped to California on Tuesday, though they were unable to leave their problems behind. A six-game losing streak trailed them to U.C.L.A., where they reviewed film (again) and practiced (again) and tried to unearth solutions (again) ahead of Wednesday’s game against the Clippers.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Philadelphia Schools Merged in Despair Find Reason to Celebrate in Football
abstract: After archrival high schools joined forces because of a budget shortfall, many doubted the merger would work. But the football team has triumphed over skepticism and inspired hope for academic success.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The footballs. Where were they? The season was about to start and somebody forgot to bring the balls.

headline: Egypt’s Jon Stewart on Comedy and Politics
abstract: Bassem Youssef talks about the future of his show, the turbulent political situation in Egypt, and what it is like to be a comedian in a country plagued by violence, division and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: During the administration of Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s deposed president, Muslim Brotherhood partisans sought unsuccessfully to try Bassem Youssef, an Egyptian satirist and late-night talk show host, on charges of “insulting the president.” After Mr. Morsi was overthrown in the summer, Egyptians tuned in eagerly to the season premiere of Mr. Youssef’s show in October to see if he would lampoon their new military rulers as harshly as he had the Islamists. His jokes clearly made an impact: One week later his show was abruptly suspended. Now he faces dozens of accusations of “insulting the military” — a potential crime.

headline: In Steubenville Rape Case, a Lesson for Adults
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Football', 'Education (K-12)', 'Principals (School)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: By holding adults accountable, prosecutors might persuade school administrators and coaches to make it their business to tell the police when they hear students or athletes have done something illegal.
lead_paragraph: A year ago this week, Michael McVey, the superintendent of schools in Steubenville, Ohio, sat in a conference room down the hall from his office and said he knew none of the details of Aug. 11, 2012, the night a 16-year-old girl was raped by two Steubenville High football players at a series of parties on a hot summer night.

headline: Karzai’s Bet: U.S. Is Bluffing in Warning on Security Pact
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations']

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When President Hamid Karzai met with an audience of supporters gathered by the Afghan state television network, RTA, six months ago, he was asked what he would consider a favorable conclusion to the security negotiations he was conducting with the United States.

headline: Number of Settings
abstract: Jules P. Markey sets a precedent.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a special year. This year, THANKSGIVING overlaps with the first night of Hanukkah, an event that will not reoccur for another 70,000 years, so enjoy those sweet potato latkes while you can.

headline: Suit Claims Racial Harassment at Security Firm With New York City Contracts
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Two former officials say that MSA Security tolerated racial harassment of one of the few African-American employees in the corporate office.
lead_paragraph: By now, the men are a familiar part of the post-Sept. 11 streetscape of Lower Manhattan, wearing black polo shirts and handling dogs trained to sniff out explosives. They work for MSA Security, a contractor that has made tens of millions of dollars guarding some of the city’s ferry terminals and important buildings.

headline: Life Term Given in Triple Murder Near Columbia University
abstract: The State Supreme Court justice who sentenced Roberto Nunez, 32, said the crime warranted the maximum sentence, which he imposed for the first time in his 18 years on the bench.
lead_paragraph: Justice Thomas A. Farber is not given to fiery speeches or draconian sentences, but he made an exception on Tuesday in the case of a Bronx man convicted of executing three men in a car near Columbia University last year.

headline: Where Is Breast Cancer?

headline: In Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Mastectomy', 'Women and Girls', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Series']
abstract: As an effort ensues to test for cancer-causing gene mutations that are common among many Jews, women are facing hard choices about how much they want to know.
lead_paragraph: KFAR SABA, Israel — Ever since she tested positive for a defective gene that causes breast cancer, Tamar Modiano has harbored a mother’s fear: that she had passed it on to her two daughters. Ms. Modiano had her breasts removed at 47 to prevent the disease and said that the day she found out her older daughter tested negative was one of the happiest of her life.

headline: U.S. B-52 Flight Prompts Indignant Reaction in China
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A flight by American B-52 bombers in an air defense zone declared by China over a set of disputed islands is being viewed as a test of Chinese resolve.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:07 a.m. ET | News that the United States sent two B-52 bombers on a patrol through China’s newly declared air defense zone prompted widespread criticism Wednesday on Chinese websites, both of the United States for an action many Chinese commentators saw as provocative and of China for its lack of an immediate response.

headline: Xi Pays Homage to Confucius, a Figure Back in Favor
abstract: The Chinese president suggests that Confucius’ thinking deserves attention, but only through the prism of Communist Party views.
lead_paragraph: China’s Communist Party leader, Xi Jinping, likes venerating his forebears. Mr. Xi has made a reverential visit to a statue of Deng Xiaoping, the party patriarch who oversaw China’s shift to a market economy. Mr. Xi has also paid respects to Mao Zedong, and to his own father, a revolutionary who served under Mao.

headline: Changing Assistance for the Unemployed
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: With new health-insurance subsidies reducing incentives to hold or create jobs, extended unemployment benefits should be allowed to expire to limit disruption to the labor market, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: The Power of a Daily Bout of Exercise
abstract: A new study suggests a moderate daily exercise session can blunt the harmful effects of overeating and being inactive, which too many of us will be doing as the holidays approach.
lead_paragraph: This week marks the start of the annual eat-too-much and move-too-little holiday season, with its attendant declining health and surging regrets. But a well-timed new study suggests that a daily bout of exercise should erase or lessen many of the injurious effects, even if you otherwise lounge all day on the couch and load up on pie.

headline: Firm Charged With Defying Sanctions Settles With U.S.
abstract: In one of the biggest settlements for corporate misbehavior overseas, a Swiss oil services company agreed to pay over $250 million to resolve charges that included defiance of sanctions against Iran.
lead_paragraph: The United States on Tuesday announced one of the biggest settlements ever made for corporate misbehavior overseas, chronicling a litany of charges against a leading energy services provider. The charges included bribery and kickbacks in the Middle East and Africa and systematic defiance of economic sanctions on Iran and three other countries.

abstract: The Guangzhou National Sex Culture Festival is where hedonism meets capitalism in China, and its mostly male visitors reflect the country’s gender imbalance.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — Slack-jawed and perspiring, Chen Weizhou gazed at a pair of life-size female dolls clad, just barely, in lingerie and lace stockings. Above these silicone vixens, an instructional video graphically depicted just how realistic they felt once undressed.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) MY LIFE AS A TURKEY Joe Hutto can “talk turkey,” a result of having spent more than a year as a full-time parent to a clutch of wild hatchlings. This Emmy Award-winning film, the first installment in a “Nature” triple bill, listens as Mr. Hutto, a wildlife artist and environmentalist, recounts his efforts to bond with turkey poults the way their mother would, while viewers watch Jeff Palmer, above, a photographer and actor, recreate the experience by bonding with a brood of his own. The next thing Mr. Hutto knew, he was rearing 16 chicks, becoming especially fond of Sweet Pea, a snuggler, and Turkey Boy, the bold rascal of the bunch. He wrote about the experience in his book “Illumination in the Flatwoods.” “An Original DUCKumentary,” at 9, follows wood ducks, among the most vividly colored of the more than 120 duck species, as they bond, migrate across thousands of miles, nurture a brood of ducklings — including prodding them out of their nest, 70 feet up an oak tree, for their first flight — and return to their wintering grounds. Paul Giamatti narrates. And “The Private Life of Deer,” at 10, uses night vision cameras and GPS tracking to demystify the routines and rituals of the nearly 30 million whitetail deer that populate North America.

headline: Bad Thanksgiving
abstract: Love does not come as expected in a cancer hospital.
lead_paragraph: The worst Thanksgiving I had came two days after they sliced me open, belly to pubic line, and the surgeon, coming to see me in recovery said, “We got most of it.”

headline: Island Dispute Used to Argue Against Forced Eviction
abstract: A man in Jiangxi Province tried to save his property from demolition by comparing his plight to China’s territorial dispute with Japan in the East China Sea.
lead_paragraph: In a country where standoffs between local governments and residents over land seizures and forced evictions regularly make headlines, one man’s attempt to save his property by drawing parallels between his plight and a sovereignty dispute between China and Japan has drawn amused comment online.

headline: In Raipur, Tribal Artists Finding Fewer Spaces for Self-Expression
abstract: Longtime residents of the capital of Chhattisgarh lament the loss of culture and art in the city.
lead_paragraph: RAIPUR, Chhattisgarh — As rain played hide-and-seek on an overcast September evening, keeping many residents of Raipur, the capital of Chhattisgarh, confined to their homes, a group of about 20 tribal artists from conflict-ridden Bastar assembled in a dormitory in the back of a state-run museum. Insulated from the outside world, they practiced a range of dance and folk music exclusively devoted to their deities, and unique to their regions and subculture.

headline: German Rivals Reach Pact for Coalition Government
abstract: The agreement between Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative bloc and the center-left Social Democrats would introduce Germany’s first minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After five weeks of negotiations, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives reached an agreement on Wednesday with their Social Democratic rivals on a program for a new coalition government, with concessions to the left that pleased labor leaders and almost immediately drew criticism from business interests.

headline: Finding Comfort and Food on Lines

It’s the time for food lines because the end of the month is near, which for many families means their food stamp allotment has run out and dollars are tight.

headline: Who Is Your Family?

headline: Dispute Over Immigration Widens Between Britain and E.U.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Responding to political pressure from his right and public fears about an influx of Romanians and Bulgarians early next year, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said on Wednesday that he would restrict state benefits for European Union migrants, including a ban on housing subsidies for new arrivals and sharp limits on unemployment compensation.

headline: An American Neurotic in Paris
abstract: Thanksgiving prompts the question that expatriates everywhere face: Shouldn't I be going home?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A few years back I took the ultimate expatriate plunge: I started doing psychotherapy in French. I figured that, as part of the deal, I’d get free one-on-one French lessons. And I hoped that if I revealed my innermost thoughts in French, I might finally feel like an ordinary Parisian — or at least like an ordinary Parisian neurotic.

headline: The Turkey’s Turkey Connection
abstract: How the bird got its name.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is the all-American holiday. Turkey is the all-American bird. It was here long before Columbus or the Pilgrims. Early explorers reported vast flocks of turkeys nesting in the magnolia forest. Turkeys are a lot more American than apple pie. But they’re named after a country 4,429 miles away.
