headline: The Shadow Politics of Shadow Education
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: The Turkish government’s plan to reform special schools is a disguised attack on the Gulen movement.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — “Shadow education” is academic jargon for the way ordinary people bypass the failings of the formal school system by enlisting their children in special programs on the side. In Turkey, the practice is so widespread it has spawned a multibillion-dollar industry of private tutorial colleges that help students cram for highly competitive high-school and university entrance exams. Nearly 1.3 million children in Turkey are enrolled in more than 3,800 tutorial colleges.

headline: A New Credit Boom
abstract: A loan package to a little-known company highlights a new credit boom taking shape. | Business development companies are suddenly hot, but they come with risks. | A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors agreed to testify against his onetime boss in a bid to avoid jail time. | Men’s Wearhouse turned the tables on Jos. A. Bank.
lead_paragraph: A $330 million loan package to a small, little-known company from Missouri highlights how a new credit boom is taking shape, five years after the bubble, Lynnley Browning reports in DealBook. The company, Learfield Communications, of Jefferson City, Mo., owns multimedia rights to more than four dozen college sports programs and made just under $40 million last year in a common measure of earnings. It borrowed the money from Deutsche Bank and GE Capital on Oct. 9. Though the loans were rated subprime, with few of the standard protections seen in ordinary debt, investors clamored to buy pieces of the loans, one of which pays annual interest of at least 8.75 percent.

headline: Understanding War Through Hanukkah
keywords: ['Chaplains', 'Jews and Judaism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: David Frommer, a chaplain who served in the United States Army and Israel Defense Forces, shares how his understanding of Hanukkah has evolved since his childhood.
lead_paragraph: The chaos of battle swirled all around us. As the soldiers advanced, an explosion severed a chunk of the rock face with a thunderous crack. “Children! What are you doing in there?” yelled Mom. It was too late. In my eagerness to augment the sounds of war, I had lifted one end of the marble coffee table and dropped it to the floor. Mom burst into the living room and fixed her eyes on the damage. My sister Kate and I gulped and looked at our valiant comrades. There were four bears, three rabbits, six mice, one tiger and five dogs. Mom was not amused. Now we were in serious danger.

headline: Paratransit: Stuck in the Slow Lane
abstract: Transportation options for seniors are not keeping pace with demand.
lead_paragraph: I have always found it reassuring to see New Jersey Transit’s striped Access Link vans motoring around my suburban town and to spot New York City’s Access-a-Ride vehicles criss-crossing Manhattan. Elderly and disabled people I know have used them, and while they have sometimes grumbled about having to wait too long for pick-ups, the vans have taken them where they needed to go.

headline: No Pecan Pie? Thank China, Rain and Pigs
abstract: A rare collision of ill-timed rain, wild animals, and a growing love affair between China and the pecan has led to the worst supply in years, and grocery store prices are up by about 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: OCILLA, Ga. — It is a meager holiday in the pecan groves of the South, and the pain is stretching to kitchens across the country.

headline: The Case for Techno-optimism
abstract: Machines operating in natural environments.
lead_paragraph: The debate over secular stagnation has shown some signs of getting confused with the debate over technological stagnation; it’s important to understand that they are not the same thing. What Bob Gordon (pdf) is predicting is disappointment on the supply side; what Larry Summers and I have been suggesting is that we may face a persistent shortfall on the demand side. It’s true that Gordon’s world might suffer from low investment demand, since investment demand depends more on the rate of growth than it does on the level of real GDP. Still, they are distinct concepts.

headline: Bookshelf | Edmund White Dishes on His Colorful Paris Years
abstract: In a new tell-all, the American novelist shares uproarious tales of encounters in the City of Light with notables like the Queen, Valentino, Pia Zadora and Peggy Guggenheim.
lead_paragraph: Edmund White’s new tell-all paints a lavish picture of his time in Paris — with some not-so-flattering sketches of the characters he met there.

headline: The Trouble With Economics Is Economists
abstract: If only we had listened to the textbooks.
lead_paragraph: That’s in large part what Simon Wren-Lewis is saying in this post defending mainstream economics. And I largely agree.

headline: The Lives They Loved: Submit Your Memories
abstract: We are inviting you to contribute stories and photographs of your loved ones who died this year.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:04 p.m. | We are once again inviting readers to contribute to The Lives They Lived, the magazine’s celebration of people who died in the past year. We would like photographs that illustrate a moment in the life of someone close to you who died in 2013. This is not a place for eulogies or obituaries, but for stories. (View submissions from 2012 and 2011.)

headline: Merger of American and US Airways Is Waved Ahead
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Bankruptcies', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: A federal bankruptcy judge approved American’s reorganization plan, which means the carrier’s proposed merger with US Airways can proceed.
lead_paragraph: With American Airlines’ exit from bankruptcy on Wednesday, the grunt work of merging the airline with US Airways can begin and it will most likely be a long-haul affair, analysts said.

headline: Shopping for Fall Fashion? Don’t Fear the Dark
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Midnight blue is the coolest color for boots; Warby Parker’s Leith Clark eyewear; Jayne Min and Jennifer Fisher design jewelry; and an app for the busy shopper.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to boots this season, midnight blue is the coolest color. You can wear them pretty much interchangeably with your beloved black. Pair with bluejeans, various warm layers or, perhaps, a smart gray coat for a casually refined look. To dress up, slip them on with a black skirt (or even black leather pants) and a white blouse. The blue will prove unexpected and polished. Just dare to try.

headline: You’re Here to Be Lectured
abstract: Frances McDormand takes to the intimate Fishman Space at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to portray Suzanne Bocanegra giving a lecture in “Bodycast.”
lead_paragraph: In the context of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival, which scours the globe for cutting-edge performances, the presence of an Oscar winner qualifies as exotica. But this week, Frances McDormand, who won Hollywood’s big prize for “Fargo,” takes to the intimate Fishman Space stage to portray Suzanne Bocanegra giving a lecture in “Bodycast.” Ms. Bocanegra’s works range across mediums: she paints, creates large-scale installations and orchestrates complex interdisciplinary events, often involving other artists. Paul Lazar, who directs “Bodycast,” portrayed Ms. Bocanegra giving a lecture in Ms. Bocanegra’s “When a Priest Marries a Witch,” to which “Bodycast” is a quasi-sequel. In the new piece, which includes guest appearances by the singer Theo Bleckmann and the dancer Emily Coates, Ms. Bocanegra reflects (in the person of Ms. McDormand) on evolving ideals of female beauty, among other topics, as refracted through her experience of wearing a body cast for two years in her teens to correct her scoliosis. (Opens Tuesday, Fisher Building, 321 Ashman Place, near Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene; bam.org.)

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 13 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: If you are a fantasy owner of a Kansas City Chiefs offensive player not named Jamaal Charles, you can finally be thankful, just in time for Week 13.
lead_paragraph: If you are the fantasy owner of a Kansas City Chiefs offensive player other than Jamaal Charles, specifically the team’s quarterback and top wide receiver, you may finally get to be thankful this season — and just in time for the all-important Week 13, the final week of the regular season for many fantasy teams.

headline: Ask Well: Genetic Testing for Breast Cancer
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Mastectomy', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: Answers to common questions about genetic testing for the three common harmful mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes that heighten the risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
lead_paragraph: Some Israeli doctors want Israel to conduct a national screening campaign to test all Jewish Israeli women of Ashkenazi descent for harmful genetic mutations that heighten the risk of breast and ovarian cancer. The debate is detailed in the article, “In Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted.”

headline: Law of Gravity, Made to be Broken
abstract: Virgil Gadson and Julius Chisolm discuss their dance routine for the jazz revue “After Midnight” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of “After Midnight,” the acclaimed jazz revue at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, two dapper men dance a sinuous, playful duet. As they move — to the driving strains of “Hottentot,” played by the Jazz at Lincoln Center All Stars — laws of physics shatter. These men force time to slow and speed. Their bodies curve in ways that would stagger Newton.

headline: What’s Next? The Poky Little Pediatrician?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Parenting']
abstract: Children’s books including “Goodnight Moon,” “Curious George” and “Are You My Mother?” now have adult-themed parodies.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate the commercial potential of bored parents.

headline: My Religion. My Mother-in Law. Our ‘Thanksgivukkah.’
abstract: My husband converted to Judaism to marry me, and the rift between me and my mother-in-law lasted until the birth of my son. Now, with “Thanksgivukkuh,” we’re coming even closer together.
lead_paragraph: One of my most testy mother-in-law moments came over holiday wrapping paper. A few months into my husband’s conversion to Judaism, we were discussing why Christmas was a bright, intractable line for me — and now us — and how her grandchildren (at the time, theoretical) would never be able to celebrate Christmas morning with their Catholic grandparents.

headline: The N.S.A. Dips Into Pornography
abstract: New documents reveal that agents gathered evidence on the pornography-viewing habits of alleged radicals.
lead_paragraph: There is so much that’s outrageous about American spy agencies’ data collection programs that I felt slightly guilty this morning when I burst into laughter at the latest revelation from the Snowden papers.

headline: Berlusconi Expelled From Senate in Italy After 2 Decades in Government
abstract: Silvio Berlusconi, Italy’s once-powerful former prime minister, was stripped of his seat on Wednesday, leaving him without elective office for the first time in about two decades.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Having spent months manufacturing procedural delays and conjuring political melodrama in hopes of saving himself, Silvio Berlusconi could no longer stave off the inevitable: Italy’s Senate stripped him of his parliamentary seat on Wednesday, a dramatic and humiliating expulsion, even as other potential troubles await him.

headline: De Professor
abstract: De Professor performing “God Nah Sleep” at this year’s calypso competition in Guyana.
lead_paragraph: De Professor performing “God Nah Sleep” at this year’s calypso competition in Guyana.

headline: Springsteen’s Handwritten ‘Born to Run’ Lyrics Head to Auction
abstract: The manuscript, said to date from 1974, includes 30 lines in Mr. Springsteen’s handwriting, neatly written in blue ink, but with second thoughts added in the margins and in the space above some of the lyrics.
lead_paragraph: The lyrics to “Born to Run,” the evocative title track of Bruce Springsteen’s third album, from 1975, seem to roll off Mr. Springsteen’s tongue on the recording, a torrent of inspired urban car-culture imagery. But a page torn from a spiral-bound notebook that once belonged to Mr. Springsteen, which is currently up for auction at Sotheby’s, shows that it was a long road from Mr. Springsteen’s early thoughts about the song to its finished version.

headline: Macy’s Parade Balloons Come Alive, With the Wind Closely Watched
abstract: Strong gusts are in the forecast, and a final decision will be made Thanksgiving morning on whether Snoopy and his friends will soar.
lead_paragraph: SpongeBob SquarePants and Snoopy lay on their bellies on the pavement of West 77th Street in Manhattan on Wednesday evening, the giant balloons netted and tethered to the ground. Spectators to the inflation of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade balloons streamed by, children in strollers pointing out their favorites, parents pulling tiny parkas closed and shoving little hats down on heads as the wind steadily picked up throughout the afternoon.

headline: After the Parade, a Macy’s Christmas Musical
abstract: A musical developed by the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade team will get its concert hall premiere next month in Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: The music — and marketing — of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade will not end when the last float makes its way to the flagship store on 34th Street on Thursday morning. A musical developed by the Macy’s parade team will get its concert hall premiere next month when the Cincinnati Pops Orchestra performs “Macy’s Presents ‘Yes, Virginia’ in Concert.”

headline: Classical Playlist: Martha Argerich, Third Coast Percussion, Garrick Ohlsson and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: Venice by Kayak
abstract: Tofino Expeditions is offering kayaking tours of Venice, with a stop for a glass-blowing lesson.
lead_paragraph: A new trip offered by Tofino Expeditions will give active travelers a different view of the city of canals by exploring Venice on an eight-day kayaking tour.

headline: Moncler Sets Price Range for Public Offering
abstract: The Italian maker of luxury winter jackets plans to raise as much as $1.1 billion in its initial public offering on the Milan stock exchange.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:57 p.m. |

headline: Sampling a Tasty Sliver of Singapore’s Cuisine
abstract: On a trip back to Singapore, where she grew up, the author explores the world of Hainanese food, tasting a connection to the past in dishes of the present.
lead_paragraph: On the small sidewalk that hugs a corner coffee shop in the Tiong Bahru neighborhood in Singapore, a long line was once again firmly in place. Though it was just late morning, people had gathered to make sure they’d get a morsel of the lunch treats sold out of the closet-size stall that is Loo’s Hainanese Curry Rice.

headline: Navigating Art Fairs in Miami and Beyond
abstract: Nick Korniloff, director of Art Miami, talks about the scene when fairs sprout across the city in early December, and names some of his favorite events overseas.
lead_paragraph: Art takes over Miami next week, with fairs setting up shop in convention centers, studios and hotel rooms across the city. To name just a few, exhibitions will be held by Art Basel Miami Beach, Art Miami, Scope Miami, Pulse Miami and the New Art Dealers Alliance.

headline: The American Family: Reader Comments
abstract: In this week’s Science Times, Natalie Angier takes stock of the changing definition of the American family.
lead_paragraph: American households have never been more diverse, more surprising, more baffling. In this week’s Science Times, Natalie Angier takes stock of the changing definition of family. Read their stories in “The Changing American Family,” and post your comments below.

abstract: New leadership in Pakistan; a pecan shortage; and Ron Burgundy in real life.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Apple’s Pages, Going the Distance With Word
abstract: To point out the vast improvement in the new version of Pages, we offer a three-round comparison bout between it and Word.
lead_paragraph: My mother is not anti-Apple. She owns a Mac and an older iPad, but has always been perfectly satisfied with her trusty copy of Microsoft Word. “That’s what everyone uses,” she says.

headline: In Our Pages: November 28
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1888: French Oppose Income Tax

headline: Thanksgiving, by the Numbers
abstract: From parades to pumpkins, the facts and figures behind this year's Thanksgiving holiday.
lead_paragraph: From parades to pumpkins, the facts and figures behind this year's Thanksgiving holiday.

headline: A Prediction: Bitcoin Is Doomed to Fail
abstract: The web currency appeals to right-wing thinkers. But private sector money is a fantasy. Currencies need political authority to raise taxes or to pass laws to unwind monetary excesses.
lead_paragraph: The developers of bitcoin are trying to show that money can be successfully privatized. They will fail, because money that is not issued by governments is always doomed to failure. Money is inevitably a tool of the state.

headline: A History of the Presidential Turkey Pardon
abstract: Until 1989, turkeys sent to the White House for Thanksgiving usually suffered a different fate.
lead_paragraph: Like most American traditions, the presidential turkey pardon is wrought with intrigue and legend. Now a holiday staple, the pardon was once merely a presentation – with the chosen birds going to the gallows rather than a farm in Virginia. Most presidents have had turkeys formally given to them, but it was not until the first President George Bush officially used the word “pardon” during the ceremony in 1989 that the custom formally began.

abstract: New leadership in Pakistan; a pecan shortage; and Ron Burgundy in real life.
lead_paragraph: New leadership in Pakistan; a pecan shortage; and Ron Burgundy in real life.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: How does a couple decide which co-workers to invite? Who is an appropriate escort for the widowed mother-of-the-groom?
lead_paragraph: Which Co-Workers on Invitation List?

headline: Accidental Detour Leads to Deep Snow
abstract: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind the Line,” a group of skiers encounters snowstorms and icy roads before finding deep snow in Fieberbrunn.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind the Line,” a group of skiers encounters snowstorms and icy roads before finding deep snow in Fieberbrunn.

headline: Video: Accidental Detour Leads Skiers to Deep Snow
abstract: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind the Line,” a group of skiers encounters snowstorms and icy roads before finding deep snow in Fieberbrunn.
lead_paragraph: “Behind the Line” is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Video: A Texas Flower Girl
abstract: Lisa Taye Cohen, a hairstylist in Austin, showcased a style that fits in in a neighborhood known for its vintage stores and outdoor cafes.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Taye Cohen was recently walking to work in the South Congress neighborhood in Austin, Tex., sporting rolled-up denim shorts, a Rolling Stones tank top and vintage cowboy boots.

headline: The Hills Are Alive on Long Island
abstract: On Dec. 5, NBC will broadcast a live version of “The Sound of Music” starring the country music star Carrie Underwood.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 5, NBC will broadcast a live version of “The Sound of Music” starring the country music star Carrie Underwood.

headline: The Hills Are a Prop, the Show Is Live
abstract: With a little over a week to go before the live broadcast of “The Sound of Music” on NBC, the production is taking shape on a Long Island sound stage.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before “The Sound of Music” goes live for one night only on NBC, the actors were fretting about some scenes more than others.

headline: Aiming to Build Customer Loyalty in Hands-On Activities
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Customer Relations', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: To help them sell products, some small businesses are finding it useful to first sell themselves through interaction with their customers.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2008, still early in the economic crisis, Butter Lane Cupcakes opened its doors in the East Village of Manhattan. With business slow, the co-founders, Pam Nelson, Maria Baugh and Linda Lea, decided they needed to try something different to get people into the shop, and they hit on the idea of offering classes in cupcake making.

headline: Qatar Lets Soccer Player Leave After Two Years
abstract: Zahir Belounis, the French-Algerian player who had been unable to leave the emirate because of its labor laws, has been told he will finally be granted an exit visa.
lead_paragraph: Zahir Belounis, a French-Algerian soccer player who has been unable to leave Qatar for more than two years because of a contract dispute with his former club, and whose case shined a light on the emirate’s labor laws, has been told he can return home.

headline: The Perils of Anti-Decadence
abstract: On J.F.K., “Brave New World,” and the perils of seeking political solutions to cultural and moral stagnation.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column tried to draw a serious point out of the coincidence of Aldous Huxley, C.S. Lewis and John F. Kennedy all entering the hereafter within a few hours of each other, portraying the resilience of the Kennedy mythos as, in part, a kind of secular/liberal rebellion against the same disenchanted utilitarian materialism that both Huxley and Lewis famously critiqued. This is a reason, I wrote, for even J.F.K. skeptics like myself to feel a little sympathy for the cult of Camelot — because it speaks to a deep and admirable human desire “for grace and beauty, for icons and heroes, for a high-stakes dimension to human affairs that a consumerist, materialist civilization can flatten and exclude.” The various things that J.F.K.’s admirers cite when they praise the man and his administration — the physical vigor and the soaring rhetoric, the patronage of high culture and the man-on-the-moon technological ambition, the Cuban Missile Crisis drama and the founding of the Peace Corps  — might not match up to a reality that was much more personally sleazy, culturally incurious and geopolitically reckless. But better a slightly bogus “vigah” than a society that deliberately cultivates what Lewis termed “men without chests.” Better a gap between self-sacrificial aspirations and grubbier realities than a society like Huxley’s “Brave New World” that excludes any dreams higher than comfort and consumption.

headline: Researchers Retract Report That Linked Bitcoin Creator and Silk Road
abstract: A paper written by two Israeli computer scientists linked a Bitcoin account to a transaction on Silk Road, an Internet black market. But the owner of that account, who is not the still-anonymous creator of Bitcoin, has come forward.
lead_paragraph: Two Israeli computer scientists who over the weekend published a paper describing a financial connection between the Bitcoin peer-to-peer transaction system and the operator of Silk Road, an Internet black market, have backed away from the claim after an independent security researcher took responsibility for the puzzling account that generated the transfer.

headline: Last Call for Student ‘Hamlet’ Videos
abstract: There are a few days left to for student actors to submit “Hamlet” Instagram videos.
lead_paragraph: As part of The New York Times’s deep dive into a Shakespeare-heavy theater season, we invited student actors to submit Instagram videos of their own 15-second scenes from “Hamlet.”

headline: What Have You Seen Businesses Doing to Get Customers in the Door?
abstract: A microdistillery in Washington invites its customers to help with its bottling.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published a story about small businesses that are using classes and events to get customers in the door. One example is the Woodinville Whiskey Company in Woodinville, Wash., which holds bottling parties, where customers bottle, label, cork and case whiskey. These efforts are rewarded with a “bottling crew” T-shirt, a discount on anything they buy that night and dinner.

headline: And So to Bed
abstract: Three new picture books to read before a good night’s sleep.
lead_paragraph: If breakfast is the most important meal of the day, surely the half-hour or so before bed is, for families, the day’s most important moment: a time to reflect on the past, plan for tomorrow, and read together. Three new picture books for bedtime offer very different pleasures for children of different ages and temperaments.

headline: Daylight and $69 Million Transform a Queens Museum
abstract: The museum, formerly called the Queens Museum of Art, was a forbidding bookend to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Now it fits its environment.
lead_paragraph: Chances seemed pretty dim nine years ago that the plan to reconstruct and expand the Queens Museum of Art would have a happy architectural ending.

headline: Believe in Eternity, or at Least 100 Years
abstract: “Der Rosenkavalier” returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday with Nathaniel Merrill’s 1969 production and felt utterly fresh.
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel Merrill’s 1969 production of Strauss’s “Rosenkavalier” is the oldest in the Metropolitan Opera’s repertory. Its opulent Rococo sets, furnished with loving historical details, have played home to singers including Christa Ludwig, Tatiana Troyanos and Luciano Pavarotti. And yet Friday evening’s season premiere with a wonderful cast — many singing these roles for the first time at the Met — felt utterly fresh. Witty, elegant and profoundly moving, the production continues to be an excellent vehicle for Strauss’s reflection on the impermanence of the human existence and love’s power to nevertheless make us believe in eternity.

headline: Greek Editor Acquitted Anew Over Publication of Swiss Bank Account Names
abstract: The authorities had accused Kostas Vaxevanis, who wanted to shine a light on tax evasion, of violating privacy laws.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A Greek magazine editor who caused a political storm a year ago when he published the names of more than 2,000 Greeks with Swiss bank accounts in a bid to shine a light on unpunished tax evasion was cleared of violating privacy laws on Wednesday.

headline: Lighting Up the Lawn With 16 Million Colors
abstract: New computerized systems and smartphone apps can make Christmas much more than incandescent lights and inflatable snowmen.
lead_paragraph: It starts with an innocent string of incandescent holiday lights around a porch window, maybe a plastic caroler or two on the front lawn.

headline: Online Health Law Sign-Up Is Delayed for Small Business
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In yet another setback for the rollout of the health care law, the Obama administration announced that the online exchange for small businesses would not be available until next November.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday announced a one-year delay in a major element of the new health care law that would allow small businesses to buy insurance online for their employees through the new federal marketplace.

headline: Rich Twits, Back in the Day
abstract: Sidney Frances Bateman’s 1856 play “Self,” at the Metropolitan Playhouse, offers timeless humor centered on social climbers.
lead_paragraph: Somehow it’s comforting to know that silly rich people were ever thus.

headline: 100 Notable Books of 2013
abstract: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.

abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Oldboy,” “Black Nativity” and “Frozen.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Oldboy,” “Black Nativity” and “Frozen.”

headline: Market Report | Evening Shoes for Guys Who Want to Step Out
abstract: These elegant, versatile loafer styles can add a playful note to black tie and dress up more casual outfits.
lead_paragraph: Snazzy evening loafers add a touch of insouciance to a black-tie ensemble and a bit of prepster panache to a more casual jacket and jeans look.

headline: Party Claims It Identified Top C.I.A. Spy in Pakistan
abstract: The political party of former cricket star Imran Khan apparently revealed the name in an escalation of its campaign to end American drone strikes in the country.
lead_paragraph: The political party of the former cricket star Imran Khan on Wednesday identified a man it described as the C.I.A.'s top spy in Pakistan, in an escalation of Mr. Khan’s campaign to end American drone strikes in the country.

headline: A Giant Among Men
abstract: Leo Damrosch’s biography of Jonathan Swift gives full rein to his many talents and contradictions.
lead_paragraph: Those of us at Harvard who took the seminar on Swift and Pope offered by the eminent scholar and specialist George Sherburn elicited the professor’s savage indignation as he returned our papers, many of which had called Swift ferocious. I chuckled, thinking myself innocent of the charge, until I received my paper with a furiously circled “ferocious” in it.

headline: Game? What Game? Let’s Tailgate
abstract: At Louisiana State, football can be an excuse for a good, old-fashioned Southern tailgate party.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Just how legendary is the tailgating culture at Louisiana State University? Legendary enough to draw Allison DiBenedetto, a 28-year-old teacher from Staten Island, to the L.S.U. campus over homecoming weekend to celebrate her bachelorette party with a group of friends. Never mind that Ms. DiBenedetto didn’t attend L.S.U., and her wedding isn’t until September of next year.

headline: Europe Urges U.S. to Handle Data Privacy With Care
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The call from the European Commission stopped short of a threat to overturn the agreement that enables American technology companies to mine Europeans’ personal data.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Commission demanded on Wednesday that the American authorities take greater care in protecting European citizens’ personal data. But it did not take steps to change the rules that allow American companies like Google and Microsoft to compile that data.

headline: A Region Totters Toward Democracy, Gathering Momentum
abstract: Although elections remain far from trouble-free in countries like the Maldives, Nepal and Bhutan, that they are happening at all is encouraging.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At a certain point this fall, the presidential elections in the Maldives stopped looking like the hiccups of a young democracy and veered into the realm of farce.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Oldboy,’ ‘Black Nativity’ and ‘Frozen’
abstract: Times critics share their thoughts on the week in film.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on Spike Lee’s dark thriller “Oldboy,” Kasi Lemmons’s musical “Black Nativity” and the latest animated film from Walt Disney Pictures, “Frozen.” See more of this week’s reviews.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Florida and Australia
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Key West Literary Seminar, Florida

headline: Norma Kamali Is Playing Dress-Up With Sweatshirts
abstract: Ms. Kamali and her sweatshirt are back on the scene.
lead_paragraph: WHO COULD HAVE PREDICTED a couple of years ago that the homebody sweatshirt would attain high-fashion status? Well, Norma Kamali, for one. It was, after all, Ms. Kamali who in the late 70s transformed this downtime staple, linked with the locker room and the living room couch, into a fashion trophy.

headline: Cold War Tensions Reheated
abstract: “The Jack Ryan Collection,” a four-disc set spanning his adventures, provides an object lesson in how, and how not, to manage a series.
lead_paragraph: “The Hunt for Red October” might better have been called “The Hunt for a Paramount Thriller Franchise.” In 1990, the sun had just set on the Reagan administration, but Paramount, the home of “Top Gun,” hungered for a property capitalizing on the president’s brand of patriotism. Filling the bill were the best-selling novels of Tom Clancy, a former Baltimore insurance salesman with a passion for high-tech Defense Department lingo and jingoism. (He died in October.) Reagan himself said Clancy’s “Red October” was “my kind of yarn.”

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: This month’s books include the reissue of a classic novel by John Rechy, stories by Laura van den Berg and a biography of Richard Pryor.
lead_paragraph: This month, fiction with grim edges, including a hustler’s lonely life, a possible assassination in Mexico City, women emotionally adrift and a murderer on the run. Also, a look at Richard Pryor’s career and a literary miscellany.

headline: Hope Doesn’t Come Out of a Bottle
abstract: Conor McPherson’s “The Night Alive” opens at the Atlantic Theater Company in a production he directed.
lead_paragraph: For 20 years, Conor McPherson ended most of his plays with a faint hope of salvation — for the lonely souls in “The Weir,” the therapist and patient in “Shining City,” and the Everyman alcoholic in “The Seafarer,” to name his three works that had critically acclaimed runs on Broadway. But his latest play, “The Night Alive,” tops them. Mr. McPherson, one of Ireland’s greatest living playwrights, has gone all in to render a powerful moment of redemption in the final scene — sure to be one of the most debated of the New York theater season, given that it leaves much room for interpretation.

headline: Engineering His Own Vermeer
abstract: With a film crew recording his every brush stroke, Tim Jenison, a Texas inventor, painted his version of Vermeer’s “The Music Lesson.”
lead_paragraph: Tim Jenison has always thought of himself as an inventor, the kind of person who keeps a running list of practical puzzles for when he can devote spare brain cells to solving them.

headline: Getting Secret Money Out of Campaigns
abstract: The I.R.S. has a new definition of “political activity.”
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service spent years averting its eyes while clever campaign operatives abused the tax code for political purposes. Advocacy groups, mostly on the right, wanted to run attack ads while concealing the source of their money, and they came up with a brilliant way to do it: claim to be “social welfare” groups, which are allowed to hide donors.

headline: Brazil High Court Puts Off Depositor Ruling Until 2014
abstract: Multiple class-action lawsuits over more than two-decade-old policies could together cost Brazil’s $64.8 billion — more than a quarter of the banking system’s equity.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:30 p.m. |

headline: Rise in Unprotected Sex by Gay Men Spurs H.I.V. Fears
abstract: The number of men who told federal health investigators that they had had unprotected anal sex in the last year rose nearly 20 percent from 2005 to 2011.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials are reporting a sharp increase in unprotected sex among gay American men, a development that makes it harder to fight the AIDS epidemic.

headline: Living With Cancer: Giving Thanks and Latkes
abstract: How can I refuse to grant cancer a positive role in my life, given all the substantial rewards?
lead_paragraph: When I consider how this Hanukkah will be different from all other Hanukkahs, I wonder if my giddiness can be attributed to cancer and the treatments that have governed my life for the past five years.

headline: Good Looks, Specially Wrapped
abstract: Fragrances and skin care products for women and men.
lead_paragraph: With the unusual convergence of Thanksgiving and Hanukkah, gift-giving season seems extra-long this year. Some of these specially packaged beauty products will help glamorize recipients for holiday parties, while others may just help them relax.

headline: Thanksgivukkah Reading: A Lending Boom for ‘the Devil Incarnate’
abstract: To the dismay of regulators, investors are increasingly embracing to higher credit risk for the potential of higher returns.
lead_paragraph: To the dismay of regulators, investors are increasingly embracing to higher credit risk for the potential of higher returns.

headline: italysyriarefuge-loop
