lead_paragraph: italysyriarefuge-loop

headline: How to Choose a Carry-On Bag
abstract: From size to wheels to pockets, here are factors to consider when you’re selecting that piece of luggage to take on board.
lead_paragraph: The Samsonite roll-aboard bag I’ve been using for 15 years announced its retirement this spring, when a wheel tread ripped on a cobblestone street in Belfast. I coaxed it through the rest of the trip with duct tape and taxi rides, but it was clearly time to find a new carry-on — not a simple task, I quickly discovered.

headline: Looking for an Edge During Holiday Travel
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: To smooth the often bumpy winter air travel season, travelers are eyeing everything from expedited screening to apps.
lead_paragraph: Connecting to technology may be the best way to get to loved ones this holiday season. Speed and efficiency are essential, and without an app or two in a back pocket, travelers could be stuck at the back of the line.

headline: Latvian Premier Resigns Over Collapse of Building
abstract: There had been no public calls for Prime Minister Valdis Dombrovskis to resign after the collapse of a supermarket killed at least 45 people, but he said he accepted responsibility.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — The prime minister of Latvia unexpectedly resigned on Wednesday, saying he was accepting “political and moral responsibility” for a building collapse last week that killed at least 54 people.

headline: Hotel Review: Great Northern Hotel in London
abstract: This 91-room property, an updated classic situated at one of London’s principal transit points, reopened this spring.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: A ‘Powerful’ Image of Breast Cancer Offends Some Times Readers
abstract: Readers objected for a number of reasons, but an editor defends it as newsworthy and beautiful.
lead_paragraph: Many Times readers were disturbed and offended by the front-page photograph of an Israeli woman’s upper torso in Wednesday’s newspaper. It was the dominant image on the page, and it accompanied an article in a series called “The Cancer Divide,” which is examining “how the treatment of breast cancer is shaped by wealth and poverty, culture and values.”

headline: What You Get for... $875,000
abstract: This week’s homes include an adobe-style house in Arizona, a Georgian house in Virginia, and a contemporary in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ.

headline: What You Get for ... $875,000
abstract: Properties include an adobe-style house in Arizona, a Georgian in Virginia and a contemporary in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: Properties include an adobe-style house in Arizona, a Georgian in Virginia and a contemporary in Vermont.

headline: Tidying Up the World
abstract: The year gone by was very, very messy. Here’s how to set it straight.
lead_paragraph: The year gone by was very, very messy. Here’s how to set it straight.

headline: Two Lucky Birds
abstract: On the eve of Thanksgiving, the president saves two turkeys from becoming dinner.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Thanksgiving, the president saves two turkeys from becoming dinner.

headline: Moscow Says Louis Vuitton Doesn’t Go With Red Square
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The designer has built a temporary, two-story replica of a traveling trunk, but to some officials, it is not temporary enough.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — If Lenin were alive today, instead of spinning in his mausoleum nearby, he no doubt would be aghast at the two-story replica of a Louis Vuitton traveling trunk on Red Square. He might also update the title of his famous essay on the need for a revolutionary vanguard party, asking not “What Is To Be Done” but “Why the Heck Was It Done?”

headline: In Bulgaria’s Charming Old-World Capital, a Modern Oasis
abstract: The recently opened Sense Hotel brings a splash of contemporary luxury to the appealingly low-key metropolis of Sofia. Plus: four can’t-miss destinations while staying there.
lead_paragraph: Until the beautifully designed 71-room Sense Hotel opened in June, luxury in Sofia, the handsome capital of Bulgaria, was often more defined by what the Balkan city doesn’t have than what it does — which is a lot of character and un-self-conscious charm. Despite a population of 1.2 million, the city has none of the stress-tinged, work-centric rhythms found in most European capitals, existing instead in a gentle post-Ottoman twilight, its leafy neighborhoods still full of small cafes, bars and taverns. The arrival of Starbucks hasn’t completely sidelined the local preference for Turkish coffee and the city’s old market — where kerchiefed farm wives sell their pickles in recycled jars and there is an abundant supply of the delicious cheese-filled phyllo pastries known as banitsa — is still busy, despite the big supermarkets opening on the outskirts of town.

headline: Shopping Events in New York Starting Nov. 28
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)']
abstract: Sales at Project No. 8, Creatures of Comfort and Assembly New York.
lead_paragraph: Sales

headline: My Favorite Ways to Kick the Bucket
abstract: The veteran actor Stacy Keach recalls the death scenes he’s most fond of from his career on film, stage and television.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody at Warner’s died like me. It’s the one thing I had a knack for.”

headline: Familiar Faces, Broad Humor
abstract: After bouts of self-mockery (“Fat Actress”) and a public weight-loss regimen, Kirstie Alley has re-emerged.
lead_paragraph: When it’s Kirstie Alley, size doesn’t matter. But after bouts of self-mockery (“Fat Actress”) and a public weight-loss regimen (Jenny Craig and “Dancing With the Stars”), she has re-emerged: thinner, younger — at least in TV years — and ready for prime time once again.

headline: Tourist Sites as Inspiration
abstract: A look at the work of the Chinese artist Sun Xun.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of the Chinese artist Sun Xun.

headline: Inspiration Far From Home
abstract: The Chinese artist Sun Xun is spending the fall in New York in preparation for an exhibition next year at the Sean Kelly Gallery.
lead_paragraph: When the Chinese artist Sun Xun was growing up in Fuxin, a small city near the North Korean border, he already knew that China was a country with at least two histories. In school, during the day, he studied the Chinese history presented in official accounts, a version remarkably free of such troubling episodes as the Great Leap Forward or the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Heading Wherever, Together
abstract: One Direction’s new album has a blankness that perhaps is a strategy: Testing how little is needed to keep a pop phenomenon moving.
lead_paragraph: In the current issue of Billboard, at the end of the cover feature on One Direction, there is a cooling mist of reality spritzed by, who else, Simon Cowell, the TV judge-impresario who helped Frankenstein this group into existence on the 2010 season of the British version of “The X Factor.”

headline: Musical Underground
abstract: Xuefei Yang, a gifted guitarist who is said to have been the first guitar major at Beijing’s Central Conservatory of Music, will perform at SubCulture.
lead_paragraph: Xuefei Yang, a gifted guitarist who is said to have been the first guitar major at Beijing’s Central Conservatory of Music, will perform at SubCulture on Tuesday in a show presented by the 92nd Street Y. This intimate new subterranean space on Bleecker Street has joined Le Poisson Rouge, among others, as a prominent downtown platform for classical music. Ms. Yang, who has several records on EMI Classics, will perform works by Britten (whose centennial is being celebrated this season) as well as pieces by Ginastera, Chen Yi and Mertz. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.)

headline: Whitish Gray, Also Quite Green
abstract: An event of a permanent nature may overshadow the five-day confab of art fairs in Miami this week: the inauguration of the striking Pérez Art Museum Miami.
lead_paragraph: An event of a relatively permanent nature may overshadow the five-day confab of art fairs that will descend on Miami this week: the inauguration of the striking Pérez Art Museum Miami (formerly the Miami Art Museum) in Bicentennial Park on the Bay of Biscayne. The whitish-gray, mostly environmentally green building is the latest museum from Herzog & de Meuron, which designed the expansion of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the De Young Museum in San Francisco. The three-story 120,000 square-foot building consists of a group of geometric volumes that seem almost to levitate between a base of several platforms and an immense perforated canopy overhead. In addition to reducing energy consumption, the canopy will support one of the museum’s most distinctive features: a hanging garden of native plants irrigated by collected rainwater. The effect is of an expanded Corbusier villa that has absorbed its greensward. The opening exhibitions seem bent on making the most of the museum’s small collection and nearly 31,000 square feet of gallery space, but with a probable destination building like this, it may not matter.

headline: Braided Bodies Up Onstage
abstract: Robert Battle is giving his dancers a reason to have an extra bounce in their steps.
lead_paragraph: It can’t be easy being the artistic director of one of America’s most beloved dance companies, but Robert Battle — after a little more than two years on the job — is gradually and imaginatively giving his dancers a reason to have an extra bounce in their steps. Beginning on Wednesday, his troupe, the versatile Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will unveil Wayne McGregor’s “Chroma,” originally choreographed for the Royal Ballet in 2006. The work pits John Pawson’s stark set against Joby Talbot’s original compositions and arrangements of music by the White Stripes. It was also the dance that led to Mr. McGregor’s appointment as resident choreographer at the Royal Ballet.

headline: Seeing Beauty With Saul Leiter
abstract: Tony Cenicola had no idea who Saul Leiter was when he first met the fabled photographer. But he spent a decade helping — and learning from — Mr. Leiter, who died on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Tony Cenicola thought he was leaving behind the world of being a photo assistant to start his own studio. He had been helping a photographer move into a lower Fifth Avenue studio duplex in 1985 when its owner was struck by something: Mr. Cenicola could pack delicate cameras and gear. Soon, Mr. Cenicola got a call from that photographer to be his assistant. He spent the next 10 years working with Saul Leiter, an important figure in the New York School. Mr. Leiter died late Tuesday night in New York City. Mr. Cenicola, who is now a staff photographer at The New York Times, recalled his time assisting — and learning from — Mr. Leiter. His conversation with David Gonzalez has been edited into a first-person narrative.

headline: West Coast Style, by the Numbers
abstract: The rapper who calls himself 100s has a genuinely beautiful mane of hair not seen since the days of Suga Free, and that’s not an accident.
lead_paragraph: The rapper who calls himself 100s has a genuinely beautiful mane of hair not seen since the days of Suga Free, and that’s not an accident: 100s is part of the proud California pimp-rap legacy, and aesthetics matter. On his self-released debut album from last year, “Ice Cold Perm,” he raps with a smooth sneer over gooey tracks that recall the West Coast of the early-mid 1990s, a sound that’s been undervalued historically. And his new singles “Life of a Mack” (also heard in the video game “Grand Theft Auto V”) and “Keep a Bitch Broke” — in advance of a new EP, “IVRY” (Fool’s Gold) — show an admirable commitment to keeping that style alive. 100s is the most exciting artist on the “Turnt & Burnt” tour — along with the headliner, ASAP Ferg — which comes to Irving Plaza this week, and also features various other members of the ASAP Mob, as well as Joey Fatts, Aston Matthews and OverDoz. (Friday at 7 p.m., 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan; irvingplaza.com.)

headline: See Stanwyck, All Month Long
abstract: Forty of Barbara Stanwyck’s best films, many in 35-millimeter prints, appear in a Film Forum celebration.
lead_paragraph: I recall watching “The Big Valley” as a child, a western series on ABC about a family led by a matriarch who was smart, graceful, independent and tough (and partial to turtlenecks and black leather). Only later did I learn the true majesty of the star, billed on the show as Miss Barbara Stanwyck. Stanwyck (1907-90) — born Ruby Stevens in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and a former Ziegfeld chorus girl — had 35 years of movies behind her. Forty of her best films, many in 35-millimeter prints, appear in “Stanwyck,” a Film Forum celebration running Friday through Dec. 31.

headline: Civil Complaint Against MSA Security
abstract: Read the full civil complaint against MSA Security.
lead_paragraph: Read the full civil complaint against MSA Security.

headline: At Edward Hopper’s Home, Legally This Time
abstract: An exhibition by Tony Oursler, who once sneaked into Edward Hopper’s childhood home, ties in snippets of Mr. Hopper’s youth to scenes from the famous artist’s marriage.
lead_paragraph: As a mischievous boy in the late 1960s, Tony Oursler sneaked into Edward Hopper’s childhood home, then unoccupied and in disrepair, and just blocks from where Mr. Oursler’s family lived in Nyack, N.Y. Now an internationally recognized multimedia artist, Mr. Oursler has returned to the scene of his trespassing, today known as the Edward Hopper House Art Center, with “Tony Oursler: hopped (popped),” a site-specific installation that interweaves anecdotal snippets from his youth with biting reimaginings of Hopper’s complicated 43-year marriage.

headline: A Violin Prodigy, Now Grown
abstract: During her transition from prodigy to adult violinist, Sirena Huang focused on preparation, not competition.
lead_paragraph: The seeds of Sirena Huang’s professional relationship with Carolyn Kuan, music director of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra, were planted at the 2007 Eastern Music Festival in Greensboro, N.C. Ms. Huang, then a 12-year-old violinist in the Juilliard School’s pre-college division, was the soloist with a student orchestra conducted by Ms. Kuan, who was then assistant director of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra.

headline: House Hunting Near Marseille
abstract: A house designed by the architect André Stern is on the market for $2.6 million.
lead_paragraph: A house designed by the architect André Stern is on the market for $2.6 million.

headline: House Hunting Near ... Marseille
abstract: Prices in the area remain in a holding pattern, agents say, but there are signs that resales in the French market over all are starting to revive after a slump in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A MODERN VILLA IN THE COASTAL TOWN OF ST.-CYR-SUR-MER

headline: Digital Passivity
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: We have backed ourselves into a virtual corner.
lead_paragraph: I fear that 2013 will be remembered as a tragic  and dark year in the digital universe, despite the fact that a lot of wonderful advances took place.

headline: From the Editor
abstract: “Turning Points” is the theme of this year-end magazine as we gaze with equal measures of anticipation and alarm into 2014.
lead_paragraph: The experts we corralled for our “Conversation” on aging, as you are about to discover, agree that we are pushing death farther and farther back, so that many of us may now expect to live a century or more. I find this most heartening, sharing as I do the common fear of the Reaper. But I am also aware that I and my fellow centenarians will pose some difficult new problems for our 80-year-old kids and 60-something grandkids, problems memorably identified by the Beatles back in the day: Will you still need me, will you still feed me, when I’m one-oh-four?

headline: So Many Sounds, but Jazz Is the Core
abstract: A Kennedy Center honor and a new 34-CD boxed set honor Herbie Hancock’s many triumphs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES —  Herbie Hancock, a pianist of sparkling touch and brisk intuition, has often seemed like a figure rushing ever onward, and the direction in which he has increasingly hurled himself is globe-trotting cultural diplomacy. “I don’t consider myself a spokesperson for jazz,” he said recently, implying that he has bigger concerns.

headline: Week 13 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: The Value of Aaron Rodgers
abstract: If Rodgers, who is injured, were able to play the entire season, his numbers would add four wins to make the Packers more like an 11-win team.
lead_paragraph: The model used here to produce the game probabilities is a “parametric” model, meaning its inputs are parameters that can be varied easily. That’s obviously a good thing, as team statistics certainly vary from week to week. It’s also handy because those parameters can be manually adjusted to account for injuries and just to play what-if.

headline: The Past in Our Future
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The ghosts of repetition reside alongside the prophets of progress.
lead_paragraph: I recently took my 16-year-old daughter Adele to see a section of the Berlin Wall that has been preserved as part of a museum devoted to the division of the city, Germany and Europe. It was a bright Berlin morning. Tourists gazed at the wall. They read placards describing the young lives lost in attempts at escape from the Soviet empire. Adele, born in 1997, with just a toehold in the last century, wandered around. She examined these curious relics. Every now and again she checked her Facebook page on her device. ‘‘This just seems so ancient,’’ she said, leaning back against the wall. ‘‘I mean, it feels like it comes from the 19th century.’’

headline: Our Compass
abstract: Who are the moral leaders for these times?
lead_paragraph: In each issue, the editors of Turning Points invite contributors to explore one of the big questions of the year. For 2013 we asked Elif Shafak, Salam Fayyad, Liao Yiwu, Rowan Williams, Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Mata Amritanandamayi Devi: Who are the moral leaders for these times?

headline: Cyber Subterfuge
abstract: The Internet has lost its innocence: The virtual world is awash with espionage, malware and deception.
lead_paragraph: I awoke one morning to a disturbing email from the software giant Adobe. The message warned that thieves had hacked into the company’s servers, stolen the source code for some of its software products and almost three million passwords and credit card details, among which might be mine. It included a link to reset my password.

headline: An Unlikely Throne for Dance Royalty
abstract: Works by the British choreographer Frederick Ashton have a reverent American home at the Sarasota Ballet in Florida.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Michelangelo’s David framed by palm trees: The image may seem incongruous, but it’s a semiofficial symbol for this resort city on the Gulf Coast of Florida. A bronze version of that Italian Renaissance sculpture has long stood in a bayside courtyard of the Ringling Museum of Art here, part of the collection of European antiquities and old master paintings that the circus tycoon John Ringling imported in the early 1900s. Along with a long-established opera company, orchestra and repertory theater, the museum explains why Sarasota is accustomed to billing itself as Florida’s Cultural Coast.

headline: The World of Mars
abstract: There are un-Earthly parallels between the exploration of the Grand Canyon 140 years ago and what is happening on Mars today.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘We have an unknown distance yet to run, an unknown river to explore. What falls there are, we know not; what rocks beset the channel, we know not; what walls ride over the river, we know not. Ah, well! we may conjecture many things.’’  — John Wesley Powell

headline: Leaving Home Coming Home
abstract: I have experienced exile from both perspectives: that of those who leave, and of those who say goodbye. Both are terribly emotional and sobering.
lead_paragraph: Organizing one’s address book is always a thankless task. Every year, from my home in Havana, I attack the job of reviewing, page by page, all the names and data that make up my network of personal and professional relationships. Like a tapestry in which I am barely one strand, I review every thread that remains and each thread that was lost. And I find myself facing the alarming evidence of how many people I must subtract.

headline: Power in 2030: The Roads We May Take
abstract: How we manage the balance between conventional energy sources – oil, natural gas and coal – and renewables will shape our future.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that we are at a turning point in world energy. But then we are often at a turning point. Just as everybody gets comfortable with what they expect to happen, a big change comes along that undercuts existing assumptions. Just consider:

headline: Father to a Nation, and to a Family
abstract: “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom,” based on Nelson Mandela’s memoir, presents him as an inspiring leader with complexities.
lead_paragraph: Zindzi Mandela’s earliest memory is sitting outside a Pretoria, South Africa, police station in 1962 while her mother, Winnie, delivered a favorite dish to her father, Nelson Mandela, being held inside.

headline: Deep Cover
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Families and Family Life', 'Names, Personal', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: In search of my original name, I came upon a greater mystery.
lead_paragraph: “Please, what is my name  —  you have to tell me my name!’’ I was on the corner of 72nd Street and Broadway in New York, talking with the urgency of a madwoman into my cellphone.

headline: After Recovery, a Return Fit for Longing and Loss
abstract: Deborah Warner’s production of “Eugene Onegin” returns to the Met, this time with the tenor Rolando Villazón as Lenski.
lead_paragraph: When the tenor Rolando Villazón last sang at the Metropolitan Opera in 2009, he suffered various mishaps, prompting cancellations attributed to laryngitis and other illnesses. He sought medical advice and was told he would probably never sing again. He was eventually found to have a congenital internal cyst on his left vocal cord; after surgery in 2009, he relearned first how to speak and then how to sing, making a sometimes unsteady foray back into the professional opera world.

headline: Women Rising
abstract: We must move past the good intentions of the international community. The words that fill declarations and resolutions must be made real.
lead_paragraph: In a Belfast hotel last spring, stories of children and life floated through the rooms.

headline: Drug War No More
abstract: A fundamental shift is underway in methods to combat narcotics.
lead_paragraph: After covering drug trafficking and violence in Latin America since 2001, I look through endless photos and videos and ask myself what would be its single most iconic image  —  one that people could look at in a hundred years and understand.

headline: A Force of 120 Million
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Being able to decide when to have children is central to fulfilling one’s potential. In the year ahead, many women will harness this power for the first time.
lead_paragraph: I met Sharmila Devi when the youngest of her four children, Babita, was 4 months old. After Babita was born, Sharmila made a brave decision that will give her children a good chance at a better future.

headline: Euro Marriage in Peril
abstract: Are the differences between the euro zone’s shaky periphery and its more stable core too great to overcome?
lead_paragraph: On the morning of July 26, 2012, I was meeting with the central bank governor of a country at the core, or stable center, of the euro zone. He was telling me that the European Central Bank could do little to rescue peripheral countries like Italy and Spain, whose interest rates were going through the roof.

headline: Do I Dare to Eat a Peach?
abstract: Serge Schmemann moderates a discussion about aging with Sarah Harper, Babatunde Osotimehin and Ruby Wax.
lead_paragraph: This discussion was held in London in partnership with the lecture curator 5x15. The moderator was Serge Schmemann, editor of the Magazine. The participants were Sarah Harper, a British gerontologist and founder of the Oxford Institute of Population Aging; Babatunde Osotimehin, a physician and former Nigerian minister of health who is executive director of UNFPA, the United Nations Populations Fund; and Ruby Wax, an American-born, London-based comedian, writer, TV personality and mental-health campaigner.

headline: Fashion’s Latest Muse
abstract: The creator of the wrap dress and other legendary designs talks about personal style in the age of technology.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenue department store, asked a few designers to create looks for their windows. The instruction: What will we be wearing in the year 2000? Instead of designing a dress, I painted a leopard-print skin on a mannequin. Little did I know the wrap dresses I was making at the time would still be relevant in the 21st century. I am amazed that, as I celebrate the 40th anniversary of the dress in 2014, my little creation is still being worn by young women across the globe.

headline: What’s So Funny?
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: If you can’t make sense of 2013, just turn to the world’s comedians.
lead_paragraph: This year, the world became just a tad more crazy, sick and difficult to understand. “A man who is not confused is not well informed,” goes the old Irish saying, and that has never been more true. Economists, journalists, psychologists and other poor souls who deal with the hard questions of daily life  —  with no relief in sight  —  have no easy answers to offer.

headline: Notable Children’s Books of 2013
abstract: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s book editor of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: YOUNG ADULT

headline: Wrath, Lust and Other Punch Lines
abstract: In “Seven Deadlies,” Gigi Levangie offers satirical parables about teenagers obsessed with junk food, boy bands and making money.
lead_paragraph: Gigi Levangie’s latest black comedy is a set of scathing parables about the seven deadly sins, which are made a bit deadlier by the filthy-rich Beverly Hills ambience that the author can skewer so well. Ms. Levangie, now using this nom de divorce after writing her funnier books (“Maneater,” “The Starter Wife”) as Gigi Levangie Grazer, can be hit or miss, especially when she has a plot to concoct. But “Seven Deadlies” requires no such exertion. It’s not much more than a set of seven meanspirited stories about what sin and wretched excess can do.

headline: 2013: The Year in Images
abstract: A look at events around the world from the past year.
lead_paragraph: A look at events around the world from the past year.

headline: A Record Store Rises
abstract: Stephen Mallon, a visual artist, shot a behind-the-scenes preparations for the opening of Rough Trade’s first flagship store in the U.S. on November 25th.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Mallon, a visual artist, shot a behind-the-scenes preparations for the opening of Rough Trade’s first flagship store in the U.S. on November 25th.

headline: Council Bill Aims to Limit Use of E-Cigarettes as Their Popularity Grows
abstract: Fearing that e-cigarettes are a gateway to conventional cigarettes, and that they may pose health hazards, the New York City Council is trying to ban their use in public places.
lead_paragraph: The City Council is seeking to add electronic cigarettes to New York’s ban on smoking in public places.

headline: Global Agenda
abstract: In 2014 we’ll mostly be talking like pirates and growing mustaches.
lead_paragraph: What the editors of Turning Points look forward to in 2014.

headline: The Dead Return. They Need Hobbies.
abstract: Weighing the rewards and efforts involved in following “The Returned,” the surreal French series about dead people who come back to life.
lead_paragraph: The word “zombie” is thrown around a lot in reference to “The Returned,” the spooky French series whose first season has hit the halfway point on Sundance Channel. It’s even been called the French “Walking Dead.” But it’s not really a zombie show. Only one character eats flesh, and he started doing it while he was still alive. When an undead girl says, “Zombies have to stick together,” her smile tells you that she considers herself anything but.

headline: What Becomes a Diva Most?
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s costume designer faces new challenges, like creating clothes and accessories that look good in high-definition screenings.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday afternoon, the soprano Lisette Oropesa was standing in a mirrored changing room inside the Metropolitan Opera’s costume department playing with her wedding veil. The costume designer Brigitte Reiffenstuel looked on critically, stepping back as far as possible within the cramped space. Elise Aragon, a draper, knelt at the soprano’s feet with pins cupped in her hand. Ms. Oropesa fluffed the veil with her hands and allowed the diaphanous material to settle like a mist around her face. By way of experiment, she took a few deep breaths and declared herself satisfied. “I’ve had to sing with way worse stuff on my face,” she said.

headline: ‘Falstaff’ Costumes
abstract: Designing opera costumes in an era of high-tech challenges.
lead_paragraph: Designing opera costumes in an era of high-tech challenges.

headline: The Gun Report: November 27, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The gun violence we cover fades from the headlines after a day or two, when we’re onto the next batch. Here are follow-ups to some notable recent shootings we’ve covered in the report.

headline: Letters: The President and the Press
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Doris Kearns Goodwin’s “Bully Pulpit,” Richard A. Posner’s “Reflections on Judging” and more.
lead_paragraph: The President and the Press

headline: Music of the Season Taking Center Stage
abstract: Festive concerts, from “Nutcracker” selections to jazz, dot the year-end calendar.
lead_paragraph: All across Long Island this month, the holidays are being rung in with music including rock, pop and classical, at venues both traditional and less so. Here is a sampling of what is around.

headline: Art and Technology
abstract: Four creators are using modern tools to push the boundaries of innovation. Here, they explain their work and its inspiration.
lead_paragraph: ‘HOVER FLY’ and ‘MUSHROOM GILLS’ By Susumu Nishinaga, Japan

headline: A Surge in Value for Bitcoin and Currencies Similar to It
abstract: The trading price of Bitcoin reached a new high, and the value others like it rose significantly in the last week as attention was focused on these cryptocurrencies.
lead_paragraph: This has been quite the week for the peer-to-peer digital currencies. Exactly seven days ago, Bitcoin, the digital cryptocurrency, was trading at about $615, but early Wednesday morning it had passed $1,000 on Mt.Gox, the leading Bitcoin exchange, setting a new high. This pushed Bitcoin’s market capitalization to over $11 billion.

headline: Tom Perrotta: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Little Children,” “Election” and “The Leftovers” had to force himself to finish “Lolita”: “All that sparkling wordplay just got exhausting after a while.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Little Children,” “Election” and “The Leftovers” had to force himself to finish “Lolita”: “All that sparkling wordplay just got exhausting after a while.”

headline: How Long Does It Take to Shelve 23,000 Albums?
abstract: Watch a big, new music store in New York City get stocked with thousands of CDs and vinyl records in this time-lapse video by Stephen Mallon.
lead_paragraph: The biggest record store in New York City, Rough Trade NYC, opened in Williamsburg on Monday. The store carries approximately 23,000 CDs and vinyl records, and it took 20 employees plus various friends and family members 30 hours, over three days, to stock the shelves in time for the store’s opening party. They’ve still only stocked about two-thirds of their complete inventory, according to Stephen Godfroy, one of the owners.

headline: Grief and Heroism as Survivors Struggle in the Philippines
abstract: Acts of heroism abound in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan, often with a special emphasis on ensuring the survival of children.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Jomar Pascual stirred a steel pot full of instant noodles carefully in a typhoon-damaged former kindergarten building. He had already cooked rice. His three younger brothers and a younger sister, suddenly orphans like him, were hungry, and he began to feed them, spooning the pallid meal onto their green plastic plates.

headline: Lorde Reigns at No. 1; Lady Gaga’s Sales Fall Sharply
abstract: Lorde’s “Royals” remained at No. 1 on the singles chart for a ninth week. Sales of Lady Gaga’s album “Artpop” dropped sharply.
lead_paragraph: On the music charts these days, it’s good to be Eminem. And really good to be Lorde. But not nearly as good to be Lady Gaga.

headline: Bryant Alone Can’t Carry the Lakers
abstract: The Lakers once said Kobe Bryant, who signed a two-year, $48.5 million extension, was worth $60 million a year, but that was predicated on the team’s being really good.
lead_paragraph: As the architect of the 1990s, six-time champion Chicago Bulls, Jerry Krause was quoted as saying that players and coaches do not win championships; organizations do. Krause insisted he was misquoted because, he said, one word — “alone,” after “championships” — had been dropped.

headline: Saul Leiter, Photographer Who Captured New York’s Palette, Dies at 89
abstract: Where other eminent photographers in midcentury captured the city most often in sharp-edged black and white, Mr. Leiter was one of the first professionals to photograph it regularly in color.
lead_paragraph: New York at midcentury was a monochrome town, or so its best-known documentarians would have us believe.

headline: Stylishly Smooth, Roughly Edged
abstract: The R&B singer Jaheim invoked the spirit and sensuality of Luther Vandross during his show at the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t see enough lights,” Jaheim said, strutting across the Theater at Madison Square Garden stage on Tuesday night. “I got to do Luther right.”

headline: In Performance: David Harewood
abstract: The actor David Harewood in a scene as Oberon from Julie Taymor’s new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The actor David Harewood in a scene as Oberon from Julie Taymor’s new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the West Bank, India, Ukraine and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, India, Ukraine and Egypt.

headline: Always an England
abstract: Jane Ridley’s “Heir Apparent” demonstrates that Edward VII, though popular when he became king, was immoral, selfish, philistine and rather stupid.
lead_paragraph: Jane Ridley’s book is timely in a double sense. When the British edition was released shortly after the 2012 Diamond Jubilee summer, America was still perplexed by the high point of that comically un-summery event as an armada-size flotilla of “tugboats and garbage barges” (Jon Stewart’s sardonic description) passed in hours’ long chugging convoy down the Thames, rain pelting remorselessly. Saluting on the dank royal barge were the freezing 86-year-old monarch and her nearly 91-year-old consort. The riverbanks were crowded with a million sodden subjects, roaring jubilantly. What, had Americans wondered, was that all about? Ridley’s book will go some way toward explaining.

headline: The Lure of a Brave New World
abstract: On the utilitarian utopia’s apologists, and Sam Harris as Mustapha Mond.
lead_paragraph: Since my last post dealt with the problems inherent in the various strategies for resisting modern society’s potential drift toward a kind of dystopic, Aldous Huxleyan destination, let me add, as a kind of pre-Thanksgiving coda, an example of how that drift tends to be packaged and sold by people who don’t see it as something to be resisted in the first place.

headline: Broadway Can Hear the Echoes of Jazz Tap
abstract: The only way virtuosic jazz tap has made it onto Broadway this century is in a vehicle that purports to jump back eight decades.
lead_paragraph: Is great tap dance on Broadway a thing of the past? In one sense, apparently not. “After Midnight,” the jazz revue that opened at the Brooks Atkinson this month, showcases some of the best, most state-of-the-art tapping presented in a Broadway theater in many a year. Funny thing is, it’s set in 1932.

headline: Another Round in Legal Battle Over Firing at El Museo del Barrio
abstract: Margarita Aguilar, the former director of El Museo del Barrio, is challenging the dismissal of her complaint about discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The legal battle continues between Margarita Aguilar and officials at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan after her firing as director of the museum earlier this year and her subsequent claim that she was the victim of gender discrimination and a hostile workplace. The New York State Division of Human Rights dismissed her complaints in September. Ms. Aguilar is now calling for that dismissal to be set aside, citing a shoddy investigation.

headline: The Vaccination Effect: 100 Million Cases of Contagious Disease Prevented
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Medicine and Health', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: The estimate of prevented diseases, published in an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, is an analysis of some of the data in a broad project to digitize disease report records going back to 1888.
lead_paragraph: Vaccination programs for children have prevented more than 100 million cases of serious contagious disease in the United States since 1924, according to a new study published in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Hospital Studies Link Heart Device to Clots
abstract: Patients with the HeartMate II, an implant used to treat advanced heart failure, are suffering clots at nearly four times the rate they used to, data shows.
lead_paragraph: Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic began to suspect in 2012 that something might be wrong with a high-tech implant used to treat patients with advanced heart failure like former Vice President Dick Cheney.

headline: Gender Benders
abstract: As a new crop of cross-dressing actors appears in drag, a fresh look at some of the best in the genre, then and now.
lead_paragraph: As a new crop of cross-dressing actors appears in drag, a fresh look at some of the best in the genre, then and now.

headline: New Romanian Cinema
abstract: Select images from films in the series at the Film Society of Lincoln center.
lead_paragraph: Select images from films in the series at the Film Society of Lincoln center.

headline: A Defaced Gap Ad Goes From the Subway to the Web to Its Demise
abstract: When a “Make Love” Gap ad featuring a Sikh man was defaced, a photographer shared the image online and the company reached out to pinpoint its location. The ad was later removed.
lead_paragraph: As the New York City-based photographer Robert Gerhardt waited last Sunday for the No. 6 subway train to take him from the Bronx to Manhattan, he spotted a poster from Gap’s “Make Love” ad campaign. It featured a female model and a man wearing the distinctive turban of the Sikh religion.

headline: Dim Sum, and Much More, in a No-Frills Setting
abstract: Great Wall Restaurant offers chicken feet and tripe among their more standard Sichuan and Cantonese fare, with dim sum on the weekends.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine advised caution when I told him I was visiting Great Wall Restaurant in New Haven, noting the tripe and chicken feet on the menu. In fact, both are delicious, but the restaurant also offers pages of less adventuresome options.

headline: A Soldier’s Nightmare Follows Her Back Home
abstract: “One Night...,” a timely new play by Charles Fuller, tackles issues around sexual assault in the armed forces.
lead_paragraph: Charles Fuller tackles a searing subject — sexual assault in the armed forces — in his new play, “One Night ...,” set in a dingy motel room where two former soldiers have taken refuge after the shelter they were staying in caught fire. With increasing attention being paid to the alarming frequency of rape in the United States military — there are three competing pieces of legislation on the issue being considered by Congress — Mr. Fuller’s play could hardly be more timely.

headline: Discovering the D.J. Caroline Corley, Only to Quickly Lose Her
abstract: I enjoyed Corley’s on-the-air persona, the kind of cool rock chick we all like to hang out with.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, as I often do, I tuned into Caroline Corley’s morning show on the Peak (107.1 FM in New York) during my commute to work.

headline: After 35 Years, They Know Their Fish
abstract: P.F. Market evokes the fresh fish and bare-bones décor of seafood restaurants in New England coastal towns.
lead_paragraph: If the server at P.F. Market says to order the halibut, order it. The staff at this hybrid restaurant and fish market in West Caldwell knows what’s good, and happily for fish lovers, many of the 16 or so varieties of seafood available daily are fresher and more flavorful than at many inland restaurants.

headline: Yes, Survival’s Important. But Then What?
abstract: “Sunset Baby,” by Dominique Morisseau, is about two generations of urban outlaws struggling to stay afloat in the lower depths.
lead_paragraph: People do what they need to do in “Sunset Baby,” Dominique Morisseau’s smart and bracing new play about two generations of urban outlaws struggling to stay afloat in the lower depths. That can mean, among other things, lying to, stealing from, blackmailing and pulling a gun on your nearest and dearest.

headline: Zeke Jabbour’s Game at the Truscott Event
abstract: The American Contract Bridge League’s Fall North American Championships get underway in earnest on Friday in Phoenix.
lead_paragraph: The American Contract Bridge League’s Fall North American Championships get underway in earnest on Friday in Phoenix.

headline: Some Still Like It Hot
abstract: As a new crop of cross-dressing actors, including Jared Leto in “Dallas Buyers Club,” appears in drag, a fresh look at some of the best in the genre, then and now.
lead_paragraph: Men in frocks, a tradition as ancient as Aeschylus, has been revived time and again onstage, in clubs and sometimes in the broadest strokes, at the suburban megaplex. Wherever she appears, though, the sight of a burly man compressed in a curve-hugging mermaid gown rarely fails to elicit in audiences a queasy mix of empathy and raucous laughter.

headline: Robert Hammond: Leaving the High Life
abstract: A walk and talk with Mr. Hammond, executive director of Friends of the High Line, who is stepping down at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning in early November, as Robert Hammond was taking one of his last official walks along the High Line, the urban park he helped develop 14 years ago, he was approached by a tall, well-dressed man who seemed to recognize him.

headline: Kerry and Zarif Turn to Selling Nuclear Deal to Skeptics Back Home
abstract: Having reached an interim agreement to freeze Iran’s nuclear program, Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, turned their attention to selling at home.
lead_paragraph: Having finally reached an interim agreement to freeze Iran’s nuclear program in Geneva on Saturday, Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, turned their attention this week to selling the deal to skeptics back home.

headline: Thai Classics in a Spot Known for Them
abstract: Bangkok Pavilion is the latest restaurant serving Thai food to land at 25 Main Street. Its fare ranges from thunder shrimp as a starter to whole red snapper as a main dish.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, 25 Main Street has been Thai food central in Kings Park. Bangkok Pavilion, which opened in September, is the latest in a series of Thai restaurants there. This one looks like a keeper.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Acid-Attack Trial, Dancers Trade Stage for Stand
abstract: Dancers took the stand in the trial over an acid attack that nearly left the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director blind.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Dancers of the Bolshoi Ballet occupied a different stage on Wednesday as a procession of performers took the witness stand to defend the reputation of the troupe’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, who was the victim of an acid attack and — during the trial of those accused of involvement in the assault — the subject of denunciations by present and former company members.

headline: A Textbook Lecture With Tropical Heat
abstract: Patricia Hoffbauer presented “Para-Dice (Stage 2),” a sequel to her “Para-Dice (Stage 1),” with wry humor, at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Patricia Hoffbauer presented  "Para-Dice (Stage 1)” at Danspace Project, as part of a platform called “certain difficulties, certain joy.”

headline: Two New Lawsuits Accuse Manhattan Gallery of Having Sold Fakes
abstract: Two more lawsuits contend that the now defunct art gallery, Knoedler & Co., sold collectors paintings that were fake.
lead_paragraph: The lawsuits keep coming.

abstract: Grocery store prices for pecans are up by 30 percent, which is causing Thanksgiving bakers to think twice about their menus.

headline: In Search of the Perfect Holiday Drink
abstract: Behind-the-bar pros give tips for selecting must-have spirits to entertain guests and making well-balanced cocktails.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re expecting a handful of holiday drop-ins or hosting a spirited party, a well-made cocktail can set the tone. As restaurants around the county are raising their mixology standards, consider enhancing your home efforts with this advice from behind-the-bar pros.

headline: Small Business Health Exchanges Delayed Again
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The SHOP exchanges had been of most interest to a limited segment of the small-business market — those seeking tax credits.
lead_paragraph: With little more than a month before the new year — and many small businesses under pressure to make a decision about health insurance plans for 2014 — the Obama administration on Wednesday announced that the federally run small-business health insurance exchanges will not accept online enrollments for another year, until November 2014. It also announced that in the meantime, small businesses can enroll in exchange-listed plans through an insurance agent or broker, or directly with the carrier.

headline: Wines for Dessert, or Just for Fun
abstract: From tropical to spicy, dessert wines are a charming feature of Long Island vintners’ portfolios.
lead_paragraph: Dessert wines, which accompany all sorts of final dinner courses and sometimes serve as such courses in themselves, are a charming feature of Long Island vintners’ portfolios.

abstract: Suzanne Cooke wanted a brownstone, but found a Prospect-Lefferts Gardens two-bedroom to call home.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Cooke bought a large and sunny one-bedroom in the Clinton Hill Co-ops in Brooklyn in 2000. She lived there happily while working in the television field.

headline: No Charges for Officers Who Killed Harlem Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Lawyers for Mohamed Bah’s family said police officers failed to follow protocol governing how they handle emotionally disturbed persons. The family has asked for a federal investigation.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury has decided not to bring charges against police officers involved in the fatal 2012 shooting of Mohamed Bah, a 27-year-old Guinean immigrant who apparently had a mental breakdown and lunged at officers with a knife, the Manhattan district attorney said on Wednesday.

keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Contracts']
abstract: The Navy said it had suspended a ship-supply company for significantly overcharging on a contract, the second such suspension since mid-September.
lead_paragraph: The Navy said Wednesday that it had suspended a ship-supply company for significantly overcharging on a contract, the second such suspension since mid-September.

abstract: Bargains on clocks, pillows, plates and home accessories.
lead_paragraph: Alessi will discount some items by 50 percent on Saturday only (The 24h Sentence Maker clock, right, originally $167, will be about $83); 130 Greene Street (Prince Street), 212-941-7300, and 30 East 60th Street, 212-317-9880, alessi.com.

abstract: A list of abbreviated schedules and closings in observance of the holiday.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: With an Eye for the Artisanal
abstract: LF8, a shop that sells the work of artists, makers and Buddhist monks, opens in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: A week ago Monday, Khen Rinpoche, a Tibetan Buddhist monk, blessed Lisa Fox’s new store, LF8, in the East Village. Ms. Fox promotes artisans and designers like Natalie Chanin, whose handmade garments and home goods are sold under the Alabama Chanin label.

headline: Dreamscapes Are Made of These
abstract: Kristin Victoria Barron’s Orchis collection of decorative objects owes something to her Jungian analyst.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve always had very vivid dreams, dating back to childhood,” said Kristin Victoria Barron, an interior and product designer. “I started seeing a Jungian analyst in college because these dreams would stay with me in my waking life.”

headline: Crackdown in Egypt Fuels New Dissent
abstract: There were street protests in Egypt’s two largest cites on Wednesday, amid signs that attempts by the military-backed government to stifle dissent were fueling a backlash.
lead_paragraph: There were street protests in Egypt’s two largest cites on Wednesday, amid signs that attempts by the military-backed government to stifle dissent were fueling a backlash.

headline: Chandeliers That Like a Little Primping
abstract: Raw Collection chandeliers can be hung as they are or embellished with ornaments from a kit.
lead_paragraph: Your chandelier need not be a permanent fixture, but can swing with the times. Michael McHale, a lighting designer, has created the Raw Collection, chandeliers whose looks can be easily transformed. The lights are made of black steel pipes covered with a grid of galvanized steel cable. They can be displayed in their naked form, but they are really meant as platforms for adornment. Festoon them with your own decorations, or buy kits from Mr. McHale. Two are available, with the promise of more to follow: an arrangement of plants ($940) by Matthew David, a floral designer, and a concoction of colorful Plexiglas ($680), below, by an East Village resident known as Billy the Artist. Neither version requires tools to install. The chandeliers will be introduced next week at Design Miami. The fixture is $980; 347-688-0070 or michaelmchaledesigns.com.

headline: Well-Appointed Kitchens Have Wish Lists, Too
abstract: The design experts Charlotte and Peter Fiell publish a sourcebook of the world’s best kitchen items.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte and Peter Fiell, a couple who have written many books about international design, are now giving advice about what to buy. They recently published “Essential Equipment for the Kitchen: A Sourcebook of the World’s Best Designs” (Goodman Fiell, about $30).

headline: Inspector Who Pepper-Sprayed Protesters Is Ordered to Appear Before Panel
abstract: The decision involving Deputy Inspector Anthony Bologna represents a significant victory for the investigative powers of the Civilian Complaint Review Board.
lead_paragraph: The police commander whose pepper spraying of several women sparked sharp criticism of the New York Police Department’s response to the Occupy Wall Street protests has been ordered to appear before investigators and account for his actions, a state judge has ruled.

headline: A Talking Mailbox That Growls
abstract: Gauri Nanda, the designer of Clocky, on her latest invention: a toy that sends and receives messages.
lead_paragraph: The product designer Gauri Nanda, 34, is best known for waking up adults, and now she is giving children their first phones. In 2006, fresh out of M.I.T. graduate school, she introduced Clocky, a wheeled alarm clock that noisily runs away if no one turns it off. More than 600,000 Clockys and their spherical cousins, Tockys, have been sold through her company, Nanda Home. Her latest idea, Toymail, is a line of plastic miniature mailboxes with animal faces. They play messages sent from phones, and children can send recorded replies by pressing simple arrow buttons. Ms. Nanda spoke at her all-white Brooklyn apartment about how she and her co-developer, Audry Hill, finalized the creatures (expected to sell for $55, plus a minimal charge per message) and how young testers for Toymail Co. are reacting. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: How Do I Tackle Clutter?
abstract: Advice on repairing or redecorating a home before selling.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have a small bathroom and end up storing my toiletries on the edge of the tub. How do I tackle the clutter?

headline: Gifts With a Twist of Nostalgia
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Christmas', 'Gifts']
abstract: Riffing on quaint forms and technologies is the key to some of the year’s best design.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, Hans Harald Rath of the Austrian company J. & L. Lobmeyr traveled to New York to present his design for chandeliers for the Metropolitan Opera House at the new Lincoln Center. The building’s architect, Wallace K. Harrison, rejected the proposal outright.

headline: The Masculine Mystique
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Daniel Friedman, 34, who owns Bindle and Keep in Brooklyn, finds his niche in the fashion industry by giving female and transgender clients a masculine look, one that fits their bodies.
lead_paragraph: Breakthrough ideas often come from the least expected sources.

headline: Vonn Hit a Tricky Turn, Coach Says
abstract: Lindsey Vonn injured her right knee again while training this month when she hit a compression turn made more difficult by a shadow that obscured the curve at Copper Mountain, Colo.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — As Lindsey Vonn’s teammates trained on the downhill course on Wednesday, new details emerged about the crash that reinjured her right knee on Nov. 19 at Copper Mountain, Colo.

headline: Arik Einstein, 74, Beloved Israeli Singer, Dies
abstract: Mr. Einstein’s blend of folk and rock helped shape a new Hebrew popular culture and his ballads became modern Israeli anthems.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Arik Einstein, an Israeli singer and songwriter whose blend of folk and rock helped shape a new Hebrew popular culture and whose ballads became modern Israeli anthems, died on Nov. 26 in Tel Aviv. He was 74.

abstract: Millions are being spent on stopping the stink bug’s rampage.
lead_paragraph: Millions are being spent on stopping the stink bug’s rampage.

headline: Wanted Dead or Alive (No, Just Dead)
abstract: Stink bugs, a scourge of crops, are on the run from a growing number of predators.
lead_paragraph: This Thanksgiving, I’ll be thanking the bugs, not the turkeys, for sustaining me in the wilderness. In my case, the wilderness was of the stink-bug variety.

headline: A Rustic Haven for a Life Remade
abstract: Putting privilege and addiction behind her, a former debutante comes out and comes home.
lead_paragraph: Most days, Alison Aldrich walks from her co-op in the West Village to the stately old building on Washington Square Park where she works as a professor at New York University. There, each year, she helps train a few hundred new social workers, many of whom will fan out into the city she has adored since moving here as a 19-year-old newlywed in 1965.
