headline: The East China Sea Islands Dispute
abstract: Readers focus on reasons to ease military tensions over disputed islands in the East China Sea.

headline: Christie Is Said to Waffle on In-State Tuition for People Living in U.S. Illegally
abstract: There are accusations that Gov. Chris Christie has shifted positions since his re-election, before which he made the Latino vote a priority and advocated for tuition equality.
lead_paragraph: During his re-election campaign this year, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey made the Latino vote a priority, hiring a full-time director for Hispanic outreach, opening bilingual campaign offices and securing key Latino endorsements.

headline: 3 States End Resistance to Spousal Benefits Order
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Texas, Oklahoma and West Virginia are now complying with an order requiring state National Guard units to process federal marriage benefits for same-sex spouses of guardsmen.
lead_paragraph: Texas, Oklahoma and West Virginia are now complying with an order from Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel requiring state National Guard units to process federal marriage benefits for same-sex spouses of guardsmen, according to the Department of Defense. Mr. Hagel issued the order — which also extended benefits to same-sex spouses of military service members — after the Supreme Court struck down a law this summer that had prevented federal recognition of same-sex marriages. At one point, nine states had objected to Mr. Hagel’s order, citing conflicts with state laws that do not recognize gay marriages. As a result, same-sex National Guard spouses in those states could sign up for benefits only by traveling to a federal military installation. As of Wednesday, only Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana were still defying Mr. Hagel’s order, said a spokesman for the National Guard Bureau in Washington.

headline: A Local Bakery That Draws From Afar
abstract: La Tropezienne in East Harlem offers traditional French baked goods, and its sandwiches are particularly popular with West African cabbies.
lead_paragraph: La Tropezienne in East Harlem offers traditional French baked goods, and its sandwiches are particularly popular with West African cabbies.

headline: Retirement Secured for Chimpanzees
abstract: President Obama signed a bill removing a cap on spending for federally owned chimpanzees in sanctuaries. The change does not involve any budget increase.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good Thanksgiving for about 300 research chimpanzees headed for retirement. President Obama signed a bill on Wednesday removing a cap on spending for federally owned chimpanzees in sanctuaries. The change does not involve any budget increase. But it allows the National Institutes of Health to spend money to support the chimps in retirement that would have been used to support them in research labs. The institutes announced in June that the 300 would be retired, leaving only about 50 for potential future research needs.

headline: Official Quits in Backlash Over Colorado Gun Vote
abstract: A backlash against Colorado’s new gun-control laws claimed its third political casualty on Wednesday, as Senator Evie Hudak, a Democrat, resigned to protect her party’s majority.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A populist backlash against Colorado’s new gun-control laws claimed its third political casualty on Wednesday as a Democratic state senator resigned her seat rather than face a recall vote that could have cost her party control of the chamber.

headline: French Flavor by the East River
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: After more than 20 years, La Tropezienne continues to pack in customers, many of them immigrant cabbies who appreciate the buttered baguettes they remember from West Africa.
lead_paragraph: The customers at La Tropezienne packed in tightly near the counter on a recent Sunday morning, bundled in coats and gently shouting over one another. Babacar Mbaye, 40, gave an assertive “Hello!” in order to be noticed. Originally from Gambia, he said he drove his cab to this little bakery and patisserie in East Harlem mainly for the coffee (but also for three croissants: two chocolate, one cinnamon).

headline: Illinois Lawmakers Say They Have Plan to Fix Underfunded Pension System
abstract: One of the most troubled public systems in the nation has jeopardized the state’s financial stability and has become a political risk for its leaders.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Leaders of the Illinois legislature on Wednesday announced that they had found, at long last, a way to repair the state’s deeply troubled pension system, which has been deemed among the most underfunded public systems in the nation, has jeopardized the state’s financial stability and has become a political risk for state leaders.

headline: For Fervent Fans of the Dutch Masters, ‘It’s a Dream Come True’
abstract: During a tantalizing and temporary convergence, nearly 40 percent of all known Vermeers are on view on the Eastern Seaboard, resulting in an influx of Dutch art lovers.
lead_paragraph: Shin-Ichi Fukuoka, a molecular biologist from Tokyo, really — really — loves Johannes Vermeer. He has traveled around the world to visit 34 of the 36 paintings known or believed to be Vermeers.

headline: Thursday’s N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: Green Bay and Detroit are playing for a division title or bust: Packers (5-5-1) at Lions (6-5).
lead_paragraph: Packers (5-5-1) at Lions (6-5)

headline: Democrats in Alaska Praise Palin
abstract: Democratic lawmakers remember Gov. Sarah Palin’s oil-profits taxes and oppose efforts by the Republican-controlled legislature to repeal her tax package.
lead_paragraph: Democratic lawmakers remember Gov. Sarah Palin’s oil-profits taxes and oppose efforts by the Republican-controlled legislature to repeal her tax package.

headline: Not for Prime Time: Music Video With Iran’s President
abstract: A music video honoring President Hassan Rouhani includes features banned on state TV.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — It might not make MTV, but a music video surfaced Wednesday honoring Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, and showing him alongside musical instruments — which are banned on state television — and women singing.

headline: Analyst Says SAC Trader Sought ‘Edgy’ Information
abstract: Jon Horvath, the federal government’s star witness in an insider trading case, said his former boss, Michael S. Steinberg, wanted him to cross a legal line.
lead_paragraph: Jon Horvath needed to step up his game at SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Persistence in the Genes: Connecting the Dots to the Mayflower
abstract: A New York organization has rigorous rules for applicants to be recognized as a descendant of one of the 102 settlers who made the voyage in 1620 to Plymouth, Mass.
lead_paragraph: A well-worn potato masher was a tantalizing clue.

headline: The Magic of Witch Hazel
abstract: Witch hazel, better known as a bottled astringent than a native shrub, likes to grow in damp woodlands and propels its seeds for yards.
lead_paragraph: There is something compelling about a plant flowering in autumn’s frosty grip, but our native witch hazel’s magic only begins there. Witch hazel (Hamamelis virginiana) is far better known as a bottled astringent than a native shrub. Its medicinal uses date back to the Native Americans, who taught Europeans how to identify the plant and decoct its leaves and stems into the now-familiar tonic.

headline: Moore, Rookie Giants Pass Rusher, Finds It Hard to Break Through
abstract: Damontre Moore, the Giants’ third pick in this year’s draft, seems to match a glaring need: the team’s sack totals are in decline. But Moore is still waiting for a chance to make a difference.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants took defensive end Damontre Moore with their third pick in this year’s N.F.L. draft, General Manager Jerry Reese defined Moore’s worth in three words: “He is sacks.”

headline: Alaska Democrats See a Palin Legacy They Can Like
abstract: Efforts to repeal a new, more lenient tax law on oil profits in Alaska are stirring up a strange political cocktail, in which Democrats find themselves backing Sarah Palin.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — For many Alaskans, Sarah Palin is a figure in the rearview mirror, the memories of her time as governor obscured and distorted by the national spotlight she stepped into as Republican vice-presidential candidate, pundit and Tea Party darling. And often as not the memories come with a grumble anyway, since her shooting-star career mostly took off after leaving the state.

headline: The Seeming Resurrection of Comet ISON
abstract: After 4.5 billion years in the farthest reaches of the solar system, Comet ISON may provide clues on how the bits of dust and ice came together to form planets.
lead_paragraph: Updated 5:39p.m., Nov. 29 | After astronomers initially believed Comet ISON had melted away following its close encounter with the sun on Thursday, they had second thoughts on Friday, as we report here.

headline: Here’s to the Better Angels of the Sports World
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Football (College)', 'Marathon Running', 'Horse Racing', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Football', 'Golf', 'British Open (Golf)', 'Sports Injuries', 'Baseball', 'Skiing', 'Swimming', "AMERICA'S CUP", 'Boats and Boating', 'Wrestling', 'Olympic Games (2016)', 'Automobile Racing']
abstract: Giving thanks to those who are deserving, including football players who boycotted a game, a wheelchair racer and all who campaigned to restore wrestling as a medal sport in the Summer Olympics.
lead_paragraph: In a sports year often interrupted by sorrow and scandal, more than ever some deserve a Thanksgiving Day thank-you:

headline: Deadly Accident at Stadium Raises Worry on Brazil’s World Cup Aims
abstract: A construction crane collapse at the site of the São Paulo stadium where the 2014 World Cup is scheduled to open puts a spotlight on increasing tensions among Brazilians about cost overruns, delays and the country’s priorities.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — At least two workers were killed on Wednesday when a construction crane collapsed at the stadium in São Paulo where Brazil plans to hold the opening game of next year’s World Cup, raising concerns over the country’s ability to finish an array of lavish arenas that have been plagued by delays and cost overruns.

headline: A Part of Utah Built on Coal Wonders What Comes Next
keywords: ['Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The Carbon Power Plant, the state’s oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of stricter new federal pollution regulations.
lead_paragraph: PRICE, Utah — For generations, coal has been the lifeblood of this mineral-rich stretch of eastern Utah. Mining families proudly recall all the years they toiled underground. Supply companies line the town streets. Above the road that winds toward the mines, a soot-smudged miner peers out from a billboard with the slogan “Coal = Jobs.”

headline: When the First Hurdle Is Remembering
abstract: After a grand mal seizure in March, Nikkiya Simmonds lost all her memories of the last two years, including the birth of her daughter.
lead_paragraph: Her memory ravaged by damage done to her brain, Nikkiya Simmonds, 32, returned to an apartment that might as well have belonged to a stranger. It was a cozy dwelling, strewn with cute knickknacks and calming artwork that she was tickled to learn that she had chosen, that she was, indeed, home.

headline: Where Is the Love?
abstract: It’s easy to scorn the poor from a position of privilege. But, on Thanksgiving, maybe we need a conversation about empathy for fellow humans in distress.
lead_paragraph: When I’ve written recently about food stamp recipients, the uninsured and prison inmates, I’ve had plenty of pushback from readers.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 27, 2013
abstract: Winning numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Secret Weapon in Mall Battle: Parking Apps
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Parking', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Parking Garages and Lots']
abstract: Smartphone apps are one way malls and shopping districts are trying to make parking easier to lure customers away from their computers and back into the realm of brick-and-mortar stores.
lead_paragraph: Phoebe Scott of Orange County, Calif., has a new routine before heading to the mall.

headline: Giving Thanks
abstract: I fear that far too many people have no familiarity — or even empathy — with what it means to be poor.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday morning, I got a call about a girl — now a woman — whom I had gone to grade school with. She was gravely ill. Cancer. It had spread to her brain, I was told. From where, it wasn’t clear. She was on life support. By early afternoon her childhood friend and next-door neighbor had posted on Facebook:

headline: The Hard Charger at Obama’s Side Has His Hands Full
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Denis McDonough finds himself fixing the health care debacle he did not see coming, preparing for the next spending showdown with Congress and trying to rescue an imperiled presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Denis McDonough was pacing the path on the South Lawn of the White House one day this fall, ruminating on the challenges of a second term for his boss, President Obama. Mr. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, likes to stroll outside from time to time. It helps clear his head when he has a lot on his mind.

headline: Doesn’t Eat, Doesn’t Pray and Doesn’t Love
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Corporations', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The question of whether companies can claim a religious identity is really about sex and has opened a new front in the culture wars.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether for-profit companies can claim a religious identity, one that exempts them from obeying a generally applicable law, is fully worthy of the attention the Supreme Court is about to give it. But to the extent that much of the commentary about the challenges to the Affordable Care Act’s contraception-coverage insurance mandate frames the issue as a debate about the rights of corporations – as a next step beyond Citizens United’s expansion of corporate free speech – I think it misses the point. What really makes these cases so rich, and the reason the court’s intervention will dramatically raise the temperature of the current term, lies elsewhere.

headline: After Football Player’s Death, California School Team Wavers, but Carries On
abstract: At Arlington High School in Riverside, players and coaches felt the loss of a popular player, who died just days after collapsing from a head injury, as they persevered through an up-and-down season.
lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — When DeAndre Thornton stretched every bit of his angular 6-foot-5 frame to catch a pass over the middle of the field, he could not immediately pull the ball down to protect himself. And so, when the hit arrived, with all the fury a 205-pound opponent with a running start could muster, the crunch of shoulder pads and helmets reverberated beyond the sidelines.

headline: Survivors Describe Fights and Fear After Haitian Migrants’ Boat Ran Aground
abstract: An odyssey that began without enough rations and ended in a frenzy is the latest in a spate of deadly crossings by Haitians.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Haitians piled onto the rickety vessel with visions of a new life in the United States. But five days into the voyage, the overloaded sailboat packed with 150 people ran aground and quickly broke apart. At least 30 people died in the frigid seas.

headline: China’s Move Puts Airspace in Spotlight
keywords: ['AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Who has the right to fly where is an issue that has created confusion, and danger, in places affected by territorial disputes.
lead_paragraph: China’s proclamation of a new “air defense identification zone,” an obscure aviation term that became the catalyst for escalating military tensions with Japan and the United States this week, has thrown a broader spotlight on the control of international airspace, an issue that has created confusion, and danger, in other places affected by territorial disputes.

headline: End of an Era in Coal Country, Utah
abstract: The Carbon Power Plant, the state’s oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of new stricter federal pollution regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Carbon Power Plant, the state’s oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of new stricter federal pollution regulations.

headline: Loving Families, Lousy Meals
abstract: Cooking and culinary bias in the Lipman home. Salmon with vinegar, anyone?
lead_paragraph: THANKSGIVING 2013 falls on my mother’s birthday, so I’ll begin by swearing that she was an excellent, ambitious cook who made her own blintzes, challah, marmalade and fudge. Her cakes were baked from scratch, and she had a repertory of five different custards (plain, rice, coconut, bread and Grape-Nut).

headline: Grief, Team Spirit and High School Football
abstract: The season has been one of raw emotions for Arlington High School in Riverside, Calif., after a football player, Tyler Lewellen, 16, sustained a head injury and later died.
lead_paragraph: The season has been one of raw emotions for Arlington High School in Riverside, Calif., after a football player, Tyler Lewellen, 16, sustained a head injury and later died.

headline: Silencing Dissent in Egypt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Injustices of the Mubarak era are being repeated, and the Obama administration has struggled to find an effective policy response.
lead_paragraph: The military-backed government that has ruled Egypt for the past five months is looking increasingly like the old dictatorship of Hosni Mubarak without Mr. Mubarak. In the name of crushing all resistance by the Muslim Brotherhood supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the democratically elected president ousted by the military in July, Egyptian authorities have now moved to ban most public protests and threaten those who take part in them with jail or heavy fines.

headline: More Money to Treat AIDS Abroad
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Doubling the number of people who get antiviral treatments by the end of 2016 would slow the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: At a time when partisan bickering has crippled Congress, it is encouraging to find agreement on the important issue of curbing the global AIDS epidemic.

headline: The Perils of Polystyrene
keywords: ['Foam', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Editorials']
abstract: New York City officials should make a ban on foam containers and loose packaging happen as soon as possible.
lead_paragraph: Every year New York City residents throw away about 20,000 tons of plastic foam containers or, worse, the peanut-shaped packaging filler that sticks to anything in its path. Polystyrene foam is a plague on the environment. It is brittle. It breaks into pieces — sometimes very tiny pieces — that are devilishly hard to pick up. And there is no easy or cheap way to recycle it. New York City officials are considering a ban on foam containers and loose packaging. They should make it happen as soon as possible. Earlier this year the City Council speaker, Christine Quinn, made a pointed case for banning the substance. “It lives forever,” she said. “It’s worse than cockroaches.”

headline: Room at the Table
abstract: Even though we rarely ask outright “what are you thankful for?” on Thanksgiving anymore, the question hovers over the holiday, awaiting an answer.
lead_paragraph: There may be a stranger at dinner today — the friend of a friend, the brother of a daughter’s roommate, a business acquaintance stuck in town, someone who reminds us how expandable this close-knit holiday really is. And there will surely be someone missing for whom we keep a place set in our thoughts. On Thanksgiving Day, we sit down with the memory of everyone who has shared this holiday with us, and perhaps with an unexpected stranger, the person who helps us tell this one Thanksgiving apart from all the others.

headline: During Lions Games, Giving Thanks While Gnashing Teeth
abstract: In Detroit, the tradition of football on Thanksgiving is deeply personal. The Lions have hosted the holiday games since 1934. But for the past decade, a new tradition has taken root: losing.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — On Thanksgiving Day, Darin Idyle will be tailgating in a church parking lot, as he has every Thanksgiving for about a decade. Tim Harry will be bonding in Ford Field’s stands with his teenage son. And M. G. Shapiro’s family knows that his overtime rule is in effect once again — a tie score means he will be late for Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Tony Musante, Actor Known for Role in ‘Toma,’ Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Musante acted on stage and in many films in the United States and Europe, working with Gene Hackman, Meryl Streep and George C. Scott.
lead_paragraph: Tony Musante, a rugged-looking American actor who was seen on television, in films and on stage in the United States and Europe for over 50 years but who was probably best known for a TV series he left after one season, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Cult Classic
abstract: A debut by Loren Muse Smith and the return of the nefarious Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle by Loren Muse Smith (who is making her New York Times debut today) and Jeff Chen is very clever. Even if you’re easily “squicked” out by SNAKES, you’re going to like this one. And there are two different ways to look at this answer, as it turns out. I’ll talk about how my noncaffeinated brain looked at it first.

headline: Mystery of Missing Mushrooms Leaves French Blaming Roma
abstract: Competition between established French companies and outside mushroom pickers has brought with it darker undercurrents of hostility and discrimination.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Guy Sant is distressed about the sorry state of his mushroom business this year. Usually in the autumn, when the weather turns brisk and the leaves begin to fall, his pickers gather 60 tons of wild fungi to satisfy European consumers, he said. This fall, they found only 16 tons. “I lost so much this year, I may have to close,” he said bleakly.

headline: Late to the Parade
abstract: Late to the parade.
lead_paragraph: Late to the parade.

headline: Savoring a Steak
abstract: From pondering just ordering Chinese to a delicious London broil served on wedding China.
lead_paragraph: CHRISTINE and I had been friends in high school — but only friends. Voted “Loveliest Lady” at the Coronation Ball, the signature social event of the Class of 1968, she was clearly out of my league. Plus, she already had a boyfriend. Tom was a suave older man of 21 who had graduated to that “real world” for which we high schoolers were being prepared via the manipulation of our slide rules, the firing up of our Bunsen burners, and our allemande-lefting and do-si-do-ing during the square dancing unit in gym. Two years later, Christine was Tom’s bride. I was a guest at their wedding.

headline: Egypt: 14 Female Protesters Receive 11-Year Sentences
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In addition, seven girls ranging from 15 to 17 years old were also sentenced to an indeterminate term at a juvenile facility for joining the protest.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Alexandria on Wednesday sentenced 14 women who participated in an Islamist protest last month to 11 years in prison, the state news media reported. In addition, seven girls ranging from 15 to 17 years old were also sentenced to an indeterminate term at a juvenile facility for joining the protest. The sentences, after an uncommonly swift trial, highlighted the severity of the military-led government’s crackdown on Islamists since the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi in July. Also on Wednesday, prosecutors ordered the arrests of two of the best known liberal activists in the country, Ahmed Maher and Alaa Abdel Fattah, for organizing what was called an unauthorized protest.

headline: The New Pope's New Direction
abstract: What does Pope Francis’s exhortation tell us about his priorities and plans? What obstacles will he face?

headline: Even After a Fortuitous Spill, the Nets See an Opportunity Slip Away
abstract: Trailing by 27, the Nets rallied behind the little-used reserve Mirza Teletovic, but even a well-timed mishap could not save them from defeat.
lead_paragraph: The tumbling Nets lost again, but this time, at least, the defeat came through bizarrely entertaining means.

headline: Bill Foulkes Dies at 81; Soccer Star Survived Team’s Plane Crash
abstract: Sustaining only minor injuries in the crash in Munich in February 1958 that killed eight starting players, the rugged defender went on to help Manchester United rebuild.
lead_paragraph: The date Feb. 6, 1958, has long haunted the British consciousness. It was then that a plane carrying the Manchester United soccer team crashed while taking off from the Munich airport, killing 23 of 44 passengers, including eight starting players.

headline: Behind the Chinese-Pakistani Nuclear Deal
abstract: A deal in which China will help build nuclear plants in Karachi should help ease Pakistan’s chronic power supply problems, but it has also raised alarms about nuclear security.
lead_paragraph: The prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, announced this week that China would help build two nuclear power reactors in Karachi, a port city with chronic electricity shortages. The deal marks a big step in nuclear energy cooperation between China and Pakistan, but financing and other important parts of the project have yet to be settled. Here is an explanation:

headline: The Hague: Eased Rules May Affect Trials of 2 Kenyans
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto, have pleaded not guilty to charges that they were responsible for deadly violence after the 2007 elections.
lead_paragraph: Member states of the International Criminal Court eased the trial rules on Wednesday in ways that could enable Kenya’s two top leaders, facing prosecution on charges that include crimes against humanity, to avoid personal appearances and even miss parts of the proceedings against them, news agencies reported. The changes, which apply to suspects who hold high office, had been strongly advocated by Kenya and other African members that have criticized what they call the court’s unfair focus on prosecuting African political figures. President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto, have pleaded not guilty to charges that they were responsible for deadly violence after the 2007 elections. They have also asserted that the trials interfere with their ability to govern Kenya. Mr. Ruto’s trial has begun, and Mr. Kenyatta’s is scheduled to begin in February.

headline: Victorian Style Makes a Comeback
abstract: Nineteenth-century wardrobe staples are enjoying a streamlined, contemporary renaissance.
lead_paragraph: The Victorian aesthetic — high collars, leg-o-mutton sleeves, pearl trim — is having a renaissance. In the modern interpretation, minimalism is key and military references abound. Metallics are often paired with black so that they pop — as in the oversize brass buttons on a slim Balmain topcoat; the gold hardware on a simple Dolce & Gabbana bag and a Givenchy belt; and the trim around a dainty Phoebe Coleman lacquered pinkie ring. The ornate decoration of a simple Erdem skirt and round Monica Rich Kosann earrings are the essence of restrained elegance. Lace-up booties by Tabitha Simmons and a crown-shaped pendant necklace by Katie Mullally offer especially Anglophilic takes on the trend.

headline: 4 Hit and Killed by Cars in New York City
abstract: The police said they were investigating the deaths, including those of two women who were struck by a single vehicle as they crossed a street on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Four people were hit by cars and killed across the city on Wednesday, including two women who were hit by a single vehicle while crossing the street on Staten Island, the police said. The circumstances of each of the crashes were still under investigation as of midnight on Thursday. No one was immediately charged with a crime.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 A.M. (NBC) MACY’S THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE Matt Lauer, Al Roker and Savannah Guthrie host this 87th installment of the parade, with appearances by the Big Apple Circus; Kristin Chenoweth; the Cherokee National Youth Choir; Cirque du Soleil, Gavin DeGraw; Brett Eldredge; Fall Out Boy; Jimmy Fallon; Kellie Pickler; the Roots with the cast of “Sesame Street”; Florida Georgia Line; Megan Hilty; Joan Jett and the Blackhearts; Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings; Miss America 2014, Nina Davuluri; the retired N.F.L. players Bart Oates, Amani Toomer and Hines Ward; the retired N.H.L. players Cam Neely and Mike Richter; the Robertson family from “Duck Dynasty”; and the Radio City Rockettes. The casts of the Broadway shows “Matilda” and “Motown: The Musical” perform. So does Carrie Underwood, in her role as Maria in “The Sound of Music Live!,” next Thursday on NBC. Soaring above it all, weather permitting: Spider-Man; a 47-foot-tall balloon featuring portraits of characters from “The Wizard of Oz” and carrying the Wizard himself, in anticipation of the film’s 75th anniversary next year; Snoopy and Woodstock, in a 40th-anniversary tribute to “A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving”; and a spinning dreidel to celebrate Hanukkah.

headline: A Second Career as a Pastor, Schooled by the Homeless
keywords: ['Ministers (Protestant)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Careers and Professions', 'Baby Boomers', 'Homeless Persons', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'News and News Media']
abstract: I became the pastor to a nondenominational mission church to the homeless, and I quickly found out that if God had a vision for the place, I wasn’t privy to it.
lead_paragraph: The airplane that crashed had been heading to Greenville, S.C., where I was a reporter.

headline: The Art of the Carve
abstract: A butcher demonstrates how to carve a turkey.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, The Times asked Ray Venezia, a butcher and then the head of the meat department at Fairway Market, to demonstrate how to carve a Thanksgiving turkey.

headline: Yao Ming on Third Year as a College Student
abstract: Yao Ming is less than two years away from fulfilling his promise to his parents that he would go to college, a common but seldom realized dream for Chinese athletes.
lead_paragraph: On class days, Yao Ming, the 7-foot-6 retired N.B.A. center, wakes up at the crack of dawn to beat the Shanghai traffic. Carrying a lunch prepared by his wife, Ye Li, a 6-foot-3 former player in China’s professional league, Mr. Yao drives more than an hour to Jiao Tong University, where he sits through his required courses in the economics and management department. According to one Chinese news report, Mr. Yao would prefer to live in the dorms with his 20-year-old classmates, a move that would save time and energy, “but the beds are too small.”

headline: Managing Editor of Newsmagazine Resigns Amid Sexual Assault Controversy
abstract: In her resignation letter, Shoma Chaudhury defended her handling of a complaint by a staffer who had accused the editor in chief of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The managing editor of the newsmagazine Tehelka, whose editor in chief has been charged in the sexual assault of a junior reporter, resigned Thursday morning in an email to the staff, citing the growing controversy over her handling of the initial complaint.

headline: Corrections: November 28, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 28, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: No Solutions in Sight, Knicks Lose Seventh Straight
abstract: A hamstring injury that sidelined the Clippers’ Chris Paul in the second half gave the Knicks a chance, but they squandered it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — J. R. Smith flew across the lane, the back of his untucked jersey flapping behind him. He was determined to do something Wednesday night to salvage the Knicks’ fourth-quarter hopes, and it came in the form of a flat-footed lob that the Clippers’ DeAndre Jordan batted away as soon as it left Smith’s hand.

headline: Happy Thanksgiving
abstract: Happy Thanksgiving, and don’t forget that our 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest ends on Dec. 3.
lead_paragraph: We’re taking a brief break, until Monday, but we leave you with some reminders from Kid President, as well as a few ideas of our own:

headline: Protest This!
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Every new anti-protest law in Egypt sparks more demonstrations — and more police violence.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — On Monday evening, Mohammed Adel, of the April 6 Youth Movement, and Ali Esam, of the liberal Constitution Party, headed to the Kasr El Nil police station, a pink stucco villa on a leafy side street in central Cairo. They came bearing an official request to hold a protest … against a protest law promulgated just the day before.

headline: Corruption Scandal Hits One of China’s Top Universities
abstract: A top administrator at a prestigious Chinese university in Beijing was accused of trying to flee the country after he came under investigation in a corruption case.
lead_paragraph: Renmin University of China, in Beijing, one of the leading centers of higher learning in the country, conferred its first degrees this year in a new graduate program in combating corruption. Future classes now have a case study close to home to draw from.

headline: The Quest to Belong
abstract: Opportunity is the bright star of the immigrant story. Its black sun is displacement and loss.
lead_paragraph: With a grandchild about to be born in Atlanta, another on the way in Ho Chi Minh City, I have been thinking about the beginning of the family odyssey; of my great-grandfather, Isaac Michel, and his decision to leave the shtetl in northern Lithuania and head south from Russian pogroms toward the sun, the ostrich feathers, the gold and the promise of South Africa.

headline: Thailand’s Premier Survives Vote as Protests Continue
abstract: The number of antigovernment protesters appeared to drop Thursday as Thailand’s prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra, urged that the demonstrations cease.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Ignoring Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra’s victory in a parliamentary no-confidence vote, protesters in Thailand continued their campaign to shut down government offices, cutting power on Thursday to Bangkok’s police headquarters.

headline: China Patrols Air Zone Over Disputed Islands
abstract: China sent fighter jets to patrol its newly declared air defense zone after Japan and South Korean military planes flew through it unhindered.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China sent fighter jets on the first patrols of its new air defense zone over disputed islands in the East China Sea on Thursday, the state news agency, Xinhua, said.

headline: Julia Mancuso Carves Her Path in Lindsey Vonn’s Shadow
abstract: Julia Mancuso, who has patched up her relationship with Lindsey Vonn, isn’t the superstar on the U.S. team, but she does rack up her fair share of medals.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Minutes after watching a helicopter pluck her injured teammate Lindsey Vonn from the super-G track at the Alpine world championships in Schladming, Austria, in February, Julia Mancuso raced down a foggy course to a third-place finish.

headline: Other Great Moments in Eating Fish Alone
abstract: Our film featuring Cate Blanchett recalled a poem by Billy Collins that ran in the magazine in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Of the 11 films featured in this week’s Movies Issue, my hands-down favorite is Cate Blanchett’s fantastic exchange with a plate of fish, directed by Janusz Kaminski. When I watched it with my spouse at home, it reminded him of a poem by Billy Collins.

headline: A Not-So-Festive Season
abstract: Year-end parties were lavish and held at five-star hotels last year, but with President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption drive in full force, state-owned enterprises and government agencies are scaling back.
lead_paragraph: When Zhang Xuyan accepted his cushy entry-level position at a major state-owned enterprise, the salary was not the main draw. Instead it was the unofficial benefits that lured him in: networking opportunities, close proximity to senior Communist Party members and, last but not least, the banquets and luxury gifts that the company regularly showered on its employees.

headline: How to Start a Year-Round Family Gratitude Ritual
abstract: Expressing gratitude need not be a once-a-year Thanksgiving ritual, and there are many ways to do it that children may enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Sometime this Thanksgiving or in the coming weeks, you and yours will probably share notes on the things for which you’re thankful.

headline: Ignore Karzai’s Arrogant Insults
abstract: The United States has too much invested in Afghanistan to be derailed now.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What is going on with President Hamid Karzai? The world’s only superpower, leading a coalition of some 50 nations, is willing to stay on in his country after a war that has already lasted a dozen years and cost the United States more than $600 billion and more than 2,000 fatalities — and yet the Afghan president keeps throwing up roadblocks.

headline: Andhra Pradesh Heaves Sigh of Relief as Cyclone Lehar Becomes Deep Depression
abstract: The storm is still expected to bring heavy rain that could add to the damage caused by two previous cyclones over the past eight weeks.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — Cyclone Lehar weakened to a deep depression over the Bay of Bengal on Thursday, to the relief of Andhra Pradesh disaster management officials, but the storm is still expected to bring heavy rain that could add to the damage caused by two previous cyclones over the past eight weeks.

headline: In Performance: David Harewood
abstract: The actor performs a scene as Oberon from Julie Taymor’s new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: In Julie Taymor’s new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” David Harewood plays Oberon, the king of fairies, who is quarreling with his wife, the fairy queen Titania. In this scene he talks with the fairy Puck about a plan to make Titania “full of hateful fantasies” by having Puck apply the juice of a magic flower to her eyes so she falls in love with the first thing she sees when she wakes up.

headline: Linking Genes to Diseases by Sifting Through Electronic Medical Records
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Medicine and Health', 'Research', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: In so-called phenome-wide association studies, scientists start with a gene variant and search thousands of medical conditions for a match.
lead_paragraph: The days of scrawled doctor’s notes are slowly coming to a close. In the United States, 93 percent of hospitals are now using at least some electronic medical records and 2.2 percent have given up paper records completely, according to the consulting firm HIMSS Analytics.

headline: Giving Musical Thanks on Thanksgiving
abstract: A soundtrack for Thanksgiving and giving thanks.
lead_paragraph: On Thanksgiving (and Hannukah), here’s a quick note — and song — of thanks to you for reading this blog, for attending to the issues and opportunities facing humanity as we come of age on a finite planet and, for those who comment here, trying to maintain a constructive approach.

headline: Balloons Fly Low, but Parade Delights
abstract: There were early concerns that the winds would exceed the city’s limit for flying balloons, so marshals for the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade ordered tethers kept short.
lead_paragraph: To the joy of children and the relief of parents endlessly checking the weather report and bracing for their little ones’ dashed hopes, New York officials gave the giant balloons the all-clear Thursday morning to fly in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: T HOLIDAY
abstract: Evening sandals merge comfort with festiveness, and add a wink of hauteur without the heel.
lead_paragraph: Evening sandals merge comfort with festiveness, and add a wink of hauteur without the heel.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Virginia Johnson Pouch
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: a purse accessory that doubles as an evening clutch.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: A Thanksgivukkah Song
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Now that “Thanksgivukkah” has been popping up to reflect holiday convergence, it’s time for its own song.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: UBS Consolidates, and Shifts Executives, in Effort to Shrink Its Investment Bank
abstract: The Swiss bank is combining its currency, interest rates and credit trading businesses into one unit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Swiss bank UBS is combining its currency, interest rates and credit trading businesses into one unit, according to a memo circulated at the bank earlier this month.

headline: Image of the Day: November 28
abstract: A cauliflower field in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Insert Homeless Headline Here
abstract: Some lawmakers support bans on food lines and loitering, because that’s easier than building affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: You can call this post: Don’t Let Them Eat Cake. Or, Let Them Eat Cake Somewhere Else. Or Hide the Cake Altogether.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Invited to Iranian Facility
abstract: The invitation to the International Atomic Energy Agency came days after Tehran struck a landmark nuclear deal with world powers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Days after Iran struck a landmark accord with world powers on its nuclear program, the International Atomic Energy Agency announced on Thursday that Tehran had invited its inspectors to visit a heavy-water production plant linked to the deal — the first tangible step since the agreement was concluded.

headline: Getting the Volcker Rule Done
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Further delay in codifying limits on risk-taking by big banks will only weaken, not enhance, the prospect of effective regulation, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: E.U. Eases Rules on Liquids on Planes
abstract: Starting next month, the European Union will begin lifting restrictions on liquids, aerosols and gels at airports, with the goal of completely eliminating the ban by January 2016.
lead_paragraph: The European Union will begin lifting restrictions on liquids, aerosols and gels at airports in its 28 member countries in phases, beginning in January, with the goal of completely eliminating the ban by January 2016. “What is happening in January is a small first step,” Dale Kidd, press officer for Transport at the European Commission in Brussels, said in a telephone interview.

headline: Europe vs. Amazon: Anger Rising
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In the United States, where unemployment remains stubbornly high, people are grateful that Amazon.com is hiring so many workers for its warehouses. In Europe, where the recession was worse, there is a different question: Are these jobs dehumanizing?
lead_paragraph: On its home territory, Amazon.com is routinely hailed as a jobs machine. Thanks to its warehouse building spree, it is hiring tens of thousands of workers, plus many more for the holidays. President Obama, speaking at the retailer’s Chattanooga, Tenn., warehouse in July, called Amazon “a great example of what’s possible.”

headline: A Scientist Predicts the Future
abstract: How will the ways we work, play and love change over the next 10 — or 30 — years?
lead_paragraph: When making predictions, I have two criteria: the laws of physics must be obeyed and prototypes must exist that demonstrate “proof of principle.” I’ve interviewed more than 300 of the world’s top scientists, and many allowed me into laboratories where they are inventing the future. Their accomplishments and dreams are eye-opening. From my conversations with them, here’s a glimpse of what to expect in the coming decades:

headline: In Our Pages: November 29
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1913: Rebels Destroy Ciudad Victoria

headline: Orange to Sell Dominican Telecom Business
abstract: Orange, the French telecom company, will sell its Dominican unit for $1.4 billion to Altice, a Luxembourg cable and broadband provider that is expanding its presence in the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The French telecommunications company Orange has reached an agreement to sell its Dominican Republic operations to the Luxembourg cable and broadband provider Altice for $1.4 billion.

headline: Once for Women Only, Georgian Court Looks to Men’s Teams to Raise Profile
abstract: Georgian Court, which this fall became a full-time coed institution, hopes the addition of men’s teams will expand awareness of the university beyond the campus gates.
lead_paragraph: LAKEWOOD, N.J. — Luka Zgonjanin arrived in the United States from Serbia in August, barely able to speak English. He had accepted a scholarship to play basketball at Georgian Court, a small liberal arts university on the outskirts of the Jersey Shore. A few months earlier, he had never heard of the college.

headline: 36 Hours in Shanghai
abstract: Experience the past, present and future in this Chinese city, sampling everything from museums to street food to dancing in the park along the way.
lead_paragraph: What takes most cities eons to build, Shanghai can do overnight. Consider this: Just a decade ago, the city had four metro lines; now there are a dozen. The Jin Mao Tower was the tallest building in the neon-streaked financial center of Pudong; it has since been surpassed by the Shanghai World Financial Center and the nearly completed Shanghai Tower, which will be the second-tallest building in the world (after Dubai’s Burj Khalifa) when it’s finished next year. Still, what fascinates about this city is how little seems to have changed in the maze of lanes that have (thus far) eluded the bulldozer in the Old City or the former foreign concessions. Here, residents haggle over freshly caught fish in tiny markets or doze in lawn chairs on summer afternoons, ignoring the pounding jackhammers. Shanghai is remaking itself to become a “City of the Future,” but what’s so alluring is how much old-world character remains.

headline: In Cyprus, a New Spirit Animates the Capital
abstract: Nicosia is experiencing a renaissance with more and more venues catering to the artistic set.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s last divided capital, Nicosia, Cyprus, is experiencing a renaissance with more and more venues catering to the artistic set. No longer wary of the demilitarized United Nations Buffer Zone that bisects the ancient walled city between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot sides, young Nicosians have reclaimed their old town. Emboldened by falling real estate prices, arty cafes, boutiques celebrating homegrown fashion and buzzy restaurants have opened among the Venetian fortifications and Byzantine churches on the Greek side. While beachgoers have long flocked to the coasts, the rebirth of the inland capital is evidence of a historic city in transition.

headline: Who Was Rick of Rick’s Place in Prospect Park?
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: A wooded area bears the name of a Prospect Park ranger from the 1980s, but his birth name was not Rick.
lead_paragraph: Q. On a hill near the Midwood in Prospect Park, an old sign says “Rick’s Place,” without any elaboration. I am a Rick, but not that Rick. Who was the Rick of Rick’s Place, and why is this place named after him?

headline: On Beauty | A London Spa That Is One With Nature
abstract: With saunas, a pool and a specialty food bar, the soon-to-open Akasha Holistic Wellbeing Centre at London’s Cafe Royal hotel is seriously in sync with the elements.
lead_paragraph: Each of the four areas of the David Chipperfield-designed Akasha Holistic Wellbeing Centre, opening on Dec. 9 in London’s Café Royal hotel — a favorite among the likes of Miuccia Prada and L’Wren Scott — corresponds to a natural element: water (Watsu pool), fire (Canadian hemlock saunas), air (personalized yoga) and earth (a food bar that serves Champagne).

headline: Fighting ‘Rooster’ Returns to Ensemble Studio Theater
abstract: “The Year of the Rooster,” the critically lauded play, will come back to the Ensemble Studio Theater in January.
lead_paragraph: Odysseus Rex the Rooster is back. “The Year of the Rooster,” the critically lauded play about cockfighting by the 25-year-old playwright Eric Dufault, featuring Bobby Moreno as the central gladiatorial bird, will return to the Ensemble Studio Theater for a four-week run, Jan. 9 through Feb. 2, after a run this fall that Neil Genzlinger writing in The Times called “astonishingly entertaining.”

headline: The World in a Toothpick
abstract: Steven J. Backman of the Bronx fashions intricate scale models of things like the Eiffel Tower from a single toothpick.
lead_paragraph: Impatience is anathema to a toothpick artist, and Steven J. Backman was inoculated against it in second grade when he smashed one of his figures, a molecular model, in frustration, impaling his hand.

headline: Medicaid Growth Could Aggravate Doctor Shortage
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors']
abstract: Under the new health care law, a wave of additional Americans will soon be covered by Medicaid, a program that has struggled with a shortage of doctors willing to accept its low reimbursement rates and red tape.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Dr. Ted Mazer is one of the few ear, nose and throat specialists in this region who treat low-income people on Medicaid, so many of his patients travel long distances to see him.

headline: South Carolina Threatens Washington Over Cleanup
abstract: The Energy Department began cleaning up the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in 1996, and now says the work may not be finished until the 2040s.
lead_paragraph: AIKEN, S.C. — The Energy Department began cleaning up an environmental nightmare at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant here in 1996 and promised a bright future: Within a quarter-century, officials said, they would turn liquid radioactive bomb waste into a solid that could not spill or dissolve.

headline: Slowdown in Radioactive Waste Cleanup
abstract: Officials in South Carolina say the federal government has not met its promise to clean up waste at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant.
lead_paragraph: Officials in South Carolina say the federal government has not met its promise to clean up waste at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant.

headline: A White House Menu, Heavy on the Pies
abstract: President Obama and his family will have a traditional Thanksgiving meal this holiday, enjoying a menu that will look familiar to many American families: Turkey, ham, stuffing and plenty on the side. What’s remarkable is the dessert menu: the number of pies rivals the number of dishes in the dinner menu itself.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and his family will have a traditional Thanksgiving meal this holiday, enjoying a menu that will look familiar to many American families: Turkey, ham, stuffing and plenty on the side. What’s remarkable is the dessert menu: the number of pies rivals the number of dishes in the dinner menu itself.

headline: Reclaiming Label of a Progressive City
abstract: A look at three books: a collection of essays arguing for progressive policies in New York City; the history of the pizza box; and a tour through old hangouts and restaurants in the city.
lead_paragraph: If you’re terrified, or merely curious, about Bill de Blasio’s mayoral agenda, then read “Toward a 21st Century City for All: Progressive Policies for New York City in 2013 and Beyond,” edited by John H. Mollenkopf (City University of New York).

headline: The Birth of Thanksgiving
abstract: You can thank Abraham Lincoln for the holiday’s fixed, official status.
lead_paragraph: Though we most often associate Thanksgiving with Pilgrims and New England Indians, the holiday, at least as an official national event, began 150 years ago, at the height of the Civil War.

headline: Taking Flight
abstract: Balloons floated down the route of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade after an early scare they might be grounded because of high winds.
lead_paragraph: Balloons floated down the route of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade after an early scare they might be grounded because of high winds.

headline: Feeling For | Decorative Hair Ornaments That Are Perfect for the Holidays
abstract: Liven up your party look with one of these festive clips, combs and pins.
lead_paragraph: Sparkle this holiday season with golden clips, combs and pins that add a flash of decorative romance and make styling a breeze.

headline: Salinger Stories  ‘Leaked’ Online
abstract: Three previously unpublished short stories by J. D. Salinger have appeared online for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Three previously unpublished short stories by J. D. Salinger have appeared online for the first time, apparently after an unauthorized edition of the stories was sold on eBay and its pages scanned and uploaded, Buzzfeed reported.

headline: Ready for Some Football. A Lot of It.
abstract: At this time of year, Brian Schwartz, the chief executive and co-founder of DraftStreet, a daily online fantasy sports site, juggles work with family time on weekends.
lead_paragraph: “What I do on a Sunday impacts what a lot of other people do on a Sunday,” said Brian Schwartz, the C.E.O. and co-founder of DraftStreet, a daily online fantasy sports site. Mr. Schwartz, who is 30 and lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan with his wife, Jaime, their year-old daughter, Liv, and a pet puggle, Bascom, wasn’t being arrogant; he was being accurate. Since it started in 2010, DraftStreet has acquired more than 350,000 users, he said. Most of them visit the site on Sundays during football season, which tend — at least in part — to be workdays for Mr. Schwartz. The company has its Fantasy Football Championship on Dec. 15.

headline: Renaissance and Baroque Bronzes at the Frick
abstract: The show “Renaissance and Baroque Bronzes From the Hill Collection, which opens at the Frick Collection on Jan. 28, will offer visitors juxtapositions they may never have expected.
lead_paragraph: BAROQUE AND MODERN,

headline: At Large in the Kingdom of Dreams
abstract: “The Sandman Omnibus” gathers Neil Gaiman’s complete 75-issue run of Sandman (with extras) into two volumes.
lead_paragraph: THE SANDMAN OMNIBUS

headline: A Film Nudge to Find the Folkie in You
abstract: Tools for finding out more about the early 1960s Greenwich Village folk scene recreated in the Coen brothers film, “Inside Llewyn Davis.”
lead_paragraph: “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers film set among Greenwich Village musicians in the early 1960s, is poised to generate a tidal wave of nostalgia — and stir interest among moviegoers who were unfamiliar with this milieu. It’s a safe bet that anyone who sees the film (opening next Friday) will want to know more about the folkie world that the Coens recreate so wittily and well. There are great ways to read, see and hear more about it.

headline: They’re Already Boxed, Now Just Wrap
abstract: The outpouring of boxed sets of CDs make for easy gift-giving for music lovers.
lead_paragraph: DEEP catalog keeps getting deeper in the annual outpouring of boxed sets. The latest collections are less likely to be anthologies of hits — that’s been done — than plunges into the archives. Superstars are represented by alternate versions, outtakes, live tracks, remixes and official versions of long-bootlegged material. Unknowns, meanwhile, get a new hearing, as compilers and collectors work through the holdings of ever more obscure labels and producers. Annotators, for their part, piece together stories, and art directors enjoy creating packages larger than a CD case. Here, the critics of The New York Times delve into the year’s notable boxed sets. Prices may vary, depending on where the purchase is made.

headline: Holden Caulfield Redux
abstract: What is striking about “The Goldfinch,” a novel of Manhattan adolescence by Donna Tartt, is that it is as much a narrative of post-9/11 New York as it isn’t.
lead_paragraph: “The Goldfinch,” Donna Tartt’s third novel in 20 years, set in an opaquely rendered Manhattan of the 21st century, has followed its predecessors, selling robustly, while its eponym, a 1654 painting by Carel Fabritius, has been drawing crowds to the Frick. In an apparently serendipitous feat of cross-promotion, the painting currently appears at the museum as part of an exhibition of Dutch masterworks from the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis in The Hague, a show that has drawn more than 61,000 visitors since its debut in October.

headline: Life on $7.25 an Hour
abstract: Like most of the 55,000 fast-food workers in New York, Eduardo Shoy, 58, is struggling to stitch together a living on minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday evening, Eduardo Shoy left work at 6 p.m. Mr. Shoy, a deliveryman for KFC and Pizza Hut, was coming off an eight-hour shift of driving three-cheese pies and crispy chicken fingers, in an automotive blur, to private homes and businesses in central Queens.

headline: A Star, More Than Just a Voice, Is Back Onstage With Her Magnetism Intact
abstract: Lauryn Hill gave old material new life as part of her re-emergence in a concert on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t just a club date and the start of a tour; it was also a video shoot. When Lauryn Hill performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night, the camera swiveling over the heads of the audience suggested that the show was something more than Ms. Hill’s re-emergence after her recent three-month jail term for failing to file taxes. It was gathering the kind of material performers use to promote new releases — which, in Ms. Hill’s case, would be more than welcome.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘A Dog’s Life: A Rowlf Retrospective’

headline: The High Road Through a Struggle Is Never Easy to Navigate
abstract: “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom” is a stately film biography of Nelson Mandela, starring Idris Elba.
lead_paragraph: Hard moral decisions weigh heavily. And in “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom,” Justin Chadwick’s stately screen biography of Nelson Mandela, the British actor Idris Elba conveys the agony as well as the nobility of Mr. Mandela’s quest for South African racial equality. Much of that pain is suppressed rage at the cruelty and injustice of apartheid. As Mr. Mandela looks beyond the fury of the moment and calculates the cost of urging violence, you sense his frustration at having to make the only reasonable choice and taking the high road.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
abstract: A listing of exhibitions, literary talks, cultural and holiday-related events.
lead_paragraph: Holiday Lighting Displays (Friday through Thursday) Switches will be flipped — or oil lamps lit — in the coming week for Hanukkah and Christmas displays. Since 1977, the Lubavitch Youth Organization has sponsored the lighting of a menorah at Grand Army Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. The menorah will be lit at various times daily through Thursday. An outdoor party accompanying Sunday’s lighting, at 5:30 p.m., will feature music, dancing and latkes. More information: (718) 953-1000.

headline: Russia Charges Ex-Defense Minister Over a Road Project
abstract: The charges against Anatoly E. Serdyukov reflect a rift in the coterie of officials surrounding President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian investigators on Thursday charged a former minister of defense, Anatoly E. Serdyukov, with negligence for ordering the Russian military to build a road from a village to a private country residence in the south.

headline: Among Rich Twits, Back in the Day
abstract: Sidney Frances Bateman’s 1856 play “Self,” at the Metropolitan Playhouse, offers timeless humor centered on social climbers.
lead_paragraph: Somehow it’s comforting to know that silly rich people were ever thus.

headline: A New Orleans-Inflected Style Puts Some Macho in the Standards’ Sweet Talk
abstract: Steve Tyrell’s show “Wordsmiths: Lyricists of the Great American Song,” running through December at Café Carlyle, applies his gruff flair to standards.
lead_paragraph: Aw, shucks, folks. That describes the attitude Steve Tyrell imparts to everything he sings. In his ninth holiday season show at Café Carlyle, “Wordsmiths: Lyricists of the Great American Song,” he brings an unwavering tone of genial bonhomie to standards by the Gershwins, Rodgers and Hart, Cole Porter and others.

headline: One Isn’t Like the Other, and That May be the Point
abstract: Tanya Holt and Marcus Simeone brought chemistry to their show, “Quiet Storm,” at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: Congenial vocal chemistry is where you find it, and sometimes unlikely couples like Tanya Holt, a sultry pop-soul singer, and Marcus Simeone, a hyper-emotional tenor, who performed together at the Metropolitan Room on Saturday evening, have it. The title of their show, “Quiet Storm,” refers to the simmering romantic radio format first popularized in the mid-1970s. Adapted for cabaret, it embraces everything from Motown to “West Side Story” to Anita Baker.

headline: Britain Reconsiders Cigarette Regulation
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Law and Legislation', 'Youth', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The government has stepped away from an expected rejection of a proposed set of sweeping restrictions on cigarette packaging aimed at preventing smoking by young people.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Until recently, the British government appeared to be on the verge of rejecting sweeping restrictions on cigarette packaging. But on Thursday it changed course, announcing a policy review that could lead to curbs on labeling and require the use of neutral colors on packages.

headline: To Cool Housing Market, Britain Curtails Loan Help
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgages']
abstract: The Bank of England and the Treasury agreed to shift the focus of the so-called Funding for Lending program from mortgages to business loans.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a surprise step aimed at keeping Britain’s housing market from overheating, the Bank of England on Thursday scaled back a government program that encouraged mortgage lending.

headline: After Years of Famine, Lions Have Fall Feast
abstract: Reggie Bush fumbled on the Lions’ first possession, but Detroit finished the game by scoring 37 straight points to earn its first win on Thanksgiving since 2003.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Thanksgiving Day football game is always marked on the calendar long in advance by fans here, and with hope. But over the last 10 years, the Detroit Lions could not deliver a win, often losing in heartbreaking or spectacular fashion.

headline: Holiday Movie or Music Video?
abstract: Singers known and not as well known try to give Harry Connick Jr.’s character the Christmas spirit in “Angels Sing,” set in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Daughters Look for a Mother Lost to the Mexican Military
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Kidnapping']
abstract: Teenage sisters in El Paso are working hard to learn the fate of their mother, who was forcibly taken by the Mexican military in the state of Chihuahua four years ago.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Mitzi and Nitza Alvarado Espinoza wear different colors at news conferences, their lawyer says, so people can tell them apart as they talk about their missing mother and the group they have formed to help others in their situation. The Alvarados, 18, are identical twins.

headline: A Lo-Fi Idol, Fondly Considered
abstract: Kathleen Hanna, the feminist punk hero of the 1990s and beyond, is the main event of the fast-moving documentary “The Punk Singer.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: For Democrats, Luring Voters Is the Challenge
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Elections, Governors', 'Voting and Voters', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Texas has enough Democratic voters to put a Democrat in statewide office, but the problem is getting them to cast a ballot.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: If Buses on MoPac Go Faster, More People Will Ride (Maybe)
abstract: When a stretch of Texas State Highway Loop 1 adds two lanes in 2015, most vehicles will pay tolls to use them and avoid congestion, but buses will have free access, which may draw new Austin riders.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, an 11-mile stretch of MoPac Boulevard in Austin will expand to eight lanes from six. The two new lanes will require tolls, and drivers will be able to pay a premium to avoid frequent congestion.

headline: Build a Beach, Rinse, Repeat
abstract: “Shored Up” is a thought-provoking documentary about the folly of shoreline construction in the Hurricane Sandy age.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Emirates, based in Dubai, is building routes to developing countries, providing an alternative to local carriers and buying a lot of big jets.
lead_paragraph: There is little doubting the ambitions of the giant Middle Eastern airlines, but recent large plane orders demonstrated just how aggressively these carriers plan to compete in coming years.
