headline: A Bison Centennial
abstract: The shipment of American bison in 1913 from private ownership to public land was a landmark in wildlife conservation.
lead_paragraph: The year 1913 was a good one for American bison — one of the first good years for bison since the early 19th century. In February, the new buffalo nickel was introduced. And on Nov. 25, two railroad express cars loaded with 14 bison left the New York Zoological Park, now called the Bronx Zoo, for the town of Hot Springs in the Black Hills of South Dakota. On the 28th, the bison were taken overland in their crates 11 more miles and released onto native grassland.

headline: The Power of Cigarette Warning Labels
abstract: A provocative new study says the F.D.A. vastly underestimated the impact such warnings would have in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A provocative new study has suggested that the Food and Drug Administration greatly underestimated how much graphic warning labels on cigarette packs reduced the rate of smoking among Canadians. As a result, the study says, the F.D.A. vastly underestimated the impact such warnings would have in the United States.

headline: Ukraine Backs Down
abstract: Faced with Russia’s anger, President Yanukovich suspends trade talks with Europe.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to sympathize in any way with Ukraine’s corrupt and cynical president, Viktor Yanukovich, but the choice before him was indeed nasty. To sign an association and free-trade agreement with the European Union was to invite brutal Russian economic punishment, which Ukraine’s badly suffering economy is in no shape to absorb. Europe could only offer medium- to long-term advantages. Not signing, however, inevitably meant protests in Ukraine, whose population has consistently expressed support for European integration. Sure enough, tens of thousands of Ukrainians took to the streets as soon as their government announced last week that it was suspending negotiations with the European Union.

headline: Government in Slow Motion
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Can Republicans actually gum up the gears of Congress any more than they already have?
lead_paragraph: Last week, in a fit of fury after they lost the ability to filibuster President Obama’s nominees, several Congressional Republicans threatened to retaliate by slowing things down on Capitol Hill. Democrats “will have trouble in a lot of areas because there’s going to be a lot of anger,” said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, specifically warning that a United Nations disability treaty was now in danger of being rejected for the second time.

headline: A Long Walk for Glaciers
abstract: “Pad Yatra: A Green Odyssey” documents a trek through the Himalayas by a large group of people whose eco-friendly intentions.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Rooting for Failure
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: It’s hard to remember a time when a major political party and its media arm were so actively hoping for fellow Americans to lose.
lead_paragraph: I just spent 15 minutes on my local health care exchange and realized that I could save a couple hundred dollars a month on my family’s insurance. Of course, I live in Washington State, which has a very competitive market, a superbly functioning website and no Koch-brothers-sponsored saboteurs trying to discourage people from getting health care.

headline: The Many Shapes of Time
abstract: The Canadian director Peter Mettler explores the human perception of time in his experimental documentary, “The End of Time.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Mighty Love, and Mighty Anger, in a Night of Song
abstract: In Baby Jane Dexter’s new cabaret show, running well into December at the Metropolitan Room, she explores originals and covers by the likes of Randy Newman.
lead_paragraph: “I Got Thunder (and it Rings),” a proudly self-assertive anthem written by Abbey Lincoln and belted by Baby Jane Dexter in her new show, “More Rules of the Road,” at the Metropolitan Room, distills the resilient spirit of this venerable cabaret singer. “Love is an emotion, and it moves things,” announces the chorus of a song whose opening verse warns the faint of heart, “better run when I start coming.” Applying her formidable contralto to the song, Ms. Dexter tosses thunderbolts, but they won’t hurt you; their big, crashing sound is driven by a big heart.

headline: Mortgages Without Risk, at Least for the Banks
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A part of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law is being challenged by a coalition that wants to drop risk retention for mortgage loans.
lead_paragraph: There was no single cause of the financial crisis, but a chief one was surely the way mortgage loans were made by people who believed they had no reason to care if the loan was repaid.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS

headline: Flynn’s Encore Features Little to Applaud
abstract: Matt Flynn, who threw for 480 yards and 6 scores against Detroit in the 2011 season finale, had an ugly stat line Thursday, with no touchdowns, two fumbles, an interception and seven sacks.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — To most of the N.F.L., Matt Flynn is just another journeyman quarterback, moving from team to team, starting a game here and there. His name hardly signals fear.

headline: Shop First, and Eat Later
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: Many retailers didn’t wait for the predawn hours of Black Friday this year. They were open before breakfast on Thanksgiving Day, and customers were waiting.
lead_paragraph: Before most Thanksgiving turkeys even approached the oven on Thursday, a small line of tents had formed in front of a Best Buy in Falls Church, Va., their inhabitants waiting for the holiday deals to begin. First in line was William Ignacio, who pitched his tent at 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

headline: Afghan Leader Lashes Out at U.S. Allies After NATO Drone Strike
abstract: Told that civilians had been killed in at least one drone strike in Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzai indicated again that he would not sign a security agreement.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai lashed out at his American allies again on Thursday after word came that at least one, and possibly two, NATO drone strikes had killed civilians in southern Afghanistan.

headline: B. Altman, a Store From Yesteryear, Still Makes Its Presence Felt in the City
abstract: The legacy of the Fifth Avenue department store lives on as its founder prescribed a century ago, through a foundation that hands out grants.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when shoppers would crowd into B. Altman & Company on the Friday after Thanksgiving. That imposing Fifth Avenue department store still had a certain specialness as it aged gracefully, perhaps too gracefully — by the 1970s, it seemed almost fusty. And then, after a listless going-out-of-business sale that began on the day after Thanksgiving in 1989, it closed.

headline: Photographs Tell a History of Palestinians Unmoored
abstract: An exhibition of restored photos and film footage compiled by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency documents the history of Palestinian refugees since the 1948 Arab-Israeli war.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — There is one picture of Palestinian children studying around a small table by the dim light of gas lamps in the Beach Camp in Gaza, and another of children peeking over a sandy dune, with rows of small, uniform shacks of a desolate refugee camp in the background. In a third, a family walks across the Allenby Bridge, the father carrying two bulging suitcases, a young son clutching a white ball, heading east over the Jordan River.

headline: Two Marilyns, Six Scotches and 20 Hamburger Toppings
abstract: Marketing decisions, like Marilyn Monroe appearing in competing fragrance ads and customized Quarter Pounders, offer more choices and raise a few questions.
lead_paragraph: Can it be time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, the media and popular culture? (O.K., that one was free.)

headline: Despite Filibuster Limits, a Door Remains Open to Block Judge Nominees
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: The move left unchanged the Senate’s “blue slip” custom, which allows senators to block nominees to judgeships associated with their states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decision by Senate Democrats to eliminate filibusters for most judicial nominations only marginally enhanced President Obama’s power to reshape the judiciary, according to court watchers from across the political spectrum, because Republican senators can still veto his nominees to most currently vacant appeals court seats.

headline: Paper Tying Rat Cancer to Herbicide Is Retracted
abstract: The editor of the journal Food and Chemical Toxicology said the results of a study, while not incorrect or fraudulent, were “inconclusive, and therefore do not reach the threshold of publication.”
lead_paragraph: A food safety journal has decided to retract a paper that seemed to show that genetically modified corn and the herbicide Roundup can cause cancer and premature death in rats.

headline: How Will AIDS Be Eradicated?
abstract: In the U.S. and around the world, there are obstacles to prevention and treatment. How will they be overcome?

headline: Russia: Court Grants Bail to Last Detainee in Greenpeace Case
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: A court in St. Petersburg granted bail on Thursday to Colin Russell, the last of the 30 people on a Greenpeace International ship seized in September after a protest in the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: The last of the 30 people on board the Greenpeace International ship seized in September after a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic was granted bail on Thursday. A court in St. Petersburg had initially ordered the crew member, Colin Russell of Australia, held for 90 more days, even as the others were released on bail of roughly $60,000 each. The foreign crew members, from 17 countries, are now required to remain in St. Petersburg as the investigation on charges of hooliganism continues.

headline: Russian-Backed Free-Trade Zone May Expand Its Borders
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The bloc, less tightly woven than the European Union, currently comprises Belarus, Russia and Kazakhstan, and may be joined by at least three more former Soviet states.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Today, a train car loaded with coal in Kazakhstan can rumble thousands of miles across the Eurasian steppes to a factory in Belarus, all without once clearing customs.

headline: Week 13 N.F.L. Matchups: Browns Try Going Back to the Future
abstract: Jacksonville’s win against free-falling Houston was impressive, and Cleveland, which lost its last two games, has gone back to Brandon Weeden.
lead_paragraph: Jaguars (2-9) at Browns (4-7)

headline: Reporting on Motorcycle Clubs
abstract: Serge Kovaleski of The New York Times shares anecdotes from his reporting on motorcycle clubs around the country, including the Hells Angels.
lead_paragraph: Serge Kovaleski of The New York Times shares anecdotes from his reporting on motorcycle clubs around the country, including the Hells Angels.

headline: Syrian Forces Press Rebels With Gains
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: With fighters from Hezbollah, which is based in Lebanon, Syrian government troops gained control of the town of Deir Attiyah, which straddles a critical highway.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government forces battling alongside fighters from the Lebanon-based Hezbollah have nearly broken the rebels’ hold on a strategic region north of the capital, Damascus, Syrian state news media and opposition activists said Thursday.

headline: On Register’s Other Side, Little to Spend
abstract: The struggle of low-income workers, many in retailing, is adding momentum to efforts to increase the federal minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: In many stores around the country, the workers stocking the shelves and ringing up the gifts are at the very heart of this season’s retail lament —many Americans are so financially strapped that projections for holiday sales have grown bleaker by the week.

headline: Law Limiting Plastic Guns Set to Expire
keywords: ['Gun Control', '3-D Printers', 'Law and Legislation', 'Firearms', 'Airport Security', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: As 3-D printing technology makes it possible to produce weapons that can avoid detection, the police and members of Congress fear the consequences if the Undetectable Firearms Act is not renewed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the movie “In the Line of Fire,” a deranged killer smuggles a homemade gun past the Secret Service and tries, unsuccessfully, to shoot the president.

headline: Disillusionment Grows Among Syrian Opposition as Fighting Drags On
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: More people are turning their backs on the revolt and becoming disaffected by the growing power of Islamists and the disarray, division and greed among rebel commanders.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — In a terrace cafe within earshot of army artillery, a 28-year-old graduate student wept as she confessed that she had stopped planning antigovernment protests and delivering medical supplies to rebel-held towns.

headline: Hard Times for a Small (and Fuzzy) Group of Europeans
abstract: In an era of austerity, donkeys have been swept up in the debate over just how far the European Union should go to maintain its farming regions.
lead_paragraph: PARADELA, Portugal — It’s not easy being a donkey today.

headline: Giants and Jets, Super Bowl Hosts, Have Already Been Richly Rewarded
abstract: The deal to build the $1.6 billion MetLife Stadium, the site of next year’s Super Bowl, has proved to be lucrative for its two tenants.
lead_paragraph: Even if the two teams that call it home do not have a championship season, their three-year-old, $1.6 billion stadium in New Jersey will soon have its biggest moment: staging the first Super Bowl in the New York City area.

headline: Obamacare’s Secret Success
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare']
abstract: Follow the bending cost curve and you will find that the slowdown in health costs has been dramatic.
lead_paragraph: The law establishing Obamacare was officially titled the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. And the “affordable” bit wasn’t just about subsidizing premiums. It was also supposed to be about “bending the curve” — slowing the seemingly inexorable rise in health costs.

headline: Ire in Canada Over Report N.S.A. Spied From Ottawa
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'International Relations']
abstract: Documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden describe surveillance during a summit meeting of world leaders in Canada in June 2010.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canadian opposition politicians expressed shock and anger on Thursday over a report that the National Security Agency conducted widespread surveillance during a summit meeting of world leaders in Canada in June 2010.

headline: Retirement Ends 4-Decade Career of Drafting Big Plans for New York City
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Zoning']
abstract: As a strategic thinker for the Department of City Planning, Samuel Hornick presided over a legal apparatus that instructed developers where and how big they could build.
lead_paragraph: You have never heard of him, but he was a modern Robert Moses. As a strategic thinker for the Department of City Planning, under eight chairmen since 1975, Samuel Hornick was instrumental in a number of initiatives that have changed the face of New York.

headline: Bangladeshis Build Careers in New York Traffic
keywords: ['Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Bangladeshi-Americans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Bangladeshi immigrants are earning a living as traffic enforcement agents in New York, a growing presence navigating the congestion and sea of parked cars.
lead_paragraph: Above a Korean fried chicken restaurant in Jackson Heights, Queens, Showkat Khan worked the room of mostly Bangladeshi men, speaking Bengali with a few English phrases mixed in, his enthusiastic message of opportunity broadcast through a crackling amp. At one point, he held aloft a copy of New York City’s Civil Service newspaper, The Chief.

headline: Some Big Public Pension Funds Are Behaving Like Activist Investors
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Some of the biggest public pension funds are engaging with, and sometimes seeking to oust, directors of companies whose stock they own.
lead_paragraph: Activist investors like Carl C. Icahn, Daniel S. Loeb and William A. Ackman are getting deep-pocketed imitators.

headline: Tortorella Returns, Relentless as Ever
abstract: John Tortorella will return to Madison Square Garden for the first time since being fired last May in the only meeting between the Canucks and Rangers this season.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — As long as John Tortorella coaches the Vancouver Canucks and Alain Vigneault coaches the Rangers, the comparisons will be inevitable.

headline: Protecting the Brand
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: The Hells Angels have grown increasingly litigious, learning to employ the legal system to protect the recognizable symbols of their club.
lead_paragraph: The Hells Angels have grown increasingly litigious, learning to employ the legal system to protect the recognizable symbols of their club.

headline: Secrecy Bill Could Distance Japan From Its Postwar Pacifism
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The bill, which is close to being adopted, and the creation of a security council are prompting fears that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is pushing the nation backward.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Brushing past angry street protests and apocalyptic editorials in leading newspapers, Japan’s conservative prime minister, Shinzo Abe, appears set to achieve one of the first items on his legislative agenda to roll back his nation’s postwar pacifism: passing a national secrets law.

headline: Despite Outlaw Image, Hells Angels Sue Often
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: Just in the past seven years, the Hells Angels have brought more than a dozen cases in federal court, alleging infringement for borrowing the motorcycle club’s name and insignias.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Fritz Clapp, a 67-year-old lawyer with a bright red mohawk, practices intellectual property law. Years ago, his clients were “small-time businesses that nobody had ever heard of.” Then he found something bigger. Today, Mr. Clapp, an eloquent and irreverent man known to wear a purple fez during negotiations with other lawyers, represents the interests of a group not commonly associated with intellectual property: the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club. His main role is not as a bulldog criminal defense counsel for the notorious group but as a civilized advocate in its relentless battle to protect its many registered trademarks.

headline: Retailers’ Sly Message: Get Yourself a Gift, Too
keywords: ['Gifts', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)']
abstract: Self-gifters, who take advantage of frenzied holiday sales to buy a few things for themselves, have been growing in numbers and dollars spent.
lead_paragraph: Even the most clueless and bumbling gift-giver probably knows that it is not a good idea to give wrinkle cream, an electric toothbrush or a vacuum cleaner to anyone for Christmas or Hanukkah.

headline: At European Meeting on Partnership, Ukraine and Armenia Balk
abstract: The nations’ decision to reject closer ties with Europe has turned a summit meeting partly into a strategy session over how to confront the unexpectedly strong challenge from Moscow.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — A European summit meeting that opened here on Thursday was supposed to celebrate the achievements that put former Soviet republics on a path to Western integration — a program that would ultimately fulfill the more than half-century pursuit of a truly Continental economic and political alliance.

headline: True to Form, Cowboys Tantalize Fans With Late-Season Signs of Life
abstract: With a win over the Raiders, Dallas moved two games above .500 for the third time in three years — but in both previous years, the team finished with consecutive losses.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Dallas Cowboys should know better than to take success for granted. Mired in mediocrity for several seasons, they have teased and tortured fans while manufacturing playoff runs late into December.

headline: Americans’ Views on the Minimum Wage
abstract: Should the federal minimum wage be raised or not?
lead_paragraph: Should the federal minimum wage be raised or not?

headline: Mixed Legacy for Departing Pakistani Army Chief
abstract: As the taciturn Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani steps down, little has changed in the American-Pakistani relationship despite years of diplomatic effort.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When he leaves his post on Friday, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, the inscrutable Pakistani Army chief and former spymaster, will end a nearly decade-long chapter as the focus of American fears and frustrations in Pakistan, the reluctant partner in a contentious and often ill-tempered strategic dance.

headline: No Longer a King, but Always an Artist
abstract: Sam Shacked, 66, of Brooklyn lost his home and family after business reverses and struggles to subsist as a graphic designer.
lead_paragraph: When Sam Shacked was up, he was way up.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 28, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for Nov. 28 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Nets’ Kidd Fined for Spilling Soda
abstract: The N.B.A. handed Nets Coach Jason Kidd a $50,000 fine for “intentionally spilling a drink on the floor.”
lead_paragraph: Jason Kidd’s drink-spilling tactic late Wednesday night was considered both devious and ingenious. By Thursday, it had also proved costly.

headline: Borough President for Not Much Longer, but a Brooklynite Always
abstract: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president and one of the city’s most popular politicians with a personal touch, can be surprisingly polarizing.
lead_paragraph: If Marty Markowitz’s grand entrance at the annual Borough Hall Thanksgiving turkey giveaway this week seemed less sprightly than usual, his wisecracks more muted, his smile less dazzling, well, it was hard to blame him. After 12 years as Brooklyn’s borough president and chief cheerleader, Mr. Markowitz is relinquishing what he has repeatedly proclaimed is the only job he ever wanted.

headline: Shortage of Doctors Accepting Medicaid
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: As people sign up for Medicaid under the new health law, some may find it challenging to find doctors.
lead_paragraph: As people sign up for Medicaid under the new health law, some may find it challenging to find doctors.

headline: Opponent Highlights Knicks’ Weakness From 3-Point Range
abstract: J. J. Redick of the Clippers had a solid performance on Wednesday against the Knicks, who are 25th in the league in 3-point proficiency.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As J. J. Redick moved from spot to spot along the perimeter, he had a number in mind: 106. It never changes. He caps every pregame shootaround with a routine that requires him to make 106 shots at a series of locations, most of them from beyond the 3-point arc, and he was at it again as he prepared on Wednesday morning for the Clippers’ game against the Knicks later that night.

headline: Where to Take Stock
abstract: A tasty post-feast puzzle by Ned White.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Has everyone recovered from turkey coma? I hope everyone is looking forward to leftovers. Thanksgiving leftovers is a favorite meal of mine.

headline: Keeping Ball on the Ground, Auburn’s Offense Still Soars
abstract: In the Iron Bowl on Saturday, No. 1 Alabama will have to contend with the offensive high jinks of the Tigers and their coach, Gus Malzahn.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Ala. — Auburn Coach Gus Malzahn squinted through his glasses to see the spot of the ball, studied plays on a clipboard and gave commands through his headset to his staff. The play was then signaled to the players on the field. It all appeared to be the normal functioning of a no-huddle offense.

headline: A Timeline of the Hells Angels
abstract: The Hells Angels, in less than 70 years, have become a part of counterculture lore — American antiheroes exported to the rest of the world with dubious effect.
lead_paragraph: The Hells Angels, in less than 70 years, have become a part of counterculture lore — American antiheroes exported to the rest of the world with dubious effect.

headline: Bloomberg Code Keeps Articles From Chinese Eyes
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Chinese Language', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Some stories that Bloomberg runs are considered too sensitive to run in China, raising questions about a clash of journalistic ideals with commercial interests.
lead_paragraph: In early 2011, during a period of heightened tension between the Chinese government and foreign journalists, Bloomberg News created coding to give editors the ability to categorize stories under a new class, called 204. Such stories would not show up on Bloomberg terminals in mainland China. Managers did this after Chinese officials stressed to top editors in Hong Kong that the license granted to Bloomberg by the State Council allowed the company to publish only financial data and news on its terminals, not political news, employees said.

headline: Australia Blocks A.D.M.’s $2.7 Billion Bid for GrainCorp
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Foreign Investments', 'Grain', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The rejection of the takeover by the American agribusiness giant raised doubts about the coalition government’s pro-business pledges.
lead_paragraph: In the first major test of the pro-business platform of Australia’s new government, the country’s treasurer rejected on Friday a $2.7 billion takeover bid for GrainCorp Ltd. by Archer Daniels Midland, the American agribusiness giant, saying the deal was against the national interest.

headline: Reducing the Impact of Too Big to Fail
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: It is too soon to say that the problem of financial institutions that are too big to fail is a thing of the past, but reforms made in the wake of the financial crisis diminish the advantages of large banks, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Spoleto Festival USA Announces Lineup
abstract: The Spoleto Festival USA announced its 2014 lineup, which will feature 152 performances of opera, music, theater and dance from May 23 through June 8.
lead_paragraph: Entering its 38th year, the Spoleto Festival USA announced its 2014 lineup, which will feature 152 performances of opera, music, theater and dance from May 23 through June 8. The festival, in Charleston, S.C., will include a new production of John Adams’s opera “El Niño.” Janacek’s “Kat’a Kabanova,” will be staged by Garry Hynes, above, who in 1998 became the first woman to win a Tony for directing, for her production of “The Beauty Queen of Leenane.” The festival will also feature the American premiere of the opera “Facing Goya,” by Michael Nyman, below, in a new version to be performed without amplification. The Spoleto Festival USA Orchestra, conducted by John Kennedy, will pair Beethoven’s Seventh symphony with Louis Andriessen’s “The Nine Symphonies of Beethoven” and Michael Gordon’s “Rewriting Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony.” The festival’s theatrical productions will include Joseph O’Connor’s adaptation of “My Cousin Rachel,” drawn from the Daphne du Maurier novel, in a production by the Gate Theater of Ireland, as well as the American premiere of Ravi Jain’s autobiographical play, “A Brimful of Asha,” and a multimedia work by Laurie Anderson called “The Language of the Future.” Dances will be performed by Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, Dorrance Dance, Keigwin & Company and Gregory Maqoma.

headline: Ohio Turnpike Shut Down After High-Speed Crash
abstract: A stretch of the Ohio Turnpike was shut down after a high-speed chase outside of Toledo that resulted in at least one death, according to local reports.
lead_paragraph: The Ohio Turnpike was shut down near Fremont, the police said late Thursday, after what local reports described as a high-speed crash that may have left more than one person dead.

headline: Q. & A.: Adam Minter on Why China’s Scrap Trade Helps the Environment
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: Desperate for resources to fuel its fast-growing economy, China has become the world’s biggest importer of garbage: scrap paper, metals, wires and plastic. And while reprocessing discarded electronics and other goods can exact a toll on the environment, recycling can be less polluting than extracting the raw materials from mines, oil wells or forests.
lead_paragraph: In his new book “Junkyard Planet: Travels in the Billion-Dollar Trash Trade” (Bloomsbury Press), Adam Minter paints a Dickensian portrait of China’s massive garbage and recycling dumps. And then he tells us why they’re so vital to the environmental movement.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) BARBRA STREISAND: BACK TO BROOKLYN In this “Great Performances” presentation, Ms. Streisand, above, sings with Il Volo, Chris Botti and her son, Jason Gould, at the Barclays Center in her first hometown concert since childhood. The two October 2012 performances from which this special was culled were “a sentimental homecoming and a royal act of noblesse oblige in which a show business monarch regaled the adoring subjects of her native province in a concert that was steeped in Brooklyn lore,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “Appetite, yearning, curiosity — whatever you call it — is a quality embedded in Ms. Streisand’s voice. Like few singers of any age, she has the gift of conveying a primal human longing in a beautiful sound. She is hungry still.”

headline: Daring the Audience to Not Laugh
abstract: The confrontational comic Brody Stevens is the subject of a new reality show, “Brody Stevens: Enjoy It!” on Comedy Central.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Like those apocryphal monks who spent the Middle Ages quarreling over the number of angels per pinhead, stand-up comics endlessly obsess over the minutiae of their lives.

headline: Corrections: November 29, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 29, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: China Eases Rules on the Coveted Pilot’s License
keywords: ['AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The move by the Civil Aviation Administration of China is likely to unleash pent-up demand in the country’s civil aviation sector.
lead_paragraph: The Civil Aviation Administration of China has said it will relax requirements for obtaining a private pilot’s license, a move that is likely to unleash pent-up demand in the country’s civil aviation sector. The new regulations make it considerably easier for individuals to acquire a license, a coveted status symbol within China’s burgeoning class of business moguls and millionaires.

headline: A Friendship Is Rekindled With Albania
abstract: China’s cultural exchange program, the Confucius Institute, opens its first branch in the Mediterranean country, an old Communist ally from the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Educators, politicians and diplomats from China and Albania gathered last week to celebrate the opening of a new Confucius Institute at the University of Tirana, which welcomed the Chinese government-backed program whose mission is to promote Chinese language and culture abroad.

headline: Creating a Photo Market Afterlife
abstract: When photographers are discovered after their deaths, creating a narrative can be just as important as creating a market. Often, the two go hand in hand.
lead_paragraph: Every artist needs a champion — someone who can turn raw aesthetics into gallery-ready art. Granted, the relationship between creator and curator can be fraught, as they tussle over competing interpretations, edits or even visions.

headline: Tepid Data From Euro Zone Leaves Open Debate on Price Downdraft
abstract: The data showed improvement, but just faintly: Joblessness edged down, but remained a painfully high 12.1 percent; inflation ticked up, but was listless at 0.9 percent.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The euro zone, suffering from years of stagnation or worse, reached another milestone in its stumbling recovery on Friday when the official unemployment rate fell for the first time since 2011. But a separate report showing a slight rise in inflation was not enough to quell fears that the 17 nations that rely on the euro as their common currency were at risk of being sucked into a potentially ruinous downward price spiral.

headline: Migration Hurts the Homeland
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Many on the left don’t understand that immigration takes away the brightest.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — Liberals have long fought for the rights of immigrants. Businesses have long fought for the right of people to immigrate. It’s a crucial distinction.

headline: New York Today: Beware of Parking Tickets
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: Black Friday parking ticket blitz, mostly sunny weather, and holiday activities galore.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:07 a.m.

headline: Isolation Under House Arrest for Wife of Imprisoned Nobel Laureate
abstract: Liu Xia, the wife of the Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo, says she finds joy in reading. “My reading has no specific goal; for me it’s rather like breathing — I have to do it in order to live,” she wrote in a letter.
lead_paragraph: Liu Xia, the wife of the imprisoned Chinese Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo, says she feels completely isolated living under house arrest in Beijing and finds rare happiness in reading, according to a July letter.

headline: U.S. General Apologizes After Afghan Drone Strike
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Apologies']
abstract: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan that the United States regrets any civilian casualties that resulted from a drone strike in southern Helmand Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American military commander called President Hamid Karzai to apologize for a drone strike in southern Helmand Province, which the military conceded had killed and wounded civilians, a coalition official said on Friday.

headline: Ukraine Faces E.U.’s Dismay on Turnabout on Accords
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, who last week ditched plans to sign trade agreements with the European Union, found himself confronted by the Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Undoubtedly, it was an uncomfortable moment. President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, who last week ditched plans to sign far-reaching political and trade agreements with the European Union, found himself confronted Thursday night by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and by the host of a summit meeting here, President Dalia Grybauskaite of Lithuania.

headline: Ukraine's Battle for Europe
abstract: Despite their dashed hopes for an accord, E.U. supporters look west for the future.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On Nov. 21, summoned by a Facebook post by a journalist named Mustafa Nayem, more than 1,500 Ukrainians showed up in Independence Square in Kiev to protest their government’s decision to “pause” preparations for signing an association agreement with the European Union. The next day, more crowds gathered, in Kiev and other cities. Soon, the protesters numbered over 100,000.

headline: In Bihar Village, an Enduring Love for Lalu Prasad Yadav
abstract: The author recalls, “more than a chief minister of the state, he was a character of folklore for us.”
lead_paragraph: My Bihar village of a few hundred is just a few miles from Phulwaria in Gopal Ganj, where the populist leader Lalu Prasad Yadav was born. The leader, who charmed everyone with his wit and simplicity, ruled Bihar for almost 15 years starting 1990 –- seven years himself as chief minister, eight years through his homemaker wife, Rabri Devi, as proxy.

headline: Power Claims in the East China Sea
abstract: China, Japan and South Korea test each other.
lead_paragraph: China, Japan and South Korea test each other.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s homes include a five-bedroom in New Rochelle in a gated waterfront community and a three-bedroom townhouse with a boat slip in Nassau County.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes include a five-bedroom in New Rochelle in a gated waterfront community and a three-bedroom townhouse with a boat slip in Nassau County.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s homes include a condo in the South Street Seaport area; an Upper West Side condo; and a Williamsburg loft.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes include a condo in the South Street Seaport area; an Upper West Side condo; and a Williamsburg loft.

headline: Dr. Ruth Westheimer: Her Bedrooms Are Off Limits
abstract: At home in Washington Heights with the radio and television sex therapist, author and collector.
lead_paragraph: When Ruth Westheimer first saw that three-bedroom rental in Washington Heights almost half a century ago, her attraction was instant and intense.

headline: Stair Masters
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Complain about the stairs? Far from it. The walk-up apartment is a must-have in some quarters.
lead_paragraph: Robert Peruzzi was so determined to rent the fifth-floor walk-up he had seen on Irving Place that he was willing to outbid another potential tenant and pay $150 more than the original asking rent.

headline: Choosing Between Mortgage Broker and Bank
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Financial Brokers']
abstract: Before deciding on a lender, borrowers should compare offerings from both brokers and banks, whether online or at a bricks-and-mortar location.
lead_paragraph: Disparaged by some as the bogeymen of the housing crash, mortgage brokers have taken a beating over the last few years.

headline: Miami Project Off to Arty Start
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Restaurants', 'Art', 'Art Basel Miami Beach', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: A waterfront development gets rolling on paper with a show of design proposals at Art Basel Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: What do Tennessee Williams, Alexander Graham Bell and Madonna have in common? They all once lived in Coconut Grove, one of Miami’s oldest and most storied neighborhoods.

headline: College on the House
abstract: Financial advisers say that to help fund a child’s college education, it’s better to tap into home equity than retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: Parents who want to pay for their children’s college education but haven’t saved enough may consider tapping into either their home equity or their retirement accounts. Which is the smarter way to go?

headline: The Public Life of Hamid Karzai
abstract: Select moments in the evolution of Hamid Karzai, seen through excerpts from The Times.
lead_paragraph: “Be fair,” urged Hamid Karzai at the conclusion of his long talks with William Dalrymple, which stretched over three evenings in July, during the fasting month of Ramadan. It had been about four years since Karzai sat down with a reporter for The New York Times Magazine, and he was slightly skeptical about the outcome of the meeting. “As long as you’re fair, I’m good” Karzai said. “Criticize where I’m weak, recognize where I’ve done right.”

headline: At Home With Dr. Ruth
abstract: Dr. Ruth Westheimer has lived in Washington Heights for almost half a century. Her apartment is home to a myriad of cherished objects collected over her lifetime.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ruth Westheimer has lived in Washington Heights for almost half a century. Her apartment is home to a myriad of cherished objects collected over her lifetime.

headline: The Threat to British Curry
abstract: The travails of South Asian restaurants in Britain says more about the country’s prejudices than its palate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Upon first moving here from Pakistan two years ago, I was inundated with restaurant recommendations: Tayyabs and Lahore Kebab House, Daawat and Brilliant. I spent many weekends sampling curries and kebabs in the east and halwa in the south. In the end, I settled on a Drummond Street standby.

headline: U.N. Warns of Lasting Harm to Syrian Refugee Children
abstract: A report from the United Nations refugee agency warned of a generation “traumatized, isolated and suffering” as a result of the Syrian conflict.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syria’s conflict is creating a generation of damaged children, the United Nations warned Friday in a report on the plight of more than a million children who are refugees in neighboring countries, many of them deprived of access to education and of any semblance of a normal family life or childhood.

headline: One-Thing Shops: Specialty Stores Around the World
abstract: Bringing craftsmanship, devotion and unparalleled expertise to a single extraordinary item, these stores prove that less is often much, much more. Our contributors offer their favorites.
lead_paragraph: Bringing craftsmanship, devotion and unparalleled expertise to a single extraordinary item, these stores prove that less is often much, much more. Our contributors offer their favorites.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Maximum Henry Belts
abstract: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions. Today’s pick: simple belts for picky men.
lead_paragraph: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: The New York Collective
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: As different as city residents are, passers-by didn’t hesitate one day when help was needed.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pearson to Sell Financial News Group for $623 Million
abstract: Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, put Mergermarket up for sale earlier this year, and private equity firm BC Partners emerged as the buyer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Funds affiliated with the private equity firm BC Partners have reached an agreement to acquire the Mergermarket Group from the British publisher Pearson for 382 million pounds, or about $622.7 million.

headline: Exhausted Shoppers Head Home, Replaced by the Next Wave
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: As overnight shoppers packed it in, more flooded stores at dawn in search of Black Friday deals.
lead_paragraph: With nine family members — adults, teenagers and a toddler in tow — Ludivina Zuniga stretched her shopping spree over two days and never left the Harlem Irving Plaza mall in a Chicago suburb.

headline: 18 People, Abducted in Baghdad, Are Found Shot to Death
abstract: The bodies were dumped on a farm near the predominantly Sunni neighborhood where they were rounded up the night before, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Eighteen people were found dead in what appeared to be an execution-style killing on Friday, their bodies dumped on a farm near the predominantly Sunni neighborhood where they had been rounded up the night before, according to the police.

headline: At Bolshoi Trial, Prosecutors Ask for Sentence in Labor Camp
abstract: Russian prosecutors asked that Pavel Dmitrichenko, accused of ordering an attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, be sentenced to nine years in a labor camp.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW —Russian prosecutors on Friday requested a sentence of nine years in a labor camp for Pavel Dmitrichenko, once a star Bolshoi Ballet dancer, who is charged with ordering an acid attack that disfigured and nearly blinded the company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin.

headline: Spoleto Festival Will Include New John Adams Opera
abstract: Entering its 38th year, the Spoleto Festival USA announced its 2014 schedule in Charleston, S.C., which will feature 152 performances of opera, music, theater and dance from May 23 through June 8.
lead_paragraph: Entering its 38th year, the Spoleto Festival USA announced the schedule for its 2014 iteration in Charleston, S.C., which will feature 152 performances of opera, music, theater and dance from May 23 through June 8. The festival will include a new production of John Adams’ opera “El Niño.” Janacek’s “Kat’a Kabanova,” will be staged, directed by Garry Hynes, who in 1998 became the first woman to win a Tony, for her production of “The Beauty Queen of Leenane.”

headline: Talking Turkey
abstract: Defending against the chicken people.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Yglesias is completely wrong.

headline: Recent Drone Strikes Strain U.S. Ties With Afghanistan and Pakistan
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The tension highlights the political complications from America’s persistent reliance on the lethal remote-controlled weapons
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two separate but similarly bitter disagreements over drone strikes in Pakistan and Afghanistan have complicated relations between the United States and those two countries at a delicate moment, again highlighting the political complications from America’s persistent reliance on the lethal remote-controlled weapons.

headline: Defending the Queen
abstract: Anne Somerset reconsiders some of our most unflattering ideas about Britain’s Queen Anne.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Queen Anne (who reigned from 1702 to 1714) has not been treated kindly by historians. Consensus has it that “Brandy Nan” was obese and of limited intelligence, with a predilection for the bottle. More dangerously, she is supposed to have put herself under the thumb of domineering women favorites with political agendas: first the Whig partisan Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough, and subsequently the duchess’s upstart cousin Abigail Masham, a Tory sympathizer. (It is suggested from the surviving correspondence that Anne might have had lesbian leanings, though whether these were ever acted upon is unknown.) She is seldom given any credit for the great events of her reign, which included the 1707 Act of Union and the glorious victories over the armies of Louis XIV.

headline: Oscar Hopeful Revives Searing Memoir
abstract: Steve McQueen’s film “12 Years a Slave” has made a best seller of the book on which it’s based, Solomon Northup’s 1853 memoir.
lead_paragraph: The success of the director Steve McQueen’s “12 Years a Slave,” a likely Oscar nominee, has also given new life to a classic autobiography, Solomon Northup’s now best-selling 1853 memoir. Movie adaptations are reliably good news for the books on which they’re based, and McQueen says he believes few sources are more worthy of the attention than Northup’s narrative of his experience as a free man kidnapped into slavery.

headline: Anthologies
abstract: New anthologies include “XO Orpheus,” with classical myths reimagined by Aimee Bender, Joy Williams, Benjamin Percy and others.
lead_paragraph: THE COOL SCHOOL  Writing From America’s Hip UndergroundEdited by Glenn O’Brien  The Library of America, $27.95.

headline: Hungry, Hungry Voters
abstract: Hammertime with Gary Shteyngart; Rob Ford or Ford Focus?
lead_paragraph: Hammertime with Gary Shteyngart; Rob Ford or Ford Focus?

headline: Who Made That Spork?
abstract: The medieval tool that led to today’s plastic utensil that “swings both ways.”
lead_paragraph: The last time you picked up a “spork” — whether a plastic one for your fast-food meal or the titanium one you took on your camping trip — you might have had the fleeting thought that the clever spoon/fork feels almost futuristic, or at least from a not-so-distant past. Actually, it has been around for centuries.

headline: Did I Fence a Sign?
abstract: Black-market gray area; contribution conundrum.
lead_paragraph: Looking for artwork for my home, I recently bought a used road sign online — a bright blue one advertising a campground ahead. I liked it and ended up buying a second one. Only after I purchased those two signs did it occur to me that they may have been stolen. Now I feel guilty. Throwing them in the recycling bin doesn’t really make the situation right. Selling them to someone else is no better. Reporting the sellers seems hypocritical — plus, I have no evidence. What is my obligation as an ethical citizen? BEVERLY BARTLETT, LOUISVILLE, KY.

headline: The 11.17.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: Danica Patrick on Racing Cars and Building Brands
abstract: The Nascar driver says that her brand is “about being feminine but unique and different and kind of blazing a trail.”
lead_paragraph: You dropped out of school when you were 16 to pursue racing. Do you think you would be where you are had you not done that?  I took the opportunity that was in front of me, which meant moving to England and leaving school. I did get my G.E.D. — I call it my “Good Enough Diploma” — but I don’t know, I think I showed my dedication by doing that.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: R. J. Palacio, whose debut novel, “Wonder,” is No. 2 on the middle-grade best-seller list, has said she wrote the book as a sort of atonement.
lead_paragraph: Choose Kind: It’s been exactly 52 weeks since the Book Review modified its children’s best-seller lists, splitting the former chapter books category into two new lists — middle grade and young adult — to better reflect the different ages of those books’ primary readers. In that time, only one book has stayed on the middle-grade list all 52 weeks: R. J. Palacio’s debut novel, “Wonder,” about a boy with a facial deformity trying to fit in at school. (This week, it’s No. 2.)

headline: My Man Bertie
abstract: Jeeves and Wooster reverse roles in Sebastian Faulks’s revival of P. G. Wodehouse’s classic series.
lead_paragraph: What, ho? A new Jeeves and Wooster novel? Steady on. Your faithful reviewer may not be the brightest bulb in the old marquee, but dash it, isn’t this anno dom 2013, and didn’t “the Master” — yclept Pelham Grenville Wodehouse (“Plum” to his chums) — shove off across the old Rio Styx back in 1975?

headline: The Art of Celebrity
abstract: A gossipy account of Lucian Freud’s life.
lead_paragraph: Just in case we’ve been wondering how important a painter Lucian Freud was, or what an enormous celebrity he became, or why the British journalist Geordie Greig has written a book about him, “Breakfast With Lucian” answers these questions in its opening pages. Freud was so well known that he was allowed into Clarke’s — a “small upmarket restaurant” frequented by Bryan Ferry, Salman Rushdie, Dame Maggie Smith, and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge — before it opened in the morning, and invited to enjoy a leisurely meal in what functioned as his private salon. Over dinner at London’s more glittering establishments, he could pelt strangers with breadsticks, spew obscenities, pummel a waiter, grope the waitresses, amuse his companions by imitating a masturbating whale — and be welcomed back the next evening. At Clarke’s, “Lucian’s conversation ranged from dating Greta Garbo to the best way to land a punch without breaking your thumb, to how he had popped in to 10 Downing Street to see Gordon Brown, or had been to a nightclub with Kate Moss.” Oh, the life of an artist!

headline: Calls to Arms
abstract: Two appraisals of Winston Churchill’s role during Britain’s “finest hour.”
lead_paragraph: In “Churchill’s Bomb,” Graham Farmelo recounts two related but distinct stories: the British role in the development of nuclear weapons from the 1920s through the 1950s and Winston Churchill’s relationship with cutting-­edge military science generally, and the Bomb specifically.

headline: A Ski Spot That’s Remote, No Frills and Not for Profit
abstract: A community cooperative in British Columbia has purchased Shames Mountain and is offering reasonable lift prices, few amentieis, and lots of snow.
lead_paragraph: The community of Terrace, British Columbia, has taken a purist’s approach to the ski season the last few years, forming My Mountain Co-op, Canada’s first nonprofit ski community cooperative, a no-frills outfit where amenities are secondary to the sport itself.

headline: Time Was on Their Side
abstract: The Rolling Stones hated to be compared with the Beatles, but after 50 years they still are.
lead_paragraph: As the 50th-anniversary milestones for the Beatles and the Rolling Stones fly off like calendar pages in an old film, even the stuff of barroom debates gets elevated into book-length exegeses. At least that’s true on the evidence of “Beatles vs. Stones,” by John McMillian, and “Rocks Off: 50 Tracks That Tell the Story of the Rolling Stones,” by Bill Janovitz. The good news is that despite some flaws, each of them justifies its extended treatment of essentially irresolvable disputes. They manage to make their cases in balanced, informed, yet still passionate terms. And, best of all, when you’re done, you don’t need to worry about a crippling hangover.

headline: Twisted Spinster
abstract: Ronald Frame reimagines the life of Miss Havisham, Charles Dickens’s jilted bride.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Frame’s fast-moving new novel makes use of the eccentric Miss Havisham from “Great Expectations,” but the first two-thirds of it is much more Trollopian than Dickensian. Right from the start, Catherine Havisham suggests she was born into a world she might never understand: “I killed my mother.” That she was a breech birth, that the death of women in childbirth was a given in early 19th-century England, are simply facts. What is important is that the machine of her life is already operating full tilt, and the most she can do is keep her eyes open and attempt to understand its workings.

headline: Imperial Rhymes
abstract: Selected poems of Rudyard Kipling combine the canonical with the never before published.
lead_paragraph: Kipling was a conundrum even to himself. One of the first modern writers to live in the fraught intersections of empire, he wrote between two worlds. Born in Bombay, named after the picturesque Staffordshire lake where his parents had courted, he enjoyed a pampered childhood among the Anglo-Indians, as they called themselves, with a native ayah and loads of Indian servants. At 5, he was banished from this paradise and sent back to the mother country to be raised by a placid English couple. The husband had the bad manners to die, leaving the boy in the charge of the wife, who was secretly a monster. Kipling suffered, as did Dickens, a Dickensian childhood whose cruelties could never be erased.

headline: The Help and the Helped
abstract: A history of 100 years of domestic service in England and how it evolved.
lead_paragraph: “Downton Abbey” fans may be disappointed to find that Lucy Lethbridge’s lively history of British servants concludes with “Upstairs, Downstairs,” the 1971-75 television series created by the children of a housemaid and an under-­butler. On-screen, this costume drama may have looked like a period piece, but behind the scenes, class tensions persisted. Upon arriving at the set, the actors playing the downstairs roles discovered they had been allotted inferior dressing rooms, with showers monopolized by the actors playing their masters.

headline: Kind Regards
abstract: An ode to the art of letter writing in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Once there were letters: handwritten, typewritten, carefully crafted, dashed off, profound or mundane, tinged with expectancy. Correspondence required waiting. “I need you more and more, and the great world grows wider, and dear ones fewer and fewer, every day that you stay away,” Emily Dickinson wrote to her future sister-in-law, Susan Gilbert, in 1852. Were they alive today, would Dickinson and Gilbert merely G-chat?

headline: Materfamilias
abstract: Alison Weir chronicles the life of the first Tudor queen.
lead_paragraph: Alison Weir’s new biography documents the life of the Tudors’ other Queen Elizabeth. Weir has already produced biographies of Elizabeth I, Henry VIII and Eleanor of Aquitaine, all better known than Elizabeth of York, whose obscurity belies the high profile of her connections. She came of age during the Wars of the Roses, the dynastic rivalry between the Houses of York and Lancaster. As the daughter of a Yorkist king, Edward IV, and the wife of the first Tudor (Lancastrian) king, Henry VII, she united these warring houses. For this alone, she deserves a prominent place in English history.

headline: Murder at the Vicarage
abstract: In “No Man’s Nightingale,” by Ruth Rendell, Inspector Wexford investigates a murder case bungled by his old deputy.
lead_paragraph: NO MAN’S NIGHTINGALE (Scribner, $26) is Ruth Rendell’s 24th Inspector Wexford procedural mystery in almost 50 years, so we’re naturally curious about how that venerable detective may have mellowed in retirement. Well, his mind is still sharp enough to solve a murder case bungled by Mike Burden, his old deputy and now detective superintendent of the Kingsmarkham constabulary. Always a tolerant man, Wexford is ever more alarmed by the racism and bigotry that have taken root in his little patch of England and were a factor in the murder of the Rev. Sarah Hussain, a biracial single mother raising an out-of-wedlock child. And, if anything, he’s grown more caustic about barbaric insults to the mother tongue, like the Alternative Service Book that replaced the Book of Common Prayer in Anglican churches.

headline: Cold Comfort
abstract: Anthony Russell recalls holidays at grandmother’s house.
lead_paragraph: Why are wealthy Britons so entertaining to read about? Maybe it has something to do with the collision of crisp formality and a kind of babyish loopiness — looming over every well-manicured herbaceous border and syntactically rigorous sentence is an eccentric uncle named Birtwhistle. Or, more darkly, maybe fans of the Patrick Melrose novels and “Downton Abbey” are drawn like moths to the flame of scandal: To learn of an illustrious family’s secret shame is to put a human face on a glamorous abstraction.

headline: Dealing With Burnout, Which Doesn’t Always Stem From Overwork
abstract: That feeling of overwhelming exhaustion, frustration and a sense of failure may have more to do with the way the workplace operates, or even your colleagues, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: IT’S the end of the year, and lots of us are feeling a little overwhelmed. Tired, unfocused and ready to take a nice break with our families (or away from our families in some cases).

headline: The Class of Its Class, Again
abstract: The all-new 2014 edition of the Mazda 3 continues to stake its claim as the front-runner among affordable small cars.
lead_paragraph: The all-new 2014 edition of the Mazda 3 continues to stake its claim as the front-runner among affordable small cars.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE WORLD UNTIL YESTERDAY: What Can We Learn From Traditional Societies?,  by Jared Diamond. (Penguin, $18.) In “Guns, Germs, and Steel” (1997) and “Collapse” (2005), Diamond offered sweeping descriptions of how geography and environment shape the destiny of nations. “The World Until Yesterday” holds up tribal societies of the Amazon, New Guinea and elsewhere as “natural experiments” that have much to teach us about child rearing, eldercare, fitness and conflict resolution.

headline: Thai Protesters Enter Army Headquarters as Government Avoids Violence
abstract: The intrusion of protesters at the Royal Thai Army compound on Friday capped a week of dramatic and provocative gestures against the country’s most influential political family.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters broke into and briefly occupied the grounds of Thailand’s army headquarters on Friday, capping a week of dramatic and provocative gestures against the country’s most influential political family.

headline: In Our Pages: November 30
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1888: Revolution-era Fashion in Paris

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MY PROMISED LAND: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel,  by Ari Shavit. (Spiegel & Grau, $28.) Shavit, a columnist for Haaretz, expresses both solidarity with and criticism of his countrymen in this important and powerful book.

headline: Shopping for a Girl? Consider Science and Engineering Toys
abstract: A small group of toymakers and others are trying to break gender stereotypes by making toys to get girls excited about science and engineering.
lead_paragraph: Sofia the First, a new Disney princess decked out in a lavender gown, is high on most retailers’ list of the hottest toys this holiday season. But if you’re shopping for a girl, why not skip the doll aisle for toys that encourage science and engineering?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Edward VII
abstract: This week, Jane Ridley talks about “The Heir Apparent,” her new book about Edward VII; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen discuss Hannah Arendt’s “Eichmann in Jerusalem”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jane Ridley talks about “The Heir Apparent,” her new book about Edward VII; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen discuss Hannah Arendt’s “Eichmann in Jerusalem”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Edward VII
abstract: This week, Jane Ridley, Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jane Ridley, Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen.

headline: Turning Leftovers Into Latkes
abstract: Five new latke and potato pancake recipes that combine potatoes and other vegetables, from the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: Planning ahead, I was all set to devote this week’s recipes to potatoes, which I have always defended against the anti-carb brigade because potatoes are a wholesome food, high in B vitamins and vitamin C, potassium and fiber, with some protein and lots of complex carbohydrates. A plain, seven-ounce baked potato eaten with the skin contains half the daily amounts of Vitamin C and Vitamin B6 recommended for adults. I had Thanksgiving in mind, the most popular time of the year for this tuber; or is Hanukkah the most popular time?

headline: Off the Charts: Fewer Firings, but Long-Term Joblessness Is Still High
abstract: The rate of firings in the United States has fallen to the lowest level since the government began measuring it more than a decade ago. But the number of people being hired has only slowly increased since the bottom of the recession, leaving many long-term unemployed workers still unable to find jobs.
lead_paragraph: The rate of firings in the United States has fallen to the lowest level since the government began measuring it more than a decade ago. But the number of people being hired has only slowly increased since the bottom of the recession, leaving many long-term unemployed workers still unable to find jobs.

headline: The Magical Allure of a Shop That Sells Only One Kind of Thing
abstract: Want an out-of-print cookbook? There’s a shop for that. How about the perfect umbrella? That too. T’s contributors reflect on five amazing, totally unique specialty shops from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Bringing craftsmanship, devotion and unparalleled expertise to a single extraordinary item, specialty stores prove that less is often much, much more. Our contributors offer their favorites.

headline: For Long-Term Jobless, a Stubborn Trend
abstract: For 61 years until mid-2009, the long-term rate was never as high as the short-term rate; since then, it has consistently been higher.
lead_paragraph: IN 2006, with the American economy booming, the proportion of workers who were laid off or discharged over a 12-month period fell to 15.5 percent. That was the lowest rate since the government began collecting the data at the end of 2000 — and a sign that the job market was exceedingly strong.

headline: Airlines Urged by U.S. to Give Notice to China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The Obama administration is urging American commercial airlines to comply with China’s new air defense zone, hours after China scrambled jets to patrol it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as China scrambled fighter jets to enforce its newly declared air defense zone, the Obama administration said on Friday that it was advising American commercial airlines to comply with China’s demands to be notified in advance of flights through the area.

lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, John Sutherland reviews Jane Ridley’s “The Heir Apparent: A Life of Edward VII, the Playboy Prince.” Mr. Sutherland writes:

lead_paragraph: One is a century-old transit hub permitted to age gracefully beneath Lower Manhattan, its chandeliers, terra-cotta tiles and ceiling of Guastavino vaults carefully preserved.

lead_paragraph: Audis that need a new crankcase pressure valve and Corvettes low on differential oil are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Performer Available for Private Parties
abstract: The new Mazda 3 has grown better looking outside and more deluxe inside, but it’s the car’s entertaining driving experience combined with improved fuel economy that puts it over the top.
lead_paragraph: Mazda fans are like the denizens of a cool underground speakeasy, hidden behind a false door and a mounted antelope head. They’d love people to know how much fun they’re having, but they may not want the masses to force their way inside.

headline: In Formula One, It’s Already 2014
abstract: Sweeping rules changes, including a shift to turbocharged 1.6-liter V6 engines, have kept the sport’s designers and engineers busy for many months.
lead_paragraph: The competition for the 2013 Formula One drivers championship may have officially ended last Sunday with Sebastian Vettel’s victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix, but as a practical matter this year’s campaign was over soon after it began.

headline: To Bring Back the Drivers, Rallies Add Brain-Teasers
abstract: Enthusiasts look to revive the sport’s popularity through “gimmick” rallies, in which understanding the cryptic instructions is as important as precision driving.
lead_paragraph: ISLANDIA, N.Y. — One by one, the cars rolled out of the parking lot and onto the Long Island Expressway for the start of the 2013 Vintage Rally:

headline: A Chevy So Exclusive That You Can Only Borrow, Not Buy
abstract: The Chevrolet Captiva, which traces its lineage to the Saturn Vue, is a rare thing in the market: a vehicle that isn’t available to consumers but is offered only to fleet customers, like rental car companies.
lead_paragraph: Rental cars are rarely anything special. And that’s just fine. All you really need from a rental is unlimited miles, long-term shelter for a few stray curly fries and a hassle-free ride from A to B and back again before those martinets at the counter charge you for an additional day.

headline: Image of the Day: November 29
abstract: The Mypadu Beach in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Angela Lansbury Returning to London Stage in ‘Blithe Spirit’
abstract: Angela Lansbury will reprise her Tony-winning performance in “Blithe Spirit” when she returns to the London stage for the first time in nearly 40 years.
lead_paragraph: After a four-decade absence from the London stage Angela Lansbury, best known for her portrayals of the detective Jessica Fletcher in the television series “Murder, She Wrote” and the murderous pie-maker in “Sweeney Todd,” plans to make her return in March in a new production of the  Noël Coward comedy “Blithe Spirit.”  She will reprise her portrayal of Madame Arcati, the medium who communicates with Elvira, the deceased ex-wife of the novelist Charles Condomine. She won a Tony Award when she played the role on Broadway in 2009.

headline: Big Ticket | Outdoor Living, in NoHo for $23 Million
abstract: A condominium at 40 Bond Street, emerald-green-glass apparition that brought a dash of Oz downtown to NoHo in 2007, sold for $23.5 million.
lead_paragraph: A statement-making condominium that monopolizes the eighth floor at 40 Bond Street, the 11-story emerald-green-glass apparition that brought a dash of Oz downtown to NoHo in 2007, sold for $23.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Night Watchman With Wheels?
keywords: ['Security and Warning Systems', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Privacy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A California company’s mobile robot is intended to serve as a security tool, but some see it as an entry point to a post-privacy world and a threat to take over some low-paying jobs.
lead_paragraph: The night watchman of the future is five feet tall, weighs 300 pounds and looks a lot like R2D2 — without the whimsy. And will work for $6.25 an hour.

headline: Helping a Shy Guy Build Up His Nerve
abstract: Addressing matters of a shy guy in a bar, and guests, co-workers and mentors.
lead_paragraph: While having a cocktail at a bar with my sister and her boyfriend, a woman walked in alone, looked around and took a seat at the bar. I thought it might be the woman I’d chatted with the night before on OkCupid (a dating website), but I wasn’t sure. And even if I was, we had only exchanged a couple of short messages. I didn’t even know her name. Well, it turns out, it was her. But instead of a fortuitous encounter with an attractive woman, I was the creepy guy who wasn’t confident enough to say hello. What should I do the next time something like this happens?

headline: Coming Out as a Modern Family (Updated With Podcast)
abstract: Life partners need not be narrowly defined; they can be exes, children, best friends or lovers.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress and writer Maria Bello in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below or subscribe on iTunes or Stitcher.

headline: Increased Global Demand Aids India’s Mild Recovery
abstract: A three-month growth spurt at rate of 4.8 percent was led by banking and insurance.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India’s economy is showing signs of a gradual recovery as gross domestic product increased at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the three months that ended in September.

headline: Diamond-Paved, Deal-Obsessed
abstract: The diamond district, on a block of West 47th Street, pulses with the competition of the jewelry sellers, who are always looking for a way to make a deal.
lead_paragraph: The diamond district, on a block of West 47th Street, pulses with the competition of the jewelry sellers, who are always looking for a way to make a deal.
